title: Bring on the Bats
description: At the beginning of the movie ''Batman,'' the people of Gotham City regard the dark, nocturnal figure with suspicion and fear. By the end, they recognize him as a crusader against evil. Naturalists are working to effect a similar change in the real-life image of bats. This year, the public has a powerful reason to listen.

title: Review/Music; The Danish Radio Choir Stops Over
description: The Danish Radio Choir, a mixed-voice group of 28, is in the midst of a seven-event American tour - one that seems to be carrying them mostly to big churches and big performing spaces. Listening to this choir sing at St. Bartholemew's Church on Park Avenue on Thursday night created the impression of considerable refinement and delicacy. These are qualities that might better have been matched to a smaller hall.

title: Session Is Rite of European Passage for Spain
description: For many people in France, West Germany and Britain, the European Community summit conference here this week may have been just another meeting on obscure monetary issues, but for Spaniards it became a celebration of the end of generations of political isolation from Europe.

title: Parents Upset Over Gypsy Moth Spray That Fell on Children
description: ON the morning of May 19, about a dozen young children were waiting for their school bus at the intersection of Pine Shore Road and Delaware Avenue here. Hearing an unusually noisy airplane approaching, the children looked up and saw a small twin-engine aircraft flying toward them at treetop level.

title: Inciting Hitler
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
The Benefits of Catching Rainwater
description: LEAD: READERS often come up with important points that garden writers overlook. One reader noted that recent articles on water conservation failed to include collection and use of rainwater. This is certainly a good suggestion and also a reminder of times past when collecting rainwater was essential.

title: Question Of the Week; Are the New Tennis Players Exciting?
description: While established players like Steffi Graf and Mats Wilander and newcomers like Michael Chang and Monica Seles are enjoyable to watch, what the game has really lacked over the last few years is the intensity and drama of either a Borg-Connors slugfest or a Borg-McEnroe duel. That was true excitement. JULIUS CHANG Morganville, N.J.

title: My Friends Are Getting Old
description: THERE was a time when I actually thought I was immortal. In the supreme ego of youth I couldn't, for the life of me, picture myself as getting old. I convinced myself that aging was a fate for other people, not me.

title: Correction
description: The credit line following Gail Godwin's essay ''My Mother, the Writer: Master of a Thousand Disguises'' on June 11 omitted the name of the publisher of the forthcoming collection ''Family Portraits: Remembrances by Twenty Distinguished Writers,'' from which the essay was excerpted. The publisher is Doubleday.

title: Iraq Says It Will Halt Arms Flow to Lebanon
description: Iraq announced today that it was discontinuing the delivery of weapons to its Christian allies in Lebanon in an effort to assist Arab mediators who are trying to bring peace to the country.

title: East End Envisions An Artistic Alliance
description: WANTED: Summer home for Manhattan-based, renowned repertory company, preferably in the Hamptons, where artistic director and leading playwrights have homes.

title: Rebecca S. Moss To Marry in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Moss of New York and Great Cranberry Island, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter Rebecca Sarah Moss to Patrick Richard Guyver, a son of Mrs. John Guyver of Stratford-on-Avon, England, and the late Mr. Guyver. An October wedding is planned.

title: Handling Of Arts Center Criticized
description: A STATE SENATE committee's investigation of the New Jersey Highway Authority has resulted in a highly critical assessment of the agency's management of the Garden State Arts Center and a recommendation that operation of the 10,000-seat amphitheater be turned over to an independent, professional management company, committee members say.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Andrea Littlefield To Be the Bride Of Robert Marino
description: Mr. and Mrs. Allen Littlefield of Hammonton, N.J., have announced November wedding plans for their daughter, Andrea J. Littlefield, and Robert Marino, a son of State Senator and Mrs. Ralph J. Marino of Muttontown, L.I.

title: Gridlock: When You Have It Too Good
description: I have been having trouble commuting, which puts me squarely in the middle of a large segment of the population.

title: High Standards and Good Humor
description: To the Editor:

title: THE JOYS OF VICTIMHOOD
description: A SHAME THERE ISN'T A MA-chine, the sociological equivalent of a seismograph, that registers fundamental shifts in social attitudes and concerns. In the absence of such a machine, we all have to operate with our own often rather primitive social radar, taking our signals where we find them. When one's dentist, for example, begins to say ''pasta'' instead of spaghetti or noodles, one knows that the interest in cookery has fully swept the middle classes. When one sees Mafia men jogging and worrying about their cholesterol, one knows that anxiety about health really is endemic. What began as a fad becomes a trend, which becomes a shift, which finally becomes a serious change in the way we live and think about ourselves.

title: PASTIMES: Stamps
description: Few Americans today can identify the small Caribbean island that was the site of the first naval salute to the infant United States.

title: A Surge From Below in Soviet Sport
description: The Bolshevik Party that made the Russian Revolution of 1917 did not number many hard-core sports fans among its members. From Stalin through Brezhnev, even as Soviet ''amateurs'' came to dominate the Olympics, Soviet commentators condemned the evils of professional sport under capitalism. Today, however, Soviet soccer players dot the rosters of Western Europe's best-known teams. Young tennis stars perform on the world circuit. An Italian company sponsors a Soviet bicycle team in European road racing, and next year, some Soviet athletes will be permitted to play in the National Hockey League and the National Basketball Association.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Accidental Tourist 1988. Warner Home Video. 2 hours, 1 minute. $89.95. Laser disk, $29.98. Closed captioned. PG. Based on a novel by Anne Tyler and directed by Lawrence Kasdan, this dark, somber picture, ''unaccountably voted the best film of 1988 by the New York Film Critics' Circle,'' forgets that movies have a language of their own. It ''often relies on Miss Tyler's methods without tempering them, and gives a tone of crashing obviousness to material that need not have seemed that way.'' The plot proves diffuse and rambling. As a writer of travel guides for business people, William Hurt is abandoned by his wife of 20 years, played by Kathleen Turner, and hits rock bottom. So does the film, as he takes up with a dog trainer, who - meant to be charmingly offbeat - proves insufferable, despite Geena Davis's best efforts in the role. (Janet Maslin) I'm Gonna Git You Sucka 1988. MGM/UA Home Video. 1:27. A cheerful and gag-filled (though not terribly sharp-toothed) sendup of the blaxploitation genre, this film actually owes more to the ''anything goes'' humor of the ''Airplane!'' school. Keenen Ivory Wayans, who wrote and directed, plays the nice-guy hero somewhat blandly. Bernie Casey, Isaac Hayes and Jim Brown play cranky middle-aged shadows of their former selves. Though the film is capable of dipping into unexpectedly low humor, its script is genuinely funny at times, ''a lively but uncertain mixture of nostalgia, silliness and genuinely unpredictable humor.'' (Maslin) Cocoon: The Return 1988. CBS/Fox Home Video. 1:56. $89.98. LD (Image Entertainment), $39.98. CC. PG. In a film ''so tired . . . that it can barely recapitulate the winning formula of the original hit,'' all the actors from ''Cocoon'' return as elderly people enjoying a delirious resurgence of youth, having spent the last several years on the planet Antarea losing track of earthly time. This weary sequel does have a few things to recommend it: Tak Fujimoto's cinematography ''gives a crisp, lively look to the Florida scenery.'' And some of the actors - particularly Don Ameche, Hume Cronyn and Jessica Tandy - ''radiate grace and gallantry even when the material does not.'' (Maslin) Frida 1984. Connoisseur Home Video. 1:48. $79.95. Subtitled. Not rated. This Mexican film is an affectionate and affecting tribute to the colorful native artist and political radical Frida Kahlo, who died in 1954 at the age of 47. Paul Leduc, who directed, has not attempted a standard biography. The series of bright tableaux flows not in chronological order, but ''elegantly in a sort of order of the spirit.'' Ofelia Medina stars, and Juan Jose Gurrola plays Frida's husband, the painter and political activist Diego Rivera. ''What Mr. Leduc and Ms. Medina do is open up a life to us in the way that Kahlo herself attempted in her art. Whatever the real Kahlo was like, in their movie, she is vibrant.'' (Walter Goodman) Middle Age Crazy 1980. CBS/Fox. 1:35. $59.98. R. This entertaining movie about sex, far from being pornographic, soon turns into a highly moral lecture on responsibilities and love, and ends in a tide of sentiment. Bruce Dern stars as a Houston architect, whose wife, played by Ann-Margret, is lustily intent on setting a record in connubial relations. This and other pressures drive him to flights of fantasy and a bout of infidelity, but home and hearth ultimately prevail. ''John Trent has directed Carl Kleinschmitt's screenplay along an earthy, human, believable course.'' (Richard F. Shepard) Each Dawn I Die 1939. MGM/UA. 1:32. $19.95. No rating. When this film appeared, a critic - accustomed ''to serv [ ing ] out a term in at least one Warner prison picture every month, with no time off for good behavior'' - found it ''of secondary quality.'' Still, it has achieved classic status, if only on the strength of its stars. The critic found the story of James Cagney's framing ''wildly implausible,'' but acknowledged that ''Mr. Cagney almost plays it plausibly,'' while George Raft ''ably seconds him as the big-shot gangster who becomes his friend, and subsequent liberator, through familiar exigencies of a Warner prison term.''

title: Rose ZweibackA Bride in Omaha
description: Rose Zweiback, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Eugene Zweiback of Omaha, was married there yesterday to Mace Anthony Hack, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Hack of Greenwich, Conn. Judge Lynn Ferer of County Court in Douglas County, Neb., officiated at the Highland Country Club.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Iowa; Elderhostel: Creativity In Writing
description: On the face of it, the class on writing short fiction taught by a University of Iowa teaching assistant, Tomas Murphy, does not seem different from similar classes across the nation. But there is one startling change: every student is older than 60.

title:
STYLE MAKERS;
Arnold Chan: Architect and Lighting Designer
description: LEAD: Four years ago Arnold Chan, a 30-year-old architect who had also studied lighting engineering, embarked upon a career as a lighting designer from his apartment in west London. Armed with dual qualifications that are rare in Europe, his strategy was simple: ''Start at the top by finding important clients, and if you're no good you can always work down,'' said Mr.

title: Helena White Is Wed to Bruce Fifer,Cathedral's Liturgical Music Director
description: The wedding of Helena Comfort White and Bruce Thacher Fifer took place yesterday at the Episcopal Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York. The ceremony was performed by the Very Rev. James ParksMorton, the Dean of the cathedral, assisted by Canon Michael Cray Kuhn and the Rev. Louis Ewald Fifer 3d, the bridegroom's father. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. F. L. Peter White of St. James, L.I. The bridegroom is also a son of Virginia Fincke Fifer of Wyncote, Pa.

description: Eleanor Han Marsh and Peter Sweet Putnam Sanborn, equities analysts in Toyko, were married yesterday at St. Martin's Episcopal Church in Providence, R.I. The Revs. Halsey DeWolfe Howe and Victoria B. M. Sanborn, an aunt of the bridegroom, officiated.

title: Replacing Broken Windows
description: BROKEN window glass must be replaced promptly. The job is not too difficult, but there are a few pitfalls that can be avoided by knowing beforehand how to proceed and by working in a safe, orderly fashion.

title: Choosing Not to Run
description: Grete Waitz has won the New York City Marathon nine times but last week she just watched as her husband did the running. It was, after all, more of a sprint than a marathon. Ms. Waitz and her husband, Jack Waitz, were walking in midtown Manhattan when a man sprayed hand lotion on her back, and a second man rushed up with paper napkins to help wipe it off. During the confusion a third man grabbed her backpack, containing her wallet and about $40, and dashed away. The police called the incident the ''ketchup con game'' and said it happens a lot. Ms. Waitz was left at the starting line, but Mr. Waitz gave chase, grabbing back the backpack. Two passing police officers joined the race and eventually caught one suspect. Said the marathoner, ''It happened so fast.''

title: Jennifer Kingson To Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles I. Kingson of New York have announced August wedding plans for their daughter, Jennifer Anne Kingson, and Jack Sandler Bloom, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Bloom of Palm Beach, Fla., and Brookline, Mass.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: I DON'T know what possessed me. Call it whim. Call it nostalgia. But the memory came to mind, and I thought I'd go take a look and see what a memory looked like after 30 years. There was a certain timeliness about it.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-13

title: The Fabric of the Flag
description: What is it about Americans and their flag? As each Fourth of July rolls around, we excite the wonder of other democracies with our explosive patriotic fervor. Americans salute flags, chant pledges and belt out anthems more than any other free people. And this year, the patriotism has been whipped up by exaggerated reaction to the Supreme Court's flag-burning decision. What explains the intensity of public reaction?

title: Bench Candidate Is Rebuffed
description: LEAD: IN a rare occurrence, the Suffolk County Bar Association has labeled a candidate for District Court judge unqualified for the bench because he refused to be screened by the association's Judiciary Committee.

title: A ROMANCE OF THE SECRET ANNEX
description: THE DIARY OF ANNE FRANK The Critical Edition. Edited by David Barnouw and Gerrold van der Stroom. Translated by Arnold J. Pomerans and B. M. Mooyaart-Doubleday. Illustrated. 719 pp. New York: Doubleday. $30. EVA'S STORY A Survivor's Tale by the Step-Sister of Anne Frank. By Eva Schloss with Evelyn Julia Kent. Illustrated. 224 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $16.95.

description: EVERY time President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d have spoken with the press in the last two weeks, they have been badgered with the same question, ''Why aren't you saying and doing more about China?'' Each time, with increasing exasperation, they have answered, ''Look at all we have said and done.''

title: Simple, Homestyle Cooking in Westport
description: IT is always a rare pleasure to find a restaurant that serves food as good as that found in the home of a caring, expert cook. Such a place is the newly opened Francine's in downtown Westport.

description: ANNA POLIMENI attends a lot of parties, although, she says, it is more work than play.

title: Park Path Becomes a Memorial
description: LEAD: ''MAN'S dream wife in reality'' is how Raymond Jacobs, 83 years old, describes his late wife, Ann. The couple lived for many years in Hartsdale, and often walked together along a path near the Bronx River Parkway on the Scarsdale-White Plains border. Last week, a section of that path was designated by the county as ''Ann's Way.

title: Sweet Memory of a Cherry Tree That Touched the Stars
description: THE scream of a chain saw has never been my favorite sound, but this time my imagination must be kept sternly in check. It is the saw and not the cherry tree that's screaming.

title: On Language; Haven Maven
description: A PUNDIT CARE-less with his usage wrote this about the astrophysicist Fang Lizhi, the Beijing dissident who is now a house guest of the United States: ''You can send him and his family a welcome note care of the U.S. Embassy in Peking [ Box 50, FPO San Francisco, Calif. 96655 ] , where they are holed up under our protection. The asylum granted him has infuriated the Deng re-gime. . . .''

title: Alicia Clare, Lawyer, Wed to George McCarthy Jr.
description: Alicia C. Clare, an associate in the law firm of Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer & Wood, and George F. McCarthy Jr., a commercial real-estate appraiser and an associate with the Real Estate Research Corporation in New York, were married yesterday. The Rev. Robert McKee officiated at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Roman Catholic Church in Centerport, L.I.

description: In years past, the end of the New York State legislative session came with the dark of night or with the first few streaks of sunlight through the Capitol windows at dawn.

description: A Federal district judge here has overturned a brand-new Tennessee law that would have required minors who seek abortions to obtain their parents' consent.

title: No Headline
description: Flocks of sheep and teams of woodsmen have replaced chemical defoliants along Oregon's Pacific Coast as Government foresters use safer methods for clearing brush from slopes for new forests.

title: Bright Flowers, Big City: L.I. Nurseryman on Park Avenue
description: IF where you work defines who you are, Peter Van de Wetering has a split personality. Visit the two avenues on which he makes his living and you'll see an extraordinary difference in work environs.

title: Free Tuition At Webb Institute
description: Dean Eleanor Baum of Cooper Union [ Long Island Interview, June 4 ] is incorrect in her belief that Cooper Union is the only tuition-free college in the country. Webb Institute of Naval Architecture, a century old accredited engineering school located in Glen Cove, shares the free-tuition tradition with Cooper Union. EVERETT C. HUNT Professor of Marine Engineering Webb Institute

We have painted this door about once every three years since it was installed, but it has now developed a hole that has become rusty near where the metal frame joins the house wall. This hole is about the size of a quarter. Is there a way to patch it?

description: And why can't the Baltimore Orioles win the American League East championship?

description: To the Editor:

description: Janice AurittOser and Alan S. Oser of St. George, S.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Andrea Oser, to David Alan Miller, the son of Rachel Galperin and Gerald Miller, both of Los Angeles. A September wedding is planned.

description: I RECENTLY had the good fortune to attend my son's arraignment at the State Superior Court in Norwich to answer a charge of driving while intoxicated.

DINING OUT;
Worthy of a Journey to Rockland County

title:
CONNECTICUT Q & A: MARTHA STEWART;
'It's Kind Of Fun To Entertain Outside'
description: LEAD: MARTHA STEWART began her lifework in entertaining when she was in high school and catered a party for the football team in her hometown, Nutley, N.J. She served homemade breads, jams and jellies. In the years since, she has become a nationally known specialist on food and entertaining, and has written six books on entertaining, which from her first success, ''Entertaining,'' to the recent ''Quick

title: Smorgasbord of Summer Fare
description: WITH summer stock companies bursting out all over and virtually all the state's major theaters on a break, how is a theatergoer to sort out the genuinely professional from the strictly potluck?

title: FICTION
description: PRETTY WOMEN. By Kate Coscarelli. (New American Library, $18.95.) A sharp political sensibility distinguishes this otherwise routine piece of commercial fiction by the author of ''Perfect Order.'' The novel opens in 1976, when a mysterious phone call reminds Tess Kipling, the dean of women at a California university, and Samara Mulhare, the head of a Hollywood studio, of their shared past as the wives of United States Air Force officers stationed in Libya in the 1950's. The bulk of the action takes place during those years on the American base in Tripoli, where the men must contend with a sadistic commanding officer, Brick Masters, while strong-minded Tess and Samara struggle to adjust to a world in which women are expected to devote their lives to supporting their husbands' careers. Kate Coscarelli is at her best when she's evoking the rigid, hierarchical society of the postwar armed services. And the denouement of ''Pretty Women,'' which reunites the scattered principals roughly 20 years later, reveals the degree to which some of the officers subordinated morality to their desire to please their unscrupulous commandant. Ms. Coscarelli nicely draws the obvious parallels between the cover-up her characters expose and the then-recent Watergate scandal, and her larger point about the dangers of unquestioning obedience to authority is timeless. Unfortunately, she's rooted her ideas in a cliched plot, complete with an utterly implausible device for its resolution and a group of characters without much emotional depth. Still, it's a pleasure to read a popular novel in which the main concerns are ethical rather than sexual or sartorial.

title: Happy Birthday
description: A year and a half from now Americans will celebrate the 200th anniversary of our Bill of Rights. It was in 1791 that the first 10 amendments were added to the Constitution, at popular insistence that the new United States needed guarantees of individual rights.

title: Kean Signs New Budget He Says No One Likes
description: Gov. Thomas H. Kean signed a new budget into law shortly before dawn this morning, ending 48 hours of grueling negotiation and bitter confrontation among state legislators that had threatened to leave New Jersey drifting without the authority to spend money or pay its employees.

title: The Kirov Enters the World of Glasnost
description: A new history is being made here these days at the Kirov Theater. In a spacious rehearsal room this spring, a dozen dancers practiced the steps to George Balanchine's ''Scotch Symphony.'' On a stairwell landing, two dancers discussed a program for the company's experimental studio theater. And in his office, the Kirov's energetic director, Oleg Vinogradov, was reviewing an agreement to bring Mikhail Baryshnikov and the American Ballet Theater to Leningrad later this year, checking the latest project for the company's joint theatrical business venture with a British firm and finalizing plans for the company's first New York engagement in 25 years.

title: PERSPECTIVES: New York City's Property Taxes; The Homeowners' Break on Assessments
description: FROM the standpoint of property taxes, it is pleasant to be a homeowner in New York City. Legislators guard the homeowners' interests.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Purdue; 2 Thefts in a Year Are Jarring Notes In Music Program
description: For the second time in nine months, Purdue University's musical groups have been shaken by allegations of financial wrongdoing by their leaders.

title: Ms. Combemale And Paul Murphy To Wed in August
description: Pamela Pauline Combemale, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard F. Combemale of New York and Winthrop, Me., and Paul Robert Murphy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter K. Murphy of Bonn, plan to marry in August, the future bride's parents have announced.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: INDIANAPOLIS;
State Vacating Private Offices
description: LEAD: THE private office market here, with a 20 percent vacancy rate that is climbing, is bracing for the loss of a major tenant, the state government.

title:
Westchester Q&A;: Ingeborg J. Childs;
Rearing a Retarded Child, Then and Now
description: LEAD: FORTY years ago, a group of Westchester parents with a common bond got together in Mount Vernon. All of them had retarded children. At the time, there were few options for such children. The public schools could not and would not educate them; there was no job training or work for them; most of them were eventually placed in private or state institutions.

title: Legislators Count Successes As Albany Session Closes
description: Ending this year's legislative session with a drawn-out all-night session, the New York State Legislature recessed shortly after noon today, leaving hundreds of bills on Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's desk, including a measure that would allow residents of Staten Island to vote to secede from the rest of New York City.

title: Correction
description: A map last Sunday with an article about Burmese rebels misidentified territory west of Myanmar (formerly Burma). The country's coastal border is with Bangladesh, not India.

title: Jana P. Bonn MarriedTo Douglas W. Peters
description: At the Westhampton Presbyterian Church in Quogue, L.I., Jana Patrice Bonn, a daughter of Mary Leonard Bonn of East Aurora, N.Y., and the late Raymond Henry Bonn, was married yesterday to Douglas Witham Peters, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan W. Peters of Englewood, N.J. The Rev. Charles Cary officiated.

description: Like scouts interpreting the landscape, New Yorkers at this season can read the late afternoon light striking Manhattan facades and understand something about the natural world beyond the island.

title: Ending Tax Quarrels Among States
description: The recent article ''Tax Quarrels Among States Go Back a Long Way'' provided an interesting review of the more than 200 years of interstate tax disputes in the tristate region. More importantly, however, the article was illustrative of the need to create finally a mechanism for effectively resolving these recurrent disputes.

description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Dance; Collins and Browne in 'La Sylphide'
description: The Romantic notion of women as preternaturally knowing - and therefore ruinous - creatures ran through a fine performance of ''La Sylphide'' by the American Ballet Theater on Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. The three lead male dancers brought an almost giddy sweetness to their characters, making the two lead women look like members of an indisputably stronger sex.

title: Sheila McHugh Becomes Bride
description: Sheila McHugh, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John McHugh of Doylestown, Pa., was married yesterday to Robert Thompson Puopolo, a son of Mrs. Frank Folino of Weston, Mass., and the late E. Michael Puopolo. Msgr. James Howard and the Rev. Joseph Casey performed the ceremony at the Cathedral Basilica of SS. Peter and Paul in Philadelphia.

title: Deborah Frankel Planning to Marry W. W. Bancroft Jr.
description: The engagement of Deborah Anne Frankel, the daughter of Deltra Locke Frankel of Garden City, L.I. and Sandisfield, Mass., and the late Dr. Emanuel Frankel, and William Woodward Bancroft Jr., a son of William W. Bancroft of Brookville, L.I., and the late Julie Echols Gould of New York and Southampton, L.I., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents. A September wedding is planned.

title: WHAT IS TOO OLD?
description: The admission of a 99-year-old woman with fainting spells is a common occurrence in the hospital emergency room (Body and Mind, ''What Is Too Old?'' by Michael S. Wilkes and Miriam Shuchman, June 4).

title: Sex Bias Is Found Pervading Courts
description: Bias against women pervades the court system in Massachusetts, affecting them as lawyers, litigants and employees, an analysis for the state's highest court has concluded.

description: Because of an editing error, an article on Greenwich condominiums on June 25 omitted the first name and position of the assistant to the president of Cardinal Development Corporation of New York City. She is Ashley Warwick.

title: Spike Lee's Blacks: Are They Real People?
description: A half-century ago, Eleanor Roosevelt wrote Richard Wright a note complimenting him on his book of short stories, ''Uncle Tom's Children.'' Wright fumed. Mrs. Roosevelt's approval made him think he had written a book that ''even bankers' daughters could read and weep over and feel good'' about. He resolved that his next work would be so hard and cruel that readers would face it without the consolation of tears.

title: The Stars and Stripes: How Sacred a Symbol?; Too Much Freedom
description: To the Editor:

title: All-Star Coaches Are Chosen
description: Baseball's two leagues named their coaches yesterday for the All-Star Game in nine days and only one of the four managers selected started the day with his team in first place in its division.

title: Why Kaiser Is Still the King
description: Kathy Adams looked down at her 4-week-old son, born two months prematurely, and remembered the weeks of medical care he received under the Kaiser Permanente Medical Care Program, from the intensive-care ward to the doctor's office. ''Emotionally and medically,'' she said, ''they were top notch.''

title: Spinning the Revolving Door
description: The Ethics in Government Act sought to close a revolving door by barring officials who left the executive branch from lobbying former colleagues until a year after departure. Last week, a Federal appeals court gave a new spin to the law, overturning the conviction of Lyn Nofziger, who faced 90 days' imprisonment and fines of $30,000 for lobbying former colleagues after leaving the White House as Ronald Reagan's political adviser. Writing for a 2-to-1 majority, Judge James Buckley, a former New York Senator who was appointed to the bench by Mr. Reagan, said the Government had not shown criminal intent by Mr. Nofziger and the law was ambiguous on whether intent is required for a conviction. The dissenting judge, appointed by President Jimmy Carter, said the majority had strained to find an ambiguity. The independent prosecutor who brought the case may appeal.

title: A Pete Rose Fan Asks Mercy
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Scorsese's 'Temptation' in a Context of Risks
description: Among contemporary American directors, no one is more versatile or artistically accomplished than Martin Scorsese. When Mr. Scorsese's LAST TEMPTATION OF CHRIST was released last year, the furor caused by some conservative Christians who threatened to boycott the film all but overshadowed its artistic value. Now available on video (MCA Home Video, $89.95), the picture can be seen in the context of Mr. Scorsese's extraordinary career.

title: Delgado Puts Tour in Turmoil
description: The Tour de France began in turmoil today as Pedro Delgado, the defending champion, showed up nearly three minutes late for his start in the race. The time counted against him in the race, which is decided on least elapsed overall time, and tonight the Spaniard ranked last in the 198-man field.

title: Slavic with an Italian Accent
description: AFTER exploring the plaintive heart of Yugoslavia's Slavic-Muslim interior, to come upon the Istrian Peninsula was like turning a corner and discovering the Piazza San Marco shining in the sun. A stone's throw across the Adriatic from the stones of Venice, Istria is a loose Yugoslav translation of Italy at its most carefree and most atmospheric, tailor-made for travelers who rate the investigation of a Roman city as sybaritic as a dinner of perfectly grilled fish and a bottle of great wine on a terrace overlooking the Adriatic.

title: The Stars and Stripes: How Sacred a Symbol?; Misguided Chauvinists
description: To the Editor:

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Menu; A Tasty Meal in a Pocket
description: This meal-in-a-sandwich takes advantage of summer produce: the dewiest cucumbers, the crispiest peppers and the juiciest tomatoes. Fresh herbs are more plentiful now, too, and add a fillip of flavor. The meal takes just minutes to prepare and barely heats up the kitchen. But perhaps the nicest surprise is that it is low in calories. Using ground turkey instead of beef cuts down on both calories and fat.

title: Support Is Off For Abortion
description: As both sides await a Supreme Court ruling on abortion, public support for the existing state of the law has slipped slightly, a New York Times Poll shows.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: ESSEX;
A Town Upon Which Tourists Visit Their Woes
description: LEAD: A BIG green and white tour bus with Rhode Island license plates lumbered down Essex's picturesque Main Street last week, stopped by the park and flung open its doors. The passengers disembarked, scattering in all directions, but the bus remained on the narrow one-way street, defiling the atmosphere with the sounds and smells from its idling engine.

title: Helping Children Learn to Face Defeat
description: IN a recent soccer game between 8-year-olds of neighboring communities, the visiting team was trailing, 2-to-0, with less than two minutes to play. Just then one of its better players (who had apparently overslept) arrived, and with the permission of the referee was inserted into the game. Moments later the team was making a charge on the goal.

title: 'The Rise of the West'
description: To the Editor:

title: If This Is July, It's Time to Think April 15
description: Taxes, it seems, have become a year-round occupation. With many people still not quite recovered from the unpleasant task of filing their annual tax returns, it is time to delve into some midyear tax planning. There are new wrinkles this year, courtesy of the Technical and Miscellaneous Revenue Act of 1988. In addition, some provisions of the 1986 Tax Reform Act and the 1987 Revenue Act are just now taking effect.

title: Japan Agrees To Open a Market
description: Japan said it would provide foreign companies greater access to its mobile telephone market, after being threatened by the Bush Administration with heavy penalties on some of its exports to the United States. Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher said the agreement ''should serve as a model for future negotiations.''TR

title: The County Past, the County Future
description: WELL over a third of a century ago I became Chief Planner of Weschester County. Later I was named Commissioner of Planning and left that position 21 years ago. Things in Westchester seemed better in those days: there was a sense of satisfaction with how the county was developing, and there was optimism about the future.

title: WHAT'S DOING ON: Cape Cod
description: Three of Cape Cod's oldest and largest communities are celebrating their 350th birthdays this summer and fall, paying homage to their austere Puritan ancestors for founding the towns of Sandwich, Barnstable and Yarmouth in 1639.

title: Elizabeth Carter Campbell Is Engaged To Wed Gary Bruce Shaye in August
description: Elizabeth Carter Campbell, the manager of the economic development unit of the Save the Children Federation in Westport, Conn., and Gary Bruce Shaye, the federation's regional director for Latin America and the Caribbean, plan to marry in August. The engagement was announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Colin G. Campbell of New York and Old Black Point, Conn. Mr. Shaye is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Shaye of Albany.

title: PASTIMES: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Time off to enjoy the holiday on Tuesday. Books for Summer

title: Ticket Tempest in a Teacup
description: They are the only impolite aspect of the queue, the seedy men trafficking in tickets, shouldering their way through the line of patient tennis fans. Now one of them has landed a Dutch player, Nicole Jagerman, in hot water with Wimbledon officials and the Women's International Tennis Association.

title:
The View From: Washington's Headquarters Museum;
Taking a Step Back Into the Everday Life of 1776
description: LEAD: ON this weekend of flags and fireworks, it seems fitting to glimpse one of the spots where the Father of Our Country slept, for at least a week.

title:
GARDENING;
The Benefits of Catching Rainwater
description: LEAD: READERS often come up with important points that garden writers overlook. One reader noted that recent articles on water conservation failed to include collection and use of rainwater. This is certainly a good suggestion and also a reminder of times past when collecting rainwater was essential.

title: McCullers to Start For Yankees Today
description: When John Candelaria limped out of the starting rotation on a bad right knee early in May, the revolving door whirled and Clay Parker emerged as his replacement. The revolving door turns again today, and Lance McCullers becomes the Yankees' 11th starting pitcher this season.

title: Walking the Streams; Aquatic Connections
description: LEAD: AS Dr. Barbara Dexter talks, she holds up a map of the river basins of Westchester County. The map is filled with wavy lines that merge into one another like branches on a tree. Some of the lines flow in and out of lakes. Ultimately they wend their way into the Long Island Sound or the Hudson River.

title: Grass-Roots Groups Show Power Battling Pollution Close to Home
description: A new form of environmental protest is spreading through the country as thousands of people band together in small community groups. Their target is usually pollution by local industrial plants, employers traditionally respected but now reviled as poisoners of the neighborhood.

title: Denise Gill Wed To Douglas Nash
description: Denise E. Gill and Douglas H. Nash were married yesterday at St. Thomas More Church in Rochester. The Rev. Robert L. Collins performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: Books Tell Tales Of Art and Money
description: Rare books, manuscripts and autographs are acquired today as enthusiastically as during the last book-collecting boom in the 1920's - but with greater intellectual discrimination. The variety of penned and printed works sought is astonishing. So are the prices, which can exceed $1 million for lavishly illuminated medieval manuscripts, copies of the Gutenberg Bible or a complete ''Birds of America,'' by John James Audubon.

title: New York Charter Bus Flips In Virginia and 42 Are Hurt
description: A chartered bus from New York clipped the rear of a tractor-trailer and overturned about 50 miles south of Richmond on Friday afternoon, injuring 42 passengers, the police said.

title: POSTINGS: A Walk to Wall; Pied-a-Terre
description: Three Asian investors are renovating an 86-year- old office building near Wall Street and converting it into 49 small condominium apartments intended as corporate and private pied-a-terre for people working in the Financial District. The group, Target Two Associates, is spending $9.5 million to buy and renovate the eight-story Empire-style building at 129 Front Street, at the corner of Pine Street.

title: Louis XV's Mississippi Valley
description: SIXTY miles south of St. Louis on an island in the Mississippi, there is a shrine to a period of American history now largely forgotten. It is a 650-pound bronze and silver bell, cast in 1741 in La Rochelle, France, given by Louis XV to the mission church at Kaskaskia. The once-bustling French Colonial town of Kaskaskia was separated from the Illinois mainland when the Mississippi changed its course in 1881; thus stranded, it slowly sank into the muddy water. But the bell was saved, moved to its present drier location in the center of Kaskaskia Island. Beneath its twining fleurs-de-lis, there's an inscription: ''For the church of the Illinois by gift of the King from across the water.''

title: Question Of the Week; Are the New Tennis Players Exciting?
description: If exciting means enjoying the precision of Lendl, the grace of Noah, the fluidity of Edberg and the desire of Becker, then the answer is yes, yes, yes.

title: The Agents Who Took H.U.D.'s Money and Walked
description: THE cascade of accusations about the Department of Housing and Urban Development can be divided into two categories: so-called influence peddling, in which Republican consultants and housing developers who hired them have cashed in on their access, and straight-out old-fashioned theft.

title: THE IMPORTANCE OF BEING OPRAH
description: Your author writes that lack of self-esteem is a ''favorite daytime talk-show subject'' and that talk shows are ''full of language'' like ''the internalized mother.'' She notes that ''people like to have experiences; it saves them from having to think.'' Could she be suggesting that reasoning is superior to feeling? She might benefit from reading the books of Eudora Welty and Flannery O'Connor to see how characters who repress their feelings fare. ELAINE PRESTON Huntington, L.I.

title: Prison Inmates Exhibit Wistful Works on Paper
description: DR. JOHNSON observed that the prospect of being hanged ''wonderfully concentrates the mind.'' But from the looks of the show now at the Vanguard Gallery in New London, being in prison doesn't do a bad job.

title: PASTIMES: Bridge
description: The European championships can be considered the world's strongest bridge event, since at least six of the contesting countries are capable of winning world titles and nearly all the others are only just short of that level. The 1989 event began yesterday in Turku, Finland, and will qualify two teams to represent the zone in the world championships in Perth, Australia, in September.

title: 18 Authors Are Recipients Of American Book Awards
description: Isabel Allende, Henry L. Gates Jr., Frank Chin, Emory Elliott, Alma Luz Villanueva and William Hohri are among 18 winners of the 10th annual American Book Awards, which are presented by the Before Columbus Foundation ''to advance American writing in all its diversity.''

title: Fireworks and Pops To Celebrate the Fourth
description: The Charles Ives Center for the Art in Danbury will begin its summer season tomorrow night with ''Pops and Fireworks.'' The Ives Symphony Orchestra will reconvene under the direction of Skitch Henderson, and the program will include Morton Gould's arrangement of ''When Johnny Comes Marching Home Again,'' Leroy Anderson's ''Bugler's Holiday' and ''Trumpeter's Lullaby'' and Suppe's 'Morning, Noon and Night in Vienna'' overture.

title: HOW THE MOON WAS WON
description: MEN FROM EARTH By Buzz Aldrin and Malcolm McConnell. Illustrated. 312 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $19.95.

title: Limits on Striped Bass Irk Fishermen
description: LEAD: ONCE the commercial netter's mainstay, always an angler's prize and, for more than four decades, a problem for Federal officials, the migratory striped bass once again has churned political waters.

title: Counting the Legal Ways To Pay for Campaigns
description: EVEN before President Bush announced a legislative package last week that he said would ''truly clean up'' campaign financing, Ronald H. Brown, the Democratic national chairman, already had a name for it: the ''Fat Cat Protection Act.''

title: China Party Chief's Son Keeps Low Profile at a U.S. School
description: The son of the new Chinese Communist Party leader has spent the last three years as a graduate student in electrical engineering at Drexel University here.

title: Rats, Leaks, Crackheads and All, Apartments Beat Welfare Hotels
description: After two years of being homeless, Sophie Bosket and her children have their own apartment now. And though the walls of the city-owned Harlem tenement are crumbling, rats roam the courtyard and strangers smoke crack in the hallway, Ms. Bosket says it is a vast improvement over their last residence - one room at the Martinique Hotel.

title: FICTION
description: NO EASY PLACE TO BE. By Steven Corbin. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) It's easy to imagine buoyancy in the mood above 125th Street in Manhattan during the 1920's, a time when all the women seemed to be bold and unconventional, with hands that were creamy soft rather than calloused from scrubbing floors or picking cotton. And their nails, of course, were painted red. Steven Corbin's first novel, ''No Easy Place to Be,'' presents that era through the eyes and lives of three black sisters who come of age during the Harlem Renaissance. But, unfortunately, it falls short of capturing the vivacity of the period. Each sister has her story: Miriam is a nurse at Harlem Hospital who channels her impatience with integration into Marcus Garvey's ill-fated Universal Negro Improvement Association; Velma, a Barnard-educated writer, travels between the salons of Greenwich Village and Harlem; Louise, the youngest sibling, is a fair-skinned Cotton Club dancer who finds happiness only after passing for white. But as Mr. Corbin describes their lives, one must struggle to feel the spontaneity and vitality of their experiences. It's particularly dismaying to note that the author slips, perhaps inadvertently, into the clumsy, somewhat simplistic characterization of black Harlem as tough and difficult - in contrast to downtown white Manhattan, where everything appears to be not only better but more attractive. And so, while the novel has its high points, it quickly becomes clear that Harlem in the period between 1919 and 1929 is no easy place for Mr. Corbin to make his debut.

title: A Man of the Theater With an Affinity for Opera
description: Harold Prince is delighted when people ask him whether he has any background in opera. The master of spectacle and laughs on Broadway is about to unveil his production of one of the great canonic operas, Mozart's ''Don Giovanni,'' on the New York City Opera's opening night, Thursday. Is he dabbling or what? Mr. Prince smiles. He has been going to the Metropolitan Opera since about 1936.

title: Review/Dance; Mark Morris Troupe In Jacob's Pillow Bill
description: For the last year, Mark Morris's troupe has been the dance company of the Theatre de la Monnaie, the opera house of Brussels. Although his headquarters has changed, this young American choreographer has not. He remains as unpredictable as ever. That was clear Thursday night when the 24-member Monnaie Dance Group/Mark Morris performed five works from its repertory at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival.

title: Body and Mind; Backward Protection
description: IT SEEMS TO ERUPT FROM NOwhere: a young man, finishing his shift as a taxi driver, sits down to have a snack. Within seconds, he complains that he has a lump in his throat. Moments later he is gasping for air, and as the ambulance arrives, he loses consciousness. On arrival in the emergency room, the man suffers a respiratory arrest, and his heart stops briefly. As physicians treat him they wonder what evil can strike such a powerful blow: Drugs? Asthma? Clots in the lungs? Several hours later, in an intensive-care unit, he wakes up on a ventilator and gives us an answer: cashews.

title: Napoletano Wins With Record Time
description: Napoletano justified his reputation as one of the world's top trotters by capturing the $250,000 Statue of Liberty Trot tonight at the Meadowlands.

title: 780 West End Ave.
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Great Lakes, Some Pollution Defies the Cleanup
description: TWENTY years after Cleveland's Cuyahoga River caught fire and Lake Erie was pronounced dead, strangled on its own algae, the Great Lakes have made a slow recovery. Because of tougher pollution controls, the lakes look and smell better, and cities from Duluth to Buffalo have invested millions of dollars in marinas and waterfront parks.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some of the most notable releases of the last few months.

title: Question Of the Week; Are the New Tennis Players Exciting?
description: An exciting player takes risks and tries to end the point. But most new players have a two-handed backhand, the trademark of defensive specialists.

title: THE IMPORTANCE OF BEING OPRAH
description: Who would have thought of deconstructing Oprah Winfrey? Your article is the most honest piece of writing on a star I've read.

title: PANEL SAID TO SEEK NEW MILITARY ROLE IN FIGHT ON DRUGS
description: A special National Security Council task force plans to recommend that President Bush greatly intensify the military's role in the drug war by sending military advisers and increasing economic aid to South American countries where cocaine production flourishes, Administration officials say.

title: America Needs an Investment Boom
description: So far, the word which best describes the Bush Administration's economic policy is empty. Its budget agreement was a mouse. Its dollar exchange rate policy has been made obsolete by market forces. Its trade policy consists of loud protectionist noises. And its new policy on international debt is stuck on the launch pad. The honeymoon has been dissipated without getting an economic agenda off the ground.

title: PASTIMES: Chess
description: There have been lots of excuses for not showing up for a game or even a tournament, but for stark simplicity, not to mention total incredibility, it is hard to beat Boris Spassky's reason for backing out of the Fifth World Cup Tournament in the World Trade Center in Rotterdam, which began June 3. He was simply too tired.

title: Outdoors; Making Rivers Salmon-Friendly Again
description: Before their upstream passage was blocked by dams, Atlantic salmon swarmed up the Connecticut River by the tens of thousands to reach their spawning beds on the upper river and its tributaries.

title: On St. George Orwell
description: To the Editor:

title: Issues and Decisions to Test Bush Popularity
description: As he nears the end of his first six months in office, President Bush will leave for Europe next Sunday in a mood of sunny confidence supported by upbeat polls. But Congressional leaders and even some Administration officials say he faces a cloud of issues demanding a set of decisions that could put his popularity to a serious test.

title: Reporter's Notebook; In Pyongyang, Pro-American And Anti-U.S.
description: It is now ''Anti-United States Month'' in North Korea. As thousands of foreigners, including Americans, descend upon the capital for the World Festival of Youth and Students, many North Koreans are having a hard time explaining the concept of this month as they are trying to welcome foreigners.

title: Harvard Tops Penn For Fourth Time
description: Three times on American waters this season, Harvard University's varsity heavyweight crew had narrowly defeated its rival from the University of Pennsylvania. Today, at the 150th Henley Royal Regatta on the Thames, Harvard once again prevailed over Penn, this time in a semifinal of the Ladies' Challenge Plate.

title: THE IMPORTANCE OF BEING OPRAH
description: Ms. Harrison makes Oprah Winfrey out to be someone we are supposed to resent without really telling us why. She concentrates on Ms. Winfrey's critics and on her circle of elitist, black friends, but she does not provide us with one interview of any of her 16 million viewers.

title: Los Angeles Site for Soccer
description: The United States Soccer Federation was informed yesterday by the world governing body of soccer that Los Angeles will be the neutral site for its World Cup qualifying game against El Salvador.

title: Sound Barriers Are an Eyesore
description: Your report on the construction of sound barriers along Interstate highways in Connecticut (''Muffling the Interstates by Walling in Their Noise,'' June 4) failed to indicate what an unattractive view they create for anyone who has to ride past them.

title: Room for Economy In School Budgets
description: As the founder of No More, the Long Island anti-tax organization which recently burned school budgets, may I comment on our call for voters to reject school budgets this year.

title: Moody Is Tied For Seniors Lead
description: Just 20 years and 16 days after he was a surprise winner of the United States Open, Orville (Sarge) Moody had a spectacular five-hole finish today to shoot a record eight-under-par 64 in the third round of the 10th United States Senior Open.

title: PASTIMES: Camera
description: Those of us who have struggled to make slides of black-and-white prints will not soon forget Kodak's direct-positive film developing kit. Here's the way it worked: You loaded up with ultra-fine-grain, ultra-slow Panatomic-X, bracketed your exposures wildly and then souped the film in no fewer than 15 different solutions. Voila! Some 50 minutes later, out came positive black-and-white images of whatever you had bothered to copy.

title: The Stars and Stripes: How Sacred a Symbol?; Wrong Flag
description: To the Editor:

title: Patent Problems
description: To the Editor:

title: Is Art Above the Laws of Decency?
description: LEAD: The fierce controversy now raging over the decision of the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington to cancel an exhibition of photographs by the late Robert Mapplethorpe was an event waiting to happen. If it hadn't happened at this time and at this institution, sooner or later it would surely have erupted elsewhere.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: BUYING TIME by Joe Haldeman (Morrow, $18.95) takes a good idea and fails to develop it. This is all the more disappointing since Mr. Haldeman has distinguished himself in the past for the sensitive exploration of conventional science fiction premises, as in his fine post-holocaust novel ''Worlds Apart.''

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Developers Win Mitchel Field Tax Battle
description: LEAD: THE most recent controversy over leases between Nassau County and developers at Mitchel Field has resulted in a victory in court for the developers. At stake was about $5 million in property tax revenues to which the county claimed it was entitled.

title: Correction
description: An article on page 29 of the Arts and Leisure section today about Tanglewood gives an incorrect date for the opening concert by the Boston Symphony. It will be Friday; it was not last weekend.

title: Patent Problems
description: The article gives the reader no clue as to the proportion of patents that result in viable products. It is my understanding that only one in seven patents results in commercially useable products or processes.

title: Q and A
description: South Seas

title: Tapes on Alaska's Oil Spill Erased by Exxon Technician
description: A computer operator at Exxon headquarters here says he inadvertently destroyed computer copies of thousands of documents with potentially important information on the Alaskan oil spill.

title:
INVESTING;
A Giant Grows Even Stronger
description: LEAD: Giant Food Inc., the dominant supermarket chain in the Baltimore-Washington area, continues to gain market share. Last year it picked up two percentage points in metropolitan Washington, increasing its share of one of the nation's most prosperous markets to 47 percent. And analysts expect the chain to gain two more points there this year.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Berkeley; Far From Shores Of Gitche Gumee, A Concrete Canoe
description: It is not the type of canoe found by the shores of Gitche Gumee, but it was good enough for civil-engineering students at the University of California at Berkeley to bring home top honors in the National Concrete Canoe Race Finals last weekend.

title: Natalie duPont Edmonds Is Engaged To Wed Peter Andrew Fair in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. George Phippen Edmonds Jr. of Cambridge, Mass., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Natalie duPont Edmonds and Peter Andrew Fair, a son of Mrs. Frederick Maul Fair of New York and the late Mr. Fair.

title: THEY HAD NOTHING TO FEAR FROM J. EDGAR HOOVER
description: BLOOD AND POWER Organized Crime in Twentieth-Century America. By Stephen Fox. Illustrated. 512 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $22.95.

title: Galen Drake, Broadcaster, 83
description: Galen Drake, for many years a radio commentator in New York City and one of the first talk show hosts, died Friday of lung cancer at a nursing home in Long Beach, Calif. He was 83 years old and a resident of Long Beach.

title: Parked Car, No Radio: Where the City Is Losing Control
description: ONE New York City deputy police commissioner routinely leaves the family car unlocked so thieves intent on stealing the radio won't smash the windows, too. The director of the state's Consumer Protection Board moved to Long Island from Manhattan's West Side after his car radio was stolen for the third time in three months.

title: MIG-Making
description: THE MIKOYAN MIG-29, THE Soviet Union's top-of-the-line defense aircraft, went into service in 1985, and by last year about 450 were operational with Soviet air forces at home and in Eastern Europe. Roughly similar to the American F-15, the MIG-29 has been exported as well - to India, East Germany, Yugoslavia and Syria - though probably with variations on the Soviet standard model. Last month during a flight demonstration at the Paris Air Show, an engine malfunction caused one of the export models to crash. The pilot, Anatoly Kvochur, who ejected seconds before the plane hit the ground, suffered extensive injuries.

title: Flatbush
description: To the Editor:

title: Papua New Guinea Aide Slain
description: A Papua New Guinea Cabinet minister was shot dead today, the authorities said. The victim, Communications Minister Malapu Balakau, 34 years old, was gunned down at Mount Hagen, in the Western Highlands, 350 miles northwest of Port Moresby. A hospital spokesman confirmed that the official died of gunshot wounds. No further details were available.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
Beach Blanket Bingo, 50's Style
description: LEAD: MANY Long Islanders celebrate July 4th with that old Colonial ritual, going to the beach. On today's beaches, you face potential hazards like raw sewage, pollution, discarded medical wastes - and wearing this year's bathing suits in public.

title: Old Glory Fills Crew With Pride
description: LEAD: WHEN the American flag is lowered into position on the George Washington Bridge on the Fourth of July, the bridge manager says, the maintenance crew and staff are filled with pride.

title: A Century of Black History Brought Into Focus
description: ''Black Photographers Bear Witness: 100 Years of Social Protest,'' at the Williams College Museum of Art, is fascinating evidence of the incomplete and unsettled state of photography history. Consisting of some 70 photographs by 13 photographers, it brings to light a largely unexplored chapter of picture-making with a combination of scholarship and passion. Most of its photographers and images will be unfamiliar to a general audience, and those that are well known have never before been presented in such an intriguing and illuminating context.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Sitting for portraits in Times Square at midnight, throwing themselves down on the hoods of trucks in the noonday sun, promenading with odd pets or peddling the most whimsical bicycles, people are being their summer selves on the streets of New York.

title: Youngsters Board Buses For Fresh Air Escapes
description: The Port Authority Bus Terminal was awash with children Wednesday as the first of 10,000 disadvantaged New York City youngsters boarded buses to begin two-week adventures in the country.

title: Toasting the Flag
description: LEAD: Distinguished Democrats, Straphangers, Fisherman, Movie Fans, Beer Drinkers, Newspaper Readers, Patrons of Park Benches and Fellow Pedestrians:

title: Reviews/Music; Composers Chamber Theater
description: Golden Fleece, the Composers Chamber Theater, has concerned itself with contemporary American opera for the last 13 years, and has done some admirable small-scale productions on what is clearly a limited budget. In the life of any such endeavor, there are bound to be hits and misses, and the program of four premieres presented by the company on Tuesday evening at Greenwich House weighed heavily in the debit column.

title: Foreign Marketers
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Theater; A Widow's Problems With Love
description: True love among the innocent is the theme of Brenda Shoshanna Lukeman's ''Double Blessing'' at the Jewish Repertory Theater. And even though perfect moral simplicity in ordinary adults becomes utterly preposterous after a while, the actors in this production bring a warmth and good humor to their roles that make you want to go on believing in their characters.

title: POSTINGS: For Pioneers?; Housing Near Javits Center
description: In recent years, Manhattanites unable to find homes in recognized residential neighborhoods have become pioneers. They have moved into SoHo, NoHo, TriBeCa, the Financial District and other commercial and industrial districts, and they have helped to transform those areas into interesting hybrids.

title: Questions Unanswered In Tanker's Grounding
description: A Coast Guard hearing into the cause of the World Prodigy oil spill has adjourned without providing a clear, simple explanation of the navigating error that brought the tanker aground off Newport a week ago.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Colchester, Vt.;
Mixed Uses for A Hilltop Site
description: LEAD: CONSTRUCTION has begun on a three-story, 65,000-square-foot office building here, the first element in a mixed office-hotel-retail development planned for a 100-acre hilltop site.

title: Miss Patton Wed To Michael Cone
description: Pamela Watson Patton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard B. Patton of Pittsburgh and Vero Beach, Fla., and Michael Thomas Cone, a son of Barbara Cone and Sherman Cone, both of Grand Rapids, Mich., were married yesterday. The Rev. Robert English, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Heinz Memorial Chapel at the University of Pittsburgh.

title: NEW YORK CITY'S PROBLEMS ARE IN THE PICTURE
description: ''Do the Right Thing,'' SPIKE Lee's jazzily aggressive folk tale about a Brooklyn racial confrontation, was filmed in bright primary colors on location in Bedford-Stuyvesant, where it all might have happened. The time is summer, in the middle of a heat wave capable of melting the polar ice caps. ''Whew!'' is the page 1 headline on one tabloid. ''Helter Swelter,'' reads another. ''Baked Apple'' announces a third, as if its readers didn't already know.

title: THE DEVILS WHO MAKE US DO IT
description: THE WANT MAKERS The World of Advertising: How They Make You Buy. By Eric Clark. 416 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95.

title: The Painstaking Ambiguity Of Robert Moskowitz
description: When Robert Moskowitz first made his mark on the New York scene it was during the early 1960's as a young man who seemed very much in tune with Pop art. Mr. Moskowitz had spent a year in London, where he became familiar with the work of artists like Peter Blake, and when he returned to New York in 1960 at the age of 25 he brought with him collages incorporating window shades. Coming not long after Robert Rauschenberg exhibited his ''Bed'' and Jasper Johns completed his ''Shade,'' Mr. Moskowitz's works seemed very much of the moment. Or at least they appeared so to William Seitz, a curator who included the collages in a group exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art in 1961, and to Leo Castelli, who sponsored Mr. Moskowitz's first solo show the following year.

title: Add the Bay Star To River Cruises
description: I found Charlotte Libov's May 28 article, ''Cruise Lines Are Riding a High Tide,'' most interesting. However, she seems to have missed an important, and not new, addition to the Connecticut shoreline list of excursion boats. We are starting our second season in Madison.

title: Radio Personality Without Limits
description: Bruce Williams is in no rush. He knows that 'Talknet,' his nationally syndicated radio show, goes on the air at 7:06:32 P.M., after the news. And, for goodness' sake, it is just 7:03:25, and he is only a block from the studio.

title: Court Backs Drug Tests For the Justice Dept.
description: A Federal appeals court has upheld drug tests for Justice Department employees with national security clearances for top-secret material but not for those with access to secret grand jury proceedings.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
Homeless: Stereotypes Blur The Human Reality
description: LEAD: HERE are three quick facts about the new homeless in Nassau and Suffolk: first, two-thirds are women and children; second, 50 percent are under 30 years old; third, the old stereotype that the homeless are former mental patients or Bowery bums is wrong.

title: To Quell Revolt, Halpin Pledges No Tax Increase
description: ADMITTEDLY bearing the brunt of a tax revolt in Suffolk County, County Executive Patrick G. Halpin has started a determined campaign to establish an image as a fiscal conservative, pledging not to raise county real-estate taxes for the two remaining years of his term.

title: Brash New South Is Still a Stranger To Its Dramatists
description: A picture caption on page 24 of the Arts and Leisure section today about ''Steel Magnolias'' misidentifies the actress at the left. She is Mary Fogarty.

title: Gooden Out for 2 Weeks
description: The start was the shortest of Dwight Gooden's career, and now the wait for further word on his condition is likely to be the longest of the season for the Mets. Gooden, who had nothing on the mound but pain, walked off it in the third inning today, dropped dejectedly into the dugout and disappeared from sight.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Moscow Boats For Visitors

title: Review/Jazz; The Zawinul Syndicate
description: Joe Zawinul's quirks, the foundation of some of the most influential jazz-rock fusion, led him off the deep end for the Zawinul Syndicate's late set Wednesday at the Bottom Line. Mr. Zawinul is fond of kinetic rhythms, jumpy melodies, exotic sounds, electronic timbres and jolts of dissonance. But in his best work with Weather Report and Miles Davis, interruptions were balanced with melody. At the Bottom Line, even the best selections offered little more than momentum and virtuosic flourishes.

title: Educators Plan Ways to Woo Taxpayers
description: CONCERNED over the broad-based taxpayer rejections of education budgets this year, school board officials around the state are already planning a campaign to counter another antitax wave next year.

title: Albany Attempt to Expand Shield Law Fails
description: An expansion of New York State's shield law for journalists was unexpectedly turned back early today after Democrats in the State Senate staged a series of unusual parliamentary maneuvers to defeat the bill.

title: Seeking Out Weekend Trips
description: AMERICANS are traveling more often but taking shorter trips. This trend, which surfaced in 1984, has been growing , according to survey after survey. Most recently, the United States Travel Data Center, a research arm of the Travel Industry Association, said that the total of domestic weekend vacations rose 10.5 percent in 1988 while the number of nights spent 100 miles or more away from home dropped 4 percent. Specifically, the average duration of a domestic vacation trip in 1988 was 4.8 nights, compared with 6 nights in 1983.

title: Dr. Judith Hirsch Stoikov Wed to Dr. Richard Miller
description: Dr. Judith Hirsch Stoikov, a labor economist and president of the consulting firm Employment Econommics in New York, and Dr. Richard Miller, chairman of the chemistry department at the State University of New York at Cortland, were married yesterday at their home in Skaneateles, N.Y.

title: A Porch Holds 7 Decades of Memories
description: I'VE always been fond of the wraparound porch that graces our old farmhouse but it was only recently that I began to appreciate fully the significant role a porch can play, over the years, in the life of a family.

title: Susan Noyes Plans to Be Married To H. Edward Bilkey Next Month
description: Mr. and Mrs. David C. Noyes Jr. of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter, Susan Noyes, and H. Edward Bilkey, the son of Mrs. Ross McFarland of Boston and the late Edward Bilkey.

title: Ancient Flat Bread Rises to the Occasion
description: ALTHOUGH focaccia is one of the most ancient Italian dishes, it has only recently become known in this country. The name derives from focus, Latin for hearth.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our outside cellar steps are covered by a Bilco metal door that opens upward and outward. We have painted this door about once every three years since it was installed, but it has now developed a hole that has become rusty near where the metal frame joins the house wall. This hole is about the size of a quarter. Is there a way to patch it?

title: John T. Brister, 38; Made Animated Films
description: John Tyler Brister, a filmmaker whose animated movies won awards at the Cannes Film Festival, died here Wednesday. He was 38 years old.

title: A Vegetarian Diet Is a Healthy One
description: My heart goes out to Tanya Allen, author of ''Your Children Are Calling to You for Help'' (Opinion page, May 21). Obviously she is in much pain and is writing on behalf of many of her peers.

title: Cuomo Delays His Call On Baseball's Origin Bill
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has been sent a bill that has renewed an old rhubarb between baseball fans in the Legislatures of New York and New Jersey.

title: Allegations Of Cheating Prompt Investigation
description: INVESTIGATORS for the Educational Testing Service are examining allegations that a private tutor in Scarsdale gave his Westchester high schoo students advance information about the College Board Biology Achievement Test they were to take last month.

title: 200 Ways To Look at 35 Years
description: To celebrate her 35th year as a fashion designer, Hanae Mori is staging a retrospective of her work at the Space, a theater in the Hanae Mori Building in Tokyo.

title: Malcolm Morris Is Wed in Maine T>o Miss Hudson
description: Meriwether Wright Hudson, the daughter of Fitzgerald S. Hudson of Charlotte, N.C., and Meriwether Wright Hudson of Durham, N.C., was married yesterday to James Lawrence Meredith Malcolm Morris, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James S. Morris of Woodcote Park, Midlothian, Scotland, and Philadelphia. The Rev. Paul E. Gilbert, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Mary's by-the-Sea in Northeast Harbor, Me.

title: INSIDE
description: From Pillar to Post in Japan The Japanese ruling party chose Sousuke Uno as Prime Minister to rescue it from a financial scandal. But a sex scandal involving Mr. Uno seems to have dragged the party to new depths of public mistrust. Page 12. Oil Spill Data Destroyed An Exxon computer operator said he had inadvertently destroyed electronic copies of documents about the oil spill in Alaska. A Federal court order requires the company to maintain all such copies. Page 14. The Politics of Secession Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, facing the latest twist in this political season, refused to say whether he would sign a bill allowing Staten Island residents to vote on whether to secede from New York City. Page 21. Cloud on a Sunny Horizon Officials say President Bush faces decisions that could put his popularity to a severe test. Page 17.

title:
PASTIMES: Gardening;
Keeping House Plants Happy While You Are Away
description: LEAD: While you are on vacation, traipsing up hill and down dale, will you fret about what will happen to all those luxuriant house plants that you have been pampering throughout the year?

title: Naming Names for China
description: In his inaugural address Wednesday, China's new party secretary, Jiang Zemin, tried to reassure his listeners that the Chinese Government has no intention of persecuting intellectuals because of their past expression of reformist views. But some Chinese intellectuals know better:

title: Let the Rich Help Fund Catastrophic Insurance
description: To the Editor:

title: Turning Off Niagara Falls
description: THE time may have come to consider turning off Niagara Falls and using the resulting additional energy to supplement the electrical needs of the Northeast, especially on Long Island.

title: Bryant's Homer Lifts Kintetsu
description: Ralph Bryant, formerly of the Los Angeles Dodgers, hit a two-run homer in the eighth inning today to lead the Kintetsu Buffaloes to a 5-3 Japanese baseball victory over the Fukuoka Daiei Hawks. The homer was Bryant's 19th of the season.

title: 20 Years, and 50 Miles, Down the Road
description: THE AMBIANCE IN THE TINKER STREET CAFE ON A spring evening is peaceful. Two men in their early 40's, graying ponytails hanging past their shoulders, sip martinis. Construction workers hoist beers, a miniskirted girl reads a book. Neighborhood dogs drift in and out.

title: The Cult Dons the Armor of Heavy Metal
description: The successes and failures of the Cult say a lot about the current state of heavy metal as it begins to absorb other musics. Along with comic books and horror films - from which many bands take their names and themes - heavy metal belongs to what the science fiction writer Clive Barker calls the literature of the fantastic. Heavy metal, extranormal in both volume and imagery, finds liberation in its own extranormality.

title: The Message for China
description: There are valid grounds for debate on how far the United States and allies should go in response to China's brutal new policy of repression. Sheer indignation is natural, but emotion alone is a poor base for complex international decisions.

title: THE CALLING OF YUSSEL FETNER
description: LEAD: GOD'S EAR By Rhoda Lerman. 309 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $19.95.

title: Publisher of Playboy Marries 26-Year-Old Playmate of Year
description: Hugh Hefner, the publisher of Playboy magazine, married Kimberley Conrad, the publication's playmate of the year for 1988, in a ceremony today at the Playboy mansion.

title: THE IMPORTANCE OF BEING OPRAH
description: Barbara Grizzuti Harrison's article ''The Importance of Being Oprah'' (June 11) was a bit harsh in its portrayal of Ms. Winfrey as a self-ordained New Age guru for the talk-show masses. If Ms. Winfrey toots her own horn - if she feels compelled to evangelize about her ''path'' - it is understandable, given her triumph over a hellish childhood. Surely, she is as entitled as anyone else in the communications media to peddle her sometimes contradictory philosophies to those who wish to accept them. Ms. Harrison herself frequently writes for the sort of women's magazines that provide ''strategies'' for bagging everything from a hunky husband to a dream job while simultaneously paying lip service to feminism. CAROL L. SKOLNICK Kew Gardens, Queens

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Dartmouth; Riddle Is Solved: Sphinx Is Culprit In Scavenger Hunt
description: The riddle of the Sphinx (Society) has been solved and the Dartmouth campus has breathed a sigh of relief. The solution led to the punishment of a secret undergraduate senior society and 16 of its members.

title: EXILES ON THE UPPER WEST SIDE
description: FRAGMENTS OF STAINED GLASS By Claire Nicolas White. 230 pp. San Francisco: Mercury House. $18.95.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE POWER OF ONE. By Bryce Courtenay. (Random House, $18.95.) Here is a brash and burly first novel from Bryce Courtenay, one of Australia's premier advertising men, a gentleman who writes as if he's well schooled in the popular reading tastes of the American public. His venue, however, is the South Africa of World War II and the years shortly thereafter, the era when that melting-pot colony was in the process of becoming a racist rampart.

title: Math Solves Biological Puzzles
description: LEAD: IT might seem improbable that mathematical formulas could explain how the body functions or what causes a brown tide, but researchers in biology and medicine are working increasingly with mathematicians to explain these questions.

title: Tennis Court Appeal: Ground the Grunters
description: Anyone who has watched the 15-year-old Yugoslav tennis star, Monica Seles, in her French Open match against Steffi Graf or during this past week at Wimbledon, must have been filled with admiration for the youngster. At the same time, I cannot see how anyone could help but be annoyed at the grunts - more like piercing shrieks - that she emitted every single time she hit a shot.

title: France to Sell Parts to Libya In Effort to Influence Qaddafi
description: Seeking to encourage Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya to steer a less radical course, France has authorized a limited sale of military spare parts to the North African nation, according to officials and diplomats.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Howell $299,900 167 Lanes Mill Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 25-year-old colonial; dining room, den, 8.5-acre lot; taxes $2,440. Lakewood $88,000 4A Poppy Court 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 10-year-old town-house condo; c/a, 1-car garage, monthly maintenance $96; taxes $1,545. Manchester Township $285,000 7-C Hemlock Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 18-year-old co-op apartment; h/w floors, 2-car garage, monthly maintenance $150; taxes $1,579. Neptune Township $142,000 706 Wakefield Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 30-year-old ranch; deck, family room, fireplace; taxes $2,352. Oakland $190,000 47 Oneida Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old ranch; full basement, w/w carpeting, recently redecorated; taxes $2,519. Ocean Grove $115,000 117 Asbury Avenue 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 20-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in-kitchen, h/w floors; taxes $1,500. OTHER AREAS Southport, Conn. $290,000 208 Wakeman Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 1733 colonial; 4 fireplaces, attic with bedroom, 110- by 114-foot lot; taxes $2,295. New Rochelle, N.Y. $362,000 84 Maywood Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 61-year-old Tudor; fireplace, bar, playroom, eat-in kitchen, patio, 2-car garage; taxes $4,127. Amityville, L.I. $152,000 12 Lombardi Place 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; finished basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,600.

title: Sudanese Coup Leader Offers Vote on Islamic Law
description: A day after seizing power, Sudanese Army officers pledged today to end the country's six-year civil war and offered a referendum on the future of Islamic law, the central issue driving the conflict.

title: Otis's '29 Stories Full of What-Ifs'
description: Clunk. Rrrrrr. Clunk. Rrrrr.

title: Rachel Crespin: Shearling-Coat Maker
description: Five years ago Rachel Crespin discovered Turkey. She returned from a trip there with a shearling coat that her friends admired. They sent her to designers like Calvin Klein and Donna Karan, who also admired the style.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE MEXICANS: A Personal Portrait of a People. By Patrick Oster. (Morrow, $19.95.) Arguing that ''we must deal with [Mexicans] on the basis of who they are,'' Patrick Oster, the former chief of the Mexico City bureau for the Knight-Ridder newspapers, introduces readers to the people tourists do not meet ''during a week's vacation in Acapulco.

title: As Tanglewood Goes, So Go the Berkshires
description: An article on page 29 of the Arts and Leisure section today about Tanglewood gives an incorrect date for the opening concert by the Boston Symphony. It will be Friday; it was not last weekend.

title: Buttercup, Incarnation of Evil
