description: LEAD: At long last, the great American lawn is having to take its lumps. And people who have been wasting the best outdoor hours of the year cutting and coddling grass that would much rather be left alone can feel free to let it grow as it wants to.

title: Prateeksha Misra Wed in Scarsdale
description: The marriage of Prateeksha Misra, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Shashi Kant Misra of New Delhi, and Andre Dhawan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Chandra Kant Dhawan of New Delhi, took place yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. C. K. Sharma in Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Donald Wood officiated at a Roman Catholic ceremony, followed by a Hindu ceremony performed by Anand Mohan, a professor of political science at Queens College.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: HOUSE OF CARDS. By Conall Ryan. (Knopf, $18.95.) This may be the only book ever to recommend poker as a means of building character. The central figure, Martin Oakes, is a professional gambler, making his living removing Jaguars, home furnishings and a great deal of cash from acquaintances. But Oakes has a sideline that would astonish most of the boys out in

title: Little Rock School Integration Hits New Roadblock
description: A legislative snag coupled with a judicial order has derailed an agreement intended to end three decades of litigation and turmoil in desegregating schools here.

title: Butterscotch on Snow
description: To the Editor:

title: Readers Worthy of the Books They're Reading
description: Time was when a handful of companies were the custodians of the spoken word on recordings. Today, in addition to a few independent outfits such as Spoken Arts, Listening Library and Listen for Pleasure, many a major publishing house - Random House, Simon & Schuster, Bantam Books and Harper & Row among them - has its own audio book division, and the catalogue of books now available on cassettes runs to about a thousand pages.

title: Conflicting Accounts Emerge of Suspect's Death
description: Widely varying accounts are emerging of the death of Daniel Mirambeaux, a 42-year-old Dominican who died mysteriously Thursday night in Santo Domingo minutes after being told he would be extradited to New York City to face charges that he killed a police officer.

title: NONFICTION
description: DON BAYLOR. Nothing but the Truth: A Baseball Life. By Don Baylor with Claire Smith. (St. Martin's, $18.95.) Don Baylor's book on his life in baseball is rare in its genre. It covers the usual trip from the bush leagues to victory and defeat in the big leagues and retirement. But happily Mr. Baylor, collaborating with Claire Smith, a baseball columnist for The Hartford Courant, tells his story calmly, without hyperventilating, without trying to create a sensation with some nasty revelation about a teammate or a manager. And there is a blessed and refreshing lack of the scatological dialogue that spatters the pages of many books by sports heroes. But why bother to read one more book by a good, even very good, but not great athlete like Don Baylor? Well, if you pick it up and give it a chance, the story of a man working hard at baseball just carries you along, like an ordinary baseball game played well on a warm Saturday afternoon in the middle of the season. Don Baylor is the only player to play in three consecutive World Series for three different teams (the Red Sox in 1986, then the Minnesota Twins and the Oakland A's). He grew up in a black ghetto in Austin, Tex. While racism among fans is muted in the majors, Mr. Baylor was bothered by it in the 1960's while playing in minor-league towns like Marion, Va., and Wytheville, Tenn., where ''a beer-bellied hillbilly . . . called me everything but a nigger.'' He played three seasons for the Yankees, respected but did not like Billy Martin, remembers that Graig Nettles was called Puff because he disappeared so fast after a game, avoiding his teammates and reporters. And the best manager he ever had, he says, was Earl Weaver of the Baltimore Orioles.

title: The Northwest's Sweet Bounty of Cherries
description: THE high meadows of the Cascade Mountains give up their snow in mid-June, when torrents of runoff pour down from the peaks of Washington and Oregon. On the eastern side of these mountains, a near desert with less than 10 inches of rain a year, the icy snow melt is directed into orchards of cherries, apples, peaches and pears as well as vineyards of grapes.

title: The ABC's of Burying a Nuclear Plant
description: IF a big question about the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station was answered last week, with the vote by the shareholders of the Long Island Lighting Company to sell it for $1 in exchange for rate increases, a thousand smaller questions remain.

title: David Dale Wed To Mary Toepfer
description: Mary Elvera Toepfer, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Kenneth H. Toepfer of Leonia, N.J., and El Maadi, Egypt, was married yesterday at the United Methodist Church in Leonia to David John Dale, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James P. Dale of Wirral, England. The Rev. Curt Garrett officiated.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Now, $1 Million-Plus Greenwich Condos
description: THE advent of the Greenwich condominium priced at $1 million or more was marked last month with the sale of the first units in Waterford, a 24-unit complex overlooking Cos Cob Harbor.

title: Congress Gives African Leaders the Human Rights Test
description: THE issue of human rights was high on the agenda at meetings last week between President Bush and President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire. Mr. Mobutu rejects criticism of his rights record as interference, and he asserted last week that human rights conditions in his impoverished country had improved substantially. But members of Congress, led by Representative Ronald V. Dellums, the chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus, have not allowed Mr. Mobutu to brush aside the criticism.

title: Bonn Halts China Aid And Pulls Out Advisers
description: West Germany has frozen more than $110 million in development aid to China because of the ''bloody events'' there.

title: Cubs Beat Reuschel
description: Greg Maddux held San Francisco to two runs in seven and two-thirds innings today and added two singles and the game-winning run batted in to lead the Chicago Cubs past Rick Reuschel and the Giants, 3-2.

title: THE NEW HISTORIANS RECAPTURE THE FLAG
description: A century ago, some Americans celebrated the Fourth of July with gestures more controversial than the lighting of Roman candles. In Denver and San Francisco, radical unionists issued fierce ''declarations of independence'' from monopoly and the two-party system. In Worcester, Mass., working-class men - many of them recent immigrants - thronged downtown streets, passing around strong drink and harassing more privileged citizens with drums and firecrackers. One group of these workers even built a cannon and fired it outside the house of their factory's superintendent.

title: Lynn Davis Weds Steven Quamme
description: Lynn Ashley Davis, a daughter of Robert D. Davis of Ponte Vedra, Fla., and the late Carole Weatherly Davis, was married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Ponte Vedra to Steven Jerome Quamme, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack O. Quamme of Kettering, Ohio. The Episcopal Bishop of Florida, Frank S. Cerveny, and the Rev. James H. Cooper, the pastor of the church, officiated.

title: Ann Reynolds Weds Robert deButts Jr.
description: Ann Elizabeth Reynolds, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Telfer B. Reynolds of Los Angeles, was married yesterday at her parents' home to Robert Edward Lee deButts Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. deButts of Norfolk and Upperville, Va. Judge Robert W. Armstrong of Superior Court of Los Angeles County officiated.

title: PASTIMES: Numismatics
description: This Fourth of July weekend is an appropriate time to look at one of America's first coins - a coin imprinted with some of the Revolutionary slogans current that first Independence day.

title: Respect Young Animals When Feeding Children
description: I surely don't fault Moira Hodgson for wanting to give her baby the best (''Some Recipes That Keep Baby in Mind,'' May 28. But what I do find disturbing is that she recommends veal, of all things, as an alternative to the bland fare babies usually have to put up with. Doesn't she see the paradox? Doesn't she realize that by urging readers to feed their babies veal, she is ignoring the terrible cruelty inflicted on the infants of another species?

title: The Medium: Music; The Message: Charity, And the Purpose: Fun
description: It was jazz week. Billy Taylor, the pianist, was honored at the JVC Jazz Festival concert at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday, and afterward, at a supper-dance at the Equitable Center, a benefit for the Jazzmobile, which Mr. Taylor founded 25 years ago.

title: A Visitor's Sorrow and Pity Yield a Memorial
description: When Stephen Draisin, a lawyer from New Jersey, visited the site of a concentration camp in eastern France, he was shocked that there was no marker to commemorate the 87 Jews who were put to death there.

title: Secret Lair of the Jedi, the Grail and Green Slimers
description: Call it just another one of their little tricks.

title: Adventure Blossoms On First Day of Camp
description: For 4-year old Allison Kessler, last Monday was a special day, her first at summer camp. Up and ready early, she waited with her grandmother, Ruth Cozzons, outside her New Caneen home for the bus to Camp Playland.

title: Sullivan on Sidelines
description: While the rest of the drivers prepared for today's Cleveland Grand Prix, Danny Sullivan was sitting at home in Media, Pa., yesterday.

title: AT MOTHER CONFESSOR'S BOOKSTORE
description: THE EDUCATION OF HARRIET HATFIELD By May Sarton. 320 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $18.95.

title: No Headline
description: LEAD: On Staten Island, More Doubts Than Joy

title: A PACKET OF UNOPENED LETTERS
description: LEAD: THE WAITING ROOM By Mary Morris. 273 pp. New York: Doubleday. $17.95.

title: Soviet Players Sign
description: The Calgary Flames and the Vancouver Canucks of the National Hockey League announced in Moscow yesterday the signings of two Soviet teammates from the Central Red Army team. Sergei Makarov, 31 years old, will play for Calgary, and Igor Larionov, 29, signed with Vancouver. Both will be in the lineups this season.

title: Improved Gear Is the Fair Game
description: Almost any fair, even a high-tech event like the Consumer Electronics Show last month in Chicago, has the aura of a carnival. There were the buntings and the lights, the milling crowds and the cheerful raffishness that goes with any kind of hawking and huckstering, even when it's done quietly in three-piece suits.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: SEAPORT AMUSEMENTS

title: Question Of the Week; Are the New Tennis Players Exciting?
description: As the father of a nationally ranked 14-year-old boy, I am greatly surprised and somewhat appalled by the new crop of teen players (Chang, Agassi, Courier, Sanchez, Sabatini, Fernandez, Seles, et al.) who unaggressively hang around the baseline and have what I call ''net fret.''

title: David Kleiser and Jana Strauss Wed
description: Jana Strauss, the daughter of Joanne Strauss of Galveston, Tex., and Henry J. Strauss of Wimberly, Tex., was married yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University to David Ewing Kleiser, a son of Dr. and Mrs. John R. Kleiser of Rosemont, Pa., and Haleiwa, Hawaii. The Rev. Dr. Ted Sturm, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Lawyer Suspended For Having Clients Pose Nude as His Fee
description: A lawyer has been suspended from practicing law for a year by the State Supreme Court because he told three women who were clients that he would not charge for his work in their divorce cases if they would pose for him nude or in lingerie.

title: Shriver Upset By Magers
description: Martina Navratilova, who says she has recaptured her lost affection for tennis over the last two months just in time for Wimbledon, today cruised into a fourth-round meeting with Hana Mandlikova. But Navratilova's doubles partner, Pam Shriver, who has also doubted her devotion to the game, faltered and was beaten, 6-2, 2-6, 12-10, by the little-known Gretchen Magers.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: MAKE-BELIEVE BALLROOMS. By Peter J. Smith. (Atlantic Monthly, $18.95.) At first it threatens to be a ''Bright Lights, Big City'' clone, but when Peter J. Smith's second novel moves beyond its artist protagonist's failed relationship and his disastrous gallery opening, it treads darkly humorous turf that's worthy of the author's sinewy prose.

title: Correction
description: The Practical Traveler column on June 18 erroneously included the American Association of Retired Persons as a source of traveler's checks sold without a fee. The association does not sell traveler's checks.

title: STREETSCAPES: The Knickerbocker Laundry; A Cloudy Future for an Art Moderne Clean Machine By CHRISTOPHER GRAY
description: THE Art Moderne Knickerbocker Laundry near the Sunnyside railyards in Queens has been vacant for three years, its 1932 streamline design competing with huge banners advertising that it is available for occupancy. Its future will probably be decided this summer, and thousands of Long Island Rail Road commuters who pass it daily will see either its facade reused in a new shopping center or its demolition.

title: Japan's Uno Reeling From One Crisis to Another
description: After a debilitating year of scandals, Prime Minister Sousuke Uno and his associates knew that they faced an uphill struggle this summer in trying to salvage the reputation of the governing Liberal Democratic Party in the eyes of a sullen electorate.

title: Note on Lodgings 'Over the Store'
description: ''Revitalizing a Fading Tradition: Living Over the Store'' [ June 4 ] , about the Westchester County photographic exhibition, highlighted many of the important issues involving the pros and cons of residential uses of spaces above commercial buildings.

title: A Great 'Great Expectations' Haunts a TV Version
description: Outside the mist-shrouded manor house, where a crumbling wedding cake and cobwebs symbolize time's passage, Jean Simmons, the actress who played the young, beguiling Estella in ''Great Expectations'' more than 40 years ago, talked of portraying the reclusive, embittered Miss Havisham in the latest adaptation of the Charles Dickens novel. Among numerous memorable performances by Martita Hunt, the British character actress who died in 1969, was her finely etched portrayal of Miss Havisham in the 1946 film of ''Great Expectations,'' directed by David Lean.

title: In Southeast Asia, Japan Dominates In Aid, Trade and Old Resentments
description: THIS week Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d is attending a conference of 19 countries and 11 institutions willing to give aid to prop up democracy in the Philippines. It is only fitting that the conference will be in Tokyo. The importance of Japanese aid and trade to the non-Communist countries of Southeast Asia would be difficult to exaggerate. At the same time, it is hard to pretend that such dependency does not cause severe resentments.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''It's another disaster of late capitalism with all these plastic dinosaurs bashing against one another in the primeval swamp.'' Robert Hughes, Time magazine art critic, on Time Inc.'s battle with Paramount.

title: Those Tailgate Terrorists
description: THERE is a new kind of terrorism that needs to be addressed - the kind that is happening on our roads. These terrorists are not bomb throwers or killers with automatic weapons; they are young people in what can only be described as powerful racing machines called automobiles.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: COLCHESTER, VT.;
Mixed Uses for A Hilltop Site
description: LEAD: CONSTRUCTION has begun on a three-story, 65,000-square-foot office building here, the first element in a mixed office-hotel-retail development planned for a 100-acre hilltop site.

title: Jaruzelski Move Doesn't Move Solidarity
description: The Solidarity movement said today that Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski's decision not to be a candidate for president had not altered its decision to stay out of the race.

title: Bush Policy Makers Reach Uneasy Balance on an Approach to the Soviets
description: Midway through the meeting in May between Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, the Soviet leader suddenly glanced across a gilded Kremlin chamber to Robert M. Gates, the deputy national security adviser. Smiling, but with a steely edge in his voice, Mr. Gorbachev said he had heard that the Bush White House had a special unit assigned to discredit him. He also said he had heard who was in charge of that unit: Mr. Gates.

title: Candlewood Stages a Revival of 'Camelot'
description: ''CAMELOT'' is not the best musical in history, and it is not the shortest one, either. Heaven knows, it has its lulls. Yet, one would be hard-pressed to come up with a musical that evokes such moving, deeply felt associations to an era, even from people who have never seen it.

title: Carla Paganelli Marries John Ruffner
description: Carla Elizabeth Paganelli, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Paganelli of Dallas, and John Montgomery Ruffner, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Ruffner of New Canaan, Conn., were married yesterday at the Community Church in Pound Ridge, N.Y., by the Rev. Dr. Richard S. Monkman, a Methodist minister.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Interrupting Is My Job

title: Why the Ban on Ben Johnson Should Stand
description: To the Editor:

title: World Beat Music Struggles With An Identity Crisis
description: Last Sunday at Avery Fisher Hall, Arrow, from Montserrat, paused during his set of pan-Caribbean dance music to announce, proudly, that ''this next song went to No. 26 on the Billboard charts.'' ''So what?'' an American audience member yelled.

title: Suit Attacks Off-Campus Arrests by B.Y.U. Police
description: The right of the security police of a religiously affiliated university to enforce state laws beyond its campus is being challenged in court by the American Civil Liberties Union.

title: A CORRECTION
description: The Streetscapes article on June 25 misidentified the second of three wives of the late Edward Durrell Stone. She is Maria Stone, who owns the town house at 130 East 64th Street and is the mother of Hicks Stone. Violet Campbell Stone is Edward Durrell Stone's widow.

title: Peace and Profits
description: To the Editor:

title: THE IMPORTANCE OF BEING OPRAH
description: It is hard to imagine a more demeaning sight than Oprah Winfrey's staff scrambling to gather their gifts within the time limit she gives them. It certainly caters to the most visible human failing, greed.

title: Elizabeth Morehouse Weds
description: Elizabeth Curtis Morehouse, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Curtis B. Morehouse of Rumson, N.J., was married there yesterday at St. George's by-the-River Episcopal Church to Lieut. Kenneth Rohn Ebner Jr., U.S.A., the son of Dr. and Mrs. Ebner of Rumson. The Rev. George J. Willis Jr. officiated. Mrs. Ebner, who graduated in May from Rutgers University, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, is to begin biochemistry studies at Texas A & M University in September. The bridegroom, a graduate of Monmouth College, is an engineering officer with the 17th Engineer Battalion in Fort Hood, Tex.

title: The Stars and Stripes: How Sacred a Symbol?; Frietchie Fiction
description: To the Editor:

title: A Regal Island Of Yachts and Poets
description: QUEEN VICTORIA started it all, of course, when she took up summer residence at Osborne House near Cowes in 1846. Soon after that, the diamond-shaped Isle of Wight, guardian of the southern ports of Portsmouth and Southampton and largely the domain of farmers and fishermen, became fashionable as a watering spot for the Victorian middle class - and others. One of the others was Karl Marx who proclaimed it ''a little paradise.''

title: The Ultimate In Folly
description: To the Editor:

title: Can It Be? Nice People, and a Way to Meet Them?
description: Sheila Owens was close to about a dozen of her co-workers at a Boston travel concern. She organized the company's softball team, Christmas parties and ski trips. Then one by one, her colleagues moved, changed jobs or quit to raise families.

title: WHAT IS TOO OLD?
description: As a nurse on a cardiac unit, I have seen many 80-to-100-year-old patients receive pacemakers and other high-tech medical procedures. Many of these patients want everything possible done to prolong their lives; others refuse the procedures.

title: Female Gamblers Share Their Pain
description: LEAD: A GROUP of women who are compulsive gamblers, all members of Gamblers Anonymous, have begun meeting separately from male members because they say they feel more stigmatized and have different issues to discuss than the men do. The women say that separating themselves would make recovery easier.

title: Envoy in Tunis Has Met Many Top P.L.O. Leaders, Bush Aides Say
description: The United States Ambassador to Tunis has held informal discussions with virtually all of the top leaders of the Palestine Liberation Organization, not just the second-in-command, Saleh Khalef, Administration officials say.

title: POSTINGS: Sonny Mae Loans;
description: New York State released another batch of low-interest mortgage money last Friday, this time $11 million for 30-year loans at a fixed rate of only 5 percent. The money is expected to provide mortgages to 200 qualified low- and moderate-income families who are buying their first house or apartment. The funds are issued by the State of New York Mortgage Agency, known as Sonny Mae, which has provided about $2.5 billion in low-interest mortgages to some 60,000 families since it was created in 1970.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: HAPPY HOLIDAY

title: POSTINGS: A View of the Sound; Costly Condos Replace Connecticut School
description: The site of a private girls' school in Rowayton, Conn., on Long Island Sound, is being developed into 20 expensive residential condominiums by the heirs of the school's founder. The eight-acre property in Fairfield County, the former Thomas School for Girls, was purchased in 1874 by the Rev. William Harrison Thomas whose daughter, Mabel, founded the school in 1922. When the school closed in 1980, Miss Thomas's three heirs decided to slowly develop the property, which has a large stone and timber schoolhouse and five other buildings on Wilson Cove on the Sound.

title: 'Every Organization Needs Tinkerers'
description: According to Abraham Zaleznik, the Konosuke Matsushita professor of leadership at the Harvard Business School, companies are becoming increasingly political and bureaucratic. In this environment, talent is submerged and leaders are replaced by people adept at conciliation. Direct communication, creative dialogue and honest confrontation are replaced by manipulation. As a result, the creativity of the organization is diminished, people lose their zest for work and valuable talents go unexploited.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Dwellings Proliferate in Newark's Ironbound
description: LEAD: NO neighborhood in Newark is more densely populated than the Ironbound, a 2.5-square-mile wedge east of the Pennsylvania Railroad Station. The area is bounded by railroad tracks on the south and west -hence the name - and by the Passaic River on the north and the New Jersey Turnpike and Route 1-9 on the east.

title: A SPRAY OF SPARKS ERUPTS TO MUSIC - WITH THE AID OF ELECTRONICS
description: New technologies are taking some of the quesswork out of fireworks exhibition, making displays fancier and more dramatic. Rather than setting off aerial shells haphazardly during the shows, some exhibiters are now using computers to map out the programs beforehand and to set the affair to music - making sure that the chrysanthemums blossom in the sky at the crescendo.

title: Susan E. Berner to Wed Mark Wenger
description: Prof. and Mrs. Robert A. Berner of North Haven, Conn., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter, Susan Elizabeth Berner, and Second Lieut. Mark Franklin Wenger, U.S.A.F., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Wenger of Stevens Point, Wis.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Amityville $152,000 12 Lombardi Place 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; finished basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,600. Bay Shore $725,000 39 Lawrence Lane 7-bedroom, 6 1/2-bath, 60-year-old waterfront Tudor; guest cottage, 3-car garage, 1.9 acres; taxes $10,900. Bayport $216,000 380 Middle Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 105-year-old Victorian; fireplace, porch, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,500. Commack $180,000 23 Cedarwood Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 26-year-old ranch; basement, den with fireplace, 1-car garage; taxes $3,400. East Islip $191,000 43 East Madison Street 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 2-year-old high ranch; dining room, den, 2-car garage; taxes $4,450. Westbury $265,000 27 Marietta Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 17-year-old colonial; fireplace, den, finished basement; taxes $6,800. OTHER AREAS Southport, Conn. $290,000 208 Wakeman Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 1733 colonial; 4 fireplaces, attic with bedroom; taxes $2,295. New Rochelle, N.Y. $362,000 84 Maywood Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 61-year-old Tudor; fireplace, bar, playroom, patio, 2-car garage; taxes $4,127. Oakland, N.J. $190,000 47 Oneida Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old ranch; full basement, w/w carpeting, recently redecorated; taxes $2,519.

title: Gorbachev Warns on Ethnic Unrest
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev used a rare televised address tonight to warn that a chain reaction of ethnic conflict threatens to tear the country apart and stifle economic and political change.

title: 5 Tolls on Hudson Rise Today
description: Tolls will rise by 50 percent on the five Hudson River bridges operated by the New York State Bridge Authority in the first toll increase in the authority's 57-year history. Tolls for passenger cars and light trucks increase to 75 cents from 50 cents, and for two-axle heavy duty trucks to $1.50 from $1. Increases for heavier vehicles average about 50 percent.

title: The Stars and Stripes: How Sacred a Symbol?; America in a Free Fall
description: To the Editor:

title: A Support for Students Who Grieve for China
description: LEAD: WHEN Vera Schwarcz, a professor of Chinese history at Wesleyan, returned from her most recent trip to Beijing, she planned to resume work on two books she is writing. That was on May 23. On June 4, Chinese troops stormed the center of Beijing, repeatedly clashing with pro-democracy demonstrators and firing on the crowds with their submachine guns.

title: SNUFFING OUT BOOTLEGGERS AND INJURIES
description: In a report issued last week, the Consumer Product Safety Commission warned that 10,000 people - many of them children - are expected to be injured in fireworks-related accidents this year.

title: East European Pollution Pact
description: Poland, Czechoslovakia and East Germany today signed a pact on combatting cross-border pollution, the official Polish press agency reported. It said the agreement, sought by Poland for several years, set out plans for cooperation among the three nations, particularly on air and water contamination.

title: Civil Rights Act Leaves Deep Mark On the American Political Landscape
description: While its aim was to tear down the barriers of race in housing, employment and trade, the Civil Rights Act of 1964, signed into law 25 years ago today, profoundly altered the nation's political life as well.

title: Roi Danzig First in Dwyer
description: The 3-year-old picture beyond Easy Goer and Sunday Silence took an unexpected turn yesterday at Belmont Park when Roi Danzig led all the way to win the $222,800 Dwyer Stakes while Is It True and Fast Play trailed as the heavy favorites.

title: Mrs. Vecsey Has Bridal
description: Jeanne-Marie Vecsey and Richard Sutro Rothschild were married yesterday at the Rye (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church by the Rev. David L. Uhl. The bride is the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Helmuth C. Kranich of New York. Her husband is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Hans S. Rothschild of Greenwich, Conn.

title: From Sound Stage To Strong, Silent Museum
description: First it was the International Design Center, now it is the American Museum of the Moving Image. The architects Charles Gwathmey and Robert Siegel seem to have cornered the market in making old industrial structures in Queens into significant new public buildings. Like the International Design Center, a vast complex of furniture and design showrooms housed in a pair of old factory buildings in Long Island City, the American Museum of the Moving Image has an importance that goes far beyond Queens, and beyond New York City as well. These buildings stand as testaments to the remarkable potential that lies in the industrial buildings of half a century or more ago. And both show us a dimension to Mr. Gwathmey and Mr. Siegel's architecture that is barely hinted at by their better-known work, elaborate and pristine modernist houses and apartments for clients like Steven Spielberg and Faye Dunaway.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; What Should Happen To Rose?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Westwood One's Comeback Bid
description: Norman J. Pattiz has ridden the radio dial up and then down in quick order, building the Westwood One Companies into the nation's second-largest radio company in just four years and then watching earnings plunge when advertising turned soft in 1988. Now, bolstered by surging ratings at his most important operations, Mr. Pattiz seems to be heading up again, testament to his staying power and his skills as a savvy packager of radio time.

title:
GARDENING;
The Benefits of Catching Rainwater
description: LEAD: READERS often come up with important points that garden writers overlook. One reader noted that recent articles on water conservation failed to include collection and use of rainwater. This is certainly a good suggestion and also a reminder of times past when collecting rainwater was essential.

title: Prospects; Falling Indicators
description: Figures released last week by the Commerce Department showed a 1.2 percent decline in the economic index for May. This is the biggest fall in the last 18 months in the Government's chief economic forecasting measure. Few economists dispute that the index shows that the economy is slowing, but opinions are mixed on whether the numbers point to a recession. Four economists assess their significance. David Hale Chief economist, Kemper Financial Services Inc.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption on page 24 of the Arts and Leisure section today about ''Steel Magnolias'' misidentifies the actress at the left. She is Mary Fogarty.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Illinois; Hazing Incident Brings Lawsuit Against Fraternity
description: The victim of a fraternity hazing incident at the University of Illinois, saying the sanctions invoked by the university were inadequate, said last week that he planned to file a lawsuit naming his former fraternity brothers as defendants.

title: THE GREAT WAR AND RUSSIAN MEMORY
description: LEAD: AUGUST 1914 The Red Wheel/Knot I. By Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn. Translated by H. T. Willetts. 854 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. Cloth, $50. Paper, $19.95.

title: China Party's Birthday: Festivities in Minor Key
description: China today celebrated the 68th anniversary of the founding of its Communist Party with songs and dances, special television programs and even the reopening of some tourist sites and parks bordering Beijing's Tiananmen Square.

title: A Preview of Summerfare's Finale
description: ''FOR the first time, everything fits into place - now that it's over,'' Christopher Hunt said of the ''grand finale'' season of Pepsico's Summerfare, the festival's 10th and his fifth as director.

title: OUTLASTING THE GANG OF FOUR
description: TANYIN ALLEY By Liu Zongren. 313 pp. San Francisco: China Books & Periodicals. $17.95.

title: A Celebrity Returns, Undimmed
description: Playing the piano, if you will excuse the comparison, is something like bicycle riding. Once the basic skill is acquired, it is never quite lost. So, no one would have been surprised if Van Cliburn, after an 11-year retirement from public performance, had played acceptably if rustily in his recent return to action with the Philadelphia Orchestra. What did astonish one, however, was the seemingly undiminished technique that America's most celebrated native-born pianist brought to two virtuoso concertos, the Liszt No. l and the Tchaikovsky No. 1. It was as if, after more than a decade of riding his bike to and from the grocery store, a retired Olympic cyclist would enter the games again and carry off a gold medal.

title: It's Peak Season for County Restaurants
description: WITH the children in camp, Susan and Robert Broud of Rye go out to dinner at local restaurants at least twice a week. ''Going to restaurants in the summer is my mini-vacation,'' Mrs. Broud said. ''I love eating out.''

title: In the Trenches of the Chip Wars
description: Charlie Sporck and Jerry Sanders have been out there on the front lines as American computer chip companies have rallied to fight back against Japanese competition in recent years. As the respective presidents of the nation's fourth- and fifth-largest chip companies, the National Semiconductor Corporation and Advanced Micro Devices Inc., Mr. Sporck and Mr. Sanders worked to bring about the semiconductor trade agreement with Japan, the Sematech research consortium and the recently announced joint venture to produce memory chips, U. S. Memories Inc.

title: A CONSPIRACY SO MONSTROUS
description: THE CIRCUS MASTER'S MISSION By Joel Brinkley. 403 pp. New York: Random House. $18.95.

title: Tamar Michelle Epstein Weds Dr. Randall Kaye
description: Tamar Michelle Epstein, the daughter of Paul and Dr. Sue Epstein of Watchung, N.J., was married yesterday evening to Dr. Randall Earl Kaye, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan Kaye of Falmouth, Mass. Rabbi Joseph Gelberman officiated at the Headquarters Plaza Hotel in Morristown, N.J.

title: SPONSORS KEEP FIREWORKS FROM FADING
description: Corporations are starting to displace cities as the chief underwriters of public firework events. In search of fresh mediums to advertise their products and images - and ways to escape the clutter of traditional promotional venues - a growing number of companies are sponsoring fireworks events not only on Independence Day but at festivals throughout the year.

title: Summer Scenes
description: LEAD: THE Fourth of July. Independence indeed! How gracious of the cosmic calendar-makers to declare it for a Tuesday. For this is no mere three-day weekend created by statutory fiat. It is a weekend that of its own accord stretches almost into the middle of another week. Now, there is cause for celebration!

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE TWO DEATHS OF SENORA PUCCINI, by Stephen Dobyns. (Penguin, $7.95.) A rich surgeon in a fictional Latin American land tells the story of the woman he has tried to terrorize into loving him for 20 years. ''Mr. Dobyns skillfully examines the way desire can translate into a passion for control,'' Angeline Goreau said here in 1988. ''What makes this novel so memorable, however, is his powerful evocation of the ultimately corrupting influence of that control.'' NORA: A Biography of Nora Joyce, by Brenda Maddox. (Fawcett Columbine, $12.95.) Who could have guessed that when a young Irish chambermaid named Nora Barnacle eloped with an aspiring writer named James Joyce, it would be a mismatch made in heaven? Last year our reviewer, Edna O'Brien, said Brenda Maddox shows that Nora, the model for Molly Bloom, was an important inspiration. ''She brings us closer to Nora and reveals her not as the dormant (doormat, as Joyce might say) wife, but a vital, moody, outspoken young woman whose two greatest assets were her sexual assurance and her apparent unflappability.'' GIRL, 20, by Kingsley Amis. (Summit, $8.95.) A middle-aged British composer refuses to understand why he can't have everything he enjoyed when he was young: the excitement of left-wing political rallies and a girlfriend 17 years old. In 1972 our reviewer, R. V. Cassill, said the novel's cast of characters ''has been adroitly shaped to expose a sort of folie a deux in which youth and an aging misleader of youth contribute equally to the mischief.'' Summit has also reprinted ONE FAT ENGLISHMAN ($8.95), in which a gluttonous English publisher practices his lechery in the United States. ''Mr. Amis has a penetrating eye, a salty wit and the power of vivid portrayal,'' one reviewer said in 1964. BEING WITH CHILDREN, by Phillip Lopate. (Poseidon, $9.95.) A novelist and essayist tells about his experiences trying to teach writing to children on New York's Upper West Side. Phillip Lopate is ''a poet who sets out to tell us about his own experience only and ends by bringing us an affecting picture of modern urban life,'' Vivian Gornick said here in 1975. SUMMER'S LEASE, by John Mortimer. (Penguin, $7.95.) Uprooting themselves from London for a summer in Tuscany, the members of the Pargeter family find themselves caught in a number of scandals, sexual and otherwise. ''Mr. Mortimer had fun with 'Summer's Lease,' '' Ann Cornelisen said in The Book Review in 1988. ''His readers will too, whether they dream of a villa in Tuscany or a beach in the Hamptons.'' WHEN THE MIND HEARS: A History of the Deaf, by Harlan Lane. (Vintage, $15.95.) For hundreds of years, deaf people have tried to make the hearing understand that words need not be spoken - or even written - to qualify as language. ''The one true deafness, the incurable deafness, is that of the mind,'' as Victor Hugo once wrote. '' 'When the Mind Hears' reads like a suspense novel,'' Stella Chess said here in 1984. ''The villains are those, mostly hearing but a few deaf, who viewed those who had only signing skills as inferior in all ways, subhumans who were to be barred from associating with other deaf persons, prevented from marrying lest they have deaf sons and daughters, prohibited from having a language suited to their needs.'' THE HOUSE THAT JACK BUILT, by Ed McBain. (Mysterious Press, $3.95.) A salt-of-the-earth Indiana farmer named Ralph is outraged at his brother Jonathan's gay life style, complete with a beach house in the Florida Keys. But he insists that he did not kill him. ''It all adds up to an exceptionally fast-paced effort,'' John Gross said in The Times last year. THE RAGMAN'S SON: An Autobiography, by Kirk Douglas. (Pocket Books, $5.50.) Born to a family of illiterate Russian-Jewish immigrants in upstate New York, Issur Danielovitch moved to Manhattan, changed his name to Kirk Douglas and made 75 films. When his life story was published last year, our reviewer, Susan Stamberg, said that its strength and its weakness lie in the fact that he wrote it himself. ''It has the freshness and pell-mell quality of firsthand telling. But it lacks the deep analysis and introspection that a good ghostwriter might have pushed him toward.'' ROSIE, by Anne Lamott. (North Point, $8.95.) Not yet in her teens, Rosie finds herself caring for her widowed mother, who can't seem to do much of anything since her husband was killed in a car crash. Anne Lamott ''describes the mother-daughter bond with a sharp and graceful style,'' Diane Cole said here in 1984. MILENA: The Story of a Remarkable Friendship, by Margarete Buber-Neumann. Translated by Ralph Manheim. (Schocken, $8.95.) In 1940 the author was imprisoned in the Ravensbruck concentration camp with the Czechoslovak journalist Milena Jesenska, the woman to whom Franz Kafka wrote his passionate ''Letters to Milena.'' Last year our reviewer, James D. Bloom, called this account ''inspiring and sobering.'' WITHIN OUR REACH: Breaking the Cycle of Disadvantage, by Lisbeth B. Schorr with Daniel Schorr. (Anchor/Doubleday, $9.95.) When society finally disabuses itself of the myth that nothing works, ''we can mobilize the political will to reduce the number of children hurt by cruel beginnings,'' Lisbeth Schorr writes. In 1988 our reviewer, Richard R. Green, the Schools Chancellor who died this year, said the book ''presents a useful, progressive antidote to those overly pessimistic critics who insist that we are losing ground in the fight to provide quality educational and social welfare services to an underclass of economically and socially disadvantaged families.''

title: Susan Starr Walker Married in Paris To Andre Wyss, a Geology Professor
description: Susan Starr Walker, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Dodsley Walker of New York, and Andre Robert Wyss, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Wyss of Manhattan Beach, Calif., were married yesterday in Paris. The Very Rev. James Leo, the Dean of the American Cathedral, performed the Episcopal ceremony at the cathedral, where the bride's parents and her brother, Peter Hayes Walker, and his wife, Karen Moyer Walker, were also married.

title: Sarah E. Sinclair Marries a Banker
description: Sarah Ellen Sinclair, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph S. Sinclair of Providence and Narragansett, R.I., was married last evening at her parents' home in Narragansett to Peter Brett Scoliard, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis A. Scoliard of Providence and Narragansett. Rabbi Leslie Y. Gutterman performed the ceremony.

title: The Tenant-as-Landlord Movement
description: THE Cooper Square Committee, a feisty group of neighborhood advocates that first squared off against City Hall when Robert Moses tried to bulldoze blocks of tenement buildings in 1959, may seem an unlikely real estate developer.

title: Dancer to Dancer: First Encounters With Balanchine
description: Prominent among the piles of casting sheets, letters and sketches on the desk of Oleg Vinogradov, the director of the Kirov Ballet, are several dance books from the West. Russian dancers are hungry for information, and photographs, books, magazines and videotapes are highly prized and hard to come by. One recent rehearsal came to a standstill when a British dance book was produced, and all gathered around to identify their Western peers; yet, the dancers pictured were recognized only from other photographs, not from live experience.

title: Chinese Troupe a Circus Highlight
description: ''THE Big Apple Circus Meets the Monkey King'' is the title of this 12th edition of a circus that has become a regional touring treasure.

title: Cheney Seeks Change In Pentagon Procedure
description: Responding to pressure for better procurement managing, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney is proposing to overhaul top Pentagon committees to give a small group the power to make major decisions, a Bush Administration official said.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Green Leads by 3 Strokes: Tammie Green's two-under-par 70 in wet weather yesterday gave her a three-stroke lead after the third round of the $600,000 du Maurier Classic, the third of the four major tournaments on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour. The 29-year-old Green rebounded from a double-bogey on the 16th hole with a birdie on 17 and finished 54 holes over the 6,261-yard Beaconsfield Golf Club in Montreal at nine-under-par 216. She was three shots better than the first- and second-round leader, Betsy King; the 1983 champion, Hollis Stacy, Jane Geddes and Penny Hammel in the richest tournament on the L.P.G.A. tour. Hammel tied Nina Foust for the day's best round, with a 68. King, who began the day at eight under, bogeyed the 6th, 9th and 11th holes and finished with a two-over-par 74.(AP) Mize and McCumber Share Lead: Larry Mize and Mark McCumber capitalized on two late bogeys by Paul Azinger to move into a tie for the lead after yesterday's third round of the $1 million Western Open at Oak Brook, Ill. Mize, the 1987 Masters champion, shot a five-under-par 67 while McCumber, who needed an ice treatment on the 10th hole for his ailing back, had a 71. Both were tied at 10-under-par 206 after 54 holes over the Butler National course. Azinger, who led by a stroke after 16 holes, bogeyed the last 2 to finish at par 72 and was tied with Peter Jacobsen at 207.(AP) Auto Racing Allison Takes Daytona 400: Davey Allison, who took the lead when Mark Martin ran out of gas with five laps left, won the Daytona 400 yesterday for his first Winston Cup victory at Daytona International Speedway at Daytona Beach, Fla. Allison's Ford edged Morgan Shepherd's Pontiac by two car lengths. Phil Parsons finished third and Bill Elliott fourth. Allison's average speed was 132.207 miles an hour. There were 28 lead changes involving 11 drivers in the race, which had a purse of $686,667. Fourteen cars were on the lead lap at the finish, tying the record set in 1986.(AP) Tennis Garner Captures State Title: Chris Garner of Bay Shore, L.I., seeded No. 1, routed No. 2 John Schmitt Jr. of Brookville, L.I., 6-2, 6-1, yesterday to win the New York State clay-court championship at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens. Schmitt, son of a former Jets center, teamed with Gary Cuppernull of Huntington, L.I., to defeat Garner and Howard Endelmen of Roslyn, L.I., 2-6, 7-6, 6-4, in the doubles final. Carol Ann Watson of Jamaica Estates, Queens, upset top-seeded Christina Dragomiescu of Jackson Heights, Queens, 6-2, 6-2, in the women's final. Watson and Jemma Mozeak, also of Jamaica Estates, beat Rosalind and Michelle Chua of Centereach, L.I., 7-5, 3-6, 6-4, for the doubles title.(AP) Horse Show Raposa Wins Speed Stake: David Raposa of Clinton, N.Y., won the Adirondack Speed Stake yesterday with a fault-free ride in 57.189 seconds, capturing his first event in the 20th annual Lake Placid Horse Show. Raposa won by almost a second and a half from Barney Ward of Brewster, N.Y., who finished the 14-jump, 424-yard course in 58.602 seconds. Finishing third was the 1987 World Cup champion, Katharine Burdsall of North Salem, N.Y., in 58.733 seconds.(AP) Soccer Brazil and Paraguay Triumph: Brazil beat Venezuela, 3-1, and Paraguay routed Peru, 5-2, yesterday as the America Cup, South America's quadrennial soccer championship, opened. Adolfino Cannete scored two goals and Gustavo Neffa, Alfredo Mendoza and Jose del Solar scored one goal each for Paraguay. In the second game, Bebeto, Geovani and Baltazar scored for Brazil, which was missing five starters who play for European clubs. Today, the defending World Cup champion, Argentina, plays Ecuador and Uruguay plays Bolivia. The 10-nation tournament concludes July 16.(AP)

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Outing; On the North Fork of L.I., Quaint Waterfront Towns
description: There is a treasure of weekend pleasures here and in neighboring towns. More quaint than chic, and with a touch of New England flavor, the five towns that make up Southold - Laurel, Mattituck, Cutchogue, East Marion and Orient - are about a two-hour drive from Manhattan, and just 10 to 15 minutes from the Orient Point docks of the Cross Sound Ferry to New London, Conn.

title: Second New Hampshire Man Is Not Guilty in Arson Fires
description: A former volunteer firefighter was acquitted Friday of a series of arson fires that terrorized this community last summer.

title: Susan Waters to Marry Andrew Lese
description: Dr. and Mrs. Edward G. Waters Jr. of Little Silver, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan Elizabeth Waters to Andrew Shain Lese, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Lese of Rye, N.Y. A November wedding is planned.

title: Tracy Summerwill Wed
description: Tracy Ann Summerwill, a vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, and Robert Russell Hampton Jr., a vice president of J. P. Morgan Securities, both in New York, were married yesterday at the First Congregational Church in Harwich, Mass. The Rev. Charles T. Newberry and Msgr. John A. Goodwine officiated. The bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Russell Hampton, live in Katonah, N.Y. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Richard Summerwill of Iowa City. She graduated summa cum laude from the University of Michigan and received a master's degree in economics from the London School of Economics and Political Science. Mr. Hampton graduated from Colgate University.

title: DATABANK: July 2, 1989
DATA UPDATE: July 2, 1989
Kathryn Mastronardi Wed
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York, Kathryn Jane Mastronardi, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas D. Mastronardi of Mamaroneck, N.Y., was married yesterday to Mark Patrick Davis, a son of Marjorie G. Davis of Mahwah, N.J. Msgr. George F. Bardes officiated. Mrs. Davis, a social worker at the Family Conference Center in New York, graduated from Providence College, as did her husband. She received a master's degree from the Columbia University School of Social Work. Mr. Davis is a senior accountant for American Express Travel Related Services in New York.

title: Ballard Ends 2 Slumps as Orioles Beat Tigers
description: Jeff Ballard snapped two pitching slumps, his own and Baltimore's, by holding Detroit to five hits in seven and one-third innings, and Randy Milligan, Cal Ripken and Craig Worthington hit bases-empty home runs as the Orioles defeated the Tigers, 8-1, tonight.

title: Under Deng, Running China Has Become a Family Affair
description: When the Reagan Administration complained about China's sale of missiles to Iran and Saudi Arabia over the last two years, Chinese officials denied responsibility, saying the arms dealers were free-lancing, diplomats involved in the talks say.

title: Concern for Environment
description: Public support for greater environmental efforts regardless of cost has soared since the Exxon Valdez oil spill in Alaska, a New York Times Poll shows.

title: Jeannette Kelting Is Married in Italy
description: Jeannette Snare Kelting, a daughter of Mrs. Fred J. Keen of Tenafly, N.J., and Howard W. Kelting Jr. of New York and East Hampton, L.I., was married yesterday in Peccioli, Italy, to Francesco Sacchini, a son of Caruso Sacchini of Peccioli and the late Mrs. Sacchini. The Rev. Franco Giubbolini officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of San Verano.

title: Food; A Day for Old Glories
description: IMAGINE A TIDY CLAMBAKE. PICTURE EATING AN EAR OF sweet corn or a wedge of watermelon on wafer-thin china. Try timing a beurre blanc sauce for the arrival of guests from the city.

title: Piano Solos by Don Pullen
description: The pianist Don Pullen opened the second tune in his performance at Weill Recital Hall on Friday night with quiet, simple chords. Within a few bars, Mr. Pullen began contrasting overdriven, harmonically complex lines, played by his right hand, with straighforward harmonies produced by his left. Each line gained momentum and complexity, and the piece grew richer by the moment.

title: Cabby and Taxi Chief Clash
description: One New York City taxi driver may need a refresher course in dealing with people: The man he is accused of shoving is a city taxi commissioner.

title:
INVESTING;
Hunting for Values in Canadian Stocks
description: LEAD: Like the United States stock markets, Canadian exchanges have been enjoying a strong year. The Toronto Stock Exchange 300 index stood above 3,700 last week, up from a 52-week low of 2,976. Analysts say the market should continue climbing if Canada manages to avoid a recession, as many economists expect it will.

title: FICTION
description: WHITE BADGE. By Ahn Junghyo. (Soho, $19.95.) Han Kiju, an editor for a publishing company in Seoul, South Korea, is a psychologically crippled, impotent man still reeling from a youth misspent as a volunteer infantryman in the South Korean Army's White Horse Division, which fought beside American troops in Vietnam. An uncomfortable reunion with a veteran even more shellshocked than he results in an extended flashback that culminates in a tense, terrifying reconnaissance mission behind enemy lines. There Sergeant Han, who has rejected his war-torn native culture for Western ideals, discovers that the price of survival is the betrayal of human values. For him, the color of the badge worn by the White Horse division becomes the color of death, emptiness, extermination and purposeless annihilation. Of Americans, Sergeant Han says, ''I felt I was watching the fall of a swaggering idol, a boastful giant who had never learned how to live outside his own world.'' ''White Badge,'' which was translated by its author, the South Korean editor and novelist Ahn Junghyo, suffers from stilted dialogue, trite phrasing and an antihero whose lugubrious self-loathing tends to overwhelm the story. It also contains what have become the cliches of the Vietnam novel: a doomed love affair with a Vietnamese peasant girl, depictions of the reptilian cunning of the Vietcong and the neurotic behavior of some of the army's commanding officers. However, the awkward passages do not detract from the book's finale, which occurs years after the war has ended, when a coward who betrayed his fellow troops and injured Sergeant Han returns to beg him for death. The code of combat demands that Han take vengeance, but by the values of Westernized, modern South Korea, he must refuse. His impossible decision becomes the book's despairing end.

title: A New Phase Begins in Europe's Unification
description: THE European Community is a ponderous, plodding institutional elephant. Even when it makes momentous decisions, they are often dismissed as lofty aspirations or lowest-common-denominator fudges that put off hard choices until tomorrow. In 1985, for example, community leaders adopted the Single European Act, declaring that they intended to create a frontierless market by the end of 1992 and to strive for ''the progressive realization of economic and monetary union.'' Few realized at the time that the Single Act would prod the elephant into a gallop.

title: Miss Hart to Wed Thomas Clements
description: Carolyn Ayres Hart and Thomas Lightfoot Clements will be married later this month, the parents of the bride-to-be, Harry Hart of Canton, Mass., and Mrs. Leo Johnson of Framingham, Mass., have announced. Mr. Clements is a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Clements of Darien, Conn.

title: Question Of the Week; Are the New Tennis Players Exciting?
description: It is quite boring watching the monotonous motions of Graf and Lendl. The current crop of players seems pale and lifeless compared to Ilie Nastase, Jimmy Connors, Vitas Gerulaitis, Guillermo Vilas, and of course, Billie Jean King. KATHERINE M. NOWICKI Astoria, Queens

title: A Steakhouse That Prizes Continuity
description: FOR more than 50 years, Locust Valley's country club set has equated dining out with Caminari's. Then, last February, Mark Downey, Caminari's owner, changed the restaurant to M. Downey's Steakhouse.

title: In Albany, This Was the Year for Housing, but It Wasn't
description: ONCE again, tenants and landlords converged on Albany this spring, beseeching the Legislature to tackle housing issues that have been left unresolved for years. They sought an end to disputes over who should have succession rights to an apartment lease, and over how much landlords should be allowed to charge tenants for capital improvements. Perhaps most important, amid nearly universal demands that the state generate more affordable housing in New York City, the Legislature had left unsettled the destiny of thousands of Mitchell-Lama apartments built for moderate-income tenants. Many of those apartments have been converted to market-rate rentals or co-ops, generally putting them beyond the reach of the people for whom they were built.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Salem, Mass.;
107 Condos For the Aged
description: LEAD: A 107-UNIT condominium development, with a center for elderly owners providing such health maintenance services as dietary and nutritional advice and an exercise room, is nearing completion in this 363-year-old port city.

title: Poetry Reading
description: The poet Michelle M. Tokarczyk will read from her work at 7:30 P.M. Thursday at Judith's Room, 681 Washington Street, between West 10th and Charles Streets. Other free summer programs there are to feature Ruth W. Messinger, New York City Councilwoman, at 7:30 P.M. on July 27; Nadja Tesich, the novelist, at 6 P.M. on July 30, and Maud Farrell, the mystery writer, at 7 P.M. on Aug. 10. Information: 727-7330.

title: Afghan Groups Are Reported To Agree to Arafat Peace Plan
description: President Najibullah and several guerrilla groups fighting to overthrow his Government have agreed to a proposal by the P.L.O. leader, Yasir Arafat, aimed at ending the war, an Arafat envoy said today.

title: Mrs. MacShane Wed to Minister
description: At the Christ Church United Methodist Chapel in New York Virginia Lynn Fry MacShane, the librarian of the Town School in New York, and the Rev. Philip Arthur Cadman Clarke, the pastor of the Park Avenue United Methodist Church in New York, were married yesterday. The Rev. Thomas Falshaw, the bridegroom's stepfather, officiated. Mrs. Clarke, who is known as Lynn, is a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Duhme Fry of Cincinnati. She is a graduate of Vassar College and received a master's degree in library science at Columbia University.

title: A PASSION FOR THE MARQUIS
description: LAFAYETTE, HERO OF TWO WORLDS The Art and Pageantry of His Farewell Tour of America, 1824-1825. By Stanley J. Idzerda, Anne C. Loveland and Marc H. Miller. Illustrated. 203 pp. Hanover, N.H.: Queens Museum/University Press of New England. Paper, $24.95.

title: Stephen Naidoo, African Prelate, Dies at 51
description: Archbishop Stephen Naidoo, the Roman Catholic primate of Cape Town and one of South Africa's leading anti-apartheid campaigners, died today during a private visit to London, his office said. He was 51 years old.

title: Sports of The Times; Commemorating the Iron Horse's Iron Will
description: While baseball endures the Pete Rose headlines, it is commemorating one of its most sainted legends. Lou Gehrig will be remembered July 4 at Yankee Stadium on the 50th anniversary of his goodbye there. Stricken by the mysterious disease now named for him, he described himself that day in 1939 as ''the luckiest man on the face of this earth.'' Within two years, he was dead at age 37.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''They call me the crazy lady of Texas City because in Texas City when the air stinks they still think it's the smell of jobs and money.'' - Rita Carlson, an environmentalist in Galveston County, Tex. [ 18:2. ]

title: Question Of the Week; Are the New Tennis Players Exciting?
description: A father of two boys, I'm glad to see my sons imitating Michael Chang and Andre Agassi. With Chang and Agassi, I see Americans being in the top ranks of tennis for a long time to come. LEONARD JUSTIN Rego Park, Queens

title:
GARDENING;
The Benefits of Catching Rainwater
description: LEAD: READERS often come up with important points that garden writers overlook. One reader noted that recent articles on water conservation failed to include collection and use of rainwater. This is certainly a good suggestion and also a reminder of times past when collecting rainwater was essential.

title: Yugoslavia's Land of 16 Lakes
description: THIS is a country of sprained ankles, I thought, as we drove inland from the Adriatic at Split. Stone, stone, stone: Yugoslavia here has taken on a skull and old tooth color. It isn't the large rock formations that impress most. No, mile after charnel-white mile, knuckle-size, fist-size, knee-size, stone - as if all Yugoslavia had once been paved in concrete and were now breaking up. The biblical valley of dry bones, you might imagine, lay somewhere between Knin and Obrovac.

title: Lighting the Night Skies for a Banner Year
description: For several hours this Fourth of July, the skies will light up with a spray of fireworks - from $50,000 public displays to backyard sparklers and fountains.

title: Hers; It Still Takes A Bride and Groom
description: NOW THAT JUNE IS over, I may as well confess my secret vice: reading newspaper accounts of weddings and engagements.

title: Ron Toomer: Roller-Coaster Designer
description: Ron Toomer has spent the last quarter century devising new ways to make people gasp, shriek and race upside down at breakneck speeds. Although he never rode a roller coaster before being hired in 1965 by a company that designed rides for amusement parks, and says he does not ride them now because ''I have a real problem with motion sickness,'' Mr. Toomer is the unquestioned king of coaster design. This year the 59-year-old mechanical engineer unveiled his two most vertiginous, equilibrium-defying creations yet; the Great American Scream Machine at Six Flags Great Adventure in Jackson, N.J., and the Magnum XL-200 at the Cedar Point amusement park in Sandusky, Ohio.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Tests on the Giant outfielder Kevin Mitchell, who leads the majors with 25 homers and 72 r.b.i., showed he has an inflammed left knee. The Giants, who feared cartilage damage, said Mitchell would take oral medication and rest occasionally. Yesterday, one day after the Giants pitcher Mike Krukow underwent arthroscopic surgery that disclosed a torn rotator cuff that is expected to end his season, another right-handed starter, Scott Garrelts, was placed on the 15-day disabled list by San Francisco with a pulled left hamstring. Garrelts, 6-3 with a 2.75 earned run average, suffered the injury while hitting a two-run triple Thursday against the Chicago Cubs. . . . Jackie Joyner-Kersee, who won gold medals in the heptathlon and long jump at the 1988 Summer Olympic Games in Seoul, South Korea, will make her first outdoor appearance ever in the New York area when she competes in two hurdles events at the New York Track and Field Games on July 22. She is entered in the 100- and 400-meter hurdles in the meet, which will be staged at Columbia University's Wien Stadium.

title: Julie Stevenson Weds Thomas Meyer
description: The marriage of Julie Stevenson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nikolai Stevenson of Sands Point, L.I., to Thomas Wolpert Meyer, a son of Morton L. Meyer and Roxanne Harris Frank, both of St. Louis, took place yesterday at the home of the bride's parents. The Rev. Frederick Rapp, an Episcopal priest, and Rabbi Joseph Rosenbloom officiated.

title: Sweatshirts: You Are What You Wear
description: AMONG the walkers in my neighborhood, sweatsuits are in fashion. They can be seen all over town. Sweatsuits used to be just that, something you wore in a gym to sweat in. Today, they make a personal statement.

title: FASHION: On the Street; Where Being Hot Is Not at All Cool
description: Down south, below 14th Street, they know something about handling heat. Let the mercury soar past 90, let midtown melt down: the shop-till-you-drop crowd in Greenwich Village and SoHo never loses its cool. Take the couple at right, enjoying their ice cream. If the steamy temperature bothers them, they're not letting on. She is chic in cocoa ankle-length lace culottes with a loose-fitting, ivory silk tank top. He is hip in a silk leisure suit with a wrap jacket. And ultra-dark shades? But of course.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Following are the major economic indicators to be released this week. Monday Construction Spending June Tuesday None Wednesday New-Car Sales June Thursday None Friday Employment June

title: Cap-Maker Sews History in Flannel
description: When William Arlt finishes one of the 10 old-fashioned baseball caps he sews every day, he takes a trip into baseball's past. ''Whenever I research a cap, work on it, then see it in the flesh, it knocks me out,'' Arlt said. ''I mean, to see a 1921 Negro league hat when I'm done is a trip. It's part of the magic of hats.''

title: In Defense Of Comical Commercials
description: EVER since the 1989 advertising awards season began, advertising executives have been sounding like the comedian Steve Martin, muttering that ''comedy is not pretty.''

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Takeover Stocks Staying In Wall Street's Limelight
description: As they have been in many previous quarters, takeover stocks were prominent among the strongest performers on the three major exchanges in the last three months.

title: MILITARY RESEARCH FACING THE PINCH OF TIGHT BUDGETS
description: After nearly a decade of feverish growth, the military research complex is entering a phase of contraction that could slow the pursuit of new weapons but open new opportunities for developing civilian technologies.

title: Cherry Output Up a Bit
description: Cherry production, which was severely affected by heat and drought last year, is making a bit of a comeback this year but is still behind 1987 levels, the Agriculture Department said. Production of tart cherries is expected to rise by 10 percent, to 260.7 million pounds, from last year's levels. The 1987 harvest totaled 358.5 million pounds.

title: Beijing Offers Details on Those Killed June 4
description: China made a distinction today between two kinds of people killed in the suppression of the pro-democracy movement last month - those to be held in revered memory and those to be forgotten.

title: Washington Talk; Justice
description: The cliffhanging finale of the Supreme Court term has turned that usually austere and dignified institution into something resembling daytime soap opera.

title: Debt-Equity Swaps Have a Place in Mexican Relief
description: To the Editor:

title: The Chick Corea Brand Of Rhythmic Interplay
description: Even though the gifted and versatile pianist Chick Corea is better appreciated performing solo than with a group, his Avery Fisher Hall concert on Saturday evening with his Akoustic Band (the bassist John Patitucci and the drummer Dave Weckl) demonstrated lively teamwork among the three musicians.

title: And How Many Tigers Make One Elephant?
description: To the Editor:

title: Amy B. Ehrlich, A Rabbi, Is Wed
description: Rabbi Amy B. Ehrlich, an assistant rabbi at Temple Emanu-El in New York, and Dr. Joseph J. Fins, a senior resident in internal medicine at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, were married yesterday at Temple Emanu-El by Rabbis Ronald B. Sobel and Rosette Barron Haim, assisted by Cantor Howard Nevison.

title: Alva Sole, Airmail Pioneer, 99
description: Alva Sole, a United States Airmail Service pioneer, died in his sleep Thursday. He was 99 years old.

title: Expos' Smith: 1 Victory, 4 R.B.I.
description: Bryn Smith drove in 4 of Montreal's season-high 13 runs today as the Expos beat the Houston Astros, 13-2.

title: European Stocks Gain As Asian Markets Fall
description: Foreign stock markets again bewildered analysts in the second quarter of this year as European stock markets posted steady gains and Asian market results were mostly disappointing.

title: Five-Day Fourth for Bush
description: President Bush went jogging today, worshiped at an oceanside church and planned to play tennis and fish over a five-day Fourth of July vacation. Mr. Bush began the day at 6:30 A.M. by jogging for 20 minutes along back roads. Later, he attended services at St. Ann's Episcopal Church.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Crying Wolf in the Greenhouse
description: Who could want to endure another summer like last, with drought-stricken crops, fish kills and ozone alerts? Some environmentalists, that's who. They hope it will ''galvanize political opinion'' and make Congress pass legislation to combat the greenhouse warming of the earth's atmosphere.

title: Colombia Tries to Shift Crops
description: When Luis Fernando Gomez Enriquez began growing coca leaves here five years ago, he could hardly wait for the riches that the cocaine-producing crop had already showered on neighboring villages.

title: Major Leaguers Are Serious And Superstitious About Their Caps
description: FANS may wear baseball caps as a fancy, but major leaguers wear them to work. The players are serious, and sometimes superstitious, about the caps they wear.

title: Unilever Unit To Acquire Minnetonka
description: The Minnetonka Corporation, which makes Calvin Klein fragrances, said yesterday that its board had unanimously approved the sale of the company to Chesebrough-Pond's Inc., a subsidiary of Unilever P.L.C., for $22.86 a share, or $376.2 million.

title: Israel Bans Arab's Play As Racist and Inciteful
description: Israeli authorities said today that they had banned a play written by an Israeli Arab because it was racist and would incite anti-Israeli protests.

title: Review/Dance; From Buenos Aires, Troupe With Roots in Tango
description: The Ballet Contemporaneo del Teatro San Martin, an Argentine troupe with exceptionally fluent and imposing dancers, concluded the American Dance Festival's Latin American series here on Friday.

title: Continental Cuts Fares
description: Continental Airlines today announced $76 one-way fares on United States flights for three days after the Fourth of July holiday. United Airlines said it would match the offer.

title: Buffeting the Chicago Art Institute
description: In the last year, the School of the Art Institute of Chicago and the institute itself have come to be known as much for the controversies that have enveloped them as for the art that is taught and displayed within their walls.

title: With Hindsight, Lawmakers Admit They Ignored Warnings on H.U.D.
description: Members of the Congressional committees that oversee the Department of Housing and Urban Development acknowledge that they were repeatedly warned about mismanagement and fraud in the department but did little to stop them.

title: Mexicans Vote Amid Charges of Irregularities
description: Mexicans in five states voted in local elections today amid widespread complaints by opposition parties of balloting irregularities.

title: New Amax Gold Chief To Seek High Output
description: Amax Gold Inc., a mining company that has gone from an annual output of zero to 300,000 ounces of gold since 1985, on Friday named a new president and chief executive, Timothy J. Haddon. Mr. Haddon, who is 40 years old, succeeds Charles E. Stott, 55, who took early retirement.

title: Rates Heading Lower As Economy Weakens
description: If there were any bears in the fixed-income securities market last week, they were out of sight, and they are expected to remain in hiding during this holiday-shortened week.

title: Today Is a Sort of Holiday, Not Created Equal to the 4th
description: The absolutism of history is such that today is not, repeat NOT, officially a holiday. The Fourth of July continues to fall on the fourth. Tomorrow.

title: In Overhaul of Hospital Rules, New York Slashes Interns' Hours
description: Regulations that dramatically change the way hospital staffs in New York State operate took effect this weekend, sharply reducing the grueling working hours of medical interns and residents and greatly increasing their supervision by senior doctors.

title: INSIDE
description: A Cliffhanger at the Court The Supreme Court's delay in announcing its abortion decision has created an air of high drama around a normally austere body. Page 10. Defiance in the Pulpit A black Roman Catholic priest defied his church's hierarchy by establishing what he calls an African-American Catholic Congregation. Page 8. Rumblings Over Aquino President Aquino of the Philippines has become the target of growing charges of incompetence, cronyism and corruption. Page 6. Greek Cabinet Sworn In The conservative head of Greece's new Government swore in an unusual cabinet that included a Communist in the key justice post. Page 3. Foster Care in Disarray New York City's system remains overwhelmed, three years after it was described as in crisis. Page 21.

title: Trivializing Ambassadors
description: Presidents and Congress have a habit of rewarding fat cats and cronies with foreign embassies, of treating many ambassadorial appointments as if they don't much matter in representing American interests and values. But they do matter, sometimes critically.

title: Books of The Times; A Stone Wall and an Obsession
description: Stone Work By John Jerome 212 pages. Viking. $17.95.

title: Ally & Gargano In Pin Stripes
description: Ally & Gargano will take on a distinctly pin-striped hue after winning the advertising account of Shearson Lehman Hutton on Friday. The agency prevailed over a large field of candidates, which had been winnowed down to two agencies -Ally and Ammirati & Puris -in a three-phase review process.

title: Kim Reilly Wed To Robert Profaci
description: At the Monastery Church of the Sacred Heart in Yonkers, Kim Jenifer Reilly, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert James Reilly of Irvington, N.Y., was married yesterday to Robert John Profaci, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph Profaci of Dongan Hills, S.I. The Rev. Philip Bohan, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated. Mrs. Profaci is a kindergarten teacher in the Eastchester, N.Y., public schools. She graduated from Boston College, as did her husband, and received a master's degree in education from Fordham University. Her father is an architect in Irvington; her mother, Susan Reilly, is a teacher in the Irvington school system.

title: General's Grandson Says Gunfire Thesis Is Backed
description: A grandson of the prominent but controversial military analyst Brig. Gen. S. L. A. Marshall has sought to refute assertions in American Heritage magazine that a major work by his late grandfather was based on faked evidence.

title: Ms. Parker Wed To Dan Reicher
description: Carole Lisbeth Parker, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maclyn Taite Parker of Fort Wayne, Ind., and Aspen, Colo., was married yesterday to Dan William Reicher at the Pine Creek Cookhouse in Ashcroft, Colo., a ghost town in the mountains near Aspen. The Rev. Gregg R. Anderson, a Methodist minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony. Mr. Reicher is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Norbert B. Reicher of Syracuse and Cazenovia, N.Y.

title: Corrections
description: A music review last Monday about a performance of Benjamin Britten's ''Albert Herring'' on June 23 at the Glimmerglass Opera in Cooperstown, N.Y., misidentified the soprano who sang Miss Wordsworth. She was Marsha Hunter, not Angela Norton.

title: Cliburn Plays In Moscow
description: Van Cliburn, who triumphed here in 1958 in the Tchaikovsky Piano Competition, was acclaimed anew tonight playing the concerto that helped win him his title 31 years ago.

title: Florida's Jammed Prisons: More In Means More Out
description: Doyle W. Kemp has come to dread Fridays. That is when he receives court projections of how many new prisoners will come into Florida's overloaded state prison system the next week.

title: Yankees' Phantom Of the Basepaths
description: The fans who filed happily out of Yankee Stadium late Saturday night knew that the Yankees had beaten the Milwaukee Brewers. What they didn't know was the score.

title: Orioles Find Heath A Nemesis Again
description: Mike Heath seems to be in the middle of things that undo the Baltimore Orioles. Heath drove in an unearned run in the sixth and then was the victim in a disputed call in the eighth inning of the Tigers' 7-3 victory over the Baltimore Orioles today.

title: In New Jersey, 3 of 4 Nuns End Cloister Protest
description: Three of four Roman Catholic nuns who barricaded themselves in a monastery infirmary here to protest liberalizing trends in their cloistered life left quietly over the weekend under the cloak of darkness.

title: A Day of Rest at Wimbledon
description: Just as the sun set behind him on Centre Court Saturday night, Stefan Edberg, Wimbledon's defending men's champion, got his night vision in working order and became the final player to advance to the round of 16 by eclipsing Scott Davis of the United States, 6-3, 6-4, 4-6, 6-2.

title: Numbers Are Few For Female Drivers
description: The number of women competing professionally in auto racing is small. Besides Shirley Muldowney, who has won drag-racing championships at the sport's top level, only about a dozen women have progressed to the professional level.

title: Business and the Law; New York Dispute Over Kosher Meat
description: A COURTROOM dispute between New York State and Hebrew National Kosher Foods Inc. over the company's practices of keeping kosher began as a tempest in a meat pot. But the fight has recently intensified and threatens to keep the company's frankfurters out of the state.

title: Julie Ann Schwartz Married
description: The marriage of Julie Ann Schwartz, an assistant casting director for Lois Planco in New York, and Alan Madison, a freelance film maker in New York, took place yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Irvin Schwartz, in Southhampton, L.I. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Madison of Englewood Cliffs, N.J. Rabbi Balfour Brickner officiated.

title: Why Do We Cheer Vigilante Cops?
description: Movies about violent cops who push past legally and morally acceptable limits to achieve justice have proliferated recently. This summer alone, we'll be treated to ''Renegades'' and ''Lethal Weapon II.'' And in the past two years moviegoers have been offered ''Robocop'' ''Lethal Weapon,'' ''Dead Bang'' and ''Die Hard.''

title: Hefner Weds '88 Playmate
description: Hugh Hefner, the publisher of Playboy, married Kimberley Conrad, 1988's Playmate of the Year, in an outdoor ceremony at the Playboy mansion here Saturday afternoon.

title: Dr. Lisa Framm Weds in Capital
description: At Temple Sinai in Washington, Dr. Lisa Framm, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Daniel Herschel Framm of Potomac, Md., was married yesterday to Dr. Mark Sklar, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Sklar of Jericho, L.I. Rabbis Eugene Lippman and Fred Reiner officiated.

title: Dialing for Details
description: The Dawn Patrol, a wake-up program on WEBN-FM in Cincinnati, has a format featuring soft rock and phone calls from listeners. Robin Wood, who plays the music and chats with callers, says the main topic this spring, not surprisingly, has been the seemingly endless tribulations of Pete Rose.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-7

title: Spanish Banks in High Gear For Stiff Competition of 1992
description: With the European Community now committed to deregulating most financial services, Spain's long-protected banking sector is feverishly preparing to survive the stiff competition that will follow creation of a single regional market after 1992.

title: Solidarity to Stick to Deal With Party
description: Solidarity's new members of Parliament decided today that for the time being they would not try to take more power away from the Communist Party as a result of Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski's decision not to seek the Presidency.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Officer Says Banc One Is Optimistic on Texas
description: LEAD: Thomas E. Hoaglin, who has been put in charge of the Banc One Corporation's new Texas affiliate, says the banking company's management has the ''full intention of being an active lender'' in the state.

title: Consistent Skippers At Grey Advertising
