description: Grey Advertising proved on Thursday that consistency sometimes triumphs over flash and dazzle - if not on Madison Avenue, then on the waters of New York Harbor.

title: Love You By Heart Breaks a Record
description: Love You By Heart, who failed to handle a soft turf course as the favorite in the New York Handicap last time out, stormed down the stretch over firmer footing yesterday to win the $120,800 Sheepshead Bay Handicap at Belmont Park in stakes-record time.

title: Fourth Of July Oration
description: The political exploitability of the flag - as a symbol to stir emotions of fierce patriotism and profound resentment - was brought home to me on a balmy summer's day in Indianapolis in 1968.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Finance/New Issues column of Business Day on Wednesday about financing for a Federal archive in Maryland misstated the type of securities to be used. The $301.7 million in securities are not guaranteed by the Federal Government, and the income they earn is subject to Federal tax. The report also misidentified the issuer. It was the National Archives Facility Trust, not the National Archives.

title: Photo Center Branch To Open in Midtown
description: Photographs by Berenice Abbott and James Nachtwey are to be included in an exhibition to begin Sept. 15 with the opening of the midtown branch of the International Center of Photography, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43d Street. The branch will also offer a screening room and permanent collection gallery, a bookstore and spaces for lectures and changing exhibitions.

title: USA Invitational
description: Syracuse has won the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division I lacrosse tournament the past two years, a tournament that did not exist in 1957. The Orangemen had an unbeaten team that year but the national championship went by acclaim to Johns Hopkins of Baltimore because most of the acclaimants came from the Baltimore area.

title: In New Jersey, and in Earnest, a Museum of Trash
description: So much trash has been dumped in the Hackensack Meadowlands over the last half century that garbage has become part of the very fabric of life here.

title: Fast Way to Get News That's Hot Off the Fax
description: Each afternoon about 4, The Hartford Courant uses facsimile machines to send a 1,500-word summary of what will appear in the next day's paper to a small but growing group of subscribers.

title: Julia Palmore Married To Christopher Shaida
description: Julia Palmore and Christopher Shaida were married yesterday at the Columns in New York. Jean Kotkin, a leader of the American Ethical Union, officiated.

title: Hats Off To the Game
description: JOHN COONEY rubs his forehead and takes a deep breath when asked why he is a baseball fan and why he proves it by constantly wearing a Boston Red Sox cap. There are so many stories to tell about his family's experiences in professional baseball, so many anecdotes to sort through.

title: New Offer for Gateway
description: A group headed by Wasserstein, Perella & Company raised its bid on Friday for the Gateway Corporation, a British food-store chain, by $71 million in an effort to defeat an offer from a rival investment group, Isosceles P.L.C.

title: Still Waiting for That First Black Governor
description: To the Editor:

title: Black Priest Defies Church, Forming Own Congregation
description: Amid the rhythms of African drums and jazz and defying a Roman Catholic hierarchy he calls racist, a black priest celebrated Mass today and established what he termed an African-American Catholic Congregation.

title: Three Men Are Shot And One Is Stabbed In L.I. Beach Melee
description: An all-day beach party for more than 12,000 fraternity members erupted into a brawl that left three men shot, one stabbed and 11 arrested on various charges, the New York State Police said today.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;
Latest in Amusements: Going Around in a Maze
description: LEAD: ABOUT halfway between San Francisco and Reno, the billboards along the farmlands of Interstate 80 remind travelers of the gambling meccas 125 miles up the road. Among the signs for risque shows and lounge singers, there are also advertisements announcing something called the Wooz.

title: As Aquino Appears to Drift, the Cheering Fades
description: While Corazon C. Aquino is still revered as a secular saint for leading the restoration of democracy in the Philippines, the murmuring about her performance as President is growing louder.

title: Episcopal Outreach Includes Gay People
description: To the Editor:

title: Meredith Smallens, Graduate Student, Is Married to Christopher R. Lonner
description: The marriage of Meredith Ann Smallens, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Smallens 2d of Scarsdale, N.Y., to Christopher Robert Lonner, a son of Mrs. Ernest B. Lonner of San Francisco and the late Mr. Lonner, took place yesterday at the Hammond Museum in North Salem, N.Y. Rabbi Emily Korzenik officiated.

title: Ailing Tudor To Be Examined
description: John Tudor of the Los Angeles Dodgers, who left today's game against Pittsburgh with a sore left shoulder, will be examined Monday.

title: Donald Carrick, 60, Illustrator and Author
description: Donald F. Carrick, a landscape artist and author and illustrator of children's books, died Monday at his home in Edgartown, Mass., after a brief illness. He was 60 years old.

title: Braves Deal Smith, James
description: Zane Smith, who has a 1-12 record with a 4.45 earned run average, was traded by the Atlanta Braves to the Montreal Expos today for three minor leaguers.

title: No Headline
description: Because of holiday production requirements, The Times is printed today in two sections.

title: Retiring Teachers' Leader Calls For Restructuring of School System
description: Mary Hatwood Futrell, who rose from rural poverty to the presidency of the National Education Association, called today in her farewell address for a ''massive, systemwide restructuring'' of the nation's schools.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allied-Signal Inc., Morris Township, N.J., the diversified aerospace, automotive and engineering company, named James J. Verrant a senior vice president and president of its Allied-Signal International Inc. subsidiary.

title: A British Star in TV's Back Room
description: Carlton Communications P.L.C. is scarcely a household name. But chances are that most people in the United States and Britain who have recently watched a television program, movie or videocassette have had their screen entertainment enhanced, edited, processed or duplicated at some stage by Carlton or by Carlton-made equipment.

title: Companies Hesitating On China
description: Despite uncertainty about China's political course, most American corporations doing business in China express confidence in the country's long-term economic prospects and seem intent on maintaining operations there.

title: Graduate of the Gulag Voices Doubts bout the New Era
description: From behind the barbed wire of Perm Labor Camp 35, Vyacheslav N. Cherepanov has watched the unfolding fantasia of the Gorbachev years with frequent amazement and faint hope.

title: 2 Harvard Losses In the Same Race
description: The stewards who rule the Henley Royal Regatta outdid themselves to make this year's 150th anniversary rowing of ''this unique pageant of English life'' - as in the souvenir program - memorable.

title: Protect It - And Ideas
description: As we reflect on Independence Day on the meaning of our flag, who can doubt the importance of a national debate about the pros and cons of a constitutional amendment to protect it?

title: Review/Television; Two Who Made the Theater Magic
description: Following last week's essay on ''Broadway Dreamers: The Group Theater,'' public television's ''American Masters'' is continuing its three-part series on major forces in the American theater with separate profiles of two enormously vibrant figures who were closely associated with the Group Theater and, for several years, were even married to each other. ''Harold Clurman: A Life of Theater'' can be seen at 9 this evening on Channel 13. ''Stella Adler: Awake and Dream'' is being broadcast next Monday at 9 on 13. Here indeed are theatrical figures who revel jubilantly in being bigger than life.

title: Washington Talk; Diplomatic Corps Dean? Spin the Revolving Door
description: The practice of diplomacy moves with a measured pace. Protocol, ritual, tradition. But in recent weeks the diplomatic community here has seen a whirl of comings and goings. The deanship of the corps, the community's most prestigous job, has changed hands twice in two months, and not even the State Department seems to know when the door will stop revolving.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: INTERNATIONAL REPORT The freewheeling ways of the shipping industry are illustrated by the tanker that spilled oil into Narragansett Bay last month. The World Prodigy was made in Greece, registered in Liberia, insured by a Bermuda-based group managed from London and owned by a Greek shipping magnate. Although subject to national laws and supranational standards, international shipowners may undermine maritime safety in the pursuit of cost cutting, critics say. [ Page 1. ] U.S. corporations doing business in China express confidence in the country's long-term economic prospects, despite the violent suppression of protests. It remains unclear whether companies that do not already have Chinese operations will be willing to make investments in coming years. [ 25. ] Spain's banks are preparing to survive the stiff competition that will follow the creation of a unified European market in 1992. The result has been a flurry of activity, including mergers, board shake-ups, corporate reorganizations, exchanges of shares with foreign banks and the expansion of domestic branches. [ 25. ] COMPANIES Minnetonka's board agreed to sell the company to Chesebrough-Pond's for $376.2 million. The deal would unite three of the top ''prestige fragrance'' brands: Calvin Klein's Obsession and Eternity, and Elizabeth Taylor's Passion. [ 25. ] MARKETS Takeover stocks were again prominent on the list of strong performers for the second quarter. The big losers represented a variety of industries. [ 25. ] European markets posted steady gains in the quarter, while results in Asia were mostly disappointing. [ 30. ] Underwriting revenues plunged 32 percent in the first half of 1989, increasing the likelihood of more Wall Street cutbacks. [ 25. ] THE MEDIA BUSINESS Carlton Communications has become a leader in the lucrative television-support business. The British company now supplies everything from stage props to sophisticated special-effects equipment. Its customers include Hollywood movie studios, TV networks, individual stations and advertisers. [ 25. ] The Hartford Courant is delivering a news summary by facsimile machines to a small group of subscribers. Some other news organizations have expressed interest in the concept. [ 29. ] Southern Progress has been mentioned as a candidate for sale if its parent, Time Inc., becomes mired in debt from its struggle to avoid a hostile takeover by Paramount Communications. The regional publishing unit says its plans to introduce a magazine, Southpoint, will not be affected by the developments at Time. [ 29. ] The TV networks have sold more commercial time in advance for the next season than ever before. The gains were attributed to increased automobile advertising and renewed confidence in the medium's ability to sell. Television. [ 29. ] Although some ad people would cut out the funny business, Cliff Freeman intends to have the last laugh. The creator of comic commercials like ''Where's the Beef?'' says humor sells because it is surprising and timeless. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ 28. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS A court fight has intensified between Hebrew National and New York State over the company's practices of keeping kosher. The feud threatens to keep the company's frankfurters out of the state. Stephen Labaton: Business and the Law. [ 26. ] Syntex has been the subject of much takeover speculation, but its evolution from a Mexican research institute to a drug maker may mean large obstacles to a merger. Market Place. [ 28. ] There is a bullish mood in the fixed-income markets. Spurred by more signs of a weakening economy, the Fed is considered likely to allow lower interest rates soon. Credit Markets. [ 28. ]

title: Little People Oppose Events In Which Dwarfs Are Objects
description: Traveling shows featuring dwarf tossing contests are the latest outrage that dwarfs find themselves fighting to preserve their dignity and safety, officials of Little People of America said Saturday.

title: Debt-Equity Swaps Have a Place in Mexican Relief; To Be Creditworthy
description: To the Editor:

title: Green Is Winner For First Time
description: Tammie Green made her first Ladies Professional Golf Association victory a big one, holding off Pat Bradley and Betsy King today for a one-shot victory at the $600,000 du Maurier Classic. Green, the top 1987 rookie, won $90,000 and now has $172,821 in this year.

title: Underwriters' Revenues Fall Sharply
description: Underwriting revenues have dropped steeply this year, increasing the prospect of more belt-tightening on Wall Street, where many firms have had profits shaved and thousands of workers have already lost their jobs.

title: What About U.S. Unity?
description: LEAD: In the Supreme Court's only significant liberal decision of this term, a majority of the justices interpreted the First Amendment broadly to protect flag burning as free speech. If Gregory Lee Johnson could only express his antipatriotic sentiments by burning the flag in Dallas, then the First Amendment affirms his constitutional right to assault the symbols of our national unity.

title: No Headline
description: Out on the lake, wind surfers are tacking in a desultory breeze, their pastel sails framed by the familiar landscape of northwestern Indiana: oil refineries with flickering tongues of flame and smokestacks belching black clouds across the sunset.

title: Michele Deitch Weds Michael Sturley
description: Michele Yve Deitch, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Deitch of Todt Hill, S.I., and Michael Fisher Sturley, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Sturley of Kirkville, N.Y., were married yesterday at the Stronghold Mansion in Bernardsville, N.J. Rabbi Fredric Dworkin and the Rev. Laura Edwards-Jenks, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: New Zealand Wins Liberty Cup Regatta
description: Victory was short-circuited for New Zealand yesterday in the final races of the Liberty Cup regatta in New York Harbor. On the way back to shore, after winning a two-of-three final series against France, New Zealand was told to race again.

title: Avrett, Free Grows
description: Avrett, Free & Ginsberg added a small agency to its portfolio on Friday, acquiring Symon & Hilliard, whose principle clients are the appliance and automotive divisions of General Electric and which had billings of $20 million. Avrett's billings will now stand at $132 million.

title: Abortion Foes Discuss Plans for 'Post-Roe Era'
description: On the weekend before the widely expected Supreme Court decision on abortion, opponents of abortion gathered here to plan for what they hoped could be an ''abortion-free America.''

title: Bridge
description: If the prerequisites for a bridge job included 30 years at the top as a teacher (thousands of students), writer (at least 15 books and at least 100 articles) and player (world champion), there would probably be only one applicant. His name is Eddie Kantar of Los Angeles, and he recently collected his favorite articles, mainly about his ex-partners and his travels around the world.

title: Raw Reactions to Film on Racial Tension
description: The world of Jamez Williams's Bedford-Stuyvesant childhood flickered large before his eyes. By the end of the weekend, Mr. Williams, an usher at a movie theater in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, had already seen or heard Spike Lee's new feature film about racial tensions and urban brutalities nearly a dozen times.

title: Suspect in Officer's Death Is Buried to Angry Protests
description: Demonstrators burned tires and barricaded streets Saturday during the funeral of Daniel Mirambeaux, who the police here say jumped to his death just after being told he would be extradited to New York to face charges of killing a police officer.

title: Holiday Tomorrow
description: Here are Independence Day holiday schedules. Regular schedules apply today. NEW YORK Fireworks: East River, 9:15 P.M., between 23d and 42d Streets. The F.D.R. Drive will be closed between 14th and 49th Streets from 8 P.M. to 1 A.M. Government offices: Closed. Post Offices: Express Mail and special delivery only; main post office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Banks: Closed. Parking: Sunday rules in effect. Sanitation: No collections. Financial markets: Closed. Transportation: Subways and buses on Saturday schedule. L.I.R.R. and Metro-North on holiday schedules. Libraries: Closed. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Closed. Post Offices: Special delivery and Express Mail delivery only. Banks: Option to close. Transportation: N.J. Transit trains and buses on Sunday schedules CONNECTICUT Government offices: Closed. Post Offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Transportation: New Haven Line on holiday schedule.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS: BOXING;
Dancing in the Ring
description: LEAD: The Mike Tyson-Robin Givens romance did not have a happy ending, but another champion finds true love and happiness in Twyla Tharp's ''Everlast,'' the contemporary ballet recently performed by American Ballet Theater.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;
Underhand Move Isn't Underhanded
description: LEAD: THE key match in Michael Chang's historic march to the men's singles title in the French Open last month was his fourth-round upset of Ivan Lendl, the world's No. 1 player.

title: New Picture Technologies Push Seeing Still Further From Believing
description: In the 1960's, it took almost five years and $40 million to move two colossal Egyptian temples from Abu Simbel, where rising waters from the Nile threatened the monuments, upriver to Aswan.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Leaders Tied at Western Open: Mark McCumber and Peter Jacobsen ended in a tie after 72 holes and a rain delay yesterday and will finish the Western Open with a sudden-death playoff today. McCumber shot a final-round 69 for a 72-hole total of 13-under-par 275. Jacobsen had a 68 for 275. Both broke the Butler National Western record of 276 set by Tom Weiskopf in 1982. (AP) CYCLING Da Silva Leading Tour de France: Acacio da Silva of Portugal took the overall lead in the 76th Tour de France yesterday after winning the 84-mile first stage through Luxembourg. In the second stage, a team time trial, da Silva's Carrera team placed 12th, but da Silva held on to the overall leader's yellow jersey. The Super U team won the time trial in 53 minutes 48 seconds over the 28 1/2 miles. Pedro Delgado of Spain, the defending champion, fell 9:37 behind. Da Silva is 26 seconds ahead of Soren Lilholt of Denmark. (AP) HORSE RACING Derby Sweep for Cauthen: Steve Cauthen became the first jockey to sweep the world's four major thoroughbred derbies when he rode Old Vic to victory yesterday in the Irish Derby at the Curragh in Dublin. Cauthen added the Irish title to earlier victories in the Kentucky French and English derbies. He had a four-length victory over Observation Post. Ille de Nisky was third. (AP) HORSE SHOW Show Jumper Wins No. 25: Leslie Lenehan of Westport, Conn., gained her 25th show jumping grand prix victory yesterday, topping a 57-horse field in the United States Open jumping championship at the 20th annual Lake Placid show. Lenehan finished in 65.065 seconds on Pressurized. Rodney Jenkins of Orange, Va., show jumping's career leader with 70 victories, was second on Gusty Monroe. BOXING Ruddock Defeats Smith: Razor Ruddock survived a second-round knockdown to defeat James (Bonecrusher) Smith yesterday, scoring a seventh-round knockout in Fayetteville, N.C. Smith was counted out at 2:18. Ruddock, the Canadian heavyweight champion, is 22-1-1, with 15 knockouts. Smith, 36, is 19-8-1. (AP) SOCCER Ecuador Downs Uruguay: Hermen Benitez scored with one minute remaining as Ecuador stunned Uruguay, the defending champion, 1-0, yesterday at Goiania, Brazil, in the America Cup, South America's quadrennial championship series. In another game, Argentina beat Chile, 1-0. (AP) AUTO RACING Nissan Wins at Watkins Glen: Geoff Brabham, driving a Nissan GTP-ZXT prototype, teamed with Chip Robinson yesterday to win the Camel Continental sports car race at Watkins Glen International.

title: New-Look Outriggers for Canoes
description: The idea of attaching outriggers to stabilize a canoe is something the Hawaiians have known about for centuries. Now an outdoorsman from Wyoming has given outriggers a new look.

title: Leslie Pittel Wed To John W. Heins
description: Leslie Jill Pittel, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Pittel of North Woodmere, L.I., and John William Heins, a son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Edward Heins of Columbia, Mo., were married yesterday at the East River Yacht Club in New York. Cantor David Benedict officiated.

title: Ethics Mire Jersey Race; Charges on Associates Distract From Issues
description: Less than a month after the two major political parties nominated their candidates for governor of New Jersey, the campaigns of both men are now mired in allegations of wrongdoing by some of their associates.

title: Subtlety in Piano Textures
description: The solo piano series at Weill Recital Hall, part of the JVC Jazz Festival, may not be the best context in which to hear the pianist James Williams. While Mr. Williams, who regularly plays in New York and is one of the city's finest mainstream pianists, is capable of sustaining a solo performance easily, it's with a rhythm section that he shines.

title: Question Box
description: Beginner's Fortunes Q. Since baseball expansion began in the major leagues, which team had the worst record in its first year and which had the best? A. The expansion period dates only from 1961, when the American League went from 8 teams to 10 teams a year before the National League did likewise, through 1977, when the American League went from 12 to 14 teams. In that 17-year span, no first-year team has been worse off the mark than the New York Mets of 1962. In fact, no team since 1900 - expansion, relocated or permanent - has ever lost as many games as Casey Stengel's Mets did that year with their 40-120 record and 10th-place finish in the National League. Oddly, the National League expansion team with the best first-year mark was the Mets' companion newcomer that season, the Houston Colt .45's (now Astros), who won 64 games and lost 96 under Manager Harry Craft. The worst first year for an American League expansion team was the one turned in by the Toronto Blue Jays, who finished at 54-107 in 1977 under Roy Hartsfield.

title: Mortgage Rates Drop
description: Fixed-rate home mortgages are averaging 10.07 percent, according to a national survey released Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. That rate was down from 10.19 percent a week earlier. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.92 percent this week, compared with 9 percent the previous week, Freddie Mac said.

title: Correction
description: A transmission error in an ''On My Mind'' column by A.M. Rosenthal form Jerusalem printed June 30 resulted in a complete reversal of the meaning of a critical sentence. The sentence should have read: ''Mr. Shamir's friends, and his enemies, are convinced that the [ election ] proposals are not simply a tactical bluff on his part, and after days of talk here, so am I.'' The error was the omission of ''not.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article last Monday about the British Health Service, and a picture caption with it, named the Health Secretary incorrectly. He is Kenneth Clarke.

title: Spiked on Top: Brooklyn Dodger Caps Are a Hot Headgear Trend
description: WHEN manufacturers and retailers of old-fashioned baseball caps talk about the soaring demand for their product, they describe the Brooklyn Dodgers' cap as the hottest item going. When they talk about reasons why, the name of a man who was born the year the Dodgers left Brooklyn for Los Angeles almost always comes up.

title: Brewers Finish A New Starter
description: The Yankees' great experiment failed. They tried it, they hoped and then they watched the afternoon fall apart in small pieces. By the end of the day, they were back to considering their options, none of which seem very appealing.

title: New Delhi Journal; Shiny Tomorrow Meets Ragged, Hungry Today
description: A haunting video documentary making the unofficial rounds here chronicles a community's psychological progression from bewilderment through awakening to defiance as it realizes it is about to be displaced by a missile site.

title: Ute Sacksofsky and Jonathan Berck,Lawyers, Married in West Germany
description: Ute Sacksofsky, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Horst Sacksofsky of Schopfheim, West Germany, was married yesterday in Inzlingen, West Germany, to Jonathan Samuel Berck, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin G. Berck of Teaneck, N.J. Carl-Freidrich Rauber, the town clerk of Schopfheim, officiated at Inzlingen Castle.

title: British Foreign Secretary Is Booed By Angry Crowds in Hong Kong
description: In an outpouring of fear and anger unusual for this British colony, crowds jeered Sir Geoffrey Howe, the British Foreign Secretary, when he arrived today on a visit intended to restore Hong Kong's confidence in its future.

title: Dr. Wiener Wed To Stuart Rabner
description: Dr. Deborah Ann Wiener, an instructor in dermatology at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University, and Stuart Jeff Rabner, an assistant United States Attorney in New Jersey, were married yesterday at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I. Rabbis Leon Katz, Mordecai Rubin and Edward Feld performed the ceremony.

title: Florida Drug Crackdown Nets Nearly 2,200
description: An unprecedented statewide drug crackdown by 1,000 officers ended early today with nearly 2,200 people arrested on charges of using or dealing crack. Many suspects were back on the street within hours.

title: A Magazine's Bid to Unite the South
description: When the Southern Progress Corporation decided to put together Southpoint, a new magazine about the South, it expected to have enough headaches without having to worry about its own future as well.

title: Pendulum Swing Helps Moody Win
description: Orville Moody, who has used the long-shafted putter and the pendulum stroke for great success, won the 10th annual United States Senior Open today while the United States Golf Association was thinking about outlawing that putter, the pendulum swing or both.

title: Jazz to Comemorate Landing on the Moon
description: The American Museum of Natural History has scheduled two jazz concerts at the Planetarium to commemorate the 20th anniversary of the first manned landing on the moon.

title: Beth A. Pletcher, Physician, Weds
description: Dr. Beth Ann Pletcher, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold D. Pletcher of Naperville, Ill., and Paul Robert Glassberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Glassberg of Huntington, Conn., were married yesterday at the Crest Hollow Country Club in Woodbury, L.I. Rabbi Steven Folberg performed the ceremony.

title: Tanker in Big Spill Typifies Freewheeling Industry
description: The tanker that spilled 420,000 gallons of oil into Narragansett Bay last month after hitting a reef off the Rhode Island coast was made in Greece, registered in Liberia, insured by a Bermuda-based group managed from London and owned by a Greek shipping magnate.

title: Washington Talk: Snapshot; On the Trail of a Spy Agency Commercial
description: Attention, listeners. This radio commercial will self-destruct in 10 seconds.

title: Scores Detained After 11 Die In South African Homeland
description: Two tribal chiefs and scores of villagers in South Africa's Bophuthatswana homeland were arrested today by police investigating the deaths of 11 people in clashes at a protest meeting, civil rights workers said.

title: William Stanton And Miss Cluett Marry in Maine
description: Amanda Bird Cluett, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mark S. Cluett of San Francisco and Blue Hill, Me., was married yesterday in Blue Hill to William Brook Stanton, a son of Emily Hart Stanton of Darien, Conn., and the late John Pulsifer Stanton. The Rev. Henry Bird, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church.

title: Russian Reversal
description: To the Editor:

title: Byron Jay, 84, Is Dead; Formerly Headed A&P
description: Byron Jay, a former president and chief executive of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, died of heart failure yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Holiday Reduces Offerings of Bond Issues
description: The Treasury's schedule of new issues this holiday-shortened week is confined to today's regular auction of new three-month and six-month bills. Late Friday the three-month discount rate was 7.99 percent, while the six-month bill rate was 7.73 percent.

title: Outdoors: How to Avoid Being Among the Missing
description: SOONER or later, nearly every serious woods wanderer will get lost, even if only for an hour or two. In the wilder areas of the Northeast, game wardens never make it through fall and early winter without leading search parties for lost hunters. On many such occasions, snow and extreme cold are life-threatening.

title: Prosecutor Steps Softly In His New Job in Bronx
description: Robert T. Johnson, the Bronx District Attorney, is not known as a big risk taker. As a boy he dreamed of becoming a court officer like his father because ''it looked like a secure job.''

title: Allman Brothers: Rock Amid the Jazz
description: The latest reunited version of the Allman Brothers Band brought out vociferous fans for a late show on Friday at Avery Fisher Hall. Although it was put on by the JVC Jazz Festival, it was a full-fledged rock concert, complete with audience shouts and singalongs, dancing in the aisles and armed security guards.

title: Confessions of ann Old Little Leaguer
description: ONE morning not long ago I drove by a small ball park on the far North Side of Chicago, empty now except for the sprinklers whirring, and the shadows under the warm morning sun.

title: Helms Slips, but Still Gets Things Done, or Undone
description: With a word on the floor of Congress, Senator Jesse Helms can get an arts exhibition canceled. He has blocked or delayed dozens of appointments by Presidents of his own party. He has tied the Senate in knots through his mastery of parliamentary procedure. And few in public life have made more liberals more angry more often.

title: Uno Finds Himself Japan's No. 1 'Women's Issue'
description: Over the last four decades, the Japan Housewives Association has pressed traditional causes like forcing manufacturers to reveal the true ingredients of fruit-juice bottles, warning Japan about industrial pollution sites that threaten the health of children and fighting new sales taxes.

title: Jerusalem Mayor Calls For Letting Arabs Vote
description: Palestinians living in East Jerusalem should be allowed to vote in elections Israel is proposing for the occupied territories, Jerusalem's Mayor, Teddy Kollek, said today.

title: Open-Ended 1970's Funk for Saxophone
description: With its big-beat drumming, electric guitars, riff-driven compositions and rounds of solos, Friday's Knitting Factory Goes Uptown concert at Alice Tully Hall could almost have been one of the JVC Jazz Festival's large jazz-rock shows - except for a few crucial differences.

title: Options Board Suspends 3
description: Three traders who were accused of violating rules of the Chicago Board Options Exchange have been suspended, the exchange said on Friday.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of July 3, 1989: MONDAY Nevada Pwr Co WEDNESDAY Houston Inds Inc Neiman-Marcus Group Inc THURSDAY American Wtr Wks Inc Rite Aid Corp Freeport-McMoran Copp Sierra Pac Res General Pub Utils Corp Sun Inc Grace WR & Co Texas Eastn Corp Puget Sound Pwr & Lt Co FRIDAY Ashland Coal Inc Pittston Co Luby's Cafeterias Inc US West Inc SATURDAY Teleflex Inc

title: Chairman of Joint Chiefs of Staff to Retire
description: Adm. William C. Crowe Jr., chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said today that he would retire Sept. 30, ending a 47-year Navy career that included the last four years as the nation's military chief.

title: Bush Campaign Aide Tied To Another Housing Deal
description: Business associates of Paul J. Manafort, a strategist in George Bush's Presidential campaign, promoted a project in Georgia similar to one in New Jersey that has become the focus of Congressional investigations, The Hartford Courant reported today.

title: Market Place; Hurdles Seen For Suitors Of Syntex
description: EVEN though the takeover speculation about the Syntex Corporation has again reached a feverish pitch, industry analysts say the company's unusual evolution, from a Mexican research institute into a pharmaceutical manufacturer, may pose a formidable obstacle to any merger.

title: Cecil Taylor Pummels and Surprises
description: For all the consistency of his music since the 1960's, it's still impossible to guess what Cecil Taylor will do in concert.

title: For Child Welfare Agency, Small Gains and Big Flaws
description: More than three years after New York City's child protection system came to be widely described as in crisis, there is growing evidence that the system remains overwhelmed and deeply troubled.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I can't think of any other time that a women's issue has so affected politics. It has suddenly become clear that someone who does not respect women is not fit to be Prime Minister of Japan. '' - Kii Nakamura, vice president of the Japanese Housewives Association. [ 1:3. ]

title: Review/Dance; Movement As Music's Mirror
description: It is not easy to compete with the likes of Jean Ritchie and her Appalachian folk music. And Martha Connerton did not try in ''Patchwork,'' performed on Friday night at the Nikolais/Louis Choreospace by Miss Connerton's new Sphere Company, based in Louisville, Ky., and here making its New York debut. Instead, the new suite of dances offered a pleasant, amusing and occasionally poignant counterpart to the music performed live by Ms. Ritchie and Mark Englert.

title: U.S. and Cuba Should Cooperate to Stop Regional Drug Trafficking
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about Sears, Roebuck & Company's decision to move 6,000 employees from Chicago to a suburb, Hoffman Estates, Ill,, misidentified a concert arena at the new site. It is the Poplar Creek Music Theater.

title: Namibia Guerrillas Offer Election Platform
description: Before 20,000 cheering supporters, Namibian guerrilla leaders made public an election platform today that toned down the rebels' earlier Marxist language.

title: Mets Defeat Reds As Johnson Sizzles
description: The manager, with the first half of the season winding down, sat back in his office chair here and quickly replayed the the last three months in his mind. Dave Johnson was then asked to list his highlights.

title: Campaign Matters; On the Upside And Downside Of Endorsements
description: When Howard Samuels was running for governor 15 years ago, everything, it seemed, was going his way.

title: Greek Communist in a Key Cabinet Post
description: Greece's new conservative Prime Minister, Tzinnis Tzannetakis, swore in an unusual Cabinet today that included a Communist in the key post of Justice Minister and an independent Socialist as Interior Minister.

title: Advertisers Rush Back to the Networks
description: SPURRED by increased automobile advertising and renewed confidence in television's ability to sell, the networks have sold more commercial time in advance for the next season than ever before.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a boycott of California table grapes by New York City supermarket chains misstated the percentage of sales from grapes at Gristede's and Red Apple stores. It is 8 percent of produce sales, not 8 percent of total sales.

title: Fascination for Things Japanese
description: John Burnham Schwartz thought he had it all figured out. He was going to graduate from college, become an investment banker and work 90 hours a week. Then he wrote a senior thesis about a summer he spent in Japan, and that changed everything.

title: Edward Ruhe, Collector of Aboriginal Art
description: Dr. Edward L. Ruhe, a professor of English literature at the University of Kansas who specialized in studies of John Milton, Samuel Johnson, James Agee and films, died of a heart attack Wednesday at his home in Lawrence, Kan. He was 66 years old.

title: An Evening of Percussion
description: The second half of Latin Jazz Jam '89, held Saturday night at Carnegie Hall and part of the JVC Jazz Festival, opened with an explosion of virtuosity, the type that leads straight to a standing ovation. The Fania All-Star Six, led by the elegant Johnny Pacheco, who sang and played flute, tore through a set's worth of compositions that set bass ostinatos, played by the bassist Bobby Valentin, against percussion flurries, or let the group's pianist, Papo Lucca, place slabs of agitated modernist harmony against walls of roiling drums.

title: Deranged, Homeless - and Rich
description: It was one of the darker moments in the Reagan Presidency: the Social Security Administration denied benefits to severely disabled Americans who had every right to Government support. Federal courts eventually forced a reversal of that policy -callous to be sure, but also one that may have inadvertently spawned a creative plan for sheltering homeless mental patients.

title: Franklin J. Schaffner Dies at 69; An Oscar-Winning Film Director
description: The Academy Award winning director Franklin James Schaffner, whose 1970 film ''Patton'' won seven Oscars including best picture, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 69 years old.

title: Metro Datelines; Two Officers Kill Man Who Shot Them
description: Two officers shot and killed a 29-year-old Brooklyn man early yesterday morning after he shot and wounded them slightly, the police said.

title: Our Towns; Moving a Strike From Coal Pits To Suburbia
description: Sam Hughes had never been in Greenwich before. All he knew was that rich people lived here, and executives of the Pittston Company, which runs the coal mines in southwestern Virginia. Mr. Hughes and 1,400 others worked there until they went on strike on April 5.

title: Statue to Women Cast But Pedestal Is Denied
description: The members of American Legion Post 272 in Queens had a grand idea. They would sponsor and finance New York City's first monument to women who had served in the nation's armed forces in wartime.

title: Shift by Japan on Research
description: Japan will admit foreign companies to some Government and industry research projects that have been criticized as benefiting domestic industry, a Government official said last week.

title: Lukens May Face New Counts
description: The local prosecutor's office said today that it might seek felony charges against Representative Donald E. Lukens if he is successful in his appeal of a misdemeanor conviction of having sex with a 16-year-old girl.

title: Medical Science Steps Up Its Assault on Lyme Disease
description: AS the summer tick season reaches its peak, the small but growing epidemic of Lyme disease is spreading in several areas of the country. Reported cases are rising rapidly and the tick that transmits the disease is deploying from its initial strongholds into new areas, including suburban backyards.

title: Coffee Prices Fall; Futures At 8-Year Low
description: The International Coffee Organization suspended all export limits today, foreshadowing a drop in coffee prices worldwide.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 26 about chromium contamination in New Jersey, referring to environmental problems around the country, misstated the location of Times Beach. It is in Missouri.

title: Local TV News Is Reaching Beyond Body Bags
description: To the Editor:

title: SUPREME COURT, 5-4, NARROWING ROE V. WADE, UPHOLDS SHARP STATE LIMITS ON ABORTIONS
description: The Supreme Court today gave states the right to impose sharp new restrictions on abortion in a splintered decision indicating that a majority of the Court no longer considers abortion to be a fundamental constitutional right.

title: Johnson Loses Contract Case
description: A Federal jury returned a $7.9 million verdict last week against Johnson & Johnson in a breach-of-contract suit brought by a Pennsylvania distributor of medical products.

title: VISIT TO POLAND DELAYED BY KOHL
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl has abandoned hopes for a symbolically important state visit to Poland this summer after German and Polish officials failed to agree on an aid package, his spokesman said today.

title: Boeing Prepares Planes for Britain
description: The Boeing Company is scheduled to roll out the first of seven AWAC planes for the British Royal Air Force on July 11 in a ceremony to be attended by Defense Minister George Younger of Britain, the Seattle-based company said. The advanced warning and control system plane is part of a contract valued at $1.3 billion that Boeing won in December 1986.

title: Deborah Carras, Lawyer, Marries
description: The marriage of Deborah Elisabeth Carras, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Carras of Port Washington, L.I., to Michael Zimmerman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Zimmerman of Port Washington, took place yesterday at the Swan Club in Roslyn Harbor, L.I. Justice Vincent R. Balletta Jr. of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn officiated.

title: Further Economic Lag Seen
description: The nation's economy slowed in June for the second consecutive month, according to a monthly report by the association of purchasing managers.

title: Arson at Abortion Clinic
description: A fire broke out at an abortion clinic here only hours before the Supreme Court issued its decision on abortion today, and Capt. Jack Davis of the Fire Department said it was a result of arson. Captain Davis gave no further details about the cause of the fire, which occurred at the Feminist Health Center about 2 A.M. and was confined to a bookcase. He said the police were investigating.

title: Building Up Over All, But Housing Declines
description: Housing construction fell for the fourth straight month in May, but overall construction spending rose 1.3 percent, the Government reported today.

title: Jersey City Grows Angry as It Learns About Chromium Threat
description: The lot next to Hector Rodriguez's cramped automobile-repair shop on Grand Street is fenced in and marked by a warning sign. It reads, ''This area contains dangerous and contaminated materials that are harmful to human life.''

title: U.S. Lodges Protest With China; A Taiwan Journalist Is Arrested
description: The American Embassy today formally protested what it called a ''premeditated'' attack on a foreigners' residential compound here a month ago. It said certain apartments of American diplomats and others were ''deliberately targeted'' by the Chinese Army.

title: Bitter End in Greece
description: The unlikely Greek coalition of conservatives and Communists must count as a perverse achievement for Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou.

title: Markets Closed
description: Stock, credit, currency, futures and commodities markets in the United States, as well as banks and government offices, are closed today in observance of the Fourth of July.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 17 about the continued use of World War II aircraft misstated the position of the International Group for Historic Aircraft Recovery on proposals to ground such aircraft. The group supports the voluntary retirement of planes that are the last of their kind. It does not support the mandatory grounding of the planes.

title: I.B.M. Raises Chip Output
description: The International Business Machines Corporation today stepped up production of a new four-megabit memory chip critical to the development of the computer giant's most sophisticated products.

title: Preventing Data Loss In Summer Months
description: JULY and August are the cruelest months for personal computers. The flow of electricity becomes capricious, surging and ebbing according to the whims of power-hungry air-conditioners. Thunderstorms attack with lightning; grit and grime blow in through open windows, and rising room temperatures put stress on computer components as well as on computer operators.

title: Clark Terry, in the Spotlight, Doing Almost Everything
description: Clark Terry, who has frequently provided an enlivening element in jazz programs that were focused on other musicians, was finally given center stage in a JVC Jazz Festival concert Saturday evening at Town Hall. In Mr. Terry's usual do-it-yourself manner, he produced the concert and by billing it as ''Clark Terry and Friends,'' he shared the evening with many musicians, some well known, some little known.

title: Careers; Data Systems Managers Get Bigger Role
description: CHIEF information officers have become more important at big companies in recent years, says Norman D. Sanders, a managing director at Russell Reynolds Associates Inc., a leading management recruiting firm. Now, he adds, medium-sized and small companies are hiring them.

title: Diana Corp reports earnings for Year to April 1
description: The company said the loss in the latest year resulted primarily from provisions to record additional interest and taxes payable to the IRS on adjustments to prior years' tax returns and interest paid to its Farm House Foods Corp. unit related to Diana Corp.'s treasury stock purchase.

title: Missouri Participants Foresee the Start of a 'War'
description: Officials at Reproductive Health Services, the clinic that challenged a 1986 Missouri law restricting access to abortion, called the Supreme Court decision today upholding the law ''the beginning of a war'' that will be fought for years to come.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Economy

title: Shopping? Don't Forget a Warhol
description: LEAD: Marty Blinder is trying to do for art what Ray Kroc did for the hamburger at McDonald's: sell in volume to the masses and become wealthy in the process.

title: Billionaire Buys 8.3% Of Georgia Gulf Stock
description: Harold C. Simmons, the Texas billionaire, disclosed today that he had acquired an 8.3 percent stake in the Georgia Gulf Corporation, a large producer of commodity and specialty chemicals, spurring speculation of a possible takeover offer.

title: Adelphia Communications Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Oil Concerns Get Request
description: The trustees of two huge government pension funds said yesterday that they had asked the chief executives of six large oil companies to add to their boards a member ''with significant expertise in environmental matters.''

title: Andrei A. Gromyko: Flinty Face of Postwar Soviet Diplomacy
description: Whether Andrei Andreyevich Gromyko was a principal architect of the policies he expounded over nearly three decades as Soviet Foreign Minister, or simply their loyal executor, remains a mystery shrouded in his loyalty to the cause he served so long.

title: Pepsico, to Aid Europe Sales, Buys 2 British Snack Units
description: Seeking to strengthen its European sales of snack foods, Pepsico Inc. announced yesterday that it had paid $1.35 billion for two British companies that were owned by RJR Nabisco Inc. until last month.

title: In the Crowd: Confusion Amid the Confrontation
description: The lawyers, demonstrators and journalists piled out of the Supreme Court building shortly after 10 A.M. today, waving copies of the court's abortion decision as they ran. The crowd milling nervously in front of the building then broke toward them.

title: Patterns
description: Summer Calm on 7th Avenue

title: Marcom Telecommunications Inc reports earnings for Year to Feb 29
NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 2-5 Losses in a Tokyo municipal election were suffered by Prime Minister Uno's Liberal Democratic Party in an extraordinary rebuke to nation's entrenched political establishment. Page 1

title: Canada Curtails $1 Bills
description: The Bank of Canada stopped issuing dollar bills last week in a program to phase in the 11-sided gold-colored coin bearing the image of a loon, the bird that makes its distinctive call in many northern Canadian lakes. The Royal Canadian Mint has 240 million in new $1 coins in circulation and reluctance among Canadians to use them is fading, said Michael Francis, a spokesman. Dollar bills remain legal currency, but their life expectancy under normal use is 9 to 12 months. The $2 bill is now the smallest issued by the Bank of Canada.

title: By Design; The Flag as Fashion
description: Hooray for the red, white and blue. Long may it wave. But please don't wear it if you want to look stylish.

title: Monzon Guilty
description: Carlos Monzon, the former middleweight champion, was convicted of homicide tonight in the February 1988 death of his longtime companion, Alicia Muniz. Monzon, 47 years old, was immediately sentenced to 11 years in prison.

title: How Stories Written for Mother Became Amy Tan's Best Seller
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 3 -- Finding one's voice in writing fiction is crucial for a beginning writer, but for Amy Tan, it seemed as if the voice found her first.

title: L.I. Expressway Shut Eastbound By Hole in Deck
description: A portion of the eastbound Long Island Expressway in western Queens was closed to traffic yesterday afternoon after a two-by-three foot hole developed in an elevated section, dropping concrete and asphalt onto a railroad right-of-way 50 feet below. The closing tied up traffic coming through the Queens-Midtown Tunnel and off the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway.

title: RJR Move on Tobacco
description: RJR Nabisco Inc. has consolidated its domestic tobacco operations as the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company. James W. Johnston, chairman and chief executive of RJR Nabisco's domestic tobacco subsidiary, siad last week that the move would consolidate R.J. Reynolds Tobaco USA, RJR Sales Sports Marketing Enterprises Inc. and R.J. Reynolds Tobacco International Inc. will remain a separate operation, he said, and both companies will report to Louis V. Gerstner Jr., chairman and chief executive of RJR Nabisco.

title: Holiday Today
description: Here are Independence Day holiday schedules. NEW YORK Fireworks: East River, 9:15 P.M., between 23d and 42d Streets. The F.D.R. Drive will be closed between 14th and 49th Streets from 8 P.M. to 1 A.M. Government offices: Closed. Post Offices: Express Mail and special delivery only; main post office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Banks: Closed. Parking: Sunday rules in effect. Sanitation: No collections. Financial markets: Closed. Transportation: Subways and buses on Saturday schedule. L.I.R.R. and Metro-North on holiday schedules. Libraries: Closed. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Closed. Post Offices: Special delivery and Express Mail delivery only. Banks: Option to close. Transportation: N.J. Transit trains and buses on Sunday schedules CONNECTICUT Government offices: Closed. Post Offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Transportation: New Haven Line on holiday schedule.

title: Message to the Chinese
description: To the Editor:

title: Marlene Beth Pitkow Weds Mark L. Kalow
description: At the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, Marlene Beth Pitkow, a doctoral candidate at New York University, was married yesterday to Mark Lawrence Kalow, a strategy consultant in Paris with the computer company Groupe Bull. Rabbi Marshall Meyer performed the ceremony.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about Canada's decision to scale back a military buildup gave an incorrect date in some copies for the installation of Prime Minister Brian Mulroney's Government. It was 1984. Because of an editing error, a passage in some copies also misstated the year the buildup was announced. It was 1987.

title: 'Batman' Sets Sales Record: $100 Million in 10 Days
description: Inexorably swooping down on movie audiences for the second weekend in a row, ''Batman'' continues to dominate the box office. The movie broke another record on Sunday. In just 10 days, the movie, from Warner Brothers, has sold $100.2 million worth of tickets, breaking the record of ''Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade,'' which reached $100 million on its 19th day.

title: Bill Rates Drop in Short Session
description: Treasury bill rates eased yesterday at the weekly auctions of three- and six-month bills. The prices of most Treasury notes and bonds were nominally higher in an abreviated pre-holiday trading session. Dealers in Government securities, who normally do not observe fixed-trading hours, agreed to close at 2 P.M. Most of their offices had operated with sharply reduced staffs.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: The Doctor Needs to See The Doctor
description: rrOn the mound, the pain had been in Dwight Gooden's right arm. Barry Larkin and Kal Daniels had hit home runs for the Cincinnati Reds, and the Mets were losing by 3-0. His head down, the Mets' 24-year-old right-hander had been taken out of Saturday's game at Riverfront Stadium with nobody out in the third inning, his earliest departure in his 174 starts in six seasons. But now, as he sat in the trainer's room off the Mets' clubhouse, others asked him what was wrong. And now the pain was on his face. ''It hurt,'' he said. His right arm had never hurt this much before. His right arm that only two weeks ago had lifted his career record to 100-37, a .730 percentage that is the best in history for any pitcher with 100 or more decisions. His right arm that had won him the nickname Doctor K but that this week would make him undergo a magnetic resonance imaging exam to determine the cause of the pain under his right armpit. His right arm that Doc now needed to take to a doc.

title: HONG KONG HEARS DISQUIETING NEWS
description: In what was billed as the key speech of a three-day visit here, the British Foreign Secretary, Sir Geoffrey Howe, bluntly told anxious Hong Kong residents today that Britain would not give them the right to live in the United Kingdom after the colony is returned to China in 1997.

title: Firecracker Blows Hands Off
description: A Bronx man lost both his hands and his two companions were injured seriously yesterday evening as they poured gunpowder from firecrackers into a pipe to make a bigger firecracker, the police said. The gunpowder exploded at about 6:30 P.M. in the basement apartment at 2166 Bronx Park East where Harry Perlmutter, 18 years old, and his brother Joseph, 29, live, the police said. Dante Bang, 18, of 2079 Wallace Avenue in the Bronx, was also injured. Harry Perlmutter, who lost both hands, was in serious condition at Jacobi Hospital. Joseph Perlmutter lost four fingers on his left hand. Mr. Bang lost a portion of his right index finger. Joseph Perlmutter and Mr. Bang were taken to Montefiore Hospital.

title: LVMH Warrants
description: A Paris commercial court today rejected a claim by small shareholders in LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton, the French luxury goods group, that warrants owned by the group's chairman, Bernard Arnault, were not valid. The court ruled that there was no ground to say that the warrants, crucial to Mr. Arnault's 35 percent voting power in the company, had been issued and placed illegally.

title: Growing Interest In Circle K Buyout
description: The American Financial Corporation said it was ready to discuss the possibility of taking part in a leveraged buyout of the Circle K Corporation. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Carl H. Lindner, American Financial's chairman, said he would be willing to talk with the successful bidder selected by a special committee of Circle K's board.

title: Battle Lines Again Form Around Quebec
description: At the edge of the Plains of Abraham here, bilingual signs in English and French warn visitors away from the cliffs that Gen. James Wolfe's forces scaled in 1759 to capture New France for England.

title: General Nutrition
description: The General Nutrition Corporation, one of the nation's largest retailers of health products, agreed to be acquired by a Boston investment firm for nearly $330 million. General Nutrition said its board had agreed to sell the company to the Thomas H. Lee Company and its affiliate, ML-Lee Acquisition Fund L.P., for $11.50 a share in cash. General Nutrition's shares rose 37.5 cents today, to $10.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Micro HealthSystems reports earnings for Year to March 31
Bus Accident Injures 24 Migrant Workers
description: A bus plunged down a 10-foot embankment after its brakes failed on a hill yesterday, injuring 24 migrant farm workers, the police said.

title: L. B. La Farge, 89, an Architect
description: L. Bancel La Farge, an architect, president of the New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects from 1958 to 1960 and a founding member of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission, died Sunday at his home in Pennswood Village in Newtown, Pa. He was 89 years old.

title: Power Fades for Savings Lobbying Group
description: As the bailout bill that will determine the savings industry's future heads for final consideration, the industry's largest trade association is by most accounts a spent force.

title: Carrington Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company said the loss in the latest quarter included a non-recurring, non-cash expense of $225,000 associated with the issuance preferred stock.

title: Bush, in Polish Press Interview, Urges a Pullout of Soviet Troops
description: In an interview published in Poland in advance of his visit beginning Sunday, President Bush has urged the Soviet Union to withdraw its troops from the country.

title: A Possibility Overlooked in the Rush to Therapy
description: FEW medical devices have been adopted as quickly and widely as the lithotripter, a machine that smashes kidney stones and spares a patient from major surgery. The machine was developed in West Germany, where the first human tests were conducted in 1980.

Revenue represented net revenue.

title:
Celebrating Baseball;
Generation to Generation, the Game Goes On and On
description: LEAD: The cheers and the light show of sparks fade to a void and suddenly a baseball is spinning slowly through the darkness into light. One generation passes to another. The place where the father lofted his game-winning home run, which defeated not only a rival team but all evil as well, is transformed into a windblown prairie field, where the son catches the ball and returns it once again to the father, now retired from the wars, who is teaching his son the elemental secrets of the game - and of family life.

title: Metro Datelines; Man Shot to Death At a Bas Mitzvah
description: A 21-year-old man was shot to death yesterday in a Brooklyn catering hall during a dispute over the music at a bas mitzvah.

title: BRIEFS
description: * AON Corp., Chicago, an insurance company, said its Rollins Burdick Hunter insurance brokerage unit had acquired Bayly, Martin & Fay, Fort Worth, an insurance broker. Terms were not disclosed.

title: U.S. Is Bigger Debtor Nation
description: The United States, already the world's largest debtor, sank an additional $154.2 billion into the red last year as foreign money poured in to plug the nation's balance-of-payments gap.

title: On the West Bank, Hiking Is Political
description: As a loose column of 15 Jewish settlers, outfitted in sun hats and canteens, tramped through this city's narrow alleys with a guard of 11 soldiers on Friday, Yossi Bahir produced a trumpet and began playing a popular Israeli folk song.

title: Metor Datelines; Woman's Body Tied To Leap From a Cab
description: A woman jumped from a moving cab yesterday on the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive and apparently hurled herself to her death over the East River seawall, the police said.

title: Court to Rule on Right to Die in Case of Brain Injury Victim
description: The Supreme Court today accepted its first case involving a brain-damaged patient's right to die, agreeing to decide whether a Missouri couple may remove their daughter from a life-support system.

title: Estonian Journal Runs Solzhenitsyn's 'Gulag'
description: An Estonian literary journal has published the first chapter of Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn's banned epic ''The Gulag Archipelago,'' a newspaper reported. It is believed to be the first publication of the work in the Soviet Union.

title: Books of The Times; How It Was to Those Who Were There
description: You Must Remember This An Oral History of Manhattan From the 1890's to World War II. By Jeff Kisseloff. 622 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $24.95.

title: Reagan Testimony Is Sought
description: Joseph Fernandez, the former Central Intelligence Agency station chief in Costa Rica, is seeking to compel former President Ronald Reagan to testify in his trial, according to court papers filed today.

title: Shooting Suspect Freed After Judge Cuts Bail
description: The man accused of being the subway gunman who asked, ''Remember me?'' just before he fired was released on $2,500 bail yesterday after a state justice in Brooklyn found his earlier bail excessive.

title: Q&A
description: Ducks and Rain Q.When they say ''great weather for ducks,'' I wonder, do ducks really like rain? A.''In the long term, they love it,'' said Trevor L. Lloyd-Evans, an ornithologist who is a staff biologist at the Manomet Bird Observatory, Manomet, Mass.

title: Doctors' Tools Limited In Testing Fetal Viability
description: Doctors have only limited tools to determine fetal viability in the early stage required by the Missouri law that was upheld by the Supreme Court ruling on abortion, medical experts said yesterday.

title: Darwin Had Stress, Not Chagas' Disease
description: To the Editor:

title: On Both Sides, Advocates Predict a 50-State Battle
description: The Supreme Court ruling on abortion will move the issue to the center of the nation's political debate and lead to a bitter 50-state battle that is certain to spill over to the 1990 elections, people on both sides predicted today.

title: Empire Co reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: How Stories Written for Mother Became Amy Tan's Best Seller
description: Finding one's voice in writing fiction is crucial for a beginning writer, but for Amy Tan, it seemed as if the voice found her first.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''The biggest winners today are the tiniest people of all - children within the womb.'' - Archbishop John May of St. Louis, president of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops. [ 1:5. ] ''Now, a woman's access to abortion will become hostage to geography as states enact a patchwork of laws and regulations aimed at blocking abortions.'' - Faye Wattleton, president of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America. [ 1:5. ]

title: Dollar Posts Sharp Decline In Light Pre-holiday Trading
description: The dollar dropped sharply yesterday in thin pre-holiday trading. The decline may have been exaggerated by the light volume.

title: Candidates Vow to Fight Abortion Rule
description: In the wake of a United States Supreme Court ruling yesterday that granted states more powers to curb abortion, most major candidates for mayor of New York City said they would oppose any attempt to limit a woman's right to an abortion.

title: Salt and Sleep
description: Low-sodium diets can cause fitful sleep, researchers have found.

title: Court Opinions on Religious Displays
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today limiting religious displays on government property. Justice Harry A Blackmun dissented and Justices William J. Brennan and Anthony M. Kennedy filed partly concurring and partly dissenting opinions. By Justice Blackmun

title: Jim Backus, 76, Character Actor Best Known as Mr. Magoo, Dies
description: Jim Backus, the beetle-browed actor whose booming voice gave life to the nearsighted cartoon character of ''Mr. Magoo'' and the self-indulgent, ascot-wearing millionaire of ''Gilligan's Island,'' died of pneumonia yesterday in St. John's Hospital and Health Center in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 76 years old.

title: Washington Talk; Congress
description: As the television generation takes charge of the House, many Democrats are hoping for a retooled Congress, with a crisp message of the day, good visuals and snappy lines for the evening news. But bringing Congress into the era of modern communications will not be easy.

title: Joanne Resnic Is Wed
description: Joanne Hope Resnic and Neil Andrew Lippman, both students at the University of Miami Law School and graduates of Washington University, were married yesterday at Congregation Sons of Zion in Holyoke, Mass. Rabbi Mark Finkel performed the ceremony. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Burton S. Resnic of Holyoke. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew D. Lippman of Woodmere, L.I.

title: Ann Irene Kotlar Wed To Dr. Brian I. Collet
description: Ann Irene Kotlar, a daughter of Isadore Kotlar of Brooklyn and the late Esther Kotlar, was married yesterday to Dr. Brian Ira Collet, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Collet of Brooklyn, at Temple Hillel in North Woodmere, L.I. Rabbi Solomon Aidelson officiated.

title: Deals
description: Baseball

title: Air Midwest Spurns Bid
description: The board of Air Midwest Inc. has rejected a $31.1 million offer by Resort Air Inc. to buy the commuter airline.

title: Earthquake Off Aleutians
description: A moderate earthquake was recorded today in the Pacific 70 miles off Adak Island in the Aleutian chain, the United States Geological Survey reported. The tremor had a preliminary magnitude of 5.8 on the Richter scale of released energy, said Don Finley of the Reston, Va., office of the survey. A quake measuring 5 on the scale can cause considerable damage.

title: Yankee Doodle Dandy
description: ''I hope that I shall never hear that tune again!'' That's what General Gage is said to have exclaimed after suffering another defeat at the hands of Colonials who insisted on whistling it in battle. But ''Yankee Doodle'' continued to be sung throughout the Colonies and went on to become the new country's most familiar patriotic song. Familiar but still poorly understood.

title: A Birthday Gift to France: 500 American Feet in Paris
description: The Florida A & M University band calls itself the Marching 100. But it isn't. Its members number 250, not 100. And they don't march. They boogie.

title: Open Mind Wins Filly Triple Crown After a Foul
description: Open Mind yesterday became the seventh winner of the New York filly triple crown, and the first to win it on a disqualification, when she finished second but was placed first after being badly bumped by Nite of Fun in the $283,500 Coaching Club American Oaks at Belmont Park.

title: Wall Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Dodger Hitting Slump Benefits Pirates, 4-2
description: Even though the defending World Series champions are 39-42 at the halfway point, Tom Lasorda is not planning any changes.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Brendle's Inc., Elkin, N.C., a discount retail chain, named Dennis B. Johnson president and chief operating officer, and promoted Jeffrey D. Mick to executive vice president and chief financial officer.

title: How Debate Over Abortion Evolved With Changes in Science and Society
description: While abortion has in recent decades become a wrenching legal and moral question, it has not always been so troubling an issue.

title: Sanchez to Face Graf In Wimbledon Rematch
description: Steffi Graf was in imperial form this sunny afternoon as she provided 15-year-old Monica Seles with a breathless, 6-0, 6-1, lesson in grass-court initiative on Centre Court.

title: New Delhi Prepares Attempt to Control Pervasive Pollution
description: THE Indian capital, the haphazard amalgam of a walled Mogul town, a majestic imperial quarter of British design and a welter of expanding slums that fill up the empty spaces, is also a city of multiple environmental hazards, a World Health Organization report says.

title: Appeal Is Rejected Over Law in Florida On State Language
description: The Supreme Court today rejected appeals by Hispanic residents challenging Florida's designation of English as the state's official language.

title: Soccer Game Moving Again
description: Strong objections by Costa Rica and Guatemala to the selection of Los Angeles as the neutral site for Sunday's World Cup qualifying game between the United States and El Salvador sent FIFA, the world governing body of soccer, searching for a new site yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Thursday comparing the health-care systems of Canada and the United States omitted the names of two information sources. The information about medical technology was from the American Hospital Association and the American Medical Association.

title: President of Tofutti Brands Plans to Go Out on His Own
description: Francis I. Mullin 3d, the president and chief operating officer of Tofutti Brands Inc., plans to leave the maker of nondairy frozen desserts on Aug. 1 to go out on his own.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Chief of Imperial Corp. Quits Amid Loan Woes
description: LEAD: The Imperial Corporation of America, a San Diego savings and loan holding company that made a painful foray into automobile financing, said its president and chief executive had stepped down.

title: A Tale of Two Ballplayer Generations
description: To the Editor:

title: Higuera Puts Yanks In Loss Column Again
description: In the four years that have come and gone in Ted Higuera's big league career, one thing has remained constant: a domination of the Yankees.

title: Making Mahler Loved in France
description: Who invented Gustav Mahler? During the last 25 years or so, most musicians would say Leonard Bernstein, who started a Mahler binge in the 1960's and has shown no signs of letting up. But close on his heels has been Henry-Louis de la Grange, who became hypnotized by the composer around the same time.

title: Plan to Restore a Park in Queens Is Scaled Down
description: After their first proposal drew vigorous opposition from community and environmental groups, Federal park officials have issued a scaled-down plan for rehabilitating an oceanfront park in Queens that is part of the national park system.

title: Perceptronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and included a tax credit of $157,800.

title: Merrill Lynch Resignation
description: Stanislas Yassukovich, the chairman of European and Middle Eastern operations for Merrill Lynch & Company, has resigned but will continue to serve as an adviser and director at the firm, Merrill said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Thursday about the British philosopher Sir Alfred Jules Ayer misstated the origin of another philosopher, Ludwig Wittgenstein. He was Austrian, not German.

title: Indexing Capital Gains to Inflation Is in the Spirit of Tax Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: New Argentine Head Faces a Crisis
description: President-elect Carlos Saul Menem will probably find few if any dollars in the central bank to use in Argentina's trade and other international business when he takes office Saturday.

title: Mayotte Takes Wind From Chang's Sails
description: The telltale glint of invincibility disappeared from the eyes of Michael Chang today almost as soon as his match with Tim Mayotte, a perennial Wimbledon quarterfinalist, began.

title: A Handful of Touchy Issues Continue to Plague Charter Panel
description: After three months of debate, the 15 members of the Charter Revision Commission have agreed on a fundamental reshaping of New York City's government. But they have not resolved a handful of politically divisive issues that could yet make their work hard.

title: Annette Gorsky, Lawyer, Married
description: Annette Gorsky, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Gorsky of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Dr. Neil Stanley Shachter, a son of Mrs. Joseph Greenbaum of Philadelphia and the late Leon Shachter of New York, were married yesterday at Congregation Beth Shalom in Lawrence, L.I. Rabbi Philip Weinberger performed the ceremony.

title: Barbarous Executions
description: To the Editor:

title: Lebanese Muslims Offer Deal to Christians
description: Lebanese Muslim and leftist militias backed by Syria offered tonight to lift a land and air blockade of the country's embattled Christian enclaves, but called for major concessions in return.

title: Sunlight Is Tested For Purifying Water
description: RESEARCHERS at Sandia National Laboratories in Albuquerque, N.M., are testing the use of concentrated sunlight to destroy toxic discharges. Candidates for destruction include dioxins, pesticides, munitions, dyes, cyanides, solvents and polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCB's.

title: Great Country Bank reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Chess
description: Six Soviets and one American got what they came to Moscow for -qualification into the prestigious World Cup Tournament cycle for 1990-91.

title: No Place For Lucas
description: Anyone bringing an employment discrimination suit will find it significantly harder to win, as a result of recent decisions by the reactionary Supreme Court that Ronald Reagan bequeathed us. But these rulings also have given the Senate new cause to reject another of President Bush's nominees - William Lucas to head the civil rights division of the Justice Department.

title: Court Rejects 3 Bids to Curb Punitive Damages Court Rejects 3 Bids to Curb Awards Against Companies
description: The Supreme Court today rejected three appeals in cases involving punitive-damage awards in personal-injury lawsuits against companies.

title: Michigan Teacher to Head Education Union
description: Keith B. Geiger, who for the last six years has served as the National Education Association's vice president and as a philosophical ally of Mary Hatwood Futrell, was elected today to succeed her as president of the nation's largest union.

title: Gary Hendler, Lawyer And Film Producer, 50
description: Gary Hendler, a tax lawyer for entertainers who became head of Tri-Star Pictures and then an independent film producer, died of cancer Thursday. He was 50 years old.

title: Mets Beat Deshaies For the First Time
description: Jim Deshaies, who pitched a shutout when he last faced the Mets, had neatly piled up five scoreless innings tonight. Deshaies, who had never lost to the Mets in his career, appeared prepared never to allow them to so much as score.

title: Holiday Box
description: Because of holiday production requirements, The Times is printed today in two sec-tions. Science Times beings on page 15, Busines Day on page 40.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
A Buyout Partnership Is Established in Dallas
description: LEAD: The breakup of Hicks & Haas, the leveraged buyout group based in Dallas, has produced a new partnership and a new player, John R. Muse.

title: Washington Talk; This President Relaxes By Wearing Others Out
description: In the summer of 1954, while President Dwight D. Eisenhower was on a fishing trip to the mountains in Colorado, Herbert Hoover stopped by for grilled steaks.

title: Excerpts From Court Decision on the Regulation of Abortion
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today upholding Missouri's restrictive abortion law. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist wrote the majority opinion. Concurring opinions were filed by Justices Sandra Day O'Connor and Antonin Scalia. Justices Harry A. Blackmun and John Paul Stevens filed dissenting opinions. FROM THE OPINION By Chief Justice Rehnquist

title: Egypt's Debt Prospect
description: A senior International Monetary Fund official ended a weeklong visit to Cairo on Saturday saying he was optimistic about prospects of reaching an accord on rescheduling Egypt's heavy foreign debt. But Abdel Shakour Shaalan, the head of the I.M.F.'s Middle East division, said there could still be issues to be resolved before the I.M.F. would approve an accord. Egypt's foreign debts total $45 billion to $50 billion.

title: Buckeyes Finally Find A New Head Coach
description: After a nationwide search, Ohio State promoted from within yesterday when Randy Ayers was named to succeed Gary Williams as the Buckeyes' head basketball coach.

title: U.S., Liable on Loans, May Cut Shaky Housing Projects for Elderly
description: The Department of Housing and Urban Development is considering proposals to overhaul or terminate a program that has left the Government liable for hundreds of millions of dollars in mortgages on troubled housing projects for the elderly, Federal housing officials said today.

title: Nicole Schreiber Weds R. A. Agus
description: At the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I., Nicole B. Schreiber, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Avram H. Schreiber of Brooklyn, and Raanan A. Agus, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Saul G. Agus of Englewood, N.J., were married last evening. Rabbi Shmuel Golden performed the ceremony.

title: Dow Up 12.71; Volume a Low 68.9 Million
description: In the quietest trading in more than two and a half years, stock prices rose moderately yesterday and the Dow Jones industrial average rose 12.71 points, to 2,452.77.

title: Bridge
description: If the cognoscenti were asked to vote on the strongest father-and-son partnership of all time, they would focus on two families with world championship credentials.

title: Article 048489 -- No Title
description: A Roman Catholic priest, upset by two suicides and an accidental shooting death in his parish during the last month, is offering to pay $50 out of his own pocket for each gun people surrender to him.

title: Nancy M. Tanner, 56, Anthropology Writer
description: Nancy Makepeace Tanner, an anthropologist and author of ''On Becoming Human,'' which deals with food-gatherers in early human evolution, died of a heart attack June 20 at the home of her brother-in-law in Tucson, Ariz. She was 56 years old.

title: Rain Forest Worth More if Uncut, Study Says
description: PROVIDING evidence that environmentalists and Brazilian officials say could slow the pace of large-scale clearing of tropical forests, a team of scientists has found that rain forests are worth more if left standing than if cut for timber or cattle grazing.

title: Christina Reid Is a Bride in Chicago
