Here is a listing of some of them. VAUXHALL GARDENS, mid-19th century. A summer entertainment area, offering music and theater, that existed briefly near the Bowery. JONES WOOD, late 19th century. Shooting contests and beer halls filled this 150-acre park on the East River between 70th and 75th Streets. SEA LION PARK, 1895-1902. Though started as a trained-seal show by Capt. Billy Boyton, this Coney Island park (north of Surf Avenue) in Brooklyn came to include America's first ''shoot-the-chutes'' ride. PALISADES AMUSEMENT PARK, 1895-1971. This famous New Jersey park, which boasted the world's largest salt-water swimming pool, the first Tunnel of Love and more than 200 other rides and attractions, was opened by the Bergen Traction Company, a trolley line trying to attract riders. The park's 36-acre site overlooking the Hudson River in Fort Lee and Cliffside Park is now occupied by apartment buildings. STEEPLECHASE PARK, 1897-1965. This Coney Island park, owned by the impresario George Tilyou, included one of America's first great Ferris wheels, a cyclorama, Venetian canals and steeplechase, elephant and ''shoot-the-chutes'' rides. Rebuilt after a 1907 fire, it added a Pavilion of Fun that featured a Human Pool Table and Human Roulette Wheel. The now-rusted 260-foot Parachute Jump was moved to Steeplechase after the 1939 World's Fair. There have been recent proposals to build a new Steeplechase amusement park on the site, between Surf Avenue and the Boardwalk, from West 15th to West 21st Streets. ROCKAWAYS PLAYLAND, 1901-1986. This long-running seaside park in Queens (near Beach 97th Street and Rockaway Beach Boulevard) - built by L. A. Thompson, ''father of the roller coaster'' - included a huge wooden roller coaster and Olympic-size pool. It was sold in 1986 to developers building a condominium complex. LUNA PARK, 1903-1946. Luna Park, noted for its spectacular, fanciful architecture and illusion rides, was built by Frederic W. Thompson and Elmer Dundy on the 22-acre site of Sea Lion Park on Coney Island and is the true precursor of Disneyland. Its most famous rides included a Trip to the Moon, a Trip to the North Pole, 20,000 Leagues Under the Sea, the Canals of Venice, Mountain Torrent and Dragon's Gorge. DREAMLAND, 1904-1911. This Coney Island park (where the Aquarium now stands), built after Luna Park's success, included a Lilliputian Village with 300 midgets, sleighs riding across snow-covered Alps, a 300-foot Tower of Seville and the world's largest ballroom, situated on an ocean pier. FREEDOMLAND, U.S.A., 1960-1964. The most unusual feature of this short-lived park - where Co-op City now stands in the Bronx - was that its physical shape was roughly that of the continental United States. A tableau of reconstructed American history, it included a Civil War battle, Indian settlements, the Chicago fire and the San Francisco earthquake.

title: Review/Film; 'The Music Teacher,' Belle Epoque Opera Tale
description: If you didn't know that ''The Music Teacher'' was based on an original story, you'd swear it was a poor adaptation of some subtle Henry James tale. In this sleek literary film, the Belgian director Gerard Corbiau aims to capture the psychological tensions, emotional undercurrents and relentless gamesmanship of the opera world at the turn of the century - all the elusive inner struggles masked by any eloquent artist. But the film is as pretty, shallow and uninvolving as a painted backdrop.

title: Restaurants
description: Gage & Tollner

title: Another Voice Raised in Praise of Singing
description: To the Editor:

title: A Retirement Set at Kellogg
description: The Kellogg Company said yesterday that its vice chairman, Robert L. Nichols, planned to retire on Aug. 1 after 44 years with the breakfast food company based in Battle Creek, Mich.

title: Government Issues Directive For Airport Bomb Detectors
description: The Federal Aviation Administration issued a rule today to require airlines to install bomb detectors capable of spotting plastic explosives in checked baggage at 40 American and foreign airports.

title: Review/Art; 'Mountains of the Mind, Chinese Landscapes at Met
description: ''Mountains of the Mind (Part II): Nature and Self in Later Chinese Landscape Painting'' is the second and more spectacular half of the Metropolitan Museum of Art's survey of Chinese landscape painting from the 10th to the 20th century. Assembled almost entirely from the Met's own collection, the exhibition is intended to underline the strengths of that collection, as well as to call attention to areas - most obviously the 18th and 19th centuries - that need to be developed.

title: Excerpts From Speech By Gorbachev in France
description: Following are excerpts from President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's address yesterday to the Council of Europe in Strasbourg, France, as provided in translation by the Soviet press agency Tass:

title: New York Court Defines Family To Include Homosexual Couples
description: New York's highest court today expanded the legal definition of a family, holding that a gay couple who had lived together for a decade could be considered a family under New York City's rent-control regulations.

title: A.T.&T., MCI Win Contracts
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the MCI Communications Corporation, the nation's largest long-distance carriers, each announced yesterday that it had won a multimillion-dollar contract for telecommunications services.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY BIG FISH IN A BIG POND

title: Bing Steps Forward To Help Detroit
description: Dave Bing, who led the Pistons in scoring five times from 1966 to 1975, is trying to assist Detroit these days. Bing, now the owner of a steel company in Detroit, said yesterday he was seeking to raise $2 million to restore to the Detroit public schools the sports programs dropped by the Board of Education recently as part of a $50 million budget-cutting plan. Interscholastic sports made up $1.4 million of the cuts.

title: Steel Pension Is Extended
description: Retirees of the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation will continue to receive supplemental pension benefits under a Federal court ruling. United States District Judge Paul Simmons on Wednesday approved a request to extend the payments, which expired last month for 965 retirees.

title: Drexel Chief a U.S. Witness At Princeton/Newport Trial
description: Frederick H. Joseph, the chief executive of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., yesterday made the first of what are expected to be several appearances as a Government witness in trials stemming from investigations of crime on Wall Street.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 12 about the disappearance of Peter G. Schmidt, a lawyer and entrepreneur, misstated the ownership of a duplex maisonette at 775 Park Avenue. It is owned by Mr. Schmidt's first wife, Dina Schmidt, not by him.

title: A Summer Campaign For Coke's Classic
description: Coca-Cola announced yesterday that it would team up with the Fox Broadcasting Company in a huge marketing promotion starting this week. Cineplex Odeon theaters and Westwood One Radio Networks will also participate in the campaign to promote Coca-Cola Classic as the ''official soft drink of summer.''

title: Janos Kadar of Hungary Is Dead at 77
description: Janos Kadar, who rose to power in Hungary as the Soviet Army crushed the 1956 uprising and who gradually won a measure of acceptance by softening Communist dogma and presiding over a prosperity and tolerance unusual in Eastern Europe, died yesterday in Budapest. He was 77 years old.

title: West's First Start Stops Early As Reds Roar Over the Mets
description: David West's numbers were as follows: 4 innings pitched, 7 hits, 7 runs, 3 home runs, 1 wild pitch and 1 hit batsman. It was, to be sure, an ugly line for the box score. And in that, it's a line that's growing terribly old for the Mets.

title: Carter Hawley Cuts Staff in New York
description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. of Los Angeles said it would reduce its market services staff in New York and join the Associated Merchandising Corporation for services in buying, market coverage and research. Carter Hawley will become a shareholder in Associated, a retail consulting, marketing and merchandising organization owned by various retail chains.

title: Harry Grossman, 77, Drug Program Founder
description: Harry A. Grossman, a lawyer who was a founder of Daytop Village, the narcotics treatment program, died of a heart attack on Sunday in Quogue, L.I., where he was on a family visit. He was 77 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: For the Record
description: Image of the Bar I

title: Vienna Talks: Complex Array of Arms Issues Plus an East of Many Voices
description: To appreciate the complexity of the effort to reduce Europe's conventional arms, take disarmament at its most basic as two adversaries trying to agree to lay down their knives.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In the context of eviction, a more realistic, and certainly equally valid, view of a family includes two adult lifetime partners whose relationship is long-term and characterized by an emotional and financial commitment and interdependence.'' - Judge Vito J. Titone, for the majority of the New York State Court of Appeals. [ A1:2. ]

title: GORBACHEV SPURNS THE USE OF FORCE IN EASTERN EUROPE
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today implicity renounced the use of force against other Soviet-bloc nations and offered to reduce Soviet short-range missiles ''without delay'' if NATO agreed to negotiations on such systems.

title: San Rafael Journal; Homeless Are Greeted With Food for Psyche
description: Anywhere else, an invasion of panhandlers on a street of pleasant shops would inspire shopkeepers to hire a security guard. But here in the heart of Marin County, where promoting psychic health is a civic duty as sacred as voting, the Downtown Merchants Association has hired a psychological counselor.

title: Egypt Spurring Investment
description: The Egyptian parliament has approved a law to encourage foreign and domestic investment in the private sector by offering tax breaks and simplifying bureaucratic controls.

title: City Moves To Clean Up Tompkins Sq. After Raid
description: After a day and a night of confrontations between more than 250 police officers and hundreds of residents of the Lower East Side, no trace remained yesterday of a shantytown of 40 tents and shacks in Tompkins Square Park.

title: Travelers to Sell A Mortgage Unit
description: The Travelers Corporation said it had agreed to sell its mortgage services subsidiary to the unit's management and a partner. Terms were not disclosed. Hyperion Partners L.P., a private, New York-based investment partnership specializing in the housing, real estate and financial services industries will join the management group in the acquisition of the unit, Travelers Mortgage Services Inc.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums #46TH ANNUAL CHILDREN'S ART EXHIBITION, by children in the New York metropolitan area and in Israel, with the theme ''We Want a Perfect World, Not a Wasteland,'' Central Queens Y Fine Arts Gallery, 67-09 108th Street, Forest Hills, 8:45 A.M. to 6:45 P.M. Sundays; 9 A.M. to 9:45 P.M. Mondays through Thursdays, and 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. Fridays. Through Aug. 27. Admission: free. Information: (718) 268-5011. NEW CANAAN (CONN.) NATURE CENTER, a 40-acre site, with trails open from sunrise to sunset, exhibition buildings and greenhouses, 9:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Tuesdays through Saturdays and 12:30 to 4:30 P.M. Sundays, at Oenoke Ridge. Free. Information: (203) 966-9577. ''THE RED SHOES,'' a story by Hans Christian Andersen told by Carol Lewis, and Andersen's ''Collar,'' told by Marcia Lane, 11 A.M. Saturday at the Hans Christian Andersen statue in Central Park, 72d Street and Fifth Avenue. Free. ''CINDERELLA,'' a musical version by the Papageno Puppet Theater with Susan Delery Whedon, who is to sing during the performance accompanied by recorded music. 1 P.M. Saturdays and Sundays, at the West 72d Street Studio, 131 West 72d Street. For young children. Admission: $4. Reservations: 874-3297. BARTLETT ARBORETUM, a 63-acre garden, 8:30 A.M. to sunset daily, at 151 Brookdale Road, Stamford, Conn. Information: (203) 322-6971. THEODORE ROOSEVELT SANCTUARY, a preserve of 12 wooded acres, with trees and vines planted to attract birds, 134 Cove Road, Oyster Bay, L.I. Suggested admission: $1.50. Information: (516) 922-3200.

title: Market Place; Money Managers Top S.&P. 500
description: FOR four of the last six years, institutional money management firms have, on average, been unable to outperform the stock market, at least as it is measured by the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. But so far this year, the money managers are slightly ahead of the market.

title: Shamir's Shift on Vote Angers P.L.O.
description: A Palestine Liberation Organization official said today that conditions agreed upon by the Likud party for negotiations on Palestinian elections amounted to the annexation of the Israeli-occupied territories.

title: Carnation Halts Formula Claims
description: The Carnation Company agreed yesterday to drop several claims from advertisements for its infant formula after nine states had accused the company of falsely suggesting that the formula would not cause an allergic reaction. In the agreement, Carnation said it would stop describing the product, called Good Start H.A., as hypoallergenic.

title: Accounts
description: * Flamingo Hilton Reno, to Ogilvy & Mather, Los Angeles, and Pan Pacific Hotels and Resorts, to Ogilvy & Mather, Hawaii, with a combined budget of $6 million.

title: High Cholesterol Poses Heart Risk in a Third of Adults, New Study Says
description: More than one-third of American adults need to lower their blood cholesterol because they are at high risk of coronary disease, a new study has found.

title: Leonard-Hearns Possible
description: Is there a third Sugar Ray Leonard-Thomas Hearns match in the works? On Friday, Leonard appeared on Arsenio Hall's late-night television talk show in Los Angeles and challenged Hearns to fight again.

title: Oil Spill Documents Are Safe, Exxon Says
description: The Exxon Company U.S.A. said today that records and documents from the nation's worst oil spill are intact even though computer backup tapes were erased earlier this month.

title: N.F.L. Fails To Approve Finks as Leader
description: In a bold and unexpected move, a bloc of 11 National Football League owners tonight repeatedly voted to abstain each time that Jim Finks was nominated as commissioner, thus causing Pete Rozelle, the current commissioner, to adjourn the meeting after more than six hours. Rozelle said in a news conference afterward that he would call another owners' meeting with seven days' notice to try again to find his replacement. Rozelle set no timetable for the meeting.

title: Health-Care Workers Reach Pact for Catholic Hospitals
description: In a settlement that will increase pressure on private hospitals in New York City, the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York's hospitals agreed yesterday to a contract with the state's largest health-care workers union.

title: Collins Dismissed as Bulls' Coach
description: In a move that stunned the city's basketball fans, the Chicago Bulls yesterday dismissed Doug Collins as their coach.

title: Results Plus
description: CYCLING LeMond Leads Tour: Greg LeMond moved into the lead of the Tour de France yesterday by capturing an individual time trial. LeMond, who has been bothered by injuries since he became the first American to win the Tour in 1986, took the 45-mile time trial in 1 hour 38 minutes 12 seconds to gain the the leader's yellow jersey. LeMond, who was 13th over all entering the stage, has a five-second margin over Laurent Fignon of France, the winner in 1983 and 1984, who took third in the time trial with 1:39:09. Thierry Marie of France is third, 20 seconds behind. The mountain climbs of the Pyrenees and the Alps are ahead, and LeMond is wary of them. ''There are still some moments where I still lack some confidence,'' LeMond said.(AP) GOLF Trio on Top: Paul Azinger, Bob Gilder and Kenny Knox led by one stroke after shooting 65's, six-under par, in the first round of the Greater Hartford Open in Cromwell, Conn. Five players were tied at 66 and 11 at 67 on the 6,786-yard course, which was softened by rain Wednesday. ''This is absolutely as easy as a golf course can play,'' said Roger Maltbie, who shot 66. Eighty-two players broke par and Azinger's 65 matched his low score for his previous 67 rounds this year. (AP) MACCABIAH GAMES Record Day for United States: Amer-ican swimmers won 12 of 18 medals and broke four Maccabiah Games records yesterday in Tel Aviv. Rick Aronberg won the 200-meter freestyle, edging John Witchel in a record time of 1 minute 52.51 seconds. Ruth Grodsky, another American, broke two Maccabiah records, including her own mark in the 200-meter breaststroke, set in 1985. She was timed in 2:40:29. Grodsky also broke the record in the 400-meter individual medley with a time of 5:01:75. Joshua Mikeseld also set a record by winning the 100-meter backstroke in 58:08.(AP)

title: AFTER WILD TRIP, STORM BREAKS UP
description: The remnants of a tropical storm called Allison spawned a grumble of thunderstorms and showers along a saturated Eastern Seaboard yesterday before passing into the record books, but meteorologists and residents of a score of states will not soon forget the renegade tempest.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Exact Words; Judge's Plea: Write English, Not Legalese
description: Judge John C. Godbold, director of the United States Judicial Center, in the spring issue of Litigation:

title:
About Real Estate;
Town Houses to Go Up On a Weehawken Pier
description: LEAD: A concrete pier in Weehawken, N.J., that is almost as long as the Empire State Building is high is being developed into a complex of five-story town houses by the Coastal Group of Colts Neck, N.J.

title: Probation and Fine for Jefferies
description: Boyd L. Jefferies, the former broker who helped shape some of the biggest corporate takeovers of the 1980's, was sentenced yesterday to five years' probation and fined $250,000 on two counts of securities law violations stemming from the Government's crackdown on Wall Street corruption.

title: Review/Dance; Surprises From France As Statues Perform
description: Ris et Danceries, the French dance company that specializes in the Baroque period, never ceases to surprise.

title: Can S.I. Flourish Without New York City?
description: Would Staten Island, severed from New York City, manage on its own? Some residents think the community would not merely manage, it would flourish: Freed of the financial burden of the city's crumbling roads and bridges and its dependent poor, they argue, Staten Island would be able to lower taxes or improve public services.

title: Yanks Pack a Victory On Bus Ride to Boston
description: At a point in the season when the .500 mark was beginning to look like some sort of barrier in the Bronx, when consistency had become as difficult to deal with as nearly everyone else in the American League East, the Yankees won a game yesterday they hoped would gain significance.

title: Kraft Becomes Big Loser In Its Botched Promotion
description: Kraft Inc. is getting ready to pay out $3 million to $4 million to thousands of customers who submitted winning entries in its botched ''Ready to Roll'' promotion, a spokeswoman for the company says.

title: Our Towns; An Entrepreneur Takes a Stand On Lemonade
description: 'Lemonade! Popcorn! Soda!''

title: 'Twelfth Night' Opening Delayed Till Sunday
description: The formal opening of the New York Shakespeare Festival's production of ''Twelfth Night,'' at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, has been rescheduled from last night to Sunday night at 8 o'clock. Previews will continue tonight and tomorrow, weather permitting.

title: Jazz in Brooklyn
description: Celebrate Brooklyn is to present a weekend of jazz beginning tonight at the Prospect Park Band Shell, near Prospect Park West and Ninth Street. Lester Bowie, a trumpeter, will lead his band Brass Fantasy tonight, on a double bill with the saxophonist Bill Saxton and his quartet. Tomorrow, the alto saxophonist Steve Coleman and his jazz-funk group Five Elements will share a bill with the composer Gretchen Langheld and her group House Afire. And on Sunday, the Persuasions vocal group and the trumpeter Marvin (Hannibal) Peterson with his quintet are to perform with the Brooklyn Philharmonic Orchestra, in a program that includes Mr. Peterson's ''Flames of South Africa.'' The concerts begin at 8 P.M.; admission is $1. Information: (718) 768-0799.

title: Bush Rebuffs Gorbachev's Move For Swifter Cuts in Nuclear Arms
description: President Bush said today that he would not be drawn into a faster timetable for cutting short-range nuclear weapons in Europe by Soviet blandishments or into a personality contest with Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: Shamir's Defeat, Shamir's Choice
description: By capitulating to the right wing of his Likud Party, Prime Minister Shamir of Israel has made the Middle East quiver. Likud's new hard-line position on talks with Palestinians could unhinge the coalition Government with Labor, ignite even more Arab violence in the occupied territories, spark confrontation with the United States and block the direct Israeli-Palestinian negotiations that seemed so likely only days ago.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Abortion and the G.O.P.
description: Despite loud cries of triumph and tragedy, the Supreme Court in Missouri v. Webster made no change whatever in abortion law or in a woman's constitutional right to choose an abortion.

title: Japan Arrest Over Export
description: The Japanese police today arrested a company president who has been accused of illegally exporting to East Germany a rare metal that can be used in nuclear submarines, a police spokesman said.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation is selling $250 million of subordinated notes, due in 2001, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Where to Find The Major Parks
description: Here are the hours and admission prices for major amusement parks in the New York area. ASTROLAND, Surf Avenue at West 10th Street, Coney Island section of Brooklyn. Accessible by subway, via the BMT B and N lines and the IND D and F lines, and by car, via the Belt Parkway to Exit 7S (Ocean Parkway South). A pay-one-price ticket, for $11.99, provides unlimited use of most rides during specified five-hour periods. (One is limited to five Cyclone rides, and go-karts are an additional $3.) Individual rides are $1 to $3, with Kiddie Park rides $1.50 each. Astroland is open daily from noon until after midnight, until a week after Labor Day. Information: (718) 265-2100. RYE PLAYLAND, Rye, N.Y. Thirty miles from New York City by car via the New England Thruway (Interstate 95) to Exit 19 (Playland Parkway). An 11-ride ticket book is $12.50. Rowboats and paddle boats are $5 to $8 an hour; miniature golf is $1.50; pool admission is $3.50 ($1.50 for children); beach admission is $2.25; Friday night dance concerts are $5, and parking is $2.50 on weekdays and $4 on weekends. The Metro-North Commuter Railroad offers round-trip transportation from Grand Central Terminal, along with an 11-ride ticket book, for $15.50. Rye Playland is open Fridays and Saturdays from noon to midnight, and Tuesdays through Thursdays and Sundays from noon to 11 P.M., through Labor Day. Information: (914) 921-0370. ACTION PARK, Vernon Valley, N.J. Fifty miles from New York City via Interstate 80 west to Routes 23 and 515 north to Route 94. Admission, including unlimited use of all rides except the Grand Prix cars (which are $2 a lap), is $21; $16 for children less than 4 feet tall on weekends and $15 on weekdays, and parking is free. Action Park is open daily from 10 A.M. to 9 P.M., through Labor Day. (Hours after Labor Day vary.) Information: (201) 827-2000. GREAT ADVENTURE, Jackson, N.J. Sixty miles from New York City via the New Jersey Turnpike to Interstate 195 east (Exit 7A) to Exit 16 (Mount Holly-Freehold). Admission, including the Safari and unlimited use of all rides, is $23; $15 for children 54 inches tall or less, and $11.50 for people age 55 or older. (Safari-only admission is $9.) Season passes are $50; $35 for children, and $150 for a family of four. Parking is $3. Great Adventure is open Fridays and Saturdays from 10 A.M. to midnight, through Labor Day, and weekdays from 10 A.M. to 10 P.M. (From Labor Day through October, open weekends only; hours vary). Information: (201) 928-3500.

title: RJR Nabisco Will Maintain Guarantees on Swiss Bonds
description: RJR Nabisco Inc. has chosen not to ask Swiss courts to decide whether its $25 billion buyout by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company constituted a reorganization of the company, the Swiss Bank Corporation said today.

title: Bankers See Progress In Mexican Debt Talks
description: There are signs of progress in the negotiations between Mexico and its banks on a debt-reduction package, as the talks have moved from the committee level to the top echelons in an effort to reach a compromise, bankers said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A cast listing yesterday with a theater review of the Riverside Shakespeare Company's production of ''Cyrano de Bergerac'' in Manhattan misattributed the music and lyrics. They are by Dan Levy; Shoukoufeh-Azari designed the makeup.

title: Review/Film; Documentary Look at Pina Bausch
description: It is perfectly fitting that Chantal Akerman, the Belgian experimental film maker whose work is being shown retrospectively at Film Forum 2, should be attracted to the dance-theater of Pina Bausch and her international multi-lingual company from Wuppertal, West Germany. Both artists create reflective, large-scale visual compositions that convey a powerful but ambiguous emotional intensity. In examining their own compositions, both artists fixedly concentrate on nuances of image and behavior that tap into the unconscious mind.

title: Contract Trades in Chicago
description: More than 100 brokers and local traders piled into a new pit at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange today to trade in a contract structured to help banks and other financial institutions lock in interest-rate spreads across countries.

title: Students Need Attention at Every Level, Especially High School
description: To the Editor:

title: Janos Kadar Dies at 77
description: Janos Kadar, who rose to power in Hungary as the Soviet Army crushed the 1956 uprising and was party chief for 32 years, died in Budapest. He was 77 years old. Page A12.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Ollie's Noodle Soup and Grille

title: News Summary
description: International A3-7 Mikhail Gorbachev renounced force against other Soviet-bloc nations and offered ''without delay'' to reduce Soviet short-range missiles if NATO agreed to negotiations. Page A1 In Israel, at least 14 were killed when an Arab bus passenger grabbed the steering wheel, screamed ''God is great!'' and sent the bus plunging more than 400 feet. A1 A settlement in Cambodia that left the Vietnamese-installed Government in place would be accepted by President Bush provided that Prince Norodom Sihanouk, has ''real power'' as head of state. A1 For nuclear weapons cuts in Europe, President Bush said that he would not be drawn into a faster timetable by Soviet blandishments or into a personality contest with Mikhail S. Gorbachev. A6 News analysis: Vienna's arms talks have taken on a sense of urgency since President Bush recently set a target of 6 to 12 months for an agreement between East and West. A6 Lech Walesa and General Jaruzelski are having difficulties because of Solidarity's landslide election victory last month, Mr. Walesa said. A3 Poland assailed West Germany in unusually strong terms over the failure to reach agreement on an aid package and over comments by a Bonn Government minister. A3 The Likud conditions for negotiations on Palestinian elections amounted to the annexation of the Israeli-occupied territories, a Palestine Liberation Organization official said. A7 Tokyo is trying to build its image in preparation for the economic summit conference in Paris next week. The Government is reported to be working on several initiatives. D2 China rejected an American protest against the shooting of a diplomatic compound in Beijing, and the Government published new attacks on Zhao Ziyang, that may presage criminal proceedings against him. A3 Chile's transition to democracy has been eased by agreements within the main opposition coalition and between the opposition and the Government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet. A5 National A8-11, B4 A housing program for the elderly that has cost the government $119 million in losses was suspended by Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp. A1 News analysis: The Supreme Court term that ended Monday was a watershed in the Court's modern history. For the first time in a generation, a conservative majority was in a position of control. A1 Efforts to hire Robert B. Fiske as deputy attorney general were abandoned by Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, who yielded to conservative Republican senators. A1 Two giant accounting firms announced merger plans and two more confirmed they were holding merger talks, as they sought greater international muscle to compete in serving multinational clients. A1 A gradual ban on asbestos products was announced by the Environmental Protection Agency. Over the next seven years the E.P.A. will bar the manufacture, use and export of most asbestos products. A8 Treatment to lower blood cholesterol is needed by more than one-third of American adults because they are at high risk of coronary disease, a new study has found. A8 The danger of a recession has replaced inflation as the chief threat to the economy in the minds of many economists and even at the Federal Reserve. D1 A grumble of storms and showers passed along a saturated Eastern Seaboard before passing into the record books, but the tempest will not soon be forgotten. A11 Dean Lechner's journey home ended early yesterday when he died of AIDS, and the bells of an old church in his hometown of Waseca, Minn., chimed 35 times in tribute to the years of his life. A8 Washington Talk B4 Stephen Studdert is often criticized for arranging fuzzy Presidential trips that garner little national press coverage. But the events director doesn't seem to mind. Bush's response to the High Court's flag decision Regional B1-3, B16 A homosexual couple can be a family under New York City's rent-control rules, the New York Court of Appeals found. It was the first such decision by a state's top court. A1 Single-room occupancy housing may be converted or demolished, the state's highest court ruled, striking a blow to efforts to prevent the spread of homelessness. B1 200 homeless people lost their homes as their makeshift shacks in Tompkins Square Park were demolished in a suprise raid by 250 police officers and park workers. B1 In New Jersey, the abortion conflict is taking on national significance, as national groups plan to turn New Jersey's contests for governor and the Assembly into referendums on the issue. B1 Staten Island is pressing Albany to allow its residents to secede, but many analysts of New York City's finances are skeptical about the economic reprecussions. B1 At a nuclear dump near Buffalo, F.B.I. agents and criminal investiga-tors from two other Federal agencies made an unannounced entry to look for criminal violations of Federal anti-pollution laws. B2 Leona Helmsley approved payments by Helmsley companies for the mansion she and her husband remodeled in Greenwich, Conn., the first witness in the trial testified. B3 Catholic archdiocesean hospitals signed a new contract with the state's largest hospital workers union in a settlement that will increase pressure on private hospitals in their current labor negotiations. B3

title: Time Effort To Discredit Paramount
description: In a continued attempt to thwart a takeover bid by Paramount, Time released court documents yesterday showing that Paramount's principal lender, Citibank of New York, has estimated that Paramount might have to wait almost a year to take over Time.

title: Auctions
description: Lure of Chippendale

title: New Forum for Gorbachev
description: The Council of Europe, which heard a keynote speech from President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union today, is an organization committed to human rights that just granted observer status to Moscow.

title: Remy Martin Account To Goldsmith/Jeffrey
description: Remy Martin Amerique yesterday awarded Goldsmith/Jeffrey the business for two of its brands, Macallan Single Malt Scotch and Piper Heidsieck champagne. The combined billings of the accounts are $3 million. Macallan had not previously used consumer advertising in the United States, while Remy Martin bought Piper Heidsieck in 1988.

title: Economic Scene; Bush's Goals At Summit Talks
description: PRESIDENT BUSH intends to use next week's economic summit talks in Paris to take the lead on economic and environmental issues, much as he used the North Atlantic Treaty Organization summit meeting in Brussels in May to establish his leadership on military policy.

title: Goodbye, Mr. Levy
description: To the Editor:

title: Figure Identified in Rose Case, Source Says
description: Investigators for the commissioner of baseball have learned the identity of one of the New York bookmakers with whom they say Pete Rose bet on baseball games and are pursuing additional information, a source close to the investigation said yesterday.

title: Irish Flute Music
description: Skip Healy, a flutist, will play traditional Irish music tonight at the Eagle Tavern, 355 West 14th Street (924-0275). Sets begin at 9 and 10:30 P.M.; tickets are $5.

title: Review/Film; Chases, Crashes, Shootings: More in 'Lethal Weapon 2'
description: Though it includes a smashed car full of Krugerrands, a hillside house blown off its stilts and a bomb set under a toilet, the point of ''Lethal Weapon 2'' is that Mel Gibson and Danny Glover get to race around in all that chaos, acting crazy. Before it skids out of control in the final sequence, the film is so careful to preserve its successful comic-action formula that it follows the most basic law of sequels. If you liked ''Lethal Weapon,'' you'll like ''Lethal Weapon 2''; it's almost as simple as that.

title:
THE LAW;
After 200 Years, the Silent Juror Learns to Talk
description: LEAD: For more than 200 years, the American jury has been a passive audience in the courtroom, breaking its silence only to deliver a verdict. But now an experiment in more than 100 courts nationwide is giving the jury a voice.

title: Ford Didn't Sell Cars In Classroom TV Test
description: To the Editor:

title: President Is Named In Changes at Grace
description: W. R. Grace & Company, the specialty chemical maker, named a new president yesterday and announced several other changes to its top management.

title: Japan Summit Offering: Trade Surplus Lending
description: Shaken by scandal and political crises, Prime Minister Sousuke Uno's Government is quietly taking up another delicate problem this week: how to overcome a widespread perception of weakness at the economic summit conference that Mr. Uno is to attend in Paris next week.

title: Evert Loses To Graf Briskly and Graciously
description: Like a human pendulum, Chris Evert rushed to the left, rushed to the right, huffed and puffed, then began to feel too much like a 34-year-old woman and wife and potential mother in a futile foot race with a 20-year-old athlete whose life revolves around her sport.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: The Big-Band Sound

title: 10-Part Financing By Fannie Mae
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association is selling $300 million of real estate mortgage investment conduit securities through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. as sole underwriter.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly AD HOC COMMITTEE ON INDIAN OCEAN - 10 A.M. PARTIES TO CONVENTION AGAINST APARTHEID IN SPORTS - 10:30 A.M.

title: Retailers Report Modest Gains in Sales in June
description: The nation's largest retailers yesterday reported mostly modest gains in June compared with 1988. The sales of women's apparel continued to grow more quickly.

title: On Stage
description: Culture in the Country

title: A Court Spins the Revolving Door
description: Lyn Nofziger served as political director during Ronald Reagan's first year as President. He left in 1982 and, despite a law requiring a year of insulation, promptly lobbied his old buddies on behalf of paying clients. That brought his conviction last year for breaking the anti-lobbying law, but now a divided panel of the U.S. Court of Appeals in Washington has overturned the verdict. It's a mistaken decision that, if sustained, would start the old ''revolving door'' spinning again.

title: New Jersey's Endless Summer
description: Long before the advent of theme parks, amusement areas were generally raucous assemblages of roller coasters, fun houses and other divertissements clustered near seaside resorts. Although Coney Island set the standard, the Jersey Shore was never far behind as a destination for those seeking surf, sun and assorted rides, games and other cheap thrills.

title: Third World Debt More Than a Banker's Worry
description: To the Editor:

title: Lou Rawls: Back in Club, Back to Blues
description: ''I think it's a sign of the times,'' said Lou Rawls, the husky-voiced pop-jazz baritone, in commenting on his return to a jazz-blues idiom. ''A lot of people out there want to hear this music but haven't in a long time. A lot of others haven't heard it at all.''

title: Republicans Say Poor Gained Under Reagan
description: House Republicans issued a study today concluding that the poor had gained economically while Ronald Reagan was President.

title: Warsaw Assails Bonn, Citing Aid Failure and 'Revisionism'
description: The Polish Communist Party assailed West Germany in unusually strong terms today over the failure to reach agreement on an aid package and over comments by a Bonn Government minister that suggested continuing German claims to territories ceded to Poland after World War II.

title: 14 Killed in Israel in Bus Plunge When Arab Grabs Steering Wheel
description: At least 14 people were killed this morning when an Arab bus passenger, screaming ''God is great!'' grabbed the steering wheel and sent the bus plunging more than 400 feet into a ravine.

title: Footwear Imports Drop
description: American imports of non-rubber footwear fell by 12 percent in the first three months of 1989 from the period last year, the United States International Trade Commission said on Wednesday. It said imports in the latest quarter totaled 217 million pairs of footwear, worth $1.6 billion. The commission said American production rose in the same period by 2 percent, to 56 million pairs, worth $989 million. Production was also up in the last quarter of 1988, giving the nation the first back-to-back quarterly gains since 1984.

title: Recession Fears Are Growing
description: With every day bringing new evidence of an economic slowdown, the danger of a recession has abruptly replaced inflation as the chief threat to the economy in the minds of many economists and even among officials of the Federal Reserve.

title: When Do the Mentally Ill Become Dangerous?; Domestic Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: Pro-Life? Then Pay Up
description: The cruelest irony of the antiabortion movement is that many of its proponents have so little interest in the health and welfare of the resulting children after they are born.

title: Supreme Court in Hungary Declares Nagy Was Innocent
description: Hungary's Supreme Court today declared the innocence of former Prime Minister Imre Nagy, who was hanged as a traitor three decades ago.

title: BUSH SAID TO SHIFT CAMBODIAN POLICY
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d indicated today that the Bush Administration would be prepared to accept a settlement in Cambodia that left the Vietnamese-installed Government essentially in place, provided that Washington's ally, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, has ''real power'' as head of state.

title: Saatchi Denies Reports On Bid for Division
description: Executives involved in the potential sale of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C.'s consulting division dismissed reports yesterday that a French consulting company, Bernard Krief Consultants, was about to make a bid for the Saatchi unit.

title: West, Not East, For Young Germans
description: LEAD: The Germans are appeasing. The Germans are drifting. The Germans are reuniting. Such are the myths. But what are the realities? What do the Germans want for themselves?

title: Exploring Several Worlds At Two Summer Festivals
description: SUMMER festivals have turned what used to be a dry spell in the arts calendar into a lively extension of the season. Particularly inviting among the growing number of festivals are those that challenge their audiences with unusual works, singular approaches to familiar works, or programs that suggest historical or philosophical connections between works and styles.

title: Khorixas Journal; For Apartheid's Castaways, Heartbreak in Desert
description: At the height of the South African Government's pursuit of territorial segregation along racial lines, a group of black farmers were moved more than 1,000 miles from their long cherished lands and jettisoned in this famished landscape of red rocks, scarce rain and wild animals.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: South African Reggae

title: White House
description: Was George Bush's outrage at the Supreme Court's flag decision a visceral response to the notion of desecrating Old Glory? Or was political motivation involved too?

title: Winning by Losing in Mexico
description: Mexico's governing Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, has just registered a rare political triumph. For the first time since it was founded by revolutionary generals 60 years ago, the party conceded defeat in a major election, for governor of the state of Baja California Norte. Not only that, but the ruling party may soon acknowledge a possible second defeat, in elections for the Michoacan state legislature.

title: AIDS Victim Ends Journey In Hometown
description: When he began the journey back home, Dean Lechner feared the scorn, or silence, of a town whose native son was returning with AIDS.

title: Apple Selling Adobe Stake; Two Could Become Rivals
description: Apple Computer Inc. said today that it would sell its 16.4 percent stake in Adobe Systems Inc., whose Postscript software controls the output of Apple's laser printers.

title: Queens Residents' Feelings Mixed After Racial Encounter
description: As police detectives worked to make more arrests, white and black residents of Rosedale, Queens, stood around a schoolyard and an adjacent park yesterday and spoke of an encounter between whites and blacks there Tuesday night that has focused unwanted attention on the community.

title: Proud Father Sets Change At Deutsch
description: DAVID DEUTSCH ASSOCIATES is an unquiet advertising agency. For the New York, New Jersey, Connecticut Pontiac dealers, it tried to deliver a Grand Prix to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and created a television commercial around the event. For Lear's magazine, it has used photographs of semi-nude women over 40.

title: Treasury Securities Inch Higher
description: Prices of Treasury securities inched higher in moderate trading yesterday, as many participants interpreted the open-market activity by the Federal Reserve Board as a sign that the central bank has decided to push interest rates lower.

title: Prison In the Sand
description: This is a report from a prison in the Israeli desert to a friend in Maryland.

title: Volt Sells Portion Of Stake in Triad
description: Volt Information Sciences Inc. has reduced its stake in the Triad Systems Corporation to 9 percent, from 13.5 percent. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Volt gave no reason for the sale.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Air Canada shares will be sold by the Canadian Government for $12 each. The Government sold 43 percent of the airline in October and will sell the remainder now.

title: Europe Jobless Rate
description: The unemployment rate in the European Community was unchanged at 9.3 percent in May from the previous month, Eurostat, the community's statistical office, said today. Between August 1988 and January 1989 unemployment fell by one-tenth of 1 percent a month, but between February and May this year the monthly declines have been a third of that rate.

title: 79 Are Seized as Police Start Anti-Drug Program in Clinton
description: Seventy-nine people were arrested and $1,000 and 286 crack vials were seized yesterday during the first day of an anti-drug program in Clinton, Mayor Edward I. Koch and Police Commissioner Banjamin Ward announced.

title: Teen-Ager Is Challenged by Ultragorgon
description: One of the bigger disappointments of the last season was the failure of ''The Jim Henson Hour'' to find a permanent berth on NBC's prime-time schedule. The show will not be returning this fall. The only consolation is that several remaining programs are now being presented as original summer broadcasts. On Sunday at 7 P.M., the entire hour is to be devoted to ''Monster Maker,'' a British film starring Harry Dean Stanton.

title: Consultant Is Placed on Probation For His Role in Iran-Contra Affair
description: A Federal district judge today sentenced Richard R. Miller, a communications consultant who helped raise money for the Nicaraguan rebels, to two years' probation and 120 hours of community service.

title: Metropolitan Soloists
description: The Metropolitan Soloists will give a free concert at the Dairy in Central Park, 64th Street entrance, at 1:30 P.M. Sunday. The program is to include a wind octet by Carl Reinecke, and arrangements of Mozart and Donizetti overtures. Information: 397-3165.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES Two big accounting firms announced merger plans, and two others confirmed that they were holding merger talks. Deloitte, Haskins & Sells and Touche Ross, the smallest members of the nation's Big Eight, said they had agreed in principle to combine. Arthur Andersen, the nation's largest accounting firm, and Price Waterhouse said they would formally explore a merger. [ Page A1. ] Apple Computer will sell its 16.4 percent stake in Adobe, whose Postscript software is used with Apple's laser printers. [ D1. ] Time Inc. released court documents showing that Paramount's principal lender, Citibank, has estimated that Paramount might need almost a year to take over Time. [ D1. ] The nation's largest retailers reported mostly modest gains in June compared with 1988. Sales of women's apparel continued to grow more quickly than those of other goods. [ D3. ] A Federal bankruptcy court approved a fund that could total $20 million to reimburse travel agents who had used their own money to make refunds to Eastern Airlines' ticket holders. [ D15. ] Clayton & Dubilier renewed its $1.8 billion offer for American Medical International. [ D4. ] THE ECONOMY The danger of recession has abruptly replaced inflation as the chief threat to the economy. The Federal Reserve, the bond and stock markets and many economists have set anti-inflation policy aside and have begun to focus instead on averting a recession. [ D1. ] INTERNATIONAL President Bush said the U.S. would cancel loans it has made to some of the poorest African countries. He said the decision reflected agreements at last year's summit meeting of the U.S. and its allies to do more to help countries whose economies and living standards have been in decline. [ D1. ] Mexico and its creditor banks have a new proposal on the table for debt reduction. ''The talks are moving along in the right direction and the differences are narrowing,'' one banker said. [ D1. ] Prime Minister Uno of Japan is trying to decide how to overcome a widespread perception of his weakness when the Group of Seven meets in Paris next week. [ D2. ] MARKETS Boyd L. Jefferies was sentenced to five years' probation and fined $250,000 for securities law violations. The light sentence reflected his cooperation in the investigations of Wall Street. [ D1. ] Frederick H. Joseph, chief executive of Drexel Burnham Lambert, testified at the trial of five principals of Princeton/Newport Partners and a former Drexel employee. [ D6. ] Stocks rose moderately after vacillating in a narrow range throughout the session. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 5.88 points, to 2,462.44. [ D6. ] Prices of Treasury securities inched higher in moderate trading, as many participants interpreted the open-market activity by the Federal Reserve Board as a sign that the central bank has decided to push interest rates lower. [ D12. ] Lower interest rates allowed some mutual funds to increase their investment returns in the second quarter. [ D6. ] The dollar closed narrowly higher against all major currencies in thin, uneventful trading. [ D13. ] Coffee futures prices slid to new eight-year lows. [ D13. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS President Bush intends to use next week's summit to take the lead on economic issues. Leonard Silk: Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Institutional money management firms are outperforming the stock market this year. Market Place. [ D6. ] David Deutsch Associates decided to change its name to Deutsch. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D5. ]

title: People
description: * Mary Kay Moran has been named senior vice president and publisher of Intermarket magazine, a publication of Murphy Communications.

title: U.S. Agents Search Nuclear Dump Site
description: F.B.I. agents and criminal investigators from two other Federal agencies entered a nuclear waste dump near Buffalo unannounced yesterday to look for criminal violations of Federal anti-pollution laws.

title: Why Finks Is N.F.L.'s Best Choice
description: For sports trivia buffs, he'll always be one part of a three-part answer to one of pro football's favorite questions: when the Pittsburgh Steelers cut Johnny Unitas during their 1955 training camp, who were the three quarterbacks they kept?

title: Court Overturns Law on S.R.O.'s
description: A New York City law intended to prevent the spread of homelessness was ruled unconstitutional yesterday by the State Court of Appeals.

title: China Rejects U.S. Protest And Hints at More Purges
description: China today sharply rejected a United States protest against gunfire directed at a diplomatic compound here, and the Government published new attacks on Zhao Ziyang, the ousted Communist Party leader, that may presage criminal proceedings against him.

title: Hasbro Names Chairman
description: Hasbro Inc., the toy company, said yesterday that it had named Alan G. Hassenfeld its chairman and chief executive.

title: George E. Shibley, Sirhan's Lawyer, 79
description: George E. Shibley, a lawyer who represented Sirhan Sirhan in appeals of his conviction for the assassination of Robert F. Kennedy, died Tuesday. Mr. Shibley, 79 years old, died at Good Samaritan Hospital, where he had undergone heart surgery June 8.

title: Honeywell Executive To Join Allied-Signal
description: Allied-Signal Inc. has named an executive from Honeywell Inc., James J. Verrant, to be the president of its vast international operations.

title: N.H.L. Raid Is On
description: John Ziegler, the president of the National Hockey League, making good on a promise to play tough with the Swedish Hockey League, has given the N.H.L.'s 21 teams a green light to raid Sweden. In a June 27 directive to teams released yesterday in Toronto, Zielger said: ''As of this date, you are no longer under any obligation to respect any Swedish playing contract for any Swedish player. Further, you are advised to suspend the making of any payments to the Swedish Ice Hockey Federation or any of its clubs relating to any past or present agreements as to Swedish players.''

title: MAI Considering New Bid for Prime
description: MAI Basic Four Inc., which has been pursuing Prime Computer Inc. since November, said it was considering topping a rival bid from J. H. Whitney & Company. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, MAI asked for confidential Prime information to prepare a new bid. Prime, a minicomputer maker, last month agreed to be bought by Whitney for about $1.2 billion.

title: Banners to Wave Again for Hudson Park
description: After abruptly removing a chain of banners along the West Side of Manhattan - each one proclaiming, ''Let's Build a Hudson River Waterfront Park'' - unhappy and embarrassed New York City officials pledged yesterday to restore the green-and-blue nylon standards.

title: Norma French, 47, a Coloratura Soprano
description: Norma French, an American coloratura soprano who sang with the New York City Opera, died of lymphoma on June 26 at Toronto General Hospital. She was 47 years old.

title: Dow Rises 5.88 Points, To 2,462.44
description: Stocks rose moderately yesterday after vacillating in a narrow range throughout the session.

title: McEnroe Is Nursing An Injured Shoulder
description: John McEnroe could not remember the exact shot that produced the twinge, but sometime in the third set of his doubles match on Wednesday evening, he pulled a shoulder muscle in his left arm, the one that has helped earn him more than $10 million swinging a racquet on tennis courts all over the world.

title: State Offers Bonds For Con Ed Project
description: The New York State Energy and Research Development Authority is offering $100 million of bonds for a Consolidated Edison Company of New York project through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Chileans Reach Accords That Smooth the Road to Democracy
description: What was once expected to be a difficult transition to elected democracy in Chile has been eased by recent agreements within the main opposition coalition and between the opposition and the Government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet.

title: Walesa Urges Caution Amid Changes in Poland
description: Lech Walesa, in a reflective mood in advance of a meeting with President Bush next week, said today that he thought both he and Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski were having difficulties because of Solidarity's landslide election victory last month.

title: Guillermo Belt, 83, Ex-Cuba Envoy to U.S.
description: Guillermo Belt, a former Cuban Amb-assador to the United States and a signer of the Charter of the United Nations, died Sunday at Arlington Hospital of complications after surgery for an intestinal blockage. He was 83 years old and lived in Bethesda, Md.

title: Wary of Amending Constitution, Cuomo Offers Flag-Burning Ban
description: In an effort to stave off a constitutional amendment to ban flag-burning, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today proposed a new New York State law that would make destruction of the American flag a crime.

title: Gooden Is Relieved
description: Dwight Gooden said the pain had abated, and with it the fear had gone, too. All that was left was the wait.

title: The Man Who Puts Bush on the News, Maybe
description: When President Bush traveled to Richmond recently to speak to the Family Motor Coach Association at the Virginia State Fairgrounds, the event was an odd flashback to his campaign.

title: Eastern Fund Approved To Pay Travel Agents
description: The United States Bankruptcy Court yesterday approved a fund that could total $20 million to reimburse travel agents who had used their own money to pay those holding tickets on Eastern Airlines flights canceled after the strike.

title: D. Anthony D'Esopo, A Retired Surgeon, 91
description: Dr. D. Anthony D'Esopo, a retired surgeon and professor emeritus at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, died of pneumonia Monday at Glover Memorial Hospital in Needham, Mass., where he lived. He was 91 years old and had lived in Tenafly, N.J., and Alpine, N.J.

title: Review/Pop; Aretha Franklin, Body and Soul
description: Aretha Franklin's voice is one of the glories of American music. Lithe and sultry, assertive and caressing, knowing and luxuriant, her singing melts down any divisions between gospel, soul, jazz and rock, bringing an improvisatory spirit even to the most cut-and-dried pop material. Her concert Wednesday at Radio City Music Hall, opening a three-night stand that is her first New York engagement since 1981, presented the singer as a glitter-swathed supper-club entertainer. Her 90-minute set touched down on her revelatory 1960's soul hits but leaned toward ballads.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping; With Your Financial Affairs
description: If you're going to be away for an extended time this summer, a legal document called a power of attorney is a good idea. It allows someone you trust to pay your bills, make investments for you or open your safe-deposit box.

title: The Times Names Lelyveld Deputy Managing Editor
description: The appointment of Joseph Lelyveld as deputy managing editor of The New York Times, with the expectation that he will succeed Arthur Gelb as managing editor, was announced yesterday by Max Frankel, executive editor. The change takes effect July 16.

title: Jobless Report For June Shows A Rise to 5.2%
description: Job growth continued to lag in June as the unemployment rate edged up one-tenth of a percentage point to 5.2 percent, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Nelson Mintz, 81, Ex-Judge in New Jersey
description: Nelson K. Mintz, a retired judge of the Appellate Division of the New Jersey Superior Court, died of cancer Wednesday at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, N.J. He was 81 years old and lived in Verona, N.J.

title: Times Sq. Deserves a More Sensible Safety Plan;
description: To the Editor:

title: A Farewell Gift to Jersey Commuters
description: Governor Thomas Kean of New Jersey, whose administration ends next January, wants to leave a present for the state's commuters: an intelligent transportation plan for the Hudson River waterfront.

title: Import Ban on Assault Rifles Becomes Permanent
description: The Bush Administration declared a permanent ban today on almost all foreign-made semiautomatic assault rifles. Imports of the weapons have been suspended since spring.

title: Argentine Departs, Democracy Hardly Bankrupt
description: Raul Alfonsin, who brought to the Argentine presidency the hopes of a people trying to cast off a bitter history, leaves office on Saturday with his legacy hostage to the country's debilitating economic crisis.

title: Marlboro Concerts to Begin
description: The 39th season of weekend concerts at the Marlboro Music School in Marlboro, Vt., is to begin July 15 at 8:30 P.M. The concerts will take place at 8:30 P.M. Saturdays and 2:30 P.M. Sundays through Aug. 13. Among the performers scheduled to appear during the festival are the Blanche Moyse Chorale, members of the Beaux Arts Trio and the Guarneri Quartet and the pianist Richard Goode; Rudolf Serkin is the artistic director. Tickets: $5. Information: (802) 254-2394 or 254-8163.

title: Probation for a Fund-Raiser In Tax Fraud for Contra Aid
description: A Federal district judge today placed a conservative fund-raiser, Carl R. Channell, on two years' probation but imposed no other penalties on him for using a tax-exempt foundation to funnel millions of dollars to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Madrid Strives to Become Spain's Art Capital. But Will Barcelona Yield?
description: Art has become big business in Madrid as the city pursues an aggressive campaign to surpass its archrival, Barcelona, as the artistic capital of Spain. Beyond publicity and boosterism, Madrid's museums are restoring their treasures, expanding display and storage facilities, wooing collectors and playing host to major international exhibitions.

title: Fed Seems to Have Shifted From Credit Policy in May
description: The Federal Reserve Board's policy-making committee decided at its meeting on May 16 to leave credit conditions unchanged, according to minutes of that meeting that were released today.

title: Unfriendly Fenway Fells Yanks
description: The Green Monster gets all the attention. But the advantage for the home team in Fenway Park can be found in those odd-angled places along the green outfield walls, big and small, that can create just an instant of indecision that can become the difference in a game.

title: Review/Cabaret; An Energetic Julius LaRosa
description: Even on a soggy night like that last Thursday, when the dazzling view of the city from Rainbow and Stars, the cabaret on the 65th floor of the RCA Building, was obscured, Julius LaRosa's energy and enthusiasm filled the room with a warming glow.

title: Dr. Benjamin Merritt, Emeritus Professor, 90
description: Dr. Benjamin Dean Merritt, emeritus professor of Greek epigraphy at the Institute for Advanced Study, Princeton, N.J., died yesterday at his home in Austin, Texas. He was 90 years old.

title: Bush Choice for Health Post Withdraws Under Pressure
description: Under fire from conservative Republicans, Drew E. Altman today withdrew his name from consideration to be administrator of the agency that oversees the $100 billion Medicare program. It was the second time in two days that a person chosen for a top Bush Administration position had withdrawn under such pressure.

title: Borrowing Pace Showed Rise in May
description: Americans took out $3.6 billion more in consumer debt than they retired in May, as the pace of borrowing rose again, the Government said today.

title: A Summit to Probe New Soviet Ideas
description: Mikhail Gorbachev offered two promising new thoughts in France this week. Both warrant prompt attention from President Bush as he prepares for his trip to Poland and Hungary next week, and discussion at an early summit meeting.

title: S.R.O. Tenants to Get Free Legal Service
description: New York City will provide free legal services to any tenant of single-room-occupancy housing who is facing improper eviction or is being harassed by a landlord, Mayor Edward I. Koch said yesterday.

title: Transactions
description: Football

title: Books of The Times; A Master of Form Before Function
description: Nocturne and Five Tales of Love and Death By Gabriele D'Annunzio Translated by Raymond Rosenthal. 264 pages. Marlboro Press. Hard cover, $20.95; paperback, $13.

title: Vic Perrin, 73, Actor And Announcer, Dies
description: Vic Perrin, an actor and announcer on many radio and television shows, died of cancer Tuesday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center. He was 73 years old.

title: Times Sq. Deserves a More Sensible Safety Plan; A Positive Symbol
description: To the Editor:

title: Squibb to Invest In Research Center
description: The Squibb Corporation said it would invest $50 million in long-term research in cellular and molecular biology and genetics at the University Louis Pasteur in Strasbourg, France. The drug company, based in Princeton, N.J., will build a research center at Illkirch-Graffenstaden, near Strasbourg, where it will support 50 of the 400 scientists directed by Prof. Pierre Chambon, a molecular biologist.

title: Peres Escapes Crowd at Funeral As Rage Over Bus Attack Spreads
description: Enraged mourners tried to attack Finance Minister Shimon Peres today at the funeral of a victim of a bus crash that killed 14 people, while in several other parts of the country angry Jews assaulted any Arabs they encountered.

title: Partnerships Join In Allegheny Bid
description: A New York investment group comprising Steinhardt Partners and Japonica Partners has offered to acquire Allegheny International Inc. for $700 million in cash, debt and equity securities. The offer is part of a reorganization plan for the consumer products company, which filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code in February 1988.

title: 'I Want This Park Back'
description: The serious-looking woman in khaki shorts was having a hard time saying what she thought of the case of Tompkins Square Park on Manhattan's Lower East Side, her neighborhood park for the last 12 years.

title: Meadowlands To Get Final 4
description: A National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball committee today recommended awarding the Final Four to four sites through 1997, including the Meadowlands in New Jersey in 1996.

title: Why Hurry To Retire Sport Elders?
description: Now that we have said all those gushy things about the teen-age brigade of tennis, where are all those nerveless and inexhaustible little devils?

title: Betsy Nolan Married To Robert J. Kunze
description: Betsy Nolan, a New York literary and publicity agent, and Robert J. Kunze, a partner in Hambrecht & Quist Life Science Venture Partners, an investment firm in San Francisco, were married there yesterday at the Forest Hill Club. The Rev. Donald Schell, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: In U.S., Student Recalls China Tumult
description: Shen Tong spoke slowly to make sure his English would be understood as he described the tumultuous events that in the last seven weeks cast him first as a student leader in Beijing, then as a fugitive in hiding, and finally led him to the United States.

title: Gotti's Brother Is Sentenced To 50 Years
description: Gene Gotti, the brother of reputed Gambino family boss John Gotti, and an associate, John Carneglia, were each sentenced to 50 years in prison yesterday for racketeering and drug trafficking. The two men were also fined $75,000 each. Speaking forcefully in a crowded courtroom, Judge John R. Bartels of Federal District Court in Brooklyn imposed the maximum sentence, saying the defendants were ''tied by reliable testimony to gangland-type activity and lawlessness; their actions tore at the very fabric of society.''

title: 2 Soviet Defensemen For Devils Take a Bow
description: At a ceremony today that included the Soviet Ambassador to the United States, the Devils introduced their two Soviet defensemen, Vyacheslav Fetisov and Sergei Starikov, whose signing the Devils termed historic for the franchise and the National Hockey League.

title: Ex-Spain Magnate Turns Arrest Into Election
description: Jose Maria Ruiz-Mateos may yet wind up serving a long prison term, if not for defrauding the giant Rumasa conglomerate that he built up in the 1960's and 70's, then perhaps for recently punching the official who ordered its expropriation in 1983.

title: Review/Opera; 'Mathis' Revived In Munich
description: Ever since his death in 1963, Paul Hindemith's music has been poised for a revival. He wrote many wonderful works, and their revival has long seemed imminent. But it cannot be said that the new production of his best-known opera, ''Mathis der Maler,'' which opened the Munich Opera Festival last night at the National Theater, served to advance his cause.

title: Major Fires Plague 7 States As Season Gets Off Quickly
description: Major forest and brush fires were burning todayin seven states at the start of what forestry and firefighting officials say is likely to be a hot, dry summer around the nation.

title: Soviets Cut Back Nuclear Testing As Hazards Become a Local
description: The Soviet Union has scaled back its nuclear testing program, possibly to ease concerns of Soviet citizens that the blasts are contaminating the environment, Bush Administration officials say.

title: Rates Fall; Fed Easing Expected
description: Short- and long-term interest rates declined yesterday, as retail buyers, anticipating further easing of credit costs by the Federal Reserve, actively bid up Treasury and other fixed-income securities. Their expectations came in response to a modest rise in nonfarm employment and wages for June, announced yesterday.

title: Universal Foods Gets Improved Bid
description: The High Voltage Engineering Corporation said it would raise its offer for the Universal Foods Corporation to $42 a share, or a total of about $640 million. Laurence Levy, chairman of High Voltage, based in Burlington, Mass., said his company had delivered a letter to Universal's board, offering to buy the company in a negotiated transaction.

title: Progress in Mexico Talks Reported
description: Bankers and Mexican officials have apparently agreed to certain key terms of a debt restructuring plan that would reduce Mexico's debt payment outflow by about $2 billion a year, far less then the Government initially requested, bankers who are close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Ruling Stretches Legal Concept of Family
description: When New York State's highest court ruled Thursday that a gay couple who had lived together could be considered a family under New York City's rent-control regulations, it was a critical step in a changing definition of society's basic unit: the family.

title: Shoemaker's Final Race
description: Bill Shoemaker, whose career will have touched six decades, will ride for the final time next Feb. 4 at Santa Anita, where he has been a dominant force for nearly 40 years.

title: After Election of Finks Is Blocked, N.F.L. to Try Again
description: When a bloc of 11 National Football League owners repeatedly voted not to vote Thursday night during the league's attempt to nominate Jim Finks as the new commissioner, it caused the outgoing commissioner, Pete Rozelle, to signal for a timeout.

title: Western Union
description: Edward F. Heil, a business executive from Deer Park, Ill., has acquired 6.32 percent of the Western Union Corporation, the troubled telex operator based in Upper Saddle River, N.J. Mr. Heil, president of the American Environmental Construction Company, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that he had purchased 2.66 million Western Union shares - at prices ranging from $1.50 to $2.57 each, between May 17 and June 27 - for investment purposes only. Western Union has been struggling with its debt repayments since a major restructuring in December 1987 that put the investor Bennett S. Lebow in control of the company.

title: Midsummer Dances
description: The sixth season of free outdoor dance performances is to begin July 14 at the Soldiers and Sailors Monument, Riverside Drive and 89th Street. The program, sponsored by Midsummer Dances, will feature works by Jamie Stiller, Alice Teirstein and Anita Willoughby. Performances at the monument are at 7 P.M., July 14 through 16. There is also to be a performance on July 15 at 4 P.M. at the rotunda of Riverside Park, at 79th Street, as well as shows on July 22 and 23 at 6 P.M. at the Conservatory Garden in Central Park, Fifth Avenue at 105th Street. Information: 473-5560.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about an American aid pledge to the Philippines referred incorrectly to Corazon C. Aquino's succession to the presidency. She succeeded President Ferdinand E. Marcos immediately after he was toppled in 1986.

title: Ford Cuts '89 Forecast
description: The Ford Motor Company has trimmed its 1989 forecast of vehicle sales in the United States to 14.7 million to 14.8 million units from 15 million, Donald E. Petersen, the company's chairman and chief executive, said today.

title: New York's Unemployment Rate Drops, While New Jersey's Rises
description: New York's unemployment rate dropped slightly in June, while New Jersey's rose after a sharp drop the month before, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: 4 Cuban Officers Sentenced To Die for Drug Trafficking
description: A Cuban military court today condemned a highly decorated former army general, the general's aide and two other former officers to death by firing squad for drug trafficking in the country's worst scandal since Fidel Castro seized power 30 years ago.

title: Canada Pushes Privatization
description: The Conservative Government of Canada, which has privatized 18 companies since 1984, plans more sales in the next four years, John McDermid, the privatization minister, said today.

title: News Summary
description: International 2-4, 24 The Boeing Company can sell China four commercial jetliners, the State Department said, granting a waiver of the sanctions announced by President Bush last month. Page 1 The need to maintain ties with China was stressed by officials of Southeast Asia in a meeting with Secretary Baker, who reaffirmed the U.S. policy of ''measured response.'' 3 A Chinese ''most wanted'' student has made his way to the United States and is telling of his experiences in the pro-democracy movement. 3 News analysis: The Gorbachev visit to France this week was intended to promote the concept of ''a common European home'' from the Urals to the Atlantic. The Soviet leader had mixed success. 1 Moscow has reduced nuclear testing by roughly half so far this year, possibly to ease concerns of Soviet citizens that the blasts contaminate the environment, Amercian officials say. 3 Israelis tried to attack Shimon Peres at the funeral of a victim of a bus crash caused by a Palestiniann that killed 14 people. In several other parts of Israel angry Jews assaulted any Arabs in sight. 1 Egypt's population growth is straining the country's resources and creating tensions between secular au-thorities favoring birth control and some Islamic leaders. 1 A Cuban court condemned a general, the general's aide and two other former officers to death for drug trafficking. 3 Raul Alfonsin leaves office today, his term as Argentine President marked by success in developing democratic institutions and failure in managing the country's economy. 2 News analysis: World debt problems are presenting the Bush Administration with enormous difficulties because, experts say, there is not enough money available to make the White House's solutions work. 31 Former Spanish magnate turns arrest into election 24 Khagrachari journal: Seeking happiness high in the hills 4 National 6-8 A pay increase for Federal officials of up to 25 percent, as well as bigger raises for 200 Government employees with highly specialized skills, was proposed by President Bush. 1 Job growth continued to lag in June as the unemployment rate edged up one-tenth of a point to 5.2 percent, signaling a continued, but not severe, economic slowdown. 1 New York's unemployment rate dropped slightly in June 7 Stock prices shot up, with the Dow Jones industrials up 25.42 points, as anticipation of lower interest rates grew. 34 Stock in the UAL Corporation, owner of United Airlines, soared $13.50, ending the week up 19 percent amid takeover speculation. 31 A Bush choice withdrew his name from consideration as administrator of the agency that oversees Medicare. It was the second time in two days that a person withdrew under pressure from conservatives. 1 Most foreign semiautomatic rifles were placed under a permanent embargo by Bush officials. But the virtually identical weapons made in the United States are unaffected. 6 An official in charge of housing at the White House has been removed from oversight responsibilities after a House panel requested that she testify about her own links to the scandal-plagued housing department. 8 Salmon farmers around Puget Sound are finding resistance as they and scientific critics clash over the safety of production practices, including the use of antibiotics. 6 Forest and brush fires are burning in seven states at the start of what forestry and firefighting officials say is likely to be a hot, dry summer around the nation. 8 Louisiana laws restricting abortion that were on the books before the Supreme Court legalized abortion should be enforced, the state's legislators have declared. 7 A three-day holiday for miners east of the Mississippi River was called for by the United Mine Workers of America, which said the move would restore calm amid strikes. 8 Probation for a fund-raiser in tax fraud for contra aid 6 Exxon allows workers to be questioned on tape erasures 8 Regional 25-28 A new welfare program for the poor in Connecticut relies on a combination of educational approaches and incremental promotions to reward and encourage progress out of the welfare system. 1 John Gotti's brother was sentenced, along with an associate, John Carneglia, to 50 years in prison for racketeering and drug trafficking. Mr. Carneglia and Gene Gotti were also fined $75,000 each. 25 New York State's high-court ruling that a gay couple who had lived together could be considered a family was a critical step in a changing definition of society's basic unit. 25 The Clinton section of Manhattan is under siege by crime, which threatens residents with violence, and gentrification, which threatens them with higher living costs. 25 Rent increases were approved by the New York City Rent Guidelines Board. The increases are 5 1/2 percent for one-year lease renewals and 9 percent for two-year renewals on rent-stabilized apartments. 27 New York City will give legal service to any tenant of single-room-occupancy housing who is facing improper eviction or is being harassed by a landlord, Mayor Koch said. 27 Former convicts infected with AIDS or at high risk of becoming infected meet in Manhattan for 24 sessions of intensive education and group support in what is believed to be the first program of its kind. 25 Issues before Governor Cuomo include several of the most highly charged ones of the day: abortion, the death penalty and the sanctity of the flag. His summer strategy is to head off the Legislature. 26 New York City building contracts involved in a political dispute about a company accused of links to organized crime were approved by the Board of Estimate. 27 Inmate paralyzed in scuffle with guards 27 Last nun leaves monastery protest 26 Joseph Lelyveld is to be deputy managing editor of The Times 13

title: Government Bans Most Baldness Treatments
description: The Food and Drug Administration said today that it was banning the sale of nonprescription creams and lotions whose manufacturers assert would grow hair or prevent baldness. The agency said the products had not proved effective.

title: Tons of Mail Stashed at Home
description: Postal inspectors removed two tons of mail and half a ton of postal equipment Thursday from the yard of a letter carrier. The seizure occurred after neighbors complained about bags of paper and reams of bulk mail in the yard. Postal Service officials, who would not release the carrier's name, said they had no idea why he had been stashing the mail. They said he might face Federal charges.

title: Khagrachari Journal; Seeking Happiness High in the Hills
description: South Asia slips into Southeast Asia somewhere here in the Chittagong Hills, where the great floodplain of the Ganges and Brahmaputra gives way to sharp ridges and gorges whose depths are lost in tropical foliage.

title: LEARNING TO AVOID AIDS: CLASSES FOR FORMER PRISONERS
description: The course pays students $10 apiece for each class they attend, and admission is strictly limited to ex-convicts and ex-addicts. They meet three nights a week in the basement of St. Augustine's Episcopal Church on the Lower East Side, but the goal is not to redeem souls. It is to save lives.

title: Photo of Randy Hodgin, an assistant manager at Sea Farm Washington in front of some of the pens in which salmon are raised. (NYT/Michael O'Leary) Puget Sound Fish Farms Challenged
