description: Salmon farmers in the Puget Sound region are encountering resistance this summer as they and a group of scientific critics clash over the safety of production practices, including the use of antibiotics.

title: Investors Lose Decision On Philadelphia Options
description: A Federal judge has ruled that investors who lost money when options were exercised in apparent violation of Philadelphia Stock Exchange rules cannot sue to recover damages.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 46.

title: Asbestos Ban May Increase Some Prices
description: Manufacturers of products that contain asbestos said yesterday that they had anticipated the Government's ban on virtually all products using the mineral and had begun to substitute other materials.

title: Police Are Criticized in Queens Assault Case
description: Lawyers for four black people who say they were assaulted by a group of whites in Queens Tuesday night accused the police yesterday of ''improprieties'' in their investigation of the case. But the police, who announced a second arrest in the case last night, rejected the claims, insisting they were handling the case properly.

title: Governor Tries to Draw Battle Lines on Flag, Abortion and Death Penalty
description: At a time that is normally the start of state government's slack summer season, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has chosen to tackle several of the most highly charged issues of the day: abortion, the death penalty and the sanctity of the flag. Those are issues the

title: INSIDE
description: Gun Import Ban Extended

title: Hitachi Chip 'In Volume'
description: Hitachi Ltd. said the newest generation of computer memory chip, the 4-megabit dynamic random access memory, is now in ''volume production'' and available for sale in the United States. The new chip can store four million bits of information. The International Business

title: Miners' Union Calls Holiday as Thousands Strike
description: The United Mine Workers of America called a three-day holiday for its members east of the Mississippi River today, saying the period would restore calm in the coal fields.

title: His Blueprint for European Amity Is Fuzzy And Tinged by Hints of His Own Problems
description: Declaring that the postwar era is over, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev spent three days in France this week trying to sketch his seductive but elusive concept of ''a common European home'' stretching from the Urals to the Atlantic.

title: A Federal License for All Gun Owners
description: LEAD: Our society licenses doctors, lawyers, plumbers and teachers. Yet guns, which kill more Americans than people in any other nation in peacetime, remain largely unlicensed. To regulate the proliferation of guns, gun users should be required to obtain a Federal license. In addition, every gun owner should be required to carry liability insurance.

title: Stake Bought In McClatchy
description: The Times Mirror Company, the communications giant that publishes such newspapers as The Los Angeles Times and Newsday, has acquired 7 percent of McClatchy Newspapers Inc.'s class A common stock.

title: Review/Music; City Opera's New Production of 'Don Giovanni'
description: The chief merit in the fashionably bizarre productions that clutter the world's opera stages nowadays is that they can divert attention from mediocre singing. The New York City Opera's new staging of ''Don Giovanni,'' a studiously conventional one by Harold Prince, did not have even that dubious advantage on Thursday evening at the State Theater. As an interpretation of Mozart's ''dramma giocoso,'' this first performance of the company's summer season did not venture beyond the commonplaces of ''Don Giovanni'' commentary. That, unfortunately, forced attention on the musicians, both on the stage and in the pit.

title: This Is A Rec . . .
description: How can you make your answering machine stop talking if you pick up the phone after the recorded message begins? You trick it into thinking the person on the other end has hung up.

title: Government Will Buy Apples Left Over From Scare on Alar
description: The Department of Agriculture will buy $15 million worth of apples to reduce a huge surplus created when consumers stopped buying them because of concerns about the chemical Alar.

title: The Flag, Free Speech Take a Beating in Washington Square
description: LEAD: The July 4 holiday, coming shortly after the Supreme Court ruled that flag-burning was protected by the First Amendment, provided an immediate opportunity to put the decision to the test. The occasion was a flag-burning attempt in New York City's Washington Square Park.

title: Times Sq. Deserves a More Sensible Safety Plan; Some Greed!
description: To the Editor:

title: Lauder Sees a Boondoggle In a Lily Pond in Harlem
description: Ronald S. Lauder went to Morningside Park in Harlem yesterday and said that if elected mayor he would stop construction on an $11-million renovation project that the community has been supporting for two decades.

title: Jack Rubenstein, 81, Labor-Union Official
description: Jack Rubenstein, a labor-union official who led efforts to organize textile workers in the 1920's and later became a vice president of the New York State A.F.L.-C.I.O., died of a brain tumor Wednesday in Margate, Fla., where he lived. He was 81 years old and a former Bronx resident.

title: Review/Dance; A Painterly And Gallic Approach To Violence
description: The Made in France festival, an American dance celebration of the bicentennial of the French Revolution, arrived in New York on Thursday with performances by L'Esquisse in the American premiere of ''Un Imprudent Bonheur'' at the Florence Gould Hall of the French Institute-Alliance Francaise (55 East 59th Street). Seen here in its New York debut, L'Esquisse is the only one of the festival's seven participating companies and individual soloists to appear in New York, for the balance of the celebration is taking place at the American Dance Festival in Durham, N.C., and the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in Lee, Mass. But proximity is not the only virtue of the Manhattan performances, which run through tomorrow. An evening with L'Esquisse is an absorbing and provocative experience.

title: Cowboys Take Walsh In Supplemental Draft
description: Steve Walsh, who played two outstanding seasons as quarterback under Coach Jimmy Johnson at the University of Miami, might be playing under Johnson in the National Football League this season.

title: U.S. Halts Panamanian Ship And Seizes Hidden Cocaine
description: The Coast Guard said today that it seized more than a ton and a half of cocaine Thursday in a hidden compartment of a Panamanian freighter at sea.

title: Just Up From Minors, Meyer Spurs Brewers
description: Joey Meyer, just back from the minors, triggered Milwaukee's five-run third inning with a leadoff homer tonight and the Brewers held on for a 6-4 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

title: Bronx Man, 65, Guilty in Rapes Of Two Girls
description: A 65-year-old Bronx man was convicted yesterday of raping two girls, 9 and 11 years old, who authorities said had prostituted themselves last year because their mothers were crack addicts and their homes were impoverished.

title: Time to End the Sudan's Wars
description: Americans can understand but scarcely welcome the overthrow of a civilian Government in the Sudan by junior officers led by Brig. Omar Hassan Ahmed al-Bashir. He replaces Prime Minister Sadiq al-Mahdi, who came to power in 1986 through free elections, which is a rare distinction in authoritarian Africa. What's understandable is military frustration over Mr. Mahdi's seeming inability to end a ruinous civil war or steady a collapsing economy. What remains to be seen is whether the soldiers in Africa's largest country can do better - a process that Washington can help speed along.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''He's like a driver on a slippery road. He can't take the turns as if he were on a dry highway.'' - Foreign Minister Roland Dumas of France, speaking of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. [ 4:4. ]

title: Archbishop John J. Maguire, 84, Longtime Spellman Aide, Is Dead
description: Archbishop John J. Maguire, a longtime aide to Francis Cardinal Spellman of New York, died on Thursday evening at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 84 years old.

title: Times Sq. Deserves a More Sensible Safety Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Thousands of Subway Riders Detained 2 Hours in Queens
description: Thousands of subway riders on three trains were trapped in a Queens tunnel for more than two hours last night after someone pulled an emergency-brake cord, bringing one of the trains to a halt near the Queens Plaza station, the police and Transit Authority officials said.

title: Race Is the Issue - Either Openly or in Whispers
description: LEAD: This year, the race for Mayor of New York promises enough melodrama to fill the back cover of a paperback:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Ajinomoto Co., Tokyo, a food products company, will set up a joint U.S. sake-brewing subsidiary with Sanraku Inc. and Gekkeikan Sake Co. Ltd., Gekkeikan said. The companies invested $7 million in the operation and will open a plant near Sacramento, Calif.

title: Prisoners Refuse Vaccination
description: New York State has put 12 inmates in medical confinement after they refused to be vaccinated against German measles, prison officials said yesterday. James Flateau, a spokesman for the Department of Correctional Services, said yesterday that 12 inmates at Downstate state prison who refused vaccinations have been kept in isolation ''for about a week.''

title: Government Rests Its Case Against Princeton/Newport
description: The Government rested its case yesterday in the first Federal racketeering trial to result from the investigation of crime on Wall Street.

title: Your Money; When It's Better To Rent Than Buy
description: Home ownership was at the heart of yesterday's American dream, but today's reality for many people is that renting is the better choice, for the short term, at least.

title: Gateway Stake Up
description: An investment group led by Wasserstein, Perella & Company said it had raised its stake in Gateway, the British supermarket chain, to more than 30 percent. Almost 380 million shares changed hands today as the investor group bought the stock on the open market. In the United States, the American depository receipts of Gateway gained 50 cents today, to $18.75.

title: John W. McCoy, 79, An Artist and Teacher
description: John W. McCoy, an artist who specialized in landscapes of Pennsylvania and Maine, died after a long illness Thursday at Friends Hall nursing home in West Chester, Pa. He was 79 years old and lived in Chadds Ford, Pa.

title: A Folding Kayak Needs No Tools for Assembly
description: For people who prefer exploring inland waterways, but do not want to haul boats over long distances, a husband-and-wife team has invented a folding kayak.

title: Louisiana Moves Against Abortion
description: The Louisiana State Senate decided today to ask Louisiana's district attorneys to enforce state laws restricting abortion that were on the books before the 1973 Supreme Court decision that legalized abortion.

title: Jackson, Pitino Assistant, to Coach Knicks
description: Two years ago, when the Knicks hired Rick Pitino as head coach, Stu Jackson, Pitino's assistant coach at Providence College, followed Pitino to New York. Six weeks ago, when Pitino left the Knicks for a coaching job at Kentucky, Jackson had an opportunity to follow him again as his assistant coach. This time, though, Jackson, still under contract with the Knicks, chose to remain in New York as an assistant under the man who would be hired as coach.

title: Buyout Of Hospital Chain Set
description: American Medical International Inc. said today that it had agreed to a leveraged buyout by an investment group that includes the Pritzker family of Chicago and the First Boston Corporation. The $2.14 billion offer was accepted over several other proposals, including one from Clayton & Dubilier, a New York investment firm.

title: To Commuters, New York's Surtax Is Costly
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Cites Ford On Job Safety
description: Secretary of Labor Elizabeth Hanford Dole today accused the Ford Motor Company of violating an agreement it made two years ago to improve the way it records work-related safety problems. She proposed a fine of nearly $2 million.

title: Prisoner Is Paralyzed After Being Subdued
description: A Rikers Island inmate was left paralyzed with a broken neck after being subdued by correction officers two weeks ago, the New York City Correction Department said yesterday.

title: Discovery of 3d Neptune Moon Is Confirmed
description: The space agency announced today that a third moon orbiting Neptune had been discovered by the Voyager 2 space probe, which is speeding toward a close encounter with the planet next month.

title: Under Cover of Darkness, 400 Flee to Haven in India
description: Anupam Chakma traveled with more than 400 other tribespeople from the Chittagong Hill Tracts of Bangladesh into this refugee sanctuary in May, escaping a reported Bangladesh Army crackdown, hiding in thick jungle in the day and moving only at night.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Fighting Off Mildew
description: Mildew is a common fungus that thrives in damp, airless conditions; summer heat and humidity accelerate its growth. It has a musty odor and forms a powdery white film or black spots resembling soot. To mildewproof a home, trim surrounding shrubs and trees, and install exhaust fans, air-conditioners and dehumidifiers. Basement walls may require waterproofing. In dresser drawers and closets use bags or canisters of a safe chemical dessicant like silica gel, activated alumina or calcium chloride. When using the remedies below, work in a ventilated area (outdoors if possible to avoid spreading the spores) and follow precautions on labels. If these remedies fail, strong chemicals may be needed, which should be applied only by professionals. Tile: Apply commercial mildew stain remover or scrub with mixture of 1 part chlorine bleach to 4 parts water. Rinse. Use undiluted chlorine bleach on problem areas. Painted walls: Apply commercial mildewcide recommended for use on paint, or sponge with 1/2 cup vinegar, 1 cup ammonia, 1/4 cup baking soda and 1 gallon warm water, then rinse. Wear rubber gloves and eye protection. Upholstery, mattresses: Brush, vacuum and dry in sunlight, then sponge with detergent or equal parts denatured alcohol and water. Washable fabrics: Brush off mold, treat stains, then launder with bleach. Smooth leather: Clean with saddle soap. Apply conditioner containing fungicide (available at riding-equipment stores). Books: Wipe off mold and sprinkle cornstarch between pages. Clean leather bindings with equal parts denatured alcohol and water and apply leather conditioner.

title: New Japanese Winner: A Mazda Convertible
description: While the United States auto industry ponders dwindling sales and the prospect of closing plants, customers are lining up to buy a peppy convertible sports car from Japan.

title: Court Reduces Reason For Burning the Flag
description: To the Editor:

title: Do Justice to Another Hero of Hungarian Rising
description: To the Editor:

title: A Shampoo to Eliminate Odor of Skunk Spray
description: The wilderness can be full of perils, but Charles J. Wiesner, an organic chemist and inventor in Fredericton, New Brunswick, has patented a solution for one of them: the skunk.

title: An Edberg Backhand Conquers McEnroe
description: There was John McEnroe, the weight of the world on slender shoulders not only stooped but also sore, out in the drizzle on Wimbledon's Centre Court trying to stare down sunny-haired, lithe-limbed Stefan Edberg, the defending champion of a tournament McEnroe has won three times and still covets.

title: Mozart Piano Concerto To Open '89 Y Season
description: The pianist Richard Goode is to be the soloist with the New York Chamber Symphony on Sept. 21 in a performance of Mozart's Piano Concerto No. 23 to open the 1989-90 season at the 92d Street Y. The chamber group, under the direction of Gerard Schwarz, is also to give eight pairs of concerts at the Y starting Sept. 23. Mr. Goode is to give a solo recital on Dec. 13, and a recital with the soprano Dawn Upshaw on Feb. 7.

title: Tito Puente Cancellation
description: Tito Puente, the salsa musician, has canceled his appearance at the Midsummer Night Swing series on Tuesday at Lincoln Center. Raul Azpiazu y los Maniseros is to replace him. The event, part of a 20-night series celebrating Lincoln Center's 30th anniversary, takes place on the Fountain Plaza at 9:30 P.M.

title: The End for Guidry?
description: In what might have been the last game of his illustrious career, Ron Guidry pitched four and one-third innings for Columbus last night in a 2-0 loss to the Toledo Mud Hens. He then planned to drive to his home in New Jersey and await word from the Yankees on his future with the team.

title: Banks Offer to Lend Time Inc. $27.5 Billion
description: Time Inc. said last night that bankers were so eager to lend it money to finance its $14 billion offer for Warner Communications Inc. that it had been offered more than three times as much as it had sought.

title: KEY RATES
Triad Stake Sold
description: Volt Information Sciences Inc. has sold its entire 9 percent stake in the Triad Systems Corporation. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Volt gave no reason for the sales. Volt had offered to acquire Triad, a computer services concern based in Livermore, Calif., for $17 a share, or a total of $132.6 million, but agreed to end its bid in favor of a recapitalization plan under which Triad will pay shareholders $15 a share in cash and one share of the recapitalized company. Volt sold the 713,800 Triad shares on Thursday for prices ranging from $17.125 to $17.25 each.

title: Coors to Offer Lower-Price Beers
description: The Adolph Coors Company, the nation's fourth-largest brewer, said it would offer lower-priced beers starting Sept. 11. Coors plans a large advertising campaign to introduce the new beers, Keystone and Keystone Light, said Mike Willey, the brand's development manager. He said the beers would be brewed at the Coors plant in Golden, with existing employees.

title: New Welfare Focus Is '4th R': Readiness
description: As Connecticut prepares, with other states, to carry out a new Federal law that requires most welfare recipients to accept job training, state officials have backed away from optimistic talk of breaking the welfare cycle by teaching people how to flip hamburgers or operate a cash register.

title: Whites in Mississippi Town Seek Representation
description: White residents of this small Mississippi River town are complaining about their lack of representation on the Board of Aldermen, so town leaders have asked their lawyer to study creation of a white-majority district.

title: Egyptian Population Growth Strains Resources and Society
description: Aam Kamel bought his first television set the other day, but by then it was much too late.

title: Democracy Now, Bread Later in Hungary
description: LEAD: One conspiracy theory heard in Budapest cafes to explain the rush toward free elections in Hungary initiated by the Communist Party is fun, especially when outlined over cakes and brandy by an ex-member of the Hungarian Workers' Militia. It contains key elements of truth. and goes like this: ''The party leadership has no idea how to save the country from economic collapse.

title: About New York; Can Jobs, Profits And Potato Chips Mix in Bronx?
description: A box filled with bags of potato chips arrived in the mail. Did somebody actually think such succulent, golden morsels would sway a seasoned journalistic pro?

title: Contractor Approved Despite Mob Allegation
description: The Board of Estimate voted early yesterday to proceed with housing construction contracts involved in a political dispute about a company accused of links to organized crime.

title: William Tompkins, Ex-Prosecutor, 76; Fought Subversives
description: William F. Tompkins, who as an Assistant Attorney General headed the Justice Department's new internal security division during the Eisenhower Administration, died of a heart attack Thursday at the Mid-Ocean Club in Bermuda, where he was vacationing. He was 76 years old and lived in Maplewood, N.J.

title: ASIAN ALLIES BACK U.S. CHINA POLICY
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that the countries of Southeast Asia had stressed to the United States the importance of ''maintaining open lines'' of communication with China despite the shooting of demonstrators in Beijing last month.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article on Thursday about memorial service plans for the journalist I. F. Stone misstated the location of the Ethical Culture Society, where a service will be held at noon on Wednesday. It is at 2 West 64th Street, not 66th Street.

title: Bridge; Despite today's specialization, some bridge and chess champions do well at both games.
description: A century and a half ago it was possible for one man, Alexandre Deschapelles of France, to be, in all likelihood, the best in the world at chess and also at whist, the ancestor to bridge. The intellectual games have become so specialized and time-consuming that this double accolade is no longer possible. Nevertheless, some world bridge champions, notably Bob Hamman of Dallas, are competent chess players, and one of the two best chess players in the world is a competent bridge player.

title: Dismissed Employee Shoots 2 of His Former Supervisors
description: A dismissed worker at a Coca-Cola plant shot two of his former supervisors, killing one and seriously injuring the other, then took a co-worker hostage at the plant late today, the police said.

title: Main Hall at Ellis I. Had A Sort of Steam Bath
description: To the Editor:

title: 2-Person Sub, As a Tourist Attraction
description: One of this nation's unsung strengths in innovation is in fun and games. While the majority of American patents in many fields, from photocopying to steelmaking to internal combustion engines, go to foreign inventors, Americans still receive well over three-quarters of all patents issued for games and exercise devices, according to the United States Patent and Trademark Office.

title: DOW CLIMBS BY 25.42 ON RATE HOPES
description: Stock prices shot up yesterday as anticipation of lower interest rates grew.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JULY 8, 1989
description: International

title: Rising Bank Fees Touch Off a Backlash
description: Bank fees for checking and savings accounts have been rising steadily, and much of the burden is falling on consumers who do not keep $1,000 or more in their accounts, depending on the bank's rules.

title: U.S. GRANTS BOEING A WAIVER TO SELL JETLINERS TO CHINA
description: Granting a waiver of the sanctions announced by President Bush last month, State Department officials said today that the Boeing Company could sell four commercial jetliners to China.

title: Portugal Plant For Ford Audio
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it would spend $120 million to build its first European audio equipment plant, on Portugal's Setubal peninsula.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 12.

title: New York City Rent Panel Votes Rises
description: Rent increases of 5 1/2 percent for renewals of one-year leases on rent-stabilized apartments and 9 percent for two-year leases were approved yesterday by the New York City Rent Guidelines Board.

title: Graf's Winning Style: Dispassion and Desire
description: Steffi Graf, Wimbledon's reigning queen, is impervious to the identities of her opponents, flicking the challengers away with the same consideration she might afford a swarm of gnats.

title: Rough Going for U.S. Debt Plan
description: Behind the self-congratulatory facade likely at the economic summit conference in Paris next week, the Bush Administration's effort to resolve the debt problem of the developing world is facing enormous difficulties.

title: Brazil Says There Is No Moratorium
description: After missing $812 million in debt payments this week, Brazilian officials stressed today that the developing world's largest debtor was not declaring a moratorium.

title: Gentrification And Crime Lay Siege To Clinton
description: When Mabel Hackett steps outside her eyeglass shop in the Clinton section of Manhattan, she is confronted with crack dealers and users, prostitutes and pimps, and street people who use the sidewalks as battlegrounds and bathrooms.

title: EXXON TO RESPOND ON TAPE ERASURES
description: Alaskan investigators will question employees at the headquarters of the Exxon Company U.S.A. here to determine whether destruction of computer copies of documents about the Valdez oil spill resulted from company negligence and whether, as Exxon asserts, other copies of those documents still exist.

title: Court Reduces Reason For Burning Flag
description: To the Editor:

title: Share Price of UAL Up 8.9% As Pilots Weigh New Bid
description: The share price of the UAL Corporation, the owner of United Airlines, soared $13.50 yesterday, to $166, after the pilots' union said it was considering whether to revive its bid to acquire the company.

title: Corrections
description: An art review on June 13 about the Hess Collection in Napa, Calif., misidentified an artist. He is Leopoldo I. Maler, not Maier.

title: Students' Foreign Aid Is Criticized by Beijing
description: China accused foreign countries today of giving money and passports to leaders of the student democracy movement, whom it called ''a gang of political hooligans.''

title: RJR Nabisco Sales
description: ATLANTA, July 7 (AP) - RJR Nabisco Inc. announced the sale of its biscuit and food businesses in India and Pakistan for about $44 million, another move in its effort to reduce the debt from its nearly $25 billion leveraged buyout by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company. Britannia Industries Pte. Ltd. of Singapore, will purchase the unit, Associated Biscuits International Ltd.

title: Mexico Eases Foreign Curb
description: The Government has opened Mexico's stock exchange to foreign investment in a move that could lead to foreign-owned brokerages.

title: Appointment To Arts Post Is Praised
description: John E. Frohnmayer, the Oregon lawyer who has been selected by President Bush to head the National Endowment for the Arts, knows the position will place him at the center of political debate and controversy. But he confidently says, ''There is no job in the country I prefer.''

title: New Deal for Boggs
description: His season began with his play overshadowed by trade rumors and continuing discussion of his affair with Margo Adams. But going into the 81st game of the season, the halfway point, Boston's Wade Boggs was batting .330, the fourth-leading average in the American League, with a spot in the top six in hits, doubles, walks and triples.

title: Bush Calls for Raises of Up to 25% For Officials of Executive Branch
description: President Bush asked Congress today to increase salaries as much as 25 percent for 7,900 officials of the executive branch and to give larger raises to 200 of them who are Government specialists like doctors and scientists.

title: Budget Aide Loses Duties in Housing Inquiry
description: The White House official who monitors the housing department's budget has been removed from many oversight responsibilities after a House subcommittee requested that she testify about her own links to the troubled agency.

title: Fernandez Has Reds Guessing and Losing
description: Sid Fernandez has been, perhaps above all else, an enigma. Loaded with talent, he is capable of overwhelming opponents and defeating himself in the same inning. He has said little about this, perhaps because he knows it is difficult to explain.

title: Corrections
description: A map in some copies yesterday tracing the path of a storm system from the Pacific Ocean to the Eastern Seaboard misidentified the body of water southeast of North America.

title: For the Older Voyager, Custom-Made Tours
description: The most popular outing sponsored by an adventure-tour company in Canada is a six-night hiking and canoeing holiday for people at least 50 years old. Still more specialized are travel packages to national parks for adults and their grandchildren.

title: Manischewitz Deal
description: The B. Manischewitz Company, a maker of kosher foods based in Jersey City, said it had accepted an acquisition offer from Levine, Tessler, Leichtman & Company, a Los Angeles investment firm. The offer, for $841 a share, or a total of about $44 million, was $1 a share higher than an offer from National Foods Inc., the maker of Hebrew National products. Manischewitz said its shareholders would vote on the offer at a special meeting on Friday.

title: Fix Up the Front Porch
description: To the Editor:

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Outing; The Wet and Wild Route to the Delaware Gap
description: On a recent sun-dappled Sunday, a blue rubber raft floated end-around-end down a dark green river as its four passengers exchanged easy banter, their paddles drying in the sun.

title: Pediatric Hospital Plans To Face Tough Scrutiny
description: HARTFORD and Yale-New Haven Hospitals plan to build children's hospitals, but they face a tough regulatory review on whether two new buildings are needed.

title:
IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut;
New Housing for Downtown White Plains
description: LEAD: THERE is a growing residential presence in downtown White Plains, known more for its midrise office buildings and commercial activity.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: SOUND MONITOR

title: AN ANGELENO IN NUEVA YORK
description: SKIN DEEP By Guy Garcia. 186 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $16.95.

title:
DINING OUT;
Eclectic Cuisine and Jazz in Montclair
description: LEAD: I WOULD go to Trumpets even if it did not serve food. The fact that this very good jazz club just a few blocks from Bloomfield Avenue in Montclair serves decent food along with very hot jazz makes it a find for anyone interested in listening to old standards along with the new.

title: Dick's Castle
description: To the Editor:

title: The Seas as Classrooms
description: I ENCOUNTERED my first doctorfish on a Caribbean reef. This was not the finned variety, but the two-legged species, a group of physicians combining a scuba vacation with a ''Diving Medicine in Depth'' seminar. I felt so secure diving with a bunch of doctors, that I joined them on a dive trip to Fiji a few months later. As a nonphysician, I didn't take the seminar, although I sat in on lectures like ''Hazards of the Marine Environment.'' Those lectures satisfied my need to know as a recreational diver, even if they didn't give me a tax-deductible reason to take a vacation underwater.

title: A World Court for Terrorists
description: Terrorists continue to get away with murder by playing one nation against another, avoiding extradition, escaping prosecution and even securing their freedom by blackmailing powerful countries. The fight against terrorism could be tremendously aided by an international court to try these international criminals.

title: For Some Comics, Life Can Be More Than a Cabaret
description: What happens when cabaret performers decide they've had enough of cabaret? In the case of Kathy Najimy and Mo Gaffney, who specialize in socially conscious skits about the interactions between ''real people,'' they hire a theatrical director and move to Off Broadway.

title: John Cammack Marries Ms. Warren
description: Kimberly Warren, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Warren 3d of Rochester, was married there yesterday to John Haworth Cammack, a son of Mrs. Charles W. Cammack Jr. of Charleston, W.Va., and the late Mr. Cammack. The Rev. George Scarlett, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Third Presbyterian Church.

title: 20 Years Fallow To 2,500 Units
description: WHEN Forest City Enterprises began buying farmland in this suburb east of Cleveland in the early 70's, it anticipated continued demand for new housing. After nearly 20 years, its 900 acres of countryside are being transformed into the largest planned development in Summit County.

title: Meeting Artists At Two Fairs
description: THE pathways of the historic village at Allaire State Park in Monmouth County will be lined on Saturday with 110 crafts people whose work is unfettered by time frames. A broom maker and glass blower will demonstrate their time-honored skills, while a jewelry maker sells earrings made from space-age materials. There will be a display of hand-thrown ceramic pots, inspired by 19th-century jugs, but less than three inches tall and grouped in Plexiglas boxes.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Security Systems; The New Watchmen: TV Monitors and Computers
description: EVERY day a video-production facility at 17 State Street in downtown Manhattan pumps out more than 100 epic-length features. None will ever win an Emmy; most will not even win an audience of one.

title: East Europe Awaits Bush
description: President Bush, who leaves for Poland today, can expect an enthusiastic, emotional welcome there and in Hungary, which he is to visit later in the week. Poles and Hungarians, many of whom have ardently sought to shed the Soviet mold, see Mr. Bush's visit as a symbol of acceptance by the Western democracies. They also see it as a beacon of hope that the West might help lift the awesome debts that are dragging down their nations' economies. But vast sums of money and painful restructuring are required and Mr. Bush is unlikely to offer anything approaching a real rescue. Article in The Week in Review.

title: New Argentine Leader Offers Only Toil
description: Carlos Saul Menem became President of a virtually bankrupt Argentina today, promising tough economic adjustments that run counter to the Peronist political movement's tradition of populism, state beneficence and economic nationalism.

title: Hole-in-1 Odds Off by Zillions
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Phone Link Treatment Is Used in Heart Attack
description: A woman waiting for a heart transplant has become the first person treated through a telephone connection for a heart attack she suffered at home, hospital officials report.

title: Elizabeth Kramer Weds J. F. Wood
description: At the Reformed Church in Brookville, L.I., Elizabeth Jane Kramer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Kramer of Brookville, was married yesterday to James Francis Wood, a son of Alan F. Wood of Utica, N.Y., and the late Anne Wood. The Rev. Allan Ramirez, a minister of the Reformed Church in America, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Mario Costa, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Question Of the Week; What Should Happen To Rose?
description: The issue here, as with flag-burners, is much more important than the fate of the individuals accused. It involves the Constitution. If we are a democracy, and if baseball is our national game, why is it governed by a commissioner who is routinely called a ''dictator'' or a ''czar''? If Pete Rose's contract is not renewed by the corporation, can he get a job with the opposition? If somebody loses a position with Dow, he can always look for work at Allied or at Du Pont, but there is only one major league in baseball, just as there is only one Hall of Fame.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-17

title: Virginia Thorson Weds G. G. Moll
description: Virginia Lee Thorson, a daughter of Mrs. Abram Claude Jr. of Bedford, N.Y., and the late Robert D. Thorson, was married yesterday to George Gerard Moll, a son of Mrs. Jack Moll of Phoenix, Ariz., and the late Mr. Moll, by the Rev. Dr. William E. Foley, an Episcopal minister, at St. Matthew's Church in Bedford.

title: STREETSCAPES: The Old Yale Club; Make Way for the Blue and Gold
description: THE club district in the West 40's has seen a gradual decline from its high point around 1910 as the Elks, Lambs and other social clubs have given up their buildings. But now it looks like the old Yale Club at 30 West 44th Street - the first high-rise club building and a school since 1971 - will return to club use. The likely new owner is another Ivy League institution, the University of Pennsylvania's New York Club.

title: 3 Take Lead at Hartford Open
description: Kenny Knox bogeyed the 17th hole after Wayne Levi and Wayne Grady birdied it, and all three finished tied with a one-stroke lead after today's third round of the Greater Hartford Open.

title: Some Major Regattas, but Not as Costly
description: Three major regattas with as many as 700 boats and 3,000 competitors are set for the Northeast this summer. Sailors are gravitating to a less costly approach to the sport. It is one in which racing identical boats reduces the need to keep up with the ever-changing rating rules of handicap regattas.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: GARDEN OF LIES. By Eileen Goudge. (Viking, $19.95.) ''Sylvie and Her Daughters'' would be a better title for this contemporary version of ''The Prince and the Pauper,'' a story that is replete with garden-variety deceptions: babies switched at birth, hidden letters, a hidden bank account, hidden love.

title: Question Of the Week; What Should Happen To Rose?
description: We should extend a hand with compassion rather than try to bury Pete Rose. He deserves and has earned the right to be treated as an individual and not as a pawn in a misguided policy to deter future offenders. TED GREENBERG New York

title: 'Do the Right Thing': Issues and Images
description: Spike Lee's new film, ''Do the Right Thing'' - which depicts racial tensions on the hottest day of the summer in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, ending with the killing of a black man by the police and a riot - has generated considerable discussion about its portrayal of blacks, racism and violence. The New York Times recently invited a group to explore issues raised by the film.

title: Lisa A. Schneider Engaged to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas C. Schneider of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Ann Schneider, to Augustus Bradhurst Field 4th, the son of Earl Field of Hilton Head, S.C., and Mr. Field 3d of Tuxedo Park, N.Y. An August wedding is planned. Ms. Schneider, a graduate of Choate Rosemary Hall and Duke University, is an assistant account executive at the Stamford, Conn., advertising agency of North Castle Partners. Her father is the chief financial officer of the Dean Witter Financial Services Group in New York.

title:
DINING OUT;
A Winery Where Food Steals the Show
description: LEAD: EVEN travelers familiar with the stunning, gently undulating landscape of Dutchess County will be impressed by the idyllic Berkshire views from the approach to the Cascade Mountain Winery.

title: Beth Fowler Adds Her Touch to ''42nd Street''
description: THERE is just a month left to see the second-longest-running musical in Broadway history (''42d Street,'' nine-and-a-half years) in Westchester's longest-running year-round professional theater (An Evening Dinner Theater, 15 years old today).

title: NEW JERSEY OPINION; ENDING REQUIRED GYM: 2 VIEWS
description: LEAD: MANY years ago, while interviewing a 16-year-old delinquent boy at Highfields, a treatment center in Hopewell, I asked him about his school experiences. ''I liked school,'' Joe said.

title: The Lure of the Sky, for Work and Play
description: FED up with highway traffic, extravagant fares and overbooked flights, many adventurous business people and vacationers are choosing to fly - and in some cases buy - their own planes.

title: Marc Friedman Weds Lisa Lane
description: The marriage of Lisa Shari Lane, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jules Val Lane of Sands Point, L.I., to Marc Lawrence Friedman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Jay Friedman of New City, N.Y., took place in New York last evening at the Plaza. Rabbi Martin S. Rozenberg performed the ceremony.

title: Making Ice While the Sun Shines
description: NINETY degrees in the shade is the kind of weather Richard G. Hendler likes best. Mr. Hendler heads the Saxony Ice Company here, one of the largest ice manufacturers in the Northeast, and when the temperature soars, so do sales of ice.

title: >Disabled Finding Wider Job Opportunities
description: LEAD: IN light of the state's labor shortage, employers have begun to turn to a largely untapped pool of potential workers - the disabled. Advances in computer technology are enabling many people whose disabilities previously precluded entry or re-entry into the work force to perform a variety of jobs as well as able-bodied workers.

title: Let's Not Worry About the Dollar's Rise; Predicting Inflation
description: To the Editor:

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Handling High Inflation In Argentina

title: East Bloc Optimistic On Arms
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his Warsaw Pact allies agreed here today that NATO had met them halfway with its proposals for reducing conventional arms in Europe, and they said the first agreements could be reached as early as next year.

title: Donald S. Voorhees, U.S. Judge Who Backed Internees, Dies at 72
description: Donald S. Voorhees, who as a Federal district judge in Seattle issued a major decision favoring Japanese-Americans who had been interned by the Government during World War II, died Friday at the Hospice Northwest in Seattle. He was 72 years old.

title: Rhode Island Court Rules Out Police Use Of Sobriety Checks
description: Police roadblocks intended to catch drunken drivers violate the Rhode Island Constitution even if they conform with guidelines that the United States Supreme Court has implied are acceptable, the State Supreme Court ruled Friday.

title: Food; We're All Ears
description: MY MOTHER preferred Country Gentleman and my father liked Silver Queen. These were the names that buzzed around the kitchen when corn was ready for picking. In those days, farms were a hop away from our house, and one of our chores was to bicycle to a farm stand and buy a dozen or more ears. My brothers and sisters would gather on the back porch to husk (which we liked) and pull off all the silken threads (which we hated), piling them on our little sister's head. A voice from the kitchen would call us when the water was boiling.

title: POSTINGS: For the Disabled; Yonkers Rentals
description: Alfred Weissman, a Yonkers developer, knew firsthand about the problems disabled people have finding apartments with the built-in safety features they need and want to make their lives safer and more comfortable.

title: Leila Metz Wed To W. M. Hewitt
description: Leila Fallon Metz, an advisory systems engineer with the International Business Machines Corporation in New York, and William Matthew Hewitt, an account marketing representative at I.B.M., also in New York, were married yesterday by Msgr. Edward F. Kavin at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Gabriel the Archangel in Saddle River, N.J.

title: Suburb Wants an Uzi for Every Officer
description: Police officials in this affluent lakefront suburb of Chicago are considering something even their beleaguered colleagues in Detroit or Washington have not done: equipping their regular police patrols with Uzi submachine guns that can fire up to 10 rounds a second and are a favorite of military commando units.

title: PASTIMES: Stamps
description: There is a country where there is no charge to send a letter domestically; never has been, probably never will be.

title: Dr. Margaret McElrath Wed
description: Dr. Margaret Juliana McElrath, an assistant professor of cellular physiology and immunology at Rockefeller University in New York, and Dr. Kenneth Daniel Stuart, the director and senior investigator of the Seattle Biomedical Research Institute, were married yesterday in Mount Kisco, N.Y. Anthony Pieragostini of the Justice Court of Mount Kisco officiated at the Seven Springs Center. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank McElrath of Greer, S.C. Dr. Stuart is a son of Mrs. Fred Ferren of Billerica, Mass., and the late John Stuart.

title: Correction
description: The Stamps column on June 25 misidentified the designer of a cachet commemorating the 1805 peace treaty between the United States and the Barbary states. It was Roy Hubbard.

title:
FOCUS;
The Japanese Don Hard Hats for a New U.S. Role
description: LEAD: In the face of an uncertain office market, a $500 million mixed-use project rising here is moving forward with the help of a Japanese partner, providing further evidence of the emergence of Japanese institutions as active participants in new construction projects in the United States.

title: THE MINI-SERIES: LESSER EXPECTATIONS
description: Just as a splendid new three-part production of Charles Dickens's ''Great Expectations'' makes its debut on the Disney Channel this evening, the future looks grim for the mini-series genre, especially the kind of made-in-Britain costume dramas that have long been the bedrock of public TV's Masterpiece Theater. They are too expensive, we're told. Or, undoubtedly more to the point, their audiences have leveled off. Even the fiercely standoffish BBC now feels the pinch of ratings pressures.

title: BAD TIMES ON THE BAYOU
description: Thank you for a very accurate account of Louisiana's economic depression (''Bad Times on the Bayou,'' by Wayne King, June 11). I have recently left my home in southwest Louisiana to find work and a better quality of life. This doesn't, however, lessen my love for my Cajun heritage, for Saturday mornings at Fred's bar in Mamou or for the Liberty Theater in Eunice on Saturday nights. I will continue to look forward to a time when I can go ''home'' again. GILDA A. LITTLE Atlanta

title: WHEN WOMEN FINALLY GOT THE WORD
description: What does a woman need in order to write? A room of her own and a fixed income, perhaps, but only later on. First she needs a language to write in. But for much of history, East and West, the languages of literature were unavailable to women. Classical languages - Greek and the literary Latin of ancient Rome, an imported Chinese used in early Japan - were once the only written languages that were different from the contemporary spoken tongue, and they were taught almost exclusively to wellborn men. Only an occasional woman - an empress, the daughter or wife of a poet - received this elite education, and thus almost all classical writers were men. But in medieval Japan and Europe, a linguistic phenomenon occurred that broke this classical - and male - monopoly on writing: the development of the written vernacular. What was spoken became what was written. Women began writing in their native languages, and these vernacular works, independent of the classical tradition, prefigured what was to become modern literature.

title: A New Mandate?
description: To the Editor:

title: Coke, With a Squirt of Ammonia
description: To the Editor:

title: PASTIMES: Chess
description: When that great French genius, Francois Andre Danican Philidor, said, ''The pawns are the soul of chess,'' there was probably no one around who had any idea what he was talking about. After all, it was 1749 and the leading players of the day were given to tactical brawls involving the much speedier and farther-ranging pieces. At most, they considered pawns to be just so many obstacles to be removed in order that the armies of pieces could get clear shots at each other.

title: A Modest French Bistro in Bethel
description: BILLED as a bistro, Le Tout-Paris, on the main thoroughfare of Behtel, more closely resembles a modest French village restaurant, with lace curtains in the windows, a pastel interior, walls adorned with scenic engravings and framed wine labels, a burgundy carpet and banquettes.

title: On Abortion, Can Democracy Do the Right Thing?
description: PRIOR to nearly all other political questions is one that rang out around the country last week after the Supreme Court's decision in the Missouri abortion case: Who decides?

title: Budget Office Asks Cabinet To Review Financial Controls
description: The Director of the Office of Management and Budget, Richard G. Darman, has asked all Cabinet departments and two major non-Cabinet agencies to report on what they are doing to combat financial fraud and abuse, a spokesman for the Office of Management and Budget says.

title: Westport Rents Are High for All
description: As long-established merchants on Main Street in Westport, we'd like to offer the following comments on ''The View From: Main Street in Westport'' (June 4).

title: New & Noteworthy
description: ON THE NATURE OF THINGS EROTIC, by F. Gonzalez-Crussi. (Vintage, $8.95.) F. Gonzalez-Crussi, a very literate pathologist, discourses on love and sex throughout the ages. ''Dr. Gonzalez-Crussi considers courtship, seduction, male jealousy, female deities, lust, desire, satiety, perversion, androgyny,'' Maralyn Lois Polak said in The Book Review last year. ''His erudition is a delight, plundering as he does such diverse sources as Dear Abby, Roland Barthes, Hugh Hefner, Kierkegaard, personal ads and the 14th-century Chinese novelist Shih Nai-an.'' LIBRA, by Don DeLillo. (Penguin, $4.95.) Mixing fact with fiction, Don DeLillo's novel is about a C.I.A. conspiracy to kill President John F. Kennedy and blame Fidel Castro by fingering a Communist dupe named Lee Harvey Oswald. Last year, our reviewer, Anne Tyler, said that this is the richest of Mr. DeLillo's novels, which include ''White Noise'' and ''Ratner's Star.'' ''It is also his most complicated, with a dual slate of characters and a plot line that might be described as herringbone-shaped. Apparently unrelated events slant forward from distant sources to be channeled into a single moment in history: six seconds in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963.'' WE ARE NOT AFRAID: The Story of Goodman, Schwerner, and Chaney and the Civil Rights Campaign for Mississippi, by Seth Cagin and Philip Dray. (Bantam, $5.95.) The movie ''Mississippi Burning'' gave a highly fictionalized account of the murder of three civil rights workers near Philadelphia, Miss., 25 years ago. In their book about the case, Seth Cagin and Philip Dray find that the unadorned facts are horrifying enough. ''They trace the fateful day in riveting detail drawn from interviews with civil rights movement veterans, the 1967 trial transcript and thousands of file pages obtained from the F.B.I. under the Freedom of Information Act,'' Henry Mayer said here last year. ''Especially moving are the book's biographical flashbacks, which evoke the personalities of men known principally by their stark mug shots on the F.B.I.'s 'missing' poster.'' In WITNESS IN PHILADELPHIA (Louisiana State University, $9.95), a long-time resident of the town, Florence Mars, with the assistance of Lynn Eden, gives a firsthand account of the turmoil that followed the killings, including her run-ins with the Ku Klux Klan after she testified before a grand jury. ''In view of what befell her and the town she dearly loves, the calm dispassion of her book is all the more impressive,'' one reviewer said in 1977. ''So is her modesty.'' SURVIVING THE SEASONS, by Fern Kupfer. (Laurel/Dell, $7.95.) With two long marriages behind them, a widow and a widower decide to spend what's left of their lives together. '' 'Surviving the Seasons' is an old-fashioned novel about nice people,'' Donovan Fitzpatrick said here in 1987. ''It can be taken also as a moral tale, a handbook on how to make a marriage work through tolerance and understanding - many a marriage counselor could read this book with profit.'' LAST DAYS OF THE SICILIANS: The FBI's War Against the Mafia, by Ralph Blumenthal. (Pocket Books, $4.95.) After Carmine Galante was murdered in a Brooklyn restaurant in 1979, Federal investigators learned of a Mafia within the Mafia, which used a network of pizzerias to launder drug money. Last year, our reviewer, Teresa Carpenter, said Ralph Blumenthal's account of the case has ''narrative drive'' and real-life characters with ''texture and dimension.'' HIGH-TECH SOCIETY: The Story of the Information Technology Revolution, by Tom Forester. (MIT Press, $9.95.) When this primer on the computer revolution was published in 1987, our reviewer, Rob Kling, said it was ''broad ranging and engaging'' and for the most part ''written in amiably fluid prose.'' THE POSTMAN ALWAYS RINGS TWICE, by James M. Cain. (Vintage Crime, $6.95.) After it was published in 1934, this well-known tale of a drifter who schemes with a waitress to murder her husband was banned for obscenity in Boston. The former newspaperman's first novel ''makes Hemingway look like a lexicographer and Caldwell like a sob sister at her first eviction,'' Harold Strauss said in The Book Review. ''Cain can get down to the primary impulses of greed and sex in fewer words than any writer we know of.'' Published a year later, Cain's next novel, DOUBLE INDEMNITY ($6.95), is a variation on the same theme: an insurance salesman sells a woman a policy on her husband, then helps her kill the man. Vintage has also reissued two other books by Cain. MILDRED PIERCE ($6.95) is about a divorced woman who tries to support her children while staving off unscrupulous lovers. ''It has in it the deep, slow pull of the ancient ooze where worms and serpents crawled,'' Robert van Gelder said here in 1941. THREE BY CAIN ($9.95) contains ''Serenade,'' which is about a love triangle involving an opera singer, a conductor and a prostitute; ''Love's Lovely Counterfeit,'' about a group of gangsters in a Midwestern city; and a story of incest called ''The Butterfly.'' THE GREAT TRIUMVIRATE: Webster, Clay, and Calhoun, by Merrill D. Peterson. (Oxford University, $12.95.) With their oratorical skills, Daniel Webster, Henry Clay and John C. Calhoun dominated American politics for the first half of the 19th century. ''Basing his work on a careful combing of the original sources, [ Merrill D. Peterson ] has made a distinguished contribution to the study of American history,'' Donald B. Cole said here in 1987. ''He has reminded us of a generation of statesmen who died thinking they had preserved Jefferson's Republic without a civil war.''

title: Posters Renew Drama of World War I
description: LEAD: FOR the theme of an ideal summer art exhibition, what comes to mind just before ''a guided tour of hell'' is posters from World War I. The subject blocks out the sun. World War I was a grisly shock to Western civilization, not least because the scientific promise of the 20th century was used so perversely, in poison gas and bombs dropped from the sky.

title: A Wealth of Diversity in Fiber Art
description: ''FIBERARTS,'' a show and sale in the Chesebrough-Pond's Gallery at the Westport Center for the Arts from Wednesday through next Sunday, encompasses a wide variety of techniques and materials. About 30 artists have contributed works that include traditional rugs handwoven of cotton, baskets fashioned of paper, woolen blankets and delicate hand-knitted lace.

title: Vive la Contre-Revolution!
description: ''MY grandmother was guillotined,'' is the startling statement often heard in the Department of the Vendee. This Vendean habit of leaving out the greats when speaking of murdered ancestors brings the dark side of the French Revolution constantly into the present. The Vendee, where a savage popular rebellion against the revolution resulted in the massacre of roughly half the population by the armies of the revolutionary government, is just the place for those who want to escape the brouhaha of the bicentennial celebrations elsewhere in France. Most people in the Vendee see no reason to celebrate.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Tarrytown
description: LEAD: EACH weekday morning, hundreds of Rockland County commuters stream across the Tappan Zee Bridge to Westchester County to catch the Metro-North Commuter Railroad from Tarrytown to Manhattan. But when the railroad proposed to build a parking structure at the overburdened express-stop train station at no cost to local taxpayers, the village said no, thank you.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Brunch; Finding Good Food in Some Classic Settings
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in the Connecticut, Long Island, New Jersey and Westchester Sunday regional sections of The New York Times. Ratings at the end of each item - satisfactory, good, very good, excellent and extraordinary - are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. Box Tree

title: Texas Businessman Hands Out $10,000 Checks in State Senate
description: A millionaire handed out $10,000 checks on the State Senate floor one day this week while legislation that interested him was pending. He says the checks were political contributions, not an attempt to bribe the lawmakers.

title:
GARDENING;
Summer Chores That Are Keys to Success
description: LEAD: SUMMER brings its own set of chores for gardeners that will either assure the success of plantings or make it easier to care for them.

title: DANGEROUS TRAFFIC
description: After reading William Stockton's article ''Dangerous Traffic'' (June 4), I looked out my window in time to see another ''missed approach'' of a plane trying to land on La Guardia Airport's Runway 04, which is less than a mile from my house.

title: Why Do We Treat Woman's Work as Inferior?; Choice Is Too Limited
description: To the Editor:

title: Nuggets Are Sold, Newspaper Says
description: The Denver Post, quoting sources, said today that the Denver Nuggets have been sold to a group of Chicago investors for $65 million, but the team owner, Sidney Shlenker, said merely that negotiations were under way. ''I expect for something to be announced in the next few days,'' he said.

title: PERSPECTIVES: Battery Park City; Shaping the Pattern of Future Housing
description: AT Battery Park City, construction has achieved a steady rhythm. For all that has already been achieved in commercial and residential development on this 92-acre landfill site, the breadth of the undertaking is perhaps lost in the methodical block by block, neighborhood by neighborhood advance.

title: Stephanie Shell Is Wed to Kurt Read
description: Stephanie Shell, the daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Karl Shell of Ithaca, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Kurt Cushing Read, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter C. Read of Boston. The Rev. John M. Scott and the Rev. Charles M. Hawes 3d, Episcopal priests, officiated at the Sage Chapel at Cornell University.

title: Circle Rep's '5th of July' Shines at the John Drew
description: THE John Drew Theater in East Hampton has taken an exciting step by inviting New York's award-winning Circle Repertory Company to produce shows there.

title: Panama Red: Canvas Designer
description: Her name is Panama Red, a nickname with such sticking power that the red-haired Ms. Red won't tell anyone her real name anymore. So when it came time to open a canvas shop in Newport, R.I., and to put a trade name on the unusual line of duffel bags, totes and custom canvas work she was producing for the city's influx of yachtsmen, the name Panama Red fit just fine.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Compaq's Conquests in Europe
description: The sleek, sprawling factory nestled here in the Scottish countryside is just 18 months old, but it came as no real surprise on May 30 when the Compaq Computer Corporation announced a $40 million plan to double the size of its operation.

title: Becker Rallies to Block Lendl From Final
description: Ivan Lendl carried his own towels, lilac before the rain hit and pink thereafter, into his semifinal meeting with Boris Becker on Centre Court today, hoping they would provide a familiar, restorative touch during changeovers. Lendl makes life so difficult for himself here that he'll accept help from any friendly source, even a towel.

title: Lendl Mowed Down Again
description: Back in the old neighborhood, there was a guy who hated the way his lawn called feed me, cut me, water me while he was trying to listen to a ball game or read ''Martin Chuzzlewit.''

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: DR. CHRISTINE L. WILLIAMS;
Catching Cholesterol Problems Early
description: LEAD: ACCUMULATION of cholestoral - a wax-like substance known to clog the blood vessels - is not a problem restricted to the middle-aged or, for that matter, to adults. Experts in preventive cardiology say preschool children - particularly those whose families have a history of heart problems - should have their cholesterol tested and, when necessary, their diets modified.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: THE CHIP CONSORTIUM DEBATE;
Cooperation Is the Best Way to Beat Japan
description: LEAD: Sematech Inc., the semiconductor manufacturing technology consortium, was formed to restore semiconductor manufacturing leadership in the United States. Knowing only too well that America does not have the luxury of time, we built our fabrication facility in a record 32 weeks and beat our own deadline for producing the first semiconductor wafers at that facility earlier this year.

title: Courthouse Loses a Familiar Figure
description: LEAD: ''ELEGANT. When people said, 'How are you?' I always answered, elegant.'' Frank Mattera, 80 years old and blind for 54 of those years, was reminiscing about the job from which he has just retired: operator of the newsstand at the Westchester County Courthouse.

title: All-Star Voting Dismays a Fan
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Mighty MITI Loses Its Grip photo of Seiroku Kajiyama, MITI's chief, urging executives last month to buy more foreign goods (Haruyoshi Yamaguchi).
description: Two weeks ago, I. B. M. and other leaders of the American computer industry took a page out of Japan's post-war industrial history: They organized a cooperative venture, to rebuild a manufacturing industry - this one in memory chips - that has been devastated in trans-Pacific battle.

title: A Struggle to Compete in a Shrinking Market
description: For distillers, the 1980's have proved to be a prolonged hangover.

title: Abortion in Missouri Now: A Bit Harder to Get, a Great Deal More Divisive
description: Abortion has become only a little harder to obtain in Missouri in the days since the Supreme Court upheld a state law restricting it, but many expect an intense social and political confrontation between those who want to preserve the right to abortion and those who want to ban it almost entirely.

title: BUILDING AN ARSENAL OF BRANDS TO SURVIVE
description: Dwindling consumer demand for liquor is forcing distillers to consolidate. Last year 12 companies, led by Britain's Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. and the Seagram Company Ltd., based in Montreal, controlled 72 percent of all liquor sales in the United States - up from 67 percent in 1984, according to Mr. Maxwell. ''When you have a maturing market, you have consolidation,'' he said.

title: BAD TIMES ON THE BAYOU
description: Wayne King seems to have spent an inordinate spell standing on Interstate 10, peering at beer cans in the swamp, and he ventured no further into this profoundly spiritual culture than to attend a Jimmy Swaggart prayer meeting.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Prom for Seniors THE day after her senior prom, Janet Beatrice of Lindenhurst had no plans to go to the beach. She was too busy recovering. ''I woke up this morning and thought, 'What is this, my prom hangover?' '' she said. ''It's put me back 30 years.'' It also put her husband, Michael, back 30 years, she said. ''He woke up and said, 'I should have taken you to a motel last night.'

title: Creating a Thriller, Their Words Are Their Bond
description: Relentless, ruthless and rarely stopping to savor a martini, an implacable James Bond takes his license to kill literally in ''Licence to Kill,'' the 16th in the series of Bond movies produced by Albert (Cubby) Broccoli. That the barrel of this James Bond's Walther PPK is seldom cold is no accident. The 27-year-old series is adapting to 1989 newspaper headlines as well as to Timothy Dalton in the leading role. Whereas Mr. Dalton simply stepped into the finished script of the 1987 movie ''The Living Daylights,'' ''Licence to Kill,'' opening Friday, has been tailored to fit him.

title: 'Modern Ireland'
description: To the Editor:

title: The Vanity of Scholars
description: Some works of scholarship, like the compilation of dictionaries, legitimately take a lifetime. But with others, the reasons for delay can be less lofty: greed for glory, pride, or just plain old sloth.

title: FASHION: On the Street; Black: a Color For All Seasons
description: These are black days for fashion, thank goodness. When the humidity has frizzled both your mood and your hair, it is comforting to have something reliable to call on for a touch of elegance, and black certainly fills the bill. Whether it comes in the melodramatic shape of the newly hot Sicilian-influenced styles, the layered look from Japan, a simple tank-top dress that resembles a turn-of-the-century bathing costume (far right bottom), a sleeveless business sheath (below right), black has an unmistakable aura of sophistication.

title: Accessory Apartments Face Growing Legal Attention
description: LEAD: MANY Westchester communities have been forced to come to terms with a grass-roots solution to the housing shortage, one that meets the need but is often illegal.

title: THERE WAS REASON NOT TO TRUST THEM
description: ''RACIAL MATTERS'' The FBI's Secret File on Black America, 1960-1972. By Kenneth O'Reilly. 456 pp. New York: The Free Press. $24.95.

title: SHORTAGE OF ENTRANTS TO THE CLERGY CAUSING ALARM FOR U.S. RELIGIONS
description: Alarmed by signs that fewer gifted young people are joining the ranks of the clergy, religious leaders are groping for new ways to recruit candidates for religious careers. They warn that if they fail, the country, not just their congregations, faces a loss of moral leadership.

title: MEXICO AND BANKS NEARING AN ACCORD ON DEBT REDUCTION
description: Negotiators for Mexico and the commercial banks that lend to it have tentatively agreed on important elements of a plan to reduce the burden of Mexico's foreign debt and are close to a final accord, bankers said yesterday.

title: Astros' Bullpen Prevails
description: The Astros, who lead the majors in one-run victories this season, achieved their 23d one-run decision this afternoon in a 3-2 defeat of the Montreal Expos, who had won their eight previous games at the Astrodome.

title: The Punishment Of Oliver North
description: GERHARD A. GESELL, the unpredictable 79-year-old Federal District Judge who presided over the Iran-contra trial of Oliver L. North, saved a final surprise for last by punishing Mr. North for his crimes with a sentence that included a fine, community service and probation, but no prison term.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE COLD WAR ROMANCE OF LILLIAN HELLMAN AND JOHN MELBY. By Robert P. Newman. (University of North Carolina, $24.95) Lillian Hellman, the playwright and author, often chose friends who were not as celebrated or extraordinary as she was but just ordinary people who had one or two special characteristics that captured her fancy.

title: DATA UPDATE: July 9, 1989
The Browning of America, Part One
description: IT took them over a year to build our new house. We finally moved in during a torrential rainstorm. Of course our yard was a sea of mud, and the moving van couldn't get up the driveway since the driveway was mud and a few stones, and the decorative island the developer had planted in the middle of our cul-de-sac prevented a large van from making a turn up our driveway even if we had had a functional one.

title: Eve T. Hall and James Duplessie Wed
description: At St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn., Eve Taplin Hall, the daughter of Ruth Anne Binns Dohanos of Darien, Conn., and the late Alan M. Hall, was married yesterday to James John Duplessie, a son of Antoinette Duplessie of Bethesda, Md., and the late Arthur T. Duplessie. The Rev. Julio Rivera performed the ceremony.

title: Accounting Firms Plan to Merge
description: Arthur Andersen and Price Waterhouse, two of the largest accounting firms, confirmed that they would formally explore a merger. Deloitte, Haskins & Sells and Touche Ross, the smallest of the nation's Big Eight accounting firms, also agreed in principle to combine. Joseph E. Connor, chairman of Price Waterhouse, and Lawrence A. Weinbach, chief executive of Arthur Andersen, said they were undertaking talks to benefit from the continuing rapid globalization of world economies, the accelerating pace of technological change and the broad-based need for new services and investments. *

title: Cheryl A. Young Is Wed in Quebec
description: Cheryl A. Young, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alphonse E. Young of Brockton, Mass., was married last evening to Robert I. Carswell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Carswell of Brooklyn and Magog, Quebec. The Rev. Joseph LaReau, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at St. Patrice Parish in Magog.

title: Something Missing
description: To the Editor:

title: DEVOURED BY THE PAST
description: FROM BEIRUT TO JERUSALEM By Thomas L. Friedman. 525 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $22.95.

title: Soviets Test Nuclear Device
description: The Soviet Union exploded a nuclear device of up to 20 kilotons today at its test site near Semipalatinsk, the Tass press agency reported. The test, the fourth this year and the first conducted by Moscow since February, came after Bush Administration officials said Moscow has scaled back its nuclear testing.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the effect of the Civil Rights Act on the American political landscape stated the composition of the Southern Congressional delegation incorrectly in some editions. Out of 41 Congressional districts, there is only one black member of Congress.

title: Guys and Dolls at the Malls
description: The mall in Virgil, Tex., the small-town setting of David Byrne's ''True Stories,'' is as sanitized and anonymous as any airport terminal. Striding down its fluid passageways, Byrne, the rock performer turned film maker/narrator and bemused social commentator, is prompted to observe, ''People here are inventing their own system of beliefs. They're creating it, doing it, selling it. . . .'' And, he might have added, wearing it. It is show, tell and sell time.

title: Susan Stabler Plans to Wed Executive
description: Mr. and Mrs. Wells Stabler of Washington have made known plans for a September wedding of their daughter Susan Brooke Stabler and Stephen Hobbs Paneyko, a son of Leonore Lane Paneyko of Princeton, N.J., and the late Mirko Paneyko.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: LABORATORY TOURS

title: Hung Up by Sprint
description: To the Editor:

title: Loops and Drops, Squeals of Delight
description: LEAD: LAST Mother's Day, while other mothers were being showered with flowers and greeting cards, Irene Carpenter was screaming at her children. Her idea of maternal appreciation was having each of her five children ride with her on the largest looping roller coaster in the world, at Six Flags Great Adventure here.

title: Minority Contractors Push for Set-Aside Laws
description: Among the minority contractors, the recently completed Legislative Office Building in Hartford is seen as clear proof that discrimination exists in Conneticut construction circles. Because the building was a project of the legislative branch of government, it was exempt from a state set-aside law and less than 0.5 percent of its cost went to minority contractors.

title: Lora Jaffin Wed To D. J. Peters Jr.
description: At the Nassau Presbyterian Church in Princeton, N.J., Lora Webster Jaffin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Jaffin of Princeton, was married yesterday to Donald Joseph Peters Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peters of Catonsville, Md. The Rev. Dr. Wallace M. Alston Jr. officiated.

title: Exploring the Reefs Off the Sinai
description: IT was no great shark, maybe four feet long. Its tail moved slowly in clear water spangled with sunlight, just below a reef at the tip of the Sinai peninsula in Egypt. The Red Sea Fishwatchers' Field Guide, a laminated sheet showing many species of fish, identified it as a white-tip reef shark - harmless to humans but not to be ''touched or molested.'' The guide, however, did not say whether the shark was programmed to avoid touching or molesting humans. So the beach felt all the better for being regained untouched and unmolested.

title: MARGARITAS: A FAD LIKE FUZZY NAVELS?
description: Premium brands are not the only ones that are popular. The ''white goods'' market of vodka, gin, tequila and white rum has grown 60 percent in volume since 1977, to 70 million cases last year, according to Impact. Consumers are turning to these lighter-flavored, clear-colored spirits because they are good for mixing and don't require an acquired taste.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our house has tin ceilings that were previously painted with a flat paint. This paint is now chipping off in pieces, and I would like to repaint with an oil-based paint. Is there any way to remove all of the old paint without damaging the ceilings?

title: Root, Root, Root For Other Team
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The End of Asbestos Is Both Near and Far
description: THE Government took a big step toward ending the long sad saga of asbestos last week when, years after having conclusive medical evidence of the danger, it imposed a gradual ban on the widely used construction and insulating material.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Williamstown, Mass.;
Splicing Saves An Old Cinema
description: LEAD: IN an effort to save Images Cinema, one of the last downtown movie theaters in Berkshire County, the size of the cinema will be reduced and the remaining space in the building will be converted to retail and office use.

title: The East Demands Power And Finds It Hard to Supply
description: THE electric companies of the middle Atlantic states ran so short of power last summer that on two occasions the utility consortium that coordinates their production had to cut voltage to avoid blackouts. This year, with the summer less than one-third gone and the hottest weeks ahead, the consortium has already taken that step twice.

title: Gayle Levy Wed To Fellow Lawyer
description: Gayle Pamela Levy and Geoffrey Edward Liebmann, New York lawyers who graduated from the University of Chicago Law School in 1986, were married last evening in Wilmington, Del. Rabbi Elliot J. Holin officiated at the Brandywine Country Club.

title: Miss Belica Weds Lance Contrucci
description: Marina Elena Belica, a daughter of Paul Belica of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., and the late Mary H. Belica, was married yesterday to Lawrence Franklin Contrucci Jr., a son of Marsha J. Contrucci and Mr. Contrucci Sr., both of Indiana, Pa. The Rev. Harold P. Theriault performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Theresa in Briarcliff Manor.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
For Tinton Falls, a 5-Year Transformation
description: LEAD: OVER the last five years, much of the open countryside in Tinton Falls has been transformed into a mix of housing, small commercial and warehouse complexes. Now, this Monmouth County borough is entering the next phase of its economic growth with the development of first-class office space.

title: Where Little Saba Looms Large
description: SABA is an island where all of life's accouterments are reduced to unexpected simplicity: a pastry shop named Mom's, a Chinese restaurant called the Chinese Restaurant, a population of about 1,000, all of whom seem to be named either Hassell or Johnson. Underneath Saba, the world is more complex. Seventy feet below Diamond Rock - a starch-white, guano-covered pinnacle some 300 yards from shore - a wriggling azure blob turns out to be a school of blue tangs feeding on an uprotected mass of fish eggs. A seemingly bare patch of brain coral harbors a single, tiny cleaner shrimp, only too willing to clean the dirt from beneath the fingernail of a human visitor. Away from the coral-covered rock, what appears to be an empty expanse of rippled white sand suddenly teems with life: a school of whiskered goatfish peck for food, a manta ray glides by and a giant barracuda hovers, silently watching.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Talking Too Plosively

title: San Diego Eyes Its Big Bad Neighbor
description: Fear and loathing lurk beneath placid San Diego, with its near perfect weather, skiffs bobbing in Mission Bay and profuse gardens of oleander and jasmine.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: BENT ON HOLLYWOOD
description: SOMEBODY'S BABY By Claire Harrison. 244 pp. New York: Doubleday.

title: New Hot Line Offers the Latest Information on Parks Events
description: LEAD: THE new number to call to find out what is happening in County Parks and Recreation programs is 285-PARK.

title: Giamatti Should Resign
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: With America Well Wired, Cable Industry Is Changing
description: With most of the nation now wired for reception, the cable television industry is entering a new phase, aiming for an even greater surge of growth based on better programming and more aggressive marketing.

title: U.S. Envoy Is Center of New Dispute in Rome
description: His nomination as United States Ambassador to Italy raised questions in Rome about his qualifications and complaints in Washington about his lapses into undiplomatic language.

title: A New Embassy Mixes the Appropriate And the Awkward
description: The new Canadian embassy here is not like Washington's other embassies. First, it is nowhere near the rest of them; instead of being off amid the elegant mansions of Massachusetts Avenue, this one is right on Pennsylvania Avenue, four blocks from the Capitol and across the street from the National Gallery of Art. To be any closer to the center of official Washington it would have to have been in the middle of the Mall.

title: Now, North Korea Would Like to Reach Out
description: FOR four decades, North Korea has confined its trade relations and barter arrangements mostly to Communist nations. Now it seems to be trying to open up parts of its economy to the rest of the world. But the effort does not appear likely to produce a transformation as dramatic as its neighbor China has experienced; here, new visions of economic openness remain tightly restricted by older dreams of self-sufficiency and ideological purity.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Stanford; California-Moscow Tie: Joint Student Magazine
description: Students at Pepperdine and Stanford Universities have teamed up with Soviet students to establish a Soviet-American student magazine.

title: The Way I Live Now
description: IN MAY 1988, I ATTENDED THE AMERICAN BOOKSELLERS Association convention in Anaheim, Calif. Every A.B.A. has its ''big books,'' and that year, one of the biggest was a novel called ''At Risk'' by Alice Hoffman. It was the story of an 11-year-old girl who contracts AIDS from a blood transfusion.
