I was just one of many gay men at the A.B.A. that year, and looking back, I think we were all a little frightened by the brouhaha about ''At Risk'' - the huge pyramids of glossy readers' copies, the enormous advertising budget, the ''six-figure paperback floor.''

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: DR. LESLEY MANDEL MORROW;
Developing Children Into Avid Readers
description: LEAD: WITH summer in full swing, legions of parents will urge their children to use their free time to read. Dr. Lesley Mandel Morrow says it takes more than exhortation to convert young people who avoid books into book lovers.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: PLAYS IN PROGRESS

title: Why India Is Still Failing To Stop Its Population Surge
description: WHEN India's Ministry of Health submitted its annual report to be considered in framing the country's 1989-90 budget, it included a cry for help. ''Population control can no longer be the responsibility of one ministry or department,'' it said. ''The entire planning process must be geared toward controlling population.''

title: Neneh Cherry Puts a New Spin On Dance-Pop
description: Day and night, radio stations pump them out: computerized drumbeats and synthesizer lines that plink, hum and kick behind girlish voices vowing love or striking tough poses. It's the style Madonna built by putting a pop veneer on post-disco dance music, and it has turned out to be as durable as it is limited.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Belleville $152,440 9 Hill Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 43-year-old ranch; eat-in-kitchen, finished basement, 5-zone heat; taxes $2,796. Jackson $149,900 56 Forest Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 24-year-old Cape Cod; family room, 1-car garage, new roof, c/a; taxes $2,272. Livingston $550,000 10 Tremont Terrace 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 28-year-old colonial; 2-car garage, fireplace, screened porch; taxes $6,137. Ocean Township $150,000 1500 North Wanamassa Drive 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 37-year-old colonial; dining room, front porch, h/w floors; taxes $2,100. Paramus $227,500 382 Ridgewood Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 30-year-old split level; full basement, w/w carpeting, recently remodeled; taxes $1,780. West Orange $325,000 15 Overlook Avenue 6-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 42-year-old colonial; fireplace, 2-car garage, deck; taxes $4,884. OTHER AREAS Rye, N.Y. $585,000 4 Stanley Keys Court 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 6-year-old contemporary; country kitchen, family room w/ fireplace, Jacuzzi, patio, 2-car garage; taxes $8,693. New Milford, Conn. $126,000 9 Pleasant Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 88-year-old Victorian; close to town, 0.25 acre; taxes $1,100. Glen Cove $183,000 18 Jackson Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 50-year-old colonial; dining room, deck, hardwood floors; taxes $1,200.

title: Report Says 340 Died At Soviet Match in '82
description: As many as 340 fans were crushed to death at a 1982 international soccer match in Moscow as a result of police incompetence, a Soviet newspaper said today.

title: 'I AM ALEC. PLEASE LOOK AFTER ME'
description: BICYCLE DAYS By John Burnham Schwartz. 253 pp. New York: Summit Books.

title: Car Rental
description: To the Editor: With all the advertising and talk about hidden charges one sees from the automobile rental companies it is nice to be able to tell of an incident in which costs and competition were not the overriding concern of the company or party involved. Rather, courtesy and care for a distressed traveler were.

title: KOCH AGAINST KOCH
description: In his article on Mayor Edward I. Koch, Sam Roberts writes: ''Few experts, after all, anticipated the emergencies engendered by crack, homelessness and AIDS'' (''Koch Against Koch,'' June 11).

title: PASTIMES: Bridge
description: Those who think that a Caucus-Race is something vaguely Congressional are quite wrong, and should refresh their memories of the subject by consulting chapter three of ''Alice in Wonderland.'' The chief feature of a Caucus-Race is that everyone moves in a circle and occasionally drops out. This was the procedure April 27 at the Cavendish Club in New York City when 13 of the Lewis Carroll characters gathered to contest a bridge Caucus-Race invented by the White Knight.

title: POSTINGS: New Rochelle Mall; A 50% Expansion
description: The New Rochelle Mall in Westchester County is to grow by 50 percent, with the addition of a 12-story building that is to include a 12-screen movie theater and eight floors of offices. The $30 million project, which is scheduled for completion in 1991, is to be erected on the site of an unused ice-skating rink and plaza.

title: Men's Style; THE HEAT IS ON
description: In an era of global warming trends and equatorial summers, men's clothing is following suit.

title: Players' Anger Roils in Clubhouses
description: Tim Teufel of the Mets had four hits in the 8-3 triumph over the Reds yesterday at Shea Stadium, but his accomplishments on the field were overshadowed by his role as a protagonist in an eighth-inning brawl that was still simmering off the field after the game.

title: Work Is Now Option On Youth Probation
description: ON a recent Saturday six young people 14 to 16 years old were busy weeding and gardening at St. Peter's Church in Yonkers. But these teen-agers were not simply volunteering their time: the work was part of their probation sentence for such juvenile-delinquent offenses as petty larceny and criminal possession of stolen property.

title: Review/Opera; Comissiona Conducts 'Il Barbiere'
description: Rossini's ''Barbiere di Siviglia'' at the New York City Opera on Friday night began with some promise. The overture offered not the most settled of ensemble playing nor the most balanced of sound, but the evening's conductor, Sergiu Comissiona, found just the right kind of well-judged forward impulse. The intent compensated for the deed.

title: How the Devils Melted Soviet Ice
description: Sitting around a Montreal hotel room the night before the 1983 National Hockey League draft, John McMullen, the owner of the New Jersey Devils, pondered the struggle of their first season. Now he had a question for Max McNab, the vice president of operations, and Billy MacMillan, then the general manager and coach.

title: Beyond Nostalgia: Reviving a Tough Game of Stickball
description: IF you want to hit a home run in stickball at the Trenchard Street playground here, belt a tennis ball about 200 feet toward the abandoned building across the road. With two lanes of traffic whizzing by what is considered the outfield, it is doubtful a fielder will snare it. Or find the ball once it lands, in the untrimmed grass in front of what was once Public School 4.

title: Bush Heads to Europe With Economic Plans And Economic Limits
description: FOR President Bush, this is the week of his debut in the international economic arena. His first stops are in Poland and Hungary, to savor the winds of perestroika. In return for ''a little more democracy, a little more openness,'' as he put it last week, Mr. Bush promises a little economic aid. Then in Paris, he is to join the heads of the other leading industrial democracies for his first economic summit.

title: Latin Literacy: Pro Bono Redux
description: As a classicist and educator by profession and an educated and literate person, I take issue with a recent letter to the editor [ Is the Use of Latin 'Pro Bono?' May 28 ] . The authoress finds fault with the 'cavalier use of Latin' in our language in light of the growing illiteracy among our student population (am I to suppose then that the rest of the American populace is equally illiterate and so has no understanding and appreciation of Latin phrases?).

title:
HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: SOUNDINGS;
Another Young Fiddler Faces a Classic Test
description: LEAD: Although overplayed, the Tchaikovsky concerto remains a litmus test by which young violinists are judged. Requiring less maturity than the Beethoven and Brahms concertos, the Tchaikovsky offers a perfect balance of heart-on-sleeve emotion, virtuoso display and poetic insight. It's no wonder that up-and-coming violinists turn to it - along with the Mendelssohn and

title:
FOCUS: Japanese Investors;
They Don Hard Hats for a New U.S. Role
description: LEAD: IN the face of an uncertain office market, a $500 million mixed-use project rising here is moving forward with the help of a Japanese partner, providing further evidence of the emergence of Japanese institutions as active participants in new construction projects in the United States.

title: Caroline Goldberg To Wed S. L. Saxl
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald Jerome Goldberg of Philadelphia have announced August wedding plans for their daughter, Caroline Virginia Walter Goldberg, and Stephen Lawrence Saxl, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sherman Joel Saxl of New York.

title: Treatment For Addicts Is as Elusive As Ever
description: DESPITE promises this year from Governor Mario M. Cuomo and Mayor Edward I. Koch to provide significantly more treatment slots to addicts who need them, New York state's drug treatment system remains overloaded and under financed, its officials say.

title: HARSH WORDS FOR POETIC BABBLE
description: WHITE PAPER On Contemporary American Poetry. By J. D. McClatchy. 351 pp. New York: Columbia University Press. $37.50.

title: OPRAH TALK
description: Oprah Winfrey presents facts, guests and situations in a fresh manner (because of who she is) and we make of it what we will. That's pretty good for television. She may be guilty of ''superficial curiosity,'' but that is equally true of every moderator and anchor that I have ever seen on television. JUDE MCGEE Santa Monica, Calif.

title: Gail M. Quigley to Wed Ens. Townsend Morey 3d
description: August wedding plans for Gail Marie Quigley and Ens. Townsend Reed Morey 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morey Jr. of Loudonville, N.Y., and Edgartown, Mass., have been made known by the prospective bride's mother, Mrs. Charles F. Quigley of South Natick, Mass., and West Center Harbor, N.H.

title: Sarah H. Perkins Becomes a Bride
description: Sarah Harrison Perkins, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John S. H. Perkins of Bronxville, N.Y., and Sarasota, Fla., was married yesterday at the Reformed Church in Bronxville to John Richard Cortese Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Cortese of Albany and Lake George, N.Y. The Rev. Frank A. Goodwin, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony. Mrs. Cortese graduated from the Masters School and attended Rollins College. She was until recently a sales associate with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in Yonkers. Her father retired as the president and chief executive officer at Volkswagen of America in Englewood Cliffs, N.J.

title: Question Of the Week; What Should Happen To Rose?
description: If Pete Rose is found guilty, we should all line up and he can pay us $15 for his signature. SUSAN SCHOTZ RHODES Waban, Mass.

title: VIEWS FROM THE BARRICADES
description: WORDS OF FIRE, DEEDS OF BLOOD: The Mob, the Monarchy, and the French Revolution. By Olivier Bernier. (Little, Brown, $21.95.) A history of the French Revolution poses two nearly insurmountable ''story problems'': first, in easing the reader through those stodgy early chapters in which the deficit mounts and a series of finance ministers fail to grasp the situation; then, in finding a way to stitch together a coherent narrative from the ragbag of obscure factions, variegated personalities and unaccountable plot turns that make up the later course of events. Olivier Bernier, who has written biographies of Louis XIV and Louis XV and ''Secrets of Marie Antoinette,'' overcomes these difficulties by borrowing the suspense novelist's technique of dramatic rearrangement. After a quick opening account of the first mob invasion of the Tuileries Palace on June 20, 1792, he flashes back to the storming of the Bastille, builds up to the royal family's decision to flee Paris, then jumps back to the start of Louis XIV's reign and the events that led to the forming of the National Assembly. Then he picks up the flight to Varennes and takes the narrative through the trial and execution of Marie Antoinette, after which, says Mr. Bernier, ''the Revolution had essentially run its course.'' In spite of its many-pronged title, then, ''Words of Fire, Deeds of Blood: The Mob, the Monarchy, and the French Revolution'' is mainly the story of the luckless reign of Louis XVI, a man who ''while unable to govern, refused to be less than an absolute king.'' As in a novel, economies are achieved by sharp characterizations. Philippe d'Orleans is an underhanded rogue. Mirabeau is the one man who sees the situation clearly. Lafayette is vain, indecisive, self-seeking. And the King and Queen, in their efforts to spur a counterrevolution, are guilty of deceit and ineffectuality - and of outright treason. Mr. Bernier is highly readable and has a good eye for detail (on the night before his execution, Louis XVI had a supper of ''two chicken breasts and cookies accompanied by Malaga wine''), but the demands put on him by his title leave him with a book thinner and more diffuse than the one he might have written. At the same time, Mr. Bernier is too honest a historian to romanticize his characters, or to sidestep the story problems in a reign symbolized by the King's arrest at Varennes: ''the half-measures adopted too late, the disasters that invariably followed, the invincible lethargy that precluded rapid, effective action.'' This is a well-supported assessment, but as a story line it impedes the very qualities that this book seems to promise: fire and catharsis, the ring of high rhetoric and the shrill of a bloodthirsty mob.

title:
TELEVISION;
In Quest of the Many Faces of Democracy
description: LEAD: At the back of Patrick Watson's home in central Toronto there is a bright white room. It used to be a library containing some 1,200 books of philosophy and poetry as well as first editions of Scott Fitzgerald and Virginia Woolf. A fire destroyed them about a year ago, fortunately not harming the other 7,500 books in the house, and they were replaced by two walls of videotapes, two VCR's, a photocopier and a large black TV set.

title: VIEWS FROM THE BARRICADES
description: LEAD: THE OXFORD HISTORY OF THE FRENCH REVOLUTION. By William Doyle. (Clarendon/Oxford University, $29.95.) William Doyle offers no fireworks, just traditional, scholarly, narrative history in ''The Oxford History of the French Revolution,'' a chronological account of the Great Event. If you want to know the who, what and when of the Revolution, here is where to find it.

title: OPRAH TALK
description: I am thoroughly disgusted by Oprah Winfrey's arrogant and self-serving theory of ''the Universe'' (''The Importance of Being Oprah,'' by Barbara Grizzuti Harrison, June 11). Her claim that she was ''born for greatness'' ideologically contradicts her convenient reliance on free will. Furthermore, her accusation that welfare mothers consciously ''choose'' to be such leads me to believe that her boyfriend, Stedman Graham, is not the only Republican in this wonder couple of the 1980's. KATHLEEN MARLEY Bethlehem, Pa.

title: DANGEROUS TRAFFIC
description: The cause of dangerous traffic - the airway congestion in the New York area -does not lie in too few air-traffic controllers or inadequate airports. Rather, it is the result of our unbalanced transportation system.

title: Kristin Lund to Marry a Psychologist
description: Diane Lund and Erik Lund of Lexington, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kristin Valerie Lund, to Dr. Edmund C. Neuhaus 3d, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Edmund C. Neuhaus of North Bellmore, L.I. An August wedding is planned.

title: Upset in the Tidal For Three Engines
description: Three Engines, a steady and improving campaigner, ran down Alwasmi in the final yards to win the $121,400 Tidal Handicap by a head yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: THE PRINCELY PROFITS AND ALLURE OF PREMIUM BRANDS
description: Distillers are toasting one encouraging trend: Americans are drinking less, but they are drinking better.

title: It All Started With One Tug on a Cord
description: It was a sequence of unpredictable events - some perhaps avoidable -that left more than 2,600 rush-hour passengers stranded on stifling, unlit subway cars Friday night, causing many riders to panic, break windows and doors and begin streaming into the dark tunnels outside the Queens Plaza station, Transit Authority officials said yesterday.

title: LOVE WITH THE FARMER'S DAUGHTER
description: A FARM UNDER A LAKE By Martha Bergland. 199 pp. St. Paul: Graywolf Press. $16.

title: INSIDE
description: Fallout of Israel's Vote Plan

title: Change, the Only Certainty
description: ONE day more than three decades ago, I went for a walk on my lunch hour with two co-workers near the building on Long Island where wer were employed. It was a walk I have remembered over the years.

title: When the Sun Becomes a Deadly Enemy
description: HOW I loved the sun. As a child on the beaches of Far Rockaway, later as a teen-ager strutting and sunning myself on the sands of Coney Island, my love affair with the outdoors gave me a happy outlook. Sunny days brought a sunny disposition.

title: Snorkeling
description: To the Editor: When my husband and I became interested in snorkeling a few years ago, we discovered that there were not many people who were knowledgeable about snorkeling vacations, so we did our own research. While it is true that weather in the Caribbean can be uncertain in September and October (Q & A, May 14), I am surprised that you did not suggest Curacao or Bonaire, both of which are said to be outside the hurricane belt.

title: TALK TO PAKISTAN, BUSH URGES INDIA
description: In an effort to cool the growing arms race in the region, President Bush has privately urged Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India to forge closer ties with Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto of Pakistan, Administration officials say.

title: For One, Life Without a Maid
description: I RECENTLY met a woman who is the mother of 10 and co-owner with her husband of a local ladies' clothing store. She was calm, well-groomed and seemingly well-rested. ''How do you manage so much?'' I asked in awe. ''You manage because you have to manage,'' she answered. ''You do what you have to do. Whoever said that life is supposed to be easy?''

title: Summertime, But the Music Won't Be That Easy
description: ''The fast sketch is: Richard dies and what the hell do we do now?'' Richard is Richard Wagner. The sketch is Paul Zukofsky's explanation for the series of eight weekend programs devoted to the world of Debussy and Bartok. And already you should have some notion that Summergarden - the annual summer series of free concerts offered in the Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Sculpture Garden of the Museum of Modern Art - is no typical outdoor concert series.

title: Bailing Out
description: The MIG-23 fighter flown by Col. Nikolai Skurigin last week was not as badly damaged as he thought. Colonel Skurigin noticed smoke from one engine right after he took off on a training flight from Kohlberg, Poland. The pilot ejected soon after takeoff; the plane kept going, and going and going. The pilotless MIG picked up an escort of United States fighters from the Netherlands as it headed toward the English Channel. It did not make it. It crashed into a house in Belgium, killing a man. The next day, the Soviet Union offered to compensate the dead man's family, and Colonel Skurigin publicly apologized, saying, ''If I could have foreseen such tragic consequences to this pilotless flight, I would have stayed in the plane to the end.''

title: PRETORIA LEADER AND MANDELA MEET IN HINT OF RELEASE
description: Nelson R. Mandela, South Africa's most celebrated political prisoner, met informally Wednesday with President P. W. Botha, the South African Government disclosed today.

title: With Interfaith Marriages, Conflict Over Role of Rabbis
description: A picture caption last Sunday about a custom-designed ketuba, the Jewish marriage document, omitted the designers' names. It was made by Sylvia Wolff, a North Tarrytown calligrapher, and Francine Fierstein, a Scarsdale artist.

title: Deserter in 1969 Given Suspended Jail Term
description: A military judge has ordered a bad-conduct discharge and a suspended prison term for a Navy man who for two decades led a normal life within 10 miles of the base from which he deserted.

title: Sally P. Zimmer To Wed in August
description: Nancy Child Zimmer of Portland, Conn., and the Rev. Layton P. Zimmer of Wailuku, Hawaii, have announced August wedding plans for their daughter, Sally Paine Zimmer, and Peter Runkel Knight, a son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Thomas Knight of Rye, N.Y.

title: Ruling May Spur Recycling Efforts
description: LEAD: A NEW interpretation of the Federal Clean Air Act may alter requirements for incinerators planned for Long Island, and also spur recycling programs, Federal and state officials said last week.

title: Outdoors; Near a Hudson Dam, Fish Cooperate
description: When challenged to find good fishing on a big river, one can rarely go wrong by exploring the tailrace of any dams that occur along it. There is something about the live waters below these barriers that seems to gather fish in disproportionate numbers. The Hudson River has one such place, the Federal Dam, at the head of tidewater, just above Albany.

title: Victor Lopez-Balboa Weds Ms. Huber
description: At the Central Presbyterian Church in New York, Linda Susan Pickens Huber, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harley L. Pickens of Princeton Junction, N.J., was married yesterday to Victor Manuel Lopez-Balboa, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Enrique Lopez-Balboa of Montclair, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Victoria Erikson officiated.

title:
ART;
Using 'Love Red' as Signature
description: LEAD: IT is tempting to say that what Georgia O'Keeffe is to New Mexico, Oscar Bluemner is to New Jersey. Both artists cast their respective territories in highly symbolic terms, distilling in the language of modern art what they sensed was the essence of place. The link goes deeper than this: the two artists were friends in the early decades of the century, and Bluemner wrote an exhibition catalogue for O

title: Joan Fitzgerald Plans Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Walter P. Fitzgerald of Rye, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter Joan Reid Fitzgerald to Christopher Vincent Clarke, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Clarke Jr. of Southport, Conn. An August wedding is planned.

title: HATRED AND OTHER JEWELS OF ASIA
description: GOD'S DUST A Modern Asian Journey. By Ian Buruma. 267 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $18.95.

title: Eleanor Hyland Patterson Is Married
description: Eleanor Hyland Patterson, the daughter of Dorothy M. Wallace of Baltimore and William Patterson of Cartaxo, Portugal, was married yesterday to Charles Ridings Schaller Jr., a son of Mrs. Sanford G. Simmons of Greenwich, Conn., and Savannah, Ga., and Charles R. Schaller of Fairfield, Conn., at the Congregational Church in Phippsburg, Me. The Rev. William Cleary officiated. The bride, who was presented at the Bachelor's Cotillon in Baltimore, graduated from St. Paul's School for Girls in Brooklandville, Md., and the University of New Hampshire and is studying for a master's degree in museum studies at Harvard University. She is a staff assistant at the research and financial administration office at Harvard for the archeological exploration of Sardis, Turkey. Her father owns William Patterson Ltd., an export company in Cartaxo. The bridegroom, a third-year student at the Vermont Law School, graduated from the University of New Hampshire. His father is a management consultant in Fairfield for the chemical industry.

title:
IDEAS & TRENDS;
Saboteurs for a Better Environment
description: LEAD: ON May 30, in the darkness of an Arizona desert evening, some 30 agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested two men and a woman who the authorities said were trying to topple a tower that carried high-voltage lines to the Central Arizona Project, a mammoth irrigation system opposed by many environmentalists.

title: U.S. Is Urging Vast Effort to Treat Million People Infected With AIDS Virus
description: Federal health authorities are urging a vast new effort to encourage medical examinations to find and treat all the estimated 1 million or more Americans infected with the AIDS virus, saying that drugs can prolong the lives of many if they can be found early enough.

title: LEAN ON HIM
description: LAYING DOWN THE LAW Joe Clark's Strategy for Saving Our Schools. By Joe Clark with Joe Picard. Illustrated. 207 pp. Washington: Regnery Gateway. $17.95.

title: I.B.M.'s Top Scientist
description: When a breakthrough in superconductivity was first made in 1986 it came from researchers at the International Business Machines Corporation in Zurich. Today the world's largest computer maker is taking an increasingly global view of science and engineering. Its most advanced four-million-bit memory chips are being made in manufacturing centers in Europe and Japan, as well as in the United States.

title: Free Trade's Price
description: To the Editor:

title: 'ALASKA' OR BUST
description: JOURNEY By James A. Michener. 244 pp. New York: Random House. $16.95.

title: The Purloined Party
description: Francois Mitterrand's 200th birthday party has got out of hand. Plans for celebrating the bicentennial of the French Revolution have been in the making for nearly a decade, with drastic changes reflecting changes of government.

title: Vietnam Memories: The War Within
description: BOMBS seemed to explode inches away from my unprotected skull, while grenades soared like bats all around me, draining the blood from all who stood in their way. Tanks roared in, grinding the soft, moist jungle earth. The Vietnam War was always at its most exciting in Theater No. 3 of the Mid-Plaza Sixplex.

title: If Pete Rose Has Hurt Baseball, He Must Go
description: To the Editor:

title: Students' Articles Find Their Way To Other Readers
description: Last fall, Andrea Simakis, as part of her requirements as a journalism graduate student at New York University, submitted an article to her professor on a growing trend toward tattooing among affluent teen-agers.

title: Jon Planas: Painter
description: Jon Planas, a Peruvian-born artist known for hand-painted jackets that have been bought by Madonna, Bob Geldof, Cyndi Lauper and other notables of the rock world, has been anointed by Absolut Vodka: the 29-year-old Mr. Planas has just finished an illustration for the company's advertising.

title: A Fall Wedding For Miss Hudson
description: Mr. and Mrs. Fletcher L. Hudson of Germantown, Tenn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katherine Ann Hudson, to David George Zrike, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond W. Zrike of Greenwich, Conn. An October wedding is planned.

title: Being Chinese Means Never Having To Say I Love You
description: AS Carolyn was helping me to clean up after dinner last night, she asked me rather unexpectedly, ''Mom, have you ever kissed Grandma?'' ''No.'' I put away my tray. ''Have you ever told her that you love her?'' ''No. Why?'' ''Why not?'' Yes, why not? I stopped to think. It simply is not our custom to show our affections openly. We Chinese are trained since childhood to hide our emotions. I grew up in a conservative family in Hong Kong and kissing my Mom would embarrass both of us. True, I never told her that I love her. I assume she knows.

title: Jean Marie Flynn Wed To Thomas J. McNiff
description: Jean Marie Flynn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Flynn of Spring Lake, N.J., was married there yesterday to Thomas J. McNiff, a son of Thomas J. McNiff of East Windsor, N.J., and the late Joan A. McNiff. The Rev. Ronald Richardson, an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at St. Catherine's Roman Catholic Church.

title: N.F.L. Search: More at Stake Than Finding a New Leader
description: The National Football League owners' circuitous search for a new commissioner involves much more than just finding the best man for a crucial job. Actually, Jim Finks, the 61-year-old president and general manager of the New Orleans Saints, has the support of more than 19 owners, and 19 votes is the number required to make him chief.

title: Review/Pop; A Rock Beat for Dancing, With a Zairian Twist
description: The set by the Zairian singer and keyboardist Ray Lema at S.O.B.'s on Thursday night had a stillborn feel to it; the sound system was feeding back and the group looked sullen. Under different circumstances, the band could probably have played better.

title: Residents Buying Own Mobile Park
description: LEAD: ONE day last April, the 45 families at the Parkview Mobile Home Park in the fledgling Suffolk County village of Pine Valley were informed by their landlord that he was planning to sell to a developer the 6.75-acre park, which lies along the Peconic River.

title: Charles Garvin: Cassette Producer
description: Anyone who has ever painstakingly put together a cassette tape of favorite songs gleaned from various records, to play in the car, at a party or at the beach, will understand what drove Charles Garvin. The 36-year-old former Rhodes Scholar, Harvard-trained lawyer, co-author of two books on economic policy and partner in a corporate-consulting concern spent five years and raised $12 million to try to carve a spot in the music business for custom cassettes.

title: Why Do We Treat Woman's Work as Inferior?
description: To the Editor:

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: SAN FRANCISCO;
Code Shifts Aid Loft Dwellers
description: LEAD: THE use of living/working space in older commercial lofts is growing here because of zoning and building code changes adopted a year ago that made it more affordable.

title: Glasgow Isn't Paris, But...
description: SHORTLY AFTER EDDIE FRIEL BECAME chief executive of the Greater Glasgow Tourist Board, in 1983, he wandered into a downtown hotel and asked the clerk what there was to do in Glasgow on a Sunday afternoon. ''Go to Edinburgh,'' she replied without looking up.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: PROUD KNIGHT, FAIR LADY The Twelve Lais of Marie de France. Translated by Naomi Lewis. Illustrated by Angela Barrett. 100 pp. New York: Viking Kestrel. $19.95. (All ages) EAST OF THE SUN & WEST OF THE MOON By Nancy Willard. Illustrated by Barry Moser. 64 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $14.95. (All ages)

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.$375,000 34 Magnolia Road 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 27-year-old ranch; fireplace, family room, 2 patios, 2-car garage, 0.55 acre; taxes $5,675. Harrison, N.Y.$750,000 90 Park Drive North 7-bedroom, 5 1/2-bath, 57-year-old Tudor; library, solarium/greenhouse, 4 fireplaces, 4,500 square feet, pool; taxes $10,846. Rye, N.Y.$585,000 4 Stanley Keys Court 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 6-year-old contemporary; country kitchen, family room w/ fireplace, Jacuzzi, patio, 2-car garage; taxes $8,693. New Milford, Conn.$126,000 9 Pleasant Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 88-year-old Victorian; close to town, 0.25 acre; taxes $1,100. Norwalk, Conn.$201,000 Old Trolley Way 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 28-year-old ranch; sunken living room, finished basement, 0.2 acre; taxes $2,804. Trumbull, Conn.$288,000 68 Hammertown Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 10-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen w/pantry, pond, 0.5 acre; taxes $3,253. OTHER AREAS Glen Cove, L.I.$183,000 18 Jackson Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 50-year-old colonial; dining room, deck, hardwood floors; taxes $1,200. Glen Head, L.I.$275,000 91 Todd Drive North 2-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 30-year-old split level; fireplace, patio, 2-car garage; taxes $4,600. Belleville, N.J.$152,440 9 Hill Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 43-year-old ranch; eat-in-kitchen, finished basement, 5-zone heat; taxes $2,796.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Cycling LeMond Still Has Lead: Greg LeMond of the United States retained the lead in the Tour de France yesterday after an easy ride in which most of the pack gathered strength for the mountain stages coming in two days. Etienne DeWilde of Belgium outsprinted Jean-Claude Colotti of France to take the seventh stage -160 1/2 miles, from Poitiers to Bordeaux - in 7 hours 21 minutes 57 seconds. LeMond kept his five-second advantage over Laurent Fignon of France in the overall standing of the 23-day, 2,020-mile event.(AP) Harness Racing HH Killington Wins: HH Killington, the 3-5 favorite driven by Jody Stafford, led all the way last night to win the $138,479 Dexter Cup at Yonkers Raceway, the first major race of the year for 3-year old trotters. HH Killington was clocked in 2:02 1/5 and finished a length ahead of Swirlabout, driven by Bruce Riegle. HH Killington paid $3.20 for $2 to win.(AP) Qualifiers for Meadowlands Pace: Dexter Nukes, Kentucky Spur and Shipps Scorch each won elimination races Friday night at the Meadowlands in East Rutherford, N.J., to qualify for the $852,000 Meadowlands Pace on July 14. The three winners, all betting favorites, were among 10 3-year-old pacers to qualify for the Meadowlands Pace. Dexter Nukes won the first elimination in the fastest time of the night, 1:51 3/5.(AP) Road Racing Lessa Wins Qualifying Race: Ewaldo Lessa was timed in 4 minutes 36 seconds at Central Park yesterday to win the first of three qualifying races for the Mercedes Fifth Avenue Mile, to be run Sept. 23. Jose Ribeiro finished second in 4:37, with David Stein third in 4:39. Kathy McIntyre was the women's winner in 5:17, followed by Cookie Cruz in 5:35. The second qualifying race is set for July 29, and the third one will be Aug. 19.(AP) Horse Show Lenehan Wins on Normandy: Leslie Lenehan, winner of the 1989 United States Open jumping championship, rode Normandy to a comfortable, fault-free victory yesterday in the Lake Placid Speed Stake phase of the I Love New York show. Lenehan, of Westport, Conn., finished the 12-jump, 492-yard course in 51.32 seconds to best 42 other riders. Margie Goldstein of Miami rode Apple King to second place, fault-free in 53.25 seconds. Ludger Beerbaum of West Germany was third with a clean run of 53.77 seconds on Suleiman.(AP) Archery South Korean Women Win: South Korea swept to victory in the women's team final at the world championships yesterday in Lausanne, Switzerland. The Soviet team won the men's competition, 11 points ahead of the second-place United States. The American team of Allen Rasor, Jay Barrs and Christopher Yeoman scored a total of 976 points. (AP) Boxing Mugabi Captures Title: John (the Beast) Mugabi won the World Boxing Council super-welterweight title yesterday when the defending champion, Rene Jacquot of France, twisted his left ankle in the first round and couldn't continue in the scheduled 12-round fight in Sergy-Pontoise, France. Mugabi and Jacquot had been fighting for about two minutes when Mugabi threw a left and a right. As Jacquot was turning to avoid the blows, Mugabi's right seemed to graze Jacquot's head, sending the Frenchman down. As Jacquot fell, his left ankle twisted. Referee Arthur Mercante stopped the bout. It was Jacquot's first defense of the title he won over Donald Curry of the United States in February. Jacquot is 24-10; Mugabi is 35-2.(AP) Fencing Westbrook in Final: Peter Westbrook of New York City, at 37 years old the oldest person in the saber competition, upset the world champion, Jean Francois Lamour, 10-9, yesterday and then defeated Fernando Meglio of Italy, 10-5, to advance to the finals of the world championships in Denver. It was the first time since 1958 that an American had advanced to the finals. Carlos Pedrosa of Cuba defeated Robert Marx of Portland, Ore., 10-7, to win the gold medal in epee in the Pan American championships, also in Denver.(AP) Gymnastics Ryan Takes Title: Stanford's Tim Ryan became the youngest American men's gymnastics all-around champion since Bart Conner in 1975 when he put together six strong optional routines yesterday to edge the 1988 Olympian Lance Ringnald at the national championships in Bloomington, Minn. The 18-year-old Ryan had an optional-round score of 56.80 points, 45.44 when adjusted for the 40 percent the optionals count toward the all-around title. With his score in Friday's compulsories, which count for 60 percent, his total adjusted score was 112.22. Ringnald, 18, of the Gold Cup Gym in Albuquerque, N.M., scored an adjusted 45.28 in his optionals yesterday. Combined with the compulsories score, his total was 112.00. In third place was Mike Racanelli of Ohio State with 111.58 points.(AP) Soccer Argentina in Semifinals: Argentina edged Uruguay, 1-0, and Chile routed Bolivia, 5-0, at the America Cup soccer tournament, the South American championship, yesterday in Goiania, Brazil. The victory lifted Argentina into first place in Group B and clinched a berth in the semifinals next week in Recife. Chile, rebounding from a bruising 3-0 defeat Thursday by Paraguay, now has 2 points and can qualify for the semifinals only if it defeats Ecuador by four goals on Sunday.(AP)

title: Page Chisolm Is Engaged to Architect
description: Mr. and Mrs. William A. Chisolm of New York have made known the engagement of their daughter Page Anderton Chisolm to Robert Andrew Hughes, a son of Kathleen Hughes and Robert Hughes, both of Haverfordwest, Wales. An August wedding is planned.

title: Learning the Dangers Of Overexposure to Sun
description: ''On L.I., Skin Cancer Threat Appears to Be on the Increase'' [ June 4 ] was well written and informative.

title: POLLINATE ME, YOU HAIRY THING!
description: WILY VIOLETS & UNDERGROUND ORCHIDS Revelations of a Botanist. By Peter Bernhardt. Illustrated. 255 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $18.95.

title: Artifacts Redolent of Myth and Mystery
description: Ancient Traditions shaped the wood, stone and brass objects made by island peoples of the Pacific and Indian oceans that Fred and Rita Richman acquired over 15 years. In 1988 the Richmans presented most of what they had assembled - 180 artifacts and carvings - to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in a gift the museum describes as its first collection of Southeast Asian tribal art.

title: PRIVATE DOCTORS TESTING AIDS DRUGS IN NOVEL APPROACH
description: A new movement by private doctors to test AIDS drugs independently of university medical centers has gained the support of Federal officials and drug companies. It represents a major change in the way experimental drugs are tested in clinical trials.

title: Camps Responding to Lyme Disease
description: THE threat of Lyme disease has claimed another casualty: carefree camp days for the county's children.

title: Old Rail Stations Don't Just Fade Away
description: THE train hasn't stopped at the Water Mill railroad station for decades, but serious diners in search of the sophisticated and serene have been making tracks to this charming converted country railroad depot for more than four years.

title: A ROLLING STONE
description: Bob Spitz's article ''Raw, Raunchy and Middle-Aged'' (June 4) on the Rolling Stone Keith Richards was insightful. Insightful, that is, except for Mr. Spitz's description of Keith Richards: ''a permanent 5-o'clock shadow clings like moss to the hollows of his cheeks.'' I thought everyone knew that a Rolling Stone gathers no moss. THOMAS F. X. FEENEY Glen Rock, N.J.

title: PASTIMES: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: This would be a good day to use water-soluble fertilizers on container plants, especially window boxes, patio tubs and clay pots; if any of the crops in the vegetable garden seem to be waning, water them with a water-soluble fertilizer, too. Order the spring-flowering bulbs as fall catalogues are beginning to arrive in the mail. For Shade

title: Town Fights to Limit Visitors From Above
description: MORE than 3,300 times over the last 13 years, Michael Hennessy has jumped out of airplanes, and he still has a hard time explaining why.

title:
ART;
Crockery, From A Painter's Perspective
description: LEAD: FOR 27 years, the Fairfield Chamber of Commerce has sponsored a Festival of the Arts in early summer. Since 1976, part of the celebration has been the naming of the Artist of the Year.

title: Curbing Violence Before Immunity Sets In
description: THE search for answers to the brutality of the ''wilding'' in Central Park in April has become a growing psychosocial enterprise. The racial overtones of black on white has further accelerated interracial conflict between students at some prestigious universities. Similar incidents have occurred in Bridgeport, Hartford and New Haven. We have a tradition of violence. After all we gave Rambo to the world in four different versions and may even have a fifth in the offing.

title: Innovative Handicrafts in Stamford
description: LEAD: CRAFTSMEN in the 18th century hammered out the necessities of life. Today's craft artists still forge objects by hand but their goal is to create objects of art.

title: AFTER THE REVOLUTION, THE ARTS LIVED ON ...
description: A CULTURAL HISTORY OF THE FRENCH REVOLUTION By Emmet Kennedy. Illustrated. 463 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $35.

title: Lichtenstein's Latest Is a Perfectly Pop Thing to Do
description: In the entrance hall of the Tel Aviv Museum of Art in Israel one evening not long ago, a gray curtain swept aside to reveal a colorful addition to the museum's collection - a vast mural, measuring 23 by 54 feet, by Roy Lichtenstein, the American Pop artist who in recent years has energetically taken to painting public murals.

title: U.S. 4-Oar Crew Edges Into Final
description: The United States four-oared crew without coxswain made a superb comeback after a stale start today and placed second to East Germany in a semifinal heat of the Lucerne International Regatta, qualifying for Sunday's final.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: MAZES: Essays. By Hugh Kenner. (North Point, $22.95.) In these essays written for diverse occasions and readerships, Hugh Kenner weaves his characteristically subtle verbal lacework around such unlikely and varied subjects as Einstein's theory of time dilation, ''King Kong,'' Charlie Chaplin, R.

title: At Basketball Camp. Lessons Beyond Passing
description: When the Bagley-Walden Foundation Basketball Camp begins tomorrow on the University of Bridgeport campus, 125 youths will learn more than how to shoot, pass and dribble. They will also learn about career opportunities, music, drugs and the need to stay in school and the problems of teen-age pregnancy.

title: Teammates
description: When architects talk about design as a collaborative effort, they are generally referring to the teamwork that occurs between architect, client and contractor. In the case of this house, however, the New York architect M. Louis Goodman joined forces with an especially large cast. Besides client and contractor, eight artists contributed to some aspect of the building, grounds, color scheme, lighting or furnishings. ''I saw myself as a film director,'' says Goodman, ''whose job involved trying to bring out the best of many talents.'' The house was also designed to capture the local building styles. Located on an island off the coast of Georgia, it recalls such vernacular forms as a large overhanging roof and raised porches that wrap around the house.

title: AFTER THE REVOLUTION, THE ARTS LIVED ON ... AND THE CENSORS WERE SILENCED
description: REVOLUTION IN PRINT The Press in France, 1775-1800. Edited by Robert Darnton and Daniel Roche. Illustrated. 351 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. Cloth, $50. Paper, $24.95.

title: Israelis Have Much to Offer to Dead Sea Scrolls Scholarship
description: To the Editor:

title: A Real Sailor's Look: Light and Layered
description: Nautical themes may be showing up in sportswear collections, but beware of them if you get invited to sail.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ending June 24 MANHATTAN Carnegie Hill $1.5 million 1170 Fifth Avenue (98th St.) 4-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, 2,800-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining room, large kitchen, maid's room, Central Park view; maintenance $1,886, 33% tax-deductible (Broker: Carnegie Hill Properties) Chelsea $1.1 million 161 West 15th Street 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 3,400-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; dining room, large kitchen, den, high ceilings, oak floors, two esposures; maintenance $1,600, 60% tax-deductible (Broker: Delson-Ginsberg Real Estate) Greenwich Village $284,000 11 Fifth Avenue (8th St.) (Brevoort) 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 900-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, concierge, manned elevator, dining area, terrace; maintenance $698, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Marilyn Weigner Real Estate) Greenwich Village $837,500 41 Barrow Street 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, single-family, 4-story, Federal town house; dining room, large kitchen, 4 fireplaces, greenhouse in rear, landmark district, 21- by 40-ft. lot; taxes $3,780 (Broker: Ambrose Mar-Elia) Inwood $90,000 25 Indian Road 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 700-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; dining foyer, Hudson River view; maintenance $367, 46% tax-deductible (Broker: C-Uptown Realty) Upper East Side $400,000 10 East 85th Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,200-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, windowed kitchen, fireplace; maintenance $936, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Helene Fields Limited) BRONX Riverdale $115,995 2530 Independence Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 830-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; part-time doorman, large renovated kitchen; maintenance $369, 62% tax-deductible (Broker: Susan E. title: Inflation Sign: $990,000 Paid For 1804 Coin
description: An 1804 silver dollar has been sold at auction for almost a million times its face value, the most ever bid for a coin.

title: Catherine Elizabeth Nelson Is Wed To Coco Brown, an Investor, on L.I.
description: Catherine Elizabeth Nelson and Harry Joe Brown 2d were married yesterday in Southampton, L.I., at the home of Mrs. George A. Nelson Jr., the bride's mother, by Judge Edward P. Sharretts of Southampton Justice Court.

title: Wisconsin, Danish Pastry With a Classic Twist
description: THERE are few outward signs of Danish heritage in Racine, a small industrial city on the shores of Lake Michigan once known as ''the most Danish city in America.'' The Danish-language newspapers are defunct and ''The Danish Hour,'' a local radio broadcast, has long been off the air. But Racine's Danish heritage is alive and well in its bakeries, in the shape of a pastry known as kringle.

title: Cracking Down on Software Pirates
description: For each copy of a software program sold through legitimate channels, three to seven copies are made and distributed illegally, the Software Publishers Association estimates.

title: For Unusual Art, Classes on Rubbing Gravestones
description: LEAD: LINDA TOREN kneeled and anchored a piece of soft paper with masking tape around a small gravestone in the Grove Street Cemetery in New Haven. Then she dipped a nylon stocking wrapped around her finger into burnt sienna paint oil and gently rubbed the paper. A relief print of the words and a small angel carved on the stone began to appear.

title: Corporate Strategy: Reading for Trends
description: LEAD: THE world has never been as conscious of trends, from changes in the earth's ozonosphere to the availability of toilet paper in Kiev. Spotting trends - both global and specific - and interpreting their importance for major corporate clients like A.T.&T.;, Sears, Roebuck & Company and the Ford Motor Company is the business of Perception International of Ridgefield.

title: Andrew Swank Wed to Amy Sargent
description: At Christ's Church in Rye, N.Y., Amy Sargent and Andrew Wright Swank, account executives with the Saatchi & Saatchi advertising agency in New York, were married yesterday by the Rev. Edward Johnston, an Episcopal minister.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: AMERICA'S GILDED AGE: Intimate Portraits From an Era of Extravagance and Change 1850-1890. By Milton Rugoff. (Holt, $24.95.) Milton Rugoff has produced a pop history of personality, a digest of scandalous and extreme behavior that illuminates a time of high passions and low scruples. The vivid biographies are described in pedestrian prose, but still the stories fascinate.

title: Thrashing by Mets Becomes Real Melee
description: There were hard feelings and the usual assortment of bad punches and awkward kicks. Finally, the Mets and the Reds, having engaged in the mixture of boxing and ballroom dancing that marks baseball donnybrooks, began to collect their bats and helmets and what remained of their tempers.

title: Drug Wars: U.S. Weighs A Military Escalation
description: IN the frustrating battle against the illegal drug trade, the Bush Administration is considering a sharp escalation in the use of force abroad: a deployment of American military advisers and an offer of far more assistance to the military forces of countries where drugs are produced.

title: A Breezy Summer in Acadia
description: LEAD: SITTING at one of the tables with green wooden tops on the lawn, we were finishing our tea and popovers with the butter melting into the strawberry jam. Like the other families at the Jordan Pond House in the heart of Acadia National Park in Maine, we were enjoying the afternoon sun and the masses of summer flowers near the house.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Baltimore;
Locals Sour On Dairy Plans
description: LEAD: WHAT began as the routine redevelopment of a closed dairy on an eight-acre site in central Baltimore has become a protracted struggle between the would-be developer and area residents.

title: Trotting Around The Globe
description: Of course Delvin Miller is driving standardbred horses this week.

title: Where Doctors Learn Beside Manner
description: LEAD: SEVERAL times a month, Marilyn Sousa of West Hartford can be found sitting in an open-backed examining gown complaining about her symptoms to a young doctor at the University of Connecticut Health Center in Farmington. Her problems on any given day range from abdominal pain, to a cough and fatigue, chest pain and constipation.

title: Hollywood's Most Secret Agent
description: HOLLYWOOD, NORMALLY A TOWN EX-traordinarily fond of talking about itself, is a closed shop when it comes to Michael S. Ovitz, the 42-year-old president of the spectacularly successful Creative Artists Agency. Of the industry figures who will speak, few will permit their names to be used. And those who flatly refuse to comment include some of the most powerful and respected figures in the film community.

title: Caren G. Reingold To Wed in August
description: The engagement of Caren Gail Reingold to Richard Corbin Francis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Francis of Fremont, Ohio, has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Michael H. Reingold of Boston and Concord, Mass. An August wedding is planned.

title: When Pastoral Is Enough, Who Needs the Symphony?
description: A conductor I know, music director in an unpleasantly industrial European city, was off on sabbatical to the South Seas not long ago.

title: The Sounds of Summer Let the Good Times Roll
description: ''Dear media friend,'' began a recent press release. ''It's pool party time. It's Beach Blanket Bingo time. It's time to turn up the volume.''

title: Question Of the Week; What Should Happen To Rose?
description: Pete Rose should take his lumps (as he gave them to Ray Fosse and Bud Harrelson) from the commissioner's hearing. Then, if he doesn't like the result, he should go to civil court. Rose is a grown man who agreed to abide by baseball's rules. For him to try an end run around the commissioner's office is to make his own rules, which is what I suspect he has been doing for years. P. J. KERSTEN New Canaan, Conn.

title: U.S. May Back International Talks if Israel Stymies Vote Plan
description: If Israel imposes so many conditions on a proposal for Palestinian elections that the plan is impossible for Arabs to accept, the United States will have to consider organizing an international peace conference to break the impasse, reporters traveling with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d were told today.

title: Judith Brudnick Engaged to Wed
description: August wedding plans for Judith Ann Brudnick and Steven Michael Kaye, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Bernard M. Kaye of Highland Park, Ill., have been made known by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Irving S. Brudnick of Malden and Magnolia, Mass.

title: Another Soviet Defector Threatens to Go Back
description: A Soviet K.G.B. colonel who defected to the United States in Athens three years ago says he has become so disillusioned with his treatment by the Central Intelligence Agency that he is talking about redefecting.

title: August Wedding For Catey Heller
description: August wedding plans for Catherine Frances Heller and James Hendrick Terry 3d, the son of Kathryn P. Terry of New York and Dr. James H. Terry Jr. of Brooklyn, have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Francis Heller of Winnetka, Ill.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Texas; For an 'Escape,' Superheroes In Gameland
description: James Mason calls himself ''Blaze'' tonight, and a blast of light from his palm can temporarily stun any enemy that dares to get in his way. Although he sits in a sparsely furnished apartment near the University of Texas, strange creatures may soon hasten his doom.

title: POSTINGS: Jersey City Landmark; Now It's Time to Move the Colgate Clock
description: The huge Colgate-Palmolive clock on the Jersey City waterfront, by which people in lower Manhattan have told time for 65 years, will be taken down later this month and moved to a temporary site two blocks away where it will stay for several years until a permanent site is found for it in the company's massive redevelopment project along the Hudson River.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Glen Cove $183,000 18 Jackson Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 50-year-old colonial; dining room, deck, hardwood floors; taxes $1,200. Glen Head $275,000 91 Todd Drive North 2-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 30-year-old split level; fireplace, patio, 2-car garage; taxes $4,600. Massapequa $227,000 147 Division Avenue 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 29-year-old split level; den, fireplace, 1-car garage; taxes $4,600. Muttontown $700,000 1884 Muttontown Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 152-year-old colonial; wine cellar, inground pool, 2 acres; taxes $3,200. Seaford $210,000 3933 Eve Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 33-year-old split level; new windows, central air-conditioning, basement; taxes $3,800. Wantagh $170,000 3012 North Jerusalem Road 3-bedroom, 1- bath, 33-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kchchen, finished basement; taxes $3,400. OTHER AREAS Rye, N.Y. $585,000 4 Stanley Keys Court 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 6-year-old contemporary; country kitchen, family room w/fireplace, cathedral ceiling in living room, Jacuzzi, patio, 2-car garage; taxes $8,693. New Milford, Conn. $126,000 9 Pleasant Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 88-year-old Victorian; close to town, 0.25 acre; taxes $1,100. Belleville, N.J. $152,440 9 Hill Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 43-year-old ranch; eat-in-kitchen, finished basement, 5-zone heat; taxes $2,796.

title: Maverick Priest Says He Is No Luther but a Man of Ethnic and Religious Soul
description: The Rev. George Augustus Stallings Jr. says he is no Martin Luther, no renegade Roman Catholic with a fistful of heretical theses to nail to a church door.

title: The Pain of a Burglary Lingers
description: THE problem with having a predictable husband is that any change in routine can mean only one thing: trouble. So when my husband telephoned me at work an hour after his usual mid-afternoon ''touching base'' call, as he refers to it, I held my breath.

title: Abbott Wins No. 8 as Angels Defeat Twins, 4-1
description: Neither the California Angels nor Jim Abbott, their rookie left-hander, were given much chance of sticking around for long this season.

title: SARTRE WITHOUT APOLOGIES
description: JEAN-PAUL SARTRE Hated Conscience of His Century. Volume One: Protestant or Protester? By John Gerassi. Illustrated. 213 pp. Illinois: The University of Chicago Press. $19.95.

title: Abby M. Purdy Plans Wedding
description: Abby Marler Purdy's engagement to Gregory Paul Taylor, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James G. Taylor Jr. of Fairfield, Conn., has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Donald R. Purdy of Wilton, Conn. An August wedding is planned.

title: Can Men and Women Be Friends?
description: Rob Reiner got married in May, and it's only coincidence that the script he's now preparing to direct - an adaptation by William Goldman of a recent novel by Stephen King - is titled ''Misery.'' But it's also only coincidence that Mr. Reiner, who was divorced from the actress-cum-director Penny Marshall several years ago, met his current wife, the photographer Michele Singer, on the set of the film he's just finished, ''When Harry Met Sally . . . ,'' which, among other things, happens to be about a divorced fellow who can't get used to being single again. Dating, loneliness, sex without love - that, as the predicament of Harry Burns is portrayed, is misery. And it is solved when Harry marries his best friend, Sally Albright, the woman who has been right for him all along.

title: ENDING REQUIRED GYM: 2 VIEWS
description: WHAT are they going to do with all those balls if decisive action is taken on the Governor's proposal to kill gym class? New Jersey students have carried memories of strong women and buzz-cut men into adulthood and can probably recall both embarrassing and heroic incidents of that sweaty hour sandwiched between frog dissection and ''The Scarlet Letter.''

title: Turning Campers' Energies Into Beauty
description: The campers supply the raw material: creativity, energy and curiosity. Eight counselors help them transform it into beautiful things: enamel jewelry, poems, the ability to dance.

title: Miss Hardenburg To Wed in August
description: Dr. and Mrs. Harold C. Hardenburg Jr. of Berkeley Heights, N.J., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Heidi Holt Hardenburg and William Ellsworth Evenson 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Evenson of Seattle.

title: R. M. Platte Wed To Danielle Jerry
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Joseph in Albany, Danielle Guerin Jerry, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold A. Jerry Jr. of Albany and Speculator, N.Y., was married yesterday to Robert Michael Platte, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George William Platte of Marne, Mich. The Rev. Nellis J. Tremblay performed the ceremony. The bride was attended by her sister, Jocelyn Jerry Wolcott. David Dietrich was his brother-in-law's best man.

title: Ex-Mayor Rizzo Comes Back, But on Radio, Not at the Polls
description: He last won an election when Gerald R. Ford was President, Reggie Jackson had not yet been a Yankee and Archie Bunker ruled the tube, but there is a considerable coterie in the nation's fifth-largest city who still consider Frank L. Rizzo ''Mr. Mayor.''

title:
GARDENING;
Summer Chores That Are Keys to Success
description: LEAD: SUMMER brings its own set of chores for gardeners that will either assure the success of plantings or make it easier to care for them.

title: Soloists to Enrich Summer Music Series
description: IN just a few years, Summer Music, the outdoor series at Harkness Memorial State Park in Waterford, has become so popular concertgoers are warned they cannot be assured entrance into the park without an advance ticket. A look at this season's roster of soloists indicates that another sellout summer might lie ahead.

title: Therapy Offers Hope at the Brink
description: LEAD: A MAN who had been a heavy drinker for 20 years suddenly stopped drinking.

title: Rerouting Asian Trips Away From China
description: WHEN the first tanks rolled through Tiananmen Square on June 4, ''tourism to the People's Republic of China was crushed for the foreseeable future and probably for many years to come,'' Linda Ball, editor of the trade publication Tour and Travel News, wrote after she returned from China. Although her colleagues may dispute her on how long tourism to China will be eclipsed, people in the trade agree that a decade of effort by Chinese officials and Americans with commercial and personal investments was blown away in a matter of hours.

title: About Men; Images of a Brief Moment
description: LET'S GET THIS straight. I grew up angry, bitter, confused, wild. I started smoking before I was 10 and sampled most of the better-known hallucinogens when I hit college. But I never did any heavy drinking. Maybe that was because my father did enough of that for both of us.

title: China Expels Correspondent for Voice of America
description: China today ordered the expulsion of a correspondent for the Voice of America radio network, asserting that his reporting had violated provisions of martial law.

title: Sukey Bryan Wed To J. D. Brooks
description: Susannah Margaret Bryan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Barry R. Bryan of New Canaan, Conn., was married in New Canaan yesterday to Dr. James Duane Brooks, a son of Mr. and Mrs. C. David Brooks of Stillwater, Minn. The Rev. Margaret Minnick performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Episcopal Church.

title: Numbers Don't Lie: Batters Are on Track
description: Is offense dying in the National League? A few weeks ago, there was much talk about the abnormally low batting statistics the league had compiled through the first quarter of its schedule. Since then, the offense has picked up, but it is still low. Is something wrong?

title: Pity the Poor Architect
description: To the Editor:

title: Will Maglev Transportation Help?
description: I wish to disagree with the point of view about a Maglev system [ 'Maglev Transit: Out of Place on L.I.,' Letters, May 28 ] .

title:
ART;
Tribal Visions, Modern Times
description: LEAD: FOR the seven artists represented in ''Indigenous Vision,'' the current exhibition at the Islip Art Museum, forging links between their traditional cultures and modern society has evidently been an arduous task, one that involves compromises with both the past and the present.

title: Catherine Carter Weds David Kulow
description: Catherine Mather Carter, a daughter of Priscilla D. Carter of New York and Richard E. Carter of Nahant, Mass., and Tetbury, England, was married yesterday at the Village Church in Nahant to David Mattson Kulow, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick C. Kulow of Weston, Mass., and New London, N.H. The Rev. Hugh Knapp, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated.

title: Susan E. Fisher Marries
description: At the First Presbyterian Church in Southold, L.I., Susan Elaine Fisher and Paul Raymond Nannig were married yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Robert S. MacLennan. The bride, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Fisher of Scarsdale, N.Y., is an art teacher at Mount Vernon (N.Y.) High School. The bridegroom, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Urban R. Nannig of North Kingstown, R.I., is a loan analyst for the Bank of Darien (Conn.) and a candidate for an M.B.A. degree at the University of Bridgeport.

title: Corynne Nathan to Marry a Marine, And Her Sister Will Wed B. S. Street
description: Corynne Jill Nathan is planning to marry First Lieut. Daniel Arent Colfax, U.S.M.C., later this month and her younger sister, Leslie Ruth Nathan, will marry Bryan Shephard Street in September, the parents of the prospective brides, Mr. and Mrs. Peter W. Nathan of Westport, Conn., have announced.

title: Humor In Summer Snapshots
description: NOW that all the people on summer vacations and at picnics are lugging suitcases and coolers, something else has come out of winter-long hibernation: the camera.

title: In War on AIDS, A Tangle of Rules About Tracing, Testing and Telling
description: FIVE years after the AIDS antibody test was developed, governments across the country are still grappling with the issues of testing, confidentiality and tracing sexual and needle-sharing partners. In the absence of a uniform national policy, states and localities have devised -and are now frequently revising -varied and often contradictory rules.

title: 'Modern Ireland'
description: To the Editor:

title: RACIAL QUESTIONS: WHERE HAS ALL THE FURY GONE?
description: BLACK LIVES, WHITE LIVES Three Decades of Race Relations in America. By Bob Blauner. 347 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $25.

title: ART ON THE FIRING LINE
description: When, at the prospect of Congressional disfavor, the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington canceled a touring show of photographs by the late Robert Mapplethorpe, financed in part by the National Endowment for the Arts, the action raised issues about artistic freedom and censorship that bear directly on public support for the arts in this country.

title: HE MADE THE FURNITURE TALK
description: FRED ALLEN His Life and Wit. By Robert Taylor. Illustrated. 340 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company.

title: Maywood Journal; >Residents Irked About Storage Of Tainted Soil
description: IN a remote part of this borough of 9,800 residents, a tarpaulin-covered mound rises above the ground like an infamous landmark, and officials here, urged on by residents, have taken a step they feel will ultimately remove the tainted fixture.

title: PASTIMES: Camera
description: Yet another new color-print film has crossed my transom. It's not Polaroid or Agfa. It's not Fuji or Kodak. It's . . . Chandi Premium Plus.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE AGE OF MIRACLES. By Catherine MacCoun. (Atlantic Monthly, $18.95.) Inspired by two brief historical references, Catherine MacCoun's first novel re-creates the life of a failed saint, a 14th-century Englishwoman called Ingrid Fairfax. Ingrid studies medicine at the nunnery where she is raised, and by age 18 she has come to display what appear to be supernatural powers of healing.

title: OPRAH TALK
description: Ms. Harrison is not the only one who finds Oprah Winfrey's show often loose and dangerous. Professional therapists who have appeared on her show have written about ''the danger that arises when the illusion of familiarity and intimacy entices people into sharing personal information . . . that they never dared to say out loud to anyone before.'' Once the show is over, Oprah moves on and the survivors are left to fend for themselves. ANN G. RUBEN North Miami Beach, Fla.

title: Paying More to Use Money Machines
description: ''Your transaction is complete. Would you like another transaction? Please press Yes or No.'' A familiar type of question, asked again and again on the screens of more than 70,000 bank cash machines nationwide. But these days, many of the estimated 50 million consumers who regularly use automated teller machines, or A.T.M.'s, are finding it to be a costly question as well. More and more commercial banks and savings institutions are imposing new fees - or increasing old ones - for the use of cash machines. And many banks have raised the minimum amounts that have to be kept on deposit in order to reduce or avoid fees.

title: Julia H. M. Smith Planning to Marry Arthur R. G. Solmssen Jr. Next Month
description: Julia Herrick Macaulay Smith and Arthur Robert George Solmssen Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Solmssen of Bryn Mawr, Pa., plan to marry in August. The engagement has been announced by the prospective bride's mother, Mrs. Thomas W. M. Smith of Washington and Woodstock, Vt.

title: CIRME
description: ''Every place is dangerous,'' declares the elderly narrator of Susan Taylor Chehak's absolutely stunning first novel, THE STORY OF ANNIE D. (Houghton Mifflin, $17.95), about the small farming town of Wizen River, Neb., where she has lived all her life. ''By now almost all of us here have begun to lock our doors.''

title: The Rose Case: Beyond the Legal Thicket
description: A. Bartlett Giamatti, the commissioner of baseball, is sitting on one of the biggest baseball gambling controversies since the Black Sox scandal involving the 1919 World Series. But instead of being in control of the Pete Rose case, he finds himself on the defensive, mostly on the other guy's turf, and fighting a local judge who has already labeled him biased. Belatedly, his lawyers have taken the case into Federal court, and are hoping a judge will keep it there. But the case involves far more than strategic legal maneuvering.

title: Yanks, With Strong Relief, Bounce Back
description: In the once-dominant Eastern Division of the American League, where the act of reaching the .500 mark can quickly lead to a discussion of championship possibilities, the Yankees took one happy step above mediocrity this afternoon.

title: Supremely Surly
description: Suddenly but predictably, the Reagan appointees to the Supreme Court have taken control. What's neither inevitable nor acceptable is the raucous tone and unruly language the members of the new majority direct even against each other. It's been a needlessly contentious takeover, unbecoming to a great institution. Precedents are not merely overruled; they're trashed, sometimes in sour disrespect and sometimes without acknowledgment.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our house has tin ceilings that were previously painted with a flat paint. This paint is now chipping off in pieces, and I would like to repaint with an oil-based paint. Is there any way to remove all of the old paint without damaging the ceilings?

title:
MUSIC;
Nostalgia Is Theme In 2 Series
description: LEAD: WITH its fare ranging from Dixieland to Cole Porter, the William Carlos Williams Center of the Arts in Rutherford has embarked on a musical nostalgia trend this summer. Audiences, in increasing numbers, are turning to the popular music of the earlier years of this century, say the directors of two organizations whose musicians will perform at the Williams

title: Lisa Palache Wed To Robert Carey
description: Lisa Biscoe Palache, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John G. Palache Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and Nantucket, Mass., was married yesterday to Robert Alan Carey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth B. Carey of Bakersfield, Calif., by the Rev. Richard VanWely at St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Greenwich.

title: Should the Natural Erosion of Fire Island Beaches Be Halted?
description: LEAD: AT first glance, the issue appears to be a quarrel about a pile of concrete on a beach in one Fire Island community. At the heart of this problem, however, is whether people can or should try to stop the erosion of Fire Island's beaches and the natural progression of the island toward union with the mainland.

title: 'Sugar,' A New Musical, Performed in Brigeport
description: THE Downtown Cabaret Theater production of ''Sugar'' serves a useful purpose. It proves that ''Sugar'' is, well, useless.

title: What Bar Patrons See as Trivia, Owners Discover Is a Pot of Gold
description: Greg Rogers stared at the small computer terminal on the bar and shook his head. He had just spent 20 minutes trying to answer questions about toothaches, electrical currents and South American trees, and his disappointment at finishing second to a patron down the bar was evident.

title: Wedding Planned By Julie Mariash
description: Mr. and Mrs. Raymond L. Mariash of Pine Brook, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Julie Mariash to Charles D. Noble, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles D. Noble of Monroe, N.Y.

title:
GARDENING;
Summer Chores That Are Keys to Success
description: LEAD: SUMMER brings its own set of chores for gardeners that will either assure the success of plantings or make it easier to care for them.

title: American Team Gets Close Look At Soviet Laser
description: Down a potholed road here in the forlorn steppes of Soviet Central Asia lies a shabby cluster of concrete buildings that has loomed large in the lore of the Pentagon.

title: FICTION
description: PALU. By Louis Nowra. (St. Martin's, $15.95.) In the Australian playwright Louis Nowra's first novel to be published in America, sex, politics and the supernatural determine the fate of a fictional South Pacific nation. President Emo, the country's dictator, has imprisoned his wife, Palu. On sheets of paper smuggled into her cell, she tells her story, which takes her from the bush to a white man's coffee plantation to a teachers' college, where she meets her firebrand husband, to their shared exile in Australia and then to her newly independent country's presidential palace. While the novel revolves around third-world politics, its strongest passages describe the sex-charged system of beliefs that are held by Palu's people. Unfortunately, Emo cannot drag his countrymen into the 20th century. Instead, he becomes convinced that ''his people were incapable of rising above their primitive state.'' As he slides into despotism, he himself is ''swallowed up by his primitive past. . . . His blood stopped flowing and his veins clogged with the ashes of his ancestors.'' Cultural alienation in the developing world remains a rich literary subject, but Mr. Nowra lacks enough sympathy for his characters to make us care about it. He mocks Australian liberals who sought independence for Palu's nation (superficially based on Papua New Guinea), ridicules her countrymen's ignorance of Western culture and derides their efforts at self-government. Mr. Nowra's artless prose, which fails to endow ''Palu'' with a consistent, plausible voice, gives the novel the sullen cast of an imperialist tract.

title: Jennifer Moore Marries
description: At the Packer Memorial Chapel at Lehigh University in Bethlehem, Pa., Jennifer Scholl Moore and Richard Renwick Benn, 1986 graduates of the university, were married yesterday by the Rev. Hubert L. Flesher, an Episcopal priest. Mrs. Benn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley A. Moore of Longwood, Fla., is to become a teacher at the Bear Tavern Elementary School in Hopewell, N.J., in September. Mr. Benn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alec Benn of New York, is a financial analyst at the Prudential Insurance Company in South Plainfield, N.J.

title:
INVESTING;
STRIPS Versus Synthetics
description: LEAD: There are some advantages to buying zero-coupon Treasury bonds rather than investing in them through a mutual fund. For example, an investor can select a more precise maturity by buying the bonds. In addition, if investors plan to hold the bonds until they mature, investors will pay significantly less in brokerage commissions than they would in mutual fund charges.

title: On Being Slightly Askew
description: MY mother once responded to my complaints about school by leaping to a ledge suspended over the stairs at home. As I pleaded with her to stop and listen, she proceeded to swing back and forth while singing ''The Daring Young Man on the Flying Trapeze.''

title: On Language; Winkle-Pickers Of the Press
description: I HIS MORNING briefing, Marlin Fitzwater, the President's press secretary, was working his way through the intricacies of arms-reduction negotiations. The White House press corps was riddling his presentation with detailed questions. Finally, the mildly exasperated Mr. Fitzwater said to the assembled reporters, ''As the lady who sat beside me at the luncheon with the Queen in Buckingham Palace says, 'We can't >winkle-picker this anymore.' ''

title: Stewart Wins Games, but Cy Young Award Proves Elusive
description: Maybe this will be Dave Stewart's Cy Young season. Or will his teammate Mike Moore overtake him in the second half of the season? Perhaps Greg Swindell will have a second half that matches his first half. Then again, maybe Nolan Ryan will have as consistent a second half as he has had a first half and edge Stewart on the sentimental vote.

title: Dr. Peter Yu Married to Grace Wang
description: Grace Hwei-shu Wang, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley H. Wang of Ossining, N.Y., and Dr. Peter Paul Yu, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul C. Yu of Scarsdale, N.Y., were married yesterday at Our Lady of Fatima Roman Catholic Church in Scarsdale by the Rev. Paul Chang. Mrs. Yu, a graduate of the State University of New York at Stony Brook, received an M.B.A. degree and a master's in international studies from the University of Pennsylvania. She was until recently an associate at Goldman, Sachs & Company in New York. Her father retired as the managing director of the European office in London of the Orient Overseas Container Line Ltd. in Hong Kong.

title: Warrant on Jordan
description: In what the judge called a standard practice for out-of-state drivers, a warrant for the arrest of Michael Jordan was issued in Lexington, Ky., on Friday after the Chicago Bulls' star guard failed to appear in Fayette County District Court to deal with a traffic ticket.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Menu; A Light, Tangy Dessert
description: More than 25 years ago, a version of this lemon angel trifle was very popular with my guests. Where it got its name was a mystery, but no one seemed to mind.

title: An English Garden in Maine
description: LEAD: AT 7 each morning, workmen towing lengths of garden hose drag the dew from the grass, so early visitors can stroll the lawns without getting wet feet. Chilly nights, sunny days and plenty of fog support mighty delphiniums in July, the blooming of forget-me-nots and pansies right through August. Between the caretaking and the climate, it's easy to imagine that Thuya Garden is English in location as well as in style.

title: On His Own
description: The Rev. George A. Stallings Jr. and the Roman Catholic Church have disappointed each other. Father Stallings, who is black, has repeatedly objected to the predominantly white leadership of the Washington Archdiocese, whose 100,000 Catholics include 50,000 blacks.

title: 4 Held in Tompkins Sq. Skirmish at Symbolic Tents
description: Seventy police in riot gear and more than 200 protesters skirmished over a line of symbolic tents in Tompkins Square Park last night, as demonstrators repeatedly pitched sheets of plastic over branches and wires and the police moved in to tear them down.

title: The Right Cartoonist
description: To the Editor:

title: Kabul Reports New Gains in East
description: The Marxist Government reported today that its troops, backed by tanks and artillery, advanced toward the Pakistani border east of Jalalabad, destroying guerrilla bases and killing 81 insurgents.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Middlebury; It All Started With Pie Tins In the Air
description: Students at Yale University insist they were the first to pick up a Frisbie Pie Company plate and fling it into the air. But then similar claims have come from Princeton and other Eastern colleges and universities.

title: Riding the Polar Bear Express
description: HEADED due north at a steady clip, our train came to an unexpected halt. Thirty minutes dragged by. Day trippers shifted impatiently in their seats. Why such a long stop at this scruffy little settlement of wooden houses and buildings identified by its signpost as Fraserdale? Wild guesses wafted through the aisles: engine trouble, a collapsed bridge, a moose on the tracks?

title: Hilary Ginsberg Weds J. A. Feshbach
description: At the Pierre in New York, Hilary Carla Ginsberg, the vice president of advertising and the director of sales at the Roseland Ballroom, was married last evening to Joseph Alan Feshbach, a first vice president and a chief market analyst at Prudential Bache Securities in New York. Rabbi James Prosnit performed the ceremony.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: WILLIAMSTOWN, MASS.;
Splicing Saves An Old Cinema
description: LEAD: IN an effort to save Images Cinema, one of the last downtown movie theaters in Berkshire County, the size of the cinema will be reduced and the remaining space in the building will be converted to retail and office use.
