title: Guidry's Going Home, One Way or Another
description: Shortly before midnight Friday, Ron Guidry left the visitors' clubhouse at Ned Skeldon Stadium in Toledo, Ohio, and walked toward his car. A teen-age girl approached him.

title: Officials Reach Impasse Over Yonkers Budget
description: Yonkers officials are continuing to resist suggestions by a state monitoring agency that last week rejected their plan to use most of the city's $34 million surplus to pay for two schools that must be built under a Federal desegregation order.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Wisconsin; A Radio Station Is Transferred, Despite Protests
description: Student protests, culminating in a punk-rock show punctuated with obscenities uttered by two disk jockeys, have failed to avert a plan to transfer operations of a radio station partly run by students here.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Kittery, Me.; From Farmland, An Outlet Mecca
description: TWO new shopping centers for manufacturers' outlets are under construction here, the latest in a decade-long development process that has transformed farmland along Route 1 into a brand-name discount mecca.

title: Correction
description: A report in the Travel Advisory column on June 18 about hotel discounts misstated a telephone number for the Travelodge chain. Its number is 800-255-3050.

title: Poland and Hungary Hope for Aid From Bush
description: President Bush's visit is arousing high expectations of economic aid in Poland and Hungary, countries whose political situations will make it difficult to rescue them from material woes.

title:
ART;
Five Emerging Artists Interpret the Social Landscape
description: LEAD: ''HOT SPOTS'' is the specific title of this year's edition of Curator's Choice at the Bronx Museum of the Art. If this sounds like the title of a snappy Off Broadway revue, that's fine, because the museum's assistant curator, Laura J. Hoptman, sees her endeavor as a sort of play.

title: Thatcher Loses Battle On Former Spy's Book
description: The Government has lost a legal battle to stop publication of a retired intelligence agent's book after banning an American magazine that published excerpts.

title: Kinder? Gentler? Aloof
description: ON Sunday mornings, when the weather is good, my husband and I, 60-ish and retired, walk to a deli about half a mile from home. We take about 15 minutes each way because we pause to observe and discuss flowers or changes in the houses along the way.

title: Lyme Disease Study of Horses
description: LEAD: HORSES sick with Lyme disease often mimic a stricken human's condition in the baffling array of symptoms they might present. Westchester horses infected with the deer tick-borne bacteria are showing the catch-all symptomology in growing numbers. Veterinarians say a far greater number are being shown to have been exposed to the bacteria.

title: Buffalo Bill's Medal Restored
description: Seventy-two years after Congress stripped Buffalo Bill Cody of his Medal of Honor, it has been restored.

title:
GARDENING;
Summer Chores That Are Keys to Success
description: LEAD: SUMMER brings its own set of chores for gardeners that will either assure the success of plantings or make it easier to care for them.

title: A Guide to Exploring the World Under
description: DEJA VU is common among skiers who go scuba diving in the Caribbean: Despite the warmth, there is something oddly familiar about that first plunge into the blue-green water. Most will tell you that few things compare with the exhilaration of an early morning run through fresh-fallen powder; but one of them is the thrill of soaring, weightless and silent, over a coral reef alive with fish.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
The Importance of Local Landmarking
description: LEAD: A HOUSE completed in 1969 that serves as a showplace for the works of Petras Kiaulenas, a Lithuanian-born painter, would seem to be an unlikely candidate for landmark status in the Town of Brookhaven. But the town's Historic District Advisory Committee thought otherwise, and last March the Town Board declared the structure - on Linden Lane in Farmingville - a local landmark.

title: Strategies to Promote Affordable Housing
description: I was dismayed that a former Fanwood Councilman misunderstood some of the strategies proposed by the Kean administration to address the affordable-housing crisis that were described in my recent Opinion page article (''Affordable Housing: State Has Ideas''). Allow me to set the record straight. The goal of regulatory permit reform is to streamline development improvement standards and make them predictable while preserving the rights of communities to grow in a manner consistent with community desires. Regulations should be clear. They should not overlap. And they should be enforced - as much as possible - by local officials licensed by the responsible state agency.

title: No Headline
description: LEAD: DURING the week before his historic May 20, 1927 flight across the Atlantic, Charles Lindbergh tested his small, silver single-engine Ryan monoplane over the potato fields of Long Island. His only obstacle was stormy weather passing out into the ocean.

title: Reveling in A Repertory's Unpredictability
description: Over the years, it has been increasingly difficult to predict what Dance Theater of Harlem, which just concluded a brilliant 20th-anniversary season at the City Center, will introduce into the company's repertory. The swings have frequently been wide if not wild, anything, in fact - from Geoffrey Holder's Caribbean genre pieces to George Balanchine's best-known neo-classical ballets; from Agnes de Mille and Jerome Robbins's works from American Ballet Theater to revivals related to productions of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo and Serge Diaghilev's Ballets; from distinctive stagings of the 19th-century classics to new works by outside choreographers and Arthur Mitchell, the company's director-founder.

title: DROPPING THE DIME ON JACKIE PRESSER
description: POWER AND GREED Inside the Teamsters Empire of Corruption. By Allen Friedman and Ted Schwarz. 284 pp. New York: Franklin Watts. $19.95.

title: POSTINGS: Fraunces Tavern Neighbors; Deals Preserve Old Facades
description: In an unusual and complicated series of deals, the Landmarks Conservancy has found a way to preserve the exteriors of five 19th-century buildings next to Fraunces Tavern in lower Manhattan while allowing the buildings to be converted into a cooperative with 41 apartments. The deals are also producing a $400,000 profit for the Conservancy, to be used in other preservation efforts.

title: Leave Schools Out of It
description: To the Editor:

title: Pressing Ahead for Poor Children
description: The second year of Gov. Mario Cuomo's Decade of the Child has been remarkably productive in terms of new laws. Even though the New York Legislature's session was shadowed by the need to close an enormous budget gap, the Governor won enactment of important parts of his program to enhance the life chances of poor children. He and the lawmakers who cooperated with him all deserve praise.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''We want to ban the majority of abortions throughout all nine months of pregnancy. The question is, How far and how quickly do we go right now?'' -Samuel Lee, a lobbyist who helped draft Missouri's restrictive abortion law. [ 19:2. ]

title: Alec Wyeth Plans To Wed Ms. Julier
description: Elizabeth Chamberlain Julier and T. Alexander Symington Wyeth, a son of Carolyn L. Goodyear and Stuart MacReynolds Wyeth, both of Bryn Mawr, Pa., plan to marry in August, the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Henry S. Julier 2d of Concord, Mass., have announced.

title: D. N. Moran Wed To Sarah Buckley
description: Sarah Louise Buckley and David Nolan Moran, graduates of the school of hotel administration at Cornell University, were married yesterday by the Rev. Joseph Hughes at Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church in Rumson, N.J. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Weed Buckley of Little Silver, N.J. Her husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip J. Moran of Millbrook, N.Y.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our house has tin ceilings that were previously painted with a flat paint. This paint is now chipping off in pieces, and I would like to repaint with an oil-based paint. Is there any way to remove all of the old paint without damaging the ceilings?

title: Successful Sale
description: It took more than $50,000, a 10-minute video and even an endorsement from former President Richard M. Nixon to help lure college basketball's Final Four to the New York metropolitan area in 1996.

title: What Else Is There Besides Shoreham?
description: Miriam Goodman's article on Shoreham (''Shoreham's Rainy Day,'' June 4) is a classic example of anti-nuclear ballyhoo with no substantive alternatives offered.

title: Saratoga Springs
description: Despite an embarrassment of tourist riches this old spa in the Adirondack foothills retains plenty of small town charm. You can be five blocks from the fabled flat track on a summer afternoon and hardly be aware that 20,000 railbirds are yelling their heads off as the horses charge down the homestretch in the seventh race.

title: Now Playing on Broadway, the Big Squeeze
description: In any real-life tale of the Broadway theater these days, the issue of real estate intrudes like Banquo's ghost, bent on ruining Macbeth's dinner party. A number of theater people, however, manage to do what Macbeth could not - ignore the bloody corpse and get on with the business of eating and drinking and staying alive.

title: Review/Dance; A New 'Giselle' and a New Star, From the Kirov
description: To see the production of ''Giselle'' that the Kirov Ballet presented for the first time in New York on Friday night is to see the company in all its greatness and to be present at the triumph of a new young Soviet star.

title: Outbreaks of Beirut Fighting Leave Dead, 28 Wounded
description: Rival Shiite Muslim militias battled in the streets of West Beirut today and Syrian and Christian gunners fired artillery at each other's positions across the city's dividing line.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q & A: ALICE KATZ;
'Expressing Anger Assertively Is Good'
description: LEAD: ANGER in moderation is normal and healthy, says Alice Katz, a psychotherapist who has been running workshops on ''Living With Anger'' for four years. The workshops are an outgrowth of her work with women who eat compulsively, mainly out of anger. They help people learn to be less angry and to express their anger in more effective ways.

title: The Right To Die Needs Protection
description: MY mother, 89 years old, died in her sleep last summer, three weeks after suffering a massive stroke that paralyzed her on one side and severely limited her mental and speech capacities. Her illness almost caused a permanent breach between my brother and me.

title: Question Of the Week; What Should Happen To Rose?
description: Before anyone decides what should happen to Pete Rose, he or she should see the movie ''The Thin Blue Line.'' This documentary deals with the conviction and imprisonment of a man based on the testimony of a convicted felon looking for leniency. After serving 15 years in prison, an innocent man was released and the witness against him was back in jail for committing another felony. I think the more important question is: ''What should happen to Ron Peters?'' JEAN LAINO Amherst, Mass.

title: Lionized, Forgotten and Now Resurrected
description: Arnold Bax lived long enough to be lionized, knighted, named Master of the King's Musick and then forgotten. By the time he died, in 1953, a month shy of his 70th birthday, Vaughan Williams and Britten had long since displaced his claims on England's audiences, and even the late-starter Tippett had become a major force. To Bax's 1947 autobiography, ''Farewell My Youth,'' there's more than a little bitterness.

title:
Body and Mind;
The Long Haul
description: LEAD: MY SISTER-IN-law, Ronnie, is a 44-year-old screenwriter and mother of two who suffered a major stroke 18 months ago. A tiny blood vessel in the brain had ruptured; she became slightly unsteady at first, and her tongue felt a bit thick. But she worsened so fast that within a week she had been hospitalized, and rapidly became paralyzed and comatose.

title: Portraits of the Artists, by Namuth
description: LEAD: AT the start of a notable career that has spanned more than five decades, the photographer Hans Namuth did not set out to become the leading pictorial chronicler of contemporary artists. It just happened that way.

title: Island Towns Strive To Comply on Garbage
description: LEAD: HERE is the current resource-recovery situation at the 15 municipalities on Long Island.

title: Philosopher Coming to U.S. as India's Envoy
description: He said it himself: ''There's a new kind of ambassador coming.''

title: Shoreham Set For New Arena
description: LEAD: WITH the overwhelming support of its shareholders, the Long Island Lighting Company has locked itself into a deal with New York State to insure dismantling of the $5.5 billion Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: JERSEYANA
description: LEAD: ONE hundred and eighty-five years ago this month, the most famous bullet in New Jersey history left the barrel of Aaron Burr's pistol. Traveling at 600 feet a second, it entered Alexander Hamilton's abdomen, just above the hip.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our house has tin ceilings that were previously painted with a flat paint. This paint is now chipping off in pieces, and I would like to repaint with an oil-based paint. Is there any way to remove all of the old paint without damaging the ceilings?

title: French Influence Prevails in Programs
description: THE Caramoor Festival is taking note of the Bicentennial of the French Revolution with back-to-back concerts this week.

title: EAST EUROPE VISIT CHALLENGES BUSH
description: When President Bush arrives in Warsaw on Sunday night, he will embark on a schedule that has been delicately orchestrated to allow him to give a stirring boost to democracy in Eastern Europe without appearing overbearing or intrusive to his Communist hosts.

title: Wallace's Brother Is Charged With Evading Income Taxes
description: Gerald Wallace, a 68-year-old Montgomery lawyer who is a brother of former Gov. George C. Wallace, has been indicted by a Federal grand jury here on charges of failing to pay taxes on income of $165,000.

title: Pro & Con: Remaking the Government  Do New York's Borough Presidents Still Have Jobs Worth Paying for?
description: THREE months ago, the United States Supreme Court ruled unconstitutional the voting system of New York City's Board of Estimate, the powerful body that lies at the heart of the city's affairs.

title: A Toy Company Finds Life After Pictionary
description: It is the stuff of which business nightmares are made: A company rides the crest of a phenomenally successful product. The next year, the product peaks and starts to decline. Sales are more than halved, and there is no new blockbuster in sight.

title: Impressionist Show Draws Crowds
description: THE Annenberg Collection of Impressionist and Post-Impressionist paintings is attracting crowds of up to 5,400 a day at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, according to the museum's count.

title: Niedenfuer Demoted
description: After signing the reliever Tom Niedenfuer to a two-year, $1.7 million free-agent contract last December, hoping he would be their stopper, the Seattle Mariners have given up on the 29-year-old right-hander, and he has agreed to be sent to their Class AAA farm team in Calgary, Alberta. Niedenfuer, who pitched for Baltimore last season, had an 0-3 record with a 9.50 earned run average in a dozen games for the Mariners this season, and was on the disabled list from April 12 to May 30 with a broken bone in his left wrist.(AP)

title: The Gospel According to Verity
description: KNOWN AS THE PORTAL OF Paradise, it is the central entryway on the west front of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, the world's largest cathedral, located in upper Manhattan. And though much of the portal, including the bronze doors with their magnificently sculpted panels, has long been complete, for more than half a century the 24 lime-stone blocks flanking the doorway stood uncarved.

title: The Night Ragtime Came to Carnegie Hall
description: Although he is far from a household name today, James Reese Europe was New York's (and America's) most prominent dance band leader in the early years of the century, appearing in exclusive hotels, restaurants and cabarets, performing at social functions for the cream of society, booked for Ivy League proms. In 1913, his became the first black orchestra to make phonograph records, for Victor, then the world's foremost label. His band, not above playing ragtime, was a precursor of the jazz age and he insisted on the importance and value of black music.

title: Nominal Value
description: In 1986, during his 10th year in prison for a murder conviction that he maintained was unjust, Randall Dale Adams evidently considered an option on the rights to his story to be worth somewhere in the low two figures. He settled for $10 in a deal with Errol Morris, a film producer. Mr Morris then made a movie, ''The Thin Blue Line,'' which raised doubts about the case against Mr. Adams and contributed to the reversal of his conviction.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: MISTAKEN IDENTITY. By Nayantara Sahgal. (New Directions, $16.95.) Bhushan Singh, the narrator of Nayantara Sahgal's eighth work of fiction, leads the pampered life common to the sons of minor rajahs. However, upon his return to Bombay after a brief sojourn abroad, he is mistakenly arrested and charged with ''conspiracy to deprive the King Emperor of his sovereignty over India.

title: OPRAH TALK
description: I lived in Baltimore when Oprah Winfrey was the host of ''People Are Talking.'' A friend of mine appeared on her show to promote a book she had written that described her experience in getting over a terrifying rape. As I watched the show, Oprah directed all her questions, hammering at times, to the mechanics of the act of rape itself: ''What did he do . . . where did he hold the knife . . . what did he do after that?''

title: Tape-Copying Decks Improve Their Act
description: Among the higher animals and human beings, larceny seems to be an innate trait held in check by social conditioning. But inhibitions fail, and the primal impulse asserts itself when it comes to tape recording. Even decent folk, who refrain from pocketing silver spoons, think nothing of taping copyrighted music.

title: Carolyn Bora Marries
description: Carolyn Bora and George McCully Laughlin Gould Jr. were married yesterday at the Federated Church in Edgartown, Mass., by the Rev. Robert L. Hammett, an Episcopal priest. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. Wallace C. Ross of Darien, Conn., and Douglas A. Bora of Rowayton, Conn. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gould of Sewickley, Pa.

title: TALKING: Condos; Securing Municipal Rights
description: THE efficient operation of a condominium, homeowner association or cooperative often requires officers and directors to get involved in local politics. It may be the only way for the residents to fight successfully for the services and perogatives they need.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: THE CHIP CONSORTIUM DEBATE;
Let a Thousand Companies Fight
description: LEAD: Unlike the Libertarians and the supply-siders, my opposition to consortiums is not politically or ideologically motivated. Rather, it is based on an even deeper strain of American philosophy: pragmatism. Simply put, consortiums don't work as well as the present system does. And consortiums don't have the confidence of America's business leaders.

title: It's a New Age For Father-Son Relationships
description: The latest new-age consumer products are not crystals or self-help tapes or Shirley MacLaine books; they are movies. Several of this summer's films, from the sublime to the ridiculous, send their heroes searching for hints of God's presence in the universe, on quests for spiritual meaning. There is the search for the Holy Grail in the high-spirited ''Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade,'' the ghostly return of the Chicago Black Sox in the poignant ''Field of Dreams'' and even a journey through space to visit a possible deity in the simple-minded ''Star Trek V: The Final Frontier.''

title:
Prospects;
Auto Sales Slump
description: LEAD: Sales of new cars made in the United States for the third period in June showed big declines over the same period from last year. Sales by domestic manufacturers were down 19 percent for the period. Despite aggressive incentive programs offered by the manufacturers, sales for the first half of the year were down 5.6 percent.

title: To the Poles and Hungarians, Bush Is the Lure of the West
description: TRAVELING through Warsaw, Gdansk and Budapest this week, President Bush should at last find the sort of eager welcome that has too often gone to his Soviet rival. It is not often that an American President comes to Eastern Europe - certainly not as often as Mikhail S. Gorbachev goes to the West. The last time a President was in Poland was in 1978, and none has ever been to Hungary.

title: BAD TIMES ON THE BAYOU
description: Wayne King could have done a less predictable job of portraying the state of Louisiana. The picture he painted was a tired, old one. When he was here, Mr. King visited with a mix of young professionals who are committed to Louisiana; he met with artists and administrators who are behind a rich and vital arts movement.

title: Q and A
description: Fixing an Air-Conditioner

title: 53% Found to Disagree With Abortion Ruling
description: Fifty-three percent of the American people say they disagree with the Supreme Court decision last week allowing states to restrict abortion, a Gallup Poll for Newsweek magazine shows.

title:
Long Island Interview Gerard J. McKeon;
For Head of Racing Unit, Good Old Days are Now
description: LEAD: GERARD J. McKEON, the president of the New York Racing Association Inc., feels that, measured by the caliber of the sport, the good old days of horse racing are here and now.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE AARON COPLAND MUSIC AND ARTS PROGRAM;
A Harmony of Study and Nature
description: LEAD: SOMETIMES the campers in the Aaron Copland Music and Arts Program seem to transform themselves before one's eyes: sophisticated musicians, actors, artists and dancers one minute; the next, just kids - the kind who make a ruckus in the dining hall and curl up on their bunkbeds to write letters home.

title: Market for Top Apartments Is Cooling
description: TO many New York City renters, particularly those who endured the search for an apartment during the city's economic boom earlier in the 80's, it may seem as if Richard E. Hubner and Janet Aquino are talking about somewhere else.

title: Teamwork Works
description: To the Editor:

title: UPSTAGED BY BLANCHE AND SCARLETT
description: VIVIEN LEIGH By Hugo Vickers. Illustrated. 411 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $22.95.

title: Ousted Sudan Leader Facing Capital Charge of Corruption
description: The ousted Sudanese Prime Minister faces trial on corruption charges and possible execution, the Sudan's new military leader said today.

title: AIDS Initiative Is Urged
description: Federal health officials are recommending a vast new effort to reach those infected with the AIDS virus, saying that drugs can help prolong the lives of many. Page 25.

title: Jefferies Defended
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Tax Burden On Fairfield County
description: As I read your article ''New Taxes Renew Complaints of a Burden on Fairfield County'' (June 11), I was pleased to see that the recent increases had reaffirmed what most people, including legislators and administrators, already knew. However, it was nice to see that The New York Times was reporting it and confirming the cynical acknowledgement in Hartford that it is unfair, but so what.

title: Clean Air
description: To the Editor: In the Travel Advisory of March 5, the article ''No Smoking Area Not Smoke-Free'' about airplane cabins alarmed me far beyond the scope of the study mentioned.

title: Chiffon, Never a Cover-Up, Turns Into a Show-Off
description: Chiffon was so popular in the 1960's they named a soul group and a margarine after it. The latest chiffon craze started in Europe about a year and half ago, with the couture collection of Christian Lacroix. The transparent swish is now making a splash at all levels of fashion, from the hot city streets to the cool varnished interiors of the best restaurants and clubs.

title:
THE NATION: A Voice From Coal Country;
'It Was Old Men That Made This Union'
description: LEAD: EVERY day since early April, 50 old men have gathered beneath a makeshift tent in this Appalachian mountain town to erect their own picket line in support of the United Mine Workers' long, bitter and sometimes violent strike against the Pittston Coal Group.

title: Hotels in Business Areas Seek to Lure Weekend Vacationers
description: LEAD: HOTELS in New Jersey that for years have depended on business travelers are increasingly touting themselves as weekend getaway spots for residents of the New York metropolitan region who want a mini-vacation without the rigors of a long trip.

title: New Service Industry: Care of City Critters
description: For most service businesses in New York, the pace is sleepy after the Fourth of July. But it is the high season for the city's brigade of pet sitters.

title: August Wedding For Allene Smith
description: Mr. and Mrs. William N. smith of Wilmington, N.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter Allene Robinson Smith to Peter Alexander Cooley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel P. Cooley of West Hartford, Conn. An August wedding is planned.

title: DATA BANK: July 9, 1989

IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: STILL SMALL VOICES. By John and Janet Wallach. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $18.95.) In his foreword to John and Janet Wallach's ''Still Small Voices,'' a collection of profiles of 12 men and women living in the West Bank and Gaza, Teddy Kollek, the Mayor of Jerusalem, claims that even astute political and social analyses of the problems plaguing the Middle East ''ignore the most essential factor, a factor that does not always function as decreed by computer and does not always react according to laws of time and motion.

title: Assessments
description: To the Editor:

title: A Symbol of South African Struggle
description: Despite 27 years of imprisonment, Nelson R. Mandela is still the patriarch of black aspirations in South Africa and a powerful symbol of the multiracial struggle against apartheid.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: ON AND OFF THE AIR: An Informal History of CBS News. By David Schoenbrun. (Dutton, $18.95.) David Schoenbrun died in May 1988 after a brilliant 17-year career as a CBS News correspondent, followed by work at other broadcast organizations, then as a lecturer and author of seven books before ''On and Off the Air.

title: Employee Is Dismissed, Kills Two and Is Slain
description: A dismissed Coca-Cola driver killed two superiors Friday night, then barricaded himself inside a company office for seven hours, emerged this morning firing his guns and was fatally shot by the police.

title: An August Bridal For Diane Murray
description: Mrs. Morgan Thomas Murray of Lawrence, L.I., has announced August wedding plans for her daughter, Diane Margaret Murray, and Kenneth John Monk, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Monk of Chorley, Lancashire, England. Miss Murray is also a daughter of the late Mr. Murray.

title: PASTIMES: Numismatics
description: This week will mark the bicentennial of the fall of the Bastille and France has issued a set of medals to commemorate her revolution. In the hoopla surounding the celebration of the Bastille's storming, we should not forget that American indebtedness to France had a great deal to do with causing the French Revolution. American ideals of republican government, an end to royalty and a volunteer army were readily accepted in French intellectual circles.

title: Pamela von Dohlen a Bride
description: Pamela von Dohlen and Fred Richard Luthy, stockbrokers for Lombard Securities in New York, were married yesterday at the Presbyterian Church at New Providence, N.J., by the Rev. Russell O. Hays. A graduate of American University, Mrs. Luthy is a daughter of Mrs. Henry von Dohlen of Stirling, N.J., and the late Mr. von Dohlen. Mr. Luthy, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Luthy of Little Neck, Queens, graduated from Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some of the most notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted. Classical

title: A Calm, Ambivalent France Looks Back to 1789's Fervor
description: The 200th anniversary of the French Revolution finds France becalmed, its ancient rifts between right and left closing if not healed and its citizens looking with a mixture of pride and horror at the upheaval that shook Europe two centuries ago.

title: Turning Classroom Into Chaos
description: GET rid of those spitballs, ruffians. Sit up straight, timorous ones. Miss Margarida is back to espouse her ''method of instant erudition,'' to berate you into submissiveness - to show you the way.

title: Ways to Enliven the Home Barbecue
description: NOW that every fancy new restaurant seems to possess a charcoal grill, people are becoming increasingly more adventurous about the home barbecue. In addition to mesquite, grape-vine cuttings, hickory and apple woods are now widely available in stores and add an interesting smoky flavor to the food as it is cooked. Lemon rinds, bits of fruitwood or herb stalks can also be added to the fire.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''This slowdown is turning out to be so widespread that it cannot be ignored.'' Peter L. Bernstein, economic consultant

title: New Jet, Left Idle, Symbolizes Pilots' Dispute With United
description: A brand new Boeing 747 parked at San Francisco International Airport has stood for more than a week as a stark symbol of United Airlines' tense relations with its unionized pilots.

title: Helen G. Howell To Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry L. Howell of Atlanta have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Helen Garrison Howell and Christopher Asher Wray, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Cecil Wray Jr. of New York.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: It's happening right now. Two couples, or individuals, who have been friends for years are traveling together for the first time. For many of them, this will also be, if not the dissolution of the friendship, certainly the last joint expedition. For it is a certain, if not well-known, fact that getting along beautifully at home is no guarantee of getting along equally as well elsewhere.

title: Labor Party Considers Pulling Out Of Governing Coalition in Israel
description: The Labor Party is considering whether to leave its governing coalition with Likud, bringing down the Israeli Government, and analysts on both sides of the question are giving the proposition an even chance.

title: Judith Pentek Arthur Wed To Jerry Kearns, an Artist
description: Judith Pentek Arthur, an independent public relations consultant in New York, and Jerry Byron Kearns, a painter, were married yesterday in a nondenominational ceremony at Opus 40, an environmental sculpture in High Woods, N.Y. The Rev. Arthur Oudemool, a Unitarian minister, officiated.

title: Showdown Time for Danny Wall
description: When the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif., was taken over by Federal regulators in April, it became just one of more than 200 sick savings institutions to be commandeered by the Government this year.

title: A Castle to Dream
description: TRAVELING in England today, some writers tell us, is often depressing. In his recent ''Coasting,'' Jonathan Raban described a deteriorating rural culture and landscape. Circling the island in ''Kingdom by the Sea,'' Paul Theroux sadly remarked, ''And that was how I began to think of the whole country; if I had only one word to describe the expression of England's face I would have said: insulted.'' Other critics frequently say that England has been turned into a giant theme park. A passionate pilgrim to the English countryside, I remain unconvinced.

title: Hospital Rates Get 'Overhaul'
description: LEAD: NEARLY 10 years after New Jersey began the nation's first system that set hospital rates based on why patients were admitted to the hospital rather than how long they stayed, state regulators are refitting the complex setup for the 1990's. The revisions address such developments as the AIDS epidemic, declining occupancy rates and higher labor costs linked to a shortage of nurses and other personnel.

title: Replacing Asphalt Roof Shingles
description: ASPHALT shingles normally last 15 to 25 years before needing replacement because of age. But roofs with such shingles should be inspected annually for wear, and individual shingles should be repaired or replaced if damaged.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE POTATO BARON. By John Thorndike. (Villard, $17.95.) Austin Pooler loves his family's potato farm in northern Maine with the passion of a native son. He feels an equal devotion to his wife, Fay. His life is rich and complete, until one spring morning when Fay leaves the farm with their 8-year-old son, asking Austin to join her (she's not sure where) as she makes a new life for herself.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: RECENT RELEASES
description: CLASSICAL Janacek: Glagolitic Mass, 'Taras Bulba' Libuse Domaninska, soprano, Vera Soukupova, contralto, Beno Blachut, tenor, Eduard Haken, bass, Jaroslav Vodrazka, organ, Czech Philharmonic Chorus (Mass); Czech Philharmonic conducted by Karel Ancerl. Supraphon DC-8037; CD only. The Czechoslovak conductor Karel Ancerl left Prague in 1969 for the Toronto Symphony and died in 1973, at 65, without having attained the international acclaim his musicianship merited. His 1963 recording of the Glagolitic Mass is a high point of his discography (and Janacek's), a stunning example of his gift for balancing fervor and finesse. No other performance so fully conveys the fierce, elemental quality of this exuberant pantheist-nationalist manifesto, yet none is more elegantly musical. Mr. Vodrazka and Mr. Blachut are wonderful. ''Taras Bulba'' makes a nice bonus, and the sound stands up well. - Richard Freed Beethoven: Late Piano Sonatas Richard Goode, piano. Nonesuch 79211; two CD's, cassettes and LP's Richard Goode's Beethoven always satisfies though it does not thrill, always explains cogently though it does not make revelations. Throughout this well-played, thoughtful and expressive traversal, one senses the pianist's awareness of the music's many dimensions, senses that he has asked questions and probed the scores. Nothing just goes by, so the playing rings true, but one misses something at the extremes, whether of serenity, tempestuousness or brio. I prefer a more headlong approach in the ''Hammerklavier,'' but otherwise find the shape of Mr. Goode's interpretations persuasive; I also wish for a more singing tone in the lyrical passages - a complaint against a whole generation of current pianists. - Will Crutchfield Beethoven: Symphonies Nos. 2 and 4 North German Radio Symphony conducted by Gunther Wand. RCA Victor 60058-2-RC; CD and cassette. Like the previous entries in Mr. Wand's Beethoven cycle, these are solid, carefully laid out, cleanly executed readings, with rhetorical leanings toward Romantic grandeur, not Classic trimness. Still, in both symphonies, Mr. Wand favors the brisk tempos and sharp accents currently in vogue among early-instrument players. He also keeps textures transparent and applies a remarkable dynamic fluidity so logically that even the most personal phrasing twists seem inevitable. The Hamburg orchestra responds with precise, bright string playing, an appealingly acrid wind sound, and good, punchy percussion. - Allan Kozinn Richard Strauss: 'Elektra' Hildegard Behrens, Nadine Secunde, sopranos; Christa Ludwig, mezzo; Ragnar Ulfung, tenor; Jorma Hynninen, baritone; Boston Symphony conducted by Seiji Ozawa. Philips 422 574; two CD's only. Mr. Ozawa's concert version of ''Elektra'' last year received much favorable attention, but this composite document of the November performances in Boston's Symphony Hall is disappointing. While Ms. Behrens makes an exciting, involved title figure, the recording and the role's tessitura expose her raw, unsteady middle register. Ms. Secunde sounds like a provincial German soprano, loud but quavery; Ms. Ludwig is good but past her prime, and Mr. Hynninen makes a lightweight Orest. Mr. Ulfung provides a pungent Aegisth. Mr. Ozawa takes a curiously lyrical view of this hot-blooded score, eliciting many alluring details but undercutting the passion and grandeur. Stick with the Solti-Nilsson version on London. - John Rockwell Johann and Josef Strauss: Waltzes, Polkas, Other Works Vienna Philharmonic conducted by Carlos Kleiber. CBS Masterworks MK2 45564; two CD's, one cassette. Wonderful stuff: a great orchestra in its traditional New Year's romp under a master of the style. Joining the inevitable (''Fledermaus,'' ''Danube,'' ''Radetzky'') and the familiar (''Artist's Life,'' ''Voices of Spring,'' ''Pizzicato Polka'') are a raucous ''Peasant Polka,'' with the orchestra members vocalizing (''singing'' is hardly the word), a lively ''Little Chatterbox,'' a lovely ''Dragonfly'' and other confections. The only issue is whether the buyer, knowing of near-80-minute CD's, will pay full fare for two disks totaling less than 81 minutes of music. (CBS, a representative said, wanted to ''document'' the entire event, yet it provides no notes of any kind.) - James R. Oestreich POP/JAZZ 'Imelda Papin Featuring Songs With Mrs. Imelda Romualdez Marcos' Papin Records (1020 Keeaumoku Street, Honolulu, Hawaii 96814). Not known for her modesty, Imelda Marcos here reveals new heights of hubris. She is presented by a younger friend, the Philippine pop star Imelda Papin, who sings ballads in both English and Filipino. If Ms. Papin's clear, neutral vocals don't grate, Mrs. Marcos's four solos (including ''Feelings'') and one duet (Irving Berlin's ''Always'') border on the grotesque. Thin, cheesy arrangements augment the atmosphere of tin-plated sentimentality, as Mrs. Marcos who has wobbly pitch and no sense of rhythm, emotes with an affected tremulousness. Vocally she bears a striking resemblance to another famous wife, Yoko Ono, who at least had the good taste never to record ''Feelings.'' - Stephen Holden Don Henley: 'The End of the Innocence' Geffen 24217; all three formats ''How can love survive in such a graceless age?'' asks the former Eagle in ''The Heart of the Matter,'' which concludes an album whose songs connect personal disenchantment with a social climate of greed, cynicism and selfishness. The theme is announced in the opening title cut, a sweetly flowing folk-rock ballad written with Bruce Hornsby, that reflects sadly on the image versus the reality of the typical American father, as exemplified by Ronald Reagan. Also outstanding are ''New York Minute,'' in which a frenetic urban pace exacerbates the singer's sense that the bottom could drop out of his life at any second, and ''The Last Worthless Evening,'' a ballad of jaded romance. At once boyish and surly, Mr. Henley's singing perfectly underscores the mixture of longing and disillusion. - S.H. Carol Sloane: 'Love You Madly' Contemporary 14049-2; all three formats. Matching Carol Sloane's voice with Art Farmer's flugelhorn was an inspiration. Both lack great reserves of power and rely on a shrewd assessment of their limitations, and pure jazz smarts. They step lightly over bar lines, tying stray phrases together, altering only a few notes to freshen the melody. In her first album in a decade, Ms. Sloane gives much space to her other sidemen: Kenny Barron, Kenny Burrell and Rufus Reid; only Clifford Jordan is slighted. Ms. Sloane shines in ''Love You Madly,'' ''My Gentleman Friend,'' and Blossom Dearie's ''Inside a Silent Tear.'' She can sound too much like Sarah Vaughan, minus the spectacular vibrato, but she is a team player. You can hear these musicians listening to each other. - Richard B. Woodward Mavis Staples: 'Time Waits for No One' Paisley Park 25798; all three formats. The first solo album since 1976 by the Mississippi-born gospel singer was primarily produced by Prince, and its mixture of warm Southern soul-singing and gimmicky Minneapolis studio funk, though not always comfortable, is more harmonious than one might have expected. In the best cuts, like the lovelorn ''Come Home,'' which Prince wrote and produced in a style that deliberately echoes Willie Mitchell's 70's productions for Al Green, he extends himself knowledgeably into Ms. Staples' territory. In other cuts, like ''Interesting'' and ''Jaguar,'' her personality is all but smothered in Princely sound effects. - S.H. Hilton Ruiz: 'Strut' Novus/RCA 3053-2-N; all three formats. Hilton Ruiz once again seems better as accompanist than as star. The rhythm section - his piano, Rodney Jones's guitar, Francisco Centano's electric bass and the percussionists Robby Ameen, Steve Barrios and Mongo Santamaria - consistently lights fires under the soloists, who seldom justify the energy propelling them. The material is often second-rate: ''Goin' Back to New Orleans'' hammers away with a boring funk riff; ''All My Love Is Yours'' is pure corn. Mr. Ruiz goes on too long in his unaccompanied solo on ''Lush Life.'' But when he rides and creates cross-rhythms, as in ''Aged in Soul,'' he can be a captivating soloist, whose light, agile two-handed chords give his music the Latin tinge Jelly Roll Morton deemed essential. -R. B. W.

title: SHI IS ISHTAR, SHE IS ISIS, SHE IS MARY MAGDALENE
description: THE MOON UNDER HER FEET By Clysta Kinstler. 315 pp. San Francisco: Harper & Row. $17.95.

title: No Headline
description: IN a town where many people resolve their land-use disputes in court, one Westport businessman has vented his frustration in song.

title: Miss McGeehan Weds John Arrix
description: The Chapel of St. Lucy Filippini in Morristown, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Barbara Grant McGeehan, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John McGeehan of Chatham, N.J., to John Andrew Arrix, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Arrix of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Robert Hoffmann, an uncle of the bride, performed the Roman Catholic ceremony, assisted by Msgr. John Carroll and the Rev. Peter Krebs.

title: State Agencies Seek to Adjust to Impact of the Budget Cuts
description: IN the General Assembly's scramble to make budget ends meet this year, most of the attention and the headlines focused on taxes. Sales taxes, interest and revenue taxes, capital gains taxes - all were raised sharply and dramatically in the last days of the session to close the budget gap.

title: A Discomforting Quiz
description: To the Editor:

title: Bilingual Party Talk And Lights in the Sky
description: At the Russian Tea Room on Thursday night, there was more Russian than usual in the air. The party was for the principals of the Kirov Ballet, who were bused to the restaurant after their performance at the Metropolitan Opera. Of the dancers, only Faruk Ruzimatov, a star performer, spoke English. The Met's chairman, James S. Marcus, made his welcoming remarks in Russian. Yuri Dubinin, the Soviet Ambassador, spoke in English, though, and eventually the dancers and other guests struck up at least a nodding acquaintance at the buffet.

title: Surgery for Farr
description: After competing in 17 events this season and winning $33,344, Heather Farr, a member of the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour for the past four years, will miss the rest of the 1989 season because she needs to have surgery for breast cancer. The 24-year-old Farr is scheduled to undergo surgery July 17 at Cedars-Sinai Hospital in Los Angeles.(AP)

title: VIEWS FROM THE BARRICADES
description: LEAD: THE FRENCH REVOLUTION. By George Rude. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $19.95.) At least on one level, ''The French Revolution'' seems to have been intended as an overview, an introduction to the Revolution and its place in history, suitable for the general reader. But George Rude, a professor of history at Sir George Williams University in Montreal and the author of several other books about the Revolution, is really writing for and about other historians.

title: Pamela O'Connor Weds Navy Officer
description: At St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Basking Ridge, N.J., Pamela Ann O'Connor, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald P. O'Connor of Bernardsville, N.J., was married yesterday to Ensign Jon Christian Cannon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walt Cannon of Far Hills, N.J., and Sarasota, Fla. The Rev. Stephen Rozzelle officiated.

title: ART VIEW
description: Benjamin West is part of the mythology of American art. He was the first American artist to take the grand tour of Italy. He was the first American expatriate artist. He was the first American artist to become an international star. In his rise from humble beginnings in Chester County, Pa., to court artist for King George III he more or less created himself from scratch. As a historical figure, West was an original.

title: Let's Not Worry About the Dollar's Rise
description: To the Editor:

title: CONSUMER RATES
NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD: CHARLIE DANIELS BAND

title:
INVESTING;
Speculating in Zero-Coupon Bonds
description: LEAD: Once zero-coupon Treasury bonds were mainly the choice of conservative investors who wanted to make sure that a specific amount of money would be available at a given time for a purpose - like a college education. But these heavily discounted bonds have recently found a new constituency: speculators who hope to profit from declining interest rates.

title: TALES FROM THE STOOP AND THE BALLROOM
description: YOU MUST REMEMBER THIS An Oral History of Manhattan From the 1890s to World War II. By Jeff Kisseloff. Illustrated. 622 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $24.95.

title: Andreotti Being Asked to Try To Form New Italian Cabinet
description: Former Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti will be asked to try to form a new Italian government, a statement from the presidential palace said today.

title: Q and A
description: Guest Ranches

title: Reform Medicare: The Rest Will Follow
description: In mid-1981, when the Chrysler Corporation was in the midst of a massive recovery effort, it established America's first board-of-directors-level committee devoted to analyzing the problems of health care costs and searching for solutions. Since then, a number of cost-management initiatives have been adopted by Chrysler, in cooperation with the United Automobile Workers union, and more are planned.

title: Where Information Is All, Pleas Arise for Less of It
description: AS the population of books and journals continues to explode, librarians complain that shelf space is running out and expenses are spinning out of control. At the same time, authors and scholars say that the multiplicity of mediocre publications makes it impossible to sift out the ones that contain fresh ideas. The proliferation of books and journals seems to have narrowed access to information instead of widening it, and some universities are considering ways to encourage their faculty members to publish less, not more.

title: Question Of the Week; What Should Happen To Rose?
description: Pete Rose has been accused of betting on baseball. He has been accused of betting on his own team. He has not been accused of betting against his team. But he has been quoted as saying that if he had enough money on a game against the Reds, he might think of throwing it.

title: On Issues of the Environment, Who Teaches the Students?
description: EVERY few years the issue of ''values'' in education is raised -perhaps by parents objecting to the teaching of evolution or by moralists objecting to the selfishness of modern society or by political theorists questioning the depth of our democratic convictions.

title: OPRAH TALK
description: Oprah seems rather comfortable and forthright in expressing herself in comparison to Ms. Harrison's attempt to give cosmic importance to what is merely another celebrity profile.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Are Foreign Golfers Better Than Americans?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Bridget K. Ready, a Teacher, Plans To Wed C. G. Robustelli in August
description: The engagement of Bridget Kathleen Ready and Christopher George Robustelli, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Robustelli of Stamford, Conn., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Ready of Atlantic Highlands, N.J. An August wedding is planned.

title: One Man's Crusade Against Boredom
description: ALAN CARUBA is bent on obliterating boredom. After seeing too many television shows with no class and too many movies with no plot, and hearing too many celebrities talk when they really had nothing to say, he decided to declare war.

title: Review/Music; Tanglewood '89 Opens With Ozawa and Watts
description: The Boston Symphony Orchestra opened its Tanglewood season Friday night by combining the tried and true with the well known and the beloved. It was good outdoor fare, and the outdoors themselves were heavenly; it had rained in the afternoon just enough to raise a scent of earth and cut grass and to put a haze around the streaming sunset without making puddles or scaring away the lawn crowd.

title: No Headline
description: AMONG the lengthy string of honorifics that make up Bangkok's official name - the longest of any capital in the world, according to the ''Guinness Book of World Records'' - one has lately assumed a particular significance: ''Jeweled Abode of Indra.''

title: Hempstead Taxes Without Representation
description: ''No taxation without representation!'' Sound familiar? That was the Colonial cry when England imposed the Stamp Act taxes without the people being represented in Parliament.

title: FICTION
description: THE DOWNFALL OF THE GODS. By Villy Sorensen. Translated by Paula Hostrup-Jessen. (University of Nebraska, $14.95.) The versions of the Norse myths with which we are most familiar today are still the romantic 19th-century ones. But each age must find its own truths in ancient lore, and so it is time for a new interpretation of these stories. ''The Downfall of the Gods,'' by the Danish novelist Villy Sorensen, is certainly topical in its approach. Here Odin, the king of the gods, is presented as an enigmatic dictator. The war god Thor resembles a paranoid commander in chief. Balder, god of justice, is a much-admired but ineffectual liberal statesman. Freyr and Freyja, the god and goddess of love, resemble flower children. And Loki, the archetypal trickster, emerges as a modern tragic hero. Outspoken, alienated, he alone sees that both the gods and their enemies, the frost giants, are capable of treachery, and is destroyed because he cannot act as intermediary between irreconcilable forces. Mr. Sorensen's prose, as smoothly translated by Paula Hostrup-Jessen, is fast-paced and economical, often laced with dry humor. The tales are connected by a theme, like chapters in a good novel. From the beginning, we are aware that the escalating militarism of the gods will ultimately cause the destruction of the social order. Thus the saga ends with the apocalypse rather than, as with most versions of the myths, the redemption of the world following the gods' demise, and this makes the book a kind of parable for the nuclear age. Though ''The Downfall of the Gods'' is based on the ''Younger Edda'' of Snorri Sturluson, the 13th-century Icelandic poet, many minor characters from the original have been left out, along with some important material about the major characters. Also missing is a sense of magic and mystery, and the rich, evocative language that gives ancient tales the ability to inspire every new generation with a sense of wonder.

title:
PASTIMES: Gardening;
Transformation In Green For Philadelphia
description: LEAD: A green Philadelphia was a veritable mandate from the city founder William Penn, who called for a ''green countrie towne.'' A city garden program there is helping to transform hundreds of bleak, bottle-strewn lots and, in the process, the lives of the gardeners who tend them. The Pennsylvania Horticultural

title: Tudor Sidelined
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers yesterday placed John Tudor on the disabled list for the second time this season.

title: Foreign Influences
description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth Ivers Weds J. R. Munro Jr.
description: Elizabeth Ellen Ivers, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Ivers of Corning, N.Y., was married in Clinton, N.Y., yesterday to John Richard Munro Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Richard Munro of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. John P. Croghan, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the chapel of Hamilton College.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Several Accounts Garnered by Tarlow
description: Tarlow Advertising landed a fistful of new accounts that were announced on Friday. Filofax Inc., the British maker of the popular personal organizer, appointed the shop as its first American agency, and Baxter Inc., a maker of men's clothing, also gave Tarlow its account. Both companies have budgets of about $1 million annually. Dansk International Designs Ltd.'s Gorham division, a maker of flatware and crystal, awarded its $2 million account to Tarlow.

title: Big Business In Marijuana On Vanderbilt
description: LEAD: Vanderbilt Avenue, a five-block strip flanked by gilded office buildings, the Yale Club, two banks and a large hotel, has become a thriving enclave for drug dealers selling marijuana to workers in the midtown Manhattan neighborhood.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by Reuters in Business Day on Thursday about auto dealers in the United States misstated two findings of a study by the consulting group of J. D. Power & Associates. The number of individual dealers is expected to be 15,500 by early 1990; it is not currently 17,660.

title:
Advertising;
Accounts
description: LEAD: * Hanes Hosiery Inc. and Bausch & Lomb to Arnell/Bickford Associates for DKNY Coverings and DKNY Eyes, respectively, two product lines licensed by the designer Donna Karan, with a total budget of $2.4 million.

title: 1-2-3, Kick! 1-2-3, Turn! 1-2-3, Bend!
description: AEROBICS as a fitness activity has more than 23 million participants in the United States. Of these millions, approximately 10,000 engage in the competitive sport of aerobics, according to the United States Aerobic Federation. In competitive aerobics, performers are judged on three-minute routines that include jumping jacks, leg kicks and strength and flexibility movements set to music.

title: Corrections
description: A Company News article by The Associated Press in Business Day on Tuesday misstated terms of the buyout of General Nutrition Inc. The Thomas H. Lee Company and its affiliate, ML-Lee Acquisition Fund L.P., have agreed to pay $11.50 a share for 91.3 percent of the outstanding common stock and to issue preferred stock for the rest of the shares. The total value of the deal is $360 milllion.

title: Both Sides Gird for an Abortion Battle in Albany
description: Although Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has said that he would reject any attempts to restrict abortion in New York, officials on both sides of the issue said next year's legislative session will likely be dominated by efforts to limit the availability of abortions in the state.

title: Policy
description: The Federal Government nowadays is driven more by imitation than innovation. What are billed as initiatives from the White House or Congress often are actually warmed-over ideas that trickled up from the states or, as they are known in the trade, the locals.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Veryfine Drops Chiat/Day
description: LEAD: Chiat/Day, which has had more than its share of good news lately, suffered a setback on Friday, losing the $10 million Veryfine Juices account. A spokesman for Veryfine said the company removed the account because of a growing conflict with another Chiat/ Day beverage account, Soho.The spokesman,

title: Annapolis Journal; City Fighting to Keep Its Soul Afloat
description: Sometimes it seems that almost all six million people living in the Baltimore-Washington corridor have discovered Annapolis, with its domed state Capitol, 18th-century homes, narrow cobbled streets lined with trendy boutiques, its starched Naval Academy midshipmen and, most of all, its crabs and oysters and boats, boats, boats.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the major economic indicators to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday None Wednesday None Thursday None Friday Capacity Utilization ... June Industrial Production ... June Producer Prices ... June Retail Sales ... June

title: Housing Authority Suspends Its Director
description: The city's housing authority has suspended its director of redevelopment and construction as part of an investigation into the building of a town house complex, the agency said Saturday.

title: Allegra K. Mertz, 76, Leading Yacht Figure
description: Allegra Knapp Mertz, the only woman to win yachting's most prestigious accolade, the Nathanael D. Herreshoff award, died yesterday at the Swedish Hospital in Seattle. She was 76 years old.

title: 'Pension Millionaires' Arising From Congress
description: In a little-noticed perquisite, members of Congress over the years have awarded themselves a generous pension plan that often pays more in retirement than members earned in salary.

title: Two Old Hands Meet Again on Mexico's Debt
description: Around 5 o'clock Saturday morning, Jose Angel Gurria, Mexico's chief debt negotiator, and William R. Rhodes, the Citibank executive who heads the 15-member bank committee Mexico is bargaining with, sat down to write.

title: Seidman Proposal on World Debt
description: The chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, L. William Seidman, has come up with a new proposal to help solve the intractable third-world debt problem.

title: Bridge
description: Ask the cognoscenti to name the world's best woman player and you would get a variety of answers. Many votes would go to Kerri Shuman, a Californian now living in Manhattan, and she might head the poll. On the diagramed deal from the Women's Team Trials played in Memphis in mid-May she demonstrated the skill that has brought her one world title and hundreds more at national, regional and local levels. She has a good chance to win another in September, when she will be a member of the United States women's squad in Perth, Australia.

title: The George & Gorby Show
description: Last week, Mikhail Gorbachev was working the fences of Western Europe, trying in Strasbourg to drive the tactical missile wedge into the rift that NATO patched over last month.

title: Finally, Fighting Murderers in Cambodia
description: With Vietnam's promised withdrawal from Cambodia only a few months away, the need there grows more insistent to block a return to power by the Khmer Rouge mass killers. That message, fortunately and finally, appears to have impressed Secretary of State James Baker.

title: Thornburgh Predicts Roe V. Wade Reversal
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh predicted Saturday that the Supreme Court would overturn Roe v. Wade, the 1973 decision that legalized abortion.

title: Azinger Breaks Record
description: Paul Azinger sank a 40-foot chip shot from the rough for a tie-breaking birdie on the final hole today and beat Wayne Levi by one stroke with a course-record 267 at the Greater Hartford Open.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Real Estate Group, Irvine, Calif., a real estate development unit of New American Holdings Inc., named Frederick T. Waldeck chairman and chief executive.

title: Process of Elimination Favored Jackson
description: Pat Riley remembers Nov. 19, 1981, the day he replaced Paul Westhead as the coach of the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: New Line of Cards
description: Thirty-five years ago, the Topps Company bought out the company that produced Bowman baseball cards. Last Thursday, Topps announced it was starting a new line of Bowman baseball cards.

title: Review/Ballet; A Bad-Boy Choreographer With His Nasty Schoolgirls
description: William Forsythe is full of surprises. And his ''Impressing the Czar,'' a 1988 work that received its American premiere in a performance by the Frankfurt Ballet tonight at the Pepsico Summerfare festival, is no exception, though not in the way one might have expected.

title: Housing Troubles Raise Kemp's Political Stature
description: When Jack F. Kemp chided his predecessor last week for mismanaging the Department of Housing and Urban Development, it was an unusual measure of how much of a mess he thinks he has inherited.

title: LaRussa Given 3-Year Extension
description: Tony LaRussa, the Athletics' longest-serving manager since the franchise moved to Oakland in 1968, agreed today to a three-year contract extension going through the 1992 season.

title: East German Team Dominates Finals
description: The East German national team, with entries in all the heavyweight men's and women's events, dominated the finals of the Lucerne International Regatta today. The East Germans placed first in five of the six women's events and won four gold medals, two silver and one bronze in the eight men's races.

title: Note to Readers
description: The Op-Ed page welcomes unsolicited manuscripts. Because of the growing volume of submissions, however, we regret that we can no longer return articles unless they are accompanied by a self-addressed, stamped envelope.

title: Nuggets to Black Group
description: A group of black investors led by Bertram M. Lee is buying the Denver Nuggets in a move that would make the National Basketball Association team the first minority-owned major league sports franchise.

title: Becker and Graf Seize Wimbledon Championships; Edberg's Style Bows to Power
description: This time the sullen British sky didn't rain on Boris Becker's Wimbledon parade until he had shocked the defending champion, Stefan Edberg, in three determined sets, 6-0, 7-6, 6-4, an outcome he pursued as the only acceptable antidote for his loss to Edberg in last year's final.

title: London Journal; Battling for England's Green and Pleasant Land
description: In the tiny, cluttered headquarters of Britain's Green Party, where workers seem to do three things at once, the walls are decorated with posters that read: ''The earth can't vote. You can. Vote Green.''

title: Leslie Anne Coolidge Wed To Brian Barry Stephens
description: Leslie Anne Coolidge and Brian Barry Stephens, senior managers at the accounting concern of KPMG Peat Marwick in New York, were married yesterday in Ridgefield, Conn. The Rev. Donald H. Baker officiated at the Ridgebury Congregational Church.

title: Unisys Chooses a Chip by Motorola
description: The Unisys Corporation plans to announce on Monday that it will use a Motorola microprocessor in a new line of computers.

title: Behind the Wheel Or Behind a Desk, Rahal Has Success
description: Sitting in his office at his new Honda dealership here, Bobby Rahal makes it clear he is ready to deal. But he isn't talking about working the showroom.

title: Pohlad Quits Jacobs Group
description: The Minneapolis businessman Carl Pohlad has pulled out of a group controlled by Irwin L. Jacobs that holds 20.6 percent of Tidewater Inc.'s common stock. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the group said Friday that it had bought Mr. Pohlad's option for $36,521 on Wednesday. It also bought back Dennis Mathisen's option and purchased his 235,475 shares.

title: Koch Agrees to Debate Rivals But Sets Limit in Primary of 4
description: Although he calls them ''the biggest bore in the world,'' Mayor Edward I. Koch has decided to attend four debates with rivals for the Democratic mayoral nomination. But he said he would take part in only four, even though he has been invited to more.

title: Chinese Were Voting Their Government Out; What Prekindergarten Education Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: Festival Latino Is Adding Film Judging to Its Events
description: The Festival Latino in New York, a hemispheric cornucopia of performing arts, will have something new, a film competition, when it observes its 13th year next month.

title: Ex-Colonel Is Guilty of Giving Away Secrets
description: A Federal court jury has convicted a retired Army lieutenant colonel of giving military secrets to a Defense Department contractor.

title: Tax Watch; Accounting Rules That Aid Mergers
description: BEHIND the wave of British acquisitions of American companies, particularly in advertising and other service industries, are tax and accounting rules that give British bidders a significant competitive edge, says Robert Willens, a senior vice president of Shearson Lehman Hutton.

title: Greedy Bankers Are Not the Villains
description: After agonizing negotiations, Mexico and its creditor banks are nearing an accord on debt relief. Even if the final agreement occurs in time for this week's Paris economic summit meeting, there will be only modest cause for celebration. Roadblocks will continue to stymie adequate relief for Mexico and dozens of other debtor nations.

title: Chinese Were Voting Their Government Out; Intervened Too Early
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Pop; French Caribbean Steam
description: Though Martinique isn't as well known for music as its French-speaking neighbors, Haiti and Guadeloupe, one of its best pop groups, Marce et Tumpak, is easily the equal of any band in the French-speaking Caribbean. Mixing the guitar-powered rhythms of zouk, the silvery and sophisticated pop music of the region, with the older folk music of Martinique, the group put on a steaming set at S.O.B.'s on Saturday night.

title: Hartford Boy Fatally Shot While Playing With Cousin
description: A 12-year-old Hartford boy was accidentally shot and killed Saturday during a tussle with his cousin, the police said yesterday.

title: BUSH IN WARSAW ON DELICATE VISIT TO PUSH CHANGES
description: President Bush arrived in Poland tonight for what he called a delicate mission in a Communist country unsettled by economic misery and swift political change.

title: Judith S. Gordon Married in Oregon
description: The marriage of Judith Sarah Gordon, the daughter of Ellen Faull Gordon of New York and the late Dr. Maurice B. Gordon, to Paul Schwyhart, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Keith Schwyhart of Vancouver, Wash., took place yesterday in Portland, Ore. Judge Thomas Moultry of the Multnomah County Court in Oregon, officiated at the West Hills Garden Estates.

title: Review/Music; A 'Rigoletto,' by City Opera, Without Much Ugliness
description: If something could have been done about that statue in Act I, a demolition contractor perhaps, then Saturday afternoon's ''Rigoletto'' at the New York City Opera might have given even more satisfaction than it did.

title: Liberty's Door Is Still Golden To Only 1 State
description: Although Governors Mario M. Cuomo and Thomas H. Kean publicly agreed three years ago that sales tax revenues from concessions on Liberty and Ellis Islands would be shared by both states, New York continues to keep all the money.

title: LOS ANGELES CASES SEEK HISPANIC GAIN
description: As part of a nationwide struggle to enhance Hispanic power, two lawsuits are challenging the political structure of Los Angeles County, where more than one-fourth of the residents - but none of the five supervisors who govern the county - are of Hispanic descent.

title: Laurie Silberg Becomes Bride
description: Laurie Silberg and Bruce Goldsmith, graduates of Union College in Schenectady, N.Y., were married yesterday at Temple Judea in Manhasset, L.I. Rabbi Michael Katz and Cantor Kalman Fliegelman officiated.

title: Political Campaigns Can Be Kept Free of Racism
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet City, Home of the A-Bomb, Is Haunted by Its Past and Future
description: Here on the shore of Lake Irtyash, east of the Ural Mountains, is a city with no name.

title: When the Government Said, 'Let's Put On a Show'
description: During the dark middle years of the Depression, the United States Government went into the theater business. From 1935 to 1939, the Works Progress Administration's Federal Theater Project employed 9,000 actors, directors and stagehands who gave 60,000 performances of 924 plays to 30 million people. Some performances cost a dollar, but most were free. On Monday evening at the Los Angeles Theater Center, the rise and fall of the Federal theater is to be chronicled by several actors who honed their craft there.

title: Xerox Is Trying a Comeback
description: The Xerox Corporation, which invented the personal computer in the 1970's but never capitalized on the advance, is steeling itself for a new effort to succeed in the office of the future.

title: INSIDE
description: Abortion Ruling's Ripples In issuing its decision on abortion, the Supreme Court complicated efforts by both political parties to gain voters and state legislatures. Page B8. Hurdles for Cable TV The fast-growing cable television industry is facing a rising number of consumer complaints and increasing scrutiny from Washington. Page D1. Debt Crisis: A New Idea L. William Seidman, the banking regulator, proposes an insurance fund that would encourage banks to reduce third world loans. Page D1. Good Pay, Off the Job A generous pension for members of Congress allows many to get more pay when in retirement than they did on the Hill. Washington Talk, page B6.

title: With Encouragement of U.S., Puerto Rico Seeks an Identity
description: Ninety-one years after it became a United States possession, Puerto Rico has begun negotiations with Federal officials to end its makeshift legal status and decide once and for all what it is to be: the 51st state, an independent country or a commonwealth with ties to Washington, as it is now, but with greater control over its own affairs.

title: An Austrian Solution for Eastern Europe
description: LEAD: In a recent speech in France, Mikhail Gorbachev seemed to renounce the Brezhnev Doctrine, saying that force was ''inadmissible'' within or between alliances. While lowering fears of a Soviet military crackdown and the end of another era of detente, his assurances heighten the need for the West to decide on a policy of how to encourage change in the lands between Western Europe and the Soviet

title: Navratilova Countdown Resumes
description: AFTER 16 years on the tennis circuit, Martina Navratilova seems comfortable with her latest role of underdog, chasing Steffi Graf and another Wimbledon championship.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a chart in Business Day last Monday about the second-quarter gainers and losers on the New York Stock Exchange misstated the percentage decline in the stock of one company, and thus incorrectly included it among the biggest percentage losers. The stock of the company, the Hallwood Group Inc., fell 7.7 percent from March 31 to June 30, rather than the 64.9 percent reported, when adjusted to take into account the value of a bond distribution to stock-holders.

title: HIGH COURT CALLED THREAT TO BLACKS
description: In the aftermath of recent Supreme Court decisions establishing tougher tests for discrimination suits, the head of the N.A.A.C.P. said tonight that the Court ''is more dangerous to this nation'' than the segregationist foes of the civil rights movement.

title: P.L.O. Chief Rejects Conditions on Vote
description: Yasir Arafat said the decision by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir to accept conditions voted by his Likud party on Israel's proposal for elections in the occupied territories dealt a ''deadly blow'' to the plan, and meant the Palestine Liberation Organization would no longer consider the plan. Mr. Arafat also voiced disappointment with American-P.L.O. talks.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS: BOXING;
Salesman With Punch
description: LEAD: When Art Tucker, an undefeated heavyweight from Newark, closes a deal, his counterpart usually drives off in a new automobile.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-7 President Bush arrived in Poland for what he called a ''delicate'' mission in a Communist country unsettled by economic misery and swift political change. Page A1

title: Phyllis Curtin Reflects On the Art of Singing
description: Phyllis Curtin admits that she sometimes feels she is swimming against the current. ''Nobody's interested,'' she says, ''in this preoccupation of mine. I sit on panels and commissions about the future of music and they all think I am peculiar.''

title:
ON YOUR OWN;
Synchronized Swimming for Nonmovie Stars
description: LEAD: IN Europe, where the activity began, it was called ornamental swimming. Esther Williams popularized it in movies in the 1950's as water ballet. Today, it is called synchronized swimming, and it has achieved Olympic status as a competitive sport for women. Competitors perform required and optional figures and esthetic routines, which are judged on a point scale, similar to the system used for judging divers, ice skaters and gymnasts.

title: Half of Emergency Phones Work, Audit Says
description: Motorists and pedestrians in New York City who turn to emergency telephone call boxes for help face a 50 percent chance that the units will not work, an audit released yesterday by the City Comptroller said.

title: Digital Plans to Introduce New Computers
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation, the nation's second-largest computer maker, plans to introduce a broad range of new computers tomorrow in an effort to strengthen its position in the technical and scientific computing markets.

title: Abortion Ruling Shakes Up Races for Legislatures
description: The Supreme Court's decision on abortion has complicated the efforts of both political parties to control state legislatures and dominate the redistricting that will follow the 1990 census.

title: Koch Widens City's Policy On 'Family'
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch will take the first step this month toward establishing broader rights for city employees who live with a partner outside of marriage.

title: Short-Term Rates Seen Declining
description: The marked slowdown in economic growth in the second quarter is likely to push short-term interest rates down even further in the second half of the year, credit market analysts say.

title: Elliott Sanger, a WQXR Founder And FM Radio Pioneer, Dies at 92
description: Elliott M. Sanger, the co-founder and longtime chief of WQXR, the pioneer classical music radio station that became the station of The New York Times in 1944, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 92 years old. Mr. Sanger founded the station in 1936 with John Vincent Lawless Hogan, an engineer and inventor. They shared a dedication to classical music and a conviction that programming semi-classical and light concert music with high standards would attract listeners and eventually advertisers. They believed there was an audience for live concerts in their entirety and for new composers and performers.

title: Language of Sport
description: Whether or not United States skiers win medals on the World Cup circuit in Europe next winter, some of the racers are bound to impress officials, hotel concierges and local residents.

title: The March Of the Party Animals
description: Anheuser-Busch Inc. had expected a quick knockout when the company tried to stop a small New York marketing concern from using the name ''Party Animals'' on a new cracker.

title: Treasurer of West Virginia Retires Over Fund's Losses
description: After 41 years in politics, A. James Manchin retired yesterday as the Treasurer of West Virginia, ending a saga that illustrates the problems state officials face when they try to compete in the financial markets with highly skilled and well-paid professional investors.

title: Beirut Beachgoers Trapped By Battle of Muslim Militias
description: Thousands of sunbathers were trapped today on Beirut beaches for hours as rival Shiite Muslim militiamen battled with machine guns, mortars and rocket-propelled grenades in nearby neighborhoods, the police said.

title: What Prekindergarten Education Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: LeMond in Form to Tackle Peaks
description: Greg LeMond retained the leader's yellow jersey today as the first act of the Tour de France ended here within sight of the Pyrenees.

title: Review/Television; An Unlikely Hero Copes, but Holds to His Dreams
description: Dennis Potter's ''Pennies From Heaven'' is back - on Channel 13 at 9 P.M. tonight, tomorrow and Thursday - and the 1978 mini-series remains as fresh, original and brilliant as ever. It is an outstanding example of how television itself can be a distinctive art form whose true potential is still being realized only sporadically.

title: Denise Borenstein Marries a Lawyer
description: Denise Joy Borenstein, a daughter of Ruth Hammond Harrington of Woodbridge, Conn., and the late Dr. Morris V. Borenstein, was married yesterday to Vlad Gerard Spitzer, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Adrian Spitzer of Irvington, N.Y. Rabbi Charles M. Feinberg officiated at the Valeur mansion in Rhinebeck, N.Y.

title: Day of Bible Reading For Murder Suspect
description: A former Sunday school teacher who the authorities say was on the run for 18 years after slaying his three children, wife and mother spent the day before his arraignment today reading the Bible in his cell, an officer said.

title: Tension Eases in Tompkins Park Protest
description: Ronnie Johnson came to live at Tompkins Square Park three months ago after he was stabbed with a sharpened toothbrush at one of the city's homeless shelters. ''It's too crowded, and there are fights,'' he said.

title: Campaign Matters; The Question Is, Does Koch Have Your Confidence?
description: On the very day Edward I. Koch declared his candidacy for mayor in 1977, bankers were demanding an outside overseer of the city budget.

title: REview/Theater; Night of Stars, and Also Shakespeare
description: Not all movie stars are created equal. Some are born great, some achieve greatness and some have greatness thrust upon them, to paraphrase William Shakespeare's ''Twelfth Night,'' the play serving as a Central Park summer camp for some visitors from Hollywood. Some stars, one might add, are not so great at all. But as visitors to the Delacorte Theater can discover, every variety of star, however dim, is welcome in the New York Shakespeare Festival production of a comedy that has rarely lived up so well to its full title, ''Twelfth Night, or What You Will.''

title: Quotation of the Day
