description: ''Poland has started along an ascending path of democratic change. This climb is exhilarating, but not always easy, and will require sacrifices. But, if followed, if will lead to a renaissance for this remarkable nation.'' - President Bush, in Warsaw. [ A7:3. ]

title: Eda Ergul and Jeffrey Peterson Wed
description: At the First Presbyterian Church of Greenwich, Conn., Eda Ergul, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Necdet F. Ergul of Greenwich, was married yesterday to Jeffrey Randolph Peterson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Peterson, also of Greenwich. The Rev. Richard Stearns officiated.

title: Corrections
description: A table in Business Day on Friday about mutual fund performance in the second quarter showed percentage changes incorrectly for all of the bottom performers on the list except the first. All quarterly figures in the bottom performance category were ''minus.''

title: After Amazon Slaying, Deals Abound
description: The killing of a rubber tapper in the Amazon rain forest last year has set off a stampede among film makers and book publishers in the United States, Europe and South America to be first with his life story.

title: Yankees Battered As Pitching Falters
description: As he prepared for the long drive home for the All-Star Game break, Dallas Green sat in the visiting manager's office at Fenway Park, listened to a question about the Yankee starting rotation, and began to list the names.

title: Dr. Margaret Meyer, Economist, Weds
description: Dr. Margaret Ann Meyer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Meyer of New York and Bridgehampton, L.I., and Dr. Paul David Klemperer, a son of Dr. Ruth Klemperer of Birmingham, England, and the late Dr. Hugh Klemperer, were married yesterday at the Bridgehampton home of the bride's parents. Rabbi Charles Davidson and the Rev. Dorothy Peyton Jones, an Anglican deacon, officiated. The bride, who is known as Meg, will keep her name professionally. She graduated from the Dalton School and summa cum laude from Harvard University, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, and received a master's degree from Cambridge University and a doctorate from Stanford University, both in economics. She is an economics fellow at Nuffield College of Oxford University. Her father is the president and chief executive officer of Grey Advertising in New York. Her mother, Sandra Meyer, is an interior designer.

title: Bhutto Says She Favors Pact With India to Bar Atom Arms
description: Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto of Pakistan today denied that her country was building a nuclear bomb and said she would like to work for nuclear nonproliferation with India.

title: Question Box
description: Flawless at Wimbledon

title: Slew Colt Wins
description: Slew the Knight, who surrendered to Orange Sunshine by three-quarters of a length in the Long Branch Stakes at Monmouth last month, held off that rival by the same margin to win the $94,200 Hill Prince Stakes yesterday at Belmont Park.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Americana Sells Goods To Japanese
description: LEAD: THE commercial seemed pure Americana - or at least a television facsimile of it. As background singers belt out a jingle called ''Smilin' smile,'' a happy group of people gather poolside beneath the palm trees at a California home. They pop the cork on champagne. A man in a bright blue sports jacket falls in the pool and everyone laughs.

title: Becker and Graf Seize Wimbledon championships; Determination Fails Navratilova
description: Steffi Graf captured her second consecutive Wimbledon singles championship at Martina Navratilova's expense today and, in her version of going to Disney World, Graf took her family to Brighton for the vacation that was her incentive to excel here.

title: Mets Reward Johnson
description: Howard Johnson has looked at his offensive numbers this season and has concluded that he is the best third baseman in the National League. Yesterday, Johnson got a look at another set of numbers that convinced him the Mets, too, must think he is.

title: Cable May Get Its Wings Clipped
description: Even as it secures its place as the fastest-growing sector in television, the cable industry is facing a rising number of complaints from consumers and increasing scrutiny from Washington.

title: Rosario Stops Jones In Sixth Round
description: A straight right-hand punch combined with a lapse in concentration made a champion out of a beaten fighter today as Edwin Rosario of San Juan, P.R., became the second man in boxing history to win a lightweight title three times.

title: INDIA SEEN AS KEY ON CHEMICAL ARMS
description: Chemical companies in India have sold hundreds of tons of chemicals needed to make poison gas to Iran, Iraq and Egypt in the last two years, Bush Administration officials say, adding that they fear the trade may expand.

title: The Lure of Lifeguarding Fades on L.I.
description: Tom Kennedy's choice was clear: He could spend the summer in a pharmacy, filling prescriptions, working the cash register and growing paler and weaker. Or he could spend it in a bathing suit, the sun on his face, the sand at his feet, envied by men and admired by women. He could be a lifeguard.

title: F.C.C. Loses Court Ruling
description: A Federal appeals court has rebuffed the Federal Communications Commission in its attempt to revoke the authority of the states to oversee on-premises telephone wiring and maintenance.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of July 10, 1989: MONDAY Central Vt Pub Svc Corp P S Group Inc Pacific Gas & Elec Co Phillips Pete Co Pitney Bowes Inc Southwestern Energy Co Xerox Corp TUESDAY Cummins Engine Inc Divers Energies Inc Minn Hillenbrand Inds Inc Household Intl Inc Proctor & Gamble Co Weis Mkts Inc Weyerhaeuser Co WEDNESDAY Bard C R Inc CBS Inc CSX Corp Corning Inc Dayton Hudson Corp Hartmarx Corp Melville Corp Tokheim Corp Walgreen Co Woolworth F W Co THURSDAY Ford Mtr Co Del Idaho Pwr Co Petroleum & Res Corp Shelby Williams Inds Inc Texas Inds Inc Wisconsin Pub Svc Corp FRIDAY Aluminum Co Amer Chaparral Stl Co First Chicago Corp N Y St Elec & Gas Corp Unum Corp Williams Cos Inc

title: 6 Killed on Georgia Highway
description: A van loaded with 15 people returning from a family reunion collided with a pickup truck this morning, killing 6 people and injuring 10. Jack Crawford, Waycross post commander of the Georgia State Patrol, said the truck apparently veered off the road and then back into the path of the van. The accident happened at 12:15 A.M. on U.S. 84 west of here.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly AD HOC COMMITTEE ON INDIAN OCEAN - 10 A.M. TRADE LAW COMMISSION WORKING GROUP ON INTERNATIONAL PAYMENTS - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Television; Networks Want Every Viewer to Count
description: THE television networks need viewers, and they will take them wherever they can find them -even in hotel rooms, bars and college dormitories.

title: Jill Rappaport Weds Frederick Leiner
description: Jill Ellen Rappaport, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. M. Robert Rappaport of Baltimore, and Frederick C. Leiner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Leiner of McLean, Va., were married yesterday at the Suburban Country Club in Baltimore. Rabbi Elias J. Lieberman officiated.

title: Tjela of Lethoso Wins Marathon
description: Ernest Tjela of Lesotho set a fast pace from the start today and won the San Francisco Marathon nearly six and a half minutes ahead of the second-place finisher. Tjela beat about 2,000 runners in 2 hours 15 minutes 1 second.

title: Zimmer's Contract Extended by Cubs
description: Manager Don Zimmer of the Chicago Cubs was rewarded today for his team's improved play with an extension of his contract.

title: Priest, Holding Masses in Defiance of Church, Seeks Reconciliation
description: The Rev. George A. Stallings Jr., the black Roman Catholic priest who has been suspended for establishing an ''African-American'' congregation, said today that he would send a ''proposal of reconciliation'' to church officials.

title: Treasury Selling 7-Year Notes This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of new issues this week includes a seven-year note auction on Wednesday, as well as today's regular auction of new three- and six-month bills.

title: Deloitte-Touche Fit Was Easy for Leaders
description: J. Michael Cook and Edward A. Kangas are about the same age and they head similar New York-based firms, for which they have worked for about the same amount of time. Now they plan to work together in a merger of their businesses.

title: Bank Board Memo Details A Shift in '88
description: Top officials of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board repeatedly noted in a confidential memo last year that allowing a shift of examiners for a California savings association would send a dangerous signal to the industry that it could shop for lenient regulators.

title: Results Plus
description: Auto Racing Prost Wins French Grand Prix: Alain Prost of France won his fourth French Grand Prix yesterday. His 44-second margin over Nigel Mansell of Britain gave him a solid lead in the world driving standing. Ayrton Senna of Brazil, Prost's main rival and McLaren-Honda teammate, lasted just over 100 meters in the second start after an accident. Prost has 39 points after 7 races. Senna is 11 points behind.

title: Toni Glassman Is Married
description: Toni Glassman, the fashion coordinator of accessories at Lord & Taylor, and Bruce David Katz, a lawyer in private practice in New York, were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Sanford Glassman, in Waterford, Conn. Cantor George Weinflash officiated. The bride graduated from the Fashion Institute of Technology. Mr. Katz, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph S. Katz of New City, N.Y., graduated from Franklin and Marshall College and received a law degree from Yeshiva University.

title: American League; Brewers Defeat Orioles By 7-2
description: Rob Deer paced a 14-hit Milwaukee attack with three run-scoring singles today, leading the Brewers to a 7-2 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

title: Sax Combines Comedy and Intensity
description: ON the green grass of Yankee Stadium, the quiet of the late morning seems almost soothing. Players stretch and hit and field ground balls under a cloudless sky, and for a time, the only sound comes from the batting cage, where someone is spraying line drives toward the outfield.

title: New Argentine Leaders Move on Economic Crisis
description: As the pomp and ceremony of the presidential inauguration continued into its second day, the Government of President Carlos Saul Menem today announced a plan to attack Argentina's hyperinflation and begin economic recovery.The new Government halved the value of the country's currency against the United States dollar and decreed sharp increases in charges for public services to halt runaway inflation, Economy Minister Miguel Roig announced in a television address.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Investment Up in Taiwan
description: Foreign investment in Taiwan reached new highs in the first half of the year as a stabilized currency and reduced labor militancy attracted overseas capital, its Investment Commission said today.

title: In Brooklyn, Support for a Maverick Priest
description: The worshipers at Our Lady of Charity Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn spent most of the service yesterday on their feet, swaying and clapping as they sang robust gospel melodies. A set of drums next to the organ helped keep the syncopated beat. And over the altar hung the imposing figure of a black Jesus.

title: Workers Who Turn In Bosses Use Law to Seek Big Rewards
description: When the Justice Department last month settled charges that a military contractor had overcharged the Air Force and the Navy for ball bearings, there were two winners.

title: Brawl Costly to Reds' Pitcher
description: The Mets and the Cincinnati Reds played baseball in a gentlemanly fashion yesterday, but the proceedings of the day before proved costly to the Reds in their final meeting of the season with the Mets.

title: Review/Ballet; A Kirov Giselle's Fame Precedes Her
description: Altynai Assylmuratova was the jewel in the diadem that is the Kirov Ballet's ''Giselle'' Saturday night; she shone brightly but differently from Zhanna Ayupova, the virtually unknown 22-year-old dancer who scored such a triumph in the title role Friday at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Books of The Times; After 'Gorky Park,' Hiding Out on the Slime Line
description: Polar Star By Martin Cruz Smith Illustrated. 386 pages. Random House. $19.95.

title: Chinese Were Voting Their Government Out
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; UAL Is Called Attractive Target
description: SOME airline analysts think the UAL Corporation, the parent company of United Air Lines, has become a prime takeover target, for a price far higher than the current value of its stock.

title: Merrill Lynch Move Benefits Metropolitan Area
description: To the Editor:

title: Outdoors: Couple Have Caught On To the Enticements of White Perch
description: ONE of the most ignored fish in the tristate area is the white perch, a small cousin of the venerated striped bass. The piscatorial version of Al Capp's Shmoo, the white perch is abundant in a number of local waters, and its firm white flesh makes superb eating. In his ''New Standard Fishing Encyclopedia,'' A. J. McClane, possibly the world's most experienced fish gourmet, declares, ''There is no finer fish to eat than the white perch.''

title: Donna M. Dodson Is Wed To Scott Michael Krasner
description: At the Appleford Estate in Villanova, Pa., Donna Maria Dodson, the daughter of Donna Levy Dodson of San Anselmo, Calif., and the late Fred Levy, was married yesterday to Scott Michael Krasner, the son of Drs. David and Barbara Krasner of King of Prussia, Pa. The Rev. Dr. Austin Joyce, a Presbyterian minister, officiated, assisted by Cantor Robin Sherman.

title: Helmet for All Seasons
description: A safety helmet for motorcyclists and snowmobilers has been designed to keep your head cool in summer and warm in winter.

title: Girl, 15, Dies in Gun Accident And a Bronx Man Is Charged
description: A 15-year-old girl was shot and killed yesterday by a man who was cleaning his gun in an apartment in the Fordham section of the Bronx, the police said.

title: Speeding Is Easy (and Almost Free) in Montana
description: Trying to drive the speed limit here in the Big Sky State is like trying to eat nothing but bread crusts at a banquet.

title: Winnie Mandela Accuses Pretoria Of Exploiting Husband in Meeting
description: Winnie Mandela, the wife of Nelson Mandela, the country's most famous political prisoner, invited reporters into her Soweto home today to accuse the Government of manipulating her husband's meeting last week with President P. W. Botha.

title: E.P.A. Memo Cites Chryser
description: The Chrysler Corporation avoided paying $29 million in taxes on a series of 1988 cars that should have been classified as ''gas guzzlers'' because they did not meet Federal fuel-economy standards, a memo by the Environmental Protection Agency shows. The memo asserts that

title: Waive Jackson-Vanik For Now
description: My parents fled the Soviet Union in 1947. Like many Soviet Jews, my parents fled to preserve their religious freedom, their dignity - indeed, their very lives.

title: Woman Is Charged In Desertion Case
description: A 23-year-old Bronx woman was charged yesterday with endangering her baby girl, who was passed along by three babysitters and finally abandoned while the mother was buying crack, the police said.

title: Arafat Bars Israel's Election Proposal
description: Yasir Arafat said today that the Palestine Liberation Organization could no longer consider supporting the Israeli plan for Palestinian elections because of new conditions accepted by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir.

title: Expos' Langston Wins 4th Straight
description: Langston pitched a five-hitter over eight innings today and had two hits and two runs batted in as the Montreal Expos scored a 6-1 victory over the Houston Astros.

title: Gina Luria Weds Chauncey Walker
description: Gina M. Luria and Chauncey L. Walker were married yesterday at their home in Rhinebeck, N.Y., by Judge John Kane, a Rhinebeck village justice.

title: Chinese Boxers in U.S.
description: Wang Weixiong, the heavyweight amateur champion of China, and four other amateur titleholders from China arrived in New York on Saturday to begin 15 months of training at Gleason's Gym in Brooklyn in preparation for the 1990 Asian Games and the 1992 Olympics. One of the five athletes, Bai Shijie, with 10 years of amateur boxing experience, will act as their coach.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Gillette Wins Round In Wilkinson Fight
description: LEAD: The Gillette Company has won a skirmish in its battle with Wilkinson Sword over whose razor provides the more comfortable shave. The Federal District Court in Manhattan granted Gillette a preliminary injunction on Friday against a television commercial for Wilkinson's ''Ultra Glide'' razor.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Raul Alfonsin's Achievement
description: With a barely suppressed grin, Raul Alfonsin, who turned over Argentina's presidency to Carlos Saul Menem Saturday, used to tell a story about the frustrations of high office:

title: Business Digest
description: The Economy

title: Samuel's Homer Soothing to Mets
description: It was late Saturday night and Juan Samuel lay in bed contemplating the worst. He had been one of the central combatants in the brawl between the Mets and the Cincinnati Reds earlier in the afternoon, and he could not rid himself of the thought of further violence.

title: New York's Juvenile-Thug Mill
description: LEAD: A judge in Brooklyn's Family Court recently heard the case of a 14-year-old boy and his 10-year-old companion who dragged a 7-year-old girl into a school bathroom and raped her. The older boy, awaiting trial in the adult system as a juvenile offender, is out on the street. The 10-year-old's Legal Aid Society lawyer asked that his client be put on probation; the boy was placed in a limited-security facility in upstate New York, and his lawyer is seeking to return him to his abusive mother.

title: Israel Assails Revenge Attacks on Arabs
description: The Israeli Government urged Israelis today to end attacks against Palestinians in revenge for the deaths of 14 people in a bus crash said to have been deliberately caused by an Arab.

title: Corrections
description: A report on June 26 about the wedding of Dr. Meryl Ann Baurmash misstated her occupation. She is an independent surgical orthodontist.

title: E. Mt. Pleasant Jr., 70, Tuscarora Nation Chief
description: Chief Edison P. Mt. Pleasant Jr., widely recognized as the leader of the Tuscarora Nation, died Friday in Mount St. Mary's Hospital here after a brief illness. He was 70 years old.

title: Court Ruling Brings Fear to S.R.O. Hotel Rooms
description: The room where Ernesta Devore lives is no more than 10 feet by 15 feet with a sink in one corner and an old Frigidaire beside it. Mrs. Devore's bed is a cot, and a tin night stand, rusting in spots, holds her hot plate.

title: Chinese Were Voting Their Government Out; Bloody Campaigns
description: To the Editor:

title: Spain Announces Plan to Counter Inflation
description: Finance Minister Carlos Solchaga of Spain has announced a broad set of monetary, financial and fiscal measures intended to brake inflation, slow Spain's overheated economy and raise tax revenues.

title: Lightning Sparks Fire In Northwest Nebraska
description: A fire that was sparked by lightning raged out of control today along a 20-mile front in northwestern Nebraska, threatening the small community of Crawford and forcing the evacuation of a hospital, a nursing home and a park.

title: New Hasbro Chief Cites Strong Management
description: Alan G. Hassenfeld, the new chairman and chief executive of Hasbro Inc., has stepped into the shoes of his brother, Stephen D. Hassenfeld, who built Hasbro into the nation's largest toy company.

title: Bulls Elevate Phil Jackson to Head Coach
description: Phil Jackson, the top assistant to Doug Collins, was named head coach of the Chicago Bulls today, three years after he was passed over when the job was given to Collins.

title: Night of Rioting and Arson Ends at Prison in California
description: Rioting inmates were brought under control at a prison camp today after a racially motivated melee that left nine people injured and seven buildings burned, the authorities said.

title: Former Officer For Helmsleys Depicts Payoffs
description: A former controller of a company owned by Leona and Harry B. Helmsley testified yesterday that Leona Helmsley took payoffs from liquor distributors as part of a kickback scheme.

title: Hungarian Accuses Rumania of Military Threats
description: The Hungarian Foreign Minister said today that Rumania was posing ''military threats'' to Hungary.

title: Shipper Cuts Military Work
description: The Federal Express Corporation is ending its shipments of Defense Department packages that require special handling, a company spokesman said today. He said too much paperwork was involved in the shipments.

title: Article 780589 -- No Title
description: The man accused of being John Emil List, who is said to have killed his family in their Westfield home in 1971, listened impassively today as a judge read a 17-year-old-indictment against Mr. List.

title: French Tour Operator Is Seeking to Be No. 1
description: Jacques Maillot, president of the French budget tour operator Nouvelles Frontieres, calls himself the champion of ''the people's right to travel.'' When the French Government tried to stop his sale of discounted airline tickets, he fought back and helped win the legal battles for European airline deregulation.

title: Rangers Close to Picking a General Manager
description: The Rangers, after nearly two months of interviews and intrigue, are close to picking the team's next general manager and could conceivably announce his appointment, as well as those of his assistants, within the week.

title: Our Towns; Volunteers Quit In a Messy Fight Over Recycling
description: For 17 years, Betty Evans, a third-generation resident who is now 78, went to the township's bustling recycling center and got up to her elbows in sorting cans and bottles and greasy aluminum trays and copper wires and all sorts of things to get Montclair the best prices at market for ''clean'' recycled junk.

title: As Graf and Becker Reign Again, The Old Guard Suffers Setbacks
description: Steffi Graf and Boris Becker, who were once pint-sized practice partners in West Germany, regained their grip on the Grand Slam championship they have come to regard as their own.

title: Westchester's Farthest-Flung Homeless
description: Across the Tappan Zee Bridge, up the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway and west on Interstate 84 where New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania meet, live a group of weary families from Westchester County. Not merely homeless, they are far from home.

title: Defensive Tactics by Delta Air
description: In a series of moves apparently intended to discourage takeover attempts, Delta Air Lines Inc. said today that it had formed an employee stock ownership plan, sold 5 percent of the company to Swissair and begun a buyback of 9.5 million common shares.

title: The Palestinian Time Bomb
description: LEAD: The bus crash in Israel, and the anti-Arab vigilantism that broke out this weekend in response to that tragedy, only underscore what many have been saying for some time: The occupied territories are spinning out of control, threatening to become another Lebanon in the Middle East.

title: Bahrain Buys Smelter
description: Bahrain has bought 17 percent of a local aluminum smelter from Kaisertech Ltd. of Oakland, Calif., increasing the island's stake in the plant to 74.9 percent. The Bahrain-based Gulf News Agency said the deal was worth $73 million. Other shareholders in Aluminum Bahrain are the Saudi Arabian Public Investment Fund with 20 percent and West Germany's Breton Investments with 5.1 percent.

title: Experimental Lung Treatments Offer Hope for Tiniest Patients
description: DESPITE enormous strides in saving premature infants in recent years, physicians have been unable to do much for some of their tiniest patients: very premature babies of low birth weight who suffer from serious lung ailments.

title: Inquiry About an Inquiry Unearths Feud in N.R.C.
description: The White House's intention to nominate Victor Stello Jr. as head of production at the nation's nuclear weapon plants is focusing new attention on an unorthodox investigation he approved in his current job as the top-ranking staff official at the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

title: Intel Demonstrates New EISA Chip
description: The Intel Corporation said it had demonstrated the first chip set designed to put into effect the Extended Industry Standard Architecture, a system for transferring data within a personal computer. EISA, which is supported by a coalition of personal computer companies, including the Compaq Computer Corporation and the Hewlett-Packard Company, competes with the Microchannel architecture used in the PS/2 computers of the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: Daniels Is Trying For Another Comeback
description: Six weeks after he was shot three times on a New York City street, Lloyd Daniels, a former high school star, is practicing again and hoping for yet another comeback at the age of 21.

title: Australian Clothier Grows in U.S.
description: Hemmed in by the likes of Brooks Brothers, Paul Stuart and F. R. Tripler on Madison Avenue, a small retailer is trying to capture a bit of sunlight by saying ''G'day, mate'' to shoppers seeking traditional sportswear.

title: Oil Near Exxon Valdez Delays Ship's Arrival
description: The arrival here of the crippled oil tanker Exxon Valdez was delayed today when the Coast Guard sighted an oil slick near the ship.

title: Jackson, the Knicks' New Coach, Contends He Has All the N.B.A. Experience He Needs
description: Stu Jackson said yesterday that he had ''jumped in the air, kicked my heels and screamed for joy'' when he was told last Thursday that he would become the Knicks' 14th head coach.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on July 3 about international shipping misstated the registry of the tanker World Prodigy. It is registered in Greece and owned by a company incorporated in Liberia.

title: Coral Cos reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company attributed the latest year loss to a significant investment in revising the company's software program.

title: Explosions in Mecca Kill 1 and Wound 16 Near Grand Mosque
description: Two explosions rocked Mecca today, killing 1 person and injuring 16, two of them critically, during the annual pilgrimage to Islam's holiest city, the official Saudi Arabian Press agency said.

title: Father Uses Business Skill to Hunt Missing Daughter and Fight His Grief
description: In hotel lobbies from Puerto Rico to California, posters carry the face of a smiling Tiffany L. Sessions. Truck stops, service stations, fast-food outlets throughout the South give out her picture. One minute her face is on a box of pizza, the next it is on a television commercial.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about Secretary Jack F. Kemp's political stature in the face of troubles at the Department of Housing and Urban Development misidentified the Secretary's chief of staff. He is Wendell W. Gunn.

title: Review/Theater; All the World's a Stage Within a Stage Within, Etc.
description: In the powerfully imaginative theater of Andrzej Wajda, the characters are forever slipping from world to world, between stages within stages. It is a theater in which unseen forces and historical ghosts exert as much control over life as the most powerful of the living, in which those who seek to know their fates must grapple with spirits in order to understand the past.

title: With Media Losing Mass, What's Left?
description: FUTURISTS have long predicted the demise of conventional mass media, to the consternation of those whose livelihoods depend on the media remaining massed. Now, Information Age seers like Alvin Toffler have been joined by one of the nation's largest advertising agencies, which has begun telling clients that the foundations of modern advertising - including mass-circulation magazines and far-reaching television networks - are eroding beyond recognition.

title: What's for Dinner? Psychologists Explore Quirks and Cravings
description: PSYCHOLOGICAL factors lie at the heart of many eating problems, from children who refuse anything but hot dogs to people who gain weight the moment they go off a diet, researchers are finding.

title: Symbol of the Lost Cause
description: When in his speech to the Polish Parliament today, President Bush referred to the Constitution of May 3, 1791, he was referring to a document that has come to represent a dominant element of Polish consciousness: the noble lost cause.

title: Stealth Bomber Tested at Full Engine Power
description: The B-2 Stealth bomber went through its first full-power engine tests today, emerging from its super-secret research hangar and rolling out onto a desert runway for the first time under its own power.

title: Santiago Journal; Hope of Chile's Right Rides Hype and a Motorcycle
description: With a flourish that evokes a combination of guerrilla hero and rock music star, Hernan Buchi's ''return'' has been announced by full-color newspaper ads and posters all over town.

title: Cherry Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income The company said that reduced automotive production, a temporary drop for data entry keyboards and switches were factors contributing to the decline in sales.

title: Giuliani's Powerful Image Under Campaign Scrutiny
description: In five and a half years as the Federal prosecutor in Manhattan, Rudolph W. Giuliani won extraordinary attention with major victories against organized-crime figures, drug traffickers, Wall Street manipulators, tax cheaters and corrupt officials.

title: Figuring Mortgages and Interest
description: EVEN those of us who do not work professionally with numbers must face them frequently. Which is the better deal on that new car: A cash rebate or a low-interest financing package? How much should I be putting away every month to realize a particular income when I retire? What will that house really cost?

title: Drew Eberson, 85, a Designer of Theaters
description: Drew Eberson, an architect who designed and renovated many motion-picture theaters in the United States and abroad, died of pneumonia on Saturday at the Bloomfield (Conn.) Convalescent Center. He was 85 years old and lived in Stamford.

title: Books of The Times; A Socialist's Aim: Human Capitalism
description: Socialism Past and Future By Michael Harrington 320 pages. Arcade Publishing/Little, Brown. $19.95.

title: Critic's Notebook; New York as Film Setting and as Star
description: The city of New York is not just the setting of ''Batman,'' ''Ghostbusters II'' and ''Do the Right Thing,'' three summer movies that take place in imagined and real versions of the city. New York is raised to the status of a character - in some ways the major character - in all three films. And it is a malevolent character, its evil positively taking center stage in ''Batman,'' oozing and percolating beneath the surface in ''Ghostbusters II,'' and hovering over false tranquillity in ''Do the Right Thing.''

title: Hydrogen Transformed
description: By applying extreme pressure to hydrogen gas between two diamond ''anvils,'' scientists have been able to transform this most basic element into what they believe may be a metal. If further research confirms this discovery, it could benefit those who study planets and stars and could have applications in other areas of experimental physics like the development of new superconductors.

title: Success Seen On Inflation
description: Central bankers from the West's industrialized countries are starting to win the battle against inflation, the president of the West German Bundesbank, Karl Otto Pohl, said today.

title: Mr. Bush's Challenge on Federal Pay
description: The issue of Federal pay remains too tender for Congress - to the detriment of the whole Government. President Bush has now offered reasonable proposals for reform that make the lawmakers' responsibility clearer than ever.

title: Careers; Environment Experts in Short Supply
description: SOLVING environmental problems for companies has become a fast-growing career field, says Vance M. Bakeman, who is vice president of engineering and environmental affairs for W. R. Grace & Company's largest unit, the Grace Specialty Chemicals Company.

title: Autodie Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $758,187.

title: U.S. Securities Prices Rise a Bit
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds inched higher in sluggish trading yesterday.

title: Washington Talk; Personalities Eclipse Legalism in Abortion Debate
description: For all the legalisms and nuances of abortion policy, the debate often comes down to television, to a brief face-off between Kate Michelman, director of the National Abortion Rights Action League, and Susan Smith, spokeswoman for the National Right to Life Committee. And often, the debate is conducted in extraordinarily personal terms.

title: Nike Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Anti-N.B.A. Appeal
description: Officials of the Basketball Union of Yugoslavia have appealed to clubs to stop allowing their top players to sign contracts in the United States. Yesterday, in a statement carried by the state news agency, the union called on local clubs to be more selective when allowing players to join the N.B.A., ''or our basketball is faced with irreparable loss.''

title: Review/Operetta; 'Merry Widow,' With Revisions, at City Opera
description: Viennese operetta is a fragile genre, not easily transported across geographic, cultural and linguistic borders. The New York City Opera apparently recognized this in 1982, when it introduced its current production of Franz Lehar's ''Merry Widow'' in a version that jettisons the work's stylistic soul and makes it into a hybrid of a Broadway musical and a sitcom.

title: Most Titles Are Still Undecided
description: The hiatus of baseball's break for the All-Star Game, and the sense of a season divided, is mirrored in horse racing's current July doldrums. Between the major July 4 weekend stakes races, and the Saratoga and Del Mar meetings next month, the sport seems to be taking a breather.

title: Joseph Corr Jr., 62, Advertising Executive
description: Joseph E. Corr, Jr., an advertising executive, former magazine publisher and cartoonist, died of heart failure Saturday at New York Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday about Sudanese military officials described an action by the junta leader incorrectly in some copies. The leader, Brig. Omar Hassan Ahmed al-Bashir, said he was abandoning a peace agreement reached last year between Sudanese rebels and the country's main political party; he did not say he had scrapped a cease-fire.

title: What's a Family?; Returning Property to S.R.O. Landlords
description: In finding New York City's S.R.O. law unconstitutional, the state's highest court read the law fairly, but the decision holds a potential for serious trouble that city officials dare not ignore.

title: Mel Blanc, Who Provided Voices For 3,000 Cartoons, Is Dead at 81
description: Mel Blanc, the versatile, multi-voiced actor who breathed life into such cartoon characters as Bugs Bunny, Woody Woodpecker, Daffy Duck, Porky Pig, Tweety Pie, Sylvester and the Road Runner, died of heart disease and emphysema yesterday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 81 years old.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Nobody in this country had any illusions that the stream of gold would flow. We did not expect alms or handouts. But while we are very much satisfied with the political tone of the visit, the substance is somewhat limited.'' - Col. Wieslaw Gornicki, a spokesman for the Polish Government. [ A1:6. ]

title: Neoax Unit Sale
description: Neoax Inc. said it had agreed to sell its Fairfield Manufacturing Company unit for $145 million to an affiliate of the New York merchant banking firm of Joseph, Littlejohn & Levy. Neoax, based in Stamford, said it would have a pre-tax gain of about $70 million from the sale, almost all of which will be sheltered by tax-loss carry-forwards. The sale is expected to be completed in the company's third quarter. Fairfield, based in Lafayette, Ind., manufactures custom gears for industrial use, and its sales totaled $100 million last year.

title: Home S&L (NC) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Beauty Amid the Beastliness In Portraits of Manhattan
description: ''News From Home,'' a hauntingly somber portrait of Manhattan by the Belgian film maker Chantal Akerman, requires a kind of patience that many moviegoers in search of escapist entertainment may not possess.

title: Bridge
description: Those who think that they play better than experts have a chance to prove it on the diagramed deal. Cover the East-West hands, and plan the play in six hearts after the lead of the club king. The opponents have done no bidding.

title: DCNY Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Cimarron Petroleum Ltd reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars. Year-ago figures have been restated.

title: Nuggets Are Purchased by Black Investors
description: Sidney Shlenker confirmed today that he had sold the Denver Nuggets to Bertram M. Lee and Peter C. B. Bynoe for $65 million. If the sale is approved, as expected, by the other National Basketball Association owners, Lee and Bynoe would become the first black owners of a major professional sports franchise.

title: Keller Industries reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said the figures of the Collingswood, Canada company are reported in U.S. dollars under U.S. GAAP.

title: Namibia Cuts Rhinos' Horns to Thwart Poachers
description: Trying a new tactic to conserve one of Africa's most endangered species, the Namibian wildlife authorities have cut off the horns of black rhinoceroses that roam the remote red-gravel desert here. The goal is to discourage poachers who sell the horns for tens of thousands of dollars apiece.

title: Backman Sidelined
description: Wally Backman, the Minnesota Twins' second baseman, who has been plagued with a sore left shoulder, has been placed on the 15-day disabled list, the second time he has been sidelined this season. Backman reinjured his shoulder Saturday in a game against the Angels.(AP)

title: Atlantique Video & Sound Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 20
description: b-Included tax credits of $623,787 and $645,318 for the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Questions on Authenticity Of 19 Warhol Collages
description: The authenticity of 19 Superman collages attributed to Andy Warhol has been questioned by two comic-book experts. They noticed that the collages are dated 1960-61, several years before the cartoon panels that were used to make them appeared in print.

title: 'I'm Just Kevin' For Now
description: In the National League clubhouse, Kevin Mitchell's locker is next to that of Ozzie Smith. And when more than a dozen sportswriters swooped in yesterday to surround the San Francisco Giants' left fielder, who has 31 home runs and 81 runs batted in, the St. Louis Cardinals' shortstop laughed. ''Time to go,'' Smith said, walking away. Not that tall at 5 feet 10 inches, not that muscular at a slim-legged 210 pounds, 27-year-old Kevin Mitchell was wearing a gold left front tooth and enough gold chains to be the envy of Mr. T. But he's having a season that is the envy of all the other hitters here for tonight's All-Star Game. And in his soft-spoken style, he tried to minimize his sudden stature.

title: Addendum
description: * J Minden Co., a sales promotion company, has been started by John Minden, who has worked for Morton Goldberg Associates Inc.

title: Andres Wines Ltd reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-9

title: Banponce Gets Merger Offer
description: Banco Popular de Puerto Rico said yesterday that it had offered cash and stock worth $293 million for the Banponce Corporation, in a transaction that would combine Puerto Rico's two largest banks.

title: Women in Rural Areas Face Many Barriers to Abortions
description: Outside the nation's biggest cities, women who seek abortions must drive for hours and often cross state lines to reach a doctor willing to perform one. In other areas, it is the doctors who must travel long distances.

title: Middleby Accord
description: The Middleby Corporation said it had agreed to acquire the assets of the Foodservice Equipment Group from the Hussman Corporation, a unit of the Whitman Corporation, for $62.5 million. It said it would also assume unspecified liabilities and obligations.

title: Soviets Open to U.S. Arms Plan
description: A Soviet official has spoken favorably of the Bush Administration's proposal to work out ways to monitor strategic forces before completing an arms treaty, according to published reports.

title: Dows Gains 14.80 Points in Light Trading
description: Stocks rose broadly yesterday in sharply slower trading, and the Dow Jones industrial average climbed back above the 2,500 level, jumping 14.80 points, to 2,502.66.

title: BUSH, IN WARSAW, UNVEILS PROPOSAL FOR AID TO POLAND
description: President Bush announced a six-part program of American aid to Poland today to help capitalize on what he termed the ''unprecedented opportunity'' presented by Poland's tenuous experiment in democracy. But the carefully limited package got a lukewarm reception from leading Polish political figures.

title: Sad Twilight For Factories In New Jersey
description: Another factory is closing here. And at age 60, Ben Forestieri, who is losing his job, fears that he is one of a dwindling class in New Jersey: the factory worker.

title: A Wrenching Time for Accountants and Clients
description: With six of the nation's Big Eight accounting firms embroiled in merger plans, the next few months promise to be wrenching ones for the profession and for its clients.

title: Novotna-Pugh Duo Wins
description: Jana Novotna of Czechoslovakia became the only two-time winner at the Wimbledon tournament this year by teaming with Jim Pugh of the United States today to win the mixed doubles final.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Beneficial Corp., Wilmington, Del., a financial services company, promoted Theodore L. Boyer to president of its Beneficial Data Processing Corp.

title: Iraqi Pipeline to Start
description: Iraq's $1.5 billion oil pipeline across Saudi Arabia to the Red Sea will open on schedule in September, significantly increasing its export capacity, the Middle East Economic Survey reported today. But Iraq said it would adhere to its OPEC production limit of 2.783 million barrels a day despite its increased capacity. The weekly quoted a senior Iraqi oil official as saying that the 580-mile pipeline would not be delayed by a four-month strike at the Hyundai Engineering and Construction Company of South Korea, which was producing units for an offshore terminal.

title: Nike Is Bounding Past Reebok
description: After falling behind Reebok in the race for the $4.5 billion American market for sports shoes, Nike Inc. is once again pulling ahead.

title: Winfield Told to Pay
description: Dave Winfield, the Yankees outfielder, has been ordered by a Texas judge to pay $162,000 annually in maintenance and child support payments to his former common-law wife.

title: K-V Pharmaceutical Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
People
description: * Lee Haikin has been named editor in chief and Kathleen H. Parmenter has been named vice president of advertising of Weight Watchers magazine.

title: Courtaulds in Bid
description: Courtaulds P.L.C., the British chemical and textiles giant, said it would buy the Products Research and Chemical Corporation of Glendale, Calif., for $32 a share, or $260 million. Courtaulds, which spent $21.7 million in April to buy 10.5 percent of Products Research's shares, said that the companies had signed a merger agreement and that Products Research's managers had agreed to tender their shares. Products Research's stock jumped $6.50 today, to $31.625 a share, with the 25.9 percent gain being the second largest on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: New Test Finds Signs of AIDS at an Earlier Point
description: RESEARCHERS say they have developed a test that detects evidence of the AIDS virus in blood earlier than current tests do.

title: Rolling Stones' Tour
description: The Rolling Stones have announced the first leg of their North American tour in support of their Columbia album ''Steel Wheels,'' which is to be released soon.

title: Washington Talk; Congress
description: In Indiana, Iowa and North Carolina, political advertising for the 1990 Senate races is on the air, a year and a half before Election Day.

title: Smearing the Dead
description: On June 9, after the death of Owen Lattimore, I pointed out in this space that in the 1950's he had been accused by Senator Joe McCarthy of being a Soviet spy and had had to live ''under the shadow'' of that false charge for five years.

title: Earth Technology Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 26
LeMond Keeps Lead In Tour
description: Greg LeMond of the United States retained the lead in the Tour de France today after the first tough mountain stage of the 23-day cycling race.

title: Marriott Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 16
Edison Mt. Pleasant, Tuscarora Chief, 70
description: Chief Edison P. Mt. Pleasant Jr., widely recognized as the leader of the Tuscarora Nation, died Friday in Mount St. Mary's Hospital here after a brief illness. He was 70 years old.

title: Just Free Nelson Mandela
description: Much that ails South Africa is apparent in microcosm in the meeting last week between President P. W. Botha and Nelson Mandela, jailed leader of the African National Congress. Not since the A.N.C.'s establishment in 1912 has any South African president or prime minister deigned to meet with its leader.

title: Yankee Doodle's 'Macaroni' Lingers On
description: To the Editor:

title: Giuliani Faults Koch on Bereavement Leave
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani assailed Mayor Edward I. Koch's decision to grant bereavement leaves to city employees who live with partners outside marriage, and yesterday the Mayor accused Mr. Giuliani of attacking homosexual rights.

title: A Challenge To Giuliani Is Faltering
description: With three days left before a filing deadline, a possible primary challenge to Rudolph W. Giuliani for the Liberal Party's mayoral nomination appeared to be evaporating yesterday.

title: Lindsay Manufacturing Co reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Banco Popular de Puerto Rico reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
'88 Quake Tremors Went Far In the East
description: AN earthquake in Quebec last year caused high-frequency ground motions 125 miles away that were much more severe than those from comparable quakes in the West, seismologists have reported.

title: Todd Shipyards Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
description: Latest fourth quarter and year results included a $100 million pretax provision for closure of the company's Los Angeles shipyard.

title: Xicor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 18
On-Time Performance Is Ranked for Airlines
description: America West and Eastern Airlines led the industry in on-time performance in May, the Transportation Department said today.

title: King World Productions Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company said the latest 9 months included an increase in net income of about $2.9 million from the adoption of FASB No. 96 in the 1989 first quarter. The company said the decrease in the number of shares outstanding was attributed to share repurchase in fiscal 1988 and the first quarter of fiscal 1989.

title: Business and Health; When Companies Hire Own Doctors
description: HOPING to curb rising health-care costs, some employers have long wished they could choose their workers' doctors, with an eye toward cost-effectiveness without sacrificing quality. Why not, then, hire physicians for the company and encourage employees to use them?

title: Collaborative Research reports earnings for Qtr to June 3
description: b-Net income and share earnings was less than one cent a share. The company said the latest quarter results reflect reduced sales of its bio- medical products and declining revenue from Sandoz Ag due to phasing down of work over the past year.

title: Jacqueline Ireland, 65; Active in Civic Affairs
description: Jacqueline Mayhew Ireland, a former civic leader in Manhattan, died of cancer Wednesday at her summer home in Pemaquid Harbor, Me. She was 65 years old and had lived in Thomasville, Ga., since 1986.

title: Miners' Union Cooling-Off Period Starts With Gunfire and Explosion
description: A cooling-off period called by the United Mine Workers was shattered almost as soon as it began today by gunfire at a nonunion mine and an explosion that damaged a coal company trailer.

title: Why Hide Rapes?
description: I understand why newspapers tend not to use rape victims' names. No crime is more horribly invasive, more brutally intimate. In no crime does the victim risk being blamed, and in so insidious a way: She asked for it; she wanted it. Perhaps worst of all, there's the judgment: She's damaged goods - less desirable, less marriageable.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY Chase Manhattan lowered its prime lending rate to 10 1/2 percent from 11 percent. Other leading banks did not follow but several analysts predicted they would do so soon. [ Page D1. ] A tense debate between the Administration and the F.D.I.C. over who will set policy for the cleanup of the savings industry has taken center stage as the House and Senate take up the savings bailout bill today. [ D2. ] The next few months promise to be wrenching ones for the accounting profession and for its clients, with six of the Big Eight firms embroiled in merger plans. [ D2. ] COMPANIES A Delaware court will begin a hearing today on Paramount's suit to block Time's proposal to buy Warner Communications, and Paramount took several steps yesterday to bolster its case. Among them, Paramount amended its $200-a-share cash offer for Time to include an interest payment of 9 percent a year. [ D1. ] Delta Air Lines took several steps to discourage takeover attempts, including the formation of an employee stock ownership plan. It also sold 5 percent of the company to Swissair. [ D1. ] Nike is once again pulling ahead in the $4.5 billion American market for sports shoes, overtaking its rival Reebok. [ D1. ] CVN agreed to be acquired by a smaller rival, QVC Network, for about $400 million. [ D4. ] Banco Popular de Puerto Rico has offered cash and stock worth $293 million for Banponce. [ D4. ] MARKETS In the first insider-trading conviction of a specialist firm on the New York Stock Exchange, a Federal jury in Manhattan found Marcus Schloss & Company guilty of two counts of conspiracy and securities fraud. [ D6. ] James Sutton Regan denied that he had committed a crime. The managing partner of Princeton/Newport is the main defendant in the first racketeering case to evolve from Wall Street's insider trading scandals. [ D20. ] The S.E.C. toned down its proposal to liberalize trading in the private-placement market, in a 5-0 vote. [ D5. ] Stocks rose broadly in slower trading, and the Dow Jones industrial average jumped 14.80 points, to 2,502.66. The Dow transportation average climbed 8.09 points, to 1,208.93, another record. [ D6. ] Prices of Treasury notes and bonds inched higher. [ D15. ] The dollar declined against several foreign currencies after Chase Manhattan cut its prime rate. [ D16. ] Prices of corn, soybean and oat futures fell in expectation of wetter weather. [ D16. ] INTERNATIONAL France's President Francois Mitterrand is pushing for the annual Group of Seven summit conference talks to focus on helping the world's poor nations, while President Bush intends to press his efforts to aid Poland. [ D1. ] Business groups responded critically to measures taken by the new Argentine Government of President Carlos Saul Menem aimed at taming runaway inflation. [ D20. ] Japanese business leaders say they are eager to use a trade conference in New York this week to make the case that Japan is taking significant strides toward free trade with the U.S. [ D5. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Some employers have hired physicians in an attempt to provide workers with lower-cost health care. Business and Health. [ D2. ] First Executive's rights offering may be intended more to raise money than to fight takeovers. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [ D6. ] Lintas: U.S.A. has begun telling clients that the foundations of modern advertising are eroding beyond recognition. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D19. ]

title: INSIDE
description: Anti-Eviction Law Attacked Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp is seeking repeal of a new law intended to protect families of drug dealers from being evicted from public housing. Page A10. A New Radiation Concern Taking a new look at the electromagnetic fields radiated by cables, wires and appliances, scientists say they can no longer rule them out as health hazards. Science Times, page C1. Mel Blanc Dies at 81 Mel Blanc, the voice of Porky Pig, Bugs Bunny, Road Runner and countless other cartoon characters, died in Los Angeles. Page A16.

title: By Design; Squishable Hats
description: Carolyne Roehm sits on her hat. The dress designer has also been known to pile books and papers on it. Recently she stuffed it in a suitcase and took it traveling, from the dust and heat of India to the rough rapids of a Canadian fishing stream. Like many people, she finds that a summer hat is indispensable.

title: Winchester Journal; Animal Haven Worth Braying About
description: Though it has never rained for 40 days and nights in Tennessee, Noah would have been pleased to know Don Shadow.

title: Argentine Businesses Reject Price Rollback
description: Business groups responded critically today to measures taken by the new Argentine Government of President Carlos Saul Menem aimed at taming runaway inflation. They said they would be unable to honor the order to roll prices back to those of July 3.

title: Pretoria's Ruling Party Keeps Silent on Mandela
description: Facing parliamentary elections in two months, the ruling National Party maintained silence today on President P. W. Botha's meeting with the imprisoned anti-apartheid leader Nelson Mandela. Speculation continued that Mr. Botha had arranged the meeting to try to upstage the National Party leader, F. W. de Klerk, and take credit for Mr. Mandela's eventual release.

title: Bank of New Hampshire reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Federal Crop Insurance Deserves a Fresh Start
description: To the Editor:

title: PATTERNS
description: After Isaia

title: Market Place; First Executive's Unusual Offering
description: WHEN the First Executive Corporation, a life insurance company known for its aggressive investments in ''junk bonds,'' announced plans at the end of June to raise money through a rights offering, the initial Wall Street reaction was that it had come up with a clever anti-takeover ploy.

title: Talks to Begin on Savings Bailout Bill
description: A tense debate between the Bush Administration and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation over who will set policy for the cleanup of the savings and loan industry has taken center stage as the House and Senate take up the savings bailout bill Tuesday.

title: BEACH OWNERSHIP SPLITS MAINE TOWN
description: Edward Bell has been telling town fathers and residents of this seaside resort for years that the beach in front of his home is his private property, but it took a ruling by the state's highest court earlier this year to convince them. Now, as Maine reaches the height of its summer season, the ruling is being put to the test.

title: 4 Bodies Found in Hartford In Home of Ex-Judge's Son
description: Four bodies, including that of a man believed to be the son of a retired Chief Justice of the Connecticut Supreme Court, were removed tonight from a three-story Tudor home in a wealthy Hartford neighborhood three blocks from the Governor's mansion. The police said the deaths appeared to be a triple murder and a suicide, with two of the victims killed by shotgun blasts, and two by pistol shots.

title: Scientists Debate Health Hazards of Electromagnetic Fields
description: IN the century since electric power revolutionized human existence, most people have scarcely thought, if at all, about whether it is safe to live with the electromagnetic fields radiated by the cables, wires, fixtures and appliances all around them. When the question did come up, scientists generally assured the public that there was no danger to health.

title: Paramount Amends Time Bid
description: A Delaware court will open a hearing today on the suit by Paramount Communications Inc. to block Time Inc.'s proposal to buy Warner Communications Inc., and Paramount took several steps yesterday to bolster its case.

title: Challenger International Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a $140,000 gain on discontinued operations. c-Net income and included gains on discontinued operations of $994,000 and $487,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Walsh Leaving 49ers
description: Bill Walsh has resigned as executive vice president of the San Francisco 49ers to join NBC as an analyst, the network said last night.

title: For Bush, a Polish Welcome Without Fervor
description: Poland is a country of tremendous emotion, and leaders from the West who have visited have often been overwhelmed with citizens throwing themselves on motorcades, pushing down barriers, and other signs of adulation.

title: Recognition Move
description: Recognition Equipment Inc. said its board would seek proposals as an alternative to a hostile $11-a-share proposal from the Prospect Group Inc., a New York buyout firm. Recognition's directors last month unanimously rejected as inadequate the Prospect Group's partial tender offer for about 7.1 million common shares. Recognition asked that proposals be submitted by Friday. The company, based in Dallas, makes data- and document-processing systems.

title: ITALY ADDRESSES POLITICAL IMPASSE
description: Giulio Andreotti, Italy's most durable politician of the postwar era, has been called on once again to try to form a government and finally end a political impasse that has left the country without effective leadership for nearly two months.

title: Charlotte Neuville: Life Near the Top
description: Charlotte Neuville is on a roll. Her two-and-a-half-year-old sportswear business is growing, her fall collection got rave reviews, and she is expecting her first child. ''The baby is due Dec. 26,'' the 38-year-old designer said, ''between seasons, when the market is quiet.''

title: Spectrum Control Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31

Income statement for last-year 6-month period reflected Initial Application of Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 96, Accounting for Income Taxes. Second quarter period comprised 13 weeks, and the 6-month period, 26 weeks.

title: Sotheby's Employees Striking Over Contract
description: Negotiations resumed late yesterday in a three-day-old strike at Sotheby's of 72 porters, bid spotters, doormen and property handlers. The union members of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Local 814, who work in the auction house galleries and three warehouses went on strike Friday when a majority voted not to accept a proposed contract.

description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's address today to the Polish Parliament:

title: Hooker Corp.'s Chief Expected to Drop Job
description: George Herscu will surrender this week the job of chief executive of the Hooker Corporation, the debt-laden Australian owner of Bonwit Teller, B. Altman, Sakowitz and the Parisian specialty stores, retailing executives in New York said yesterday.

title: Review/Television; How a Horse Opera Can Become Operatic
description: Replete with pasta and Frascati, my wife and I returned to our hotel room in Rome a few weeks ago and flicked on the televizione. After a bit of dial switching, we settled down with an old movie, made in America and dubbed in Italian. That became a sort of routine, and so we watched and heard, without understanding many of the words, ''Mary of Scotland,'' 'Nevada Smith'' and ''Little Caesar.'' Maybe it was the ambiance, or the wine, but they all came across like operas.

title: A Wrenching Time for Accountants and Clients
description: With six of the nation's Big Eight accounting firms embroiled in merger plans, the next few months promise to be wrenching ones for the profession and for its clients.

title: Xerox Sets Buyback Plan
description: The Xerox Corporation said yesterday that it would buy back about 11 million shares of its common stock, or about 11 percent of its 103 million shares outstanding.

description: To the Editor:

title: For Many Writers, a Mac Is Ideal
description: WRITERS and Their Computers, Episode Three, in Which the Virtues of the Macintosh as a Writing Machine Are Revealed.

title: An Audubon Group Finds Its Interests Extend Far to South
description: ASIDE from the fact that they are former British colonies and about the same size, Massachusetts and Belize would seem to have little in common. But they do share the wood thrush, the hooded warbler, the American redstart, the Northern waterthrush and the crested flycatcher.

title: Shaping a Summit Agenda: Mitterrand and Bush Goals
description: As the leaders of the seven leading industrialized democracies prepare to meet here on Friday, President Francois Mitterrand of France is pushing for the annual Group of Seven summit conference to focus on helping the world's poor nations.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TRACK AND FIELD World Record in Women's Mile: Paula Ivan of Rumania set a world record in the women's mile yesterday at the Mobil Grand Prix meet in Nice, France. Ivan, the Olympic 1,500-meter champion, ran the mile in 4 minutes 15.61 seconds to better the mark of 4:16.71 set in August 1985 by Mary Slaney in Zurich. Ivan ran alone the final two laps. Her quarter-mile splits were 63 seconds, 2:01.1 and 3:12.6. In the 3,000-meter run, Yobes Ondieki held a fast pace but faltered in the last lap to finish in 7:35.01, which was 3 seconds off the world record. In the steeplechase at the same distance, Patrick Sang ran 8:14.74. He pushed his fellow Kenyan Peter Koech to a world record 8:05.35 on July 3. Sang also started fast with the Olympic champion Julius Kariuki in tow but both quickly went off record pace. The Olympic champion in the 800 meters, Paul Ereng, ran 1:43.22, a personal best, but came up short of Sebastian Coe's world mark of 1:41.73. Jose Luis Barbosa of Brazil finished second in 1:44.36. Robert Kibet of Kenya was third in 1:44.46.(AP) FENCING Roldan Advances: Pilar Roldan, who won a silver medal for Mexico in the women's foil in the 1968 Olympics, advanced to the round of 32 in women's epee competition yesterday at the world fencing championships in Denver. The 49-year-old Roldan is president of the Pan American Fencing Confederation. Two members of the United States contingent, Donna Stone and Laura Maskell, also advanced.(AP) HORSE RACING Beirne Station Prevails: Beirne Station, carrying 112 pounds under Chris Antley, swung wide entering the stretch to join the leaders and then edged away to a 2 1/4-length victory yesterday in the $28,000 Tumiga purse for 3-year-olds and up at Belmont Park. Icy Jr. was second in the field of six, a length ahead of Sparkling Wit. The victory was the third in five career starts for Beirne Station, who covered seven furlongs on the fast but dull racing strip in 1:25 1/5 to earn $16,800 for Loblolly Stable. Beirne Station returned $5.60 for $2 to win.(AP) TENNIS Duncan Advances: Lawson Duncan, losing finalist in the United States Pro clay-court tournament a year ago, defeated a rookie opponent in straight sets last night in the weather-delayed opener at Longwood Cricket Club in Brookline, Mass. The 23-year-old Duncan from Asheville, N.C., who is seeded 10th, routed Mike Brown of Sebring, Fla., 6-1, 6-0.(AP)

Latest quarter results included an $8,907,000 loss from discontinued operations and a $65,000 charge on the disposal of assets. C.I.A. TAKES ISSUE WITH A DEFECTOR
description: In an unusual public statement today, the Central Intelligence Agency took sharp issue with a high-ranking Soviet defector's assertion that he had been mistreated.

title: Lava Field Reveals Magnetic Gyrations
description: ANALYSIS of lava that erupted in southern Oregon during a reversal of the earth's magnetic field about 15 million years ago indicates that the field fluctuated wildly, changing as rapidly as three degrees a day. The finding implies that fluid motions assumed to be generating the magnetic field where the liquid core of the Earth brushes the overlying mantle may be far more rapid than supposed, reaching one kilometer (0.6 miles) an hour, the authors of the report said.

description: b-Net loss c-Net income

title: Guidry To Retire As Yanks Spurn Bid
description: Told that the Yankees had no place for him on their pitching staff, Ron Guidry reluctantly agreed yesterday to retire, a source close to the club said. The Yankees made no announcement but scheduled a news conference at Yankee Stadium for tomorrow, at which Guidry would formally announce his retirement.

title: Saatchi Loses Pioneer
description: Pioneer Electronics (U.S.A.) has pulled its advertising account from Saatchi & Saatchi's Torrance, Calif., office and invited more than 15 agencies to try for the business, worth $10 million in billings. Among those approached were indigenous West Coast shops like Goodby, Berlin & Silverstein in San Francisco, Cole & Weber in Seattle and Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore., as well as Western affiliates of Young & Rubicam, N.W. Ayer, Ogilvy & Mather and Della Femina, McNamee WCRS.

Interco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31

title: Rocket Attack Kills 30 in Kabul
description: Guerrillas fired 53 rockets into Kabul today, killing 30 people and wounding 167 in the worst bombardment of the Afghan capital in a year, Government officials and hospital workers said.

title: What's a Family?; Turning Landlords Into Spies
description: The American family: once it meant a working father, nurturing mother and apple-cheeked children who trotted happily to school. The image was always romantic. Now, divorce, affluence and social tolerance are spawning many family forms, including partnerships of unmarried adults. As a result, people in California, Wisconsin, New York and elsewhere urge defining ''family'' more broadly.

title: 5 Arabs Die in Occupied Regions
description: Five Palestinians died today after clashes in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, and the army disclosed tonight that an armed Palestinian was shot dead by troops near Hebron last week.

title: Monetary Pact Set by Europe
description: Economic and finance ministers from 12 European nations set a timetable today to prepare for the first stage of European monetary union.

title: Isaia Rankin Is Dead; Dressmaker Was 35
description: Isaia Rankin, a New York designer known professionally as Isaia, died on June 28th at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 35 years old.

title: Gasoline Prices Ease
description: The national average price of gasoline has fallen 1.67 cents a gallon since early June, the Lundberg Survey reported. The average retail price in the latest biweekly survey on July 7 was 116.76 cents a gallon,. About 12,000 gasoline stations were surveyed.

title: American Medical Sends Humana Up
description: The shares of Humana Inc. rose sharply today after American Medical International Inc. agreed on Friday to be bought for more than $3 billion. But analysts said they did not think Humana, a hospital and health insurance company based in Louisville, Ky., was a takeover candidate. Rather, they said, Humana's stock benefited from the values ascribed to American Medical by the buyers, which included the Pritzker family of Chicago.

title: Contacts Approved for Pilots
description: The Air Force has approved the use of soft contact lenses by pilots and air crew members because they can improve eyesight in combat, the service announced today. New pilots are required to prove that they have 20-20 vision, said a spokeswoman for the Air Force Surgeon General. But if a pilot or crew member's vision worsens after completion of training, and it can be corrected to 20-20, he will be allowed to use glasses or the soft contact lenses, said the spokeswoman, Patti Turner. Previously, only glasses were permitted.

title: F.D.A. Chemist Is Charged
description: Federal prosecutors accused a Food and Drug Administration chemist today of taking a payoff and charged two officials of a generic drug company with giving cash to the chemist's supervisor. Prosecutors in the United

title: Patriots Sign Flutie
description: The quarterback Doug Flutie has signed a one-year contract with the New England Patriots, the team announced yesterday. The pact reportedly will pay him at least $350,000 and could be worth more than $1 million, depending on the amount of his playing time. Flutie, who is 26 years old, made $150,000 last season. (AP)

title: Telemarketers in $400 Million Deal
description: The CVN Companies, a telemarketing company, has agreed to be acquired by a smaller rival, QVC Network Inc., for about $400 million, the companies said yesterday.

title: McCaw Cellular Cuts Lin Bid
description: McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. said today that it had reduced its bid for the Lin Broadcasting Corporation to $110 a share, from $120, after a court rejected Lin's contention that it had the right buy cellular telephone interests in New York and Philadelphia.

title: At Pyramids, Clues to Laborers' Lot Emerge
description: NOW that the power and splendor of the Pharaohs have largely been revealed, archeologists are making a concerted effort to learn how the common people lived in ancient Egypt, starting with the laborers who hefted the huge blocks of stone to erect the monumental pyramids at Giza.

title: L.I. Man Held In Racial Attack On 4th of July
description: A 22-year-old Long Island man was charged with assault yesterday in connection with an attack on several blacks in Rosedale, Queens last Tuesday, and the authorities said he was the catalyst in the attack.

title: Prime Rate Cut to 10 1/2% By Chase
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank lowered its prime lending rate to 10 1/2 percent from 11 percent yesterday, responding to lower rates available for the bank's own borrowing.

title: Kemp Asks Repeal of Drug-Related Law
description: Jack F. Kemp, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, is asking Congress to repeal a new law intended to protect the families of drug dealers from being evicted from public housing.

title: Q&A
description: Volcanoes Q. If the ocean was allowed to pour into a volcano, would the cold seawater put it out? A. No, and in fact there are submarine volcanoes, called guyots or seamounts. Their molten rock spreads on the ocean floor and is eventually cooled by seawater, creating what is called pillow lava.

title: Girl Is Killed in Connecticut As Storms Batter the Region
description: Severe thunderstorms and heavy winds swept through the New York metropolitan area yesterday evening, knocking down some power lines and spawning at least three twisters that cut a swath of damage through four separate towns and killed a 13-year-old girl in a Connecticut state park.

title: New York Panel Urges Lawyers To Aid the Poor
description: Citing the growing need for legal services for the poor, a New York panel has urged that the state's 88,000 practicing lawyers be required to devote at least 20 hours a year to public service.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Twilight to Limelight for All-Star Pitchers
description: The irony to the All-Star Game that will begin in Tuesday's twilight at Anaheim Stadium is that the starting pitchers were once without jobs, both of them released by their former teams. So, somewhat in triumph, Dave Stewart and Rick Reuschel will represent the American and National leagues as the best pitchers in the midseason game.

title: New Staff at Stagebill
description: Less than two weeks after completing its purchase of Stagebill magazine from B&B Enterprises in Chicago, Levitt Communications has begun building the staff by hiring several executives from Working Mother magazine. Carol Evans, 36, Working Mother's publisher, will assume the same title at Stagebill, and Sandra A. Hayworth, 29, will move from Midwest advertising manager to the same position at Stagebill, a program guide for 13 performing-arts centers in the United States, including Lincoln Center and Carnegie Hall. The magazine distributes 14.5 million copies annually. Last week, Levitt, which was founded by the departing chairman of the American Stock Exchange, Arthur Levitt Jr., announced the hiring of Sidney R. Ferenc, 35, the vice president for finance at Newsweek, as its executive vice president and chief financial officer.

title: Corrections
description: The News Summary yesterday referred erroneously in some editions to an article about suggestions of misfeasance by three housing officials. Reporting for the article was incomplete, and it did not appear.

title: Albert A. Lawrence, 84, Coast Guard Dean
description: Albert A. Lawrence, a retired Coast Guard captain who was a professor and dean for 23 years at the United States Coast Guard Academy, in New London, Conn., died Saturday at Florida Keys Memorial Hospital in Key West, Fla. He was 84 years old.

title: Review/Opera; In Europe, 2 by Mozart On Early Instruments
description: Mozart is popular at summer festivals everywhere, and his music - his operas especially - is still normally heard with modern instruments. But the early-music movement is making steady inroads, and this weekend has offered a European traveler the chance to hear two staged productions of Mozart operas in intimate theaters using period instruments.

title: 20 Groups Paid U.S. Lawmakers $1.4 Million
description: Twenty interest groups paid more than $50,000 each in speaking fees to members of Congress last year, an analysis of financial disclosure reports by Common Cause, the public affairs lobby group, has found. The payments totaled $1,440,000.

Chess

It is the Catalan's 60th anniversary, as well as the 60th anniversary of the Catalan Chess Federation, which is offering a prize of $5,000 and two $2,500 consolation prizes for the best games played with the opening in 1989.

description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Pregnant Women to Get AIDS Drug in Test
description: The drug AZT will be given for the first time to a group of pregnant women infected with the AIDS virus to determine if the drug can protect newborns from the disease, the Government said today.

title: Testimony in Princeton Case
description: James Sutton Regan, the managing partner of Princeton/Newport Partners L.P. and the primary defendant in the first racketeering case to evolve from Wall Street's insider trading scandals, denied yesterday that he had committed a crime.

title: Brock Exploration reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: Eldec Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 25
description: The company said the net income and share earnings for the first quarter fiscal 1989 included income from Transducers Inc., a subsidiary that was sold in 1988.

title: Federal Paper Board Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 17
Christian E. Albert, Executive, 46
description: Christian E. Albert, a marketing executive at Schieffelin & Somerset Company, liquor importers of Manhattan, died of cancer of the stomach July 1 at his mother's home in Quogue, L.I. He was 46 years old and lived in Pelham Manor, N.Y.

title: Inciting Eastern Europe
description: When I was young and reporting from Poland, a good friend in Warsaw asked me a question:

title: Missing Tables
description: Because of a malfunction in the computers that receive financial market data from The Associated Press, several tables reflecting yesterday's trading in gold; Treasury bills, bonds and notes, and Canadian stocks were not available.

title: British Pubs Get New Rules
description: The Government said today that Britain's biggest brewers would not have to sell 22,000 pubs as had been recommended as a way of fostering competition. The Trade Secretary, Lord

title: Philanthropy Plans to Shed Usual Secrecy
description: The Surdna Foundation, a family philanthropy with $300 million in assets and for 72 years a penchant for privacy, has named its first executive director and intends to take a more visible role among foundations.

title: Brambles Seeks Environmental
description: Brambles Industries Ltd. offered to acquire the shares of the Environmental Systems Company that it does not own for $14 each, or $137 million. Environmental's shares jumped $2.25 each today, to $13.75, with the 19.6 percent gain being the third largest on the New York Stock Exchange. The offer was made in a letter sent on Friday to Jack W. Forrest, the president and chief executive of the hazardous-waste management company based in Little Rock, Ark.

title: New Perot Project: Airport for Industry
description: Few developers have tried to create an industrial park with a new airport as its centerpiece, but H. Ross Perot, the Dallas computer entrepreneur, and his son, Ross Jr., are not typical developers.

title: Vacant Job of President Filled by National Foods
description: National Foods Inc., known for its Hebrew National kosher hot dogs, announced yesterday that it had named Steven I. Bachenheimer president and chief operating officer.

title: Education; Jewish Day Schools Cope With Teacher Shortage
description: Jewish day schools are facing an acute shortage of teachers of Jewish studies at a time when the number of students attending the schools is soaring.

title: A Vegetarian in the Pork Belt
description: THIS town (population 103) 15 miles east of Iowa City is not a place that springs to mind in connection with vegetarian food. Deep in Iowa's pork belt, surrounded by fields of corn and alfalfa that climb in the summer sun, Downey looks like real meat-and-potatoes country, where people tackle midday dinner with gusto and then have pie for dessert.

title: Review/Film; It's Harry  [ Loves ]  Sally in a Romance Of New Yorkers and Neuroses
