description: The opening credits feature Woody Allen's trademark white letters on a black background, with a jaunty version of ''It Had to Be You'' on the soundtrack. The score is rich with Gershwin, the camera infatuated with Manhattan, the dialogue obsessed with love, sex and death. Altogether, Rob Reiner's ''When Harry Met Sally . . .'' is the most blatant bow from one director to another since Mr. Allen imitated Ingmar Bergman in ''Interiors.''

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Y.&R. Buys Into Agency In Hungary
description: TAKING advantage of President Bush's arrival in Budapest to spread the gospel of Western democratic capitalism, Young & Rubicam announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a controlling interest in one of Hungary's largest advertising agencies.

title: Review/Television; Could East-Bloc Loans Threaten Western Security?
description: Those who detect a leftward tilt in public broadcasting's coverage of international affairs, from Vietnam to Nicaragua, should be gratified by ''Follow the Money - an American Interests Special.'' The hourlong documentary, on Channel 13 at 10 P.M., is a cautionary report on how Western loans to the Soviet bloc could hurt Western security.

title: Fake Window Decals Pulled In Favor of Real Occupants
description: The fake six-pane windows overlooking the Cross-Bronx Expressway have disappeared. So have the half-open window shades and gray-and-blue louvered shutters. By the end of 1990, the Koch administration hopes, these newly gaping frames will hold real windows, real shades and real shutters -with real people behind them for the first time in more than a decade.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Reporter's Notebook; Miseries Temper Poles' Good Cheer
description: Among the Poles who began gathering this morning several hours before President Bush was to speak at the Lenin Shipyard was Maria Jankowska, a librarian at the Medical Academy who seemed to share fully in the festive air.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CHICAGO (NL) - Reassigned Ty Griffin, third baseman, from Peoria of the Midwest League to Charlotte of the Southern League, and John Jensen, outfielder, from Winston-Salem of the Carolina League to Peoria. CLEVELAND (AL) - Purchased the contract of Paul Zuvella, infielder, from Colorado Springs of the Pacific Coast League. YANKEES (AL) - Activated Chuck Cary, pitcher, from the 21-day disabled list. Sent Don Schulze, pitcher, outright to Columbus of the International League. BASKETBALL BOSTON (NBA) - Signed Kevin Gamble, guard, to a one-year contract. HOUSTON (NBA) - Signed Larry Smith, forward, to a three-year contract. COLLEGES ALABAMA-HUNTSVILLE - Named Joe Baker head men's basketball coach. HOFSTRA - Announced the resignation of Sharon Giblin, head softball coach. INDIANA - Named Don Donoher assistant basketball coach. IONA - Named Rich D'Amico assistant head football coach; Jim Bostic assistant men's basketball coach, and Rich Sutter men's graduate assistant basketball coach. MARYLAND - Named Roger McCready assistant men's basketball coach. NEW HAMPSHIRE - Named Lee Gove and Paul Faison assistant men's basketball coaches. ROSE-HULMAN - Named Scott Duncan athletic director; Bill Fenlon associate athletic director, and Greg Ruark intramural director. RUTGERS - Named Kristin Foley assistant women's basketball coach. WOFFORD - Announced the resignation of Jeff Leach, defensive coordinator. FOOTBALL JETS (AFC) - Waived Jeff Christenson and Eric Dahlquist, quarterbacks. NEW ENGLAND (AFC) - Waived Kennard McGuire, wide receiver. SAN FRANCISCO (NFC) - Announced the resignation of Bill Walsh, executive vice president. GOLF UNITED STATES GOLF ASSOCIATION - Named David B. Fay executive director. HOCKEY VANCOUVER (NHL) - Signed Paul Reinhart, defenseman.

title: And Just a Tad of Chromium
description: A healthful diet should include a smidgen of chromium a day, the Federal Agriculture Department reports.

title: Judge Throws Out Conviction In Case Over a Flapping Flag
description: A judge has thrown out the conviction of a Navy veteran whose flapping American flag bothered a neighbor. The veteran had agreed to put up a quieter flag.

title: NEWSPAPER PAYS BIG LIBEL AWARD
description: The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette paid nearly $2.8 million yesterday to a former judge defamed by an article the newspaper published in 1979, executives of The Post-Gazette's parent company said. It is by far the largest libel award against a newspaper ever to withstand review by state and Federal courts, legal experts said.

title: LAWMAKER ASSAILS DEFOLIANT STUDY
description: A Federal effort to study Agent Orange was flawed and may have been designed to fail, a Democratic Congressman said today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 A $43 billion Japanese aid package to improve the environment and help poor nations will be announced at the Paris economic meeting this week, Japan officials said. Page A1

title: Cuomo Signs Equal-Toilet Bill
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo signed a law today that requires new buildings to install the same number of toilets in men's and women's restrooms. The law applies to any building intended for public assembly and built after June 1, 1990. The number of toilets in a women's room would have to equal the number of urinals and toilet stalls in men's rooms. The lone dissenter to the bill, Assemblyman Kemp Hannon, Republican of Garden City, had said women should have more toilets than men because women take longer.

title: China Condemns Zhao and Weighs Holding Trial
description: A Government spokesman today blamed Zhao Ziyang, the ousted Communist Party leader, for growing corruption and said a continuing investigation would determine whether he would stand trial.

title: North Will Appeal, So His Fine Is Deferred
description: Oliver L. North said today that he was appealing his conviction and sentence in the Iran-contra affair, six days after the judge in the case announced that Mr. North would not be sent to prison.

title: G.M. Engines For Saab Plane
description: Saab-Scania A.B. said it would buy engines from the General Motors Corporation for its new turboprop airliner Saab 2000 in a deal valued at $500 million.

title: Head of F.D.A. Says He's Upset by Report Of Bribes to Agency
description: The Commissioner of Food and Drugs told Congress today that he was ''shocked, embarrassed and angered'' that scientists from his agency had accepted bribes from makers of generic drugs.

title: Their Masters' Voices
description: ''Ehh, what's up, doc?'' ''I tawt I taw a puddy tat.'' ''Sssssufferin' sssssuccotash.'' ''Beep beep!'' Mel Blanc and Jim Backus, both of whom died this month, populated memory with hundreds of the most unforgettable characters that kids, and adults, ever knew: Bugs Bunny, Daffy Duck, Sylvester the Cat, the Road Runner and, by George, the nearsighted, absent-minded mumbler Mr. Magoo. Also objects, like Jack Benny's Maxwell, an automobile that moved in fits and starts if at all.

title: Maryland Bonds
description: A $160 million revenue bond issue by the Maryland Department of Transportation was priced yesterday through competitive bidding. The winning group of underwriters was led by the First Boston Corporation. Consisting entirely of serial bonds, the issue was priced to yield from 6 percent for an issue due in 1992 to 6.25 percent in 1994, 6.50 percent in 1999 and 6.65 percent in 2004. Underwriters said the bonds are rated Aa by Moody's Investors Service and AA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. They also reported that the deal had been well received and that only a small inventory remained.

title: Those Costly 'Good Old Boys'
description: LEAD: A short time ago, an article in the Harvard Business Review enraged some and satisfied others by suggesting that women who want families should opt for a modified business career - that is, for second-class status and salaries. It began with the assertion that it is more expensive for a corporation to employ women than men, because women may divide their attention between family and career.

title: Exxon Valdez Kept From Harbor As Steel Plates Dangle From Hull
description: The Exxon Valdez has brought her owners a cargo of new woes, raising doubts today about where she can dock for repairs.

title: Buffalo Area Players Lead New York Open
description: Tim Straub, a 22-year-old amateur from East Aurora, had a simple explanation for the domination of Buffalo area golfers in the Michelob New York State Open.

title: High-Priced Rebounder
description: Larry Smith, a rebounding specialist with Golden State for the last nine seasons, signed a three-year contract worth $2.5 million yesterday with the Houston Rockets.

title: JAPAN TO PROPOSE A PACKAGE OF AID WORTH $43 BILLION
description: Japanese officials said tonight that Prime Minister Sousuke Uno would announce to leaders of the major industrialized democracies this week a $43 billion package of grants and loans to improve the global environment and to spur economic growth in countries crushed by poverty and indebtedness.

title: Battles Erupts over Honoring Officer Byrne
description: It has been more than a year since Edward R. Byrne, a rookie police officer, was killed on a Queens street while guarding the home of a drug-case witness, making him a martyr at least to his fellow police officers and Mayor Edward I. Koch.

title: Telerate Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Earl L. Sydnor, Actor, 81
description: Earl L. Sydnor, an actor, died of lung cancer on Sunday. He was 81 years old and lived in New York City.

title: William S. Maxwell, 89, Is Dead; Ex-Admiral and Pollution Official
description: William S. Maxwell, a career Navy officer who led a campaign against air pollution in New York after retiring as a rear admiral, died of a heart ailment on Monday at the Veterans Affairs Medical Center in Brooklyn. He was 89 years old and lived in the Midwood neighborhood.

title: Education; Lessons
description: Makers of standardized reading tests have become so adept at protecting school officials from the embarrassment of low pupil scores that genuine gains in test scores sometimes go unnoticed.

title: Hei Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 3
description: b-Included a reversal of a tax loss carryforward of $7,000. c-Net income and included tax credits of $71,500 for the quarter and $153,000 for the 9 months.

title: Ex-Shaklee Official Gets Nature's Sunshine Post
description: Nature's Sunshine Products Inc., a fast-growing marketer of herbal nutrition products, has named a former executive of the Shaklee Corporation, Alan D. Kennedy, as its president and chief executive, the company said yesterday.

title: City Opera Drops 'Moses Und Aron'
description: The New York City Opera announced yesterday that it was indefinitely postponing its new production of Schoenberg's ''Moses und Aron.'' The production was to have its first performance on Sept. 16.

title: Food Notes
description: American Food in Moscow

title: Conston Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to May 27
description: b-Net income The company said the loss in the latest quarter is primarily due to a decrease in sales.

title: Witnesses Clash Over Blame For Deaths From Bad Cheese
description: Testimony is expected to end this week in a case that has baffled medical investigators for four years: the source of the deadly bacteria that got into a batch of cheese and killed 48 people.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Torrents and Rainbows In Lubars Ads for Lotus
description: David Lubars is well schooled in dynamic computer advertising. As a creative group head at Chiat/Day, he wrote copy for several Apple Computer ads. And while he did not work on Apple's celebrated ''1984'' television commercial, Mr. Lubars does not hesitate to invoke that spot as the model for a new print advertising campaign, making its debut this month, for Lotus 1-2-3 software by his agency, Leonard Monahan Lubars & Partners in Providence, R.I.

title: Time Plans February Start For Entertainment Weekly
description: Time Inc. plans to begin publication in February of Entertainment Weekly, a magazine that will be its most ambitious magazine venture since faltering with TV Cable Week, Picture Week and Discover.

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: A Short Circuit Halted Subway, Officials Believe
description: The breakdown that stranded 2,600 subway riders in stifling, unlighted trains during the rush hour Friday night was caused by an electrical failure, Transit Authority officials said yesterday, and did not start when a passenger pulled an emergency cord.

title: United States Selects Its Davis Cup Team
description: Andre Agassi, John McEnroe, Ken Flach and Robert Seguso were named yesterday to the United States Davis Cup team that will face West Germany, the defending champion, in a semifinal match July 21-23 at Munich. Tom Gorman will again be the nonplaying captain. McEnroe, Flach and Seguso were members of the team that lost to West Germany in Hartford in 1987. The United States holds a 6-2 advantage against West Germany in Davis Cup play.

title: Christian E. Albert, Executive, 46
description: Christian E. Albert, a marketing executive at Schieffelin & Somerset Company, liquor importers of Manhattan, died of cancer of the stomach July 1 at his mother's home in Quogue, L.I. He was 46 years old and lived in Pelham Manor, N.Y.

title: Justice
description: Investigators, prosecutors, defenders, politicians, commentators, jurors: all have had something to say in the last two and a half years about Oliver L. North. Last week, a Federal district judge had the last words, and they were not comforting.

title: Peruvian Economy Plan
description: Peru's Economy Minister has vowed to raise wages and clear the way for easier imports by the end of the year as part of a plan to revive the country's battered economy. ''Over the next six months the state will promote a revival of economic growth, we hope with the firm cooperation of the private sector,'' the Economy Minister, Cesar Vasquez Bazan, said in a television address on Monday. He said that the economic plan would include cuts in customs duties and paperwork to increase capital goods imports, allowing factories to modernize and produce more, and that the central bank would continue its month-old policy of small, daily devaluations of the local inti currency, which spurs imports.

title: 2 Azerbaijanis Killed In Soviet Ethnic Clash
description: Two people were killed and at least 20 wounded today in renewed clashes between Armenians and Azerbaijanis in the southern Soviet region of Nagorno-Karabakh, the press agency Tass said.

title: U.S. Men Get Into the Fray
description: In the United States, most people think of field hockey as a game played by high school girls. And this country's greatest success in the sport came when the United States women's team won the bronze medal at the 1984 Olympics in Los Angeles.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I had inherited a legacy of abuse and mismanagement, fraud and favoritism in certain H.U.D. programs. I think it was run in a slipshod manner. The previous Secretary was a decent and honorable man. At the same time, I think it was managed poorly.'' -- Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp. [ B5:1. ]

title: Walsh Leaving the 49ers To Be NBC Commentator
description: Bill Walsh, who moved to the San Francisco front office after coaching the 49ers to the Super Bowl championship last January, has jumped to the NBC announcing booth.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Masur and Armitraj Eliminated: Wally Masur, the defending champion, and Vijay Armitraj were eliminated in the first round yesterday of the Volvo Hall of Fame championships in Newport, R.I. Masur, seeded fifth, lost to Matt Anger, 6-2, 7-6. Armitraj, the winner here in 1976, 1980, and 1984, fell to Christian Saceanu, 6-7, 6-3, 6-4. Paul Annacone, seeded first, defeated Jonathan Canter, 7-5, 6-4, in a match started Monday but suspended because of rain.(AP) Three Seeded Players Beaten: Three seeded players, Luiz Mattar of Brazil, Bruno Oresar of Yugoslavia and Jimmy Brown of Florida, were defeated yesterday in a wild scramble of makeup matches in the $415,000 United States Pro championships in Brookline, Mass. The weeklong tournament was forced to revise its schedule at Longwood Cricket Club after heavy rains Monday washed out 13 matches. Mattar, seeded ninth, lost to Karsten Braasch of West Germany, 6-2, 7-6. Oresar, seeded 12th, was defeated by Broderick Dyke of Australia, 6-4, 2-6, 6-4. Brown, seeded 16th, lost to Martin Barba of LaCosta, California, an unranked qualifier, 4-6, 6-3, 6-4.(AP) FENCING American Reaches Final Round: The United States placed its first finalist ever in women's epee in world competition yesterday as Donna Stone of Belleville, N.J., defeated Saba Amendolana of Italy in the qualifying round of the world championships in Denver. Stone, 32 years old, edged Amendolana, 8-7, to win a spot in the eight-member final competition. This the first world championship to feature women's competition in epee, which is 10 ounces heavier than a foil (17 ounces).(AP) MACCABIAH GAMES Aronberg Triumphs: Rick Aronberg of Fairport, N.Y., won the 1,500-meter freestyle yesterday for his fifth gold medal in the Maccabiah Games at Kibbutz Gezer, Israel. Aronberg, a senior at Clemson University, finished the 1,500-meter event in 15 minutes 37.66 seconds, a record for the Maccabiah Games.(AP)

title: International Paper Net Rises
description: The International Paper Company said today that its second-quarter earnings rose 22 percent from a year ago, because of strong sales and acquisitions. For the three months ended

title: Fresh Produce Bringing Fresh Choices
description: THIS time of year at the Union Square Greenmarket is the most exciting for me because of the arrival of Jersey tomatoes and corn picked the day it is sold. Jersey tomatoes are the only commercially produced tomatoes worth eating, and corn any older isn't worth the calories.

title: Dow Jones & Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an after-tax gain of $164,149,000, or $1.63 a share, from the January sale of the company's holdings in Continental Cablevision Inc. c-Included an after-tax gain of $64,491,000, or 67 cents a shre, from the sale of a book publishing subsidiary. Excluding one-time gains, net income for the first half of 1989 decreased 5 percent to $84,208,000, or 84 cents a share, from $88,632,000, or 92 cents a share, in the year-ago 6 months.

title: Hope Remains in Quebec Language Battle
description: To the Editor:

title: Mr. Bush and the Other 10 Percent
description: As he set off on his current trip to Eastern Europe, President Bush recalled Woody Allen's line that 90 percent of life is just showing up. The point was movingly made yesterday by the crowds waiting in the rain to greet him in Hungary, and by Mr. Bush's appearance on a Gdansk stage before the workers of Solidarity in Poland. Whatever the content of his words, just the presence of an American President in the heart of Eastern Europe radiates democratic change.

title: Notes Priced By Sallie Mae
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $450 million of short-term floating-rate notes with a final maturity of Jan. 11, 1990.

title: Banponce Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Cetus Drug Gains
description: The Cetus Corporation said it had received approval to market its new drug, interleukin-2, in Denmark as a treatment for kidney cancer. Denmark is the first European nation to grant approval following a recent favorable recommendation of the European Community's central drug regulatory body. Cetus, a biotechnology company based in Emeryville, Calif., said its version of interleukin-2, which it calls Proleukin, will be sold in Denmark by Farmos Group Ltd., a Finnish pharmaceutical company.

title: Koch Sells Stock Linked to South Africa
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch yesterday sold stock he owned in seven companies that either have or may soon be subject to divestment by city pension funds because the companies do business with South Africa.

title: Tranzonic Cos. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $701,500 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change for the latest quarter; the year-ago quarter included a gain of $606,000, or 17 cents a share, as a result of a credit to income taxes because of a change in an accounting estimates.

title: A Place for Poetry In Land of Pictures
description: LEAD: It's poetry, Hollywood style, every Tuesday night at Cafe Largo as the likes of Judd Nelson, Justine Bateman, Robert Downey Jr. and Patti D'Arbanville recite poetry - their own and others' - to S.R.O. crowds.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times yesterday about possible health hazards of electromagnetic fields misstated the amount the Electric Power Research Institute, an industry group, is spending this year for research on the issue. It is $5.5 million, not $5.5 billion.

title: Jordan Pays Ticket
description: Michael Jordan has paid an overdue speeding ticket in Kentucky, and a warrant for the arrest of the Chicago Bulls' star has been withdrawn. Jordan's agent, Barbara Allen of Arlington, Va., paid the $102.50 fine by mail, a Fayette District Court clerk in Lexington said Monday. On June 6, a Lexington police officer clocked Jordan traveling 90 miles an hour, on Interstate 75 near Lexington. Jordan was also cited for not having a driver's license. Fayette District Judge John Adams issued a warrant for Jordan last week after he failed to show up in traffic court. Jordan still has to produce a copy of his driver's license within 10 days.(AP)

title: Cellular Products reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
What Makes National Service Bill Misguided; Exemption for the Rich
description: To the Editor:

title: Ruling Says Acts of Coal Company Caused Strike
description: A regional office of the National Labor Relations Board said today that the Pittston Company was guilty of unfair labor practices that led the United Mine Workers of America to go on strike against the company three months ago.

title: Digital Equipment Offers New Models
description: As expected, the Digital Equipment Corporation introduced a variety of computers today, including a scientific work station, the Decstation 3100, with prices starting at $7,950, and a more powerful model of its VAX minicomputer line, the VAX 6000 Model 400. The company said the new minicomputer offered an 85 percent performance increase over its existing 6300 line. Digital also introduced an entry-level Microvax 3100 with a starting price of $6,680, 40 percent lower than its predecessor.

title: Review/Film; The French Revolution Is Portrayed as a Carnival
description: In ''1789,'' the French Revolution is conceived as an extravagant performance piece, a spectacle that is part Brecht, part commedia dell'arte, part puppet show and largely carnival. The revolution that included more street drama than any other is shrewdly reconceived in the terms most accessible and sympathetic to ordinary citizens.

title: Five Charged By the S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged a former broker at Merrill Lynch, his mother and three other individuals with violating Federal securities laws by trading on information from advance copies of Business Week magazine over a two-year period.

title: Calton Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income

title: U.S. OFFICIALS URGE LABOR TO REMAIN IN ISRAELI CABINET
description: The Bush Administration has told Israeli political leaders that it hopes the Labor Party will not leave the coalition Government in Jerusalem, American officials said today.

title: For Takeover Advisers, Battle Lines Are Forming Again
description: The battle lines formed yesterday as B.A.T. Industries gathered advisers to help in fighting off the takeover bid by a group including Sir James Goldsmith and Jacob Rothschild and as the raiders disclosed members of their team.

title: INSIDE
description: American League Wins The American League's first two batters, Bo Jackson and Wade Boggs, hit home runs in a 5-3 All-Star Game victory. Page A17. Mexican Vote Tensions In an action criticized as ''selective democracy,'' Mexico's Government has conceded an opposition victory in one state but not in another. Page A5. Costly Trouble at H.U.D. Fraud and mismanagement in Federal housing programs have cost the Government $2 billion, Secretary Jack F. Kemp said. Page B5. Protest Leader Arrested The organizer of mass anti-abortion protests last summer has been arrested on charges stemming from those demonstrations. Page A10.

title: For Late-Night Crowd, Half-Hour More to Party
description: The late-night crowd won an extra half-hour of revelry today from New York State's highest court, which ruled that New York City cannot force discotheques to close at the unfashionably early hour of 4 A.M.

title: BUSH URGES POLES TO PULL TOGETHER
description: In a vigorous appeal to thousands of workers at a shipyard in Gdansk, Poland, President Bush today urged the Solidarity movement to shed ''the legacy of distrust and shattered dreams'' and to pull together with the Communist Party to create a brighter Poland.

title: KEY RATES
An Australian Who Plays for Big Stakes
description: Kerry F. B. Packer, a member of the group that bid for B.A.T. Industries yesterday, is a 52-year-old Australian media owner whose competitiveness and wealth are often compared to those of an archrival, Rupert Murdoch.

title: Feasts on This Side of the Atlantic
description: TO celebrate the French bicentennial, chefs and restaurateurs in the New York region have turned to history books for inspiration. Menus re-create 18th-century dinners with dishes that were favorites of royalty and revolutionaries.

title: Bronx School Board Member Pleads Guilty to Theft Count
description: A member of a Bronx school board that has been the subject of a wide-ranging criminal investigation has pleaded guilty to using school materials to produce literature for her re-election campaign, Robert T. Johnson, the Bronx District Attorney, said yesterday.

title: What Makes National Service Bill Misguided
description: To the Editor:

title: How British Rules Will Affect B.A.T.
description: THE war for B.A.T. Industries, the old British-American Tobacco, is expected to be fought under British takeover rules. And that could make all the difference in determining who wins.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Cadbury Shifts Account To Foote, Cone & Belding
description: Citing a disagreement in advertising strategy, Cadbury Schweppes yesterday switched its account for Canada Dry and Sunkist to Foote, Cone & Belding from Wells, Rich, Greene. The account is worth $20 million to $25 million.

title: Bridge
description: The success of a recent match between Congress and corporate America, with Epson America as sponsor, suggests another possibility. Since three Senators and six Representatives took part, an annual match between the two houses seems to be an event waiting for an organizer and a sponsor.

title: Star Banc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-earlier six-month results included an accounting change gain of $3,066,000.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Organizer of Abortion Protests Is Jailed in Atlanta
description: The organizer of demonstrations that sought to disrupt abortion clinics last summer is in an Atlanta jail on charges stemming from those protests.

title: Review/Television; Allen Funt Calls 'Totally Hidden Video'
description: ''It can't be described,'' the advertisements for ''Totally Hidden Video'' say, speaking about a new Fox Broadcasting series that can easily be described as ''Candid Camera Rip-Off.''

title: New York State Medical Unit Begins a Hospital Offering
description: The New York State Medical Care Facilities Finance Agency is offering $150 million of secured hospital revenue bonds through underwriters led by the Chemical Securities Corporation.

title: Taiwan Gold Imports Off
description: Taiwan, the world's largest gold importer, bought less of the metal in the first six months of the year than it did in the corresponding period in 1988, bullion dealers said today. Imports of gold bars and coins totaled 94.8 tons, worth $1.14 billion, between January and June, compared with 249.5 tons valued at $3.69 billion in the period last year, according to the Finance Ministry. Bullion dealers attributed the decline mainly to the central bank's decision to halt gold imports beginning in July 1988.

title: What All Those Words Really Mean
description: THESE are some terms commonly used on food packages and nutrition labels:

title: First Georgia Holding Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GROWING TENSIONS OVER MEXICAN VOTE
description: In a move that is being widely criticized here as ''selective democracy,'' the Mexican Government has overridden the left-wing opposition's claims to victory in one state while acknowledging the election triumph of a right-wing opposition party in another.

title: No Headline
description: Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp estimated today that fraud and mismanagement in Federal housing programs had cost the Government $2 billion and said he had warned agency employees that their jobs depended on their cooperation in an overhaul.

title: Execufirst Bancorp Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: This is the company's initial year of operation. The company said that second quarter and 6 months losses were principally attributable to its requirement to create loan loss reserves to match its strong loan growth. In the second quarter, these provisions totalled $122,422, and in the 6-month period, they totalled $203,747.

title: Corrections
description: The table of New York Stock Exchange indexes in the Market Indicators section of Business Day yesterday carried incorrect numbers throughout for changes in Monday activity. The numbers represented the changes in the Standard & Poor's stock indexes. A corrected table for the N.Y.S.E. Indexes at the end of Monday appears today on page D8.

title: Excerpts From Remarks by Walesa and Bush at the Solidarity Monument
description: Following are excerpts from Lech Walesa's remarks introducing President Bush at the Solidarity workers monument today, and from Mr. Bush's address there. Mr. Walesa's remarks were translated by an interpreter for Mr. Bush. WALESA'S REMARKS

title: Orion Pictures Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Polish Delicacies for Bush
description: When President Bush and his wife, Barbara, dropped in on the Solidarity leader, Lech Walesa, and his wife, Danuta, for lunch today, they found a copious spread of Polish delicacies despite the austerity that grips much of this country this summer.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Market Place column in Business Day yesterday misstated the value of the corporate bond portfolio of the First Executive Corporation. The value is now $13.9 billion - down $564 million, or about 4 percent, from its original cost.

title: The Pop Life
description: Songs of Confession

title: Review/Film; When Rock Was Young And Monterey a Festival
description: Not long ago, the 1967 Monterey Pop Festival, which helped usher in the modern rock era, began to lose its contemporary aura and to seem increasingly quaint and far away. That impression is heightened by ''Jimi Plays Monterey'' and ''Shake,'' two films by Donn Pennebaker and his associates that open today at Film Forum 1. The movies compile unreleased film of Jimi Hendrix and Otis Redding that had been shot for the rock documentary ''Monterey Pop.''

title: Fixing Suspected In High Schools
description: The F.B.I. said today that more than $500,000 in cash was confiscated in raids on a suspected gambling operation that, the Florence police said, may have involved game-fixing at the high school level.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bank of America, San Francisco, named Thomas M. Quigg, a senior vice president, to be the head of its international private banking operation.

title: Education; A School Salvaging Dropouts Faces Peril
description: Supporters of an alternative school that has pulled dropouts off the street and back into the classroom for 17 years now find themselves preparing to fight for its survival.

title: WINE TALK
description: WHAT goes into a first-rate restaurant wine list? An enormous selection? Not necessarily. Famous names? Rare vintages? Maybe, maybe not. A sommelier to explain it all? Hardly.

title: Saudi Arabia Accused by Iran Of Planting Bombs in Mecca
description: Iran accused Saudi Arabia today of planting the bombs that killed one person and wounded 16 near Islam's holiest shrine during the annual pilgrimage to Mecca.

title: Prices Are Mixed in Quiet Trading
description: The prices of Treasury notes and bonds were mixed in light trading yesterday, as participants in the United States took profits after a run-up on foreign markets.

title: Betting on a Different Videotex Idea
description: Prodigy Services Inc., the joint venture into videotex by the International Business Machines Corporation and Sears, Roebuck & Company, last week announced a new information distribution agreement that highlighted the technological reasons the company believes it can succeed in a business that has been most famous for its failures.

title: A Polish Journey; Bush Escapes Pitfalls in Weathering Tough Economic and Political Climate
description: Like most such journeys, George Bush's two-day visit to Poland, the first by an American President in 12 years, had both a public and private agenda. What was said at airports and in stately halls and in formal toasts was meant to facilitate the private talk.

title: Corrected Data
description: The table of New York Stock Exchange indexes in the Market Indicators section of Business Day yesterday carried incorrect numbers throughout for changes in Monday activity. A corrected table follows. High. Low Last. Change Index 182.70 181.78 182.70+ 1.14 Industrial 218.30 217.29 218.30+ 1.26 Transport 176.95 176.51 176.51+ 0.65 Utility 89.87 89.27 89.87+ 0.67 Finance 156.31 155.39 156.31+ 1.15

title: Economic Scene; Nicaragua In Extremis
description: POUNDED by the contra war, the American trade embargo and inept central planning, the Nicaraguan economy is unraveling. Last year output per person fell to half the pre-revolution level, while prices rose by 33,000 percent. Western advisers to the Government, financed by the Swedish International Development Authority and led by Lance Taylor of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, forecast a continuing decline in production in 1989.

title: Sight-Reading Bach Is Almost Aerobic
description: The thing you have to remember when you sing the B-minor Mass is to count. It's not like ''Messiah'' or ''The Creation,'' in which almost everything is straightforward and you can get your entrances by feel. Bach has you coming in every which way, and when everything is whizzing by, and likely as not you're changing keys, and the accompaniment is no help, you get one beat off and hoo boy!

title: Mark IV Industries reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $900,000 and $400,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively. Latest-quarter results and year-ago quarter results included after-tax gains of $700,000 and $5,400,000, respectively, from securities transactions. The company said certain planed divestitures have been accounted for as discontinued operations and year- ago results have been restated to reflect this treatment.

title: After Months of Turmoil, Congress Returns for Grunt Work on the Budget
description: Congress returned to Washington today after a long holiday recess and settled down for a month of grunt work, with House leaders particularly eager to project the image of a hard-working legislature grinding away on the nation's business.

title: Merrill Lynch Is Committed to New York as Global Headquarters
description: To the Editor:

title: Marriott to Sell Air Catering Unit
description: The Marriott Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell its airline catering division, Marriott In-Flite Services, to a group of private investors.

title: Bradley Is Optimistic After Battling Illness
description: Within months of completing one of the finest seasons in women's golf history in 1986, Pat Bradley was in the throes of depression and embarrassment. She didn't have any answers about why she was tired and unable to come close to winning a tournament.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Offer for B.A.T.

title: Fignon Gets Lead In Tour
description: Laurent Fignon of France, a two-time winner of the Tour de France, moved into the overall lead today, taking the yellow jersey from Greg LeMond of the United States.

title: Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 17
60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: LOBSTER is so delicate and expensive that I handle it as little as possible in cooking. Fresh lobster, simply steamed or broiled, is sublime with melted butter or a light herb sauce.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Citizens and Southern Corp., Atlanta, a bank holding company, said it had created a $125 million employee stock ownership plan.

title: Sacramento, Calif.
description: MRS. T's natural gourmet pizza may be the world's best pizza, at least nutritionally speaking.

title: Education; For Teaching New British Grammar, Forget the Rain in Spain
description: Stoking the fires of a long-running national debate, Prince Charles has called the teaching of contemporary grammar a ''fundamental problem'' in British education.

title: What Do You Do Apres la Revolution? Go Out to Eat
description: The ideals of the French Revolution may have been liberty, equality and fraternity, but most French citizens in 1789 were probably more preoccupied with eating. In fact one of the revolution's lasting legacies was the rise of the French restaurant.

title: Town Thanks Beavers For Water in Drought
description: Once upon a time in a county in northwest Missouri, right next door to Iowa, a stream named the Grand River flowed freely, most of the time, past the town of Grant City.

title: Draft of Anti-Pollution Bill Falls Short, Critics Say
description: The Bush Administration's draft legislation to amend the Clean Air Act drew criticism today from some Congressmen, environmentalists and state officials who contended that it falls short in several important areas, including limiting emissions from automobile tailpipes.

title: A Mixed-Use Project for Times Square
description: MOST of the new commercial projects taking shape in Times Square are either office buildings or hotels. But there is an exception in a mixed-use development rising on 45th Street and Broadway.

title: EA Engineering, Science & Technology Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
What Makes National Service Bill Misguided; Impulsive Adventures
description: To the Editor:

title: Fay Is New Director
description: David B. Fay, a former administrator at the Metropolitan Golf Association, was named yesterday as executive director of the United States Golf Association. He succeeds Frank Hannigan, who resigned last January to pursue work in television and magazine writing. The 38-year-old Fay, a native of New York City and a Colgate University graduate, is the fifth person named to the highest-paid position with the U.S.G.A., the organization that establishes and administers the rules of golf in this country and conducts 13 annual national golf championships for men and women. Fay served in various positions on the U.S.G.A. staff for the past 10 years.

title: TV as Big as a Billboard
description: A New York-based company has developed a portable projection device that produces high-resolution television pictures bright enough to be displayed on walls or billboards.

title: Israel's Ties That Bind; Despite Talk of a Split, Political Exigency Is a Powerful Force for Likud-Labor Unity
description: Though Likud and Labor party leaders stepped forward today to assert their determination not to compromise, even if it means the Israeli Government will fall, it seems clear that it is in the interest of both parties for the coalition Government to continue, at least for now.

title: Nuggets Purchase Sparked by Economics as Much as History
description: After Bertram M. Lee and Peter Bynoe sealed their $65 million purchase of the Denver Nuggets on Monday, they called a news conference in Denver to announce the deal to the local news media.

title: Gtech Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to May 27
description: b-Included a $974,000 gain from an accounting change.

title: EATING WELL
description: ''I'VE been had,'' my son said sheepishly last week as he held up a container of a new ''lite'' orange juice. What had caught his eye was the top of the carton, which proclaimed, ''Premium orange juice taste and nutrition with one-third fewer calories.''

title: Oce-van der Grinten N.V.  reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Revenue figures for the latest quarter gave effect to aggregate exchange rate effect (plus 5 percent); revenue figures for the 6 months took disposals (minus 2 percent), and exchange rate effects (plus 4 percent) into account. The company said it is Dutch practice to state prior-year per-share figures on the basis of the number of shares outstanding at the fiscal year- end. The actual number of shares outstanding at May 31, 1988, was 2,921,379. Converted from Dutch florins at Dfl 2.2265: US $1.00. Five ADRs equal one ordinary share. The agreement to acquire the graphics division of Schlumberger Ltd. announced May 25 was finalized July 3. As of July 1, 1989, Oce Graphics' results will be included in the consolidated figures of the Oce group.

title: Yields Fall Sharply in Week For C.D.'s and Money Funds
description: Yields offered for certificates of deposit and money market accounts were down for the week ended yesterday, by a somewhat steeper amount than the previous week's fall.

title: Olivier Is Dead After 6-Decade Acting Career
description: Laurence Olivier, hailed as one of the greatest classical stage actors of his time, died yesterday at his home near London. He was 82 years old.

title: Cara Operations Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 25
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Dokes's Last Stand
description: Michael Dokes, who held the World Boxing Association heavyweight title in 1982 and 1983 and is ranked the No. 4 contender for Mike Tyson's unified title by the World Boxing Council, announced yesterday that he would ''give it my all for 12 more months and then retire from boxing.'' Appearing at a news conference in connection with his fight tomorrow night in Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum against Danny (Smiley) Sutton, Dokes said he would like ''one more shot at the title and then - win, lose or draw - quit boxing.''

title: J. Bruno Benziger, 64, Vintner in California
description: J. Bruno Benziger, co-founder of the Glen Ellen Winery in California, died of heart failure on Monday at his farmhouse in Glen Ellen, the Sonoma County town for which the winery is named. He was 64 years old.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: The Philadelphia Daily News and the Linpro Company's Christina Gateway office development in Wilmington, Del., to Earle Palmer Brown & Spiro, Philadelphia, with budgets of approximately $1 million each.

title: On Burning Flags And Freezing Assets
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly AD HOC COMMITTEE ON INDIAN OCEAN - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. TRADE LAW COMMISSION WORKING GROUP ON INTERNATIONAL PAYMENTS - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: FNW Bancorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: All second-quarter 1989 figures reflected the increases associated by the company's year-end 1988 purchase of the Heritage Group, Inc., which increased the company's 1989 assets by $100.60 million.

title: Charter Meeting
description: The New York City Charter Revision Commission has added a meeting for tomorrow from 9 A.M. to noon at the City Bar Association in New York, at 42 West 44th Street.

title: Saint Laurent Trading Halted
description: Stock trading in Yves Saint Laurent, the French fashion house, was called off today because of heavy demand.

title: Chinese Crackdown Proceeds Quietly in Shanghai
description: China's campaign to repress dissent is quietly spreading in the country's largest city, with the unannounced arrest of several liberal journalists and intellectuals and the reintroduction of mandatory political study sessions in virtually all offices and factories.

title: Shell and Exxon Plan
description: The British subsidiaries of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group and the Exxon Corporation said today that they had approved a $1.14 billion program to develop the North Sea Gannet oil and gas field by 1992. They added that the project would involve a platform linked to three undersea field developments. The Gannet field, lying about 300 feet under water, is estimated to hold 170 million barrels of recoverable oil and 700 billion cubic feet of natural gas.

title: Obituary; Joseph Kershaw, 76; Economist Taught At Williams College
description: Joseph A. Kershaw, an economist who was the first provost of Williams College, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Williamstown, Mass. He was 76 years old.

title: Romans Also Had a Thing About Thing
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 840689 -- No Title
description: Undertaking by far the largest corporate takeover bid in European history, an investor group led by Sir James Goldsmith, the British-French financier, made a $21 billion offer today for B.A.T. Industries. B.A.T., a London-based conglomerate with extensive operations in the United States, owns Saks Fifth Avenue and the Hardee's fast food chain and sells Kool and Lucky Strike cigarettes. It is Britain's third-largest company behind British Petroleum and Shell.

title: Book Notes
description: About Pete Rose

title: MAN IN THE NEWS: Sir James Goldsmith; A Gambler With Good Timing
description: Sir James Michael Goldsmith, who offered $21 billion today for B.A.T. Industries, is a swashbuckling, 6-feet 3-inch gambler who knows when to play a hand and when to fold.

title: Texas Instruments Offers 9% Notes
description: Texas Instruments Inc. is offering $150 million of notes through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Decision On Time by Friday Seen
description: After a one-day hearing today, a Delaware court said it hoped to rule by Friday on Paramount Communications Inc.'s attempt to block Time Inc.'s takeover of Warner Communications Inc.

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
New Paltz, N.Y.
description: LEAD: AS a baker, Tom Ambrosina has a limited repertory: he makes only chocolate and vanilla cake layers.

title: Bangkok Journal; Thai Cliffhanger: Case of the Puritanical Buddhist
description: A former television personality who founded an austere and unorthodox Buddhist sect is at the center of a criminal investigation for refusing an ecclesiastical command to renounce his calling as a monk.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Broadcast TV Promotes Itself
description: Stung by the enormous growth of cable television, broadcast television outlets are striking back with the equivalent of a $100 million campaign to promote their medium. The campaign, called ''Turn on the Power,'' was introduced yesterday by the Television Bureau of Advertising, which initiated the project and has recruited Campbell-Mithun-Esty to create advertising for it.

title: Fighter Spars With His Mother
description: LEAD: Egerton Marcus bears a startling facial resemblance to Jersey Joe Walcott - a square, scarred face with small, narrow eyes under a scowling forehead - but he inherited his boxing skills from his mother.

title: 2 Air Force Security Policemen Charged in Theft of F-16 Engines
description: Two Air Force security policemen were arrested on charges of stealing three F-16 jet fighter engines after an undercover investigation identified dozens of people suspected in the theft of military goods, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

title: Education; School as a Model for Race Relations
description: A middle school will open here this fall that educators hope will be a model for race relations and improved academics.

title: Panel Faults Racial Pattern Of Court Staffs
description: New York State courts are staffed so overwhelmingly by whites that minorities have lost confidence in the justice system, a state commission has found.

title: Stocks Rise Broadly; Dow Is Up by 11.95
description: Stock prices moved ahead broadly yesterday as optimism reappeared over the likelihood of lower interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 11.95, to 2,514.61, its sixth straight gain.

title: Sowell, a Late Starter, Becomes Fast Finisher
description: The world's fastest female sprinter is 23-year-old Dawn Sowell of Chester, Pa., a vivacious senior at Louisiana State University. But her spectacular success in track and field was not exactly love at first sight.

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
Oak Park, Ill.
description: LEAD: WHEN Memere's serves rattlesnake, the head and tail are lopped off before it reaches the table. The dish, served in a spicy sauce, is just one of the unusual entrees at Memere's, a Louisiana-style restaurant in Oak Park.

title: Syrian Says New Israeli Stance Undercuts Arafat
description: As Middle East peace efforts falter, Syrian officials and their hard-line Palestinian allies seem to be sensing victory over those Palestinians and other Arabs who they say sued for peace with Israel but gained no concessions in return.

title: DMI Furniture Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 3
Talks on Bailout Hit a Snag
description: House and Senate conferees failed today in their first attempt to agree on which special-interest amendments should be eliminated from the House and Senate passed versions of the Bush Administration's bailout bill for the savings and loan industry.

title: Books of The Times; Baseball's First Jewish Star Tells His Own Story
description: Hank Greenberg The Story of My Life Edited and with an introduction by Ira Berkow Illustrated. 311 pages. Times Books. $19.95.

title: National City Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Yalta Fades Slowly
description: The big phrases are pouring in torrents from East and West now, a lot of it smarm, which isn't new. My metaphor tolerance for the ''common European house'' and its rooms, doors, attic, wallpaper is about to snap.

title: Corrections
description: The over-the-counter stock listings in Business Day yesterday carried an incorrect price provided by The Associated Press for Carrington Laboratories Inc. It closed Monday at $30 a share, down $1.75, or 5.5 percent, from Friday. It was not the leading over-the-counter gainer on Monday.

title: For Innovative Ideas, French Embassy Chef Looks to the 1700's
description: For Francis Layrle, chef to the French Ambassador in Washington, the 200th anniversary of the French Revolution is focusing attention on something he has drawn inspiration from all along: French cooking of the 18th century.

title: Robinson Does Turnabout on Resignation
description: The Baltimore Orioles, surprising leaders of the American League East, defused a potentially destructive situation yesterday when Frank Robinson withdrew his threat to quit as their manager.

title: Review/Jazz; Re-creating Ellington Debut At Carnegie Hall in 1943
description: The Carnegie Hall debut of Duke Ellington and His Orchestra on Jan. 23, 1943, was panned at the time as overreaching the limits of jazz. Re-created on Monday night to open this week's three-concert Landmark Jazz series, reconstructed and directed by Maurice Peress, its only failing was that it didn't reach jazz's heights consistently.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Ila Clarkson has been named head of new business and public relations at Wells, Rich, Greene.

title: B.A.T. Bid Lifts Stocks in U.S.
description: The stocks of American tobacco companies made strong gains in heavy trading yesterday, in response to the $21 billion takeover bid for B.A.T. Industries, a leading British cigarette manufacturer.

title: Campaign Law Fails to Rein In 'Bundled' Gifts
description: Despite a new campaign finance law in New York City intended to hold down spending and limit contributions, the mayoral candidates this year are hiring platoons of high-paid political consultants and receiving large combined donations.

title: Middle East Peace: Not Dead Yet
description: LEAD: The Middle East peace process is reeling from a series of blows dealt by Ariel Sharon on Israel's right, Shimon Peres on Israel's left, Yasir Arafat in Tunis and Palestinian acts of violence on the ground. This unholy coalition of ambition and attrition is about to destroy the only hopeful opportunity for an Arab-Israeli negotiation in eight years.

title: Hospital Union Holds One-Day Strike
description: More than 20,000 striking hospital employees marched on the offices of the bargaining unit for the city's private hospitals yesterday to demand a new contract with higher wages and benefits.

title: Marie M. Seedor, 71, Ex-Professor of Nursing
description: Marie M. Seedor, a former associate professor of nursing education at Teachers College of Columbia University, died of ovarian cancer on July 4 at her home in Melbourne, Fla. She was 71 years old.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Chief Named at Farah As a Retirement Is Set
description: LEAD: Richard C. Allender has been named the president and chief executive of Farah Inc., replacing William F. Farah, who said on Monday that he would retire from the positions.

title: A Far-Flung Corporate Empire
description: B.A.T. Industries, the target of Sir James Goldsmith's $21 billion takeover bid, is one of the most far-flung international corporations, selling insurance in Australia and the United States, producing paper pulp in India and Portugal, and processing tobacco in Zimbabwe and Zaire. Its shares, which are traded in New York as well as London, are widely held by individuals and institutions that specialize in assembling global portfolios.

title: Gateway Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings are adjusted for 10 percent stock dividend in May.

title: I Can't Hear, But I Can Listen
description: LEAD: In 1970, I contracted meningitis, which left me completely deaf.

title: Symbols of Faith, Symbols of Power
description: The case of the creche and the menorah raised again the question of Thomas Jefferson's ''wall of separation'' between private religious faith and public power.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, an article in Science Times yesterday about the pyramids was partly obliterated in some copies by a drawing.

title: RJR to Move Unit
description: RJR Nabisco Inc. said it would move the executive headquarters of R. J. Reynolds Tobacco International Inc. from London to Winston-Salem, N.C. by Oct. 1. RJR, based in Atlanta, said that the move was part of a reorganization of the company's worldwide tobacco operations. About 12 senior executives will move to Winston-Salem, where the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company already has a corporate staff of 135. R. J. Reynolds has also reorganized its worldwide business into three regional operating units.

title: Chicago Milwaukee Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included tax credits of $1,910,000 for the quarter and $10,868,000 for the 6 months. c-Included tax credits of $2,813,000 and $10,868,000 for the quarter and 6 months. The company said the second quarter's decrease in net income was largely because of a 13 percent in investment income due to lower cash balances as a result of the $92 million of cash disbursed for payment of the $20 a share special dividend to common shareholders in December 1988 and the purchase of 309,270 common shares from the March tender offer. Share earnings are computed after giving effect to a $2.50 a share preferred stock dividend in 1989 and two $2.50 a share preferred stock dividend in 1988. The company said the latest 6 months included $22.7 million derived from the sale of the Milwaukee Land Co. Timberland in January.

title: Schulze Back to Minors
description: After one fine effort and another poor one, Don Schulze was returned by the Yankees to their Columbus farm club. The 26-year-old right-hander pitched seven shutout innings against the Tigers on July 4, then was knocked out in the fourth inning by the Red Sox in Boston. The Yankees activated Chuck Cary, another pitcher, from the 21-day disabled list.

title: Unusually Fierce Winds Razed 100 Homes
description: The barrage of severe thunderstorms that crashed across the New York metropolitan region on Monday, spawning tornadoes in a display of violent weather rarely seen in the Northeast, destroyed more than 100 homes and scores of businesses in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey.

title: Colorado Issue To Yield 5.70%
description: The State of Colorado yesterday tapped the short-term municipal note market with a $145 million issue of tax and revenue anticipation notes, which the BT Securities Corporation won in competitive bidding.

title: For Ryan, a Special Victory in Anaheim
description: To 42-year-old Nolan Ryan, the winning pitcher in tonight's 5-3 American League triumph, this was the ''most meaningful'' of his seven All-Star games.

title: Reagan 'Uptight' In Booth
description: Moments after Bo Jackson and Wade Boggs opened the first inning for the American League with back-to-back homers over the center-field fence, former President Ronald Reagan sounded relaxed for the first time in his one-inning appearance as a baseball analyst for the NBC network at last night's All-Star Game.

title: Enrollment Problems Increasing, Soviet Communist Party Admits
description: The Soviet Communist Party is troubled by dwindling recruitment and a steep decline in prestige, according to an unusually candid collection of articles and letters published today in Moscow's main party newspaper.

title: The Kirov's 'Beauty' Is Youth
description: One of the most unusual aspects of the Kirov Ballet's current season at the Metropolitan Opera House lies in the wealth of young talent that the Soviet company has brought to New York.

title: Central Pacific Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Chairman of Rights Agency Is Chosen for U.S. Judgeship
description: The White House announced today that President Bush plans to nominate Clarence Thomas, the chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, to a Federal judgeship.

title: Third Man Arrested in Rape On a Roof in Crown Heights
description: A Brooklyn youth was held yesterday on charges that he raped a woman who was thrown from a roof and down an airshaft, the police said.

title: Kinark Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Imperial Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
House Panel Starts Work on 'Bare-Bones' Tax Bill
description: The House Ways and Means Committee began deliberations on a tax bill today, working from a ''bare-bones'' proposal by its chairman, Representative Dan Rostenkowski. The plan would raise only the $5.3 billion needed to meet this year's budget target.

title: About New York; Couple Returns To Hall of Magic And Marriages
description: New York City depends on its legends. Big legends for the big town. Roseland Ballroom, self-styled ''home of refined dancing,'' is one. When Roseland opened in 1919, just around the corner from its current home at 239 West 52d Street, word was out that Florenz Ziegfeld and Will Rogers would be on hand - not to mention two live bands and the snazziest hostesses in town. Mounted police were needed to control the crowd.

title: Grand Old Job Machine Is G.O.P.'s Safety Net
description: If you are not an elected official, making a career in politics can be like a game of Chutes and Ladders. The opportunities for instant upward mobility are enormous. So are the chances of ending up on the street.

title: Bentsen Sees Dim Hope of Cutting Health Surtax Paid by the Elderly
description: The chairman of the Senate Finance Committee said today that hopes were fading for reducing the surtax that older Americans pay to insure against the cost of prolonged illness.

title: Mandarich's Preference
description: With the Green Bay Packers apparently unwilling to consider his demand for a six-year contract worth more than $11 million, Tony Mandarich said yesterday he would like to play for the Dallas Cowboys. Mandarich, a 6-foot-6-inch, 308-pound offensive tackle from Michigan State, was the No. 2 selection over all in the National Football League draft. ''I'd sit at Green Bay, but I'd rather go to Dallas and crush people,'' said Mandarich. ''They'd like my style there.'' (AP)

title: Review/Dance; Artful Poses in an Homage to the Murdered Inez
description: This year, two major dance centers - the American Dance Festival and the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival -have collaborated on ''Made in France,'' a project by means of which French dancers and choreographers are being presented in the United States in celebration of the bicentennial of the French Revolution.

title: Economic Bananas
description: Have countries threatened with retaliatory tariffs under the new trade law entered into negotiations with the United States? S. Linn Williams, deputy U.S. Trade Representative, says: ''There are discussions. We can call them negotiations. They can call them a banana as long as it produces results.''

title: 15.2% Fuqua Stake For Triton Group
description: Triton Group Ltd., a diversified holding company, has raised its stake in Fuqua Industries to 15.2 percent, from 14 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Triton said there was no change in its previously announced intention to seek control of Fuqua, a garden and consumer products company based in Atlanta.

title: A Banker Who Relishes Deals
description: Jacob Rothschild's willingness to join Sir James Goldsmith in a hostile $21 billion bid for B.A.T. Industries could not have surprised many observers in the City of London.

title: Finicky About Free Music
description: A New Yorker who returned to live in the city after years of absence is delighted to discover how much freelance music now brightens the streets and leavens the din in subway stations. He was pleased to hear a young flutist playing Vivaldi in front of the library, an intense saxophonist playing a recognizable Coleman Hawkins solo in a bus terminal and a combo of Ecuadorean reed players piping Andes mountain music on lower Broadway.

title: Question of Scientific Fakery Is Raised in Inquiry
description: Science magazine, one of the nation's most respected scientific journals and a longtime proponent of the view that scientific fakery is extremely rare, said yesterday that it had been struck by its own serious case of deceit.

title: Jackson Hits Homer and Steals All-Star Show
description: In his life and times as a big league baseball player, Bo Jackson has done the kinds of things expected of legends. He has made the spectacular diving catch, hit the electric home run, thrown out the runner sliding across the plate. He has done them often enough to be admired for his wondrous talent. But they are still merely glimpses.

title: Airlease Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said although total revenue in the latest 6 months increased over the year-ago 6 months, the year-ago 6 months included a $332,000 gain on a sale which was not repeated in the latest 6-month period.

title: Coney Island Photos
description: An exhibition of recent photographs by Ira McCrudden, ''Coney Island: A Summer Vacation for a Subway Token,'' is on view at the South Street Seaport Museum, 207 Water Street. The show runs through Sept. 4. Hours are 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. daily; admission is free. Information: 669-9430.

title: International Paper Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. Offers New Plan On Trade
description: The United States is advocating a new strategy to liberalize global trade in food products, a goal it has long sought.

title: United Airlines Strike Threat
description: Flight attendants at United Airlines have overwhelmingly voted to authorize a strike, the Association of Flight Attendants said Tuesday. But the negotiations between the union and United are under the supervision of a Federal mediator, who would have to declare an impasse and call for a 30-day cooling-off period before a strike could be called. The negotiations, which have been going on for nearly two years, are in recess.

title: Still Rising: the H.U.D. Bill, and Smell
description: Secretary Jack Kemp now estimates that losses from the Reagan Administration's trashing of the Department of Housing and Urban Development could reach $2 billion. Others have said it could be as much as $6 billion.

title: Bonds From New York City
description: New York City yesterday tentatively priced $750 million in general obligation bonds through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Burlington Resources Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included net from discontinued operations of $9,527,000 and $20,981,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and a gain on a sale of Plum Creek Timber Co. of $265,611,000 for both periods. c-Net loss and included net from discontinued operations of $13,446,000 and $24,157,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Year-ago quarter results also included a $143 million after-tax charge which related to the company's estimate of its natural gas take-or-pay contract exposure.

title: Qualms on Proposal for Status of Puerto Rico
description: A top Justice Department official has testified that a Senate proposal to enhance Puerto Rico's commonwealth status ''would render the island virtually independent of U.S. authority in many areas.''

title: False Obstacle to Arms Control
description: LEAD: Along with strategic missile defense, the issue of sea-launched cruise missiles stands as one of the principal obstacles to an agreement to limit strategic nuclear weapons. However, recent Soviet statements have opened the way to a compromise on SLCM's. The next move belongs to the Bush Administration.

title: Accounts
description: * AMP Inc., an electronics company, to Al Paul Lefton Co., Philadelphia, with an undisclosed budget.

title: Lawmaker Asks Carla Hills to Testify on H.U.D. Inquiry
description: The chairman of a House panel investigating mismanagement in Federal housing programs said today that he would call the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, to testify about her lobbying and legal work on behalf of a mortgage concern and a real estate developer.

title: Haughey Voted A Fourth Time As Irish Premier
description: Charles J. Haughey was elected Prime Minister for the fourth time today after reluctantly forming a coalition with his bitterest political enemy.

title: Argonaut Group d reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CBS Says Its Profit Fell 7.7% in Quarter
description: CBS Inc. said yesterday that its net income fell 7.7 percent in the second quarter, reflecting higher programming costs and reduced advertising revenues from the National Basketball Association's championship series.

title: Pacific Western Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a $1,200,000 gain from an accounting change.

title: Comex Has New Chief From Philadelphia
description: Arnold F. Staloff, who won the reputation of a strong innovator of financial products as a senior officer of the Philadelpia Stock Exchange and president of the Philadelphia Board of Trade, yesterday was named the president and chief executive of the Commodity Exchange Inc., or Comex, based in New York.

title: BAKER ANNOUNCES NATO AGREEMENT ON AIRCRAFT CUTS
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d announced today that NATO had reached agreement on the type of fighter aircraft it wanted to include in conventional-arms talks with the Warsaw Pact. He said the West would submit its proposals in Vienna on Thursday, two months ahead of schedule.

title: Legislature in Texas Votes Repeal of Law That Restricted Press
description: The Texas Legislature passed a bill today repealing a law that allows the police to withhold the names of felony crime victims. The vote was unanimous in both houses.

title: Nonchemical Pesticides Need Encouragement
description: To the Editor:

title: Quayle Defends Administration's Record on Rights
description: Vice President Dan Quayle, in his first appearance before the nation's largest civil rights organization, sought today to soften the sting of recent Supreme Court decisions on affirmative action by defending the Bush Administration's record.

title: Untutored Fancies That Grew Into Art
description: ONE of Barbara Head Millstein's responsibilities as the associate curator of painting and sculpture at the Brooklyn Museum is ''to look for art wherever it is.'' She has found it in a five-room railroad apartment on 16th Street in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn.

title: Accugraph Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Close to Home
description: I SKULKED into the theater in the manner of a man who doesn't want to be seen at a dirty movie: head down, eyes on sidewalk, ticket money in hand. All I lacked was the raincoat. It was high noon, and I was supposed to be either researching or writing an editorial. At the very least I was supposed to be planning an edifying lunch. Instead I - along with some children, lots of layabouts and probably a few three-card monte dealers - was at the midday showing of ''Batman.''

title: State Insurance Laws Could Slow B.A.T. Bid
description: Sir James Goldsmith's $21 billion bid for B.A.T. Industries could be complicated by state regulations concerning any change in ownership of B.A.T.'s American insurance subsidiary, the Farmers Group Inc., analysts and regulators said today.

title: Manager at First Boston Leaving to Join Wespar
description: The First Boston Corporation continues to suffer more personnel defections. The latest is Kelly A. Dunne, manager of $1.5 billion in high-yield investments at First Boston asset management, who is leaving to join Wespar Financial Corporation in Century City, Calif.

title: Bridge
description: A small departure from routine bidding can occasionally have a big impact. On the diagramed deal from the Cavendish Invitational Charity Pairs, played in mid-May, two South players chose to conceal their feeble four-card spade suit after a Stayman response. As a result, both were able to bring home an ''impossible'' slam.

title: 2 Boys Hurt in Falls From Bronx Windows
description: Two young boys were injured, one critically, when they fell from windows in their apartments in two separate incidents in the Bronx yesterday morning, the police said.

title: The Brightest Star Belongs to Jackson
description: There is no denying that Bo Jackson stole the show at the All-Star Game Tuesday night. But there were others who deserved some recognition, too.

title: Gannett Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 25
description: Second quarter comprised 13 weeks, and the 6-month period, 26 weeks.

title: Nielsen Leads New York Open
description: Three former winners of the Michelob New York State Open were atop the leader board today with one day remaining in the 12th annual tournament.

title: Tunisia Loan Approved
description: The World Bank said it had approved a $130 million loan for Tunisia to help finance a restructuring of public enterprises like the national railway, fertilizer and state-owned mining operations. The loan is for 17 years and carries a variable interest rate, currently 7.73 percent.

title: Hungary's Communists Threaten to Split Party
description: Members of the self-styled ''reform circles'' in Hungary's ruling Communist Party threatened today to form their own party, saying the Communists were incapable of winning a free election with Karoly Grosz as general secretary.

title: Olivier's Wooden O
description: Laurence Olivier's gifts stood out in a remarkable generation of British actors, yet at his death one achievement deserves special, lasting recognition. He, more than anyone else, helped restore Shakespeare to groundlings everywhere in the English-speaking world.

title: Morgan's Foods reports earnings for Qtr to May 23
description: b-Net loss and included a loss from discontinued operations of $307,000.

title: In Hungary, the Ideas for Change Are Selling Themselves
description: When President Bush visited four Western European capitals last month, he found changed attitudes and new policies everywhere. But in three Eastern European cities this week, he has seen something altogether different and infinitely more challenging.

title: Massachusetts on the Brink of Higher Taxes
description: In the face of mounting voter hostility, Massachusetts legislators are moving to raise personal income taxes to pay the state's debts.

title: INB Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
From Rich Fabrics, Colorful Rag Rugs
description: When Judie Landis took a weaving class for fun eight years ago, she had no idea it would be the beginning of a new career.

title: Potent Crack Blend on the Streets Lures a New Generation to Heroin
description: A highly addictive mixture of crack and smokable heroin is emerging as the new drug of choice among some of New York City's nearly one million chronic drug abusers, city and state drug-treatment officials say. The combination threatens to addict a new generation on heroin, which was recently believed to be waning in popularity.

title: Addendum
description: * Campbell-Mithun-Esty has started a subsidiary agency devoted to the health care industry. The shop, Campbell-Mithun-Esty Healthcare, will be based in Minneapolis.

title: Metalbanc reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Net loss Results for fiscal 1988 are restated because the company was required to change its income statement presentation following the sale of its precious metals business in fiscal 1989. MetalBanc realized a net gain of $232,000 on the sale.

title: Laurence Curtis, 95, Former House Member
description: Laurence Curtis, a Republican who served five terms in the House of Representatives, died Tuesday at Brigham and Women's Hospital. He was 95 years old, Mr. Curtis also served one term as Massachusetts Treasurer, three terms as a State Senator, two as a State Representative and two as a Boston City Councilor.

title: INSIDE
description: House in Furor Over Art The House administered a slap on the wrist to the National Endowment for the Arts after conservatives said it offended taxpayers' taste. Page A18. Soviet Psychiatry Criticized After of tour of Soviet psychiatric hospitals, American experts said that despite improvements the system is still ''unduly harsh.'' Page A3. Black Bishops Rebuff Priest The nation's 13 black Roman Catholic bishops sharply rebuffed a black priest in Washington for establishing a separate congregation. Page A12. Lean Times in New Jersey New Jersey's tight budget will mean longer lines at car inspection stations, less aid for needy students and possible layoffs of state workers. Page B1.

title: Parent & Child
description: A FEW weeks ago 3-year-old Marissa Arnold climbed out of the pool in Minneapolis where her father and two older brothers were playing, took the inflatable floats off her arms, walked over to the ladder and jumped back in the water. When her father, Josh, turned around several seconds later, he saw his daughter completely submerged, holding her breath, and oblivious to the danger that surrounded her.

title: Judge Throws Out Conviction In Case Over a Flapping Flag
description: Now that a Navy veteran has replaced an American flag whose loud flapping bothered a neighbor, his conviction has been thrown out by a local judge.

title: School Investigations Leave Much to Be Desired
description: To the Editor:

title: Hormone Is Found to Help Skin Wounds Heal Faster
description: An experimental hormone treatment makes skin grow more quickly and may someday be used to speed the healing of wounds from minor cuts to life-threatening burns, doctors have reported.

title: O. Robert Gibbons, Consultant, 70
description: O. Robert Gibbons, a mergers and acquisitions consultant for Midlantic National Bank in Edison, N.J., died of cancer Monday at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan and Washington, Conn., with his longtime companion, Vincent J. Mastracco.

title: Campaign Matters; The Middle Class Asks Dinkins For Solutions
description: The question that seemed to stump David N. Dinkins at an appearance before leaders of the American Jewish Congress had nothing to do with Yasir Arafat, affirmative action, the Rev. Jesse Jackson or black-Jewish relations. Seated at a small conference table in a wood-paneled board room the other night, Mr. Dinkins talked about his love of children, his concern for the homeless and the need for programs to keep troubled families together and give poor children an alternative to drugs.

title: Currents; When Inspiration Strikes Twice
description: A. Acton Stacker chair, designed by Hugh Acton for the American Seating Company, was introduced in 1976. B. Albi stacking chair, designed by Don Albinson for Fixtures Furniture, was introduced in 1988.

title: Lively Time for Maple Leaf Fans
description: The Ballards have been in the news again, and it's a rather messy affair this time. The family patriarch, 85-year-old Harold Ballard, is angry at his children, who he feels are only waiting for him to die so they can get their share of his estate.

title: Greek Bank in U.S. Is Sued
description: An attorney for depositors in a Greek bank that was raided by Federal authorities last month has filed a lawsuit accusing the bank of taking hundreds of millions of dollars from its depositors.

title: Benjamin Rubinstein, Psychiatrist, Dies at 84
description: Benjamin B. Rubinstein, a psychiatrist and psychoanalytical theorist, died of cancer yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Drought Disaster Declared
description: Officials declared a statewide drought disaster in North Dakota today, the first step in making farmers eligible for Federal assistance. ''The 1988 drought never really ended,'' Lieut. Gov. Lloyd Omdahl said. ''Now, we're back to a very serious situation.''

title: A Legal Lid for Doctors' Fees
description: The Congressional version of E.T. isn't lovable or extraterrestrial. But it will likely become an even bigger financial success than the joyous movie character. Medicare payments to doctors have risen more than 15 percent a year in the 1980's. Because three-quarters of these reimbursements are paid by taxes, Congress wants to impose a program of expenditure targets, or E.T. While not without risk, the plan deserves support.

title: KEY RATES
A 'Cost-Unconscious' Medical System
description: LEAD: Our health care system is becoming a disaster.

title: Judges' Actions Await Report on Minorities
