description: New York State's Chief Judge and the Chief Administrator of the Courts said yesterday that they were awaiting recommendations from a Judicial Commission on Minorities to determine what action they should take to ''confront the apparent perception among some citizens that minorities are not treated fairly in the courts.''

title: Suspension At Northrop
description: The Northrop Corporation said the Air force had temporarily suspended business with its precision products division as a result of charges brought last spring.

title: Sotheby's Strike Ends
description: A five-day strike by porters, bid spotters, doormen and property handlers at Sotheby's in New York City was settled yesterday when union members of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Local 814, voted to accept a contract that increases pension and welfare benefits and raises salaries by about $78 a week over the three years of the contract. The final contract was worked out with the assistance of Irwin Gerard of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Board.

title: 600 Share Laughter and Memories At a Service Honoring I. F. Stone
description: The human side of the independent, radical journalist I. F. Stone, who died June 18, was recalled yesterday by the speakers at a public gathering of his family, friends and admirers.

title: Max Zuger, Psychiatrist, 86
description: Dr. Max Zuger, a retired psychiatrist, died June 30 at Hillhaven Convalescent Center in Sarasota, Fla., where he lived. He was 86 years old.

title: Mark IV Weighs Bid for Interlake
description: Mark IV Industries said it would explore the possibility of buying the Interlake Corporation of Oak Brook, Ill. Mark IV, which owns 5 percent of Interlake's stock, also said it had asked the Federal Government for permission to raise its stake in Interlake to 14.9 percent. The announcement came a day after Mark IV said it planned to sell the Blackstone Cororation, a manufacturer of heat transfer products for new and used cars.

title: ARGENTINE LEADER NAMES ARMY CHIEF
description: President Carlos Saul Menem has moved quickly to try to calm the restive Argentine Army by naming as Chief of Staff a man favored by dissident officers who led three barracks rebellions in the last two years.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the death of Dean Lechner, an AIDS patient in Minnesota who had worked with Representative Bella Abzug, referred incorrectly to the period she served in Congress from New York.

title: SOME IN N.R.A. SEEK EXPULSION OF BUSH
description: Some members of the National Rifle Association are trying to oust President Bush from the group because of his ban on imports of semiautomatic rifles.

title: Drastic Cuts In Budget Will Affect All in Jersey
description: From car owners to needy students to the sick and the disadvantaged, just about every one of New Jersey's 7.6 million residents will in one way or another feel the impact of the almost stagnant $12 billion state budget that was adopted at the last possible moment, on July 1.

title: Home Improvment
description: INSTALLING an outlet on an exterior wall is a convenient way to provide electric current for outdoor activities. An easy installation method - connecting the outlet to an indoor receptacle on the other side of the same wall - is described here, but before starting any electrical project, it is wise to consult a local building inspector.

title: The Palm Crossed With Silver
description: Waiters, waitresses and their bosses almost defeated a clause Senator Bob Dole wanted in the big 1982 tax bill. It was designed to collect more taxes on income from tips, and quickly proved its worth. Tip income reported from bars, restaurants and hotels jumped 127 percent, or $1.2 billion, in just two years.

title: Castle & Cooke Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: All share net figures are fully diluted. Year-earlier results have been restated to reflect consolidated of Oceanic Properties, a wholly-owned subsidiary.

title: BRIEFS
description: Preferred Stock

title: Review/Ballet; New Cast in the Kirov's 'Sleeping Beauty'
description: Altynai Assylmuratova, a vision of loveliness, and Konstantin Zaklinsky were the new Aurora and her Prince, encouraged by Lyubov Kunakova as a grand Lilac Fairy, on Tuesday night in the Kirov Ballet's ''Sleeping Beauty.''

title: Kazan Journal; Street Gangs Return, and Soviet City Is Chagrined
description: Ten years ago, at the height of citizens' panic over the rise of teen-age gang wars in this ancient city on the Volga, the most notorious of the gang leaders, Zavdat Khantimirov, was executed for banditry before a firing squad.

title: The Stylish Wall: What It's Wearing
description: PAINTINGS, drawings, prints, mirrors, china plates - one or several of these elements may be grouped on today's wall. But these days the grouping will be carefully composed.

title: Mayoral Rivals Will Not Challenge Petitions
description: The four Democratic mayoral candidates in New York City say they will not challenge each others' designating petitions for the September primary.

title: Structural Dynamics Reearch reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Currents; Classical Scenes On Sheets
description: ALTHOUGH they will not be introduced until October or available until spring, Robert A. M. Stern is already dreaming about his new sheets.

title: American Medical
description: M. Lee Pearce, a Miami doctor, has sold his 9.4 percent stake in American Medical Inc. for $184.6 million, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. Dr. Pearce was American Medical's largest shareholder and was instrumental in forcing the removal of Walter L. Weisman, the company's chairman. The filing did not say how much he paid for the shares.

title: Excerpts From Speech By Bush on Hungary
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's speech today at Karl Marx University:

title: Behind Film's Warning on Cigarettes
description: A PROMINENT Congressional opponent of cigarette advertising said yesterday that his accusations that the placement of brand-name cigarettes in movies constituted advertising had prompted a studio to add the Surgeon General's warning on cigarette use at the end of a film.

title: Events: Show House and Mansion Tours
description: Connecticut Show House, Palmer Mansion, 1 Palmer Street, off Route 1A, Stonington, Conn.; 203-535-3519.

title: Taiwan Investments
description: Overseas investment by Taiwan business people rose about 33 percent, to $113 million, in the first half of 1989, from $85 million in the corresponding period a year earlier, Liu Kwun, an Investment Commission official, said today. ''The outward investment is expected to reach a record high of about $500 million this year,'' Mr. Liu said. Last year, a record $219 million was invested abroad from Taiwan. John Ni, director of the Industrial Development and Investment Center, said, ''The actual figure of our outward investment is about 10 times more than the official count.''

title: Now, Chiat/Day/Mojo
description: Chiat/Day officially added the name Mojo yesterday, reflecting the completion of its acquisition of Mojo MDA, the Australian ad agency. Chiat/Day Holdings said it had purchased more than the required 90 percent of Mojo's shares to combine the agencies. Chiat/Day/Mojo will have billings of more than $1 billion and 1,200 employees.

title: Former Curator Admits He Stole Cartoon Art
description: The former curator of the Museum of Cartoon Art pleaded guilty today to stealing and selling valuable cartoon strip originals featuring Dick Tracy and Prince Valiant.

title: Hospital Rules Shift Burden From Residents
description: To the Editor:

title: Finding City Space Just Below
description: Businesses looking to expand in congested cities like New York, Chicago and San Francisco usually turn to skyscrapers or the suburbs, but a group of engineers and architects says a better solution lies just below the surface. Building underground has the potential to provide millions of square feet of energy-efficient space in the nation's largest cities, the American Underground-Space Association says.

title: National Fuel Gas Debenture Offering
description: The National Fuel Gas Company is offering $100 million in 9 1/2 percent debentures due in 2019 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation, which made the winning bid in a competition yesterday.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly AD HOC COMMITTEE ON INDIAN OCEAN - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. TRADE LAW COMMISSION WORKING GROUP ON INTERNATIONAL PAYMENTS - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: BBDO in Global Deals
description: BBDO Worldwide announced that it has firmed up links with several ad agencies in Europe, Latin America and Asia. In Europe, BBDO acquired a minority interest in Jenssen & Borkenhagen A.S., a Norwegian agency, and signed a non-equity agreement with an Irish agency, Doherty Advertising Ltd. BBDO's Puerto Rican agency has grown with the acquisition of a local agency. And in Asia, BBDO acquired a majority interest in Stantor/BBDO, of Taiwan, and became an affiliate of Manhattan International, one of Pakistan's largest shops.

title: Soviets Planning to Launch Ads Into Space
description: The Soviet Union has turned to the world's largest advertising agency for help in exploiting commercial opportunities and placing advertising in space.

title: Stolt Tankers & Terminals reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a non-recurring gain of $5,000,000 from an insurance settlement. c-Included a nonrecurring gain of $30,500,000 from the sale of a subsidiary.

title: Yankee Cast May Be Set But Gaps Remain
description: In another division, or at another time, the Yankees would have been finished long ago. But as the season resumes tonight at the Stadium, they are right there: a vision of the American League East's mediocrity but nonetheless in second place and still close after 14 weeks.

title: A Book That Helps Bypass Bookstores
description: Since books are his world, Jason Epstein, the editorial director of Random House, has created a tome to help find them: a ''Reader's Catalogue'' the size of the Manhattan phone book.

title: Worldclass Poets On Love and Death
description: The theme of the show is ''Love and Death'' and the writers behind it range from King Solomon to Saul Bellow, with scores of worldclass poets in between.

title: U.S. Seeks Buyers for Seized Assets
description: Regulators of the nation's troubled savings industry said today that they were seeking buyers for $9.6 billion in problem real estate throughout the country and other assets now held in receiverships. They said they expected to receive $5.9 billion for the properties over five years.

title: Household Insider Case Is Settled
description: A former employee of Household International Inc. and her husband have settled Federal civil insider trading charges that they purchased shares of Booth Inc. while in possession of nonpublic information that Household had agreed to acquire the company.

title: U.S. FORESEES RUSH IN SOVIET EMIGRES
description: American diplomats here are bracing for an explosive increase in Soviet emigration to the United States under a law now being drafted that would lift long-standing restrictions on who can leave the country.

title: A Revamping of Fox Film Puts Emphasis on Movies
description: The 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation announced a revamping today that signals a new emphasis on movies.

title: 2 Agents' Bond Continues
description: A Federal judge ruled today that Norby Walters and Lloyd Bloom could remain free on bond pending their appeals of their convictions of mail fraud and racketeering.

title: Drug Is Given New Chance as Cure for Back Pain
description: A once-popular drug used to treat ruptured spinal disks is receiving renewed but cautious interest as an alternative to surgery after being sidelined for five years because of unexpected adverse effects.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 24 about the effect of Nicaraguan inflation on the use of piggy banks described Nicaraguan coins incorrectly. One-cordoba and 50-centavo coins minted in the early 1980's bore the image of the revolutionary hero Augusto Sandino, not merely his hat.

title: Bush Extends Support to Hungary And Offers Modest Economic Aid
description: President Bush extended American support today to Hungary's efforts toward political and economic change with a series of modest measures of economic aid.

title: 13 People Are Indicted In L.I. Housing Scheme
description: Thirteen people were indicted today on charges they conspired to defraud a federally subsidized housing program in the Town of Brookhaven.

title: Report Reproaches Soviet Psychiatry
description: An official delegation of American experts said today that Soviet psychiatric hospitals were still ''unduly harsh and restrictive,'' that patients were ''denied basic rights'' and that doctors sometimes used drugs to punish patients.

title: Barnett Banks Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
New York City Inspector Is Detained at U.N.
description: A New York City health inspector was detained and interrogated at the United Nations headquarters on Tuesday after he arrived unannounced to check a report of improper asbestos removal, a spokeswoman for the city's Department of Environmental Protection said yesterday.

title: Era Ends: Gator Says 'So Long'
description: Ron Guidry, the suddenly former Yankee pitcher, had a smile on his lean face, though, at times, in the glare of the lights of the television cameras at the news conference, one could see a little moistness rimming his eyes, and perhaps belying some of his words.

title: Curb on Soybean Trading Puts Market in Turmoil
description: An emergency order by the world's largest commodities exchange touched off frenzied trading in soybeans today, with prices plummeting and the move threatening to spark an international dispute.

title: French Revolution: Visions and Deeds
description: 1789 May 5: Formal opening of the States-General - clergy, nobility and commoners - on initiative of Louis XVI. June 17: Third Estate declares itself the National Assembly. July 14: Fall of the Bastille. Aug. 4: Abolition of feudalism and special priveleges. Aug 27: Declaration of the Rights of man adopted. $ Oct. 6: Royal family brought to Paris. 1790 July 12: Civil Constitution of the Clergy adopted, requiring clergy to pledge loyalty to the Revolution. 1791 June 20-25: Flight of Louis XVI and Marie Antoinette to Varennes, where they are arrested. Sept. 14: Louis XVI accepts the Constitution of 1791. 1792 June 20: Mob of Sans-Culottes invades the Tuileries. Sept. 2-6: September Massacres; jails stoned, prisoners killed. Sept.22: Abolition of the monarchy. Year one of the Republic. 1793 Jan. 21j: Execution of Louis XVI. March 4: Insurrection in Vendee begins. An estimated 300,000 to 600,000 are killed as it is repressed over the next three years. June 2: Girondist (moderate repulican) leaders arrested. July 13: Assassination of Marat. Oct. 10: Revolutionary Government declared. Oct. 16: Execution of Marie-Antoinette. 1794 April: Execution of Danton. July 28: Execution of Robespierre.

title: A Sure Sign of Spring, Only in the Fall
description: THE bulb catalogues from companies like Burpee and Smith & Hawken have made their annual appearances in our mailboxes in recent weeks.

title: Q&A
description: Hot Water for Showers

title: Ravitch Campaign's a Hands-On Affair
description: For Richard Ravitch, the race for mayor of New York City consists largely of shaking hands - hundreds and hundreds of hands.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * BB&T Financial Corp., Wilson, N.C., a bank holding company, named John A. Allison 4th chairman and chief executive.

title: Japan Corrects Aid Figures
description: Japanese officials said today that a new aid package for poor countries to be presented by Prime Minister Sousuke Uno in Paris this week would total about $38 billion, not $43 billion, as figures released in Japan on Tuesday had indicated.

title: Connecticut Residents Remember A Storm Worthy of a Nightmare
description: Domenic Piscitelli had never seen a Mazda fly before. ''It just picked up and wound up in the backyard,'' he said.

title: Currents; Of Gorillas, Bananas And Pie
description: FOR 10 years, John Margolies, a Manhattan photographer, has been documenting roadside and commercial buildings as well as resorts of the last century. Through July 31, in an exhibition entitled ''Bar Harbor to Key West: Atlantic Coast Resorts,'' 58 of his 100,000 images will be on view at the Virginia Beach Center for the Arts, 2200 Park Avenue, Virginia Beach, Va.

title: Hungarian Fund Aid
description: The International Finance Corporation, an arm of the World Bank, has said it is helping set up the first fund for foreign portfolio investment in Hungary. International Finance said on Tuesday that it would put up $7.5 million, or 15 percent of the shares in the First Hungary Fund, which is to total $50 million and to last 10 years. International Finance said it was also providing $40,000, or 20 percent of the shares in First Hungarian Advisory R.T., a new Hungarian joint stock company to be set up in Budapest to manage the fund's investments.

title: Beecham Is Projecting Big Savings
description: Executives of Beecham P.L.C. expect $300 million to $500 million in eventual annual savings from cost-cutting moves to be made after the company's merger with the SmithKline Beckman Corporation is completed, analysts said yesterday.

title: Leningrad Party Chief, Election Loser, Is Ousted
description: The leader of the Leningrad Communist Party, who suffered a humiliating defeat in elections in March, was removed from his party post today and replaced by a 56-year-old chemical engineer.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transmission error, an article on July 3 about technology in India misidentified a documentary about a community's realization that it is about to be replaced by a missile site. The title is ''Voices From Baliapal,'' not Baliapore.

title: Books of The Times; Boxers and the Violence They Endure and Enjoy
description: Serenity A Boxing Memoir By Ralph Wiley 230 pages. Henry Holt & Company. $22.50. Fire and Fear The Inside Story of Mike Tyson By Jose Torres Illustrated. 242 pages. Warner Books.

title: Rangers Intensify Their Pursuit Of Bowman
description: The Rangers, who earlier this week said they were eager and prepared to conclude their search for a general manager, have intensified their efforts to persuade Scotty Bowman to take the position, a source familiar with the process said.

title: Waking From a New 'Nightmare' to New Profits
description: On Aug. 11, Freddy Krueger will once again extend his razor-sharp fingers toward sleeping teen-agers, invading their dreams in 1,900 theaters. With the regularity of a vampire awakening at sunset, each summer brings a new ''Nightmare on Elm Street.'' And each new ''Nightmare'' is another sweet dream for New Line Cinema.

title: Walgreen Co reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
RESULTS PLUS
description: CYCLING Fall Drops Leader Back: A fall in the final 500 meters cost Rudy Dhaenens the individual victory yesterday, and Laurent Fignon of France held onto a seven-second overall lead over Greg LeMond of the United States as the Tour de France passed the midway mark. Dhaenens, of the Netherlands, had an uneventful ride until he broke away from the pack two miles from the finish of the 96-mile leg from Luchon to Blagnac. He fell while rounding a curve, damaged his bike and could not finish until everyone had passed him. Mathieu Hermans of the Netherlands then outsprinted the pack in 3 hours 47 minutes 47 seconds.

title: 2 States Grapple With Issue Of Executing Retarded Men
description: Less than a month after the Supreme Court ruled that states can execute murderers who are mentally retarded, two executions that were scheduled this week in the South have focused attention on the complex issues raised by the decision.

title: No Ford Unit Bid
description: The Ford Motor Company said a bidder for its Rouge Steel Company subsidiary was no longer interested in acquiring the unit, but it said it would seek a partner to run the steel operation. The United Automobile Workers union has said the bidder, believed to be Worthington Industries, had approached Ford about buying the unit. Ford confirmed that it was holding talks on Rouge Steel, and Worthington had no comment.

title: Paul A. Salomone, Executive, 67
description: Paul A. Salomone, a retired retail executive, died of cancer Tuesday at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, N.J. He was 67 years old and lived in South Orange, N.J.

title: Prices of U.S. Securities Are Mixed
description: Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in fairly light trading yesterday, in a session highlighted by a seven-year note auction that saw yields on those securities fall to their lowest level in more than two years.

title: Rules Eased By Fannie Mae
description: The nation's largest buyer of home mortgages said today that it was changing its rules to make it easier and cheaper for homeowners to refinance their mortgages.

title: Nonchemical Pesticides Need Encouragement; California Grape Boycott
description: To the Editor:

title: Talking Deals; Bank Merger Plan Stirs Puerto Rico
description: BANCO POPULAR DE PUERTO RICO and Banco de Ponce would hold about 31 percent of Puerto Rico's banking market if they merged, and as much as two-thirds of the island's retail banking business. That prospect has brought cries of alarm from a leader of the main opposition party in Puerto Rico and from some smaller banking companies.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a Chinese student leader who fled to the United States referred to Karl Popper incorrectly. He is a professor of logic and scientific method at the London School of Economics.

title: Why World Is Revolving Around Paris
description: A helium-filled air-ship hovers over the city, snapping live television images to police command centers on the ground. More than 30,000 police officers and soldiers have been mobilized; anti-aircraft batteries have been installed in the Bois de Boulogne.

title: Mandela Urges Pretoria to Talk to Apartheid Foes
description: Nelson Mandela said in a statement issued today that the Government could bring peace to South Africa only if it entered into discussions with the anti-apartheid movement, and the outlawed African National Congress in particular.

title: Mercury Finance reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Group Seeks to Buy a Suffragist's Home
description: The New Jersey birthplace of Alice Paul, a crusader for women's rights, may become a conference center and office for women's groups. The Alice Paul Centennial Foundation plans to buy the house in Mount Laurel, but first the organization must raise $500,000 by Sept. 8.

title: Senate Debates Overhauling the Laws Governing Legal Immigration
description: The Senate is debating an overhaul of immigration laws aimed at establishing an overall limit on legal immigration to the United States for the first time in 65 years and increasing immigration from Western Europe.

title: More Searches Begin In Game-Fixing Inquiry
description: Federal and local authorities today were continuing their investigation of an alleged sports gambling ring that is said to have taken bets on high school football games and may have had a role in fixing some of the contests.

title: Chip Index Steady in June
description: A closely watched index of the health of the semiconductor industry remained steady in June at a level that indicates that business is neither growing rapidly nor declining rapidly.

title: Dow Rises 18.02 to Reach Post-Crash High
description: The Dow Jones industrial average moved to a post-crash high, rising 18.02, to 2,532.63, its seventh straight gain.

title: Fund Yields Fall Sharply
description: Yields offered on money market mutual funds tracked by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were down sharply for the week ended yesterday, reflecting the Federal Reserve's moves to ease credit conditions.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Hungarians Acquaint Barbara Bush With One of Their Points of Light
description: A few years ago, if you got a little tipsy at a Budapest dinner party and began singing the Transylvanian anthem, your hostess would have run to slam shut the windows for fear the police would hear.

title: Japan Trade Surplus Cut
description: Japan's world trade surplus narrowed 11 percent in June, but continued to widen against its largest trading partner, the United States, Finance Ministry officials reported today.

title: Evocative Site for Women's Open
description: Indianwood Golf and Country Club, a beautiful course that has been called a links away from the sea, is the setting for the 44th United States Women's Open, which begins tomorrow.

title: Kellogg Journal; Mining Town Given Lift In Effort to Be a Resort
description: Slouching toward trendiness, this worn-out mining town is giving itself a makeover and earnestly striving to shed its scruffy past.

title: Mead Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
Reserve Industries reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included a gain from extinguishment of debt of $28,914 and $476,457 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Included a loss of $33,600.

title: Conferees Progressing on Savings Bailout Bill
description: Congressional conferees today moved close to removing an accounting provision from the House version of the savings bailout bill, an action that would make its capital standards even tougher.

title: Oracle Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Quaker Plans Pretax Charge
description: The Quaker Oats Company said today that it expected to take a onetime pretax charge of $104 million, or 80 cents a share, against its 1989 earnings because of a plant closing in Ohio and the elimination of 560 jobs, or about 3 percent of its American work force.

title: Jackson Said to Plan a Move To Washington Next Month
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson plans to move to the District of Columbia next month but remains undecided about running for Mayor, associates who asked not to be named said today.

title: Two Troopers Shot in Rockland County Ambush
description: Two state troopers were shot here early this morning by a man posing as a Federal treasury agent who had called for police assistance, officials said.

title: Institutions Balk at Bid For B.A.T.
description: Anticipating a higher bid, institutional investors today described the $21 billion offer for B.A.T. Industries made by an investor group headed by Sir James Goldsmith as totally inadequate.

title: Market Place; Closer Scrutiny Of Bid for B.A.T.
description: IN 1985, Ted Turner made an offer for CBS Inc. that seemed absurd - all paper and not a penny of cash. Eventually, Mr. Turner retired from the scene, but that offer helped set in motion the chain of events that led to control of CBS passing to Laurence A. Tisch of the Loews Corporation.

title: Daniels Changes Plans
description: Lloyd Daniels, the troubled New York City basketball star who was shot six weeks ago in what the police said was retaliation for a drug debt, has decided to forgo a decision to play in the World Basketball League this summer in favor of a conditioning program he hopes will help get him into the National Basketball Associ-ation.

title: Losses Twice as High as Thought Are Found in an F.H.A. Program
description: Government officials and independent auditors say a Federal Housing Administration program has accumulated losses of $1 billion, twice as much as auditors for the Government originally thought.

title: House Sends Art Endowment Message on Taxpayers' Taste
description: The House of Representatives held a rough seminar on art today, administering a carefully designed slap on the wrist to the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: Bid Is Challenged By Dunkin' Donuts
description: Dunkin' Donuts Inc. charged in a Federal lawsuit that two Canadian companies have made false and misleading statements about their financing for a $305 million bid to take over the doughnut chain. The company said in United States District Court in Boston that the financing arranged by Unicorp Canada and Cara Operations Ltd. would not meet Federal margin regulations.

title: Gannett Net Up by 14.9% In 2d Quarter
description: The Gannett Company said today that its second-quarter net income rose 14.9 percent, to $112.1 million, or 70 cents a share, from $97.5 million a year earlier because of higher advertising revenues, lower newsprint costs and the first second-quarter profit at USA Today.

title: Radyne Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: Pickpockets Swarming Summer's Crowds of Tourists
description: The police call them ''spitters'' and ''mustard chuckers,'' among other things, but to the tourists flooding New York City this summer and losing money, credit cards and jewelry, they are simply pickpockets.

title: Team Inc reports earnings for Year to May 31
Investor Reduces Texas Air Stake
description: Michael Steinhart, a New York-based money manager, has lowered his stake in the Texas Air Corporation to 3.5 percent, from 5.2 percent. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing , Mr. Steinhardt gave no reason for the sales.

title: Japan-Europe Talks on Cars
description: Japan is ready to discuss the European Community's fears that it could be flooded with Japanese cars if limits are scrapped in creating a single market in late 1992, a community spokesman said today.

title: Reviews/Television; A Series Explores the Urge Toward Democracy
description: The timing for ''The Struggle for Democracy,'' Patrick Watson's ambitious series that begins tonight at 8 on Channel 13, is positively serendipitous. Even viewers with the short memory span bred by television cannot yet have forgotten the moving scenes of that struggle being waged in China, the Soviet Union, Poland and other lands. They invite all manner of questions. Is there a common impulse behind such upsurges? Can democracy be tailored to fit differing traditions and conditions? What are the risks of introducing political freedoms to societies that have never known them?

title: Lin Broadcasting And McCaw Talk
description: McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. disclosed that it is in talks, ''on a preliminary basis,'' with the Lin Broadcasting Corporation about possibly raising its $110-a-share takeover offer. The offer from McCaw, of Kirkland, Wash., the nation's largest cellular telephone concern, is valued at just under $6 billion.

title: Reviews/Television; A Month of Tributes to the French Revolution
description: In an ambitious and somewhat curious programming campaign, cable television's Arts & Entertainment Network has been conducting a monthlong programming effort to salute the bicentennial of the French Revolution. The centerpiece, a seven-hour presentation called ''Paris Live,'' gets under way tomorrow at 7 P.M. Actually live on tape, the program will offer highlights of Bastille Day celebrations held only hours earlier throughout France, from the neighborhoods of Paris to such cities as Marseilles, Versailles and Lyons.

title: Contenders, Pretenders Vie for Division Titles
description: The Pete Rose affair has dominated the season and will maintain its place of notoriety the rest of the way. Beyond the Rose mess, however, are four divisional races that will be settled out of court in the next two and a half months. They, too, will be worth watching.

title: Of Course, Oil Spills Can Be Prevented; Fuel From Waste
description: To the Editor:

title: Spain Begins Investigation Into Drexel's Sale of Shares
description: Securities regulators in Spain are investigating whether Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. improperly sold shares in one of Europe's largest petroleum companies to a few large private institutions.

title: Woman Slays College Official Going to Work
description: A Hunter College administrator was killed yesterday morning by a woman disguised in a black wig and sunglasses who ambushed him as he arrived at work, the police said.

title: Frederick Haviland, Executive, 77
description: Frederick Haviland, the executive vice president of Haviland China Inc., died of cancer Sunday at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mt. Kisco, N.Y. He was 77 years old and lived in Somers, N.Y.

title: Hooker Corp.'s Chief Resigns
description: The Hooker Corporation, the Australian owner of Bonwit Teller, B. Altman and other American retailers and shopping centers, said that its chief executive, George Herscu, had resigned, as expected. Mr. Herscu, who founded the company, will continue as chairman.

title: 13 Named in Bribery Plot At a Motor Vehicles Office
description: Thirteen people, including six employees of the Motor Vehicles Department in Queens, were charged yesterday in a bribery scheme that helped drug dealers register stolen vehicles that were used to transport narcotics and cash, the Federal authorities said.

title: Bank Merger In Baltimore
description: MNC Financial Inc., a regional banking giant based in Baltimore, said today that it had agreed to acquire Equitable Bancorporation of Baltimore in a tax-free stock swap, valued at about $583 million.

title: Hasbro's Purchase Of Coleco's Assets
description: Hasbro Inc. said it had completed the purchase of most of the financially troubled Coleco Industries' product lines and would immediately begin producing popular Cabbage Patch Kids dolls. Hasbro, the nation's largest toy maker, agreed last week to buy Coleco's main assets for $85 million cash and an option for Coleco to purchase one million shares of Hasbro at $28.85 each after Coleco's bankruptcy reorganization plan was confirmed, said Barry Alperin, Hasbro's executive vice president.

title: Review/Music; Itzhak Perlman Shares the Stage, With TV
description: The principal player at the Mostly Mozart season-opening concert in Avery Fisher Hall on Tuesday night was the television camera. It peeked from balconies, wings and backstage, rehearsing camera angles and lighting to prepare for a live national telecast of the same concert of Mozart and Bach 24 hours later.

title: Washington Talk; U.S. Considers the Once Unthinkable on Korea
description: A decade ago, President Jimmy Carter sought to pull some American troops out of South Korea. He ran into so much opposition from military leaders, politicians and diplomats here, and from many foreign governments, that he dropped the plan.

title: Todd-AO Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
BLACK U.S. BISHOPS CRITICAL OF PRIEST
description: The 13 black Roman Catholic bishops in the United States today sharply rebuffed a black priest here for establishing a separate ''African-American'' congregation.

title: Upstart Airline Is Coming of Age
description: Midway Airlines, which started a decade ago as a discount carrier serving the Midwest, has been looking a lot more like a first-tier airline lately.

title: Abbott Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the latest second quarter included foreign exchange losses of $4,741,000, compared with losses of $3,495,000 in the year-ago quarter. For the 6 months, foreign exchange losses were $14,781,000 in the latest period and $6,778,000 a year ago.

title: Restoring or Copying a Fine Mirror
description: IN the back of a long, narrow shop cluttered with pieces of glass, wooden frames and jars of powdered chemicals, Martin Shardan begins to work. He places a piece of green-tinted glass on a worktable, and he pours a liquid that smells strongly of ammonia over it. It contains a combination of chemicals he calls ''a professional secret.''

title: L. F. Rothschild's Ex-Chief Will Head Meridian Unit
description: Meridian Bancorp Inc., a regional banking company pushing into the securities industry, has created a merchant banking unit and named Gary Lieberman as its president.

title: Reagan Era Scandals Don't Stop at Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: Paychex Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
U.S. Eases Export Rules
description: The Commerce Department said today that it was easing security rules on the sale of up to $30 billion worth of goods a year to 18 large trading countries. The rules are intended to keep strategic products out of the hands of the Soviet Union and its allies.

title: Currents; Steamer Trunk of Old Is Now Fit for Business
description: RIGHT now there is only one, and that might just do for the time being, considering that the ''Malle Cabine'' costs $200,000. The one-of-a-kind steamer trunk by Hermes is a relative of the closet-size suitcases that used to accompany travelers on luxury liners, but it has been adapted to modern times.

title: CBS Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $200,000 on extinguishment of debt. c-Included a gain on disposal of discontinued operations of $866.6 million and an extraordinary loss of $100,000 on extinguishment of debt.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MARKETS An order by the Chicago Board of Trade to liquidate soybean contracts set off frenzied trading and a sharp drop in prices. Market professionals said the order was aimed at Ferruzzi, a large European grain trader. [ Page A1. ] Wheat prices also fell. [ D16. ] Securities regulators in Spain are investigating whether Drexel Burnham Lambert improperly sold shares in one of Europe's largest petroleum companies to a few large private institutions. [ D8. ] Blue-chip issues finished strongly as some program buying pushed stocks to their seventh consecutive advance as measured by the Dow Jones industrial average. The Dow rose by 18.02 points, to 2,532.63, a post-crash high. [ D8. ] Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in fairly light trading, in a session highlighted by a seven-year-note auction that saw yields on those securities fall to their lowest level in more than two years. [ D15. ] Yields fell sharply on money market mutual funds for the week ended yesterday. [ D11. ] The dollar drifted lower in quiet dealings as traders awaited several Government reports on the economy. [ D16. ] INTERNATIONAL The Soviet Union has turned to the world's largest advertising agency for help in exploiting commercial opportunities and placing commercials in space. [ A1. ] The U.S. is advocating a new strategy to liberalize global trade in food products, but it is likely to be opposed in Europe. [ D1. ] Japanese officials said a new aid package for poor countries would total about $38 billion, not $43 billion, as figures released in Japan on Tuesday had indicated. [ D2. ] President Bush's economic aid plan for Poland borrows some tried and true Wall Street techniques. News Analysis. [ D2. ] THE ECONOMY The House Ways and Means Committee tentatively approved the outline of a tax bill that would not affect the taxes paid by most individuals but would raise the $5.3 billion necessary to meet next year's budget target. [ D1. ] Congressional conferees moved close to removing an accounting provision from the House version of the savings bailout bill, an action that would make its capital standards even tougher. [ D5. ] Regulators of the savings industry said they were seeking buyers for $9.6 billion in problem real estate throughout the country. [ D5. ] The Financial Accounting Standards Board postponed for the second time the deadline for adopting an unpopular ruling that changes the ways companies report their income tax expense to shareholders. [ D4. ] COMPANIES Institutional investors dismissed as inadequate the $21 billion offer for B.A.T. by investors led by Sir James Goldsmith. [ D1. ] The bid could be complicated by insurance regulators in states where B.A.T.'s American subsidiary, Farmers Group, operates. [ D6. ] Twentieth Century-Fox Film said it was beginning a reorganization that would put greater emphasis on its film-making operations. Joe Roth, a producer and director was named chairman of the film unit. [ D1. ] CBS said its net income fell 7.7 percent in the second quarter, reflecting higher programming costs and reduced advertising revenues from its coverage of the N.B.A. playoffs. [ D19. ] Beecham's executives predicted $300 million to $500 million in eventual annual savings from the company's proposed merger with SmithKline Beckman, analysts said. [ D4. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Cries of alarm in Puerto Rico have greeted Banco Popular's offer for Banponce. Talking Deals. [ D2. ] Sir James Goldsmith's chances of succeeding with his offer for B.A.T. are slim, experts say. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [ D6. ] The new James Bond movie carries the Surgeon General's warning at its end. Advertising. [ D19. ]

title: Putting Together Furniture From a Kit
description: LEAD: Assembling copies of classic furniture made up in kit form is becoming increasingly popular. And for good reason: you can own a useful and attractive piece in mint condition as a substitute for a costly and hard-to-find antique. Whether in a hundred years such pieces will themselves be considered desirable antiques is another matter.

title: Personal Health
description: Will waiting until your 30's or beyond to have your first baby impair the chances that it will be healthy or jeopardize your own health?

title: Review/Music; 'Madama Butterfly' at City Opera
description: ''Madama Butterfly'' is one of the works with which the New York City Opera has felt most at home in recent seasons. The story is so affecting and direct that no one has been tempted to trick it up with added luridness; the company's young singers have often been able to find their way to the hearts of the characters; the orchestra plays Puccini better than Verdi or Mozart; the opera works theatrically even if, say, the small-part singers mug and exaggerate instead of playing in character. Sunday afternoon's performance (the first of the season) conveyed the drama movingly; surely no eye was dry when Butterfly brought out her little boy, Trouble, in heartbreaking triumph in Act II.

title: Natural Gas Bill Is Passed
description: The House passed and sent to the White House today a bill to end Federal price controls on natural gas by Jan. 1, 1993.

title: Topics of The Times; When to Register: Now
description: More and more New Yorkers are starting to get interested in one of their most provocative municipal elections in years - but interest alone won't take them far if they can't vote. Voting requires registering, and time is about to run out. Tomorrow. That's the registration deadline for the Sept. 12 primaries.

title: Panel Rejects Fusion Claim, Urging No Federal Spending
description: A panel of experts convened by the Federal Government concluded yesterday that the prospects of producing energy with low-temperature nuclear fusion are quite remote and that no new laboratories should be built by the Government or private groups to study the disputed phenomenon.

title: Consolidated Paper reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Tommy Tucker Dead; Band Leader Was 86
description: Tommy Tucker, a big-band leader of the 1940's, died Tuesday. He was 86 years old and lived in Sarasota.

title: Washington Talk; Politics
description: The civil rights era of the 1960's is commonly referred to as the second Reconstruction, a name drawn from the first Reconstruction after the Civil War, when Congress passed and northern troops enforced a series of civil rights laws aimed at granting full citizenship to black Americans.

title: Exxon Valdez Is Towed in Circles As Officials Disagree on Her Leak
description: As the crippled Exxon Valdez was being towed backward in small slow circles off the coast of San Diego, Exxon and Coast Guard officials disagreed today on why the tanker had sprung a new leak here after the company had given assurances she was empty and clean when she left Alaska last month for repairs.

title: Bruins Hire Sator
description: Almost a month after being let go as head coach of the Buffalo Sabres, Ted Sator has been hired by the Boston Bruins as an assistant coach, joining the staff of the new head coach, Mike Milbury.

title: Ex-Helmsley Executive Testifies on a False-Invoice Scheme
description: The former chief engineer of Helmsley-Spear Inc. testified yesterday that Leona Helmsley berated him after he refused to participate in a false-invoice scheme.

title: Argument in Rose Case
description: Control of Pete Rose's legal battle with A. Bartlett Giamatti, the baseball commissioner, should remain in Federal Court because of pressures generated by Rose's fame in Cincinnati, baseball attorneys said today.

title: People
description: * Doug Shores has been promoted to senior vice president of corporate development of the Weightman Group, Philadelphia.

title: Baker's Four Blunders
description: At Karl Marx U. in Hungary, President Bush displayed his competence in enunciating a policy of daring prudence; meantime in the Middle East, the Bush State Department has displayed a depth of professional ineptitude not seen in seven years.

title: BRIEFS
description: * CCL Industries Inc., said it would buy all the outstanding shares and convertible debentures of Hi-Port Industries Inc., a liquid products packager, for $12.50 a share, a total of $30 million.

title: Currents; Intricate Backwoods Carvings
description: JANIS NORI-BERTUCCI had been selling antiques at flea markets and shows around the country for 10 years when she decided a few months ago to settle down and open American Pastime, an emporium on the ground floor and basement of 240 Lafayette Street in Manhattan, between Spring and Prince Streets in SoHo.

title: FEE FOR LOBBYING H.U.D. IS DISCLOSED
description: A real estate partnership owned by the principals of a prominent political consulting firm was paid $47,000 in 1984 to secure Federal housing subsidies for a low-income housing project in Waterbury, Conn., one of the principals said today.

title: Accounting Board Delays Tax Ruling
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board postponed yesterday for the second time the deadline for adopting an unpopular ruling that changes the ways companies report their income tax expense to shareholders.

title: Tommy Trinder Dies; British Comic Was 80
description: Tommy Trinder, a comedian whose irreverent wit endeared him to generations of Britons, died Monday at St. Peter's Hospital in Chertsey, west of London. He was 80 years old. Mr. Trinder made his London debut at the age of 13. He became a favorite at London clubs, theaters and dance halls, and in 1938 made the first of many appearances at the Palladium. During World War II, he entertained British soldiers all over the world, and later toured the United States.

title: Chrysler Agrees to Promotions for Minorities
description: The Chrysler Corporation has pledged to increase opportunities for women and members of minorities for management positions.

title: Valley Victory Favored in Trot
description: Valley Victory, undefeated in five starts this year, is the 3-5 favorite in the $418,810 Yonkers Trot, the opening leg of the triple crown for trotters, Saturday night at Yonkers Raceway.

title: Israel Says It Will Reopen West Bank Schools
description: Israel announced today that it would reopen West Bank schools, which have been closed almost continuously since just after the start of the Palestinian uprising in December 1987.

title: Cornering Markets Past, From Silver to Salad Oil
description: The events yesterday at the Chicago Board of Trade raised the specter that there might have been an attempt to corner the market in soybeans. While the main company believed to be responsible for the Board of Trade's action said it had made its purchases for legitimate business purposes, the hectic events brought back memories of a number of efforts that have been made to corner markets in commodities.

title: Panel Backs $11.4 Billion in Salvador Aid
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved an $11.4 billion foreign aid bill today that would increase military aid to El Salvador but reject an Administration request for covert military aid to the non-Communist resistance in Cambodia.

title: Novametrix Medical reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: Federal National Mortgage Assn reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company's provision for loan losses in the latest second quarter was $80 million, compared with $95 million a year ago. The loan loss provision for the latest six months was $160 million, compared with $190 million in the year-ago period.

title: Soviets Plan to Publish Full 'Gulag Archipelago'
description: Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn's ''Gulag Archipelago'' is to be published in full by a Soviet publishing house, the editor of Novy Mir said today.

title: Aid With Leverage; Bush Borrows Wall St. Techniques To Cut Cost of Package for Poland
description: In the best capitalist tradition, President Bush's economic aid plan for Poland borrows some tried and true Wall Street techniques and transfers them into the arena of East-West relations. One is the notion of

title: Mets Upbeat Amid Injuries And Pitching Problems
description: The Mets, contrary to conventional wisdom, haven't lost any of their arrogance. It hasn't become less vocal, just more curious. Their clubhouse last weekend was still full of a certain haughty pride, still stocked with boasts and toasts.

title: Exiles Urge Trade Sanctions Against Beijing
description: A group of Chinese exiles issued an open letter today asking world leaders gathered in Paris to impose economic sanctions on China and to aid ''combatants for democracy who are victims of repression.''

title: Big Goals and Hurdles For New Chip Maker
description: Analysts surveying the ambitious plans of U.S. Memories Inc. say that even if it meets its growth targets, the computer-memory chip maker could still fall short of its main goal of significantly reducing American dependence on Japanese chip companies.

title: Perfectdata Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Playgrounds Shaped By Today's Urban Concerns
description: FOR the sandbox set, there are no lazy days of summer: this is the peak season in the playground.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-11 NATO has reached an agreement on the type of fighter aircraft it wants to include in conventional-arms talks with the Warsaw Pact, Secretary of State Baker announced. Page A1 President Bush extended support to Hungary's efforts toward political and economic change with a series of financial measures. He also announced that Peace Corps volunteers would be sent to Hungary. A1 A rise in Soviet emigration to the U.S. is expected under a law now being drafted that would lift longstanding restrictions on who can leave the Soviet Union. A1 For the Anglo-Soviet space mission, named Juno, the Soviet Union has turned to the world's largest advertising agency for help in exploiting commercial opportunities. A1 In Eastern Europe, President Bush has seen a world full of contrasts. Where Poland is drab and subdued, Hungary is the opposite. A10 In Hungary, Barbara Bush traveled to Tahitofalu, a village 45 minutes outside the capital to see a Hungarian version of ''a thousand points of light.'' A10 Soviet psychiatric hospitals are still ''unduly harsh and restrictive,'' patients are ''denied basic rights'' and doctors sometimes use drugs to punish patients, an official delegation of American experts reports. A3 Leningrad's Communist leader, who suffered a humiliating defeat in elections in March, was removed from his party post and replaced by a 56-year-old chemical engineer. A8 To calm the restive Argentine Army, President Carlos Saul Menem has named as Chief of Staff a man favored by dissident officers who led three barracks rebellions. A5 Nelson Mandela made a statement saying that the Government could bring peace to South Africa only if it entered into discussions with the anti-apartheid movement, particularly the African National Congress. A3 Paris is about to have a huge party. But sometimes it feels more as if it is about to go to war because of the preparations for the summit and the bicentennial celebrations. A8 National A12-21 Losses in a co-insurance program at the Federal Housing Administration are double the original estimate, Federal authorities and auditors say, making the mortgage agency the most troubled part of H.U.D. A1 In the H.U.D. inquiry, Carla Hills, the United States Trade Representative and a former Federal housing Secretary, will be called to testify about her lobbying. A21 Producing energy with ''cold'' fusion is quite unlkely, and no new facilities should be built by the Government or private groups to study the phenomenon, experts concluded. A1 Prices on soybean futures contracts plunged, the first day after the Chicago Board of Trade issued an emergency order directing buyers and sellers of the contract to liquidate their positions. A1 The House held a seminar on art, with conservative Republicans accusing the National Endowment for the Arts of offending the taxpayers with the taxpayers' money. A18 Rev. Stallings was rebuffed by the 13 black Roman Catholic bishops in the United States for trying to establish a separate African-American congregation in Washington. A12 Executions of retarded inmates, authorized by the Supreme Court last month, is raising complex issues in two Southern states that had scheduled the deaths of two such murderers this week. A12 Why the Valdez sprung a new leak was debated between Exxon and Coast Guard officials. Exxon had given assurances that the tanker was empty and clean when she left Alaska last month for repairs. A13 Before the N.A.A.C.P., Dan Quayle sought to soften the sting of recent Supreme Court decisions on affirmative action by defending the Bush Administration's record and commitment to fairness. A17 Washington Talk A20 To reduce U.S. troops in Korea, the Pentagon has embarked on a reassessment of United States military deployments in East Asia. Is the second Reconstruction coming to an end? Regional B1-4 A smokable mix of crack and heroin is emerging as a dangerous trend among New York City's nearly one million chronic drug abusers, drug officials said. A1 Richard Ravitch is not well known, despite his years of public service. Until his television commercials begin airing, the mayoral candidate will have to rely mainly on pressing the flesh. B1 New Jersey's $12 billion budget will affect the state's 7.6 million residents almost immediately. Broad drastic cuts will change the ways residents live and work. B1 Pickpockets are busy in the summer in New York City when crowds swell and pockets, unobscured by winter coats, are easier to get to. A mustard chucker, for instance, sprays a victim with mustard. B1 Thirteen people were indicted on charges they conspired to defraud a federally subsidized housing program in the Town of Brookhaven. The indictments involve a Brookhaven program called Save-a-House. B1 Two state troopers were shot in Valley Cottage, N.Y., by a man posing as a Federal treasury agent who had called for police assistance. Neither trooper was seriously wounded. B2 In Hamden, Conn., the storm that raked the New York City area injured 100 people but killed no one. It did, however, destroy at least 200 homes and businesses and left at least 100 people homeless. B2 A Hunter College official was killed by a woman, disguised by a black wig and sunglasses, who shot him as he arrived at work on the campus yesterday morning. B3 In the trial of Leona Helmsley, the former chief engineer of Helmsley-Spear Inc. testified that Mrs. Helmsley berated him after he refused to participate in a false-invoice scheme. B3

title: White of Cowboys Announces Retirement
description: Danny White, who spent 14 years in the National Football League and was the Dallas Cowboys' starting quarterback for most of the 1980's, retired yesterday at the age of 37. White was injured during the last three seasons and did not start a game in 1988.

title: House Panel Sets Shape of A Tax Bill
description: The House Ways and Means Committee tentatively approved today the outline of a tax bill that would not affect the taxes paid by most individuals but would raise the $5.3 billion necessary to meet next year's budget target.

title: House Panel to Call Ex-Chief of H.U.D.
description: The chairman of a House panel investigating mismanagement in Federal housing programs said he would call Carla A. Hills, the United States Trade Representative, to testify about her lobbying on behalf of a mortage concern and a developer. The move to call Mrs. Hills, a former Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, seemed to signal a more adversarial approach by the chairman, Representative Tom Lantos, a California Democrat.

title: Viren Will Compete
description: Lasse Viren of Finland, who won gold medals in the 5,000 and 10,000-meter runs at both the Munich Olympic Games of 1972 and the Montreal Games of 1976, will celebrate his 40th birthday on July 22 by competing in the Masters Mile at Columbia University's Wien Stadium as part of the New York Track and Field Games. The event will be Viren's first Masters race and he will be aiming for the over-40 world record of 4 minutes 5.37 seconds.

title: Nets Sign Blaylock To Pact For 4 Years
description: The Nets yesterday signed Mookie Blaylock, their first-round choice in the National Basketball Association draft, to a four-year contract worth more than $2 million.

title: Nadler Announces His Bid for Comptroller
description: Using Boss Tweed's Courthouse as the setting to call his opponents proteges of modern political bosses, Assemblyman Jerrold L. Nadler announced yesterday what has been known for months - that he is a candidate for New York City Comptroller.

title: Of Course, Oil Spills Can Be Prevented
description: To the Editor:

title: T.V.A. Bond Sale To Reduce Debt
description: The Tennessee Valley Authority, the largest electric power system in the nation, said today that it would sell bonds to reduce $6.5 billion in debt owed to the Treasury.

title: Ticket for Canesco
description: Jose Canseco, the Oakland Athletics outfielder, received his fourth speeding ticket of the year on Tuesday, the police in Castro Valley, Calif., said yesterday. Canseco, riding alone in a new convertible that still had paper license plates, was pulled over and ticketed for driving 51 miles per hour in a 35 mile-an-hour zone, said Nick Verhoek, a California Highway Patrol spokesman. The speeding ticket was Canseco's second on Crow Canyon Road, which runs between his home in San Ramon and the Castro Valley-Hayward area.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Would you like to have your company's name on a Russian rocket when it goes up? We can write a contract to do that. We can endorse products for the Soviet space program. We can put signage up at the launch site.'' - Art Dula, president of the Space Commerce Corporation of Houston. [ A1:4. ]

title: G.M. Dealers Get Quota Incentives
description: The General Motors Corporation said it had begun a dealer incentive program in addition to previously announced consumer rebates that could mean up to $1,000 a car to dealers who exceed sales quotas.

title: Student Loan Marketing Assoc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SunTrust Banks Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SJNB Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Southwest Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $207,000 and $366,000 from the benefit of a tax loss carryforward for the quarter and 6 months, rjespectively. c-Net loss

title: Planters Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
No School, No License
description: West Virginia has a blunt message for teen-agers: If you want to drive a car, stay in school. A new state law lifts the driver's license of any student who drops out of school. It's a promising tactic worth a sympathetic look elsewhere. But it's also only a tactic. To conquer the complicated dropout problem, states and school districts need to create educational environments that nurture a desire to learn.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums THE WIZARD OF OZ, a musical presented by the Theater Workshop, 2 P.M. Saturdays, at the Fantasy Playhouse, 317 Merrick Road, Lynbrook, L.I. Tickets: $5; reservations required. Information: (516) 599-1982. THE INTREPID, the aircraft carrier sea-and-air space museum, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. daily with the last tour at 4 P.M., at Pier 86, at 46th Street. Admission: children, $2.50, the elderly, $4; others, $4.75. Information: 245-2533. 46TH ANNUAL CHILDREN'S ART EXHIBITION, by children in the New York metropolitan area and in Israel, with the theme ''We Want a Perfect World, Not a Wasteland,'' Central Queens Y Fine Arts Gallery, 67-09 108th Street, Forest Hills, 8:45 A.M. to 6:45 P.M. Sundays, 9 A.M. to 9:45 P.M. Mondays through Thursdays and 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. Fridays. Through Aug. 27. Admission: free. Information: (718) 268-5011. BOSCOBEL RESTORATION, the restored 18th-century home of States Morris Dyckman, surrounded by fruit groves and gardens, open 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. daily except Tuesdays; last tour, 4:15 P.M. In Garrison-on-Hudson, N.Y. Admission: children, 6 to 14, $2.50; under 6 free; the elderly, $4; others, $5. Information and directions: (914) 265-3638. NEW CANAAN (CONN.) NATURE CENTER, a 40-acre site, with trails open from sunrise to sunset, exhibition buildings and greenhouses, open 9:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Tuesdays through Saturdays and 12:30 to 4:30 P.M. Sundays, at Oenoke Ridge Road (Route 24). Free. Information and directions: (203) 966-9577. ''THE RED SHOES,'' a story by Hans Christian Andersen, told by Carol Lewis, and ''The Collar,'' also by Mr. Andersen, told by Marcia Lane, 11 A.M. tomorrow at the Hans Christian Andersen statue in Central Park, 72d Street and Fifth Avenue. Free. MYSTIC SEAPORT, a 17-acre outdoor maritime museum with historic ships, boats, exhibition buildings and two restaurants, in Mystic, Conn. 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. daily. Admission: children under 5, free; 5 to 18, $6.25, and adults, $12.50. Information and directions: (203) 572-0711. ''PINOCCHIO,'' by the Puppetworks, noon Saturdays and 1 and 3 P.M. Sundays, at 287 Third Avenue, at Carroll Street, Park Slope, Brooklyn. Children, $4; adults, $5. Reservations required: (718) 834-1828.

title: Plea to Europe on Air Traffic
description: International airline officials, warning that air traffic congestion in Europe is getting out of control, are calling on governments to make a major political commitment to tackle the problem.

title: Review/Ballet; Students Of Bolshoi On Tour In U.S.
description: Russians everywhere! Just as the Kirov Ballet from Leningrad had settled into the Metropolitan Opera House in New York for the first time in 25 years, a group of students from the school of its traditional rival in Moscow, the Bolshoi Ballet, embarked on a United States tour.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''If we don't do something, I fear that Americans, and especially veterans groups, are going to stop the desecration of the flag in their own way and people are going to get hurt.'' - Representative G. V. (Sonny) Montgomery, Democrat of Mississippi. [ B6:2. ]

title: LEADERS IN PARIS ARGUE OVER CHINA
description: Leaders of the world's seven most powerful democracies gathered in Paris today for their 15th annual economic summit meeting, to be held in the afterglow of France's 200th birthday bash, and fell at once to arguing over how far they should go in condemning China for bloodily crushing student-led protests with troops and tanks.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly AD HOC COMMITTEE ON INDIAN OCEAN - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. TRADE LAW COMMISSION WORKING GROUP ON INTERNATIONAL PAYMENTS - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: McCaw Might Raise Takeover Bid for Lin
description: McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. said yesterday that it might raise its bid for the Lin Broadcasting Corporation to $127.50 a share, or about $6.7 bilion.

title: Soviet Arms Official Criticizes West's Plans
description: As the Vienna negotiations on reducing conventional arms in Europe began their summer break, the chief Soviet negotiator today criticized the Western proposals.

title: About Real Estate; Co-op Converters Start To Rent in Slowdown
description: A growing number of cooperative and condominium converters in New Jersey have begun to rent rather than sell their swelling inventory of vacant units, reflecting the continued slowdown in residential sales that has especially affected that state's conversion market.

title: New Sudan Leader Is Sending Mixed Signals on Ending War
description: The new Sudanese military leader has sent conflicting signals about whether and how he intends to resolve the six-year civil war that has brought famine to most of the southern Sudan.

title: Equipment Divides Marlboro Challengers
description: When the two dozen or so drivers line up for the Marlboro Grand Prix at the Meadowlands on Sunday, no more than 10 will have a realistic chance of winning. For some of the rest, victory comes in other forms.

title: 2d Drug Test Urged
description: Gene Upshaw, executive director of the N.F.L. Players Association, said yesterday that the union was dissatisfied with the league's drug-testing program and called for double testing of urine samples, by the league and also by a laboratory approved by the players. ''Players have no confidence in this program and the way the league administers it,'' Upshaw said. The league testing procedure has been in place since 1980.

title: Fewer Jobless in Britain
description: Britain's unemployment rate fell to a seasonally adjusted 6.3 percent in June from 6.4 percent in May, the Government said today. The latest rate was the lowest since October 1980, and it compared with 8.1 percent in June 1988, the Department of Employment said. The number of jobless people fell 26,500. The number of unemployed, without seasonal adjustment, was 1.74 million people in June, compared with 1.80 million in May and 2.34 million a year ago.

title: Inspector Barred On Principle
description: A New York City environmental inspector was not allowed to check a report of improper asbestos removal at the United Nations on Tuesday because the inspector had not received permission in advance, a United Nations official said today. ''If the environmental department had phoned us first, we probably would have let the chap in right away,'' said Richard Foran, Assistant Secretary-General for General Services. ''But it's a matter of principle. The United Nations is considered international territory and therefore outside the city's jurisdiction.

title: Cuts Urged In Deposit Insurance
description: The chairman of Citicorp today recommended that Congress gradually reduce the level of deposit insurance to 85 to 90 percent of what the Government currently offers, in an effort to force depositors to judge whether banks and savings institutions are taking risks with their money.

title: Time Ruling Is Due Today; Chris-Craft Files Two Suits
description: The Delaware Chancery Court is expected to rule today on a lawsuit by Paramount Communications Inc. that seeks to block Time Inc.'s $14 billion offer for Warner Communications Inc.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in some copies yesterday about Soviet youth gangs in Kazan located the city incorrectly. It is in the European part of the Soviet Union, not Asia.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Three Top Executives Promoted by Rockwell
description: LEAD: The Rockwell International Corporation announced a major corporate revamping yesterday, promoting three senior executives to the newly created position of chief operating officer. The move, in effect, gives the company three presidents.

title: Righetti Balks
description: Even though the corner locker in the Yankee clubhouse has been passed from Ron Guidry to Dave Righetti with Guidry's retirement, it remained unused yesterday.

title: Sun Sets Up Cost Controls
description: Sun Microsystems Inc., facing what could be its first loss, has instituted tight cost controls, a company spokeswoman, Carol Broadbent, said today.

title: Dinkins Raises Idea of Tax Shift, Drawing Rivals' Quick Criticism
description: David N. Dinkins, a Democratic candidate for mayor, said yesterday that he was considering a proposal to cut sales taxes in New York City to make retail businesses more competitive. The income tax would be raised to make up for the loss of revenue.

title: WASHINGTON TALKJustice
description: Robert H. Bork is almost everywhere these days: on the morning television news programs the evening commentary programs, the lecture circuit and the op-ed pages. In fact, it sometimes appears that the only place the former Federal judge is not, is on the Supreme Court, and it is clear that his admirers are still in no mood to forgive anyone who played a part in denying him confirmation to the Court two years ago.

title: Canseco Back in Style As Athletics Beat Jays
description: Jose Canseco, returning to the Oakland lineup tonight, hit a home run and stole a base, and Mark McGwire and Dave Parker hit homers as the Athletics beat the Toronto Blue Jays, 11-7.

title: Devils' Sauve Retires
description: Bob Sauve, a goaltender who spent the last 2 of his 12 National Hockey League seasons with the Devils, announced his retirement yesterday at the age of 34 because of recurring back problems.

title: The Other Side of That Third Fight
description: Sugar Ray Leonard invited Thomas Hearns to return for a third match so that each can once again work like archeologists to dislodge the other from his senses.

title: Correction Officer Indicted In Death of Rikers Inmate
description: A 26-year-old New York City correction officer was indicted yesterday in the death of an inmate who was struck on the head with a flashlight during a disturbance on Rikers Island.

title: 1789, Avec Cookies And Milk
description: LEAD: The French Revolution came to Arlington, Mass. the other day.

title: USAir Drops Deal at Eastern
description: USAir Inc. said it had withdrawn its offer to buy $376 million in assets from the embattled Eastern Airlines Inc. In a Securities and Exchange

title: Weighing In With Conferees on Bailout Bill
description: Most, when asked, say they have never seen anything quite like it on Capitol Hill.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Williams in the Park

title: Two Testify on Being Pressured Over False Invoices for Helmsleys
description: Leona and Harry B. Helmsley personally approved the use of business funds for their house in Greenwich, Conn., two witnesses testified yesterday.

title: Lockheed Net Declines 27%
description: The Lockheed Corporation today reported a 27 percent drop in earnings and a 3 percent decline in revenues in the second quarter after taking $27 million in write-offs on three programs.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in some editions yesterday about a Senate committee's action on a foreign aid bill misstated the proposed amount of aid to El Salvador. It is $90 million.

title: Mercantile Exchange And President Part
description: Responding to pressure from the board of the New York Mercantile Exchange, Rosemary T. McFadden resigned yesterday as president of the futures exchange.

title: Dibble Fined $400 And Suspended 3 Days
description: Rob Dibble, the uninhibited Cincinnati relief pitcher, paid three times over yesterday for his lost weekend in New York. Dibble ($400) was one of four players fined by Bill White, the National League president, for the fight the Reds and the Mets engaged in during their game at Shea Stadium last Saturday. Tim Teufel ($200) and Juan Samuel ($200) of the Mets and Norm Charlton ($100) of the Reds were also fined.

title: Isosceles Holds 51% of Gateway
description: Isosceles P.L.C. asserted yesterday that it had won control of the Gateway Corporation, Britain's third-largest food chain.

title: 3 Gunmen Shoot 9 People in Stamford
description: Three armed men opened fire on a crowded West Side street here Wednesday night, wounding nine people, and then led the police on a 12-mile chase through Darien and into New Canaan.

title: Thompson of Illinois Says He Isn't Seeking a 5th Term as Governor
description: James R. Thompson, who has served longer than any other current Governor, announced here today that he would not seek election next year to a fifth consecutive term as Governor of Illinois.

title: Counterfeit Cache Is Seized
description: Secret Service agents seized $1 million in counterfeit $100 bills on Tuesday and arrested a man they said had produced the bills using a photocopier. Richard Perez, 39 years old, could face up to 15 years in prison if convicted of counterfeiting, Agent Don Tucker said. Mr. Perez was arrested after trying to negotiate with an undercover agent to buy 500 pounds of marijuana with the counterfeit money, Mr. Tucker said.

title: Coca-Cola Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said that during the quarter, it repurchased 4.5 million shares, bringing the total amount repurchased under its current program to 35 million shares. Results for 1988 have been restated to reflect the consolidation of Coca- Cola Financial Corporation, a finance subsidiary previously accounted for under the equity method of accounting, due to adoption of FASB Statement No. 94, Consolidation of All Majority-owned Subsidiaries. The restatement had no effect on previously reported net income or net income per common share. CPC International Inc(N) Qtr to June 30 1989 1988 Sales 1,255,447,000 1,225,978,000 Net inc 83,129,000 72,002,000 Share earns 1.06 .91 6mo sales 2,518,613,000 2,308,294,000 Net inc 150,780,000 129,959,000 Share earns 1.92 1.64 The company said operating income from worldwide consumer foods operations increased 7.6 percent in the second quarter and 10.5 percent in the first half over comparable periods last year.

title: Gun Import Ban Enriches Small U.S. Arms Makers
description: The Bush Adminstration's ban on imports of military-style assault rifles has created a bonanza for some small and medium-sized American gun manufacturers, which are selling semiautomatic weapons as fast as their assembly lines can make them.

title: HUNGARIANS MOURN PASSING OF KADAR
description: Tens of thousands of Hungarians of all ages and from all over this country filed past the coffin of Janos Kadar today, in a surprising and spontaneous outpouring of mourning for a leader who died a week ago in virtual disgrace among his colleagues.

title: A Cup of Tea for Mandela: Is the Overture Sincere or Is It Merely Politics?
description: Most South Africans would find it hard to imagine their country's white head of state sitting down with its most prominent black political prisoner and asking solicitously how many lumps of sugar he takes in his tea.

title: Nielsen Establishes Record In New York Open Victory
description: Lonnie Nielsen, the leader after all three rounds, won the $65,000 Michelob New York State Open by four strokes today and achieved three distinctions in doing so.

title: U.S. WOULD ADD 52 TO WASTE SITE LIST
description: The Environmental Protection Agency proposed today that 52 Federal installations, mostly of them run by the Defense and Energy departments, be added to the list of the nation's most serious hazardous waste sites.

title: Wedtech Prosecutor Seeks to Tar Meese Stature as Defense Witness
description: The prosecutor in the Wedtech racketeering trial of E. Robert Wallach and two others sought yesterday to undermine the credibility of former Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d as a witness for the defense.

title: Cycling for a Cleaner Image
description: Andy Hampsten would like to win the Tour de France for most of the usual reasons, including fame and fortune, and for a special purpose, as well: to speak out against the use of drugs in a sport bedeviled by them.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Unexpectedly, Koch Declares His Candidacy
description: Although he has been campaigning for weeks, Mayor Edward I. Koch finally made his candidacy official yesterday, catching even his closest advisers by surprise.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Philip L. Balshi and Peter S. Kellogg have been named senior vice presidents of Lintas USA.

title: Senate Votes to Ease Immigration For Professionals and Europeans
description: The Senate today approved an overhaul of the nation's immigration laws aimed at guaranteeing more visas for skilled workers with no family ties in the United States and at increasing immigration from Western Europe.

title: Cheney Takes On L.I. Lobby in F-14 Dispute
description: What began as a quiet lobbying effort by the Grumman Corporation and Congressmen from Long Island to save the F-14 fighter has erupted into a test of wills with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney.

title: Review/Pop; Willie Nelson at a Revamped Pier 84
description: Red, white and blue are the colors of the relentlessly promotional new Reebok Riverstage on Pier 84, which opened on Wednesday night with a concert by the country singer Willie Nelson. Radio City Music Hall, which produces the concerts, has turned around the old Pier 84 setup, placing the stage so the audience faces the river (and the sunset), and the 8,000 seats, at pier level and in bleachers, are now all reserved - both improvements. The sound for Mr. Nelson's low-key band was clear and full.

title: Ex-Official Indicted in Thefts From Bellevue
description: A former director of transportation at Bellevue Hospital Center was indicted yesterday in Manhattan on charges of stealing more than $13,000 from the hospital from 1986 to 1988.

title: Court Upholds Soybean Ruling
description: A Federal District judge today upheld an emergency order by the Chicago Board of Trade to curb trading in soybean futures contracts. The ruling was a setback to Ferruzzi Finanziaria S.p.A., an Italian conglomerate that faces multimillion-dollar losses as a result of the order by the world's largest commodity exchange.

title: To Fight Crime: A Police Corps
description: How do cities beset by drug violence and tight budgets field enough police to secure the streets? Too often, they can't. Sometimes drug gangs seize control of whole neighborhoods or housing projects. Even cities that can afford to hire find it hard to attract recruits capable of handling what has become one of the most demanding jobs in America.

title: Earnings Jump at Bank of New York
description: Bolstered by its November 1988 acquisition of the Irving Bank Corporation, the Bank of New York yesterday reported a strong gain in second-quarter earnings.

title: Search for Schools Chancellor Widens
description: The committee seeking a new New York City schools chancellor has expanded its search to include several candidates who have never run urban school systems, education officials said.

title: Review/Film; Dalton as a Brooding Bond In 'License to Kill'
description: When Sean Connery was James Bond, a time many still consider the Golden Age, he was smoother than a dry martini, faster than an Aston Martin, practically able to leap from tall buildings and land in a woman's bed. His sardonic secret agent for the 1960's gave way to Roger Moore's infinitely more urbane Bond; the Moore 007 always seemed more comfortable sipping Dom Perignon than a shaken-not-stirred martini.
