And now Timothy Dalton promises to become the first James Bond with angst, a moody spy for the fin de siecle.

title: TV Weekend; A Program Takes a Look at Unpleasant Issues
description: While not quite flourishing, independent film and video productions are decidedly active on public television these days. The content ranges from the culture-oriented essays of ''American Masters'' to the art explorations of ''Alive From Off Center'' to the social investigations of ''P.O.V.,'' which returns next week for a second summer season. Not to be overlooked in the hubbub is ''Independent Focus,'' celebrated by Channel 13 as New York's longest-running broadcast forum for independent film and video.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Education page on June 21 about high school reading lists misidentified the executive director of the National Council of Teachers of English. He is John C. Maxwell, not Richard Maxwell.

title: Trucking Executive Indicted In a Scheme to Evade Taxes
description: A businessman, described by the authorities as the owner of a Brooklyn trucking concern, was indicted yesterday for evading payment of more than $10 million in personal income taxes.

title: Sun Electric's Stock Plunges $6
description: Shares of the Sun Electric Corporation plunged $6 today, to $18.625, after the company disclosed that it had received ''no satisfactory'' takeover proposals. The stock had traded as low as $17 and 24.4 percent drop was the largest on the New York Stock Exchange. Sun Electric, an automotive test-equipment manufacturer based in Crystal Lake, Ill., said it plans to continue as a public company, thus ending its informal auction.

title: Holyfield, Rodrigues Short on Verbal Jabs
description: As a rhetorical battle, Evander Holyfield vs. Adilson Rodrigues does not stack up with Lincoln vs. Douglas.

title: Peres Aide Says P.L.O. And Israel Are Dealing
description: An aide to Shimon Peres, the Labor Party leader, said today that Israel was conducting ''clear, official and unequivocal'' negotiations with the P.L.O. via intermediaries from the United States and other countries.

title: Dexter Nukes Heads Rich Pace
description: Dexter Nukes, who recorded the fastest winning time in the eliminations last week, will try to score his second big victory of the year when he heads a field of 10 in the final of the $852,000 Meadowlands Pace for 3-year-olds on Friday night.

title: Tax Panel Takes Step On Interest
description: Completing a $5.3 billion package of revenue-raising measures, the House Ways and Means Committee proposed today to speed up repeal of the interest deduction on consumer loans.

title: Democrats Agree to Effort To Reduce Medicare Surtax
description: The Democratic majority on the House Ways and Means Committee agreed today to try to reduce the surtax that many older Americans pay to insure against the cost of prolonged illness.

title: New York Area Retail Sales Up
description: Several of New York's largest retailers yesterday reported moderate sales increases in June from the period a year earlier. The retailers reported average gains of 1.9 percent in the city and 4.6 percent in the metropolitan area.

title: Books of The Times; A Scholarly Crusader for Fran Liszt
description: Franz Liszt Volume II The Weimar Years 1848-1861 By Alan Walker 626 pages. Illustrated. Alfred A. Knopf.

title: 10-Year Notes Offered by Xerox
description: The Xerox Corporation is offering $200 million of notes due in 1999 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Yonkers Rejects Compromise
description: The Yonkers City Council last night rejected a compromise budget that would have allocated $24 million to build two schools as part of a court-ordered desegregation plan.

title: FRANCE CELEBRATES A DAY OF HISTORY
description: As if to make Paris again the center of the world, Francois Mitterrand today presided over the opening of a week of ceremony to mark the bicentennial of one of the pivotal events of history, the French Revolution.

title: Art Exhibitions Celebrate France's Turning Point
description: IT may well be that the French Revolution inspires more unadulterated enthusiasm among Americans than it does among the French, who have tended to view 1789 and its stormy aftermath with a skeptical eye. Parisians reportedly have reacted laconically to this year's wide array of bicentennial celebrations, perhaps in part because there is nothing like a consensus concerning the monarchy, the Terror, Napoleon or even the extent to which the storming of the Bastille, 200 years ago today, furthered the cause of the working class.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Sonic Youth at the Ritz

title: 3 Young Stars and Their Paths to the Kirov
description: It is their one day off. But the three young Soviet ballerinas sitting in the lobby of a midtown Manhattan hotel one recent Sunday morning are not about to go off sightseeing or on a shopping spree. Instead, it will be a day of class and rehearsal, for New York is an important stop on the Kirov Ballet's North American tour. And Zhanna Ayupova, Veronika Ivanova and Yuliya Makhalina seem destined for magical futures. But ballet magic requires long, hard work.

title: U.S. PREPARES LOAN TO ENABLE MEXICO TO MEET PAYMENTS
description: Eager to breathe some life into its third-world debt policy on the eve of the seven-nation economic summit conference, officials of the Bush Administration said today that they were preparing to grant Mexico a short-term loan of $1 billion to $2 billion.

title: Auctions
description: Mapplethorpe Sale

title: Sidney Hook, Political Philosopher, Is Dead at 86
description: Sidney Hook, a major American philosopher who wrote many books on Marxism, public policy and education, died of congestive heart failure Wednesday at Stanford University Hospital in Stanford, Calif. He was 86 years old and lived on the university campus.

title: Dining Out Guide: Hot and Spicy
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. Arizona 206 *** (March 24, 1989), 206 East 60th Street (838-0440) - A source for peerless Southwestern cooking has taken root on East 60th Street in this restaurant where diners indulge a taste for chili-fired creations. Arizona 206's current menu offers appetizers of Southwestern Peking duck with plum mole sauce, and red-chili corn cakes with pumpkin-seed pesto and creme fraiche. Rib eye of lamb, a recommended entree, is nicely smoky and served with a smoldering tomato chili sauce. Among new entrees are achiote pan-seared Louisiana shrimp and crab meat gumbo, and charred split baby chicken with Hatch chili sauce. At lunch, appetizers are $6 to $9, entrees $13 to $18; at dinner, appetizers are $6 to $13, entrees $21 to $27. Lunch: noon to 3 P.M. Monday to Saturday; dinner: 6 to 11 P.M. daily. Bukhara ** (March 17, 1989), 148 East 48th Street, in the Helmsley Middletowne Hotel (838-1811) - Eating with the hands is a tradition encouraged at this restaurant specializing in India's frontier cuisine, which is actually derived from the Pathan people of Pakistan. (Flatware is provided on request.) Many of the dishes are marinated in yogurt, spices and herbs and cooked in a superhot oven, the tandoor. Cubes of lamb, aromatic of ginger and cumin (barah kebab); rolls of minced lamb spiked with hot pepper and cumin (seekh kebab), and a chicken dish (murgh malai) infused with garlic, ginger and potent fresh coriander are good main courses. All tandoor-baked breads are recommended. Appetizers are $3.95 to $4.25, entrees $11.25 to $16.95. Lunch: noon to 3 P.M. Monday to Friday; buffet ($14.95): 11:30 A.M. to 2:30 P.M. Saturday and Sunday; dinner: 6 to 11 P.M. daily. Chin Chin ** (Oct. 16, 1987), 216 East 49th Street (888-4555) - The Chin brothers run a stylish and strikingly designed restaurant serving ''uptown'' Chinese cooking with a peppery Sichuan bent. The menu offers such savory items as cold egg noodles in hot sesame sauce; pepper-laced orange beef, and sliced leg of lamb with leeks and chili peppers. Seafood dishes include pan-fried soft-shell crabs in a Sichuan sauce, and jumbo prawns prepared with ginger, garlic, hot peppers and chili paste. Appetizers are $2 to $7, entrees $13 to $18. Open 11:30 A.M. to midnight Monday to Friday and 4:30 P.M. to midnight Saturday and Sunday. Pamir ** (Feb. 13, 1987), 1437 Second Avenue, at 75th Street (734-3791) - There is a mysterious charm to Pamir, a dimly lighted Afghan restaurant where Middle Eastern weavings, soft music and candles set the atmosphere. Coriander, cardamom and green chilies are used in Pamir's cooking, mostly based on lamb and vegetables. Recommended appetizers include scallion and herb-filled turnovers with a yogurt sauce, turnovers made with blazing-hot chili and coriander, and flat ravioli sauced with ground meat, yogurt and mint. Intriguing main courses are pilafs served with lamb stew, one with saffron, orange zest and pistachios and another brown rice, raisins and nuts. Appetizers are $2.75 to $2.95, entrees $9.75 to $14.95. Open 5 to 11 P.M. Tuesday to Sunday. Closed Monday. Tommy Tang's ** (Dec. 5, 1986), 323 Greenwich Street (334-9190) - Tommy Tang's unorthodox renditions of Thai cuisine and its lively social scene set it apart from many of New York's subdued, family-run Thai restaurants. The best of the dishes are intended to ambush the taste buds with volleys of hot peppers, mint and fresh ginger. Two examples of this complex style are spicy mint noodles with beef, and chili fish - red snapper fillet seasoned with pepper, garlic and Thai red peppercorns that is pan-fried and served with a Serrano chili, ginger and garlic sauce. Appetizers are $4.75 to $14.50, entrees $9 to $22. Lunch: 11:30 A.M. to 3 P.M. Monday to Friday; dinner: 6 to 11 P.M. Monday to Thursday, until midnight Friday and Saturday. Closed Sunday.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday DIVE-IN MOVIES

title: Papandreou Weds in Athens
description: Twenty-five days after his defeat in national elections, former Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou remarried today. Mr. Papandreou, 70 years old, and Dimitra Liani, 35, were married in a Greek Orthodox church in an Athens suburb. It was the third marriage for each.

title: U.S. Closes Study on Audi
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said today that it had closed a three-year investigation of sudden acceleration in Audi 5000 models, saying driver error was the main source of the problem.

title: Theologians in Europe Challenge Pope's Conservative Leadership
description: As divisions inside the Roman Catholic Church appear to deepen, dissident theologians across Western Europe have begun openly challenging the conservative teachings and highly centralized leadership of Pope John Paul II.

title: For the Globe's Sake, Debt Relief
description: Two years ago, the leaders of the Group of Seven nations offered invaluable support to the Central American peace initiative. Today I ask them to devote their attention to another set of urgent problems: the threat of tropical deforestation and the need to redirect development strategies toward a sustainable course.

title: Stricken Pilot Is Safe as Wandering Plane Crashes
description: A small private plane, its pilot apparently unconscious, raced down the East Coast on automatic controls for a thousand miles today as military jets and rescue craft scrambled in pursuit.

title: Child-Care Bill Aids Churches, Not Parents
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-7 A temporary U.S. loan to Mexico of between $1 billion and $2 billion will be granted, the Bush Administration said. The loan is contingent on an agreement between Mexico and its foreign banks on reducing debt. Page A1

title: U.S. Vehicle Sales Up 8.9% in Early July
description: Sales of domestic cars and light trucks rose 8.9 percent in early July, bouncing back from the lackluster level of June. But analysts cautioned against reading too much into a single 10-day report and predicted further production cuts.

title: Football Wins Out
description: Rodney Peete, who starred in both football and baseball at the University of Southern California, will concentrate on football for a professional career. His lawyer, Leonard Armato, reached an agreement yesterday with the Detroit Lions, who drafted the quarterback on the sixth round of the college draft. Peete had considered turning to baseball with the Oakland Athletics, who drafted him last June. (AP)

title: Review/Art; The Wonders of Wood: 50 Years of Nakashima's Furniture
description: Since the early 1940's, George Nakashima, the American designer, has worked with and against the grain of modernism, forging what might be called his own personal International Style. From his workshop compound in New Hope, Pa., he has extolled the virtues of wood and traditional handcrafting techniques. He has disdained the man-made materials and, for the most part, the mass production that have been fundamental to modern design. In all this, he has set an inspiring example for several generations of American craftsmen.

title: New York Starts Required Recycling
description: The specially designed truck that rumbled slowly through the narrow streets of Brooklyn Heights one morning this week is part of the process of taking New York City into a new era of recycling.

title: At the Bar; A Glimpse at the Secrets of Penalizing Judges
description: A dispute between a prominent Harvard Law School professor and a combative judge in Rhode Island provides a rare glimpse into the machinery for disciplining Federal judges.

title: Deals
description: BASEBALL CALIFORNIA (AL) - Called up Max Venable, outfielder, from Edmonton of the Pacific Coast League. Sent Terry Clark, pitcher, to Edmonton. PHILADELPHIA (NL) - Traded Bob Sebra, pitcher, to the Cincinnati Reds for a player to be named later. FOOTBALL DENVER (AFC) - Named Lide Huggins director of football operations. DETROIT (NFC) - Signed Rodney Peete, quarterback; Jerry Woods, defensive back-kick returner, and Chris Parker, defensive lineman. Named Wayne Moss assistant director of public relations. HAMILTON (CFL) - Signed Alphonso Williams, wide receiver. HOCKEY DEVILS (NHL) - Announced the retirement of Bob Sauve, goaltender, and named him president of the Devils Alumni Association. Announced the retirement of Murray Brumwell, defenseman. Announced that Anders Carlsson, forward, will play in Sweden this season. ST. LOUIS (NHL) - Named John Kelly broadcaster. SOCCER MAJOR INDOOR SOCCER LEAGUE -Awarded St. Louis an expansion franchise for the 1989-90 season and placed the team in the Western Division. CLEVELAND - Signed Charley Greene, midfielder, to a one-year contract.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article by The Associated Press in some copies on July 6 about the arrest of a demonstrator, Russell Means, by Navajo tribal police officers misstated his relationship to the American Indian Movement. He resigned from the organization more than a year ago.

title: First Commerce Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Net charge-offs of $6.17 million were included in the quarter results, compared to $3.51 million for the year-ago quarter. As a percent of loans and leases, annualized net charge-offs were 1.14 percent, compared to .71 percent for the year ago. Nonperforming assets were $72.86 million on June 30, 1989, versus $74.85 million at the end of the first quarter and $70.86 million on June 30, 1988. On June 30, 1989, stockholders' equity was 5.33 percent of assets, primary capital was 6.39 percent and total capital was 8.57 percent. The company ended the quarter with total assets of $4.3 billion, loans and leases, net of unearned income, of $2.3 billion and deposits of $3.4 billion. First Wachovia Corp(N) Qtr to June 30 1989 1988 Net inc 67,900,000 59,400,000 Share earns 1.17 1.07 6mo net inc 135,200,000 118,200,000 Share earns 2.34 2.15 First Union Corp(N) Qtr to June 30 1989 1988 Net inc 73,697,000 75,804,000 Share earns .69 .70 Net inc 145,878,000 153,178,000 Share earns 1.37 1.41 Latest quarter results included after-tax gains of $2 million from the sale of investment securities. Year- ago quarter results included after-tax gains of $11 million from the sale of investment securities and the purchase of pension annuities. Latest 6-month results included after-tax gains of $6 million primarily from the sale of mortgage servicing rights and mortgages. Year-ago 6-month results included after-tax gains of $25 million primarily from the sale of investment securities and the purchase of annuities for certain retirees. The company said on an annualized basis, net charge-offs as a percent of average net loans for the second quarter of 1989 were 0.31 percent compared with domestic net charge-offs of 0.35 percent in the second quarter of 1988 and 0.28 percent in the first quarter of 1989. The allowance for loan losses was 1.22 percent of net loans and 101 percent of problem assets at June 30, 1989, compared with 1.50 percent of net loans and 135 percent of problem assets at June 30, 1988. The loan loss provision in the second quarters of 1988 and 1989 was $15 million. Mercantile Bankshares Corp(O) Qtr to June 30 1989 1988 Net inc 15,523,000 12,483,000 Share earns 1.21 .98 6mo net inc 30,831,000 25,594,000 Share earns 2.40 2.00

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Ketchum's Bastille Day
description: Ketchum Advertising's New York office yesterday celebrated the 200th anniversary of the storming of the Bastille a day early, winning the business of the French Government Tourism Office. If the timing was propitious, so was Ketchum's perseverance: the agency had unsuccessfully bid for the $4 million account three years ago against a French agency, Publicis. This time, after another review, Ketchum edged out Publicis. The agency will create United States advertising for the tourism office.

title: Pop/Jazz; 270 Rock Bands to Perform At 10th New Music Seminar
description: ''Networking'' was barely a verb in 1980, when about 250 disk jockeys, musicians, record-company executives, managers, booking agents, journalists and music-business strays got together for the first New Music Seminar. Following the punk-rock upheaval, they had noticed the stirrings of an alternative, do-it-yourself rock community, in which bands beneath the notice of the major record labels and commercial radio stations could garner a reputation (if not much immediate cash) with homemade albums and self-organized tours.

title: KEY RATES
BRIEFS
description: * AGS Information Services Inc., Mountainside, N.J., a software design company, said it had acquired Multiple Technologies Corp., Detroit.Terms were not disclosed.

title: On Helping Defectors to Stay In From the Cold
description: In their slow metamorphoses into American citizens, defectors seem almost invariably to become tortured souls, facing an often dispiriting struggle to find a niche without family, friends or credentials.

title: Tesoro Petroleum May Get an Offer
description: Pentane Partners L.P. said it and the Harken Energy Corporation had agreed to make a joint bid for the Tesoro Petroleum Corporation. Shares of Tesoro rose 87.5 cents today, to $10.75, on the New York Stock Exchange, giving the company a value of $150 million.

title: Big Puppets
description: Thirty larger-than-lifesize puppets are to perform ''The Birds'' by Respighi and Prokofiev's ''Peter and the Wolf,'' tomorrow at 11 A.M. and 1 P.M. at the Caramoor Music Festival in Katonah, N.Y. In the cast of characters are the red-haired Peter, his eight-foot-tall grandfather, a yellow-beaked ibis, a trio of flamingos, a tiptoeing cat and a swaggering wolf. Tickets are $3 for children and $6 for adults. Information: (914) 232-5035.

title: Seabrook Shutdown Is Explained
description: Officials at the Seabrook nuclear plant today provided Federal regulators with details of errors that required them to shut down a reactor during a low-power test last month.

title: Bush Credits Moscow With Change in East Bloc
description: President Bush said today that the changes transforming Eastern Europe are ''absolutely amazing,'' and credited the Soviet Union with making those changes possible.

title: North Honduras Blast Wounds 7 Americans
description: A homemade bomb exploded outside a discotheque in north Honduras today as a group of American soldiers passed by, wounding seven of them, three seriously, officials said.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Sutton and Simpson Early Leaders: Hal Sutton, seeking to regain the form that brought him seven victories in his first five years on the PGA Tour, shot a seven-under-par 64 yesterday that tied him with Tim Simpson for the first-round lead of the Anheuser-Busch Golf Classic in Williamsburg, Va. (AP) TENNIS Sabatini Victorious: Gabriela Sabatini used a powerful service game to rout Helen Kelesi, 6-0, 6-3, yesterday in the first round of the Gunze World tournament in Yokohama, Japan. In the first round of the men's singles, Jim Grabb rallied to take a second-set tie breaker and went on to beat Brad Gilbert, 3-6, 7-6, 6-4. (AP) An Upset by Layendecker: Unseeded Glenn Layendecker of Boston upset No. 1 seeded Paul Annacone of Knoxville, Tenn., 4-6, 6-3, 7-6, yesterday to advance to the semifinals of the Volvo Tennis Hall of Fame championships at Newport, R.I. Layendecker won the third-set tiebreaker, 7-0. No. 2 seeded Johan Kriek of Naples, Fla., was eliminated by Danie Visser of South Africa, 6-3, 6-2.(AP) BOXING Dokes Stops Crabtree: Michael Dokes, former World Boxing Association heavyweight champion, knocked out Bobby Crabtree with a thundering left hook to the ribs 1 minute 46 seconds into the first round of a scheduled 10-round bout last night at the Felt Forum. Dokes, who is 30 years old, weighed in at 235 and Crabtree was 210 pounds. Dokes improved his record to 38-2-2 with 24 knockouts and Crabtree dropped to 35-21-1 with 32 knockouts. In another heavyweight bout, Alex Stewart continued his unbeaten streak with his 23d victory and 23d knockout when he stopped the 35-year-old Fernando Montes at 1:50 of the second round. Montes, a former two-time heavyweight champion of Mexico, has a record of 22-20-1 with 14 knockouts.

title: Our Towns; Suburbs Beckon Officers Spurned By a City's Crisis
description: Detective William Pinho Sr., a 23-year veteran of the 320-member Elizabeth police force, says he hates to see his son and namesake leave the department, but he thinks that maybe it is not altogether a bad thing.

title: Defense Chief Warns House Panel on Cuts In 'Star Wars' Budget
description: Fighting to protect his 1990 budget from Congressional cuts, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said today that the reductions approved so far in the House would delay until the 21st century a decision about whether to build a space-based anti-missile shield.

title: Kaplan Journal; Bastille Day Celebrated As Cajun Fourth of July
description: This weekend the Bastille will be stormed once again, but this time it will be made of crayon and cardboard and glue, and its bars will be the inner tubes of paper towel rolls covered with aluminum foil.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Aaron Brothers Art Marts, to AC&R Advertising, with a budget of $3 million to $5 million.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Malvasia

title: Restaurants
description: Akbar

title: Treasuries Drop in Light Trading
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds dipped in sluggish trading yesterday as market participants reacted to automobile sales figures that were a bit stronger than anticipated.

title: NBD Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago quarter and prior-year results have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in June. Sonoco Products Co(O) Qtr to June 30 1989 1988 Sales 415,437,000 410,669,000 Net inc 28,555,000 26,260,000 Share earns .65 .60 6mo sales 848,571,000 786,881,000 Net inc 53,128,000 48,510,000 Share earns 1.21 1.11 Year-ago quarter sales included the plastic motor oil bottle business which was merged into Sonoco Graham Co. in April 1989, and is now accounted for on the equity basis. The company said it did not make progress expected in resolving problems associated with the January 1989 acquisition of Hilex Poly Co., and estimates that earnings during the first half of the year have been negatively impacted by about 7 cents a share from operating losses and interest cost on acquisition indebtedness. Significant efforts continue to return the business to profitability. Southeast Banking Corp(N) Qtr to June 30 1989 1988 Net inc 32,269,000 22,421,000 Share earns 1.00 .71 6mo net inc 65,354,000 45,760,000 Share earns 2.04 1.46

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Ayer's Global Move
description: N. W. Ayer yesterday took heed of the trend toward global markets by appointing its first director of worldwide business development. Charles E. Decker, a former vice president of advertising at the Quaker Oats Company and once an executive vice president of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos/New York, will be responsible for drumming up new business on a global basis. John F. Foley, an Ayer vice president, has been promoted to director of business development for the Unites States.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; The Value Of a Seal Of Approval
description: THE American Heart Association is hoping to do for processed foods what the American Dental Association has done for toothpaste.

title: Reality at the Summit
description: The earth's capacity to support a rapidly expanding population is declining ominously. So the $2.25 billion Japan is offering the third world for environmental purposes is too little and dangerously near too late.

title: Honda Raises Its Stake in Europe
description: In a late effort to bolster its presence in Europe, the Honda Motor Company said today that it would buy 20 percent of the Rover Group P.L.C., the British car-making subsidiary of British Aerospace P.L.C., and that it would build a manufacturing plant in Britain.

title: Savings Plan Compromise Is Offered
description: Senate conferees offered a compromise today to their House counterparts on the rescue plan for the savings industry, but the conference stalled in confusion and procedural gridlock.

title: Cuban General and Three Others Executed for Sending Drugs to U.S.
description: Cuba announced today that a firing squad had executed four Cuban Army officers convicted by court-martial of conspiring to ship tons of cocaine and marijuana to the United States.

title: 3 ARRESTED IN U.S. IN I.R.A. BOMB CASE
description: Three electronics experts were arrested Wednesday on charges of seeking to supply the Irish Republican Army with sophisticated bomb detonators and components of anti-helicopter rockets, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; New Look for Ad Age
description: Advertising Age will introduce its 91,000 subscribers next week to the results of its two-year, $50,000 redesign effort. The page 1 logotype has been replaced by a more streamlined version. And the magazine's columnists, once scattered throughout the news and features pages, will now be gathered together on the viewpoint page. Most significantly, Ad Age, which is published by Crain Communications, will now have a colored bar across the top of each page to identify its contents, ranging from international news to features and people items. ''The driving force behind this was to respond to the criticism that Ad Age was a tough book to get through,'' said Fred Danzig, the editor.

title: The Drug Czar's Report
description: This scourge will end. George Bush made that promise about drugs to the American people the very first time he faced them as President, on Inauguration Day.

title: Showcasting the Latest, All in Serious Fun
description: ''WHEN Serious Fun started in 1987, it was like storming the Bastille, with the rabble-rousing artists of the U.S. and particularly the Lower East Side storming the gates of Lincoln Center,'' said Jed Wheeler, in a rather timely metaphor for the three-week festival of contemporary dance, music, theater and performance art that he has produced and that opens today at Alice Tully Hall.

title: In Philippines, War Against Civilians Drags On; Failed Vietnam Tactics
description: To the Editor:

title: POLAND'S LEADER ASKS WEST FOR AID
description: Warning that Poland's economic crisis poses a major threat, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski appealed today to the major non-Communist powers for a two-year, multibillion-dollar rescue program.

title: Istomin at Waterloo
description: Eugene Istomin is to be the soloist with the Waterloo Festival Orchestra in Beethoven's Fourth Piano Concerto at 8:30 P.M. tomorrow at Waterloo Village, Stanhope, N.J., Exit 25 on Route 80. The program, which is to be conducted by Karl Anton Rickenbacher, also includes Mendelssohn's ''Calm Sea and Prosperous Voyage'' and the Schumann Second Symphony. Tickets are $10 to $18. Information and directions: 307-7171 or (201) 507-8900.

title: Cuomo Signs Aid Bill For Officers' Families
description: Fulfilling a pledge to help the families of police officers and firefighters killed in the line of duty, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo yesterday signed legislation that will allow surviving spouses to continue to collect benefits if they remarry and will provide scholarships to their children.

title: Belzberg Money For Armstrong Bid
description: The Belzberg family of Vancouver, British Columbia, said it had raised $40 million to finance a possible takeover bid for Armstrong World Industries. The Belzbergs disclosed the financing in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Scientists Say Proteins Can Jam AIDS Virus
description: Fake proteins can jam the delicate machinery the AIDS virus uses to reproduce inside the body, scientists reported today. The findings could lead to a new treatment for AIDS, although researchers cautioned that the new technique, used only in test tubes, could be years or even decades from practical application.

title: King Survives Roughs to Gain 1-Shot Lead in Women's Open
description: The tall grass rough at Indianwood Golf and Country Club proved to be just what everyone expected today in the opening round of the 44th United States Women's Open championship as it held a merciless grip on golf balls.

title: Forget Life Sentence Without Parole and Restore Death Penalty; Justice East and West
description: To the Editor:

title: Hernandez Fits Into New Lineup
description: Dave Johnson, asked how he had spent his days off this week, said he had done just what he planned: nothing.

title: At the Movies
description: Nazis in America

title: Unilever's $1.55 Billion Deal To Buy Faberge Is Revived
description: Unilever, whose many consumer products include Lipton tea, All detergent and Signal mouthwash, said yesterday that it had revived an agreement to buy Faberge Inc.'s toiletries, cosmetics and fragrance businesses for $1.55 billion in cash. The deal would include Faberge's Elizabeth Arden subsidiary.

title: Brambles Filing On Environmental
description: Brambles Industries, which offered to acquire the Environmental Systems Company for $14 a share, said it wanted to be able to sell its 30.8 percent stake in Environmental if its bid was rejected.

title: Hospitalization Of Sick Infants Faulted in Suit
description: A children's advocacy group filed suit against New York City and State child-welfare officials yesterday, saying they have failed to provide appropriate care for babies with medical problems who do not need to be hospitalized.

title: Sinclair Hatch, 82, a Retired Lawyer, Dies
description: Sinclair Hatch, a retired partner in the law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy, died after a heart attack yesterday at his home in Oyster Bay, L.I. He was 82 years old and also had a home in Setauket, L.I.

title: H.U.D. Grants Under Reagan: A Case Study in Connections
description: Four former housing officials who got more than $130 million in renovation contracts present a case study of how development grants were awarded in the Reagan Administration.

title: Ferruzzi's Bold Growth Has Made Big Waves
description: Ferruzzi Finanziaria S.p.A. of Italy, whose American grain-trading arm is at the center of a storm in the commodity markets, has hardly been shy about making waves in recent years.

title: Washington Mayor Will Run For Re-election, an Aide Says
description: Mayor Marion Barry says he will seek a fourth term in 1990 and expects Jesse Jackson to campaign for him, The Washington Post reported today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Hill, Holliday and Heinz
description: Heinz U.S.A. yesterday awarded Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos/ Boston the account for a category of new products in its Weight Watchers line. A spokesman for Hill, Holliday said the new assignment could some day be worth as much as $5 million, doubling the size of the agency's Heinz account. Hill, Holliday began its relationship with Heinz 15 months ago, when it won the account for Chico-San Popcorn Cakes.

title: Bowman Tells Rangers No On General Manager Offer
description: Scotty Bowman, the former National Hockey League coach and general manager, has turned down an offer to become the next general manager of the Rangers, and as of yesterday was said to be adamant in no longer wanting to be considered for the position.

title: Profits Up 14% at Coca-Cola
description: Benefiting from strong overseas shipments of its soft-drink concentrates and syrup, the Coca-Cola Company reported yesterday that its earnings for the second quarter increased by 14 percent.

title: AIDS Drug Will Be Offered To Those Ineligible for Tests
description: In an initiative intended to give AIDS patients speedier access to promising new medicines, an experimental drug will be made available to patients in September at the same time a clinical trial of its efficacy begins, the drug's manufacturer said today.

title: House Subcommittee Takes Up Touchy Issue of Protecting Flag
description: After weeks of passion and positioning around the American flag, a House subcommittee got down to the difficult details today of protecting the flag and the First Amendment, too.

title: Hawkins's Shutout Is Near Perfect
description: There wasn't much doubt that it was over. The ball jumped quickly off George Brett's bat, then fell safely on the grass in right field, where no one could touch it. Andy Hawkins conceded later that he had felt let down momentarily, that he had wanted his night of perfection to continue.

title: Niigata Journal; Farmers, in Deep Pain, Make Politicians Share It
description: There have been plenty of times over the last several years when Keniichi Nogami felt exhausted or bored working all day under the hot sun in his family's rice paddies and lotus gardens, but he has tried never to say so in front of his children.

title: Washington, D.C., $212 Million Issue
description: A $212 million bond issue by Washington, D.C., is being offered through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc. The maximum yield is 7 percent for a bond due in 2005.

title: Putting a Face on Corporate Crime
description: Nearly two months ago, a Federal prosecutor and defense lawyers representing the Pennwalt Corporation showed up in the Tacoma courtroom of Federal District Judge Jack E. Tanner for what was supposed to be a routine plea agreement in a criminal case.

title: Fannie Mae Is Offering Debt Secured by Ginnie Mae
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, priced $500 million of debt securities yesterday.

title: Olajuwon in Hospital
description: General Manager Ray Patterson confirmed a Houston television station report that the Rockets' All-Star center, Akeem Olajuwon, is hospitalized, but he declined last night to comment about his player's condition. KTRK-TV reported that Olajuwon had been hospitalized since Monday or Tuesday because of a blood clot in his leg.(AP)

title: Teamsters Urging Workers Not to Broaden Milk Strike
description: Union leaders representing milk distribution workers in the New York metropolitan area were urged yesterday to refrain from joining a four-day-old strike by 200 to 250 drivers against Dellwood Farms Inc., a Yonkers-based distributor.

title: Conagra Chairman Names His Second in Command
description: Conagra Inc. in a decade has grown from $1 billion in annual sales to $11 billion, all without a president and chief operating officer. To be sure, it has had Charles W. Harper, chairman and chief executive, running the diversified food company, and he will now get a helping hand from Philip B. Fletcher, newly designated No. 2 man.

title: Former Security Guard Is Arrested In Shooting of Two State Troopers
description: A former security guard from New Jersey was arrested today in the shooting of two New York state troopers in Rockland County on Wednesday.

title: Charter Panel Declines to Change Police Board
description: After a discussion that lasted about five minutes, the New York City Charter Revision Commission declined to act yesterday on suggestions that it make the city's police complaint review board an all-civilian body.

title: Broker Said to Violate Ban
description: A man barred for life from the securities industry has worked as a broker for five years with several Florida firms, the Securities and Exchange Commission charged yesterday.

title: 'Do the Right Thing' Is an American Movie in the Best Sense
description: To the Editor:

title: 7 Indicted For Fraud
description: Seven people, including three former presidents of financial institutions, have been indicted on Federal charges of defrauding savings and loans of more than $30 million, authorities said today.

title: Medal for Jackson Is His 'Validation'
description: After years of a complicated and at times tense relationship with the Rev.

title: INSIDE
description: Cuban General Executed Four Cuban Army officers, including a highly decorated general, were put to death for conspiring to ship drugs to the United States. Page A3. Koch's Plans Slip Out After weeks of campaigning, Mayor Koch declared his candidacy for re-election on a radio program. Page B1. Sidney Hook Is Dead Dr. Hook, a leading philosopher and defender of academic and political freedom, was 86 years old. Page D15.

title: In Philippines, War Against Civilians Drags On
description: To the Editor:

title: Stories of a Detention Farm, From One Who Lived There
description: ''I'm basically an Irish storyteller,'' John O'Keefe explained. ''The single element unifying everything I've done is a strong sense of an oral tradition. I want to work a piece so that the audience can see it in their heads.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Markets

title: La Revolution Remembered: Concerts, Croissants, Cancans
description: JULY 14th! The anniversary of the French Revolution! Music and dancing in the streets. Concertinas. Hurdy-gurdies. Mimes. Jugglers. Cancan dancers. Acrobats. Croissants and cafe au lait.

title: Drug Found in Babies, And Mother Is Guilty
description: An addict who gave birth to two children with traces of cocaine in their system was convicted today on charges of delivering drugs to minors under a state law routinely used against drug dealers.

title: L.I. Man Held in July 4 Attack
description: An 18-year-old Long Island man was arrested yesterday and charged in connection with an attack on several blacks in Rosedale, Queens, on the Fourth of July. The suspect, Richard DeCurtis, of 167 Hamilton Avenue in Island Park, was the fifth person arrested in the incident, in which the police said more than 30 whites chased about six blacks after a dispute over firecrackers. Mr. DeCurtis was charged with assault, riot, aggravataed harassment, violation of the state's civil rights law and possession of a weapon, a stick.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Capital and Research Corp., Fairfax, Va., a diversified construction and consulting company, named James R. Janis executive vice president, and Kenneth B. Kolsky president of its subsidiary ICF Inc.

title: A Muslim Celebration Of Sacrifice and Sharing
description: An Islamic celebration of sharing began yesterday, as Muslims filled mosques in the New York area with prayers and holiday greetings.

title: Economic Scene; Bush's Caution In Eastern Europe
description: PRESIDENT BUSH's run-up to the Paris economic summit conference through Poland and Hungary has been a modest triumph not only for the American President but also for democratic capitalism.

title: Japanese-Americans Still Await Redress
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviets Promise to Meet Demands of Striking Miners
description: Striking coal miners who halted production at one of the Soviet Union's major coal centers began returning to work tonight after the authorities promised to meet their demands for better living conditions, according to Soviet press reports.

title: Dow Rises 5.69 Points, To 2,538.32
description: The Dow Jones industrial average rose to yet another post-crash high, by 5.69 points, to 2,538.32. It was the index's eighth straight advance.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 468 money market mutual funds increased by $4.39 billion, to $328.15 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 142 institutional funds increased by $1.99 billion, to $84.11 billion. Those of the 231 general-purpose funds were down by $196.4 million, to $104.85 billion. The 95 broker-dealer funds' assets increased by $2.59 billion, to $139.19 billion, the institute said.

title: Netherlands Recovers 2 van Gogh Paintings
description: Two van Gogh paintings that were among three stolen last Dec. 12 from the Kroller-Muller National Museum in Otterlo have been recovered, a local official said today.

title: Banponce Corp.
description: The Banponce Corporation said its directors had discussed the unsolicited merger proposal from Banco Popular de Puerto Rico at their regular board meeting yesterday, but made no decision. Alberto Paracchini, Banponce's chairman, said the board did not feel bound to reach any decision by July 21, the date on which Banco Popular said its offer would expire. Banco Popular is offering $50 a share for 40 percent of Banponce's stock and stock in the merged company for the remaining 60 percent. It values its offer at $293 million.

title: Forget Life Sentence Without Parole and Restore Death Penalty
description: To the Editor:

title: Asbestos Suit for $3 Billion
description: Attorneys for thousands of asbestos-disease victims today asked a Texas state court to make Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the leveraged-buyout specialists, and Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. liable for damage claims estimated at more than $3 billion.

title: Houston Adding Intrigue to Tom Fool
description: The sprinters in New York so far this year have been a gritty but uninspiring bunch. Every three or four weeks, it seemed, Pok Ta Pok would take on Dr. Carrington and True and Blue, and while the contests were good entertainment, you couldn't help thinking that none of them looked like an Eclipse Award-winning sprinter.

title: Sealed Air Stake
description: A group including the Fort Hill Investors Management Corporation said it had acquired a 7.23 percent stake, or 593,400 shares, in the Sealed Air Corporation. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the group said it bought shares between May 15 and June 22 for prices ranging from $11.25 to $16.375 each. Sealed Air shares rose 37.5 cents today, to $18.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Woman's Execution for Murder at 15 Is Barred
description: The Indiana Supreme Court today barred the execution of a woman for a murder committed when she was 15 years old.

title: Liberte Won, and Lost
description: Two hundred years ago today, a Paris mob stormed the Bastille and touched off the French Revolution. The intent was not to free the seven men imprisoned inside but to demand arms for the defense of Paris against royalist forces surrounding the capital. When the military governor refused, the mob attacked. When the struggle ended, 98 citizens and 6 soldiers lay dead.

title: Market Place; Liz Claiborne Inc. Is Turning Heads
description: FOR several days, the stock of Liz Claiborne Inc. has been among the most active Nasdaq stocks, enjoying not only a trading flurry but also a gain of 25 cents to 50 cents a share each day, closing at $24.25 yesterday, up 50 cents.

title: 2 Top Contenders Seen For Chief of the S.E.C.
description: The vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Manuel H. Johnson, and President Bush's chief adviser on the savings and loan crisis, Richard C. Breeden, have emerged as the top contenders for the position of chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Administration officials said today.

title: Review/Theater; Poems Put Onstage in 'Spirit Time'
description: When theater is harnessed to poems, there is always a question about how well they will work together. In the case of Wilfred Cartey's poetry and the performance of a gifted trio in ''Spirit Time'' at the Arts for Living Center of the Henry Street Settlement, on the Lower East Side, the match works quite effectively.

title: N.A.A.C.P., Long at Odds With Jackson, Is Giving Him Award
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People today reached out in reconciliation to the Rev. Jesse Jackson, who has long struggled to gain acceptance among the major civil rights groups.

title: On Stage
description: Two in One for Goulet

title: Petitions Filed, Some Amid Fanfare
description: If mayoral races were settled by the number of signatures on nominating petitions, Borough President David N. Dinkins of Manhattan could spend this day choosing furniture for Gracie Mansion.

title: Atom Particles Fired in Test Heralding Space Shield Era
description: The Defense Department said yesterday that it had fired a beam of atomic particles in the first space test of the technology as a potential anti-missile weapon.

title: CNW Buyout Is Advanced
description: Blackstone Capital Partners L.P., a member of the group acquiring the CNW Corporation, said today that the the Interstate Commerce Commission had denied a motion to halt the $1.6 billion tender offer for the freight railroad company.

title: Mayor Barry Says He'll Run As Jackson Waits in Wings
description: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr., seeking to turn back a potential challenge from the Rev. Jesse Jackson, said through aides today that he would seek a fourth term as Mayor of the nation's capital.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; He Who Hesitates . . .
description: ''Time is money'' is a saying never more true than today. Interest rates have been falling since April 26 and further drops are expected. Waiting to decide at what yield to buy a certificate of deposit (C.D.) or to reinvest in one can cost a depositor dearly. Assuming yields decline at the pace of a quarter of a percentage point every three months, the loss in interest paid on a $10,000 certificate is $25 every quarter. The figures below show what a consumer would have lost in interest over the life of a certificate by buying it now, as opposed to April 26. $ ($10,000 Current Yield on Lost minimum) Yield April 26 Interest 1-year C.D. 8.63% 9.51% $88 2 1/2-year C.D. 8.50 9.33 $237 5-year C.D. 8.45 9.20 $525 Source: Bank Rate Monitor, North Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Producer Prices Fell Last Month
description: Prices fell at all stages of production in June, the first month this has happened in more than three years, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Review/Dance; French Mix of Opposites at Jacob's Pillow
description: Myriam Herve-Gil has a wry view of the world. And she is witty and poignant in communicating that view, through imagery as various as spiders clinging to a bridal gown and a woman tugging insouciantly at fleshy spots on her body.

title: British Inflation Steady
description: Britain's annual inflation rate held steady at 8.3 percent in June, and may have reached its peak, the Government announced today. Britain's retail price index rose three-tenths of 1 percent in June from May, the Department of Employment said. Market forecasts had called for a five-tenths of 1 percent gain.

title: H&R Block Plans Bid for Microbilt
description: H&R Block Inc., an accounting services company, said it would acquire the Microbilt Corporation, a communications systems company, for $144 million in H & R Block shares.

title: INSIDE
description: A Drop in Inflation Prices fell at all stages of production in June (chart, right), evidence that the economy is slowing. But some economists still worry about underlying inflationary trends. Page 33. Capital Mayor to Run Again Washington's Mayor, Marion S. Barry Jr., said he would seek another term, setting up a possible battle with Jesse Jackson. Page 6. Budget Imposed on Yonkers A state agency imposes a budget on Yonkers after the city rejected a plan with money for schools required by a desegregation order. Page 27.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 2-5 Lech Walesa declared his support for any candidate put forward by the Communist Party as President of Poland. He urged that elections be held without delay to end political disarray. Page 1

title: In Long Run, the Price Of Milk Will Go Up
description: To the Editor:

title: Reviews/Jazz; Texas Group Taps Louis Armstrong Spirit
description: The Jim Cullum Jazz Band, which has been based in San Antonio for more than 25 years, plays traditional jazz with an inventive personal touch and a polish that reflects the long and close association of the seven members of the band. The group rarely gets to the East Coast, and its current engagement at Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street, through next Saturday, is its debut at a New York club.

title: Abortion: The Issue Can't Be Ducked
description: There was a time when abortion was a private matter. In this mayoral election, it is a public one as well.

title: Here a Sale, There a Sale: Is Anything Really on Sale?
description: To summer shoppers, it may seem that almost everything in America is on sale, as retailers try to get the last dollar out of warm-weather goods and stimulate early demand for fall merchandise in a softening economy.

title: Stop Arming for a War That We Won't Fight
description: To the Editor:

title: Violinist at Caramoor
description: The violinist Elmar Oliveira is to play Mozart's Sonata in G (K. 379), Grieg's Sonata No. 3 in C minor, Prokofiev's Sonata in F minor (Op. 80) and Ravel's ''Tzigane'' at 5:30 P.M. tomorrow in the Spanish Courtyard at Caramoor, Girdle Ridge Road in Katonah, N.Y. Walter Ponce is to be the pianist. Tickets are $20. Information and directions: (914) 232-5035.

title: Union to Strike Hospital League For 2 More Days
description: Members of New York State's largest health-care workers' union voted overwhelmingly late Thursday to hold two more one-day strikes against 53 hospitals in New York City later this month to demonstrate their dissatisfaction with the hospitals' contract offer.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Albany Surplus Funds Decline
description: New York State's surplus revenues declined by more than $130 million last month, according to a report issued today by the State Comptroller. The report renewed a debate between Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and leaders of the State Senate over how much extra spending the state could afford. The state's official surplus for the present fiscal year now stands at $183.7 million, down from $317 million last month.

title: Dim Pitching Returns, But Yanks Win One
description: There was one out in the ninth inning last night, and the Yankees were watching their night slowly fade away. They had already lost the first game of a doubleheader against the Kansas City Royals, and now they were losing the second. Then, everything changed.

title: Miguel Roig, 68, Economy Chief In Argentina, Dies of Heart Attack
description: Argentina's new Economy Minister, Miguel Roig, died of a heart attack today, less than a week after taking on the task of restoring Argentina's crumbling economy. He was 68 years old.

title: William T. Bandy, 86, A Baudelaire Scholar
description: William T. Bandy, a retired professor of French at Vanderbilt University and a scholar who preserved the works of the poet Charles Baudelaire, died July 6 after a stroke at his summer home in Wayne, Me. He was 86 years old and lived in Nashville.

title: House Votes to End Tongass Timber Deals
description: The House has approved legislation that would cancel 50-year deals under which two timber companies have been cutting trees from Tongass National Forest in southeastern Alaska at bargain-basement prices.

title: School Board Names A Successor to Clark
description: The Board of Education has chosen a principal to succeed Joe Clark at Eastside High School in September. The board unanimously approved Charles Lighty, who ran an elementary school last year.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HARNESS RACING Dexter Nukes Wins Easily: Dexter Nukes, a 3-year-old bay colt and 2-1 favorite, broke in front on the first turn last night and was never challenged as he won the Meadowlands Pace at East Rutherford, N.J. The colt, driven by John Campbell, finished three and a half lengths ahead of Casino Cowboy, a 15-1 shot. Barefoot Hanover, at 25-1, was third in the 10-horse field. Dexter Nukes's first 27 seconds were the fastest first-quarter time in the 13-year history of the race. The colt, owned by Thomas A. Dexter, returned $4.40 for $2 to win, and earned the $426,000 first prize from an $852,000 purse, nearly doubling his previous earnings. CYCLING Fignon Retains Lead: French riders swept the top three positions in the 13th stage of the Tour de France yesterday, but Laurent Fignon of France and Greg LeMond of the United States still led the overall standings, with Fignon up by 7 seconds. Vincent Barteau, Jean-Claude Colotti and Matial Gayant were ahead of the pack in the leg, 110 miles from Montpellier to Marseille. In the women's Tour, Jeannie Longo of France took the overall lead by 13 seconds and Bunki Bankaitis-Davis of the United States won the third stage, 36 miles from Martigues to Marseille, in 1 hour 20 minutes 7 seconds.(AP) TENNIS Steeb Gains Semifinals: Carl-Uwe Steeb of West Germany, seeded eighth, beat second-seeded Aaron Krickstein of Grosse Pointe, Mich., 6-2, 6-4, in the quarterfinals yesterday at the Swiss Open in Gstaad.(AP) Wilander Advances: Second-seeded Mats Wilander continued his struggles through the United States Pro clay-court championships in Brookline, Mass., with a 7-6, 6-4 quarterfinal victory over eighth-seeded Jordi Arrese of Spain to advance to the semifinals. (AP) Pugh to Semifinals: Unseeded Jim Pugh defeated Christian Saceanu of West Germany, 6-3, 6-4 yesterday to advance to the semifinals of the Volvo Hall of Fame championships in Newport, R.I. Rain forced suspension of the match between third-seeded John Fitzgerald of Australia and sixth-seeded Peter Lundgren of Monte Carlo.(AP) AUTO RACING Fittipaldi Still Blazing: Emerson Fittipaldi of Brazil continued to dominate the CART Indy-car circuit yesterday, driving the day's fastest lap on the first day of qualifying for the Marlboro Grand Prix tomorrow. Fittipaldi drove a lap at 114.589 miles an hour at the Meadowlands late in the 30-minute session.(AP) GOLF Hulbert Moves Ahead: Mike Hulbert birdied his last two holes to cap a five-under-par 66 and take a one-shot lead in yesterday's second round of the Anheuser-Busch Classic in Williamsburg, Va. Hulbert was at 11-under 131 after his second tour of the Kingsmill Golf Course. Hulbert's closest pursuers were Tim Norris, who was at 132 after a 67, and Don Shirey, who shot his second consecutive 66. (AP) Moody Leads Seniors: Orville Moody shot a seven-under-par 64 yesterday to take a one-stroke lead over Dave Hill after the first round of the Greater Grand Rapids Open seniors tournament in Grand Rapids, Mich. Moody, the defending champion, was one stroke off the tournament record over the Elks Country Club course.

title: Device Permits Aircraft To Exchange Data
description: James Manion, a retired Navy systems analyst in San Diego, proposes using less glamorous technology in a collision avoidance device that he believes would cost as little as $2,000 per aircraft.

title: More Gains on Debt Talks With Mexico Are Reported
description: Mexico and its bankers were said to be making progress yesterday in their effort to agree on the remaining elements of a plan to reduce and overhaul the nation's debt.

title: Review/Ballet; New Aurora In the Kirov's 'Beauty'
description: The Kirov Ballet gave a disappointingly weak repeat performance of ''The Sleeping Beauty'' on Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Advocate for Animal Rights Pleads Guilty in Bomb Case
description: The animal-rights advocate accused of planting a bomb outside a medical-research company in Norwalk, Conn., pleaded guilty yesterday to Federal charges that she possessed two other bombs in her Queens apartment.

title: A Grand Jury Clears Officers in Fatal Fall
description: The police were not at fault in the death of a man who fell from a Harlem rooftop while being chased by officers on a drug raid, said a grand jury that dismissed the case yesterday.

title: Robert Hoag, 53, Ex-Head of Seneca Tribe
description: Robert C. Hoag, a leader of the Seneca Nation of Indians in western New York State, died after a long illness yesterday in Salamanca, N.Y., where he lived. He was 53 years old. Mr. Hoag was a lifelong resident of Salamanca, which lies largely within the Senecas' 22,000-acre Allegany Reservation, the state's largest. He was president of the Seneca Nation for three terms, the most recent in 1986.

title: Canada Inflation Surges
description: Canada's inflation rate surged in June to its highest level in five years, the Government said today in a report that economists predicted would bolster the central bank's argument against lowering interest rates. On an annualized basis, the inflation rate swelled to 5.4 percent in June, its highest level since Febrary 1984, up from 5 percent in May and 4.6 percent in April, the Government agency Statistics Canada reported.

title: Bush Administration Drops Plan To Send a Special Envoy to Israel
description: The Bush Administration has decided to hold off sending a special envoy to Israel to assess Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's commitment to his Government's proposal for Palestinian elections in the occupied territories, officials said today.

title: Janos Kadar, Hungary's Ex-Leader, Buried
description: Janos Kadar was buried today, and those who deposed him from leadership of the Communist Party last year and cast him into virtual disgrace delivered eulogies.

title: WALESA TO BACK A COMMUNIST CHIEF
description: Lech Walesa, the Solidarity leader, moved today to end the deadlock that has prevented the election of a Polish President by declaring that he would support Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski or any other candidate put forward by the Communist Party.

title: Larkin Out With Injury
description: Barry Larkin, the Cincinnati Reds' shortstop, learned yesterday that he'd be sidelined for six to eight weeks with a torn ligament in his right elbow. Larkin felt something pop in the elbow while making a throw last Monday during a competition in the All-Star Game festivities.

title: Deadly Logic on Assault Rifles
description: Military assault rifles embarrass President Bush: there's a compelling case to ban sales to the public, yet he won election as an ardent foe of gun control. Last spring he dodged the issue by ordering a temporary ban on imported assault rifles - 25 percent of the market - while asking the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms for a study.

title: Slowly, North Korea Begins to Stir
description: LEAD: North Korea seems to be getting serious about opening to the world.At a time when the

title: American Bankers Stake
description: An investment group led by the Lodestar Group, a New York-based leveraged buyout firm, , has acquired a 5.67 percent stake in American Bankers Insurance Group Inc. In a Securities and Exchange

title: Correction
description: An article on July 4 about language disputes in Quebec referred incorrectly to reactions to a court ruling in December permitting signs in English. There were protests by French-speakers, but not riots. The article also located Meech Lake incorrectly. It is in Quebec, not Ontario. Another article that day, about a special issue of a French-language cultural review in Quebec, misstated the legal basis of Premier Robert Bourassa's action making restrictions on English-language signs exempt from the Canadian Charter of Rights. He invoked the ''notwithstanding clause,'' a basic article of the Constitution, not a loophole.

title: Senate Committee Approves Cheney's '90 Military Plan
description: The Senate Armed Services Committee approved Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's 1990 budget proposal with only minor changes today, setting the stage for battles on the Senate floor and with the House over the anti-missile program, the Stealth bomber and two other warplanes.

title: T. R. Pulton Jr. Weds Ms. Sydney
description: Laura Helen Sydney, an account manager at McCall's magazine in New York, and Theodore Robert Pulton Jr., a senior vice president and a group account director at the New York advertising agency of Berenter Greenhouse & Webster, were married yesterday aboard the yacht Celebrity off Liberty Island. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman officiated.

title: Uncoddle Steel
description: Three Presidents gave U.S. steel makers ''temporary'' protection against foreign competition that has lasted for most of the past 20 years, and a fourth seems ready to compound the blunder. Thanks to a campaign miscalculation, President Bush is committed to renew quotas on steel imports, and American consumers will have to pay.

title: Bradley's Hot Bat Helps Orioles Subdue Angels, 6-4
description: Phil Bradley extended his hitting streak to 16 games as the Orioles defeated the California Angels, 6-4, tonight in a battle of the American League division leaders.

title: Colombia Journal; A Battle Grande for a Lucrative Span
description: The Rio Grande flows tranquilly past this sleepy hamlet. But in nearby cities on both sides of the United States-Mexican border, a proposal to build an eight-lane bridge across the river here has created an intense struggle over who will share in the lucrative and fast-growing overland trade between the two countries.

title: Proposal On Foreign Investors
description: For the first time, most foreign investors will have to obtain formal approval from United States authorities before acquiring American companies, under proposed regulations published today.

title: May Soybean Turmoil Cited
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission disclosed today that the same sort of turmoil that has been disturbing soybean trading here occurred earlier this year as well.

title: Software Reduces Radar False Alarms
description: Systems engineers at the Hughes Aircraft Company have patented software for air traffic control systems that among other features cuts down on the number of false alarms from inaccurate radar data.

title: Dwight Robinson, 89, Head of Mutual Fund
description: Dwight P. Robinson Jr., retired chairman of the Massachusetts Investors Trust, the country's oldest mutual fund, died of a heart attack Wednesday in Wareham, Mass., while traveling to his home in Brookline. He was 89 years old.

title: Summit's Leaders Focus on Debt, Drugs and Ecology
description: When the industrial world's 15th annual economic summit meeting opened today in the Louvre's new gleaming glass pyramid, the leaders talked about the big issues of the day, and they were already making a little progress on Eastern Europe, third world debt and other issues.

title: Apollo 11 Astronauts to Mark Moon Landing Anniversary
description: The Apollo 11 astronauts will embark on a weeklong sentimental journey Saturday, traveling to Washington and the nation's space centers to commemorate the human landing on the moon 20 years ago.

title: Compaq and I.B.M Sign Patent Accord
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation and the International Business Machines Corporation signed a patent cross-license agreement under which each company granted to the other a non-exclusive license that covers patents having an effective filing date before July 1, 1993, Compaq said today.

title: Black Priest Is Termed Threat to Catholic Unity
description: The National Conference of Catholic Bishops said today that the Roman Catholic church in the United States was making special efforts to meet the needs of black members and that a recent effort by a black Washington priest to establish a separate ''African-American'' congregation had ''wounded'' the church and threatened its unity.

title: Hospital Partners Gets HEI Stake
description: Hospital Partners Ltd., a limited partnership controlled by a San Antonio broker, Dana F. McGinnis, has acquired a 7.6 percent stake in the HEI Corporation and said that it might seek third parties to acquire control of the Houston-based acute-care hospital chain.

title: Foyt Charged in Assault
description: A. J. Foyt, who is recognized as one of the top Indy-car drivers in history, was apparently not recognized by a security guard at the Meadowlands in East Rutherford, N.J., yesterday and has been charged with simple assault. According to a spokesman for the New Jersey State Police office at the Meadowlands, Foyt, a four-time Indianapolis 500 winner, pushed a security guard at the track before the first day of qualifying for the Marlboro Grand Prix tomorrow.

title: 2 Ex-Navy Officials, 3 Others Plead Guilty in Fraud Case
description: The Federal inquiry into Pentagon procurement fraud advanced today with guilty pleas by five people, including two former Navy officials.

title: Your Money; Unwed Couples' Planning Needs
description: When New York's highest court ruled last week that a gay couple who had been living together for a decade could be considered a family under New York City's rent control regulations, it cited an economic reality that many unmarried couples overlook: financial interdependence.

title: U.S. Court Says Industry Polluters Should Pay Full Environment Cost
description: In a ruling that could cost American industry billions of dollars, a Federal appeals court here declared today that companies responsible for oil spills and other pollution should be forced to pay the full costs of restoring the environment to its original condition, not just the market value of damaged natural resources.

title: G. Derwood Baker, 89, Professor Emeritus
description: G. Derwood Baker, professor emeritus of educational administration at New York University, died of a heart attack on July 7 at his home in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 89 years old.

title: Doctor Is Charged With AIDS Fraud
description: A Hudson County physician concealed a positive AIDS test for an immigrant seeking residency status in exchange for $3,000, the government charged yesterday.

title: Alicia Rand Wed To Mikael Moller
description: Alicia Rand, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Rand of New York, was married yesterday to Mikael C. L. Moller, the son of Ingabritt Moller of Vanersborg, Sweden, and the late Lorenz Moller. The Rev. Leslie Merlin, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Brick Church in New York.

title: Review/Opera; A 'Fairy Queen' Transformed at Aix
description: Now in its 42d year, the Aix-en-Provence Festival remains one of the most charming, elegant stops on the European summer music circuit. Its success derives in part from its tasteful, innovative productions, which have waxed and waned in quality over the years (this writer recalls the golden age of Hans Rosbaud's Mozart and modernism in the mid-1950's) and which seem now, under Louis Erlo's direction, to be in the ascendancy.

title: Pact to Ease Psychiatric Ward Crowding
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Mayor Edward I. Koch announced agreement Friday on a plan to help relieve crowding in the psychiatric units of New York City's hospitals.

title: Days of Post-Crash Highs And Wide Trading Swings
description: Stocks swung wildly yesterday but finished moderately higher, setting the market's third post-crash high in a row, as the Dow Jones industrial average rose 16.50, to 2,554.82. For the week, the Dow showed a gain of 66.96 points.

title: A Farewell to Amateurism
description: With two days left in a two-week event dominated by the usual countries, a pair of aging fencers have struck a resounding blow for the new United States policy in the world championships at Boettcher Concert Hall.

title: In Paris, Nazi Victims Go Undifferentiated
description: To the Editor:

title: Siberian Miners' Strike Spreads As Authorities Make Concessions
description: Soviet officials struggled today to pacify a wave of labor militancy that gained momentum in coal-mining regions as the Government announced concessions but still faced striking workers' demands for many consumer necessities and economic changes.

title: New Twist in Errant-Plane Case: The Pilot Was Shot in Midflight
description: The mysterious tale of a pilot who survived a thousand-mile flight while apparently unconscious took a new twist today: the police disclosed that he had been shot between the time the plane took off from Washington on Thursday and the time it sank in the Atlantic Ocean nearly six hours later.

title: Summit Debate: How to Help the Poorer Nations
description: To the presumed pleasure of the French host and the palpable discomfort of the Americans here, the conference of the seven mightiest democracies has opened with a political and philosophical struggle over helping the world's poorer countries.

title: Gunmen Kill Kurdish Exiles Holding a Meeting in Vienna
description: Gunmen stormed a meeting of Kurdish exiles in an apartment and fatally shot three of them, including the leader of an anti-Iranian faction, the police said today.

title: William Fetridge, 82, A Republican Figure
description: William H. Fetridge, an editor, business executive and Republican Party official, died of pneumonia Thursday at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago. He was 82 years old and lived in Chicago.

title: Bridge
description: To a geographer, ''Brunswick'' might suggest a German duchy, a Canadian province or a New Jersey city. To a bridge player, it will in the future suggest the diagramed deal. It comes from a remarkable collection compiled by the veteran French writer Jose Le Dentu.

title: State Agency Forces Budget On Yonkers
description: A state monitoring agency imposed a 1989-90 budget on Yonkers today after the City Council rejected a nearly identical spending plan that included $24 million to build two schools required under a Federal judge's desegregation order.

title: Ex-Housing Official Contradicts Pierce Testimony on Aid Projects
description: A former senior Federal housing official today contradicted testimony from Samuel R. Pierce Jr., the Housing Secretary in the Reagan Administration, that he had no direct involvement in selecting projects for assistance under a housing rehabilitation program.

title: Some Countries Can't Let Their Names Alone; Kobenhavn to Munchen
description: To the Editor:

title: Stalinist Rumania Closes In on Itself
description: While Hungary and Poland move toward a multiparty system and all of Eastern Europe ponders its future, Rumania steadily closes in on itself in pursuit of the Stalinist visions of its leader, Nicolae Ceausescu.

title: Review/Dance; Laura Dean Combines Old and New
description: The Berkshire Ballet has a fine new work in Laura Dean's ''Arrow of Time,'' a world premiere presented on Wednesday night at the Koussevitsky Arts Center of Berkshire Community College. Hard-driving and elegant, the piece inextricably blends the spare formal patterns for which Ms. Dean is known and the strong dramatic undertones that have become more evident in her work in recent years.

title: Fenech Says He'll Fight
description: Jeff Fenech of Australia was the World Boxing Council featherweight champion when he announced his retirement three months ago after he broke bones in both hands during a successful title defense against Marcos Villasana of Mexico. But yesterday in Sydney, Fenech said that he planned to undergo treatment for his the hands and return to the ring.

title: Savings Bill Deadlock Ended by House Side
description: House and Senate conferees got back on track today in their efforts to iron out differences in President Bush's $157 billion proposal to bail out the savings and loan industry.

title: Change at Tanglewood
description: The Aug. 19 concert performance of Bizet's ''Carmen'' at the Tanglewood Festival has been postponed until the 1991 season. The Boston Symphony and the soprano Jessye Norman made the decision jointly, they said, to give her time to prepare for the title role. Instead, Miss Norman will sing other works by Bizet, Berlioz, Offenbach and Ravel. Seiji Ozawa will conduct. The concert begins at 8:30.

title: New York Gets Chance To Save on Phone Bills
description: For the last two years, consumers across the nation, except those in New York State, have trimmed millions of dollars from their telephone bills by installing and maintaining the phone wiring inside their homes.

title: U.S. Dance Importing Other Ideas
description: Bring dancers and choreographers from many nations to the same festival. Let them attend performances and take classes at the festival's school. What happens next? One thing that doesn't happen is a blurring of artistic differences.

title: Suspect in Shooting of 2 Troopers Is Said to Have Sought Police Jobs
description: A man accused of posing as a Federal agent and shooting two state troopers in New York had tried unsuccessfully to become a trooper in New Jersey and an F.B.I. agent, the authorities said today.

title: Rockets Unconcerned By Olajuwon's Ailment
description: Although Akeem Olajuwon, the All-Star center for the Rockets, remained in a hospital in Houston yesterday for treatment of what is believed to be a blood clot in the calf of his leg, the president and general manager of the Rockets seemed unfazed.

title: 2 Chinese Protesters Executed
description: Two men connected with anti-Government protests have been put to death, bringing to 12 the number of officially announced executions directly linked to last month's crackdown on the country's democracy movement.

title: No Evidence of Fixing
description: The police chief of Florence, Ala., Rick Thompson, said that an investigation into sports gambling in northern Alabama had turned up no specific evidence to link coaches or officials to allegations of game-fixing in high school games. At a news conference Thursday night, Thompson referred to two former Coffee High School assistant coaches, Ganum Smith and William Hamilton, whose homes were searched.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 13.

title: 2 Electric Jolts in Alabama Execution
description: Alabama prison officials had to use a second jolt of electricity today to execute a mildly retarded murderer after the first charge failed to kill him.

title: Letter: On H.U.D.; The U.S. Attorney Did Recuse Himself
description: To the Editor:

title: H. Mason Hicks, 85, Manhattan Physician
description: H. Mason Hicks, a physician and former chief of medicine at Doctors Hospital, died there of cardiac arrest Thursday. He was 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Papp Cancels Palestinian Play
description: Joseph Papp, the producer of the New York Shakespeare Festival, has canceled a scheduled appearance next week by the El-Hakawati Palestinian Theater Company of Jerusalem at his Public Theater. The six-person company, which had performed in Israel and Europe before making its American debut two weeks ago in Philadelphia, was to present ''The Story of Kufur Shamma,'' a drama about a Palestinian man's 40-year search for survivors from his village after the 1948 Arab-Israeli War.

title: Some Countries Can't Let Their Names Alone
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Refuses to Halt Work at Shoreham
description: A judge refused yesterday to block the unloading of fuel from the Shoreham nuclear power plant while he decides on the legality of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's agreement to have the Long Island plant dismantled.

title: Milk Strike Ends at Union Leader's Direction
description: A five-day walkout by drivers against one milk-processing company and a one-day sympathy strike that halted all milk deliveries in New York City and on Long Island were called off yesterday afternoon when a union leader was released from jail after urging that his members return to work.

title: Profits Up 28.3% at Motorola
description: Motorola Inc. reported today that its second-quarter earnings rose 28.3 percent, to a quarterly record, on the strength in its cellular telephone, communications and computer chip businesses.

title: Some Countries Can't Let Their Names Alone; From the Celts
description: To the Editor:

title: New Systems To Prevent Air Collisions
description: Collisions in the air are rare, but they still happen, and both corporate and independent inventors have been hard at work to find ways to prevent them.

title: Ballet Theater Promotions
description: American Ballet Theater has announced the promotion of four dancers, effective Nov. 1. Ricardo Bustamante and Wes Chapman have been promoted to principal dancer. Jeremy Collins and Christina Fagundes have been promoted to soloist.

title: What Landmark Compensation Decision Does
description: To the Editor:

title: Dollar Rises Above Ceilings Believed Set by Group of 7
description: The dollar rose sharply yesterday, once again passing the ceilings the United States and its economic allies are believed to have set for it against the West German mark and the yen.

title: Fumes, Fire and a Brake Failure Delay Subways, Buses and Trains
description: A fire on an Albany-bound Amtrak train and a failed brake on a subway train stranded thousands of passengers yesterday, and strange-smelling fumes prompted the evacuation of the Port Authority Bus Terminal at the end of the evening rush hour, delaying thousands more.

title: Athletes' Cancers a Coincidence, Study of Meadowlands Site Finds
description: A study has concluded that nothing peculiar to the Meadowlands Sports Complex poses an increased risk of cancer to athletes, fans or employees.

title: Irb H. Fooshee, 80, Ex-Chemical Executive
description: Irb H. Fooshee, a chemical engineer who retired in 1971 as an executive vice president of the Allied Chemical Corporation, died of prostate cancer Tuesday at Hilton Head Island, S.C., where he had lived since last year. He was 80 years old and had previously lived in Austin, Tex.

title: Retail Sales Down by 0.4% Last Month
description: Retail sales fell by four-tenths of 1 percent in June, dragged down by lagging auto and home furnishing purchases, the Commerce Department reported today, and analysts said big-ticket items would continue to bear the brunt of high interest rates.

title: In Paris, Nazi Victims Go Undifferentiated; Carmelites at Auschwitz
description: To the Editor:
