title: Consulting Firm Admits Possible Links to More Projects
description: A prominent Washington consulting firm today issued its broadest description yet of involvement in a Federal housing program under investigation, saying its top officers might have privately secured Federal rental subsidies for projects clients were building.

title: Factory Operating Rate And Output Fell in June
description: Both the factory operating rate and industrial production fell last month, providing more evidence of a slowing economy.

title: Fruehauf Sets Sale of Some Units
description: The Fruehauf Corporation said it had completed the sale of its trailer, maritime and Cemco businesses to the Terex Trailer Corporation.

title: U.S. Issues Fall as Fed Acts to Bolster Rates
description: Treasury note and bond prices declined yesterday, largely because the Federal Reserve, which had been widely expected to lower interest rates, instead moved to bolster basic rates by draining reserves from the banking system.

title: Filmgoers Say 'Charge It'
description: Moviegoers who never seem to have enough cash on hand may want to take advantage of a credit-card program being advertised in the July newsletter for American Express card members and in Cineplex Odeon theaters.

title: A DELAWARE COURT REFUSES TO BLOCK TIME-WARNER LINK
description: Broadly affirming the rights of corporate directors to control the fate of their companies, the Delaware Chancery Court refused yesterday to block Time Inc.'s proposed acquisition of Warner Communications Inc.

title: King Leads by 3 at Women's Open
description: While the tall grass at Indianwood Golf and Country Club's links-style course continued to impede most golfers in the 44th United States Women's Open championship, Betsy King kept playing cautiously to avoid that e wheatlike rough.

title: Drafting Lawyers for the Poor
description: Most lawyers live well, thanks in part to their licensed monopoly on access to the legal system. Most can afford to spend some time representing people too poor to pay legal fees. The bar's own ethical canons call for such work and many lawyers and firms answer the call - but many do not.

title: Executive Wed To Ann Halleron
description: Elizabeth Ann Halleron, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Halleron 3d of East Islip, L.I., was married there last evening to William A. Eagan 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eagan Jr. of Wellesley and Hyannis Port, Mass. Msgr. Charles E. Diviney officiated at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Suit Accuses U.S. Agency Of Denying Work Permits
description: A lawsuit filed yesterday accuses the Immigration and Naturalization Service in New York City of illegally denying work permits to applicants for political asylum.

title: Despite Voter-Registration Drives, Few Are Added to Rolls
description: A series of voter-registration drives, including many focusing on black and Hispanic New Yorkers, produced only a negligible increase in the number of people eligible to vote in the Sept. 12 primary, the Board of Elections reported yesterday.

title: Mayor Decides On Dismantling Of Talent Bank
description: In a decision that will effectively dismantle the Talent Bank, Mayor Edward I. Koch said yesterday that the city job-placement agency would be transferred from his office to the city's Personnel Department and its operations combined with other recruitment efforts there.

title: Eastern and Pilots Seem Ready to Modify Stands
description: Negotiators for the pilots' union and Eastern Airlines are showing a willingness to modify their positions, providing the first indication that the strike that has crippled the carrier for four months might be settled, people close to the talks said yesterday.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article yesterday about Edward I. Koch's candidacy for a fourth term as Mayor of New York City discussed two recent polls that sought to assess the strength of Mr. Koch and other contenders in the Democratic primary on Sept. 12. The article reported that a Daily News/WABC-TV poll taken July 6 to 9 found that if the primary were held then, Mr. Koch would have had 31 percent of the vote and David N. Dinkins, the Manhattan Borough President, 45 percent. It also reported that a New York Times/WCBS-TV News Poll taken June 11 to 17 found that Mr. Koch would have 24 percent and Mr. Dinkins 37 percent of the vote then.

title: Reviews/Jazz; An All-Percussion Group With a Host of Variations
description: The drummer Max Roach's all-percussion group M'Boom moved easily from style to style at a rare engagement Tuesday night at Indigo Blues.

title: N.B.A. Games Moving To TNT, Turner Says
description: Ted Turner moved this week to assure the future growth of his latest cable television venture, Turner Network Television, by announcing the ''virtual certainty'' of a switch in channels for next fall's coverage of National Basketball Association games.

title: Review/Music; Works by George Antheil 62 Years After the Fact
description: The conductor Maurice Peress's recent Landmark Jazz Concerts series sought to re-create historically significant programs that took place at Carnegie Hall during the first half of the century. It is a curious concept - a cross between the Civil War restagings that take place annually on various old battlefields and such endeavors as Christopher Hogwood's reconstruction of specific Handel-directed performances of ''Messiah.''

title: Rangers Send Lafleur Back Home in Deal With Nordiques
description: Guy Lafleur, the Hall of Fame forward who played for the Rangers last year after four years of retirement, was signed today by the Quebec Nordiques.

title: Review/Pop; Jody Watley on Stage, in Video Style
description: Jody Watley, whose record ''Larger Than Life'' has produced a handful of hits and made her into a hot property, is a good example of how pop music generated in a recording studio can run into trouble in live performance. Throughout her show at the Beacon Theater on Monday night, Ms. Watley and her two backup singers put on an almost hyperactive show - dancing, running, grinding and everything else that might entertain an audience.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 48. 1. In the Bronx, homey scenes like this are disappearing. Why is that good news? 2. East of the Ural Mountains, a Soviet city with no name is haunted by its past and its future. Why is the city nameless and what are the circumstances? 3. Nearly a third of Congress's retired members are said to be getting pension checks larger than their paychecks. What feature of the Congressional retirement system has created these ''pension millionaires?'' 4. If it turns out that everyday electric and magnetic fields pose health risks, researchers theorize, small sources like the electric coffee maker could play a major role. What is the reason? 5. The Namibian Government is employing a new tactic to conserve one of Africa's most endangered species, the black rhinoceros. What is the tactic, and why do some conservationists oppose it? 6. Why was it a milestone for sports when the National Basketball Association's Denver Nuggets were sold for $65 million by Bertram M. Lee and Peter Bynoe? 7. The House of Representatives gave a slap on the wrist to the National Endowment for the Arts, reducing its appropriation for 1990 by a tiny but significant amount, $45,000. What does that figure represent, and what is at issue? 8. In an extraordinary meeting, President P. W. Botha of South Africa had Nelson Mandela in to tea. What motive is said to have led to Mr. Botha's invitation to the imprisoned leader of the outlawed African National Congress? 9. ''Community-based'' research was once derided by academic scientists, but suddenly it has become the darling of those who test experimental drugs in clinical trials. What is ''community-based'' research and what advantage does it have over traditional testing? 10. ''Reader's Catalogue,'' a book due out soon that lists more than 40,000 volumes in print, has been denounced by some bookdealers. What is at issue? 11. ''There are certain times in diplomacy when a certain delicacy is called for,'' President Bush said of his visits to Poland and Hungary. To what was he referring? 12. Mayor Edward I. Koch broadened the eligibility for bereavement leave to unmarried city employees who live together. What did he say about health and other economic benefits? 13. The Rev. Jesse Jackson called the Spingarn Medal a welcome ''validation.'' What is it and what were the circumstances? 14. West Germany triumphed at one of the world's premier sporting events. What happened? 15. Moscow has adopted a capitalist approach to a future space mission. Explain.

title: Fernandez Strikes Out 16, But a Homer Beats Him
description: The ball jumped off Lonnie Smith's bat and began it's long, cruel arc toward the outfield wall in left. Sid Fernandez, who had done everything a pitcher could to win a ball game, could now do nothing to stop from losing it. He stood, his spirits sinking with the ball's persistent ascent, unable to bring it back and thus unable to reclaim a night he had completely owned.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Mitterrand's Etiquette Has Leaders Confused
description: After the military parade on the Champs-Elysees today, a heavy-metal Nutcracker ballet of Mirage jets, camouflage tanks and plumed and fringed soldiers, there was a much more intriguing display in front of the Egyptian obelisk in the Place de la Concorde.

title: McDonald's Begins Testing of Pizza
description: The McDonald's Corporation., which operates the nation's largest fast-food restaurant chain, will begin test-marketing its 14-inch traditional pizzas at four stores in Owensboro within about 60 days, a spokesman said.

title: Prudential Ends Its Bid For Thomson
description: The Prudential Securities Group said late yesterday that it had terminated plans to acquire Thomson McKinnon Inc., which operates the nation's ninth-largest brokerage. The disclosure came one month after the acquisition was announced.

title: Adobe Systems
description: Adobe Systems Inc. said it plans to purchase 300,000 of the 3.4 million shares of its common stock being sold by Apple Computer Inc. The shares were offered today at $24.125 a share, including a commission of $1.05, meaning Adobe will pay $7.2 million for its purchase. Apple said last week that it would sell its 16 percent stake in Adobe, which makes software that controls laser printers, because the two companies are now becoming competitors. Adobe's shares rose 50 cents today, to $24.75, in over-the-counter trading. Apple gained 12.5 cents, to $40.75

title: Dissidents in N.F.L. Join Search for Commissioner
description: The search for a new National Football League commissioner has been reopened and this time the group of dissident owners will become more involved in the selection process.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I will cooperate with any president elected for this term - whether it be General Jaruzelski or General Kiszczak, or some other representative of the coalition - in order to solve Polish problems and strive for the assurance of a more dignified life for the Poles.'' - Lech Walesa. [ 4:1. ]

title: CAMPAIGN STOP: Laurelton, Queens; Residents Mobilize to Nurture Laurelton
description: A row of abandoned stores at 226th Street and Merrick Boulevard tells the story of where Laurelton stands in its battle against crack dealers - the biggest issue in this predominantly black middle-class community on New York City's eastern edge in Queens.

title: 5 Beaches Are Closed After Sewage Spill
description: Five beaches on Hempstead Harbor were closed Wednesday and will remain closed over the weekend because 100,000 gallons of sewage were dumped in the water, the Nassau County Health Department said yesterday. The beaches are Bar, Hempstead Harbor, IBM, Sea Cliff Village and Tappen.

title: 20-Year Term for Dumping
description: Joseph Mocco, the former township clerk of North Bergen, and four other defendants received prison sentences today for an illegal garbage dumping scheme in the Meadowlands. Superior Court Judge Burrell Ives Humphreys imposed the maximum sentence of 20 years in prison on Mr. Mocco, and fined him $200,000.

title: Death Penalty Sought in Case of 4 Killings
description: Prosecutors said today that they will seek the death penalty for a Yale graduate accused in the Memorial Day stabbing deaths of his mother, brother and two others.

title: Whirlpool Plans To Lay Off 850
description: Citing declines in demand for refrigerators, the Whirlpool Corporation plans to lay off 850 employees next month. The layoffs, scheduled for Aug. 14, will leave Whirlpool's payroll at about 2,750 in Fort Smith, where the plant ranked as the largest local employer and the third-biggest manufacturer in Arkansas.

title: Boeing Jet Orders
description: Boeing Commercial Airplanes, a unit of the Boeing Company, said Aer Lingus had ordered an additional four aircraft - three 737-400's and one 737-500. The order has an estimated total value of about $111 million, the company said. Aer Lingus has now ordered a total of five each of the 737-400 and the 737-500 jets. Delivery of the 737-400's began earlier this week and is scheduled to continue through March 1990. Delivery of the 737-500's is to begin in September 1990 and continue through 1991, the company said.

title: Beyond the Moon's Horizon - Our Home
description: LEAD: By this time, 20 years later, you might expect that we would all be sharing some single, most vivid impression of the first moon walk, holding in mind one dominant, emotional image. But it is not so; our memories are still mixed.

title: California Dairy Is Absolved Of Blame in Poisonings of 48
description: A jury today absolved California's largest dairy of any blame for a batch of bacteria-contaminated cheese that killed 48 people four years ago.

title: F.B.I. Inquiry Begun at Ohio Atomic Weapon Plant
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that it had begun investigating possible environmental crimes and financial fraud at a troubled nuclear weapons plant in Ohio.

title: A System to Train Air Traffic Controllers
description: Arthur Gerstenfeld, founder of UFA Inc. in Newton, Mass., has patented an air traffic control simulator that embodies all the rules and techniques of a seasoned controller. The system, which would be used for training air traffic controllers, features a mock radar screen and computer-generated pilot voices, and it can conjure up various situations, like surprise snowstorms and the need to make an emergency landing at periods of heavy travel.

title: Guests at the Bicentennial
description: Bangladesh - President H. M. Ershad. Brazil - President Jose Sarney. Britain - Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. Cameroon - President Paul Biya. Canada - Prime Minister Brian Mulroney. Congo - President Denis Sassou-Nguesso. Cyprus - President George Vassiliou. Djibouti - President Hassan Gouled Aptidon. Egypt - President Hosni Mubarak. Gabon - President Omar Bongo. Greece - President Christos Sartzetakis. India - Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi. Ireland - President Patrick Hillery. Italy - Prime Minister Ciriaco De Mita. Ivory Coast - President Felix Houphouet-Boigny. Japan - Prime Minister Sousuke Uno. Madagascar - President Didier Ratsiraka. Mali - President Moussa Traore. Mexico - President Carlos Salinas de Gortari. Niger - President Ali Seybou. Pakistan - Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto. Philippines - President Corazon C. Aquino. Portugal - President Mario Soares. Senegal - President Abdou Diouf. Tongo - President Ghassingbe Eyadema Uganda - President Yoweri Museveni. United States - President Bush. Uruguay - President Julio Maria Sanguinetti. Venezuela - President Carlos Andres Perez. West Germany - Chancellor Helmut Kohl. Yugoslavia - President Janez Drnovsek Zaire - President Mobutu Sese Seko. Zimbabwe - President Robert Mugabe.

title: POINTED QUESTIONS FOR CHIEF OF K.G.B.
description: The past and present practices of the K.G.B. were sharply criticized today in the halls of the Kremlin, as members of the new legislature questioned, and ultimately confirmed, Vladimir A. Kryuchkov as head of the agency.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATRUDAY, JULY 15, 1989
description: Companies

title: Quaker Fabric Agrees to Takeover
description: The Quaker Fabric Corporation said it had agreed to be acquired by Unione Manifatture S.p.A. of Italy for $11.35 a share in cash, or a total of about $20.5 million in cash. Quaker said the amount to be paid may not be reduced by more than $1,650, or about 92 cents a share, for certain environmental matters.

title: Cooke Selling Cable Units
description: Jack Kent Cooke signed an agreement yesterday to sell his cable systems to a group of cable operators for an estimated $1.6 billion, or roughly $2,300 a subscriber. The deal is 10 percent higher than the initial transaction with the same group, which fell through in March.

title: Southmark Files Bankruptcy Petition
description: The Southmark Corporation, a large, diversified financial services and real estate company, said today that it had filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy code.

title: Donations to Giuliani Of $1.2 Million Listed
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani, a candidate for the Republican nomination for mayor of New York City, raised $1,251,674 in campaign contributions and spent $1,438,540 from June 12 to July 11, his campaign reported yesterday. It said the money came from more than 4,000 contributors.

title: Sculpture and History Clash in East Hampton
description: For years modern sculptures have been displayed in front of Guild Hall in the Village of East Hampton, a community known as much for its artists as its beaches and wealthy summer residents.

title: After 7 Years, a 'Viable Suspect' in Murders of 48
description: Exactly seven years after the police discovered the first of 48 victims in the nation's worst unsolved murder case, the authorities here say a law student alleged to have posed as a small-town police chief is a ''viable suspect'' in the case.

title: That's Him: The Next Secretariat
description: If you get lucky, you can survive the steamy and dull days of July racing at Belmont Park with enough of a bankroll to get to Saratoga next month and a reason for living at least another 10 months: a glimpse of your Derby horse for next year.

title: 13 Cases of Typhoid Fever Are Traced to the Catskills
description: Thirteen cases of typhoid fever have been confirmed in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey, New York health officials say. They have traced the source of the outbreak to the Catskills.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Airbus Industrie said Braniff Inc., had ordered 50 of its single-aisle Airbus A320 aircraft and had taken options on 50 more. The sale price was not disclosed.

title: Lev N. Tolkunov, 70; Was Editor of Izvestia
description: Lev N. Tolkunov, who was twice chief editor of the Government newspaper Izvestia, has died, the Soviet press agency Tass reported today. He was 70 years old.

title: Georgia Court Releases Abortion Foes' Leader
description: Randall Terry, the leader of the anti-abortion group Operation Rescue, was released from an Atlanta jail late Thursday after a judgesaid he did not have to post a $20,000 bond that the prosecution had sought.

title: About New York; In Twilight World Of Alzheimer's, A Place of Solace
description: New Yorkers accept confusion and disorientation as a fact of life. For most, things could be worse.

title: At Papp's Public Theater, a Show of Arrogance
description: While the Israeli public remains sharply divided on whether representatives of the Palestine Liberation Organization should speak with its Government, producer Joseph Papp has decided that Palestinian actors should not speak to New York audiences.

title: KEY RATES
Excerpts From Decision On Time-Warner Merger
description: Following are excerpts from yesterday's opinion by Chancellor William T. Allen of the Delaware Chancery Court denying a request by Paramount Communications Inc. to block the proposed acquisition of Warner Communications Inc. by Time Inc.:

title: Senate Move on Flag Is Scheduled for Fall
description: The Senate will act this fall on both a constitutional amendment and a less sweeping statute to overcome last month's Supreme Court ruling that allows flag burning, Senator George J. Mitchell said today.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping; With Uninvited Wildlife
description: Sometimes it is a coyote that snatches puppies or kittens from a backyard patio, as is happening increasingly in the Los Angeles area. Or the intruder may be an overweight racoon that regularly ransacks the rubbish after dark. In the Southwest it is likely to be a snake that slithers into the house through an open doorway or a plumbing line.

title: Books of The Times; Japanese Put a Spin on Baseball
description: You Gotta Have Wa By Robert Whiting Illustrated. 339 pages. Macmillan. $17.95.

title: Day of Wines and Bunting: 200th Anniversary for France
description: France toasted the 200th anniversary of its revolution today with stirring spectacle and relaxed revelry: a day of vintage wines and tricolored bunting, full of Gallic panache, that began with a Napoleonic display of military might on the Champs-Elysees and ended with a surreal pageant of dance and music and light in the Place de la Concorde.

title: Ted Turner Provokes Protests Over Attack On Foes of Abortion
description: Statements by Ted Turner, chairman of the Turner Broadcasting System, that abortion opponents were ''idiots'' and ''bozos'' prompted picketing outside TBS headquarters today and calls by opponents for air time to present their views.

title: Get Your Ticket to 'Batman' or Boston
description: Under one roof there are 110 retail shops, a nine-screen movie theater and a string of fast-food restaurants that sell everything from chili to sushi. This isn't a typical shopping mall; it's the recently renovated Union Station, the train depot built in 1908 on Capitol Hill.

title: POLITICAL TENSION RISING IN MANAGUA
description: On the eve of a national election campaign here, tensions between the Sandinista Government and its opponents have created an atmosphere of barely controlled hostility that diplomats fear may set the tone for a volatile campaign season.

title: The Lightning of Olivier
description: LEAD: I met Laurence Olivier in the fall of 1965. I was to audition for the National Theater in London, of which he was then - I was going to say artistic director, but he was everything.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Suzanne Beth Marlin Becomes Bride Of Gadi Ben-Menachem in New Jersey
description: Suzanne Beth Marlin, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert L. Marlin of New York and Parsippany, N.J., and Gadi Ben-Menachem, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Yoram Ben-Menachem of Houston and Seattle, were married last evening at the Tammy Brook Country Club in Cresskill, N.J., by Rabbi Daniel Franzel.

title: Suzanne M. Shea, a Coach, Weds Donald F. O'Connell
description: At the Fordham University Church in the Bronx, Suzanne Marie Shea, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Shea of Middle Village, Queens, was married yesterday to Donald Francis O'Connell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John O'Connell of Lloyd Harbor, L.I. The Rev. Joseph A. O'Hare, the president of Fordham University, performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: Camera
description: When a camera maker chooses to identify a model with a single-digit number, you know it must be something special. That's certainly the case with Canon's forthcoming EOS-1.

title: Landmark Status for Cottages Is an Honor that UConn Regrets
description: LIVING the edge of the University of Connecticut campus stands a row of 11 brown-shingled cottages, a remnant of the days when just 500 students attended the agricultural school in Storrs. The cottages are now designated as landmarks in the National Register of Historic Places.

title: TV Technology
description: To the Editor:

title: Cigarette Tossed Into River In Ukraine Ignites Spilled Oil
description: A farm worker in the northwestern Ukraine tossed a cigarette butt into a river and caused a major alert as spilled fuel in the water burst into flames for several miles, destroying two bridges.

title: Feminist Art, Traditional Forms
description: LEAD: IT is a question asked frequently of Miriam Schapiro: Isn't there a contradiction between her ardent feminist views and her use of such traditional ''women's crafts'' as embroidery, quilting and crocheting in her collages, or ''femmages'' as she calls them?

title: Melissa E. Mask And Marc James Wed in Brooklyn
description: Melissa Elizabeth Mask and Marc Stephen James were married yesterday at the Congregational Church of the Evangeline in Brooklyn. The Rev. Edward Goode performed the ceremony. Mrs. James, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George C. Mask of Brooklyn, graduated from Yale University and received an M.B.A. degree from Harvard University. She expects to join Morgan Stanley & Company next month as an associate in capital markets.

title: Guitar Center Expands Offerings and Reputation
description: THE National Guitar Summer Workshop, which now includes studies in bass, voice and keyboard and has a sister program in San Rafael, Calif., proclaims itself the largest summer music program of its type in the country. ''In a time when many of the summer festivals have closed down or dramatically reduced in size and scope, our project has flourished,'' said David Smolover, the director of the workshop, which is based at the Canterbury School in New Milford.

title: Six Plan to Cross Antarctica on Foot
description: Lured by the romance and danger of the great polar expeditions of the past, a group of six explorers from six nations is to embark here soon on a seven-month, 4,000-mile trek across Antarctica by dog sled and ski.

title: Wagner Coming to Westchester
description: WHEN the Greenwich soprano Lili Seggos conceived her dream of a Richard Wagner summer festival, the Kensico Dam Plaza in Valhalla was its setting. Valhalla, of course, is the name of the mythical hall in Wagner's four-opera cycle ''Der Ring des Nibelungen,'' but the plaza also appeals to Mrs. Seggos because of its ''imposing'' outdoor setting - well-matched, she felt, to the German composer's monumental works.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Cycling Leaders 7 Seconds Apart: Jelle Nijdam of the Netherlands won the 14th leg of the men's Tour de France yesterday, but as the 2,020-mile bicycling event reached the base of the Alps in Gap, France, Laurent Fignon of France and Greg LeMond of the United States were running one-two, just seven seconds apart. Charly Mottet is third over all, 57 seconds back. The defending champion, Pedro Delgado of Spain, is fourth, 3:03 back, with Andy Hampsten of the United States fifth at 5:18. (AP) Canadian Moves Into First: Kelly-Ann Way of Canada moved into the overall lead of the women's Tour de France as Katrin Tobin of the United States won the fourth stage ending at Gap yesterday. The two-time champion Jeannie Longo of France dropped to second over all.(AP) Tennis Wilander to Face Gomez: Top-seeded Andre Agassi was knocked out of the $415,000 United States Pro Tennis championships last night, losing to Andres Gomez after Mats Wilander had earned a place in tonight's finals. Agassi, who had reached the semifinals with three successive straight-set victories, lost to Gomez, 7-6, 6-7, 6-2, in 2 hours 34 minutes before a capacity crowd at the Longwood Cricket Club in Brookline, Mass. Agassi, 19 and ranked fourth in the world, lost for the second time in three career meetings with 27th-ranked Gomez of Ecuador. Wilander overcame his usual slow start to eliminate Martin Jaite in the afternoon semifinal. Wilander beat Jaite for the seventh time in eight meetings and put himself over the $7 million mark in career earnings with a 3-6, 6-4, 6-4 triumph.(AP) Sabatini and Jarryd in Finals: Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina overpowered Katerina Maleeva of Bulgaria, and Anders Jarryd of Sweden defeated Jim Courier of the United States yesterday to earn berths in the finals of the $250,000 Gunze World Tournament in Osaka, Japan. Sabatini beat Maleeva, 6-3, 6-4. In the final today, Sabatini will face Mary Joe Fernandez of the United States, who defeated Nana Miyagi of Japan, 6-1, 4-6, 7-5. In the men's semifinals, Jarryd rallied to beat Courier, 3-6, 6-3, 6-2. He will face Pete Sampras, who defeated fellow American Jim Grabb, 6-3, 4-6, 6-4, yesterday.(AP) Lundgren Advances: Sixth-seeded Peter Lundgren of Sweden won two matches yesterday to advance to the final of the $160,000 Volvo Tennis Hall of Fame Championships in Newport, R.I. Lundgren will meet unseeded Jim Pugh of Palos Verdes, Calif., in today's final. Pugh defeated Danie Visser, 6-4, 6-7, 6-3. Lundgren beat the third-seeded John Fitzgerald, 7-6, 7-6, yesterday morning in a quarterfinal match that had been suspended by rain Friday. After a 2 1/2-hour break, Lundgren beat unseeded Glenn Layendecker, 6-3, 6-4.(AP) Golf American Wins Scottish Open: Mike Allen, an unheralded American who had never finished better than fifth in three years on the European Tour, holed shots from off the green three times in a round of 63 that lifted him to a two-stroke, 272 victory yesterday in the Scottish Open at Gleneagles. Allen finished 12 under par. (AP) Zembriski Ties Moody: Walter Zembriski shot a sizzling front nine and scored a five-under-par 66 yesterday to tie defending champion Orville Moody for the lead with 134 after two rounds of the Greater Grand Rapids Open senior tournament in Michigan. (AP) Hulbert Holds Off Sutton: Mike Hulbert put together a bogey-free round of three-under-par 68 and held off a charging Hal Sutton for a one-shot lead at 199 after yesterday's third round of the Anheuser-Busch Golf Classic at Williamsburg, Va. (AP) Track and Field Butler Wins Dash: James Butler won the 100-meter dash and another American, Nat Page, captured the 400-meter hurdles yesterday at a Grand Prix track and field meet in Getxo, Spain. Butler was timed in 10.48 seconds, beating Renaldo Nehemiah (10.53). Page won his event in 49.68. Diane Williams of the United States won the women's 100-meter dash in 11.60. (AP) Boxing Decision Goes to Rosi: Gianfranco Rosi of Italy knocked down Darrin Van Horn 30 seconds into the fight and went on to beat the previously undefeated 20-year-old champion from the University of Kentucky in a unanimous 12-round decision to capture the International Boxing Federation junior-middleweight title in Atlantic City yesterday.(AP)

title: Interior Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: Only an Occasional Cusser
description: To the Editor:

title: PRICES: OUT OF SIGHT
description: Does beauty have a price? A casual spin through a department store reveals that it does, and the price is soaring. A 1.7-ounce jar of face cream can cost $125. An elaborate box of loose powder, $75. An ounce of perfume, $350. Even a lipstick, something women pick up on impulse, can easily reach a blistering $16. Some companies believe that the trend is peaking out. Others, meanwhile, are pushing their prices farther into the stratosphere.

title:
A LA CARTE;
Mixing and Dining and Cultural Outings
description: LEAD: CONCERT- and theatergoers attending the final Pepsico Summerfare festival at the State University of New York at Purchase and looking for a dining spot nearby might consider making reservations for the special pre-festival dinner offered at Cobble Creek Cafe (761-0050) at 578 Anderson Hill Road.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD: TOMATO CELEBRATION As history or legend has it, standing on the steps of the Salem County Courthouse on a hot day in July 1820, Col. Robert Gibbon Johnson ate a tomato. Supposedly, his public action started an appreciation of the ''love apple,'' and the tomato will be celebrated at a festival on Saturday in

title: Tenant Landlords
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Poland's Paradoxes Poland's changes are exemplified by the sight of Lech Walesa all but urging his recent jailer, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, to run for the presidency.

title: Cappuccino by the Bay
description: LEAD: THERE are mornings when the aroma of coffee hangs over San Francisco's North Beach like an invisible cloud. With the roasting kettles of Graffeo Coffee Company at one end of Columbus Avenue and those of Caffe Trieste at the other, the area draws San Franciscans devoted to fresh, Italian-style coffee beans.

title: Not Another Pretty Face
description: ''I'M DOING THIS SEQUENCE where puppets come out of my back with the faces on them of the other cast members in torment,'' says Robert Englund. ''They're the souls of my victims.'' Englund is the actor known by millions of mostly teen-age film viewers as Freddy Krueger, the heinous, disfigured, dream-haunting murderer who first reached the screen in 1984 in ''A Nightmare on Elm Street.'' By now, Freddy is probably the most profitable evildoer in Hollywood history, ''Nightmare'' and its three sequels having generated some $300 million in box office receipts and video-cassette sales. Englund is speaking by phone, from the set of ''A Nightmare on Elm Street 5: The Dream Child,'' which opens next month; he says he's in makeup.

title: Robin Topping, Reporter, Is Married
description: Rebecca Lynn Topping, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Topping of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday at the Scarsdale Congregational Church to Kevin Kearon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Kearon of Lynbrook, L.I. The Rev. Phillip S. Washburn officiated.

title: A Show Meant to Give Pleasure
description: AT most private galleries, end-of-the-season exhibitions tend to be lackluster affairs. But the one now at the Kornbluth Gallery here, seasonable though it is, could hold its own at any time of year.

title: LET'S HEAR IT FOR THE EARTHBOUND
description: APOLLO The Race to the Moon. By Charles Murray and Catherine Bly Cox. Illustrated. 506 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $24.95.

title: Injured Brooklyn Man Dies After His Arrest
description: A 25-year-old man died late Friday in Brooklyn after he was arrested by police officers who said he had been hit in the back with a stick by another man and struck by a passing car, after several altercations.

title: Economics Lesson
description: Seeking gold from the Nuggets cost Bertram M. Lee and his partner, Peter Bynoe, $65 million. When the National Basketball Association, as expected, approves their purchase last week of the Denver Nuggets, they will become the first black owners of a major American professional sports franchise. Mr. Lee, the architect of the deal who already owns three radio stations, a hair-care company and a Boston television station and had been shopping for a sports franchise, said the purchase was motivated by economics, not posterity. ''If it didn't make economic sense, believe me, we would not be sitting out there having a need to be first,'' Mr. Lee said. ''To the extent that we are, and that we can be used as role models, that we can give hope and inspiration then, fine. It's not a challenge, though. I'm not putting down the gauntlet.''

title: NONFICTION
description: SONGS FROM THE ALLEY. By Kathleen Hirsch. (Ticknor & Fields, $22.95.) In ''Songs From the Alley,'' Kathleen Hirsch illuminates the painful, appalling lives of Amanda and Wendy, two homeless women in Boston. Amanda struggles to hold down low-level jobs, fails to resolve unfinished emotional business with her severely disturbed mother and alcoholic, abusive father, finds love with a man who falls ill and dies. Then she succumbs to dependence: ''The city's hidden map of soup kitchens, shelters, and homeless hangouts, and the people she is meeting - all her needs are being met. She has food, clothing, shelter, and more real friendship than she ever knew on 'the outside.' '' But ultimately, Amanda forms a positive relationship with a counselor at a shelter, resumes working and gets placed in a room of her own. Wendy defies happy endings. After a childhood of abuse she turns to drink as a teen-ager and emerges a hopeless alcoholic. In her 30's, she is a haggard wreck. Too disruptive for the shelters, she spends days panhandling change to finance her daily liter of vodka, sleeps on a grate, clings to men whose alcohol-induced viciousness repeatedly lands her in the hospital, battered and slashed. The wretched details are rendered brilliantly, and if Ms. Hirsch had limited herself simply to the two women, this would be a fine, if less ambitious, book. She attempts more, with lengthy chapters tracing the history of social welfare in Boston. They leave the reader more impatient than informed. Are Wendy and Amanda typical? How much are they simply the victims of their own bad luck and character flaws? To what extent has government failed them? Ms. Hirsch, a Boston writer, talks vaguely about the need for a ''holistic approach'' to homelessness, the mobilizing of resources to create ''healthy communities'' and ''owning up to the bankruptcy of some of our dominant social values.'' Amanda, Wendy and the reader deserve better than that.

title: Elster Is Sitting and Fuming
description: He is 24 years old and again in that state of temporary unemployment known as ''benched.'' It has happened to Kevin Elster before. But now anger has replaced acceptance, and disgust, not diplomacy, dominates his conversation.

title: Stella, Reborn as an Unmarried Mother
description: The director would be just a moment. A nurse rushed into his office to administer the Hollywood equivalent of a swift kick in the backside, his twice-weekly vitamin B injection. So when the young assistant knocked to say the cast and crew of ''Stella'' were ready on the set, a revitalized John Erman practically flew down the corridor in his white running shoes. ''Mr. Erman is traveling,'' the assistant shouted in a walkie-talkie, breathless to keep pace.

title: A Balance of Nature and of Nature Lovers
description: ON summer weekends, hundreds of sailors and sunbathers flock to Sandy Point, a sandy island in Little Narragansett Bay where hundreds of herring gulls tend their nests. To protect the fragile island and its creatures but also to let people enjoy the island's popular beaches, the Mashantucket Land Trust and the Stonington Community Center have joined forces.

title: French Revolution
description: To the Editor: I found ''In the Revolution's Footsteps'' most informative, but I missed a reference to the Chapelle Expiatoire in the Square Louis XVI (south side of Boulevard Haussmann, two blocks west of the Printemps department store). Here were buried the victims of the events of Aug. 10, 1792, in the Tuileries followed by the 1,300 victims of the guillotine in the Place de la Concorde, including the King and Queen. As a result of a search ordered by Louis XVIII, the remains of the royal couple were recovered and buried at St. Denis. The crypt altar of the Chapelle Expiatoire is located where their bodies were found. The Chapelle also contains memorials, in marble, to Louis XVI and Marie-Antoinette.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: RALEIGH, N.C.;
Tall Neighbor For the Capitol
description: LEAD: SITE preparation here is nearly complete for a 29-story building that, when completed in two years, will join three others that now rise 17 stories or more just a few blocks from the three-story State Capitol.

title: Danbury Plans a Tribute to Marian Anderson's Lustrous Career
description: LEAD: THOUGH she has made her home on a rambling 100-acre farm here for just shy of a half century, the celebrated contralto Marian Anderson has kept a low profile. So low, in fact, that when the directors of the Charles Ives Center for the Performing Arts in Danbury suggested that a gala concert be staged in her honor, the 87-year-old singer was opposed to it.

title: A Composer Who Lived In Too Many Worlds
description: History is a kind of housekeeping for the memory. It comforts us by finding a place - a context - for all the disparate things and people that dangle in our pasts. What is it, indeed, that we remember lastingly? Is it necessarily the things of intrinsic value or is it things that make sense of history? Do we remember Schoenberg with such vividness not because all of his music is very beautiful (some is), but because of his decisive positioning as artist-philosopher-politician in the historical wars of style and method? Posterity embraces him because he pushed history forward.

title: Radical Transformations
description: AROUND MIDNIGHT ON THE EVENING before George Bush's inauguration, a founding member of the New Left made his first visit to the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in Washington. Nineteen years earlier, as a Marxist theoretician and co-editor of Ramparts, the slick journal of the New Left, David Horowitz had tried to bring the anti-war rebellion to a revolutionary boil by publishing a luridly tinted cover photo that showed demonstrators torching a branch of the Bank of America. Now he stood in front of the monument, a stocky, bearded 50-year-old, squeezing back tears as a friend, Wallace Nunn, searched for the names of 12 buddies who had died in Vietnam, where Nunn served as a helicopter gunner. ''I told David this fellow was with me here, that one was there,'' says Nunn, a managing director of Smith Barney and a Republican Party contributor. ''It was a special moment, a coming together.'' For Horowitz, the meeting at the monument symbolized more than a reconciliation with the ''imperialist'' establishment he once sought to overthrow by any means possible. It marked the final stage in a self-imposed political rehabilitation that has grown into a national crusade. Three years ago, the disillusioned ex-radical re-entered the ideological lists with another deserter from the 1960's left, Peter Collier, the Ramparts co-editor with whom he has written best-selling dynastic biographies of the Rockefellers and Kennedys. Together, the two launched the Second Thoughts Project, a kind of peripatetic think tank that promotes the revisionist views of some 20 former radicals who once drafted key New Left texts and led anti-war protests. The project has developed into one of the most spirited anti-left, pro-American campaigns since the lapsed Communist Whittaker Chambers turned on his former comrades in the 1940's.

title: North's Sentence Teaches Wrong Lessons
description: To the Editor:

title: Legal Guidance For Facing Divorce
description: LEAD: A WOMAN with no income of her own is being sued for divorce by a once-wealthy man on the verge of personal bankruptcy. Another woman has been separated for four years and wonders if her divorce, mired in legal technicalities, will ever actually take place. A third worries that she cannot compete with her husband, who has hired the most expensive, high-powered matrimonial lawyer in town.

title: NEW JERSEY FOLLOW-UP
description: Auto Insurance

title: HOW 'HEALTH FOOD HIPPIES' BECAME SERIOUS MARKETERS
description: Before introducing his line of New Morning cereals in 1982, Jean Fialkoff conducted a taste test with a small group of consumers he knew quite well. He gathered his four children - ages 2, 3, 5 and 6 - around the kitchen table one morning for a sampling. They approved and a company was born.

title: Now, the U.S. Looks at Cambodia Differently
description: FOR 10 years, the United States has condemned the Vietnamese occupation of Cambodia. Now that Vietnam's troops are leaving, the United States has had to refocus its policy on a different objective: how to prevent a return to power by the Khmer Rouge.

title: The Flip Side of Florence
description: FLORENCE'S art treasures make an extraordinarily strong claim on travelers' attention, but few visitors realize that the city played as great a role in the history of music as in the history of art and architecture. Opera and the piano were invented in Florence, and the city has for five centuries been home, haven or source of inspiration to many outstanding musicians, Italian and foreign.

title: A Leftist Group in Honduras Admits Bombing on 7 G.I.'s
description: A leftist group has taken responsibility for the bombing that injured seven United States Army soldiers.

title: Bittersweet Meditation Of a Lone Ranger
description: IN a framed cartoon in my office, a middle-aged man sits alone on a blanket in a summer meadow, munching a sandwich and staring absently into space, a portable radio his only company. The caption reads, ''Wally Prestwicke, self-employed, holds his annual picnic.''

title: When Festivals Are Passports to the World
description: Modern dance has flourished abroad in the 1980's, and those who first brought us the tidings and continue to introduce foreign dance groups into the United States are the summer festivals - principally the American Dance Festival in Durham, N.C., the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in Becket, Mass., and the Pepsico Summerfare festival in Purchase, N.Y.

title: A Merger Clicks, Painfully
description: After three years of turmoil, one of the biggest mergers in advertising is starting to pay off, thanks mostly to its architect - a Middle Western adman who stumbled badly at first in making the transition to Madison Avenue.

title: New York Finds A Tie to the West
description: The western string tie is roping in more and more city slickers.

title: For Italy's Entrepreneurs, The Figures Are Bella
description: AT THE AGE OF 43, AFTER 17 YEARS WITH I.B.M., AL-berto Tripi had tired of working for an international giant, so he started his own computer company, with offices inside the 15th-century Palazzo Colonna in the heart of Rome. He chose the palace deliberately because of its elegance and its enviable address, a stone's throw from Trajan's Forum and the central Piazza Venezia. It set a certain tone, Tripi says. Image counts, especially in Italy, where people devote considerable effort to present una bella figura, a fine figure.

title: H.U.D. Inquiry Focuses on L.I. Projects
description: LEAD: FROM the village of Island Park to the town of Brookhaven, accusations of corruption and favoritism in federally subsidized housing programs have given a strong Long Island angle to the investigations that have shaken the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: Factionalism Hurts Afghan Rebels as Government Army Fails to Collapse
description: Paradox seems to be the guiding principle of the 10-year-old war in Afghanistan. The Soviet Army lost in Afghanistan because it never learned to fight a guerrilla war. Now the rebels who beat them do not appear able to fight a conventional one.

title: Dinkins Offers Plans to Reduce Crime
description: In his first major statement on crime, David N. Dinkins, the Manhattan Borough President and Democratic candidate for mayor, said yesterday that he would increase the number of police officers on the city's subway trains and in its neighborhoods, and would make sure that all convicted criminals face certain punishment.

title: It Was Mozart's Mystery to Be Genius and Fool
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Scratch, Get Even
description: To control breeding: Remove debris that collects water (cans, bottles, old tires, and so on). Empty watering cans, flowerpots, toys, swimming pools not in use and other outdoor objects.

title: How Rock Is Changing Hollywood's Tune
description: Jack Nicholson's fiendish Joker and Michael Keaton's Caped Crusader aren't the only forces that collide in the smash-hit movie ''Batman.'' The film's noisy soundtrack presents a pitched battle between the two strains of music that have accompanied movies since the dawn of the sound era: one derived from high culture, the other from pop. The majority of the film's score is loud, post-Wagnerian action music composed by Danny Elfman. Sly, subterranean funk songs by Prince make up the rest.

title: Nina Liggett Weds
description: Nina Louise Liggett and Lieut. Andrew Richard Bacas, U.S.N., were married yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in San Diego by the Rev. Murray Albertyn. The bride is the daughter of Rex A. Liggett of McCall, Idaho, and the late Marianne S. Liggett, and the adopted daughter of M. Jane Haubert of San Diego. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Bacas of Arlington, Va.

title: Question Of the Week; Are Foreign Golfers Better Than Americans?
description: No way, Jose, Seve, Sandy, Nicky, Bernie, Greg. This may have been arguable two years ago, but not now. First-class American players (those with realistic chances of winning one of the four major tournaments) vastly outnumber foreigners, and the gap is widening. The 1989 Ryder Cup will be no contest. DAVID SMITH New York

title: Wheelchairs
description: To the Editor: Thanks for your article, ''Finding Cruise Ships Fitted for Wheelchair Users'' (Practical Traveler, April 9). I booked a vacation for my family of five with Premier Cruise Lines, the official Walt Disney World cruise line. I had checked with several travel agents to see if there were cabins on the ship that were suited for the handicapped - my husband has multiple sclerosis and is confined to a wheelchair - and I was told that there were several cabins available.

title: 2 New Shows Stretch Limits Of TV News
description: During the first week in August, both ABC and NBC will introduce new hourlong news shows in prime time, and neither will look like any prime-time program previously produced by a network news division.

title:
GARDENING;
There's Treasure in Those Weeds
description: LEAD: TO paraphrase an old saying, one gardener's flowers may be another gardener's weeds.

title: Robin Workman Weds
description: Robin Workman and Marc Persily, magna cum laude graduates of the State University of New York at Albany, were married last evening at Temple Judea in Massapequa, L.I., by Rabbi Leonard Stern. The bride, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Workman of Massapequa, recently received a master's degree in education from Hofstra University. Mr. Persily, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Persily of East Windsor, N.J., is a certified public accountant for KPMG Peat Marwick in New York.

title: Mission for Europeans Signals Growing Power
description: By asking the European Community to coordinate Western aid to Poland and Hungary, the Group of Seven major industrial countries today acknowledged the community's growing importance and gave it a major new opportunity.

title: 2,000 to Compete in State Games
description: LEAD: SEVERAL years ago, William Mudano and a friend, Dan Doyle, a former basketball coach at Trinity College, were discussing why Connecticut was one of only about 10 states without a sports festival for its amateur athletes.

title: Question Of the Week; Are Foreign Golfers Better Than Americans?
description: Greatness in golf is determined by a player's performance in the sport's major championships. None of the top five players on the PGA Tour money list -Kite, Calcavecchia, Couples, Stewart and Hoch - have ever won a major. The top five foreign golfers - Faldo, Lyle, Ballesteros, Norman, Langer - have won nine majors. ADAM S. ROSENBERG Dix Hills, L.I.

title: Mara Beth Landis Is Wed To David Arzi, a Banker
description: Mara Beth Landis, a daughter of Paul Landis of North Woodmere, L.I., and the late Jacqueline B. Landis, was married yesterday to David Arzi, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ezekiel Arzi of Parsippany, N.J., at Temple Emanuel in Great Neck, L.I., by Rabbi Robert S. Widom.

title: Lesley C. Snelling Plans a Wedding
description: The engagement of Lesley Coates Snelling and John Bober has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Darwin Snelling of Allentown, Pa., and Alexandria Bay, N.Y. The wedding is to take place in August. Miss Snelling, a graduate of the Northfield Mount Hermon School and the University of Pennsylvania, is a fourth-year student at the Tulane University School of Medicine.

title: Reviews/Music; Puccini's 'Trittico,' in Central Park
description: For 16 summers, Vincent La Selva and his amusingly misnamed New York Grand Opera have offered humble but honest free staged performances of Italian potboilers in Central Park, with curiously mixed results. On the one hand, these efforts are surely conducted, decently sung and modestly but idiomatically staged. On the other hand, they are decidedly of the ''little opera'' genre, with frayed veterans, unpolished newcomers and unabashed second-raters crowding the stage.

title: Are Feminist Heroines An Endangered Species?
description: In the distant days of 1978, the heroine of ''An Unmarried Woman'' had a memorable series of reactions to the news that her husband was leaving her. As the abandoned Erica, Jill Clayburgh lost her lunch on a SoHo street, took up with an artist played by Alan Bates, then amazingly let him move to Vermont without her. We last see her walking through Manhattan, struggling to carry the large painting he left behind, a perfectly contented smile on her face. At the time, even enlightened women were heard to mutter about the wisdom of her choice; independence, in this case, had to be measured against the virtues of Alan Bates at a time when he might have given Mel Gibson competition in the heartthrob race. But no one, feminist or not, could doubt that the film ends in triumphant self-reliance.

title: P. J. Schuyff Wed To Miss Puckette
description: At All Saints' Chapel at the University of the South in Sewanee, Tenn., Charlotte Elliott Puckette was married yesterday to Peter Johan Schuyff. The Rev. Samuel T. Lloyd 3d, assisted by the Rev. G. Cecil Woods Jr., performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: Correction
description: An article on June 25 about special education for gifted students who are disabled misstated the practice of the Middle States Association in accrediting special-education schools. The association has accredited the Craig School in Boonton and the Winston School in Summit.

title: Poignance Measured in Digits
description: Normally the phonograph plays a casual accompaniment to our lives. We think of it, quite rightly, as a means of entertainment. Yet there are times when the machine suddenly shows a deeper aspect of its character, and the miraculous nature of the instrument stands revealed.

title: Aces Wild! Refiguring the Hole-in-One Odds
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Tuning Up Air-Conditioners
description: SUMMER'S dog days call on air-conditioners to deliver peak performance under grueling conditions. Even if your air-conditioner was thoroughly prepared at the beginning of the summer, you should inspect and maintain it at least once in midseason to make sure that it performs well during the sultry months ahead.

title: 19th Century Had Its Young Victors
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Meanwhile, The P.L.O. Is Depending on Washington
description: WHEN the late President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt argued in the mid-1970's that the United States held 99 percent of the cards in the Middle East game, the Palestine Liberation Organization attacked him bitterly as a defeatist American stooge. But today, all Palestinian eyes are on the United States as the holder of the keys to peace in the Middle East and the Palestinian dream of a homeland.

title: Can the Pentagon Account for Itself?
description: OVER the last 40 years, perhaps nothing in Washington has been so scrutinized, assessed and reassessed as the way the Defense Department works. At least six Presidential or Congressional commissions and dozens of lesser groups have called for change.

title: Aces Wild! Refiguring the Hole-in-One Odds
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Child's Pursuit of Stardom, a Family's Quest for Balance
description: LEAD: FOUR days a week during the school year, Jim Scarle of Eatontown picks up his 14-year-old daughter, Kelly, after classes and drives 72 miles to her ballet lesson in Manhattan. While Kelly works equations in the back seat, Mr. Scarle plots parking strategies and weighs the merits of browsing for stereo equipment on the Upper West

title: A MOSCOW COP AT SEA
description: POLAR STAR By Martin Cruz Smith. 386 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.

title: At Last, Japan Takes Center Stage
description: The seven largest Western industrial nations will conclude their annual economic summit conference in Paris today. Since 1975, these yearly meetings have generated an impressive degree of consensus among world leaders on how to organize their complex trade, monetary and financial relations in an increasingly interdependent world. This summit meeting managed to address the traditional issues as well as issues relating to the environment.

title: Claudia Steinegger Weds
description: Claudia Jean Steinegger, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Steinegger of Darien, Conn., was married there yesterday at the Noroton Presbyterian Church to Steven Adam Dey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Dey of Lynbrook, L.I. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Marie Reed, the pastor of the church, and the Rev. Lester L. McGongle, a United Methodist minister.

title: When All the Stars Are Gone
description: TWO OR THREE TIMES A MONTH I RE-ceive a collect call from my best friend in high school, who is now homeless in Miami Beach. He calls from a telephone booth across the street from a fruit store on Collins Avenue.

title: Miss Thompson Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Jennifer Laura Thompson to Stephen John Van de Graaf took place yesterday at the Norfield Congregational Church in Weston, Conn. The Rev. Susan DeSimone performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Steven Bauman, a United Methodist minister.

title: Soviet Directors Mix Illusion and Reality
description: ''Artists are never appreciated in the motherland,'' said the theater director Anatoly Vasiliev. ''The motherland loves portraits and the dead. When I die, probably I will be loved by the motherland, too. If I want my people to love me, I should get in a car accident as soon as possible.''

title: On Language; Shades of Gray/Grey
description: HOW DO YOU SPELL the color (achromatic, but it's still a color) created by mixing black and white? Is it >grey or >gray?

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: RED BRANCH. By Morgan Llywelyn. (Morrow, $19.95.) The novelist Morgan Llywelyn has created a lusty, poetic and legendary world in ''Red Branch,'' based on disparate tales of Ireland's mythical warrior-hero Cuchulain (pronounced koo-KHOO-len). The story begins with a boy, Setanta, born in mysterious circumstances to Dectera, the King's half sister.

title: North's Sentence Teaches Wrong Lessons
description: To the Editor:

title: King Trips Over Bogeys at Open
description: Betsy King crumpled over the last four holes of the Indianwood Golf and Country Club course today, took two bogeys and a double bogey in the stretch, and saw her four-stroke lead at the 44th United States Women's Open evaporate in the pressure cooker of the major championship.

title: 'MOONLIGHT' AND MARXISM
description: MARK THE MUSIC The Life and Work of Marc Blitzstein. By Eric A. Gordon. Illustrated. 605 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $29.95.

title: NONFICTION
description: THE DEBT AND THE DEFICIT: False Alarms/Real Possibilities. By Robert Heilbroner and Peter Bernstein. (Norton, $12.95.) This mercifully short economics primer, ''The Debt and the Deficit,'' sets out to prove that neither the United States' national debt nor its annual budget deficit is quite the bogyman that Americans have been led to believe. The debt, contend Robert Heilbroner, a professor of economics at the New School for Social Research, and Peter Bernstein, a financial analyst, is actually smaller than it was during the 1950's and 1960's, when viewed as a percentage of the gross national product. Nor is it especially large compared to the current debt of other industrialized nations, including that model of thriftiness, Japan. The authors argue that the budget deficit has been vastly exaggerated because of the Government's antiquated bookkeeping methods. While corporations differentiate between current operating expenses and capital expenditures, the Government does not. So, they note, ''all expenditures for whatever purpose - as durable as a dam or as ephemeral as a White House dinner party - are lumped together.'' By setting aside capital spending, adjusting for inflation, subtracting state and local government surpluses and the amount of Federal debt held by the Government itself, Mr. Heilbroner and Mr. Bernstein arrive at a deficit for fiscal 1988 of about $3 billion - contrasted with the Government's own figure of $255 billion. If both the debt and deficit are false alarms, is there nothing Mr. Heilbroner and Mr. Bernstein would have us worry about? There are several things: the United States' diminished position in the world economy, the ever-present threat of inflation, and the decay of our cities. These are all, the authors point out, problems likely to require Government involvement - and, of course, money.

title: A CORRECTION
description: The headline on the ''Streetscapes'' column on July 9 misidentified the colors of the University of Pennsylvania. They are red and blue.

title: On the Heels of a Dog Law, a Bit of Nipping
description: Somehow, in the midst of signing a bill today concerning the humane treatment of guide dogs, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the New York State Senate's majority leader got into a battle over the subject of bias-related violence against people.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I asked my fuel company not to top off the oil tank during summer, as I would rather not have to pay for all that fuel now. They said that if the tank were not filled it would be subject to scaling, and debris could clog the lines. I noted that this was a new tank, but they still say this is a possibility.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE SECRET LIFE OF CYNDY GARVEY. By Cynthia Garvey and Andy Meisler. (Doubleday, $18.95.) Cynthia Garvey might have been just another woman victimized by men, except that she was beautiful, rich, famous and married to Steve Garvey when he was a star first baseman for the Los Angeles Dodgers. And so she got to write ''The Secret Life of Cyndy Garvey,'' a book whose title alludes to the dichotomy between Cyndy, the name the press gave her, and Cynthia, the woman she really was.

title: August Wedding For Miss McGrath
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. McGrath of Rochester have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Catherine Hale McGrath and William Lee Kissick Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Kissick of Philadelphia.

title: Cecily W. Rock and Joseph W. Nega, Lawyers, Exchange Vows in Virginia
description: The marriage of Cecily Wyatt Rock, the daughter of Sue Wyatt Rock of Princeton, N.J., and Robert B. Rock Jr. of Wilmington, N.C., to Joseph Walter Nega, the son of Harriet E. Nega of Chicago and the late Walter J. Nega, took place yesterday at Our Lady of Lourdes Roman Catholic Church in Arlington, Va. The Rev. Robert J. Rippy officiated.

title: Stephanie Amiot Weds Robert Hull
description: The Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Stephanie L'Abbe Amiot, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Louis Amiot Jr. of Greenwich, and Robert Stuart Hull, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd Nelson Hull of Greenwich. The Rev. Caroline S. Pyle performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: Leslie Vought Is Affianced
description: September wedding plans for Leslie Vought and Christopher Brian Kuenne, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Kuenne of Princeton, N.J., have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mrs. William O. Harbach of New York and Peter Vought of Santa Fe, N.M.

title: Employers Are Looking Abroad For the Skilled and the Energetic
description: EVERY morning, the administrators of Hermann Hospital decide who will be turned away from the emergency room, one of the city's major trauma centers. Some days, for example, ambulance drivers are told that heart attack victims are welcome but that people with head injuries will have to go elsewhere.

title: The Other Face of Glenn Close, Powdered
description: In Stephen Frears's DANGEROUS LIAISONS (1988, Warner Home Video, $89.95), the circling camera scours the powdered faces of Glenn Close and John Malkovich, who play the Marquise de Merteuil and her accomplice in seduction, the Vicomte de Valmont. Beneath their masks of 18th-century respectability, it finds evil in the half-concealed smirks and glittering eye contact shared by these ultimate sexual sophisticates.

title: The Candidates Are in Place, but Where Are the Voters?
description: NOW that Mayor Edward I. Koch has improvised a formal announcement of his candidacy - letting slip his decision to seek a fourth term during an afternoon radio interview last week - all the actors in New York City's mayoral drama have taken their places on the stage.

title: Moto Saito, 82, a Japanese Restaurateur
description: Moto Saito, a restaurateur who was among the first to introduce Japanese cuisine to New Yorkers, died of heart failure June 13 in Tokyo. She was 82 years old and lived in Tokyo.

title: NOTES FROM A SOLDIER OF FORTUNE
description: LEAD: T. E. LAWRENCE The Selected Letters. Edited by Malcolm Brown. 568 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Company. $27.50.

title: CELEBRATING LOUISIANA
description: Wayne King's jeremiad on Louisiana was far too grim (''Bad Times on the Bayou,'' June 11). In fact, this is a splendid place to live: a refuge for the thin of blood, strong hunters, aged storytellers, tycoons, revelers, scientists and charlatans.

title: Yankees Failed by Relievers
description: The game was going to start in only 15 minutes, and Chuck Cary, the starting pitcher, was suddenly stuck in traffic. So he did the only thing he could do: he jumped out of his car, turned the wheel over to his wife, Katherine, and began sprinting wildly toward Yankee Stadium.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: WARWICK, R.I.;
Jewelry Center Next to I-95
description: LEAD: THE International Jewelry Trade Association of America plans to begin construction next September on a $20 million trade center here for 135 condominium showrooms next to an existing 266-room Holiday Inn.

title: Scotland's Little-Known Province
description: LEAD: THE Province of Dumfries and Galloway, as it is usually known, is bypassed by most visitors to Scotland. Tucked away in the southwest corner of the kingdom, it has kept its unusual charm intact. For it is a treasure trove of dramatic seascapes; ancient and historic towns; sites of pagan ritual 5,000 years old; rounded mountains, covered in summer with golden gorse and purple heather; streams and rivers of clear water with fish to challenge the most jaded angler.

title: Integration Is a Matter of Economic Survival
description: AMERICA is facing a demographic challenge so unprecedented that it will leave no aspect of our national life unchanged. By the year 2020, white Americans will find themselves in a minority as their numbers within the population are surpassed by the combined total of American citizens who are of African, Asian and Hispanic descent.

title: Lois Bruu Weds Gregory Battista
description: Lois Marian Bruu and Gregory Joseph Battista were married in New York yesterday at the West End Collegiate Church by the Rev. Kenneth Gorsuch, a minister of the Dutch Reformed Church.

title: Flinging Away at the Highland Fly
description: TOURISTS who come to Scotland may shudder at the thought of sighting the Loch Ness monster. Little do they suspect that a far more fearsome monster awaits them.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Four Home Projects for Shore Counties
description: LEAD: DESPITE an oversupply of new and resale houses throughout the state, developers are counting on location to lure year-round home buyers to new waterfront projects in what were once summer resort areas of Ocean and Monmouth Counties.

title: New Tests Confirm Exxon Valdez Is Leaking Oil in Rough Waters
description: New tests have confirmed that the crippled tanker Exxon Valdez is leaking crude oil as she sits 60 miles offshore in rough seas, but the oil is decomposing, the Coast Guard said today.

title: Question Of the Week; Are Foreign Golfers Better Than Americans?
description: Foreign golfers are more complete, having learned to play and compete on demanding links-type courses. With the exception of the majors, in which a foreign golfer always seems to be on the leader board, the American tour pros are pampered and coddled by courses made for condominium developments and manicured country clubs. JAMES C. SHERIDAN Jr. Manhasset, L.I.

title: Long Road Home for Italy's Would-Be King
description: For the man who would be King of Italy, the road home has grown longer.

title: The Take-It-or-Leave-It Game
description: THE other day, my wife, Ruth, did something foolish. She tried to throw away a pair of old boots by dropping them in the garbage. Eddie, the trashman, was at our back door within the hour. ''Can't take boots,'' he said flatly. ''This neither,'' he added, holding up a green wine bottle. ''Sorry, Eddie,'' Ruth said. ''The bottle must have slipped through. But can't you please, please take the boots?'' Ruth was sounding a little desperate. For two years, since recycling started and the big yearly pickups ended, she'd been trying to get these boots out of her life. Goodwill had rejected them. ''Boots aren't on our 'yes list' anymore,'' Eddie explained. ''Then what is on the 'yes list,' Eddie?'' Ruth barked. She was losing control. Recycling rage gripped her. This can be as serious as bank rage, which comes from having to wait in line to get your own money. Recycling rage comes from spending $500 a year on trash haulers who pick through your garbage and leave most of it behind.

title: Veterans' Hospital Faces Change in Role
description: LEAD: THE Veterans Affairs Medical Center at Northport looks more like a university campus than a hospital. Its rolling lawns, golf course and brick buildings have a look of tranquillity and stability.

title: Review/Dance; Balanchine By Miami Company
description: The Miami City Ballet brings its own fresh but considered accent to dances by George Balanchine, which are part of the heritage of the company's director, Edward Villella. And the company was seen at its best in two of the Balanchine works it presented on Wednesday night at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival. But the other Balanchine ballets were disappointments, and it would have been nice to see more of the home-grown work represented by ''Nous Sommes,'' by Jimmy Gamonet De Los Heros, the promising resident choreographer.

title: Walking Tour
description: Those who like walking tours, especially in Manhattan's nooks and crannies, might consider donning comfortable clothing and shoes next Saturday and ambling around the Upper East Side with a group from the Municipal Art Society. In cooperation with the society, Val A. Ginter, a professional tour guide and a student of New York City lore, will conduct a group on a three-hour tour of the area between 70th and 79th Streets, from Third Avenue to the East River.

title:
Body and Mind;
Ill, or Just the Blahs?
description: LEAD: FROM TIME TO TIME we've all felt sluggish, bushed, dog-tired, drained, exhausted or just plain blah. Sometimes, we can pin fatigue on emotional stress, physical overwork or illness. Too often, we cannot, and that's why fatigue is one of the most common complaints presented to family physicians.

title: Homeless Issues Move Into Campaign Arena
description: HOUSING for the homeless, a growing problem that seemed to develop in Westchester outside the arena of partisan politics, has become thoroughly enmeshed in the county executive race between Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Republican incumbent, and Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, his Democratic challenger.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
Can This Weekend Be Saved?
description: LEAD: MANY couples say there's nothing like a spring weekend in a secluded hideaway to spark your marriage. Right. The last time my husband, Morty, and I spent a romantic weekend alone was in 1974. Every time one of us considers doing it again, we take two Gelusils and, luckily, the feeling goes away.

title: FICTION
description: MISCHIEF MAKERS. By Nettie Jones. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $16.95.) The title of this novel by Nettie Jones - spanning the decades between the 1920's and the 1950's - refers to a family of beautiful and adventurous women whose African and American Indian heritage is concealed behind fair-skinned complexions. Raphael De Baptiste is a trained nurse whose color- and class-conscious parents send her away from Detroit to end her love affair with a dark-skinned factory worker. She eventually builds a new life passing as a white woman, and falls in love with a handsome Chippewa Indian. They marry and produce three daughters: Blossom Rose, Lilly and Puma. Raphael dies giving birth to a stillborn son and takes to her grave the secret of her mixed ancestry. Years later, the middle daughter, Lilly, now a teen-ager, learns of her mother's heritage. In her exchange with grandfather De Baptiste about this discovery, however, Lilly expresses no shock, anger or confusion. Instead, Ms. Jones portrays her as immediately elated by the knowledge that she is ''partly Negro, partly white, partly Indian.'' Lilly's response is hard to believe, considering the child's awareness of her father's pride in ''having been married to a 'white' woman'' and his prejudice toward the black fruit pickers who work for him. The author never discloses the reactions of the father and his other daughters to Lilly's news regarding the deception of Raphael, the woman they all loved; they're portrayed as accepting the truth and moving on with their lives. Perhaps Ms. Jones intended her story to leave us with a sense of never having penetrated its surface because the real issue here is the significance of appearance. But the effect is overwhelmingly disconcerting; we are left with a yearning for glimpses of her insight into the emotional lives of these fascinating characters.

title: Richard L. Gerloff, Executive, 53
description: Richard L. Gerloff, an executive vice president of the American Savings Bank and president of its Westchester community lending division, died Friday at White Plains Medical Center. He was taken there two weeks earlier after suffering a stroke. He was 53 years old and lived in Scarsdale.

title: Dana L. Conroy Is to Wed in October
description: Mr. and Mrs. John D. Conroy of Baltimore have made known the engagement of their daughter Dana Louise Conroy to James Harold Rosenfield Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Rosenfield of New York and Pound Ridge, N.Y.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: One of the strangest and most popular coins munches coral and algae on the bottom of the Indian Ocean. The shell of the Maldive cowrie, Cypraea moneta, has been used as money by the Chinese, the Hawaiians, the West Africans and Ojibwa Indians. It was considered money 4,300 years ago and is still used today.

title: Taking the Joy Stick Out of Life
description: I AM no stranger to longing. I am seized by it whenever a red Porsche passes or when I see photographs of lovers walking along the Seine. But I doubt I have ever known longing like that of my son David.

title: Double Header In Toronto: Batter Up, Top Down
description: The best show at the Sky Dome, Toronto's extraordinary new 53,000-seat stadium, is the one almost no one gets to see: the smooth, nearly silent metamorphosis of this building from an indoor stadium to an outdoor one. Watching the transformation is like no other experience in architecture. Two massive, vaulted roof panels, each weighing more than 1,800 tons, slide to one end of the stadium, opening up the middle of the roof to the sky, after which a rounded panel at the end rotates all the way around the stadium and disappears beneath the others.

title: Style Makers; Oriel Harwood: Ceramics Artist
description: Most people have a limited view of pottery, says Oriel Harwood, a ceramics artist. ''They think you either make things like mugs and ashtrays or you do sculpture.''

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I asked my fuel company not to top off the oil tank during summer, as I would rather not have to pay for all that fuel now. They said that if the tank were not filled it would be subject to scaling, and debris could clog the lines. I noted that this was a new tank, but they still say this is a possibility.

title:
GARDENING;
There's Treasure in Those Weeds
description: LEAD: TO paraphrase an old saying, one gardener's flowers may be another gardener's weeds.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption last Sunday about a custom-designed ketuba, the Jewish marriage document, omitted the designers' names. It was made by Sylvia Wolff, a North Tarrytown calligrapher, and Francine Fierstein, a Scarsdale artist.

title: LEADERS AT SUMMIT BACK FINANCIAL AID FOR EAST EUROPE
description: The Group of Seven major industrial democracies agreed today to give financial assistance to Poland and Hungary, as well as emergency food supplies, and called for the European Community to organize a meeting in the next few weeks to coordinate efforts.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: KENOSHA, WIS.;
Chicago's Reach Grows Longer
description: LEAD: WHEN the Chrysler Corporation closed its 5,500-employee assembly plant here in December, many thought that the loss of the city's main employer would send the housing market into a tailspin.

title: SPIKE LEE
description: No Historian To the Editor:

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: A Boulevardier of Power

title: Ruth Perlman Wed in Illinois
description: Ruth Ann Perlman and David Michael Bender, graduates of Northwestern University, were married last evening by Rabbi Herbert Bronstein at North Shore Congregation Israel in Glencoe, Ill. Mrs. Bender is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Perlman of Northfield, Ill. Mr. Bender's parents are Dr. Stuart Bender and Phyllis Bender, both of Westport, Conn.

title: Miss Collison to Wed T. A. Williams Jr.
description: Serena Dee Collison and Thomas Allison Williams Jr. are planning a December wedding, the prospective bride's parents, William Norwood Collison and Margaret Wei Collison, both of New York, have announced. Mr. Williams is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Williams of Rye, N.Y.

title: Miss Baker Weds R. J. Zilenziger Jr.
description: Jennifer Templeton Baker, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael D. Baker of Hudson, Ohio, was married yesterday to Rodman Jay Zilenziger Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Zilenziger of Scarsdale, N.Y., at the First Congregational Church in Hudson. The Rev. Mark H. Miller officiated.

title: NONFICTION
description: A YEAR-LONG NIGHT: Tales of a Medical Internship. By Robert Klitzman. (Viking, $17.95.) An internship is meant to acquaint a young doctor with a variety of diseases. In ''A Year-Long Night,'' Robert Klitzman's account of his internship year, the author meets 33-year-old Judy, who is battling ovarian cancer. ''When I had lifted away her hospital gown to examine her, my hands felt the hard bulges of tumor floating on the surface of her intestines.'' There is also Claude, the AIDS baby; the psychiatric patients - the list is long. Each tale serves to illustrate how Dr. Klitzman hardens himself against the cruel limitations of modern medicine.
