Throughout, he struggles to retain his compassion while detaching himself emotionally from patients he cannot cure. He is not afraid to point up problems in the medical profession: ''No other field is more focused on studying errors. Yet no other field so avoids examining its own mistakes or even admitting that it makes them.'' Dr. Klitzman concludes: ''What I learned during the year was no great single revelation, no prescription for revamping American medicine.''

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: I AWOKE to the unfamiliar feel of a familiar bed and the sound of Eastern birds in the window. We hadn't experienced either in a long time, Linda and I. When we'd left New Jersey, spring was still routing out winter. For seven weeks, we'd followed that spring north, almost to the limit of spring's reach, then south and west to lands where summer is a constant and spring touches the world in the form of rain.

title: Picky About Blueberries
description: WHEN we moved into our house, it was late October, and hard to tell what was growing in and around the yard. By May, we discovered that the bushes on the side of the house were not ornamental shrubs, but were going to give us some kind of crop. City people that we are, we didn't know what to expect.

title: Ms. Bass to Wed Kevin F. Kostyn
description: August wedding plans for Nancy Ann Bass and Kevin Francis Kostyn, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Kosztyn of Edison, N.J., have been made known by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Fred Bass of Pelham Manor, N.Y.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: PHILADELPHIA;
Health Center Raises Hopes
description: LEAD: IN West Philadelphia, where gracious Victorian homes, cavernous three-story twins and block after block of rowhouses are crammed together near universities and hospitals, residential construction is rare.

title: Recent Sales
description: Bohemia$184,000 69 Aron Drive 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 23-year-old ranch; basement, 2-car garage, 0.5 acre; taxes $3,500. Commack$170,000 8 Dorothea Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 29-year-old ranch; basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,600. Islip$114,000 46 Islip Boulevard 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 66-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, basement; taxes $2,900. Massapequa Park$230,000 149 Southgate Drive 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 8-year-old condominium town house; fireplace, c/a, library, pool, tennis; monthly maintenance $163, taxes $6,800. Wantagh$150,000 238 Willowwood Drive 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 37-year-old ranch; den, fireplace, 1-car garage; taxes $3,000. Westbury$222,500 145 Longwood Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 36-year-old Cape Cod; fireplace, finished basement; taxes $3,700. OTHER AREAS Weston, Conn.$565,000 59 Treadwell Lane 5-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, 3-year-old colonial; brick floors in several rooms, security system, 2.1 acres; taxes $6,485. Harrison, N.Y.$675,000 603 Purchase Street 4-bedroom, 4 full and 2 half-bath, 23-year-old colonial; fireplace, sun room, den, deck, 3,505 square feet, 3-car garage; taxes $9,894. Maplewood, N.J.$330,000 27 Ridgewood Terrace 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 47-year-old colonial; fireplace, eat-in-kitchen, full basement; taxes $5,575.

title: Rain Takes a Toll On Farms' Output
description: LEAD: TALK about the weather among the 200 farmers who still work the Island's rich soil has an edge to it this summer.

title: Nesuhi Ertegun, a Top Record Producer, Dies at 71
description: Nesuhi Ertegun, who helped make Atlantic Records an important label for rhythm and blues and jazz, died yesterday from complications following cancer surgery at the Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 71 years old and lived in Manhattan, Katonah, N.Y., and Biot, France.

title:
DINING OUT;
Spain's Contemporary Fare in Mt. Kisco
description: LEAD: SOON to celebrate its fifth birthday, La Camelia continues to surprise and charm diners with Spain's light contemporary cuisine. Over the years the owners - Antonio Alverez, who oversees the front of the house, and Dionisio Anes, the chef - have refined La Camelia to a near-perfect state. In order to offer diners both the freshest ingredients and variety, the table menu has been shortened and the blackboard menu of specials expanded to take advantage of the produce of the day.

title: Fishing Industry Rebounding
description: PUBLICITY on ocean pollution wounded the billion-dollar New Jersey seafood industry last year, but with diversification and state-aided promotion the industry is making a comeback.

title: Gandhi and Gorbachev Talk About Chinese and Afghans
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev met today and discussed their policies toward China and Afghanistan, the Soviet press agency Tass said.

title: Canvassing Opinion
description: To the Editor:

title: Klan Wins a Battle for Cable TV
description: The Kansas City Council voted Thursday to restore a local cable television company's public access channel that the city shut off last year after the Ku Klux Klan applied to use it for broadcasts.

title: Dancing on a Plaza, Among Stuffed Toys And in Other Venues
description: If you've ever had the urge to dance across the plaza of Lincoln Center after an exhilarating night at the ballet, you have until Aug. 4 to satisfy the fantasy. To celebrate Lincoln Center's 30th anniversary, a dance floor and bandstand have been set up between the fountain and the cafe. The public dancing was Peter Duchin's idea, and last week his band led off the first of 20 evenings sponsored by Citicorp. The music starts at 9:30 most nights; the cover charge is $5.

title: Bo Jackson as Paul Bunyan
description: A man with a microphone and a deployment of camerapersons was staked out in a corridor beside the entrance to the visiting team's clubhouse in Yankee Stadium. He was staking out Bo Jackson, who only a few nights earlier last week had left a former President of the United States nearly speechless.

title: L. A. Gear Tries A Full Court Press
description: LEAD: He entered the business world as a hair stylist. For the next 25 years, he reaped profits on everything from wigs to blue jeans to E. T. shoelaces. When the money fizzled out in an unsuccessful retail shoe store, he turned to the hottest market at the time: athletic shoes.

title: Teufel Sparks Mets, 6-4
description: The ball dropped into Oddibe McDowell's glove in center field, and with it Tim Teufel's streak of reaching base safely was snapped at nine plate appearances. But, as he turned away from first base and made his way back to the dugout, there was a hint of a smile on Teufel's face.

title: MARKETS DON'T HAVE TO BE SAVAGE
description: SOCIALISM PAST AND FUTURE By Michael Harrington. 320 pp. New York: Arcade Publishing/Little, Brown & Company. $19.95.

title: New Rules in Warsaw: The Politics of Paradox
description: The heady new world of Polish politics that has taken shape since last fall seems to generate endless paradoxes large and small.

title: A Made-for-TV French Bicentennial and Summit
description: The world watching the Paris celebrations on television never knew: President Bush did not see the spectacular finale of a madcap parade in the Place de la Concorde shortly after midnight this morning, which is a pity for a politican who has so frequently expressed his reverence for the American flag.

title: The Group of 7 Statement: Concern From East Europe to China
description: Following is the official text of the political declaration issued today by the Group of Seven major industrialized democracies: EAST-WEST RELATIONS

title: Diana Hurwitz Marries Timothy Cone
description: Diana Susan Hurwitz, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert S. Hurwitz of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married last evening to Timothy Cone, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sydney M. Cone of New York. Rabbi Robert I. Summers performed the ceremony at Tarrytown House in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Sarah D. Forbush Weds Bruce Lee
description: Sarah Dill Forbush and Bruce Hatch Lee were married yesterday at the Wickenden Chapel of Tabor Academy in Marion, Mass. The Rev. Nehemiah Boynton 3d performed the Congregational ceremony. Margaret McDermott was the matron of honor, and Richard Needham was the best man.

title: North's Sentence Teaches Wrong Lessons
description: To the Editor:

title: Dumars Extends Pact
description: The Detroit Pistons, champions of the National Basketball Association, signed the player most crucial to winning that title yesterday when they gave Joe Dumars a multiyear contract extension. General Manager Jack McCloskey would not disclose terms of the contract with the 6-foot-3-inch guard. But with the latest agreement, he said, ''We will have him, I think, through his entire career.'' The Pistons also signed a veteran forward-center, Scott Hastings, to a multiyear contract. (AP)

title: Orioles Top Angels With Disputed Homer in 9th
description: Mike Devereaux's disputed ninth-inning home run broke a 9-9 tie and gave the Baltimore Orioles an 11-9 victory over the California Angels tonight.

title: A Herbert Operetta Unfolds at the Emelin
description: IF early 20th-century operetta isn't alive and well at the Emelin Theater, at least it's awake and breathing. The Light Opera of Manhattan production of Victor Herbert's ''Sweethearts'' (circa 1913), being co-presented with the Performing Arts Center here, isn't likely to convert the uninitiated to the simple pleasures of an antiquated musical genre. But it is sincerely, not condescendingly, performed (a must) and sweetly, purely sung (another must).

title: A Boy's AIDS Death and a Caseworker's Duty
description: A caseworker for the South Carolina Social Services Department has been indicted on charges of failing to investigate or report a suspected case of sexual abuse of an 8-year-old foster child, who later died of AIDS.

title:
Focus: San Francisco;
Banks Plan to Aid Lower-Cost Housing
description: LEAD: LAST month, representatives of 26 banks in California held the final meeting of a yearlong effort to establish a nonprofit mortgage-banking corporation to finance affordable, or lower-cost, housing in the state.

title: A Grab Bag of Questions From Readers
description: Below are answers to some recent questions from readers of the Personal Finance column. Q. My college and I have a difference of opinion about how to value the 10 shares of stock I gave to the annual fund drive last year. My college sold the stock and says the value of my contribution is equal to the proceeds of the sale, minus the brokerage commission it paid. But I thought the value of my gift was determined by the market value of the stock on the date I turned it over. A. You're right, with a few clarifications. ''The general rule for valuing a charitable gift is the date of delivery to the charity,'' says Conrad Teitell, a White Plains tax attorney. Typically, that is the date on which you hand over the actual certificates, signed and completed on the reverse side, to the charity. If, like many people, you sent the certificates through the mail, then the delivery date is considered the date of mailing.

title: A One-Dish Meal of Improvisational Origin
description: One hundred years from now, someone trying to determine the ethnic origin of this recipe would be out of luck. But the recipe, for a quick one-dish supper, does offer clues about its creator: someone who had forgotten to buy all the necessary ingredients for a pie with a crust of ground meat and a custardlike filling, and who had several ingredients in the house that had nothing to do with the original recipe.

title: Coup Could Deprive Sudan of American Aid
description: In the wake of the military coup here, a relatively untested law approved by the United States Congress three years ago is likely to result in the cutoff of all American economic aid to the Sudan.

title: Stamps
description: Nostalgia can prove persuasive in seeking new collecting interests. Remember trains?

title: When Junk Mail Turns Into Its Name
description: The Wainscott post office serves 1,130 box holders in this rural community. As one leaves our post office building there are two trash cans the accumulation of which fill an average of 17 large plastic bags each day. These bags are taken to the East Hampton landfill, which is rapidly approaching full capacity. Post offices serving larger communities could easily have 5 to 10 times the amount of waste that we have.

title: Outdoors; Bonito Challenges The Best of Anglers
description: To some light-tackle enthusiasts - including fly fishermen - the Atlantic bonito is the ultimate quarry.

title: Reviews/Music; Mostly French at Mostly Mozart
description: What was a good Frenchman like Jean-Pierre Rampal doing in New York on the 200th Bastille Day? A moment's reflection on the conditions in America's larger cities on July 4, 1976, might persuade the skeptical that Mr. Rampal, and for that matter his compatriot Jean-Bernard Pommier, acted prudently when they accepted concert engagements far from Paris on the great day. They didn't have to fight traffic, and the Mostly Mozart Festival got to have a French evening Friday.

title: Erica Helen Ling Becomes the Bride Of Stephen Dorrance Mink in Troy
description: Erica Helen Ling, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick F. Ling of Troy, N.Y., was married yesterday to Stephen Dorrance Mink, a son of Mrs. Louis O. Mink Jr. of Middletown, Conn., and the late Mr. Mink. The Rev. Donald Stroud, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Alumnae Chapel of the Emma Willard School in Troy.

title: A Comeback for Polo and Croquet
description: CROQUET and polo have long been thought of as Great Gatsby types of sports, games played by the gentry. Their popularity faded after the 1930's, but now, after a long hibernation, both are again thriving. But this time around, enthusiasm for the sports appears to extend far beyond the top drawer.

title: Command Post of a War Against a Nation's Fires
description: In a windowless conference room, the chiefs of staff have gathered for a briefing on battle strategy. A man with a pointer turns to a series of color-coded maps. He charts the movement of the enemy. It could be the basement of the Pentagon, but in this war the enemy is forest fires. Here at the Boise Interagency Fire Center, near the foothills of the Sawtooth Mountains, officials of five Federal agencies direct firefighting around the country.

title:
FOCUS: SAN FRANCISCO;
Banks Plan to Aid Lower-Cost Housing
description: LEAD: Last month, representatives of 26 banks in California held the final meeting of a yearlong effort to establish a nonprofit mortgage-banking corporation to finance affordable, or lower-cost, housing in the state.

title: SNATCHING THE GRAIL FROM THE NAZIS
description: PARSIFAL By Peter Vansittart. 256 pp. Chester Springs, Pa.: Peter Owen/ Dufour Editions. $25.

title: Fuel-Tank Codes Cause Confusion
description: LEAD: AS deadlines approach for the thousands of Long Islanders who have underground fuel-storage tanks to meet stringent environmental ordinances, there is mounting confusion among the public on compliance.

title: AIDS Led to Death of Pikul, Autopsy of Prisoner Shows
description: Joseph J. Pikul, who was convicted in the killing of his wife, died of complications from AIDS, autopsy results released Friday have found.

title: National Issues Enter Governor's Race
description: IN one of those events designed to generate some modest news coverage, Representative James J. Florio, Democrat of Gloucester Township, recently brought his campaign for governor to Hudson County to pick up the endorsement of some police organizations.

title: Ms. Blackwood Wed to Banker
description: At St. Paul's Episcopal Church in the Chestnut Hill section of Philadelphia, Barbara J. Blackwood, the public relations director of the Dorland & Sweeney advertising agency in Philadelphia, was married yesterday to Bruce Foster Morgan, a vice president of the Philadelphia National Bank. The Rev. Charles A. Carter 3d performed the ceremony.

title: Correction For a Hikers' Inn
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Dealing With Erosion in Housing Prices
description: LEAD: AFTER listing their three-bedroom Cape Cod in Melville with a broker for $200,000, and seeing it shown to only six potential buyers over a four-month period, Yvonne and Charles Coleman have dropped the price to a negotiable $185,000 and are attempting to sell it themselves.

title: Commuter Rail Lines and Competition
description: After reading Rodney Fisk's Opinion piece, I believe some issues need to be clarified and expanded upon.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE COVENANT: Love and Death in Beirut. By Barbara Newman with Barbara Rogan. (Crown, $18.95.) In a 1982 meeting about fighting in Lebanon with Rafael Eitan, Israel's adviser on terrorism, the veteran newswoman Barbara Newman was warned, ''Let me tell you something about the Christians. They are very, very, very good-looking.

title: The Antiquities Boom - Who Pays The Price?
description: ONLY RARELY DOES AN ART AUCTION achieve the taut dramatic pitch familiar from the movies. And almost never when ancient artifacts are on the block. But at Sotheby's in New York one day last December, it happened.

title: When a Family Faces Surgery
description: THE pediatrician was adamant. The lump would have to come out. My 6-year-old climbed on my lap and pressed a wet cheek into my neck. ''Take her to Schneider,'' he said. ''I hate hospitals.'' ''Schneider is different.'' ''I won't like it.'' He shook his head. ''You'll love it.''

title: To the Moon - and Back
description: The United States caught the world's imagination when the Apollo project sent Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin to tread the moon's ancient surface. But in the 20 years since, the hope of Apollo, that humankind would take more giant steps in exploration of the universe, has been miserably thwarted.

title: H.U.D. Inquiry Reaches New Stage, Leader Says
description: The leader of a Congressional inquiry into Federal housing programs said today that new testimony about former Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. had brought the investigation to a critical point and he would press for more exact details on Mr. Pierce's actions.

title:
GARDENING;
There's Treasure in Those Weeds
description: LEAD: TO paraphrase an old saying, one gardener's flowers may be another gardener's weeds.

title: Sewickley Surges To Win Tom Fool
description: Sewickley stormed past Houston inside the furlong pole and drew clear to score a three-length upset victory yesterday in the $113,200 Tom Fool Stakes at Belmont Park.

title: Apollo as Mirage; 20 Years After the Moon Landing, A Sense of Mission Is Gone
description: ALL through the night, in the hours of gathering suspense before the three men were to depart, the Saturn 5 stood on a pedestal of concrete and steel at the edge of the dark sea, glistening in a bath of xenon floodlights. From a few miles away, the 360-foot-tall white spaceship took on the aspect of a monumental obelisk, the reality and symbolism of the human reach for the heavens meeting in one shining form.

title: VINTAGE AUSTRALIA
description: Once, a list of the great red wines of the world would have begun and ended in France; five or six Bordeaux, a couple of Burgundies, maybe one from the Rhone Valley. No longer. Great red wines are made all over the place these days: Italy, Spain, California, Chile, Australia. In fact, one of the best of them all comes from Australia. It's called Grange Hermitage, it's made by Penfolds in South Australia and it's one of the most sought-after of all wines, red or white.

title: Miss Brown Weds J. P. Tassoni Jr.
description: Jennifer Edmunds Brown, a critical-care nurse, and Dr. Joseph Paul Tassoni Jr., an internist and clinical fellow, both at the Tufts-New England Medical Center in Boston, were married yesterday in Darien, Conn. The Rev. Anne B. Kimball officiated at St. Luke's Episcopal Church.

title:
INVESTING;
A Retailer Makes a Comeback
description: LEAD: Earnings are surging at Ross Stores Inc., an off-price retailer based in Newark, Calif. After losing money in 1986, the company altered its approach, focusing on more fashion-oriented, brand-name merchandise. And analysts say the strategy is working.

title: Food; Cutting Edge
description: Every once in a while, a new dish starts showing up on restaurant menus with almost conspiratorial regularity. It may arise in New York, Los Angeles, Dallas or Santa Fe, and, faster than you can say tirami su, it is everywhere. Often the creation is merely a fleeting fashion, sort of a Nehru jacket of gastronomy. (Remember the kiwi tart?) Other times, the dish has more staying power, such as blackened redfish (all sorts of fish today are ''blackened''), carpaccio (an Italian import) or creme brulee (hardly new in France but a relatively recent passion in America).

title: Santa Fe
description: Much has been made of the tricultural heritage of Santa Fe - Indian, Spanish and Anglo. Four centuries ago, Pueblo Indians apparently used the site as a seasonal residence; three centuries ago, a more permanent settlement consisted of Spaniards and Indians trying to adjust to each other while making a meager living, and in the last century or so, Anglos (basically anyone who is not Indian or Hispanic) have come to intermingle with the others.

title: SPIES & THRILLERS
description: Larry Bond's RED PHOENIX (Warner, $19.95) is a big, big book with a big, big cast. Mr. Bond, a former naval officer, seems to know everything about warfare, from the grunt in a foxhole to the fighter pilots far above the earth.

title: Gavel Falls on High-Flying Era of Texas Savings and Loans
description: Mementos of a lost civilization went on sale today in the half light of a dusty warehouse as the Government auctioned off ivory tusks, teak desks and mere adding machines accumulated by Texas savings and loans when there seemed to be no end to the money.

title: Newcomer Stuns the Offshore Circuit
description: A broken engine part deprived Charles Marks, a 49-year-old businessman from Potomac, Md., of a recent victory in the national offshore powerboat circuit. But the troubled finish did little to tarnish Marks's reputation as the new wonder of offshore racing.

title: FICTION
description: INDIAN NOCTURNE. By Antonio Tabucchi. Translated by Tim Parks. (New Directions, $19.95.) Once again a novella arrives from Europe, garlanded with praise (in this case, the 1978 Medicis Prize, for its French translation), trailing the weighty pendant of an epigraph by the French novelist Maurice Blanchot, encumbered by a meticulous index of the locations - in Bombay, Madras and Goa - where each of the 12 brief chapters takes place and confiding in the hoarse whisper of an author's note that ''as well as being an insomnia, this book is also a journey.'' The Italian writer Antonio Tabucchi, who has two collections of short stories translated into English, has achieved a remarkable, though by no means a rare, feat in the 88 pages of ''Indian Nocturne,'' neatly translated by Tim Parks. Mr. Tabucchi's own description of the work - ''this Nocturne in which a Shadow is sought'' - is a diminutive emblem of his miniature achievement. ''Nocturne'' and ''shadow'' are full of vague resonance and romantic suggestion; the capital letters, however, act like a rush of helium and the flimsy abstractions billow up imposingly. Lighter than air in terms of plot and character, ''Indian Nocturne'' has the gravitational field of a black hole when it comes to the portentous, the gnomic, the elliptical. Christine, a traveling acquaintance who makes her living ''photographing wretchedness,'' urges the narrator, over dinner: ''Tell me about your novel, come on. . . . I'm intrigued, don't keep me in suspense.'' '' 'But it's not a novel . . . it's a bit here and a bit there, there's not even a real story, just fragments of a story. And then I'm not writing it, I said let's suppose that I'm writing it.' Clearly we were both terribly hungry.'' You will be, too, minutes after swallowing ''Indian Nocturne.''

title: In Memories, Maps of Lives
description: THE roads we travel become a map of our life. It is our memories that forge its landmarks and symbols, our intimacy that determines the scale.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: There are all kinds of small things that are apt to drive one party in a marriage or relationship crazy. There is, for example, the well-documented fact that a number of drivers (male, usually) refuse to acknowledge that they are lost, and, moreover, will almost never stop to ask for directions.

title: 3 Killed in Plane Crash
description: A single-engine plane smashed into a machine shop shortly after takeoff Friday, killing all three people aboard and injuring two workers at the shop, one of them seriously. About 50 employees were in the shop, owned by the Walco Tool and Engineering Company. The plane crashed about a quarter mile from the runway of the small airport where it had taken off.

title: Once More, But With Feeling
description: Trust the Germans to come through with the precise, pretty phrase to describe any complicated phenomenon, even if it means stringing words together like so many boxcars. I was therefore happy though not surprised to come across, in the the spring issue of Historical Performance (the Journal of Early Music America), the dainty epithet musealer Klangmaterialismus. Borrowed by Denis Stevens, the musicologist and conductor, from the late Hans Redlich, the phrase means a devotion to museumlike sound materials. That devotion, as I have noted several times in this space, has been the life-force behind the historical-performance revival, but also continues to limit the revival's musical importance. Preoccupied with finding and appreciating correct techniques and sonorities in older works, musicians and listeners risk losing contact with the music beneath the piquant surface. This week, as the Mostly Mozart Festival makes the first of several gestures in recognition of the early-music crusade's arrival in the concert mainstream, test yourself: how often are you made aware of the heart-wrenching power that contemporary critics heard in Mozart's or Haydn's music? It is impossible to disentangle sonority from genuine music, of course, and even the most innocent early-music fan would not be guilty of such a crime of abstraction. Nonetheless, the subtler dangers that lurk in musealer Klangmaterialismus need to be understood. In a witty and astute article, Mr. Stevens deplores what he sees as the mindless concentration on historical techniques and sonorities. What he terms ''. . . an unquenchable and insatiable desire for conscious and affected archaism . . .'' still seems to dominate too many period-instrument performances. ''Reading music and performing it may be all very well, but to get to its heart one must see through it, X-ray fashion. Without that ability, which only experience can bring, the most industrious exploiter of ancient instruments is powerless, even ridiculous.''

title: Roll Back the Subway Fare!
description: To the Editor:

title: >LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: 'LIGHT OPERA'

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about garbage disposal misstated the cost and completion date for an incinerator in Oyster Bay. The cost is estimated at $135 million, not $350 million. Completion is expected in 1992, not next month.

title: Tracy Mullen and James Lilly Jr. Marry
description: Tracy Gibbs Mullen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. T. David Mullen of New York and Quogue, L.I., and James Thomas Lilly Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lilly of St. Paul, were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception in Quiogue, L.I. The Rev. Joseph Murray officiated. Mrs. Lilly was until last month the showroom manager for Hinson & Company, a New York wallpaper and fabric manufacturer. She is a graduate of Miss Porter's School and William Smith College, and she was presented at the Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball in 1980. Her father is a vice president and the general counsel of Crazy Eddie in Edison, N.J. Her mother, Joan Mullen, is the executive secretary of the Knickerbocker Cotillion, which offers ballroom-dancing classes to children in New York.

title: California
description: To the Editor: Having lived on California's Monterey Peninsula for 20 years, I can tell you that Steven Weisman, in his otherwise informative article on hiking in Big Sur (Travel, June 4), should have mentioned that a post-hike total body search for ticks is mandatory. Contrary to his report, there are indications of the spread of Lyme disease to the West Coast. And hikers should be equipped with emergency materials for field treatment of rattlesnakes and poison oak.

title: Eight New Floors
description: When Augustus Merritt, an Upper West Side real estate developer, built a block of four red-brick faux romanesque apartment buildings at the southeast corner of Amsterdam Avenue and West 80th Street in 1887 he was able to complete the five-story structures for a total of just $80,000. In their heyday, their residents were then considered the solid middle-class people that stabilized Manhattan society. The neighborhood went into sharp economic decline after World War II, the buildings became vacant a decade ago and the area gained a reputation more for drugs and crime than genteel living.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORTS;
Bringing Sports Back to the City's People
description: LEAD: ''There is no city in the world that has a greater influence than New York . . . all over this continent it is imitated, even where it is said to be feared.'' - Thomas Adams, 1931 New York City's sports history parallels that of American sports. Madison Square Garden is the birthplace of indoor track and field, the site of the first organized prizefight in 1920, and the mecca of college basketball.

title: THE EDUCATION OF DAN QUAYLE
description: Dan Quayle spent more than 10 years in the United States Congress (''The Education of Dan Quayle,'' by Maureen Dowd, June 25). How is it that he appears to have had so little interest in how the world works? He has assembled a team of advisers to tutor him and to prepare him for his future leadership roles. One would think that he might be the Prince of Wales, his only task to be groomed to ascend the ceremonial throne.

title: Cuba Police Officials Quit in Drug Scandal
description: Some of the top officials of Cuba's police and state security apparatus have resigned in the latest twist to the country's drug smuggling scandal, the Government has announced.

title: Sports of The Times; Will Finks Become Lost in the N.F.L. Shuffle?
description: Just when Pete Rozelle thought he was about to escape from the wild-animal act of club owners he has tamed with a whip and chair for nearly 30 years, he is now confronted with what he calls the ''toughest'' challenge of his National Football League reign: calming the young lions growling over the nomination of Jim Finks as the next commissioner.

title: Improving Passenger Safety in Airplane Accidents
description: IN a ground-floor research room at the Federal Aviation Administration Civil Aeromedical Institute in Oklahoma City are two cloth-covered dummies the size of a 6-month-old baby. One is the weight of an average 6-month-old, 17 pounds. The other weighs 51 pounds, or what the same baby would weigh if a force was exerted on it three times the pull of gravity.

title: Ban on Alcohol
description: Because of disruptions caused by fans at night football games, the sale of alcoholic beverages will be banned at Giants and Jets night home games this season under regulations announced by the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, which runs the Meadowlands complex and Giants Stadium.

title: For High School Athletes, Taste of College Rigor
description: For seven summers, Frank DuBois has been fighting statistics. The numbers he has been trying to defy are those showing that most elite high school basketball players are not ready to study college curriculums.

title: SPIKE LEE
description: A Certain Imperviousness

title: Talking; Recycling New Law Poses Many Challenges
description: FINDING the best way to implement the new mandatory garbage recycling law in New York City is about to become a major challenge for board members of co-ops and condominiums and landlords of rental buildings. The law will also affect thousands of residents who will have to alter their housekeeping habits to comply.

title: Rachel C. Hobart Weds E. S. Toole
description: Rachel Cahill Hobart, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Harrison Hobart Jr. of Troy, Ohio, was married yesterday to Edward Spencer Toole, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Allan Lawrence Toole of Hamden, Conn. The Rev. Stanley E. Johnson, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Union Chapel in Siasconset, Mass.

title:
MUSIC;
Englewood to Give Itself a Birthday Party
description: LEAD: FOR Mayor Donald Aronson, a day of musical performances seemed like the appropriate way to celebrate Englewood's 90th anniversary. ''Music is the universal language, and it becomes a conduit for bringing people together,'' he said. ''Our idea is to bring north New Jersey together.''

title: GETTING READY TO SEE THE LIGHT
description: LEAD: THE PAPERS OF THOMAS A. EDISON Volume One: The Making of an Inventor, February 1847-June 1873. Edited by Reese V. Jenkins and others. Illustrated. 708 pp. Baltimore: The Johns Hopkins University Press. $65.

title: FROZEN IDYLL
description: MOVIELAND Hollywood and the Great American Dream Culture. By Jerome Charyn. 304 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $21.95.

title: Reviews/Music; Pere Ubu: Punchy Rock
description: Pere Ubu came to the Ritz Wednesday night as a crisp, punchy five-man rock band with one of rock's great quirky lead singers - David Thomas, a rotund man in a suit who was always up to something. The band's songs, mostly from the two albums it has made after a six-year sabbatical ended in 1987, were three-chord rock built on garage-band stomps, lent some eccentricity by an occasional dissonance and by Mr. Thomas's high, reedy voice and off-center lyrics.

title: Hers; Ready, Willing and Wary
description: RECENTLY I HAVE arrived at what I consider to be a dramatic new understanding of the concept of change. Although I have always been intrigued by the idea of change in the abstract - even of radical self-transformation - and am daringly open to the untried and untrodden on an intellectual level, I have pursued a rather mollusk-like course in my personal life.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: LYME DISEASE DIAGNOSTIC CENTER;
For 60 People a Day, Exams Offer Reassurance
description: LEAD: THEIR attitudes range from placid (''It's curable. I'm not worried'') to panic (''Could this tick have crawled through my navel into my abdomen?'').

title: THE WORST KIND OF SECRET
description: ON TRIAL America's Courts and Their Treatment of Sexually Abused Children. By Billie Wright Dziech and Charles B. Schudson. 227 pp. Boston: Beacon Press.

title: A RETAIL WAR AS GROCERS GO ORGANIC
description: Suzanne Levine may be on the cutting edge of a retail trend in natural foods. Ms. Levine, who has 18 years of experience in the health foods industry, was hired last September by Larry's Markets to oversee the natural foods sections at its five conventional supermarkets in Seattle.

title: For Argentina's Economy, the President Prescribes Pain
description: ''GOD is Argentine,'' people here like to say - a way of assuring themselves that the rich and bountiful soil of Argentina will, somehow, take care of whatever abuses and excesses they commit.

title: The Need for Improving New York's M.C.I. Program
description: AT the beginning of 1988, the rent on Ariel and Harriett Morelli's two-bedroom flat in the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx was $370. Now, 18 months later, it is $438, even though the Morellis regular lease-renewal increase is not due until the fall.

title:
DINING OUT;
International Cuisine in West Cape May
description: LEAD: CRAB cakes with coriander and lemon mayonnaise, lobster with black beans, and a hot and spicy saute of beef are not exactly standard restaurant fare at the Shore. But then neither is Cape May's Globe Restaurant the typical seaside eating place. Opened last summer by Michael Colameco, who is of Italian extraction, and his wife, Heijung Park, who was born in

title: Julie R. Brannan, Neurologist, Wed
description: Dr. Julie Ross Brannan, an associate in neurology at the Mount Sinai Medical School in New York, and Dr. Douglas Winston Williams, a research associate in psychology at Rutgers University, were married yesterday. The Rev. Richard Leonard officiated at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York.

title: Holyfield's Right Stops Rodrigues in 2d Round
description: Evander Holyfield retained his Continental America's heavyweight title when he knocked out Adilson Rodrigues of Sao Paulo, Brazil, at 1 minute 29 seconds of the second round of a scheduled 12-round bout here tonight.

title: Rock From Underground
description: ''Everything i'll sing you's gonna be made out of rubber,'' Peter Mamonov declares on the first internationally released album by the Moscow band Zvuki Mu. But with Soviet-bloc rock just beginning to reach the outside world, the music's implications are likely to be flexed and stretched in ways its creators could never have predicted. Rockers are becoming symbols of openness and repression; in the Soviet bloc, far more than in the West, rock has lived up to its reputation as rebel music.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Successor to Finance Chief Of Argentina Takes Office
description: Nestor Rapanelli was sworn in today as the fifth economy minister in 3 1/2 months, and he pledged to complete the austerity program of Miguel Roig, who died only six days after taking office.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
Incidental Tourist: The Urge to Roam
description: LEAD: I HAVE, lately, been haunted by the most trivial locales in distant places, at banks, bakers and post offices. It is not necessarily the monuments, the great works of art, the spectacular views at sunset that tug at my subconscious as if I were leading several lives at the same time.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about a Warsaw Pact gathering described Imre Nagy's execution in 1958 incorrectly. Mr. Nagy, who as Hungary's Prime

title: Pieces of the Big Apple That Tourists Take Home
description: She was not quite certain what she would do with a set of six porcelain thimbles, each inscribed ''New York, New York,'' Mae Marshall of Norman, Okla., was saying the other afternoon in Value and Quality, a souvenir shop and drugstore in Times Square. But at $9.54 for the set, how could she resist?

title: Campaign Cash: The Tide Turns
description: A funny thing just happened to Rudolph Giuliani, who's running for Mayor of New York. He's been complaining for weeks about all the money being spent by Ronald Lauder, the cosmetics heir who's running against him for the Republican nomination. Mr. Giuliani has agreed to the limits of the new campaign finance law; Mr. Lauder, rejecting them, has outspent him five to one. Now, suddenly, Mr. Giuliani finds himself free, within the law, to spend all he can raise.

title: DATA UPDATE
description: BUILDING PERMITS ISSUED(Housing units)

title: Knicks and Bucks In Exhibition
description: The Knicks and the Milwaukee Bucks will meet Oct. 31 in the 17th annual Hall of Fame exhibition game at the Springfield Civic Center.

title: Stripping Titles
description: The international governing body for track and field will recommend to its council and congress that athletes holding records or titles be stripped of them if they admit under oath to taking banned substances.

title: Elizabeth Lippincott, Editor, to Wed Charles David Rosen, an Orthopedist
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Barton Lippincott to Dr. Charles David Rosen, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Rosen of La Jolla, Calif., has been made known by her parents, Mrs. Anthony N. B. Garvan of Spring House, Pa., and Barton Hirst Lippincott of Philadelphia. They are to be married this summer.

title: Miss Andersen Weds Treasury Official
description: The marriage of Karen Louise Andersen, a daughter of Arthur E. Andersen 3d of Barrington, Ill., and Elizabeth G. Wine of Barrington Hills, Ill., to Richard Worfolk Porter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Porter of Mount Kisco, N.Y., was performed yesterday by the Rev. Janice L. Walker at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Barrington Hills. Kristen A. Collins was her sister's matron of honor. Stephen Porter was his brother's best man.

title: New Peronist: Blending Grit With Wealth
description: Primly perched beneath her debutante portrait, Amalia Lacroze de Fortabat spoke in aristocratic tones about her new assignment: roving ambassador for Peronism, a movement traditionally associated with raucous, blue-collar nationalism.

title: 'Nippon Phobia'
description: To the Editor:

title: Camcorders Take Readily to the Road
description: With suitcases being packed and cars loaded up for summer travel, this is the season when camcorders come out of the closet. As part of getting ready for that trip, here are a few pointers to help make travel tapes more than just a string of random shots.

title: Tennis, Anyone
description: In the wake of yet another Wimbledon without a trophy for Britain, Sports Minister Colin Moynihan has decided to change tactics drastically in an effort to uncover tennis talent: looking to the masses instead of the classes, playing hardball instead of lob-ball.

title: Aces Wild! Refiguring the Hole-in-One Odds
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Reviews/Music; A Glass Adaptation Of Poe Tale
description: It is easy to understand why Debussy so ardently pursued Poe's ''Fall of the House of Usher.'' The opera was never really written, but its subject matter exudes the animism of the one stage work that Debussy did complete. The forests, pools and gardens that surround ''Pelleas et Melisande'' have a spirit of their own - anthropomorphic properties that well out of Debussy's orchestra and eventually smother his characters.

title: SYRIA AND U.S. SEEK A WIDER DIALOGUE
description: The United States has established a new, widening dialogue with Syria aimed at bringing the Soviet-armed nation closer to Washington's Middle East peace diplomacy, Western diplomats and Syrian officials say.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I asked my fuel company not to top off the oil tank during summer, as I would rather not have to pay for all that fuel now. They said that if the tank were not filled it would be subject to scaling, and debris could clog the lines. I noted that this was a new tank, but they still say this is a possibility.

title: DON'T STAND IN HIS WAY
description: THE JACKSON PHENOMENON The Man, The Power, The Message. By Elizabeth O. Colton. Illustrated. 290 pp. New York: Doubleday. $19.95.

title: Being Faithful to 'Leonore'
description: In December of 1805, an extremely delicate conference was held at the Lichnowsky Palace in Vienna. The previous month, Beethoven's first and, as it turned out, only opera had been performed to lukewarm success. His friends and colleagues, having taken counsel among themselves and made detailed plans, were to meet the composer at a soiree and tell him that his opera needed work. Lots of work.

title: For One Top Free Agent, Compensation Meant Penalization
description: In the 1981 labor negotiations, the club owners, at the risk of a shutdown, insisted they had to have a system of professional compensation for free agents. Four years later, they decided to abolish professional compensation. The clubs, it developed, didn't really like the idea, but it took them four years and a 50-day strike to find out.

title: 10 Named to Walker Cup
description: Ralph Howe 3d of Sayville, L.I., the 1988 United States Public Links champion, and Phil Mikelson, the Arizona State freshman who won the 1989 National Collegiate Athletic Association golf championship, were named to the 1989 United States Walker Cup team today. Both are left-handed, making this the first time the American squad has had two left-handed golfers.

title: Foreign Publications Are Banned in Beijing
description: China has banned the sale of foreign newspapers and magazines in Beijing to try to stop the dissemination of Western ideas and tighten ideological control after democracy protests were crushed by the army last month.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester; Vacancies Troubling Connecticut's Hotels
description: HOTEL vacancy rates in Connecticut have risen to an average of 50 percent, reflecting sharp cutbacks in business travel and the relocation or reduction of corporate staffs. Nevertheless, optimistic chains continue to build new hotels to the dismay of those who own existing ones and now face new competition.

title: Recent Sales
description: Weston, Conn.$565,000 59 Treadwell Lane 5-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, 3-year-old colonial; brick floors in several rooms, security system, 2.1 acres; taxes $6,485. New Canaan, Conn.$559,000 72 Wellesley Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 22-year-old colonial; enclosed porch, moldings, 2 acres; taxes $4,401. Simsbury, Conn.$246,000 19 Gates Lane 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 22-year-old colonial; updated kitchen with bay window, new roof, 1.3 acres; taxes $2,624. Harrison, N.Y.$675,000 603 Purchase Street 4-bedroom, 4 full and 2 half-bath, 23-year-old colonial; fireplace, sun room, den, deck, 3-car garage; taxes $9,894. Mamaroneck, N.Y.$735,000 40 Magnolia Avenue 5-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 102-year-old Victorian; 2 fireplaces, family room, sun room, deck, 2-car garage; taxes $8,120. Rye, N.Y.$725,000 39 1/2 Barlow Lane 6-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 15-year-old colonial; family room, eat-in kitchen, 2 fireplaces, 4,500 square feet, deck; taxes $11,537. OTHER SALES Commack, L.I.$170,000 8 Dorothea Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 29-year-old ranch; basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,600. Freehold, N.J.$224,000 683 Colts Neck Road 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 20-year-old colonial; fireplace, 2-car garage, c/a, finished basement; taxes $3,498. Howell, N.J.$212,900 15 Spicy Pond Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 4-year-old colonial; family room, 2-car garage, eat-in-kitchen; taxes $2,770.

title: Supreme Court Tends To Goad Presidents
description: To the Editor:

title: City Youths Relish Life On the Farm
description: Criis Neal, an 11-year-old from the Park Slope section of Brooklyn, stood on the sun-drenched porch of the farmhouse with a gray kitten in her arms. Next to her was Abigail Matteson, 10, who has lived her entire life in that house.

title: WESTCHESTER BOOKCASE
description: Chaining the Hudson The Fight for the River In the American Revolution By Lincoln Diamant Lyle Stuart. 233 pages. $21.95.

title: The Soviets Show Scars From Nuclear Arms Production
description: LIKE its counterpart in the United States, the Soviet nuclear weapons industry existed for decades in secrecy, protected by barbed wire, miles of empty land and an atomic brotherhood of scientists, engineers and technicians.

title: Teaching Values: Where Are the Parents?
description: The New Jersey Department of Education has established a council to define commonly acceptable values and to advise on goals and objectives for character education. Character and values education are mandated in the public schools. The council recommended that every public school have a group of appointed citizens to develop local guidelines for values and character education.

title: Carolyn Martino, Student, Marries
description: Carolyn Holt Martino, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Martino of Clifton Park, N.Y., was married yesterday to Fred Anthony Payne, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ben J. Payne of Los Angeles. Judge Con Cholakis of Federal District Court in Albany officiated at the Canfield Casino in Saratoga Springs, N.Y.

title: About Cars; Allante Makes for Smooth Travel
description: My brother was up from Virginia this week, and we spent much of his visit in the car, looking - in vain - for a Kiekhaefer-Mercury steering cable for my 1971 Caravelle runabout.

title: THE EDUCATION OF DAN QUAYLE
description: That's great that Dan Quayle learned a little Spanish prior to his recent trip to Central America. Too bad he couldn't find time to brush up on the eight-word slogan of the United Negro College Fund. But then, in Central America he probably had the opportunity to meet with a lot of potential campaign contributors.

title: Annie Laidlaw to Marry W. F. Selke
description: Mrs. Winthrop S. Emmet of West Stockbridge, Mass., and Francis Welch Laidlaw of Barrington, R.I., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter, Christian Pierce Laidlaw, and Whitney Floyd Selke, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William August Selke of Stockbridge, Mass.

title: One Killed, 8 Hurt as Building Explodes
description: An explosion tore through a four-story brownstone in Washington Heights yesterday afternoon, killing one man and injuring at least eight other people.

title: Cable TV License To Be Weighed By State
description: WITH about half of the state's cable television companies facing re-licensing in the next couple of years, the decision in the United Cable TV Corporation case - the first to go before the state - is likely to set the tone for those to follow. United Cable, whose case is being heard this week, is like a number of franchises that were granted about 15 years ago and are now due for state scrutiny.

title: Social Security Nomination
description: Gwendolyn S. King was nominated Friday by President Bush to replace Dorcas Hardy, who has resigned, as Administrator of the Social Security Administration. Ms. King, an executive vice president at the government relations firm of Gogal & Associates, directed Pennsylvania's office in Washington when Attorney General Dick Thornburgh was Governor of Pennsylvania.

title: Style Makers; Richard Carleton Hankins: Scenic Designer
description: If having lots of people see one's work is most designers' goal, then Richard Carleton Hankins must think he is doing all right. Mr. Hankins, 39 years old, is the art director for ''Guiding Light,'' the long-running - 52 years on radio and television - CBS soap opera watched by eight million people daily.

title: Miss Burgett Weds Price Lowenstein
description: Carolyn Davis Burgett, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Burgett of Seattle and Rudgwick, Sussex, England, was married yesterday in Rudgwick to Price Gordon Lowenstein, the son of Eudora L. Richardson of Washington and Seal Harbor, Me., and James G. Lowenstein of Washington and Paris. The ceremony was performed at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity by the Rev. Bernard Cotter.

title: Police Say Two Arab Youths Admit Killing Jewish Builder
description: The police said today that two 16-year-old Palestinians from the occupied territories have confessed to stabbing and beating a Jewish contractor to death in a dispute over money on Friday.

title: Joy, Seen and Heard With the Heart
description: HANDS intertwined, their fingers move as fast as hummingbirds hovering. ''Yes, yes that's right,'' say the fingers of the teacher, Michelle J. Smithdas. ''But what about this?'' ask the fingers of the student, Rowland Smith.

title: Chevron Oil Tanker Aground But Leaking None of Cargo
description: A Chevron tanker carrying 16.5 million gallons of crude oil ran aground 10 miles south of here late Friday, but the Coast Guard said today that there was no oil leak or damage to the vessel's hull.

title: WHAT IS THIS THING CALLED BRONZE?
description: THE GIFT OF STONES By Jim Crace. 170 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons.

title: Teiichi Suzuki, 100; A Last War Criminal
description: Teiichi Suzuki, a former army general who helped plan Japan's economy in World War II and later was imprisoned as a war criminal, died of heart failure today, his family said. He was 100 years old.

title: WHAT'S MERCY GOT TO DO WITH IT?
description: PARDONS Justice, Mercy, and the Public Interest. By Kathleen Dean Moore. 271 pp. New York: Oxford University Press.

title: Blue-Blood Lineage, Prices to Match
description: YEARS ago, the Montauk Yacht Club was the playground of the Whitneys, Vanderbilts and Astors. These days, common folks make the scene, but the bank balance of a blue blood wouldn't be out of place when dining at Ziegfeld's, the club's restaurant. The menu lists a $34 veal chop and lobster at $15 a pound. (A three-pounder was the smallest available, making for a $45 entree.) Ziegfeld's restaurant is new this season. The name commemorates the location of the former Florenz Ziegfeld estate. The recently-refurbished dining room is large, light and airy with walls of windows affording panoramic views of yachts at dockside.

title: His Vision Charted the Course of 'The Navigator'
description: ''When i first thought up the story of five men and a visionary boy from the Middle Ages who tunnel through the earth to the 20th century, it seemed so bizarre, naive and almost crazy,'' admitted the New Zealand director Vincent Ward, ''that I knew it would take an enormous amount of gall to make it into a film.'' Since audacity is hardly lacking in the 32-year-old film maker, the result was ''The Navigator,'' a magical adventure story at the Festival and the Quad.

title: The President Tours a New Europe That Calls Its Own Shots
description: PRESIDENT BUSH swept more or less triumphantly last week through a Europe that has emerged from the postwar era, traversing a political landscape that has been reshaped in the space of a few years. Less obvious was the subtly altered relationship of Europe to the America he leads.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
THE BIGGEST HOMESPUN THING
description: LEAD: For many of the Grand Ole Opry's 64 years the radio show symbolized country music. An appearance on the show signaled that an artist had arrived; to become a family (cast) member could catapult a performer to superstardom. Virtually all of country music's great performers - Roy Acuff, Patsy Cline, Hank Williams, Johnny Cash, Minnie Pearl, Randy Travis - have ties to the Opry.

title: Problems in Translation
description: To the Editor:

title: For Serious Shoppers (And Their Friends)
description: From the wide brick courtyards that make the shopping center seem spacious even on a crowded day to the lampposts adorned with American flags, a stroll at the Woodbury Common Factory Outlets here offer a singular shopping experience.

title: French Revolution
description: To the Editor: Part of the touring romantic's pleasure rests on the conviction that the tear is being shed or the events recalled at the precisely correct historical spot. This may be more elusive than James M. Markham suggests in his interesting article on revolutionary sites in Paris (''In the Revolution's Footsteps,'' Travel, March 19).

title: Museums of 2 Colonies Exchange Collections
description: THE mere mention of Old Lyme is enough to arouse associations with Impressionism and perhaps a twinge or two of ''enough already.'' Nor do the associations subside at the news of ''En Plein Air,'' the show now on view at the former residence of Florence Griswold, an impoverished aristocrat who augmented her income by taking in the Old Lyme colony of Impressionists as summer boarders.

title: Mosquito Swarms Expected
description: LEAD: HEAVY rains have created conditions that promise a peak stinging season on Long Island this summer.

title: For China's Entrepreneurs, a Mood of Uncertainty
description: It was midnight, very late by the standards of Chinese night life, and Wang Xiaoguang was having a few beers in a new privately owned club, the Manhattan Bar.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''The Time board may be proven in time to have been brilliantly prescient or dismayingly wrong. In this decision, as in other decisions affecting the financial value of their investment, the shareholders will bear the effects for good or ill.'' Chancellor William T. Allen, Delaware Chancery Court, in issuing the Time ruling.

title: Q and A
description: Credit Cards Question: During a trip to Paris, I entertained friends in an elegant restaurant. When I presented my Visa card to pay the bill, it was returned on a silver tray with the polite but widely audible remark that Madame's card was unacceptable. When pressed, the maitre d'hotel informed me that the computer would not accept my card because it was demagnetized and manual processing was not possible ''in computerized France.'' Back home a Visa representative confirmed that complaints do periodically occur and stem from the type of wallet in which the card is carried or from airport security checks. My question is how frequently are travelers inconvenienced and why can't the credit card industry come up with a protective cover? - E. H. B., Easton, Conn. Answer: According to Daniel Brigham, media relations manager of Visa U.S.A., magnetic strips fail about 2 percent of the time. There are various causes, but the type of wallet is not one of them. A rumor that eel-skin wallets can demagnetize a credit card has been disproved and the amount of X-ray at airports is too low, he said. A money clip, however, can cause damage. He himself had to get a new card after his wife gave him a clip with magnets on the ends.

title:
MILLBURN JOURNAL;
A Slice of SoHo Comes to Suburbs
description: LEAD: A SLICE of SoHo in the suburbs. That is what Daniel Cannizzo envisioned when he created Cafe Main, a French-style bistro in this affluent bedroom community 21 miles from New York.

title: More Students Need Extended Contact With One Teacher...
description: CAN you imagine a man letting his business go down the drain while under his arm he has a plan guaranteed to make it a winner? In my opinion, this is the state of affairs with our high schools today.

title: A Court Victory For Time Inc.
description: Time Inc. won a favorable court ruling in its attempt to acquire Warner Communications Inc. to create the world's largest media company. In a major defeat for Paramount Communications Inc., a Delaware Court refused on Friday to block Time's $14 billion buyout of Warner. But the court decided to give Paramount 10 days to appeal the ruling.

title: Castle Country Along the River Dee
description: IT was not until 1852, when Queen Victoria apparently lost her heart to ''this dear Paradise'' and she and Prince Albert bought Balmoral Castle and its surrounding estate on the banks of the River Dee, that Britain's love affair with northeastern Scotland - its wind-swept grouse moors and salmon-teeming rivers - began.

title: Dr. M. E. Van de Berghe Is Married
description: Dr. M. Elizabeth Van de Berghe and Dr. Michael J. Brennan were married yesterday at St. Pius X Church in Fairfield, Conn. The Rev. Joseph Keane performed the Roman Catholic ceremony. The bride, who will keep her name, is the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Richard L. Van de Berghe of Fairfield. A graduate of Clark University and the New York Medical College, Dr. Van de Berghe is to become a fellow in pain management at Penrose Hospital in Colorado Springs in August. Her father is a cardiologist in Fairfield.

title: Maiden Flight of Stealth Bomber Aborted by Low Pressure Reading
description: A low reading on a fuel pressure gauge delayed the first flight of the B-2 stealth bomber today, after a Senate committee warned that future spending on the plane depends on successful flight tests by the Air Force.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Antarctica is the hot continent now. Mount Everest is out. It's been done every which way.

title: Supreme Court Tends To Goad Presidents
description: To the Editor:

title: BRITANNIA RUINS THE WAVES
description: MOTHER COUNTRY By Marilynne Robinson. 261 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $18.95.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Great Neck
description: LEAD: A SUBURBAN way of life within a 30-minute train ride of Manhattan, offering attractive housing and an abundance of recreational and cultural opportunities, makes the Great Neck peninsula one of Long Island's most desirable places to live.

title:
ART;
Five Photographic Portfolios
description: LEAD: THE observation of photography's 150th anniversary won't necessarily end with the calendar, as the Museum of Modern Art plans its big tribute for next year. Another twist is that the Neuburger Museum at the State University of New York here has made a summer show out of its observation and has skipped most of the usual accompanying platitudes.

title: Arafat's Guerrilla Group Plans a Policy Meeting
description: The largest Palestinian guerrilla group, led by Yasir Arafat, is planning a reappraisal of its strategy and a restructuring of its leadership at a conference in Tunis this month, Palestinians here say.

title: A Revue on the High Life in ''Red Hot and Cole''
description: COLE PORTER, who rhymed youth with gin and vermouth, created his own genre: the sophisticated and playful, cooly romantic popular song that represented a time of, in his own inimitable lyric, ''falderal frivolity.''

title: Bush Is Warned on Bugged Moscow Embassy
description: In unusually blunt language, the Senate Intelligence Committee has warned the Bush Administration that any decision against tearing down the new American Embassy building in Moscow invites a ''security disaster'' for which President Bush would be responsible.

title: CHESS
description: When the former world champion Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union met the Dutch grandmaster Jan Timman in the Fifth World Cup Tournament in Rotterdam, the Netherlands, which ended June 24, it was a case of stubbornness confronting stubbornness.

title: BURNED BY HER LIPS
description: TERRIBLE KISSES By Robley Wilson Jr. 219 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: Polilce Departments Try To Pick Up on Satanism
description: WHEN sheriff's officers in Camden County, N.J., began to find obscure symbols, what appeared to be runic writings and some tombstones turned over in a county cemetery last spring, they thought it was nothing more than the work of teen-age vandals.

title: Show Goes On for Retired Entertainers
description: WALLACE ROONEY will never forget the eyes of Ethel Barrymore.

title: KEEPING UP WITH THE JAMESES
description: A RING OF CONSPIRATORS Henry James and His Literary Circle, 1895-1915. By Miranda Seymour. Illustrated. 327 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company.

title:
ART;
Art Colony Offers Views of the Past
description: LEAD: EITHER of two responses are likely with Guild Hall's exhibition of landscapes by painters working at the famed art colony in Old Lyme, Conn., in the early 20th century.

title: For Art, Coastal Convergences
description: It wasn't long ago that Los Angeles art - at least in the eyes of the East Coast - was treated as a sunny imitation of styles originating in Europe and New York. Swimming pools and palm trees, shiny ''fetish finish'' surfaces, funky pop and ''light as space'' sculpture were all lumped together as aspects of a Los Angeles look. Contrasted with the austere Minimalism of New York during the 70's, Los Angeles art suffered a reputation, not altogether deserved, as fun, bright, slick, pleasant, likable or just plain dumb.

title: Beethoven's Ninth, Bottom of the Ninth
description: ''DADDY, do you yell at your orchestra as much as you yell at our baseball team?'' asked the blue-eyed fielder of the Dad's Club Darlings. A legitimate question given the fact that after each loss and cliff-hanging victory my vocal chords sound and feel like I have gorged on sandpaper canapes.

title: Flordia Family Gives $6 Million to School
description: A family that sold its bean farm on the edge of the Everglades for nearly $23 million has donated about a third of the proceeds to a college scholarship fund at a local high school.

title: Shuttle on Launching Pad
description: The space shuttle Columbia arrived at its launching pad today, and officials began preparing for an August mission in which a military spy satellite is to be deployed.

title: Question Of the Week; Are Foreign Golfers Better Than Americans?
description: I don't think foreign golfers are better than ours, they are just hungrier. Our guys are accustomed to large purses and are a little more laid-back. HARRY J. TREDE Setauket, L.I.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I asked my fuel company not to top off the oil tank during summer, as I would rather not have to pay for all that fuel now. They said that if the tank were not filled it would be subject to scaling, and debris could clog the lines. I noted that this was a new tank, but they still say this is a possibility.

title: Style Makers; Ronald Mallory: Jewelry Designer
description: The warmer the weather, the faster Ronald Mallory's jewelry moves. His medium is mercury, the silvery stuff of thermometers that expands in heat and contracts in cold.

title: Diana Dempsey Becomes a Bride
description: Diana Lynn Dempsey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Dempsey of Conway, S.C., was married yesterday in Durham, N.H., to William Rotch Bullard 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lyman G. Bullard of Andover, Mass. The Rev. Frederick J. Pennett performed the ceremony at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church, assisted by the Rev. Albert W. Snow, an Episcopal priest.

title: Church's Carnival Stirs Massapequa
description: LEAD: THROUGHOUT the summer, carnivals and bazaars will dot the Long Island landscape, inviting residents to their festive activities. But one planned carnival, sponsored by St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church in Massapequa, is generating heated debate between the church and a group of nearby residents.

title: HE WAS USED TO BEING LIED ABOUT
description: ADLAI STEVENSON His Life and Legacy. By Porter McKeever. Illustrated. 591 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $25.

title: 'Stick-Built' Houses in Putnam County
description: As developers, Homesites Associates of Patterson, N.Y., have stuck to the tried-and-true ''stick-built'' approach at their latest subdivision in Putnam County.

title: NANNY'S LITTLE SECRET
description: LEAD: A LITTLE STRANGER By Candia McWilliam. 181 pp. New York: Doubleday. $15.95.

title: Mary B. Oakley Plans Wedding
description: August wedding plans have been announced by Ambassador and Mrs. Robert Bigger Oakley of Washington for their daughter, Mary Bigger Oakley, and Joseph Henry Kress, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Anthony Kress of Arlington, Va.

title: Getting a Start on 'Wish You Were Here'
description: SAY you are bound for Belgium or Bulgaria or Burundi. You may want to send postcards to your friends and relatives, but you don't want to waste your valuable vacation time buying and addressing those cards. Or, say you are strictly an armchair traveler, yearning for views of Avignon, Biarritz or Dijon. Either way, Palmer Chambers is your man.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: YELLOW DOGS. By Donald Zochert. (Atlantic Monthly, $16.95.) It is too rarely that American fiction explores themes of a political nature. Donald Zochert's novel about a World War I conscientious objector, one of the ''yellow dogs'' of the title, bravely raises questions of moral responsibility, the use of violence and allegiance to one's country.

title: Luncheon Dress: A Little Primness On a Sultry Day
description: The luncheon dress might be called fashion's version of a watercress and endive salad. It's perfect for a midday meal when the weather's sticky, and it can be found at all the best restaurants.

title: Question Of the Week; Are Foreign Golfers Better Than Americans?
description: Foreigners are beginnng to dominate golf. Just look at the facts: In winning his green jacket this year, Nick Faldo joined three other Europeans as winners of the Masters during the eighties. Furthermore, Faldo joined Sandy Lyle to lead the British to victory in last year's Ryder Cup. What was it that Paul Revere said? HAMPTON TAYLOR New York

title: Miss O'Connell Is Married
description: Kate O'Connell, an administrative manager, and David Robert Hubbell, a corporate pilot, both for RJR Nabisco in Morristown, N.J., were married yesterday at St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church in Larchmont, N.Y. The Rev. Joseph DeSanto officiated. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond T. O'Connell of White Plains. Mr. Hubbell is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Hubbell of Scotia, N.Y.

title: Car Bomb Laid to Guerrillas Kills Nine in Kabul
description: At least nine people died today when a bomb exploded in a vehicle parked on one of Kabul's busiest shopping streets. It was the worst incident of its kind in almost a year, and came during a period of intensifying guerrilla pressure on the capital.

title: T.W.A. Broadens Use of 'Frequent Flier' Tickets
description: Trans World Airlines has changed the policy of its ''frequent flier'' program in response to complaints and a lawsuit filed by a homosexual couple.

title: Past Imperfect
description: To the Editor:

title: Crossing the Continent, in Canada
description: A COUPLE of years ago in Montreal I picked up a slim novel with the somewhat cryptic title ''Sitting in the Club Car Drinking Rum and Karma-Kola.'' I never got around to reading it, deciding the task should be undertaken on the train itself - which is how I recently found myself standing in the cavernous old Canadian National terminal in Vancouver, British Columbia, listening to the stationmaster intoning through the loudspeaker, ''. . . with service to North Bend, Kamloops, Revelstoke, Lake Louise, Banff, Calgary . . .'' Before the announcement could be completed, ''Regina, Winnipeg, Thunder Bay, White River, Sudbury, Mon-n-n-tre-a-a-al!'' we passengers had formed a long snake leading to the platform gate.

title: Foes of Gandhi Make Targets of His Children
description: When Rahul Gandhi won admission recently into St. Stephen's College, one of the most reputable educational institutions in the country, it touched off a furor among its students and faculty, with angry groups coming out onto the streets of Delhi University to support or oppose the decision.

title: Leslie MacKimm Marries
description: Leslie Ann MacKimm, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Bradley MacKimm of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to Mark Lawrence McCarthy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward E. McCarthy of Springfield, Mass. The Rev. Sharon Clayton officiated at Christ's Episcopal Church in Rye. Mrs. McCarthy, a graduate of Denison University, received an M.B.A. from the University of Chicago, as did her husband. Mr. McCarthy, a cum laude graduate of the University of Massachusetts, is a real-estate analyst for Aetna Realty Investors in Hartford.

title: North's Sentence Teaches Wrong Lessons
description: To the Editor:

title: Jill Gardiner Wed To a Tax Lawyer
description: At the Princeton (N.J.) University Chapel, Jill Marie Gardiner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter W. Gardiner of Westfield, N.J., was married yesterday to Stuart Chessman Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Chessman of Garden City, L.I. The Rev. Ignacio Barreiro performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: Rebel Group Gains Among White South Africans
description: The pilgrimage of white South Africans to meet exiled members of the outlawed African National Congress appears to have acquired new respectability as a result of President P. W. Botha's surprise meeting with Nelson Mandela a week and a half ago.

title: Figuring Fats
description: To the Editor:

title: Don Pullen, Making Sense of Jazz's Radical 60's
description: Since the late 1950'S and early 1960's, when the cadres of the avant-garde momentarily overran the positions of the jazz mainstream, jazz has struggled, in its more fecund experiments, with a rapprochement between the two.

title: POSTINGS: DOBBS FERRY CONVERSION;
description: Because most of the land in the four-square-mile Irvington, N.Y., is built upon, real estate entrepreneurs are taking the only other path open to them: They are rehabilitating, renovating and altering the structures that now exist in the Hudson River town of 9,000 residents 20 miles north of midtown Manhattan. More than 20 structures, many modest Victorian homes built over a century ago for the town's growing blue-collar population, have been restored this year alone. Gingerbread details have been preserved, porches added, and the prices are heading over $300,000.

title: Cutting Losses
description: West Virginia's State Treasurer, A. James Manchin, delegated responsibility for the state's investments to others and preferred to judge beauty contests, serve as a parade marshal and give medals to people who reached the age of 100. Last weekend, he retired after 41 years in politics, avoiding an impeachment trial in the State Senate stemming from a loss of $279 million in a state fund. As investigations continued into the activities of the $2.5-billion fund, which pooled the short-term assets of local governments and some retirement funds and invested them in securities like Treasury bills, Mr. Manchin blamed subordinates for making risky investments, explaining, ''I'm not a lightweight, but I'm not a financial genius.'' Mr. Manchin, whose annual pension of $24,000 is intact, said, ''I'm 62, and it's time to say goodbye.''

title: OIL-SPILLS TREATY MEETS OPPOSITION
description: The Bush Administration's proposal for comprehensive legislation addressing liability for oil spills has run into powerful opposition. The Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, has denounced its central feature, an international treaty.

title: Fittipaldi Gains Control in Orderly Fashion
description: For those who want to see it that way, the Emerson Fittipaldi story preaches the virtues of everything from proper diet to American democracy, from being well organized to just driving the right car.

title: A Textbook Essay
description: To the Editor:

title: ONE SMALL SHELF FOR LITERATURE
description: ''With how sad steps, O Moon, thou climb'st the skies! / How silently, and with how wan a face!'' Are you looking for your lovers, those Apollonian heroes who pursued you for 10 years and were faithful, at intervals, for only three?

title: Why Israel Stumbles So In the Search For Peace
description: IT took 15 months of sustained violence in the West Bank and Gaza Strip - and inside Israel as well - to push the Israeli Government into proposing elections in the occupied territories. But last week the proposal all but came apart, under the pressures of an Israeli political system that seems to leave no room for bold action in the absence of national unanimity.

title: Holly B. Walker Weds J. S. Nixon
description: Holly Barnwell Walker, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James Elliot Cabot Walker of West Hartford, Conn., was married there yesterday to Jeffrey Scott Nixon, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Louis Nixon of Rumson, N.J. The Rev. Allan H. O'Neil, an Episcopal minister, officiated at St. John's Church.

title: A Welcome Voice
description: To the Editor:

title: Holding On In Devastation
description: IT will take weeks to undo the damage of Monday's storm and put an accurate price on the loss of businesses, houses, furniture and cars, but for many people, property was almost an afterthought.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: BRENTWOOD, N.H.;
A Bastille Day Grand Opening
description: LEAD: SEIZING the occasion of Bastille Day, last Friday, a New Hampshire developer opened the first eight shops of an ambitious theme retail center designed to resemble a French village.

title: Italian Fare and a Trattoria Ambiance
description: THE owners of Gate's in New Canaan and the Pompano Grill in Westport have opened a new restaurant, in Fairfield, just beyond the green on the Post Road. It is called Centro (pronounced CHEN-trow, the Italian way), thus establishing the restaurant's identity almost immediately. Not that you will have any trouble catching on. You enter through a take-out area where pasta machines are set up and large round loaves of hearth-style Italian bread line the display shelves.

title: David Wiener Married in Vermont To Kate Ashforth, an Art Teacher
description: Katherine Perkins Ashforth, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Adams Ashforth Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and Peru, Vt., was married yesterday at the Peru Congregational Church to David Michel Wiener, a son of Eva Michel Wiener of New York and Samuel Wiener Jr. of Guilford, Conn. The Rev. Richard F. Van Wely and Rabbi Albert Ginsburgh performed the ceremony.

title: 'You Have to Broaden Yourself'
description: JACQUELYN C. DURRELL, the First Selectman of Fairfield, is the new president of the Connecticut Conference of Municipalities, which represents 110 of the state's 169 towns and cities.

title: Luise Woelflein To Wed Teacher
description: Mr. and Mrs. Kevin Gerard Woelflein of Greenwich, Conn., and Washington, have announced August wedding plans for their daughter, Luise Ann Woelflein, and Daniel Lee Bogan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William James Bogan of Chillicothe, Ohio.

title: Anne Schmutz Wed to Donald Hovey
description: At Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Boston, Anne Elizabeth Schmutz and Donald Campbell Hovey, both graduates of Williams College, were married yesterday by the Rev. Ronald A. Romeis, a Presbyterian minister.

title: Balancing African Anthropology and Art
description: The 1980's art world will probably be known for many things - its art stars, mega-museums, runaway auction prices. But in a quiet way, it may also come to be seen as the beginning of the golden age of African art exhibitions.

title: Sheffield Demoted
description: He was promoted as a candidate for American League rookie of the year before the season, but midway through it, Gary Sheffield, the Milwaukee Brewers' shortstop, has been demoted to the Class AAA farm team at Denver. The 20-year-old Sheffield, nephew of the Mets' Dwight Gooden, batted .270 through late April, but by Friday had slipped to .248 with 4 home runs and 29 runs batted in. Worse, he was in the midst of a 1-for-21 slump.

title: GORBACHEV URGES ECONOMIC ACCORDS
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet President, surprised the summit leaders today by sending them a letter calling for greatly expanded economic cooperation between Eastern Europe and the West to promote worldwide growth and ease the third world's debt problems.

title: FOR SALE: THE ADIRONDACKS
description: One must admire the wily business sense of individuals like Roger Jakubowski and Henry A. Lassiter or the way in which groups like the Patten Corporation or the Finch-Pruyn paper company have maximized their profits (''For Sale: Thousands of Pristine Adirondack Acres,'' by James Howard Kunstler, June 18). Recognizing that competing against the Japanese or West Germans to make and sell something of value involves risk and a slower return on investment, they, instead, wisely have used their capital for land speculation in New York's Adirondack Park.

title: LOVING AND OTHER MAGIC TRICKS
description: BEND THIS HEART By Jonis Agee. 130 pp. Minneapolis: Coffee House Press. Paper, $9.95.

title: It Was Mozart's Mystery to Be Genius and Fool; Art Isn't Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Woman Held in Custody Case Is Out of Punitive Detention
description: The director of the District of Columbia Jail has overturned a decision that placed Dr. Elizabeth Morgan in punitive confinement.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Should Bo Jackson Give Up One Sport?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number.
