Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: A Painting Prodigy, but Still a Child
description: Wang Yani is a prodigy. She is largely self-taught. She paints rapidly in brush and ink. The earliest of the 69 paintings in ''Yani: The Brush of Innocence,'' at the Arthur M. Sackler Gallery, were made when she was 3 and 4 years old. She has spent her 14 years in the village of Gongcheng in Guangxi province in southern China, 50 miles from Guilin, which the catalogue says has been renowned since Ming times for ''the most beautiful mountains and waters under heaven.''

title: Imagination (and Attention) at the Grill
description: GRILLING becomes more versatile and imaginative with each passing year. Not just meat and poultry but vegetables, fish and even fruit are now being grilled routinely.

title: MAKING THE MOST OF DUBLIN
description: A LINK WITH THE RIVER By Desmond Hogan. 325 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.95.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Disney Reviews Pass Policy In Florida

title: Canadian Comics Take Aim at Cable Funny Bone
description: In the back room at the Rivoli, you never know what you're going to see. The front room is a trendily downscale bar and restaurant typical of Toronto's Queen Street West scene, with a cheerfully bohemian-artist ambiance. Some of the regulars would consider it slumming to venture into the Back Room, which caters to a younger, more raucous constituency.

title: ROBBERY SUSPECT MUGGED
description: A man stole $2,100 from a Brooklyn savings bank on Friday but was mugged as he made his getaway, so he immediately reported the crime to the nearest police station house, the police said. Officers promptly arrested the man.

title: YOU COULD BUY RADIUM IN THE DRUGSTORE
description: MULTIPLE EXPOSURES Chronicles of the Radiation Age. By Catherine Caufield. Illustrated. 304 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $19.95.

title: Stitchery by Slaves Soars Free In a New Show
description: Textiles stitched and woven by slaves - bed coverings, a rag rug and a wedding dress - dominate the exhibition of highly expressive works by 19th-century African-American artisans opening Thursday at the Museum of American Folk Art's annex at Lincoln Square. The landmark show of 27 works, the first to present the full range of textiles produced by slaves on plantations of the South, remains through Sept. 17.

title: Does the Jazz of the Past Have a Future?
description: It was a moment precious enough to keep. Benny Goodman, clarinet tucked easily under one arm, up there in front of a brand-new band, counting off ''Let's Dance'' one more time for an overflow audience bursting with long memories.

title: ONTO SUPERMARKET SHELVES WITHOUT PAYING A SLOTTING FEE
description: Manufacturers of health food are trying to exploit their current window of opportunity for moving into supermarkets. For despite consumer demand, the major food companies have shown little interest in entering the health foods market - a precious opening for these small concerns.

title:
INVESTING;
Are Soda Stocks Recession-Proof?
description: LEAD: As evidence mounts that the economy is slowing, investors are turning to stocks that are likely to hold up in a recession. And the shares of the Coca-Cola Company and Pepsico Inc. are among Wall Street's favorites. Both have increased by more than 30 percent since the beginning of the year and have room to grow, analysts believe.

title: Commercial Property: Grand Central Tower; Law Firms Expand Their Presence in Midtown
description: SITES for new office projects are nearly nonexistent on the east side of midtown Manhattan and large new tenants are scarce, too. But a tower set to rise above the Grand Central Post Office is using construction and financial gymnastics to surmount those obstacles.

title: The Beggars of Moscow Ask Not for Money but for Justice
description: Street mendicants in the Soviet Union rise up swift as the agonized beggars of Bombay to plead a far more Kafkaesque need than money.

title: Beating Japan at Its Own Game
description: Robin Bates moves with practiced ease as she assembles a microfilm machine at the Eastman Kodak Company's sprawling Elmgrove factory complex in Rochester. The microfilmer is a tricky combination of delicate optics and high-speed mechanical components that enables it to photograph 500 canceled checks a minute, but Ms. Bates seldom hesitates. After all, she helped Kodak engineers design the machine.

title: N.F.L. Tackles New Issues On the Field, Around the Globe
description: With no new commissioner, no union contract and most of the draft picks unsigned, most of the National Football League goes back to work this week as training camps open.

title: Wade Is Enshrined
description: When she captured the Wimbledon singles title on her 18th attempt in 1977, Virginia Wade became the toast of Britain. When she defeated Billie Jean King in the United States Open final at Forest Hills nine years earlier, she helped usher in the open era of tennis. Yesterday in Newport, R.I., Wade was toasted for her career achievements and ushered into the International Tennis Hall of Fame, along with an Australian player from the post-World War I era, Gerald Patterson, a two-time Wimbledon winner who died in 1967.

title: Pre-emptive Strike
description: The third term hasn't been a charm for Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. of Washington. Damaged by reports of a visit to a drug suspect's hotel room and by rising crime, drug use and homelessness in the capital, Mr. Barry nonetheless is on the offensive. Ending speculation that he might step aside in favor of the Rev. Jesse Jackson, who has hinted he might run if Mr. Barry does not, the Mayor said through aides that he will seek a fourth term. But the road does not promise to be easy. In addition to his other problems, Mr. Barry might yet face a challenge from Mr. Jackson, who needs the pulpit of elective office to bolster his Presidential aspirations. Indeed, some Washington Democrats say that, by making his announcement only through aides, Mr. Barry has left himself a loophole should Mr. Jackson press him.

title: Triborough Tolls Rise 25 Percent
description: Tolls on the seven bridges and two tunnels operated by the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority rose by 25 percent at 3 A.M. today, prompting many motorists to buy extra tokens at toll booths yesterday because the existing tokens will be accepted indefinitely.

title: A Nibble and a Wet
description: To the Editor:

title: Question Of the Week; Are Foreign Golfers Better Than Americans?
description: No. Curtis Strange won the last two United States Opens, the first golfer to achieve that feat since Ben Hogan. Young American players who don't get their tour cards the first time around go to Europe or Japan where the competition isn't as strong.

title: Margaret Praskac Becomes a Bride
description: At the First Presbyterian Church in Red Bank, N.J., Margaret Praskac, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Praskac Jr. of Rumson, N.J., was married yesterday to Peter Bruce O'Brien, a son of Lucie Suter O'Brien of New York and William O'Brien of Center Sandwich, N.H. The Rev. Foster Wilson performed the ceremony. Jody Praskac was her sister's maid of honor, and Nancy Parry was matron of honor. Richard Hutton and Kenneth Richieri were the best men.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York Senate 1. Immigration: Vote on an amendment to a bill to overhaul immigration laws that would prevent the deportation of spouses and minor children of illegal aliens who received under the 1986 reform of laws affecting illegal aliens. Approved 61 to 38, July 12. 2. Immigration: Vote on an amendment to the immigration bill that would guarantee a minimum number of visas for extended family members of current American citizens. Approved 62 to 36, July 12. 3. Immigration: Vote on an amendment to the immigration bill that would give extra preference to immigrants who spoke English. Rejected 56 to 43, July 13. 4. Immigration: Vote on final passage of an overhaul of the nation's immigration laws aimed at guaranteeing more visas for skilled workers with no ties in the United States and at increasing immigration from Western Europe. Approved 81 to 17, July 13. $ 1 2 3 4 Connecticut Dodd (D) Y N N Y Lieberman (D) Y Y Y Y New Jersey Bradley (D) Y Y N Y Lautenberg (D) Y Y N Y New York D'Amato (R) Y Y N Y Moynihan (D) Y N N Y House 1. National Endowment for the Arts: Vote on an amendment to an Interior Department spending bill that would cut the proposed $171.4 million Endowment budget by $45,000 - the amount the agency gave for two controversial art projects. Approved 361 to 65 (with one member voting ''Present''), July 12. 2. National Endowment for the Arts: Vote on an amendment to an Interior Department spending bill that would cut the Endowment's proposed $171.4 million budget by five percent. Rejected 328 to 95, July 12. $ 1 2 Connecticut 1. Kennelly (D) Y N 2. Gejdenson (D) Y N 3. Morrison (D) Y N 4. Shays (R) Y N 5. Rowland (R) Y N 6. Johnson (R) Y N New Jersey 1. Florio (D) Y N 2. Scheuer (D) Y N 9. Manton (D) Y N 10. Schumer (D) Y N 11. Towns (D) Y N 12. Owens (D) P N 13. Solarz (D) Y N 14. Molinari (R) Y Y 15. Green (R) Y N 16. Rangel (D) Y N 17. Weiss (D) N 18. Garcia (D) Y N 19. Engel (D) N 20. Lowey (D) Y N 21. Fish (R) Y N 22. Gilman (R) Y N 23. McNulty (D) Y N 24. Solomon (R) N Y 25. Boehlert (R) Y N 26. Martin (R) Y N 27. Walsh (R) Y A 28. McHugh (D) Y N 29. Horton (R) Y N 30. Slaughter (D) Y N 31. Paxon (R) Y N 32. LaFalce (D) Y N 33. Nowak (D) Y N 34. Houghton (R) N N KEY Y Yea; N Nay; (A) Absent or did not vote; (P) Present.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Boost 1988. HBO Video. 1 hour, 35 minutes. $89.99. Closed captioned. R. This attempted demonstration of the emotional havoc caused by drugs proves far more convincing as a picture of an ephemeral kind of southern California culture. James Woods, as the manic fast-talker Lenny Brown, seems headed for disaster long before he becomes hooked. Once he and his wife (Sean Young) do succumb, this turns into another ''movie about the awful things that addicted people do to themselves and to one another, whether they drink, sniff or shoot up.'' As Lenny's mentor, Steven Hill gives the film's most sophisticated performance. (Vincent Canby) True Believer 1989. RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Video. 1:43. $89.95. CC. R. This thoroughly gripping film begins with a Chinatown gang murder and makes a powerful impression even before the opening credits are over. Mr. Woods is back - here playing Eddie Dodd, a lawyer whose 60's idealism has given way to the business of defending drug dealers - now ''a fierce and formidable leading man.'' Though narrow and even incomplete, the character of Eddie is a wonderful invention. Robert Downey Jr. and Margaret Colin offer strong supporting performances. Joseph Ruben gives lively and surprising direction to Wesley Strick's tightly knit screenplay. (Janet Maslin) Talk Radio 1988. MCA Home Video. 1:50. $89.95. R. This adaptation of Eric Bogosian's short Off Broadway ''slice of bizarre life'' provides ''a nearly perfect example of how not to make a movie of a play.'' Mr. Bogosian again plays Barry Champlain with a lot of furious energy but no real payoff; though the talk-show host is apparently headed for the junk heap, it's hard to care. Directed by Oliver Stone, this mess of a movie incorporates elements from the real-life story of Alan Berg, the Denver talk-show host murdered in 1984. The story still takes place mostly in one night, but the tension is greatly reduced by a series of spongy flashbacks. (Canby) I Cover the Waterfront 1933. King Bee Video. 1:12. $14.95. Not rated. Adapted from a book by Max Miller and directed by James Cruze, the film is set in San Diego. At the time of its original release, a critic called it ''a stolid and often grim picture, the principal asset of which is the clever acting of the principals'' - particularly Ernest Torrence, in his last performance, as a sinister fisherman who supplements his income by smuggling Chinese into the United States. ''Unusually attractive,'' Claudette Colbert is ''scarcely convincing as a fisherman's daughter, chiefly because she does not look the type.'' Ben Lyon plays a bibulous newshawk who first uses her to learn about her father and then falls in love. The Cocoanuts 1929. MCA. 1:33. $19.95. Not rated. According to a contemporary critic, writing when talking pictures were ''still in their puppyhood,'' ''fun puts melody in the shade in the audible pictorial transcription'' of the musical comedy ''The Cocoanuts,'' featuring ''that incongruous quartet'' the Marx Brothers. Groucho, equipped with George S. Kaufman's crisp lines, ''rather monopolizes things, allowing but scant time for the fair Mary Eaton and her partner, Oscar Shaw, to rhapsodize on love'' to the music of Irving Berlin. Harpo, meanwhile, remains ''content with a silence that has proved golden.'' ''Although the comedy aroused considerable merriment among the first-night gathering, it is of the robust variety, lined here and there by witty words.'' Don't we know.

title: How to Assess Juried Art Shows
description: The letter by Rosalyn Weene [ ''Esthetic Goals at Exhibitions,'' June 25 ] commenting on the last Huntington Township Art League, and in particular the favorable review by Helen A. Harrison, just scratches the surface of how to assess juried art shows in general, and not just the annual shows of the art league at the Heckscher Museum. These shows have been under constant criticism because of their uneven levels, crowded hangings and shifting judges with wildly changing standards.

title:
FARE OF THE COUNTRY;
Maryland's Bounty: Bushels of Blue Crabs
description: LEAD: BEFORE dawn, Capt. Roby Cornelius, like the other watermen who gather daily in Rock Hall, Md., has downed his last cup of breakfast coffee and headed out in the Robyn-De to harvest the Chesapeake Bay for Atlantic blue crabs, long the most prized catch from these prolific brackish waters. It's a scene repeated generation after generation, town after town along Maryland's saw-toothed Eastern Shore every March to

title: A Polish Paper Accuses Jews From Bronx in Nuns' Attack
description: Poland's Government newspaper today accused New York Jews who staged a protest against a Roman Catholic convent at the former Nazi death camp at Auschwitz of making an attack on nuns.

title: Capitalizing on a New Crop of Customers
description: Health foods, once a staple for only a small segment of the population, are moving into the mainstream.

title: When Vacation Is Time for the Real Work
description: College students are doing more than catching a few rays on the beaches of Malibu or working at desk jobs in New York this summer. Many are spending their vacations in ways that might make even Indiana Jones blink: flying abroad to volunteer as social workers, rural teachers and presidential aides, or landing jobs at home as singing waitresses, baseball players and stand-up comedians.

title: When Reliability Is Most Important
description: Small businesses are particularly vulnerable to computer failure. It is not that their computers fail more often than those of larger companies. Rather, it is that small companies can rarely afford to keep a technical support staff and maintain an inventory of spare computers and parts. If something breaks, fixing it is usually not quick, easy or cheap.

title: Problems in Translation
description: To the Editor:

title: Clare Sullivan Is Wed To Steven John Adams
description: Clare Killeen Sullivan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Sullivan Jr. of Rowayton, Conn., and Windham, Vt., was married yesterday at the Community Church in Landgrove, Vt., to Steven John Adams, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lowell G. Adams Jr. of Plymouth Meeting, Pa. William Reed, a justice of the peace in Peru, Vt., performed the ceremony.

title: Susan B. Chaleff, Consultant, Weds Jeffrey B. Wallace
description: At the Stanhope Hotel in New York yesterday, Susan Beth Chaleff, a daughter of Jean E. Chaleff of Tonawanda, N.Y., and the late Frank S. Chaleff, was married to Jeffrey Bennett Wallace, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Wallace of Short Hills, N.J. The Rev. Vishnu Jayson, an interfaith minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Miss Flanagan, Student, to Wed
description: Mrs. John Joseph Flanagan of Green Village, N.J., and Cotuit, Mass., has announced August wedding plans for her daughter Mary Jane Flanagan and Douglas Charles Turnbull, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Charles Turnbull of Collinsville, Conn.

title: Helen Walker Puner, Editor, 74
description: Helen Walker Puner, the first female editor at Fortune magazine and the author of four books, died Friday at Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla, N.Y. She was 74 years old and lived in Ossining, N.Y.

title: Yorkshire
description: To the Editor: The article on steam trains in Yorkshire, England (Travel, May 7) in effect gave incorrect postage for obtaining the booklet ''Guide to Steam Trains in the British Isles.'' The required postage is 62 cents, but since the British Post Office values International Reply Coupons only at the minimum rate of 37 cents regardless of what might be printed on the coupon, it is necessary to send two coupons worth a total of 74 cents. Readers may write to me, Douglas A. Whittle, general administrator of the Association of Railway Preservation Societies Ltd., 3 Orchard Close, Watford, Hertfordshire, WD1 3DU England, or get in touch with the British Tourist Authority, 40 West 57th Street, New York, N.Y. 10019 (212-581-4700). The authority has a large supply of the booklets, which are offered free (including postage). DOUGLAS A. WHITTLE Watford, England

title:
New Jersey Q & A: Dr. Harold P. Furth;
Seeking the Key to Nuclear Fusion
description: LEAD: DR. HAROLD P. FURTH, a Princeton University physicist, says he has not seen or heard any evidence to suggest a shortcut to unlocking the vast potential of nuclear fusion - the fusing of lightweight atomic nuclei into a nucleus of heavier mass with a resultant loss in the combined mass, which is converted into energy.

title:
PASTIMES: GARDENING;
An Expanded Role for Dwarf Iris
description: LEAD: Home hybridizers, everyday gardeners who have experimented with plant breeding, are responsible for expanding the roles of many garden perennials. Their efforts are especially true with the standard dwarf bearded iris.

title: The Condo Style of Life Takes Hold in Westchester
description: LEAD: FRESH from a six-mile run through White Plains, Dr. Neil Spielsinger put his finger on an advantage of life in a high-rise condominium. ''The terrace is my backyard,'' he said, ''and I don't have to water it.''

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: EMMA WHO SAVED MY LIFE. By Wilton Barnhardt. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) ''But what's in the books, on the billboards, these things often let you down'' says Gilbert Freeman, the narrator of an ambitious first novel that might be appropriately titled ''Emma Who Let Me Down.'' Emma is the focus of this romp that begins at a wild party thrown on the eve of President Richard Nixon's resignation and ends during the AIDS epidemic.

title: DO NOT BE AFRAID OF THE UNIVERSE
description: AT THE HEART OF THE WEB The Inevitable Genesis of Intelligent Life. By George A. Seielstad. Illustrated. 294 pp. Boston: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $24.95.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: PHILADELPHIA;
Health Center Raises Hopes
description: LEAD: IN West Philadelphia, where gracious Victorian homes, cavernous three-story twins and block after block of rowhouses are crammed together near universities and hospitals, residential construction is rare.

title: A Neighborhood Makes Its Peace With Public Housing
description: ON a recent Wednesday at noon in Runyon Heights, a middle-class black neighborhood in Yonkers, elderly residents gathered for lunch and companionship at the community center, as they have for years.

title: 25 Years of Finding Jobs for Youths
description: THIS summer, 17-year-old Yurko Iwai of Larchmont hopes to go to a lot of parties. Having recently completed a course in table setting, serving and kitchen cleanup, Ms. Iwai is now qualified to be placed as a hostess helper by the Youth Employment Service of Larchmont-Mamaroneck Inc.

title: Local 1199 Gets Organized, and Daring, In Its Latest Round With the Hospitals
description: MOUNTING a one-day strike last week to demand better wages and benefits, health care workers in New York City dramatically raised the stakes in their hitherto fruitless contract negotiations with 53 of the city's private hospitals.

title: Film About a Fatal Beating Examines a Community
description: Seven summers ago, on a mean June night outside a McDonald's in Detroit, a young Chinese-American engineer named Vincent Chin was beaten to death with a baseball bat by Ronald Ebens, a Chrysler foreman. Mr. Ebens - who is caucasian - confessed, pleaded guilty to manslaughter and never spent a day in jail.

title: Baker Now Confirms No Special Emissary To Be Sent to Israel
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d confirmed today that the United States might at some point send a special envoy to Israel, but not now and not a high-level mission like those headed in the past by Philip A. Habib.

title: For Asia, The Strain Is Showing
description: AS negotiations about the future of Cambodia build momentum, with an international conference opening in Paris at the end of this month, the six countries of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, or Asean, have managed to get their act together at least one more time. But the task is getting harder as the interests of the member nations - Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore and Thailand - begin to diverge.

title: It Was Mozart's Mystery to Be Genius and Fool; Don't Blame Hugo Wolf
description: To the Editor:

title: How U.S. Can Go About Deploying a Shrinking Missile Arsenal
description: To the Editor:

title: Valley Victory, With Rally, Prevails in Yonkers Trot
description: Valley Victory, bidding to become the first trotting Triple Crown winner in 17 years, took the first step last night, coming from behind to win the $418,810 Yonkers Trot by three lengths.

title: Pilot Says He Doesn't Have Answers
description: The pilot who was apparently unconscious while his small plane flew a thousand miles and crashed told Federal investigators today that he had no idea how he was shot and that the last thing he remembered was having difficulty breathing.

title: For a First Job, Dress to Blend In
description: ''Know what everybody's wearing, because that's what you're going to live with if you want to succeed.'' That is the first rule of first-job dressing, as stated by Mara Urshel, senior vice president and general-merchandise manager of women's wear at Saks Fifth Avenue. For a new college graduate shopping for a fall career outfit, it may be more useful than many professorial pronouncements.

title: Choices in Manhattan: Down-Home or Plush
description: This is a summary of reviews of Manhattan restaurants by Bryan Miller that have appeared in The New York Times. Ratings are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have ratings. Prices are current. B. Smith's

title: FICTION
description: THE GUEST OF HONOR. By Irving Wallace. (Delacorte, $18.95.) What if President Reagan had been unhappily married to Nancy? And what if Corazon Aquino had come to Washington and Reagan had fallen madly in love with the spunky widow? And what if the pesky Sam Donaldson learned that the President was engaging in hanky-panky with another head of state? Spin all that into a novel and you have ''The Guest of Honor.'' President Matt Underwood, a former television anchorman, is lazy and lacking in curiosity, but he is a handsome and kind man. His wife, Alice, a former Miss America, is beautiful, manipulative and cold. Madame Noy Sang has become the young, inexperienced President of Lampang, an island west of the Philippines, following the assassination of her husband by political enemies. She travels to Washington for financial aid, knowing that, in return, the Americans will want to put a large air base in Lampang. Until his lunch with Madame Noy, the President had not even heard of Lampang. But after seeing her eager face, lissome body and gauzy yellow dresses, he tosses out his 3-by-5 cards and gives her a lot of aid in return for a little base. The trade upsets his chief of staff, Paul Blake. Underwood ignores Blake, sensing that he is under the sway of the First Lady, who likes to conduct meetings with the chief of staff wearing a peach-colored negligee. The President is determined to help Noy find her husband's killer. He is also determined to get re-elected so that he can give her more American aid. This is not just another Washington saga of sex and power. It's a heartwarming tale of two presidents, a vast love and a puny air base.

title: Foreign Films May Translate Into Rentals
description: In video there's this adage: foreign films play well only in New York and Los Angeles, and woefully almost everywhere else. Consequently, it is estimated that only about 8 percent of the country's approximately 35,000 video outlets carry any foreign titles. This fall, though, Orion Home Video will test the prevailing wisdom by deploying 24 of its strongest foreign titles in 500 outlets nationwide. ''We want some hard data on how these films would rent if people knew more about them,'' says Paul Wagner, vice president for public affairs of Orion. ''We stress the point that these countries send us only their very best.''

title: Opera in Concert Form Returning to Caramoor
description: IT has been almost a decade since opera in concert form - once a hallmark of Caramoor summers - transported festival audiences to earlier times and places. The hiatus is almost over.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ROBERT M. MACCARONE;
Pulling the Strands Together on Drugs
description: LEAD: WHEN Democrats on the Board of Legislators called for an office within county government to coordinate the fight against illegal drugs, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke initially criticized the idea as an unneeded new layer of bureaucracy. But in a reversal, Mr. O'Rourke, running for re-election, last month appointed Robert M.

title: Prospects; Curbing Commodity Trades
description: Last week, a Federal court upheld the Chicago Board of Trade's order to soybean traders to reduce their holdings of July futures contracts. Speculators may get a bonanza, while soy farmers and Ferruzzi Finanziaria S.p.A., the Italian company whose aggressive buying sparked the ruling, may face a debacle. Should the exchanges have this much power? Or should Congress take some power away when it votes on reauthorizing the Commodity Futures Trading Commission later this year? Henry Jarecki Chairman of the Mocatta Futures Corporation, a New York-based commodity broker.

title: DATA BANK: July 16, 1989
Wrong Number? Wrong Solution
description: DEAR Ma Bell, I recently lost a friend. An old friend. We've been together for 24 years and now, for no fault of my on, I had to let the old-timer go.

title: Managers Win One
description: Ever since businesses became too big for individual owners to run, there has been a tug-of-war between the managers of companies - the hired hands - and the shareholders - the owners.

title: Economic Watch; Forces in Society, and Reaganism, Helped Dig Deeper Hole for Poor
description: A quarrel erupted in Congress last week over a document showing that the gap between rich and poor widened under President Ronald Reagan.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-17

title: Paris's Classic Look for Kids
description: JUST about every American who has strolled through the Tuileries on a weekend afternoon has been entranced by the children in their Sunday best riding the old-fashioned carousel and sailing boats on the pond. While sneakers, Oshkosh overalls and le jogging suits have made inroads into the French children's fashion scene, the true Parisian look - floral hand-smocked dresses and pretty straw hats, crisp sailor suits and boys' blue and green madras Bermuda shorts complete with suspenders - will always rely on the classics.

title: Summitry's Purpose
description: The tone of the annual summit meetings of the powerful industrial democracies has changed remarkably in 15 years, and so has the world. The ritual began in the throes of the first great oil crisis. Valery Giscard d'Estaing, then President of France, had the idea of assembling five economic heavyweights for a private exchange on how to avert disaster.

title: Europe Atom Smasher Completes Test Run
description: The world's biggest particle accelerator, designed to deepen understanding of nature's basic forces by smashing atoms, has successfully completed its first test run, scientists said today.

title: Minority Rights?
description: To the Editor:

title: Union Leader Urges Miners to End Walkout
description: Richard Trumka, president of the United Mine Workers, issued a plea striking miners Friday to end their unauthorized walkouts, and workers in at least three states planned to return to the coal mines.

title: Paunches and Pinstripe Magic
description: The old man took his place at the far end of the Yankee clubhouse, tugged on his uniform, then sat back and smiled. All around him, there was the typical sort of noise and activity that precedes old-timers' games. But there was a quiet reverence near Joe DiMaggio.

title: Long Island Journal
description: Radio Memories

title: BRIDGE
description: When the organizers of an event provide the players with expert analyses prepared in advance, the pre-mortem adds fun to the post-mortem. Contestants can sometimes find that they have done better at the table than the analyst predicted when looking at all four hands.

title: We Must 'Do Better' for Our Children
description: I am a son of Greek immigrants. My parents, George and Venetia, came to America in their teens with nothing more than grade-school educations, and from a school in a Greek farm village at that. They were understandably fearful yet full of hope and confidence. This was not only the land of the free but the land of limitless frontiers and resources - a land where dreams come true.

title: Gifted Teen-Agers Learn to Fly Before They Drive
description: In a St. Vincent College course called simulated society last summer, 14-year-old Joseph Hisker learned what it would be like to be poor and uneducated. But this summer, the tall ninth-grader soared away from such troubles, choosing instead to learn to fly above the Laurel Highlands of western Pennsylvania.

title: How the Beaches Have Finally Come Clean This Year
description: ATLANTIC beaches on Long Island and New Jersey have been spared - so far, at least - the wash-ups of medical debris and garbage that doomed the last two summers, thanks in large part to merciful wind patterns and the vigilance of three Federal garbage-collection boats on New York Harbor.

title: A Time to Step: Fraternity Picnic Draws 60,000
description: From morning to dusk in stifling summer heat, tens of thousands of students streamed into Fairmount Park toward a set of tennis courts, the nerve center for what has been the largest reunion ever of black fraternity and sorority members at the annual Greek Picnic.

title: Nations Call for Action on Environment
description: The latest draft of the economic communique being worked out by the major industrial democracies known as the Group of Seven calls for ''decisive action'' to protect the global environment.

title: Capitol Hill's High-Tech Tutor
description: When the Office of Technology Assessment took on a study of how technology was changing the American economy a few years ago, it found more than it was looking for - as usual.

title: Commuter Rail Lines And Competition
description: It appears that politicians today have only one answer to all economic problems: competition. But Rodney Fisk's article on solving the problems of the New Jersey commuter rail lines (''Needed: Competition for Commuter Rail Lines,'' Opinion page, June 18), is so preposterous that one must conclude that Mr. Fisk is a professor of economics.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some of the most notable releases of the last few months.

title: For U.S. Law Enforcers, the County is No Longer a Sleepy Outpost
description: SIX years ago, the lone Federal prosecutor in the White Plains outpost of the United States Attorney's Southern District office spent much of his time looking for work by knocking on the doors of local police departments.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE PIGEON, by Patrick Suskind. (WashingtonJU Square/Pocket Books, $5.95.) The well-ordered life of a Parisian bank guard named Jonathan Noel is transformed completely when a pigeon shows up at his door. ''Mr. Suskind, a Munich-born writer whose suspenseful best-selling novel 'Perfume' was published here in 1986, gives us some whiffs of Georges Simenon in this slender but charming rendering of Noel's fateful day,'' Linda Simon said here last year. PRIVATE DEMONS: The Life of Shirley Jackson, by Judy Oppenheimer. (Fawcett Columbine, $10.95.) Rushing through life on alcohol and amphetamines, the woman who wrote ''The Lottery'' seemed so otherworldly that her neighbors in Bennington, Vt., thought she was a Communist or a witch. ''She was a true storyteller, with a rich and haunted imagination, and she could walk unafraid in regions where love and murder have each other's names and speak each other's tongues,'' Elizabeth Frank said in The Book Review last year. ''In 'Private Demons,' Ms. Oppenheimer gives us back both a woman and an artist we should honor.'' ONLY CHILDREN, by Rafael Yglesias. (Ballantine, $4.95.) Two overly driven Manhattan couples learn that having children is even harder than having a career. ''It is heartening to be convinced anew by such a competent writer that parenthood is a worthy subject for literary speculation,'' Brett Singer said here in 1988. WASHINGTON GOES TO WAR, by David Brinkley. (Ballantine, $4.95.) The television journalist recalls how World War II transformed a sleepy city with Southern efficiency and Northern charm into a boom town bureaucracy. ''The history of how bungling old Washington managed successfully to run World War II is told with such endearing detail and sneer-free humor that one concludes it was not in spite of American ineptitude that we won, but because of it,'' Judith Martin said here last year. ALASKA, by James A. Michener. (Fawcett Crest, $5.95.) One thousand seventy-three pages in paperback, James A. Michener's saga about Alaska shows he is ''still, sentence for sentence, writing's fastest attention grabber,'' Christopher Lehmann-Haupt said in The Times last year. ''It takes him, on the average, about half a paragraph to get you involved in what's happening next, whether it's the development of an ice age, a fight between a mammoth and a saber-toothed tiger or the construction of the Alcan Highway.'' RAINBOWS, CURVE BALLS: And Other Wonders of the Natural World Explained, by Ira Flatow. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $7.95.) National Public Radio's answer to Mr. Wizard explains how the universe works. ''He presents intricacies of biology, physics and technology much the way Tim McCarver, my favorite New York Mets announcer, discourses on the suicide squeeze play and the mysteries of the balk,'' James Gorman said here last year. SECOND CHANCES, by Alice Adams. (Fawcett, $4.95.) This quiet novel about a group of longtime friends growing old together on the Pacific coast is Alice Adams's strongest work, Benjamin DeMott said in The Book Review last year. ''The strength flows partly from Ms. Adams's capacity to evoke fellow feeling, kindness and devotion as entirely natural inclinations of the heart. Her people care intensely for one another, and, although not beyond rage, seem beyond meanness.'' DISCOS AND DEMOCRACY: China in the Throes of Reform, by Orville Schell. (Anchor/Doubleday, $9.95.) In a book published a year before China's latest cataclysm, a Western journalist wonders whether the ancient society can withstand the pressures of modernization. Last year our reviewer, Ian Buruma, criticized Orville Schell for succumbing to ''cultural Maoism.'' But he said that ''his enthusiasm for sifting through material that less diligent reporters might find extraordinarily dull (just try reading a magazine like Red Flag and you will see what I mean) engages the reader.'' PICTURE THIS, by Joseph Heller. (Ballantine, $4.95.) Written in a rush of non sequiturs, this fictional meditation on Rembrandt's painting ''Aristotle Contemplating the Bust of Homer''

title: ...And a Community That Appreciates Intellectual Activity
description: ONCE again education has made the headlines. Unfortunately, the articles relate the all-too-familiar refrain: American public education is in trouble. In both the state and national arenas, our leaders have delineated the schools' deficiencies and made proposals that they hope will remedy these perceived ills. They have either missed or avoided the fundamental problem.

title: BOMBS ARE NOT ENOUGH
description: THE LIMITS OF AIR POWER The American Bombing of North Vietnam. By Mark Clodfelter. 297 pp. New York: The Free Press. $22.95.

title: Q&A
description: Front-Yard Parking Question: I notice that in my neighborhood and in others around the city, some homeowners have paved over their front yards to use as parking spaces. Sometimes their parked vehicles jut out onto the sidewalk. This detracts from the appearance of the neighborhood. Is it legal to pave over all or part of the front yard for parking purposes? I have heard that a homeowner can only do this if there is a handicapped driver in the family. . . . J. P., Brooklyn Answer: Front-yard parking depends on the zoning of the area in question. The zoning rules that apply to R-1 and R-2 zones, which are mostly detached, single-family homes, for example, would prohibit it. However, in higher-density residential zones that are mostly for rowhouses and small apartment buildings, there are no bans on front-yard parking. Property owners whose buildings are in zones where this type of parking is allowed must meet certain requirements. The main one is that the distance from the front of the building to the property line must be at least 18 feet, and each parking space must be at least 8.5 feet wide. Owners must file plans with the Department of Buildings - in the Plan Examination Section of the borough office. Rights of Shareholders Question: We are 25 percent shareholders in a small co-op in lower Manhattan. Our loft is on the second floor directly above a storefront where there is a legal glass-bending operation. Gas fumes fill our loft and cause headaches and nausea for my husband and me. We have tried to persuade the other shareholders to make the tenant comply with the lease by installing some sort of ventilation system. So far they have refused to act, in part, we believe, because our co-op cannot afford to loseJU the income the rent brings. Can we withhold maintenance in an escrow account to force the co-op to deal with the matter? . . . J. C., Manhattan Answer: No matter how small your co-op or what its financial circumstances, you do have a right to a habitable apartment as the holder of a proprietary lease. Arthur Weinstein, an attorney who is a vice president of the Council of New York Cooperatives, said the courts have consistently held that the warranty of habitability applies to co-ops as well as rentals. Start by making your complaint and legal position clear in a certified-mail letter to the co-op board. You might substantiate the fact that a serious condition exists by filing complaints with the city's Department of Environmental Protection and the Department of Buildings. The possible violations being caused by the tenant would pose a greater risk than the loss of your maintenance.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: CARTOONING EXHIBITION

title: One Day Later, A Faster Lap
description: Emerson Fittipaldi today lowered his track record for the second time in two days in locking up the pole position for Marlboro Grand Prix Indy-Car race at the Meadowlands Sunday.

title: Staff and Patients Unite in Adversity
description: LEAD: THERE is an atmosphere of camaraderie among the patients at the Department of Veterans Affairs Medical Center at Northport as they trade war stories and help each other get around. But the medical center has its own war to fight as patients and staff members cope with shortages of equipment and personnel caused by eight years of cutbacks in financing.

title: FORBES MAGAZINE'S BIG GUN: Caspar W. Weinberger; From a Seat in the Cabinet To the Publisher's Chair
description: Caspar W. Weinberger, the publisher not the Defense Secretary, is not at all displeased with his new life. In the last few months, he's trekked to Singapore, Japan, South Korea, Scotland and Belgium. He's got excursions scheduled to California, Spain, West Germany and England. He mingles at frequent merry parties aboard Malcolm S. Forbes's yacht, the Highlander. Several weeks ago, he even went for an intoxicating whirl in a hot-air balloon in France.

title: Battle on Abortion Turns To Rights of Teen-Agers
description: Pregnancy and abortion have become a common part of adolescence, but the long-running debate over abortion rights has only occasionally focused on teen-agers. That is certain to change now, in the aftermath of the Supreme Court's decision this month that gave states new leeway to regulate abortion.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Who Can Be Trusted?
description: A Palestinian leader in the occupied territories who's linked to the Palestine Liberation Organization is talking:

title: Streetscapes: Seaview Hospital; A TB Patients' Haven Now Afflicted With Neglect
description: IT'S like a lost colonial outpost in the tropics - a grand complex of two dozen rotting buildings, the jungle closing in. But in this case it's a designated landmark, the 365-acre Seaview Hospital complex on Staten Island, which has been operated by New York City since its opening in 1913.

title: Latest Landmarks Include Scribner's, a Theater and a Clinic
description: Fifth Avenue's most elegant bookstore, upper Broadway's jazziest movie theater and a modest building on Ninth Avenue that was once the ''center of medical education in New York City'' are among the newest municipal landmarks.

title: PENTAGON WORRIED BY USE OF RESERVES
description: Since Vietnam, the Army has come to rely so heavily on the Army Reserve and the National Guard that by its own admission, it cannot fight even a small war without them.

title: Clark of Giants Stars Against Old Nemesis
description: Will Clark overcame his career hitting problems against John Smiley and drove in four runs to power the San Francisco Giants to an 8-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates today.

title: Get Tough on Salvador's Killers
description: During my recent visit to El Salvador, I met with a group of legislative leaders including Roberto D'Aubuisson, the president of the ruling party, known as Arena. Because of Mr. D'Aubuisson's reported association with human rights abuses, some critics pointedly asked why I had agreed to see him. The answer goes to the heart of this Administration's approach to human rights - an approach based not on posturing, but on engagement, on hands-on involvement to seek change.

title: New York's Poorest Neighborhoods Bear the Brunt of Social Programs
description: The poorest sections of New York City have a disproportionate share of housing and programs for homeless people, the mentally ill and drug abusers, prompting neighbors to charge discrimination and contend that this influx will doom efforts to rebuild their neighborhoods.

title:
GARDENING;
There's Treasure in Those Weeds
description: LEAD: TO paraphrase an old saying, one gardener's flowers may be another gardener's weeds.

title: August Wedding For Miss Cullison
description: Martha Leovy Cullison of Nyack, N.Y., and George Bennett Cullison Jr. of Harlan, Iowa, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Katharine Gates Cullison, to Yoshiki Shimada, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Naoki Shimada of New York. The wedding is to take place in August. Miss Cullison, a graduate of Greenwich (Conn.) High School and Grinnell College, is an actress. Her father is continuing a family law practice in Harlan established by his grandfather, George Washington Cullison, in 1880.

title: Review/Dance; 2 Interpretations of Aurora in 'Sleeping Beauty'
description: The Kirov Ballet saved its best performances of ''The Sleeping Beauty'' for last. On Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, Zhanna Ayupova, the company's 22-year-old revelation, triumphed again - this time as the first true Princess Aurora of the season.

title: When Writers Turn the Tables Rather Than the Other Cheek
description: From the playwright's point of view, critics occupy a special place in hell - somewhere between the eighth and ninth circles, between the hypocrites and the spreaders of false doctrine. For the playwright, the critic is the most dispensable person in the theater - unless he offers unstinting praise. In response to negative reviews, the playwright can sulk, grumble, complain by telephone or mail - or he can write a play about the experience. That last recourse has been taken by, among others, Peter Nichols, Terrence McNally, A. R. Gurney and Albert Innaurato, who, earlier this season, in ''Gus and Al,'' demonstrated the lengths to which a playwright could go in reaction to reviews.

title: Undergraduates Lament Raising Of Drinking Age
description: Last July, Wyoming raised its legal drinking age from 19 to 21. But state legislators left one loophole in the law, giving bars the option to admit 19- and 20-year-olds providing they are not served alcoholic beverages. This month the Laramie Town Council closed that loophole, and the under-age undergraduates as well as student leaders on the University of Wyoming campus - the only four-year institution in this state - are vocal in their disapproval.

title: In Search of The Rates That Bring Borrowers
description: FOR three months, interest rates have been inching down, sliding on their own as the economy weakened and then getting a slight push from the Federal Reserve. But they almost certainly must go still lower before Americans become buyers again.

title: 2 Towns Warn of Power Demands
description: LEAD: FOR 91 years, residents of Rockville Centre and Freeport have had the cheapest electric rates on Long Island simply because the towns generate their own power.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ending July 1 MANHATTAN Chelsea$345,000 1200 Broadway (29th St.) 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 3,000-sq.-ft. prewar loft co-op; darkroom, hardwood floors, southern exposure; maintenance $723, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Joffee LaSalle) Gramercy Park Area$175,000 132 East 19th Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 600-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; dining area, fireplace, 3 exposures, hardwood floors; maintenance $287, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Fields & Eychner) Greenwich Village$740,000 1 Fifth Avenue 2-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 1,200-sq.-ft. prewar duplex co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining area, marble bath, terrace, Washington Square Park view; maintenance $1,800, 35% tax-deductible (Broker: Meisel Real Estate) Greenwich Village$500,000 83 Perry Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,600-sq.-ft. prewar duplex co-op in a townhouse; dining room, den, 3 fireplaces, landmark district; common charge $200, taxes $2,400 (Broker: Ambrose Mar-Elia) Upper East Side$143,000 196 East 75th Street 475-sq.-ft. postwar studio co-op; 24-hr. doorman, separate dressing area, terrace; maintenance $531, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Penthouse Properties) Upper West Side$281,106 245 West 107th Street 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 1,100-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, remodeled large kitchen, high ceilings; maintenance $667, 51% tax-deductible (Broker: Klara Madlin Real Estate) BRONX Parkchester$238,000 1329 Noble Avenue 3-family, semi-attached, brick house; 3 bedrooms in primary unit; 2 bedrooms in others; 1 bath, dining room, large kitchen in each; 2-car garage, 25- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,300 (Broker: Marland Real Estate) Riverdale$242,000 3725 Henry Hudson Parkway (Blackstone) 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,600-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; part-time doorman, dining foyer, large kitchen, terrace; maintenance $989, 57% tax-deductible (Broker: Susan E. title: FICTION
description: UTRILLO'S MOTHER. By Sarah Baylis. (Rutgers University, $18.95.) As the subject of her only adult novel - she previously wrote two books for children - the British writer Sarah Baylis (who died in 1987) chose the life and times of the French artist Suzanne Valadon (1867-1938). Born in the provinces, Valadon at a young age moved to Paris with her mother and soon began to model for the artists who frequented the cafes of Montmartre. At 15, she began to draw. That same year she gave birth to Maurice Utrillo, arguably the most monstrous of painters. Valadon's work impressed many of the artists for whom she modeled, foremost Degas. ''This devil,'' he said of her, ''has a genius for drawing.'' Hot-tempered and fiercely independent, she probably was the devil to many of the mediocre artists of the time. Ms. Baylis wrote from Valadon's perspective, in the first person, and most of the story is devoted to Valadon's early years, from about the age of 6 to 20. The author was very good indeed at recreating the ambiance of life in the rural France of 100 years ago. She was a writer of all the senses; smells, sounds and tastes are a fundamental part of her vision, and are rendered with great verve. Ms. Baylis could make the reader truly feel for this defiant, unquestionably talented person. But ultimately her Suzanne Valadon seems merely a vehicle for projecting an antimale polemic. This is a book where all men are dull, selfish or cruel, and where no man, save Degas, is capable of truly rendering the female figure. And even he, in his only appearance, is shown as a whining old man. While there are many good things in this book, one keeps thinking how much better it could have been had there been more show and less tell.

title: Compassion Served in 'Romantic'
description: NOW that virtually all theater awards extant (perhaps a few newly invented ones, too) have been bestowed upon ''The Heidi Chronicles'' by Wendy Wasserstein, isn't it instructive to renew acquaintance with ''Isn't It Romantic,'' the play that turned a promising playwright into a critically and commercially successful one in 1981.

title: On Cold Fusion, It Looks Like Utah Stands Alone
description: THE probable death of low-temperature or ''cold'' nuclear fusion as a source of useful energy came last week as a panel of experts joined private skeptics by saying the startling finding was too good to be true.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: For This Week: Weed, weed, weed or these unwanted plants will usurp valuable soil nutrients and moisture. Remove the faded flowers from petunias, geraniums, snapdragons and other border annuals to prolong their bloom season through the summer months and prevent them from forming seed pods. Cut off stalks of flowers that bloomed either to ground level or to strong green stems, depending on the plants. Remember that Oriental poppies disappear after they have bloomed and formed a collar of foliage; do not disturb the roots. Replant If soggy growing weather, insect pests or improper planting have caused gaps in the flower borders, by all means fill them in. Garden shops still have many plants for this purpose and although the selections may be somewhat limited, at least the plants are available. Sometimes garden shops are as eager to get rid of their summer stock as your are to fill in gaps. Bargains can often be found.

title: FOR SALE: THE ADIRONDACKS
description: Mr. Kunstler states, in his article about the damage being done to the Adirondacks, that I sold 96,000 acres in September 1988 to a Mr. Lassiter. He goes on to say that I did so because I had no interest in tree farming and wanted to clear my ''junk bond debt.''

title: Deborah Coyner Planning to Wed
description: Deborah Ann Coyner and Gary Talkofksy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irvin Talkofsky of Brooklyn, plan to marry in September, the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Erwin Coyner of Rockville Centre, L.I., have announced.

title: Angolan Talks to Resume
description: Rebels for the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola arrived here today to resume stalled peace talks with Angola's Marxist Government on Sunday. The Government suspended the talks two weeks ago after accusing Unita of breaking a cease-fire agreed June 22 at a summit meeting of African leaders in Zaire.

title: King Rallies to Win Women's Open
description: Betsy King, the leading winner in women's golf in the United States over the last six years, today made her 19th triumph in that time the biggest one of all: She recovered from near-collapse in the third round Saturday to win the 44th United States Women's Open championship easily, by four shots over Nancy Lopez.

title: Town Welcomes, Then Questions a Drug Project
description: When a California group received Oklahoma's permission to open a 75-bed drug and alcohol treatment center on an Indian reservation, people in nearby Newkirk thought the project would ease local economic troubles brought on by slumps in the oil and farming businesses.

title: Supply of Long-Term Issues Due
description: The attention of the credit markets, for weeks tightly focused on a steadily slowing economy and the Federal Reserve Board, may shift slightly over the near term, analysts said.

title: Motorola Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
EXECUTIVES
description: * American Stock Exchange named L. William Alter Jr. to its board of governors.

title: Spy Trial Opens Today With Facts Like Fiction
description: An affable Turkish mechanic suspected by American officials of running a network of spies at one of this country's most valued eavesdropping posts in Europe goes on trial here Monday.

title: Commerce Bancshares Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Stoneridge Resources Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Now We Must Reason Together About Abortion
description: To the Editor:

title: Time Case: Two Views On Wall St.
description: Wall Street lawyers, investment bankers and traders split widely on the significance of a Delaware court's refusal to block Time Inc.'s proposed $14 billion purchase of Warner Communications Inc.

title: Qualifier Captures Seniors' Tournament
description: John Paul Cain's days as a qualifier on the PGA Senior Tour are over.

title: Excerpts From the News Conference Given by Bush in Paris
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conference in Paris yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times: OPENING STATEMENT

title: In 1986, It Was London; Now, It's Spain's Turn
description: With European financial deregulation coming in three years, Spain is on the brink of an ambitious overhaul of its ''Napoleonic'' equities market, a reference to the system on which it was modeled and a description of its quaintness.

title: Chairmen of Banks Discuss Mexican Debt
description: The chairmen of the banks that are negotiating with Mexico on a debt reduction and restructuring package met in New York yesterday to try to agree on the final elements of a plan, bankers said.

title: O'Toole's Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Cynthia Berman, a Medical Student, Marries Kent A. Yalowitz, a Lawyer
description: Cynthia Ruth Berman, a fourth-year medical student at New York University, and Kent Alden Yalowitz, an associate at the Manhattan law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore, were married yesterday in Summit, N.J. Cantor Theodore Aronson officiated at the Summit Hotel. Mrs. Yalowitz, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Richard L. Berman of South Orange, N.J., and her husband, the son of Dr. Philip A. Yalowitz of Beverly Hills, Calif., and Rochelle Kauffman Yalowitz of Philadelphia, are cum laude graduates of Yale University. The bride's father is a gynecologist in Livingston, N.J.; her mother, Elaine Berman, is the education program manager of The New Yorker magazine.

title: An Actress Describes Her Life As a Man and as Other Actresses
description: Talent may not be synonymous with fame, but it does have a way of getting recognition. Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio, for example, still lacks the marquee impact of actors like Michelle Pfeiffer, Gregory Hines, Jeff Goldblum or Stephen Collins. But Ms. Mastrantonio, who takes the stage with those eminently bankable stars every night in the New York Shakespeare Festival production of ''Twelfth Night,'' was singled out for unanimous critical acclaim for her portrayal of Viola, one of Shakespeare's feistier heroines.

title: Braves Top Mets on a Dreary Afternoon
description: The rain would fall and then stop, and so the game would begin and then halt. Players, like the clouds and the sun, came and went.

title: Tax Watch; Arbitrage Profit On Exempt Bonds
description: ISSUERS of tax-exempt bonds and industry trade groups have been lobbying hard for a revision of arbitrage rebate regulations that they say are unnecessarily burdensome and complex and will cost state and local governments far more for compliance than the Federal Government will receive in rebates.

title: Celanese Canada Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Topics of The Times; Another Color Barrier Broken
description: The purchase of the Denver Nuggets basketball franchise by two black businessmen could be as symbolically important as Jackie Robinson breaking baseball's color barrier in 1947. Bertram Lee and Peter Bynoe have come along with their $65 million deal and suddenly blacks are no longer just the help but the owners; no longer just ticket buyers but producers of the show.

title: Account to Foote, Cone
description: G-R-I Corp., a direct marketer of cosmetics and household products, awarded its $10 million advertising and direct marketing account on Friday to a hometown agency, Foote, Cone & Belding/Direct of Chicago. Foote, Cone prevailed over three agencies, including the incumbent, Rapp Collins Marcoa. The other agencies were Wunderman Worldwide and McCaffrey & McCall.

title: Staying Cool in the Heat of Competition
description: ULTRAMARATHONERS are not the only people who overextend themselves during exercise in hot weather. Many weekend athletes are vulnerable as well, especially those who subscribe to the popular misconception that there is no need to reduce activity levels when it's hot.

title: Old Kent Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the acquisition of Unibancorp Inc. in October 1988 on a pooling- of-interests basis.

title: Terrible Mystery of Katyn: Edging Toward the Truth
description: There is a question that lingers heavy in the air here, in a forest thick with tall birch and pine trees. Who killed some 4,500 Polish officers whose bodies were discovered here in the spring of 1943?

title: Portable Tennis Teacher
description: King Thaxton of Palm Beach, Fla., a tennis professional for 27 years, has designed a target teaching aid called Offkort Tennis. The unit is portable, and weighs 35 pounds. The 6- by 4-foot frame is made of plastic pipe covered with a green polyethylene plastic material. In the center of a vertical hitting surface is a hole, a bull's-eye designed to receive the perfect shot. A ball that bounds off the backdrop within two feet of the hole, and above a white line hits an imaginary window, which is like the preferred sweet spot on a racquet. Hitting the ball in the area around the bull's-eye, the imaginary window, is a near-perfect shot.

title: Former Gov. John Dempsey, 74; Led Connecticut During the 60's
description: Former Gov. John N. Dempsey, a liberal Democrat who helped foster Connecticut's reputation in the 1960's as a national trend-setter in social and environmental laws, died of lung cancer today at his home in Killingly, Conn. He was 74 years old.

title: Altera Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Holyfield Advances Bid to Face Tyson
description: There were clues, even before he entered the Caesars Tahoe ring Saturday night, that Adilson Rodrigues might not be the hottest import from Brazil since the coffee bean.

title: Chaparral Steel reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included a gain of $3,895,000 from an accounting change.

title: WCRS Denies Rumor
description: The WCRS Group moved to quell speculation that it would sell its advertising agency network to Eurocom, as has been widely rumored in the ad industry here and in Britain. In a statement released in London and New York on Friday, Peter Scott, chief executive of the British marketing-communications company, said: ''Speculation that the WCRS Group intends to sell or hand over control of the advertising business is entirely misplaced. On the contrary, the emphasis is very much focused on ways to strengthen our competitive position.''

title: The Sir James Gang Gives London a Show
description: Sir James Goldsmith's hostile $21 billion bid for B.A.T. Industries has bestirred London's financial community because it is the first time the City has witnessed either a huge leveraged buyout offer or the large-scale use of ''junk bonds.'' Only the $25 billion acquisition of RJR Nabisco Inc. by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company has surpassed the Goldsmith bid.

title: Cadaret Shines As Rain Pours
description: The trade took place nearly a month ago, but until yesterday, in a pouring rain at the Stadium, the only part that had not quite fit was Greg Cadaret.

title: Fab Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 3
description: Latest quarter comprised 13 weeks, and second quarter, 26 weeks.

title: Summary of Actions Taken in the 212th Session of the New York Legislature
description: After a rousing all-night finale, the 212th session of the New York State Legislature ended at 12:06 P.M. on July 1, closing on schedule for the first time in three years.

title: Ethnic Violence in Soviet Georgia Leaves 11 Dead, 127 in Hospitals
description: Another spasm of ethnic violence, this time in a region of Soviet Georgia called Abkhazia, has left 11 people dead and 127 hospitalized this weekend, the official Tass news agency reported tonight.

title: Outdoors: Luring Trout on Waters Warm or Still
description: IN his delightful ''New Streamside Guide'' (Nick Lyons Books, 1969), the late Art Flick observed that successful fly fishing for trout from now through early autumn on most Northeastern streams calls for small flies, size 20 to 24, an observation that has lost none of its validity.

title: Cards and Trump Create A Different Kind of Suit
description: The tension is mounting in an epic battle between two titans of American commerce: Donald Trump of New York and Edward A. Zito of the Atlanta suburb of Lithia Springs.

description: It is, perhaps, a basic instinct in the Congressional psyche: fear of voting.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-9

title: Unseeded Pugh Tops Lundgren in Final
description: Unseeded Jim Pugh, one of the world's best doubles players, won the first singles final of his professional career today at the $160,000 Hall of Fame Championships, beating sixth-seeded Peter Lundgren of Sweden, 6-4, 4-6, 6-2.

title: V.A. Cuts Loan Rate
description: The Veterans Administration has lowered its key 30-year fixed mortgage rate to 9.5 percent, from 10 percent, effective Monday, signaling a probable round of rate cuts for the nation's home buyers.

title: Dr. Anne S. Ruston Marries
description: Dr. Anne Sherri Ruston, a fellow in nephrology at Cornell University Medical College, and David N. Pearl, a vice president at Bankers Trust Company in New York, were married yesterday by Rabbi Joseph I. Singer at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. The bride, who will keep her name professionally, is completing her training at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. She is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Ruston of Brooklyn. Mr. Pearl is the son of Bernard Pearl and the late Florence Pearl, both of New York.

title: The Logic of Mobile Missiles
description: LEAD: In the world of nuclear defense strategy, the cliche is that decisions about acquisitions and arms control should be undertaken in tandem. Cliches, however, do not necessarily reflect reality.

title: Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of new issues this week is confined to today's regular auction of new three- and six-month bills. Late Friday the three-month discount rate stood at 7.83 percent, while the six-month bill rate was 7.62 percent.

title: Race for Ads In Outer Space
description: A small company in Los Angeles said it had won a piece of the advertising business in outer space.

title: Santa Fe Journal; Parents of Slain Texan Keep Up War on Drugs
description: Jim and Helen Kilroy have emblazoned the name of their murdered son across the windows of a storefront wedged between a pizza parlor and a printing shop in a suburban shopping center. Inside, at old metal desks, they stuff envelopes and make phone calls all day long. They are turning their grief into a crusade.

title: Draining the Spectrum
description: It hasn't quite received the attention of the Johnstown Flood, which took place in the same state exactly 100 years earlier, perhaps because the Spectrum Flood, which took place just two weeks ago, did not cause any loss of life or ruin many homes.

title: Tax Increase Plan Set, House Panel Faces Test
description: With their approval of a $5.3 billion tax increase, members of the House Ways and Means Committee last week satisfied their obligation to raise the revenues to meet 1990 budget targets. That was the easy job. But tax bills, especially those fashioned in a budget compromise, enjoy a special priority and parliamentary protection on the House floor. That makes them magnets for pet initiatives and policy changes that might otherwise languish, and this year's bill is no exception.

title: Trace Products reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $212,000 from a tax credit.

title: Siberia Mine Strike Affects 100,000 and Is Spreading
description: The western Siberian coal mines were at a virtual standstill today with about 100,000 strikers demanding further economic and political concessions in the worst wave of labor unrest yet to confront President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

Willenson and the late Milton W. Willenson of New York. The Rev. Noel Vore and Rabbi Richard Scachet officiated.

description: For fans who think it just isn't a football game without a beer, the decree from New Jersey officials is disquieting: no more alcohol at night games in Giants Stadium, and a three-hour limit on parking-lot parties.

Quotation of the Day
description: ''The pain is almost incomprehensible. The mother is infected, the father is infected, the baby is sick, the parents and baby are going to die, and they will leave a 10-year-old boy who is going to be without any family. The room doesn't seem to be big enough for all the emotions.'' - Richard Gelb, a social worker in Manhattan; the infection is AIDS. [ B5:1. ]

title: Ellen Schneider Marries
description: Ellen Gail Schneider, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Schneider of Plainview, L.I., and Tamarac, Fla., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Mark Bloom, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert A. Bloom of Dix Hills, L.I., at the Dix Hills Jewish Center by Rabbi Amos Miller. The bride and bridegroom are graduates of Tufts University. The bride is to begin studies for a master's degree in early childhood education at Boston College in September. The bridegroom is a candidate for a master's degree in accounting at Northeastern University.

title: Pan Am Shuttle's President Confident on Beating Trump
description: Harris K. Herman, who last week added the title of president to that of chief operating officer of Pan Am Shuttle Inc., says he is not afraid of going head to head with Donald J. Trump and the Trump Shuttle.

title: Washington Talk; Stealth Bomber Suffers From Secrecy, High Cost And an Unclear Purpose
description: The B-2 Stealth bomber, in the works for a decade, is about to take its first flight. But can the plane ever become a mainstay of the Air Force?

title: Thomason Has Trouble Buying an Illinois Paper
description: A dissident member of the family that owns The Register-Mail in Galesburg, Ill., has frustrated the efforts of the Thomson Newspapers Corporation to acquire the small daily in what has become a testy legal battle.

title: The Sexual Politics of Air-Conditioning

title: Review/Opera; A 'Zauberflote' Is Balanced By the Earthy and Ethereal
description: The New York City Opera's two-year-old production of ''Die Zauberflote,'' which returned to the New York State Theater on Saturday evening, is exceptional among the company's recent endeavors. Its director, Lotfi Mansouri, resisted the temptation toward kitschy excess that afflicts so many of the company's offerings and instead has allowed Mozart's music and Emanuel Schikaneder's libretto (performed in German, with supertitles) to work their charms with directness and elegance.

title: Fudging the Facts on Puerto Rico
description: What's the right status for Puerto Rico, statehood, commonwealth or independence? The answer to the perennial question isn't obvious. Yet the Bush Administration now endorses statehood while carelessly declaring that the debate should be ''unencumbered'' by tax and economic implications. That policy fuses ignorance and danger.

title: U.S. Ends Aid to Contra Office
description: The Bush Administration said today that it was ending payments to the Nicaraguan guerrillas for the operation of their office in Miami.

Arnold of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., and Grand Cayman Island in the Caribbean. Rabbi Rim Meirowitz performed the ceremony at 17 Quincy Street, on the Harvard University campus in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Failing Hospitals Get Second Chance
description: These are bittersweet days for the Daughters of Mary of the Immaculate Conception, the Catholic religious order that has operated Sancta Maria Hospital here for 41 years.

title: Bosch, Old Foe of U.S., Makes Comeback in Santo Domingo
description: Twenty-six years ago, Juan Bosch worried a lot of powerful people here and in Washington. To them, his talk of land reform and turning over businesses to workers sounded very much like Communism. He lasted seven months as President. Two years later, in 1965, when supporters tried to return him to power, President Lyndon B. Johnson sent in 23,000 American troops to prevent the Dominican Republic from becoming ''a second Cuba.''

title: Cause of Ginnie Mae Losses Said to Be Lax Supervision
description: Inadequate supervision appears to be a leading cause of the rapidly growing losses at the Government National Mortgage Association, according to officials of the Department of Housing and Urban Development and reports by department auditors.

title: Lisa Ann Cohn Becomes the Bride Of Bruce Cohen, a Bank Executive
description: Lisa Ann Cohn, a daughter of Judy Cohn Poser and Richard Cohn, both of New York, was married yesterday at the Pierre in New York to Bruce Cohen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Cohen of Highland Park, Ill. Rabbi William H. Lebeau performed the ceremony.

title: Expos Beat Reds in 12 Innings
description: Nelson Santovenia broke an 0-for-8 slump with a run-scoring single in the top of the 12th inning today to lead the Expos to a 6-3 victory over the Reds.

title: First American Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago figures were restated for the acquisition of Northern of Tennessee.

title: Local News Is Challenging Prime-Time Shows
description: In the battle for television ratings, entertainment shows are facing a growing rival: local news.

title: Ex-Head of Tropicana At Church & Dwight
description: The Church & Dwight Company, the maker of Arm & Hammer brand products, has named Spencer J. Volk, former head of Tropicana Products Inc., to be president and chief operating officer.

title: Review/Television; 3 Black Musicians and Their Roots
description: Public television's ''American Masters,'' now in its fourth season, seems to be ghettoizing its schedule in clusters of thematically related documentaries. The past three weeks have been devoted to documentaries on the Group Theater, the critic and director Harold Clurman and the actress and teacher Stella Adler. The overall scene was almost exclusively white and markedly Jewish. Now, beginning this evening at 9 and continuing for the next two Mondays, the series is offering profiles of three giants in American music, each of them coming out of this country's often troubled and troubling black experience.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: CYCLING LeMond Regains Lead: Greg LeMond of the United States recaptured the leader's yellow jersey in the Tour de France yesterday with a strong performance in an individual time trial in the Alps. LeMond finished fifth in the day's stage, 57 seconds behind Steven Rooks of the Netherlands, who climbed the 24 miles from Gap to Orcieres-Merlette in 1 hour 10 minutes 42 seconds.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Ordinarily, Not the Place to Skip Dinner
description: It was to have been the grande bouffe - the biggest blowout of all in a liver-straining week of French feasting - but the gala dinner tonight at Elysee Palace never took place.

title: Delaware Court Seen as Unlikely to Reverse Time Ruling
description: Lawyers and Wall Street experts said over the weekend that they believed it was relatively unlikely that the Delaware Supreme Court would overturn the decision of the Delaware Chancery Court letting Time Inc. buy Warner Communications Inc.

title: Topics of The Times; A Murderous Child
description: ''I know if she could turn the clock back to that day, knowing what she knows now, she certainly wouldn't do it again.'' So said the lawyer for Paula Cooper, an Indiana teen-ager who was sentenced to death for murdering an elderly Bible teacher in 1985, after the Indiana Supreme Court changed her sentence to 60 years in prison.

title: Pioneer Hi-Bred International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31

title: Peoples Heritage Financial Group reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Latest quarter results included a gain of $515,000 from the sale of condominium units.

title: Question Box
description: Ryan in Double Digits Q. In his last start before the All-Star Game break, Nolan Ryan of the Texas Rangers struck out 12 California Angel batters. It was the 189th time in his career Ryan reached double figures in strikeouts in a game, a major league record. Who is next on that list, and how far back is he? A. No one but Sandy Koufax has done it even half as many times as Ryan, who surpassed Koufax as the major league leader 12 years ago, when Ryan struck out 10 or more batters in a game 20 times during the 1977 season with the California Angels. In his 12 years in the major leagues with the Brooklyn and Los Angeles Dodgers (1955-66), Koufax struck out at least 10 batters in a game 97 times, which is 92 behind Ryan's total and widening. Ryan has also surpassed Koufax in most games with at least 10 strikeouts during a season, 23 to 21, having achieved that distinction in 1973, in 39 starts with the Angels.

title: At Reception for Visiting Gandhi, Bhutto Urges Nuclear Arms Ban
description: Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto said today that her country was prepared to join ''any arrangement'' that would prevent the spread of nuclear weapons in South Asia.

title: Review/Music; Re-creating a Night When History Was Made
description: Musical and social history were made on May 2, 1912, when James Reese Europe led the Clef Club Orchestra in a Carnegie Hall concert of marches, waltzes, liturgical music, popular songs and vaudeville tunes. On Friday evening at Carnegie Hall, a re-creation of that concert, reconstructed and directed by Maurice Peress, didn't duplicate one significant aspect of the original performance: that for the first time at the hall, all the musicians - like all but one composer - were black.

title: Most Union Miners to Return To Coal Fields in Appalachia
description: Most union miners in Appalachia decided to return to work with their Midwestern and Southern colleagues today, but many stayed out of the West Virginia coal fields where wildcat strikes began last month.

description: Swann By Carol Shields 313 pages. Viking. $17.95.
