title: Pros' Golf Game Is Not for Amateurs
description: THE argument occurred, as they often do, in a bar. Roger Maltbie, the pro golfer, was impatiently trying to explain to a sober amateur of modest skill that square grooves were ruining the game. Maltbie contended that square-grooved clubs put so much spin on the ball that playing out of the rough was no longer a penalty. The amateur said that was silly; while there may be a difference between square and conventional grooves, you couldn't take predictable advantage of it.

title: Plane With Expedition Team Takes Off for Antarctic Trek
description: A Soviet cargo plane carrying an international team that plans to cross Antarctica by dog sled and ski took off from Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport tonight.

title: Biogen reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Let Louis XVI Rest in Peace; A Funeral Mass in Manhattan
description: They came not to praise the French Revolution but to bury it. In the place of tricolor bunting, there were the black vestments of an old-fashioned Roman Catholic funeral Mass. Instead of fireworks, there were the flickering candles of a Manhattan church. Instead of the ''Marseillaise,'' there was the rise and fall of Gregorian chant.

title: Interchange Financial reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Old New Taxes
description: The House Ways and Means Committee has demonstrated once again there are ways and means to raise revenue without raising taxes. Seeking $5.3 billion of new revenue, but circumscribed by President Bush's promise of ''no new taxes,'' the committee has focused on old taxes. It has closed loopholes, extended expiring taxes and tinkered a lot. The resulting bill improves the tax law.

title: Tracy Baronfeld Is Married
description: Tracy Susan Baronfeld, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Irving R. Baronfeld of Flushing, Queens, and Lakehurst, N.J., was married last evening in New York to Ari L. Hoffman, a son of Mrs. Bernard Hoffman of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Hoffman. Rabbi Mordecai Efron officiated at the Skylight Ballroom of the Puck Building. The bride, a graduate of the State University of New York at Purchase, is an assistant buyer with the Canadian Fur Traders Corporation in New York. Mr. Hoffman, a graduate of Baruch College, is a vice president and the director of marketing and sales at Yves Saint Laurent Rive Gauche in New York.

title: W.R. Grace & Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $512,000 and $1,422,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Included a gain of $6,137,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter; the 6 months included a gain of $16,726,000 from discontinued operations and a gain of $4,854,000 from an accounting change.

An Odd Deal: Main Client Buys Tarlow
description: AFTER 18 months of explosive growth - during which the agency rose from nothing to $90 million in billings and was designated as Adweek's 1989 ''Agency of the Year'' for the Eastern United States - Tarlow Advertising was acquired on Friday by its largest client, the Revlon Group.

title: Rose Papers to Be Filed
description: Pete Rose's lawyers head back to court Monday to file papers with a Federal judge who is deciding which court system will determine the fate of the Cincinnati Reds' manager.

title: Straight Talk From Arnold Palmer on Royal Troon
description: THE Royal Troon Golf Club motto is: Tam arte quam marte. That Latin phrase could be used for most golf courses because it means: As much by skill as by strength.

title: Prudential Near Accord On Thomson
description: The Prudential Securities Group, parent of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., was working toward an agreement yesterday to purchase the retail offices and customer accounts of Thomson McKinnon Inc., officials of the two companies said.

title: Safely Kept Wins In Prioress Stakes
description: Safely Kept was so much better than her four opponents in the $82,950 Prioress Stakes yesterday at Belmont Park that she turned in one of her weaker efforts and still scored an easy 3 3/4-length victory.

title: Brownstone Explosion Is Linked to Gas Leak
description: As work crews shored up the extensively damaged building, fire officials said yesterday that they were ''reasonably certain'' that a gas leak had caused a powerful explosion that ripped through an upper Manhattan brownstone Saturday, killing one man and injuring seven other people.

title: New Shots in New England's Border War
description: The on-again, off-again border war between Massachusetts and New Hampshire is on again.

title: Dover Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Second quarter and six-month 1988 sales were adjusted to reflect the consolidation in the 1988 fourth quarter of two finance subsidiaries. This increased sales by $673,000 and $1,346,000 for the 1988 quarter and six months, respectively. The company repurchased 1.1 million of its common shares in 1988 and an additional 2.3 million shares in the first six months of this year, including 752,000 shares in the second quarter at an average price of $31 a share.

title: Sherwin-Williams Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Minister's Job Is Advocacy For Blacks
description: There was a nasty confrontation between a white merchant and a black customer in Brooklyn. After angry words were exchanged, a boycott was organized. But instead of violence, the parties negotiated and hammered out a settlement.

title: Afghan Minister Faults U.S. For Car Bomb That Killed 22
description: A top Afghan official today called the United States and Pakistan ''morally responsible'' for a truck bomb that killed as many as 20 people in Kabul on Saturday.

title: Liberty National Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Ollan Cassell: He's Private And Powerful
description: HE operates at the same level in his sport that Bart Giamatti and Pete Rozelle do in theirs, yet he disdains any public fanfare or recognition. In fact, if Ollan Cassell had his way, no one would know what he does or how he does it, running the sport of track and field in the United States.

title: A Change: Ideas Not Made in U.S.A.
description: In a novel but perhaps inevitable departure, few of the Group of Seven's prescriptions for running the world economy were made in the U.S.A. The country that had dominated the economic summit conferences since their start 14 years ago found itself accepting its neighbors' proposals as readily as it has accepted their exports.

title: Comex Officer, Citing Hardships, Quits Post
description: Responding to what he said were ''great demands'' on his personal time and finances, John H. Hanemann resigned Friday as the chairman of the Commodity Exchange Inc. of New York after 16 months in the post. The move came only days after Arnold F. Staloff was appointed president and chief executive of the exchange.

title: Hudson and Tigers End Losing Streaks
description: Charles Hudson was wondering when he would win again.

title: Correction
description: An article in some editions Sunday about an anti-crime package offered by David N. Dinkins, a Democratic candidate for mayor, misstated his proposal to double police patrols in New York City neighborhoods. Mr. Dinkins's plan would increase the number of officers in the 750-member Community Patrol Officers Program, not the 7,000 officers who patrol the city's streets.

title: Taiwan Votes Tariff Cuts
description: Taiwan's parliament has approved tariff cuts on more than 4,700 foreign products to help spur imports and reduce the huge trade surplus. A parliamentary statement on Friday said the cuts follow similar reductions on 378 foreign products in May. The cuts will go into effect in the next few days, the statement said. The new reductions, which average 23 percent, include tariffs on imported Christmas gift items, refrigerators, televisions, videotape recorders, industrial and agricultural material, toys, machinery and anti-pollution equipment.

title: Crazy Eddie Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 28
description: Crazy Eddie is operating under Chapter 11 protection.

title: Holtzman Joins New York Race For Comptroller
description: Pledging to make New York City more livable by fighting corruption and the theft of public funds, Elizabeth Holtzman, the Brooklyn District Attorney, formally announced yesterday her candidacy for city comptroller.

title: Key Sections of the Paris Communique by the Group of Seven
description: Following are key sections of the communique issued today by the Group of Seven major industrialized democracies:

title: Suspect Denies Any Link to Murders of 48
description: A law student identified by the police as a ''viable suspect'' has denied any connection to the killings of 48 women from 1982 to 1984.

description: Who's ahead in the mayoral race?

title: Review/Television; The President's European Tour
description: Insofar as President Bush's European odyssey was intended to compete with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in the television charisma market, it can't have gained many points. That might have surprised analysts. Pictures of an American President venturing past a rusted iron curtain to bring words of admiration and perhaps assistance to people struggling for democracy, then proceeding to a festive Paris to consort with the leaders of the free world must have seemed a natural to media managers. How could it go wrong?

title: Lee Dunst Wed To Ms. Diringer
description: Lisbeth Marcie Diringer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Owen I. Diringer of Freeport, L.I., was married last evening to Lee Gordon Dunst, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Laurence D. Dunst of New York and East Hampton, L.I. Cantor Robert Brown officiated at the East River Yacht Club in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Dana Olan Is Married
description: Dana Michelle Olan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Olan of Great Neck, L.I., and Darryl Erik Lieberman, a son of Ruth Lieberman of New York and Larchmont, N.Y., and the late Dr. Harvey Lieberman, were married yesterday at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I. Rabbi Myron Fenster and Cantor Avram Albrecht officiated. The bride, a nurse at the Schneider Children's Hospital at the Long Island Jewish Medical Center in New Hyde Park, L.I., is a graduate of the State University of New York at Binghamton, as is her husband, a third-year dental student at the University of Buffalo.

title: Malula Journal; A Place Where the Language of Jesus Is at Home
description: At the age of 40, Azar Maarouf Shayeb is writing his second textbook for engineering students, setting down fundamentals of advanced mathematics in the crisp uplands of this old mountain village below fissured crag and weathered hill.

title: Plasti-Line Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMIC SUMMIT The Group of Seven summit meeting ended with an appeal for ''decisive action'' to protect the environment, signaling a shift to a new area of concern. The leaders also endorsed a U.S. plan on third-world debt, expressed confidence in the general state of the world economy and agreed to set up a task force to fight the laundering of drug profits. [ Page A1. ] This time, few of the summit leaders' prescriptions for the world economy were made in the U.S.A. Unlike Ronald Reagan, who had notions of free markets and small government that the six other countries eventually bought, President Bush gave some ground when U.S. allies rejected his proposals. [ A6. ] COMPANIES Wall Street was divided on the impact of a Delaware court's refusal to block Time's takeover of Warner. Some said the ruling might make it easier for managers to thwart takeovers and focus on long-term issues. Others contend that the refusal to block Time's offer for Warner was unfair to shareholders. [ D1. ] Delaware's Supreme Court is considered unlikely to overturn the decision. [ D2. ] Prudential Securities was working toward an agreement to buy the retail offices and customer accounts of Thomson McKinnon for about $120 million. An agreement to acquire all of Thomson was terminated last week after an examination of its books. [ D1. ] THE ECONOMY Ginnie Mae's growing losses may have resulted from a lack of supervision, H.U.D. officials and auditors' reports say. The situation illustrates an emerging theme of H.U.D. in the Reagan Administration: that inadequate oversight, combined with more reliance on private parties to regulate their extensions of credit, has produced billions of dollars of Government losses. [ D1. ] The real battles over tax-law changes begin this week. Virtually all the changes that Ways and Means Committee members would like to make would cost the Government revenue. [ D2. ] INTERNATIONAL REPORT Sir James Goldsmith's bid for B.A.T. has stirred London. It is the first time its financial community has witnessed either a huge leveraged buyout offer or the large-scale use of ''junk bonds.'' [ D1. ] ''El Big Bang'' promises to radically change Spain's equities markets. The second stage of the reforms include a code of ethics and the end of a system of exclusive stockbroker rights. [ D8. ] Bank chairmen met in New York to discuss the final elements of a debt reduction and restructuring package for Mexico. [ D8. ] THE MEDIA BUSINESS A Denver bookstore is considered a symbol of the resurgence of independent bookstores. The Tattered Cover has often been called the best general bookstore in the United States. [ D1. ] Thomson's efforts to acquire a small Illinois newspaper have been frustrated by a dissident member of the family that owns it. The fight for control of The Register-Mail in Galesburg is being cast as a David vs. Goliath effort to maintain local ownership. [ D9. ] Local TV news has become a growing rival to entertainment shows in the battle for viewers. A Los Angeles station is planning to introduce the nation's first three-hour local newscast. [ D9. ] Fox is attracting the young viewers that advertisers want, and it expects a ''substanial profit'' in the next year. Television. [ D9. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS New arbitrage rebate regulations are too burdensome, bond issuers and trade groups say, and will cost state and local governments far more for compliance than the Federal Government will receive in rebates. Tax Watch. [ D2. ] Credit market participants face the prospect of a huge supply of long-term bonds that could push up yields. Credit Markets. [ D5. ] The bond rally may go on, some strategists say, although a key resistance level was reached last week. Market Place. [ D4. ]

title: Volunteers Sail for a Dolphin Census
description: As 28 boats crisscrossed the Atlantic Ocean near here, a crackle of static from a Coast Guard radio heralded another small scientific triumph: ''We've spotted a good-sized pod of dolphins.''

title: 25 Films to Become U.S. Treasures
description: American movies have been called many things. Now, 25 of them will officially be called treasures. The public will be warned when any of those classic films are significantly altered.

title: NBC Sports Head to Oversee 'Today' Too
description: In a move that he acknowledged was unusual and unexpected, Michael Gartner, the president of NBC News, announced the appointment here Saturday of Dick Ebersol, the president of NBC Sports, as senior vice president of NBC News in charge of the ''Today'' program.

title: Saving the Shoreline
description: Spending a week swimming at the Jersey Shore is a welcome respite during the sizzling summer months. Skip Storch of Monsey, N.Y., will be doing just that beginning this morning, but it will be about as relaxing as running seven marathons.

title: Dante to Cobb to Rehnquist
description: ONE day some scholar, maybe even one from Yale with a white beard and a graceful command of the language, will recall this period in baseball as a coda to ''The Divine Comedy.'' A period in which a red-capped national hero is dragged, justifiably or no, through an earthly version of Hell and Purgatory - that is, through local courts, state courts and Federal courts. Whether he will end up in Heaven, with Dante, or the Hall of Fame, with Ty Cobb, or in the Supreme Court of the United States, with Chief Justice William Rehnquist, only time will tell.

title: Now We Must Reason Together About Abortion; No Lives Saved
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Bring Shamir and Arafat to Negotiate
description: To the Editor:

title: Pilot Says He Had No Motive to Kill Himself
description: The pilot whose small plane crashed at sea after a mysterious 1,000-mile journey down the East Coast said today that he had no motive for arranging his death in a fake accident, since his insurance policy would have paid benefits to his family even if he had committed suicide, a newspaper report said.

title: KLLM Transport Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEW YORK TRACK AND FIELD GAMES
description: For the world's best track and field athletes, the summer is divided into three-week segments. The first segment (June and July) and the last (August) are devoted to Mobil Grand Prix meets in Europe. The three weeks in between are more or less dead time when the athletes compete in lesser meets or return to training.

title: Rochester Telephone Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Review/Dance; Program of Recent Works To Contemporary Scores
description: Three choreographers presented dance set to a wide variety of contemporary music scores on Friday night in the fourth-floor theater of the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University. And each of the program's pieces was clearly the work of individuals with a sure sense of how to put movement together. But their tidiness was not enough to make for a stimulating evening of theater.

title: Democrats Trail in Fund Raising, And Many Blame New Chairman
description: The Democratic National Committee may face deep financial trouble because many leading fund-raisers, critical of the new party chairman and angry about their treatment in last year's Presidential campaign, are refusing to raise money.

title: Herbert von Karajan Is Dead; Musical Perfectionist Was 81
description: Herbert von Karajan, probably the world's best-known conductor and one of the most powerful figures in classical music, died yesterday at his home in Anif, in the Austrian Alps. An aide reported that he suffered a heart attack in the early afternoon, and died before a rescue helicopter could fly him to a hospital. He was 81 years old.

title: Case Backlog Is Swamping Rights Agency
description: A backlog of more than 10,000 cases is plaguing the New York State agency that mediates complaints of discrimination in employment and housing, forcing some people to wait as long as seven years for a resolution of their complaints.

title: Jane L. Mencher Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Jane Lizabeth Mencher, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart A. Mencher of Bethesda, Md., to Andrew Robert Gold, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Steven Gold of Princeton, N.J., took place yesterday at Temple Emanu-El in Westfield, N.J. Rabbi Charles Kroloff officiated.

title: Doctor Slow
description: The last few days have given Americans the chance to see both ends of the James Bond canon and the instant impression is that the thrillers, and the world, are much more violent.

title: Interspec reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company said profit margins for the latest periods were lower because sales for its XL Series were off in anticipation of its next generation of ultrasound equipment.

title: Now We Must Reason Together About Abortion; Unborn Dependents
description: To the Editor:

title: China Said to Continue Arrests Quietly
description: The Chinese central authorities have announced few arrests and virtually no executions in the last three weeks, but there are signs that hundreds or thousands of people continue to be interrogated, arrested and sentenced in the crackdown against the democracy movement.

title: New Phase on the Moon: U.S. Weighs a Return
description: The Moon beckons again, at least to a growing band of lunar enthusiasts.

title: Critics Ask If Any Charter Can Make New York Efficient
description: Developers say it takes too long for New York City officials to approve projects. Companies that do business with the city, along with nonprofit agencies that provide a host of social services, complain that the city takes too long to pay its bills. Ordinary citizens bemoan the obstacles they face when dealing with municipal agencies.

title: Lani Klinghoffer Marries Stanley Lefcort, Salesman
description: Elaine Klinghoffer, a daughter of Gertrude Weiss of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., and the late Samuel M. Weiss, and Stanley Lefcort, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Lefcort of North Miami Beach, Fla., were married yesterday at the Union Square Cafe in New York by Rabbi Joseph Potasnik.

title: Copy of Ship Links Dutch To America
description: A new Half Moon floats in the Hudson River here, under construction as part of a celebration of the Dutch heritage of New York.

title: Kevlin Microwave reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Victory for Rahal In Shortened Race
description: Two weeks ago, after winning his third consecutive Indy-car race, Emerson Fittipaldi said his team was working like a Swiss watch. At the Marlboro Grand Prix here today, Bobby Rahal showed that the watch wasn't waterproof.

title: Did We Spawn an Arts Monster?
description: When I was appointed to the advisory council of the National Endowment for the Arts, I understood that the council received its charter from the Federal government. It functions as an autonomous body devoted to the pursuit and support of quality in the art and culture of America - past, present, future.

title: South African Labor Federation, Defying Pretoria, Calls for Protests
description: The Congress of South African Trade Unions, winding up its convention, called on its members and supporters today to join a campaign of ''sustained action'' against apartheid in the week leading up to the country's parliamentary elections on Sept. 6.

title: Simon & Schuster to Publish Nixon's Autobiography
description: Simon & Schuster is to publish former President Richard M. Nixon's autobiography next spring. The publisher said Mr. Nixon would for the first time describe in detail his life in retirement and his experiences in resigning the Presidency as a result of the Watergate scandal.

title: A Surprise Translation
description: Not many first-time authors receive letters of praise from such literary giants as James Michener. But Dan Doyle did. And what makes that particularly noteworthy is that Doyle is a former college basketball coach with no experience as a writer.

title: Young Viewers Help Fox Turn the Corner on Profits
description: THE Fox Broadcasting Company is the only over-the-air television network not wringing its hands about a declining share of the audience. Fox does not complain about the switch to the people-meter rating system or even the increased penetration of cable television.

title: AIDS Legacy: a Growing Generation of Orphans
description: AIDS has begun to produce a generation of orphans: thousands of children who are not infected but are losing their mothers and fathers to illness, disability and death from the growing epidemic.

title: Bridge
description: Some situations in the game are so rare that one could play for a hundred lifetimes without encountering them. One in this category is shown in the diagram: South bids and makes a game in a suit in which an opponent has made a genuine overcall.

title: Panel Criticizes F.B.I. for Scrutiny of U.S. Group
description: The Senate Intelligence Committee has criticized the Federal Bureau of Investigation for its 27-month inquiry into a domestic group opposing Government policy in Central America, but it called the episode an ''aberration'' in a generally sound F.B.I. performance.

title: Of Nixon, Kennedy and Shooting the Moon
description: What a weekend it was in the White House, 20 years ago, when man first landed on the moon and Ted Kennedy drove off the bridge.

title: Louise Ghertler Wed To Henry Crawford Jr.
description: Louise Xantippe Ghertler, a daughter of Edna Ghertler of New York and Monte Ghertler of Brooklyn, was married yesterday in New York to Henry Hugh Crawford Jr., the son of Amy Louise Crawford of Tracy, Calif., and the late Mr. Crawford. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel performed the ceremony at the Lotos Club.

title: Bookstore Thrives on Independence
description: This city by the Rocky Mountains is better known for skiing than scholarship. It has far fewer people than New York or Los Angeles, lacks the vibrant academic community of the San Francisco Bay area or Boston, and ranked 17th in per-capita bookstore sales.

title: Building Reactors the New Way
description: In the waning days of the construction of nuclear power plants in the United States, supporters of nuclear energy say that if a new generation of plants is ever ordered, the Limerick 2 plant here could be a model for pricing and planning.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Below are the major economic indicators to be released this week. Monday Inventory-Sales May Tuesday Balance of Trade May Wednesday Consumer Price Index June Housing Starts June Thursday None Friday None

title: Hannelore Keuper, a Schoolteacher, Marries Michael Kaplan, a Lawyer
description: At the University Club in New York, Hannelore Keuper, a daughter of Mrs. Hubbard Knox 3d of Chatham, N.J., and Philip J. Keuper of New York, was married yesterday to Michael Jonathan Kaplan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton B. Kaplan of New York and Wainscott, L.I. Rabbi Lester Bronstein officiated.

title: Labor May Preserve Israeli Coalition
description: The Labor Party, reading the political winds indicating that most people in Israel do not want the present Government to fall, is searching for ways to back away from its threat to leave its coalition with Likud.

title: A.T.&T. Sets Olivetti Swap
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said Saturday that it would exchange its 22 percent of Ing C. Olivetti & Company, the Italian computer maker, for a stake in Carlo de Benedetti's main industrial holding company.

title: Rumanian Critic of Ceausescu Regime Is Silent
description: To the Editor:

title: Walbro Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting change of $336,000.

title: Hibernia Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share net reflected 5-for-4 stock split paid May 25.

title: Heritage Financial Services reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. Is Reported to Send Arms To Revive Afghan Rebels' Drive
description: American officials said today that the United States was sending new mine-clearing equipment, missiles, mortars, artillery shells and other weapons to the Afghan guerrillas in the hope that they could regain momentum in fighting Afghan Government troops.

title: Adolph Coors Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 11
Doctors See Gap in Blacks' Health Having a Link to Low Self-Esteem
description: A widening health gap between blacks and whites is due in part to low self-esteem among blacks who react adversely to the stresses of racism, panelists at a national gathering of black doctors said today.

title: Morgan (J.P.) & Co (N) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The provision for credit losses in the latest periods totaled $35 million for the quarter and $45 million for the 6 months, compared with $30 million and $80 million for the year-ago quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Grove Bank for Savings reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
By Design; Dresses That Hug the Curves
description: Right now the hottest fashions are the ones seen after the sun sets. And the places to observe them are Manhattan's ''in'' restaurants.

title: American Banker to Buy Investdata From Mellon
description: The Mellon Bank Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Mellon Investdata subsidiary to Amerian Banker-Bond Buyer, a division of the Thomson Corporation.

title: August Soybean Contracts Seen as Possible Problem
description: Concern deepened here today that the Chicago Board of Trade, having averted a crisis in trading of its July soybean contracts, would soon face a crisis in its August soybean contracts.

title: Comerica Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Genentech Gets Japanese Grant
description: Genentech Inc. said it had received the first research grant awarded to a single foreign company by the Japanese Government. The grant is to study Werner's Syndrome, an inherited disorder causing premature aging in adults.

title: Cognitive Systems reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Vatican and Poland Restore Relations
description: The Vatican and Poland crowned years of negotiations and re-established full diplomatic relations today, the first such ties between the Vatican and a Warsaw Pact nation.

title: Independent Bank Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Office Club reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Give Foreign Service The Credit That's Due
description: To the Editor:

title: Retreating on Pledge, White House Hints at Tax Increase to Aid Elderly
description: The White House told Congress today that despite President Bush's pledge of no new taxes, the Administration could accept a tax increase to help reduce or even eliminate the surtax paid by elderly Americans for insurance against the cost of prolonged illness.

title: Swaps Freed From Agency's Control
description: In a policy reversal, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission unanimously agreed today to exclude financial transactions known as swaps from its control.

title: Review/Dance; Pageantry in 'Tales of Exile' Marks French Bicentennial
description: Lincoln Center's salute to the bicentennial of the French Revolution ended a day late when rain forced the postponement to Saturday afternoon of ''Tales of Exile.'' But the hourlong piece - choregraphed by Ruby Shang, directed by Gilberte Tsai and performed on a stage next to the fountain at Lincoln Center Plaza -seemed only marginally connected to the principles that led to the fall of the Bastille or to the struggle for democracy in China, an event alluded to by Patrick Talbot, director of cultural services of the French Embassy, in pre-performance comments.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Prudential Account Is Placed Under Review
description: LEAD: The Prudential Insurance Company of America has placed its $60 million advertising account under review, but a spokesman for the company maintained yesterday that Prudential still had a strong relationship with its agency, Backer Spielvogel Bates.

title: Elmer F. Bennett, 71, Ex-Interior Official
description: Elmer F. Bennett, a retired Washington lawyer who was a former Under Secretary of the Interior, died of congestive heart failure July 10 at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, L.I. He was 71 years old and lived in East Hills, L.I.

title: Great Western Debt for Asians
description: The Great Western Financial Corporation, the parent of the Great Western Bank, this week will become the first savings and loan association to try to sell debt in Japan, an official at Merrill Lynch Japan Inc. said today. Merrill Lynch Japan will act as underwriter for the issue. Great Western, based in Los

title: Intipuca Journal; Emigrants Feather Their Old Nest With Dollars
description: This is probably the country's richest town, a pastel oasis of plenty with more in common with an exclusive United States suburb than a destitute and devastated land.

title: Dow Drops 1.33, but Airline Stocks Climb
description: The stock market was mixed yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average slipping 1.33 points, to 2,553.49, its first decline after nine consecutive increases. But airline stocks climbed again, pushing the Dow Jones transportation average to a new high.

title: Charles Schwab Net Up
description: The Charles Schwab Corporation, the largest discount brokerage firm, today reported second-quarter net income of $4.2 million, or 15 cents a share, double the $2.1 million, or 8 cents a share it reported in the comparable period a year ago. Revenues rose 45 percent, to $139 million, from $95.7 million in the second quarter of 1988. Charles R. Schwab, chairman and chief executive, said in a statement that the firm had added more than 71,000 new accounts in the second quarter and that equity in customer accounts exceeded $22 billion on June 30, up more than 30 percent from last year.

title: Health Concepts IV reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Software Publishing reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Cypress Semiconductor Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
NCR Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Pushing to Keep Pledge To Japanese-Americans
description: About a year ago, deep in the stacks of the National Archives, Justice Department investigators began poring over dogeared internment rosters to compile a list of the 112,000 Japanese-Americans rounded up in West Coast cities during World War II.

title: Salick Health Care reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Oregon Lottery Unit Creates Weekly N.F.L. Betting Plan
description: The movement toward more legalized gambling in the United States took an unusual step yesterday when the Oregon Lottery Commission instituted weekly betting on National Football League games.

title: Why Two Sites in Jersey City Received Quick Cleanups of Chrome
description: While poisonous chromium leaches undisturbed toward the surface of neighborhoods across this city, the contaminated sites of two large developments have undergone quick exclusive cleanups.

title: Ladd Furniture Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Computers for the College-Bound
description: THRONGS of students will be heading off to college in a few months, and, judging from the mail that arrives here, many parents and grandparents are feeling generous enough to equip them with personal computers.

title: Evergreen Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
American Bank of Connecticut reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PNC Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Standby Update Moon Poem
description: The moment Apollo 11 went up, we knew the newspaper would need help four days later, when the astronauts landed on the moon, to tell the joy that was in us.

title: Trading Partners Should Put Pressure on China; The Taiwan Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alco Standard Corp., Wayne, Pa., announced the acquisition of several companies: Inter-City Paper Corp., Minneapolis, a paper distributor; Total Office Products, Omaha, and its Copier Consultants unit. Terms were not disclosed.

title: To Keep Green the Memory of Brian Boru
description: To the Editor:

title: Chicago Museum Expanding, Ready or Not
description: The Museum of Contemporary Art here is facing the toughest challenge of its 22-year career - that of getting bigger. The state's virtual gift of a prime two-acre site off the city's bustling Miracle Mile has sparked plans for a $50-million building-and-endowment drive that will allow the museum to double its size and make ambitious plans for the future.

title: Auto Output Expected to Fall
description: The Big Three auto makers will sharply reduce their production in the fourth quarter of 1989 to the lowest level in seven years, an automotive trade weekly reported today.

title: Note to Readers
description: The Op-Ed page welcomes unsolicited manuscripts. Because of the growing volume of submissions, however, we regret that we cannot acknowledge receipt of or return articles unless they are accompanied by a self-addressed, stamped envelope.

title: Wicat Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: b-Net loss

title: Marine Midland Banks Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $9,783,000 for the quarter and $18,253,000 for the 6 months. c-After extraordinary tax credits of $9,880,000 for the quarter and $17,876,000 for the 6 months. Marine Midland is a unit of the Hong Kong and Shanghai Banking Corp.

title: Willamette Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Amoskeag Bank Shares Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The latest second quarter included an addition to loan loss reserves of $2 million.

title: Mahlathini Raindate
description: Mahlathini and the Mahotella Queens, with the Makghona Tsohle Band, are to perform tonight at 6:30 at the Central Park Band Shell, 72d Street at mid-park, as part of the Summerstage series. The concert replaces the South African group's Sunday performance, which was rained out. Information: 860-1335.

title: Miami's Green Arrested
description: Hugh Green, a linebacker with the Miami Dolphins, missed the team's first day of training camp yesterday after he was arrested over the weekend on a charge of spouse battery. Green was accused of striking his wife on Saturday night during a party celebrating the football player's 30th birthday, which will be on July 27.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
2 Companies Face Boycott
description: LEAD: The Christian Leaders for Responsible Televisio, a religious group, yesterday announced a boycott of two consumer-products companies that advertised on programs the group considers offensive.

title: Gordon C. Kinney, 70, Ad Council Executive
description: Gordon Crawford Kinney, a retired senior vice president of the Advertising Council Inc., died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in White Plains. He was 70 years old.

title: Santa Fe Pacific Pipeline Parters L.P.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago results are pro-forma and are derived from combined historial statement of income from continuing operations of Southern Pacific Pipe Lines Inc. and San Diego Pipeline Co. and reflected certain pro forma adjustments as if the transactions to form the partnership occurred on Jan. 1, 1988.

title: Action Staffing Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included a loss of $129,300 from discontinued operations and a gain of $62,700 from the sale of discontinued operations. c-Net loss d-Included losses from discontinued operations of $95,200 and $287,500 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Wyse Shuffle
description: LEAD: Wyse Advertising, a Cleveland agency, shuffled its top management last week, naming four executive vice presidents. George Sapin was appointed head of the advertising division; James B. Rucker, head of the marketing division; Robert B. Wyse, integrated services division, and James G. Pockmire, media and administration.

title: State-O-Maine reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Eric Asimov Wed To Jacalyn Lee
description: Jacalyn DeVida Lee and Eric Asimov, 1980 graduates of Wesleyan University, were married yesterday in Hamilton, Bermuda. Marlene Christopher, Registrar General of Bermuda, performed the ceremony at her office.

title: Setback for Effort to Preserve Elizabethan Theater
description: Efforts by preservationists to save the remains of the Rose Theater, the only Elizabethan theater unearthed in London, suffered a severe setback today when a High Court justice upheld a decision by the British Environment Secretary refusing to list the site as a national historic monument.

title: Intergraph Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest 6 months included a gain of $8,406,000, or 15 cents a share, on the sale of a unit.

title: The End Of an Era In Breeding
description: rrTwo thoroughbred yearlings sired by Northern Dancer will be led into the Keeneland auction ring in Lexington, Ky., this afternoon. So ends the most extraordinary era in the history of the American horse breeding industry.

title: Chase and Morgan Report Declines
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation and J. P. Morgan & Company yesterday announced declines in their second-quarter earnings, while the Security Pacific Corporation reported record profits and the First Chicago Corporation and the PNC Financial Corporaton showed strong gains.

title: Tekulve, Holder of Reliever Mark, Retires
description: Kent Tekulve, who relieved in more games than any other pitcher in major league history, announced his retirement today, effective immediately.

title: First Pennsylvania Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest second quarter net included a tax benefit of $1.1 million. The latest 6 months included $5.3 million in income resulting from a change in the method of accounting for certain fee income, a tax benefit of $1.5 million, gains of $1.8 million from the sale of lease financing residuals and $1.5 million from the sale of Sallie Mae stock, offset in part by losses of $600,000 from sales of investment securities. The year-ago 6 months included gains of $3.2 million on sales of investment securities, $1.5 million from the sale of lease financing residuals and $1.5 million from the sale of Sallie Mae stock.

title: Geodyne Resourcesei reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Cleveland-Cliffs Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included gains of $2.1 million and $7,200,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, both from the sale of coal mine interests and the Grand Island sale. c-Included gains of $1.8 million for the quarter and $3,900,000 for the 6 months, both from the sale of hydroelectric facilities, and losses from discontinued operations of $2.2 million and $2,400,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Steel Technologies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said its profits were hurt by increased materials costs and that the latest third quarter net included gain on the sale of an airplane of $435,000, equal to 5 cents a share.

title: Books of The Times; When Bombing Doesn't Work
description: The Limits of Air Power The American Bombing of North Vietnam By Mark Clodfelter 297 pages. Free Press. $22.95.

title: Charles Schwab Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Rose & Co. Investment Brokers Inc. was acquired on March 31, 1989 and their operations were fully integrated with Schwab's during the second quarter.

title: Argentine Business Chiefs Agree to Price Freeze
description: In an effort to halt inflation of 200 percent a month, Argentina's new Peronist Government today agreed with business executives to freeze prices for 90 days.

title: NCR Profits Decline 1.8%
description: The NCR Corporation said today that its earnings fell 1.8 percent in the second quarter, a result of a stock-repurchase program, higher spending for research and development and the strength of the dollar.

title: New USX Chief Faces Decisions on Steel
description: Charles A. Corry, the new chairman and chief executive of the USX Corporation, has never been well known outside the company. Even the president of the United Steelworkers, Lynn R. Williams, says that what little he knew of Mr. Corry came through their common dentist.

title: First Brands Chooses Head for New Venture
description: The First Brands Corporation, which markets STP, Prestone and Simoniz auto products, plans to start a chain of automotive service centers and has hired Ronald A. Artzer from the food industry to get them off the ground.

title: Soviet Officials Appeal for End To Coal Strike
description: The strike that has shut down the Siberian coalfields was reported spreading to the Ukraine today, and the Kremlin sent a Politburo delegation to Siberia to appeal directly to workers to end their walkout before the economy is harmed.

title: A Feel-Good Theory: A Smile Affects Mood
description: PUTTING on a sad face or a smile directly produces the feelings that the expressions represent, according to a new theory of how emotions are produced.

title: 30 Afghan Rebels Slain by Rival Band; Kabul Declares Successes
description: The Afghan Government said today that its forces had scored new successes in their two-week-old offensive outside the strategic eastern cty of Jalalabad.

title: Hospital Gave False Report in Boy's Death
description: A 5-year-old boy died accidentally in Harlem Hospital's pediatric ward on July 3 when an electric hospital bed frame crushed his neck, but his family was told that he died of complications caused by AIDS-related pneumonia, a lawyer for the family said yesterday.

title: Dean Witter Expanding Operations
description: Dean Witter Financial Services Group Inc., which operates the third-largest brokerage in the nation, told its employees yesterday that it was restructuring parts of the firm, with plans to hire dozens of new analysts and bolster its corporate finance unit.

title: Dutch, Digging Deep, Find Bush's Pilgrim Roots
description: President Bush discovered his Pilgrim roots today, listened to an organ interpretation of ''Boola, Boola,'' and told the last audience of his European tour that nations around the world are joining in ''a widening circle of freedom.''

title: Keycorp Inc N) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Coast Distribution Systems reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
EAB reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Albany Impasse Puts 13 Essential Judgeships On Hold
description: For almost two years, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the State Legislature have agreed on the need for more judges, and have even approved funds for an additional 13. But because of a political impasse at the State Capitol, the judgeships have never been created, even as the backlog of criminal cases throughout the state continues to grow.

title: Olajuwon on the Mend
description: Akeem Olajuwon, the Houston Rockets' center, was released from a Houston hospital yesterday after a week of treatment for thrombophlebitis in his left leg.

title: Correction
description: A Company News article in Business Day on Friday about a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Belzberg family of Canada incorrectly characterized $40 million in credit the family received from banks. The Belzbergs had already used the $40 million to acquire their stake of nearly 10 percent in Armstrong World Industries.

title: Moody's Plans Some Ratings On Eurocommercial Paper
description: Moody's Investors Service Inc. said yesterday that it would begin to provide rating opinions on short-term obligations of selected American companies that issue Eurocommercial paper in cases where the ratings agency believes an issuer's risk is not properly being evaluated.

title: Metro Datelines; Bronx Man Is Shot By a Transit Officer
description: A transit police officer shot a 19-year-old, possibly emotionally disturbed man in the head on a midtown street yesterday after the man's second scuffle with the police in two days, the police said.

title: Great Western Expanding in Florida
description: The Great Western Financial Corporation of Beverly Hills, Calif., said today that it had agreed to acquire 63 branches from Centrust Bank of Miami, giving it the largest branch network of any savings and loan in Florida.

title: U.S. Says Afghans Killed Fellow Rebels
description: The State Department said an Afghan guerrilla group had ''brutally murdered'' 30 members of another guerrilla faction, including 7 commanders. A department spokesman said preliminary reports indicate that the killings were carried out by rebels loyal to Gulbuddin Hekmatyar, an Islamic fundamentalist leader. Article, page A6.

title: Central Jersey Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
What Castro Has Killed
description: With sensational show trials and merciless executions, Fidel Castro demonstrates his contempt for world opinion and for Mikhail Gorbachev's efforts to uproot Stalinism. Among the four officers executed was Gen. Arnaldo Ochoa Sanchez, once commander of Cuba's troops in Angola. All four were punished as drug traffickers; circumstances suggest political motives instead.

title: Help, Don't Jail, Addicted Mothers
description: LEAD: Does society really want to jail women for having drug problems when they are pregnant?

title: 8 in Sanitation Held on Charges Involving Bribes
description: Eight employees of New York City's Sanitation Department have been arrested on bribery charges involving payoffs to remove residential bulk waste or to permit improper dumping of commercial waste.

title: White Sox Sign Dykes
description: Hart Lee Dykes, a first-round draft choice of the National Football League's New England Patriots, has agreed to terms for a 1990 minor-league contract with the Chicago White Sox, it was announced yesterday.

title: Service Merchandise Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The 1988 per share data and number of shares were restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effective March 2, 1989.

title: Drexel to Close Madrid Office After Inquiry
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. said yesterday that it was closing its office in Spain and withdrawing an application for a brokerage license in that country after it was determined that employees there had improperly distributed shares in a large oil company issue.

title: Mozambican Government Ready To Start Meeting With Guerrillas
description: The President of Mozambique acknowledged today that Mozambican church leaders and a Government delegation were prepared to meet with representatives of the Government's guerrilla opponents.

title: Ameriana Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $1,587,000 for the quarter and $1,689,000 for the 6 months.

title: NBC Re-creating a Racial Attack
description: An NBC television movie this fall will re-create the racial attack in Howard Beach, Queens, that made headlines two years ago, focusing on the prosecution of the white attackers by Charles J. Hynes, the special prosecutor appointed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. Mr. Hynes will be portrayed in the film by Daniel J. Travanti, the award-winning star of the long-running former NBC series ''Hill Street Blues.''

title: I.B.M. to Buy Software Stake
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire a 10 percent equity interest in American Management Systems Inc. of Arlington, Va., a closely held company specializing in software for banks and other financial applications.

title: Summits: Not Empty at All
description: What began 14 years ago as a narrowly economic summit meeting was leavened this year by politics - to everyone's benefit. Indeed, this time the seven leaders glossed over the economic issues that divide them. But they found new direction and common purpose on broader issues, most notably how to deal with rapid change in Eastern Europe.

title: Frank Mullen, Banker, 90
description: Frank Mullen, a retired chairman of the Greater New York Savings Bank, died of heart failure Sunday in West Palm Beach, Fla., where he lived in retirement. He was 90 years old and had lived in Bellerose, Queens, and Syosset, L.I.

title: Federation Selections
description: Chris Evert, Zina Garrison, Martina Navratilova and Pam Shriver were named yesterday to the 1989 United States Federation Cup team, which will compete in Tokyo from Oct. 1 to Oct. 8. All were members of the 1986 team that won the cup in Prague. Marty Riessen will serve as captain and coach. Czechoslovakia will be the defending champion in the competition among teams from 41 nations.(AP)

title: Louisiana-Pacific Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-ago 6 months net excluded a $146 million non-recurring gain on the final settlement of the Redwood National Park condemnation. The company said year-ago results were restated to reflect the June 1988 spinoff of Fibreboard Corp., which had been a wholly owned L.P. subsidiary.

title: James P. McAllister, 84, Is Dead; Led New York Tugboat Company
description: James P. McAllister, a retired tugboat and transportation executive, died of a stroke Sunday at North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan and Port Jefferson, L.I.

title: Israel Asserts Threats by P.L.O. Imperil Bid to Revive Peace Plan
description: Even as Israel tries to revive its initiative for Palestinian elections, the Foreign Ministry asserted today that the plan is likely to fail in any case because Palestinians are threateing to kill any Arab who dares to discuss the idea with Israeli officials.

title: Gainey Going to France To Be a Player-Coach
description: Bob Gainey, the left wing and captain of the Montreal Canadiens, confirmed yesterday at a news conference in Montreal that he had signed a two-year contract to serve as player-coach with the Epinal Ecureuils, a second-division hockey club in France that is on a par with Junior B hockey in Canada.

title: Policy
description: William J. Bennett, who directs the Government's war on narcotics, is known for impatience, combativeness and for a knack for finding the limelight. Worried that people would view him as ''a showboat,'' in the words of one aide, he has spent the last three months closeted in his office devising a national drug strategy, emerging now and again to make a pronouncement on the evils of narcotics.

description: The French financial group Compagnie Financiere de Paribas said it might join Sir James Goldsmith in his $21.2 billion bid for B.A.T. Industries. ''Very advanced discussions are under way with Hoylake Investment Ltd.,'' which is controlled by Sir James, a Paribas spokesman said.

title: Busch Drops Arena Plans
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies has backed out of a deal to build a $70 million arena in downtown St. Louis.

title: New Ford Rebates
description: The Ford Motor Company announced cash rebates of $1,000 on its large Ford LTD Crown Victoria and Mercury Grand Marquis automobiles and $750 on its full-size Ford Bronco truck. The rebates will continue indefinitely. The vehicles were not included in a sales-incentive package Ford announced on June 1 and is offering through July 31.

title: Bank Action Hurts Recognition Stock
description: Shares in Recognition Equipment Inc. dropped $1.50 today, to $10.375, on the New York Stock Exchange. The 12.6 percent decline came after the Prospect Group, which offered to buy Recognition for $11 a share, said the First National Bank of Boston had terminated its agreement to provide $75 million in permanent financing for the acquisition.

description: The Aluminum Company of America said yesterday that its second-quarter net income rose 20 percent as a result of increased sales to the aircraft industry and the foreign can markets.

title: Bridge
description: It was no surprise that Poland won the European Open Championship, which ended Saturday in Turku, Finland. The Poles have captured two world titles in the last 11 years, and will now be among the favorites in the Bermuda Bowl contest in Perth, Australia, in September. Nor was it a surprise that France finished second, overtaking Sweden in the final round of play.

title: Great Northern Nekoosa Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

description: Members of the House Banking Committee today decided to present to Senate conferees on Tuesday a counterproposal on the Bush Administration's bailout of the savings and loan industry.

title: Pentair Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Oaks and Catbirds, Forever
description: Permanence does not seem to last all that long in big cities, but a piece of woodland in downtown Manhattan now has a good chance of achieving it. A 200-by-45-foot community park at the corner of Houston Street and La Guardia Place is being transferred to the Parks Department. This, as much as anything can, will insure it against intrusion or destruction.

title: Mentally Ill Homeless Gain in Project
description: Two years ago, Daniel B. was surviving, just barely, on the streets of the Upper East Side of Manhattan. Emaciated and lice-infested, he foraged for food in garbage cans and slept in doorways. With his schizophrenia untreated, he was plagued by hallucinations.

title: Cocaine Is Found Along Coast
description: More than 150 pounds of cocaine with a street value estimated at $7.5 million has been found along the coast of South Carolina in the last two weeks, an official said today. The drugs, which were wrapped in plastic foam and baled in burlap bags, may have come from an air drop by smugglers that went awry, said James McGivney, the agent in charge of the Drug Enforcement Administration in Columbia, S.C. He said no arrests have been made.

title: Rose Seeks to Return His Suit to Ohio Court
description: Attorneys for A. Bartlett Giamatti, the commissioner of baseball, and Pete Rose will face each other in court once again on Thursday. At that time a Federal judge in Columbus, Ohio, will hear their arguments on whether the Rose case should remain in his court or be returned to a state court in Cincinnati.

title: Talking Business; with Millstein of Pension Fund Task Force; A Hands-On Role For Managers
description: Since the New York Governor's Task Force on Pension Fund Investment issued its report last month, Ira M. Millstein, its chairman and a partner at Weil, Gotshal & Manges, a New York law firm, has been urging pension fund managers to start acting like corporate owners. The report, ''Our Money's Worth,'' urged New York State to adopt a public policy on the use of pension fund assets in takeovers, to establish a seven-member board to oversee the state's almost $100 billion in public fund assets, and to take a more active role in its investments. Mr. Millstein is also chairman of the Center for Law and Economic Studies - Institutional Investor Project, at Columbia University.

title: CB&T Bancshares Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

description: A yearlong effort aimed at removing drug dealing tenants from their Manhattan apartments has forced at least 120 vacancies and evictions, Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, said yesterday.

The company also said share earnings are restated to give effect to the 1-for-10 reverse stock split effective May 2, which reduced the number of common shares outstanding to about 4.7 million from about 47 million shares.

title: U.S., in Detail, Admits Its Spying In Europe as Suspect's Trial Opens
description: The Government today offered an opaque glimpse of American eavesdropping operations in Europe as Huseyin Yildirim, a mechanic who once worked at the Army's listening post in Berlin, went on trial in Federal District Court here on espionage charges.

title: Reviews/Music; The Damned's Final Tour
description: In this summer of reunion tours, a farewell reunion tour by a band that made little commercial impact outside Britain could be the toughest act to follow. In 1976, the Damned became the first British punk band to release a record and reach the charts; the band first toured the United States in 1977, a step ahead of the Sex Pistols. Now the original Damned lineup - the singer Dave Vanian, Brian James on guitar, Captain Sensible on bass or guitar and Rat Scabies on drums - is making what is billed as a final tour of the United States. ''You know we only want your money,'' Captain Sensible said to a full house from the stage of the Ritz late Saturday night. ''We're honest, ain't we?''

title: Bass Buys Stake In Longview Fibre
description: An investment group led by Robert M. Bass, the Fort Worth billionaire, has acquired a 7 percent stake in the Longview Fibre Company, a pulp paper and tree-farming concern in Longview, Wash. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Bass group said the Longview shares had been bought for investment purposes only.

title: Banc One to Buy Investment Firm
description: The Banc One Corporation said it would buy the investment banking firm of Meuse, Rinker, Chapman, Endres & Brooks. Terms were not disclosed. Banc One, the nation's 26th-largest banking company, said it expected the deal to be completed this month. Both companies are based here. Banc One said its investment banking operations would be consolidated in Meuse, Rinker.

title: Careers; Company Use Of Job Banks Is Increasing
description: THERE is a growing trend toward job banks - computerized lists of people, including many retirees, willing to work part time during summer vacations, around the end of the fiscal year or during other busy periods - according to Helen Axel, executive director of the human resources program group at the Conference Board.

description: Rush-hour traffic backed up for miles at major toll bridges yesterday morning, the first full day of a 25 percent toll increase by the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority. But at other major bridges and tunnels in New York City, congestion was described as normal or close to normal.

D'Amato in 1986, asked the Senate Ethics Committee today to investigate the New York Republican for ''questionable conduct,'' citing accusations that the Senator was linked to the Wedtech, Pentagon and Housing and Urban Development Department scandals.

description: The Staten Island Borough President, fearful that his borough will lose power, yesterday urged the panel that is rewriting New York City's Charter to postpone a referendum on its recommendations and devise new ways to make government more responsive to communities.

title: Budget Office Sees a Deficit Within the Law, Sources Say

title: Old as New: Knickers and 3-Button Sack
description: In men's wear, where major news can be about a button, the key trend these days is called ''updated traditional,'' not exactly something to send you rushing out to Charivari.

title: Results Plus
description: BOXING Camacho Takes Decision: Hector Camacho had little problem with his former sparring partner Tommy Hanks and scored a unanimous decision yesterday in a 10-round nontitle fight at Trump Plaza in Atlantic City. Camacho (37-0) set the tone from the start as Hanks (18-4) came out of his corner and tried to take the fight right to his former boss. Camacho stopped Hanks in his tracks with a right hook and then answered his opponent at every chance, using his speed and a quick jab to control the fight. There were no knockdowns. The judges, Frank Cairo and Richard Murray, scored the fight 100-90 for Camacho, while Eva Shain had it 99-91 for Camacho. The fight was the first for Camacho since he won the World Boxing Organization junior-welterweight crown on March 6 with a 12-round decision over Ray Mancini.(AP) GOLF Donald Wins Playoff: Mike Donald capped a 10-year quest for his first PGA Tour victory when he birdied the fourth hole of a playoff interrupted by rain and darkness at the Anheuser-Busch Classic in Williamsburg, Va. The victory yesterday, which came after Tim Simpson missed a 30-foot birdie putt, was worth $153,000 to the 34-year-old Donald. Darkness forced a postponement of the playoff on Sunday night after Donald and Simpson eliminated Hal Sutton on the third playoff hole, where Sutton made a double-bogey 6, and they each carded a 4. Yesterday, both players put their drives in the fairway. Donald, hitting first, landed his approach 7 feet from the pin, and Simpson landed 30 feet away. As the players walked on the green, a light rain began to fall, and Simpson, after lining up his birdie attempt, left it 4 feet short. Donald then knocked in the winner.(AP) CYCLING Longo Regains Lead Jeannie Longo of France regained the lead of the women's Tour de France yesterday by winning an individual time trial. Longo, who has won the Tour the last two years, was timed in 46 minutes 8 seconds for the 12-mile fifth stage against the clock from Embrun to Les Orres in the Alps near Gap. Maria Canins, another two-time champion, was second in 49:17. Inga Thompson of the United States was third in 50:22. Longo has a lead of 3:41 over Canins with Thompson in third, 4:52 behind. Kelly-Ann Way of Canada, who led after the fourth stage, dropped to sixth.(AP) TENNIS Galbraith and Garrow Score Upset: Pat Galbraith and Brian Garrow, former National Collegiate Athletic Association champions, rebounded from a one-set deficit to upset Neil Broad and Stefan Kruger, 3-6, 7-5, 6-4, in the doubles final of the Volvo Hall of Fame championship at Newport, R.I., yesterday. The match was suspended on Sunday with Broad and Kruger leading by 5-2 in the first set, and then moved indoors yesterday. Broad held serve when play resumed to win the first set. In the second set, both teams held serve until the 12th game, when Kruger double-faulted four times. In the third set, Galbraith and Garrow took a 4-1 lead en route to their first pro championship.(AP) HORSE RACING Bally Blue Triumphs: Bally Blue, carrying 112 pounds under Jerry Bailey, surged to the lead nearing the stretch and then drew away for a decisive 10 3/4-length victory in the $47,000 Western Warrior Handicap for 3-year-olds and up at Belmont Park yesterday. Viennese Cross was second, three lengths ahead of the favorite, Destinado. The victory was the third of the day for Bailey. Bally Blue covered 1 1/4 miles on the good track in 2:04 3/5 to record his second victory in five starts this year. He earned $28,200 for Lazy F Ranch and returned $8 for $2 to win.(AP)

Chess

His 10 1/2-4 1/2 score put him a point ahead of the former world champion Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, but his way of getting to the top place was highly unusual.

description: A NEW financial product introduced by the Chicago Mercantile Exchange is steadily gaining a following. While it is too early to call the new product a success, financial professionals say it could move forward the effort to create a truly global financial market.

description: The Ohio Edison Company yesterday offered $150 million worth of 30-year bonds through an underwriting syndicate led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

description: RESEARCHERS have discovered a substance that may prevent injured blood vessels from becoming blocked as they heal.

description: The Rev.

title: Time Stock Slides to $141
description: Time Inc.'s stock fell $4.25 yesterday, to $141, after sliding $4.75 Friday when a Delaware Chancery Court cleared Time to buy Warner Communications Inc. despite a bid for Time from Paramount Communications. Warner rose $1.125, to $65.375, on volume of more than 3.5 million shares while Paramount fell $1.25, to $56.25, as 885,000 shares were traded. All three trade on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: National System Offered for Finding Best Teachers
description: Citing a need for a ''new image of teachers in this country,'' a 64-member board released guidelines yesterday for the first national system to set standards for the best teachers and to determine who meets them.

Former H.U.D. Secretary Defends Her Lobbying
description: Carla Hills, the United States Trade Representative, today defended her lobbying at the Department of Housing and Urban Development several years ago on behalf of a mortgage concern that went on to issue millions of dollars in Government-insured housing loans that went bad.

title: Ferry Sinks in Bangladesh
description: A passenger ferry capsized in the Jamuna River near Dhaka and at least 60 people were feared drowned, the police said today. The ferry was carrying at least 70 passengers when it capsized during a sudden rainstorm on Sunday near Manikganj, about 35 miles northwest of Dhaka, the police said.

title: Aluminum Co of America reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the latest quarter and 6 months included gains of $19.7 million and $20.9 million, respectively, from favorable exchange rate adjustments. Year-ago quarter and 6 months included losses of $24.9 million and $46.1 million, respectively, from unfavorable exchange rate adjustments.

title: Ellis to Play at Syracuse
description: LeRon Ellis said yesterday that he would leave the troubled basketball program at Kentucky and transfer to Syracuse.

title: Alan M. Cohn, Professor, 63
description: Alan M. Cohn, a professor of English and the humanities librarian at Southern Illinois University at Carbondale, died of lung cancer Saturday at the Jackson County Nursing Home in Murphysboro, Ill. He was 63 years old and lived in Carbondale.

title: Dr. Louis J. Gilbert, Psychoanalyst, 75
description: Dr. Louis J. Gilbert, a psychoanalyst who was a trustee of the William Alanson White Psychoanalytic Institute, died of renal disease Sunday at New York Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.

description: Thatcher C. Jones, a securities analyst and retired professor emeritus of finance at New York University, died Saturday in Salt Lake City, where he lived. He was 100 years old.

description: Setting Standards For the Best Teachers A 64-member board issued guidelines for the first national system to set high professional standards for teachers. title: Profits Scoreboard
May Inventories Up 0.7% While Sales Were Flat
description: Business sales were virtually flat in May while inventories rose by seven-tenths of 1 percent, the Government said today. Some analysts said the figures indicated there would be further production cutbacks this year.

title: Medicare Paid $65 To Do Mom's Toenails
description: LEAD: At 91, my mother lives in a supportive care residence. Let's call it Golden Valley, a home for people in their golden years. There is also a nursing home section, but we don't talk about that. Yet.

title: National Westminster Banorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After recognition of previously unrecorded extraordinary tax benefits on the 1987 special LDC loan loss provisions of $7,050,000 for the quarter and $14.4 million for the 6 months. c-After recognition of previously unrecorded extraordinary tax benefits on the 1987 special LDC loan loss provisions of $5,575,000 and $10,355,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. National Westminster Bancorp Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of National Westminster Bank Plc., was established in connection with the Feb. 1, 1988 acquisition of National Westminster Bank NJ. Ownership of National Westminster Bank USA was transferred to National Westminster Bancorp from NatWest Holdings Inc. on the same day. The 1988 second quarter and 6 months' results reflected National Westminster Bancorp's interest in National Westminster Bank USA on a pooling of interests basis, while the results of National Westminster Bank NJ are included from the date of acquisition.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Nostalgia Helps Clinic Raise Money
description: LEAD: IN the late 1960's, casualties of the counterculture visited the Los Angeles Free Clinic for confidential medical treatment or counseling. Today, more than 20 years later, many of those former hippies have become affluent executives and professionals, who can afford to give money to the clinic, which relies on donations.

title: Ruling on Unmarried Couples Is Flawed
description: To the Editor:

title: LAUDER HAS SPENT RECORD $8 MILLION
description: In the first documentation of his immense spending in the mayoral campaign, Ronald Lauder reported yesterday that he has spent $8.5 million, double the combined expenditures of five other candidates for mayor and more than any mayoral candidate in New York history.

title: Rig Count Rise Ends
description: The number of rigs exploring for oil in the United States as of last Friday dropped by five, to 820, halting a seven-week climb, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today.

title: Hudson, a Rookie, Sparks Expos
description: Jeff Huson, who was just recalled from Indianapolis, hit a two-run double to spark a three-run fourth inning tonight as the Montreal Expos defeated the Atlanta Braves, 5-2.

title: Sri Lanka and India Deadlocked Over Troops
description: India and Sri Lanka, caught in a diplomatic confrontation over the continued presence of Indian troops in the island nation, are beginning to search for a way out of the impasse.

title: Our Towns; How Conscience Tamed a Land Of Ticky-Tacky
description: Eighteen years ago, Tom Miner was a 29-year-old Vietnam veteran with a budding career as a freelance photographer, a wife and a home on seven sylvan acres in the blue-misted hills near Kingston. Then one morning he picked up his paper, The Daily Freeman, and discovered that a developer was planning to build 500 town houses right next door.

title: Bush May Back Manned Flights to Moon and Mars
description: President Bush's top advisers are pressing him to commit the United States to a broad, ambitious agenda for exploration of space, including manned flights to the Moon and Mars, White House officials said today.

title: G.E. Net Up 16.4% In Quarter
description: The General Electric Company yesterday reported a 16.4 percent increase in earnings for the second quarter, citing gains in its plastics, financial services, medical systems and aircraft engine divisions.

title: Dash Industries reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Trading Partners Should Put Pressure on China
description: To the Editor:

title: Meese Calls Wedtech Minimal
description: Former Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, concluding three days of testimony at the Wedtech racketeering trial, said yesterday that the Wedtech Corporation, a Bronx-based military contractor, took up only a fraction of his attention in the Reagan Administration.

description: To the Editor:

U.S. AGREES TO ADD A MINORITY SURVEY TO CENSUS IN 1990
description: The United States Census Bureau agreed yesterday to conduct a random survey of 150,000 homes along with next year's national population tally that could lead to the first adjustment in the census for any undercounting of racial, ethnic and other groups.

title: Jobs of Summer Are Rare Rest of the Year
description: New York City's programs linking young people to jobs for the summer have been successful this year, yet the city is not offering enough year-round jobs for youngsters, the Federal Government's chief regional labor expert says.

title: Ralynn N. Stadler, Poet, 64
description: Ralynn N. Stadler, a poet, writer and a trustee since 1977 of Westhcester County Community College, died yesterday at her home in Mamaroneck, N.Y. after a long illness. She was 64 years old.

title: Ford Recalls Vehicles To Fix Safety Defects
description: The Ford Motor Company recalled nearly two million vehicles today, 518,000 of them to repair safety defects that it said might lead to engine fires. Federal safety officials suspect that the defects may have caused 652 fires, 9 injuries and 2 deaths.

title: Brajdas Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company said share earnings for the latest quarter was less than one cent a share.

title: Gendex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Hibernia Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest second quarter included an addition of $151,000 to loan loss reserves.

title: B-2 or Not B-2?
description: Soviet radars may see it as a blip no bigger than a bird, but to the wondering human eye it resembles a gigantic black bat. The B-2 bomber's two-hour maiden flight yesterday establishes the improbable fact that it flies. But it still falls far short of proving that the plane is worth its extraordinary cost of $530 million a copy.

description: TE Federal Government has agreed to provide $75 million to design and build a radio telescope in West Virginia to replace the one that crashed to the ground last year because of a stress fracture in one of its legs.

Jaruzelski May Be in the Running Again
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski subjected himself to hours of questioning today by Solidarity members of Parliament, indicating that he had reconsidered his decision not to seek the powerful new presidency.

title: Means Johnston Jr., 71, a Retired Admiral
description: Means Johnston Jr., a retired Navy admiral who commanded the forces of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in southern Europe from 1973 to 1975, died of prostate cancer Friday at Walter Reed Army Hospital in Washington. He was 71 years old and lived in McLean, Va.

title: High-Speed Computer Introduced
description: A new challenger entered the treacherous supercomputer business today, introducing a machine that it says will be more effective at certain tasks than those sold by the industry leader, Cray Research Inc.

title: RUPTURED TANKER CONTINUES TO LEAK
description: Scientists aboard the Exxon Valdez are collecting samples of a sticky blue substance leaking from cargo and ballast tanks on the damaged ship, preventing her passage through California waters for repairs.

title: New York Drug Maker Charged With Payoffs
description: Federal prosecutors today charged a New York generic drug manufacturer and a subsidiary with making illegal payoffs to a former Food and Drug Administration official.

title: Chief Resigns At a Utility
description: The Tucson Electric Power Company said today that Einar Greve, its chairman, president and chief executive, had resigned as an officer and director.

title: Uncle Sam's Thumb, New York's Scale
description: Persistent lawyers for the City of New York have just brightened the financial outlook for many big cities. The U.S. Government, which unavoidably undercounts poor urban residents in each census, does not yet guarantee that it will correct this wrong. But it has, finally, torn up a suspiciously partisan Reagan Administration policy and opened the way for correction.

title: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said financial data for the latest 6 months included a gain on the sale of Goodwill Bottling Ltd. and Goodwill Bottling North Ltd. in February 1989. The company also said financial data for both the second quarter and 6 months of 1988 included results of the Coca-Cola Bottling Company of Mid- America, which was sold by the company in December 1988.

title: British Open's Course Is Playing Like Arizona
description: Greg Norman blasted a tee shot 400 yards on the par-5 sixth hole at Royal Troon today in a practice round for the 118th British Open, which begins Thursday.

title: Florida Woman Dies Attached to a Tube; Legal Fight Goes On
description: Estelle M. Browning, a central figure in Florida's debate over the right to die, died the way she never wanted to: in a nursing home, attached to a feeding tube.

title: Japanese Equipment Diverted
description: The Japanese police said advanced electronic equipment was diverted to East Germany by a company also suspected of sending nuclear material to the Soviet bloc. Page. D1.

title: To Make Laws on Discrimination Stronger
description: To the Editor:
