description: The latest second quarter's net is after a $17 million pretax charge to cover costs associated with the planned closing of the company's wafer fabrication plant in Livermore, Calif.

title: Lin Exploring Its Alternatives
description: The Lin Broadcasting Corporation said today that it had held ''preliminary exploratory discussions'' last weekend with a third party about possible alternative transactions to the $6.7 billion offer from the McCaw Cellular Corporation.

title: Actress, 21, Is Shot and Killed After She Opens Front Door
description: An assailant shot and killed the actress Rebecca Schaeffer today after she opened the front door to her apartment house, the police said.

title: Ban Flag Burning That Causes Public Disorder; Each Is Only a Copy
description: To the Editor:

title: Out in the Country, the Kitchen Beckons
description: WEEKEND homes are not a New York phenomenon, but in few other cities is the exodus to the country and the beach on Friday as great as it is in New York. In part, this is because nowhere else is the difference between city and country so drastic.

title: Apple Computer Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Charter Panel Hears Support for Landmarks Law
description: Several dozen architects, environmentalists, elected officials and other proponents of New York City's landmarks law urged the Charter Revision Commission yesterday not to alter existing regulations.

title: New Directions Charted for NBC
description: The most closely watched agenda in the television industry is Brandon Tartikoff's annual outline of plans for the NBC Entertainment division.

title: White House Seeks Policy to Reduce Infant Deaths
description: Alarmed by growing numbers of newborn babies addicted to drugs or infected with the AIDS virus, the White House Domestic Policy Council has begun a review of Federal policies in the hope of finding ways to reverse an increase in infant mortality among some groups.

title: Long Seen as Frill, Arts Education Gains Support
description: In the years of serious debate about what schoolchildren should be taught, educators never seriously discussed arts education. And when public schools faced a financial pinch in the mid-1970's and early 80's, one of the first areas they cut from the budget was arts education.

title: N.F.L. to Vote Today On a Spring League
description: The National Football League is expected on Wednesday to approve the creation of a springtime league that will take its product to Europe, perhaps as early as next spring.

title: U.S. Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Toilet Leak Delays Air Travel
description: A broken pipe in a men's toilet delayed hundreds of air travelers here today as water shorted out parts of the radar system in the Logan International Airport control tower, officials said. Michael Cicciarelli, a Federal Aviation Administration spokesman, said flight operations were cut in half in the peak hour traffic period while repairs were made to the radar system.

title: Lujan Criticizes Congress for Oil Plan
description: Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. said today that a proposed Congressional moratorium on offshore oil drilling asked Americans to ''blindly reject even the possibilities before us.''

title: Weyerhaeuser Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago sales have been restated to reflect consolidation of Weyerhaeuser Real Estate Co. and Weyerhaeuser Financial Services Inc. in accordance with SFAS No. 94. Year-ago quarter and 6-month results have been restated to include gains of $112,000 and $635,000, respectively, reflecting a new accounting standard affecting the company's GNA Financial Services subsidiary.

title: Dartmouth Worried by Decline in Donors
description: Dartmouth College raised a record amount of money in the last academic year, but the percentage of alumni who gave has fallen, the school has reported.

title: Drug Makers' Profits Increase
description: The Warner-Lambert Company and the American Home Products Corporation yesterday each reported record earnings in the three months that ended on June 30, while the Upjohn Company and Eli Lilly & Company also reported gains.

title: Less Sting to Sudan's Rain and War
description: The weather and the war have been kinder to the desolate southern Sudan this season.

title: Midlantic Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The per share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Philip Winslow, 48; Landscape Architect Served on Art Panel
description: Philip Nichols Winslow, a landscape architect whose work is seen throughout Central Park and a member of the New York City Art Commission, died of complications resulting from AIDS yesterday at his home in Brooklyn Heights. He was 48 years old.

title: Punting and Passing, Mexican-Style
description: If the National Football League's proposed international league puts a franchise in Mexico City, it may have a home-grown competitor.

title: Reynolds Metals Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago share earnings are fully diluted. In the latest second quarter, the company had about 5.6 million more shares outstanding following the conversion of certain debt securities. As a result, there is no dilution to Reynolds' earnings per share in the latest quarter.

title: Doris Duenewald Garn, an Ex-Publisher, 67
description: Doris Duenewald Garn, a former publisher of Golden Books for children, died on Sunday at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. She was 67 years old.

title: Sedately, the Stones Roll Into a Small Town
description: In what might sound more like a schoolmaster's nightmare than a real-estate transaction, the Rolling Stones, legendary rockers and agents provocateurs of the sexual revolution, have taken over Wykeham Rise, a former boarding school for girls here.

title: Breads Of All Sorts, Grilled To a Turn
description: GRILLED breads are the latest trend in the barbecue frenzy that is sweeping the nation.

title: Backers of Oregon Betting Plan Reject N.F.L. Criticism
description: A day after the Oregon Lottery Commission approved betting on professional football games as a way to finance intercollegiate athletics, state officials defended the action against protests by the National Football League that such legal gambling would threaten the integrity of the game.

title: CONGRESS IS URGED TO REJECT LIMITS ON U.S.-P.L.O. LINKS
description: The Bush Administration implored Congress today to reject legislation that would put sharp new restrictions on the American discussions with the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Bid Mounted To Save Plant At Shoreham
description: Supporters of nuclear power are mounting yet another effort in the Congress to save the Shoreham nuclear power plant, but the leadership of the House has intervened to help Gov. Mario M. Cuomo in his effort to close the plant, officials on both sides of the issue said today.

title: Santa Fe Railway
description: The Santa Fe Railway announced it was cutting its staff by about 450 people, from clerical workers to upper-level management, as part of a plan to streamline operations. Michael R. Haverty, the company's president, said in a news release that nearly all of the reductions would be made through voluntary separation and early retirement. The Santa Fe Railway is a wholly owned subsidiary of the Santa Fe Pacific Corporation.

title: In Defense of Pigeons
description: To The Living Section:

title: Charges to Be Dropped
description: The wife of Hugh Green, who had filed charges of spouse battery against the Miami Dolphins linebacker after an incident in the couples' home last Saturday night, filed a waiver yesterday to drop the charges against her husband. Monique Green said that news accounts about her husband's arrest had been blown out of proportion.(AP)

title: Connecticut to Get Storm Relief Funds
description: President Bush declared parts of Connecticut a major disaster area yesterday, authorizing the release of Federal funds to help the state recover from last week's fierce storm, which caused more than $100 million in damage.

title: Former Player Arrested
description: John Turner, a member of the Georgetown University team until Coach John Thompson decided not to renew his scholarship, has been arrested on charges of possession of crack cocaine with the intent to distribute. Maryland National Capital Police said Turner and four other people were arrested Monday at a recreation center in Glenarden, Md., a Washington suburb. Turner was released on $30,000 bail. If convicted, he could face a 10-year prison sentence, officials said.

title: American Home Products Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Putting Their Mouths Where the Money Is
description: In 1988, Americans underwrote the Bush and Dukakis Presidential campaigns to the tune of $92 million. More than half of that money was spent on mass media blitzes, mostly for television ads, and mostly negative ones at that. Not so coincidentally, more voters chose to stay at home on Election Day than in any Presidential contest since 1924.

title: Japan Car Exports Fall
description: Japanese vehicle exports fell 1.4 percent in June from a year earlier, to 472,293, automobile industry officials said. Exports in June totaled 345,661 cars, down 1.8 percent from a year earlier, and 126,632 commercial vehicles, down four-tenths of a percent. Japan exported 3.06 million vehicles in the first six months of the year, down 2 percent from the corresponding period of 1988, the sources said. Official figures will be announced by the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association later this month.

title: A Rainy-Day Mood For Yanks' McCullers
description: The skies grew darker and the rain kept falling at Comiskey Park. In the Yankee clubhouse, where players gathered early in the afternoon to pass the time and dress, Lance McCullers wondered aloud why so much misfortune had rained on his season.

title: Wider Trade Deficit Trims Stock Prices
description: Stock prices fell broadly yesterday on news of a sharply wider United States trade deficit. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 8.73 points, to 2,544.76.

title: Lessons
description: Teachers in this country have always had an image problem.

title: BRIEFS
description: * C. R. Bard Inc., Murray Hill, N.J., a maker of surgical products, acquired Catheter Technology Corp., Salt Lake City, a maker of vascular access devices, and Radi Medical Systems A.B., Uppsala, Sweden, a maker of needles and other devices for taking biopsy samples. Bard said the two purchases came to about $60 million.

title: Results Plus
description: CYCLING Longo Reinforces Tour Lead: Jeannie Longo of France strengthened her lead yesterday in the women's Tour de France by taking the sixth stage. Longo won by almost two minutes in the 32-mile leg from Guillestre to Briancon. She was timed in 1 hour 48 minutes 29 seconds. Maria Canins of Italy, like Longo a two-time champion, was second, 1:55 behind, and now trails over all by 5:31. An American, Inga Thompson, took third in the stage, 2:58 back of Longo, and is third over all. (AP) TENNIS Two Seeded Players Defeated: Two seeded players were eliminated yesterday in the opening round of the Virginia Slims of Newport, R.I. Fourth-seeded Patty Fendick lost to Hu Na, 3-6, 7-5, 6-1. Fifth-seeded Amy Frazier lost to Michelle Jaggard, 6-1, 6-2. Zina Garrison, seeded first, defeated Lisa Albano, 6-1, 6-1, and Pam Shriver, seeded second, stopped Anne Henricksson, 6-3, 6-2. (AP) BOXING Camacho Takes Decision: Hector Camacho had little problem with his former sparring partner Tommy Hanks and scored a unanimous decision Monday night in a 10-round nontitle fight at Trump Plaza in Atlantic City. There were no knockdowns. Two judges, Frank Cairo and Richard Murray, scored the fight 100-90 for Camacho, while Eva Shain had it 99-91 for Camacho. The fight was the first for Camacho (37-0) since he won the World Boxing Organization junior-welterweight crown on March 6 with a 12-round decision over Ray Mancini. (AP) OLYMPIC FESTIVAL A Gold for Swimming: The first gold medal of the Olympic Festival yesterday in Oklahoma City went to Trip Zedlitz for the 200-meter individual medley. Zedlitz, an Oklahoma City resident who is competing for the West team, won in 2 minutes 6.84 seconds, about a half-second ahead of the East's Jeff Vance, of Dunwoody, Ga.(AP)

title: Change Comes to North Korea, Ever So Reluctantly
description: Such are the mysteries of North Korea that diplomats and foreign experts cannot even resolve a basic question about life in Pyongyang: why are there virtually no handicapped people on the capital's broad streets?

title: Washington Talk; Politics
description: As Secretary of Defense, Dick Cheney has canceled programs dear to the hearts of dozens of members of Congress. He addresses powerful legislators by nicknames that may not be entirely respectful. And he delights in catching his former colleagues in rhetorical inconsistencies. So why are they still smiling? This is not to say that Mr. Cheney has not had his share of trouble in his four months as Pentagon boss. He was rebuked by President Bush for remarks about Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, lost a fight with Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, over land-based missiles and clashed with his generals over internal discipline. On Capitol Hill he has come under fire for trying to kill weapons like the Navy's F-14 fighter.

title: Gambling On Football? Incredible!
description: rrA story broke the other day that the state of Oregon has instituted weekly betting on National Football League games. When this happened, there was a great thud heard on Park Avenue around 55th Street in Manhattan, where the N.F.L. office is located. The thud was the result of several N.F.L. officials crashing to the floor in a dead faint.

title: Rostenkowski Offers a Plan To Cut Surtax for Medicare
description: The chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee today proposed a sharp reduction in the surtax that many elderly Americans pay for insurance against the cost of prolonged illness.

title: Eastern-Pilot Impasse; Ritchie Gets Financing
description: Negotiations between Eastern Airlines and its pilots to end a four-and-a-half-month work stoppage reached an impasse yesterday, people close to the talks said.

U S Sprint's parent company, United Telecommunications Inc., said that its net income more than doubled in the period.

description: To The Living Section:

title: Will New Jersey Have to Kill the Great Swamp to Save It?
description: Having endured for 10,000 years, the Great Swamp of Morris County now faces an unexpected threat from those who, in trying to protect this haunting wilderness, may be endangering it.

title: Chess Seen as Aid in the Classroom
description: Some educators and parents have long feared that encouraging pupils to master chess might distract them from seeking other intellectual and academic skills.

title: MCI Communications Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a $10 million loss from early debt retirement.

title: Market Place; Transports Signal Need for Caution
description: TRANSPORT stocks are soaring ever upward, or at least one might get that impression by glancing at the most widely watched barometer of the group, the Dow Jones transportation average. Yesterday, the index rose 2.75, to 1,232.05, a record and 12 percent above its 1987 peak.

title: Navy's Evidence Suggests Sailor Set Off Ship Blast to Kill Himself
description: A Navy investigation of the gun turret explosion that killed 47 sailors aboard the battleship Iowa in April has found strong circumstantial evidence that a sailor set off the blast to kill himself, Government officials say.

title: TALKS TO RESUME IN COAL WALKOUT
description: The United Mine Workers of America and the Pittston Coal Group, prodded by a Federal judge, agreed today to resume negotiations toward ending a 14-week strike that has cut national coal production and increased coal prices.

title: Alcohol Abuse by Pregnant Indians Is Crippling a Generation of Children
description: The devastating effects of alcohol abuse among American Indians are reaching a new generation, striking children whose mothers drank heavily during pregnancy and resulting in a population that is mentally and physically disabled.

title: Bridge
description: A bidding weapon that is unknown in social games but common in tournament play is the weak no-trump opening. Since the 1930's, when it was espoused by S. Garton Churchill on this side of the Atlantic and by Britain's Acol players on the other, it has been a source of controversy. Its detractors, many of whom have never actually tried it, point out that those who use it sometimes suffer heavy penalties.

title: Economic Scene; The $12 Billion Misunderstanding
description: AMERICA's savings and loans lost billions of dollars investing in home mortgages, the asset they are supposed to understand best. Why take the chance they will lose billions more by investing in exotic, high-risk ''junk bonds''?

title: Eli Lilly & Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings are fully diluted. Share earnings are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split, effected in the form of a stock dividend in March 1989.

title: Video-Display Terminal Law Blocked
description: With a major provision blocked by a court order, Suffolk County's law regulating the use of video-display terminals has chiefly served an educational purpose since going into effect six months ago, county and labor officials say.

title: Judge Orders Halt in Delay Of Firefighter Hiring Lists
description: A Federal judge today ordered the United States Justice Department to stop delaying firefighter hiring lists for seven New Jersey cities, saying that public safety was in jeopardy.

title: Public Divided on Goals in Space
description: Although the preponderance of Americans favor keeping spending on the nation's space program at its current level, the public is divided over basic aspects of the program, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: Financial Problems At Detroit Symphony
description: The Detroit Symphony Orchestra will be unable to pay regular biweekly salaries to 155 employees this week because of worsening financial problems, the symphony's chairman, Robert S. Miller, announced Monday.

title: Alcan Aluminium Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included gains of $36 million and $66 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, resulting from $46 million of the company's Eurodollar exchangeable debentures being tendered in exchange for shares held in Nippon Light Metal Company Ltd., a related company in Japan. Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in May, 1989.

title: On a Cruel Climb in the Alps, LeMond Rises to Challenge
description: Forget the long breakaway with which Greg LeMond won the world bicycling road championship in 1983. Forget the time trial where he crashed, remounted and finished second to seal his overall victory in the 1986 Tour de France.

title: Woman Found Slain In Her Apartment
description: A 35-year-old woman was found dead in her home here yesterday morning, and the Suffolk County police arrested two men later in the day.

title: C.F.T.C. Chief Before Panel
description: Wendy L. Gramm, chairman of the Commodities Futures Trading Commission, told skeptical members of Congress today that the futures markets do not require major reforms now.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: WHEN it comes to light, healthful summertime cooking, turkey breast steaks are hard to beat for their low fat content and low cost. Fresh turkey breasts, widely available in supermarkets, can be the foundation of light summer salads, sandwiches, even barbecue.

title: Eating Well
description: ''WELLNESS Update: Thirty-year-old man starting on the twenty-five thousand-pound oat-bran muffin he must consume over 40 years in order to reduce significantly his risk of death from high cholesterol.''

title: Greeks Vote to Begin Inquiry on Papandreou
description: The Greek Parliament voted overwhelmingly tonight to begin an investigation of former Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou and four of his senior Cabinet members on corruption charges.

title: Signet Banking Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest 6 months included after- tax gain of $2 million, or 8 cents a share, related to the sale of three branch offices. The year-ago quarter and 6 months' net included $9 million, or 35 cents a share, in tax benefits attributable to the 1987 provision on loan losses on loans to less developed countries.

title: Veterans Dept. Offers Agent Orange Change
description: The Department of Veterans Affairs today proposed changes in regulations to make it easier for Vietnam veterans to make benefit claims based on exposure to the herbicide Agent Orange.

title: Jackson Tells of Move to Capital
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson confirmed today that he would move his legal residence to Washington, but he sidestepped questions about whether he would run for mayor.

title: Correction
description: An obituary in some copies on Monday about the conductor Herbert von Karajan referred incorrectly to the city of Ulm. It is in Bavaria, West Germany, not in Austria.

title: Dodgers and Reds Make 4-Player Trade
description: In a trade between rivals in the Western Division of the National League, the Los Angeles Dodgers sent Tim Leary, a right-handed pitcher, and Mariano Duncan, a shortstop, to the Cincinnati Reds yesterday for two left-handed hitters, Kal Daniels, an outfielder, and Lenny Harris, an infielder.

title: INSIDE
description: Trade Deficit Deepens The nation's trade deficit grew to $10.24 billion in May, the largest in five months. Prices of stocks and bonds fell in response. Page D1. New Toll for Alcohol Abuse A generation of American Indians suffers as long-term effects spread to people whose mothers drank heavily while pregnant. Page D24. Move on Medicare Surtax A House chairman proposed a sharp reduction in the surtax that many of the elderly pay for expanded Federal health insurance. Page A14. Life in North Korea There are hints of change in North Korea, but Kim Il Sung's country remains a place where conformity is a paramount virtue. Page A8.

title: Review/Pop; George Clinton Synthesizes 2 Decades of Funk History
description: George Clinton's performance on Sunday night at the Palladium was the very definition of funk. Strutting, chugging, oozing, cackling, sliding, grinding, it was ever-changing funk, propulsive and whimsical. For most bands, funk means choosing a vamp and repeating it with mechanical single-mindedness. But for Mr. Clinton and his 17-member P-Funk (a k a Parliament-Funkadelic) All-Stars, funk is organic and amorphous, and anything can happen over a solid beat.

title: Net Increases At Dynamics
description: The General Dynamics Corporation said today that its second-quarter earnings rose 25 percent despite an an after-tax charge of $50 million, associated with the SSN 688-class attack submarine at the company's Electric Boat division.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Brooks Brothers Inc., the men's clothier and division of Marks & Spencer P.L.C., promoted Antoine F. Moreira to senior vice president and chief financial officer.

title: Conagra Posts 41% Profit Gain
description: The food conglomerate Conagra Inc. said today that its fourth-quarter profit rose 41 percent from a year earlier.

title: Maxwell Plans a School
description: The British entrepreneur Robert Maxwell is helping to set up a school to teach business skills to Bulgarian managers. The official press agency said the school, a joint stock company between 10 of Bulgaria's leading state-owned companies and the Maxwell Communication Corporation, would train managers in marketing.

title: Morgan Stanley Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest second quarter revenue included a pre-tax gain of $51.5 million principally from the restructuring of the firm's investments in Essex Group Inc. and the Silgan Corp. Revenue for the year-ago second quarter included a pre-tax gain of $123.7 million on the sale of the firm's investment in Cain Chemical Inc. The company said share earnings have been retroactively adjusted to give effect to a 3-for-2 common stock split effective Feb. 27. Revenue represented net revenue.

title: Cyril E. Black, Former Professor Of History at Princeton, Dies at 73
description: Cyril E. Black, a history professor who was a member of the Princeton University faculty for 50 years, died of congestive heart failure yesterday at the Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center. He was 73 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: Real Estate; Renewing A Landmark In Rochester
description: AT one time the dilapidated Powers building in downtown Rochester could have served as a symbol of the decline of a city that 10 years ago was struggling to stem the flow of office tenants to the suburbs. But with Rochester's campaign to revive the downtown area showing signs of success at every turn, the empty 120-year-old structure is now more of an anomaly. The city takes pride in a downtown office-vacancy rate in its Class A buildings of only about 6 percent.

title: TV Boycott Is Criticized
description: A proposed boycott of two large television advertisers was criticized today as unfair by the two companies and as an infringement on free speech by two television networks.

title: Deals
description: Hockey

title: Striving to Build a Better 'Mouse'
description: Some inventors strive for a better mousetrap, but the Gas Research Institute is spending $1 million on a better mouse. Or, to be more precise, on a small device dubbed Mouse that could play a major role in the maintenance of small-diameter natural gas pipes.

title: Warner Communications Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a $52.3 million net gain on investments. Year-ago second quarter results included a $33.2 million. Year-ago quarter and 6-month results were restated to reflect results of Lorimar TelePictures Corp., which was acquired in January and was accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: Sound of Gunfire Leads to an Arrest
description: Hearing gunfire, an officer chased and arrested a man yesterday who the police said was a major drug dealer from Brooklyn who was involved in a Federal heroin investigation.

title: The Journal in Offer to Restaurateurs
description: Five hundred New York area restaurateurs were notified yesterday that beginning Sept. 8 The Wall Street Journal would add restaurant coverage to the editions of the paper that circulate in the metropolitan region.

title: STUDY IS APPROVED ON SAFETY OF DYE
description: The House today approved a study on red dye No. 3, the only food coloring on the market whose safety is still being debated.

title: The Future They See Works Like Today
description: They came to glimpse another time, to explore a world that does not yet exist, to examine new frontiers.

title: Lotus-Sun Accord
description: The Lotus Development Corporation and Sun Microsystems Inc. announced they would work together to develop and market software for use on Sun work stations. The financial terms, specific products and timetables were not disclosed, but Lotus is expected to develop a version of its 1-2-3 spreadsheet product to run on Sun work stations. Winning the endorsement of Lotus is a big victory for Sun, which is seeking to establish its design as an industry standard.

title: KENYA, IN GESTURE, BURNS IVORY TUSKS
description: President Daniel arap Moi ignited 12 tons of elephant tusks today in a gesture to persuade the world to halt the ivory trade.

title: Chip-Making Machines Sent To East Bloc, Japanese Say
description: Investigators disclosed today that some of Japan's most sophisticated equipment for making computer chips was illegally diverted to East Germany by a company that is also suspected of sending nuclear material to the Soviet bloc.

title: Blast in Besieged Kabul Fans Rumor of Intrigue
description: At noon on Saturday a huge bomb exploded in a truck parked a short walk from the presidential palace. Within hours, word began spreading that the Defense Minister had been arrested, possibly for a coup attempt against President Najibullah.

title: Reviews/Music; Paralamas, From Brazil
description: Three-chord songs, a Caribbean lilt and a wry lead singer in a baseball cap - if Herbert Vianna weren't singing in Portuguese, there would hardly be a clue that Os Paralamas Do Suceso hails from Rio de Janeiro. Its set at Sounds of Brazil was danceable and good-natured, but most of it was stateless, derivative reggae, as if Os Paralamas Do Suceso aspired to be Brazil's answer to the Police.

title: Accord in Mayoral Race: Boot Camps for Criminals
description: The criminal-justice system has become a central focus of the New York mayoral campaign, with just about every candidate calling for swifter certain punishment and military-style camps for criminals.

title: Ban Flag Burning That Causes Public Disorder; Against Partisan Use
description: To the Editor:

title: Five Russians Skirmish With a U.S. Kitchen, And Everyone Wins
description: It wasn't easy getting the chefs from four cooperative restaurants in Moscow to the United States. They were scheduled to arrive in October and finally arrived two weeks ago. Soviet bureaucracy got in the way. And once they were here their host, Jerilyn Brusseau, the founder of Peace Table, a Seattle group that sponsors exchanges between Soviet and American food professionals, couldn't find them.

title: Flag Burning Measures Debated
description: Senators and legal scholars argued today over whether a constitutional amendment would be political grandstanding or the best way to overcome the Supreme Court decision allowing flag burning as a form of political expression.

title: Top Officers Named For Dow-Marion Link
description: Joseph G. Temple Jr. is a chemical engineer, marketing man and spare-time scuba diver who says he ''lives for the water'' when he is not running Merrell Dow Pharmaceuticals Inc, the Dow Chemical Company's $1.3 billion drug unit.

title: Israel: A Government Paralyzed
description: LEAD: Israel's national unity government, it seems, will survive yet another crisis. It will survive despite the deep disagreements that divide the Likud and Labor parties on almost every significant aspect of policy. Their partnership continues out of weakness, not strength, and for reasons of political expediency, not national urgency.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a shortage of judges in New York State misidentified Matthew T. Crosson. He is the chief administrator of the state's courts, not the chief administrative judge.

title: Saving Units' 'Junk Bonds'
description: Many savings and loan associations continue to use federally insured funds to invest in securities that are below investment grade, commonly known as ''junk bonds,'' Alex Sheshunoff & Company, a financial information and consulting firm in Austin, Tex., said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: INTERNATIONAL The Commerce Department plans to ease curbs on sales of a broad range of personal computers to the Soviet Union and Eastern-bloc nations. In a shift in American export policy, the Commerce Department said its action reflected the Administration's desire to expand trade with Eastern European nations. [ Page A1. ] Some of Japan's most sophisticated equipment for making computer chips was illegally diverted to East Germany by a company that is also suspected of sending nuclear material to the Soviet bloc, investigators disclosed. [ D1. ] ECONOMY The trade deficit in May was the largest in five months, the Commerce Department reported. The $10.24 billion gap between imports and exports was 24 percent higher than the revised $8.29 billion recorded in April. [ D1. ] The economy will grow at a rate of 2.7 percent this year and 2.6 percent next year, the Bush Administration predicted. That is a much slower pace than Reagan advisers had projected. [ D1. ] A sharp reduction in the surtax that the elderly pay for insurance against the cost of prolonged illness was proposed by the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee. [ A14. ] House and Senate conferees agreed on a number of issues on the rescue plan for the savings and loan industry, but two ''substantial disagreements'' remain. [ D5. ] COMPANIES United Airlines will begin flying to Europe next spring, pending Government approval. The move is part of a growing trend in which U.S. airlines are expanding their international service. [ D1. ] I.B.M. and Apple Computer reported moerate improvements in profits and even better revenue gains. [ D1. ] MCI and United Telecommunications reported record earnings for the second quarter, reflecting the continued high growth and operating margins of the long-distance telephone industry. [ D6. ] Citicorp's second-quarter profits rose 10 percent, but analysts called the increase disappointing. Manufacturers Hanover, Wells Fargo, Continental Bank and Mellon Bank also posted gains. [ D5. ] Negotiations reached an impasse between Eastern Airlines and its pilots to end a four-and-a-half-month work stoppage. [ D4. ] Chris-Craft and Warner Communications settled part of their dispute over Chris-Craft's 17 percent stake in Warner. [ D23. ] The Wall Street Journal has made an overture to 500 restaurateurs in the New York area. [ D23. ] MARKETS Stock prices fell broadly and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 8.73 points, to 2,544.76. [ D8. ] The dollar lost value against most currencies in domestic trading, after finishing mixed overseas. [ D18. ] Soybean futures prices closed mixed and copper prices extended their rally. [ D18. ] Treasury note and bond prices fell in thin, lethargic trading. [ D17. ] Yields fell on C.D.'s and money market accounts. [ D5. ] TECHNOLOGY Phone companies plan to start converting their networks to digital technology in the next year to handle the increased demand for cellular telephone service. [ D1. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The economic case for curbing ''junk bond'' investments by savings associations is far weaker than the political case. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Transport stocks appear to be soaring upward. But a closer look shows a divided, even troubled, market in the transports. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [ D8. ] Comedy radio advertising has become an impressive cottage industry in Hollywood. Advertising. [ D23. ]

title: The Braun Tube
description: To the Editor:

title: New Dow Jones President
description: Peter R. Kann, publisher and editorial director of The Wall Street Journal, has been named to the additional posts of president and chief operating officer of Dow Jones & Company, the parent organization.

title: Michele Molese, 60, Tenor, Dies
description: Michele Molese, a tenor who sang leading roles for nearly two decades with the New York City Opera, died on July 5 in Broni, Italy, after suffering a heart attack. He was 60 years old and had lived in Broni since his recent retirement from singing.

title: Tomatoes and Herbs: Good Companions
description: MORE than anything else, summer brings to mind tomatoes, herbs and a convivial, relaxed way of cooking that lends itself to the preparation of fish or light meat, which can then be accented with fresh vegetables and salad.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Accounts
description: LEAD: * Store 24, a convenience-store chain based in Waltham, Mass., to Noble & Wecal, Boston, with a $700,000 budget.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I wasn't terribly short of money. I just decided I didn't ever want to worry where my next dollar was coming from.

title: Review/Film; 'Carnival of Souls' Opens Fantasy Festival
description: ''Carnival of Souls,'' Herk Harvey's 1962 cult horror movie, succeeds in being mildly tingling without the stimulus of decapitations, visceral explosions and other shock effects that have become staples of the modern horror film.

title: Wine Talk
description: AMERICANS are drinking less wine these days, but more of what they are drinking is made in the United States. Wine imports plunged by 16 percent in 1988, to 81 million gallons, the Wine Institute has reported.

title: G. Hirschberg, 69, A Manhattan Rabbi And a Civic Leader
description: Rabbi Gunter Hirschberg, the spiritual leader of one of America's leading Reform Congregations, Temple Rodeph Sholom in Manhattan, and president of the New York Board of Rabbis, died of cancer yesterday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. He was 69 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Corestates Financial reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly AD HOC COMMITTEE ON INDIAN OCEAN - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. TRADE LAW COMMISSION WORKING GROUP ON INTERNATIONAL PAYMENTS - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Prices Off Again in Slow Trading
description: The prices of Treasury notes and bonds fell again in thin, lethargic trading yesterday, pushed lower by a larger-than-expected rise in the nation's merchandise trade deficit.

title: A&W Brands reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said in computing share earnings, net earnings was reduced by scheduled dividend payments to preferred shareholders of $36,000 for the second quarter and $72,000 for the 6-month period for both 1989 and 1988.

title: Steel Output Up in June
description: Crude steel production in the non-Communist world rose by 2.8 percent, to 40.1 million tons, in June from the corresponding month a year earlier, the International Iron and Steel Institute reported today. In the first six months of 1989, output by the 33 nations covered in the report rose by 3.7 percent, to 245.4 million tons, from the period a year earlier. The June rise was led by Japan, where steel companies increased output by 5 percent, to 8.96 million tons, from June 1988. Production in the United States edged up by 1.6 percent, to 7.4 million tons.

title: Frustrated by Global Efforts, City Fights Ozone on Its Own
description: The ranks of American states, counties and cities impatient with the pace of international efforts to protect the earth's ozone layer are swelling. The latest action comes from conservative Orange County, where tonight the City Council of Irvine approved what is believed to be the most far-reaching measure yet to control ozone-depleting chemicals.

title: IN SHIFT, U.S. EASES COMPUTER EXPORTS TO EASTERN BLOC
description: In a shift in American export policy, the Commerce Department announced today that it planned to allow the sale of a broad range of personal computers to the Soviet Union and Eastern-bloc nations.

title: State Street Boston Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Probert Pleads Guilty
description: Saying ''this is my bottom,'' Bob Probert, the talented right wing whose career has been bothered by alcohol and drug problems, pleaded guilty yesterday in Detroit to a charge of importing cocaine from Canada on March 2. The conviction carries a maximum sentence of 20 years, but will likely be reduced under a plea agreement.

title: Jaruzelski, Changing Mind, Will Seek Presidency
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski declared today that he would seek the powerful new presidency, reversing an earlier decision to step aside in the face of possible defections from the Communist ranks.

title: Upjohn Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Conagra Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 28
How to Honor the Flag
description: With wiser, braver leadership, Americans would by now be celebrating the Supreme Court's flag-burning decision. The inspiring message would have sunk in: Even if some tinhorn thinks he can attract attention by torching one flag in Dallas, all the others wave more gloriously as symbols of liberty and reason.

title: Review/Television; Laughs a Serious Business for Cable
description: Cable and comedy have proven so compatible that some services, most notably Home Box Office and MTV, are now working feverishly toward the debuts this year of all-comedy channels.

title: Washington Bonds
description: The State of Washington offered $134 million in bonds yesterday through a negotiated sale in the tax-exempt municipal bond market. Maturities on the serial bonds range from 1989 to 2012. The yields are from 5.80 percent in 1989 to 7.05 percent in 2012. Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. acted as the lead manager for the issue. Ratings of A-1 from Moody's and AA from Standard & Poor's are expected.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Scali Picks Up Cruise Account
description: LEAD: Even though it is summer, the pace has yet to slow at Scali, McCabe, Sloves. Yesterday, the agency won the advertising account for Renaissance Cruises, a new luxury cruise line.

title: Wells Fargo & Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The provision for loan losses was $100 million in the latest second quarter, compared with $75 million for the year-ago period.

title: Will Bradley, 78, Dies; Wrote Boogie-Woogie
description: Will Bradley, a trombonist and band leader who composed and performed the boogie-woogie big-band hits ''Beat Me, Daddy, Eight to the Bar'' and ''Scrub Me, Mama, With a Boogie Beat,'' died Saturday. He was 78 years old.

title: First Bank System Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Meeting Mobile Phone Demand
description: Demand for cellular telephone service is increasing so rapidly in major cities across the country that mobile phone companies plan to start converting their networks to digital technology in the next year to handle the deluge of new subscribers.

title: United Planning Flights to Europe
description: United Airlines, which has profited from its acquisition of routes across the Pacific, announced yesterday that it would begin flying to Europe next spring, pending government approval.

title: Panel Makes Progress on Savings Bill
description: House and Senate conferees moved a step closer today to completing work on the $157 billion bailout plan for the savings and loan industry, agreeing on all but two issues.

title: Net Up at 3 Brokerages; Morgan Stanley Down
description: Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that its earnings in the second quarter rose by 31.2 percent, while Paine Webber Inc. and the Primerica Corporation reported sharply higher results.

title: General Dynamics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included charges of $50 million for the latest quarter and $33 million for the year-earlier period, both related to a submarine program at the company's electric boat division. The company said that in the latest second quarter it received a $25 million initial license payment from Mitsubishi Heavy Industries for the Japanese FSX fighter program.

title: United Telecommunications Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $3 million and $2 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: From Coke to Marlboro, U.S. Takes Hold in China
description: In front of a glass-enclosed display case outside the American Consulate here, clusters of Chinese gather silently to read material that the Chinese Government has demanded be removed. The State Department has refused.

title: F.B.I.'s No. 2 Post Is Filled
description: Director William S. Sessions of the Federal Bureau of Investigation filled the bureau's long-vacant No. 2 position today by promoting Floyd I. Clarke to be his deputy. Mr. Clarke, 47 years old, was named an Executive Assistant Director in February. The No. 2 position, officially the Associate Director, has been vacant since the early 1980's with the retirement of James B. Adams.

title: Savings Bond Interest Dates
description: The Treasury Department today announced maturity dates for United States Savings Bonds intended to reduce confusion among bondholders who are not aware of when their bonds stop earning interest.

title: Scott Paper Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Soviet Miners Reject Calls to End Strike
description: The strike by Soviet coal miners worsened today as more mines were shut down in the Ukraine and workers in western Siberia solidly resisted their own leaders' recommendation to end their regionwide walkout.

title: Koch Assails Dinkins Taxes And His Rival Lashes Back
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch yesterday said that David N. Dinkins was guilty of ''tax evasion,'' and for the first time in the campaign, Mr. Dinkins got angry, accusing the Mayor of ''slander.''

title: Cyril Simon, Director, 68
description: Cyril Simon, a theater director, died of a heart attack on Monday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 68 years old.

title: When Long Life Is Too Much: Suicide Rises Among Elderly
description: Reversing a half-century trend, the suicide rate among elderly Americans steadily increased in the 1980's, according to Government records.

title: Simmons Raises Lockheed Stake
description: An investment group led by Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas investor and corporate raider, has raised its stake in the Lockheed Corporation to 8.03 percent from 6.25 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Simmons gave no reason for the latest purchases of Lockheed, the big aerospace concern based in Calabasas, Calif.

title: Warner-Lambert reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A Challenge Is Filed On Goldin Petitions; He Assails Dinkins
description: The authenticity of nominating petitions to place Harrison J. Goldin on the Democratic primary ballot for mayor in September has been challenged and Mr. Goldin yesterday accused David N. Dinkins, another candidate in the race, of engineering the attack.

title: BOOK QUOTES AIDES RIDICULING QUAYLE
description: In a new book on the 1988 Presidential campaign, comments by several prominent Republican professionals depict Vice President Dan Quayle as an inept campaigner with a limited attention span, and today President Bush said he was offended by the comments.

title: Prominent Dissident Is Seized in Shanghai
description: The authorities today detained a prominent dissident who was released from prison in January and whose treatment had previously been an issue in Chinese-American relations.

title: Former Corner Men Put Knock on Tyson
description: For 35 fights, they were Mike Tyson's corner men. But in February, when Tyson fought Frank Bruno, the heavyweight champion worked without Kevin Rooney, his trainer, and Steve Lott and Matt Baranski, his seconds, for the first time in his professional career.

title: White House Shows Interest In Study of Earth From Space
description: White House officials preparing a major space message for President Bush asked for extensive briefings on a space agency plan for an intense environmental study of the Earth from space, an official said today.

title: Bush Advisers See Slower Growth Rate
description: In the first official economic forecast of the Bush Presidency, Administration officials predicted today that the economy would grow much more slowly in the next 18 months than the Reagan Administration had projected before it left office.

title: BellSouth Forming British Consortium
description: The BellSouth Corporation, the American regional telephone concern, said it was forming a consortium with the General Electric Company P.L.C. and the Plessey Company P.L.C. to bid for a personal communications network license in Britain. The Department of Trade and Industry intends to grant two or three such licenses, which will allow operators to offer two-way communications anywhere in Britain using lightweight handsets.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Jury Hears Tale of Spy Who Did It Out of Greed
description: A jury in an espionage trial today heard and saw an Army warrant officer on videotape sketch a remarkably candid self-portrait of a new breed of American spy.

title: About New York; A Tale of Giving, With a Surprise For One Reader
description: When Milton Petrie was a little boy, he took a teddy bear to bed with him. Then he would say a prayer, asking God to bless his family and ''make me a good boy.''

title: Import Rise Worsens Trade Gap
description: The trade deficit in May was the largest in five months, the Commerce Department reported today. The size of the deficit was attributed to a new monthly record in consumption of foreign goods and a modest decline in exports.

title: Reviews/Music; Kassav' in Songs of the French Caribbean
description: About three or four songs into its 90-minute set at the Palladium in Manhattan on Friday night, part of a celebration of Bastille Day, Kassav' figured out its sound problems, relaxed and gave the audience what it wanted. The audience, packed onto the dance floor and crowded onto balconies, was there to hear one of the French-speaking Caribbean's best bands play zouk, the shiny, horn-laden and slightly hyperactive music from Guadeloupe and Martinique.

title: Angels Beat Jays, 1-0, jon a 5-Hitter by Blyleven
description: Bert Blyleven pitched a five-hit shutout and Wally Joyner hit a homer in the sixth inning to lead the California Angels to a 1-0 victory over Toronto tonight before the largest crowd in the Blue Jays' history.

title: International Business Mahines Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a pre-tax charge of $600 million for estimated costs of consolidations. c-After a credit of $315 million from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The year-ago 6 months' net from operations is after the $600 million pre-tax charge in the second quarter.

title: Witness Says the Helmsleys Argued About a Pool Project
description: Leona Helmsley argued bitterly with her husband Harry about the ballooning cost of a $1 million pool enclosure at their home in Greenwich, Conn., a former construction manager testified yesterday.

title: A Constructive Shock for Argentina
description: Carlos Saul Menem, son of Syrian immigrants, flamboyant politician from the Andean West and the first Peronist to be elected President of Argentina since Peron's death, took office only 11 days ago. But already he has stunned supporters and critics with bold departures from Peronist orthodoxy. Though it's too soon to know if his embrace of free-market liberalism can cure Argentina's economic crisis, he has earned the benefit of the doubt from people who only weeks ago feared disaster.

title: Gains at Citicorp and Other Banks
description: Citicorp, the nation's largest banking company, reported yesterday that its second-quarter profits rose 10 percent, to $395 million, led by gains in its consumer banking activities. But analysts called the increase disappointing.

title: Personal Touches on European Forces
description: Can the Atlantic alliance and the Warsaw Pact reach a formal agreement to cut conventional forces in Europe within a year, as President Bush has suggested? Almost certainly not. But as the first round of talks closes, the two sides can point to valuable progress, and can realistically hope for a treaty sometime late next year - if Mr. Bush and Mikhail Gorbachev continue to give the negotiations their personal attention.

title: Continental Bank Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $2 million from the early extinguishment of debt.

title: Man Kills Stepdaughter and Self
description: A man who had twice before taken family members hostage at gunpoint killed his 18-year-old stepdaughter yesterday in Mastic, L.I., and held the police at bay for more than five hours before fatally shooting himself, the police said.

title: Bomb Plants Breaking Law, Report Says
description: The nuclear weapons industry faces more criminal investigations and possible plant closings because of persistent failures to obey Federal environmental laws, the Department of Energy's inspector general has warned.

title: Merrill Lynch & Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Revenue represented total revenue.

title: New Finance Law Forces Contenders to Run on Less
description: The new city campaign-finance law is forcing five mayoral candidates to learn to live on less as they establish patterns that are likely to persist in municipal campaigns in New York for many years.

title: Spill Contained After Jersey Oil Tank Bursts
description: An oil-storage tank on the bank of the Arthur Kill in New Jersey ruptured yesterday morning, causing about 1.26 million gallons of oil to gush into a containment area around it, officials reported.

title: Rights Unit Asks India About 7 Who Vanished
description: Amnesty International called on the Government of India today to account for seven people who ''disappeared'' in police custody in 1987-88.

title: Vestar Buys Assets Of a Nortek Unit
description: Vestar Capital Partners Inc., a New York investment firm, said it had purchased the assets of Monogram Aerospace Group from Nortek Inc. for about $90 million. Monogram, which will be known as MAG Aerospace Industries, is a Los Angeles-based maker of commercial airplane toilets, fasteners for military and commercial aviation and aluminum forgings. The company has sales of nearly $100 million.

title: Chris-Craft and Warner Settle Part of Stock Dispute
description: Chris-Craft Industries and Warner Communications Inc. have settled an important part of their dispute over Chris-Craft's 17 percent stake in Warner. The settlement was made before a hearing scheduled for yesterday in New York State Supreme Court in Manhattan on a lawsuit filed by Chris-Craft.

title:
EDUCATION;
Court Upsets Neighborhood School Plan
description: LEAD: A recent Federal appeals court ruling in an Oklahoma City case has assured a continued legal battle over the rights of school districts to abandon court-ordered desegregation plans and reassign students to schools in their neighborhoods.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-8

title: Genentech Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Valley National Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The latest quarter and 6 months included previously announced $181 million addition to the corporation's allowance for credit losses and other real estate owned.

title: Paine Webber Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflected preferred stock dividend requirements.

title: In Wartime, Good and Evil Get Mixed Up
description: To the Editor:

title: Fertilizer Industries
description: Fertilizer Industries, a company organized by Gordon A. Cain of Houston and two investment firms, said it had agreed to acquire a nitrogen fertilizer business in Clinton, Iowa, from the Hawkeye Chemical Company. Terms were not disclosed. Fertilizer Industries previously agreed to acquire six nitrogen fertilizer plants from other sellers.

title: Boatmen's Bancshares Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-ago quarter net included a one-time after-tax merger-related charges of $4.6 million.

title: TRW Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Noticing the Women Out of the Spotlight
description: When Wendy Wasserstein accepted her Tony Award for writing the best play of the 1988-1989 season, ''The Heidi Chronicles,'' it was with a special sense of her role in theatrical history. She is the first woman to win a Tony Award as the author of an original play. In 1956, Frances Goodrich shared a Tony with her husband, Albert Hackett, for their adaptation of ''The Diary of Anne Frank.'' But except for Miss Goodrich, no woman -until this season - had ever stood in the playwright spotlight in the 41 years of the Tony Awards.

title: The Mets Recover as Fernandez Excels Again
description: The Mets drew back from the brink last night, and just in time, when they swatted the Houston Astros for 15 hits and a 9-0 victory. And once more it was Sid Fernandez who led the way with seven innings of three-hit pitching that kept the Mets from taking the big tumble.

title: Kin of Mandela Visit Prison on His Birthday
description: Nelson R. Mandela, symbolic leader of the outlawed African National Congress, marked his 71st birthday today with a visit from his family and signs that this might be his last year in prison.

title: Washington Talk; Corporate Approach Hits Discordant Note At Kennedy Center
description: ''I used to do a lot of guesswork figuring how many ad pages we were going to sell,'' Ralph P. Davidson, the former Time magazine executive, observed the other day. He was talking about the uncertainties of theatrical programming and his new responsibilities as the chairman of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. ''But this is the most unscientific thing I have ever done in my life,'' he said.

title: Hoffman Estates Journal; New Home in Suburbs Seems Tailored to Sears
description: When the largest retailer in the world leaves the tallest building in the world for an out-of-the-way village called Hoffman Estates, the question on everybody's mind (after ''What is Hoffman Estates?'') is why?

title: Frank S. D'Alessandro, Executive, 79
description: Frank S. D'Alessandro, a retired group vice president of Standard Brands Inc., died of heart failure Thursday at Geer Memorial Health Center in Canaan, Conn. He was 79 years old and lived in Lakeville, Conn., and on Hilton Head Island, S.C.

title: Myers Won't Appeal
description: Angel Myers said yesterday she had given up her fight to have her suspension from international swimming lifted and indicated she might end her career. Myers was dropped by the United States Olympic team last August after a drug test imposed by the United States Olympic Committee indicated steroid use. She was suspended by U.S. Swimming through the end of 1989.

title: Mortality in a Dressing-Room Mirror
description: For women, summer is the season of reckoning, in effect the collective birthday of our gender. That's because summer is when we buy our bathing suits and see in the dressing room mirrors what the past year has added to or subtracted from our silhouettes - a ritual that is as much about mortality as it is about measurements.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Don't Touch That Dial; Just Laugh
description: LEAD: COMEDY radio advertising has become an impressive cottage industry in Hollywood, where several writing and producing teams create more than 1,000 funny radio commercials each year.

title: Marketing Magic, With Rabbit, for Disney Films
description: Perhaps the biggest surprise at movie theaters this summer is the unexpected success of Walt Disney Studios.

title: Job Growth Is Stagnant in Region
description: Job growth has stopped in New Jersey and slowed in New York this year, in yet another indication of a regional economic slowdown.

title: The Curse on Garden State Parkway
description: LEAD: In the 1950's, the famous black minister, Father Divine, was given a speeding ticket on the then new Garden State Parkway. In anger and frustration, he put a curse on the highway and asked that all his followers, whom he called ''angels,'' boycott the Garden State Parkway.

title: Ban Flag Burning That Causes Public Disorder; Protect the Constitution
description: To the Editor:

title: Citicorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a gain of $77 million on the sale of premises in Japan. In the latest 6 months, $49 million of interest due from Argentina was unpaid, and in the year-ago period, $169 million of interest due from Brazil was unpaid.

title: Manufacturers Hanover Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain of $291 million on the sale of its consumer services subsidiary for the quarter and 6 months, and other gains of $45 million and $86 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Bush, Back Home, Sees 'New World' in Reach
description: Flushed with positive reviews abroad, President Bush returned home today and said his trip to Europe had persuaded him that ''a new world is within our reach.''

title: Mellon Bank Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $5 million for the quarter and $29 million for the 6 months, both from the early retirement of debt.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Alfred Parker Is Dead; Expert on Taxes Was 81
description: Alfred Parker, retired executive director of the Tax Foundation, a research and education group in Washington, died of a heart attack on Saturday at his home in Larchmont, N.Y. He was 81 years old.

title: Estimates Increased On Nuclear Waste
description: The nuclear waste headed for a dump expected to be built somewhere in upstate New York will be more than 10 times as radioactive than previous figures indicated, the staff of a state commission reported yesterday.

title: Bar Panel Criticizes Enforcement Of Antitrust Laws by Justice Dept.
description: A panel of the American Bar Association has drawn up an unusually blunt critique of the Justice Department's enforcement of Federal antitrust laws, saying budget cuts and lack of official interest make it increasingly likely that some of those laws cannot and will not be enforced.

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for special items.(Loss) *Loss in year-earlier period.

title: Tribune Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Latest quarter results included $10,000,000 writedown on television broadcast rights.

title: Bank of New England Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Provision for possible loan losses was $69.7 million in the latest second quarter, compared with $24.8 million for year-ago period.

title: Tax-Exempt Bonds From Puerto Rico
description: The Puerto Rico Public Building Authority yesterday offered $346 million worth of triple tax-exempt bonds in a negotiated sale through an underwriting syndicate led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Queens Lawyer Admits Role in Mail Fraud
description: A Queens lawyer pleaded guilty yesterday to mail fraud in the activities of a private agency that Federal authorities said he and the late Donald R. Manes and others ''corruptly'' set up to collect overdue parking fines for New York City.

title: Security Pacific Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The provision for credit losses in the latest periods was $111.6 million for the quarter and $222.9 million for the 6 months, compared with $79.3 million and $157.9 million for the year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Jersey Utility Sets $100 Million Issue
description: The Public Service Electric and Gas Company in Newark, a subsidiary of the Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., yesterday offered $100 million in first and refunding mortgage bonds at competitive bidding.

title: I.B.M. and Apple Post Higher Profits
description: Suggesting that predictions of a recession in the computer industry might be premature, the International Business Machines Corporation and Apple Computer Inc. today reported moderate improvements in profits and even better revenue gains.

title: Book Notes
description: A Canceled Contract When the furor over ''The Satanic Verses'' by Salman Rushdie was at its peak in February, publishers predicted that houses would think twice before publishing other books that might be construed as critical of Islam. Now a Middle East scholar says, despite a publisher's denial, that he wonders if such caution led to the recent cancellation of his contract for a book about the Rushdie affair.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the dispute between Sri Lanka and India reversed the predominant religions of the two main Sri Lankan ethnic groups in some copies. Most Sinhalese are Buddhist; most Tamils are Hindu.

title: Correction
description: A front-page picture caption in some copies yesterday about the inaugural flight of the Stealth bomber misidentified the base from which the plane took off. It was a secret Air Force complex at Palmdale, Calif.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
New Chief Is Picked For Texas Commerce
description: LEAD: Marc J. Shapiro was named yesterday to succeed Ben Love as chief executive of Texas Commerce Bancshares when Mr. Love retires this November at the age of 65.

title: Adjustment of Entry List Makes 400 a Race to See
description: Steve Lewis and Danny Everett scanned the entry list for the New York Games Saturday and read that they were part of a 1,600-meter relay team. What a surprise.

title: C.D. Yields Drop, but Not As Steeply
description: Yields offered on certificates of deposit and money market accounts declined in the week that ended yesterday. While it was the 12th consecutive week of declines, they were not as steep as those posted in recent weeks.

title: Enough Mideast Ambiguity
description: A tremendous amount of diplomatic and political effort is being applied to making the Israeli-Palestinian conflict ever more surrealist. Nothing has yet been achieved but daily death and destruction, mounting fear and hatred.

title: Moriyama Journal; Even in His Town, Days in the Sun End for Uno
description: For more than a century, the longtime family business of Prime Minister Sousuke Uno has done quite well producing and purveying an unpretentious, sweet-tasting and moderately priced sake for the people of this lakeside town in the hills of central Japan.

title: Can't Keep 'em Down in D.C. Once They've Seen This Farm
description: The farms that once dotted the northern Virginia countryside are, as elsewhere, being replaced by shopping malls, office complexes and subdivisions, especially close to Washington. But some - like the Potomac Vegetable Farms here - cling to their small plots.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, an article yesterday about President Bush's visit to the Netherlands had jumbled type in some copies. Readers wishing copies of the corrected article may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: Ban Flag Burning That Causes Public Disorder
description: To the Editor:

title: Ban Flag Burning That Causes Public Disorder; Wash, Don't Burn

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Marketing Insights
description: LEAD: Marketing executives will have another magazine to put on their coffee tables, with the debut this month of Marketing Insights. Published by Focused Communications Ltd. of Manhattan, the magazine will feature articles on how to approach customers written by diverse experts, including marketing consultants and anthropologists.

title: No Cause Determined in Deaths of Boarders
description: No cause of death could be determined for the seven people whose bodies were dug up in November in the yard of a boardinghouse operator who has been charged with killing her tenants, the Sacramento County coroner said Monday.

title: KEY RATES
The Pop Life
description: New From B-52's ''Cosmic Thing,'' the B-52's first album in three years, offers ebullient reassurance that the new-wave band famous for surreal dance-floor romps like ''Rock Lobster,'' ''Dance This Mess Around'' and ''Private Idaho,'' hasn't lost its spirit in spite of hard times.

title: Books of The Times; The Wages of Lust, or, a Campus Lothario's Fall
description: Professor Romeo y Anne Bernays 277 pages. Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $18.95.

title: Agnes Reinkemeyer, Of Sisters of Mary, 65
description: Sister Agnes Reinkemeyer, the former dean of the College of Nursing at Seton Hall University in South Orange, N.J., was killed July 12 at a health-care mission she had founded in the village of Wema, in Kenya, East Africa. She was 65 years old and had lived at the mission since 1983.

title: About Education
description: French school reformers are calling for a law to prohibit anyone from adding new material to the school curriculum without at the same time eliminating something.

title: Review/Dance; The Kirov Presents Its Version of 'Potemkin'
description: The Kirov Ballet's new two-part program, presented Monday night, has its yin and yang. The first half consists of Petipa's celebrated ''Kingdom of the Shades'' scene from ''La Bayadere,'' with its all-female classical corps descending a ramp and wending its way across the stage.

title: Food Notes
description: Organically Grown Grapes

title: Michigan National Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest 6 months included a $8,325,000 gain from an accounting change.

title: A Visit Too Long Delayed
description: George Bush's visit to the Netherlands, the first by a U.S. President, was two centuries overdue. The Dutch are America's oldest friends, covert backers of the Revolution and first to recognize the new nation's independence. England's Ambassador to The Hague at the time said that ''the Americans would have had to abandon their revolution if they had not been aided by Dutch greed.''

title: Philip Morris Net Up 21.9%
description: Citing the performance of its Kraft General Foods division and strong international sales, the Philip Morris Companies yesterday reported a 21.9 percent increase in earnings for the second quarter.

title: Party Turncoats Find Capital Esteem
description: This city, where political loyalty often seems the greatest of human virtue, is at the same time inclined to hold its defectors in considerable esteem.

title: Tandem Computers reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Health; Doctors Confirm Benefits Of Aspirin
description: Healthy men over 50 years of age who take one aspirin every other day cut the risk of having a heart attack nearly in half, a nationwide study has found, confirming preliminary reports announced last year.

title: Justin Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Calendar: Quilts and Parks and Interiors
description: African-American Quilts, Museum of American Folk Art, Feld Gallery at Lincoln Square, Columbus Avenue at 66th Street; 212-977-7298.

Frankford Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: Global Services Group Established at Hanover
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation announced yesterday the creation of a global services group, the first step in its promised reorganization. The banking company is expected to announce details soon of newly organized regional banking and global banking groups.

title: Pulitzer Publishing Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Lotus Net Down 40.5%
description: The Lotus Development Corporation, which has languished because of delays in releasing an update of its core spreadsheet program, today reported a drop in earnings but increased revenues for the quarter that ended on July 1.

title: Modest Rise In New York Area Costs
description: Consumer prices in the New York area rose two-tenths of 1 percent in June, the United States Labor Department's regional bureau reported yesterday.

title: Dow Surges 39.65 Points, to a Post-Crash High of 2,5841.41
description: Stock prices soared to their highest levels in nearly 22 months yesterday on strong volume as traders reacted to the smaller-than-expected rise in consumer prices in June.

title: Carter Belts 3 as Indians Roll, 10-1
description: Joe Carter hit three home runs in a game for the fourth time in his career, tying Lou Gehrig's American League record, and drove in six runs tonight to lead the Cleveland Indians over the Minnesota Twins, 10-1.

title: American Television & Comunications Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: American Television and Communications Corp. is an 82 percent owned subsidiary of Time Inc.

title: Helmsley Controller Details 'Cheat the Government' Plan
description: The former controller of a Helmsley hotel testified yesterday that the company's chief financial officer told him that ''the only system we have around here is 'the Helmsley cheat the Government system.' ''
