title: Q&A
description: Flickering Light Q.I have a fluorescent light over the medicine chest in the bathroom. When the switch is turned on, it takes about 30 to 40 seconds for the light to come on. Then it flickers for another 40 seconds. I have changed the tubes and the starter several times, but the problem persists. Can you help? A.Assuming you have been replacing the starters with new ones of the proper rating, there are only three other possibilities I can think of:

title: PBS to Show Film on the Intifada Despite Protests
description: The Public Broadcasting Service is proceeding with plans to broadcast a documentary on the Palestinian uprising in the Israeli-occupied territories, despite protests from thousands of viewers and the opposition of some Jewish groups.

title: American Business Products Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Herman D. Bragin, Lawyer, 83
description: Herman D. Bragin, a lawyer for 49 years and a supporter of Jewish causes, died Tuesday at the Parker Geriatrics Institute in Queens. He was 83 years old and lived in Bayside, Queens.

title: Baker, Fentress & Co reports earnings for As of June 30
description: Assets represents net assets. The company said the latest period net assets per share is after $1.40 long- term and 18.6 cents short-term capital gain distributions paid in December 1988. Year-ago period net assets per share adjusted to reflect the 100 percent stock dividend paid in July 1988.

title: For Crafts, a 'Tropical Industrial' Look
description: FRAN CEY has definite opinions on Brian Murphy's design for Art Options, the new craft store she opened recently in Santa Monica, Calif., with a partner, Marlene Riceberg. ''You feel real warm when you walk in here and see 31 banana trees planted into a slab cement floor,'' she said.

title: KEY RATES
Health; Personal Health
description: Progress in preventing birth defects often has an unfortunate side. Families seeking to take advantage of new opportunities to avoid tragic births are often faced with unanticipated risks, added expense, confusion, anxiety and heart-rending decisions.

title: Cone Keeps Mets Afire With Defeat Of Astros
description: Just when they needed help the most, the Mets got it last night: David Cone, the superkid of last summer, whizzed his best nine innings of this summer, stopped the Houston Astros on four hits and no walks, faced only 31 batters, struck out eight and pitched the Mets to an 8-2 victory that kept their latest revival alive.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Jack Daniel's Strategy Is Turning 35
description: IN a marketing environment where today's innovation is tomorrow's anachronism, the Jack Daniel Distillery has prospered through dogged consistency. Its advertising strategy will be 35 years old in October, and the latest black-and-white ad for the Tennessee whisky is not a whit different from the approach of the first one in 1954.

title: Fred W. Lyon, Executive, 60
description: Fred W. Lyon, a former vice president of news pictures for United Press International, died of pneumonia Monday after brain surgery at Northern Westchester Hospital Center in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 60 years old and lived in Montrose, N.Y.

title: Review/Music; Re-revival of 'Candide' by New York City Opera
description: The successive revisions, deletions, additions, collaborations and rearrangements through which the Lillian Hellman-Leonard Bernstein ''Candide'' of 1956 became the Hugh Wheeler-Bernstein ''Candide'' that the New York City Opera performs -the latest revival opened Tuesday evening at the New York State Theater - form a web that I have never personally untangled. But some who have compared the various versions in detail insist that this was once a fine work, and I am prepared to believe them, because Mr. Bernstein's score sings, kicks and prances with a vitality that could hardly have been inspired by the book now housing it.

title: Some of Siberia's Miners Return; Gorbachev Calls Strike a Crisis
description: After decades of grimy subservience, some of the striking miners of the vast Siberian coal region began pronouncing themselves victorious today in a wildcat strike that has paralyzed the mines and brought unexpected economic and industrial concessions from the Government.

title: Forschner Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Noland Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Managers at Seabrook Shuffled After Incident
description: The company that runs the Seabrook nuclear plant yesterday announced a management realignment, naming a new chief operating officer and replacing a vice president who left the company in June after a lapse in safety procedures. The company also shifted responsibilities for its licensing, engineering and plant operations.

title: This Is No Time to Be Complacent About AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Bed Company Told Hospitals Of Peril in 1987
description: New York hospital officials said yesterday that the manufacturer of a mechanical bed that crushed a 5-year-old two weeks ago warned of the danger in 1987, but that a plan to remove the beds from pediatric units had never been fully carried out.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: WHEN the 4-year-old girl accidently saw her father naked for the first time, her parents took the opportunity to introduce her to the physical differences between boys and girls. The girl, like almost all preschoolers, was fascinated.

title: Plan to Press Banks to Serve Poor Sections
description: New York City announced yesterday that it would use its ''financial clout'' to encourage banks to maintain branches and make investments in the city's low-income neighborhoods.

title: Roe Going to Maryland
description: Matt Roe, a starter at shooting guard for Syracuse the past two seasons, announced yesterday he would transfer to the University of Maryland.

title: Bird Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $437,000 and $23,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, a gain from sale of discontinued operations of $5,763,000 and a tax credit of $3,310,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $261,000 and $794,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and a tax credit of $1,151,000 for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Lotus Development Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
Savings Bond Sales
description: United States Savings Bonds posted $623 million in sales last month, the highest level for June since 1986, the Treasury Department reported today. But the total was down from May's sales of $695 million. The department said sales totaled $5.97 billion in the first nine months of the fiscal year ending Sept. 30, up 7 percent from the corresponding period a year earlier. The interest rate on the bonds rose to 7.81 percent on May 1. The rate is effective through Oct. 31.

title: Beverly Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After pretax writeoffs of $120 million for the quarter and $128 million for the 6 months, primarily for losses related to the planned sale of 370 nursing home facilities with more than 38,000 beds. c-Net income

title: Housing Starts Rose By 7% in June
description: Housing starts, led by a steep rise in the construction of apartments, rose 7 percent in June as interest rates fell, but analysts said single-family construction would remain weak as the economy continued to slow.

title: Devon Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Reviews/Music; A New Style In Rock 'n' Roll, By the Group All
description: Somewhere between the churning, stop-start attack of hard-core rock and more melodic pop songwriting, a revved-up, post-punk rock style is starting to jell. All, one of the best ''pop-core'' bands, came to CBGB on Wednesday night as part of a New Music Seminar showcase, with a punk-length (40-minute) set that had hard-core fans diving from the stage as other audience members hummed along with guitar lines.

title: First Security Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Max Edelman, Lawyer, 82
description: Max Edelman, a lawyer specializing in insurance matters, died of cancer Tuesday at St. John's-Riverside Hospital in Yonkers. He was 82 years old and lived in White Plains.

title: Stone & Webster Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago second quarter and 6-month results included net income of $2,986,000, or 40 cents a share, and $5,754,000, or 76 cents a share, respectively, resulting from the sale of investment securities. Year-ago second quarter and 6-month revenue included gross earnings of $3,913,000 and $8,156,000, respectively, resulting from the sale of investment securities. The company said per share earnings have not been restated to reflect the 2-for-1 stock split declared in June and payable July 28.

title: UST Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said 1988 net figures included an adjustment of $2.6 million resulting primarily from an accelerated writeoff of goodwill for certain non-tobacco businesses, amounting to 2 cents a share.

title: Advice on Measles And Heart Attacks
description: Doctors offered advice on preventing measles in young people and heart attacks in older men.

title: Health; Many Smokers Hope to Quit, But Few Get Proper Help
description: Most smokers want to quit, but the task can be so daunting that surprisingly few try, fewer succeed and even fewer seek any help to stop, according to new statistics compiled by researchers for the Federal Government.

title: Review/Television; 2 Different Kinds of Debate on the Abortion Issue
description: The first reactions to the recent Supreme Court ruling upholding the right of states to impose restrictions on abortion promise no elevation of the tone of a debate in which one side flourishes pictures of destroyed fetuses, the other, pictures of coat hangers.

title: Washington Mutual Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Health Professionals Criticize U.S. Tobacco Export Policy
description: Health professionals from the United States and nine Asian countries today criticized the Bush Administration's trade policy of fostering exports by the American tobacco industry.

title: Ameritrust Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-ago second quarter and 6 months' results included an after-tax gain of $10 million from the sale and lease-back of buildings, and an after- tax loss of $4.5 million incurred in connection with agreement to sell investment in Central Bancorporation Inc. The year-ago 6 months also included an after-tax gain of $7.6 million from settlement of certain pension obligations, and an after-tax gain of $1 million on the sale of the payment service division.

title: Consumer Prices Up 0.2% in June
description: Posting the smallest increase in 16 months, the Consumer Price Index rose two-tenths of 1 percent in June, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Richardson Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Airbus Forecast
description: A recent boom in world aircraft orders could help Airbus Industrie break even by 1994, a year earlier than previously forecast, an Airbus spokeswoman said. The management of Airbus, the four-nation European consortium, has revised its break-even forecast of 1995, she said.The spokeswoman declined to comment on an article in the French newspaper La Tribune de l'Expansion that said that Airbus, set up in 1970, had lost $1.3 billion in the last two years.

title: DELTA SAYS ERROR LED TO 1988 CRASH
description: Lines said today that an error by the flight crew led to a 1988 crash at Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport that killed 13 people.

title: Salvadoran Rightist Wounded
description: A Salvadoran rightist leader was shot and seriously wounded today. The victim, Gabriel Payes, was shot twice in the chest by two men as he stepped out of a car on a San Salvador street, the armed forces said.

title: This Is No Time to Be Complacent About AIDS; Epidemic Downplayed

title: No Relief as Yanks Dip Below .500
description: The manager's voice was full of quiet and concerned anger. The owner issued the kind of warning that usually precedes changes. In the wake of another loss, the Yankees might be on the verge of their typical summer turmoil.

title: Heloise's Updated Hints
description: A FEW weeks ago, when Ponce Cruse Evans, better known as Heloise - as in ''Hints From'' - announced that she now had a Fax number (512-HELOISE), she was soon swamped. ''Hi!'' came the replies. ''We have a fax, too!'' Hints via fax might not seem very ''Heloisey,'' to borrow her phrase. But it is another step to bring her newspaper column, which was started started by her mother, Heloise, in 1959, up to date. Heloise's newest book, ''All-New Hints from Heloise - A Household Guide for the '90s,'' was published this year by Perigee Books.

title: Bennett Plans Shift to Local Effort in Drug Fight
description: The national narcotics strategy that William J. Bennett will send to the White House next month proposes a sharp increase in Federal money for state and local Governments to fight the drug problem, senior Administration officials said today.

title: Coopers & Lybrand Is Said To Seek a Bigger Merger
description: Rumors swept the accounting pro-fession yesterday that Coopers & Lybrand had called off its merger talks with the much smaller Spicer & Oppenheim and was instead stalking a possible merger with the much larger KPMG Peat Marwick.

title: Ameritech reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a one-time gain of $42.1 million on the sale of the company's Canadian cellular property. The year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective December 30, 1988.

title: Xerox Price Rise
description: The Xerox Corporation said it was raising its prices 5 percent to 6 percent for certain 50 series and 10 series copiers and duplicators for its American customers, effective Sept. 1. Xerox, which is based in Stamford, Conn., but has most of its manufacturing operations here, said its service and rental prices were not affected. The prices of Xerox personal copiers were also not raised.

title: Amax Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a nonrecurring gain of $125 million from a Federal Income Tax settlement.

title: GBC Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Dirty Words and Music
description: At Indigo Blues, where the singer and comedian Millie Jackson held court on Tuesday night, a waiter with a bald head was the featured attraction for five minutes or so, letting Ms. Jackson's naturally filthy mouth go wild. Next, Ms. Jackson asked two couples in the audience questions that at a bar or a cocktail party might start a fight, and then she was off into the next song. All this had been preceded by a set of rampages dripping with riotous vulgarity on the subjects of the club's stage, the club's lack of customers and just about anything else that crossed her mind. A club, it turns out, is good place to experience Ms. Jackson, a legendarily rude performer; it breaks her out of her routine and lets her improvisational comedic gifts have the room they need.

title: Architecture Magazine Is Sold by the A.I.A.
description: THE LATEST NEWS from the design press concerns the American Institute of Architects' sale of its monthly magazine Architecture to BPI Publications (formerly Billboard), the publishers of Interiors, American Film and The Hollywood Reporter.

title: The Talk of Cooperstown; Village's Weekend: Yastrzemski and 'La Traviata' On Deck
description: Carl Yastrzemski and Johnny Bench will be here Sunday, and so will about 20,000 other people, swelling the head count of this remote but famous village to nearly 10 times its normal size. It is expected to be the largest gathering in the history of Cooperstown, village officials said today, a tribute to two of baseball's most popular players and to the pantheon they will join: the National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum, which is 50 years old this summer.

title: In Fairy Dust, Disney Finds New Realism
description: AT exactly 9 each morning, an expectant horde of travelers, some wearing Mouse ears and perched on patient fathers' shoulders, make their way into a carefully engineered kingdom, part urban planning and part fairy dust. The "streetmosphere" they encounter is the envy of many architects.

A performance by the singer Felicia March will begin the series, sponsored by the Chase Manhattan Bank and the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council.

title: Roosevelt Financial Group reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

description: When Sun Microsystems Inc. introduced five major products in April, its slogan was ''Welcome to the New World.'' The theme was prophetic, but not in the way the company intended.

description: DC-10 jetliners were involved in several fatal accidents before yesterday's crash.

description: On the Trump Plaza dais, Mike Tyson, the heavyweight champion of the world, stared straight ahead, his face in his palms, as the final news conference for his Friday night fight against Carl (the Truth) Williams proceeded.

title: S.I. Complex to Set Aside Apartments for Blacks
description: A garden apartment complex in Staten Island has agreed to set aside a small portion of its vacant units for black applicants in the next three years to settle a Federal housing discrimination lawsuit.

title: Walter Karp, Writer Specializing In Political History, Is Dead at 55
description: Walter Karp, a writer specializing in United States political history, died yesterday morning in the Roosevelt Hospital Division of St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center, said Cathy Rohan, a hospital spokeswoman. He was 55 years old and lived on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

Jet Carrying 293 Crashes in Iowa; 186 Aboard Are Said to Survive
description: A United Airlines jumbo jet with 293 people aboard, disabled for 45 minutes and struggling to make an emergency landing at Sioux City, Iowa, crashed just short of the airport runway and burst into flames yesterday afternoon. Yet some people walked away from the wreckage, and last night a police official said there were 186 survivors.

title: Beverly Plans to Sell 370 Nursing Homes
description: Beverly Enterprises Inc., the nation's largest nursing home chain, said yesterday that it would sell 370 nursing homes in a plan to return to profitability by shrinking the company. The homes have 38,000 of the company's 106,000 beds.

title: GTE's Profits Up 10%; Ameritech Posts a Drop
description: Two major telephone holding companies yesterday reported opposite earnings results for the second quarter. The GTE Corporation said its net income increased 10 percent, while the Ameritech Corporation reported a 9.9 percent decline in net earnings.

description: b-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $55,070,000 for the quarter and $55,605,000 for the 6 months. The company said 1988 figures have been restated for discontinued operations.

title: F.D.I.C. Sells Some Stock In First City
description: Bank regulators today sold a portion of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's stake in the First City Bancorporation of Texas for $69.1 million, giving the agency a profit of $26 million.

title: Land O'Lakes Official Is Promoted to Top Job
description: Land O'Lakes Inc., a huge farmers' dairy cooperative and the nation's biggest marketer of butter, has named Jack Gherty president and chief executive, succeeding Ralph Hofstad, who will retire Sept. 1 at age 65, after 15 years in the job.

title: House Backs State Role in U.S. Waste Cleanup
description: The House of Representatives today overwhelmingly approved legislation intended to help state and Federal environmental officers enforce the nation's hazardous-waste laws at Federal plants, including nuclear sites. The vote was 380 to 39.

Khashoggi, a Saudi entrepreneur who brokered billions of dollars' worth of weapons deals over the last 25 years, was extradited to the United States yesterday to face charges that he helped Ferdinand E. charges that he helped Ferdinand E. Marcos with ''illegal property dealings.''

description: Conversion of Decatur Federal Savings and Loan Association to a stock thrift from a mutual occurred Sept. 30, 1988.

title: Officials' Post to Lewis
description: Bryan Lewis was appointed as the National Hockey League's director of officiating, replacing John McCauley, who died in June.

title: On a River, A Double Bill Of Colonials
description: PROF. STANLEY BARROWS is known for the tours of European houses he led in his years at the Parsons School of Design, influencing students like the interior designers Mario Buatta, Albert Hadley and Tom Britt. But the historic house he visited most frequently with his students of 18th-century decorative arts was only 60 miles away: the 1719 William Trent House in Trenton, which he called ''one of the finest and most sensitive restorations.''

title: Fignon Regains Lead In Tour de France
description: ''I feel strong, so strong, stronger even than yesterday,'' Greg LeMond said this morning just before he set off on the toughest Alpine stage of the 76th Tour de France.

title: Dun & Bradstreet Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included non tax-deductible costs of $14.3 million associated with the acquisition of IMS International on May 26 for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: In Berry Fields, Fear on Immigration Rule
description: Out in field 2A at the Atlantic Blueberry Company, the long rows of bushes are top heavy and bent with plump ripe berries. Some have dropped to the ground, wasted. ''And more will just keep falling off,'' said Al Galletta, president of the 1,300-acre farm, which is the world's largest grower of cultivated blueberries.

title: Commuter Line Intends to Add Parking Spaces
description: Moving to entice more motorists to take the train, the Metro-North Commuter Railroad proposed a program yesterday that would add more than 2,500 parking spaces near rail stations in Westchester, Putnam, Dutchess and Rockland Counties.

title: Northwest Pilots Hint at a Strike
description: Negotiators for Northwest Airlines' pilots said that a strike was possible by Labor Day, but the Los Angeles investor Alfred Checchi said the threat would not stop him from completing a $3.64 billion takeover of the nation's fourth-largest carrier. Negotiators for the Air Line Pilots Association told leaders of Northwest pilots' union on Tuesday that a breakdown in contract talks ''may be near.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Gen. Jaruzelski was elected President of Poland by the minimum number of votes after hours of procedural debate in which the Solidarity opposition showed vigorous evidence of its political strength. Page A1

title: Georgia Gulf Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Survivors' Tales of Noise and Smoke
description: The first sign of trouble aboard United Flight 232 over the Midwest yesterday was a loud bang from the rear of the DC-10, followed by a jolt that made the jet shudder.

title: A Ballplayer's Life Turns On One Home Run Pitch
description: It was one pitch in one game during the course of a successful 13-year professional baseball career. But some of Donnie Moore's friends and teammates say that ever since he threw that pitch, giving up a home run that cost the California Angels an important playoff game in 1986, Moore had been on a downward spiral.

title: American President Cos reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said its transportation operations contributed pretax income of $1.6 million in the second quarter and $9.5 million for the first half of 1989. This was a decrease from the $23 million adn $47.1 million reported for the like periods of 1988.

description: Looking backward decades from now, will the summit meeting of the summer of '89 seem meaningless, or will it be a watershed in the history of the health of planet Earth?

title: Journal Cancels An Ad Section
description: The Wall Street Journal has canceled plans to produce an advertising section that would have included a review featuring restaurants that bought space in the section, a spokesman for the newspaper, Danforth W. Austin, said yesterday.

title: Bush Allies Push Flag Amendment Before Panel
description: The debate over a constitutional amendment to outlaw flag burning flared before a House subcommittee today, with the Bush Administration and its allies arguing that the legislative approach advocated by many Democrats is unworkable and doomed to fail.

title: Brady Asks Germans, Taiwan for Debt Aid
description: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady today called on West Germany and Pacific Basin countries like Taiwan to play a larger role in reducing third-world debt and supplying new loans at low interest rates.

title: Dinkins Vows More Officers Will Be Hired
description: In a speech yesterday detailing his anti-crime package, David N. Dinkins, Manhattan Borough President and Democratic candidate for mayor, attacked Mayor Edward I. Koch for failing to deliver on five years of promises to increase the New York City police force.

description: In a highly unusual public protest, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said today that the Commerce Department was wrong to broaden the range of personal computers that can be sold to Soviet-bloc nations.

title: Cheney Asks Seoul to Buy Fighter Jets Direct
description: Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney urged South Korea today to buy jet fighter planes directly from the United States rather than to make them in Korea under license from an American producer, as proposed by Korean officials.

The company said the latest quarter and 6-month revenues included $164,694,000 and $156,519,000, respectively, from discontinued operations, and the year-earlier quarter and 6-month revenues included $323,280,000 and $302,813,000, respectively, from discontinued operations. The company also said the latest second-quarter and 6-month income from continuing operations included a provision of about $6.3 million, or $2.5 million after income taxes, or 2 cents a share, for the scheduled shutdown of Gallium Arsenide Wafer manufacturing facility.

AMR Profits Increase 25.8%
description: Record traffic on American Airlines in June pushed the profit of the carrier's parent, the AMR Corporation, to $177.9 million in the second quarter, a 25.8 percent increase over last year, the company said today.

description: The company said net was reduced in the latest year as the cost of ingredients for brewing operations increased by about $5,000,000 as a result of last year's drought.

title: Rail Award On Antitrust
description: A former railroad unit of the USX Corporation could face more than $630 million in damages in connection with an antitrust ruling against it, lawyers in the case said today.

title: Dunkin' Donuts Tender Response
description: The DD Acquisition Corporation, a venture of the Unicorp Canada Corporation and Cara Operations Ltd., said that through Tuesday it had received 1.1 million common shares of Dunkin' Donuts Inc. in response to its tender offer of $43 a share, giving it a total of about 35.4 percent of the chain. The offer is scheduled to expire next Thursday.

title: Ball Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: b-Included a gain of $17,800,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Koch's Doctor Says His Health Is Now Excellent
description: The physician who treated Mayor Edward I. Koch when he suffered what was termed a ''tiny, trivial stroke'' two years ago said yesterday that the Mayor is in excellent health.

title: 2 Giants to Buy Italian Cheese Maker
description: The BSN Groupe, France's largest food company, announced today that it had joined IFIL Partecipazioni, a key holding company of the Agnelli family, to make a $1.6 billion acquisition of Galbani, the largest cheese company in Italy.

description: A mounting body of evidence contradicts the explanation by Thomas L. Root of his thousand-mile flight off course last Thursday while he says he was unconscious with breathing difficulties.

title: Investor Limit Up at Rolls-Royce
description: The European Community's Executive Commission said Britain would raise its limit on foreign shareholders in Rolls-Royce P.L.C. to 29.5 percent, from 15 percent. The move followed talks with the British Government, which had been challenged by the commission, the European Community's executive body, over the 15 percent ceiling. The new limit will be valid until the end of 1992.

title: Dayton Hudson To Sell a Chain
description: The Dayton Hudson Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Lechmere appliance, electronics and leisure equipment chain of 27 stores to Berkshire Partners, an investment company; members of Lechmere's management, and other investors. The terms of the sale were not disclosed.

title: Duplicating Victorian-Era Carpeting
description: BECAUSE architectural styles changed almost every decade during the 19th century, it is difficult to generalize about colors or patterns of Victorian carpeting.

title: Bringing Ecology Into Home
description: LINDA MASON HUNTER became interested in environmental issues related to the home after reading an Environmental Protection Agency report on indoor air pollution and its effect on health. A result of her research is ''The Healthy Home: An Attic-to-Basement Guide to Toxin-Free Living,'' just published by Rodale Press ($21.95).

title: Israeli Teen-Ager Dies, Raising Bus Toll to 16
description: An Israeli teen-ager wounded in a terrorist attack on a bus traveling from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem two weeks ago died in a Tel Aviv hospital today.

title: United Vermont Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago figures restated to reflect a 5-for-3 stock split on April 4, 1989.

title: Georgia-Pacific Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said that during the latest second quarter it purchased about 3.1 million shares of its common stock at a cost of about $141,000,000, and during the latest 6-month a total of about 5.7 million shares have been repurchased and retired. About 22.2 million shares have been acquired since the company began its repurchase program in 1987.

title: MAN IS BEING HELD IN ACTRESS'S DEATH
description: The star of the television series ''My Sister Sam'' was shot to death outside her apartment here Tuesday, and a man described as ''an obsessive fan'' was being held today in Arizona in the shooting.

description: In an attempt to take advantage of the growing popularity of American sports around the world, the National Football League's owners voted today to go international with a new spring league that would have teams in Canada, Europe, Mexico and the United States.

title: Howard B. Sohn, Lawyer, 52
description: Howard B. Sohn, a founding partner of the Manhattan law firm of Squadron, Ellenoff, Plesent & Lehrer, died yesterday after heart surgery at New York Hospital in Manhattan. He was 52 years old and lived in East Northport, L.I.

title: Market Place; Drexel's 'HITS' Are Short-Lived
description: DREXEL BURNHAM LAMBERT INC. called them ''HITS.'' The buyers have every reason to view them as errors.

title: S.E.C. Looks at Audit Shift
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is weighing a proposal that would require companies to have their auditors review quarterly financial data before they are reported publicly. But in the month since the commission began seeking public comment, companies have been arguing that the costs of such a change outweigh the benefits and could delay disclosure.

title: A Cake of Soap
description: To a coal miner, the ultimate indignity is the inability to wash off the underground's grime at the end of a workday.

title: Pope & Talbot Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
This Is No Time to Be Complacent About AIDS; 8,000-11,000 Homeless
description: To the Editor:

title: 13 at a Sri Lankan Festival Are Killed in Grenade Attack
description: Attackers threw grenades into a crowd of Sinhalese and Tamil worshipers at a ceremony meant to promote peace between ethnic groups, killing 13 people and wounding 85, the authorities said.

title: Summit Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Queens Citizens Lobby Charter Panel
description: A stream of citizens loyal to Borough President Claire Shulman of Queens poured before the New York City Charter Revision Commission yesterday urging it to preserve her power and protect their borough from domination by what they called a Manhattan-oriented city government.

title: A Stolen Rembrandt Drawing Is Identified
description: A double-sided Rembrandt drawing of the artist's wife and son that was stolen 10 years ago from Rembrandt's House, a museum in Amsterdam, has been found and identified by Christie's in New York City and is to be returned to the museum, representatives of Christie's said yesterday.

title: No-Fault Divorces For Flowers
description: NOW that high summer is here, my perennial beds are at their peak of color and bloom. The astilbes, which I wish would bloom for three months instead of three weeks so that the enjoyment of their feathery plumes of rich pink or ivory or sullen red could be prolonged, are at the end of their season. But other plants are coming on in force, including day lilies, true lilies, hardy fuchsias and perennial salvias in wonderful tones of sapphire and amethyst. Red monarda or bee balm is especially fine this year in my garden, and thus far free of the disfiguring mildew that is its usual midsummer fate.

title: Bucharest Journal; To Rumanians, It Just Feels Like the Third World
description: The ''personality cult,'' in Soviet standard usage, was a euphemism for Stalin's excesses. In Rumania, the cult of Nicolae Ceausescu has developed its own rituals: adulation, sacrifice and relentless pursuit of heretics.

title: Boeing Gets Order From Texas Air
description: The Texas Air Corporation, parent of Eastern Airlines and Continental Airlines, announced yesterday that it had ordered up to 100 Boeing 737-300 airplanes valued at $2.8 billion.

title: Why Insure Richer Housing?
description: The Federal Housing Administration, which insures home loans, lost $452 million last year. Now Senators Alan Cranston and Alfonse D'Amato propose two changes that threaten to make a bad situation even worse.

title: Dean Foods Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a net gain of 21 cents a share from the sale of the company's Baskin-Robbins business and other non-recurring items for both the quarter and year. c-Included a net charge of 36 cents a share related primarily to an antitrust settlement and writeoffs of certain intangible assets for both the quarter and year.

title: Pitt Recruiting Woes
description: None of the five high school basketball players recruited by the University of Pittsburgh this year will be eligible to play in the upcoming season. Four are ineligible because they did not make the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Proposition 48 minimum score on the Scholastic Aptitude Test and the fifth cannot play because he has not yet graduated from high school.

title: Metro Datelines; Man Held in Attempt To Kidnap a Boy, 2
description: A man who described himself as a cocaine addict took a 2-year-old boy from a stroller and planned to sell the child for drugs but was foiled when he was stopped from stealing a nearby truck to make a getaway, the police said.

title: 58 Held in 160th St. Drug Raid
description: Detectives raided 13 apartments on 160th Street near Broadway yesterday evening and arrested 58 people on charges of possessing and selling cocaine. The police seized six pounds of cocaine and three guns as they checked the apartments, all suspected drug sites, a police spokesman, Sgt. Maruice Howard, said. All 58 suspects were charged with possession of a controlled substance. Some were charged with possession of firearms. The police made a series of similar raids on the street on April 28, 1988, arresting 127 people for possession of cocaine.

title: Ralston Purina Unit Being Sold
description: Beatrice Foods Inc., a unit of the Onyx Corporation, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement to acquire Bremner Inc. from the Ralston Purina Company. Terms were not disclosed. Bremner, based in Louisville, Ky., makes cookie and cracker products for sale under private-label trademarks. The company has annual sales of $75 million and employs about 450 people.

title: Boston Journal; Cleanup Comes to the Combat Zone
description: Fifteen years ago, when the operators of peep shows and pornographic bookstores were threatening to open shop in colonial mansions on Beacon Hill, it seemed like a good idea for the city to create a special zone for adult entertainment that would keep such things away from the eyes of the Brahmin. The Combat Zone was born.

title: What 'Right to Bear Arms'?
description: ''It must be remembered that the right to keep and bear arms is not a right given by the United States Constitution.'' This statement, from a 1973 Federal appeals court case may come as a surprise to many Americans. No right to keep and bear arms? After everything we have heard about the Second Amendment of the United States Constitution?

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Garrison and Shriver Advance: Top-seeded Zina Garrison and second-seeded Pam Shriver advanced yesterday to the quarterfinals of the Virginia Slims of Newport tennis tournament in Newport, R.I. Garrison beat Meredith McGrath, an amateur, 6-4, 6-0. Shriver defeated Anne Aallonen of Finland, 6-2, 6-2.

title: E.P.A. Proposing Quicker Action Against Suspect Farm Chemicals
description: In a move likely to upset farmers and their chemical suppliers, the Environmental Protection Agency is about to propose action that would let it remove potentially dangerous agricultural compounds from the market more quickly than it can now.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: WOBBLY wooden fence posts are annoying and can cause other fence parts to loosen. In fences less than five years old, the loosening is usually due to improper installation and can be corrected fairly easily. But in older fences, decay is more likely to be the problem. And while strengthening a decayed post sometimes works, it really should be replaced.

title: Reviews/Music; One of Basie's Disciples Leads His Own Orchestra
description: As one of the original members of the band that Count Basie brought to New York from Kansas City in the mid-1930's, the trumpeter Buck Clayton was an important contributor to the basic style of that brilliantly swinging group. Initially he was one of the principal soloists along with the saxophonists Lester Young and Herschel Evans and Basie himself at the piano, but he was soon contributing arrangements and compositions that became standards in the Basie repertory.

title: CLOSE TO HOME

title: Philip Morris Cos reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting change of $273 million. The company adopted in December 1988 the method of accounting for deferred income taxes prescribed by Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 96, Accounting for Income Taxes. In conformity with SFAS 96, the cumulative effects of the change through Jan. 1, 1988 were recorded in the first quarter of 1988. Also as required, 1988 quarterly earnings have been restated for the effects of this change. This retroactively increased net earnings for the first six months of 1988 by $245 million, or $1.04 per share, which consisted of a $273 million, or $1.17 per share, cumulative effect of the change through Jan. 1, 1988, partially offset by a $28 million, or 13 cents per share, increase to the provision for income taxes for the first six months of 1988. Second quarter 1988 increase in provision for income taxes was $16 million, or 7 cents per share. Kraft Inc. became a wholly owned subsidiary on Dec. 7, 1988. Accordingly, consolidated results of the company included the operating results of Kraft since its acquisition.

title: Talk to the P.L.O., but Carefully

title: Msgr. Owen J. Scanlon; Harlem Pastor Was 79
description: Msgr. Owen J. Scanlon, a Roman Catholic priest in the Archdiocese of New York for 53 years, died Tuesday at St. Barnabas Hospital in the Bronx. He was 79 years old and lived in Yonkers.

title: Time-Warner Deal Is Seen But Its Value Is Questioned
description: Wall Street appears to have assumed that the merger of Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc. will be approved by the Delaware Supreme Court on Monday, but it still seems to have doubts about the deal's real value.

description: Not long ago a political pariah for his role in Israel's Lebanon war, Ariel Sharon now has such power that many call him the real force behind Israel's Government. Page A2.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Q&A - John W. Gardner; A Philosophical View Of a Capital Career
description: John W. Gardner came to Washington 24 years ago, from the Carnegie Foundation, to be Lyndon B. Johnson's Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare. He stayed on in the capital, as first director of the Urban Coalition, founder of Common Cause, the public affairs lobby, and founder of the ''Independent Sector,'' a coalition of 650 foundations, corporations and national voluntary organizations to encourage volunteerism.

title: Mazda in Venture
description: The Mazda Motor Corporation, the Sumitomo Corporation and Indo Mobile Group of Indonesia have set up a joint venture in Jakarta to make automobile engines and body parts, a Mazda spokesman said. P.T. Mazda Indonesia Manufacturing, which is capitalized at $15.7 million, will be owned 55 percent by Mazda, 30 percent by Indo and 15 percent by Sumitomo. It plans to build a plant in the Jakarta area and will start manufacturing 1,500 engines a month in August 1990. Mazda now exports engines and car parts to its assembly plant in Indonesia.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Food Notes column in The Living Section on Wednesday misstated some prices of organically grown seedless grapes. They are $2.59 a pound at D'Agostino supermarkets in the New York region and $1.98 a pound at Grace's Marketplace in Manhattan.

description: Over nearly four decades, Japan's opposition parties have grown comfortable on the political sidelines, happily criticizing the conservative political establishment without fear that someday they might have to run the world's second-largest economy.

title: Rangers Get Farm Club
description: Only three days after being appointed general manager of the Rangers, Neil Smith has signed a one-year affiliation agreement with the Flint Spirits of the International Hockey League.

title: Afghan Rebel Leader Urges Talks on Clash With Rivals
description: An Afghan guerrilla leader whose followers have been accused of killing 30 rival guerrillas called today for negotiations to prevent further violence.

title: Fretter-Atari Unit
description: Fretter Inc. said it was discussing the possible purchase of certain assets and business of Federated Group Inc., a subsidiary of the Atari Corporation. It said no definitive agreement had been reached.

title: Mr. Bush's Giant Step Back in Space
description: On the 20th anniversary of the moon landing, in the presence of the three astronauts who made such stirring history, President Bush stepped up to declare the nation's next high goal in space: Go back to the moon.

title: Review/Film; 'Reinette and Mirabelle,' a New Eric Rohmer Tale
description: As if making a joke about the famous talkiness of his films, Eric Rohmer's latest work begins and ends with silence - or at least the idea of silence. In the first of the connected episodes in ''Four Adventures of Reinette and Mirabelle,'' the voluble Reinette treasures silence so much she wakes her friend Mirabelle before dawn to hear ''the blue hour,'' which is not an hour but a second, not a sound but a brief silence between darkness and light, when the night birds stop singing and the day birds have not yet begun.

title: Review/Art; Architectural Gadgetry In Installation at the Modern
description: ''Para-Site,'' a multi-media installation on view in and around the Projects gallery at the Museum of Modern Art, suggests a style that might be called highbrow fun house and a subtitle that might read ''Dentists From Hell.'' Combining the latest in high-tech architectural gadgetry with aspects of 1970's installation art, ''Para-Site'' is the creation of Elizabeth Diller and Ricardo Scofidio, two New York architects who also design site-specific installation work and, occasionally, performance pieces. It involves live video cameras and monitors, disorienting mirrors, chairs that sit everywhere but on the floor and an incision in the wall that reveals wood studs, electrical wiring and a bit of bisected plumbing. In all, ''Para-Site'' is a major effort in a minor key.

title: An Overly Costly 'Trip Wire' in Korea
description: When asked to comment recently on a proposal in Congress to reduce the United States troop presence in South Korea, President Roh Tae Woo chided, ''If it ain't broke, don't fix it.'' Well, it is broke and it needs fixing. More than 35 years after the Korean War, the U.S. still maintains 43,000 troops in South Korea at a cost of about $2.6 billion a year. What began as a necessary but temporary helping hand to a friend in need has become the permanent and costly expectation of a prosperous ally.

title: Ford Capri Outlook
description: The Ford Motor Company's long-delayed Capri two-seater convertible may make its American debut next spring if the quality of the Australian-built car reaches United States standards, the trade magazine Autoweek said today. The magazine said a team of Ford officials would visit Australia in August and would decide by September when the auto will go on sale here. A Ford spokesman said the auto maker had set no timetable for the car's introduction in the United States.

description: As the Bush Administration prepares to disclose the details of its recent proposal for a new clean-air bill on Friday, auto industry executives are striving to focus the debate on the high cost of a number of changes that they concede are - or soon will be - technically feasible.

description: Soviet television viewers finally got a chance to see man walk on the Moon today, on the 20th anniversary of the event. When Neil A. Armstrong and Edwin E. (Buzz) Aldrin Jr. walked on the Moon on July 20, 1969, millions of people saw it on live television. But Soviet television showed a musical variety program. The moonwalk was broadcast on Soviet television this morning.

description: ECONOMICS is a science - some would say a non-science - of metaphors. Growth, inflation, depression are terms that have been around for so long that they have become what the language experts call dead metaphors - dead in the sense that they have been severed from their original biological, physical or psychological roots.

title: Meet Dr. Squeezed
description: LEAD: Practicing medicine today means being caught in the middle. For example, my malpractice insurance carrier tells me, essentially, not to use my professional judgment. Instead, I should cover myself by ordering expensive tests and studies (that patients do not want) to verify what I already know. Conversely, many health maintenance organizations penalize me financially for doing these same tests and studies.

title: Review/Art; The Ways of Life, Death and Hope in Ancient Israel
description: For quite some time now, the words ''exodus'' and ''exile'' have been freighted with pity and terror, foreboding and dread. They sum up the lot of millions of people, worldwide, in this century, and they cast a long shadow, both forward and backward. In a few years from now, they may apply to Hong Kong. Well over 3,000 years ago, they applied to legendary migrations.

title: At The Movies
description: The Busy Lumet

title: Results Plus
description: CYCLING Longo Extends Lead: Jeannie Longo of France won her fourth consecutive stage victory yesterday and continued to move away from the field in the women's Tour de France. Longo won by 5 seconds in the eighth stage of 31 miles from Vizille to Villard-de-Lans in the Alps. Her time was 1 hour 43 minutes 20 seconds. For the fourth successive leg, Susan Elias of the United States was second, 6 seconds behind Longo. Over all, Longo has a lead of 7:09 over Maria Canins of Italy. Inga Thompson of the United States is third, 10:49 behind. (AP) Comparative Newcomer Wins: Juliana Furtado of Boulder, Colo., won the women's road race yesterday at the United States national championships in Park City, Utah. Furtado, a former all-America skier at the University of Colorado, began cycling less than two years ago. She broke away from the field early in the 49.5-mile race and won in a time of 2 hours 17 minutes 6 seconds. Ruthie Matthes, also of Boulder, avoided a crash fewer than 100 yards from the finish and placed second in 2:18:40. (AP) GOLF Defending Champion in Lead: The defending champion, Blaine McCallister, shot a five-under-par 65 yesterday to take a one-stroke first-round lead in the Hardee's Classic in Coal Valley, Ill. McCallister had six birdies and one bogey. One stroke behind were Curt Byrum, who has yet to win in six and a half years on tour; David Toms, a recent Louisiana State graduate, and Cary Hungate, the pro at the American Legion public golf course in Kokomo, Ind.(AP) Hammel and Postlewait Lead: Penny Hammel and Kathy Postlewait shot five-under-par 67's yesterday and shared a one-stroke lead after the first round of the L.P.G.A. Boston Five Classic in Danvers, Mass. Cindy Rarick, Amy Alcott, Donna White, Anne-Marie Palli and a tour rookie, Tina Barrett, were tied for second over the 6,008-yard, par-72 Tara Ferncroft Country Club course. Kris Monaghan, using a 7-iron, had a hole-in-one on the 153-yard sixth hole as she shot a 71.(AP) BOXING Foreman Wins Unanimous Decision: George Foreman, former heavyweight champion, won a unanimous decision last night over Everett (Big Foot) Martin in a 10-round heavyweight fight in Tucson, Ariz. Foreman, 19-0 since returning to boxing 2 years ago after a 10-year absence, knocked down Martin in the eighth and dominated the bout. Judge Jerry Maltz gave Foreman a 99-91 edge; Greg Hughes, 98-91, and Joe Garcia, 97-92. Foreman is 64-2 with 60 knockouts. Martin is 17-8-1.(AP)

title: Request in Iran-Contra Case
description: Lawrence E. Walsh, the independent prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair, asked a Federal judge today to dismiss the most serious charges against John M. Poindexter, President Ronald Reagan's national security adviser. Mr. Walsh's request is intended to avoid a legal battle over Government secrets that Mr. Poindexter's attorneys might want to introduce as defense evidence. The judge, Harold Greene, said he would rule within a few days. The request would eliminate charges of conspiracy, theft and fraud but leave intact charges of obstructing and lying to Congress.

description: ''I don't think I can do this,'' says Ben Loy, seen discreetly in bed with his wife. ''I just feel like everybody's watching us.'' In New York's Chinatown in 1949, all eyes are, metaphorically and often literally, on this young couple's fragile marriage. How they survive lethal doses of well-intended scrutiny carries the plot of ''Eat a Bowl of Tea,'' Wayne Wang's wry, irreverent, endearing new comedy of crosscultural manners.

title: Auctions

Spurred by these record prices, other owners have now consigned uncommon examples of animation art and timepieces to New York auction houses. Two sales - animation art at Christie's East and wristwatches at Sotheby's - are to take place, coincidentally, on the same day: Oct. 31.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY EARLY BATMAN Nearly two generations before Michael Keaton and Kim Basinger arrived in Gotham City, the original Batman (with Robin) was righting wrongs in America's movie theaters every Saturday afternoon. The 1943 serial of the Caped Crusader and 80 of both the most famous and least known fantasy and science-fiction feature films, are being shown through Sept. 21 at Film Forum 2, 57 Watts Street. This seemingly all-encompassing Summer Festival of Fantasy, Horror and Science Fiction will include such movies as Robert Wiene's ''Cabinet of Dr. Caligari,'' Werner Herzog's ''Nosferatu,'' a high-tech Japanese animated feature called ''Laputa: Castle in the Sky'' and the Dr. Seuss fantasy ''The 5,000 Fingers of Dr. T.'' The opening work in the series, ''Carnival of Souls,'' a 1962 cult film by Harold Harvey about an auto-accident survivor pursued by a ghoulish-looking man, runs through tonight, with Jacques Tourneur's ''Curse of the Demon'' (1962) and the first of 15 chapters of ''Batman'' on the bill. The festival -which will be Film Forum's last before it moves to a new theater in SoHo early next year - will also include such 3-D classics as ''Creature From the Black Lagoon'' (Tuesday and Wednesday), ''House of Wax'' (Aug. 4 to 7) and ''Cat Women of the Moon'' (Sept. 19 to 21), and theater seats will be wired to re-create the 1950's audience-tingling gimmick known as Percepto for screenings of ''The Tingler'' (Aug. 4 to 10). Tickets are $6. Information: 431-1590. CIRCUS WITH LESSONS

But new genetic tests that Mr. Chaplin might well have welcomed are taking paternity decisions away from juries, closing the files before the cases even get to court.

description: Saatchi & Saatchi DFS/Pacific has promoted Joe Cronin to president and chief operating officer of the agency's office in Torrance, Calif. Stan Becker was named vice chairman and chief creative director of the agency, while Nelson Riddle, Robert Cormier and Robert Hatfield were named executive vice presidents.

title: Florida East Coast Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Sea Sanitizers Get Summonses and Smiles
description: It started Wednesday with a 4 A.M. telephone call to Mayor Joyce P. Gould. Five local businessmen wanted permission to throw chlorine tablets - tablets commonly used to purify swimming pools -into the Atlantic Ocean.

title: 2 Congressmen Deal Blows to Nomination for Top Civil Rights Post
description: Further doubt was cast today on the confirmation prospects of William C. Lucas, the Bush Administration's nominee to head the Justice Department's civil rights division, when an important Congressional ally withdrew his endorsement.

title: Precision Aerotech reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Inland Steel Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain from tax-loss carryforwards of $13,240,000. The most recent quarter included a pre-tax charge of $17 million from the settlement of a claim made by Koppers Co. in conjunction with an earlier settlement and judgment obtained by Indland against Koppers. On an after- tax basis, the charge equals 30 cents a share.

title: Trade-School Owner Is Held in Fraud
description: The owner of a chain of vocational schools was arraigned yesterday on charges that he stole $63,000 in Government student-loan money as part of what prosecutors said was a ''massive fraud'' that may have totaled as much as $4 million nationwide.

title: Boy, 9, Is Shot in a Stairwell
description: A 9-year-old boy was shot in the head and critically wounded yesterday in a stairwell in an East Harlem apartment building, and a 30-year-old man was arrested in the incident, the police said. The victim was taken to Metropolitan Hospital. The police said the boy was sitting with friends in a stairwell at 2075 Third Avenue when a man carrying a gun came running down the stairs. The man, identified as David Cohen, who lives in the building, was carrying a .38-caliber revolver, which discharged and struck the boy, the police said. Mr. Cohen was charged with first-degree assault and criminal possession of a deadly weapon.

title: Willcox & Gibbs Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Ralph Henderson, 62, Ex-J.C. Penney Officer
description: Ralph B. Henderson, a retired execu-tive vice president of the J. C. Penney Company, died of cardiac arrest Wednesday at New York Hospital in Manhattan. He was 62 years old and had homes in Manhattan and Bedminster, N.J.

title: Pittston Co. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a tax credit of $4,493,000, or 12 cents a share, and $4,327,000, or 11 cents a share, for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Rescue and Deal Are Set For No. 6 Bank in Texas
description: Federal regulators tonight selected a group headed by a longtime Texas bank executive, Ronald G. Steinhart, to acquire the troubled operations of Texas American Bancshares Inc. in a deal that requires $900 million from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

title: Buck Clayton Still Searches For Jazz With That Swing
description: Buck Clayton, one of jazz's greatest trumpeters, is the type of person who can stop a room cold with his grace. Tall and thin, he exudes the elegance of someone who has seen his share of the world and has found most of it to his liking.

title: 30-Year Debentures Offered By Alcan Aluminum Unit
description: The Alcan Aluminum Corporation, a subsidiary of Alcan Aluminum Ltd. of Montreal, yesterday offered $150 million of 30-year sinking-fund debentures through an underwriting syndicate led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Review/Theater; 'Play to Win,' a Musical About the Integration of Baseball
description: Theaterworks/USA has opened its first monthlong season of free summer theater for young and family audiences with ''Play to Win,'' a snappy one-hour musical about how baseball became a truly all-American game when Jackie Robinson won a contract with the Brooklyn Dodgers in 1947.

title: In Shift, MAI Offers To Buy Part of Prime
description: In the ninth month of its efforts to acquire Prime Computer Inc., MAI Basic Four Inc. took a new tack today, offering to buy only Prime's minicomputer business for $450 million in cash and $150 million in debentures.

title: Cardinal Distribution Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a gain of $4,745,000 on the sale of discontinued operations.

title: Setting the Ground Rules For a Dance Improvisation
description: ''Suspect Terrain'' is a piece that might have been waiting to happen. The new dance, which will be performed this weekend and next Thursday through Sunday at the Pepsico Summerfare festival at the State University College at Purchase, N.Y., represents an unusual coming together of artists from a variety of nations and fields. Commissioned by the festival, ''Suspect Terrain'' is most visibly the work of Steve Paxton, Dana Reitz and Laurie Booth - experimentalist choreographers from the United States and England who are known to New York audiences as solo performers of extraordinary intensity - and Polly Motley, a choreographer based in Boulder, Colo.

title: Softech Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31

title: Dayal Kaur Khalsa, Author, Is Dead at 46
description: Dayal Kaur Khalsa, an author and illustrator of children's books, died of breast cancer Monday at her home in Vancouver, British Columbia. She was 46 years old.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''For the new century, back to the Moon, back to the future, and this time back to stay. And then, a journey into tomorrow, a journey to another planet, a manned mission to Mars.'' - President Bush. [ A1:6. ]

As a result, Neoax said it would consolidate Envirosafe in Neoax financial statements, causing a one-time charge of about $4 million against third-quarter results. Envirosafe's shares rose 37.5 cents today, to $14.875, in over-the-counter trading while Neoax slipped 12.5 cents, to $10.875.

title: Clean-Air Debate Heads to Congress
description: With President Bush scheduled to send Congress details of his proposals for a new clean-air law today, New York officials are calling for tough new auto-pollution controls.

title: Tough Task For Gilbert In Davis Cup
description: Five days ago, Brad Gilbert was taking a nap in his Alameda, Calif., home, just back from an exhibition tennis tournament in Tokyo and planning on 10 days off before a road tour that would take him to 9 cities in 10 weeks. His vacation ended abruptly, however, after a phone call from the United States Davis Cup captain, Tom Gorman, woke him.

title: Mozart Piano Concerto
description: Mitsuko Uchida, the pianist, will be the soloist with the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra in Mozart's Concerto No. 9 in E flat (K. 271) tonight at 8 o'clock at Avery Fisher Hall. The all-Mozart program, which will be conducted by Peter Maag, also includes the Symphony No. 1 in A (K. 16a) and Symphony No. 40 in C (K. 551) and the Flute Concerto No. 1 in G. Paula Robison will be the flute soloist. Remaining tickets are $9. Information: 874-6770.

Year-ago second quarter and 6-month results included a gain of $35 million, or 13 cents a share, from the sale of the electricity control and transformers division of Schlumberger Industries.

The 1988 results have been restated to include this business as a distributed operation.

title: Abortion Rights Backers Adopt Tactics of Politics
description: At the urging of a small army of poll takers, media advisers and consultants, leaders of the abortion rights movement have modified their message to appeal to the millions of Americans who feel deep conflict about abortion and are uneasy with some of the movement's old arguments.

Accordingly, the Laminated Products business has been reported as discontinued operations and previously reported financial statements have been reclassified. Figures for 1988 were restated to reflect the sale of the company's laminated plastics business during the 1989 first quarter.

No Novice for Civil Rights Chief

That may explain many of the nominee's absurd answers to members of the Senate Judiciary Committee trying to learn whether he is qualified. The senators found a personable black politician, but hardly the knowledgeable civil rights lawyer the job requires.

title: Czar's Wines to Be Auctioned at Sotheby's
description: Sotheby's of London announced yesterday that a cache of 13,000 bottles of wine from Massandra, once the personal cellar of Czar Nicholas II, is to be sold at auction in London in March 1990. The auction will include 24 wines from 1917, the year of the Russian Revolution, and over 1,000 wines dated before 1918, 62 of which bear the Imperial seal and are embossed with the Imperial double-headed eagle. Vintages tasted by Churchill and Roosevelt at the Yalta Conference will also be put on the block. The sale was arranged by the Soviet Government.

The cast includes Christine Seitz and Jennifer Ringo, sopranos; Michael Sylvester, a tenor; Max Witges, a bass-baritone, and Peter Van Derick, a baritone. Tickets are $10 to $30. Information and directions: (914) 232-5035.

title: Review/Pop; Gleeful, Grotesque Rock Of Moscow Underground
description: Brigada S., a nine-member band that came up from Moscow's rock underground, brought its jaunty, ominous, gleeful, grotesque rock to the Limelight on Monday night. The music tilts between bouncy, jazz-flavored tunes featuring a horn section and British-tinged, danceable rock (a la Roxy Music's ''Love Is the Drug''), both bent into very Russian-sounding minor keys laced with modern dissonances. While the tunes are crisp and catchy, the band has a greater asset - Igor Sukachev, its lead singer, whose wild-eyed theatricality commands the stage.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; SUMMER FIRST AID
description: Summertime recreation can be risky: emergency-room visits increase by 10 percent in July and August. Bee or jellyfish stings should be monitored carefully for allergic reactions, but beyond this precaution, much of the wear and tear of this active outdoor season can be treated with the contents of a well-stocked first-aid kit. Blisters: if all presure can be relieved - by staying off your feet, for example - leave the blister unbroken. Otherwise, wash with soap and water, make a hole at the base with a sterlized needle, drain, and apply a sterile dressng. If the blister is already broken, wash, bandage, and watch for infection. Poison ivy, oak, sumac: Remove contaminated clothing. Wash exposed areas with soap and water, and apply rubbing alcohol. Use soothing lotion like calamine until condition runs its course, usually in two to three weeks. If rash is severe, see a doctor. Bee stings: Remove the stinger with tweezers, or scrape it away with a credit card, Wash with soap and water, and apply cold to reduce swelling and pain. Call an ambulance if hives, nausea, vomiting, widespread swelling, labored breathing or dizziness develop. Jellyfish stings: Gently remove tentacles with a towel, then wash with diluted ammonia or rubbing alcohol. If symptoms are severe, see a doctor. Water, sand in ear: Flush with a vinegar-based preparation like Swimear. If tenderness develops, see a doctor. sources: American Red Cross; 3M First Aid; Dr. Ariadna Papageorge of Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital.

title: Duty-Free Isn't Always a Bargain
description: When Susan Bacon of Washington was going on vacation to Paris a month ago, she decided to treat herself to an Hermes scarf. She checked with the Hermes boutique in New York City and found that scarfs were selling there for $175, plus tax. They cost $160 at the duty-free shop at Kennedy International Airport in New York and $150 through the in-flight duty-free shopping service provided by Continental Airlines, about the same as at the Hermes boutique in Paris. Finally, at Charles de Gaulle Airport, outside Paris, she found a scarf she liked for $129.

title: RESULTS PLLUS
description: GOLF Alcott Shares Lead: Amy Alcott just missed an eagle at the 18th hole, settled for par and shared the second-round lead at the L.P.G.A. Boston Five Classic yesterday at Danvers, Mass., with Penny Hammel, Shirley Furlong and Cathy Marino. All were at eight-under-par 136, one stroke ahead of Beth Daniel and two ahead of Kathy Postlewait and Cindy Rarick. Alcott, seeking her 28th victory in 15 years on the tour but without a victory this year, was pleased with her second straight 68 despite missing a chance to take a two-stroke lead. Alcott had cleared a large pond and was about 30 yards from the hole in two shots on the 485-yard, par-5 final hole. Her pitch hit the pin, then the cup, but rolled about six feet away. She missed the putt that would have given her a one-stroke lead. Hammel, who shared the first-round lead with Postlewait at five-under 67, shot 69 yesterday. Marino matched her career-best of 67 and Furlong had a 66. (AP) Byrum Is in Hunt: Curt Byrum, looking for his first victory in seven years on the PGA Tour, beat the wind and rain to finish with a three-under-par 67 yesterday and take the second-round lead in the Hardee's Classic in Coal Valley, Ill. Byrum, who shot a 66 Thursday, had three birdies and played his second straight bogey-free round. He finished just before a storm hit the Oakwood Country Club course. The foul weather, a constant on the PGA Tour this year, suspended play for more than an hour in the late afternoon. Showers also delayed the start of the round for an hour. Byrum's seven-under 133 total was a stroke better than the defending champion, Blaine McCallister, and Greg Ladehoff. McCallister had a 69, his sixth stright sub-par round at the Hardee's tournament, while Ladehoff, from nearby Clinton, Iowa, had a score of 65. (AP) Unexpected Co-leader: Chick Evans, a last-minute entrant, birdied six straight holes on the back nine yesterday for a six-under-par 66 and a share of the first-round lead in the first Ameritech Senior Open in Cleveland. The co-leader is Dick Ryhan. Evans, who has never won on the PGA Senior Tour, was not in the 72-player field originally; he did not find out he was playing until Bob Goalby dropped out Tuesday night. His birdie string is the longest on the Senior Tour this season. Evans, 44th in winnings this year with $44,643, was even par on the 6,615-yard, par-72 Canterbury Golf Club after missing a five-footer for birdie on No. 11. But he hit a pitching wedge to 6 feet and sank a birdie putt at 12, followed with a two-putt birdie on the par-5 13th hole and then hit a pitching wedge to within 2 inches of the cup on 14 for another birdie. He sandwiched 35-foot putts for birdies at 15 and 17 around a 4-footer on No. 16 to run his streak to six. His string was broken on the final hole when his 20-foot birdie putt hit the cup and spun out. Charles Coody, a former Masters champion, and Harold Henning were one shot back at 67. (AP) TENNIS Garrison Advances: Top-seeded Zina Garrison led an advance of four seeded players into the semifinals of the $200,000 Virginia Slims of Newport tournament last night in Rhode Island. Garrison, ranked fifth in the world, beat Michelle Jaggard of Australia, 6-4, 6-1. She will face eighth-seeded Gigi Fernandez of Miami, who beat Laura Gildemeister, 6-3, 6-3. Second-seeded Pam Shriver rallied past Jill Hetherington, 6-4, 3-6, 6-2. Shriver, ranked 10th and champion in 1986 and 1987 of the tournament, the only United States grass-court stop on the women's tour, will face sixth-seeded Rosalyn Fairbank, a 7-6, 6-4 victor over Hu Na.(AP)

title: Henley's Fisher Bid
description: The Henley Group, a La Jolla, Calif., engineering concern, said it had renegotiated its agreement to buy the 19 percent of Fisher Scientific Group Inc. it does not own and now will pay $22.50 a share, or about $144 million. In June, Henley offered $20.50 a share, but the proposal generated several lawsuits from shareholders who contended that Fisher, a Pittsburgh-based laboratory parts manufacturer, was worth more money. The higher price was agreed to by Henley after negotiating with lawyers for the plaintiffs.

Mr. Barnes is an associate at the Edison law firm of Toolen, Abbott, Ziznewski & Hollander.

title: Social Security Faces a $60 Billion Question
description: The Social Security Trust Fund, on the verge of bankruptcy six years ago, has grown so robustly as a result of changes adopted then - tighter benefits and accelerated payroll tax increases - that it will run a surplus of close to $60 billion this year.

title: INSIDE
description: Siberian Miners' Misery Housing was at the top of the grievance lists of many Siberian miners who started the nationwide strike that has gripped the nation for two weeks. But many have returned to work disappointed. Page 12. Deng's Retirement Plans Deng Xiaoping has announced in an unpublished speech that he plans to retire, Chinese officials said. No timetable was announced. Page 9. Is a Tax Tradeoff Emerging? Recent talks raise the possibility that President Bush might agree to some tax increase in return for easing the tax on capital gains. Page 18. Merrill Lynch to Shift Jobs Merrill Lynch plans to move 250 more jobs to New Jersey from New York, officials said. Page 26.

title: THE OPENING OF THE AMERICAN MIND
description: Little is more surprising these days than the revival of blasphemy as a crime. A secular age had presumably relegated blasphemy - irreverence toward things sacred - to the realm of obsolete offenses.

title: Question Of the Week; Should Bo Jackson Give Up One Sport?
description: Why should he? A 26-year-old with such motor intelligence, desire, and professional opportunities would be a fool to do less than he is motivated to do. Bo Jackson excels at more than one sport, and he should continue to compete professionally as long as he is able to, both physically and psychologically. ROBIN M. ROSENTHAL New York

title: Nuclear Plants' Files Overwhelm Library
description: WHEN the Waterford Public Library agreed to be the repository of documents for the Millstone I nuclear energy plant 18 years ago, it was a matter of storing just a few file boxes in a closet. But with the torrent of paper that followed stricter Government regulations and the construction of two more nuclear plants on the Millstone site, the documents, which also include a microfiche collection and a reading machine, now fill 50 shelves in the library. And the library is saying, Enough!

title: August Wedding For Jill Anderson
description: The engagement of Jillese Marie Anderson and William Andrews Bedford, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert F. Bedford of New York and Ivy, Va., has been made known by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas R. Anderson of Salt Lake City. An August wedding is planned.
