title: Jazz and Folk Music Accompany Summer
description: LIGHT music and summer weather seem to be natural partners, and a number of jazz and folk-oriented concerts will be at hand, starting this evening at 6:30, when Bob Silvan and his Fine Line Jazz Ensemble will bring ''old jazz classics along with a share of new age music'' to the Guilford Green. The rain location is St. George Church Hall, on the west side of the green.

title: Corrections
description: The Practical Traveler column on March 19 included one state incorrectly in a list of United States jurisdictions that ban radar detectors in automobiles. Research for today's column on the subject (page 3) disclosed that they are banned in the District of Columbia (not Delaware), as well as Connecticut and Virginia.

title: With the Rain, Renewal and Loss
description: THE spring and summer have been a world of rain. The Eastern Seaboard, Connecticut, the Housatonic River Valley - all a world of rain.

title: Patchogue Debates the Fate of a 19th-Century Lace Mill
description: LEAD: CHARLES MILLER is among those who still remember the weaving rooms of the lace mill in Patchogue, a 19th-century complex of red brick buildings that may soon be razed for a shopping center.

title: Jet Signings
description: The Jets yesterday signed their fourth-round draft choice, Ron Stallworth, a 6-foot-5-inch, 262-pound defensive end from Auburn. He was the eighth of the Jets' 13 draft choices to sign and the highest among their picks.

title: Commissioner Must Know Football Now
description: When the original search committee was formed to recommend a replacement for the one and only Pete Rozelle, about to retire as commissioner of the National Football League, the first thing we did was to ask all 28 teams to submit in writing their thoughts and views and to offer names of possible candidates. From those letters we hoped to develop a profile that would serve as a prototype of the person we were seeking.

title: The Boat People Belong Here
description: LEAD: At the recent United Nations conference on Indochinese refugees in Geneva, Great Britain took the lead in calling for the forced deportation of the thousands of boat people living in refugee camps throughout Southeast Asia. Ominously, this idea seemed to receive significant support, despite being contrary to internationally recognized human rights standards.

title: 20 Die as Rocket Hits a Kabul Bazaar
description: A rocket hit a crowded bazaar in the heart of Kabul today, killing at least 20 people and wounding more than 100, hospital officials said.

title: EUROPEANS FEAR '92 ECONOMIC UNITY MAY BENEFIT MAFIA
description: As Italian businessmen eagerly await the new opportunities to be had after Western Europe's economic integration in 1992, law enforcement authorities here dread that some of the biggest benefits will fall to the Mafia and other criminal organizations.

title:
Body and Mind;
Suffering in Silence
description: LEAD: A YOUNG BOSTON COLLEGE PROFES-sor developed a serious knee problem that required surgery. After the operation, he lay in his hospital bed telling time by the pain. Within hours of receiving intravenous pain medication his knee would begin to ache again. By three and a half hours, the pain was excruciating - the worst he had ever known.

title: Danny DeVito Paints an American Gothic
description: Michael Douglas is a mess. His face is sweaty and unshaven, his greasy hair unkempt, and his expensive shirt looks as if Smokey the Bear used it as a pajama top. In his hand is a menacing automobile crank and on his face a look of the purest malevolence. ''Divorce,'' he says evenly, ''is a bitch.''

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: It goes without saying that $53.9 million (van Gogh's ''Irises''), $47.9 million (Picasso's ''Yo'' self-portrait) and $39.9 million (van Gogh's ''Sunflowers'') are slightly beyond most budgets and, in fact, almost beyond comprehension. Still, multimillion-dollar prices aren't uncommon today in the art world.

title: Tax 'Pinch' Explained
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Forever Silver Wins
description: Forever Silver may not be among the best horses ever to have won the Brooklyn Handicap, but he proved himself a determined and versatile performer with a 4 1/2-length victory yesterday at Belmont Park in the 101st edition of the race.

title: Repairs Promised For Park's Umbrella
description: LEAD: THE century-old umbrella of Larchmont Manor Park will be fixed. That's the word from Bruce Allen, a member of the Larchmont Manor Park Society who is also archivist of the Larchmont Historical Society.

title: Learning and Testing: The State's Role
description: I hope it is not too late to heed the warning implicit in Andrew Dunn's June 11 Opinion article, ''Test on Skills Is Warped.'' The author speaks for thousands of New Jersey teachers who see the proliferation of statewide testing as perhaps the most ill-advised attempt on the part of the state to monitor our classrooms. One has to look only across the Hudson to see in the theft and sale of current Regents exams the most recent fiasco attending statewide testing.

title: An Unhearable Message?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bryn Mawr's Book Trove
description: You didn't mention the Bryn Mawr Book Shop at 170 Grand Street in White Plains in your informative June 25 report on independent booksellers [ ''Perusing the Independent Booksellers'' ] . This shop has been selling used, rare and out-of-print books to appreciative customers for 14-and-a-half years, while contributing the proceeds to the Bryn Mawr College Scholarship Fund. Buyers come from all over the United States. One of them recently said the Bryn Mawr Shop is an American version of Shakespeare & Company of Paris.

title: Proper Path for Mobile Missiles
description: This week, Congress will try again, as it has for a decade, to decide what to do with the MX missile. The House is scheduled to vote on President Bush's proposal to move the missile out of silos and onto railroad cars so it can better survive attack. Mr. Bush also wants funds for Midgetman, a new and smaller missile that can be transported on specially designed trucks.

title: Ms. Woodstock Marries C. R. Pierce Jr.
description: At St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Church in Oyster Bay, L.I., Mary Martha Woodstock, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Steven Woodstock of East Norwich, L.I., was married yesterday to Charles R. Pierce Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Pierce of Lloyd Harbor, L.I. The Rev. Charles Ribaudo performed the ceremony.

title: Fund Commemorates Camp Director
description: LEAD: WARREN (CHIP) MATHEWS, supervisor of camping for the county's Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservation, was remembering his predecessor and former boss, the late Morton Hyman:

title: Peter Windett: Graphic Designer
description: Peter Windett, the 43-year-old graphic designer for Crabtree & Evelyn, which sells toiletries and foods in more than 170 shops in 6 countries, is a master of illusion. He creates instant tradition for new products, just as he did when he dreamed up the name of the company.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: RECENT RELEASES
description: CLASSICAL American Songs: Works by Paul Bowles, Lee Hoiby, Richard Hundley, Eric Klein, John Musto and Virgil Thomson William Sharp, baritone; Steven Blier, piano. New World NW 369; CD and LP. Lovers of the American art song have had a good year - first Jan DeGaetani's stunning ''Songs of America'' (Nonesuch 79178) and now this. Mr. Sharp has selected 24 songs written between 1935 and 1987, all tonal, consonant and lyrical. His lightness and purity of tone, clarity of diction and sensitivity to both textual and musical values make the entire collection a joy to explore, but the real discovery is a group of 11 songs by Paul Bowles. Now better known as a writer than as a composer, Mr. Bowles creates lilting, bluesy melodies, perfectly wedded to the cadences of everyday speech. His songs are an absolute delight. - K. Robert Schwarz Mozart: Piano Sonatas (K. 310, 332, 576) and Other Works Aleck Karis, piano. Bridge BCD 9011; CD and cassette. A fine young pianist with a varied repertory concentrates his efforts here on a cornucopia of Mozart: three great sonatas, the C minor Fantasy, the D major Rondo and three exquisite trifles - 77 minutes of sublime music, attractively rendered. Though playing a modern Steinway, Mr. Karis never storms the heavens. Even in the blustery moments of K. 310 and the Fantasy, he shows great restraint, though never losing energy and tautness. In K. 332's slow movement, his liquid legato occasionally produces a diffuse sonority somewhat akin to the glass-harmonica simulation of the concluding K. 617a Adagio, but on the whole, Mr. Karis's interpretations are most appealing - imaginative, supple and varied. - James R. Oestreich Richard Strauss: Songs Anton Dermota, tenor; Hilde Konetzni, soprano; Alfred Poell, baritone; Richard Strauss, piano. Preiser CD 93261; CD only. Round about his 80th birthday, in 1943, Richard Strauss taped some 40 songs in Vienna with singers who had appeared in his operas there. This CD offers 16, including several favorites. Let's hope the rest are on the way; these are most enjoyable and informative. The singing is not fabulous, but Dermota's tone is sweet, and Poell shows surprising suppleness and rhythmic alacrity. Several other pianists have played the songs with more virtuosity, though Strauss is never less than respectable; the wonderful thing is the way the playing gives the idea behind the score: a sense of dramatic tension when a new figuration appears, an accelerando that clarifies the point of destination, something in the pointing of the rhythm. . . . Must listening for all with more than a passing interest in Lieder. - Will Crutchfield Grieg: Symphony in C minor and Other Works Gothenburg Symphony Orchestra conducted by Neeme Jarvi. Deutsche Grammophon 427 321; CD only. Grieg composed his symphony at 20, fresh out of the Leipzig Conservatory. After a few performances, he withdrew it in 1867, forbidding all future performances (an injunction honored until 1981). Why the secrecy? The ardent nationalist had written a tiptop German symphony, orthodox in style and lacking the slightest glimmer of the Northern Lights he strove thereafter to capture. Though not particularly individual, it is energetic and fresh-sounding. More striking and characteristic are the other works here, the overture ''In Autumn,'' the ''Old Norwegian Romance'' and the ''Funeral March in Memory of Nordraak.'' All are played splendidly under Mr. Jarvi. - Barrymore L. Scherer Symphonies Nos. 1-3, 'Pro et Contra,' 'Perpetuum Mobile' Frans Helmerson, cello; Bamberg Symphony Orchestra conducted by Neeme Jarvi. Bis CD-434; CD only. Today Arvo Part's music is admired for its spiritual repose, its hushed stasis and its almost minimalist simplicity. But before his study of medieval music in the early 70's, Mr. Part was a very different composer. All the works recorded here were written during the years between 1963 and 1971, when Mr. Part eagerly explored avant-garde techniques - ranging from serialism, ''chance'' music and quotation to coloristic densities that recall his fellow East Europeans Ligeti and Penderecki. But it is the unremitting savagery and dramatic thrust of these early works that is most surprising. Only the Symphony No. 3 (1971), absorbed in medieval and Renaissance polyphony, hints at the future. The performances are vigorous and deeply committed. - K.R.S. POP/JAZZ Sarah Brightman: 'The Songs That Got Away' Polygram 422-839116; all three formats. The selections in this astutely chosen collection of mostly little-known theater songs include such gems as ''Meadowlark'' from ''The Baker's Wife,'' and ''I Remember'' from the early Sondheim show ''Evening Primrose.'' Also included are songs from the English musicals ''Bless the Bride,'' ''The Crooked Mile'' and ''Jeeves,'' the last (''Half a Moment'') with music by the singer's husband, Andrew Lloyd Webber. Miss Brightman's light-operatic style epitomizes the formal, nonidiomatic approach to musical-comedy songs typical of British theater singers. Her voice is pretty but often thin in texture and occasionally too piercing. Instead of communicating passion and verve, Ms. Brightman maintains a tone of elevated decorum that is agreeable but ultimately proves unexciting. - Stephen Holden Al Green: 'Too Much Joy' A&M 5228; all three formats. Al Green, one of America's finest singers, left secular soul music for gospel in the mid-70's, but he still glances over the borderline. ''Too Much Joy'' juxtaposes older, tambourine-beating gospel and slow-building hymns with Mr. Green's own loping Memphis funk and a few fairly trendy, synthesizer-tinged modern arrangements. Yet while ''You Are My Everything'' could be interpreted as a secular love ballad, most of the album makes its pious message clear. Mr. Green's voice, gliding and curving and soaring around the lyrics as if in a private reverie, is the sound of a lone supplicant, gently testifying to the comforts of faith. - Jon Pareles Nashville All-Stars: 'After the Riot at Newport' Bear Family; CD and LP (Sunshine Records, 508 Colorado Avenue, Stuart, Fla. 34994). In 1960, George Wein invited a group of Nashville studio musicians - Boots Randolf on saxophones, Hank Garland and Chet Atkins on guitars, the 17-year-old Gary Burton on vibes, and others - to the Newport Jazz Festival. The festival was canceled because of rioting, so instead of playing onstage, the band recorded an album, which until this reissue has been extremely rare. The performances - which the musicians, according to Rich Kienzle's terrific liner notes, disavow - are satisfactory and then some. Relaxed and swinging, it's classic be-bop-influnced jazz. And with a handful of solos by Brenton Banks, a violinist and pianist, and Mr. Garland, one of the greatest jazz guitarists ever, the album becomes more than a well-meaning footnote to jazz history. - Peter Watrous 'Anderson, Bruford, Wakeman, Howe' Arista AL85-90126; all three formats It's a tough, mostly futile search for melodies on the putative debut album by Jon Anderson, Bill Bruford, Rick Wakeman and Steve Howe - the singer, drummer, keyboardist and guitarist, respectively, from the most popular lineup of the British band Yes. (Other former members hold the Yes band name trademark.) The Yes-men still dispense multipart songs featuring Mr. Anderson's piping voice and nebulous homilies (''We hold our hands together / Be the sunshine''), Mr. Wakeman's quasi-classical pomp, Mr. Howe's high filigrees and Mr. Bruford's fluency in odd meters. ''Teakbois'' attempts French Antillean zouk, laughably, but the Yes-men mostly parody their older work with busy, virtuosic, glowingly recorded filler. - J.P. Babyface: 'Tender Lover' Solar FZ45288; all three formats. There is much satisfaction to be derived from the skillful working of a genre, and this is nothing if not genre music. Babyface (Kenny Edmonds), who along with his partner L. A. Reid, is one of pop's more successful producers and songwriters, has a nice melodic touch; surprising, lithe melodies sneak out from around corners. Otherwise he follows the rules of silken black pop, with overtones of Prince and Michael Jackson. Love songs, of the basically dumb variety, let Babyface's thin voice quiver and shake a bit. With lots of synthesizer gloss, it's music of opulence, and clarity; his melodies snake their way through rolling bass lines. Originality, or depth, isn't the point; Babyface writes perfect songs of the genre, slightly anonymous but delivering the pleasure they're supposed to, until the next hit. - P.W.

title: Crash Award is $64.5 Million
description: The Massachusetts Port Authority has been ordered to pay $62.9 million to World Airways for its liability in a 1982 plane crash at Logan International Airport. Federal District Judge Robert E. Keeton also ruled Friday that the airline could recover an additional $1.6 million from the Federal Government for the crash in which two people died when a DC-10 slid off an icy runway into Boston Harbor.

title: The Village Shop Flourishes in Rye
description: How fleeting is fame won from the pages of Westchester Weekly!

title:
ART;
Pairing and Then Comparing
description: LEAD: MUSEUMS frequently present thematic exhibitions in which related works by a number of artists are grouped according to subject matter or style. In such shows, viewers are encouraged to make comparisons among the various treatments of the theme, and to notice the contrasting approaches that artists may take when handling similar material.

title: T. F. Doyle Wed To Miss Mackie
description: Shevaun Maria Elizabeth Mackie, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Mackie of Irvington-on-Hudson, N.Y., and Groton Long Point, Conn., was married yesterday in Irvington-on-Hudson to Thomas Frederick Doyle, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Doyle of West Falmouth, Mass. The Rev. Timothy J. Scannell officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception.

title: Italy Has New Government With Andreotti at Head
description: Two months of infighting within Italy's five-party ruling coalition ended today when Giulio Andreotti, who has already been Prime Minister five times, succeeded in forming this country's 49th postwar Government.

title: LONG ISLAND OPINIONPrice of Progress: One Pea Patch
description: THERE used to be a wooded lot on the corner of Route 25A and Norwood Avenue in Northport. There had been a house there once, years ago, the remnants of its foundation long overgrown with weeds and scrub. All along the edge of the lot grew sweet peas.

title: Lilco Enters a Nuclear-Free Future
description: LEAD: WHEN the Long Island Lighting Company announced recently that it had completed a 240-megawatt oil-powered turbine plant adjacent to the 800-megawatt Shoreham nuclear power plant, answers about Long Island's energy future seemed to be emerging.

title: PASTIMES: Numismatics
description: ''Greenbacks'' were the first United States paper money issued for general circulation and, like a lot of other countries' paper money, they came about because of financial difficulties.

title: PASTIMES: Bridge
description: The Bermuda Bowl contest in Perth, Australia, is two months away, but the cognoscenti are predicting a final between the United States and Poland. Both teams are exempt from qualifying play and will be in the semifinal round against teams that will have struggled for a week to reach that point.

title: Never Too Early for Cuomo Not To Throw His Hat in the Ring
description: ONLY one thing, it seems, starts earlier than today's stamina-testing Presidential campaigns, and that is the speculation over whether Gov. Mario M. Cuomo will be a candidate.

title: Sarah Lee Plans August Wedding
description: Dr. and Mrs. John E. Lee of Atlanta have announced August wedding plans for their daughter, Sarah Everett Lee, and Louis Goodman Elson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward E. Elson of Atlanta and New York.

title: On a Desolate Beach in Queens, a Point of Departure
description: If there could be any doubt that the common wisdom about how large-scale housing developments are made in this country has changed, a look at the latest proposal for a very large housing complex in New York City, a plan for 10,000 units in the Arverne area of Queens, should dispel it. If it goes ahead, the Arverne project will be the largest single housing development in New York since Co-op City in the Bronx went up more than 20 years ago, and the two could not be more different.

title: Leggings: Covering a Multitude of Shins
description: Once again, what started as a fad among the young and the lissome has become a fashion staple. Now, leggings are stepping out everywhere.

title: To Buy - or Lease - Your Next Car
description: As car dealers gear up for the 1990 models, which are due in the showrooms starting about Sept. 1, consumers face a perplexing decision: whether to buy or lease.

title: Query Trails Flight 232: Just How Many Took It?
description: Responding to mounting questions about its ability to assess injuries and the loss of life in the crash of its DC-10 jet here Wednesday, United Airlines said today it was confident that it had correctly calculated the number of people on board the airliner: 296, including 285 passengers and 11 crew members.

title: SUSPENDED PRIEST ASSAILS UNIVERSITY
description: A black Washington priest suspended by the Roman Catholic Church for starting a breakaway black congregation says a major church-run university has discriminated against blacks.

title: Gretchen Bowers Becomes a Bride
description: Gretchen Lind Bowers, a daughter of Ann Lind Bowers of Far Hills, N.J., and Philip James Bowers 3d of Bedminster, N.J., was married yesterday to Kevin Fallon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Hatton Fallon of Amagansett, L.I. The Rev. Peter J. Garry officiated at St. Brigid Roman Catholic Church in Peapack, N.J.

title: Church Must Look at Causes of Clergy Shortage
description: To the Editor:

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Nothing but Whirl Inside

title: Workers Have Indeed United, As if on a Dare by Gorbachev
description: ''ALAS, over the past few years there has been less trade union activity,'' President Mikhail S. Gorbachev fairly sighed two years ago in mid-flight through the various rosy challenges he put to the Soviet masses in his book, ''Perestroika.'' Suddenly, as if poor Yorick responded in the grasp of Hamlet, the Soviet coal miner has now emerged from his dark pit to demand a new life.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf McCallister Regains Lead: Blaine McCallister, attempting to become the first player to defend his title successfully here in 17 years, regained the lead yesterday in the third round of the $700,000 Hardee's Classic in Coal Valley, Ill. McCallister, who was the first-round leader with a five-under 65, shot a 67 for a 54-hole total of nine-under 201. That put him a stroke ahead of Curt Byrum, John Adams and Lonnie Clements, all of whom are looking for their first victory on the PGA Tour. Byrum shot a 69 for 202, while Adams and Clements fired 67's. McCallister rolled in a 20-foot putt from the edge of the green on No. 14 and holed a 35-footer with a chip shot from the rough on No. 16 to go 10 under par. He bogeyed No. 17, but finished with six birdies and three bogeys. McCallister has an opportunity to become the first player to defend his title successfully since Deane Beman, now the PGA commissioner, won in 1971 and 1972, when the tourney was called the Quad Cities Open.(AP) One-Stroke Lead for Henning: Harold Henning shot a four-under-par 68 yesterday to take a one-stroke lead after two rounds of the Ameritech Senior Open in Cleveland. Henning, fifth on the PGA Senior Tour money list, was at nine-under-par 135 after 36 holes at the Canterbury Golf Club, one shot ahead of Jimmy Powell, who shot his second successive 68. Bruce Crampton shot a 67 for 137. (AP) Alcott Maintains Lead: Amy Alcott shot her third consecutive four-under-par 68 to take a two-stroke lead after yesterday's third round of the Ladies' Professional Golf Association Boston Five Classic at Danvers, Mass. With only one bogey in her last 45 holes, Alcott, who needs just three victories to get into the L.P.G.A. Hall of Fame, was at 12-under 204 on a day when her top competitors could not match her consistency. Shirley Furlong birdied the last two holes after bogeying the 16th and finished with 70 for a 206 at the 6,008-yard, par-72 Tara Ferncroft Country Club course. Tied at 207 were Cathy Marino, Jody Rosenthal and Patty Sheehan, who bogeyed the final hole after topping her second shot with a three-wood and rolling it into a pond. Sheehan and Rosenthal shot 68's and Marino had a 71.(AP) Horse Racing Nashwan Finishes Sweep: Nashwan edged Cacoethes by a neck to win the King George VI stakes yesterday in Ascot, England, and become the first horse to sweep the four major events of the English season. Nashwan, who had won the 2,000 Guineas, the Derby and the Eclipse, held off Cacoethes in a dramatic stretch run in the mile-and-a-half race to win $350,000 for his owner, Hamdan Al-Maktoum. The 3-year-old was ridden by Willie Carson. Nashwan retained his unbeaten record as he and Cacoethes, a son of Alydar, finished seven lengths ahead of the rest of the field.(AP) Auto Racing Fittipaldi Gains Pole: Emerson Fittipaldi earned his second pole position in two weeks, smashing his track record yesterday to take the top qualifying spot for today's Indy-car race in Toronto. Fittipaldi, who set a track record in winning the pole last week at the Meadowlands, did it again yesterday on Toronto's 1.78-mile 11-turn temporary circuit with a lap of 107.699 miles per hour in a Chevrolet-powered Penske PC18. Al Unser Jr., the defending champion, moved from seventh in Friday's qualifying to second, improving from 105.248 to 106.548 m.p.h. Danny Sullivan also made a big improvement, jumping from eighth at 105.154 to 106.539 and third place.(AP) Tennis Shriver to Face Garrison: Zina Garrison and Pam Shriver, gold-medal winners in the doubles at last year's Summer Olympics, will face each other in today's finals of the $200,000 Virginia Slims tournament in Newport, R.I. Shriver, seeded second, needed a third-set tie breaker to defeat Ros Fairbank, 3-6, 6-3, 7-6, yesterday. Garrison, the top seeded player, defeated No. 8 Gigi Fernandez, 6-4, 6-3, in the other semifinal.(AP) Davis Upsets Goldie: Scott Davis of Largo, Fla., upset top-seeded Dan Goldie, 3-6, 6-4, 6-1, yesterday in their semifinal match at the $200,000 OTB International tournament in Schenectady, N.Y. The fourth-seeded Davis earned a spot in today's final and will meet Simon Youl of Tasmania, who defeated Glenn Michibata of Canada, 3-6, 7-6, 7-6. (AP) Paz and Zrubakova Reach Final: Mercedes Paz of Argentina and Radka Zrubakova of Czechoslovakia won semifinal matches at the Belgian Open in Brussels yesterday. Paz defeated Manon Bollegraf of the Netherlands, 6-7, 6-4, 6-3, and Zrubakova beat Nicole Jagerman of the Netherlands, 6-3, 6-1.(AP) Dogs Bee's Best in Show: A 3-year-old pointer, Ch. Luftnase Ablelarm Bee's Knees, was selected yesterday as best of 1,271 dogs at the 36th all-breed show of the Putnam Kennel Club on the Ward Pound Ridge Reservation in Cross River, N.Y. Bee's, as she is called by her owners, Isabel Robson and Michael Zollo, who does the handling, now has 28 top awards. Last weekend she won the National Specialty in Portland, Ore., and two all-breed events in Oregon. Soccer Poland Defeats Guatemala: Ruch Chorzow of Poland defeated the Guatemala national team, 4-0, to take third place in the Marlboro Cup of Chicago tournament yesterday.

title: Williams's Camp Criticizes Referee
description: The consequences of one referee's decision continued to be the subject of debate a day after Mike Tyson retained his heavyweight title by stopping Carl (the Truth) Williams just 93 seconds into their scheduled 12-round bout Friday night.

title: NONFICTION
description: POETRY AND THE WORLD. By Robert Pinsky. (Ecco, $19.95.) Robert Pinsky, who confesses in ''Poetry and the World'' to ''a kind of pitying mistrust toward all literary criticism,'' nonetheless brings his distinguished credentials as a man of letters to bear on that double cosmos of his title. Academia today requires that a batch of essays like this one - all the pieces have been previously published, in a variety of contexts - insist on its integral status as a book, rather than a collection. Readers will find instruction and delight richly mixed in his jargon-free analyses. The author's sensitivity, as a distinguished practicing poet, to poetry's social issues - not so much of subject matter as of audience - leads him to brilliant illuminations of idiom, tone and range of diction in (mostly) American poetry. Trust his literary introductions; to read with him Philip Freneau's ''Indian Burying Ground,'' Marianne Moore's ''Steeple-Jack,'' E. A. Robinson's ''Eros Turannos'' or Frank O'Hara's ''Ave Maria'' is to savor the fine precision of response that our modern critics tend, habitually and regrettably, to devalue. Generalizations, now in critical ascendancy, also appear: ''The act of judgment prior to the vision of any poem is . . . a resistance or transformation of communal values'' or '' [ as ] the art that pulls verbal abstraction into its bodily frame, poetry is the most insistently physical art.'' If the arguments that sustain these broad assertions are less urgent and eloquent than Mr. Pinsky's close readings, yet they widen our reflection. Even the autobiographical digressions demonstrate a heartening sense of vocation. Mr. Pinsky's honorable practice confirms the dignity and creative dimension of, in Matthew Arnold's prescient formulation, the function of criticism at the present time.

title: On the Second Shift
description: To the Editor:

title: When the Lady In Question Is a Man
description: Last year, when Kyle Renick, the artistic director of the WPA Theater, was searching for a playwright to inaugurate the theater's ''Silly Series,'' he thought of Charles Busch. As the ''leading lady'' of Theater-in-Limbo, a gender-blind troupe known for playing high comic characters in low farce, Mr. Busch seemed a good choice to kick off a series designed to coax a young audience to the WPA. Since his ''Vampire Lesbians of Sodom'' opened in 1985 at the Provincetown Playhouse (where it is still running), the 34-year-old playwright had ribbed Off Broadway with such irreverent works as ''Psycho Beach Party,'' ''Times Square Angel'' and ''Theodora, She-Bitch of Byzantium.''

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Northwestern; Tradition Crumbles, Students Grumble
description: It's tradition for Northwestern University students to cheer on a losing football team, to muddle through harsh Chicago winters and paint a rock set in the campus courtyard. But traditions can be broken, or in this case, cracked.

title: IF THE WALL CAME TUMBLING DOWN
description: Peter Schneider suggests, in his article ''If the Wall Came Tumbling Down'' (June 25), that Germans on both sides of the Berlin wall have a vested interest in maintaining the secured border. This is nothing new. In fact, the division of Germany by military force was first proposed by the West Germans.

title: MANTLE AND HERSCHKOPF THE PSYCHIATRIST
description: Mickey Mantle offered his head to Herschkopf the Psychiatrist for inspection. It happened like this:

title: Curtain-Raiser In North Loop
description: CHICAGO'S efforts to bolster its faded theater district in the North Loop are advancing as developers look to the area for future office growth.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS/HISTORY
description: THE WAR AT HOME. By Connie Jordan Green. (Margaret K. McElderry, $12.95. Ages 8 to 12) There is more than one battle raging in Connie Jordan Green's novel, but the one with the most impact on her 13-year-old heroine, Mattie McDowell, is the war with the Japanese. The time is 1944, and Mattie and her family have moved from Kentucky to Oak Ridge, Tenn., where Mr. McDowell has been assigned a top-secret job. Ms. Green vividly portrays the mystery of the newly created town and also its claustrophobia, which resulted from families cramped into small, boxy houses. That trapped feeling is heightened for Mattie when her cousin, Virgil, comes to spend several months with her family. Although the novel then focuses on private wars - Mattie squabbling with Virgil, Virgil fending off a school bully, the boy's n'er-do-well father trying to regain control over him - the reader never loses the sense of the real purpose behind Oak Ridge. Unfortunately, Ms. Green's attempts to deal with the ethical issues she poses are less successful. Mattie and Virgil make their peace, but neither has fully thought out their differences, many of which revolve around the appropriate use of violence. This is a shame, since the 1940's presented the greatest moral dilemma of our time: Does ending a war justify killing millions of civilians with a nuclear weapon? But although ''The War at Home'' raises more questions than it answers, Ms. Green conveys both a sense of the period and the conviction that ethical decisions are not always easy or clear-cut.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: ARTS FESTIVAL FORTNIGHT

title:
GARDENING;
Factors That Make Beautiful Flowers Ugly
description: LEAD: MOST flowers are admired for their delicate beauty, yet their fragile nature exposes them to problems that may mar their beauty and render them unattractive.

title: By JOHN A. ADAM; John A. Adam is a Washington journalist covering national security.
description: SPYING FOR AMERICA The Hidden History of U.S. Intelligence. By Nathan Miller. Illustrated. 482 pp. New York: Paragon House. $24.95.

title: NEW BRANDS IN CINEMA SOUND
description: Since Garbo talked and the jazz singer sang, technicians have been tinkering with the sound of movies. Now they're trying to appeal to a new generation of moviegoers who, with digital records and stereo television sets at home, are increasingly sophisticated about sound.

title: THE EDUCATION OF DAN QUAYLE
description: It is a good thing that Dan Quayle is only 42 years old. This way, when he finishes his world leadership courses and schmoozes his way through the Presidency, he will still have time for the Professional Golf Association tour. HENRY BLODGET New York, N.Y.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: NOTHING BUT THE BEST: The Struggle for Perfection at the Juilliard School, by Judith Kogan. (Limelight Editions, $10.95.) Judith Kogan, a lawyer and harpist who graduated from Juilliard, tells of cutthroat competition at her alma mater. ''She's a shrewd storyteller with a good eye for emotionally charged detail, and her narratives of orchestral mutiny and precompetition jitters are deliciously real,'' Kyle Gann said here in 1987. ''Former music students will cringe with recognition; others will find a fascinating, Upton Sinclair-type expose on how musical artists are made.'' WHERE I'M CALLING FROM, by Raymond Carver. (Vintage, $8.95.) When he died last year of cancer at the age of 50, Raymond Carver left behind this collection of new and selected short stories - stark, often haunting tales that will now have to stand as his life's work. ''His impulse to simplify is like an attempt to create a hush, not to hear less but to hear better,'' our reviewer, Marilynne Robinson, said in 1988. ''Mr. Carver is rather like the poet William Carlos Williams, who declared there were 'no ideas but in things,' and who turned banality's pockets out and found all their contents beautiful.'' THE CHALLENGE, by A. B. C. Whipple. (Quill/Morrow, $12.95.) Before steam supplanted wind as the preferred means of propulsion for cargo ships, two clippers called the Challenge and the Flying Cloud raced around Cape Horn. This ''spirited history of the clipper era [ is ] one of those rare books whose chapter notes are as much fun as the text,'' Tony Gibbs said here in 1987. ''If at times Mr. Whipple's prose is a shade fervid, he never falls into the trap of romanticizing what he describes.'' THE BOOK OF THE DUN COW, by Walter Wangerin Jr. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) In an ancient world where the earth is the focus of the celestial spheres, a group of talking animals has been recruited by God to fight an apocalyptic battle against pure evil, a subterranean serpent named Wyrm. The same publisher has also reissued THE BOOK OF SORROWS ($8.95), the sequel to Walter Wangerin Jr.'s 1978 allegory. ''In his two-volume fable, Mr. Wangerin is writing nothing less than a parable of the Fall, an attempt, if not to justify God's ways to man, then to ask God to do so Himself,'' Michael Malone said in The Book Review in 1985. ''Like its predecessor, with which it should be read, 'The Book of Sorrows' is a profoundly imagined and beautifully stylized fable of the immemorial war between good and evil.'' CHAIM WEIZMANN: A Biography, by Norman Rose. (Penguin, $14.95.) Chaim Weizmann (1874-1952), the first President of Israel, left behind more than 20,000 letters when he died, the first one written when he was 10 years old. By drawing on these and other writings, Norman Rose ''provides a fluent and readable account of the career of this immensely gifted, endlessly fascinating, creative statesman,'' Bernard Wasserstein said here in 1986. PINBALL, by Jerzy Kosinski. (Arcade/Little, Brown, $8.95.) A beautiful drama student sets out to find Goddard, an elusive rock star who seems to exist only through his music. Jerzy Kosinski ''has created a suspenseful, readable, and unsentimental tale that showcases his love for and knowledge of music and examines the nature of fame and success and the frightening alienation and violence it often spawns,'' one reviewer said in 1982. Arcade has also republished BLIND DATE ($8.95), the story of George Levanter, a businessman, murderer and rapist who travels the world meting out his own weird justice. Mr. Kosinski ''wants to entertain Sade-wise readers who won't blanch at a highly literary treatment of violence and perversion,'' a reviewer said in 1977. KATHERINE MANSFIELD: A Secret Life, by Claire Tomalin. (St. Martin's, $13.95.) Katherine Mansfield, who succumbed to tuberculosis at the age of 34, gained a reputation among friends like D. H. Lawrence and Virginia Woolf as an unstable woman given to extravagant lies. ''Because Mrs. Tomalin has put the tangled facts of Mansfield's life together with intelligence and detachment, and because she has a flair for inspired guesses, she has eloquently justified a new telling of a sad old story,'' Pearl K. Bell said here in 1988. AMRITA: Or To Whom She Will, by Ruth Prawer Jhabvala. (Fireside/Simon & Schuster, $8.95.) Ruth Prawer Jhabvala's first novel, which is about star-crossed young lovers in modern India, is ''an amusing, slightly caustic comedy,'' Santha Rama Rau said in The Book Review in 1956. The same publisher has also reissued GET READY FOR BATTLE ($7.95), her novel about a middle-class family in Delhi. The author ''views her characters with a coruscating eye,'' one reviewer said in 1963. ''She deftly pinpoints her situations and characters with an economy of words.'' A HISTORY OF VENICE, by John Julius Norwich. (Vintage, $14.95.) John Julius Norwich fell in love with Venice on a trip there with his family when he was 16 years old. His history of the city is ''complete, accurate, elegantly written and easily readable by nonspecialists,'' Luigi Barzini said in The Book Review in 1982. FAMILIARITY IS THE KINGDOM OF THE LOST, by Dugmore Boetie. Edited by Barney Simon. (Four Walls Eight Windows, $6.95.) This short life story of an uneducated thief with a soaring imagination is ''a flight of wild comic exaggeration and invention that is not only vibrantly funny but a more honest expression of the despair of black South Africans than any number of moralizing exhortations,'' our reviewer, Joseph Lelyveld, said in 1970.

title: The Whitney Interprets Museums' Dreams
description: ''The desire of the museum'' is the catchy title of an eye-catching, mind-tingling exhibition of contemporary art. The latest offering from the Federal Reserve Plaza branch of the Whitney Museum of American Art's satellite system, it is a rare example of theory put effectively, and even entertainingly, into practice.

title: POSTINGS: Fannie Mae Eases Rules; Refinancing A Mortgage
description: Some homeowners seeking to refinance their mortgages to take advantage of lower interest rates may find it significantly easier as a result of a series of administrative actions by the Federal National Mortgage Association earlier this month. Officials of Fannie Mae, as the nation's largest investor in home mortgages is known, said a key change in their regulations is the use of the original appraisal for the refinancing if the refinancing involves the same lender. This would mean a savings of several hundred dollars. Fannie Mae also eased the income and credit verification requirements by considerably reducing the amount of personal financial records needed to support the refinancing request, and changed some eligibility standards so that many borrowers will find it easier to requalify for the new mortgage.

title: A Series on Elvis's Early Career Gyrates Into Action
description: ''Does anybody know 'Baby, Let's Play House'?''

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Pennsylvania; Black Students Get a Yearbook Of Their Own
description: ''Positively Black,'' a yearbook produced by the Black Students League at the University of Pennsylvania, is a collection of pictures and descriptions of the positive aspects of being black at the school.

title: The War of the Rose
description: Undeniably, Britain has a sovereign right to do what it wishes about the Rose Theater, the only Elizabethan playhouse to be unearthed in modern London. Yet sadly, Prime Minister Thatcher's Government has heeded the pleas of a developer in refusing to list the Rose as a national monument. This may permit the building of a commercial high-rise over it. Thus Britain may squander a chance to reaffirm dominion over the most lasting of empires - that of the imagination.

title: Getting Into the Twang of Things
description: EVERY evening Johnny Michaels, the program director at WWYZ in Hartford, brings home stacks of letters from listeners responding to the station's new country music format and reads them while he relaxes in front of the television. The 10,000 letters he has received typically fall into two categories, Mr. Michaels said.

title: Union Plans to Picket St. Luke's
description: A hospital workers union said yesterday that its members would picket St. Luke's Hospital in Manhattan tomorrow as part of a one-day strike against 53 private hospitals to demand a new contract with higher wages and benefits.

title: FASHION: First Picks for Fall; Serious Shoppers Buy Early, Often and Expensively
description: Who would shop for fall clothes at the height of summer? Serious shoppers, that's who. Ask any retailer why there are woolens and cashmeres on the racks in July, and you will be told that the ''fashion customer'' shops early. And that's true, to judge by a recent informal survey of New York stores.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some of the most notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted. Classical

title: 'The Face on the Back of the Book'
description: To the Editor:

title: 'The Face on the Back of the Book'
description: To the Editor:

title: Joy Bindelglass to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Howard Bindelglass of White Plains have made known the engagement of their daughter, Joy Diane Bindelglass, to Andrew Jay Klein, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilburt Klein of White Plains. A September wedding is planned. The prospective bride is an account executive at Restaurant Associates in New York. Mr. Klein is the executive chef at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Traveler's Checks
description: To the Editor: My wife lost her MasterCard in Argentina, probably in Buenos Aires, but didn't notice the loss until checking in at a hotel in Puerto Iguazu. It was late in the day and we weren't able to reach MasterCard's representative bank in town. But banks in Puerto Iguazu open at 6 A.M., and we were there when it opened only to be told that the lost card would have to be reported to MasterCard's office in Buenos Aires. We got the number and called within 15 minutes.

title:
About Men;
A Courage Born Of Broken Promises
description: LEAD: I MEET THEM EVERY-where - at parties, lectures, friend's houses, just taking a walk - and each time am astonished again by what I can only describe as the near miracle of their cheerfulness, their energy, their seemingly unflappable resilience and, in many cases, their lack of bitterness. They are single parents, mothers mostly, to be honest.

title: Equalizers Fight the Balance Battle
description: Recordings reissued on CD often sound better than the original LP versions. There are many reasons for this - not least re-equalization: a change in the balance of highs and lows.

title: The Thoroughbred Called Deauville
description: ON a visit from Paris to his native Normandy, the artist Eugene Boudin was recaptured by the loveliness of the province. ''Nature,'' he wrote in his diary, ''remains far richer than I can paint her.'' In Normandy, with its chalky cliffs and hills of granite, apple orchards and green pastures, sandy beaches and sparkling sea, nature is rich indeed. But there are other riches: Gothic, Romanesque and Renaissance chateaus and churches, harbors, turn-of-the-century villas - and Deauville.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We couldn't keep saying, 'Don't have an abortion, but you're on your own.' We had to put our money where our mouths were.'' - Betsy Powell, a Right to Life official. [ 1:2. ]

title: FICTION
description: THE WOMEN WHO WALK. By Nancy Huddleston Packer. (Louisiana State University, $17.95.) Painted in ''swirls of blood and milk,'' the carefully rendered family studies in Nancy Huddleston Packer's second book of stories examine the quiet violence of everyday life, tracing the emotional tightropes we all learn to walk and the nets we dive into as we fall. In ''The Women Who Walk,'' characters hoard their relationships to one another, alternately cherishing and tearing at the painful bonds of intimacy as the ordinary clang of kitchen pans and the rustle of silk punctuate the emotional landscape. The best pieces in the collection are anatomies of aftermath: failed relationships echo with the hollow ache of lost chances; parents sit their children down and haltingly attempt to interpret the inexplicable. In the title story, a woman struggles to reinvent herself after the demise of her marriage, reeling from the loss, grasping desperately at sources of strength. Another story, ''Making Amends,'' chronicles the meeting of two former lovers 20 years later; as they spar again, one flirts with involvement and pines for a second chance while the other yearns mutely for retribution. Most of the narrators in this book are women, many of whom share a stubborn intelligence and blind resilience, a determination based not so much on faith as on instinct. Prepped for pain, still somehow willing to risk everything in pursuit of ever-elusive emotional connections, the characters in Ms. Packer's thoughtful stories go about the quiet heroism of simply being human.

title: Shared Foes Unite Beirut Christians and Iraq
description: Dressed in a business suit, Gen. Michel Aoun, the Lebanese Christian commander, stood under a big portrait of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. He picked up a knife and began to cut an anniversary cake shaped like a flag.

title: Five More For the Hall
description: Roy Campanella is flying in from Los Angeles. Ted Williams is cutting short his fishing trip. Ralph Kiner will be absent from the Mets' broadcast booth.

title: POSTINGS: 150 Pawling Condos; Country Life
description: If there ever was an upscale address in the exurbs of New York City it was the Village of Pawling in southern Dutchess County, which at various times was the home of Thomas E. Dewey, Edward R. Murrow and Lowell Thomas.

title: An Edifying Word From a Bookstore
description: There was an inaccuracy in the article on independent bookstores in Westchester. Once Upon a Time is not the only children's-only bookstore. There is my store, the Children's Bookshelf, in Rye and there is also Storybook World in Mount Kisco.

title: Selling Tools to Biotechnologists
description: Like the merchants who found riches supplying gold miners with picks and shovels, Applied Biosystems Inc. has carved out a profitable niche producing the tools that biotechnology companies use to perform their gene-splicing magic. Applied Biosystems is the leading maker of biotechnology instruments used for either putting together or taking apart the basic building blocks of life: D.N.A., proteins and peptides.

title: VIOLENCE IN A MAN'S WORLD
description: Katha Pollitt's observations in her article ''Violence in a Man's World'' (Hers, June 18), are chillingly accurate. Unless it's headline news, violent behavior on the part of males is largely ignored, if not condoned.

title: Chorus in 'Henry V'
description: To the Editor:

title: Military Copter Crash Kills 6
description: Six soldiers were killed and one was injured before dawn today when an Army helicopter crashed at Fort Irwin on the last day of a three-week field training exercise. The UH-60 Blackhawk helicopter was carrying seven members of the First Cavalry Division from Fort Hood, Tex., when it crashed 14 miles northeast of the main garrison at Fort Irwin, in Southern California.

title: 'Suburban Home Life': The Good, the Bad and the Kitsch
description: IDEALLY, suburbia is a place that has the benefits of both rural and city living but none of their drawbacks. Books taking issue with that run from the socially scientific to the comic, and there are many of them. But even more abundant is art about the subject, which invariably takes the form of caricature, be it an affectionately witty cartoon in The New Yorker or a cruel photograph by Diane Arbus.

title: Catherine Murray Weds M. A. Bird
description: Catherine Mary Murray, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis B. Murray of Bath, N.H., and Michael Andrew Bird, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. John E. Bird Jr. of Sea Girt, N.J., were married there yesterday at the Episcopal Church of St. Uriel the Archangel. Mr. Bird officiated, assisted by the Rev. D. Bradley Murray, a Roman Catholic priest and an uncle of the bride.

title: Q and A
description: Summer Sublet

title: Hotel Plumbers
description: To the Editor:

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. After my front step was painted someone stepped in the paint and left tracks on my flagstone walk. I have tried turpentine and paint thinner, but neither has worked. How can I remove the stains from the flagstone?

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE MASTER PAINTER. By Edwin Mullins. (Doubleday, $19.95.) History has given Edwin Mullins, a novelist and art critic, very little to go on in writing ''The Master Painter,'' a fictional biography of the Flemish artist Jan van Eyck. We know that van Eyck was born around 1390 and that he served as court painter and secret ambassador for Philip, Duke of Burgundy.

title: 99 Roses for Rose Kennedy
description: Rose Kennedy celebrated her 99th birthday tonight with Irish tunes, chocolate cake and more than three dozen members of the Kennedy clan at the family compound on Cape Cod. Senator Edward M. Kennedy presented his mother with 99 pink roses.

title: Review/Dance; 'Bayadere' Third Act With New Kirov Leads
description: New York dance audiences have seen their share of productions of the ''Kingdom of the Shades'' scene from ''La Bayadere'' since the Kirov Ballet brought the excerpt from the Petipa ballet to the West early in the 1960's. And so it was possible to view the Kirov's performance of the work on Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House with a slightly jaundiced eye.

title: Human, All Too Human
description: LEAD: If the road to hell is paved with good intentions, an episode in man's interaction with nature I recently witnessed may be further evidence that the road to species extinction is composed of the same materials.

title: A Letter of Thanks to a Young Fan From Olivier
description: To the Editor:

title: Town Rifts Set Bad Examples for Children
description: A NUMBER of political and legal wrangles have recently disrupted the tranquillity of my small town. Two of them concerned the school system. Amid the debates, the referendums and the lawsuits, I wonder, what are we teaching our children?

title: N.F.L. Defends Player Updates
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Andrea R. Brown To Wed Auditor
description: Mr. and Mrs. John V. Brown of Westbury, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter Andrea Regina Brown to Barry Vincent Green, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Green of Muttontown, L.I. A 1990 wedding is planned.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Pittsburgh;
Transforming A Warehouse
description: LEAD: THE conversion of an eight-story former department-store warehouse to a mixed-use commercial building on this city's South Side has spurred renewed interest from developers and prospective tenants in a small neighborhood hardly known as a strong location for office buildings.

title: Shaw's 'Candida,' Tale of a Triangle
description: IN what must be the summer theater's most evident concession to civility, here's ''Candida.''

title: Design; The GAZEBO
description: Gazebos may seem like frivolous little garden ornaments, but they are actually quite practical structures, a fact landscape designers discovered centuries ago. Not only does a gazebo serve as a focal point - a small charming building to be looked at from afar - it also provides shelter - a place to escape to in the rain or a perch where one can read or simply look out and enjoy the view.

title: Mellow Manley Steers Jamaica to Quiet Days
description: Michael Manley promised a quiet Jamaica and, so far, that is what he has delivered.

title: Susan Cavanaugh Engaged
description: September wedding plans for Susan Patricia Cavanaugh and Habib Youssef Gorgi have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Leo P. Cavanaugh of Hingham, Mass. Ms. Cavanaugh is the assistant director of recruiting for the accounting firm of Deloitte Haskins & Sells in New York. Mr. Gorgi, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Youssef Georgy of Cumberland, R.I., is a general partner in the venture capital concern of Fleet Venture Partners in New York.

title: Pick Good Companies, Not Good Stocks
description: While a number of possible remedies for floundering American competitiveness have been advanced, few have considered the stock market itself, where so many business decisions are shaped.

title: Yanks Acquire Terrell
description: The Yankees took a determined step to resolve their pitching problems today when they acquired Walt Terrell from the San Diego Padres in exchange for Mike Pagliarulo, whose two-year slump on offense had become one of the more puzzling components of their season.

title: LESSONS FROM THE SANDBOX
description: JUST AS HE DIDN'T REALLY MEAN TO BECOME A PART-time Unitarian minister or the chairman of the art department of a fancy Seattle private school, the Rev. Robert L. Fulghum didn't really mean to write a best seller called ''All I Really Need to Know I Learned in Kindergarten: Uncommon Thoughts on Common Things.'' But accidents happen.

title: Badminton's Changing Image
description: For many American sports fans, badminton conjures up images of holiday picnics with giggling teen-agers flailing away at a feathery, wind-tossed shuttlecock with clumsy metal racquets.

title: LOBBYING TO FIGHT TAXES AND HIGHER WAGES
description: A 10-cent tax on the admission price to a local movie house may not seem like much. But add to it a possible salary increase for the staff of high-school students who work at theaters and major capital expenditures to make cinemas accessible to the disabled and you have an appreciably higher-priced admission ticket. For theater owners, that could drive away a lot of business.

title: Surface Beauty, But Who Knows The Pain Beneath?
description: I STILL don't know what brought us together. Maybe it was the hand of fate, for I surely needed a good helping of what I was about to be served.

title: OPTIMISM SOUNDED LIKE AN EYE DISEASE
description: GIRLS' NIGHT OUT By Kathy Lette. 202 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS/HISTORY: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: FICTION
description: OUR GOLDEN IRONBURG: A Novel With Formulas. By Vassily Aksyonov. Translated by Ronald E. Peterson. (Ardis, $23.50.) Written in 1972, this energetically satiric novel by Vassily Aksyonov went unpublished in the Soviet Union and saw print in the United States in a Russian edition only after the author immigrated to this country in 1980. It's hard to understand what irked the censors about this witty but fairly unsubversive tale of life in Ironburg, a mythical science institute hidden deep in Siberia. Perhaps the sheer vigor of its rapid-fire invention was enough to turn the thumbs down; then too, the novel's unconventional, free-floating narrative structure couldn't have been a plus. Mr. Aksyonov ranges at will through the minds and dreams of some half-dozen scientists and their wives, as well as an avant-garde writer who may or may not be the author himself. The result is a loosely strung collection of hyperbolized, often surreal anecdotes. We discover that physicists, like poets, chase the unseen. Of course, they also chase skirts, promotions and prestige. In fact, in-fighting, petty jealousies and career-mongering obsess Ironburg's academic elite as much as their pursuit of an elusive atomic particle dubbed the Double-Few. Mr. Aksyonov's characterization of particular scientists is a bit slapdash. No one emerges very clearly as an individual; rather, they stand in for larger groups or cultural beliefs. For example, Veliky-Salazkin, Ironburg's aging patriarch, represents the passing generation of scientific supermen. Although he is held in awe by the younger technicians, much of the tension between the two generations is too subtle, too tied to inside humor to have much effect on a less than knowledgeable audience. Further complicating this situation is the uncertainty that comes from the author's use of several narrators in a constantly shifting time frame. Nonetheless, Ronald E. Peterson's translation has effectively caught the cynical edge of Mr. Aksyonov's satire. ''Our Golden Ironburg'' strives artfully to raise laughs from the potentially leaden subject of Soviet science.

title: PASTIMES: Chess
description: Why would the most solid player in the world, enjoying a one-point lead in a tournament with only three rounds to go, suddenly lose three games and end up with second prize? That is what Anatoly Karpov did in the Fifth World Cup Tournament, which ended June 24 in Rotterdam, the Netherlands.

title: Diesel Emissions Violate Federal Law
description: Of 14 monitors in New York City that measure dangerous particulates in the air, just one is at ground level. That one, on Madison Avenue between 47th and 48th Streets, shows that in this one teeming midtown area, New York is violating Federal air-quality standards.

title: The Institution as Impresario
description: Something fundamental has changed in the way classical music performances reach the concert hall. Indeed, there has been a change in the nature of the concert hall itself, as the hall - or rather its administrators - has become today's impresario, thus changing the role it plays in bringing together performers and listeners.

title:
DINING OUT;
Skill and Invention in Pound Ridge
description: LEAD: WE had always considered the cobwebs and dark corners of the late Emily Shaw's Inn more unsanitary than atmospheric. But the progressive deterioration of that restaurant has been miraculously thrown into reverse. The new owners, Dorothy Treyball and her sons, Keith and Brendan Treyball, have sand-blasted, scoured and scrubbed from highest beams to stone floor; patched, wired, nailed and painted.

title: CAPTURING THE LIGHT OF PROVENCE
description: tr,br1RUNNING IN PLACE Scenes From the South of France. By Nicholas Delbanco. 231 pp. New York: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $16.95.

title: ALL STRINGS LEAD TO ROME
description: PEOPLE OF GOD The Struggle for World Catholicism. By Penny Lernoux. 466 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: NOT JUST FOR LAUGHS

title: Helping With Hospice Benefits
description: A MIDDLESEX COUNTY woman learned of her husband's death from a strange voice calling from the hospital in the middle of the night. When she became terminally ill, she vowed that her family would never go through the agony she experienced during that tragic time.

title: K. L. LeBrun Weds Miss Cyganowski
description: Melanie Louise Cyganowski, the daughter of Sophia Cyganowski of Buffalo and the late Bishop Daniel F. Cyganowski of the Buffalo-Pittsburgh diocese of the Polish National Catholic Church, was married yesterday at Epiphany Roman Catholic Church in New York to Kenneth Leo LeBrun, a son of Agnes Brouwer of Pipestone, Minn., and the late Felix LeBrun. Msgr. Robert A. Arpie officiated, assisted by the Rev. Bruce Sleczkowski.

title: Room With a Viewpoint
description: ''SO where are we staying?'' I asked Duke when our plane touched down in Herakleion, Crete. I envisioned a secluded white villa by the sea with round-the-clock room service and bouzouki music.

title: The Second Time
description: To the Editor: On July 31, 1988, you ran an article entitled ''The Second Time Around.'' Our unfortunate ''second time around'' came about in a Swiss mountain hotel, Haus Paradies, in Ftan.

title: The Government Is Hiring, Which Isn't Easy  It's Loneliest At the Top of The Bureaucracy
description: THE 1980's have not been kind to civil servants, and some people say the Federal work force is taking revenge by falling apart. President Bush, the first President in a dozen years who did not campaign against the bureaucracy, responded this month by proposing pay raises for political appointees and a few hundred specialists in the Civil Service. The Office of Personnel Management is trying to revise pay scales for the other two million Federal workers, while several commissions have said that is the least that could be done.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: WAIKOLOA, HAWAII;
Kona-Kohala Housing Rises
description: LEAD: NEW housing is rising quickly on the Kona-Kohala coast on the big island of Hawaii, where more than $1 billion in resorts have been completed.

title: Miss Bartunek Plans Wedding
description: An August wedding is planned by Rebecca Catherine Bartunek and Joseph Mertz Jr., the prospective bride's mother and adoptive father, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Bartunek of Westport, Conn., have announced.

title: Correction
description: In a box accompanying an article about concert halls as impresarios on page 21 of Arts and Leisure, the annual budget for the 92d Street Y's arts program is given incorrectly. It is $3 million.

title: Sharon Hall Is to Wed Todd Kessler
description: Mr. and Mrs. Monty Hall of Beverly Hills and Palm Springs, Calif., have made known September wedding plans for their daughter Sharon Hall and Todd Ellis Kessler, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis H. Kessler of Westfield and Deal, N.J.

title: In Much-Needed Defense of the Buttercup
description: To the Editor:

title: Canada's Hard Line on Radar Detectors
description: ''IF you drive into the Yukon territory,'' said Fred Jennex, Deputy Minister of Community and Transportation for the area, ''you better hide your radar detector very well.'' The Yukon is one of 7 Canadian provinces and territories - there are 12 in all - that ban the possession and use of radar detectors in automobiles. And the news is worse than just a fine; confiscation of radar detectors, which cost $100 to $400, is a likelihood for drivers who get caught using them. Quebec Province crushed and incinerated 10,000 radar detectors last year, according to officials there.

title:
GARDENING;
Factors That Make Beautiful Flowers Ugly
description: LEAD: MOST flowers are admired for their delicate beauty, yet their fragile nature exposes them to problems that may mar their beauty and render them unattractive.

title: Review/Music; Camerata Koln, at the Frick
description: At the Frick Collection on Wednesday afternoon, the Camerata Koln played a number of 18th-century styles using the same 18th-century instruments. On the surface of it, a fundamental premise of the early-music movement would appear to have been breached - the precise matching of historical instruments to precise moments in history.

title: VIOLENCE IN A MAN'S WORLD
description: Last year I received a tearful phone call from a relative, telling me her drunken husband was beating her once again (with small children looking on). Suddenly, the line went dead. I was left with the question of what I should do. Hang up and pretend nothing happened? Call in the morning to see what injuries she had suffered? Or call the police? I opted for the latter. When the news traveled through the family grapevine, I was blamed, ostracized. She provokes him, they said.

title: Just A Brief Rally?
description: Lines of eager investors have not formed outside brokerage firm offices yet, nor are telephones on Wall Street ringing madly. And almost no one is talking about stocks at this summer's parties, as they were two years ago.

title: An August Bridal For Helena Potter
description: Announcement of the engagement of Helena Belle Potter to John Bennett Marks, a son of Dr. and Mrs. John H. Marks of Princeton, N.J., has been made by the prospective bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Robert T. Potter of Plattsburgh, N.Y. An August wedding is planned.

title: Lobbying Becomes Bolder in Texas
description: The old art of influence peddling took a technological leap at the Texas Legislature recently when lobbyists began bringing cellular telephones to the Capitol's galleries.

title: GREETINGS AND SALUTATIONS
description: About this business of ''dear sir,'' why don't we stop fiddling with the vocabulary and simply change the format?

title: Benefit Parties Take to Water For the Summer
description: Last week the charity circuit abandoned its hotel ballrooms for yachts and cruise boats in the harbor. On Tuesday 300 guests paid $150 each to board the De Witt Clinton at the South Street Seaport, and dine and dance under a dazzling orange moon for the benefit of the Martha Graham School of Contemporary Dance. On the same balmy evening more than 2,000 young people herded aboard a Hudson River Day Line boat at its West 41st Street pier to help the Multiple Sclerosis Society. The $50 tickets bought drinks, huge hero sandwiches and four bands, one on each deck.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Industrial Vacancies Up in 11 Counties
description: LEAD: IN the last four years, the vacancy rate in the industrial marketplace in the state's 11 northern counties has more than doubled -from 3.6 percent in 1985 to 7.6 in the second quarter this year.

title: Shoreham Error: Building It at All
description: The mistake of Shoreham is not dismantling the plant (''Shoreham Set for New Arena,'' July 9). The mistake was bulding it in the first place.

title: Correction
description: Because of a production error, a table last week accompanying an article about L.A. Gear Inc. was incorrect. The correct table appears below. AT A GLANCE: L.A. Gear All dollar amounts in thousands, except per share data. title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Outing; A Tranquil Present Masks a Turbulent Past
description: The tranquil, muddy river, bucolic villages and thickets of wild tiger lilies belie Bucks County's tempestuous past. Revolution, commerce and geography conspired to make it a mecca, initially as a stop for weary travelers on the road between New York and Philadelphia and today as a weekend respite for denizens of those cities and many others.

title: The N.F.L. Protests, Sort Of, But State-Sponsored Betting Looks Unstoppable Now
description: THE new Oregon lottery based on the outcomes of National Football League games may have drawn protests from the N.F.L. last week, but those familiar with the Oregon scheme say the league's complaints are likely to do little more than draw attention to the new game and spur its adoption by other states.

title: Correction
description: An article on page 11 of Arts and Leisure gives an incorrect rating for the film ''Honey, I Shrunk the Kids.''

title: Variety Is Theme of Outdoor Concert Schedule
description: THIS week's concert schedule is as crowded as one in December's, but with the notable difference that many of the events are outdoors. There are orchestral programs, opera, musical comedy, solo recitals, chamber music and more.

title: Enjoy Fresh Tomatoes While They're Abundant
description: TOMATO sandwiches were one of my favorite summer treats when I was growing up in England. They were made with brown bread and butter, and tomatoes from the garden that were still warm from the sun. We ate them sprinkled with a little salt for teatime and had hot tea, which we drank even on the hottest of days because my grandfather said that no drink was more cooling.

title:
MUSIC;
Boston Sends a Sample of Pops Concerts
description: LEAD: THE Boston Pops, the oldest pops orchestra in the nation, has a success that is unmatched, ''although many others have tried to imitate it,'' said Harry Ellis Dickson, who has been closely connected with the orchestra for half a century.

title: Miss Stang Wed To U.N. Official
description: Susan Stang, a vice president of the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, and Andreas Brandstatter, an associate auditor at the United Nations Secretariat, both in New York, were married yesterday at the Wayzata (Minn.) Community Church. The Rev. James McCutcheon, a Congregational minister, officiated.

title: Jazz's Information Trap
description: At least in American music, the good old days - the early years of this century - were simpler. Music was easily divided into categories. There was regional music, from several styles of blues to several styles of country, to Tin Pan Alley and Broadway pop, ecclesiastical music, jazz, European classical music, a few eccentric American composers working the fringes of the European tradition and not much more.

title: The Way It Was At the Beach
description: Please extend my sincere thanks to Barbara Klaus for her most entertaining and reminiscent article, ''Beach Blanket Bingo, 50's Style'' (Long Island Sound, July 2).

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Lehigh
description: Lehigh University's 102-year-old chapter of the Sigma Chi fraternity has been banned from the campus for four years for creating a ''sexually offensive environment'' when it hired a woman to do a striptease at a party at its house on May 5.

title: Outdoors; Bluefish Hearings Beginning
description: If you have strong feelings about a proposed management plan for bluefish that would reduce the sport-fishing harvest of the species along the entire Eastern Seaboard, the time is at hand to make your views known. A series of public hearings begins this week.

title: Paris
description: To the Editor: I have just returned from Paris, which I have been visiting for 10 years. This year of the bicentennial I found it the worst as far as manners go.

title: Katie Cangelosi, Editor, Is a Bride
description: Katharine J. Cangelosi, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Cangelosi of East Northport, L.I., was married yesterday to Peter C. B. Homans, the son of Mrs. George C. Homans of Cambridge, Mass., and the late Mr. Homans. The Rev. Dr. Peter J. Gomes, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's mother.

title: Old Resort Draws New Clientele: Honeymooners
description: At one time, Cape May was known as the serene Victorian getaway of four Presidents and scores of wealthy New York and Philadelphia industrialists. But recently, Cape May, the nation's oldest seaside resort, has begun to attract a new breed of beachgoer.

title: The Bulk-for-Benefits Deal in Zoning
description: ALMOST 30 years after New York City rewrote its land-use policies and pioneered a controversial strategy of exchanging zoning bonuses for public amenities, its incentive zoning approach is being buffeted by a fresh round of criticism from public officials and neighborhood advocates.

title: Stanley Goes Global: Profits and Problems
description: Stanley Works, an old-line New England toolmaker best known for its saws and tape measures, has become a global company in recent years, illustrating the extent to which globalization of manufacturing is reaching into the grass roots.

title: Rembrandt's Return
description: The art dealer brought the small double-sided drawing, only 3 by 4 inches, to Christie's in New York, saying he was acting for a friend and did not know what the artwork was. Beverly Schreiber Jacoby, who heads the Old Master drawings department at Christie's, knew what it was: a Rembrandt drawing of the artist's wife, Saskia, on one side of the paper, and his son, Robartus, at age 3 or 4, on the other side, valued ''in excess of $100,000.'' From a 1954 book, Mrs. Jacoby found that the drawing had been at Rembrandt's House, a museum in Amsterdam, but the curator there said it had been stolen in 1979. Christie's said the dealer and the consignor, who are from Italy and asked not to be identified, agreed to return the drawing to the museum.

title: Intensive Search for Missing Parts
description: National Guard troops today mounted an intensive search in corn and soybean fields for crucial parts missing from the United Airlines DC-10 that crashed here on Wednesday.

title: In Summer, St. Lukes Comes Home
description: IF home is where the audiences are, then the Orchestra of St. Luke's can call many places home - from Carnegie Hall, where it presents a yearly concert series, to Avery Fisher Hall, where it will soon appear with the soprano Kathleen Battle, to the Brooklyn Academy of Music, where the group has played for such Next Wave Festival events as the Pina Bausch Dance Theater and John Adams's opera, ''Nixon in China.''

title: Virgin Atlantic
description: To the Editor: I am writing about Virgin Atlantic's recent one-day sale on June 1 of a $99 round trip, New York to London.

title: WHOLE LOTTA SELLIN' GOIN' ON
description: WOODSTOCK The Oral History. By Joel Makower. Illustrated. 361 pp. New York: A Tilden Press Book/Doubleday. Cloth, $27.50. Paper, $16.95.

title: Charlotte T. Look To Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. David Townsend Look of Brunswick, Me., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Charlotte Townsend Look and Peter Allen Szuch, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Clyde Andrew Szuch of Maplewood, N.J.

title: Olivier: Exit the Emperor
description: The age of Olivier is over. For the British theater, it is the end of a Churchillian age - brilliant, unpredictable and heroic. Laurence Olivier was a titan. He lived the lives of several great men -as actor, film star, director, impresario, leader. For more than 40 years, he was not the king but the emperor of his profession. We may talk of the age of Burbage, the age of Garrick, the age of Irving; but the mid-20th century - even when the rare cluster of other truly great British actors: Gielgud, Richardson, Guinness, Redgrave, Evans, Ashcroft has been celebrated - was undoubtedly the age of Olivier.

title: Computerized Calls To Check on Elderly
description: THREE times in the last five months, 90-year-old Helen Cattell has fallen in her one-floor house here. Mrs. Cattell was strong enough to reach a telephone each time and call for help. But her daughter, Elly Robinson, is worried.

title: Review/Rock; Zvuki Mu, Residents: Double Bill
description: The Residents, from San Francisco, and Zvuki Mu, from Moscow, made a smart pairing for a Serious Fun program Friday night at Alice Tully Hall. Both bands view rock skeptically, from a distance - a geographical one for Zvuki Mu, an artistic one for the Residents. Both write songs that pile up terse riffs to grate against each other in well-planned dissonance. And both bands present their music with a bleak, oblique theatricality.

title: Suzanne Mageean to Wed
description: September wedding plans for Suzanne Elizabeth Mageean and Gordon Reid Robertson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Robertson of Cold Spring, N.Y., have been made known by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Mageean of Glen Ridge, N.J. Miss Mageean is an associate with Alexander & Alexander, insurance brokers, in Greenwich, Conn. Mr. Robertson is an account executive with the New York insurance agency of Walter Kaye Associates.

title: Taking 'Baby Blues' Seriously
description: LEAD: CONTRARY to the image of the ecstatic new mother, the time after birth is emotionally upsetting for some women.

title: The Government Is Hiring, Which Isn't Easy  Pay: Public vs. Private
description: Average annual salaries in 1988 for selected Federal civil servants and private sector employees in jobs involving comparable training and responsibility. Federal figures describe a range, from starting to highest available salary, in the job category. Private sector figures are national averages based on a Federal survey. Pensions and other benefits are not included. Occupation Federal employees Private sector File clerk $9,811 -$12,275 $11,461 GS-1 (entry level) Chemist 15,118 - 19,654 25,314 GS-5 (entry level) Secretary 15,118 - 19,654 19,504 GS-5 (mid-level) Computer operator 16,851 - 21,480 22,682 GS-6 (mid-level) Systems analyst 22,907 - 29,783 31,130 GS-9 (entry level) Chief accountant 54,720 - 60,683 88,223 GS14 (senior level) Engineer 15,118 - 19,654 29,222 GS-5 (entry level) Engineer 54,907 - 71,377 85,725 GS-15 (top level) Attorney 54,907 - 71,377 110,489 GS-15 (top level) (Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics)

title: Correction
description: Because of misinformation from a film distributor, an article on page 1 of the Arts and Leisure section today gives an incorrect opening date for the film ''Sex, Lies and Videotape.'' The film will open in New York and Los Angeles on Aug. 4.

title: As the U.S. Gives and Takes, A Rise in the Regional Deficit
description: EACH year for the past 12, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, has released a study of how the states fare in their balance of payments with the Federal Government; that is, how much each state's citizens pay in taxes compared with how much Federal money they get. In the 1988 fiscal year, he said, the Government collected $71 billion more than it returned -an average of $291 for each American.

title: Paroled Art Dealer's Home Is Destroyed by an Explosion
description: A powerful explosion and roaring fire yesterday destroyed the Southampton, L.I., home of Andrew Crispo, an art dealer who recently completed a prison term for tax evasion and was acquitted last year of charges that he had kidnapped and tortured a man.

title:
LONG ISLAND INTERVIEW: ALAN FORTUNOFF;
A Retailer Who Followed The Customers to the Suburbs
description: LEAD: UPWARD mobility and growing prosperity of its customers through the broad middle of the 20th century put the fortune into Fortunoff.

title: Leslie W. Rowland Planning to Wed Fritz Hager, an Executive, in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Dudley Ely Rowland Jr. of Rome, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Leslie Wiggins Rowland to Frederick Hill Hager, a son of Mrs. Andrew D. Hart Jr. of New York and Charlottesville, Va., and the late Peter A. Hager of Short Hills, N.J. An August wedding is planned. Ms. Rowland, a graduate of the State University of New York at Potsdam, was until recently the manager of public information for the Air Transport Association of America, a trade organization for scheduled airlines in Washington. Her father owns Rowland, Bellinger & Comstock Inc., an insurance agency in Rome.

title: ON THE ROAD WITH GRANDMOTHER'S MAGIC
description: LEAD: THE FLOATING WORLD By Cynthia Kadohata. 196 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95.

title: An Angry Father
