description: A state district judge ordered a halt to all Little League playoff games in Texas after a father in Houston filed a lawsuit charging that the league cheated his son's baseball team. District Judge Arthur Lesher granted the temporary restraining order requested by James R. King, father of 12-year-old Jason King, whose team was eliminated in a playoff game Wednesday.

title: Emphasis Should Be On Marketing
description: The key issues facing the next commissioner of the National Football League are not unique to the league's new owners. The problems and opportunities that must be addressed by the new commissioner form a common ground for all 28 owners.

title: THE REGION  Q&A: A Student of the Underground;  The Social Order of the Subways' Homeless
description: STRUGGLING to find a new strategy for coaxing homeless people out of the subways, New York City's Transit Authority recently conducted a survey of the homeless in more than 100 stations. What emerged was the most complete portrait to date of the several thousand destitute people believed to be living underground - and why they are there.

title: Valuable Error
description: He may not yet be an impact player in the National Football League, but Brian Bosworth, the Seattle Seahawks linebacker, has became an impact player on the trading card market. Pro Set Incorporated of Dallas turned out 5,000 Bosworth cards for NFL Properties before discovering there was an error. Instead of reading ''LB-Seahawks,'' the cards said ''LB-Seattle.'' The mistake has sent the price of Bosworth cards soaring. Packets of 14 cards sell for 45 cents; the Bosworth misprint now brings $40.(AP)

title: Experts Try to Salvage Lessons From Wreckage of Jet in Iowa
description: Jumbo jets are built to fly with a missing engine, but aviation experts say it would be all but impossible to design a plane that could withstand the catastrophic failure that brought down United Flight 232 on Wednesday.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Hadley, Mass.;
Providing For the Poor
description: LEAD: THE local housing authority plans to break ground this fall on the town's first publicly owned, subsidized housing project for low-income families.

title: Kip Herrick Plans To Wed a Lawyer
description: September wedding plans for Pamela Kip Herrick and James Stephen O'Brien Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. O'Brien of Newport, R.I., have been made known by the prospective bride's parents, Edith Herrick of Princeton, N.J., and Brownington, Vt., and Daniel Herrick of Washington and Cap-d'Ail, France.

title: Glibness but No Wit at Art Show
description: It was interesting - and a bit ironic - that Helen Harrison's critique [ May 28 ] of the overly abstract Huntington Township Art League show at the Heckscher Museum was illustrated by two definitely nonabstract pieces, one a folk-art joke, in fact.

title: Dr. Huntsman Is Engaged
description: August wedding plans have been announced for Dr. Kathleen Jean Huntsman and Robert Timberlake Newcomb 3d by the prospective bride's parents, Mrs. Charles S. Rowe of Fredericksburg, Va., and Lawrence D. Huntsman of Fairfax, Va. Mr. Newcomb, whose previous marriage ended in divorce, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Newcomb Jr. of Raleigh, N.C.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS/HISTORY
description: MAKING A DIFFERENCE The Story of an American Family. By Margaret Hodges. Illustrated. 196 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $13.95. (Ages 12 and up)

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Office Rents; Rock-Bottom and Top-Drawer Space in Manhattan
description: ON opposite ends of the Manhattan rental market lie the office-space equivalents of discount outlets and expensive boutiques - separated by a gap of more than 500 percent in the rents they charge.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: VIRGINIA WOOLF: The Impact of Childhood Sexual Abuse on Her Life and Work. By Louise DeSalvo. (Beacon, $22.95.) The danger in analyzing lives and literature according to selective evidence or a single set of experiences is that the essential spirit of people and their creative products can suffer severe misinterpretation if tucked neatly into Procrustean beds.

title: Plan to Sell Public Land Is Angering Bombay
description: The residents of this city, India's wealthiest and most vigorous, have been angered and riveted by a ballooning real estate scandal involving an influential leader of the ruling Congress Party in which officials quietly decided to allow the sale of public land to private developers.

title: Forget All You Know About the Guillotine
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Singing in Rain:' Recycled Movie
description: TAKING a story originally designed for one medium and transposing it into another is always problematic. That's why you often hear disappointed moviegoers muttering ''The book was better,'' as they leave the theater.

title: Prussian Attitudes In Sag Harbor
description: Joanne Starkey's review of the American Hotel [ ''Dining Out,'' May 21 ] is right on the mark. Apparently some negative traditions on eastern Long Island are still alive and well. I can remember going there 10 or 12 years ago and suffering through hours of the staff's pretentious snobbery while choking down a piece of boiled duck smothered in what tasted like canned peas.

title: MUSTAFA HAD A WAY WITH WOMEN
description: SEASON OF MIGRATION TO THE NORTH By Tayeb Salih. Translated by Denys Johnson-Davies. 169 pp. New York: Michael Kesend/Talman. $16.95.

title: Judge Orders Lead-Paint Removal Expanded
description: A State Supreme Court justice has directed New York City to expand its program of eliminating lead-based paint in thousands of apartments.

title: Ms. McDonald Plans Wedding
description: Anne Marie McDonald, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William McDonald of Jersey City, and Edward Hartnett, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Hartnett of Jersey City, have announced August wedding plans.

title:
Wine;
More Costly Bottles Draw Summer Buyers
description: LEAD: IN summers past, local merchants stocking large supplies of fine wines would often shudder as customers chose inexpensive California blush and jug products over more costly bottles to accompany barbecue and picnic fare. But reports from a number of retail-store owners suggest that there is a high level of consumer interest now in upper-echelon wines, particularly 1985 burgundies, as well as the usual seasonal demand for lower-priced jugs.

title: Q and A
description: Wheelchairs

title: Radiation May Have Reached Soviet Sub Crew, Expert Says
description: Some crew members on a Soviet nuclear submarine that caught fire and sank off Norway in April may have been exposed to radiation, a top Norwegian scientist said today.

title: Question Of the Week; Should Bo Jackson Give Up One Sport?
description: Should little boys stop playing cowboys and Indians? Should people stop ordering steak and fries? Should Penn stop hanging around with Teller?

title:
ART;
When One Culture Dominates Another
description: LEAD: ALJIRA, the not-for-profit art space in Newark known for shows on subtle and provocative themes, has recently moved. Its new location, at 2 Washington Place, positions it at arm's length from the Newark Museum and near the main branch of the Public Library. What the organization has perhaps lost in the splendid cavernous quality of the former site is made up for by now being ''on the map.

title: 'The Labyrinthine Ways'
description: To the Editor:

title: Southport Braces for a Crush of Book Lovers
description: SOUTHPORT attracts more than its fair share of traffic once a year when people from Maine to Virginia and often as far away as Montana converge on the Pequot Library for its annual book sale. This year's event, the 28th, will run from Friday to next Tuesday and should be no exception, offering, as it does, 80,000 books.

title: A Mania for British Mergers?
description: When Henry R. Kravis, the corporate buyout specialist, boarded the Concorde in London for the three-and-a-half-hour journey to New York one evening earlier this month, he unexpectedly found himself joining a number of Wall Street's top deal makers, all of whom had been in Britain on business and were returning home.

title: Ms. Connors Wed To R. P. Vorhaus
description: At the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York, Mary Candace Connors, a New York interior designer, was married yesterday to Robert Pool Vorhaus, the special projects director for the CBS/Broadcast Group in New York.

title: Era of the Great Pyramid Is Dawning in Memphis
description: A friend recently sent Sidney Shlenker a mock front page of a supermarket tabloid with headlines screaming: ''The Egyptians, The Mayans, The Incas . . . All Built Pyramids! They All Disappeared! Stop Shlenker Before It's Too Late! It's probably too late. In September, Memphis is scheduled to begin building a $55 million, 32-story pyramid where Wolf River Harbor meets the Mississippi. Mr. Shlenker, who recently sold the Denver Nuggets basketball team and once ran the Astrodome in Houston, has contracted with local governments to operate the stainless steel pyramid as a 20,000-seat arena, American music museum, shortwave radio transmitter and who knows what else.

title: Cast Changes in Kirov Bill
description: The Kirov Ballet's fascinating double bill of the third act of Marius Petipa's ''Bayadere'' and Oleg Vinogradov's ''Battleship 'Potemkin,' '' which was repeated Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, represents this company from Leningrad at its most traditional and its most contemporary. In ''La Bayadere,'' the dancers were at their classical best.

title: Resolving Fate of New Rochelle's Station
description: A SIGN in the window of the ticket booth at the train station here sums up the state of the building. Hand-lettered on a piece of cardboard, it used to read, ''No restrooms/Amtrak planning to put them in.'' But after a few months, someone revised it to read, simply, ''No restrooms.''

title: S&L Solutions
description: To the Editor:

title: Cashing In on Rising Health Care Costs
description: Despite the best efforts of insurers and the Federal Government, health care costs continue to rise faster than the gross national product. That is bad news for the parties paying the bill, but good news for emerging growth companies in the field of medical technology that develop high-tech solutions for use in medical imaging, disease diagnosis and drug delivery.

title: Exploring the Salt Marsh: Where the Food Chain Begins
description: LEAD: IT is a gorgeous summer day at the Marshlands Conservancy here and about 20 children and adults, wearing old shoes and pants, are prepared to squish into the mud and wade knee or thigh deep into Milton Harbor. They carry big seines and hope to uncover the plant and animal life hidden here and learn about the ecology of the salt marsh.

title: Question Of the Week; Should Bo Jackson Give Up One Sport?
description: The way I see it, Bo is free in January (if the Raiders don't make it to the Super Bowl), February and March. Since Bo doesn't need to participate in football's rugged preseason camp, he can certainly forgo baseball's springtime festivities.

title: Karen Swett Weds Brian J. Conway
description: Karen Swett, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Swett of Laguna Beach, Calif., and Paris, was married in Laguna Beach yesterday to Brian James Conway, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Conway Jr. of Manhasset and Quogue, L.I. The Rev. Paul Duff performed the ceremony at St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church.

title: Reviews/Dance; French Company at Jacob's Pillow
description: Jean-Francois Duroure's dance has been admired by some savvy dancegoers who have seen his choreography in France. And cheers and whistles greeted Mr. Duroure and his company on Wednesday night in the Ted Shawn Theater at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival. But the evening was something of a disappointment for this reviewer.

title: Simple Truths From A Voice of Experience
description: ''A Horse Called Music'' (Columbia 45046; all three formats), Willie Nelson's 31st album for CBS Records, includes at least one song by the 56-year-old Texan legend that has the ring of a potential country standard.

title: Soviet Party Ponders Its Fate: Talk Is of Renewal
description: How is it possible, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev wondered aloud, that a party having an army of well-indoctrinated regulars, having control of the press, ''having everything,'' has suddenly begun to lose the initiative?

title: The Government Health Data That So Many Want to See
description: SINCE 1964, the Department of Energy and its predecessors have spent $46 million compiling employment and medical records for more than 300,000 people who have worked at atomic weapons plants and laboratories. The records are considered the most comprehensive raw data on whether chronic exposure to low levels of radiation endangers the health of workers and people living downwind from the plants. But no one except scientists under contract to the Department of Energy can see the information, a policy that is coming under criticism from some members of Congress and medical experts.

title: A Bookie Named Oregon
description: Short of money but unwilling to let its young people go without, the state of Oregon last week took state-sanctioned gambling another big step, agreeing to make book on pro football games.

title: GREETINGS AND SALUTATIONS
description: ''Greetings is a salutary salutation'' to introduce a business letter, writes William Safire in ''The Mulvihill Perplexity'' (On Language, June 25). Omigod! It's plain to see that Mr. Safire never received that famous little card from Uncle Sam saying, ''I want YOU!'' To men of a certain age, greetings is the most traumatic word in the English language. LOUIS JAY HERMAN New York, N.Y.

title: THE EDUCATION OF DAN QUAYLE
description: Marilyn Quayle's dislike of ''the term feminist'' is puzzling. Ms. Dowd reported that when Mrs. Quayle was in Singapore, she disliked riding with the other wives in a limousine behind her husband's. She wrote that Mrs. Quayle complained that, next, they'd be wanting her to walk 10 paces behind him Sounds like a feminist to me. EMILY B. SOBIN Hillsdale, N.J.

title: Anti-Abortion Revival: Homes for the Unwed
description: In a rambling Victorian house here, with lace curtains at the windows and religious samplers on the walls, 17 pregnant women await the birth of their babies.

title: The Long Way To Outer Space
description: THE tableau on the Postal Service's new $2.40 Priority Mail stamp is oddly reminiscent of the landing at Iwo Jima: two men, in this case astronauts not marines, plant an unwaving Stars and Stripes on alien territory, the airless desolation of the Moon.

title: A RAFT OF CREATURE COMFORTS TO LURE CUSTOMERS AWAY FROM HOME
description: A night at the opera perhaps it wasn't, but going to the movies was definitely a classy night out back when theaters were ''palaces'' and the movies were, well, operatic.

title: An Inspiration
description: He wasn't able to boot home another winner, but in his final appearance at Hollywood Park in Inglewood, Calif., Bill Shoemaker, the 57-year-old jockey who is on his farewell tour, proved that he's as much an inspiration as ever.

title: Traveler's Checks
description: To the Editor: Apropos the discussion on traveler's checks in Betsy Wade's article, it is not only in South America that travelers experience trouble using traveler's checks.

title: Plan Lets Teachers Keep Pensions After Moving
description: Rhode Island has become the first state to allow public school teachers to transfer the money accrued in their pension plans when they move in or out of the state, provided the other state involved has a reciprocal agreement.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: LENOIR PRESERVE;
A New Site for Ecology Workshops
description: LEAD: A FEW steps from a fancy office complex near the Hastings-on-Hudson border here, there are 40 wooded acres where creatures with four, six, even eight legs preside and man deliberately takes a back seat. Despite its location on the northwestern edge of a busy city, the Lenoir Preserve, owned and operated by the County Department of Parks, Recreation and

title: A Film Maker's Role
description: To the Editor:

title: Pittsburgh
description: To the Editor: Lest your readers believe that only ''the Duquesne Incline offers the best view of the city . . . from an observation deck connected to the Grandview Avenue station at the top of the cliff'' (''What's Doing in Pittsburgh,'' Travel, May 14), they should be informed that the same accommodations are available on the same cliffside avenue at the top station of the Monongahela Incline.

title: Bumper Stickers And Vanity
description: The article on vanity, license plates and bumper stickers (Long Island Sound, May 21) struck a responsive chord.

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Bedford, N.Y. $1.3 million Bisbee Lane 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, year-old colonial; study, 3 fireplaces, sun room, 3-car garage, 4.4 acres; taxes not assessed. Rye, N.Y. $350,000 289 Milton Road 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 60-year-old English stucco; fireplace, sun room, breakfast nook, maid's room, 1-car garage; taxes $3,139. Rye Brook, N.Y. $600,000 29 Hillandale Road 5-bedroom, 2 full- and 2 half-bath, 14-year-old split-level; cathedral ceiling in living room, family room, sun porch, 3-car garage; taxes $6,436. Old Saybrook, Conn. $172,000 6 Garden Place 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 53-year-old ranch; beach setting, fully furnished; taxes $679. Chester, Conn. $190,000 44 Spring Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, Cape Cod circa 1800; pond on property, glass entry porch, 1.6 acres; taxes $1,093. Lyme, Conn. $1.1 million Selden Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 9-year-old waterfront contemporary; beach and dock rights, 2.8 acres; taxes $4,172. OTHER AREAS Smithtown, L.I. $262,000 36 Brooksite Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 29-year-old colonial; pool, 0.75 acre, 4-car garage; taxes $6,400. Nesconset, L.I. $236,000 15 Michael Place 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 23-year-old colonial; den, fireplace, Florida room, 0.5 acre; taxes $5,100. Wayne, N.J. $276,000 12 Bristol Terrace 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 26-year-old split level; new roof, close to lake, eat-in-kitchen; taxes $3,100.

title: WAS THE GREAT WAR A SPECIAL EFFECT?
description: RITES OF SPRING The Great War and the Birth of the Modern Age. By Modris Eksteins. Illustrated. 396 pp. Boston: A Peter Davison Book/Houghton Mifflin Company. $24.95.

title: August Wedding For Sigrid Mendel
description: August wedding plans for Sigrid Arlene Mendel, an associate in the New York law firm of Brown & Wood, and Peter James Usen, an equity sales representative at Paine Webber, both in New York, have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. M. Mark Mendel of Radnor, Pa., and Aspen, Colo. Mr. Usen is the son of Robert D. Usen of Brookline, Mass., and Sybil E. Luchetti of Weston, Mass.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about Michelle J. Smithdas, who is deaf and blind, misstated the role that Anne Bancroft played in the movie ''The Miracle Worker.'' She played the part of Annie Sullivan, Helen Keller's teacher. Patty Duke played Helen Keller.

title: Chance or Causality?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Literary Corner Of Cornwall
description: ROBERT BRIDGES, the Poet Laureate in King George V's day, called Fowey, in Cornwall, ''the most poetic-looking town in England.'' The superlative is absurd, of course; other English villages are the equal in poetic beauty of this old seaport and yachting center, which lies in a wooded river valley on the south flank of the Cornish peninsula.

title: Opponents Kill Ithaca Highway After Long Fight
description: A large, vocal and relentless group of residents has claimed victory here in a 15-year battle against a four-lane highway.

title: Heavy Rains Strain Sewage Systems
description: LEAD: HEALTH officials on Long Island may be patting themselves on the back for their successful efforts in ridding ocean beaches of most floatable waste thus far this summer. But they have had no time to celebrate.

title: Helena Buonanno Weds W. G. Foulkes
description: Helena Grace Buonanno, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard V. Buonanno Jr. of Providence, R.I., was married yesterday to William G. Foulkes, a son of Mrs. Arthur F. Foulkes of Plainview, L.I., and the late Mr. Foulkes. The Rev. Robert Randall performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Mary Star of the Sea Church in Narragansett, R.I.

title: Reviews/Music; Two Styles From Jamaica
description: The concert on Tuesday night at S.O.B.'s brought together two strands of Jamaican music - pure pop and dance-hall toasting, or Jamaican rap.

title: Inflation Shows Signs of Easing
description: Inflation eased in June, with consumer prices rising only two-tenths of 1 percent. That is the smallest increase in 16 months and is sharply lower than the six-tenths of 1 percent rise in May. Prices of energy and clothing declined in June and food prices were up only modestly. Still, consumer prices have risen at a 5.9 percent annual rate so far in 1989, the highest six-month rate since 1982.

title:
GARDENING;
Factors That Make Beautiful Flowers Ugly
description: LEAD: MOST flowers are admired for their delicate beauty, yet their fragile nature exposes them to problems that may mar their beauty and render them unattractive.

title:
PASTIMES: Gardening;
Basic Rules for the Care of Mums
description: LEAD: Growing chrysanthemums has given me pleasure every year, but a little time must be spent in their care, particularly at this time of year. In China, there is a saying that ''If you cultivate mums, do not leave home for more than three days.''

title: Rodeos
description: To the Editor: The Sundance Kid did not pair up with Butch Cassidy until the early 1890's and most certainly did not participate in the June 24, 1889, holdup of the San Miguel Valley Bank in Telluride, Colo. (''Cowboy Decor, in Boot, Spur and Horn'' by Dyan Zaslowsky, Travel, June 18). According to most accounts, Butch Cassidy, Matt Warner, Tom McCarty and Bert Madden robbed the bank while several accomplices, including Cassidy's brother, Dan Parker, secured relay horses outside of town. Telluride's marshall, Jim Clark, later bragged that he had been paid to take a walk on the morning of the holdup, which netted the outlaws about $20,000 (more than $200,000 today). DANIEL BUCK Washington

title: Nancy B. Knauer Is Wed to Dr. Dicran Goulian Jr.
description: Nancy Beth Knauer, a lawyer in private practice in New York, and Dr. Dicran Goulian Jr., an attending surgeon and the former director of training for plastic surgery at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, were married last evening at the Moreno Restaurant in New York.

title: Reviewing Views Of the County
description: S. J. Schulman writes [ ''The County Past, the County Future,'' Westchester Opinion, July 2 ] in the capacity of president of the Westchester County Association, which represents large corporations. Accepting this caveat, some of the thinking in his article may still cause believers in Westchester's future progress to stop short.

title: BEATING OURSELVES AT THE GAME
description: LEAD: MADE IN AMERICA Regaining the Productive Edge. By Michael L. Dertouzos, Richard K. Lester, Robert M. Solow and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology Commission on Industrial Productivity. 344 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The MIT Press. $17.95.

title: U.S. Jews Organize to Urge Israel-P.L.O. Talks
description: Liberal American Jews have formed a lobby to persuade Congress and the Bush Administration that Israel should negotiate with the Palestine Liberation Organization and agree to the formation of an independent Palestinian state.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: 'OLIVER!'

title: Votes in Congress; Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York
description: Senate

title: VIOLENCE IN A MAN'S WORLD
description: The violence to women does not stop on the streets. The emotional trauma is perpetuated by the courts. Gender bias in judicial proceedings exists. This is a subject that cannot be ignored. It warrants the attention of every member of the bar and bench. SHARON A. HOPKINS Potomac, Md.

title: The Peter Pan Generation Makes Room for Small Fry
description: It is a truism among baby boomers that none of them ever really feels grown up. Their parents might have guarded such a feeling as a shameful little secret, but this generation refuses to be quiet about it. The idea provides the nagging uneasiness beneath ''The Big Chill,'' the bedrock assumption of television's ''Thirtysomething,'' and the most astute feature of ''Big.'' In recent years, films from ''Star Wars'' to ''Who Framed Roger Rabbit'' have catered to this childish side of a huge potential audience. Both ''Ghostbusters'' films, with their slapstick waves of slime, first green and now pink, appeal to actual children and to their baby-boomer parents, who cling to the vestiges of the days when they howled at the Three Stooges on TV after school. In ''Ghostbusters II,'' even before a wily ghost sends Sigourney Weaver's baby racing into Manhattan traffic in his carriage, Dan Aykroyd and Ernie Hudson have left a children's birthday party in disgrace. The down-and-out ghostbusters had tried to entertain a roomful of kids who would much rather have seen cartoon superheroes. Mr. Aykroyd dismisses these ungrateful wretches as disgusting little ''yuppie larva.''

title: What Kind of House Does $5 Million Buy?
description: A MILLION dollars may not buy what it once did - a baronial estate in the county, for example - but $5 million will still buy something special. And apparently there are enough affluent buyers about to encourage the speculative construction of multimillion-dollar dwellings.

title: FICTION
description: SHADES OF FORTUNE. By Stephen Birmingham. (Little, Brown, $18.95.) The ghost of '' 'Our Crowd': The Great Jewish Families of New York'' hovers over Stephen Birmingham's latest novel - not a powerful ghost but an anemic creature quite incapable of breathing life into an improbable story whose banal prose and careless point of view are all the more perplexing because they come from a writer who has, at least in his nonfiction, demonstrated a certain narrative gift. Mr. Birmingham's heroine, Mimi Myerson, the innovative head of the Miray cosmetics empire, must save her company from the machinations of her mostly distasteful family - and from the clutches of her on-again, off-again lover, Michael Horowitz, a cocky real estate magnate with holdings in Atlantic City, as well as a turreted Palm Beach mansion clearly modeled on Donald Trump's Mar-a-Lago. In between the elaborations of Mimi's business entanglements, there is romantic intrigue, greed, some humdrum (but mercifully quick) sex, a smattering of bisexuality and a touch of anti-Semitism. ''Shades of Fortune'' belongs to the genre of commercial fiction in which the opulence of contemporary New York society is evoked by the liberal dropping of luxurious brand names and the closest thing to a portentous image is the repeated mention of cockroaches penetrating the lavish apartments in a luxurious hotel.

title: New Efforts Made to Help Minority Firms
description: LEAD: A RECENT conference here that brought together more than 700 minority business owners and representatives from 23 public agencies and corporations is indicative of the efforts of many private companies to increase the amount of business they do with minority-owned companies.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. After my front step was painted someone stepped in the paint and left tracks on my flagstone walk. I have tried turpentine and paint thinner, but neither has worked. How can I remove the stains from the flagstone?

title: Maine Wedding For Sara Dowd
description: Sara Keating Dowd and Thomas Blackburn Wells were married yesterday at the Harrington Meeting House in Pemaquid, Me., by the Rev. Charles C. Smith, a Congregational minister.

title: Traveler's Checks
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''Coping With a Bogus Credit Card Charge'' by Betsy Wade (Practical Traveler, June 18), I regret to tell you that similar nefarious practices exist in the United States as well as abroad. I had a visitor who had a reservation at a New York hotel. He called from my apartment to cancel two days before the date of the reservation. To his surprise, his Eurocard account was billed for $95.26, which was deducted from his bank account in Europe. All calls to the hotel, letter writing as well as intervention by a New York consumer protection agency and the Better Business Bureau were to no avail. ARIEL DISTENFELD New York, N.Y.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
Men's Symptoms During Pregnancy
description: LEAD: ''I FEEL much better than I did during the first three months of the pregnancy. I was nauseated all the time.''

title: Reviews/Music; New Leads In City Opera 'Candide'
description: The New York City Opera has been offering its 1982 Hal Prince production of Leonard Bernstein's ''Candide'' at the New York State Theater, with two groups of singers alternating in most of the principal roles. The second cast made its first appearance on Wednesday evening.

title:
GARDENING;
Factors That Make Beautiful Flowers Ugly
description: LEAD: MOST flowers are admired for their delicate beauty, yet their fragile nature exposes them to problems that may mar their beauty and render them unattractive.

title: Israel Lets Arab Pupils Back in School
description: For a few minutes just after noon today, strike-bound Arab cities in the West Bank came to life as thousands of Palestinian students filed out of their schools, ending the first day of classes in six months.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: WASHINGTON;
Preservation With Progress
description: LEAD: JUST nine blocks from the White House, a $100 million project is under way that will transform a department store built in 1914 and preserve the facades of two turn-of-the-century buildings while creating a 500-seat theater and 381 one- and two-bedroom apartments.

title: Tent Made With Flags Set Up in Tompkins Sq.
description: About 200 homeless people built a tent made of four large American flags in Tompkins Square Park yesteday afternoon to protest a New York City Parks and Recreation Department policy prohibiting structures in the park where police officers and park workers destroyed 35 tents on July 5.

title: Derby Fare
description: To the Editor: Regarding the article on mint juleps and Derby-Pie (''The Favorite at Churchill Downs: Derby-Pie,'' Travel, April 30), may I point out that Henry Clay died in 1852? Thus, it would be difficult for him to have written ''in the 1880's'' as your author suggests. BETS BORRIES CREAN Glen Ridge, N.J.

title: More Black Voices Wanted
description: To the Editor:

title: Alison E. Valtin Plans Wedding
description: Dr. and Mrs. Heinz Valtin of Norwich, Vt., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Alison Eva Valtin and Dr. Steven Charles Erwin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Erwin of Waldwick, N.J.

title: Note to Readers
description: The Op-Ed page welcomes unsolicited manuscripts. Because of the volume of submissions, however, we regret that we cannot acknowledge receipt of or return articles unless they are accompanied by a self-addressed, stamped envelope. If your manuscript is accepted for publication, we will notify you within two weeks.

title: Tax Villain: Municipal Unions
description: In the ode to County Executive Patrick G. Halpin entitled ''To Quell Revolt, Halpin Pledges No Tax Increase'' (July 2), any Republican mentioned in the article was cast in the most negative light. It was the comment of the so-called leader of the Suffolk Republican Committee who accused me of dividing the G.O.P. caucus of the Legislature that prompts this letter.

title: Teaching Teachers to Teach the Arts
description: The term ''Arts Education'' is often suspect, conjuring images of boring slide presentations and droning lecturers in an auditorium full of uninterested and unruly third graders. But the Lincoln Center Institute for the Arts in Education takes a different approach, one that evolved after nearly a decade of trial and error.

title: The Dean Files: Flattery in the Quest for Power
description: The weighty files of letters saved by Deborah Gore Dean in the years she served as an influential executive assistant to Samuel R. Pierce Jr., then the Housing Secretary, include a note of warning that was signed, ''A Friend.''

title: Rain Is Vehicle Of Race Car Thrills
description: Once the heavy rain started in the Marlboro Grand Prix last Sunday in East Rutherford, N.J., there were only four drivers with the talent and equipment to win.

title: Just Call Her  [ Jessica ]  Leigh
description: OUR daughter, Jessica, leaves for college soon. She has informed us that she will not be returning home as Jessica. In this new life adventure of hers she intends to be called Leigh. She has informed the school of that, and coincidentally, us.

title: A Mainstream Conductor Joins the Early-Music Act
description: Simon Rattle's conducting of Mozart's ''Nozze di Figaro'' at the Glyndebourne Festival Opera in southern England this summer is an important historical event - what might be called the missing link in the evolution of the early-music movement.

title: Hot Mets Retrieve Victory From Braves
description: The Mets whirled to their fifth consecutive victory last night when they rallied in the eighth inning to defeat the Atlanta Braves, 7-5, and to extend the streak that thrust them back into the pennant race in hot pursuit of the Montreal Expos.

title: Miss Sutherland To Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard K. McLaren of New York and Darien, Conn., have announced August wedding plans for Mrs. McLaren's daughter Amanda Channell Sutherland and Thomas Wayne Mason, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Mason of Valley Forge, Pa.

title: In Defense Of Special Education
description: A May 14 letter [ ''Special Education Isn't Sacrosanct ] is incorrect, misleading and prejudicial. It attempts to take two separate issues (high taxes, and costs for special education) and tie them together.

title: Rival Claims of the Good Life Test Fairfield County
description: LEAD: SINCE spring, Rhode Island has been running advertisements to woo Fairfield County residents and companies who complain about expensive housing, traffic congestion and long train commutes into switching to the Ocean State. Now, a Stamford-based business group is setting out to reassure people that Fairfield County is the best of all possible worlds.

title:
FOCUS;
What It Took to Convince Sears to Stay in Illinois
description: LEAD: ''I'm thrilled to death that Sears is coming to town,'' said Annette Parker as she stood on line in the local post office. ''It will put Hoffman Estates on the map, and it will be good for the economy with those jobs Sears is going to bring in.''

title: Question Of the Week; Should Bo Jackson Give Up One Sport?
description: Bo Jackson's feats of derring-do have convinced me beyond the shadow of a doubt that he should not give up one sport. The fact that he might be burned out within 5 or maybe 10 years is not relevant. If he manages two incomes with prudence, he will be financially secure for the rest of his life. MARVIN WARREN New York

title: Church Must Look at Causes of Clergy Shortage; Beginning of the End
description: To the Editor:

title: FICTION
description: TRISTAN AND THE HISPANICS. By Jose Yglesias. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) ''One of those distant Tampa cousins called and told Tristan's mom . . . that Grandpa was dead. Dad's father. When the call came, Tristan was still unpacking the two duffel bags he had lugged home from New Haven. First year at Yale, so he had accumulated a lot.'' Thus begins the journalist, playwright and novelist Jose Yglesias' 11th book. And one could say that Mr. Yglesias has established a promising premise for his story: Grandpa, Juan (Pinpin) Granados, was the most famous Latin American writer of his generation and the cultural pride of Tampa's Hispanic section, Ybor City, which is replete with his Cuban-American relatives, both actual and self-anointed. Here, then, is the setting for comedy or tragedy, for a meditation on the hidden and obvious injuries of class - as well as the collision between a prim, cerebral Ivy Leaguer from New York and the earthy first- and second-generation members of his clan. But what ensues, as the young man tries to settle up the patriarch's estate, is oddly soft-pedaled. The characters seem no more than, well, characters, figures cast from a latter-day Damon Runyon mold. There is little in ''Tristan and the Hispanics'' to engage our sympathies, our anger or our sense of the absurd. The one character about whom we long to know more is the grandfather, who is revealed only through his computer files, which Tristan explores in an effort to get to know him. ''Tristan slowed down,'' reads Pinpin's account of a walk with his very young grandson, ''and said, 'Do you remember when we saw the white mouse?' and he looked up at me with shining eyes. It was a thrilling hurting blow. I was afraid for Tristan. That is how art begins. In remembering and wonder.'' That is how art begins.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
VENICE WITH EVERYBODY
description: LEAD: Perhaps no other city in the world has inspired such faithlessness. ''If I were not King of France,'' observed Henry III in 1574, ''I would choose to be a citizen of Venice.'' Generations of visitors have been seduced. In VENICE: The Biography of a City (Norton, $45), Christopher Hibbert, the author of dozens of books of history and travel, links diaries, letters, vivid firsthand accounts into a narrative history of the Most Serene

title: Easy Coming, Easy Going
description: Adnan M. Khashoggi brokered billions of dollars worth of weapons deals and was estimated to be a billionaire himself. Last week the 54-year-old Saudi financier, a lot thinner in the wallet and elsewhere, was extradited to New York to face charges that he helped former President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines in illegal real estate deals. Mr. Khashoggi, whose net worth is said to be down to $40 million and who is 30 pounds lighter since his arrest in April, agreed to extradition after the Swiss said he could be tried in the United States on lesser charges of mail fraud and obstructing justice and not more serious racketeering and conspiracy charges. Mr. Khashoggi, who helped finance an arms shipment to Iran in what turned into the Iran-contra affair, was described by his lawyer as ''quite jolly and easygoing'' on the trip.

title: POP GOES THE CANON
description: LEAD: THE CATALOG OF LOST BOOKSAn Annotated and Seriously Addled Collection of Great Books That Should Have Been Written but Never Were. By Tad Tuleja. Illustrated. 201 pp. New York: Fawcett Columbine. Paper, $7.95.

title: Safe Use of Extension Ladders
description: LADDERS are almost always necessary when working on a home's exterior. Usually, the type needed is an extension ladder. These consist of two straight sections, one of which can be slid upward and hooked near the end of the other to form a single long length.

title: Question Of the Week; Should Bo Jackson Give Up One Sport?
description: Personally, I'm getting a bit sick of Bo and all of the hype surrounding him. What's the big deal? He's batting .260 and has already struck out 98 times. He's hardly a Ruben Sierra or a Mike Greenwell, who both don't even get a third of the attention they deserve. Hitting a home run in an All-Star Game does not make someone Paul Bunyan or a legend. He'll never put up Hall of Fame numbers playing both sports. Bo, play football! ANDREW FIEDELMAN New York

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: SANDRA BERNABEI;
Helping Children Make Better Choices
description: LEAD: WHILE the town of Harrison is one of the county's wealthiest communities, not all of its residents are affluent people who can pay for the counseling services they or their families may need. So in 1980 the Harrison Youth Council was established to assist troubled and ''at risk'' youths and their families - regardless of their economic status.

title: Learning and Testing: The State's Role
description: In his article, Andrew Dunn argues that school districts that are unwilling or unable to educate all children adequately should not be taken over by the state. Fortunately, the Legislature - representing the state's citizenry - thought otherwise and passed legislation enabling the state to take over educationally bankrupt school districts.

title: PASTIMES: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Study bulb catalogues arriving in the mail and make plans for next spring's flower display; mail orders promptly as supply of the rarer bulbs is often limited. Keep after weeds. Prune back exuberance of hedges, border shrubs and flower borders, especially on small properties where growth must be kept to scale. Spray roses again to protect them from black spot disease and mildew. Keep up with fruit tree spray programs as fruit is developing; pick peaches when ripe. Biological Control

title: Echoes in the Courtroom
description: When Bette Midler sings ''Do You Wanna Dance,'' a critic wrote in 1972, her style ''irresistably wraps the vocalist in the seamiest, sexiest voice imaginable.'' Ford bought the rights to the song to use in a commercial for its Mercury Sable, and asked Miss Midler to sing it. When she refused, Ford's advertising agency, Young &

title: 2d Arrest in Highway Killing
description: State police have arrested a second man in connection with last month's highway shooting death of a motorcycle club president. Jude Sinchak, 31 years old, of Waterbury was arrested Friday and charged with conspiracy to commit murder, a state police spokesman said. Mr. Sinchak is the second man arrested in the June 28 shooting death of Jose Barriera, 30, who was killed in a hail of gunfire when a car pulled up alongside him as he drove along Route 8. The police are investigating whether feuding between rival motorcyle groups led to the shooting.

title: Quinones Released
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates released Rey Quinones, their starting shortstop, yesterday, only three months after trading a starting pitcher and two of their top minor league prospects for him. The Pirates acquired Quinones from Seattle on April 21, along Bill Wilkinson, a minor league pitcher, in exchange for Mike Dunne, a 13-game winner in 1987; Mark Merchant, an outfielder, and Mike Walker, another pitcher.

title: Gorbachev's Great Test
description: Now reform is coming to the nitty-gritty, not just the pathetic question of soap to wash the daily grime off Russian miners, but the core issues of changing society.

title: British Debate Entry of Hong Kong Refugees
description: The controversy surrounding Britain's refusal to allow holders of British passports in Hong Kong to settle here has fed a long-running debate over this nation's policies toward immigrants.

title: DATABANK: July 23, 1989
Answering The Mail
description: Q. After my front step was painted someone stepped in the paint and left tracks on my flagstone walk. I have tried turpentine and paint thinner, but neither has worked. How can I remove the stains from the flagstone?

title: When the Magic Leaves the Island
description: THE tearing sound of a $5 bill filled the hands of my magical father. My nephew's eyes, already so tremendous in their 5-year-old sockets, blossomed in amazement: ''Gramma, Grampa ripped that $5 in half!''

title: Remembering a Young Camper Who Didn't Make the Trip
description: GRAND CENTRAL TERMINAL is busy with groups of children on their way to spend two weeks with families in the country. They will be met by their hosts at various railroad stations in Westchester. The expressions on the faces of the young travelers reveal their feelings -eager or apprehensive. One, who looks wide-eyed and solemn, moves near me and asks:

title: Street Smarts Beyond Rap's Braggadocio
description: From the outside, Rap is a monolith - the sound of booming beats and loudmouthed, tuneless egotists chanting. But with rap now in its second decade as the music of urban teen-agers (and, increasingly, of suburbanites as well), it is anything but unified.

title: A Turning Point on the 8:05
description: WHEN I commuted to New York from Hoboken, a tense drama played before me every morning. Show time was 8:05, when I boarded the No. 126 bus to New York.

title: A Master List For Vacation Lists
description: NOW that summer is in full swing, one's thoughts are turning to vacation planning. That is, planning for that massive chore, packing, which is definitely a science.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q & A: MATTHEW NEMERSON;
'The Burden of Cities Is Even Greater'
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH tensions between Connecticut's cities and towns are centuries old, they can indeed work together, said Matthew Nemerson, who points to his experiences as director of the Greater New Haven Chamber of Commerce as proof.

title: For a Bite at the End of the Line
description: FOR the sailor on Long Island Sound, getting there may be half the fun. Dining there can be the other half if one knows where to dock and eat.

title: PASTIMES: Camera
description: One of the reasons professional photographers have been slow to adopt all-automatic cameras has to do with personality. Photographers have idiosyncratic personalities but automatic cameras are electronic machines that predictably, monotonously repeat themselves, perfect exposure after exposure. Most automatic cameras are conformist, while most photographers are not.

title: De Klerk Makes an Overture to Mandela's Group
description: F. W. de Klerk, the leader of South Africa's ruling party, said today that if the outlawed African National Congress was prepared to endorse a statement by its jailed leader, Nelson R. Mandela, by ''committing itself to the pursuit of peaceful solutions,'' it could become involved in a ''process of dialogue and negotiation.''

title: POSTINGS: Option for Amnesty; Vault Taxes
description: If you own a piece of one of the 14,000 buildings in New York that has a vault beneath it, the city tax man may be looking for you. While few New Yorkers may realize it, the city has since 1962 imposed a revenue-raising charge on vaults - spaces beneath city sidewalks that are connected to private buildings. But the charge had gone largely uncollected until last year when the city Department of Finance sent out thousands of bills totaling almost $9 million in vault charges, including penalties and interest on those that had gone unpaid.

title: U.S. Record Set At N.Y. Games
description: The inaugural New York Games were barely an hour old yesterday when two of the best performers of the outdoor season, Sandra Farmer-Patrick and Dawn Sowell, left distinctive but different impressions on the first major international outdoor meet in New York in 23 years.

title: An Avalanche of Information Is Coming to Video Screens
description: AS the computer screen rivals the printed page as a way of publishing information, readers may have to get used to stranger things than electronic newspapers.

title: From Back in the U.S.S.R., Rock Comes to 54th St.
description: On the Manhattan club scene, it was glasnost in Gotham.

title: Works in Progress;  From the Ground Up, Warily
description: >TEN MILES EAST OF SPITAK, the Armenian town closest to the epicenter of last December's cataclysmic earthquake, the city of Kirovakan still has a skyline. All 100 or so of the 9- and 10-story apartment buildings there remain erect. Meanwhile, in Leninakan, 30 miles west of Spitak, most of the equivalent structures were leveled by the quake (right) or damaged beyond repair and demolished. ''This is what intrigues us,'' says John Filson, a seismologist with the United States Geological Survey, ''the enormous difference in the damage pattern.''

title: International Flavor Adds Zest to London Festival
description: Beyond the appetite here for American exports - which produced the well-timed July 4 opening of ''Anything Goes,'' and continues unabated - London's theatrical life has taken an international turn of late. Such imported fare is traditional at the Edinburgh International Festival, which occasionally sends its best offerings south for further exposure. But this year, even before Edinburgh opens its 43d season on Aug. 12, London theatergoers have been able to broaden their cultural horizons closer to home. This, in fact, may be the year in which London takes the lead in an area that Edinburgh has long dominated by default.

title: Sarah Rahr Weds Benjamin Fortna
description: Sarah Elizabeth Rahr, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Guido Reinhardt Rahr Jr. of Mound, Minn., was married yesterday to Benjamin Carr Fortna, a son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Robert Tomson Fortna of Poughkeepsie, N.Y. The bridegroom's father, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Martin's-by-the-Lake Episcopal Church in Minnetonka Beach, Minn.

title: Julia A. McIntosh Marries
description: Julia A. McIntosh, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William A. McIntosh of Kenilworth, Ill., and John D. Smith, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Smith of Hyannis, Mass., were married yesterday by the Rev. Thomas Ventura, at SS. Faith Hope and Charity Roman Catholic Church in Winnetka, Ill. Mrs. McIntosh-Smith was until recently a sales assistant at Bear Stearns & Company in Chicago. Mr. Smith is a municipal bond trader at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in Clearwater, Fla.

title: Rolling Stones Gather Curiosity
description: In Washington, First Selectman Alan J. Chapin has lost count of the number of reporters who have come to town to interview him in the last week or so.

title: In Race for New TV System, Researchers Work Out Kinks
description: LEAD: AMID the euphoria of demonstrating the world's first broadcast system for high-definition television in April, scientists at the David Sarnoff Research Center realized that their effort to develop a standard for the next generation of American television was far from complete.

title: Gloria M. Hoyal Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Raymond G. Hoyal of Downey, Calif., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter Gloria M. Hoyal, 26 years old, an associate at Battle Fowler, and Randall Marc Skigen, 32, an associate at Lord Day & Lord, Barrett Smith, both Manhattan law firms. Mr. Skigen is a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Skigen of Stamford, Conn.

title: Michael J. Malone: Tape Impresario
description: Some years ago, Michael J. Malone was sitting in a friend's bar in Seattle listening to the same old tapes on a mechanically uncertain cassette machine, when he got an idea.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Hazlet $175,000 5 Revere Court 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 10-year-old contemporary; c/a, underground sprinkler system, full basement; taxes $2,392. North Plainfield $224,000 751 Ayres Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; fireplace, porch, eat-in kitchen; taxes $2,435. Plainsboro $241,500 107 Parker Road 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 8-year-old colonial; family room, w/w carpeting, family room; taxes $3,372. Pompton Plains $175,000 49 Marlin Avenue 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 12-year-old contemporary; dining room, professionally landscaped; taxes $2,510. Wayne $276,000 12 Bristol Terrace 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 26-year-old split level; new roof, close to lake, eat-in kitchen; taxes $3,100. West Orange $313,500 15 Hepworth Place 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 38-year-old colonial; patio, 2-car garage, fireplace, c/a; taxes $4,926. OTHER AREAS Old Saybrook, Conn. $172,000 6 Garden Place 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 53-year-old ranch; beach setting, fully furnished; taxes $679. Rye, N.Y. $350,000 289 Milton Road 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 60-year-old English stucco; fireplace, sun room w/greenhouse window, breakfast nook, maid's room, 1-car garage; taxes $3,139. Smithtown, L.I. $262,000 36 Brooksite Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 29-year-old colonial; pool, 0.75 acre, 4-car garage; taxes $6,400.

title: Transactions
description: FRIDAY Baseball

title: Church Must Look at Causes of Clergy Shortage; Sharing the Task
description: To the Editor:

title: Aiming Beyond The Candidates' Smoke Screens
description: As the television campaign for the New York City mayoralty primaries gets going in earnest, one's thoughts return, somewhat dispiritedly, to the 1988 Presidential campaign. On Wednesday, the candidates for mayor will have their first debate, parts of which will likely be carried by local news programs. Will it be the sort of nondebate that the managers of George Bush and Michael Dukakis imposed on the networks?

title: Review/Music; Maag, Uchida, Robison In All, Not Mostly, Mozart
description: When the Mostly Mozart festival was founded, in 1966, one of its stated missions was the exploration of Mozart's complete canon, from his earliest works to his last. Of course the Mostly in the festival's title affords ample license to look in other directions.

title:
DINING OUT;
An Elegant Atmosphere in Mahwah
description: LEAD: THE MARK was a famous restaurant in the Mahwah area until it closed in 1967. After several incarnations, the most recent being a Chinese restaurant called Chan's, the Mark has reopened under the joint ownership of Thomas Lynch, a businessman, and Dean and Glen Buttafucuo, who were formerly associated with the Carnivale Restaurant in

title: A Theater Full of Woes
description: Thanks largely to the upheaval wrought more or less by the Reagan years, the movie theater industry isn't sitting very pretty.

title: Even When He Compromises, Assad Takes a Hard Line
description: SYRIA'S President, Hafez al-Assad, attended the Arab summit meeting in Morocco two months ago under familiar conditions: the odds were stacked against him. ''The other Arabs really wanted to gang up on him,'' a Western diplomat here said.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Liechtenstein
description: Vaduz, the vineyard-girded village-capital of an independent country that is not quite three times the size of Manhattan, starts filling up around 10 A.M. every day when the tourist buses arrive. The visitors clamber out, stretch their legs, wander about Vaduz's two business streets, snap pictures of the 700-year-old gray castle that frowns on them from its steep, wooded rock, have a snack or a meal and mail stacks of postcards with Liechtenstein's pretty stamps. Some walk into the newly refurbished building of the State Art Collection to look at the masterpieces of Flemish landscape painting from Breughel to Rubens now on display there.

title: U.S. Diplomat May Have Started Spying in the 70's, Official Says
description: American investigators believe that Felix S. Bloch, a veteran diplomat suspected of espionage, began spying for the Soviet Union at least a decade ago, a senior Administration official said today.

title: Recalling the Time of the Lighthouse
description: LEAD: AN era comes to a close as the last civilian lighthouse keeper vacates his station this year, his expertise replaced by automation. In ''Northeast Lighthouses,'' an exhibition at the Maritime Center in Norwalk through Sept. 15, the stories of such keepers and their lighthouses are vividly captured.

title: Correction
description: An article on June 18 about struggling film makers misstated the role of Gary Handel in making the film ''Czechs and Balances.'' As Debra Epstein, the producer and principal financier of the film, has written to point out, Mr. Handel was co-writer and co-producer.

title: Seeing Change, Apartheid's Foes Seek a Path of Less Resistance
description: THE South African Government and the African National Congress have grown accustomed to speaking of each other in terms of good beseiged by evil, of angels locked in combat with satanic forces. The white minority Government casts the congress, which it banned in 1960, as a group of bomb-happy terrorists beholden more to Moscow than their motherland. The congress, Africa's oldest national liberation movement, dismisses the Government in Pretoria as a regime of incorrigible racists destined to join apartheid on history's trash heap.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: KHE SANH. Siege in the Clouds: An Oral History. By Eric Hammel. (Crown, $24.95.) The voices of about 100 American servicemen, mostly Marines, take the reader of ''Khe Sanh'' straight into the trenches and foxholes of one of the worst sieges in the history of the American armed forces. In the lush Vietnamese highlands, 6,000 Marines battled an estimated 40,000 soldiers from the North Vietnamese Army for 77 days in the first three months of 1968.

title: Fashion; Paris Couture Today Get Ready for Surprises
description: Consistency is certainly not a characteristic of fashion. As the fall 1989 Paris couture week neared, it seemed a capital idea to anticipate what the most important designers would show, with examples from their already completed fall ready-to-wear collections. Wrong. Caught by fax or phone, six out of seven of them indicated that, in shows starting today, they were pursuing directions other than the ones shown here.

title: Adrienne C. Muranyi Weds Daniel N. Fuss
description: Adrienne Carol Muranyi, the daughter of Donna K. Muranyi and Joseph P. Muranyi, both of New York, was married yesterday to Daniel Nathan Fuss, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard L. Fuss of Delray Beach, Fla., at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Osterville, Mass. The Rev. W. Raymond Webster 3d officiated.

title: An English TroupePuts New EmphasisOn Ensemble Work
description: When Peter Schaufuss, the Danish-born dancer, became artistic director of the London Festival Ballet in September 1984, he had big plans. At the top of his list were a new, varied repertory and a revitalized team of dancers, starting with the corps. He hoped to start a company school. He wanted a permanent London theater. And, like artistic directors throughout Britain, he had to dream up new ways to pay for everything.

title: Long Island Journal
description: 'I Got Into Pony Camp'

title: Third World and Debt Aren't Synonymous
description: To the Editor:

title: It's Not Easy to Cross the Street
description: I SAVED an earthworm in the morning. Running in the rain, I noticed hundreds (thousands?) of worms that had crawled onto the roads.

title: Salt Spring Island and Its Sisters
description: FROM the early morning ferry traveling Satellite Channel bound for Salt Spring Island, one of Canada's Gulf Islands nestled between the British Columbia mainland and Vancouver Island, the Strait of Georgia resembles azure glass in the sunlight. There is land in sight: rounded coniferous hills marking the San Juan Islands of Washington State to the south, and the smaller, sparsely populated outer Gulf Islands of Pender (pop. 1,350), Galiano (850), Mayne (750) and Saturna (260). Cormorants ruffle their feathers on buoys. A hawk circles with a snake in its talons. A sea otter rolls and dives. Pods of migrating killer whales breach in the channel, their blow holes sending spumes of stinky mist high in the air.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Are Yanks Making The Right Moves?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: FICTION
description: MY FATHER IN DREAMS. By C. E. Poverman. (Scribners, $22.50.) C. E. Poverman's fourth book of fiction is not a novel so much as a series of short stories that lurches around the narcissistic Jed Hartwick and his equally unlikable family and friends. The emotionally parasitic Jed and these other unsympathetic characters - manic-depressives, obsessive-compulsives and silent sociopaths - inflict physical and emotional pain on themselves and one another. They do this in pursuit of dubious motives and themes, which include the mutual resentments of fathers and sons, the idea of love as a prison and the family as torture, the romance of disorder and the belief in the purifying powers of self-destruction and pain. Tellingly, at some point all these characters bruise themselves or someone else. Not surprisingly, their emotions range from claustrophobia to panic to despair. And the nightmares that occur in a group with such obstinate pathologies are even worse. A facile chapter devoted to Jed's journey to India is implausible, absurdly out of step with the young Jed, who is mostly revealed in flashbacks to his glory days as a champion diver. The only remotely appealing character in ''My Father in Dreams'' is Jed's girlfriend, Grace, whose pregnancy inspires his self-examination. But eventually Grace ceases to engage our interest; if we like her and believe in her, how can we also accept her decision to ally herself with the infantile, shallow Jed?

title: For Polish Film, a Mood of Cautious Optimism
description: Among the numerous posters on the streets of Warsaw urging Poles to vote for Solidarity's candidates in the elections last month, one was particularly striking: in the middle of the bold red letters that spell out ''Solidarnosc'' was the vertical image of Gary Cooper as the sheriff in ''High Noon.'' The conjunction of politics and film - and of a unique Polish moment with a timeless American icon of individual courage - is characteristic of this complex nation: Poland is, after all, a country where the power of the silver screen has often seemed more tangible than the Iron Curtain.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Old Estates Fade as Developers Move In
description: LEAD: SOME of Long Island's most beautiful land, which had been in large estates maintained by owners in densely developed Nassau County, is only now coming on the market.

title: Day Hiking in the Heart of Jasper
description: IN the early 19th century the vast trail network of what is now Jasper National Park was an essential passageway for Indians, explorers and fur traders. Today it is a source of recreation and escape for hikers who have come to enjoy Jasper's natural wonders.

title: Forrest Anderson, Ex-Governor Of Montana, Kills Himself at 76
description: Forrest H. Anderson, who in one term as Governor of Montana helped bring sweeping changes to the state's governmental system, died of a self-inflicted gunshot wound Thursday at his home here. He was 76 years old and had been in failing health for years.

title: Shira Seaman Married to Urs Bamert
description: Shira Seaman, a daughter of the author Barbara Seaman and Dr. Gideon Seaman, both of New York, and Urs Bamert, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Willy Bamert of Zurich, were married last evening at the Museum Club at Bridgewaters at the South Street Seaport in New York. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman officiated.

title:
HADDONFIELD JOURNAL;
Vendor Wins Fight to Sell Hot Dogs on the Street
description: LEAD: MAXINE HOUSTON, a borough resident for 25 years, paused recently in front of Steven Bodner's hot-dog cart, which has caused commotion and contention in this historic town that prides itself on tranquillity and civility.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Washington;
Preservation With Progress
description: LEAD: JUST nine blocks from the White House, a $100 million project is under way that will transform a department store built in 1914 and preserve the facades of two turn-of-the-century buildings while creating a 500-seat theater and 381 one- and two-bedroom apartments.

title: Fresh Ingredients in a Farmhouse Setting
description: CAROL PECK'S RESTAURANT, situated on a hillside on Route 202 in New Milford, is the kind of imaginative roadside restaurant discerning motorists dream about (and rarely find) when looking for an enticing place to eat on an unfamiliar country lane.

title: THE END OF THE WORLD IN VILNA
description: FROM THAT PLACE AND TIME A Memoir 1938-1947. By Lucy S. Dawidowicz. 333 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $21.95

title: Sex, Lies, Truth And Consequences
description: When most people would be arriving in Hollywood, Steven Soderbergh is leaving.

title: BASEBALL: National League; Expos Get 5 Runs Off Franco in 9th to Beat Reds
description: The Reds' John Franco had given up one home run this season and recorded 23 saves in 26 opportunities. Then came his appearance against the Expos today.

title: In Today's Election, Japan's Ruling Elite Faces a Fed-Up People
description: DURING a generation of command over Japan's political system, the Liberal Democratic Party became accustomed to a world in which few bothered to wonder what it would be like if someone else were in power. But with Japanese voters increasingly irate and impatient, the party has approached the national election today with the enthusiasm of a man contemplating his own hanging.

title: Miss Huntzinger Engaged to Wed
description: September wedding plans have been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Wendell L. Huntzinger of Doylestown, Pa., for their daughter Kimberly Ann Huntzinger and James E. Buck 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Buck of New York.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Brunch; Views of the Water, Safe From Torpedoes
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in the Connecticut, Long Island and Westchester Sunday regional sections of The New York Times. Ratings at the end of each item - satisfactory, good, very good, excellent and extraordinary - are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. The Barge

title: August Wedding For Miss Ostertag
description: An August wedding is planned by Marianne Ostertag, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Torkild Ostertag of Aalborg, Denmark, who have announced her engagement to Jean-Francois de Laperouse, a son of the Count and Countess de Laperouse of Fair Haven, N.J.

title: U.S. Move May Halt An Iran-Contra Case
description: The Justice Department, responding to concerns expressed by the Central Intelligence Agency, is preparing a step that could kill some or all of the Iran-contra criminal case against Joseph Fernandez, a former C.I.A. operative.

title: Joyous Homecoming for Farmer-Patrick
description: It was a day of mixed success yesterday for Sandra and David Patrick at the first New York Games. It was great for her, awful for him.

title: A Fall Wedding For Amy Kiernan
description: Anne Madeleine Kiernan's engagement to Griffith Eric Lewis, the son of Mr. and Mrs. G. Richard Lewis of Albany, has been made known by her mother, Mrs. Peter D. Kiernan of Albany and Hobe Sound, Fla. An October wedding is planned.

title: Angola Talks Suspended
description: Talks aimed at ending the Angolan civil war were suspended today when the rebel delegation requested consultations with their leaders, according to news reports. According to reports in Kinshasa, Zaire, where the talks are being held, the negotiations are to resume July 31.

title: Get PCB's Out of the Hudson
description: New York State officials have warned the public to limit the amount of striped bass eaten, down to zero consumption for pregnant women, because of the PCB content in the Hudson River bass, which spread out along Long Island in the summer (''Limits on Striped Bass Irk Fishermen,'' July 2).

title: Further Developments in the California State of Mind
description: The presence of a show of ''California photography'' in New York this summer may strike some as odd and others as belated. It is odd because the canard of regionalism has pretty much been laid to rest, thanks to instant communications, art magazines and inexpensive air fares. It is belated because California artists should have been recognized 20 years ago for contributing something vital and important to the way photographic images are made and seen.

title: DENG TALKS AGAIN OF PLAN TO RETIRE
description: China's senior leader, Deng Xiaoping, has announced in an unpublished speech that he plans to retire and leave decision-making in the hands of a younger generation, according to three Chinese officials familiar with party matters at the highest level.

title: D. C. Oakley Wed To Miss Brennan
description: Eileen Mary Brennan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald P. Brennan of Old Brookville and Cutchogue, L.I., was married yesterday to Daniel Charles Oakley, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Oakley of Worcester, Mass. The Rev. Mario C. Costa officiated at St. Paul the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Brookville, L.I.

title: THE HAIRY HAND OF INTELLECT
description: WHAT I CAME TO SAY By Raymond Williams. 280 pp. New York: Hutchinson Radius/W. W. Norton & Company. $21.95.

title: Prospects; Candor From The Fed
description: The Federal Reserve Board chairman, Alan Greenspan, made a remarkable admission last week. Speaking to Congress, he acknowledged that the Fed itself could inadvertently cause an economic downturn by over- or under-reacting. He also indicated that he now worries more about recession than inflation. Four economists assess Mr. Greenspan's statements and the Fed's limitations. Robert DiClemente Economist, Salomon Brothers.

title: For Voice of America, the Challenge Is In China, the Competition in Moscow
description: AS the Soviet Union has changed, so too has the role of the Voice of America.

title: Bring Back Standing Room
description: To the Editor:

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS/HISTORY
description: FOREVER NINETEEN By Grigory Baklanov. Translated by Antonina W. Bouis. 168 pp. New York: J.B. Lippincott.

title: Foster Childhood Motivates Fresh Air Parent 88>
description: Blaine Kneebone looks no farther than the corn fields stretching away from his front porch to know why he has been host to two New York City children each summer for the last four years. It was on a farm a few miles from his house in upper Bucks County that Mr. Kneebone was taken in as a foster child 47 years ago.

title: Train With Crash Survivors Hits and Kills Boy on Tracks
description: An Amtrak train carrying several survivors of Wednesday's crash of a United Airlines jet here struck and killed a 6-year-old boy Friday as he walked his bicycle across the tracks, an Amtrak spokesman said today.

title: Looking at Jersey City's Housing Needs
description: RICK COHEN was director of Jersey City's Department of Housing and Economic Development from 1985 until July 1. He supervised planning and regulation of development of the city's booming Hudson River waterfront and efforts to create low- and moderate-priced housing. Mr. Cohen, 38 years old, began a nationally admired program to have developers contribute to the cost of building affordable housing.

title: The Government Is Hiring, Which Isn't Easy  The Civil Service: Doubts From Within and Without
description: THE 1980's have not been kind to civil servants, and some people say the Federal work force is taking revenge by falling apart. President Bush, the first President in a dozen years who did not campaign against the bureaucracy, responded this month by proposing pay raises for political appointees and a few hundred specialists in the Civil Service. The Office of Personnel Management is trying to revise pay scales for the other two million Federal workers, while several commissions have said that is the least that could be done.

title: The Stanley Works Goes Global
description: Globalization - making factories abroad as important as those at home - has become a familiar strategy for the I.B.M.'s, Du Pont's and Ford's of America. But now it is penetrating to the second tier of American manufacturers and making those companies less identified with the United States.

title: Debra Marie Stasior, an Executive, To Wed Jeffrey Hilton Schumacher
description: The engagement of Debra Marie Stasior to Jeffrey Hilton Schumacher has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Orkan George Stasior of Loudonville, N.Y. Mr. Schumacher is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Schumacher of New York and Sparta, N.J. The wedding will take place later this summer.

title: Charlotte Cannon Plans a Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Norman Lawrence Cannon of Shaker Heights, Ohio, have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Charlotte Walker Cannon and John Fuller Hunt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James William Hunt of Harvard, Mass., and Boothbay Harbor, Me.

title: PASTIMES: Stamps
description: One of the oddest juxtapositions of primitive mail delivery and high technology occurred during the Siege of Paris in 1870-71. The system, like so many innovations, also stirred political rivalries among believers and nonbelievers.

title: Waterfront Transit Plan Questioned
description: WHEN Gov. Thomas H. Kean announced a $2.5 billion transportation plan for the Hudson River waterfront in late June, the proposal sounded very much like a $1 billion plan he proposed in 1985. Since construction never began on the first one, planners and developers have begun to wonder if the new proposal will progress any further than the first did.

title: Peruvian Textiles: Incas' Glowing Heritage
description: WHEN Francisco Pizarro and his conquistadors invaded Peru in 1532, they were amazed to discover warehouses crammed with all manner of textiles. The Spaniards were also dazzled by the splendor of the cloth, for the Incas, elaborating on 3,000 years of tradition, had produced weavings of exceptional beauty and complexity. Soon afterward, the Incas set fire to the textiles to prevent their desecration by the Spanish. But by then, the Incas had grown accustomed to destroying their own work. They valued weaving so highly that they even worshiped a god of textiles, Aksu Mama, in whose honor much exquisite cloth was sacrificed to the flames.

title: Sally J. Adnopoz Becomes a Bride
description: Sally Jane Adnopoz, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Adnopoz of Hamden, Conn., and Steven Harris Gendler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Lee Gendler of Omaha, were married last evening by Rabbi Herbert Brockman at Congregation Mishkan Israel in Hamden.

title: A Remedy Worse Than the Problem
description: The insider-trading scandals that have rocked Wall Street have made it politically popular to increase the Securities and Exchange Commission's enforcement powers. But expanding the powers of government over the affairs of business is always a dangerous proposition. Therefore, the S.E.C.'s latest proposal to expand its powers should be carefully weighed.

title: Let's Limit Span of Congressional Careers
description: To the Editor:

title: Traveler's Checks
description: To the Editor: I had problems with cashing traveler's checks last year in Los Angeles.

title: On the Second Shift
description: To the Editor:

title:
FOCUS: Hoffman Estates, Ill.;
What It Took to Keep Sears in Illinois
description: LEAD: ''I AM thrilled to death that Sears is coming to town,'' said Annette Parker as she stood on line in the local post office. ''It will put Hoffman Estates on the map, and it will be good for the economy with those jobs Sears is going to bring in.''

title: Pilar Llusa Marries Robert P. Chew Jr.
description: Pilar Llusa and Ens. Robert Preston Chew Jr. were married yesterday at the First Church of Round Hill in Greenwich, Conn., by the Rev. Richard F. Van Wely, an Episcopal priest.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: CURBING STOCK MARKET ABUSES;
Expand the Authority of the S.E.C.
description: LEAD: Suppose the Environmental Protection Agency could fine a company for polluting the air, but not the water. Air quality might be acceptable, but would you want to go swimming?

title: Rodeos
description: To the Editor: I was dismayed to see you promoting rodeos (Travel, June 18). You must know the cruelty involved. One picture shows clearly the tight belt around the bull's abdomen, put on by the trainers to pain him so much that he will try to unseat the rider. The text says this is the most dangerous ride; how about danger to the bull?

title: Driving New England's Historic Coast
description: ''YORK HARBOR is only a half hour from Portsmouth and it is a beautiful little sea-side village. In fact everything on this coast is beautiful, and the neatness and self-respect of New England is more amazing than ever.''

title: On Language; Marry-o? Mahr-yo?
description: HAVE A SENSATIONAL expose for you,'' writes Mario E. Severino of Colesville, Md. ''Mario Cuomo isn't really of Italian descent and he was not raised in an Italian family!''

title: Fear of Spiders Brings Out The Police
description: IT was well after 11 o'clock when I went to let my dog in for the night. He waited on the back porch. Starting down the hall to the room off the porch, there was a choice of two hall switches that turn on the light. I used the first.

title: West Side Storey Awaits Coda on Its Suit
description: THERE is a continuing story on the Upper West Side that has not yet reached its final chapter - the tale of the West Side Storey, a restaurant whose owners won a judgment of more than a million dollars last year against their co-op landlord as the result of a tangled series of legal actions stretching back a decade.

title: Housing for Elderly Moves Forward
description: LEAD: AFTER a six-year search for a suitable site for a federally subsidized apartment complex for the elderly, village officials here say they do not foresee major obstacles to the third and latest site for the project.

title: THE EDUCATION OF DAN QUAYLE
description: Now I see why George Bush feels entitled to be called the education President - he is allowing us to finance ''The Education of Dan Quayle'' (by Maureen Dowd, June 25). This scholarship program includes private tutors, a modest mansion within walking distance of an exclusive house, a personal jet for exotic field trips and a ''grant'' considerably more generous than Mr. Bush's minimum-wage training pay recommended for the first year in a new job. SHARON MITCHELL New York, N.Y.

title: Hamptons Horse Show Aims High
description: LEAD: THERE are horse shows and there are Horse Shows, their importance determined by both sport and social factors.

title: Bush Ventures Little And Gets Along Fine
description: TO see why George Bush is doing so well right now, you must step back from the political canvas. No, step back again. Yet more.

title: CBS HAS WON THE WORLD SERIES......NOW IT COULD LOSE ITS SHIRT
description: SINCE THE GAME OF BASE-ball is our national pastime, the making of money our civil religion, and the watching of television our communal opiate, it follows that putting baseball on television is a very big business. Consider the All-Star Game, played less than two weeks ago in Anaheim, Calif.

title: DOCUMENTS SHOW ACTIVE PIERCE ROLE ON FUND REQUESTS
description: Newly released documents show additional instances in which Samuel R. Pierce Jr. intervened as Housing Secretary to help Republicans and took a far more active role in awarding Federal housing assistance than he has indicated in Congressional testimony.

title: Lawyer Engaged To Ms. Hamilton
description: Mr. and Mrs. George L. Hamilton of Fair Haven, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jeanmarie Hamilton to Richard Allen Drucker, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles Drucker of Lawrence, L.I. The wedding is to take place in September. Ms. Hamilton graduated cum laude from Bowdoin College and until recently was a special-needs teacher at the Lorge School in New York.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
