description: WHEN Len Fulton, the editor of The International Directory of Little Magazines & Small Presses, began compiling a list of small publishing houses in 1965, his directory consisted of 40 pages with 250 listings. This year the directory has grown to 900 pages with 4,700 listings, including 156 in New Jersey.

title: Mood Is Festive As Tour Nears End
description: L'ISLE D'ABEAU, France, July 22 -

title: Order of the Day at This Inn: Relax
description: TWO dozen miles from olde English Victoria, on the rugged side of Vancouver Island, is tiny Sooke, where the tourist attractions run to towering evergreens and lonesome rocky beaches.

title:
IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut;
Waging War on Blight in Mount Vernon
description: LEAD: MOUNT VERNON is doing battle with blight by selling derelict property it owns for conversion into ratables - the most important a shopping center on a five-acre parcel that will include a 42,000-acre Waldbaum's supermarket and 15,000 square feet of additional retail space.

title: POSTINGS: 67 Condos in Newark's South Ward;
description: An Art Deco apartment house that had been abandoned by its owners and devastated by vandals has been rehabilitated into 67 one- and two-bedroom condominiums as the first major residential renovation project in the South Ward of Newark. When it originally opened in 1938, the six-story building at 19 Lyons Avenue and Porter Place in the Weequahic Park neighborhood near the border with Elizabeth was the epitome of upper middle-class apartment living, with sunken living rooms, 10-foot ceilings and wood-paneled walls. As with much of Newark, it eventually was overtaken by difficult times.

title: New Owner His Own Man
description: Long before Jerral W. Jones wrote a check last February for $90 million and became majority owner of the Dallas Cowboys, he figured that the game of football yielded the essence needed for living a fruitful life.

title: Jennifer A. Groel Wed to a Lawyer
description: Jennifer Ann Groel, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Berdine Groel of New Vernon, N.J., was married there yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church to Douglas Alan Beimfohr, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward G. Beimfohr of Short Hills, N.J. The Rev. George E. Chorba officiated.

title: Talks Give Hint of a Tradeoff on Taxes
description: Over the last few days, House Speaker Thomas S. Foley has met with President Bush and top Administration officials to explore possibilities for a tax deal that would include reducing the taxation of capital gains by taking inflation into account, Congressional and Administration officials said today.

title: FASHION: On the Street; No, You Don't Need Ear Lobes Of Steel
description: Rap is leaving its mark in more ways than the staccato rhythms that fill the city air at night. Rap groups are influencing fashion and hairstyles, and now the oversize earrings popularized by followers of the music are gaining a following of their own.

title: HIS WIVES AND OTHER STRANGERS
description: KING OF THE NIGHT The Life of Johnny Carson. By Laurence Leamer. Illustrated. 448 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $19.95.

title: Rome
description: To the Editor: My most recent visit to Rome was marred by an incident at a trattoria. It's customary to pay more for a meal at restaurants along the Via Veneto and in the Vatican area. From 3,000 to 4,000 lire (about $2.50 to $3.25) for a cup of coffee or hot chocolate is the going rate, and the prices are usually posted.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. After my front step was painted someone stepped in the paint and left tracks on my flagstone walk. I have tried turpentine and paint thinner, but neither has worked. How can I remove the stains from the flagstone?

title: CAMPUS CONFIDENTIAL
description: NICE WORK By David Lodge. 277 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

title: Arm for Arm, Expos Seem to Have an Edge Over the Mets
description: In spring training, Buck Rodgers, manager of the Montreal Expos, boasted that his team had as good a corps of starting pitchers as the Mets. He was allowed to remain in his Expos uniform instead of being carted off in a straitjacket, and developments are showing that his committal would have been premature.

title: CONSUMER RATES
DUBLIN'S GOT A BRAND-NEW BAG
description: THE COMMITMENTS By Roddy Doyle. 165 pp. New York: Vintage Contemporaries/Vintage Books. Paper, $6.95.

title: STREETSCAPES: The McAlpin Marine Grill; The Fate of a Polychrome Grotto Hangs in Balance
description: IT'S one of the most unusual interiors in New York City - an expansive grotto of flowing, polychrome terra cotta. The 1912 Marine Grill in the old Hotel McAlpin at the southeast corner of 34th Street and Avenue of the Americas was developing a cult following among architectural historians and preservationists. But now the building's owner has closed the restaurant, is working on the space and won't say anything about its future.

title: Hints of Progress on Cambodia Are Seen
description: With a new round of talks among the warring Cambodian factions beginning Monday and an international conference on Cambodia starting next Sunday, the Communist patrons of the war, Vietnam and China, are signaling a new flexibility, Asian diplomats say.

title: Lost Vision
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD: MUSIC IN MANY MOODS

title: Indian Pudding, a Yankee Indulgence
description: AT its richest a deep reddish gold, Indian pudding is the color of its cornmeal, darkened with molasses and hours of baking. Served warm in a bowl, usually with vanilla ice cream, it is, along with toes in the Atlantic and blueberries just off the bush, among the few unforbidden pleasures of a Yankee childhood.

title: An Official at Barnard Is Named Parsons Dean
description: A Barnard College administrator has been named dean of the Parsons School of Design in Manhattan, the second dean in the school's 19-year history.

title: Bangladesh's Leader Woos the Opposition Again
description: President H. M. Ershad, who seized power in a bloodless coup in 1982, is searching for a formula that will allow him to hold early parliamentary elections, politicians of all parties say.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Yellow Algae Fouling Italy's Adriatic Coast

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Menu; Fish Cooked in a Flash
description: Those who spend weekends near the shore or in cities that have good fish markets will have no trouble finding a fresh piece of flounder for this simple but pleasingly sweet-tart sauce.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: UPROOTING POVERTY: The South African Challenge. By Francis Wilson and Mamphela Ramphele. (Norton, $27.50.) South Africa produces enough food to provide all its people with a 6,000-calorie daily diet, but at least one-third of its black children are malnourished. It generates 60 percent of all electricity on the African continent, but access to electricity is denied to two-thirds of its population.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS/HISTORY
description: THE LINCOLN BRIGADEA Picture History. By William Loren Katz and Marc Crawford. Illustrated. 84 pp. New York: Atheneum. $14.95. (Ages 12 and up) THE ABRAHAM LINCOLN BRIGADE Americans Fighting Fascism in the Spanish Civil War. By Don Lawson. Illustrated. 160 pp. New York: Thomas Y. Crowell. $11.95. (Ages 12 and up)

title: Rye Votes $2 Million for its Country Club
description: THE dogs and the golf clubs stayed in the cars, but last Tuesday scores of children in swimsuits trailed their parents to the second floor of the Rye City Hall and watched as they voted in favor of a $2.8 million improvement plan for the city's ''community country club.''

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Q & A column on May 7 about Cebu, the Philippines, incorrectly said United Airlines flies to Cebu. The airline's only stop in the Philippines is Manila. The error was pointed out by a reader in a recent letter.

title: For Siberian Miners, Misery at Home
description: There is no need to descend into the coal pits to sample the wretchedness of the Siberian miner's life. Hearth and home at ground level can serve as well.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Yorkville
description: LIKE many parts of Manhattan, the area known as Yorkville finds that its distinctiveness as a neighborhood is fading.

title: NOW Members Are Told to Seek New Allies in Fight on Abortion
description: The president of the National Organization for Women told delegates to the organization's annual conference today that they must ''reach out to new allies'' like environmentalists in their battle to preserve a woman's right to abortion.

title: Developer Has An Interest Too
description: In his article May 28, Mr. Pilevsky claims special interests ''distort reality'' in our region; yet as a developer himself he certainly has a special interest. His special interest in developing Long Island is not necessarily the right answer for our region, although it probably is the best for him personally.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: CONTESTED LIVES: The Abortion Debate in an American Community. By Faye D. Ginsburg. (University of California, $25.) Faye Ginsburg spent a year in Fargo, N.D., studying a controversy over an abortion clinic and exploring in microcosm the themes being played out in the abortion debate at a national level.

title: A Single Comedian Is Returning to His Roots
description: LEAD: JERRY SEINFELD has made a career out of sharing stories, anecdotes, witty quips and truisms about everyday things and experiences that people can relate to.

title: Emma F. Rivers Plans Marriage
description: Clarice Rivers of New York and Larry Rivers of New York and Southampton, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter Emma Francesca Rivers to Daniel Alberto Perilla, the son of Mariela Karp of Tampa, Fla., and the late Otto Perilla of Bogota, Colombia. An August wedding is planned.

title: Sprucing Up The Neighborhood
description: To the Editor:

title: Score Is Proof Old Stars Say
description: They were called America's Team, and they really were. Sunday after Sunday, people all over the country reveled in the magic of Roger Staubach and Bob Hayes and Bob Lilly and Mel Renfro and the other Dallas Cowboys. The public bought Cowboys shirts and caps and mugs and key rings, and people who knew nothing about the Dallas Cowboys recognized the Dallas Cowboys Cheerleaders.

title: Where Were The Italians?
description: To the Editor:

title: THE STRUGGLE CONTINUES
description: MICKEY SCHWER-ner and his wife, Rita,had been teaching blacks to read and register to vote for three months in Meridian, Miss., when a dozen crosses were burned in the next county. The Schwerners knew what those crosses signified - and that, contrary to the sheriff's explanation, no ''outsiders'' were involved. Still, on Memorial Day 1964, Mickey Schwerner drove the 35 miles from Meridian into Neshoba County. ''You have been slaves too long,'' he told an all-black audience at Mount Zion Methodist Church in Philadelphia. ''We can help you help yourselves. . . .

title: When Teen-Agers Speak, Some Towns Are Listening
description: IN Darien, a town committee met recently to discuss recycling. In Westport, a town committee has just published a handbook of emergency telephone numbers that will be distributed to residents of Westport and Weston. And in New Canaan this month, the town formed a committee whose members have much in common with Darien's and Westport's. They are all teen-agers.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Texas; Bat Enrollment Adds to Mystique Of 'Batman' Fever
description: Although the University of Texas boasts the nation's second-largest college enrollment, another population - one that comes out only at night - may be outnumbering the students.

title: September Bridal for Barbara Phelps
description: The engagement of Barbara Wilder Phelps to Joseph Garside 4th, the son of Mr. Garside 3d of Westwood, Mass., and the late Janet Garside, has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Phelps of Scarsdale, N.Y. The wedding is to take place in September. Miss Phelps, who was presented at the Westchester Cotillion, graduated from Scarsdale High School and Denison University. She is the operations manager at the Boston office of Paine Webber.

title: More for Kosar
description: Bernie Kosar's contract extension will pay him $15 million over six years, making him one of the highest-paid players in the National Football League, according to The Plain Dealer of Cleveland. The newspaper said the recently negotiated extension, which takes effect next season, averaged $2.5 million a year, including bonuses and base salary.

title: Simple Place in a Sophisticated Spot
description: THERE are many neighborhood bars with names like Nick & Toni's. However, this East Hampton spot is anything but. It's a simply appointed, sophisticated restaurant very much in the Hamptons mold.

title: August Wedding For Stacy Lerner
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur H. Lerner of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Stacy Carolynne Lerner and Peter Adam Hochfelder, a son of Gene Hochfelder of New York and the late Patricia Beldoch Hochfelder.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-17

title: L. A. Hamilton 3d Wed in Vermont To Leslie Benoliel
description: Leslie Hope Benoliel, a daughter of Constance Willoughby Benoliel of Philadelphia and Peter Andre Benoliel of St. Davids, Pa., was married yesterday at the Stowehof Inn in Stowe, Vt., to Lloyd Alexander Hamilton 3d, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Hamilton Jr. of Grandview, N.Y. Justice of the Peace Leighton Detour officiated.

title: Marjorie Wallace Plans to Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. John D. Wallace of Princeton, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter Marjorie Cook Wallace to Peter Edward Gibson, the son of the Rev. and Mrs. Edwin C. Bockstiegel of Upper Montclair, N.J., and Hampton Bays, L.I. A September wedding is planned.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: NATURE NEAR: Late Essays of Richard Neutra. Edited by William Marlin. (Capra Press, $18.95.) Richard Neutra was a seminal figure in the development of modern architecture in the United States. Born and educated in Vienna, he immigrated to the United States in 1923; his early masterpiece, the Lovell House in Los Angeles, was featured in the Museum of Modern Art's epochal 1932 International Style exhibition.

title: Honey, They Shrunk the Computer
description: Several companies now offer or are getting ready to offer a generation of portable machines that weigh six pounds or less.

title: Correction
description: A report last Sunday about the wedding of Tracy Gibbs Mullen to James Thomas Lilly Jr. misstated the date.

title: Food; HOT STUFF
description: As soon as the temperature edges above 80, New Yorkers start clamoring for ice cream. Out in the Southwest, and other parts of the world where hot has a whole different meaning, they fight fire with fire. Nothing is as cooling as a hot pepper.

title: ONE MOGUL'S FAMILY
description: THE ZANUCKS OF HOLLYWOOD The Dark Legacy of an American Dynasty. By Marlys J. Harris. Illustrated. 346 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $24.95.

title: Toxic Chemicals Are Set Afire As Train Derails in Michigan
description: A freight train derailed in this east-central Michigan community just before noon today, igniting a fire in at least two tank cars loaded with toxic chemicals. Officials said the blaze was so intense that firefighters could not get close enough to douse it.

title: Challenging the Validity of the Bard
description: YES, Edward deVere, the 17th Earl of Oxford, is the actual author of the plays and sonnets ascribed to William Shakespeare. This is what Thomas J. Layton, a fictitious junior professor and a doctoral candidate in a fictitious American university, tells us - and tells us - in ''All the Queen's Men,'' the numbing play by John Nassivera at the Westport Country Playhouse.

title:
REOCRDINGS;
Elgar's 'Gerontius' - the Big Gesture
description: LEAD: It was a cynical lot that once came up with the idea that Sir Edward Elgar was nothing more than a musical Colonel Blimp, a symphonic jingoist and a bore. Nowadays we realize that, while the genteel composer wore a starched shirt beneath his well-cut tweeds, he certainly didn't think like a stuffed one.

title: A Group Show at Bronx Museum LBy VIVIEN RAYNOR
description: ''ARTIST IN THE MARKETPLACE,'' a yearly event at the Bronx Museum of the Arts, is no ordinary group show but the end product of a 16-week-long program addressed to selected artists. The program consists of seminars led by curators, dealers, critics, lawyers and other professionals equipped to convey the facts of professional life; the show is provided by the artists enrolled.

title: Condos for Elderly
description: To the Editor:

title: A Novel Test for an Old Soviet Industry
description: The promise of a planned economy, whatever its shortcomings, is the security of a certain orderliness. But since Mikhail S. Gorbachev came to power four years ago, Vladimir A. Yamnikov, the stocky 49-year-old manager of the Kristall vodka distillery here, has found security in short supply. Instead, he has had to deal with the turbulence typically found in unruly free-market economies.

title: Ecology of Ethics
description: To the Editor:

title: Raising a Monkey to Help the Disabled
description: LEAD: PAT SALVATORE showed her husband a newspaper article she had clipped and said, ''Look what I'm going to do.''

title: Amelia Zurcher and Mark S. Sandy, Marshall Scholars, Planning to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arnold J. Zurcher Jr. of Pelham, N.Y., and Saltaire, Fire Island, L.I., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter Amelia Anne Zurcher and Mark Steven Sandy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Sandy of Roanoke, Va.

title: Yankees Drop 5th in Row
description: The Yankees' frustration mounted tonight. They were handed their fifth consecutive defeat, this one a 2-1 loss to the Texas Rangers, and must have wrung their hands over the failed chances.

title: Men's Style; Talking Heads
description: Twenty years ago, long hair spoke for a nation of young rebels, and the message was: Hey, I'm not the establishment. Today, it makes all kinds of statements and hangs from all kinds of heads. It goes to the board room and even the beauty parlor.

title: Wendy J. Banner To Marry Singer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stephen E. Banner of Larchmont, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter Wendy Jill Banner to Kyle Robert Gordon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Gordon of Glencoe, Ill. An August wedding is planned.

title: BASEBALL: American League; Canseco Belts Another As Orioles Fall Again
description: Jose Canseco hit his second homer in two days and Bob Welch got his 11th victory today as the Oakland Athletics beat the Baltimore Orioles, 4-1, for their fourth consecutive victory.

title: Review/Dance; Classic and Modern on Kirov Bill
description: Happiness is the Kirov Ballet's ''Paquita'' led by Lyubov Kunakova, exuding joy in every step. On Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, the company from Leningrad again ended with the grand pas from that ballet, with an exultant new ballerina providing the kind of energy that can lift the standard of an entire cast.

title: A Davis Cup Setback for U.S.
description: Before their Davis Cup semifinal series against West Germany, the members of the United States squad thought they had the entire scenario figured out. The recent Wimbledon victory by Boris Becker of West Germany, coupled with the withdrawal of the injured John McEnroe from the American team, meant that both Andre Agassi and Brad Gilbert would have to beat the West German No. 2 player, Carl-Uwe Steeb, in singles matches for the United States to advance to their first Davis Cup final since 1984.

title: A 'Midsummer' Staged For the Modern Era
description: NO dewy-eyed or Disney-like visions of ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' with fairies flying about enchanted forests will do for contemporary sensibilities.

title: Turning Mousse into Money
description: In the glitzy, but fiercely competitive beauty industry, L'Oreal S.A., known for Lancome creams, Giorgio Armani cologne and Paloma Picasso perfume, has a special sparkle.

title: A Soviet Diplomat Predicts Renewal of Ties With Israel
description: A senior Soviet diplomat was quoted today as having said Moscow would renew diplomatic relations with Israel and was ready for links with Saudi Arabia.

title: With Few Tested, AIDS Debate Erupts
description: About 90 percent of the hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers believed infected with the AIDS virus have never been tested for it, and a long-simmering debate has erupted over how best to find and help them.

title: Lauder's Mayoral Campaign Is a Bonanza for Consultants
description: Ronald Lauder's mayoral campaign, which has spent a record $8.5 million so far, has been a bonanza for campaign consultants across the nation in general and for the allies of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato in particular.

title: Krazy Kat as Icon And Investment
description: Mickey Mouse upstages all the others - Krazy Kat, Popeye, Spark Plug, Felix the Cat, Donald Duck and Betty Boop - in a collection of windup, push-pull, squeezable and noise-making comic-character toys described by its owner as the largest anywhere. Exuberant, zany and sometimes sputtering, Mickey images outnumber those of his cartoon colleagues, all of which are on display in the Samuels Museum of Comic Toys. Although the museum's 4,000 or so items of painted cast iron, lithographed tin, celluloid and stuffed straw were made over the last century, the bulk are classics produced between 1920 and 1940.

title: Fed Up With Defeatism
description: To the Editor:

title: Diane Marshall Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Marshall of Southington, Conn., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter, Diane Michele Marshall, and First Lieut. James Knippenberg Hillman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert J. Hillman of Stowe, Vt. Miss Marshall is a nursing student at Mount St. Mary College in Newburgh, N.Y. Her fiance, a graduate of the United States Military Academy at West Point, is an infantry officer stationed at the 10th Mountain Division in Fort Drum, N.Y.

title: 250 More Jobs at Merrill Lynch Are to Be Moved to New Jersey
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, which announced last month that it would move 2,600 jobs from New York City to Jersey City, is planning to move about 250 more employees to New Jersey, officials inside and outside the finanical company said.

title: THE COUNTRY THAT WAS ALWAYS AN ILLUSION
description: LEBANON Death of a Nation. By Sandra Mackey. 295 pp. New York: Congdon & Weed. $22.95.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''In our public policy - as, to some degree, in our private behavior - we consume today as if there were no tomorrow.'' Richard G. Darman, President Bush's budget director.

title: Suburban Bankshares reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
National City Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

BUSINESS PEOPLE;
CalFed Chief Quits at Board Urging
description: LEAD: John R. Torell 3d, a former New York banker, has resigned as chairman, president and chief executive of CalFed Inc., a Los Angeles-based financial services company, at the request of CalFed's board.

title: Market Place; Apparel Makers Back in Fashion
description: WITH improved retail sales in brand name clothing as diverse as Wrangler and Christian Dior and a surge of acquisitions in the apparel industry, selected apparel maker stocks are attracting investors again after nearly two years of neglect.

title: Milton Roy Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The net in the latest quarter included a gain of $2.5 million, or 45 cents a share, from the sale of the company's liquid chromatography product line.

title: Di Giorgio Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Bankers Trust New York Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest second quarter earnings included a $65 million provision for credit losses, compared with $5 million for the year-ago period.

title: One-Vote Shift Could Decide Tax-Cut Fight
description: Under increased pressure from the Bush Administration to vote on a reduction in the capital gains tax rate, a bitterly divided House Ways and Means Committee will resume deliberations on Tuesday, with the Democratic leadership one vote shy of being able to block the proposal.

title: Old National Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
An Advocate For the Arts
description: LEAD: Dear John Frohnmayer:

title: Hanna (M.A.) Co (N) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included $15 million from the sale of claims in a bankruptcy proceeding. c-Included a gain of $15.7 million from an asset sale and a tax refund.

title: A.L. Williams Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included income of $4,535,000 and $8,693,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

They have found that a judicious tapering-off can strengthen muscles and enhance your competitive ability.

title: Bridge

More players earned the needed master points, but it took until 1948 for the number to grow to 100. The requirements were somewhat relaxed, and the trickle became a flood. The total is now about 38,000, representing one-fifth of all registered competitive players.

David R. Torke, a Justice of the Peace, officiated. The bride, a graduate of the University of Colorado, where her husband is a junior, is the business manager of Alarion Press in Boulder. Her father has a public relations concern bearing his name in New York. Her mother, Shirley Bakal, is the assistant to the managing director of the Metropolitan Opera Guild. title: Review/Jazz; Tribute to Bix Beiderbecke
description: The 92d Street Y's tribute to the cornetist Bix Beiderbecke on Wednesday night, as part of its Jazz in July program, had the right idea. Opening with a ragtime orchestra, along with re-creations by a smaller ensemble of performances by the Original Dixieland Jazz band, the program tried to set a context for the music of Beiderbecke, who died in 1931. Oddly enough - and this is the reverse of what usually happens at jazz repertory concerts - the first half fell flat, while the second, which relied on Randy Sandke's interpretation of Beiderbecke's playing, offered glimpses of real music.

title: American League; Red Sox Stop White Sox Streak at 8
description: Roger Clemens gave the White Sox their first loss since the All-Star Game break, stopping Chicago's winning streak at eight games and pitching the Boston Red Sox to an 8-2 victory today.

title: Doing Violence Against Violence
description: Like many Americans, Senator Paul Simon abhors the increase of graphic violence on television - and proposes doing something about it with an ill-advised bill that may soon become an ill-advised law. The violence is deplorable; this remedy for it is worse.

title: Frank Thompson, 70; Career In Congress Ended With Abscam
description: Frank Thompson Jr., a former New Jersey Representative who was one of the most influential Democrats in Congress before the Abscam scandal ended his 26-year House career, died Saturday at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore, two days after undergoing surgery for throat cancer there.

description: They have friendly nicknames, long bureaucratic titles, have borrowed $700 billion more than they have taken in and even though their debt is not counted in the Federal deficit, it is generally accepted that they have the backing of the Treasury. What are they?

title: Chicago Schools Agree to Revamp Programs for Handicapped Pupils
description: The Chicago school board and the Federal Department of Education have announced an agreement on a plan to end a four-and-a-half-year impasse over the city's educational policies toward physically and mentally handicapped students.

title: Review/Circus; A Show by the Pickle Family, Starring Clowning
description: The Pickle Family Circus is so refreshingly unassuming and so lively that to call it a landmark institution sounds overly solemn. But the San Francisco-based circus, now in its 15th year, spawned Bill Irwin and Geoff Hoyle. An offspring of the San Francisco Mime Troupe, the Pickles were also the first in this country to establish a one-ring, intimate show on the order of European circuses.

title: 14,500 Flee Fires in Canada
description: Forest fires fanned by dry winds raged out of control in northern Manitoba today, forcing thousands to flee and straining resources of communities trying to absorb those evacuated, the authorities said. A total of 14,500 people have fled their homes as one of the worst fire seasons on record devastated a wide area in Manitoba and neighboring Saskatchewan, said Cindy Stevens, spokeswoman for the Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization. She said more than 250 fires were burning in northern Manitoba.

Results Plus
description: Auto Racing Andretti Pulls Out a Victory: Michael Andretti barely avoided the adversity that has dogged him this season, surviving a bumping incident with Emerson Fittipaldi just two laps before taking the checkered flag yesterday in the Molson Indy-car race in Toronto. The 26-year-old Andretti led the final 23 laps of the 103-lap, 183-mile race, but Fittipaldi charged into the picture in the final 10 laps, coming from an eight-second deficit. Fittipaldi finishing second, 12.08 seconds behind the winner. Danny Sullivan was third.(AP) Elliott Defends Championship: Bill Elliott, the defending champion, passed Rusty Wallace with six laps left yesterday and held on to win the caution-flag filled $527,567 AC Spark Plug 500 Nascar race in Long Pond, Pa. Elliott, driving a Ford, edged Wallace, in a Pontiac, by 2.21 seconds. Mark Martin finished third.(AP) Tennis Garrison Defeats Shriver: Zina Garrison, the top-seeded player, won the Virginia Slims of Newport, R.I., yesterday, defeating second-ranked Pam Shriver, 6-0, 6-1, in less than an hour at Newport Casino. Garrison picked up $40,000 and Shriver, appearing in her fourth final in the Newport tournament, collected $18,000.(AP) Zrubakova Beats Paz: Second-seeded Radka Zrubakova of Czechoslovakia used her superior speed to win the $100,000 Belgian Open tournament in Brussels yesterday, beating seventh-seeded Mercedes Paz of Argentina, 7-6, 6-4.(AP) Golf Byrum Rallies to Win Hardee's: Curt Byrum joined his brother as a first-time winner on the PGA Tour this year by rallying yesterday to capture the Hardee's Classic in Coal Valley, Ill. Byrum, whose brother, Tom, earned his first tour victory in June at the Kemper Open, shot a four-under-par 66 and capitalized on the collapse of the defending champion, Blaine McCallister, to finish with a 72-hold score of 12-under 268, one shot ahead of Brian Tennyson and Bill Britton. The Byrums became the first brothers to win on the PGA Tour in the same year since Dave and Mike Hill in 1972. The victory was worth $126,000 to Curt Byrum, nearly doubling his earnings for the year. (AP) Alcott Wins Boston Five: Amy Alcott shot her fourth straight 68 to win the Boston Five Classic by three strokes with a 16-under-par 272 total, the best score this year on the Ladies' Professional Golf Association tour. Alcott moved from fourth to third on the L.P.G.A.'s career earnings list. Cathy Marino matched her best finish in seven years on the tour with a final-round 68 for a 275 total. Marta Figueras-Dotti took third with a 68 for a 276 total for four trips over the 6,008-yard, par-72 Tara Ferncroft Country Club course in Danvers, Mass. (AP) Crampton Wins by One Stroke: Bruce Crampton shot a four-under-par 68 and fended off trouble down the stretch for a one-stroke victory over Jim Ferree and Orville Moody in the Ameritech Senior Open in Cleveland. Crampton's 68 followed rounds of 70 and 67 as he finished at 11-under-par 205.(AP) Ice Skating A Golden Comeback: The ice dancers April Sargent and Russ Witherby, completing a comeback from injury at the world championships in March, skated to the gold medal at the United States Olympic Festival yesterday in Oklahoma City. Sargent, of Ogdensburg, N.Y., and Witherby, of Cincinnati, presented a polished four-minute routine that received top marks on technical merit from all seven judges. Jeanne Miley, of West Chester, Pa., and Michael Verlich, of Montclair, Calif., won the silver. Elizabeth McLean, of Falmouth, Mass., and Ari Lieb, of Dorchester, Mass., took the bronze medal. (AP) Horse Show Grubb Wins in Vermont: Tim Grubb of Pottersville, N.J.,, a British Olympic veteran, rode Elan's Forecast to a show-jumping victory yesterday in the $30,000 Grand Prix of Vermont in Killington. Twelve of 23 entries reached a tie-breaking jump-off by going penalty-free over the 16-jump, 594-yard first-round course. Grubb rode eighth in the jump-off and finished fault-free in 35.262 seconds. Horse Racing Sunday Silence Loses: Sunday Silence, the Kentucky Derby and Preakness winner, suffered his second loss in two races as Prized passed him late in the stretch yesterday to win the $412,400 Swaps Stakes at Hollywood Park in Inglewood, Calif. Going off as the 1-5 favorite, Sunday Silence, ridden by Pat Valenzuela, had a firm lead turning into the stretch. But Eddie Delahoussaye, aboard the 5-1 second choice Prized, rallied his mount and overtook Sunday Silence inside the 16th pole to win by three-quarters of a length in 2:01 4/5. Endow finished third. The mile-and-a-quarter race was Sunday Silence's first outing since his loss to Easy Goer in the Belmont Stakes on June 10. The winner of only one previous stakes, Prized won $242,000 and returned $12 for $2 to win.(AP)

title: Streaking Mets Beat Braves, 7-2

With a $5,000 minimum pledge per rider - the money came from sponsors and participants - they had raised nearly $2 million for the American Lung Association.

description: A 29-year-old mother pushed her 2-month-old baby to safety last night seconds before she was struck and killed on a street on City Island by a car whose driver was charged with drunk driving, the police said. The woman, Claire Ordonez, quickly pushed her son, Julio Cesar Ordonez, in a carriage, off City Island Boulevard. He was not injured. The driver, Ventura Lopez, 50, of the Bronx, was also charged with vehicular homicide.

title: Capital Cities-ABC Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: The company said year-ago 6 months' revenue reflected advertising from the Calgary winter olympics.

title: Atlantic Richfield Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Canadian Marconi Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said results for the latest first quarter included the operations of Cincinnati Electronics Corp. acquired last September. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Federated Financial S&L reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income Latest third quarter earnings were hurt by a decline in net interest income and changes in the accounting for loan fees.

title: GORBACHEV HAILS STRIKING MINERS AS AIDING CHANGE
description: Far from criticizing the nation's striking coal miners, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev told them today that he was greatly ''inspired'' that they were ''taking things into their own hands'' to force the sort of change that he says is necessary for his troubled program of national restructuring to succeed.

title: Rochester Gas & Electric Corp reports earnings for 12mo June 30
description: Earnings in the latest year were reduced by about 33 cents a share by an accounting change.

title: D&N Financial reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Fieldcrest Cannon Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Imperial Oil reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: U.S. Seizes 7 Savings Units
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said last week that it had placed seven more troubled savings institutions under its supervision, bringing the total in the special Federal program to 244.

title: A Spy Case With an Unlikely Suspect
description: For most of his 30 years in the State Department, colleagues say, Felix Stephen Bloch has been a solid if slightly uninspired bureaucrat. He is considered a solicitous friend, but not a warm one; an efficient manager, but not a brilliant one.

title: American List Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Public Service Co. of Colorado reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Joe Carter Shuns Fame, but Yearns to Be an All-Star
description: LEAD: JOE CARTER can live without fame. He does not want the all-encompassing, can't-set-your-foot-out-the-front-door attention that follows some professional athletes.

title: GOVERNMENT CRISIS IN ISRAEL IS ENDED
description: The Israeli Cabinet formally ended the Government coalition crisis today by voting almost unanimously to endorse Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's plan for Palestinian elections as originally proposed.

title: Corrections
description: An Inside item on page one yesterday, referring to an article about Merrill Lynch & Company's decision to move 250 employees from New York City to New Jersey, incorrectly described in some copies the new job locations. The jobs are expected to be transferred to Princeton and to Piscataway in New Jersey.

title: Asarco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Palfed Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Calmat Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest second quarter and 6 months included a gain of $3.4 million from the second-quarter disposal of properties division assets held for sale.

title: Eaton Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $1.5 million for the quarter and $5.4 million for the 6 months. c-After income from discontinued operations of $700,000 for the quarter and $900,000 for the 6 months, and an extraordinary charge of $17.7 million related to litigation for the both periods.

title: F.C.C. Asks Paramount for Data
description: The Federal Communications Commission asked Paramount Communications Inc. on Friday for more information about a voting trust the company had proposed to hold Time Inc. stock while the F.C.C. considered the transfer of radio licenses.

title: Peoples Westchester Savings reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $340,000.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * BMW of North America Inc., Woodcliff Lake, N.J., an automotive company and subsidiary of BMW A.G., Munich, promoted James J. Ryan to executive vice president of automotive operations.

title: SmithKline Beckman reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said Tagamet and Dyazide sales in the second quarter increased in comparison to a weak second quarter in 1988. U.S. Tagamet sales are estimated at $291 million in the first six months of 1989, level with the same period last year. Worldwide, Tagamet sales of $554 million were up 2 percent over the first half of 1988. The company's shareholders will vote July 26 on the proposal to merge with Beecham Group to Form SmithKline Beecham.

title: Washington Federal Savings & Loan Assn reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Deluxe Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Insider Arrest In Australia
description: The former managing director of an Australian merchant bank has been arrested and charged with insider trading and blackmail.

title: Staten Island's Isolation Called Both Curse and Charm
description: Residents of Staten Island, separated from Manhattan by a 25-minute ferry ride or a circuitous drive via Brooklyn or New Jersey, sometimes feel as much a part of New York City as they do of the lost city of Atlantis.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Melville Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago share net has been adjusted to give effect to a 2-for-1 stock split paid in February 1989.

title: Allegheny Power Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Suspect in 4 Deaths Arrested
description: A man wanted in connection with four shooting deaths in three states was arrested in a hospital emergency room late today. Michael Frank Greene, 37 years old, was arrested at Comanche County Memorial Hospital in Lawton, where he had gone for treatment of a back injury, the police said. Mr. Greene has been charged with murder in the shooting death of one woman in an Ardmore flower shop and is a suspect in three other killings.

title: Flightsafety International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted to reflect the 3-for-2 stock split in August 1988.

title: Hubbell Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings for all periods have been adjusted for a 5 percent stock dividend paid on Feb. 3.

title: CMS Energy Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Lincoln Savings (Pa.) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Yankees Squander 4-0 Lead and Lose
description: This was not just another loss. The Yankees were shaken when the game was over, their faces blank in disbelief. A victory dissolved into a crushing loss, and it must feel now as if there is no end in sight.

title: 3 Held by U.S. On Exports
description: Federal agents have arrested three men and charged them with attempting to export sophisticated computer equipment to the Soviet Union.

title: Hawthorne Financial reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Ohio Edison Co reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: Latest-year results reflected a $128 million one-time non-cash net writeoff charged against 1988 earnings for certain nuclear construction costs.

title: Exit the Sun Bowl
description: Few sportswriters or editors, at least those known for their sentimental devotion to tradition, applauded in 1986 when financial necessity forced the Sun Bowl, a college football fixture in El Paso, Tex., since 1935, to become the John Hancock Sun Bowl.

title: California Water Service reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Engraph Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Obstacles Don't End for Williams of Jets
description: Terry Williams, young and strong at the age of 23, but with an ankle that throbbed, looked up at the ceiling Saturday night and said, ''Why me, God?''

title: Research Links Diet and Infertility Factors to Ovarian Cancer
description: TWO new studies have identified certain dietary and biological factors that may increase the risk of cancer of the ovary, one of the most mysterious malignancies.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about red dye No. 3, a food coloring, incorrectly described House action calling for a study of potential health risks of the dye. The request for a study was advisory and is not binding on the Food and Drug Administration. The full House did not vote on the request; it was contained in a report of the House Appropriations Committee.

title: Serbian Leaders, Calling Yugoslav System Outdated, Ask Changes
description: Serbia, Yugoslavia's largest republic, has drafted proposals for changes in the federal Constitution that it says are intended to convert this country, which is dominated by the Communist Party, into a ''modern and efficient state of laws.''

title: Marietta Net Increases 6.8%
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation said today that its second-quarter earnings rose 6.8 percent from a year earlier, mainly because of increased production of the Titan 4 rocket.

title: Patterns
description: The Role of Couture

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AAR Corp., Elk Grove Village, Ill., an aerospace manufacturer, named David P. Storch president and chief operating officer.

title: Tortoise on Endangered List
description: The desert tortoise was declared an endangered species today because it is threatened by a respiratory disease. The action by Steve Robinson, acting director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, was expected to anger cattle ranchers because it could affect their grazing rights on Federal lands.

title: Aurelio Baldeschi-Balleani, Italian Nobleman, 85
description: Count Aurelio Baldeschi-Balleani, an Italian nobleman who was the oldest living Knight of Malta, died July 16 after a brief illness in Iesi, Italy, where he lived. He was 85 years old.

title: Topics of The Times; 2,000 Miles, 8 Seconds
description: Greg Lemond has given new meaning to winning by a nose. After 87 hours, 38 minutes and 35 seconds, he won the 2,000-mile Tour de France by just eight seconds, the narrowest margin in the tour's 86 years. Having started the final 15-mile lap in second place and finished it ahead by the equivalent of less than two football fields, the 28-year-old from Wayzata, Minn., made glorious, thrilling history.

title: I.R.S. Raids Office At Georgia Power
description: Agents of the Internal Revenue Service seized records of the Georgia Power Company as part of a tax fraud investigation of the electric utility, a company spokesman said.

title: Of Inevitable Sudden Death And Backing Up Your Files
description: IT happened to me again, and it will happen to you someday.

title: Bridge
description: The luckiest player of the year may well be Joseph Ivany, who like many other bridge enthusiasts, has retired to Florida from the New York metropolitan region. He now lives in Boca Raton and played the diagramed deal there in a rubber bridge game at Jourdan's Club.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We need someone who can rebuild the party in the long term.

title: Careers; Starting Out As a Musician In the Military
description: YOUNG musicians have difficulty getting their careers under way. ''Getting started always has been hard for most musicians,'' said Maj. Stanley Cornett, chief of the staff bands office in the headquarters forces command of the United States Army, who also knows a good way to start a musical career.

title: Laser 'Tweezers' Probe Nature's Tiniest Motors
description: USING delicate laser ''tweezers'' to twist the tails of bacteria, scientists are exploring mechanisms of their propulsion, including the tiniest rotary motors in existence.

title: Impact Of Jockeys Is Vastly Overrated
description: The name of the game is horse racing, but this past weekend, the passengers were the center of attention.

title: Offerings By Bikel: Brel, Weill And Sting
description: Theodore Bikel, who has made it to the top before, is moving to new heights in New York today, when he brings his one-man polylingual and multi-melodied show to Rainbow and Stars, on the 65th floor of 30 Rockefeller Plaza.

title: Bush's Ill-Advised Letter to Shamir
description: LEAD: In the heavily laden annals of ineptitude in Middle East diplomacy, a special niche should be reserved for a secret letter that President Bush sent to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir on June 30.

title: Papp Agrees to Present Palestinian Troupe
description: Joseph Papp, who recently canceled a scheduled production by El-Hakawati Palestinian Theater Company at the Public Theater, agreed yesterday to present the company within a year at his theater. He said he would also look for an Israeli play to present at the same time.

title: Skeletons May Yield Clues On 19th-Century Cannibal
description: The discovery of five skeletons from a 115-year-old grave near here has given investigators new clues about the deaths of the companions of the 19th-century cannibal Alferd Packer.

title: Harold Gessner, 86, Shoe-Industry Leader
description: Harold B. Gessner, a footwear manufacturer who also headed several shoe-industry associations, died of prostate cancer on Sunday in New York Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Roosevelt Tram Is Shut Down After Accident
description: The Roosevelt Island tramway, the only direct link between that community's 6,500 residents and Manhattan, was shut down yesterday after its first accident involving injuries since it began operation 13 years ago, officials said.

title: Rise in Criminal Fines Backed
description: The Justice Department said today that it supported a tenfold increase in the maximum fine for criminal antitrust violations by corporations, to $10 million.

title: A Strategist Sees if His Hand Is Still Hot
description: Nobody has ever voted for David Garth.

title: Duran Next For Leonard
description: Roberto Duran will be Sugar Ray Leonard's next opponent.

title: Review/Television; The Chanel Who Created the Fashions
description: ''Chanel, Chanel,'' a one-hour documentary at 8 tonight on the Arts & Entertainment Network, traces the life and fashions of perhaps the most influential designer of clothing in this century, Gabrielle (Coco) Chanel. The show includes period film clips and a rare interview with Chanel to sketch the known facts of her life. It is dreamily narrated by the English actress Diana Quick to musical strains of Erik Satie.

title: Rookie's Grand Slam Tops Yankees
description: The spiral is now seven games long, the length of the losing streak that began their season in April. The Yankees, unable to avoid small mistakes and convert big opportunities, tumbled again tonight when a rookie playing in only his 10th game in the big leagues ended their momentary hopes with a grand slam.

title: Strawberry Continues Erratic Style of Play
description: The balls had begun to drop over the outfield fences with regularity, and so Darryl Strawberry had reason to believe things were finally tumbling into place for him at the plate.

title: Bell Atlantic's Profits Increase 4.9% in Quarter
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation, one of the nation's seven regional Bell telephone companies, said yesterday that its net income rose 4.9 percent in the second quarter.

title: Lame Ducks and Legal Services
description: For eight years the Reagan Administration tried to destroy the Federal Legal Services Corporation, which provides lawyers for the poor. Now, half a year into the Bush Administration, lame-duck Reagan appointees continue to pursue that goal. It's past time for President Bush to appoint a slate of directors committed to poverty law.

title: Maxwell Lifts Bid For Crosfield
description: Robert Maxwell, the British news media executive, told the De La Rue Company, a financial printing concern, that he would raise his offer for its Crosfield electronics unit by $:30 million ($49 million).

title: KEY RATES
LeMond Is Quick To Return to Races
description: Greg LeMond was back on his bicycle yesterday, a day after his stunning last-day, come-from-behind victory in the Tour de France. LeMond competed yesterday in a 37-mile exhibition race in Lisieux, about 100 miles west of Paris. Before the race, LeMond found time to visit students at a French-American school in the city, which he also visited in 1986 after his victory. Greeted by about 60 cheering students and a banner that read, ''Welcome to Lisieux,'' LeMond shook hands, signed autographs and drank champagne.

title: Panel Defeats Attempt to Increase Support for War Planes in Budget
description: Republican lawmakers, with Democratic support, today defeated a parliamentary maneuver intended to help restore two controversial warplanes to the 1990 Pentagon budget.

title: Blazers Sign Cooper
description: The Trail Blazers announced yesterday that the Denver Nugget center Wayne Cooper had signed a contract with Portland, returning to the team that traded him five years ago. Neither the Blazers nor the 6-foot-10-inch free agent would disclose terms of the contract. But The Rocky Mountain News in Denver quoted National Basketball Association sources as saying he would earn $1.1 million a year for three years.(AP)

title: Index for Weighted Voting Is Alive and Well
description: To the Editor:

title: 3-part Approach to Data, Improved Again
description: THERE is no lack of programs that put what is called a shell between the user and the MS-DOS operating system, offering easier ways to do disk housekeeping. There is also no lack of desktop managers, which provide a notebook, calculator and other handy tools that can be called up in the middle of another job. Nor is there a shortage of ways to recover data from a file, or whole hard disk, that has been accidentally erased.

title: Global Expansion Seen At Midland Montague
description: While American securities dealers continue to cut their staffs, legions of Wall Street economists, traders and salespeople have found new employers among the foreign firms expanding into the American market.

title: In Iowa's Corn and Bean Fields, Clues to Jet Crash
description: Somewhere in the shaded furrows of knee-deep soybeans and towering corn in western Iowa may lie the solution to the mystery of why a United Airlines jumbo jet crashed here last Wednesday.

title: Grand Jury Chooses Not to Indict Suspect In Brooklyn Attack
description: A Brooklyn grand jury voted yesterday not to indict a man that the police said was the gunman who asked, ''Remember me?'' before shooting three people who supposedly had robbed him the night before.

title: No Such Thing as a 'Reasonable' Gun Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Israeli Court Grants All Converts Full Rights
description: The Israeli Supreme Court ruled today that people converted by Conservative or Reform rabbis must be registered by the Government as Jews. The decision was a severe blow to longstanding efforts by the Orthodox establishment to control conversions.

title: Turtle-Net Rule Suspended
description: Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher today temporarily suspended regulations requiring shrimpers to use new devices intended to protect endangered sea turtles from dying in their nets. Angry shrimpers blocked ship channels along the Texas Gulf Coast over the weekend and treatened violence if the regulations, which carried penalties of up to a $25,000 fine and a six-month jail sentence, were not changed or reversed.

title: Chromosome Transfer
description: Researchers have reported success with a method for injecting human chromosomes into mouse embryos that they say could someday assist scientists in the search for treatments for illnesses such as cancer.

title: 'Aggrieved' Bush Says He Knew of Spy Inquiry
description: President Bush said today that suspicions of espionage by a career diplomat in the Vienna embassy would be a ''very serious matter'' if verified.

title: Animal Posture Seen As Clue to Legs' Size
description: A UNIVERSITY of Chicago scientist says he has solved a riddle of anatomy: how large animals, with bones and muscles that are relatively small in proportion to their weight, run without overloading their skeletons.

title: Salinas and Business Leaders Hail Debt Accord
description: The debt relief and interest rate reduction that Mexico was granted by its commercial bank creditors on Sunday night were hailed here today by the Government and by the business community as a historic breakthrough. But opposition parties, labor unions and independent economists expressed skepticism as to how much Mexico would actually benefit from the accord.

title: Students Poor In Math Pose Job Problem
description: Many of New York City's public school students are so lacking in mathematics skills that it will be difficult to absorb them into a rapidly changing city economy becoming ever more dependent on information-oriented industries, educators and economists say.

title: Capital Cities/ABC Net Jumps 21.3% in Quarter
description: Capital Cities/ABC Inc. reported yesterday that its earnings climbed 23.1 percent in the second quarter, as revenues rose by 6 percent.

title: Philadelphia Opera Plans 4 Productions
description: The Opera Company of Philadelphia is to present Donizetti's ''Lucia di Lammermoor,'' Gian Carlo Menotti's ''Saint of Bleecker Street,'' Handel's ''Ariodante'' and ''La Gazza Ladra'' by Rossini during the 1989-90 season at the Academy of Music in Philadelphia.

title: Austrian Recounts Rapport With Diplomat in Spy Case
description: Austria's Foreign Minister acknowledged today that Felix S. Bloch, the senior American diplomat being investigated on suspicion of espionage, had easy access to Austrian Government offices during his seven years of service in Vienna.

title: Data Suggest That Implants May Pose Risk Of Later Harm
description: PATHOLOGISTS and other experts are questioning the long-term safety of materials and devices implanted into the human body for medical and cosmetic reasons.

title: James J. O'Connor, 71, Engineer and Editor
description: James J. O'Connor, an electrical engineer who was editor in chief of Power Magazine when he retired in 1980 after 37 years with the publication, died of heart failure Saturday at his home on Hilton Head Island, S.C. He was 71 years old.

title: Quinoco is Sold
description: The Angeles Corporation said it had agreed to sell its Quinoco oil and gas businesses to Saxon Oil Development Partners for $26.5 million. Among the businesses are Quinoco Oil and Gas Inc. and Quinoco Energy Inc. Saxon, based in Dallas, is an oil and gas master limited partnership.

title: Former Florida G.O.P. Chief Got $500,000 for Lobbying of H.U.D.
description: The former Republican state chairman in Florida said today that he received more than $500,000 in cash and property for consulting work for developers seeking housing benefits from the Reagan Administration.

title: Iraq Requests Price Freeze
description: Private businesses have been asked to freeze prices after similar measures were taken by state-run enterprises, Al Ittihad, a weekly newspaper, reported today. Al Ittihad, published by an

title: 3 Drown Off Florida Beaches
description: Three tourists drowned in treacherous currents Sunday off unguarded southern Florida beaches, and the Miami Beach lifeguards had to rescue 15 people. While the beaches were not closed Sunday, swimmers were warned to avoid the currents after the first two drownings.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Beauty Labs Inc., Lake Success, L.I., a maker of specialty beauty products, said it had begun preliminary merger talks with Gruene Inc., a maker of men's fragrances and toiletries.

title: Griffey Fractures Hand
description: Ken Griffey Jr., the Mariners outfielder, fractured his right hand stepping out of the shower in his hotel room in Chicago yesterday and is out indefinitely.

title: William T. Whisner Jr., 65, Pilot; Was U.S. Fighter Ace in 2 Wars
description: William T. Whisner Jr., who shot down 21 enemy planes as a United States fighter ace in World War II and the Korean War, died of complications from a yellow jacket sting last Friday in Alexandria, La. He was 65 years old.

title: Go for It! Calcavecchia, LeMond Did
description: Golfers and cyclists are not always household names. Some people in America still don't know the proper pronunciations. Some call the golfer ''Calculator.'' Others call the cyclist ''Lemonade.'' But they knew each was an American winning on foreign soil. To them, that's all that mattered. And in sports sometimes, that is all that matters.

title: 1992 Whets BSN's Big Appetite
description: France's largest food company, BSN Groupe, is making a name for itself as a young giant in a hurry as it jockeys for position in the unified, barrier-free market that the European Community envisions for 1992.

title: Prices of U.S. Securities Advance
description: Prices of Treasury securities inched higher in extremely slow trading yesterday.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: ebt

title: Anger, but Also Cleaner Air
description: On June 12, President Bush won applause from environmentalists when he pledged to rid the nation of dirty air by overhauling the Clean Air Act of 1970. Now Mr. Bush has unveiled the fine print. The applause has turned to skepticism, even anger. During six weeks of bureaucratic infighting, Mr. Bush has made compromises; the bargain he seems to have struck with the automobile industry is especially disappointing.

title: Once Scorned and Nearly Extinct, Toxic Plant Is Protected
description: AS young men, Gordon and Everett Tosten spent many sweaty hours pulling up the weeds that killed the sheep on their father's ranch near Garberville, Calif. Now they find themselves protecting the rare, toxic plants.

title: Genevieve Naylor, 74, Photographer, Dies
description: Genevieve Naylor, a fashion photographer whose work appeared in Vogue, Harper's Bazaar, Good Housekeeping, McCall's, Cosmopolitan and other magazines, died of heart failure Friday at Dobbs Ferry (N.Y.) Hospital. She was 74 years old and lived in Dobbs Ferry.

title: Does Right to Privacy Include Right to Die? Court to Decide
description: With a one-line order issued on the final day of its term, the Supreme Court opened a new front in the battle over the constitutional right to privacy.

title: Olympia & York Said to Be Near Deal for Sears Tower
description: Olympia & York Developments Ltd., the huge Canadian property developer, is moving closer to reaching an agreement to buy the Sears Tower in what could be the largest real estate transaction in history, real estate executives and others familiar with the bidding process said today.

title: Sakharov Rebukes Chinese
description: Chinese delegates walked out of an international conference today when Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet human rights campaigner, called for condemnation of China's suppression of student demonstrators. ''We cannot forgive or disregard the conduct of the Chinese Government,'' Dr. Sakharov said at the opening of the 39th Pugwash Conference on Science and World Affairs.

title: Regan Urges Streamlining OTB As He Cites Declining Revenues
description: Rising costs and dwindling profits require the New York City Offtrack Betting Corporation to ''drastically streamline'' its operations, State Comptroller Edward V. Regan declared yesterday.

title: Pickens Assails Ruling on Time
description: T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman who has been widely quoted about what he sees as the interests of individual investors, assailed the Delaware Supreme Court yesterday for allowing Time Inc. to proceed with plans to buy Warner Communications Inc. and to ignore an offer for Time from Paramount Communications Inc.

title: Glimpse at Pterodactyls
description: An exceptionally well-preserved piece of pterodactyl's wing discovered in Brazil has allowed British scientists to make the first reconstruction of the creature's wing.

title: Passengers and Crew In DC-10 Crash in Iowa
description: Following is a list, released by United Airlines, of crew members and passengers on the DC-10 that crashed Wednesday at Sioux City, Iowa.
