title: Transactions
description: Football

title: Amoco Falls 25.5%; ARCO Up 16.8%
description: The Amoco Corporation said yesterday that second-quarter earnings declined 25.5 percent, to $497 million, or 96 cents a share, from $667 million last year, or $1.30 a share, but the company said that after special factors were taken into account, earnings in both periods were ''essentially identical,'' at about $530 million.

title: Merrill Lynch In Expansion
description: Merrill Lynch & Company said last week that it would form a new unit called the Tritech Services Company, to provide mail processing, proxy operations and computer printing and graphics for itself and other concerns.

title: Irvine's Story: Conservative Town Becomes Environmental Innovator
description: When the Irvine Company founded this city out of orange groves in Orange County, it planned everything down to the width of the grass strips along the broad streets, the color of roof tiles on the regimented houses and even the length of time residents could keep their garage doors open.

title: Man Arrested in Assault in East Side Park
description: A 19-year-old East Side man was arrested last night after being identified as one of 12 youths who assaulted two men in a park near Gracie Mansion early Sunday while yelling anti-homosexual slurs, the police said.

title: Market Place; A Time of Plenty For Supermarkets
description: DESPITE their recent headaches with Alar-treated apples and tainted grapes from Chile, the nation's biggest supermarket companies will enter the second half of their fiscal years on a high note.

title: Going for a Record
description: Tom Gentry, a 59-year-old real-estate developer from Honolulu, set out from New York Harbor early yesterday in a second attempt to break the trans-Atlantic speed record aboard Gentry Eagle, his 110-foot 4,500-horsepower boat.

title: More Power for Japan's Protectionists
description: ''All politics is local,'' as Tip O'Neill, the former Speaker of the House, used to say, and that holds as true in Osaka as in Cambridge. The centripetal force of localism may accelerate in Japan as the result of stunning losses by the Liberal Democratic Party in Sunday's elections. That could give protectionists more leverage, with worrisome consequences for relations with the United States.

title: Chrysler Looks For Cost Cuts
description: The Chrysler Corporation said today that it was examining ways to cut its fixed costs in expectation of a downturn in sales over the next 15 months.

title: Valentine Bargmann, 81, Einstein Assistant
description: Valentine Bargmann, a mathematical physicist who was an assistant to Albert Einstein at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J., died of heart failure Friday at the Princeton Medical Center. He was 81 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: Unisys Profits Plunged 67% in Second Quarter
description: The earnings of the Unisys Corporation fell by 67 percent in its second quarter despite a 7.5 percent increase in revenue, the company said today.

title: New York Philharmonic's Anniversary in Central Park
description: For decades, Erich Leinsdorf has labored under the image of the effective but dour kapellmeisterisch sort of conductor. His expertise and soundness of judgment has always been saluted, but rather few observers over the years have been moved to eloquence about the character of his interpretations, and veiled or unveiled complaints of earnest dullness have been heard.

title: Topics of The Times; Producer to Downey: Zip It
description: A year ago he was Exhibit A for pundits worried about ''pit bull TV'' and what seemed a growing tendency toward boorish, pugnacious behavior. To a guest who bored him he would bark, ''Zip it!'' To one with whom he disagreed he would snarl, ''Puke-breath!''

title: Claude Harmon Is Dead at 73; Taught Golf to Four Presidents
description: Claude Harmon, a former Masters champion who taught golf to four United States Presidents, died Sunday, apparently of heart failure, after undergoing heart surgery last Wednesday. He was 73 years old.

title: Long Jail Sentences Run Into 109-Day Policy
description: The police here work in the face of a gnawing contradiction. The public wants them to crack down on drug use, but the state cannot keep the people they are arresting in prison.

title: Congressman From Detroit To Challenge Mayor Young
description: Representative John Conyers Jr. filed nominating petitions today to enter the Detroit mayoral race, facing Coleman A. Young, who is seeking a fifth term.

title: Books of The Times; Minding the Business of the Beatles
description: The Man Who Made the Beatles An Intimate Biography of Brian Epstein By Ray Coleman 400 pages. Illustrated. McGraw-Hill. $19.95.

title: Even Approval of New Government For New York Will Not Speed Pace
description: Even if the New York City Charter Revision Commission's proposals meet with the approval of the Justice Department and the city's voters in November, it would take months and, in some cases, years before the new government would be in place.

title: Dr. Charles A. Weymuller, 92, Pediatrician
description: Dr. Charles A. Weymuller, a pediatrician and professor at the former Long Island College of Medicine for several decades, died in his sleep Saturday at his home in Albuquerque, N.M., where he lived in retirement. He was 92 years old.

title: What Poland Needs Is $10 Billion in Investment
description: To the Editor:

title: SmithKline Net Increases
description: The SmithKline Beckman Corporation, the pharmaceuticals maker, said today that its second-quarter earnings rose 20 percent over last year.

title: Champion Focuses On Ryder Cup
description: Mark Calcavecchia, the new British Open champion, had a good night's sleep after his playoff triumph over Greg Norman and Wayne Grady and got up this morning with a new outlook on things.

title: Corrections
description: An article June 30 about a proposal to expand Fort Riley, Kan., incorrectly described the fort's role in the Battle of the Little Bighorn. The Seventh Cavalry, with Gen. George Custer as second in command, was formed at Fort Riley in 1866. In 1876, the cavalry, led by General Custer, headed out to the Little Bighorn from Fort Abraham Lincoln in the Dakota Territory, not from Fort Riley. The error was pointed out by a reader in a recent letter.

title: Oil Rig Count Increases
description: The number of working oil rigs in the United States rose by 10 last week, to 830,Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. A year ago, the number of working rigs was 903, Baker Hughes said. The rig count reflects the number of rigs exploring for oil.

title: Ensley Llewellyn, 83, Of Stars and Stripes
description: Brig. Gen. Ensley M. Llewellyn, a founder of the World War II military newspaper Stars and Stripes and a member of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's staff in the war, died Wednesday of heart disease in a doctor's office in Tacoma, Wash., where he was having a checkup. He was 83 years old and lived in the Tacoma suburb of Spanaway.

title: Q&A
description: Animal Dreams

title: Giants Open Camp, but 12 Are No-Shows
description: The Giants opened training camp today without eight unsigned veterans, two unsigned draft choices and two signed but financially unhappy stars, Phil Simms and Lawrence Taylor.

title: Syntex Expects Earnings Drop
description: The Syntex Corporation, a pharmaceuticals company in Palo Alto, Calif., said it expected to report a decline in earnings and revenues for the fourth quarter ending July 31. Syntex attributed the decline to slower-than-expected sales of its core product, Naprosyn, which faces new competition in the market for anti-inflammatory drugs and to increased investments in research and development.

title: Berkeley Chancellor to Quit And Return to Teaching Law
description: Ira Michael Heyman, chancellor of the University of California at Berkeley, will leave his post next year to return to teaching law.

title: Jet Makes Unscheduled Stop After Hydraulic System Leak
description: A Continental Airlines jet flying from Newark to the Dominican Republic made an unscheduled stop here after the pilot detected a small leak in the hydraulic system, an airline spokesman said.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Interim Chief Named At National Education
description: LEAD: Gen. David C. Jones, once the nation's top-ranking military officer, has assumed command of the National Education Corporation, an educational training company based in Irvine, Calif.

title: Dispute Over Khmer Rouge Stalls Cambodian Talks
description: The first round of what is to be a month of negotiations on Cambodia's future broke up in discord today over the role of the Khmer Rouge in a governing coalition.

title: Holiday Stock Rises on Rumor
description: Shares of the Holiday Corporation rose sharply today in heavy trading, apparently on the belief that a bidder might emerge for the Memphis-based hotel concern.

title: Ford Australia Car
description: The Ford Motor Company's Australian subsidiary introduced a convertible sports car that the auto maker hopes to export in six months. Ford Australia's president, Bill Dix, said the car called Capri, would go go on sale in October. Ford plans to sell 5,000 cars in Australia within a year and 30,000 outside the country. Ford said it expects the car to sell locally for about $17,000, and $20,000 for a turbo-charged model.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Women Gain Foothold In Drive for Accounts
description: Once virtually absent from the upper ranks of the advertising industry, women are filling one of the newer and more critical roles in agency management: the pursuit of new business.

title: To Settle Suit, Ex-Klansmen Agree to Study 'Lessons of Brotherhood'
description: In a legal agreement few Southerners ever envisioned, seven former Ku Klux Klan members will take a course in race relations taught by civil rights figures.

title: Mexican Debt Pact Welcomed
description: The agreement Mexico reached with its American and other foreign bankers on Sunday, which provides the country with about $3 billion a year in new debt relief, was welcomed yesterday as a breakthrough in a seven-year stalemate that has weighed down Latin American economies and banking companies as well.

title: Budget Surplus in June
description: The Federal Government recorded a budget surplus of $7.79 billion in June, as individual and corporate income tax payments rose sharply from May, the Treasury Department said today, The June surplus compared with a deficit of $25.47 billion in May and a surplus of $9.13 billion in June 1988.

title: Giuliani Shifts 3 Top Advisers In G.O.P. Bid
description: In a staff shakeup that reflects fears his campaign for mayor of New York is floundering, Rudolph W. Giuliani has pressured three top advisers to step aside and added Roger Ailes, President Bush's media adviser, to the staff.

title: Restart Put Off Till Late 1990 For a Nuclear-Arms Reactor
description: The Westinghouse Savannah River Company, which operates the Government's Savannah River nuclear weapons plant in South Carolina, has told the Department of Energy it will not be able to restart the first of three shut-down military reactors until September 1990, the Energy Department said today.

title: Tokyo Leaders, Stung, Try to Contain the Damage
description: Stunned by its worst election defeat in a generation, the governing Liberal Democratic Party today began the difficult process of selecting new leadership and devising a strategy to prevent its control of the Government from unraveling further.

title: Arabs Who Report to P.L.O. Said to Meet Shamir
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir has been meeting with West Bank Palestinians loyal to the Palestine Liberation Organization, who have been sending reports of the meetings to P.L.O. leaders in Tunis, Palestinians said today.

title: Honeywell Raises Its Defenses
description: Honeywell Inc. made itself less attractive to corporate raiders today by saying it would cut 4,000 jobs, retreat from its $1.4 billion weapons business and provide added cash to shareholders.

title: Our Towns; An Artist Sees Icon of the Age In Empire State
description: When Tony Lordi was a little boy in Newark, he could glimpse the Empire State Building from some street corners. One day when he was 5 years old, his parents took him to see it.

title: NASA Plans a 'Mission to Planet Earth'
description: WHEN President Bush outlined his vision of America's future in space last week, Mars and the Moon outshone another initiative that the President said was critical to the space program: a 25-year effort using a new network of satellites to understand how the Earth's atmosphere, seas and living creatures function as a global system.

title: Japan's Voters Rise Up
description: The men who pull the levers of power in Japan have governed for decades under one of this society's many unspoken accords: Keeping the Japanese economic miracle rolling, almost everyone agreed, depended on the stable command of a single political party.

title: What Poland Needs Is $10 Billion in Investment; The 30's No Longer
description: To the Editor:

title: McMartin Mistrial Is Feared
description: An alternate juror was dismissed from the McMartin preschool molestation trial today as a result of illness, and the judge said there was a probability the case would end in a mistrial.

title: Angels Edge Athletics In Showdown in West
description: Chili Davis hit a home run to snap a seventh-inning tie and Jack Howell hit a homer in the eighth tonight as the California Angels beat the Oakland Athletics, 5-4, and won their sixth in a row.

title: Dow Falls 22.38, to 2,584.98; Trading Slows
description: Stock prices retreated broadly yesterday, as the Dow Jones industrial average of 30 blue-chip stocks tumbled below the 2,600 peak it had scaled on Friday with a 32-point climb. The Dow fell back 22.38 points, to 2,584.98, yesterday as investors took profits.

title: MAYORS CRITICIZE ANTI-DRUG EFFORT
description: Several mayors came to Washington in search of money to fight drugs in their cities today, and when they emerged from a meeting with William J. Bennett, the national drug policy director, some had harsh words for the Bush Administration's anti-drug efforts.

title: Lagging in Polls, Thatcher Shakes Up Her Cabinet
description: Trying to overcome a lag in the public opinion polls and defeat in recent elections to the European Parliament, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today named new Foreign and Defense Ministers and a new chairman for the Conservative Party.

title: A Full-Court Press For School Sports
description: Bing Steel has its headquarters in a large brick building near downtown Detroit, in a neighborhood by Tiger Stadium where the boulevards are named West Grand, Martin Luther King and Rosa Parks, and the mood is a mixture of urban weariness and street-wise wariness.

title: Gandhi's Rivals Quit Parliament in Protest
description: Most opposition members of India's lower house of Parliament resigned today in protest against Government corruption, vowing to mount street demonstrations against Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's party.

title: Carbide Profit Is Nearly Flat
description: The Union Carbide Corporation said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings were nearly flat, in part because of lower prices for polyethelyne.

title: Train Fire Keeps Hundreds from Homes
description: Hazardous materials experts reassured hundreds of displaced families today that fumes from a chemical fire will not hurt their homes, and one official said even garden vegetables will be edible.

title: Launching of Space Shuttle To Be Delayed at Least a Day
description: The planned launching of the space shuttle Columbia next month will be delayed at least a day because of a fuel valve in a power system that may be stuck, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.

title: Helmsley Home Decor Billed To Subsidiary, Witness Says
description: A former executive of a Helmsley company testified yesterday at Leona M. Helmsley's trial that he was told his company would have to ''eat'' the cost of furnishing the Helmsley's 28-room residence in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Prosecution Is Given A Delay in the Trial Of Iran-Contra Case
description: Citing national security concerns, the Justice Department won a delay today in the trial in the Iran-contra affair of the Central Intelligence Agency's former station chief in Costa Rica.

title: New York Fighter Plots Strategy as He Seeks an Upset for the Gold
description: Lionell Odom Jr. shifted his weight in the rear seat of a van carrying members of the East team to their last workout before Tuesday's championship round of the United States Olympic Festival's boxing competition.

title: Hewlett Will License Microprocessor Design
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company, in a change of strategy intended to match a rival, Sun Microsystems Inc., has decided to license its microprocessor design to other companies, company officials said today.

title: Two Are Killed, Six Wounded As Beirut Shelling Continues
description: Two people were killed and six wounded today in new artillery and rocket duels between Syrian and Christian gunners as Christian and Muslim clerics appealed to the combatants to stop the bombardment of residential districts.

title: State Officials Fine Brooklyn Hospitals For Faulty Services
description: Two Brooklyn hospitals have been fined $93,000, with one cited for deficiencies ''in almost every area'' and the other charged with operating on the wrong leg of a patient, state officials said today.

title: Washington Talk: Exact Words; 'Underclass': Coming to Terms With a Term
description: Isabel V. Sawhill, senior fellow of the Urban Institute, a nonpartisan research organization in Washington, in the summer issue of The Public Interest:

title: Concerns About Content Prove Ready for Prime Time
description: At a time when network executives and program producers are eager to ignite interest in the coming prime time television season, the major questions inside the industry concern fear of fallout from the past one.

title: As Prosperity of Steel Fades, A Town Debates Its Future
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation practically created this brawny city, bringing not only smoke and grime but also decades of prosperity when it built one of the largest steel mills in the world here on the shore of Lake Erie.

title: St. Luke's Picketed by Hospital Workers
description: Thousands of health-care workers, protesting stalled contract negotiations, picketed St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center on Morningside Heights yesterday morning. Then, joined by the Rev. Jesse Jackson, they marched across town and down Fifth Avenue to Mount Sinai Medical Center.

title: Coal Strike Disturbs Supply Of Lower-Priced Electricity
description: Consumers are likely to face higher costs for electricity as a result of the three-month miners' strike that has curtailed Eastern coal production, for the strike has prompted several big utilities to conserve their coal supplies by curbing electricity sales to neighboring utilities.

title: INSIDE
description: Shamir Reported to Meet With Supporters of P.L.O Israel's Prime Minister has been meeting Palestinians loyal to the Palestine Liberation Organization, Palestinians say. The reports support claims that Israel is indirectly dealing with the P.L.O. Page A8. Further Delay for Reactors The timetable for restarting any military reactors at the Savannah River weapons plant has been pushed back to September 1990. Page A10. Poor Mathematics Skills Many of New York City's public school students are doing so poorly that it will be hard to absorb them into the city's economy. Page B1. Giuliani Seeks Help The former U.S. prosecutor, fearing his New York mayoral bid is floundering, changes his staff. Page B1. A Class for Klansmen As part of a legal settlement, seven former Ku Klux Klan members will take a course in race relations taught by civil rights figures. Page A14.

title: A.M.A. Describes Tanning Hazards
description: Getting a tan raises the risk of skin cancer, wrinkles, eye damage and changes in the skin's immune system, according to a report in the current issue of the Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: Review/Dance; New and Longer 'Sylphide' From London
description: Prior to its season at the Metropolitan Opera House, which opens on Tuesday, the London Festival Ballet has presented an unusual and provocative production of ''La Sylphide'' at the Kennedy Center here.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-9 To prevent further labor unrest, President Gorbachev offered workers a chance to punish party, government and union officials through early local elections. Page A1

title: Reds Get a Break
description: The last thing the Cincinnati Reds needed yesterday was an exhibition game. They were coming off a four-game sweep by the Expos and had lost eight in a row to fall out of the National League West pennant race. But they were expected to limp onto Doubleday Field in Cooperstown, N.Y., to play the Boston Red Sox in the annual Hall of Fame game. As it turned out, the Cincinnati team did get the day off: the game was canceled when the Reds had trouble getting a charter flight out of Montreal. The Red Sox ended up playing a game against one of their minor league teams.

title: Panel Backs Judge in Cancer Case Jailing
description: The Brooklyn Bar Association said yesterday that a Family Court judge was ''legally correct'' and ''morally compelled'' to order the temporary jailing this spring of a woman whose husband had taken their 4-year-old son out of a New York City hospital where he was being treated for leukemia.

title: A London Accent for 'Anything Goes'
description: Last year Elaine Paige, the English singer and actress, saw Lincoln Center's revival of the musical ''Anything Goes'' in New York and loved it. She liked the campy costumes and the ship-shaped set. She liked the new script that streamlined a Depression-era farce. She particularly liked the role of Reno Sweeney, the brassy nightclub singer first played by Ethel Merman and re-created by Patti LuPone at Lincoln Center. And as for the Cole Porter classics. . . .

title: House Speaker Attacks Capital Gains Tax Cut
description: House Speaker Thomas S. Foley today criticized proposals to reduce the capital gains tax rate as bad economic policy that would benefit only the wealthiest taxpayers, but conceded that he was not confident Democrats could defeat a reduction, which has been sought by President Bush.

title: Profits Scoreboard
The Dispute on Soybeans
description: The Ferruzzi Group today called for a study of the operations of the Chicago Board of Trade, in a follow-up of the soybean processor's criticism of the exchange's emergency order that required traders to reduce their holdings in soybean futures contracts.

title: Champion-Cooper Merger Approved
description: Shareholders of the Champion Spark Plug Company approved its $800 million merger with Cooper Industries. Cooper, a Houston-based manufacturer of commercial and industrial products, had offered a cash buyout for $21 a share.

title: Sudhir Sen, 82, Dies; An Indian Economist
description: Sudhir Sen, an economist who specialized in agricultural development and rural electrification in India and on behalf of the United Nations, died of a heart attack on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 82 years old.

title: White Attitudes Make Race an Election Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: London Journal; Snooker, Anyone? Nuns Aim to Pocket $1 Million
description: The nuns of Tyburn Convent practice silence, sacrifice and snooker.

title: To Aid the Poor, Cut Capital Gains Taxes
description: LEAD: This summer, Congress will decide the most important issue that will come before it this year: the Bush Administration's proposal to cut the capital gains tax to 15 percent from its current rate of 28 to 33 percent. The outcome will decide the shape of the economy in the year ahead as well as the politics of 1990.

title: In Paris, All Eyes on Dior and Lacroix
description: There were two overriding questions as the fall haute couture shows opened this week in a city still reeling from bicentennial excitement and the Tour de France. Would Gianfranco Ferre, the Italian designer, return the house of Christian Dior to its former glory, and would Christian Lacroix have a fashion life beyond the pouf?

title: Fall Promotion Plans Are Outlined by CBS
description: In another attempt to reach a broader audience, CBS this weekend announced new fall promotion plans.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Levine Picked By Ethan Allen
description: After a two-year hiatus without an agency, Ethan Allen Inc. yesterday selected Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver to handle its $10 million advertising account. The account had been at Hill, Holliday, Connors & Cosmopulos, Boston, until two years ago, when the home-furnishing company dropped the agency and began assigning its business on a project basis. Four agencies participated in the monthlong review process.

title: Review/Opera; Mozart in the Style of Sellars or Vice Versa
description: One place to start with a consideration of the Peter Sellars Mozart-Da Ponte project, a 10-year engagement with three incomparable operas, is virtuosity. In stage direction as in all the arts, this has a fascination of its own.

title: FOLEY OBJECTING TO FLAG PROPOSAL
description: House Speaker Thomas S. Foley today voiced his strongest objections yet to a constitutional amendment to outlaw flag burning and chided President Bush for his eagerness to support it.

title: GORBACHEV PUSHES POLITICAL CHANGE AT LOCAL LEVELS
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev moved today to prevent further outbreaks of labor unrest by offering restive workers a chance to take out their fury on local party, government and union officials.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about a belly dancer's conflict with the religious authorities in Israel misstated the composition of the Israeli Government.

title: Mexico Feels Squeeze of Years of Austerity
description: Seven years after the Latin American debt crisis erupted here, Mexico is a country battered by debt-induced austerity, in which the $100 billion owed to foreign creditors is likely to remain the dominant factor in the nation's economic and political life despite the new debt accord.

title: Cable TV Becomes a Consumer Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: Study Finds Rapid Declines of 7 Bird Species
description: SEVEN species of North American birds are declining so rapidly that they should be added to the Federal list of endangered species, experts at Cornell University have concluded.

title: Heresy And Disloyalty
description: This will be my last word on Owen Lattimore, who died recently and whose experience I invoked in a recent column to illustrate the damage false charges can do to their victims. In the 1950's, Mr. Lattimore was accused by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of being ''the top Soviet espionage agent'' in the U.S.

title: Industry Fights Use of Animal Tests to Assess Cancer Risk
description: THE chemical industry is challenging the way the Federal Government classifies substances as a potential cause of cancer in humans.

title: 20,000 Hold Demonstration In Capital of Soviet Georgia
description: At least 20,000 people, some shouting ''Down with the Russian empire,'' marched in the capital of Soviet Georgia today to demand independence.

title: Bankers Trust Net Is Flat; Currency Trading Gains
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation said yesterday that strong gains in foreign exchange trading kept its second-quarter profits on a par with those of last year, despite additions to its payroll and its reserves for bad loans.

title: Kodak Plans $225 Million Charge on Net
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said yesterday that it would take a one-time charge of $225 million, or 70 cents a share, in the second quarter as a result of write-offs for restructured businesses and payments to departing employees.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Quick Lube Chain To Chiat/Day/Mojo
description: Two weeks after changing its name, Chiat/Day/Mojo yesterday won the $10 million advertising account for Quaker State Minit-Lube Inc.

title: Sale of WOR Is Approved
description: The Federal Communications Commission has approved the sale of WOR-AM, the New York talk-radio station, to the Buckley-WOR Broadcasting Corporation for $25.5 million.

title: Washington Talk; Waste-Plant Inquiry Taps Hot Water
description: In terms of Washington stories, it has the makings of one that has everything -broad questions of Federal-state relations, a role reversal for business, protests from poor blacks and Indians and an inspector general's inquiry.

title: Not Welcome At State
description: The other day in New York sad words were spoken about our country, some of the saddest I have heard.

title: Sunnyvale Journal; Store Serves All Needs Of the Computer Crazed
description: When the Silicon Valley's computer whizzes go to the store for chips, they can mean either D-RAMs or Doritos.

title: NWA Profit Up Sharply In 2d Quarter
description: NWA Inc., the parent of Northwest Airlines, announced yesterday that its second-quarter profit had more than doubled from the period a year earlier.

title: Time Inc. Gains Control of Warner Within Hours of Court Approval
description: Hours after the Delaware Supreme Court removed the final roadblock, Time Inc. today gained control of Warner Communications Inc. The merger will create one of the largest communications and entertainment companies in the world.

title: Soviet Official Acknowledges Stalin-Hitler Protocol Existed
description: A senior Kremlin official has conceded for the first time that the Soviet Union and Nazi Germany divided Eastern Europe between themselves in secret protocols to a 1939 nonaggression pact.

title: By Design; Trends in Transit
description: This is the way it used to work. A fashion trend started in Paris. In due time it would show up in New York. This old system still prevails, but nowadays style vibes travel like the Concorde, faster than the speed of sound. And they go both ways, too. Here are some examples.

title: Tele-Cable Cancels Plan
description: Tele-Cable Inc., a cable company based in Norfolk, Va., is no longer looking for a buyer and has taken itself off the market, its president, Richard D. Roberts, said last week. Tele-Cable has 585,000 subscribers and is closely held. Tele-Cable's systems are primarily in the South and Midwest and in the Dallas-Fort Worth area.

title: What Poland Needs Is $10 Billion in Investment; Polonophobic Farrago
description: To the Editor:

title: Iranian Investment Plan
description: Iran will invest nearly $10 billion in its troubled heavy industries under a five-year plan now being drafted, the Iranian press agency said last week. The agency added that the plan would create 43,000 jobs and triple the annual output of heavy industries to 324 billion rials ($4.38 billion) with annual growth of 24 percent.

title: Washington Talk; Congress
description: When Jim Wright fell, many Democrats said their next order of business was to get the man who gave the Speaker that first shove: Newt Gingrich. But Tony Coelho, the Democratic whip who was also brought down in the new ethics atmosphere, counseled patience.

title: Soviets Seek U.S. Navy Cutbacks
description: The top military adviser to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has suggested that Moscow might not sign an agreement cutting conventional forces in Europe unless Washington agrees to open talks on reducing naval forces around the world.

title: Rise in Caffeine Linked to a Halt in Smoking
description: CONCENTRATIONS of caffeine in the blood rise sharply in people who quit smoking but continue to drink the same amount of coffee, researchers have found.

title: Thousands Flee From Fires In North Manitoba Forests
description: The Canadian province of Manitoba, with its northern half heavily affected by forest fires, was under a state of emergency today as the authorities carried out large evacuations.

title: Business and Health; When Benefits Are Set by States
description: STATE legislatures have passed more than 600 laws aimed at expanding the health benefits offered by many employers. But studies by academic researchers and others indicate that such mandates may have unintentionally had the reverse effect - reducing coverage by swelling the ranks of the more than 30 million Americans without health care benefits. Small employers say they cannot afford the added costs of meeting these requirements.

title: EXXON ESTIMATING $1.28 BILLION COST FOR SPILL CLEANUP
description: The Exxon Corporation yesterday put the cost of the Exxon Valdez cleanup at $1.28 billion, which would make the March 24 catastrophe one of the most expensive industrial accidents in history.

title: Chess
description: The time when you make a major change in your openings repertory is sure to be the time when your opponents try to jump you with the trickiest variations imaginable, the stuff that produces the maximum tactical difficulty, the hardest material to master quickly. But there is another way to look at this kind of situation.

title: USX Income Rises by 17.3% As Prices for Oil Increase
description: The USX Corporation, the giant oil and steel company, yesterday reported a 17.3 percent increase in its earnings for the second quarter, citing greater demand for petroleum products, higher crude oil prices and asset sales.

title: Ukrainian Miners Return
description: Miners went back to work as Ukrainians seized on President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's offer of prompt elections. Page A10.

title: OFFICIALS OF I.R.S. ACCUSED BY PANEL OF ETHICAL LAPSES
description: A House panel charged today that high-ranking officials of the Internal Revenue Service had undertaken questionable investigations, taken favors from people with potential tax problems, and used Government resources for private purposes.

title: Pogo Producing Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income Revenue for the year-ago quarter and 6 months included a gain of $10,070,000 from the sale of various interests in pipelines in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Cuomo Signs Bill to Create Hasidic Town School District
description: Gov.Mario M. Cuomo today signed a bill creating a special school district for a Hasidic community in Orange County that had refused to send its handicapped children to public schools.

title: Ex-Senator Lobbied H.U.D. And Discussed Business Deal
description: Former Senator George Murphy of California lobbied Federal housing officials on behalf of Boston projects that later received millions of dollars in assistance, according to newly released documents that offer a tantalizing glimpse of management and potential mismanagement at the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: Griffey on Disabled List
description: Ken Griffey Jr. of the Seattle Mariners, one of the American League's top rookies, was placed on the 21-day disabled list yesterday after breaking a bone in his hand Monday in an accident in a Chicago hotel room.

title: Punishment Alone Won't Stop Juvenile Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: John M. Driscoll Engineer, 85
description: John M. Driscoll, former chief mechanical engineer of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, died of cardiac arrest Monday at his home in Oradell, N.J. He was 85 years old.

title: Salomon Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Penn Central Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a pre-tax gain of $74.7 million from the sale of certain foreign operations and investments. The year-ago periods' nets included gains equal to 2 cents a share for the quarter and 5 cents a share for the 6 months, boh from discontinued operations.

title: Taylor Joins Workouts; Hill Released
description: The Giants' defense regained one starter today in Lawrence Taylor and lost one in Kenny Hill.

title: The Pop Life
description: Strauss Meets Brown

title: Bank of San Francisco reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Concern Revealed About Time Deal
description: When Time Inc. was trying to ignore the hostile takeover advances of Paramount Communications Inc., it cited cultural incompatibility as one of the key reasons. But legal documents unsealed by the Delaware Supreme Court after Monday's decision indicate that at least two Time directors were just as worried about that issue with Warner Communications Inc., and its chief executive, Steven J. Ross.

title: Auction Houses Predicting Record Worldwide Sales
description: Sotheby's Holdings and Christies International announced yesterday that they expected record worldwide sales for the 1988-89 auction season, which winds down this month and ends Aug. 31.

title: Politics Promotes Child Health
description: Is New York City a healthy place for children? Not very, says the draft report of the Mayor's Commission on the Future of Child Health - especially not if the children are poor. The report became a political issue when Richard Ravitch, a Democratic candidate for mayor, publicized it and accused Mayor Koch of trying to suppress it. Mr. Koch, at first defensive, now promises an urgent response.

title: A New Chrysler Vehicle Expected
description: The Chrysler Corporation will begin producing a small sport-utility vehicle at its plant in Toledo, Ohio, in mid-1993, the trade journal Ward's Automotive Reports reported on Monday. The publication quoted sources as saying that Chrysler's Stickney Avenue plant would be the site for production of the ''JJ,'' a vehicle the company plans to build in a venture with the French automobile maker Renault S.A.

title: Lilco to Pay Shareholders
description: The Long Island Lighting Company said today that it would pay $390 million owed to its preferred shareholders and resume paying quarterly dividends on its preferred stock.

title: Corrections
description: The Personal Health column on Thursday about a test for birth defects gave the wrong address for the Spina Bifida Association of America. The correct address is 1700 Rockville

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Bean and Grain Helpers

title: Cityfed Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Corrections
description: A picture in some copies on July 4, with an article about a newly discovered composition by Stephen Foster, was published in error. The photograph, showing a man with a mustache, was of the composer's brother, Morrison.

title: House Panel Votes to Cut Surtax Paid by Beneficiaries of Medicare
description: The House Ways and Means Committee approved a measure today to reduce by half the surtax rate that Medicare beneficiaries pay for health insurance coverage against the catastrophic costs of extended illness.

title: Review/Music; Kathleen Battle Sings Bach Arias And Mozart
description: The Orchestra of St. Luke's was founded a decade ago, and has become ubiquitous in New York during the concert season. Summer weekends, it is resident at the Caramoor Music Festival, in Katonah. But few doors are left ajar that this enterprising ensemble cannot get its foot into, and on Monday at Avery Fisher Hall, the group made its debut at the Mostly Mozart festival, displacing the festival's own orchestra for an evening.

title: Lucetta Harkness, 92, A Missionary Teacher
description: Lucetta Harkness, who taught English at high schools in Queens for more than a quarter-century and then became a Methodist missionary teacher in Japan, died of an intestinal hemorrhage on July 18 at North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. She was 92 years old and lived in Whitestone, Queens.

title: Control Data Loss Totals $$97.3 Million
description: Restructuring charges taken earlier this year accounted for most of a $497.3 million loss for the second quarter reported yesterday by Control Data Corporation.

title: Albert Chin Restaurateur, 64
description: Albert Chin, a Long Island restaurateur, died after a stroke on Sunday at Booth Memorial Hospital in Queens. He was 64 years old and lived in Jamaica, Queens.

title: Consolidated Edison Co of New York reports earnings for 12mo June 30
description: The company said results reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective in June. The company also said its lower earnings in the latest second quarter was due to expenses associated with the refueling cycle at Indian Point 2 in 1989 with no comparable expenses in 1988, and increases in operating taxes and other expenses.

title: Eastern Slows Schedule Expansion
description: Eastern Airlines said yesterday that it would expand its flight schedule more slowly than expected. The airline has been operating in Chapter 11 bankruptcy and is trying to recover from a continuing strike.

title: Eliot Bank reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The bank's operating results for the second quarter included a $15.1 million provision for possible loan losses. Eliot Bank said its second-quarter results were impacted by $1.5 million in writedowns of closely held investments, $800,000 in nonrecurring operating expenses directed principally at reducing onging costs.

title: Showdown for Nissan: Union Vote by Workers
description: The pro-union and anti-union rhetoric being sounded here present sharply different versions of life in Nissan's car and truck assembly plants: Nissan Motor Manufacturing Corporation U.S.A. is either a ruthless taskmaster that has eroded the health of its work force, or an enlightened, safety-conscious employer, bestowing generous benefits and taking an honest day's labor in return.

title: Punishment Alone Won't Stop Juvenile Crime; Among Toughest States
description: To the Editor:

title: Interface Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: The company said the second quarter net and sales included the operations of Heuga Holding B.V. which was acquired in September 1988.

title: U.S. Sees a Threat to Namibia Elections
description: The United States has complained to South Africa that its paramilitary units are intimidating blacks in northern Namibia, imperiling prospects for free elections there, Administration officials said today.

title: Worthen Banking Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a gain of $7.4 million from the settlement of a lawsuit and a gain of $719,000 in recovery from a bankruptcy estate. c-After a gain of $916,000 from an accounting change, and included $2.9 million in recovery from a bankruptcy estate.

title: Walesa Rejects Offer of Coalition; Talks of a Solidarity Government
description: The Solidarity leader, Lech Walesa, said today that his movement would not join a grand coalition with the Communist Party, but would prepare instead for the ''inevitable'' day when it would form a government on its own.

title: EATING WELL
description: YOUR doctor has told you to reduce your cholesterol levels. The physician has provided you with a single sheet of paper intended to help you make all the necessary changes in your habits to accomplish this.

title: Union Electric Co reports earnings for 12mo June 30
Johnson & Johnson reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in May.

title: To Be Precise, a New Era for Instruments
description: On Jan. 1, 1990, thousands of the world's most precise instruments will be recalibrated. By international agreement, the national standard laboratories of most industrial countries will on that day resolve the minute differences among them on the values of two basic yardsticks in electricity: the volt and the ohm.

title: Skinner Defends Exxon Plan For a Halt in Alaska Cleanup
description: Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner said today that Exxon was living up to its obligations in the cleanup of the Alaska oil spill and defended its plan to stop work on Sept. 15.

title: The Tactics Of Thatcher
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who moved or dismissed nearly half her Cabinet on Monday, signaled her determination today to continue the policies that most of her critics, inside and outside the Government, blame for the decline in the Conservative Party's fortunes over the last six months.

title: Bolstering the Police: Question in Mayor's Race Is How
description: With the public increasingly alarmed by crime, New York City's mayoral candidates are preoccupied with a quandary: How many police officers can they promise the public and how do they propose to pay for them?

title: La Petite Academy reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Studies Now Hint It Matters Which Parent Gives the Gene
description: New findings suggest that contrary to a fundamental law of genetics, genes from the mother and those from the father differ in ways that help explain the development of some inherited diseases, researchers said today.

title: Quaker State Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Latest second quarter included a net gain of $6.7 million for settlement of a contract cancellation and the acquisition of a new contract at a subsidiary. All year-ago results and those for the latest 6 months reflected the May 31 acquisition of McQuik's Oilube Inc., which has been accounted for on a pooling of interest basis.

title: Santa Barbara, Calif.
description: IN this bastion of lithe bodies and sybaritic tastes, the Hercules Flip is as much a part of life as Highway 101: Santa Barbarans can't get through the day without it.

title: The Chop Suey Syndrome: Americanizing the Exotic
description: WHEN he fled Afghanistan in 1979, Mohammad K. Rouzyi was loath to leave the slow-cooked dishes of his homeland, like sherwa-eshamal-war, a fiery, dense soup, or yakhni pilau, a rice with chicken and lamb. But eight years ago, when he rolled a pushcart to a street corner in midtown Manhattan, Mr. Rouzyi served what Americans would buy: kofta kebabs.

title: Striking Ukrainian Miners, Appeased, Return to Work
description: Striking Ukrainian miners went back to work today as an emboldened assortment of political groups ranging from czarists to Communists quickly took President Mikhail S. Gorbachev at his word and proposed holding local elections with greater dispatch and democracy.

title: Lyphomed reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the latest second quarter and 6-month included a charge of $3,293,000 in connection with an agreement to settle shareholder litigation. The company also said the year- earlier second quarter and 6-month included a charge of $9.5 million related to a food and drug administration quarantine.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Chief Also Chairman At Convex Computer
description: LEAD: Robert J. Paluck, the president and chief executive of the Convex Computer Corporation, has been elected chairman of the company as well.

title: Mack Pleads Not Guilty
description: Kevin Mack, a fullback for the Cleveland Browns, pleaded not guilty to drug-trafficking charges yesterday in Cuyahoga County Common Pleas Court in Cleveland and was allowed to remain free on $2,500 bond. He was arrested June 28 and indicted July 10 on one felony count each of cocaine possession, cocaine trafficking, possession of criminal tools and using a motor vehicle for drug abuse.

title: Mattel Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Commercial Bancorp of Colo reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain of $491,000 from an accounting change. Year-ago quarter and 6 months were restated for an accounting change.

title: Doing a Favor For World's Deprived
description: rrAn American named Tex says he's got just the thing for the poor huddled masses in Milan, Frankfurt, Barcelona, London, Montreal and Mexico City. He's not pushing oil wells or fast-food franchises or Michael Jackson. Instead, Tex Schramm, formerly of the Dallas Cowboys, is trying to organize a spring football league for marginal American players.

title: Market Place; Bank-Run Funds Lose Bit of Ground
description: ALTHOUGH as a group they showed strong gains in the last quarter, common stock funds administered by banks lost a little ground in relation to the overall stock market.

title: Branford Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TBC Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Belo (A.H.) Corp(N) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Mobil and Chevron Off; Phillips Up
description: The Mobil Corporation and the Chevron Corporation yesterday both reported slightly lower earnings for the second quarter than they had a year ago, but each company said that after adjusting for special factors, the year's results were better than last year's.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We were just going to try to go in and land. How could we operate if we did not believe that?'' - Alfred C. Haynes, captain of United Flight 232. [ A12:1. ]

title: Northern Telecom Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Some year-ago figures have been restated.

title: Judge's Ruling Casts Doubt on Deportations
description: A Federal judge has ruled that the Immigration and Naturalization Service probably violated the law in carrying out its policy to curtail the flow of Central American refugees seeking political asylum in the United States.

title: A Simple Domestic Chore Becomes A Cause; In New York, Efforts Lag
description: WHILE New York City is in the first stages of a plan that will revolutionize the way its residents handle their garbage, New York State lags behind New Jersey and Connecticut in statewide recycling efforts.

title: Washington Federal Savings (Ore.) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Run Public Schools Like Colleges
description: There is wide agreement that American higher education is one of the finest systems of education in the world but that it rests on a rather shaky foundation of elementary and secondary education. American public schools lag badly behind their counterparts in Western Europe and Japan in basic literacy, mathematics, science and foreign languages.

title: Kings Sign Robinson
description: The free-agent defenseman Larry Robinson and the Los Angeles Kings reached an agreement in principal on a contract yesterday, the National Hockey League team said yesterday.

title: Washington
description: ON Saturday mornings the halls of Congress may be empty, but on Capitol Hill the Eastern Market teems with Government employees and other Washington residents shopping for fresh foods.

title: Carolina Power & Light Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Gingrich's Pay to Aides in 2 Races Raises Question of Rule-Breaking
description: Representative Newt Gingrich, the House Republican whip, took members of his Congressional staff off the payroll to work in his re-election campaigns in 1986 and 1988 and then gave them substantial temporary raises when they came back after the election.

title: Altron Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
In Paris, Applause For Lagerfeld's Chanel Collection
description: Too enervated by this summer's tropical heat even to move their fans, the audience at Karl Lagerfeld's Chanel collection still found the energy to be dazzled today. ''Probably the best Chanel Karl has ever done,'' said Ellin Saltzman, a vice president in charge of fashion at Saks Fifth Avenue.

title: Provident American reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: United Banks of Colorado reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
'Village' Anarchists: Master Intimidators
description: LEAD: ''I've always considered myself very liberal,'' said my neighbor, Patrick, whose East 10th Street apartment overlooks embattled Tompkins Square Park, ''but now anyone who didn't support the tent city is made to feel guilty.''

title: Westmoreland Coal reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income c-Net loss

title: Khashoggi Bail Is $10 Million
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan set bail of $10 million yesterday for Adnan M. Khashoggi, the jailed former billionaire arms broker from Saudi Arabia who is charged with helping Ferdinand E. Marcos with ''illegal property deals.''

title: V.S. Yanovsky, a Soviet Emigre Author and Physician, Dies at 83
description: V. S. Yanovsky, an author and a physician who was part of an early wave of Soviet emigres who came West in the 1920's, died of lymphoma on July 20 in Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 83 years old and lived in Queens.

title: Regional Bancorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. to Play in Honduras
description: The postponed World Cup qualifying game between the United States and El Salvador will be played in Tegucigalpa, Honduras, on Sept. 17, the sport's international governing body, FIFA, announced today.

title: Taming a Lobster, With Pinkie Lowered
description: THE problem with lobster is rarely its flavor. Except for its spawning months (in the early summer), when its shell is soft and its flesh is weary, a properly cooked lobster is sweet and tender, rich and delicate, the apex of seafood, the apogee of elegance.

title: Sears Canada reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Lake Shore Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Pope Names the First Bishop of Byelorussia in Six Decades
description: The Vatican took another significant step toward closer relations with the Soviet Union today when Pope John Paul II named the first Roman Catholic bishop in the Soviet republic of Byelorussia in six decades.

title: A MIRACL Weapon Better Left Untried
description: Congress this week will consider a Bush Administration request to begin testing a laser weapon for disabling or destroying satellites in orbit. But the U.S. depends on satellites for military communication far more than the Soviets do. That makes a competition in anti-satellite weapons potentially self-defeating.

title: Opus One Is to Get Its Own Winery
description: THE super-premium California wine Opus One is finally going to get a home. Opus One is the product of a 10-year collaboration between the Robert Mondavi Winery in Oakville, Calif., and Chateau Mouton-Rothschild in Bordeaux, France.

title: New Jersey Farms Thriving as Land Lures Part-Timers
description: It was on a transcontinental jet, speeding toward a business meeting in Seattle last November, that Patricia D. Galloway and Kris R. Nielsen decided where to plant 2,500 grapevines.

title: Ohio Casualty Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Businessland Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said that fiscal 1988 results have been restated to reflect the July 1988 acquisition of Computercraft Inc. which has been accounted for on a pooling-of-interests basis.

title: State Loses Plea On Northwest
description: United States District Judge Patrick A. Conmy has rejected a request by North Dakota's Attorney General, Nicholas Spaeth, to issue a temporary restraining order to block the sale of Northwest Airlines to the Los Angeles investor Alfred Checchi. Mr. Spaeth had contended that in a 1986 agreement between the state and the Minneapolis-based airline when it merged with Republic Airlines, Northwest promised that consumer costs would not increase and that it would make no service cuts or layoffs. Mr. Spaeth was seeking $50 million in damages for breach of contract.

title: First Oak Brook Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Smith's Food & Drug Centers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Florida Governor Proposes Legislature Limit Abortions
description: Gov. Bob Martinez today called a special session of the Legislature for October to consider restrictions on abortion.

title: Japanese Party Looks to New Generation, Then Looks Away
description: After a devastating election defeat and a year of scandals infecting most of its high command, Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party is being prodded by friends and critics alike to turn to bolder and fresher leadership to help it out of the swamp.

title: 4 Israeli Soldiers Imprisoned For Robbing Arabs in Gaza
description: Four Israeli soldiers have been jailed for stealing money from Palestinians while searching them in the occupied Gaza Strip, an army spokesman said today.

title: Campaign Is On to Draw Adults to Equivalency Test
description: The number of people who take the high school equivalency test has dropped about 10 percent since 1980, and the organization that administers the test has begun a publicity campaign to encourage more people to take it.

title: F&M Financial Services reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Punishment Alone Won't Stop Juvenile Crime; System Needs Overhaul
description: To the Editor:

title: Talley Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $85,000 for the quarter and $40,000 for the 6 months. The latest quarter included $60 million pre-tax gain on sale of automotive air bag business to TRW and establishment of a $35.3 million real estate reserve.

title: Steinbrenner Concerned With Team's Slide
description: His team had lost seven straight games and had tumbled from second place to fifth in the American League East before last night's game, but George Steinbrenner is still exercising patience with his slumping Yankees. His difference may come with Dallas Green, the manager, who has leveled occasional criticism at his players during their latest and longest slump.

title: Jersey Proposes Plans Pave Chromium Sites
description: New Jersey health and environmental authorities disclosed plans today to cover 86 chromium-filled sites with asphalt, including six vacant lots near an elementary school closed in mid-May because of contamination by the toxic chemical.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Morgan Picks Five Finalists
description: J. P. Morgan & Company has narrowed its account review for its private banking services to five agencies, executives involved in the review said. The finalists are Lintas U.S.A, TBWA, Chiat/Day/Mojo, BBDO and Della Femina, McNamee WCRS.

title: Cornell Tries to Help Cambodia Preserve Its Past
description: In their drive to purge Cambodia of the perceived taint of religious and imperialist influences, the brutal Khmer Rouge tried to wipe out any record of these influences.

title: Metro Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Per share amounts for earlier periods are not applicable as Metro converted to stock form on Nov. 10, 1988. Year-ago periods included loan loss provisions of $1,766,000 for the quarter and $1,763,000 for the 9 months.

title: About Real Estate; New Jersey's No. 2 Convention Center Is Planned
description: It took S/A Associates of Garden City, L.I., nearly three years to convince E. R. Squibb & Sons to sell its pharamaceutical distribution center in Franklin Township, in Somerset County, N.J.

title: Vintage Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
Lucas Seeks to Reassure Panel About Rights Post
description: William C. Lucas, the Bush Administration's nominee to head the Justice Department's civil rights division, sought today to remove doubts about his qualifications and his commitment to civil rights.

title: Emergency Landing in Newark
description: A Continental DC-9 made an emergency landing last night at Newark International Airport after a reported hydraulic failure, but none of the 89 passengers were seriously injured, officials said. Flight 354 from Chicago made the emergency landing shortly after 8 P.M., said Gerald Bonaventura, the general manager of the airport. He said it appeared the hydraulic system had failed, and that the pilot ''made a determined effort to stop the plane.'' Passengers slid down chutes from the plane and there were no injuries, he said.

title: Louisiana Land & Exploration Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a $2.8 million loss on the early retirement of debt for both the quarter and 6 months, and the 6-month also included a $12.5 million after-tax gain from the sale of real estate in the first quarter. c-Net loss d-After a gain of $36.9 million from an accounting change. Results for the year-ago quarter and 6 months periods included an after-tax non-recurring charge of $11.7 million associated with the Texaco claim.

description: Scattered across the suburbs and small cities of Westchester County, a fledgling network of professional child-care centers for working parents is emerging.

Mazzilli Released By Mets
description: The Mets closed one of the chapters in their recent history yesterday when they released Lee Mazzilli, the switch-hitting outfielder from Brooklyn who arrived as the ''poster boy'' of their losing teams in the 1970's and later returned as the supersub of their winning teams in the 1980's.

description: The company said latest quarter and 6 months included its French L'Unite Hermitique subsidiary, which was acquired last December.

description: Orders for big-ticket factory goods rose three-tenths of 1 percent in June, the Government said today in a report seen by some analysts as evidence that manufacturing, although sluggish, is not crumbling.

description: b-Net income

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on July 12 about President Bush and Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, at a wreath-laying ceremony in Gdansk misidentified the monument. It was the Westerplatte monument, which honors a Polish garrison surrounded by German invaders at the outbreak of World War II, not the monument to strikers killed in 1970.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Albertson's Inc., Boise, Idaho, a supermarket and drugstore chain, said it would buy three stores in Austin, Tex., from Skaggs Alpha-Beta Inc., a unit of American Stores Co., Salt Lake City. Terms were not disclosed.

title: The Growth of Urban 'Mushrooms'
description: Consider a new, bloody indicator when measuring a city's quality of life: its rate of bystander shootings. A new study confirms a surge of injuries and deaths of ''mushrooms.'' That's the street word for innocents who pop up in a gunman's line of fire.

title: First United Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
King Rejects Taiwan Offer for Tyson
description: Don King hasn't lacked for feuds lately.

title: Yugoslav Inflation Woes
description: Soaring inflation has forced money changers at the Austrian-Yugoslav border to measure the dinar, the Yugoslav currency, in cubic meters, the national press agency Tanyug reported today. Inflation in Yugoslavia has surpassed 700 percent and is expected to peak at around 1,000 percent by the end of the year.

title: Open Positions on Short Sales Slip 0.7 Percent on Nasdaq
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers yesterday reported a seven-tenths of 1 percent drop in short interest for the active over-the-counter securities in its national market system for the four weeks that ended Friday.

title: Ashton-Tate Has a Deficit
description: The Ashton-Tate Corporation today reported a-larger-than-expected loss - the first in its history - and said its president and chief operating officer, Luther J. Nussbaum, had resigned over ''differences in management philosophy.''

title: Salomon and Shearson Increase Profits Sharply
description: Salomon Inc. yesterday reported record quarterly net income, helped by large profits in its brokerage subsidiary and continued success in its energy business, but it had an 11.1 percent decline for the first six months.

title: Chefs in Need Call Cooks From Home
description: IT seems only natural, now that home cooking has moved into high-style restaurants, that chefs should turn to their mothers - and sometimes mothers-in-law - for advice on menus and help in the kitchen. After all, preparing simple, homey food is not the province of professional schools or fancy French establishments.

title: Satellite Company Sues Comsat
description: A Connecticut company today filed a $1.5 billion antitrust lawsuit against the Comsat Corporation, contending that the Congressionally created company had fixed its prices and blocked competition for international satellite communications services.

title: Owens & Minor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Chief of L.I.R.R. Since 1985 Resigns
description: Bruce C. McIver, the president of the troubled Long Island Rail Road since 1985, has resigned suddenly amid signs that the commuter line's problems had exhausted his patience and that of its parent agency, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: New York City Correction Officer Is Charged in Murders of Two Men
description: A city corrections officer, arrested Sunday on charges that he attempted to rob a male prostitute, has been charged with the murder of two other men whose bodies were found a month ago near a West Side pier, the police said yesterday.

title: Treasuries Continue to Creep Up
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds crept higher again yesterday, helped by fresh signs of softness in the economy and an indication that the Federal Reserve may be in the process of easing credit conditions further.

title: Paramount Is Bruised But Far From Broken
description: The chairman of Paramount Communications Inc., Martin S. Davis, lost his bid for Time Inc. in court, but it is by no means clear that the decision has hurt his company in the long term, Wall Street bankers and analysts said yesterday.

title: Review/Film; A Sinister, Sexual Fairy Tale of Transformations
description: Angela Carter's fiction turns legends and fairy tales inside out, revealing the dark psychology beneath the golden glow. Her images are at once blunt and lush, as a woman becomes part swan and a man becomes a wolf, and a sexual aura of power, magic and menace informs her work. This balance of schematic tales and deep mystery is not easy for the camera to capture. Even Neil Jordan's intelligent ''Company of Wolves,'' co-written by the author, is far less haunted than the Carter version of ''Little Red Riding Hood,'' which inspired it.

title: Now Turn to Women
description: The emergence of women in Japanese politics is one of those startling phenomena that can launch great change.

title: Cairo Journal; Sun Has Set on Cricket, but There's Still Croquet
description: The cricket pavilion has been converted into a mosque and the polo grounds have been given over to the poor. Of the 18-hole golf course, only 9 holes remain. But some things endure at the Gezira Sporting Club, on a big and bustling island in the Nile.

Year-ago 6 months included a gain from asset sales of 16 cents a share.

title: Big Latin Debtors Find That Lacking Austerity, Relief Is Not Coming Soon
description: A photograph printed in newspapers across Brazil recently crystallized the view held by many Latin Americans that the developed world ignores their debt crisis.

Jury Convicts Man as Chief of Drug Ring
description: A 30-year-old man who was accused of being the leader of one of the largest and most violent drug rings in Brooklyn was convicted yesterday of Federal racketeering charges, including six murders.

title: INSIDE
description: Medicare Tax Cut Approved

title: UAL Jumps $6.75
description: The stock of UAL Inc. jumped $6.75 a share today, to $183.50, amid talk that several large investors had built up stakes in the airline company. The Marvin Davis is the latest investor rumored to be accummulating UAL shares. Dan Dorfman reported in USA Today that Mr. Davis had acquired about 3.5 percent of the carrier. Other takeover players linked to United include Saul P. Steinberg, a longtime friend of UAL's chairman, Stephen M. Wolf, with about 7 percent, and a group headed by the Texas billionaire Robert M. Bass with up to 3 percent of the company.

title: PALESTINIAN SAYS HE AND SHAMIR MET
description: A prominent West Bank lawyer associated with the Palestine Liberation Organization announced tonight that he held a meeting last week with Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, contradicting assertions by Mr. Shamir's aides that the Prime Minister has not been meeting with P.L.O. supporters.

title: Sears Net Rises 21.4% In Quarter
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest retailer and a major financial services concern, yesterday reported a 21.4 percent rise in second-quarter earnings. The results reflected two non-operating factors, and some analysts said they were unimpressed.

description: Rudolph W. Giuliani signaled the end of a split in his campaign yesterday by declaring that he wanted to lead an ''independent reform administration'' and that he looked to as many Democrats, Liberals and independents as Republicans for advice.

title: With Boogie-Woogie, Hadda Brooks Is Back
description: The pianist and singer Hadda Brooks, who is playing her first engagement in Manhattan since the early 1950's, was having fun with the singer Ruth Brown over dinner the other night. ''When I had just started singing outside the church when I was a teen-ager in Virginia,'' Miss Brown told Miss Brooks, ''I would do your version of 'Trust in Me.' And one night, my father walked in. He was shaking his finger at me and saying, 'Trust in me to give you a good whupping!' ''

title: Researcher Links Heart Drugs to 2,250 Deaths
description: Two drugs designed to prevent irregular heartbeats may have caused 2,250 or more deaths in the last two years, a researcher said today.

title: Austrian Woman Sought as Witness in Spy Case
description: Lacking the evidence to bring espionage charges against an American diplomat being investigated for ''illegal activities,'' the Government has asked Austria to try to locate a woman who may become a witness in the case, Administration officials said today.

title: Worry for Gorbachev; Workers, Resentful of His Changes, Could Topple the Crippled Economy
description: Largely overlooked in the original manifesto of the Soviet coal miners, who are now returning to the pits in tentative triumph, was one demand that must have caused Mikhail S. Gorbachev a small shiver of disquiet.

description: The Pulitzer Publishing Company has agreed to buy WDSU-TV, the NBC affiliate in New Orleans, for $46.8 million from the Cosmos Broadcasting Corporation, Pulitzer announced Monday.

description: LEAD: He was enormously popular for his entire eight years in the White House. In contrast to Presidents Truman, Johnson, Nixon, Ford and Carter, he both entered and left office riding high in the polls. Yet when he stepped down, the verdict of the Washington-watchers was that he had been a passive participant in his own

title: Helmsley Aide Tells of Pressure For Free Goods
description: Leona M. Helmsley's chief aide, Frank J. Turco, held up sealed envelopes in 1984 and said: '' 'This is cash, this is what Mrs. Helmsley wants,' '' a former Helmsley company executive testified at her trial yesterday.

title: Washington Journal; Wooed by Jobs, and Now Homeless
description: The Greater Washington Research Center recently put out a study entitled ''Housing Crisis: Shortages in the Midst of Plenty.'' The bottom line was that the thousands of highly paid lawyers, diplomats and government officials who now live here had priced the region's houses and apartments out of the economic reach of many secretaries, waiters, firefighters and bank tellers, particularly those just starting out their working lives.

title: Congress Ponders Exempting N-Plant From Pollution Law
description: One week after the House voted to require nuclear weapons plants to comply with Federal environmental laws, Congress is considering a new proposal to exempt the largest plant from the nation's principal water pollution law.

title: KEY RATES
Senate Panel Asks Ban on Grants to 2 Arts Groups
description: The Senate Appropriations Committee voted without discussion today for a five-year ban on grants made by the National Endowment for the Arts to two arts organizations that helped support exhibitions of photographs by Robert Mapplethorpe and Andres Serrano.

title: Yonkers Power Is Restored After Blackout
description: A major portion of the south side of the city of Yonkers suffered a blackout last night when a fault in a feeder cable disrupted service to some 3,500 customers, officials of Con Edison said.

description: The International Business Machines Corporation said it had begun shipping limited quantities of four-megabit D-RAM computer memory chips as part of a memory-expansion option for its most powerful PS/2 computers. The company has said that it is manufacturing the dynamic random access memory chips, the most advanced chips now available, in quantity.

description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has decided that the only way to get the stalled Soviet economy moving again is to build in some new incentives for individual workers. That is why his speeches on perestroika, or economic restructuring, sound more like T. Boone Pickens than Karl Marx.

title: Yanks Hitting Again As Their Slide Ends
description: At the worst moments of the losing streak, they were the players who seemed to contribute least. Steve Sax and Don Mattingly suddenly stopped hitting, and Jesse Barfield kept swinging and missing. The Yankees kept losing.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Interpublic's Profit Up
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies said Monday that its earnings had risen 17 percent in the second quarter of 1989 from a year earlier. Interpublic, whose holdings include McCann-Erickson Worldwide, Lintas Worldwide and Lowe Marschalk, reported net income of $28.3 million, or 84 cents a share, compared with $24.2 million, or 73 cents a share, in the second quarter of 1988. Revenue rose 12 percent, to $317.1 million from $282.6 million.

description: Estimates of what Time Inc.'s core properties are worth and how Time Warner is expected to perform after the merger is completed were spelled out in court papers filed during Paramount Communications Inc.'s suit to block the merger.

title: Youths on Rampage Push Man to Tracks After Robbing Store
description: A group of 25 to 30 youths went on a rampage last night in a grocery store in the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn, then fled into a subway station, where they attacked a man and pushed him onto the tracks, the police said.

title: Ryan Fans 14 In Six Innings
description: Nolan Ryan struck out 14 in only six innings but lost to the Blue Jays, 4-0, tonight.

title: Poignant Problems of the Nation's Rural Schools
description: They may not be as rough-and-tumble as some of their city cousins, and they certainly don't get as much public attention, but schools in the nation's rural areas have their own batch of chronic problems.

title: Review/Theater; Scene: Europe 1940. Subject: True Kitsch.
description: Selfish is too kind a word for Gertrude Garnet, ''the leading concert pianist of the international stage'' and the all-American heroine of ''The Lady in Question,'' Charles Busch's latest celebration of Hollywood kitsch. Hitler may be on the march, but Gertrude, on tour in Bavaria, can't worry her pretty head about politics. She finds the Germans ''so warm, so friendly'' and reassures the Nazis' victims that patience will reward them with an afterlife of ''Champagne and caviar.'' For Gertrude, art comes first, then her wardrobe, then her cosmetics bag (Suzette, the maid, has stolen it) and then, of course, love. To paraphrase Lorenz Hart, the lady in question is a tramp.

title: A Simple Domestic Chore Becomes A Cause
description: FOR years, Barb Whittemore never thought about her family's garbage. Day after day, she simply threw it out.

Prior year earnings included net gains of $387 million from foreign exchange and special items, which were mainly asset sales. The effect of these items on first half 1989 earnings was a benefit of only $12 million. The company also said the increase in revenue reflected higher prices for refined products and crude oil.

description: A decadelong contest over offshore oil drilling erupted anew today when a Senate committee voted to keep tankers out of areas where drilling and other oil activity are banned.
