title: WINE TALK
description: Few have had more to do with the way wine is made and the way it is drunk than Dr. Emile Peynaud. As Bordeaux's most famous enologist for almost 40 years, he has literally changed the way most of the world thinks about wine.

title: Settlement in Carl's Jr. Case
description: The founder of the Carl's Jr. restaurant chain and several members of his family agreed to pay $664,000 to settle a Federal lawsuit charging them with insider trading.

title: Ladenburg, Thalmann Picks 2 Top Executives
description: Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company, a New York City investment firm, yesterday named Howard L. Blum Jr. as co-chairman and chief executive and Jonathan Groveman as president.

title: Two Charges Against Poindexter Dismissed
description: A Federal district judge today granted the request of the independent prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair to dismiss two of the most serious charges against John M. Poindexter.

title: Hercules Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Latest quarter included a net non- recurring gain of $2,532,000, or 5 cents, after accounting for a retirement incentive program and charges from accidents at plants in Utah and New Jersey. Latest 6-month also included a net gain of $6,091,000, or 12 cents a share, after accounting for the sale of a fibers business charges from the accident in Utah.

title: Frank G. Campbell Trucking Executive, 82
description: Frank G. Campbell, who went from hauling eggs and butter in a wagon to running a 19-state freight company, died Sunday after a long illness. He was 82 years old.

title: The Pie Tin That Flew Round the World
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Federal Express Picks BBDO
description: THE Federal Express Corporation yesterday named BBDO, New York, to do the advertising for its new international air-express service, putting in place a major component in its effort to become a dominant force in that business.

title: Fireman's Fund Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $11,659,000 from the cost of debt extinguishment.

title: Wickes Asset Sale
description: The Wickes Companies said it had agreed to sell its Elco Corporation group of companies to the Kyocera Corporation of Japan for $250 million. The move is the latest asset sale by the new owners of Wickes, Blackstone Capital Parntners L.P. and Wasserstein, Perella Partners L.P. Elco supplies electronic connectors and interconnecting systems for the electronics industry, and Kyocera manufactures ceramic products and electronic equipment. Wickes, with holdings in retailing, automobile products and wallpaper and fabrics, has been selling off assets since it was acquired last year.

title: Policy
description: It is a rare policy idea that becomes so popular across ideological and partisan lines that virtually everyone in Congress endorses it. It is rarer still when that idea has to do with helping the poor.

title: NatWest's Chairman Resigns
description: The chairman and three directors of National Westminster Bank, Britain's second-largest bank, resigned yesterday, five days after the Government accused the bank's investment-banking arm of misleading the authorities in underwriting a stock issue.

title: National Steel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $9 million for the quarter and $11.6 million for the 6 months. c-After extraordinary tax credits of $4.9 million and $8.2 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: USG Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $472,000 and a gain on divestiture of $2,075,000. c-After gains from discontinued operations of $8,544,000 for the quarter and $14,463,000 for the 6 months. The latest quarter included an after-tax gain of about $7 million on the sale of USG's construction metal business to Unimast Inc. The company said 1989 6-month earnings are not comparable to 1988 results because of the effects of the recapitalization and restructuring implemented in 1988 which resulted in much higher 1989 interest expense.

title: Knight-Ridder Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $1,239,000 and $1,044,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and income from disposal of discontinued operations of $55,522,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $3,791,000 for the quarter and $2,971,000 for the 6 months. The company said the latest quarter and 6 months net from continuing operations both included a pretax gain of $49,076,000, or 58 cents a share, from the sale of the Pasadena Star- News.

title: U.S. Reports 4.5% Increase in Wage Costs
description: Wages, salaries and other benefits rose 4.5 percent in the year ended in June, the Labor Department said today. The report was viewed by some economists as a sign that inflationary wage pressures may be peaking.

title: Homestake Mining Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $14,413,000 for the quarter and $16,254,000 for the 6 months. c-After a loss of $301,000 and income of $309,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, both from discontinued operations, and the 6-month also included a gain of $3,125,000 from cumulative effect of accounting change.

title: Channel 2 Planning Tabloid-Style Show
description: In the latest shuffling of its early-evening lineup, Channel 2 said yesterday that it would present ''Hard Copy,'' a new tabloid-style magazine program, beginning Sept. 18.

title: Cuba Says It Wants to Help on Drugs
description: After a month of startling allegations of drug smuggling by army officers, a senior Government official declared today that Cuba wanted to cooperate with the United States in fighting narcotics trafficking.

title: Stocks Retreat as Dow Dips 1.90, to 2,583.08
description: The stock market backed away from an early surge yesterday with the Dow Jones Industrial average closing down 1.90 points, to 2,583.08.

title: Colt's Death and an Injury Mar Meadowlands Races
description: The death of one qualifier for the $907,000 Woodrow Wilson, the biggest of the five stakes races on the Million Dollar Babies card Friday at the Meadowlands, and an injury to another qualifier will diminish the glamour of the richest night in harness racing.

title: Boeing's Net Climbs 21.9%
description: The Boeing Company said today that second-quarter profit had increased 21.9 percent, primarily because of higher sales and lower research and development costs.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Addendum
description: Capital Cities/ABC Video Enterprises has acquired a minority interest in In-Store Advertising Inc., a maker of electronic billboards for point-of-purchase advertising. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Ex-Cowboy Early Hit for Giants
description: For five seasons, Steve DeOssie was a backup middle linebacker for the Dallas Cowboys and enjoyed little of it. Seven weeks ago, he said, he was liberated: he was traded to the Giants.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: WITH today's widespread concern over health and fitness, steaming foods makes sense for many reasons. Steaming is a fat-free method of cooking, and steamed foods, particularly vegetables, retain most of their vitamins and minerals. When foods are cooked by other methods - sauteing or boiling, for example - a significant percentage of nutrients is lost.

title: Ex-Player Sues School
description: A former Creighton University basketball player who says he was functionally illiterate when he left the Omaha school in 1982 has filed a lawsuit, charging that educators there failed to adequately teach him.

title: C.D. Yields Are Off Again
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts declined for the week that ended yesterday, the 13th straight week of declines.

title: Cray Research Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Cray said its results for the latest second quarter and 6 months reflected expenses of $10 million and $20 million, respectively, for its Cray-3 project.

title: Noble Affiliates Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain of $8,825,000 from an accounting change. Results from the latest period included a one-time gain of $15.3 million from a gas contract buy down.

title: Bicycling Buys Cyclist's List
description: Bicycling magazine, a publication of Rodale Press Inc., has acquired the subscriber list of Cyclist, one of Bicycling's competitors before it ceased publication with its August issue.

title: Interest in Fuel Cells Rises Again
description: Growing concerns about air pollution and the greenhouse effect have stirred new interest in fuel cells, devices that generate electricity through chemical reactions.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: United Savers Bancorp, Manchester, N.H., to Leonard Monahan Lubars & Partners, with a budget of $1.5 million.

title: American Cyanamid Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Washington Post Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-ago first half included a non-recurring gain of $115.7 million, or $8.99 a share, from the sale of the company's interest in cellular telephone operations.

title: Ashton-Tate Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the latest quarter earnings figures are not directly comparable to year-ago figures because Ashton-Tate switched its reporting periods to a calendar year schedule. The company also said its second quarter loss was primarily attributable to reduced revenue and a writeoff of about $8 million of product rights and inventories principally related to the decision resources product line acquired in 1986. The reduction in revenue resulted primarily from the continuation of the company's previously announced joint program with its U.S. distributors and resellers to substantially reduce distribution channel inventories, and from lower than expected upgrade revenues. Year-ago second quarter ended July 31, 1988 net was $11.5 million, or 44 cents a share, on revenue of $71.9 million, and the 6-month net was $22.6 million, or 87 cents a share, on revenue of $144.3 million.

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss) *Loss in year-earlier period.

title: State Insect Cute as a Bug: Cuomo Enshrines a Lady
description: Yesterday, Coccinella novemnotata was ambling through somebody's backyard, minding its own business. Today, it's the official New York State insect, a bug of distinction.

title: Wyoming National Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Primary earnings per share calculated on 1,777,576 shares for 1989, compared to 1988 calculations based on a weighted average of 1,186,345 shares through June 15, 1988 and 1,777,576 shares thereafter.

title: Sears, Roebuck & Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest periods included income from discontinued operations of $56.3 million for the quarter and $57.7 million for the 6 months. The year-ago periods included losses from discontinued operations of $16.1 million for the quarter and $41.1 million for the 6 months; the 6 months also included a gain of $544.2 million from an accounting change.

title: Angola Says Rebels Downed Transport Plane, Killing 42
description: The Angolan Government said today that rebels shot down a military transport plane, killing 42 of 48 people aboard. The rebels denied responsibility.

title: U.S. Halts Sale of Tritium After Loss Of Enough to Make a Nuclear Bomb
description: The Energy Department has suspended all sales of the radioactive gas tritium while it investigates the possible loss of enough tritium to help make a nuclear bomb.

title: Steel Import Quotas Extended While U.S. Seeks Subsidy Curbs
description: The Bush Administration today announced a 30-month extension of quotas that protect the domestic steel industry from foreign competition, saying it would spend that time seeking an international agreement to curb the subsidies that many foreign governments provide their steelmakers.

title: SENATE DEALS BUSH A LOSS BY DELAYING STEALTH SPENDING
description: Bowing to heavy opposition to the Stealth bomber, the Senate voted overwhelmingly today to bar purchases of the radar-evading plane next year unless the Pentagon demonstrates that the bomber can perform as advertised.

title: Results Plus
description: TENNIS Mayotte Gains: Top-seeded Tim Mayotte survived early serving problems last night to defeat John Ross, 7-6, 6-2, and seventh-seeded Derrick Rostagno outlasted Philip Johnson, 7-6, 7-5, to move into the third round of the Sovran Bank Classis in Washington. Mayotte, down by 4-5 in the first set after suffering two double-faults in one game, recovered to even the score by breaking Ross's serve and then raced through a tie-breaker, 7-3. Paul Annacone, seeded sixth, beat Doug Burke of Canada, 7-5, 6-3, and Paul Chamberlin and Todd Witsken added straight-set victories to advance past the second round of the $297,500 tournament. Chamberlin, playing in 106-degree afternoon heat, needed a second-set tie breaker to oust Martin Barba, 6-2, 7-6, and Witsken took six of seven games over Neil Broad of South Africa at one stretch to take a 6-4, 6-4 decision.(AP) Upset in the Netherlands: Unseeded Paul Haarhuis of the Netherlands defeated top-seeded Kent Carlsson of Sweden, 6-3, 7-5, yesterday in the opening round of the Netherlands Grand Prix in Hilversum. Haarhuis ranks 153d in the world standing. Carlsson is 13th. (AP) YACHTING Pied Piper Wins: Not even a heavy time handicap could steal first place this time from Pied Piper, which finished first in the Port Huron-to-Mackinac Island race in Michigan and also won its class. The Bayview Yacht Club officials yesterday declared Pied Piper the winner of its International Offshore Rules class, a day after the Chicagoan Dick Jennings piloted the boat across the finish line and into port. Fighting light winds, Pied Piper completed the course in 54 hours 8 minutes 32 seconds, ending with a corrected time of 53:57:08.(AP) BOXING Unanimous Victory: Brian Lonon, a four-time national champion, won a unanimous decision over Lionell Odom Jr. of Queens last night in Oklahoma City to win his second United States Olympic Festival gold medal. Lonon, who moved up from 106 to 112 pounds after failing to make the 1988 Olympic team, dominated the bout from the outset.(AP)

title: Making Mexico a Meager Model
description: ''This is a great moment for Mexico,'' President Carlos Salinas de Gortari says of his country's new agreement with foreign banks. The moment will be fleeting. Mexico and the banks have finally achieved voluntary debt reduction. But the result will be economically meager.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TENNIS
description: Borg's Problems Continue to Grow Bjorn Borg, the former tennis star, harried by debt, personal problems and apparent conflict with the partners in his fashion company, announced in Stockholm yesterday that he was going out of business in his native country.

title: Robert J. Mullens, 66, Ex-Bond Specialist
description: Robert J. Mullens, a retired municipal-bond specialist and a community leader on Staten Island, died of a brain tumor on Monday at the St. Vincent's Medical Center on Staten Island. He was 66 years old.

title: Boston
description: LYDIA SHIRE'S long-awaited restaurant, Biba, which opened late last month, is like nothing Boston has ever seen. The restaurant, in the new Heritage Building at 272 Boylston Street, opposite the Public Garden, combines the high-energy atmosphere Bostonians associate with New York, the glitter of Los Angeles and the unmistakable daring and enigmatic chic of Lydia Shire.

title: Terex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEWS SUMMARY
description: New analysis: Soviet entrepreneurs have created huge resentment under the emerging economic order. So new activism among the working class may work to President Gorbachev's disadvantage. Page A1

title: Old Guard's Gone, but Right Finds New Strength
description: Ronald Reagan is gone. Jerry Falwell has folded his Moral Majority. A less ostentatiously conservative President is in the White House. But the Republican Party's right wing has nevertheless rolled up a series of solid victories. And the awareness is growing in Washington that more than atmospherics are at work.

title: Talks Among Cambodia Factions Break Off in Disarray in France
description: Talks among Cambodian factions to end a decade-long civil war ended in disarray today when the leading adversaries said they had reached an impasse.

title: Two Ranking Editors Leave New York Post
description: James A. Fabris, one of two managing editors at The New York Post, and Dick Belsky, the metropolitan editor, have left the paper.

title: Reuters Profit Jumps by 34.5%
description: Reuters Holdings P.L.C., the London-based news agency and information services company, has announced that its profit climbed by 34.5 percent in the first six months of the year as it continued a cost-cutting effort begun after the October 1987 stock market crash.

title: Pirates Stop Mets' Streak at 6
description: Talk about emotions. They were mixed and moody and they flowed across Shea Stadium last night.

title: Shortening of Curb Seen as Blow to Steelmakers
description: The Bush Administration's decision yesterday to extend the steel-import quotas by two and a half years dealt a blow to the nation's major steel companies.

title: Review/Pop; A Heavy-Metal Dose Of Radical Populism
description: Saturday night's heavy-metal bill at the Ritz offered a good example of how the music's anti-authoritarian impulses can be translated into a type of reactionary populism. With Wasp, which headlined the show, the two were inseparable.

title: Boeing Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the 1988 data has been restated for the 1989 3-for-2 stock split.

title: Lin Sets Deadline for McCaw Bid
description: The Lin Broadcasting Corporation today repeated its willingness to be acquired by McCaw Cellular Communications Inc., provided a definitive deal is agreed upon by next Monday.

title: Accord Clears the Way for Digital Tape Recorders
description: Record companies and manufacturers of stereo equipment have agreed upon a copyright protection plan that will clear the way for the next generation of home-recording technology to reach the American market, several industry officials disclosed yesterday.

title: Sex Survey Is Dealt a Setback
description: The House Appropriations Committee dealt an unexpected setback today to Federal plans for a large-scale survey of American sexual practices when it eliminated $11 million for the survey from the budget for the fiscal year 1990 and directed the Public Health Service not to conduct the research.

title: U.S. Military Housing Threatens Japan Forest
description: To the Editor:

title: Byrd Signs with Jets; Top Pick Still Holdout
description: The Jets today signed their second-round draft choice, Dennis Byrd, to a three-year contract worth about $1.2 million, but the team's first-round pick, Jeff Lageman, remained unsigned.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Magazine Ads Rise
description: Magazine advertising revenue is growing at a record pace so far this year. The Publishers Information Bureau, a magazine industry group, said ad revenue jumped 12.4 percent in the first six months of 1989, compared with the period a year earlier. Revenue rose to a record $3.2 billion, while the number of advertising pages - the magazine industry's standard measure - increased 4.4 percent, to 87,269.

title: Best Buy Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Books of The Times; On Soviet Dissidence as Both Sides Falter
description: Say Cheese! By Vassily Aksyonov Translated by Antonina W. Bouis. 404 pages. Random House. $19.95.

Wyse Technology Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Mayor Says Dinkins Would 'Run From the Flak'
description: In a harsh attack the day before the first campaign debate, Mayor Edward I. Koch said yesterday that Borough President David N. Dinkins of Manhattan was ''very indecisive'' and characterized him as someone who would ''run from the flak.''

title: The Midlife Crises of 5 Yale Men
description: The five men whose midlife discontents make up the subject of ''Halftime'' were chosen from the Yale class of 1963. The 90-minute documentary, on Channels 13 and 49 at 9 P.M., is devoted mainly to their accounts of careers and marriages gone awry.

title: Economic Scene; Better Highways At No Cost
description: REMEMBER the good old days, when the asphalt was smooth, the bridges were sturdy and America's highways could still be maintained with a few pennies' tithe at the gas pump?

title: Helmsley Judge Hears Defense Split on Charges
description: Lawyers for Leona M. Helmsley and her former top aide, Frank J. Turco, revealed a sharp division at their tax-fraud and extortion trial yesterday, as they each accused the other defendant of arranging kickbacks.

title: Ambase Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest second quarter results had strong earnings gains by the company's banking and investment services operations.

title: Phillies Get 2 in the 9th to End Expos' Streak
description: A two-out, two-strike, two-run single by Randy Ready in the ninth off Tim Burke gave the Philadelphia Phillies a 4-3 victory tonight, ending a six-game winning streak by the Montreal Expos. The victory ended a six-game losing streak by Philadelphia.

title: Talking Deals; Potential Conflict In Bank Rescues
description: FEDERAL regulators have generally avoided owning stock in the financial institutions they supervise because of the potential for being too lenient in situations requiring strong action.

title: Manila Reports Arrest Of Top Rebel Leaders
description: A leader of the Communist insurgency, Saturnino Ocampo, and his wife, Carolina Malay-Ocampo, were arrested in the suburbs of Manila this morning by Philippine military officers.

title: Prostitutes Walk the Streets, to Virginia
description: By Mao's standards, it did not qualify as a Long March. But Mao never tried to hike a couple of miles in translucent three-inch spike-heeled shoes and a thigh-high leather miniskirt spangled with glitter beads. Here's what happened: About 1:30 A.M. Tuesday, the Washington police, once again, began rounding up the prostitutes who cruise the Thomas Circle area, mainly on 14th Street, about half a mile northeast of the White House. The nation's capital does not have a particularly bad problem with prostitution, but now and again the 14th Street scene becomes too blatant, too embarrassing, and the police move in. A Roundup of Sorts

title: 4 Cambodian Factions To Resume Discussions
description: Talks between the Cambodian Government and three guerrilla factions will resume Thursday after breaking up in disarray on Tuesday, Prince Norodom Sihanouk said today.

title: L.I. Gets Tournament but No Contenders
description: The Massapequa Falcons and the Sachem Tomahawks of Long Island and the Union Lancers of New Jersey were three solid reasons the Eastern New York Youth Soccer Association made a bid last fall to play host to this year's national championship tournaments for boys' and girls' under-16 and under-19 club teams.

title: Dunkin' Donuts Obtains Injunction
description: Dunkin' Donuts Inc., the doughnut store chain based here, said it had obtained an injunction in the Federal District Court for Massachusetts against the pending $43-a-share tender offer by Kingsbridge Capital Group, a unit of Unicorp Canada Corporation and Cara Operations Ltd.

title: Man in the Middle
description: Remember the episode about the Sultan of Brunei's misplaced $10 million during the Iran-contra investigation?

title: P.L.O. SAID TO EASE TERMS FOR VOTING IN OCCUPIED AREAS
description: For the first time, the Palestine Liberation Organization has offered a specific list of conditions under which it might allow Israel's plan for elections in the occupied territories to go forward, Government officials said today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-10

title: Surgery for Samuelsson
description: Ulf Samuelsson, the Hartford Whaler defenseman who tore a ligament in his left knee while exercising in his native Sweden on July 16, will undergo major knee surgery next week in Sweden and will be lost to the Whalers for at least six months. Samuelsson, 25 years old, had arthroscopic surgery performed on the knee at the time of the tear, but doctors in Hartford recommended a second, more serious operation. (AP)

title: Strife Returns To a Convent At Auschwitz
description: An impassioned debate has been revived here over the presence of a Roman Catholic convent at the site of the Auschwitz death camp.

title: Investigators Encounter Difficulty In Pursuing Case of Suspected Spy
description: As senators attended a briefing on the espionage investigation of Felix S. Bloch, an American diplomat, difficulties in developing a prosecution case were becoming evident today.

title: Income Falls At Goodyear
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, the world's largest tire producer, reported yesterday that its earnings plunged by 79.9 percent in the second quarter because of losses on the sale of its operations in South Africa and the sale of part of its pipeline subsidiary.

title: Texaco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Latest 6-month results included a first-quarter net restructuring gain of $1,190 million, $4.87 a share, primarily relating to the gain from the sale of Texaco Canada Inc. Results for 1988 included a restructuring gain of $225 million, or 92 cents a share, from the sale of its West German subsidiary. Results for 1988 are restated to reflect the adoption of Financial Accounting Standards Board Statement 96 governing accounting for income taxes.

title: Bus for Cabbies: Remedial Sightseeing
description: First it was classes in how to be civil to passengers. Then it was a dress code. Now the Taxi Commission has come up with a new innovation: teaching prospective cabbies how to find their way around New York City by making them ride a sightseeing bus for eight hours.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about an espionage investigation involving an American diplomat described an ABC News report incorrectly. In broadcasting a simulation of the delivery of a briefcase by the diplomat to a Soviet agent, ABC News said the incident occurred in a European capital; it did not say Vienna.

title: Newly Built Jets Damaged by Vandals at Plant
description: Four commercial jets newly built by the McDonnell Douglas Corporation were apparently vandalized last week as they awaited preflight tests at a plant in Long Beach, Calif., a company spokesman said today.

title:
CURRENTS;
Through A Glass Brightly
description: LEAD: AT Optometric Arts, two young architects, Karen Bausman and Leslie Gill, designed an interior that frames the eyeglass frames on sale there.

title: Senate Votes to Allow Cutting Of Northwest's Virgin Forests
description: The Senate voted today to let the timber industry cut virgin forests in the Northwest despite temporary court injunctions against the logging.

title: ABC News Divided on Simulated Events
description: Several officials at ABC News say they regret using a simulation of a news event during an evening newscast last week, but a network news executive said yesterday that ABC would continue to use the practice if necessary.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: TO the casual listener, the 12-year-old boy's fear seemed ridiculous and worthy of a quick dismissal. Despite the outward signs of confidence and even arrogance he shared with his graduating sixth-grade classmates, he admitted one persistent concern about entering junior high school in the fall: He was going to have a locker for the first time, and he might forget the combination.

title: Abortion Ruling Evokes Drug Nightmare
description: To the Editor:

description: Prime Computer Inc. today rejected the latest acquisition proposal from MAI Basic Four Inc., reaffirming its intention to be acquired by J. H. Whitney & Company. But a sudden financing complication now threatens to upend the Whitney deal. Whitney said that Chemical

description: * Axel Springer Verlag A.G., a West German newspaper publisher, has acquired the Medical Tribune Group, a collection of medical publications owned by the Sackler family. Terms were not disclosed but an industry source put the price at between $75 million and $90 million.

description: ''We're gradually approaching more and more the Congress telling the art world what is art.'' - Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio. [ C18:5. ]

Hooker Corp. Pressed To Sell U.S. Holdings
description: The pressure to sell Bonwit Teller, B. Altman and several other American retailers, possibly at ''fire sale'' prices, increased yesterday, as their Australian owner, the Hooker Corporation, asked the Supreme Court of New South Wales to appoint a provisional liquidator.

title: Magma Copper Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Airlines Seeking to Take New Approach in Ads
description: The airline industry won a small victory yesterday when the Department of Transportation proposed to allow airlines to list some surcharges separately from the base ticket price in their advertising. Airlines would also be permitted to advertise one-way fares that are available only by purchasing round-trip tickets, as long as that restriction is clearly indicated in the ad.

title: U.S. Seeks Curbs on Biological Weapons
description: A top State Department official said today that it would be impractical to curb biological weapons through a system of international export controls, even though their spread is a serious threat to American security.

title: A Judge Blocks Release on Bail For Khashoggi
description: Adnan M. Khashoggi, the Saudi financier charged with helping former President Ferdinand E. Marcos defraud the Philippines, was ordered to remain in jail yesterday while a Federal judge reviews an order that set bail at $10 million.

title: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the latest quarter results included $95,000,000, or $1.65 a share in after-tax loss provisions in conjunction with the sales of the company's South Africa subsidiary and unused pipe held by the All American Pipeline subsidiary. The company also said the South African subsidiary sale resulted in a pretax loss of $43 million, or an after- tax loss of $52 million. Proceeds are expected to total $41 million when the sale is completed in the third quarter.

title: New Sex-Education Kit Aimed at Whole Family
description: In an era of AIDS and soaring teen-age pregnancy rates, the age of 4 is not too soon to start talking about sexual matters, say the developers of a new sex-education kit that includes a card game.

title: '94 World Cup Bars Standing
description: Soccer fans will not be allowed to stand to watch World Cup matches after 1992, international soccer's governing body said today.

Syringes Wash Up on Beaches Along Most of Jersey Shore
description: Syringes washed up Tuesday on beaches at Point Pleasant, Cape May Point, Middletown and Ocean City, officials said today.

description: There is a delicious irony to the Mets and their obsession with left-handed pitching, and it came back to haunt them last night in Shea Stadium when they lost for the second consecutive time to the Pittsburgh Pirates, 3-2.

description: * Christian Dior Fashion and Accessories, to Grey Advertising, Paris, for its international advertising, with an undisclosed budget.

title: U.S. Securities Little Changed
description: Prices of Treasury securities were little changed at the end of a choppy trading session yesterday, even though the Federal Reserve Board sent its clearest signal yet that it has eased credit conditions further.

title:
CURRENTS;
The 19th Century as It Was Lived
description: LEAD: DANTE GABRIEL ROSSETTI liked vibrant green walls for the sitting room of his London house. The Rothschild family preferred 18th-century boiserie purchased from the large Parisian houses that were demolished for Baron Georges Eugene Haussmann's boulevards.

title: Wm. Wrigley Jr.  Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Mixed Results Announced By 3 General Motors Units
description: The General Motors Corporation's Electronic Data Systems and GM Hughes Electronics subsidiaries today posted sharp increases in net income for the second quarter, while G.M.'s financing unit reported a nearly 20 percent drop in net income.

title: 4 More Arrested in Carl Schurz Park Attack
description: Four more suspects were arrested last night in connection with an assault on Sunday on two men in Carl Schurz Park near Gracie Mansion, the police said.

title: Review/Music; A Premiere About AIDS And Society
description: Anguish and anger have long been central components of Diamanda Galas's works for shreiking, caterwauling voice and electronic sound. But few works by Ms. Galas that this listener has encountered have been so directly and intensely focused as her ''Masque of the Red Death,'' a work about society's responses to AIDS.

title: Allegheny Ludlum Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
When One Big Gesture Is Worth 1,000 Trifles
description: SOMETHING is happening in sophisticated decorating circles. Although traditional rooms continue to be de rigueur - after all, they are what decorating with antiques is all about - the new look in traditional rooms is far from old-fashioned.

title: Business Digest
description: Economy

title: Amdahl's Net Is Off 37.9%
description: The Amdahl Corporation, a maker of mainframe computers, today reported a 37.9 percent drop in earnings for the second quarter. The company, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., had said late last month that it expected a decline in earnings.

title: Fuqua Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: After a loss from discontinued operations of $805,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $1,943,000 and $6,335,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Year-ago 6-month included an after- tax gain of $68.8 million from the combination of Fuqua's photo-finishing operation with that of Eastman Kodak Co. The company said results for its latest quarter and 6-month reflect the sale of Georgia Federal bank for $234.5 million in cash plus $7.5 million of dividends paid by Georgia Federal to Fuqua in 1989. The company also said that discontinued operations in 1989 reflect an adjustment to the reserve established in December 1988 for the estimated loss on the sale. Discontinued operations in 1988 included the operating results of Georgia Federal and Ajay Enterprises, which was sold in August 1988.

title: Jail Gun Smuggling Charged
description: A 39-year-old New York City correction officer was arrested yesterday and charged with attempting to smuggle a loaded derringer to an inmate at Rikers Island in return for a $7,500 bribe. The officer, identified as Bobby Goodwin of Brooklyn, was stopped as he arrived for work at the James A. Thomas Center, a jail for men, and was taken to the warden's office, said officials of the city's Correction and Investigation Departments. When a search revealed the derringer in his hip pocket, Mr. Goodwin was arrested and suspended from duty.

title: Jaruzelski Says Warsaw Pact Opposes a Solidarity Premier
description: President Wojciech Jaruzelski has told Solidarity that he cannot allow it to form a government because Poland's Communist neighbors ''would look at this askance,'' a Solidarity official who attended talks with him said today.

title: The New Gang in Town Confronts House Chiefs
description: First there was the Gang of 17, a bipartisan group of House members, Senators and officials of the Ronald Reagan Administration who brokered a deal on taxes and spending that got the 1982 budget through Congress.

title: In Hearings, I.R.S. Agents Tell Of Reprisals, Gifts and Nepotism
description: New complaints of misconduct within the Internal Revenue Service emerged today as I.R.S. agents described to Congress purported abuses that included nepotism, acceptance of gratuities, reprisals against whistle blowers and irregular use of Government travel funds.

title: Corrections
description: A report in About New York on July 15 about a day-care center for people with Alzheimer's disease misidentified the center. It is the JHMCB Center for Nursing and Rehabilitation, not the Jewish Hospital Medical Center, which has changed its name and is not affiliated with the day-care center.

title: No Headline
description: Calling the bureaucracy that runs the New York City schools unworkable, the New York State education commissioner said today that it should be dismantled and replaced by up to 60 autonomous school districts.

title: Income Declines by 44% at Bethlehem Steel
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation yesterday reported a 44 percent drop in earnings in the second quarter, a result of $50 million in charges for restructuring and reducing operations in one division, as well as higher costs.

title: Schloss Associates Gets Knogo Stake
description: Walter & Edwin Schloss Associates L.P., a New York-based limited investment partnership, has acquired a 5.1 percent stake in the Knogo Corporation. Knogo, based in Hauppauge, L.I., makes and distributes electronic surveillance systems used to detect shoplifting.

title: Corrections
description: A list published on Tuesday naming passengers on the United Airlines DC-10 that crashed on July 19 in Sioux City, Iowa, descirbed the fate of a passenger, George Orians of Boulder, Colo., incorrectly. Mr. Orians survived the crash but died later at a hospital

title: Results Plus
description: TENNIS Frana Eliminates Goldie: Javier Frana of Argentina added to Dan Goldie's hometown frustrations with a 6-3, 6-4 upset yesterday and Jay Berger advanced easily into the third round of the Sovran Bank Classic in Washington with a 6-2, 6-2 victory over Nduka Odizor. (AP) Mecir Upset: Goran Prpic of Yugoslavia beat Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia, 6-1, 6-3, yesterday in a second-round match in Stuttgart, West Germany. The match between top-seeded Jakob Hlasek of Switzerland and Jens Woehrmann of West Germany was halted by darkness with Hlasek leading, 6-4, 4-6, 3-1. (AP) HORSE SHOW U.S. Sweeps: Marie Meyers, riding Dimitrius, led an American sweep yesterday in dressage, the opening event of the Stockholm international show. Meyers received 1,273 points from the five judges and finished 2 points ahead of Robert Dover on Walzertak. Carol Lavell on Gifted was third. (AP)

title: Illinois Power Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The loss for the quarter included an expense of $2,820,000 related to its Clinton generating plant. The latest 6 months' loss reflected an after-tax writeoff of $346 million taken in the latest first quarter. The writeoff was taken in response to the Illinois Power Commission's March 30 order that disallowed costs related to construction of the Clinton power station.

title: JWP Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Legg Mason Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
John C. Murphy, Lawyer, 60
description: John C. Murphy, a lawyer and a vice president at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, died of pneumonia yesterday at Community Hospital in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. He was 60 years old and lived in Ardsley, N.Y.

title: Saint Laurent: A Master in Command
description: The audience rose to its feet in applause today as Yves Saint Laurent walked down the long runway of the Hotel Inter-Continental to the model wearing the last style shown of his fall collection, a bridal gown in autumnal colors. After he kissed her hand, the thunderous applause followed him all the way to the wings. He seemed to wipe away a tear, and when he reached backstage the models, fitters and support staff clapped, too. Everybody knew they had a hit on their hands.

title: Giants Rehearse With Understudy
description: Except for an occasional interlude on special teams or as a fill-in wide receiver, Jeff Hostetler has spent almost all of his five years with the Giants as a quarterback in waiting.

title: Washington Water Power Co reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: Included in 1989 results is the effect of a $4.7 million write-off related to final settlement of the company's Idaho WNP-3 investment.

title: Grossman's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Hertz Offering
description: The Hertz Corporation on Tuesday priced a $100 million offering of seven-year senior subordinated notes. The 9 1/8 percent notes, which may not be called for life, mature on Aug. 1, 1996. They were priced at $99.867, to yield 9.15 percent, 1.25 percentage points more than the prevailing yield on seven-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing. Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. acted as lead manager for the underwriting, which is rated Baa-1 by Moody's and BBB-minus by Standard & Poor's.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * American Express Information Services Co., a unit of American Express, named Robert F. Radin president of its shareholder services group.

title: Delmarva Power & Light Co reports earnings for 12mo June 30
Du Pont (E.I.) de Nemours & Co (N) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the latest quarter included a net charge of 17 cents a share from nonrecurring items. In the year-earlier quarter the company had a net nonrecurring gain of 30 cents a share.

title: Frances Sayers, 91; Wrote Books for Young
description: Frances Clarke Sayers, a librarian, teacher and author who specialized in children's literature, died after a stroke Monday at her home in Ojai, Calif. She was 91 years old.

title: Metropolitan Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $348,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: Honda Recalls Motorcycles
description: About 6,300 Honda CBR600F motorcycles from the current model year are being voluntarily recalled for safety reasons, the American Honda Motor Company said today. It said dealers, at no charge, would reroute a fuel pump tube that, under certain circumstances, might have caused a fire. The company said it had received no reports of fires or injuries resulting from the defect.

title: America's Stake in Gorbachev's Fate
description: Why aren't American political leaders and policy experts more concerned for Mikhail Gorbachev's fate?

title: Cincinnati Is Set on Edge by Report It Was Blanketed by Illegal Wiretaps
description: For more than a decade, Robert Draise and Leonard Gates say, the police and the telephone company paid them to blanket this city with a web of illegal wiretaps. They tapped judges and politicians, Black Muslims and mayors, lawyers and journalists, even a President of the United States.

title: Compaq Computer reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a $6 million gain. Share earnings are fully diluted. The company didn't disclose whether there was a gain included in the year-ago 6-month earnings.

title: Time to End U.S. Occupation of Puerto Rico; Still a Colony
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S.-Europe TV Hearings
description: Robert Maxwell, the British media executive, urged Congress today not to go to war with the European Economic Community over a proposal to limit the amount of United States programming shown on European television.

title: Castro Warns of U.S. Hopes To Exploit Soviet Bloc Woes
description: Fidel Castro charged tonight that the United States was trying to exploit difficulties in the Communist world and portrayed Cuba as a nation under siege.

title: Tambrands Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Music Festival to Open at Tanglewood
description: The annual Festival of Contemporary Music at Tanglewood is to open Saturday with a march from the opera ''Griffelkin'' by Lukas Foss, the Tanglewood Music Center's composer in residence.

title: Bo Jackson Sidelined
description: Bo Jackson, troubled since last month by a thigh injury, was placed on the 15-day disabled list by the Kansas City Royals yesterday.

title: Battle Over Teaching of Creation May Rumble Far From California
description: Some church groups have opened a campaign to require the teaching of the biblical account of creation in California's public school science classes alongside the theory of evolution.

title: For Digital Audio Tape, the Profits Will Be in Yen
description: When the next generation of home-recording technology, digital audio tape, makes its American debut next year, it will provide another example of the price the United States is paying for its retreat from the consumer electronics industry.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the New York Yankee farm team in Albany misidentified a pitcher shown about to deliver the ball. He was Rodney Imes.

title: Freeport McMoran Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said a quarter-to- quarter comparison isn't a fair representation of second-quarter performance, because the year-ago quarter benefited from the public sale of common shares in one of the company's affiliates and gains on property distributions to Freeport McMoran shareholders of stock in two other affiliates. The company also said the latest quarter earnings reflect a higher level of interest expense, primarily resulting from the increase in debt attributable to its purchase in May 1989 of 15,600,000 Freeport McMoran common shares under a Dutch auction tender offer.

title: Plan for Pastel Auto Tags Has Texans Seeing Red
description: Texans do not take kindly to being called friendly. Just ask the Texas Highway Commission.

title: Bank Deal Set in Chicago
description: An American subsidiary of the largest Dutch banking company said today that it had agreed to buy Chicago's sixth-largest banking concern for $420 million.

title: Brunswick Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said 1988 results included an after-tax gain of $10,600,000 from the sale of the filtration technology business and the writedown of certain assets.

title: A New Ontario Law Matches Women's Wages With Men's
description: Private employers in Canada's largest province are scrambling to comply with ground-breaking legislation requiring that the pay in jobs historically held by women match the pay for jobs of comparable skill that are usually done by men. In the public sector, the law has already produced substantial raises for women in secretarial and clerical jobs.

title: Nucor Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Murphy Oil Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $10.7 million from a United Kingdom tax settlement and sale of a crude oil tanker. c-Included the extraordinary gain of $10.7 million.

title: Freeport-McMoran Resource Partners L.P.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding represent units.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Josef Schreick has been named executive vice president and director of client services at Shaw & Landey.

title: Rebels Plan Next Hardship for Kabul: Winter Without Food Trucks
description: With food supplies from Pakistan blockaded by Muslim guerrillas for three weeks, the Soviet-backed Government in Kabul is confronting a new weapon to add to the rockets that have been pummeling the capital's morale.

title: Five-Year Notes From Philip Morris
description: The Philip Morris Companies yesterday offered $300 million worth of five-year notes through an underwriting syndicate led by Goldman, Sachs & Company and Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Pope Appoints Three Bishops To Posts in Czechoslovakia
description: Pope John Paul II appointed three bishops today to dioceses in Czechoslovakia, a sign that ties between the Vatican and the Eastern bloc continue to improve.

title: George Kupchik, 74, New York Engineer And Dean at Hunter
description: Dr. George Kupchik, an environmental engineer who retired as dean of the School of Health Sciences at Hunter College, died of lung cancer yesterday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Kaiser Permanente in Plan to Expand
description: Kaiser Permanente, the nation's largest health maintenance organization, will undertake a $3.6 billion expansion in Northern California in the next 10 years, officials said. The expansion, which would result in higher membership dues, would include significant renovations of hospitals in the San Francisco area.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Long Island Lighting Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income c-After a charge of $1,345,110,000 related to writeoffs of Shoreham and other nuclear plants. The company said the loss in the second quarter included its previously announced decision to discontinue the non-cash allowance for funds used during construction of Shoreham, which reduced net by about $100 million in each of the first two quarters of 1989. The net was also reduced by a $62 million after-tax charge recorded in June upon the effectiveness of the 1989 settlement with New York in which Lilco agreed to transfer Shoreham to the State of New York. Further, Lilco said the loss reflected a $113 million after-tax charge to income which is the estimated present value of the Rico class settlement.

title: Ipalco Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Armed Standoff on Mohawk Reservation
description: For six days, this Mohawk reservation has been sealed off to outsiders by the New York state police. Inside, the self-styled Mohawk Sovereignty Security Force, rifles in hand, has enforced a crude form of law and order.

From Mongrelized to Purebred Classic
description: LEAD: EVEN in that part of the Upper East Side that is now a landmark district, a number of fine older buildings had lost much of their character at street level through storefront modernization.

title: Police Search Halts Lexington Ave. Subway
description: Service on the Lexington Avenue IRT was interrupted twice in 25 minutes yesterday while the police searched for suspects they believed had fled onto the tracks at the 77th Street station, officials said.

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss) *Loss in year-earlier period.

title: Jets' Frase Doesn't Mind Competing With Rookie
description: When you're the starter and the team goes out and makes a first-round or second-round draft choice to play your position, you have grounds for feeling bad. But it was neither a surprise nor an affront to Paul Frase that the Jets made Dennis Byrd the 42d player chosen over all and the 5th defensive lineman taken, then signed the 6-foot-5-inch, 270-pound rookie defensive end out of Tulsa to a three-year contract Tuesday.

title: 9.9% Stake In Cummins
description: Only one week after the founding family of the Cummins Engine Company acted to remove the threat of a foreign takeover, another foreign company has disclosed that it holds a large stake in the diesel engine manufacturer.

title: Mayoral Contenders Bare Fangs in Their First Debate
description: In the first formal debate in the mayoral campaign, the incumbent, Edward I. Koch, faced persistent assertions yesterday that his administration had ''run out of gas'' and was ill prepared to face the future.

title: Loral Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $707,000 for the latest first quarter and $7,445,000 for year- ago period.

title: Korea Trade Surplus
description: South Korea's trade surplus fell dramatically in the first half of 1989, according to central bank figures released today. The surplus dwindled to $2 billion, less than half the $4.5 billion recorded in the 1988 period.

title: Jacobs Engineering reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GM Hughes Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a gain equal to 5 cents a share from the partial sale of stock in Nippon Avionics Co. Ltd. c-Included income of $18.7 million from an accounting change. d-Included a gain of $68.3 million, or 18 cents a share, from the sale of stock in Nippon Avionics Co. Ltd.

title: Release of Quinones Explained by Leyland
description: Jim Leyland explained the unusual development succinctly. ''I thought we were getting someone who wasn't the best of guys but had talent,'' the Pittsburgh manager said. ''We got a guy who was a good guy but didn't show talent.''

title: Just Who Was Our Envoy to Vienna?
description: The old question ''who's minding the store?'' -in this case, the U.S.

title: COMPANY BRIEFSHDL
description: * Aetna Life Insurance Co., Hartford, is part of a group that has reached agreement to acquire Greater San Diego Health Plan, a health maintenance organization subsidiary of Western Health Plans Inc. of San Diego, for an undisclosed amount. The venture group also includes Partners National Health Plans and seven San Diego-area hospital systems.

title: Corroon & Black reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a non-recurring gain of $73,851,000 from the sale of the company's investment in Minet Holdings Plc.

title: Long Child Molestation Trial Viewed as System Run Amok
description: Two years and three months after it began, the celebrated McMartin preschool child molesting case is teetering on the brink of mistrial with only one of six alternate jurors left - to many, a glistening example of the legal system run amok.

title: Rostenkowski Renews Effort for a Deal on Capital Gains
description: Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, renewed his efforts today to strike a deal with the Bush Administration that would avoid a confrontation in his committee and on the House floor over reducing capital gains taxes.

title: 3 Indicted in Sales of Bogus Orange Juice
description: A Federal grand jury indicted three former owners of a Chicago-based food company on Tuesday for what was described as a scheme to sell phony frozen orange juice from 1978 to 1985.

title: Gay Couples Should Accept Legal Burdens of a Signed Contract
description: To the Editor:

title: Plymouth Journal; On Tiny Isle of 300 Banks, Enter Scotland Yard
description: It is a little after four o'clock on a weekday afternoon and the clapboard and stone shops and offices in this little waterfront village are already closed. Except for a couple of stray roosters, the streets are empty.

title: I.B.M. Sets Software Stake
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire a minority equity interest in the Policy Management Systems Corporation, a provider of applications software and related services for insurance companies.

title: 'They Let Him Clown Around'
description: rrIn trying to explain why he waved a glove at the referee and mumbled, ''No mas, no mas,'' Roberto Duran's excuse was that he had ''stomach cramps'' from having eaten too much and too quickly after the weigh-in. Because of his reputation and his 72-1 record before that welterweight championship fight with Sugar Ray Leonard on Nov. 25, 1980, the Panamanian deserved to be believed. But not many people believed him. The popular theory was that Duran, who had outpointed Leonard to win the title five months earlier in Montreal, abdicated in annoyance and frustration at Leonard's taunting tactics. Sticking his chin out. Winding up as if to throw a bolo punch, but flicking a quick jab, then throwing the bolo.

title: Hannaford Bros Co reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: b-Included a credit of $1,874,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Compaq Income Rises 42.4% But Wall St. Expected More
description: Continuing its pattern of rapid growth, the Compaq Computer Corporation, a leading personal computer manufacturer, today reported a 42.4 percent rise in second-quarter earnings on a 58 percent gain in revenues.

title: Late Rally Lifts Dow 29.97 Points
description: The stock market surged in late trading yesterday on renewed hopes that the Federal Reserve is again easing credit. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and the New York Stock Exchange composite average reached new peaks, closing above the records they had set in 1987.

title: Ironsmith Follows Roundabout Path To Ancient Craft
description: Roland C. Greefkes spent most of his life fleeing the family business. Now, at the age of 48, he is following in his father's footsteps, even down to wearing wooden shoes.

title: Time to End U.S. Occupation of Puerto Rico; Statehood Is Dignity
description: To the Editor:
