Gerber Products Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago first quarter results are restated to include revenue and earnings from insurance operations. The company said the earnings increase came from the Gerber Products division, where operating profit rose 49.2 percent to $43,428,000, while sales rose 16.3 percent.

title: Southwest Airlines Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Reservations Expressed About Mexico Debt Accord
description: The Mexican debt accord that was announced late Sunday is getting very mixed reviews, depending on the source of the commentary.

title: Ryland Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Campaign Matters; Gloom Contest: Candidates Strive For Grim Picture
description: Halfway through yesterday's Democratic mayoral debate, a questioner noted the huge sums that New York City must spend on AIDS treatment, jail cells, correction and police officers and the homeless in what he said might be described as a ''budget of despair.'' Why, he wondered, would anyone want to live here?

title: Redus on Disabled List
description: Although X-rays and a brain scan revealed that Gary Redus suffered no fractures and his vision was not affected when he was struck just below the left eye by a 90-miles-an-hour fastball from Tim Crews of the Los Angeles Dodgers on Monday night, the first baseman for the Pittsburgh Pirates was put on the 15-day disabled list yesterday, retroactive to Tuesday. Redus was released from Allegheny General Hospital in Pittsburgh on Tuesday, but did not accompany his teammates to New York for their series against the Mets. Redus is batting .280 with 3 home runs and 18 runs batted in.(AP)

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: FEW things in nature as common as a powerful thunderstorm are as awe-inspiring. Yet even today, lightning, actually a giant spark, remains mysterious. Scientists still do not know precisely what causes it.

title: American Express Net Increases 16.2%
description: Buoyed by strong results in its financial services and travel-related operations, the American Express Company reported yesterday that its second-quarter earnings rose 16.2 percent as revenues advanced 26.4 percent.

title: Shell Oil reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago 6-month results included a gain of $35 million from an accounting change.

title: Norfolk Southern Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an after-tax gain of $13.6 million from the sale in April of half of the company's holdings in Trailer Train Co. to Conrail.

title: A Promising Pledge on Steel
description: The best line in President Bush's declaration on steel import quotas is that these damaging arrangements ''will end on March 31, 1992.'' It's too bad he wants to renew the quotas at all. It's good that he pledges to let them expire within his term as President. But the steel industry's unhappiness with his clear commitment means that he'll have to stand tough to honor it.

title: Review/Pop; Where Rock, Jazz and Blues Had a Hand in the Sound
description: Rosie Flores's show at the Lone Star Roadhouse on Monday night picked up about halfway through. The sound system, painfully loud for the first half, calmed down, and Ms. Flores and her band found their distance in a series of uptempo tunes that let them to loosen up.

title: Amdahl Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: 1988 results are restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in the third quarter of 1988 and the acquisition of Key Computer Laboratories Inc. in February 1989. The acquisition was accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: So You Think It's Hot Above Ground
description: In apartment buildings overlooking Central Park, tenants turned up their air-conditioners in the morning and turned them up some more by midday. On Canal Street, sweat-soaked salesmen declared that they were tired of pounding the pavement and called it a day before noon. On Astor Place, overheated tourists dug out change for ice cream. And people who don't go to the movies much wondered if there were still lines for ''Batman'' - and if one theater was any cooler than another.

title: State Takeover Upheld For Jersey City Schools
description: An administrative-law judge today approved New Jersey's plan for a state takeover of Jersey City's public schools for at least five years because of ''deep-rooted and endemic'' problems, including poor educational quality, political patronage and fiscal mismanagement.

title: CLOSE TO HOME
description: IT was a clean, well-lighted room, with a television set mounted on the wall, and an electric kettle should I need a cup of tea. But a Melbourne winter was sweeping in under the door, and the small heater warmed nothing more than a patch of rug. The mattress was lumpy, too. No matter. I loved that room, I will always love that room, because it was for me what hotel rooms always are: the best of all reading rooms.

title: MacLean Hunter reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: White Supremacists Charged
description: Seven members of a white supremacist group in Dallas, including four juveniles, have been charged with violence and vandalism the Justice Department said today. The targets of the violence were blacks, Jews and Hispanic people. The seven are members of the Confederate Hammerskins, a group that is a part of the skinhead movement.

title: Elderly Woman Killed and 37 Hurt as Casino-Bound Bus Overturns
description: A 76-year-old woman was killed and 37 other people were injured yesterday when a bus bound for an Atlantic City casino rolled over on the Garden State Parkway, the police said.

title: Du Pont Posts 11.7% Gain
description: Bolstered by strong sales of petroleum and chemicals for industrial applications, the Du Pont Company said yesterday that its second-quarter net income increased 11.7 percent.

title: Action Is Condemned By Artists and Institutions
description: Many leaders of arts institutions, and artists themselves, reacted strongly to the Senate vote to bar Federal support for certain types of art. They almost universally condemned the legislators' action as an abridgement of artists' freedom of expression.

title: Peter Dvarackas, Writer, 42
description: Peter Dvarackas, a writer and editor who was one of the early publicists dealing with AIDS, died of the disease on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 42 years old. Mr. Dvarackas, who contracted AIDS eight years ago, wrote a column dealing with holistic and natural remedies for People With Aids Newsline, a newsletter.

title: Bush Signs Bill Ending Gas Controls
description: President Bush today signed a law removing the last price controls on natural gas and then pledged to develop a comprehensive strategy for enhancing the nation's energy security.

title: More Autonomy for Baltics Stirs Discomfort in Moscow
description: A plan to give two Soviet Baltic republics broad economic freedom produced a startling public clash today between two Deputy Prime Ministers, indicating deep divisions within the Government over the future of the economy.

title: Ferro Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said share earnings for the latest second quarter is after payment of dividends on preferred shares issued in April 1989.

title: For Children, You Can't Fake It
description: When actors start telling stories about performing for children, a theme emerges: Don't underestimate the audience. ''I've learned that you absolutely can't act down to children,'' Peter Schmitz said. ''You have to be honest - or you lose them.''

title: Merger Backed At SmithKline
description: Shareholders of the SmithKline Beckman Corporation today approved the company's merger with Britain's Beecham Group P.L.C. The new company, Smith=

title: Computerized Design Plan Is Introduced by Chrysler
description: The Chrysler Corporation introduced a new computerized design system today that it said could greatly speed the development of cars from an artist's conception to a vehicle ready for mass production, cutting lead times by up to 30 percent.

title: Town Hall's Fall Season
description: David Byrne is to give a concert of ethnic music at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street, on Sept. 22 to open the 1989-90 season, which will run through April 17. Among the programs scheduled are the Max Roach-Cecil Taylor 10-year reunion; a lecture series on Shostakovich and performances of his complete string quartets; love poems, jazz and pop by Najma, an Indian musician; piano recitals by Ursula Oppens and Robert Helps; an appearance by the Brazilian guitarist and pianist Egberto Gismonti; a jazz series, and a concert by the flutists Robert Dick, Paula Robison, Ransom Wilson and Carol Wincenc with the New York Chamber Orchestra. Information: 840-2824.

title: Canadian Occidental Petroeum Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included gains of $1.3 million and $4.6 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title:
CURRENTS;
Lamps: Function And Form
description: LEAD: ART for art's sake may be all right for some artists. But now quite a few seem obsessed with making something useful, as the Gallery of Functional Art in Santa Monica, Calif., has demonstrated.

title: Robert Laufer, 47, Student of Combat Stress
description: Dr. Robert S. Laufer, a sociologist whose studies of the effects of combat and of captivity led to the development of counseling programs for veterans of the Vietnam War, died of leukemia Tuesday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 47 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: Steve Rubell, Studio 54's Creator And a'Pasha of Disco,' Dies at 45
description: Steve Rubell, the flamboyant co-founder of the Studio 54 discotheque who rebounded from a tax-evasion conviction to operate trendy Manhattan hotels, died Tuesday night at the Beth Israel Medical Center. He was 45 years old and lived in Manhattan and Southampton, L.I.

title: A Ukrainian Steel Town Takes Care of Its Own
description: The scarcity of food and housing among workers in this major steel-making center has driven Soviet factory executives to desperate measures worthy of Noah's efforts on his ark.

title: Exxon to Put Up $20 Million To Get Tanker to Dry Dock
description: The Exxon Shipping Company agreed Tuesday to post $20 million and meet other requirements to get its damaged tanker Exxon Valdez into dry dock for repairs.

title: CRACK USE STARTS IN FEARFUL EUROPE
description: Crack, unknown on this side of the Atlantic until recently, has begun to turn up in Western Europe, where the authorities are trying to avoid what they regard as American mistakes in failing to keep the problem from exploding into epidemic proportions.

title: L.I. Murder Suspect Released by Mistake Is Seized in Brooklyn
description: A man who was charged with murder but released because the police mixed him up with a traffic violator was recaptured today after 10 months on the run, the Suffolk County police said.

title: EG&G Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
Advisers Look at Assets Of Time and Warner
description: When investment bankers assessed the value of Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc. in preparation for their proposed mergers, they valued Time's assets as high as $14.1 billion to $16.6 billion and Warner's at about $13.5 billion.

title: 2 Student Leaders in U.S.
description: Two leaders of the Chinese democracy movement who escaped to France last month arrived in the United States yesterday, and they are to announce the formation of a new opposition movement at a conference in Chicago this weekend.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Ways to Grab Moviegoer's Attention
description: FOR all the creativity that goes into making movies, advertising for feature films has never been particularly innovative. For the most part, it has always been brief film clips or excerpts from reviews.

title: Bethlehem Steel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a charge of $50 million for restructuring and downsizing of the company's Beth Forge division for both the quarter and 6 months, and the 6-month also included $55 million in charges in the first quarter from the restructuring of the company's Baltimore Marine division. c-Included gains of $7.6 million and $18 million from repurchases of debt for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, the quarter included a charge of $9 million from the disposal of certain equipment, and the 6 months included $28 million in charges for damages and costs resulting from a coal mine fire, adjustment in certain employee benefit liabilities and a loss on disposal of equipment.

title: Student, After Delay, Is Charged In Crippling of Computer Network
description: After more than eight months, the Justice Department said yesterday that a Federal grand jury in Syracuse had indicted the 24-year-old Cornell University graduate student who has been blamed for crippling a nationwide computer network with a rogue software program.

title: Personal Health
description: The nation's soaring rate of Caesarean deliveries is coming under increasing scrutiny as researchers report that perhaps half these procedures needlessly risk the mother's life or health without benefit to the baby.

title: Work on AIDS Drugs Seen as Still Too Slow
description: The number of drugs and vaccines being developed to combat the AIDS virus has almost doubled in the past two years, but better efforts are needed to get more infected people into treatment trials and to speed drug approval, AIDS specialists said today.

title:
CURRENTS;
A Vignelli Exhibition In Russia
description: LEAD: VIGNELLI ASSOCIATES has always had a thing about the color red. Not magenta, not fuchsia, but fire-engine red. It shows up in many of the firm's crisp, elegant designs for books, magazines, interiors and products.

title: Sampling Glassware of the Presidents
description: IN 1826, after only one year in office, President John Quincy Adams asked for more money for household purchases, many of them foreign-made. A disgruntled Congress responded by passing a law specifying that all White House furnishings be, ''as practicable,'' made in the United States. Since that time, First Families have ordered their official glassware from American manufacturers.

title: Going From Strength to Strength
description: When Karyn Marshall began lifting weights in 1977, her intention was not to become a pioneer in a male-dominated sport. She played field hockey, volleyball and softball as a teen-ager growing up in Pelham, N.Y., and weight lifting seemed to be a challenging alternative. She was also intrigued by strongmen.

title: Yield Drop Continues
description: Yields on money market mutual funds continued to decline in the week that ended yesterday, again following the general trend in interest rates.

title: Deals
description: Baseball

title: Klansman Agrees to Re-education On Races, but Not to Believing It
description: A Ku Klux Klan leader says that he agreed to attend a race relations course as a way of avoiding the costs of a continuing lawsuit and that the classroom sessions will not change his attitude toward blacks.

title: Why Stealth Makes Sense
description: LEAD: The Congressional debate over the B-2 Stealth bomber now moves to a new phase.

title: Texaco Is Down 21.1%; Others Gain
description: Texaco Inc. reported yesterday that its second-quarter earnings declined 21.1 percent, to $366 million, or $1.39 a share, from $464 million, or $1.91 a share, a year earlier.

title: Film Concern Is Being Sold
description: Management Company Entertainment Group Inc., an independent film producer, said Tuesday that it plans to buy the London-based film distributor Virgin Vision Ltd. for $83 million.

title: Terrell Makes Debut; Yanks End 9-Game Trip With 8th Loss
description: The last picture of the trip seemed so appropriate. Lee Guetterman sat alone on the bench, staring into the night, his look fixed on a field where the Yankees had let one slip away. Their mistakes had overtaken their heroics, and they were going home with another loss and another day gone in their season.

title: Hewlett-Packard, Hitachi in Venture
description: Confirming earlier reports, the Hewlett-Packard Company and Hitachi Ltd. said they would jointly develop a new, higher-speed chip set based on Hewlett-Packard's reduced instruction set computing, or RISC, technology and Hitachi's advanced semiconductor and circuit-design technology. It is the first time Hewlett-Packard has licensed its RISC technology to another company.

title: Panhandle Eastern reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Included in results are gains and other special items totaling $6,465,000 and $64,290,000 for the latest and year- ago 6-month periods, respectively. Included in the 1989-period results are the operations of recently-acquired Texas Eastern Corp. from April 27. The company said its earnings were negatively affected by interest expense incurred on the acquisition debt.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Ketchum Office Gets Ross Stores Account n
description: Ketchum Advertising's San Francisco office yesterday won the $8 million to $10 million ad account for Ross Stores Inc., three months after the clothing store chain pulled its business from Chiat/Day/Mojo. Ketchum prevailed over five other agencies in the review.

title: Shoe-Town's Chief Retiring Over Health
description: Shoe-Town Inc., a chain of 250 shoe stores in the East, said yesterday that George M. Kaye, its chief executive was retiring because of health problems and would be succeeded by Edward D. Solomon.

title: INSIDE
description: Crack Use Starts in Europe Crack has begun to turn up in Western Europe, where the authorities are trying to avoid what they regard as American mistakes in failing to keep the drug from spreading. Page A7. Soviet Steel Town Has Hope Factory executives in a Ukrainian steel town have taken measures to head off the sort of despair that led to the coal miners' strike. Page A10. Mastercard and Visa Sued Joined by 11 other states, New York accused Visa and Mastercard of violating antitrust laws by preventing the introduction of debit cards that could hurt their business. Page D1. Compromise on Savings Bill House and Senate conferees reached several compromises on disputes that have delayed the Administration's savings rescue plan. Page D1.

title: Time to End U.S. Occupation of Puerto Rico
description: To the Editor:

title: Robinson's Departure Gets Team's Blessings
description: Larry Robinson will leave for the Los Angeles Kings with the best wishes of the Canadiens, General Manager Serge Savard of Montreal said yesterday.

title: Simmons in Filing On Georgia Gulf
description: An investment group led by the Dallas corporate raider Harold C. Simmons filed for permission from Federal antitrust regulators to raise its stake in the Georgia Gulf Corporation to 15 percent, from 9.4 percent. The share price of Georgia Gulf, a chemical maker based in Atlanta, rose 37.5 cents, to $39, on the New York Stock Exchange, giving the company a current market value of $955 million. A spokesman for Georgia Gulf said the company would have no comment on the filing.

title: Query in Jet Crash: Scrap Parts?
description: The chairman of a House committee asked the Federal Aviation Administration yesterday to determine whether any engine parts bought from an Air Force scrap yard were used on the United Airlines jet that crashed last week.

title: Progress On Savings Rescue Plan
description: Breaking a weeklong stalemate, House and Senate conferees agreed to compromises today on several critical elements of the Bush Administration's savings industry rescue plan.

title: White House
description: Not since Thomas Jefferson wrote some 5,000 letters in his time in office has there been such a Presidential pen pal.

title: The New York City Election, 1989; CAMPAIGN OBSERVATIONS; Four Democrats on Display
description: Not even Jackie Mason could make light of it. Standing there in front of the TV camera, the comedian groped for something pithy to say about the first debate of the Democratic candidates for mayor of New York. But he failed, as did most other observers, hangers-on, consultants and journalists who came to a Park Avenue auditorium yesterday to watch Harrison Goldin, Richard Ravitch, David Dinkins and Edward Koch.

title: No Drug Trace Found In the Wayward Pilot
description: No trace of alcohol or drugs was found in blood samples taken from the pilot who survived an unexplained shooting and a plane crash in the Bahamas, Federal investigators said today.

title: Trading Ban Put on Drexel Figure
description: Cary J. Maultasch, one of the principal figures in the investigation of Michael R. Milken and Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., has been banned from the securities industry for life, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced Tuesday.

title: Emil White, a Painter And Writer, Dies at 88
description: Emil White, a writer, a publisher and an artist who was known for his paintings of the Big Sur coast of California, died last Thursday at his home here. He was 88 years old.

title: Poll Finds G.O.P. Still Enjoys Its Prosperity Image
description: Republicans continue to be viewed by the American public as the party better for peace and prosperity, while Democrats maintain a small and somewhat reduced advantage in terms of party affiliation, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: Leonard and Duran in Rematch in November
description: ''Uno mas'' - one more.

title: Ferris to Seek Brooklyn Borough Presidency
description: At an outdoor news conference similar to one he held four years ago, Joseph Ferris, a 54-year-old former Assemblyman, formally announced yesterday that he was trying to become the Democratic candidate for borough president of Brooklyn, once again challenging Howard Golden, the incumbent.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions of Business Day yesterday about papers filed in the Delaware courts in a suit by Paramount Communications Inc. to block a merger of Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc. misidentified the source of documents provided to The New York Times.

title: Louis A. Siegel, 75, Lawyer and Executive
description: Louis A. Siegel, a corporate lawyer and business executive, died of congenital heart disease Tuesday at Berkshire Medical Center in Pittsfield, Mass. He was 75 years old and had homes in Manhattan and Stockbridge, Mass.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Doner Will Do Ads For Vax Appliances
description: Vax Appliances Inc., the American subsidiary of the British home appliance manufacturer, yesterday awarded its advertising business to W.B. Doner.

title: H. H. Robertson reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and included a $6,103,000 loss from discontinued operations. c-Net income and included $52,588,000 in income from discontinued operations. Year-ago six-month results included a reorganization charge of $21,800,000. Latest quarter and six-month results included revenue from the profitable Star Manufacturing unit purchased by the company last August.

title: Review/Television; Inside View of a Game Show And a Debutantes' Cotillion
description: ''P.O.V.,'' as the PBS series of that title reminds us each week, is movie-maker shorthand for point of view. Yet the young makers of ''Wise Guys!'' and ''Coming Out,'' the two documentaries on Channel 13 at 9 P.M., show considerable restraint in kidding their respective subjects, a game show and a debutante ball, which seem to have been created to be kidded. The result is a lively, occasionally sharp 90 minutes.

title: Imasco Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds. The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: Mets Talking to Twins About Viola
description: The Mets acknowledged last night that they have been talking to the Minnesota Twins about a trade for Frank Viola, the left-handed pitching star from St. John's University and the winner of the Cy Young Award in the American League last year.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Jordan Gets A Hasbro Job
description: After a three-month search, Hasbro Inc. assigned the advertising for its girls' toys and Milton Bradley divisions to Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor.

title: Lydall Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,661,000 for the quarter and $2,581,000 for the 6 months. Year-ago 6 months' net is less than 1 cent a share after preferred dividend requirements.

title: Broken Hill Steel Swap
description: The Broken Hill Proprietary Company of Australia plans to put its $50 million steel trade with Iran on a barter basis - swapping steel for Iranian crude oil. BHP Trading Services's special projects manager, Murray Jackson, said BHP had sold steel to Iran for about 10 years. About 200,000 tons of steel a year, worth up to $50 million, are traded now. BHP had offered Iran delayed payment terms on the steel. Mr. Jackson said barter would bring cash for the steel earlier and allow Iran to preserve its foreign exchange.

title: I.B.M. Postpones Disk Drive Introduction
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that technical problems had forced it to delay the introduction of a disk drive designed for its most powerful mainframe computers.

title: General Motors Acceptance Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The lastest second quarter included the results of financing, insurance adn mortgage operations.

title: Becker Drops Out
description: Boris Becker, the Wimbledon champion, has dropped out of the Volvo International tournament in Stratton Mountain, Vt., because of an unspecified injury. The tournament is scheduled to begin Monday.

title: Occidental Petroleum Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results included extraordinary losses of $4,000,000, or 2 cents a share, and $10,000,000, or 5 cents a share, from the early extinguishment of debt for the latest second-quarter and year-ago second quarter, respectively.

title: Mastercard and Visa Sued Over Debit Cards
description: New York, joined by 11 other states, filed suit in Federal court in Manhattan today charging Visa and Mastercard with violating antitrust laws by preventing the introduction of debit cards that could hurt the profits of their credit card business.

title: Southern Co reports earnings for Year to June 30
Key Senator Supports Lucas for Rights Post
description: William C. Lucas won over a crucial senator today in his drive to head the Justice Department's civil rights division.

title: Banks Receive Fed Backing
description: The Federal Reserve Board yesterday approved applications from three more bank holding companies to allow their securities subsidiaries to trade and underwrite corporate and asset-backed debt securities.

title: The Right Shade for the Right Lamp
description: ''I DESIGN every shade that goes out,'' said Ruth Vitow, the grande dame of the custom lamp-shade business in New York City. For 45 years, Ms. Vitow has supplied handmade lamp shades to many of New York's prominent interior designers, including Dorothy Draper and Robert Metzger.

title: KEY RATES
U.S. Allows Wider Use of Drug for Infants
description: The Food and Drug Administration authorized wider use of an experimental drug today for treating a breathing disorder that causes disability and death for thousands of premature infants each year.

title: Calendar: Gardening Classes
description: Growing it Right, Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue off Eastern Parkway, Prospect Heights; 718-622-4433 or 622-4544.

title: Midlantic Offers $100 Million Issue
description: The Midlantic Corporation, a New Jersey bank holding company, has offered $100 million worth of 12-year subordinated capital notes. The 9.20 percent notes, which mature on Aug. 1, 2001, were priced at $100, or par, 1.20 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the 9 1/8 percent Treasury notes at the time of pricing.

title: U.S.-Soviet Team Tells of Chernobyl Effort
description: American and Soviet physicians who treated radiation victims at Chernobyl have published a joint report on their efforts in Thursday's issue of the New England Journal of Medicine.

title: Lender Under Scrutiny Over Mortgages
description: A Knoxville, Tenn., mortgage lender has become the second company to come under scrutiny in a criminal investigation of inflated mortgages backed by a troubled Federal housing program.

title: Furniture Lost in Fire Is to Be Replaced
description: The Princeton, N.J., home of Dr. Arthur and Evelyn Krosnick, which was destroyed by fire May 23 along with one of the largest private collections of furniture by the furniture craftsman George Nakashima, is being rebuilt.

title: High Rate of Caesareans Among Affluent
description: Affluent women giving birth are 73 percent more likely than poor women to have their babies by Caesarean section, a new study shows.

title: American Express Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $12 million and $32 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The company said the $12 million in the year-ago quarter represented the company's share of the earnings of Fireman's Fund Corp., which is now being treated as a discontinued operation. Results for the quarter and 6 months ended June 30 reflect new Financial Accounting Standards Board rules relating to accounting for certain long-duration life insurance and annuity products. Revenues adn expenses for 1988 have been restated for comparative purposes.

title: Position of President In Filled by Dyansen
description: The Dyansen Corporation, which operates 13 art galleries and plans to open more, said yesterday that it had named Stephen B. Byer president and chief operating officer.

title: Space for Trash: a New Design Frontier
description: AS voluntary and mandatory recycling takes hold around the nation, homeowners are confronting thorny design problems in their attempts to integrate recycling into their houses. Mostly without the aid of architects, builders, appliance manufacturers or professional kitchen designers, they are coming up with solutions, some makeshift and primitive, some handsome and ingenious.

title: Chicago Journal; White Priest Embraces Blacks' Spiritual Roots
description: Every Sunday morning, the Rev.

title: Bridge
description: The Summer Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League will begin tomorrow in Chicago and continue for 10 days. A curtain raiser tomorrow evening will be the International Fund Game, played throughout North America as well as in Chicago.

title: Juanita H. Miner, Corrections Official, 57
description: Juanita H. Miner, who worked for the New York City Department of Correction for 24 years, mostly in supervisory positions on Rikers Island, died after a stroke Saturday at the Berkshire Medical Center In Pittsfield, Mass. She was 57 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title: MANAGUA REPORTS A RISE IN ATTACKS
description: The military post that guards this hamlet, about 70 miles east of Managua, consists of a few pup tents on a grassy hilltop, manned by local reservists.

title: Next Digital Tape Hurdle: Buyers
description: Digital audio tape recorders have been kept off the market for two years by a copyright dispute between record companies and stereo equipment manufacturers. With that dispute apparently resolved, the new product faces what could be an even more daunting barrier: consumer acceptance.

title: Pepsico Profits Rise 20.6%
description: Pepsico Inc. said yesterday that its earnings rose 20.6 percent in the second quarter, to $264.9 million, or $1 a share, from $219.6 million, or 84 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: Senate Votes to Bar U.S. Support Of 'Obscene or Indecent' Artwork
description: Brushing aside objections that Congress should not be deciding what is art or who is an artist, the Senate voted today to bar the National Endowment for the Arts from supporting ''obscene or indecent'' work and to cut off Federal funds to two arts groups because they supported exhibitions of work by two provocative photographers.

title: HOUSE BACKS CUT IN BOMBER PROJECT OF $1 BILLION IN '90
description: The House of Representatives voted 257 to 160 today to make deep cuts in the budget for the Stealth bomber and to halt production of the radar-evading plane until the Air Force scales back the $70 billion program.

title: Beneficial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Market Place; Partial Stock Split Worries S.E.C.
description: IT was one of the more dramatic stock moves of 1989. The Lifeline Healthcare Group, a home health care company, saw its stock rise from below $4 a share to above $30, then fall back to $15.

title: Everything That's Right About the National Debt
description: The Debt and the Deficit False Alarms/Real Possibilities By Robert Heilbroner and Peter Bernstein Illustrated with tables. 144 pages. W. W. Norton.

title: Dr. Samuel Stone, 76, Pediatric Specialist
description: Dr. Samuel Stone, a pediatrician in Manhattan for more than half a century, died of complications of intestinal surgery yesterday at New York University Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 76 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Northern States Power Co reports earnings for 12mo June 30
Jorgensen (Earle M.) Co(N) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest quarter and 6 months' nets included a gain of $4,562,000, or 72 cents a share, on the sale of excess land and buildings. Year-ago periods' nets included a loss of $1.6 million from discontinued operations.

title: It's 1-2-3 Go For Lotus
description: Finishing its design work ahead of most analysts' expectations, the Lotus Development Corporation said it would begin shipments today of the latest enhanced version of its popular computer spreadsheet software.

title: First Capital Holdings reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Microsoft Case Ruling
description: Confirming his tentative ruling on last Friday, United States District Judge William W. Schwarzer ruled on Tuesday that nearly all of the visual displays used in the Microsoft Corporation's Windows 2.03 program and the Hewlett-Packard Company's New Wave program were covered by Microsoft's 1985 license agreement with Apple Computer Inc.

title: A Chinese Newspaper Reports Over 3,000 Arrests
description: A Nanjing newspaper reported today that more than 3,000 people, including a student leader, had been arrested in connection with ''counterrevolutionary'' unrest in a three-day sweep in Jiangsu province.

title: Blues Are the Target As Fish Contests Start
description: This is the seventh year that WICC, a radio station in Bridgeport, Conn., will conduct what it calls the Greatest Bluefish Contest on Earth. A guaranteed minimum of $30,000 in cash prizes will be awarded in the tournament, which will be held Aug. 19-20. The angler catching the heaviest blue will win $10,000. Second prize is $5,000; third prize $3,000. Those who place 4th through 15th will receive $1,000 each.

title: Kirov Dancer Seeks Asylum
description: Mikhail Gaidamakin, a 34-year-old dancer in the Kirov Ballet company, has asked for asylum in the United States. Mr. Gaidamakin came here from the Soviet Union with 20 extra members of the Kirov corps de ballet to appear this month at the Metropolitan Opera House in three performances of the ballet ''Battleship 'Potemkin.' '' He did not return to Leningrad with that group on July 22.

title: Review/Music; Frank Corsaro's Staging Of 'Carmen,' at City Opera
description: Directors' opera - the postwar phenomenon of letting a stage director define the basic interpretation of an opera and, when he feels like it, play havoc with the story - has done a lot of harm. Under carefully controlled festival conditions, with close and continuous supervision by a truly gifted director, it can produce worthy and even marvelous results. But married to the bad habits of routine repertory opera it is worse than the tiredest old ''traditional'' productions.

title: For Silklike Wood, Linseed Oil
description: LEAD: In Europe in the Age of Oak - from the beginning of the 16th century to the middle of the 17th - furniture finishes were limited to vegetable oils and waxes.

title: Museums in Need Warn Thatcher of Art Damage
description: Curators have warned that Britain's five major national museums and galleries are deteriorating and that great works of art could be seriously damaged unless the Government helps with large amounts of money.

title: Review/Ballet; From London, a Poetic 'Romeo' That Makes Others Seem Prosy
description: Not for nothing was Sir Frederick Ashton, England's greatest choreographer, called the Shakespeare of ballet. To see his ''Romeo and Juliet,'' at Tuesday night's triumphant opening of the London Festival Ballet, was to be swept along, swiftly and simply, to heights of poetic inspiration.

title: British Trade Deficit Up
description: Britain's merchandise trade deficit widened to $3.1 billion in June as growth in the amount of imports exceeded that of exports, the Government said today. The seasonally adjusted deficit compared with a shortfall in May of $2.8 billion, the Department of Trade and Industry said. The current account deficit widened to $2.4 billion from $2.2 billion.

title: Pepsico Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 17
description: Latest second-quarter results included a pre-tax net credit of $22.2 million ($15.0 million after-tax, or 6 cents a share) for unusual items consisting of a soft drinks credit of $32.5 million resulting from a decision to retain a foreign bottling operation previously held for sale, a domestic snack foods reorganization charge of $6.6 million and a credit of $4.3 million resulting from a decision to retain a U.S. cookie plant previously held for sale, and an $8 million charge to consolidate Kentucky Fried Chicken's domestic field operations. Year-ago 6-month results included a pre-tax reorganization charge in domestic soft drinks of $14.5 million ($10.4 million, or 4 cents a share). The company said 1988 figures are restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: Two Right-to-Die Issues In Feeding-Tube Case
description: In the first right-to-die case to reach an appeals court since a major ruling by New York State's highest court last year, the relatives of a Long Island woman who has been in a coma since 1986 are seeking to have a feeding tube that is keeping her alive removed.

title: Philips Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Paraplegic Scales Mountain
description: Mark Wellman, a paraplegic who hauled himself up 3,200-foot El Capitan 6 inches at a time over nine days, using only his arms, reached the summit today. The 29-year-old Mr. Wellman and a friend, Mike Corbett, 35, started the day about 300 feet from the top of a granite cliff after spending the night tied into sleeping bags on Chickenhead Ledge. His legs have been paralyzed since he fell from another Yosemite peak in 1982.

title: Baker Hughes Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included tax credits of $967,000 and $1,722,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Included tax benefits of $3,742,000 for the quarter and $23,715,000 for the 9 months. The company said year-ago 9-months results included a pre-tax net of $95,000,000 from settlement of litigation, partially offset by a pre-tax charge of $64,900,000.

title: AMP Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a pretax charge of $20 million for early termination program and other restructuring costs. The company said sales of Matrix Science, which was acquired in August 1988, are included in first half 1989 total sales, but not in first half 1988 sales.

title: Lynch Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Review/Music; Theodore Bikel's Choices
description: Theodore Bikel brings a hearty enjoyment to performing that one does not often encounter, even in the extroverted world of folk music.

title: Executive at CBS Leaving To Form a New Company
description: The chairman of the CBS Broadcast Group, Gene F. Jankowski, announced yesterday that he would leave the network Monday to form Jankowski Communications System Inc., a company that will buy network-affiliated television stations and produce programming.

title: Avon Products Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $23.4 million and $22.3 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, a loss on the sale of discontinued operations of $95 million for both the quarter and 6 months, and the 6-month also included income of $20 million, or 28 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. Year-ago results have been restated.

title: G.N.P. Rate Up by 1.7% For Quarter
description: The nation's economy grew at a rate of 1.7 percent in the second quarter, while inflation worsened, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Review/Film; A Droll Buddy Who Drools And Eats a Stereo Speaker
description: ''Turner and Hooch'' is yet another mismatched-buddy movie, only this time the fussy partner is played by Tom Hanks and the slobby partner by someone who truly slobbers. Scott Turner is a small-town police investigator and Hooch is a dog even Turner describes as ''massive and ugly,'' a creature with huge floppy jowls, from which run great rivers of foamy white drool. In fact, Hooch's endless dribbling is the film's central joke.

title: Union Texas Petroleum HoldFings reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Latest quarter and 6-month results included a $58.6 million gain from the settlement with insurers on Union Texas' business interruption policy regarding the July 6, 1988, explosion at the U.K. North Sea's piper field. The $58.6 million gain represented an accrual for payments to be received in the second half of 1989 and in 1990. The periods also included a $4.9 million gain from a gas contract settlement. Year-ago results included a $12.5 million gain in the second quarter and a $14.9 million gain in the first half from resolution of international tax issues and $5.5 million gain from a gas contract settlement.

title: Shirley Verrett Recital
description: The soprano Shirley Verrett is to sing Schumann's ''Frauenliebe und -leben,'' David Diamond's ''David Mourns for Absalom'' and selections by Nin, Barber and Verdi at Caramoor, Girdle Ridge Road in Katonah, N.Y., on Sunday afternoon at 5:30. Her accompanist is to be Warren George Wilson. Tickets are $20. Information and directions: (914) 232-5035.

title: EMC Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: b-Net loss Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split.

title: Leading Rebel Official Arrested in Philippines
description: A top rebel leader was arrested today and Philippine officials called his capture a major setback for the 20-year Communist insurgency.

title: Pierce Aide Profited Greatly After Leaving Post at H.U.D.
description: Lance H. Wilson, a close friend and former top aide to Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. in the early years of the Reagan Administration, used his experience and contacts in the Department of Housing and Urban Development to reap great profits after returning to private life.

title: Merger Alchemists Find Formula in Time Ruling
description: Friendly deals are back in vogue in the wake of the Delaware court rulings that cleared the way for the merger of Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc.

title: A Publisher Is Named for Miami Herald
description: Knight-Ridder Inc. said yesterday that David Lawrence Jr., publisher of The Detroit Free Press, will become publisher of The Miami Herald, the company's flagship newspaper, on Sept. 1.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-5

title: Ford Motor Co. of Canada reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said Canadian operations' earnings rose to $78 million from $48 million in the second quarter, reflecting the continued strength of the Canadian dollar, favorable product mix and increased engine production. Lower vehicle production partly offset those factors. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Amdura Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $381,000 for the quarter and income of $34,131,000 for the 6 months, both from discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $162,000 and $449,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. In the latest quarter and year-ago 6-month periods preferred dividend requirements made share earnings less than one cent a share. The company said it changed its year-end from Nov. 30 to Dec. 31, 1988.

title: National Mine Safety reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
House Panel Backs Bill To Outlaw Flag Burning
description: The House Judiciary Committee today approved legislation intended to outlaw flag burning, setting off a partisan scramble as Republicans complained of being steamrolled and insisted that a constitutional amendment was essential to protect the flag.

title: An Intriguing Group in the Haskell
description: The Haskell Handicap at Monmouth Park tomorrow did not attract Easy Goer, but the 10 three-year-olds who will race for $500,000 are an intriguing group and a couple could end up taking on Easy Goer in the Travers at Saratoga on Aug. 19.

title: Maze Demystified
description: To the Editor:

title: Unruffled Helms Basks in Eye of Arts Storm
description: When it comes to art and ''so-called works of art,'' Jesse Helms knows what he likes. At his home in Arlington, a Virginia suburb of Washington, the Senator has oil paintings of North Carolina scenes: a man sitting at a table with his hands folded in prayer over a Bible, a summer home he once owned on Lake Gaston and a snowy scene of a pier.

title: Advanta Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a tax benefit of $1,088,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. The company said its improved 1989 earnings were primarily attributable to an $18.6 million gain on the sale of about 60,000 credit card accounts.

title: Sonat Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a gain of $13,130,000 from an accounting change. Latest quarter and 6-month results included income of $33.9 million, or 83 cents a share, related to the settlement of Southern Natural Gas Co.'s rate case and order 500 filing, $4.3 million of which represented Sonat's share of net income related to a refund received by Citrus Corp. from Southern Natural. Year-ago quarter and 6-month results included income of $14.9 million, or 37 cents a share, from the reversal of reserves related to a regulatory matter that was resolved in the period.

title: New Future, New Past on the Baltic
description: Even as Moscow presses perestroika onto new terrain by endorsing plans for economic autonomy in the Baltic republics of Lithuania and Estonia, it bravely applies some glasnost to the Baltic region's past by acknowledging at last the whole truth about the notorious Hitler-Stalin pact.

title: Fela Offers a Mosaic of Music and Politics
description: Atypical piece by Fela Anikulapo-Kuti, the Nigerian left-wing political advocate and musician who is to perform tonight at the Apollo Theater in a benefit for James Brown, plans to start out slowly, with just the chattering of percussion. He will add layer after layer of instruments, brilliant saxophone and horn lines that magically interlock with the bass, drums and keyboards, or guitar lines. Singers will sing, dancers will dance and after 20 minutes, his 35-piece band, called Egypt 80, will have taken the audience on a musical and political journey.

title: Nellcor Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
Investors Sought Amdura Meeting
description: A group led by the New York money manager Frank J. A. Cilluffo said it had unsuccessfully tried to meet with the management of the Amdura Corporation to discuss recent developments at the Denver-based hardware distributor and heavy equipment maker.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 467 money market mutual funds increased by $1.85 billion, to $332.78 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 141 institutional funds decreased by $313.20 million, to $84.79 billion. But the assets of the 231 general-purpose funds were up by $554.80 million, to $105.96 billion. And the 95 broker-dealer funds increased by $1.60 billion, to $142.03 billion, the institute said.

title: Maxxam Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest quarter included aluminum operations conducted through a subsidiary of Kaisertech Ltd., Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corp.

title: Market Place; A Tale of Woe For Bondholders
description: JUST over three years ago AP Industries, owner of a successful auto parts chain, sold $100 million in ''junk bonds'' to finance an acquisition binge.

title: Walt Disney Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Syrian and Christian Shells Rain on Beirut in New Fury
description: In the most savage fighting in Lebanon in recent months, the Syrian Army and Lebanese Christian forces exchanged artillery and rocket fire incessantly for seven hours today, killing at least 26 people and wounding 82.

title: Pop/Jazz; Fela Offers A Mosaic Of Music And Politics
description: A typical piece by Fela Anikulapo-Kuti, the Nigerian left-wing political advocate and musician who is to perform tonight at the Apollo Theater in a benefit for James Brown, plans to start out slowly, with just the chattering of percussion. He will add layer after layer of instruments, brilliant saxophone and horn lines that magically interlock with the bass, drums and keyboards, or guitar lines. Singers will sing, dancers will dance and after 20 minutes, his 35-piece band, called Egypt 80, will have taken the audience on a musical and political journey.

title: Senators Vote to Keep Medicare Tax for Now
description: The Senate today blocked an attempt to suspend for one year the surtax that many Medicare beneficiaries pay to finance insurance against the catastrophic costs of prolonged illness.

title: Keithley Instruments reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
What Democrats' New Chairman Is Doing
description: To the Editor:

title: Agreement on Bailout Bill
description: Congressional conferees settled their last differences ang gave final approval to the legislation to rescue the savings industry. Page D1.

title: San Diego Gas & Electric reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
For Children
description: For Children Shows, Nature, Museums ''PLAY TO WIN,'' free performances by Theaterworks U.S.A., about the baseball player Jackie Robinson, for children 8 and older, 11 A.M. and 1 P.M. Mondays, Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays and 11 A.M. Saturdays and Sundays, through Aug. 13, at the Promenade Theater, Broadway and 76th Street. Tickets, on a first-come first-served basis, at 9 A.M. on the day of each performance. Information: 677-5959. ''SKATES,'' ''MAGGIE AND THE PIRATE'' AND ''APT. 3,'' three short pieces, 1 and 3:30 P.M. Fridays through Mondays, through Aug. 7, presented by Tada, a children's acting group, at 120 West 28th Street. Tickets: children, $5; adults, $7. A benefit performance at 7:30 P.M. Monday is to aid the group; tickets: $25. Information: 627-1732. ''TOY BOOKS EXHIBITION,'' a show of century-old toy books - small-format publications for children - printed by stationers in the historic South Street Seaport district, on view through Labor Day, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. daily, at Bowne & Company Stationers, 211 Water Street. Free. Information: 669-9419. adults, $12.50. Information: (203) 572-0711. BARTLETT ARBORETUM, a 63-acre garden, 8:30 A.M. to sunset daily, at 151 Brookdale Road, Stamford, Conn. Information: (203) 322-6971.

title: Lynn Seymour to Reprise Role as a Mad Anastasia
description: It has been more than a decade since New York dance audiences have seen Lynn Seymour in anything more than single gala performances or on film or video. But tonight and Monday through Wednesday, the great ballerina is to return to the Metropolitan Opera House in ''Anastasia,'' created for Miss Seymour by Sir Kenneth MacMillan and presented by the London Festival Ballet.

title: General Motors Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a gain of $218.1 million, or 35 cents a share, from an accounting change.

title: Midway Airlines Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax loss carryforwards of $108,000 for the quarter and $1,174,000 for the 6 months. c-After a tax loss carryforward of $1,526,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: Jet Makes Emergency Landing
description: A USAir jet made an emergency landing at Newark International Airport today after a failure of a hydraulic system, an airport official said. No injuries were reported. The jet, a Boeing 727 flying from Charlotte, N.C., to Newark, was able to land without incident at about 8:45 P.M., said Lynn Tierney, a spokeswoman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which oversees the airport. Passengers said the pilot told them of the problem but said a backup system was working.

title: Dining With a River View in a Bountiful Region
description: The Mid-Hudson Valley is a thriving agricultural region abloom with dedicated small-scale vegetable and herb farmers, cheesemakers, bakers and the country's oldest wineries. Such bounty and dedication to quality does not always translate into fine restaurants, however, as a tour of dining spots on the Hudson River from Kingston to West Point revealed. While some notable restaurants exist inland on both sides of the river, diners desiring a nautical view must choose carefully to avoid the shoals of tourist grub that clutter the riverside.

title: Castro Begins to Talk of a Decline in Crucial Aid From Soviets
description: As a result of radical changes under way in the Soviet bloc, Fidel Castro is beginning to speak of a decline in economic aid that has been crucial to Cuba's survival.

title: Chief of Panel Says I.R.S. Tried to Impede Its Inquiry
description: The Congressional subcommittee investigating the Internal Revenue Service heard new accounts of misconduct today, while the panel's chairman accused agency officials of impeding the inquiry.

title: Ashland Unit Buys 66 7-Eleven Stores
description: SuperAmerica, the retail gasoline marketing division of Ashland Oil Inc., has bought 66 7-Eleven stores and other properties in Minnesota and Wisconsin from the Southland Corporation. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: Tosco Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included tax credits of $9,781,000 and $7,007,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Included an extraordinary charge of $919,000 from the early retirement of debt for both periods, and tax credits of $15,023,000 and $20,548,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Results do not include those of Seminole Fertilizer Corp., the acquisition of which was completed by Tosco on June 30, 1989.

title: Europe to Aid Third World
description: The European Community has agreed on a revised offer for a new five-year trade and aid pact with a big group of undeveloped nations, European diplomats said today. Ministers of the 12-nation

title: Leggett & Platt Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Corrections
description: A picture caption on Tuesday about a Silicon Valley store that sells computer supplies and snacks misidentified the man shown loading soft drinks and computer accessories into his car. He was Paul Rotschi, a programmer for American Telephone and Telegraph.

title: Burton Jacobson, 60, A Connecticut Judge
description: Judge Burton J. Jacobson, who was credited with streamlining civil-court procedures in Connecticut, died of amyloidosis on Wednesday at St. Vincent's Medical Center. He was 60 years old and lived in Fairfield, Conn.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Addendum
description: * Burson-Marsteller has acquired Conti Public Relations G.m.b.H., a public relations firm based in Munich, West Germany. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Emotional Scars From Iowa Crash Will Extend Beyond Survivors
description: The crash of a United Airlines jumbo jet last week, its effect magnified by videotaped images and the accounts of those who lived through it, will leave psychic wounds on survivors, the families of the dead and the living, and even on ''vicarious victims'' far from the wreckage, mental health experts say.

title: UAL Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $456,000 and a net gain from sale of discontinued operations of $548,478,000. The average number of common shares outstanding used in calculating earnings per share was 21,619,897 for the 1989 6-month period and 36,650,141 for the 1988 6-month period. The difference in the number of shares outstanding during these periods resulted principally from UAL's purchase of 35,500,000 shares of its common stock on March 29, 1988, pursuant to a self-tender offer.

title: Arvin Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $420,000 for the quarter and a gain of $13,000 for the 6 months, both from discontinued operations. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,013,000 and $2,478,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: SRI LANKA REJECTS INDIA TROOP TALKS
description: As the deadline set by Sri Lanka for an Indian troop withdrawal approached, the Government tonight rejected an invitation for its Foreign Minister to go to India to discuss a way out of the impasse.

title: USAir Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Consolidated income statements included the operating results of USAir Group, its principal subsidiaries, Piedmont Aviation and USAir, four commuter airlines and other subsidiaries.

title: Exploring a Valley of Vineyards
description: THE Hudson River Valley, the home of 19 wineries within a two-and-a-half-hour drive from New York City, is the oldest wine-producing region in the United States. This year is especially significant because the Brotherhood Winery in Washingtonville, the nation's oldest active winery, is observing its 150th anniversary.

title: Buying the Right to Pollute? What's Next?
description: When the Clean Air Act proposed by President Bush was passed in late 1989, few people understood that its extraordinary principle was going to sweep through the civilized world.

title: Premark International Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a charge of $15,900,000 for a change in method of accounting for income taxes. Year-ago six-month net from operations included $15 million tax benefit due to the sale of a facility.

title: Books of The Times; Brave New Africa Born of Nightmare
description: Stars of the New Curfew By Ben Okri 194 pages. Viking. $17.95.

title: TV Weekend; An Essay on Death as a Celebration of Life, on HBO
description: ''Time Flies When You're Alive'' is a one-man play written and performed by the actor Paul Linke. It is about the death of his wife from cancer at the age of 37. With Roger Spottiswoode (''Under Fire,'' ''Turner and Hooch'') as director, a 90-minute version of the show has been taped for Home Box Office, on which it is to have its premiere at 10 P.M. Sunday.

title: Alco Standard Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $57,325,000. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $1,816,000 for the quarter and $6,750,000 for the 9 months.

title: Symbol Technologies Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Brooklyn Theater Becomes Housing
description: The Park Slope section of Brooklyn has been enjoying a revival for some time, becoming the family-raising neighborhood of choice for many young professional couples who work in Manhattan.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Illinois Jacquet

title: Pierce Aide Lobbied to Save Troubled Housing Program
description: Even as the Reagan Administration tried to shut down a troubled low-income housing program that has now been linked to widespread political favoritism, the chief aide to the Housing Secretary was lobbying Congress to keep it alive, according to current and former Congressional officials.

title: MCI to Let Callers Use Visa Cards
description: The MCI Communications Corporation said yesterday that consumers would soon be able to charge long-distance telephone calls carried over the MCI network to their Visa credit cards.

title: American General Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $86,603,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $14,990,000 and $29,639,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Diner's Journal
description: La Caravelle

title: Lin Rebuffed By McCaw
description: McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. responded unfavorably today to the Lin Broadcasting Corporation's suggestion that it would be willing to merge at a price of $127.50 a share if an agreement could be reached by Monday morning.

title: Valentino's Bold Shapes Lift Him to Top
description: Valentino Garavani, the Rome designer, has just been catapulted into the top rank of couturiers here.

title: When Good Standing Has Different Meanings
description: In the beginning, Marvin Mandel was a lawyer. That was before he was elected Governor of Maryland, before he was indicted, tried, retried and convicted on mail fraud charges, before he served 19 months in prison, before his appeals, his disbarment and the erasure of his conviction from the books.

title: Times Co. Buys McCall's
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that it had acquired McCall's magazine from Working Woman/McCall's Group, a joint venture of Time Inc. and Dale W. Lang, a media investor. The parties, which had reached an agreement in principle on the deal in May, did not disclose terms of the sale, but the net price was reported to be slightly more than $80 million.

title: Norton Co. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $1.4 million for the quarter and $3 million for the 6 months. c-After tax credits of $2.2 million for the quarter and $4.4 million for the 6 months.

title: Expulsion Is Sought
description: The International Tennis Federation, eager to keep its sport in the Olympics, is supporting a move to expel South Africa, one of its founding members. The federation said yesterday in London that it was supporting a resolution from Nigeria that the South African Tennis Union be thrown out of the 147-nation organization ''until the policy of apartheid in South Africa is abandoned.'' The resolution will be voted on at the federation's annual meeting in Buenos Aires in September. No member nation has ever been expelled.

title: U.S. Reports Steep Rise in 1980's In Lung Cancer Deaths in Women
description: Deaths from lung cancer continue to rise sharply among women in the United States, a new Federal health report says.

title: Why Pick on Lawyers to Provide Free Service?; Equal Access Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: The Pentagon
description: At its best, what the public sees of the making of the military budget has often been rather like Kabuki theater, each player presenting a carefully drawn mask to the audience and executing steps choreographed to provide a mere shadow of the real offstage drama.

title: Donnelley (R.R.) & Sons Co.  (N) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Raychem Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Latest quarter results included a gain of $2.3 million, or 4 cents a share, from the sale of an investment. Year-ago quarter results included a gain of $18.1 million, or 39 cents a share, on the sale of Bentley-Harris Manufacturing Co. Sigmaform Corp. is included for all of fiscal 1989 and about three months of fiscal 1988. Fiscal 1988 results included Bentley-Harris Manufacturing Co. for about nine months prior to its sale in April 1988. The company said sales for the latest year and fourth quarter would have been higher by about $26.9 million and $17.9 million, respectively, had foreign currency exchange rates been the same as in the corresponding periods of fiscal 1988.

title: Quantum Chemical Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included net from discontinued operations of $129.4 million and $133.3 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Included net from discontinued operations of $6.3 million and $11.6 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Latest quarter results included after-tax costs of $6.2 million attributable to the fire at the company's Morris, Ill. facility. Results for 1988 have been restated to reflect the oleochemical segment as a discontinued operation and included certain reclassifications made for comparative purposes.

description: To the Editor:

title: Writer Wins Long Fight to Halt Deportation
description: Margaret Randall, the author who has conducted a long legal battle to avoid deportation for her leftist political writing, finally won her case today. The basis for her victory was an unexpected one.

title: Rise Approved In Debt Limit
description: The House Ways and Means Committee today approved a temporary $70 billion increase in the Government's borrowing authority.

title: Total Petroleum (North AmerFican) Ltd.(A) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Leader's Defection on Tax Issue May Split Japanese Ruling Party
description: Mired in the preliminaries of its struggle to select a new Prime Minister, the Liberal Democratic Party suffered a split today over tax policy that was widely seen as hampering its search and undercutting its ability to govern in the months ahead.

title: Panhandle Issue Totals $300 Million
description: The Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company yesterday offered $300 million of senior subordinated reset debentures due in 2001 through Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: Mets Rally, but Lose Third in Row to Pirates
description: Tumbling from highs to lows with reckless abandon, the Mets lost their third straight game to the fifth-place Pittsburgh Pirates yesterday and fell five full games out of first place with no answers in sight.

title: Santucci Questioned on Son's Campaign
description: Eight current and former assistant district attorneys in Queens told a state commission yesterday that aides to John J. Santucci, the Queens District Attorney, had solicited them for help in his son's 1984 campaign for the New York State Senate.

title: Why Pick on Lawyers to Provide Free Service?; Solo Practitioner
description: To the Editor:

title: Eastern Plea Is Withdrawn
description: Eastern Airlines Wednesday withdrew its request for Bankruptcy Court permission to abrogate its labor contract with striking pilots.

title: Frisch's Restaurants reports earnings for Qtr to May 28
description: b-Included income of $951,064 from an accounting change.

title: Women Gain, but Slowly, in the Foreign Service
description: ''I think I'm out of pocket about $150,000,'' said Alison Palmer, the leading plaintiff in a lawsuit filed against the State Department 13 years ago, charging it with discrimination against female Foreign Service officers. ''But it was a matter of principle. I saw the State Department - as well as the women - being injured by the terrible waste of talent.''

title: Article 241489 -- No Title
description: The Bristol-Myers Company and the Squibb Corporation said yesterday that they had agreed to merge in a deal that would create the second-largest pharmaceutical company in the world.

title: How to Be Stupid in New York
description: I do not know who will be the Democratic candidate for mayor - but.

title: Business Digest
description: Companies

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Lord, Geller Wins 3 Accounts in 5 Days
description: Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein, during the off-season this week, received three accounts in five days. The agency was chosen to handle advertising for Fasolino Foods, Palm-Aire Spa Resort and Country Club, and Citizens for a Drug-Free America. The combined budget of the accounts will be $15 million in 1990, said Tim Elliot, the agency's chief executive.

title: Crown Central Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Review/Theater; An Odyssey Of Refugees, In This Case Palestinian
description: Toward the end of the first act of ''The Story of Kufur Shamma,'' the six cast members of El-Hakawati troupe huddle close together at the front of the sand-covered stage, a lone spotlight dimly illuminating their faces. As much as anything else in the work that opened Wednesday night for a week's run at the Dance Theater Workshop, that tableau captures the cramped and desperate existence of displaced men and women forced to live in refugee camps by powers beyond their control.

title: Our Towns; After Tornado, So Many Lives At a Standstill
description: When the tornado that spun across western Connecticut on July 10 racketed through Hamden like a malevolent freight train, some residents were able to pinpoint the exact time it hit: 5:38 P.M.

title: Why Pick on Lawyers to Provide Free Service; Improving the Plan
description: To the Editor:

description: The net income figures are after extraordinary items. The share earnings are in American Depositary Receipts (ADR). Four ICI, 1-pound ordinary shares are represented by each ADR.

Downey Savings & Loan AsFsociation reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Juanita H. Miner, Corrections Official, 57
description: Juanita H. Miner, who worked for the New York City Department of Correction for 24 years, mostly in supervisory positions on Rikers Island, died after a stroke Saturday at the Berkshire Medical Center in Pittsfield, Mass. She was 57 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title: Baldwin & Lyons Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Excess Tenders In NWA Offer
description: Wings Holdings Inc., a company led by Alfred Checchi, the Los Angeles investor, said yesterday that shareholders had tendered or promised to deliver more shares of NWA Inc. than actually existed.

title: Israelis Said to Seize 3 in Raid on Lebanon
description: An Israeli commando unit kidnapped a leader of the Lebanese Shiite Party of God militia and two of his relatives and took them by helicopter to Israel today, the Israeli radio reported.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 30 about Fort Riley, Kan., and a correction of the article on Tuesday misstated the rank that George Custer held at the time of his death at the Battle of the Little Bighorn. The error, referring to him as a general, was repeated Wednesday in a picture caption about the death of a woman born in 1876, the year of the battle. Custer attained the rank of major general of volunteers in the Civil War. In the reorganization of the Army after the war, he was assigned the rank of lieutenant colonel in the 7th Cavalry.

title: Experience Tells in Operating Room, Study Finds
description: Death rates for four common operations are higher when done by surgeons with less experience, a new study has found.

title: Conferees Agree on Savings Bailout Bill
description: After more than two weeks of debate, House and Senate conferees settled their last differences and gave final approval tonight to the bailout legislation that will spend $166 billion over the next 10 years to shut, liquidate and sell hundreds of insolvent savings and loan associations.

title: Massachusetts Looks at Betting
description: Football betting could bring in $50 million yearly, a study by the Massachusetts Lottery Commission has found. The commission, in a preliminary review, estimated that the revenue would be $150 million, with the state keeping $50 million.

title: Harleysville Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Sterling Chemicals Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago 9-month results included a loss of $9 million from early retirement of debt and an $8.3 million gain from an accounting change.

title: Jerrico Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: b-After an accounting change gain of $5,684,000 and included a pre-tax charge of $1 million for a litigation settlement. The year-ago quarter and full year included pre-tax charges of $3,029,000 for losses from the sale of clothes shops and charges of $2,745,000 for an inventory writedown.

title: U.M.W. Is Fined Again
description: A judge who had earlier fined the United Mine Workers nearly $3 million for violating his orders limiting strike activities imposed a fine of $4.5 million on the union today for what he called ''acts of terror'' in the coal fields. The judge, Donald McGlothlin Jr. of Russell County Circuit Court, assailed the union for assaults and threats made by its members during the U.M.W.'s four-month-old strike against the Pittston Coal Group's operations in Virginia, West Virginia and Kentucky. A U.M.W. attorney, Mike Passino, said he expected the union to appeal.

title: Industrial Equity Not Planning a Bid
description: Industrial Equity (Pacific) Ltd. does not plan to use its stake in the Cummins Engine Company as a stepping-stone for a takeover of the Indiana engine company, the president of Industrial Equity's United States operation said today. ''We have no plans for the company other than to support management in what it's doing now,'' Robert Sutherland said by telephone from his office in La Jolla, Calif.

title: Timken Co. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
KEY RATES
Citgo Petroleum Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
No Elections Without Land, P.L.O. Officials Say
description: Two senior Palestinian officials today confirmed reports that a Soviet envoy had conveyed to Jerusalem the Palestine Liberation Organization's conditions for taking part in Israeli-sponsored elections in the occupied territories.

title: In Poland, Face of Anti-Semitism Still Jeers; Pray for Them All
description: To the Editor:

title: Kerr-McGee Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $367,000 for the quarter and a net of $29,628,000 for the 6 months, both from discontinued operations. c-After net from discontinued operations of $6,581,000 for the quarter and $6,388,000 for the 6 months.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Romanoff International Inc., to the Bloom Agency, with a budget of $1 million.

title: Review/Art; The Lily, Ungilded Though Elaborately Drawn
description: Botanical Magazine celebrated its 200th anniversary in 1987. The journal was founded by William Curtis, a London apothecary and self-taught naturalist. In 1777, Curtis began publishing Flora Londinensis, a guide that provided descriptions and hand-colored illustrations of plants native to the London area. Curtis, who had to resign his post at the Chelsea Physic Garden because of a chronic failure to keep appointments and meet deadlines, issued his volumes at erratic intervals.

title: New Drug for AIDS Yields Improvements In Small First Studies
description: A promising experimental drug for the treatment of AIDS has produced improvements in patients without causing toxic side effects, a new study has shown.

title: Eddie Palmieri
description: The pianist Eddie Palmieri is leading his Latin jazz band tonight at 8:30 and 11:30 at the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-7880). Tickets are $13.50.

title: Intermet Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Mediq Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and after a loss of $3,689,000 from discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $5,195,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary gain of $3,449,000.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alpine Group Inc., Hackensack, N.J., a maker of machine parts, retained Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. as its financial adviser to examine options for a recapitalization.

title: Million-Dollar Long Shot
description: A victory for Southern Raider in the $907,000 Woodrow Wilson Pace on Friday night at the Meadowlands would be worth $426,750 and would come in only the second start for the colt owned by Gerald Rosen, a teacher from Toms River, N.J.

title: Cabot Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $816,000.

title: Disney's Net Climbs 17.2%
description: Buoyed by a strong performance at its theme parks, the Walt Disney Company said today that its third-quarter earnings rose 17.2 percent, to record levels.

title: Construction Executive Is Indicted on Bribery
description: The head of a construction company that was awarded $18 million in New York City contracts three weeks ago was indicted yesterday as a conspirator in what prosecutors say was an organized-crime plan to control a multimillion-dollar segment of the city's construction industry.

title: John W. Studebaker Dies at 102; Developed Educational Programs
description: John Ward Studebaker, a former United States Commissioner of Education, died Wednesday at Rossmoor Manor Convalescent Hospital in Walnut Creek, Calif. He was 102 years old.

title: Customs Chief Asserts U.S. War on Drugs Is Stalled
description: In blunt criticism of Bush Administration colleagues, William von Raab, the Commissioner of Customs, said today that the Administration's war on drugs was ''mired in complacency.''

title: G.M.'s Profit Drops 4%; Ford's Net Declines 15%
description: The General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company, the nation's biggest auto makers, said today that the cost of clearing large inventories of unsold cars and trucks led to declines in profits in the second quarter.

title: California Bank in Deal With Mitsui
description: The Security Pacific Corporation agreed today to pay $38 million for 20 percent of Mitsui Manufacturers Bank, the California subsidiary of the giant Mitsui Bank of Tokyo. The deal makes Security Pacific the first American bank to buy a stake in a major Japanese bank, analysts said.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Smallest Jet Is Facing Big Test At Receiver
description: The fact that Al Toon and Wesley Walker, the Jets' All-Pro wide receivers, are both unsigned and not in training camp could be good or bad for Titus Dixon, the sixth-round draft choice out of Troy State.

title: Op-Ed; Hitler, on Art
description: On Sept. 11, 1935, Adolf Hitler gave a speech in Nuremberg. Robert Brustein of the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., and Joshua Goldstein, a playwright, found portions of it to be an apt commentary on the Senate vote to bar the National Endowment for the Arts from supporting ''obscene or indecent'' work.

title: Montreal Trustco reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: INSIDE
description: 'Great Gulf' Between Races Despite Blacks' Gains The largest study yet of postwar social and economic trends among blacks found that their gains still left them far behind whites.
