title: Two Managers To First Boston
description: The First Boston Corporation added two portfolio managers to its $7 billion investment management department this week.

title: One Price Clothing reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Household Finance In Note Offering
description: The Household Finance Corporation yesterday priced $100 million of five-year notes.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Richard W. Cuthbertson has been named executive of the Pacific region of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications.

title: A Brightening Star Is Rising in the Bronx
description: By the time the trip was over, Roberto Kelly was bruised and battered and a little worn down, a condition not unlike that of the rest of the Yankees. But while his teammates were grounded by eight losses in nine games on the road, Kelly had nudged his brightening star higher in the sky.

title: 121 Years Of Men Only Ends at Club
description: An era has ended and a door has opened. The 10,000-member New York Athletic Club, which for 121 years has been a symbol of masculine exclusivity, has bowed to the forces of change and feminine scorn and agreed to accept women as members.

title: New York Keeps 'Love' From Knife
description: After screams of horror from New York officials, Paramount Pictures Corporation has agreed to stop using the ''I Love New York'' logo in advertisements for the latest ''Friday the 13th'' sequel.

title: Chips & Technologies Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Williams Challenged For Cornerback Job
description: For years, the Giants have struggled at cornerback. They usually found two starters, but not always adequate backups.

title: Daniel Rhodes, 78, Ceramic Sculptor, Dies
description: Daniel Rhodes, a sculptor in ceramics and pottery who taught and wrote on the subject, died of a heart attack Sunday at Washoe Medical Center in Reno, Nev. He was 78 years old and lived in Swanton, Calif.

title: Review/Cabaret; Songs by Hadda Brooks
description: Hadda Brooks, who resumed her singing career in California two years ago after 16 years of retirement, is making her first appearance in New York in 35 years. In a program called ''Swing Street Legends'' at Michael's Pub, 211 East 55 Street, she has been joined by Thelma Carpenter, who sang in the 1940's with the bands of Coleman Hawkins, Teddy Wilson and Count Basie.

title: Review/Ballet; New Cast in London Company's 'Romeo'
description: If the London Festival Ballet's revival of Sir Frederick Ashton's 1955 ''Romeo and Juliet'' is the surprise success of the season, Wednesday night's debut by the second of the company's three casts was an outright revelation.

title: Paul Mangelsdorf, Botanist, 90; Tracked Corn to Primitive Maize
description: Paul C. Mangelsdorf, a botanist whose cross-breeding of corn and other grains earned him a world reputation, died in his sleep Saturday at the Carol Woods Retirement Community in Chapel Hill, N.C., where he lived. He had celebrated his 90th birthday two days earlier.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Avon Products Inc., the maker of personal-care products, named Robert J. Conologue vice president and controller.

title: Jepson to Receive $12-a-Share Offer
description: Great American Management and Investment Inc. said it would offer $12 a share to acquire the Jepson Corporation. Jepson owns a diversified group of operating companies, including Air-Maze, Atlantic Industries, Denman Tire, Hill Refrigeration and Signet Armorlite.

title: Michael Foods reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Legislation to Be Sought On Digital Recording
description: The record and stereo-equipment industries yesterday released details of their anti-copying agreement for digital audio tape recorders, and said they would also conduct negotiations about any new technologies capable of duplicating copyrighted material.

title: Indicted Officer Resigns
description: The Systems and Computer Technology Corporation said today that Michael Searcy, senior vice president and a director, had resigned after being indicted on charges of Federal securities law vialations. A grand jury on May 3 indicted Frederick Gross, the company's former chief executive and a director, on charges that he violated securities laws by filing filing false and misleading reports about the company with the Securities and Exchange Commission in 1984. A superseding indictment issued Wednesday repeated the allegations against Mr. Gross and added Mr. Searcy as a defendant.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Dave Valentin Quintet

title: Delta Air Lines Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Louis A. Siegel, 75, Lawyer and Executive
description: Louis A. Siegel, a corporate lawyer and business executive, died of congenital heart disease Tuesday at Berkshire Medical Center in Pittsfield, Mass. He was 75 years old and had homes in Manhattan and Stockbridge, Mass.

title: Mine Leaders Prove Quick Studies in the New Soviet Politics
description: Aleksei Bokorov, a 35-year-old coal miner, never elected to anything until his angry peers made him strike committee chairman a week ago, returned from Moscow today brimming with news and strategies from his meeting with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: McCartney Plans World Ecology Tour
description: Paul McCartney said today that he would begin a world tour in September and promote the environmental group Friends of the Earth along the way.

title: Senate Vote Prompts Anger, but Some Approval, in the Art World
description: Reactions in the art world ranged from shock and anger to qualified approval after the Senate's vote on Wednesday to bar the National Endowment for the Arts from supporting work that is ''obscene or indecent'' or otherwise unsuitable under restrictions proposed by Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina. The measure would also cut off Federal funds to two arts groups that supported work by two provocative photographers.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Auctions
description: A dreamy-eyed bronze faun - holding cymbals and dancing, with a foot poised on a bellows - was removed in May from a sale by Sotheby's of 19th-century garden statuary in Sussex, England, and sent to London. This week, Sotheby's in London announced that the unsigned, 31-inch figure was to be auctioned there in December, as a Renaissance sculpture attributed to Adriaen de Vries, a Dutch artist who was court sculptor to Rudolf II of Prague.

title: Warsaw Journal; Poland's Food Clamor: 'Some Are Calling It Panic'
description: The lines in front of Janina Kucharska's bakery along Pulawska Avenue lately stretch to 100 or 120 people at times.

title: Yonkers Budget Lacks Required School Funds
description: The Yonkers City Council failed tonight to earmark $24 million to build two new schools that are part of a court-ordered desegregation plan. The failure could allow the State Comptroller to order a budget for the city.

title: Loblaw Cos. reports earnings for Qtr to June 17
description: Results are in Canadian funds. The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

The company said 1988 revenues were restated to reflect the retroactive adoption of Financial Accounting Standards Board Statement No. 97 in the first quarter of 1989.

title: Elks Affirm All-Male Policy But Ease Stand on Nonwhites
description: The all-male Elks organization voted today to continue to bar women but approved a proposal that could make it easier for nonwhite men to join.

title: Policeman Kills Woman to Halt Stabbing of Girl
description: A 33-year-old Brooklyn woman, who was stabbing her 9-year-old daughter and screaming, ''The devil is in you,'' was shot and killed yesterday, the police said, when she ignored a police warning to drop her knife.

title: Lawter International reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Sanctions for Doctor of Bar Leader's Dog
description: No dog death, it is safe to say, has generated as much interest in the bar as the demise of a well-connected Chicago Dalmatian named Finnegan.

title: Review/Theater; Maria Tucci in 'The Rose Tattoo'
description: Perhaps the most exacting measure of a playwright's enduring place in dramatic literature is the scrutiny of time on the writer's secondary works. Even in the critical and commercial decline of his later years, the masterpieces of Tennessee Williams were never questioned. Now, six years after his death, revivals of some of the second-rank plays, like ''Night of the Iguana'' and ''Orpheus Descending,'' serve as a testament to the abiding power of Williams's voice.

title: ESPIONAGE SUSPECT REPORTEDLY TOLD F.B.I. OF PAYMENT
description: Felix S. Bloch, the State Department official under investigation for espionage, told the Federal Bureau of Investigation in his one brief interview that he had been paid ''a lot of money'' by the Soviet Union, an official involved in the case said yesterday.

title: Faking the News
description: On its regular evening news program a week ago, ABC News showed some faked footage depicting an American diplomat handing a briefcase to a Soviet agent. Peter Jennings, the network anchorman, has since apologized because viewers were told too late that the footage was a ''simulation.'' The fakery insulted viewers, ethics and journalism. Ethics first. Felix Bloch, who was once attached to the U.S. Embassy in Vienna, is indeed the subject of an espionage investigation by the Federal Government. He has not been charged. Yet ABC has come close to convicting him; seeing the footage, an unwary viewer might think ABC had caught Mr. Bloch in the act.

title: Mets Need New Sound This Season
description: A baseball team is an orchestra, its personnel ever changing from concert to concert, from season to season, rather than a string quartet that may stay intact for decades.

description: b-Included a gain of $905,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

Continental Bank Plans Stock Sale
description: The Continental Bank Corporation, rescued in a $4.5 billion Federal bailout five years ago, said it plans to sell up to $285 million of preferred stock to the public and use the proceeds to buy back class A preferred stock acquired by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation in the bailout. ''This proposed sale and purchase would reduce by more than one-third the F.D.I.C.'s equity investment in Continental, moving us another step closer to our goal of complete public ownership by year-end,'' said Thomas Theobold, Continental's chairman.

title: Off Jersey, a War Against Tuna
description: LEAD: For the past two months, enormous numbers of bluefin and yellowfin tuna have been slaughtered in the Atlantic Ocean, about 60 miles off the New Jersey coast.

description: Melodious Private Eye

title: Echlin European Chief Is Named President
description: Echlin Inc., a maker and distributor of auto parts that has been expanding outside the United States, underscored its embrace of foreign markets yesterday with the naming of Roger H. Storey, head of its European group, as president.

title: SOVIET PARLIAMENT BACKS AUTONOMY FOR THE BALTICS
description: The Soviet legislature today endorsed the plan of two Baltic republics to embark next year on the most far-reaching economic experiments this country has seen since at least the 1920's.

title: Ford Motor Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said earnings declined from a year-ago primarily because of lower U.S. industry sales and associated marketing expenses and higher new product development and plant modernization costs.

title: Trying to Pitch Out of a Jam
description: ''Frank Viola? It's pie in the sky,'' Dave Johnson said. ''This deal, I think, has no chance of going through. What can I tell my players? Don't worry, you'll love Minnesota?'' Frank Cashen, the general manager and maker of trades, walked into Johnson's office and handed him a typewritten statement that said in part that the Mets would have ''absolutely nothing to say about speculation'' that they were talking trade with the Twins.

title: Brown Loses To Weaver
description: Mike Weaver retained his World Boxing Association Americas heavyweight title last night when he won a dull 12-round split decision over Phillip Brown at Felt Forum.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Commercial Costs Up 12%
description: The cost of producing a nationally broadcast television commercial rose by 12 percent in 1988 over the year before, an increase that the American Association of Advertising Agencies yesterday called ''not as dramatic as those reported earlier in this decade.''

title: Economic Scene; Recession Fears And the Deficit
description: THE Federal budget deficit, denounced last winter as a horror and a danger to the economy, is now being viewed as benign. And the great outcry for deficit reduction is slowly giving way to a different concern: too much reduction might help provoke a recession.

title: Frankfurt's High-Rise Debate
description: As continental Europe's leading financial center, Frankfurt am Main already sported enough gleaming skyscapers to have been dubbed ''Mainhattan'' and ''Bankfurt'' by critics of its rapid growth. Now, however, a high-rise construction boom fed by the European Community's plans for a single borderless market by the end of 1992 is rapidly altering the city's skyline and igniting conflict among developers, realtors and city officials.

title: Midland Co. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the arrival of two Chinese student leaders in the United States misidentified the campus where a congress of Chinese students is to begin today. It is the University of Illinois at Chicago.

description: To the Editor:

title: In Iowa Jet Inquiry, an Engine Puzzle
description: Federal air crash investigators, turning their attention to the engine that failed last week on a jumbo jet above Iowa, must adopt methods as meticulous as any known to archeology.

title: Celtic Pick Eager
description: The player that the Boston Celtics selected in the second round of the National Basketball Association draft, Dino Radja of Yugoslavia, was at a training session yesterday in Brookline, Mass., and said he hoped to play for the Celtics this year. The 6-foot-10-inch center is a member of the Jugoplastika club in Belgrade whose coach, Bozidor Maljkovic, has said it will not let Radja go.

description: b-Net income

title: Blacks Found Lagging Despite Gains
description: Although blacks have made important economic and social gains over the last five decades, they still lag significantly behind whites, a new study concludes, to the point that a ''great gulf'' separates the two races.

description: b-Included pretax provisions of $54 million and $58.6 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, to cover futures losses relating to cost adjustments for certain U.S. defense contracts. c-Net income d-Included a $1.1 million pretax provision to cover future losses from cost adjustments related to contracts for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: A.T.&T. Wins Round in 'Dumping' Fight
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company cleared a major hurdle yesterday in its efforts to convince the Government that equipment manufacturers in Japan, South Korea and Taiwan are selling small-business telephone systems in the United States at unfairly low prices.

title: Review/Art; Classically Ordered Visions Of Displacement and Unease
description: For close to 50 years, Hughie Lee-Smith has been painting the experience of displacement. His classically composed works, with figures and landscape arranged in the kind of strict vertical and horizontal relationships familiar in the paintings of Balthus, de Chirico and Hopper, never communicate a clear sense of place. Even when the sky is spotless, the light is impure. Even when the setting is a beach or street, the location is unsure.

title: Dow Up 22.38 To 2,635.43; Volume High
description: Stock prices continued to set records yesterday, buoyed by higher bond prices and the announcement of a new blockbuster merger.

title: Warren S. Tryon, 87, Professor of History
description: Warren S. Tryon, professor of history at Boston University for two decades before his retirement in 1967, died of liver cancer July 13 at Addison Gilbert Hospital in Gloucester, Mass. He was 87 years old and lived in Rockport, Mass.

title: Renaissance Festival
description: Entertainment, food and crafts -some celebrating the fare of the 16th century - can be found at the 12th New York Renaissance Festival on weekends through Sept. 17 at Sterling Forest, off Route 17, Tuxedo, N.Y. Entertainment includes a Shakespearean production, puppet shows, jousting, a large-scale chess game with actors as chess pieces, dances and concerts by strolling musicians. Hours are 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Saturday and Sunday Admission is $12 ($10 for the elderly, $5 for those 6 to 12 years old, free for those under 6.) Information: (914) 351-5171.

title: House Seeks to End U.S.-Soviet Plutonium Output
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 -

title: The Sights and the Delights Of the Historic Hudson
description: FROM Lake Tear of the Clouds in the Adirondack Mountains, the Hudson River flows a little more than 300 miles to the Atlantic Ocean through some of the most beautiful scenery in the world, right in the backyard of metropolitan New York. A paradox, the river is clean enough in some places for a dozen cities to drink its water, but other cities dump their treated sewage into it. A major breeding ground for fish, the river is so polluted by PCB's that the state recommends not eating its prolific striped bass.

title: Oquendo's Streak Ends; Two Are Still Going
description: Jose Oquendo's hitting streak ended Wednesday night at 23 games, the longest in the majors this season, but two of his teammates are going strong as the St. Louis Cardinals try to stay within striking distance in the National League East.

title: In Poland, Face of Anti-Semitism Still Jeers
description: To the Editor:

title: Dining Out Guide: Salads
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have stars. Prices are current. Gotham Bar and Grill *** (Oct. 4, 1985), 12 East 12th Street (620-4020) - The stunning post-modern Gotham remains a trendsetter offering inventive, visually impressive dishes. Salads are exceptional, with the seafood salad among the best in town. The new menu lists a cold summer salade compose of poached leeks, artichokes, haricots verts, fennel and several kinds of tomato spread with pesto and lightly dressed with sherry vinegar and extra-virgin olive oil. Warm skate salad is another choice, served with grilled red onion, lettuces, lemon, capers and olive oil. Appetizers are $8 to $14, entrees $24 to $29. Lunch: noon to 2:30 P.M. Monday to Friday; dinner: 6 to 10:45 P.M. Monday to Thursday, 6 to 11:15 P.M. Friday and Saturday and 5:30 to 9:45 P.M. Sunday. The Health Pub Diner's Journal (Jan. 29, 1988), 371 Second Avenue, at 21st Street (529-9200) - The Health Pub's vegetarian menu sounds so appealing that even hard-core junk-food fans may be tempted. Salads, each with a distinctive dressing, are varied and delicious. Watercress, jicama and avocado are tossed with olive oil, lime juice, cumin, paprika and canola oil. Seasonal baby greens with nasturtiums are dressed with balsamic vinegar, miso, lemon juice, soy sauce, shallots, garlic and basil. The house salad is romaine, chicory, shredded carrots, beets and other vegetables blended wih blanched tofu, raspberry vinegar, walnut and safflower oils. Salads are $4 to $6.50, entrees $6.50 to $10.50. Open 11 A.M. to 11 P.M. daily. Manhattan Island * (Sept. 11, 1987), 482 West 43d Street (967-0533) - This restaurant near Theater Row offers an outdoor dining terrace with umbrella-shaded tables and a view of the swimming pool in the neighboring health club. It also features two poultry-based salads. Smoked chicken, fresh basil, bacon and vinegar peppers are accompanied by a Cajun mayonnaise that includes hot pepper sauce. An Oriental chicken salad combines stir-fried chicken with scallions and peanut sauce. Appetizers are $3.50 to $7, entrees $8 to $17. Open noon to 6 P.M. on Monday, noon to 9 P.M. Tuesday to Saturday. Brunch only on Sunday, noon to 4 P.M. Yellowfingers di Nuovo Diner's Journal (April 28, 1989), 200 East 60th Street (751-8615) - One of the better moderately priced restaurants around, Yellowfingers di Nuovo is also open late seven nights a week. Seasonal field greens grown in Maine get a balsamic vinegar and extra-virgin olive oil dressing. More substantial appetizers are the classic Caesar salad with anchovy toast and arugula arranged with grapefruit, fennel and endive with a sherry vinaigrette. With ripe tomatoes in high season, the chef offers the beefsteak variety with roasted peppers and fresh mozzarella. The rosemary-roasted chicken salad is highly recommended. The chicken is served warm on hearty greens, tossed wtih sweet peppers, olives and pine nuts in a champagne vinegar, olive oil and herb dressing. Appetizers are $3.50 to $8.50, entrees $7.50 to $18.50. Open noon to 1 A.M. Monday to Saturday, until midnight on Sunday.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; McCann Has 2 Big Losses And a Gain
description: MCCANN-ERICKSON U.S.A. lost two of its premier accounts yesterday when RJR Nabisco Inc. moved its Winston and Camel cigarette businesses, worth $55 million in billings last year, to two agences.

description: ''If the day comes that we need a union, we'll go looking for them. We're trying to build high-quality cars and trucks.

title: Name-calling in the Supreme Court: When the Justices vent their spleen, is there a social cost?
description: Barely two months from now, the Justices of the Supreme Court are scheduled to shake one another's hands and sit down around the conference table to begin the work of the new term. In light of the vituperative and personal tone that marked some of the major opinions of the term just ended, it seems fair to wonder whether the Justices will be able to look one another in the eye, let alone get back to work.

title: ICN Talks Held
description: Milan Panic, the chairman of ICN Pharmaceuticals Inc., said the company had held negotiations about the acquiring ''businesses similar to or compatible with'' the company's pharmaceuticals business. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr. Panic also said that ICN, which is based in Costa Mesa, Calif., might also sell certain assets in the future. Mr. Panic controls the equivalent of 5.8 percent of ICN's shares. The stock gained 37.5 cents today, to $6.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Treasury Notes and Bonds Surge
description: In a sharp rally, prices of Treasury notes and bonds surged in brisk trading yesterday, in response to Government economic reports. First, data showed that economic growth in the second quarter was somewhat weaker than anticipated, then the Government reported that initial unemployment claims figures suggested employment conditions may have deteriorated even more rapidly than had been thought in July.

title: Armco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a $45 million loss from discontinued operations for both the quarter and 6 months. c-After a $15 million loss from discontinued operations and a $3.6 million gain from the early retirement of debt for both the quarter and 6 months, and the year-ago 6-month also included a $37.4 million gain from an accounting change. The latest second quarter and 6-month included a special credit of $112.3 million from the sale of 40 percent of the business and net assets of its Eastern Steel division to Kawasaki Steel and $24.9 million from a pension curtailment gain. The latest second quarter and 6-month also included a restructuring charge of $40.4 million.

description: The Ford Motor Company announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement to purchase the Associates First Capital Corporation, a financial services company, from Paramount Communications Inc. for $3.35 billion in cash.

Whitney affiliate, pursuant to the merger agreement to acquire Prime, and additional related legal fees and other costs; and included a $1.5 million (3 cents a share) extraordinary gain, net of tax, related to the open market repurchase of $9.5 million face value of Computervision convertible debentures. Latest 6-month results also included pre-tax $6.3 million ($4.4 million after- tax, 9 cents a share) of expenses associated with MAI Basic Four's pending tender offer. title: The Helms Process
description: It looked like another Parade of Yahoos: Led by Senator Jesse Helms, the Senate Wednesday inveighed against ''obscene or indecent'' art. Shades of ''Madame Bovary'' or ''Tropic of Cancer'' or ''I Am Curious - Yellow.'' But the question here is harder than whether politicians should censor art. It's whether public funds should subsidize art that offends public taste.

The Ping of the Bat? Say It Ain't So
description: Efforts to marry baseball to modern times have served mainly to divorce the sport from the natural setting that gives it much of its charm -wind, sun, grass and sky. But just when purists surrender grudgingly to exploding scoreboards, artificial turf and domed stadiums, along comes news that the wooden bat may soon be wholly replaced by aluminum.

description: A 42-year-old Swedish drifter was convicted today of the murder of Prime Minister Olof Palme nearly three and a half years ago. He was sentenced to life in prison.

title: Prosecutor Faulted As Judge Overturns '76 Murder Verdict
description: A Federal judge threw out today a murder conviction from 1976, saying that prosecutors had systematically withheld evidence that could have cleared the defendant in the killing of a Newark police officer.

title: Chrysler to Cut $1 Billion in Costs
description: The Chrysler Corporation today announced sweeping cost reductions that it said would save $1 billion by the end of 1990, a move necessitated by its falling share of a declining auto market.

title: Penalty of $200,000 Is Proposed for Boeing
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has proposed a $200,000 fine against the Boeing Company on the ground that it did not immediately report faulty wiring of fire extinguishers on two 757-200 jets.

title: Bands on Double Bill
description: Sun Ra and his Arkestra, a big band, and the Loup Garou zydeco band are sharing a double bill tomorrow at 3 P.M. at the Central Park Band Shell, midpark at 72d Street, as part of the Summerstage series (860-1335). Admission is free.

title: House, 176-90, Votes to Scrap The Midgetman
description: The House of Representatives voted tonight to kill the Midgetman nuclear missile in a dramatic repudiation of a political compromise between the White House and Congressional leaders and a severe blow to President Bush's nuclear modernization program.

title: Trial Is Postponed
description: A Federal judge in Cincinnati agreed yesterday to postpone the start of trial on drug and tax charges of Thomas Gioiosa, a former housemate of Pete Rose. United States District Judge S. Arthur Spiegel issued the order to give Gioiosa's new lawyers time to prepare for trial, said Marianne Kuhn, an aide in Spiegel's chambers. Gioiosa's trial was to have started today, but has been postponed until Aug. 24.

title: 11-Year-Old Violinist
description: Gerard Schwarz is to conduct the Waterloo Festival Orchestra in Walter Piston's Sixth Symphony and Tchaikovsky's First Symphony (''Winter Dreams''), tomorrow evening at 8:30 at Waterloo Village, Stanhope, N.J., at Exit 25 on Interstate 80. The program also includes the Julius Conus Violin Concerto. The soloist is to be Leila Josefowicz, an 11-year-old student at the Colburn School of the Performing Arts in Los Angeles. Tickets are $18 to $10. Information and directions: 307-7171 or (201) 507-8900.

title: At the Movies
description: Pinteresque Pinter

title: Digital Income Down 21.9%; Sluggish U.S. Market Cited
description: Beset by slowing growth in the midrange computer market, the Digital Equipment Corporation said yesterday that its earnings fell 21.9 percent in its fourth quarter ended July 1.

title: G.M.A.C.'s 4-Year Notes Are Priced to Yield 8.42%
description: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation offered $400 million of four-year notes yesterday through an underwriting syndicate led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Art And Indecency
description: No doubt Senator Jesse Helms's effort to legislate art, prohibit ''indecent'' depictions and protect religion will not survive final Congressional action. But the real purpose of the Senate's most persistent yahoo will have been served; the damage to Federal patronage of the arts will have been done.

No. 2 U.S. Electric Ulitiy Names Heads for 5 Units
description: The American Electric Power Company, the nation's second-largest electric utility, named presidents yesterday for five operating companies in a major change of management.

title: H.U.D. and D'Amato: Hopes for Grants Prompted Gifts
description: In 1985, Bernard B. Brodsky recalls, he received a telephone call from the secretary of a high-ranking official in the New York office of the Department of Housing and Urban Development. It was a request, he said, from Alexander Naclerio's office that he buy a seat at a $1,000-a-person campaign fund-raising dinner for Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.

title: Opposite-Field Perfect Games in Men's and Women's Softball
description: Kathy Arendsen pitched the first perfect game ever in United States Olympic Festival women's softball today, then Peter Meredith threw one on the next field.

title: Long Island Woman, 20, Is Slain
description: A 20-year-old Long Island woman who had obtained a court order of protection against her 22-year-old husband was strangled in their home in Elmont early yesterday by her husband, who then surrendered, the Nassau County police said.

title: Northeast Utilities Bids For Owner of Seabrook
description: Northeast Utilities yesterday offered to buy the assets of the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, including its share of the Seabrook nuclear reactor, for $1.9 billion, and to limit rate increases to 5.5 percent a year for the first seven years. Northeast had bid for Public Service's nonnuclear assets, as had the New England Electric System.

title: National Healthcorp L.P. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings are in units.

title: Khashoggi's $10 Million Bail Is Upheld and He Is Released
description: Adnan M. Khashoggi, the Saudi financier charged with helping to defraud the Philippines treasury through illegal property dealings, posted $10 million bail yesterday and returned to his plush apartment on Fifth Avenue, describing his week in a jail in Manhattan as a sobering experience that turned him into a vegetarian.

title: Saluda Journal; At Silent Pool, Echoes of Racist Past
description: It was 93 degrees here today, a temperature that would normally bring out scores of children to splash and shout at the pool at the Saluda Swim and Tennis Club.

Ellan W. Young Marries James Grant
description: Ellan Windsor Young, a photojournalist, and James P. Grant, an Under Secretary General of the United Nations and the executive director of the United Nations Children's Fund in New York, were married yesterday by the Rev. Lee Reid, a Unitarian minister, at the Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., home of the bride.

title:
HARNESS RACING;
Trainer As Quick As Her Trotters
description: LEAD: Arlene Traub has one thing in common with her harness horses: quickness.

title: Restaurants
description: Like so many longtime Chanterelle enthusiasts, I hustled down to the restaurant's new TriBeCa home this spring, yearning to experience the luminous and pampering cooking of David Waltuck. In their first eight years as restaurateurs, the publicity-shy Wunderkind Waltucks (David is in the kitchen; Karen, his wife, tends the front) honed their 10-table act to four-star precision. To food-obsessed New Yorkers, their move to slightly larger quarters (15 tables) on Harrison Street after a four-month closing was the biggest boon to TriBeCa since the subway.

title: Candidates Get First Matching Funds
description: The New York City Campaign Finance Board distributed $817,758 in public funds yesterday to 26 candidates for offices ranging from mayor to City Council member, in what the board chairman called a ''historic day in the history of New York City politics.''

title: New Home For Giants Up to Voters
description: A settlement has been reached on the San Francisco Giants' proposed new 45,000-seat waterfront home and now it will be up to the voters in November to decide whether to welcome the stadium.

title: Meredith Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain of $10,801,000 from an accounting change. The company said in the latest fourth quarter it standardized its amortization for subscription expense related to its Kraftway publication. The adjustment contributed $1,125,000 to net income.

title: Review/Film; 'Gimli Hospital,' Mock Saga Of Iceland
description: What makes a movie qualify for midnight-cult status? Weirdness and eccentricity usually have something to do with it. And ''Tales From the Gimli Hospital,'' which plays Friday and Saturday nights at the Quad Cinema, is nothing if not weird and eccentric.

title: 75 Die in Libya in Korean DC-10 Crash
description: A Korean Air DC-10 with 199 people aboard crashed in heavy fog this morning short of the runway at Tripoli airport in Libya, hitting homes and cars and bursting into flames. At least 75 people were killed, including four on the ground, officials and news reports said.

title: New England Electric System reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss Year-ago second quarter included a charge of $179 million for a rate settlement agreement.

title: Murphy's Big Inning: 2 Homers and 6 R.B.I.
description: Dale Murphy tied two major league records by hitting two homers and driving in six runs in one inning tonight as the Atlanta Braves beat the San Francisco Giants, 10-1.

title: Helmsley Trial Is Given Details About 'A-File'
description: Leona M. Helmsley's former personal assistant testified yesterday that he discovered an important file in Mrs. Helmsley's desk drawer long after prosecutors had requested it as part of the investigation that led to her indictment on tax-fraud and extortion charges.

BHC Planning 37.9% Spinoff
description: BHC Inc., a company owned by Chris-Craft Industries and Warner Communications Inc., is likely to announce on Monday that it will spin off to shareholders the 37.9 percent stake held by Warner, industry executives said.

title: Max Hamburgh, Biologist, 67
description: Dr. Max Hamburgh, a biologist and educator, died of congestive heart failure Wednesday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 67 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Review/Art; One and a Half Decades Of Whitney Acquisitions
description: The two-part exhibition called ''Art in Place'' that opens tomorrow at the Whitney Museum of American Art is devoted entirely to works acquired by the museum in the last 15 years. During that time, the total number of works owned by the museum has risen more than fourfold - from around 2,000 to around 8,500.

title: Zycad Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Finks Defends Style
description: Jim Finks said yesterday that his candidacy for the National Football League commissioner's job has had no effect on his job as general manager of the New Orleans Saints. Agents for some of the eight unsigned New Orleans players - four veterans and four draft choices - have complained that Finks is taking a harder line on salaries because he knows the league is watching.

title: Nissan Workers in Tennessee Spurn Union's Bid
description: Workers at the Nissan car and truck assembly plant in Smyrna, Tenn., today overwhelmingly rejected representation by the United Auto Workers union. The U.A.W.'s defeat portends hard times for future union organizing efforts, as well as increasing competitive pressures between United States and Japanese automakers, labor experts said.

title: Hospitals, Minorities Take a Beating
description: LEAD: The family of a Hispanic boy in the South Bronx cannot afford to treat his severe asthma and, as a consequence, he requires emergency hospitalization. An elderly black man in rural North Carolina developed gangrene from an untreated foot infection, and he too is rushed to a hospital for emergency treatment.

Mr. Darman's Sermon
description: Japan's diplomats and industrialists are forever advising Americans that they must work harder. Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, in an interview with Time magazine, chides Americans for being interested in their rights rather than their duties. Even Richard Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, has joined in the scolding. He deplores the nation's feeble scale of investment, high consumption and ''self-indulgent theft from the future.'' Are these reproofs deserved?

title: Another 'Friday the 13th' Puts Jason in Times Square
description: If Jason, the hockey-masked killer, sauntered through Times Square, would anyone notice? Would he be even a little conspicuous on the subway? Of course not. And that's the arch premise ''Friday the 13th Part VIII - Jason Takes Manhattan'' is advertising. In a television commercial for the film, a teen-age couple rushes into a coffee shop and the young woman yells, ''There's a maniac trying to kill us!'' The waitress, who can spot tourists blocks away, drawls, ''Welcome to New Yawk.''

title: Review/Pop; Introducing A Measure of Spontaneity
description: The guitarist Bill Frisell opened his show with the sound of elongated steel country guitar, floating etherially. The band went into a country two-step. Slowly, the tune fragmented; the band members - a bassist, cellist and drummer - started taking the composition apart, acting independently, abstracting the tune, but arriving at pre-planned spots as if cued. Quiet, and mildly telepathic, it augered well for the rest of the set.

title: Review/Theater; A Soviet View of Chekhov Makes the Audience Voyeurs
description: Environmental theater depicting simulated brutality and degradation has a built-in limitation for an audience. As much as we are encouraged to imagine ourselves involved in the surrounding unpleasantness, we still know we are merely spectators who, barring an accident, will soon exit the scene unharmed. Even if we are yelled at, caressed and prodded to move around, we feel essentially safe.

Review/Music; Haydn and Mozart Together, A Study in Light and Dark
description: They are compatible companions on any concert program: mutual admirers in life and, in death, dual images of an entire musical epoch. Yet Haydn and Mozart - who shared Wednesday's Mostly Mozart concert at Avery Fisher Hall - are the difference between light and dark. The Haydn Symphonies Nos. 87 and 88 that began and ended this symphonic program under David Zinman return to the sunlight of the Baroque orchestra. In the first of these pieces, one heard an earlier era's general delight in high brass writing, a tendency imitated by the remarkable sopranolike wind choirs of the slow movement.

title: Behind Charter, Passion and Politics
description: The broad outlines for a new municipal government have not changed significantly since the New York City Charter Revision Commission approved its preliminary plan last May. RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Two Share Lead: Hal Sutton and Doug Tewell shared the lead yesterday after the second round of the Buick Open in Grand Blanc, Mich. Tewell shot a six-under-par 66 and Sutton had a 68 over the 7,014-yard course at Warwick Hills, about 50 miles north of Detroit. They were tied at nine-under 135 after 36 holes. Leonard Thompson, the first-round leader, was a shot behind the two leaders, tied with Wayne Grady of Australia, Mark O'Meara and Joel Edwards. (AP) Casper Takes 2-Stroke Lead: Billy Casper of the United States led Bob Charles of New Zealand by two strokes yesterday at the halfway mark of the British Seniors Open tournament at Turnberry, Scotland. Casper shot a 69 for a four-under-par 136 on the 6,480-yard Ailsa course. Charles was the only other player under par, at 138. He shot a 68.(AP) TENNIS Mayotte Gains: Top-seeded Tim Mayotte surrendered only nine points on his serve yesterday in a 6-3, 6-3 victory over Simon Youl of Australia, and advanced to the semifinals of the Sovran Bank Classic in Washington. Mayotte, ranked No. 11 in the world, won five of his nine service games at love in disposing of Youl in 74 minutes. He will face Todd Witsken, who beat Jim Grabb, 4-6, 7-6, 6-3. (AP) Sanchez and Cane to Semifinals: Second-seeded Emilio Sanchez of Spain and fifth-seeded Paolo Cane of Italy won their quarterfinal matches yesterday in the Netherlands grand prix tournament in Hilversum. Sanchez beat Franco Davin of Argentina, 6-7, 6-2, 6-3, and Cane beat third-seeded Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union, 7-5, 1-6, 6-4.(AP) Woehrmann Advances: Jens Woehrmann of West Germany defeated Guillermo Perez-Roldan of Argentina, 6-3, 6-3, yesterday in the quarterfinals of the Stuttgart grand prix tournament in West Germany. In other quarterfinal matches, Martin Jaite of Argentina beat Jordi Arrese of Spain, 3-6, 7-5, 6-4, and Goran Prpic of Yugoslavia beat Alex Antonitsch of Austria, 7-6, 6-7, 6-3.(AP) Olympic Festival No Record for Weight Lifter: Karyn Marshall thought so much about setting a world record that it hurt her performance at the United States Olympic Festival yesterday in Oklahoma City. Marshall won the heavyweight division in women's weight lifting with a total of 507 pounds, but the resident of Pelham, N.Y., had hoped to lift at least 44 more pounds. ''My problem is I think too much,'' said Marshall, a financial analyst on Wall Street. ''I didn't give it my full concentration.''

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Summer Crustaceans
description: Better fishing conditions in summer make lobsters easier to trap, bringing prices down. Finding one-pounders at $4 each is common at many seaside areas in the Northeast. Lobsters in the 1 1/2- to 3-pound range fetch premium prices, around $6 a pound. Larger specimens sell for less, sometimes as little as $3.50 a pound. Large lobsters can be as succulent as small ones. Have a hammer on hand for cracking heavy claws. Be sure the lobster you buy is alive. Some people prefer female lobsters because of the coral, or roe, which can be eaten plain or used to enrich sauces. Female lobsters have a broader tail shell than males do. Although lobsters can be boiled or broiled, steaming is more convenient. Do not overcook. Bring a couple of inches of water to a boil in a large pot. Add the lobster, cover and calculate the cooking time. Before serving, slit the tail and crack the claws to allow excess fluid to drain out. Here is a guide for steaming lobsters: Weight of lobster Cooking time Number of servings 1-1 1/4 pounds 10 minutes 1/2 to 1 1 1/2-2 pounds 15-18 minutes 1 2 1/2-5 pounds 20-25 minutes 1-2 6-10 pounds 25-35 minutes 3-5

title: THE EIGHT CASES UNDER INVESTIGATION
description: The yearlong investigation of the Internal Revenue Service by the House Government Operations Committee's Subcommitte on Commerce, Consumer and Monetary Affair's has focused on eight cases in which I.R.S. officials were accused of misconduct or violations of ethical standards. Three cases involve Ronald Saranow, the former hed of the I.R.S's criminal investigation division in Los Angeles: California Case I: Most attention has focused on Mr. Saranow and a legal battle between two big blue-jeans manufacturers, Jordache Enterprises and Guess Inc. According to testimony, the owners of Guess - the Marciano brothers - approached Mr. Saranow with information alleging tax and customs fraud by Jordache, their business partners and co-owners of Guess. Mr. Saranow pursued an aggresive two-year investigtion of Jordache without turning up any criminal violation. Testimony was given that the Marcianos repeatedly entertained Mr.Saranow and offered him a job with Guess. At issue is whether Mr.Saranow's relationship with the Marcianos should have disqualified him from any association with the Jordache case and whether he improperly used I.R.S. power on behalf of the Marciano family in its struggle for control of Guess. California Case II: Mr Saranow in 1986 tried to interfere with a Justice Department investigatin of a former I.R.S. employee whose lawyer was a friend of Mr. Saranow, according to testimony. Califronia Case III: Mr. Saranow is accused of setting up an unauthorized system by which clients of a lawyer friend could pay overdue taxes to the agency and be recorded as having paid on time. National Office Case: An assistant commissioner for criminal investigation in Washington was charged with routing many of his trips through Atlanta to visit a girlfriend, without fully reimbursing the agency for that travel. The panel found that agency officals had been reluctant to discipline the official. Central Region Case I: The agency's chief of investigations in its Central Region, based in Cleveland, was accused of taking an I.R.S. undercover boat for personal use in 1985. Central Region Case II: The same Cleveland investigator was also reported to have been stopped for speeding and driving while intoxicated when using an agency undercover car. The Duncan Case: I.R.S. attorneys are said to have told a former I.R.S. criminal investigator, William Duncan, who had complained about the slowness of a Justice Department narcotics case in Arkansas, not to give an opinion on the Justice Department's handling of the case and to ''deny the existence of information that had been reported to him concerning the alleged bribe of a high Government offical.'' The Chicago Case: A Chicago I.R.S. supervisor is accused of providing tax information to a delinquent taxpayer and accepting gratuities from the taxpayer, who owed the Government $400,000 in unpaid employment taxes.

title: NONFICTION
description: FIRE & FEAR: The Inside Story of Mike Tyson. By Jose Torres. (Warner Books, $16.95.) The prepublication hoo-ha surrounding ''Fire & Fear'' - concerning the heavyweight boxing champion Mike Tyson's alleged pleasure in beating his sex partners, especially his former wife, the actress Robin Givens - focuses on but a throwaway passage in this otherwise insightful book about the brutishness of the modern professional boxing game and those who are drawn to it. The author, Jose Torres, was a world light-heavyweight champion, the chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission and an early confidant of Mr. Tyson's. The story is ostensibly Mr. Tyson's, but in many ways it is that of Mr. Torres. There is little new information about the fighter's wretched childhood in a Brooklyn ghetto, his boxing education by the legendary trainer Cus D'Amato and subsequent fights in and out of the ring on his way to the top of the roughest hill in professional sports. Those looking for details about the fine art of boxing and about Mr. Tyson's sexual encounters will be disappointed. Both are mentioned, but only in relation to what Mr. Torres sees as the more important component of boxing, the psyche. Mr. Torres strips down the action of brawls in the ring, the bedroom and the promoters' offices to a series of one-on-one confrontations in which only the most adept with tongue, fists and guile prevail. Mr. Torres cites Mr. Tyson's meanest streaks as most necessary for a fighter. ''I used to make it my business to be a mean, ruthless bastard,'' the author quotes Mr. Tyson as saying. ''I knew I had to be mean because if I lose, I'm going to die, to starve to death.'' Seen in this context, even the seemingly most irrational acts of Mr. Tyson's recent years now appear quite a bit more understandable.

title: Hers; A Wake-Up Call

I am used to it; in fact, Ted Koppel's intelligent-sounding voice has become my adult lullaby. But last night, I was awakened by a voice talking about where to hide missiles. The voice was describing silos, underground tracks. It made frequent mention of the word ''enemy.''

title: HOME CLINIC
description: CASEMENT windows, which open and close by pivoting on hinges, generally develop fewer problems than double-hung windows, whose two sashes slide in channels. But casement windows can become hard to close because of insufficient lubrication, dirt-clogged parts, or a worn crank. Usually, casement windows are easy to repair and can be done from inside.

title: Jephtha Tausig, a Graduate Student, Wed to David Edwards, an Executive
description: Jephtha Tausig, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hans E. Tausig of New York and Nantucket, Mass., was married yesterday to David Say Edwards, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George D. Edwards of New York, at Tarrytown House in Tarrytown, N.Y. The Rev. Julie Parker, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony. Fiona McKenzie was the maid of honor and Simon Metz was the best man. Mrs. Tausig-Edwards, 25 years old, graduated from New York University and is studying there for a master's degree in psychology. Her father, who retired as the president of Nantucket Navigation Inc., an ocean-freight contractor in Stamford, Conn., is the president of the Violin Society of America, an organization of performing artists, makers and collectors of stringed instruments. Her mother, Eva-Marie F. Tausig, is the president of the Nantucket Musical Arts Society, which sponsors concerts in Nantucket, and the vice president of the National Dance Institute, which offers dances classes for children in the New York area.

title: BRITS BUY UP THE AD BUSINESS

As the buying and merging has increased, people who replicate others' work have been dismissed and a lot of heads have rolled. The hottest topic of discussion among creative people is whether to leave New York in order to stay in advertising or change careers to stay in New York.

description: Q. We had a parquet wood floor installed in two rooms over a year ago and are having trouble with tiles buckling. In one room the tongue-and-groove, 12-inch square tiles were put down over a plywood base and these tiles are O.K. In the other room the tiles were put down directly on a concrete slab (without an underlayment) and these tiles started to buckle across the width of the the room during the first summer. This buckling subsided during the winter. Will the buckling subside in time, and would it help if we weighted the tiles down?

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: FOR TV, IT'S OUT OF THE TUXEDO AND BACK TO REALITY
description: Whether by chance or calculation, television series often provide remarkable reflections of the real world. Program forms, from situation comedies to action adventures, may remain the same, but content is always being adjusted to fit the changing times. As Nancy Reagan's glittering gowns gave way to Barbara Bush's sensible shoes, so ''Dynasty'' is about to be replaced by less upscale, possibly even gentler diversions. The shift in tone can surely be detected this fall in ABC's willingness to back a new series, ''Life Goes On,'' that has a retarded teen-ager role filled by a young man who was born with Down's syndrome. Why now? ABC insists it is only because this is a good family drama. Then, CBS has ''Peaceable Kingdom,'' starring Lindsay Wagner and set in a Los Angeles zoo. Environmental concerns and threats of species extinctions move to center stage on prime time. And at least one hourlong drama series, ''Wolf,'' also on CBS, will be offering the new kind of sensitive tough-guy hero who is evidently a role model of the 1990's. The message is clear: Rambo, get lost.

title: The Tragedy Of Pete Rose
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: A Summer Job at Tass

title: Rhubarb: Baked, Frothed And 298 Other Ways
description: THEY are known as the Rhubarb Ladies. It started one April afternoon in 1987, when Rose Marie Fowler brought in a freshly baked rhubarb cake to share with her co-workers at Mansfield Town Hall. It was then that the idea of a rhubarb cookbook was born.

title: DAN QUAYLE AND ALLAN BLOOM
description: Maureen Dowd's article ''The Education of Dan Quayle'' (June 25) did little to reassure those of us uneasy with the plummeting caliber of many of our elected officials. But more disturbing to me than the Vice President's need for intensive on-the-job tutoring was the faculty hired to train him. William Kristol, the chief of staff, and Carnes Lord, Mr. Quayle's adviser on national security issues, both are disciples of the philosopher Leo Strauss, whose ideas were widely popularized by Allan Bloom in ''The Closing of the American Mind.'' Indeed, it is not a little ironic that the Straussians, with their elitist convictions, puffery about intellectual rigor and hand-wringing rhetoric about the loss of virtue (in the classical sense, please) in modern society, have found an opening through Dan Quayle.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: The sight is not an uncommon one, especially at one of those big-city cocktail parties that tend to be impersonal even when they're given by individuals. Somewhere in the room, there's an attractive young single woman, perhaps new to the city and invited along with one of the guests, a young woman who has made it her business to gravitate to a group of men. No doubt about it, the men are obviously charmed. But, as happens at these things, the group gradually breaks up. Follow the young woman's movements as the evening progresses, and darned if the same thing doesn't happen again and again. All the charm, and there is plenty of it, is spent on men. If she's introduced to a woman or if another woman joins the group, she's polite and pleasant, there's a perfunctory smile, but the effort isn't the same, the personality doesn't fizz to the same degree.

title: The Earth Comes First
description: Some criticized President Bush's pledge to establish a Moon colony and a manned flight to Mars for lacking specifics about dates and money. But the real trouble is the idea itself.

title: THE DISSERTATION THAT WOULD NOT DIE
description: THE GREAT CHALLENGE The Myth of Laissez-Faire in the Early Republic. By Frank Bourgin. Foreword by Arthur Schlesinger Jr. 223 pp. New York: George Braziller. $22.50.

title: Question Of the Week; Are Yanks Making The Right Moves?
description: The Yankees are making all of the wrong moves. A team is a well-ordered array of complementary players who fit together nicely like the pieces of a good puzzle. With the death of Munson and the trading away or abandonment of Rivers, Gossage, Lyle, Chambliss, Nettles, Jackson, and the two last casualties, Randolph and Guidry, the Yankees have lost their team. JAMES J. MELLONE Brooklyn

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales

description: Pamela Schneider found something amiss amid the usual vigorous clatter of crockery and cutlery that accompanies meals at summer camps.

description: AS the Chestnut Hill Concert Series prepares for its 20th anniversary season, it does so with new executive and music directors.

description: LEAD: REAL PRESENCES By George Steiner. 236 pp. Illinois: The University of Chicago Press. $19.95.

description: The Mets may have spiraled from disaster to downfall today when they tried to sneak the rookie pitcher Wally Whitehurst past the galloping Chicago Cubs and did not survive.

title: POSTINGS: A Time to Invest; East Meets West
description: The climate for real estate investment in New York City for Asians has never been better, according to Heo-Peh Lee, who retired from Baruch College as a professor of library science a decade ago to become a developer and has prospered. As evidence, Mr. Lee cited two Queens projects, the $12 million World Plaza office building in College Point that he and four Asian partners completed last month and a $12 million condominium that his company, Shie Jie Construction, is to undertake next fall in Astoria.

title: Carrie Gottlieb Weds E. R. Silverman
description: Carrie Faith Gottlieb, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Gottlieb of Hollis, Queens, and Boca Raton, Fla., was married last evening at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, L.I., to Edward Ralph Silverman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Silverman of Baldwin Harbor, L.I. Rabbi Myron Fenster performed the ceremony.

title: Don't Minimize Government Terror in Salvador; Independent Leftists
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: The Circus on Bloch's Block

title: In a House In Stamford, The Bond Is Illness
description: LEAD: DAVID L. HENRY was sitting on his porch and could see the passers-by who crossed to the other side of the street when they approached his house. ''People do have a tendency to do that,'' Mr. Henry said. ''I think it's ignorant. You can't catch it from a house.''

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: LOUDON, N.H.;
Homes Priced To Move
description: LEAD: MANUFACTURED homes in a planned development of 180 units are selling briskly here despite a sluggish housing market in the area around Concord, the state capital. A major reason is that the prices - $77,000 to $85,000 - are a third less than the average for the area.

title: What Exxon Will Be Leaving Behind
description: AFTER the Valdez oil spill off the coast of Alaska last March, Exxon promised to do something that many environmentalists said was impossible: clean 11 million gallons of oil from hundreds of miles of shoreline and thousands of square miles of water. Last week, the company seemed well on its way to accomplishing something that might seem equally improbable: spending $1.25 billion on the cleanup, or about $10 million a day, while making hardly anyone happy.

title: A Token Indian Pullout Begins in Sri Lanka
description: Some 600 Indian soldiers boarded a troop carrier for Madras today, accomplishing a symbolic troop withdrawal that has largely defused a diplomatic crisis between Colombo and New Delhi.

title: AIRBORNE DRUG WAR IS AT A STALEMATE
description: An intensified campaign to intercept private planes flying illegal drugs into the southeastern United States has blocked some drug traffic and seized many drugs, Federal officials say.

title: Ship to Shore, His Beat Is the Hudson
description: As a policeman, Ronald Bosela has an unusual beat - the Hudson River.

title: An Abandoned Station Inspires a Literary Quest
description: LEAD: AN ambitious group of residents here is using both rhyme and reason in an effort to reclaim the abandoned Philipse Manor train station.

title: Lawyer Engaged To Miss Emmons
description: Elizabeth Brooks Emmons and Terrence Michael Dunn, lawyers in New York, plan to marry in August, Miss Emmons's parents, Diane Neal Emmons of Manchester, Mass., and Robert W. Emmons Jr. of Annisquam, Mass., have announced. Mr. Dunn is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Dunn of Mountain Lakes, N.J.

title: There's H.U.D. Where's Justice?
description: In a brief letter, the Justice Department has informed the Department of Housing and Urban Development that it has decided not to prosecute Thomas Demery, a former Assistant Secretary implicated in the influence-peddling at H.U.D.

title: Repairing Casement Windows
description: CASEMENT windows, which open and close by pivoting on hinges, generally develop fewer problems than double-hung windows, whose two sashes slide in channels. But casement windows can become hard to close because of insufficient lubrication, dirt-clogged parts, or a worn crank. Usually, casement windows are easy to repair and can be done from inside.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Brunch; Summery Tomatoes With Fish
description: At this time of year it's impossible to find enough ways to use the sweetly acidic tomatoes of summer. The tomato cilantro vinaigrette would be excellent with any strong-flavored fish and, if your tastes run to oily fish like mackerel or bluefish, it provides a refreshing foil.

title: Dukakis, Waging New Fight, Stays Optimistic
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts is on the stump again.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: RUNNING THE AMAZON. By Joe Kane. (Knopf, $19.95.) When Joe Kane, a San Francisco journalist, learned about a proposed expedition to navigate the entire length of the Amazon, he was incredulous: ''Man had golfed on the moon but had yet to travel his planet's most famous river from source to sea?'' Six months and 4,200 watery miles - or more precisely, three million paddle strokes - later, Mr.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on July 16 about the Valhalla Wagnerfest organization misidentified an associate conductor at the Metropolitan Opera. He is Walter Taussig.

title: D. J. Heimerdinger Weds Evelyn Vance
description: Evelyn Ellis Vance, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roger P. Vance of Ann Arbor, Mich., was married there yesterday to Dr. Daniel John Heimerdinger, a son of John F. Heimerdinger of Armonk and Lake Placid, N.Y., and the late Suzanne Heimerdinger. The Rev. Stephen Murray officiated at the Westminster Presbyterian Church.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
The Import of the New Impact-Fee Law
description: LEAD: AFTER nearly three years of debate, the State Legislature passed and Gov. Thomas H. Kean signed into law last month a bill letting counties or municipalities impose traffic impact fees on developers of new commercial and residential projects.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: White Marsh, Md.;
From Sand Pits To Boom Area
description: LEAD: A 150-ROOM business-class motor inn is part of the $40 million in commercial construction under way in the town center of White Marsh, one of the most active areas of development in Baltimore County.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Arizona State; Buying Cigarettes Will Now Require A Trip Off Campus
description: All 18 cigarette vending machines on the campus at Arizona State University will be removed beginning in mid-August, in line with an order from the University's outgoing president and a recommendation by the faculty senate.

title: The Author's Silence
description: To the Editor:

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Hotels in Lower Manhattan; Deals Proliferate in a New Frontier for the Industry
description: DEVELOPERS with both patience and access to money are beginning to bet on a renaissance in the hotel business in lower Manhattan, a boom that has been widely forecast for more than a decade and has not occurred.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article on July 9 about the anniversary of the French Revolution misstated the length of the presidential term in the Fifth Republic. It is seven years.

title: Historians Old and New
description: To the Editor:

description: A potent mix of personal and bureaucratic ambitions is driving the Bush Administration to undertake a major expansion of manned exploration of the solar system, Government officials and private experts say.

description: To the Editor:

title: Question Of the Week; Are Yanks Making The Right Moves?
description: The Yankees started in the right direction when they changed the front office. Thrift and Green are obtaining the elements that characterize a contender: pitching depth and strength up the middle. The Yankees obviously are still developing the former. Terrell will be a plus.
