description: To the Editor:

title: Tyranny of The Avant-Garde
description: Two recent articles about the issues raised by the cancellation of the Robert Mapplethorpe photography exhibit at the Corcoran Gallery in Washington - Hilton Kramer's ''Is Art Above the Laws of Decency? (July 2) and Grace Glueck's ''Art on the Firing Line'' (July 9) - have prompted an unusually large number of letters from readers. Here is a sampling. To the Editor: Mr. Kramer certainly performed a marvelous public service.

title: Barbara Becker To Wed in Fall
description: Barbara Lynn Becker's engagement to Todd David Gardner, the son of Jane Whitelaw Mason of Port Washington, L.I., has been announced by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Melvin H. Becker of Manhasset, L.I. A November wedding is planned.

title: Staying With Realism, Doing Just Fine
description: LEAD: WHEN asked recently why she had become a representational painter while others in the New York School during the 1940's and 50's were exploring Abstract Expressionism, Jane Freilicher was quoted as saying: ''I paint the way I do because I have no imagination.''

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Was The Samuel Trade Good For Mets?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: A Romp Through The Laws of Logic
description: Two recent articles about the issues raised by the cancellation of the Robert Mapplethorpe photography exhibit at the Corcoran Gallery in Washington - Hilton Kramer's ''Is Art Above the Laws of Decency? (July 2) and Grace Glueck's ''Art on the Firing Line'' (July 9) - have prompted an unusually large number of letters from readers. Here is a sampling. To the Editor: Hilton Kramer's article was an amusing romp through the laws of logic. Though he elaborates on the most obscure aspects of this issue, the basics have eluded him. In a republican form of government, he who pays the piper does not call the tune. Logically, this should no more obtain with paying for the arts than with the disposition of tax dollars for defense or social programs. STEVEN B. HARVEY Chicago

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD: FOLK LEGENDS

title: A $12 Billion Merger In Pharmaceuticals
description: A new pharmaceuticals giant will be formed by a merger of Bristol-Myers and Squibb. The $12 billion deal will create the world's second-largest drug maker, with combined annual sales of more than $9 billion. Bristol-Myers makes Excedrin pain relievers and Clairol beauty aids. Squibb is known for its reasearch and some big-selling prescription drugs, like Capoten, a heart drug. Each Squibb share is to be exchanged for 2.4 Bristol-Myers shares. Squibb shares rose $24.75, or 28 percent, the day of the announcement, to $112.50. Bristol-Myers stock fell $2.375, to $49.50. Richard L. Gelb, the chairman of Bristol, will be chairman of the new company; Richard M. Furlaud, chairman of Squibb, will be president. *

title: Optimism on the Hastings Waterfront
description: LEAD: THE proverbial man in the street wants it, the woman in the Mayor's office wants it and the builder in Manhattan wants it. Maybe this time the dilapidated, underused but spectacular waterfront here will be rebuilt. The proposed residential-commercial building complex is tentatively known as the Harbor at Hastings project.

title: Spain Is Target For U.S. Fencer
description: Robert Cottingham remembers returning from the Olympics in Seoul, South Korea, last October, exhilirated at having helped the United States men's fencing team to a seventh-place finish.

title:
GARDENING;
Day Lilies Offer Beauty With Little Care
description: LEAD: IT is not uncommon to come across patches of tawny day lily growing along the road or in an old fence row in the Northeast or the Midwest. This prolific plant thrives under conditions that would make most other perennials extinct.

title: GERMANY AND THE WALL
description: In his article ''If the Wall Came Tumbling Down'' (June 25), Peter Schneider concludes that, as Dr. Strangelove might say, we should ''stop worrying and love the wall.'' Mr. Schneider would direct our energies, instead, to pressuring for improvements in the human rights of East Germans.

title: My Dinner With Heathcliff
description: LEAD: The most significant thing that happened to me in 1939 was that I saw ''Wuthering Heights'' and fell in love with Laurence Olivier.

title: Jacqueline Laura Tobey Has Wedding
description: Jacqueline Laura Tobey and Bruce David Gevertz, 1983 graduates of Middlebury College, were married last evening at Harrison House in Glen Cove, L.I. Rabbi Jack Stern Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: NONFICTION
description: THE EARTH IS ENOUGH: Growing Up in a World of Trout & Old Men. By Harry Middleton. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) Harry Middleton was an Army brat in his early teens when his father decided he needed ''a drastic change of scenery'' and sent him away to stay with his mother's people in the Ozark Mountains of Arkansas. Mr. Middleton, now a veteran nature writer and outdoor columnist for Southern Living magazine, found not only the wellsprings of his nature but his future profession during his short stay there with three contented, dignified old men, his grandfather and great-uncle and their friend, a World War I veteran. ''Only here in these mountains, here with these old men, amid the creek, the trout, the natural world, had I ever ceased to feel alone.'' The old men and the dog who expected and got his full participation in their lives and deaths were shortly gone, and so was their seductive life style - working their hardscrabble farm just enough to give themselves time for their real business, fishing and hunting the quarry they held in mystic reverence, reveling in the possibilities of wildness and the unity of all living things, spending cold fall nights on the roof wrapped in blankets to see the wild geese go south, reading and philosophizing. Though some of the stories are surely apocryphal, ''The Earth Is Enough'' is a satisfying memoir that overcomes an awkward start to build to real emotional impact. And Mr. Middleton's tone of wounded irony when speaking of his family is a striking counterpoint to his soaring lyricism in his descriptions of nature, ''a mystery, fascinating, soothing, damning, ruthless.''

title: Homecoming
description: To the Editor: One is thankful for the many visitors from other ethnic backgrounds whose sensitive response to things Italian more than makes up for the obtuseness of most of one's fellow Italians. Under the shock of discovering that their fathers were not born in a palace or in a split level, they are known to flee in despair not just from the ancestral huts but from the uneven pavement of Piazza San Marco, from the stinking Venetian canals and the oppressive Roman forum, eager only to take refuge in Ozone Park or Scranton or Bridgeport, where they can go back to basking in their own total Americanness.

title: POSTINGS: Priced Up to $1.1 Million; Old Farm, New Crop
description: A subdivision of expensive homes is sprouting from a onetime grain-and-fruit farm in Holmdel, N.J., a property that also is the site of the oldest medical building in Monmouth County. Twelve homes of 80 that are planned for the 155-acre site have already been built this year on the grounds of the so-called Cooke farm on McCampbell Road.

title: Question Of the Week; Are Yanks Making The Right Moves?
description: For the past decade, the Yankees have shown an incredible lack of patience with their young talent. A list of the young pitchers whom the Yankees have given up on is far too extensive to list here. Another mediocre pitcher is simply a mistake. DAVID M. LUBLINER New York

title: Young Athletes' Hunt for Gold Is Under Way
description: Since its creation in 1978, the United States Olympic Festival, despite occasional problems and internal conflicts, has remained true to its mission of being a springboard for the nation's best amateur athletes. In the 11 years since, practically all of the nation's Olympians have competed in a festival and many achieved their first fame before festival crowds.

title: Spending Pennziol's Billions
description: It is 15 months and counting since the Pennzoil Company's cash accounts first swelled with $3 billion wired from Texaco Inc., the huge settlement that ended their tangled legal dispute over Texaco's purchase of the Getty Oil Company. Now, Wall Street can hear the clock ticking as J. Hugh Liedtke, Pennzoil's 67-year-old chairman, decides whether to put the money into oil and gas reserves by the end of 1990.

title: 'Tailgate Terrorists': Other Views
description: What Terence M. Ripmaster describes in his article is indeed a frightening experience, which I am sure many motorists have shared. But permit me an observation he may have overlooked: a high percentage of those terrorists are young women, between 18 and 25 years of age.

title:
MUSIC;
A Very Busy Woman Helps Opera Expand
description: LEAD: WHEN Era M. Tognoli founded the Metro Lyric Opera Company in 1959, she saw a great need and audience demand for opera in the Asbury Park area. The company was, and to a large extent still is, a one-woman show, but its audience has grown to include a wide area in the state, and next season it will give its first out-of-state performance.

title: Lebanese Group Rejects Trade for Abducted Sheik
description: A senior official of the Party of God today dismissed speculation that it would exchange Israeli soldiers for an official of the group abducted by Israeli commandos on Friday.

title:
FOCUS;
Chinese Quietly Entering the U.S. Housing Market
description: LEAD: By most measures, Lantana Lakes resembles many other middle-class subdivisions springing up here. Three lakes cover large parts of the 107-acre parcel, giving many home sites both waterfront and drainage. The 42 houses, with seven more under construction, are frame with brick trim and offer standard features like two-car garages, skylights and built-in appliances.

title: H.U.D., Wright, Meese: To the Public, It's All The Same Network
description: OUT in the country there is a pervasive sense that something has gone badly awry here. Politicians and pollsters are finding that the public mood toward Washington is about as sour as it has ever been. But they are finding, too, that it is an undifferentiated mistrust. James Watt . . . H.U.D. . . . Jim Wright . . . Ed Meese . . . Iran-contra . . . Ollie North . . . Tony Coelho. The scandals blur together.

title: His Day in Court
description: When it broke in 1983, the children molesting case involving the McMartin preschool in Manhattan Beach, Calif., touched off a national uproar. Last week, two years and three months after the beginning of what is said to be the nation's longest criminal trial, the chief defendant, Raymond Buckey, finally took the witness stand in his own defense. He testified that he never sexually abused children at the school, which was founded by his mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, another defendant.

title: WHO NEEDS RESPECTABILITY?
description: TO REACH ETERNITY The Letters of James Jones. Edited by George Hendrick. Foreword by William Styron. Illustrated. 380 pp. New York: Random House. $22.50.

title: Black Comedy for a Conformist Era
description: Michael Lehmann's black comedy HEATHERS (1989, New World Video, $89.95) is the most incisive movie in years to examine the heartless social rites of the modern suburban high school. Ruling the roost at posh Westerburg High is a quartet of snooty beauties, three of whom happen to be named Heather. When Veronica (Winona Ryder), the clique's rebellious fourth member, begins collaborating with J. D. (Christian Slater), a gun-toting bohemian loner, in a series of lethal pranks, Westerburg High's superstars begin dying off in what appears to be an epidemic of suicides.

title: FASHION: On the Street; Just for Fun: Summer Hats
description: The summer hat means portable shade and a special opportunity to be whimsical. History shows that the hat was designed to protect and to display social position and wealth. Then it became an integral part of fashion. And then it all but disappeared. But hats are being worn again, especially in summer, and often just for fun.

title: Queens Waterfront Plan Gets a Push
description: An ambitious and long-delayed $2 billion development plan for the Hunter's Point waterfront in Queens gained momentum last week when New York State's Urban Development Corporation agreed to join the project.

title: After Victory, Japan Leftists Face Scrutiny
description: Would Asia's greatest bulwark of anti-Communism consider dismantling its military forces? Could a nation renowned as the world's greatest success story for private enterprise turn socialist?

title: Where Crusaders Camped in Turkey
description: ON their way to the Holy Land, the medieval soldiers, pilgrims, priests and nobles of the Crusades left behind them trails of settlement and plunder and awestruck accounts of the rich empires of the eastern Mediterranean. Although Jerusalem was the ultimate object of their voyaging, over the centuries many Crusader armies carved out principalities far from the Levant proper. Thus the numerous countries and fiefdoms of the Peleponnesus, the Aegean, Cyprus, Rhodes and, in a daring act of brigandage, Constantinople, were established.

title: Arrival of Two Canada Geese Recalls The Days of Clovis and Cicero
description: AT 5:30 one April morning, distracted by honking and the sound of wings flapping on water, I pulled up the shade. Our resident mallards, Figaro and Susanna, who had arrived on schedule weeks ago, were floating on the sidelines of the pond, still as decoys. Their eyes were focused on two great Canada geese, the size of floor pillows, who had landed on the water and were cruising, necks held aloft, with an air of satisfaction.

title: Luxury Features In Midprice Decks
description: Cassettes, it is widely unremarked, are by far the world's most popular music medium. Avid audio fans turn their attention to hotter topics, such as technical disputes about digital decoding, or the seemingly endless political tangles of DAT (digital audio tape) that have kept this superior method of home recording from gaining a foothold in this country. These timely preoccupations obscure the fact that for most listeners, cassettes remain the primary source of recorded music.

title: ANTI-CRIME MOVES WIN WIDE BACKING
description: Frustrated by what they perceive as an increase in crime nationally because of the spread of drugs, Americans favor broad anti-crime measures, a new survey to be published tomorrow by The National Law Journal shows.

title: Food; Skillet Skills
description: I had recently arrived in this country from Barcelona and was about to go with friends on my first camping trip. We spent days shopping for the right equipment: a pup tent that we'd use for a kitchen, a butane stove and a camping toaster, among other things. After setting out, we saw several signs for tag sales, a concept we foreigners couldn't understand. We decided to stop and have a look.

title: U.S. Regatta Team Has Foreign Flavor
description: A last-ditch effort to put together a United States sailing team for the Admiral's Cup regatta in Britain required yachtsmen to charter two Australian boats and half their crews. Despite the unusual approach, experts say the idea could work.

title: DATA BANK: July 30, 1989
Claire Margaret Noumair, a Teacher, Weds Gerald Smith, a Naval Architect
description: Claire Margaret Noumair, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George J. Noumair of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, and Deal, N.J., was married yesterday in Deal to Gerald Dennis Smith, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Smith of San Jose, Calif. The ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church was performed by the Rev. Richard R. Sweeny, assisted by Msgr. Francis X. Mulhall. Kathryn N. Cotter was her sister's matron of honor, and James N. Smith was his brother's best man.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an essay on July 16 about writers and space travel, ''One Small Shelf for Literature,'' misidentified Ronald Weber. He is the author of ''Seeing Earth: Literary Responses to Space Exploration,'' not its editor.

title: Women Organize PAC To Build Political Clout
description: LEAD: A NEW political action committee raised $10,000 in its first two days with this message: Women must use their checkbooks to gain more say in government.

title: Restaurant Sought for Playland Site
description: LEAD: THE county is looking for an entrepreneur to create a first-class restaurant with a nautical theme that would overlook Long Island Sound from the bathhouse of Playland Park in Rye.

title: 3 Rescued From Sinking Boat
description: Three women were rescued from a disabled sailboat that sank in Long Island Sound, the police said today. Police said the 25-foot Seafarer sailboat broke its mast around 9 P.M. Friday about a mile north of the Long Island Lighting Company plant in Northport. Two officers in a police vessel took the boat in tow but it began to sink, said a police spokesman, Officer Robert Tooker. Grace Burtis, 61 years old, of Baldwin, Patricia Mahar, 51, of Bayport, and Nancy Hopkins, 46, of Centerport, abandoned the vessel and were picked up by the officers. Officer Tooker said Ms. Hopkins and Officer Joe Condon were taken to Huntington Hospital with minor injuries and released.

title: For Pestilence, Natural Controls
description: Now we read there is a fungus that is decimating gypsy-moth caterpillars. It is related to one native to Japan that was introduced here in 1910, but then ''the scientists lost track of it,'' according to officials in the Department of Agriculture, until it ''re-introduced'' itself this spring. But why the long lapse of scientific attention and research follow-through on a potential natural control?

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: IN THE FOREST AT MIDNIGHT. By Rita Pratt Smith. (Donald I. Fine, $18.95.) Like ''A Passage to India'' and ''The Jewel in the Crown,'' Rita Pratt Smith's first novel treats the sexual awakening of a prudent young English girl in 20th-century India. However, unlike its famous predecessors, ''In the Forest at Midnight'' is told from the young woman's point of view.

title: When Film Becomes a Feast of Words
description: Part of this memory is vague, and part exceptionally clear. Several years ago, in a ''Letter From Paris'' in The New Yorker, the journalist Jane Kramer made an offhand remark that seemed to hold an essential truth. The precise subject was so beside the point that it has faded from memory entirely, but the idea resurfaces any time a new Eric Rohmer film appears. ''The French have always adored intelligence,'' she wrote. ''They take the act of thinking to be something swashbuckling and erotic.''

title: 'Tailgate Terrorists': Other Views
description: Harrowing, indeed, were the experiences related by Terence M. Ripmaster in ''Those Tailgate Terrorists'' (Opinion page, July 2), but a careful reading of his terrifying tale raises the question of whether he brings it on himself.

title: Residential Resales

title:
Body and Mind;
Trojan Eggs
description: LEAD: IT SHOULD HAVE BEEN a quiet New Year's Eve party. A middle-aged couple in upstate New York bought two quarts of eggnog, cracked in an extra half-dozen eggs, added milk and spices, and invited a few friends to celebrate. The New Year was happily rung in - but within two days, seven of the nine revelers were wrung out with nausea, abdominal cramps, severe diarrhea and fever: all symptoms of food poisoning caused by salmonella bacteria.

title: Red Sox Blank Indians on 2-Hitter
description: Mike Smithson teamed with Rob Murphy for a two-hitter, and Nick Esasky hit a three-run homer today as the Boston Red Sox defeated the Cleveland Indians, 5-0.

title: The Fears That Pool Parties Stir
description: I MADE it halfway through the summer without one and thought I was safe, but then it happened. ''I'm having a pool party Saturday night,'' my friend Joan announced. ''This party will be really different, we are going to swim.'' ''Why?'' ''I am so tired of the pool parties where everyone eats, drinks and talks - everything but swim.''

title: Question Of the Week; Are Yanks Making The Right Moves?
description: The best move Syd Thrift can make would be to trade aging veterans such as Ken Phelps, Steve Balboni and Dale Mohorcic for some solid starting pitching. The Yankees also have some bright young pitching prospects in their Class AA farm system who may be ready for the big leagues soon. ANDREW S. FIEDELMAN New York

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
description: Westbrook, Conn. $155,000 268 Pond Meadow Road 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 12-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, unfinished 2d level, 0.75 acre; taxes $911. Old Lyme, Conn. $180,000 11 Whippoorwill Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 130-year-old farmhouse; garage workshop, 0.50 acre; taxes $1,220. Weston, Conn. $375,000 28 Godfrey Road West 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 21-year-old colonial; master bedroom with cathedral ceiling and skylights, new roof, 2 acres; taxes $4,165. title: THATCHER FAULTED FOR CABINET MOVES
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has been sharply criticized inside and outside the Government for her handling of the reorganization of her Cabinet, and politicians and commentators say she has weakened the authority of her senior ministers and her personal standing.

title: Governors Call for Spending To Prevent Economic Slide
description: The nation's governors warned today that the United States had taken its preeminent position in the world economy for granted and needed to spend more on transportation and education to keep itself from falling behind.

title: New Hints That East Bloc Got Japanese Equipment
description: A widening investigation into one of the biggest high-technology diversions in recent years has raised new fears that East Germany illegally obtained far more Japanese-made precision equipment for producing advanced computer chips than first believed, according to investigators in South Korea and Japan.

title:
DINING OUT;
A Trattoria With Some Updated Dishes
description: LEAD: CHUMMY neighborhood storefronts serving robust Italian-American fare are a New Jersey specialty. Just about everyone has a favorite spot to drop into for a casual, satisfying meal that is not a major investment in either time or money. A recent addition to the roster is Gerardo's, which opened five months ago in Franklin Lakes Plaza, a modest shopping strip in northwest Bergen

title: The Worst Over, Focus Shifts to Trees
description: LEAD: THE emergency crews from the utilities have gone. So have the owners of pickups who picked up extra money by clearing backyards of some of the wreckage caused by the tornadoes and thunderstorms that tore through Connecticut on July 10. Now it is time for the tree specialists who are being called in to deal with the heavier salvage and, in many cases, to make decisions of life or death.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Making Adjustments in a Slow Market
description: LEAD: WITHOUT the worry of having to sell a house first to be able to buy another, Maria and Joseph Schmidt, who are first-time home buyers, were among the first to purchase a town-house condominium at the 264-unit Highlands at Port Jefferson when sales opened in May.

title: The Ordinary Miracle
description: FOR nine months, my body was preparing another human being for life. For nine months, I was preparing myself for the ordinary miracle of birth. I made sugar a stranger, emasculated my daily cup of coffee by ordering decaffeinated, and blacklisted alcohol. I stopped working 12 hour days and learned to putter.

title: Too Easy a Win
description: Two recent articles about the issues raised by the cancellation of the Robert Mapplethorpe photography exhibit at the Corcoran Gallery in Washington - Hilton Kramer's ''Is Art Above the Laws of Decency? (July 2) and Grace Glueck's ''Art on the Firing Line'' (July 9) - have prompted an unusually large number of letters from readers. Here is a sampling. To the Editor: For the forces of reaction it was too easy a win: the Corcoran went down without firing a shot, handing victory to a few strident Congressional voices. THOMAS W. RUSSELL 3D

title: Derby Fare
description: To the Editor: I read with interest your piece on Derby-Pie (Travel, April 30) until I came to the part about bourbon. It would be difficult for the first bourbon to have been distilled ''in Kentucky in 1789.'' Kentucky did not become a state until 1792. Until that time Bourbon County was a part of Virginia.

title: CRIME
description: ''I never realized there was so much skulduggery in the museum trade,'' marvels the Los Angeles private eye Jacob Asch. In OTHER PEOPLE'S MONEY (Mysterious Press, $17.95), Arthur Lyons's savvy sleuth also discovers the criminal lengths to which some museum directors will go as they exercise their ''divine right to write checks for whatever they deem necessary'' to rescue international art treasures from destruction - or acquisition by other museum directors.

title: Correction
description: An article in some copies of the Sports section last Sunday about Jerry Jones, the new owner of the Dallas Cowboys, misstated the ranking of his college team in 1964. Alabama was considered No. 1 that year and Arkansas, for whom Mr. Jones played, was the runner-up.

title: Desperate, Latin Nations Discover the Free Market
description: IN Latin America, where governments of the right, left and center have long intervened in the economy, an intense new interest in the idea of the free market is growing.

title: Cape May Bed and Breakfast: Victorian Inns Are the Thing
description: LONG a visual feast for admirers of period houses, this southernmost New Jersey city has taken the lead nationally in the conversion of Victorian homes to bed and breakfast inns.

title: What Ever Happened to . . . ?
description: Two recent articles about the issues raised by the cancellation of the Robert Mapplethorpe photography exhibit at the Corcoran Gallery in Washington - Hilton Kramer's ''Is Art Above the Laws of Decency? (July 2) and Grace Glueck's ''Art on the Firing Line'' (July 9) - have prompted an unusually large number of letters from readers. Here is a sampling. To the Editor: Who but an art historian recognizes the names Bonnat, Rochegrosse, Cormon, Laurens - four superstars of government-supported painting in France in the late 19th century? Their work reflected the taste and highest ideals of the populace.

title: THE JOY OF FALLING
description: AN OLD MAN'S TOY Gravity at Work and Play in Einstein's Universe. By A. Zee. Illustrated. 272 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $21.95.

title: Felice Berkowitz Plans a Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Norman H. Berkowitz of Roslyn Heights, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Felice Sara Berkowitz, to Eric Paul Schmitt, a son of Anne G. Briggin of Belvedere, Calif., and Paul F. Schmitt of Novato, Calif. A September wedding is planned.

title:
THEATER;
It's a Wrap for the Adventurous Summerfare
description: LEAD: Christopher Hunt may feel a bit like Timon of Athens, Shakespeare's tragic, unappreciated hero, at the moment. For the last five years he has been director of Pepsico Summerfare, the internationally acclaimed performing arts festival in residence at the State University of New York at Purchase. Around 7:45 next Sunday evening, after the final notes of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony are sounded by the London Classical Players, Summerfare ceases to exist and the 51-year-old

title: Alice L. McKillop And C. S. Semler Engaged to Wed
description: Mrs. David H. McKillop of Washington and Old Lyme, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Alice Llewellyn McKillop, to Christopher Strong Semler, a son of Ralph Semler and Margot E. Semler, both of Washington and Blue Hill, Me. Miss McKillop is also the daughter of the late Mr. McKillop of Washington. The wedding is planned for next year.

title: Recycling
description: To the Editor:

title: Munich
description: To the Editor: ''What's Doing in Munich'' (Travel, June 4) was excellent, but, as in reports on Rome, Florence and Venice, you tell the reader about Europe on $500 a day per person, not how to enjoy it on $100 a day - a couple, as my wife and I always have managed. Especially in Munich you can eat excellently under $10 a person; just look for the crowded restaurants where the residents eat. Also the tourist offices in the main railroad station will give a visitor a selection of small hotels or pensions that are clean and fun. Walking through the country, especially the Bavarian mountain towns, the traveler will often see Zimmer frei signs - room for rent, which in most cases will pass critical inspection.

title: Old Boys' Club
description: Two recent articles about the issues raised by the cancellation of the Robert Mapplethorpe photography exhibit at the Corcoran Gallery in Washington - Hilton Kramer's ''Is Art Above the Laws of Decency? (July 2) and Grace Glueck's ''Art on the Firing Line'' (July 9) - have prompted an unusually large number of letters from readers. Here is a sampling. To the Editor: The brouhaha over the cancellation by the Corcoran Gallery of the Mapplethorpe exhibition has nothing to do with the First Amendment or artistic freedom. It is a question of how the public is willing to see its tax money spent. And now that the cat is out of the bag and we see what an old boys' club of mutually appointed experts and professionals has decided is worthy of support, we have balked. Anyone who wants to take homoerotic photographs is free to do so with his own money and on his own time. Any gallery that wants to exhibit such photographs is free to do so with private funds. JEROME S. NISSELBAUM, Ph.D. Flushing, N.Y.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE ASSIGNMENT: Or, On the Observing of the Observer of the Observers, by Friedrich Durrenmatt. Translated by Joel Agee. (Vintage International, $7.95.) F., a woman film maker, is asked to look into the rape and murder of the wife of a psychiatrist, and she soon becomes the central character in a tapestry of intrigue, crime and terrorism. Last year our reviewer, Sven Birkerts, urged readers to bear with this brief, ambitious novel and its chapterlong sentences to appreciate it as ''a parable of hell for an age consumed by images.'' CHAPLIN: His Life and Art, by David Robinson. (McGraw-Hill, $14.95.) Charlie Chaplin, who revealed himself time and again through his movies, is revealed once more in this exhaustive biography, which reports on Chaplin the man and the artist, his Dickensian troubles and adventures, for nearly 800 pages. Writing in The Book Review in 1985, Garson Kanin said, ''In his painstaking and brilliantly researched book, with its immense wealth of names and dates and places and figures, Mr. Robinson has given us a valuable and important chronicle.'' CAT'S GRIN, by Francois Maspero. Translated by Nancy Amphoux. (New Amsterdam, $9.95.) A scrawny French teen-ager, nicknamed Cat, is caught up in the maelstrom of German occupation: his father dies in a concentration camp, his mother is broken, his brother joins the Resistance and through it all Cat survives. This novel, Herbert R. Lottman wrote here in 1986, ''brings us up close to the sights and sounds of occupied Paris. . . . We feel the weight of the German presence.'' CAPTAIN KIDD AND THE WAR AGAINST THE PIRATES, by Robert C. Ritchie. (Harvard University, Paper, $11.95; Cloth, $22.50.) By the late 17th century, piracy was falling out of favor as a way of settling differences, and Capt. William Kidd was unfortunate enough to be caught in the transition; he died in England at the end of a rope. In 1986 our reviewer, Jim Haskins, called Robert C. Ritchie's biographical study a ''fascinating story of political intrigue and complicated business-deal-making'' that makes the ''shadowy, myth-laden figure of Kidd a real and largely sympathetic character.'' TRUST ME ON THIS, by Donald E. Westlake. (Mysterious Press, $4.50.) A sane enough young reporter named Sara Joslyn finds herself employed by a sleazy, goofy Florida-based tabloid and before long is trying to succeed on the same lunatic terms as everybody else there. Molly Ivins, reviewing the novel here last year, called it ''delicious fun.'' ''In between stories about space battles, 100-year-old twins, dead country music stars and bizarre medical happenings,'' she said, ''Mr. Westlake has sandwiched a nice romance and a fairish murder mystery.'' THE SECRET WAR AGAINST HITLER, by William Casey. (Berkley Books, $4.50.) In World War II, long before he ran Ronald Reagan's Presidential campaign or became a Director of Central Intelligence ensnarled in the Iran-contra affair, William Casey worked as a spymaster for the United States in England. ''Half history, half memoir, the book is a useful guide to O.S.S. operations run out of London,'' Robert Sherrod wrote here last year of Casey's account, which was not quite finished before his death in 1987. THE PHYSALIA INCIDENT, by Art Spikol. (Penguin, $3.95.) When a financier and expert snorkler dies off Bermuda, the sting of a Portuguese man-of-war is blamed, but the facts don't add up. The investigation by Alex Black, aided by his computer, is recounted in ''sharp, elegant writing,'' Newgate Callendar said here last year, calling this novel ''an auspicious debut.'' COMING OF AGE IN THE MILKY WAY, by Timothy Ferris. (Anchor/Doubleday, $10.95.) Ancient farmers were intimate with the night sky; it seemed close and knowable. ''Coming of Age in the Milky Way,'' Marcia Bartusiak wrote here last year, chronicles the ''awakening of the human species to the vastness of our cosmos. . . . It is an exhilarating, wide-ranging journey.'' THE ORIGIN OF THE BRUNISTS, by Robert Coover. (Norton, $10.95.) Robert Coover's reputation for invention, humor and intensity got its start with this, his first novel, the story of the founding of a crackpot religious sect. In 1966, Webster Schott, writing here, saw flaws but great promise: If Mr. Coover ''can somehow control his Hollywood giganticism and focus his vision of life, he may become heir to Dreiser or Lewis.'' THE FLIGHT OF THE IGUANA: A Sidelong View of Science and Nature, by David Quammen. (Anchor/Doubleday, $8.95). The nature essayist David Quammen has an eye for the exotic, from beaded lizards to black widow spiders. Harry Middleton wrote here last year that Mr. Quammen's is ''a prose loaded with ideas and emotion that is as thrilling and upsetting as a wild ride on a slightly unsettled roller coaster.'' THE FLIGHT OF PETER FROMM, by Martin Gardner. (Noonday Press/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $8.95.) Better known as a lively science and math writer, Martin Gardner demonstrated an early flair for fiction with this 1973 novel about a hero who roams through Protestant doctrine. ''Can a novel whose action is essentially cerebral be exciting?'' Martin Levin asked here. ''Yes indeed - if the novelist is as engaged by the history of ideas as is Gardner.'' THE RAGE WITHIN: Anger in Modern Life, by Willard Gaylin. (Penguin, $7.95.) Is rage useful anymore? Or is it obsolete, an emotion left over from more primitive times? Willard Gaylin, a psychoanalyst and ethicist, offers an ''eloquent warning,'' Brett Harvey wrote here in 1985, against the anger that increasingly poisons everyday life.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We had a parquet wood floor installed in two rooms over a year ago and are having trouble with tiles buckling. In one room the tongue-and-groove, 12-inch square tiles were put down over a plywood base and these tiles are O.K. In the other room the tiles were put down directly on a concrete slab (without an underlayment) and these tiles started to buckle across the width of the the room during the first summer. This buckling subsided during the winter. Will the buckling subside in time, and would it help if we weighted the tiles down?

title:
PASTIMES: Gardening;
Barrels Produce Bumper Crop of Figs
description: LEAD: Dwarf fig trees can be grown in cold climates in half-barrels to provide plenty of honey-flavored figs by late summer. Normally, fig trees grow in the warmer Mediterranean climate.

title: 'B.B.' Style
description: Clothes are not something Barbara Bush enjoys talking about.

title: Review/Dance; Brumachon Company
description: Claude Brumachon trained as an artist before coming to dance. That training showed in ''Le Piedestal des Vierges,'' presented by the Brumachon company this afternoon and evening at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival here. For this dance for two men and four women might have been painted by the 15th-century Flemish artist Hans Memling.

title: Megan Crowley,Producer, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Schaft Crowley of New York, Greenwich, Conn., and Bondville, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter Margaret Anne Crowley to Keith Alexander McAllister, the son of Joan Seaver McAllister of New York and the late John Tower McAllister. A September wedding is planned.

title: POSTINGS: Water Conservation; Landlords Fight Fees
description: With New York's reservoirs brimming, this might seem an odd time for the city to slap property owners with $40 million in bills to pay for water-conservation programs. Yet that is what has happened, and the Rent Stabilization Association of New York, an association of 25,000 owners, is not happy. The group is suing the city in State Supreme Court in Manhattan to overturn the charges.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some of the most notable releases of the last few months. BIRD - In a psychological character study of remarkable complexity, directed by Clint Eastwood, Forest Whitaker plays the saxophonist Charlie Parker as a kind of big brilliant baby. Drenched in great music, the film ''may be long, messy, and a bit drab-looking, but it is still one of the two or three most powerful jazz-oriented features ever produced.'' (Stephen Holden) 1988. Warner. 2 hours, 41 minutes. $89.95. Laser disk, $29.98. Closed captioned. R. THE COCOANUTS - According to a contemporary critic, writing when talking pictures were ''still in their puppyhood,''

title: Summit Talk: Soviets Da, Baker Maybe
description: After a three-hour meeting with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, expressed confidence today that a further encounter in September could pave the way for a summit meeting between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Providence, R.I.;
Blighted Lots Yield to Homes
description: LEAD: A COMMUNITY development organization is helping to revitalize depressed South Providence neighborhoods by selling single-family houses at below-market prices.

title: Don't Minimize Government Terror in Salvador; While Justice Sleeps
description: To the Editor:

title: Kathleen Bentley to Wed David Wit
description: Kathleen Mary Bentley, the daughter of Martha S. Bentley and Jack F. Bentley, both of Rome, N.Y., and David Edmund Wit, the son of Joan R. Sovern and Harold M. Wit, both of New York, plan to marry in September.

title: Leonard-Duran Site
description: ThE Mirage Hotel in Las Vegas, Nev., has been chosen as the site, and Dec. 7 has been fixed as the date of the third fight between Sugar Ray Leonard and Roberto Duran, this time for the World Boxing Council super middleweight title.

title: Homeowners' Rights: Options Remain
description: Richard F. Welch [ Opinion, ''Court vs. Family: Homeowners Lose,'' June 25 ] says it's all over for family neighborhoods, the cause of death being Baer vs. Brookhaven, a New York Court of Appeals decision that struck down any restriction on the number of unrelated individuals residing in a single house.

title: September Bridal For Miss Walker
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold E. Walker of San Antonio, Tex., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter, Margaret Anne Walker, and James Garland Rose Jr., a son of Mrs. Forrest W. Brown Jr. of Richmond, Va., and the late Mr. Rose.

title: Italy's Endangered Treasures
description: ON the morning of March 18, without any warning, the massive Civic Tower of Pavia collapsed; it had for nearly 1,000 years risen at the center of the ancient and illustrious city near Milan. Within less than a minute the 256-foot-high structure of stones and bricks sagged into a giant heap of rubble, killing the woman who for half her life had been selling newspapers at its foot, two students and an elderly passer-by.

title: Deutsche Bank's Bigger Reach
description: ''Almighty Supreme Being,'' the West German press often calls him.

title: Yanks Get Pitching, Hitting and a Victory
description: Chuck Cary, an admitted appreciator of Yankee tradition, understands that security has not been a part of it for the last decade or so. Jobs aren't guaranteed, and of late, leads are anything but safe. You want a job, you win. You want a lead, you keep it yourself.

title: Ivy and Tracey Ozer Plan Weddings
description: Ivy Melissa Ozer is to marry Craig Paul Zuckerman in September, and her younger sister Tracey Brooke Ozer plans a November wedding to Scott Michael Schweber, the sisters' parents, Mr. and Mrs. Martin Ozer of Kings Point, L.I., have announced.

title: Homecoming
description: To the Editor: When I read the heartwarming story of the ''Homecoming'' by Susan Ferraro (Travel, July 2) it reminded me of my own experience. I am a naturalized American citizen who came from Europe over 40 years ago at the age of 30. I made many American friends, but every so often I feel a tinge of still being European. But, lo and behold, as soon as I travel in Europe, I am more American than any of them. LISA LOOSE New York, N.Y.

title: Two Share Lead in Tourney
description: Vicki Fergon is often mistaken for Betsy King in appearance, and today she also played like King, the leading player on the Ladies' Professional Golf Association tour.

title: A Deaf Camper Adjusts to the Country Life
description: Tami Jones sat on a bench at Camp Hidden Valley here on the Sharpe Reservation recently and leaned back, relaxing. She rolled over on her stomach, fiddled with her curly blond hair and spoke briefly in sign language. All around her, children were swimming, hiking, playing kickball. Suddenly, she lost her balance and tumbled off the bench. But Tami got up smiling.

title: 'Pvt. Wars,' a Short Play Expanded
description: WHEN do you call a play a play and let it be?

title: Christina Raper Weds
description: Christina Lynn Raper and William Edward Livingston Coster were married yesterday at St. Luke's United Methodist Church in Houston by the Rev. Kent Kilborne. The bride, 26 years old, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Raper of Houston, where she is an elementary school teacher and her husband, 28, a son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Livingston Coster of New York, is an account executive with Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith.

title: With Training and New Tactics, Salvador's Army Gains on Rebels
description: Under cover of a mortar barrage, guerrilla commandos penetrated the strategically important base, moving almost at leisure from one building to another, setting each ablaze with homemade bombs before escaping into the hills that dominate El Paraiso, the headquarters of the Fourth Brigade.

title: Beauty; Food for Thought
description: Take one quail egg and whip vigorously with honey and herbs. Mash a bunch of bananas. Peel away the skin from one pineapple. Squeeze several olives. Pulverize a bag of peanuts. Scoop out one spoonful of caviar.

title: Tofu
description: To the Editor: Our best jet-lag prevention diet calls for a high protein breakfast and lunch and a high carbohydrate dinner three days before the flight. After reading ''A Feast of Tofu'' (Travel, June 11), and on the lookout for a high protein breakfast that does not use eggs, I browned big slices of tofu in a little margarine and topped it with hot maple syrup. ''What's this,'' my husband asked. ''Japanese toast?'' To combine Kyoto with Hannibal, I named it ''Meet Twain Toast.'' The pun put us in an adventurous mood for our Chicago Transit Authority train trip to O'Hare International Airport and a flight to Athens and Istanbul. SALLY A. KITT CHAPPELL Chicago

title: IN THE STEPS OF THE HAIKU MASTER
description: ON THE NARROW ROAD Journey Into a Lost Japan. By Lesley Downer. 280 pp. New York: Summit Books. $19.95.

title: Tina Dudek, a Dancer and Actress, Weds David Van Tieghem, Musician
description: Tina Dudek, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marion Dudek of Yonkers, and David Stark Van Tieghem, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Van Tieghem of Ridgewood, N.J., were married yesterday in a nondenominational ceremony performed by the Rev. Elizabeth Ann Levy, an interfaith minister, at the James House, a historic building in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Expos' Martinez Silences the Cards
description: Dennis Martinez won his 10th consecutive decision as the Expos shut out the St. Louis Cardinals, 2-0, tonight for the team's seventh victory in nine games.

title: Soviet Business Consultants Sharpen Hammer and Sickle
description: He is 31 years old, he drives a pricey imported car, his tastes in clothing run to European-cut suits and yellow ''power'' ties, and his notion of a fringe benefit is paying tennis-court fees for his staff. Aleksandr I. Rubtsov is the Soviet equivalent of a young urban professional, a private management consultant in a country where the very concept of such a job would until recently have been alien.

title:
MUSIC;
A Voice From the Cradle of Jazz
description: LEAD: Lincoln Center's Classical Jazz 1989, which opens Friday at Alice Tully Hall, will offer five programs (one of which will be repeated) drawn from the jazz repertory of the past. On Monday, Aug. 7, the program is titled ''Mr. Jelly Lord: The Music of Jelly Roll Morton,'' and will be a salute not only to Morton, a jazz pioneer, but also to New Orleans, the cradle of jazz in the early years of this century.

title: Tougher Wetlands Restrictions Criticized
description: NEW regulations that restrict development in areas surrounding freshwater wetlands in the state have sparked angry criticism from developers and their lawyers, who say the new rules are vague, unnecessary and perhaps even unconstitutional.

title: Savings Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Hamptons Flights On the Increase
description: A GROWING number of weekend commuters are flying to the East End this summer at one-way prices ranging from $69 for a seat in a one-engine plane flying from La Guardia to $199 for a helicopter flight from midtown Manhattan on Trump Air, Donald Trump's new helicopter service. Pat Ryan, manager of East Hampton Airport, forecasts a record-breaking year for both East Hampton Air and Long Island Airlines. East Hampton Air is running more flights than ever, and Long Island Airlines is carrying the same frequency of flights but using larger planes, therefore carrying more passengers, he said.

title: Second Glance For DiMaggio
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Recitals: Hooray Has Become Ho-Hum
description: Solo recordings by opera singers have been a mainstay of recording since its inception, and the aria recital format that came into being when the LP replaced 78-r.p.m. is, to all visible signs, flourishing in the new medium of compact disks. But somehow it doesn't seem as important as it used to be. That at least is the reaction of a listener who has recently spent glum hours listening to a new batch of recitals and happy hours listening to a batch of reissues (or, in some cases, newly published recordings by singers of the 78 and early LP era). Should one compare the two experiences? ''Why,'' asked Lawrence Tibbett once by way of expounding on the odiousness of comparison, ''must we baritones continually be compared with Battistini, Campanari, Maurel, Navarini? First of all, music has become much more difficult. Our repertories are larger and broader. We have to sing and act in more and various schools. But what does all that matter? We are. They were. Is not that enough?''

title: Correction
description: A picture caption in some copies of the Sports section last Sunday about the New York Games misidentified the runner lying on the track after falling in the women's 100-meter race. She was Dawn Sowell.

title:
FOCUS: China on the Move;
Quiet Entry in the U.S. Housing Market
description: LEAD: BY most measures, Lantana Lakes resembles many other middle-class subdivisions springing up here. Three lakes cover large parts of the 107-acre parcel, giving many home sites both waterfront and drainage. The 42 houses, with seven more under construction, are frame with brick trim and offer two-car garages, skylights and built-in appliances.

title: Jennifer Paxton Weds Stephen Silvia
description: Jennifer Ann Paxton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas R. Paxton of New York and East Hampton, L.I., was married yesterday in East Hampton to Stephen John Silvia, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Silvia of Grand Rapids, Mich. Msgr. Christopher Huntington officiated at Most Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church.

title: Louise Goldsmith Marries
description: Louise Woodruff Goldsmith, the branch manager of the Guardian Savings Bank, and Dennis Earl Grogan, a warehouse specialist with the Quaker Oats Company, both in Dallas, were married yesterday in Huletts Landing, N.Y. The Rev. John Williams, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Mountain Grove Memorial Church. Mrs. Grogan, 28 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Smith Ely Goldsmith of New York. Mr. Grogan, 30, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Grogan of Red Oak, Tex.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE CENTURION. By Jan de Hartog. (Harper & Row, $18.95.) A retired Dutch sea captain finds a line from T. S. Eliot: ''Old men ought to be explorers.'' He next happens upon a dowsers' convention, discovers he has the knack and winds up using a pendulum to search for Roman ruins in Britain. As he questions the pendulum, it ''replies.

title: Homecoming
description: To the Editor: I am glad that Mary Ferraro, Susan's mother-in-law, found, after her trip back to Calabria, that she was an American with Italian roots - not an Italian, or even an Italian-American.

title: A Greek Island of Space and Light
description: IN the spring of 1945, the poet and novelist Lawrence Durrell arrived on Rhodes with a British occupation force. The war in Europe had just ended and the island's main harbor was still full of German mines. Durrell, ''speechless with gratitude'' upon taking his first swim in the blue Aegean, realized that ''space, light and solitude will have to be rediscovered again here, in all their ramifications.''

title: DATA UPDATE
FICTION
description: THE WHALES IN LAKE TANGANYIKA. By Lennart Hagerfors. Translated by Anselm Hollo. (Grove, $16.95.) This engaging novel, one of four by the Swedish writer Lennart Hagerfors, is an imaginative retelling of Henry Morton Stanley's famous 1871 expedition through what is now Tanzania to find the explorer David Livingstone. The book, as smoothly and literately translated by Anselm Hollo, is in some ways a sly refutation of Stanley's own self-serving account of these events (''How I Found Livingstone,'' published in 1872), as well as an implicit condemnation of the casual and brutish racism that characterized his entire era. Mr. Hagerfors's narrator is the unheroic John Shaw, a ne'er-do-well British sailor whose vulgarity suggests the truth behind the explorers' grand pretensions. Shaw is unhappy from the moment he joins the expedition, but as the party penetrates the interior he descends into a kind of Conradian madness. Haunted by obsessive images of the sea he has left behind, he hopes not to die until he can see ''the whales in Lake Tanganyika,'' a manifestly irrational ambition that serves to mirror and parody Stanley's monomaniacal designs. For Stanley, Livingstone is ''the light of Africa,'' yet when the great man is found he appears to Shaw - in a fine Darwinian reversal - as a chimpanzee-like creature who at one point is observed to be munching on his Bible. Lennart Hagerfors is delightfully adept at showing the many ironies of what used to be called the White Man's Burden; it never occurs to Stanley, caught in the heart of his own darkness, that the most intolerable burden of all may be the very presence in Africa of these self-important Europeans.

title: Minding the Store
description: In an age when architects and designers have achieved celebrity status, Naomi Leff thrives on anonymity. When she walks into Ralph Lauren's flagship store - the renovated Rhinelander Mansion at Madison Avenue and 72d Street -she is just another customer.

title: Helping a Modest Bequest Yield Its Greatest Benefit
description: BEFORE Albertina Bloom died in l980, the soft-spoken schoolteacher from White Plains found a way to have her lifelong effort to motivate students continue after her death. Miss Bloom designated her entire estate to provide scholarships for Westchester high school students ''who might otherwise be unable to avail themselves of the advantages of collegiate training,'' as she stated in her will.

title: In Latin America, Headlines Inspire The Drama
description: For the Latin American theater, the headlines on today's front page have become as rich a source of inspiration as the hallowed classics of Lope de Vega or Garcia Lorca. Exile, revolution, political repression, the foreign debt and drug trafficking are themes that are increasingly capturing the imagination of Latin American playwrights and directors, and it is precisely those concerns that permeate the works that will be performed at the monthlong Festival Latino at the Public Theater in New York, which begins this week.

title: Nantucket's Residents at Sea on Housing
description: LEAD: THE thousands of vacationers who flock to this island every summer are creating a problem for themselves that is perplexing municipal officials. The visitors are raising the value of land so high that the workers who serve them cannot find housing they can afford.

title: The Struggle to Make Do Without Health Insurance
description: As the nation wrestles with how to provide health care for every American, one unifying theme drives the debate: Every day millions of people fail to receive the medical treatment they need.

title: Senate Prods Bush and Allies on Sharing Burden
description: Responding to pressure to cut military commitments abroad, leaders of the Senate Armed Services Committee will propose next week that President Bush negotiate an agreement for Japan to pay all the cost of keeping American troops there.

title:
DINING OUT;
Youthful Spirit by a Peekskill Waterfall
description: LEAD: ENTHUSIASM and good taste go a long way at Wallis & Wynn. The enterprise is young, in spirit as well as in duration, and this assay into the field has a deliberateness we admire. Sharon Noland, the owner (Wallis and Wynn are family names), has clearly done the right thing in her gentle resuscitation of a brick building in the old factory part of town.

title: Review/Theater; Battles of Affection in 2 One-Acters
description: ''On my honor I will do my best/To take what they give me and steal the rest'' is the motto of Frank Dandridge, a soldier who, against all odds, persuades an aloof nightclub singer to marry him in ''Every Goodbye Ain't Gone. . . .'' by Bill Harris. But the wedding is hardly a victory. Rula Payton, the singer he marries, will give love only when she feels like it, and when she finally does, he finds he cannot take it.

title: Melanie Gustafson Is Wed
description: Melanie Susan Gustafson, the coordinator of the graduate program in women's history at Sarah Lawrence College in Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to David Leigh Foster, the president of the Institute of Management & Administration, a New York publishing company. The Rev. Laurie Whinnem Etter, a United Church of Christ minister, officiated at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Roland Stearns in Blue Mountain Lake, N.Y. The bride, 31 years old, is a daughter of Col. Melvin E. Gustafson, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Gustafson of Sun City West, Ariz. Mr. Foster, 34, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan D. Foster of Schenectady, N.Y.

title: A Plea for Ethnic Diversity
description: Two recent articles about the issues raised by the cancellation of the Robert Mapplethorpe photography exhibit at the Corcoran Gallery in Washington - Hilton Kramer's ''Is Art Above the Laws of Decency? (July 2) and Grace Glueck's ''Art on the Firing Line'' (July 9) - have prompted an unusually large number of letters from readers. Here is a sampling. To the Editor: Very often artists whose work does not conform to widely held beliefs and views are members of ethnically and culturally diverse groups. Attempts to insure that artwork supported by public funds conforms to the beliefs held by some deny the cultural plurality of our country and infringe on the freedom to express different views through artistic creation. Eliminating the type of artwork that is supported with public funds amounts to censorship, as it results in beliefs, views and esthetic values that are deemed to be acceptable to some being imposed on all.

title: Seeking a Fresh Image, the Kirov Goes Astray
description: Were those really the Kirov Ballet's dancers rolling around the stage at the Metropolitan Opera House? Or leaping off the same stage as mutinous sailors and running up the aisle with revolutionary fervor to storm who knows what, perhaps the sandwich bars run by Restaurant Associates Inc. in the lobby?

title: July 4 Racial Clash Leaves Rosedale Split Over Its Image and Its Reality
description: Rosedale unfolds like a flower from the web of concrete highway that surrounds it. It is a placid middle-class neighborhood of tidy single- and multi-family houses, where hydrangeas and roses color the front yards, and here and there a satellite dish perches on a roof.

title: Rutherford Journal; Sale of Houses by College Strains Relations With Town
description: LOCAL lore has it that the last time residents of this tree-lined suburb questioned the benefit of having a college campus in town, the president of Fairleigh Dickinson University paid the employees' salaries in silver dollars. Shortly afterward, many of the coins began to appear in local merchants' cash registers, a subtle but convincing reminder that the school was indeed a good neighbor.

title: New Plan For Parkway Roils Westbury
description: LEAD: OFFICIALS in Westbury, already embroiled in a legal battle with the State Department of Transportation over one road project, are upset over a state plan to double the size of a 2.5-mile stretch of the Northern State Parkway that runs the entire length of the village. The section stretches from the Meadowbrook to the Wantagh

title: L.A. FIGHTS FOR BREATH
description: THE POLITICIAN HAD JUST DESCRIBED HOW the new master plan to cleanse the grimy air over metropolitan Los Angeles imperils industry. Now he started on what he called its invasions of everyday life - restrictions on housepaint, deodorant, barbecue starter fluid and products in everyone's kitchen that allegedly expel more pollutants than oil refineries. Dry cleaners, too. And now even the delectable aromas wafting from bakeries, because they're actually ethanol, an organic pollutant.

title: Tone Down The Rhetoric
description: Two recent articles about the issues raised by the cancellation of the Robert Mapplethorpe photography exhibit at the Corcoran Gallery in Washington - Hilton Kramer's ''Is Art Above the Laws of Decency? (July 2) and Grace Glueck's ''Art on the Firing Line'' (July 9) - have prompted an unusually large number of letters from readers. Here is a sampling. To the Editor: Although I suppose by virtue of the fact that I directed for a number of years a private foundation program that supported the visual and performing arts in this country I can be declared a member of that self-interested and amorphous ''art-world establishment'' that Hilton Kramer decries, I find it hard to work up much heat when reading about the Corcoran/Mapplethorpe dispute. My own professional view tended toward assisting institutional basics rather than Fashion or Flash, but what really constitutes art should remain in the eye of the tax-paying beholder, who after all is free to make the choice to see or listen, or not.

title: Gorbachev's Latest Gamble
description: LEAD: Can Mikhail Gorbachev's reforms survive the nationalist violence and wildcat strikes that threaten to tear his country and party apart? No one can say, certainly not from this distance, and probably not on the scene either.

title: HARVARD'S SHREWD 'BLUNDER'
description: This is a story about how to sell less and earn more. It is brought to you by the folks at the Harvard Business School.

title: On a Quiet Street, Instant Circus for a Spy Suspect
description: In the last week, Felix S. Bloch, the high-ranking American diplomat suspected of espionage, has turned Hamilton Road, where he is staying with his daughter and her husband, into something of a three-ring circus.

title:
ART;
Ambiguous Fruits of Nature
description: LEAD: THE headquarters of the Squibb Corporation might resemble a well-manicured game preserve. Because there is such a building boom occurring around Princeton, the game would welcome such a habitat. But what we have mainly is a species of art preserve. Any art exhibited at the Squibb Gallery is seen against vast, bucolic nature - trees, ponds, lawn and sky - through large windows.

title: Outdoors; Quebec Zones Aid Fish and Anglers
description: If the management of the Ste.-Marguerite, on which I recently spent three days, can be considered typical of the Atlantic salmon rivers that are controlled through the so-called Z.E.C. system in Quebec, that approach is to be applauded.

title: Ann F. Snowden Married to Artist
description: Ann Farr Snowden, a daughter of Mrs. George Grant Snowden 3d of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mr. Snowden, was married yesterday to David Collins Johnson, a son of Ann McNevin Johnson of Marietta, Ga., and the late Gerald Justin Johnson 2d, at the Watch Hill Chapel in Watch Hill, R.I. The Rev. Seymour St. John performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: Rafsanjani Declared Iran Election Winner
description: Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, the Speaker of Iran's Parliament, was declared the winner of Friday's presidential election, the Teheran radio reported today.

title: PASTIMES: Camera
description: Last week I met a man who had just received as a gift - a gift, mind you - a brand new Yashica camera. His family thought he should have something to record his brand-new grandchild. The Yashica was just the ticket: an all-automatic, point-and-shoot camera that didn't cost an arm and a leg.

title: Marconi Radio Shack To Stay in Rocky Point
description: LEAD: THE fate of a tiny one-room shack, used by Guglielmo Marconi in pioneering radio transmissions from Long Island, has been decided after a long debate between two communities that each sought the right to preserve the historic building.

title: Willard Sektberg, a Pianist, Is Dead at 87
description: Willard Sektberg, a pianist, organist and vocal coach who accompanied Metropolitan Opera singers, including Leonard Warren, Richard Crooks, Cesare Valletti and Mattiwilde Dobbs, died at Crosslands, Kennett Square in Pennsylvania on Friday. He was 87 years old and, before his retirement to Pennsylvania 10 years ago, had maintained a studio on West 72d Street for more than 40 years.

title: Patricia Lawler Is Wed
description: Patricia Rose Lawler, an associate in the Philadelphia law firm of Fox, Rothchild, O'Brien & Frankel, and Dr. Barney Jonathan Kenet, a resident in dermatology at New York Hospital, were married in New York yesterday at the Church Center for the United Nations. Rabbi Burt Segal and the Rev. Robert Robbins, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated. The bride, who is 29 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Lawler of Philadelphia. Dr. Kenet, 28, is a son of Dr. and Mrs. David Kenet of Lakeland, Fla.

title: Stranded in U.S., Chinese Are Trying to Cope
description: A well-known Chinese opera orchestra conductor came to New York City last October to visit relatives and is now stranded because of the recent crackdown on intellectuals in China. His six-month visitor's visa has expired and he is now working illegally in a flower shop in Manhattan.

title: 'WHY NO RUSSIAN EXPRESS CARDS?'
description: SAY CHEESE! By Vassily Aksyonov. Translated by Antonina W. Bouis. 404 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.

title: Review/Music; Diverse Triple Bill for Serious Fun
description: Recent works by Lucia Hwong, Scott Johnson and Anthony Davis were presented in a Serious Fun triple bill on Wednesday evening at Alice Tully Hall. For those who seek common threads, it could be argued that these composers share a penchant for combining elements of classical style with idioms and instrumentations borrowed from popular genres. But the points of connection are few, for each of these composers has developed a personal language and is pursuing a distinct set of goals.

title: PASTIMES: Stamps
description: Pigeon posts have been known for centuries. They were usually set up to replace communications cut by war: When Antony besieged Brutus at Modena, Pliny the historian says, Brutus used carrier pigeons to get news to the Romans. Pigeons were also used at the Siege of Leiden in 1575 and the Siege of Paris in 1870-71.

title: PASTIMES: Numismatics
description: Usually we forget about small change. And why not? Pennies, nickles and dimes agglomerate in ashtrays and jelly glasses. If someone gives us lots of change instead of bills, we're almost insulted.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Economies usually don't get on a slow-growth track quarter after quarter. Something happens to push you up or pull you down. But if there's a recession coming, I can't see it from here.'' Robert S. Dederick,, chief economist, Northern Trust Company.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Wedding in Galilee 1987. Kino International. 1 hour, 53 minutes. $79.95. Not rated. Michel Khleifi, a writer and director born and raised in Nazareth and now living in Brussels, relies on a wandering, Eastern-style narrative to depict Palestinian traditions threatened by 20th-century inroads. The film is ''lyrical and extravagantly detailed when portraying the Palestinians. But because Mr. Khleifi turns simplistic and leaden whenever he points his camera at an Israeli . . . his often dazzling first feature is diminished by his insistently narrow vision.'' Still, this is ''a strong, rare example of Middle Eastern film making.'' (Caryn James) Mississippi Burning 1988. Orion Home Video. 2:07. $89.95. Laser disk (Image Entertainment), $49.95. Closed captioned. R. Taking the bare bones of the true story of three civil rights workers murdered near Philadelphia, Miss., in 1964, the screenwriter Chris Gerolmo and the director Alan Parker have come up with ''one of the toughest, straightest, most effective fiction films yet made about bigotry and racial violence.'' The principal characters are F.B.I. men investigating the victims' disappearance, played by Gene Hackman, in possibly the best role of his career, and Willem Dafoe. ''Some of the imagined twists and turns of the investigation go rather far off the track, but never for a minute does the film sacrifice the honesty of time, temper and place.'' (Vincent Canby) Tequila Sunrise 1988. Warner Home Video. 1:16. $89.95. LD, $24.98. CC. R. Robert Towne's second film as a writer-director ''has the fuzzy focus of someone who has stared too long at a light bulb.'' What starts as an entertaining romantic melodrama about a couple of high-school friends now on opposite sides of the Los Angeles law turns into an impenetrable mystery. ''The result is a long, teasing trailer for a film not yet made.'' Mel Gibson, as a former cocaine importer, and Kurt Russell, as a narcotics detective, make good company, and Michelle Pfeiffer provides a ''stunning presence'' between them. (Canby) Tidy Endings 1988. Prism Entertainment. 0:54. $79.95. Not rated. Harvey Fierstein, who wrote the Broadway play ''Safe Sex,'' from which this touching little drama derives, co-stars with Stockard Channing. Ms. Channing plays the former wife of a man who has just died of AIDS, Mr. Fierstein the homosexual lover for whom the man had left her. The bulk of the drama lies in an intelligent conversation between these diametrically opposite personalities, who dispute, explain and come to a teary and somewhat happy conclusion. ''This is a show of ideas and feelings, and the cameras always bear in mind the need to put a drama whose strength is in its words and sensibilities into a frame that does not upstage it.'' (Richard F. Shepherd) The Desperate Hours 1955. Paramount Home Video. 1:52. $14.95. CC. Not rated. The ''producer-director William Wyler has turned Joseph Hayes' [ novel ] into a crafty and crackling screen thriller,'' wrote a reviewer at the time of the film's release, ''in every respect save one. That is the matter of making the behavior of the characters believable.'' Humphrey Bogart, playing the strongest of three desperadoes who hold a family captive in a suburban home, conveys ''the menace and malevolence of the meanest kind of human beast at bay.'' Frederic March plays the father, allowed - incredibly - to leave, go to work and return. The tension thus snapped, the film becomes ''a mere exercise in melodramatic hocus-pocus.''

title: Kaiser's Formula
description: To the Editor:

title: Paisley White to Marry in September
description: Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Ellsworth White of Kenilworth, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Paisley Addams White, to Robert Paul Kelling Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kelling of Haddonfield, N.J. A September wedding is planned.

title: Behind the Capital Gains Plan
description: After the 1986 tax reform, the idea that capital gains would again be taxed at a lower rate than regular income seemed a dead issue -until President Bush resurrected the idea during the campaign last year and proposed to cut the tax on capital gains to 15 percent.

title: Even Philistines Can Get It Right
description: Two recent articles about the issues raised by the cancellation of the Robert Mapplethorpe photography exhibit at the Corcoran Gallery in Washington - Hilton Kramer's ''Is Art Above the Laws of Decency? (July 2) and Grace Glueck's ''Art on the Firing Line'' (July 9) - have prompted an unusually large number of letters from readers. Here is a sampling. To the Editor: The real issue is why did the National Endowment for the Arts and the Corcoran accept the show as art in the first place? The answer has to be that neither knew any better. Or that if they did, neither had the guts to apply intelligent criteria in the face of pressure to be trendy. And that is the kind of irresponsibility that will ultimately undermine public support for the arts - not the Corcoran's belated backdown. It's a cop-out to argue, as Grace Glueck does, that some works now regarded as great art were once viewed as outrageous.

title: Pornography and Violence
description: Two recent articles about the issues raised by the cancellation of the Robert Mapplethorpe photography exhibit at the Corcoran Gallery in Washington - Hilton Kramer's ''Is Art Above the Laws of Decency? (July 2) and Grace Glueck's ''Art on the Firing Line'' (July 9) - have prompted an unusually large number of letters from readers. Here is a sampling. To the Editor: I was as chagrined and angered by Grace Glueck's article as I was moved and inspired by Mr. Kramer's. What I believe Ms. Glueck is missing is the undeniable connection between pornography and violence, a connection that has been verified by thousands of victims, police officers, perpetrators and mental health professionals. This is not an issue of censorship, or conservatives vs. liberals, of gay rights or museum integrity. This is an issue of civil rights, no different from a public display of work promoting anti-Semitism or racism. If we are to be a public that strives against the glorification of torture and degradation, then we must also be a public willing to say no to the work of Robert Mapplethorpe and those like him. The question that comes to mind is not why did the Corcoran cancel this show, or even why was the show scheduled in the first place, but why do artists like this gain prominence?

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Outing; In Mystic, Heritage Of the Sea Lives On
description: When Humphrey Bogart and Lauren Bacall honeymooned in the coastal New England community of Mystic in the 1940's, the quiet village had little more than a few shops and a small museum as its attractions. Fifty years later, Mystic has become a tourist net, drawing more than a million visitors a year to the seaport, aquarium and shopping districts.

title: Widening the Margin of Safety in Flying
description: THE relatively high survival rate of passengers in the July 19 United Airlines crash in Sioux City, Iowa, has focused renewed attention on ways to make airplanes safer. In recent years the Federal Aviation Administration, under pressure from groups representing pilots, passengers, flight attendants and even the industry, has issued numerous rules and advisories intended to improve safety. Among the more sweeping is a requirement, now being phased in, that more than 150 parts be routinely replaced on aircraft more than 20 years old - at a cost of hundreds of thousands of dollars a plane. But many airlines face a shortage of mechanics at a time when more maintenance is required, and there is always the question of who should absorb the high costs involved in many of the changes. In other areas, some groups, including the F.A.A., have asked that on-board safety briefings be made more interesting and accurate to insure that passengers are learning the proper safety procedures. Here, compiled from discussions with government, passenger and industry groups, are other changes required, under discussion or suggested in an attempt to make flying safer. COCKPIT

title: Not Too Contrite
description: After his little meeting with Bill White, the National League president, about some intemperate remarks he had made about a couple of umpires after a costly questionable call in a game against the Astros in Houston, Nick Leyva, the manager of the Philadelphia Phillies, couldn't have been more contrite.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: ANNIVERSARY FAIR

title: Scaling New Heights
description: In 1982, while climbing Gables Peak near Yosemite National Park in California, Mark Wellman fell 50 feet and was left paralyzed from the waist down. Last week, Mr. Wellman, accompanied by a friend, became the first paraplegic to conquer Yosemite's challenging El Capitan. The 3,200-foot climb, which took seven days and four hours, required six months of training and about 7,000 pull-ups, each advancing Mr. Wellman only six inches.

title: No Headline
description: THE JEWS IN THEIR LAND IN THE TALMUDIC AGE (70-640 C.E.) By Gedaliah Alon. Edited and translated by Gershon Levi. 800 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. Paper, $18.95.

title: IT STILL TAKES A BRIDE AND GROOM
description: Letty Cottin Pogrebin's article ''It Still Takes a Bride and Groom'' (Hers, July 2), coming as it did on the eve of the Supreme Court's ruling on abortion, represents a bitter taste of ''post-feminism.'' While our right to privacy comes under attack, Ms. Pogrebin finds contentment in wedding announcements. Maybe, as she claims, ''men and women are coming together as equal human beings,'' but only in the society pages of The New York Times.

title: NONFICTION
description: THEY LOVE A MAN IN THE COUNTRY: Saints and Sinners in the South. By Billy Bowles and Remer Tyson. (Peachtree Publishers, $18.95.) This is a hardcore journalist's journalism, staples of the Southern political beat (best told with a couple of ink-stained fingers of bourbon) that never make it into the news. Billy Bowles and Remer Tyson, veterans of the turf who now work for the Detroit Free Press, traveled Dixie in the late 1970's interviewing the icons of a carefree time when politicians could be boys and not have to answer to a Congressional committee. ''They Love a Man in the Country'' is a collection of endearing yarns with no guiding principle beyond the injunction of the grandee of Southern journalism who tells the authors: ''love the rogues.'' Thus, they show equally cheerful forbearance toward Albert (Happy) Chandler, the Kentucky Governor turned baseball commissioner who endorsed Jackie Robinson's entry into the major leagues and yet never purged racial epithets from his own speech; Georgia's charmless race-baiting ex-Gov. Marvin Griffin; Herbert Douglas, the black bartender at a private club in Little Rock, Ark., who fobbed the bar tab of out-of-town reporters covering the 1957 school crisis off on the local segregationists; and Alabama's comitragic hulk of a Governor, James (Big Jim) Folsom, a victim of his own buffoonery as much as of his radical integrationist politics during his terms in the 1940's and 50's. Unlike their chapters on Orval Faubus and George Wallace, for example, Mr. Bowles and Mr. Tyson are able to contribute some new historical nuggets about Folsom as well as leave a poignant final impression of a man who, like several of the book's subjects, has since departed the Gothic world he helped make.

title: Pamela Stevens Engaged to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. William H. Stevens Jr. of New York and Saratoga Springs, N.Y., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Pamela Murray Stevens and Stevens Frederick Alcock, the son of Warren Joseph Alcock Jr. of Manalapan, Fla., and the late Ethel Stevens Alcock.

title: Christina CookAnd D. J. Bates Exchange Vows
description: Christina Warner Cook, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Carrington Cook of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday at the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich to Douglas John Bates, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Calvin Bates of Middlebury, Vt. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Ralph Ahlberg, a United Church of Christ minister.

title: PASTIMES: Chess
description: There were 43 non-Soviet grandmasters entered in the Grandmasters Association International Qualifications Tournament, which ended May 25 at the Ismailovo Hotel in Moscow.

title: Yves-Marie Morin, Accountant, Wed To Christina B. Melady, Law Student
description: Christina Badum Melady, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas P. Melady of Fairfield, Conn., was married there yesterday to Yves-Marie Morin, a son of Charlotte Morin and Bernard Morin, both of Paris. Bishop Walter W. Curtis, the retired Bishop of the Diocese of Bridgeport, Conn., performed the ceremony at St. Pius X Roman Catholic Church. Mrs. Morin, a student at the George Washington University Law Center, graduated from Boston College. Her father is Ambassador-designate to the Vatican and president emeritus of Sacred Heart University in Bridgeport.
