title: Fostering America's Interests Abroad . . . But It Lends to Oppressive Regimes
description: Barber Conable, the former New York Congressman, took over the World Bank in l986 promising to reorganize and redirect it. But, after three years, little has changed and the bank, the largest multilateral institution in the world, continues financing regimes that oppress people and mangle economies.

title: For Dominicans, Public Projects but No Light
description: The lights in the cozy office in Santo Domingo's wrought-iron-and-brick colonial section flickered, faded and went out.

title: Hungary Is Far From Democracy, and Even From Poland
description: IMRE NAGY and Janos Kadar have been buried in ceremonial funerals, and President Bush has come and gone. But these political events did not bring the catharsis that many Hungarians had expected, an opportunity to see their future more clearly at last.

title:
IDEAS & TRENDS;
Judging the Perils Of Official Hostility To Scientific Error
description: LEAD: Since the days of Senator William Proxmire's Golden Fleece awards, often given to laboratory projects he considered a waste of taxpayers' money, scientists and politicians have found themselves on opposite sides of a fundamental issue: how much control should government have over the research it pays for?

title: 'You Must Remember This'
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Shows Honor the French Revolution
description: TAKE ''Three French Brothers and Two American Sisters,'' add to it ''in an old railroad coach'' and the scene would be set for a new twist on the old thigh-slapper by Jerome K. Jerome, ''Three Men in a Boat.''

title: Mohawks Protest Reservation Roadblocks
description: About 100 people marched peacefully today to protest police roadblocks outside the St. Regis Indian Reservation, claiming the barricades keeping non-residents out were hurting the area's economy, the authorities said.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Brunch; In Village, Chelsea, Midtown, Queens
description: This is a summary of reviews of New York City restaurants by Bryan Miller that have appeared in The New York Times. Ratings are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have ratings. Prices are current. Claire

title: Ah, Vacations! A Question of Checkbooks and Balancing Acts
description: LAST month I couldn't get our checkbook to balance. Consequently, we went on a vacation to Phoenix for four days. The cause and effect may not be apparent here. Unless, of course, you understand my theory of ''vacation need.''

title: French Cuisine With Lakeside Views
description: DINING places at waterside are at a premium in Connecticut. This may explain why La Marina, a French restaurant in an old white frame building overlooking Lake Zoar, on Route 34 in Oxford, is so bustlingly busy on a weekend evening.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: East Islip $895,000 103 The Helm 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 20-year-old colonial; pool, cabana, 500-foot waterfront; taxes $12,600. East Patchogue $115,000 3 South Williams Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, enclosed porch; taxes $1,800. Old Field $360,000 10 Intervale Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 45-year-old farm ranch; fireplace, basement, pool, cabana, 1 acre; taxes $5,600. Selden $176,000 17 Palm Street 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 18-year-old ranch; fireplace, partly finished basement, 1-car garage; taxes $4,000. Sound Beach $153,000 19 Millburn Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 40-year-old colonial; fireplace, dining room, enclosed porch, 2-car garage; taxes $750. Westbury $222,500 145 Longwood Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 36-year-old Cape Cod; fireplace, finished basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,700. OTHER AREAS Westbrook, Conn. $155,000 268 Pond Meadow Road 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 12-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, unfinished 2d level, 0.75 acre; taxes $911. Armonk, N.Y. $455,000 5 East Seymour Place 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 31-year-old split-level; den, marble fireplace, eat-in kitchen, stone patio, screened porch, inground pool; taxes $4,637. Ringwood, N.J. $119,900 24 Cupsaw Drive 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 52-year-old ranch; new roof, deck, eat-in-kitchen; taxes $1,888.

title: Ringing in the Year With a Murder
description: ACCORDING to the plot of Bob Barry's ''Murder Among Friends,'' currently at the BayWay Arts Center in East Islip, one way of celebrating the new year is by murdering your narcissistic husband. Or perhaps your fabulously wealthy wife. Or maybe your virile young lover. The one sure thing in this lightweight thriller is that someone is indeed murdered.

title: The Sultry Underworld of 'Iguana'
description: AS Tennessee Williams's plays - the exalted and the considerably less so - gushed forth from the mid-1940's through the 1970's, it was easy for critics and audiences to dismiss many of them as prodigal indulgences, sheer pretentiousness or even self-parody.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: STILL LIVES. By Scott Sommer. (Viking, $18.95.) Scott Sommer's fourth novel details the life and loves of Thom Frankle, a New York freelance photographer striving to remain uncontaminated by the perilous absurdities of contemporary urban life. After losing his job at Concupiscence magazine and being ditched by his girlfriend, the soap opera actress Monica Webb, Frankle begins an arduous and convoluted quest for love and spiritual salvation.

title: Bermuda Dollar
description: To the Editor: The currency chart accompanying the article ''How to Get the Best Rate for Your Dollar Overseas'' (Travel, June 18) stated, on information supplied by Deak International, that the buy and sell rates for the Bermuda dollar were 93 cents and 99 cents, respectively. Whatever spreads Deak International may have in the United States, kindly note the following:

title: 'Equivalent' Families
description: As the attorneys for the plaintiffs in the case of Baer v. Brookhaven, it is obvious from Mr. Welch's reliance on unidentified ''published reports'' for his analysis of the case that he did not read the court's opinion. As lawyers, we acknowledge the fact that court decisions remain accessible to the public principally through secondary sources.

title: Hope N. Bigelow Wed in Vermont
description: Hope Nutting Bigelow, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David S. Bigelow 3d of Landgrove, Vt., and Paris, was married yesterday at the Landgrove Meeting House to John Rolffs Pinkerton, the son of Deborah W. Pinkerton and James C. Pinkerton, both of Tulsa, Okla. The Rev. Nicholas Van Dyke, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony. Mrs. Pinkerton, 26 years old, a graduate of Williams College, received a master's degree from the American Graduate School of International Management in Glendale, Ariz. She is the marketing services manager in Mons, Belgium, for ESCO Europe, a manufacturer of steel parts for the construction and mining industries. Her father is a director at DML & Associates, management consultants in New York and Paris.

title: Unique Perspective
description: Two recent articles about the issues raised by the cancellation of the Robert Mapplethorpe photography exhibit at the Corcoran Gallery in Washington - Hilton Kramer's ''Is Art Above the Laws of Decency? (July 2) and Grace Glueck's ''Art on the Firing Line'' (July 9) - have prompted an unusually large number of letters from readers. Here is a sampling. To the Editor: As the female model who collaborated with Robert Mapplethorpe to produce sexually explicit images, among them ''Marty & Veronica,'' a photo depicting oral sex that hung in the Whitney show, I was very curious to read Hilton Kramer's article. Speaking as one of the sex objects and as an artist, I believe my opinion comes from a unique perspective.

title: A Burned-Out Light Bulb and Other Tragedies
description: WHEN I LEFT POLAND IN 1981, to attend the opening of my play ''Cinders'' at the Royal Court Theater in London, I was sure I would be back in Warsaw in two weeks. It was a period of great hope. Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Communist Party leader, was publicly shaking hands with Lech Walesa, the head of Solidarity. To everybody's astonishment, a strange creature whose name was democracy, human dignity, or, simply, freedom, was being born in Central Europe.

title: Summer Nights Fit for Princesses And Picnickers
description: Heat or no heat, a royal affair, reigned over by Princess Margaret, opened the London Festival Ballet's engagement at the Metropolitan Opera House Tuesday night. It was in sharp contrast to the informality of the events of the rest of the week. The 350 guests who paid $500 or $1,000 a ticket to attend the opening performance and gala supper dance were at their tables when they were instructed to rise and stand as the Princess approached the Grand Tier. They did. The party was made possible by Emily Fisher Landau, who underwrote the evening.

title: SELLING A 'LIFE-STYLE' AT ONE-STOP FURNITURE SHOPSZ
description: The convenience demanded by young, dual-career couples is the driving force behind the boom in one-stop furniture shops, referred to as life-style stores. ''We are seemingly too lazy to do our own homework and we want to see everything at once, down to the napkin holders,'' said Mr. Brackett of the furniture manufacturers association.

title: Legacy of Modern Times, an L.I. Utopia
description: THE yellow octagonal building with vertical clapboard siding looks like a mini-circus tent. Brentwood's first schoolhouse, in use from 1857 to 1907, and the objective of preservationists, is hardly a typical little red schoolhouse. But, then, the people who built it were hardly typical.

title: Hotel Chains Plunge Into Life-Care Field
description: ''OF the current 65-plus American market,'' said Brian Swinton, leaning over the starched table linen and shimmering stemware in the dining room of the Quadrangle, the Marriott Corporation's new retirement development in Haverford, Pa., ''81 percent own their own home, 64 percent without a mortgage. This is a population that in the main has not only the benefit of Social Security, but also pensions.''

title: FICTION
description: RIVER SONG. By Craig Lesley. (Houghton Mifflin, $18.95.) In this worthy sequel to Craig Lesley's acclaimed first novel, ''Winterkill,'' readers once again follow the exploits of Danny Kachiah, a Nez Perce Indian, a drifter, migrant farm worker and small-time rodeo cowboy who has reclaimed his 17-year-old son Jack after his former wife's death. The boy hopes to follow in his father's footsteps on the rodeo circuit, but Danny has other ideas. Instead he plans to show his son the traditional ways of his people, heading for the ancestral salmon fishing grounds of the Nez Perce along the Columbia River in eastern Oregon. But Danny Kachiah is a man with a troubled past, haunted by images of his dead wife, his alcoholic father and his great-grandfather, Left Hand, a heroic warrior under the great chief Joseph. When a meeting with a medicine woman is arranged, she instructs Danny on the ancient healing procedures that he must undertake before he can purge these ghosts. The process is begun, and Danny returns to the fishing village - only to discover that the nets have been cut and several buildings dynamited, presumably by sport fishermen who have been attempting to force the Indians from their sacred lands. In presenting the resolution of this crisis, ''River Song'' becomes not only a tale of reconciliation between father and son, and of a people with their heritage. It also emerges as a skillfully told story that illuminates the plight of American Indians as they battle to keep their way of life alive.

title: Taste Versus Tastes
description: Two recent articles about the issues raised by the cancellation of the Robert Mapplethorpe photography exhibit at the Corcoran Gallery in Washington - Hilton Kramer's ''Is Art Above the Laws of Decency? (July 2) and Grace Glueck's ''Art on the Firing Line'' (July 9) - have prompted an unusually large number of letters from readers. Here is a sampling. To the Editor: The early proponents of the N.E.A. bent over backwards to avoid big-government domination of our vital and rowdy culture - that is, a European-style ministry of culture. We are a nation of tastes, not taste. Hand over decision-making to the many rather than the few and it is inevitable we will face an occasional Serrano or Mapplethorpe. But we receive in their stead the perpetual provocation and renewal that sharpens rather than dulls ''quality'' in the finest sense. I ask you to compare the high cultural achievements of any ''anarchic'' democratic society to any controlled system and tell me which one excels. DOUGLAS DAVIS New York

title: Wayward Pilot Convalescing
description: Thomas L. Root, the Washington lawyer who survived a mysterious gunshot and an 800-mile flight that ended with his crash into the Atlantic, is recovering from his injuries at his parents' home here, his father said today.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURe
description: The Infant Fraud

title: Company Offers Prepaid College Tuition Plan
description: A private company has proposed a nationwide ''pay now, attend later'' plan guaranteeing parents current tuition rates years before their children go to college.

title: From a Garden, A Gift to All
description: THE old gentleman's garden, a tightly planted crazy quilt of red, yellow, orange, pink and purple, always reminded me of my college economics professor.

title: Mark Jordan: Sports Car Stylist
description: When the Mazda Motor Corporation of Japan decided to open an automotive design studio in the United States in 1982, it hired the automotive stylist Mark Jordan.

title: Doing Windows
description: NONE OF THE 11 WINDOWS TO BE included in the exhibition ''Masterworks of Louis Comfort Tiffany'' have been on public display since the turn of the century. The show, opening at the Smithsonian Institution's Renwick Gallery in Washington on Sept. 29, will feature 65 Tiffany creations - lamps, vases, paintings among them - but the windows, lent by private sources, are at its heart. ''I've been in windows 20 years,'' says Art Femenella, who was commissioned by the Smithsonian to oversee the windows' restoration. ''This is the best collection of Tiffany I've seen.''

title:
INVESTING;
Bet on the Jockey, Not the Horse
description: LEAD: In recent months, several popular mutual funds closed to new investors. With $1.2 billion pouring in during the first six months of this year, the Windsor Fund, one of the largest and highest-yielding funds, closed to insure that its $7.2 billion in assets could be properly managed. Mutual Series also closed its Mutual Shares and Mutual

title: Carlton Salutes Philadelphia Fans
description: Steve Carlton saluted the fans of Philadelphia tonight as the Phillies honored the greatest left-handed pitcher in their history by retiring his number.

title: Private Art in Public Places
description: Little more than 15 years ago, Richard Manoogian, a Detroit industrialist, and Senator H. John Heinz 3d of Pennsylvania and his family had hardly begun amassing the assortment of American paintings and of Dutch and Flemish still lifes that they now own. Since then they have not always bought wisely, but they have bought with the aggressiveness that has allowed a generation of new collectors to achieve a prominence once accorded those who had worked for years refining their tastes. As evidence, the National Gallery of Art is presenting, through Sept. 4, ''American Paintings From the Manoogian Collection'' and ''Still Lifes of the Golden Age.''

title: Kathleen Daly Marries
description: Kathleen Mary Daly, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James C. Daly of Pleasantville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Joseph Alphonsus Emerson Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Emerson of Milton, Mass., at Holy Innocents Roman Catholic Church in Pleasantville. The Rev. Edward R. Daley officiated. Mrs. Emerson teaches social studies at the Framingham (Mass.) South High School. Her husband is an associate at his father's law firm, Emerson & Emerson, in Milton.

title: Spending, Politics And Darman's Slap at The Profligate American
description: JUST what is Richard G. Darman up to? Mr. Darman is President Bush's budget director, but this month he put in a strong bid to be the Administration's Big Thinker as well. In an address to the National Press Club, he offered both an overarching theme for the Bush Administration's endeavors and a warning that Americans are ''robbing the future to give to the present'' in an orgy of what he called ''cultural now-now-ism.''

title: Aimee R. Clark, Store Manager, To Wed in Fall
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Merrell Mays Clark of Scarsdale, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter AimeeRuthanna Clark to Matthew Charles Peterson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles O. Peterson of Montpelier, Vt. An October wedding is planned.

title: Ethnic Divisions Play Major Role in Florida Race
description: Two months after the death of Representative Claude Pepper, 11 candidates are fighting for his Congressional seat in a race marked by ethnic divisions reflecting a broader power struggle here among Hispanic, black and non-Hispanic white residents.

title: Patrick Frey: Fabric and Accessories Designer
description: Twenty years ago, when Patrick Frey was working in New York as a trainee at Brunschwig & Fils, the textile company, he wrote to his father in Paris that he was very happy and wanted to stay here.

title: ALCOHOL'S CHILD: A FATHER TELLS HIS TALE
description: THE BROKEN CORD By Michael Dorris. Foreword by Louise Erdrich. Illustrated. 300 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $18.95.

title: THE MORE THEY WRITE, THE MORE THEY WRITE
description: One night recently I woke my wife with a nudge. ''Now what is it?'' she asked. The question I had for her, urgent though it seemed to me, was a little anticlimactic under the circumstances. But I forged ahead. ''Darling,'' I said. ''Do you consider me . . . prolific?'' Her response will not bear repetition in these pages.

title: Mamaroneck to Buy Larchmont Motel
description: LEAD: FOR five years, a 53-room motel in Mamaroneck has brought diverging reactions from officials and residents of the town. While attempting to close down the Larchmont Motel because of drug use and other crime there, they have also reached out to help its homeless residents.

title: Home Alarms Prompt a Response: Rules and Fines
description: AT 2 A.M. one recent summer day, the Hartsdale living room was quiet. A day-old bouquet of roses with a balloon attached provided the only evidence that someone slept upstairs. But the humidity hung in the air, and gradually the helium-filled balloon began to lose pressure and bob gently over the coffee table.

title: Soldierly Conduct
description: To the Editor:

title: PASTIMES: Bridge
description: The game of bridge has occasionally made modest contributions to the reduction of international tensions. The players of Ireland and Northern Ireland regularly combine to form an Irish team in international events. In the Far East bridge contacts between players from China and Nationalist China have had an icebreaking effect. The same is true for the Near East.

title: PASTIMES: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Check tomato plants to be sure stems are tied securely to stakes; use cotton string or cloth. Do not neglect using water-soluble fertilizers for plants growing in window boxes, tubs or containers; plants need nutrients if leaves are beginning to turn yellow. Each morning pinch off faded flowers from petunias, geraniums, snapdragons and other annuals to keep them blooming; this deed is not necessary with impatiens and begonias, which are self-cleaning. Keep up with spray programs for fruit trees and roses. Bulbs for Spring

title: The Trees, and Tilt, in the Charter
description: After endless hours, hearings and drafts, the patient members of New York City's Charter Revision Commission are about to issue their final plan for revising city government. The effort, while monumental, still suffers from two flaws.

title: Demand Grows for Health Care at Home
description: ''SHE was wonderful,'' a 53-year-old English professor said, speaking about her 80-year-old mother who lives in White Plains. ''Just last year she was living alone, entertaining friends at bridge and driving everywhere,'' she said. ''Then, two days before Christmas, she slipped on a wet patch in front of her refrigerator and broke her hip.''

title: Helms Bill, Whatever Its Outcome, Could Leave Mark on Arts Grants
description: Senator Jesse Helms's move to bar Federal financing of ''obscene and indecent'' art, which sailed through a nearly deserted Senate on Wednesday evening, might not become law, some supporters acknowledge, but could have major influence anyhow.

title: Businesses Seeking New Soviet Markets
description: LEAD: WHEN Shelley Zeiger, a Trenton entrepreneur, cut the ribbon recently to signal the opening of his joint venture, the TrenMos restaurant, just off Moscow's Red Square, it was the culmination of a lifelong personal business relationship with the Soviet Union.

title: SLEEPING HIS WAY TO THE MIDDLE
description: SACRED MONSTER By Donald E. Westlake. 231 pp. New York: The Mysterious Press. $17.95.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 9 about Thuya Garden in Maine misidentified the landscape designer of Dumbarton Oaks. She was Beatrix Jones Farrand.

title: Hole-in-1 Odds Soar, Then Sink
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We had a parquet wood floor installed in two rooms over a year ago and are having trouble with tiles buckling. In one room the tongue-and-groove, 12-inch square tiles were put down over a plywood base and these tiles are O.K. In the other room the tiles were put down directly on a concrete slab (without an underlayment) and these tiles started to buckle across the width of the the room during the first summer. This buckling subsided during the winter. Will the buckling subside in time, and would it help if we weighted the tiles down?

title: New League Might Challenge Majors at Their Own Game
description: A new baseball league looms on the horizon, but the established major leagues either aren't taking it seriously or don't want to give the impression that they're taking it seriously.

title: Hospital Under Fire in Killing
description: Frustrated police officers said today that they might try to prosecute officials at a state mental hospital for not adequately supervising a patient who slipped out of the hospital Friday before he is said to have stabbed a 9-year-old girl to death at a sidewalk sale.

title: THE REGION: The First Debate; Candidates Take Aim, And the Target Is Koch
description: IS New York City succeeding in dealing with its problems, as Mayor Edward I. Koch contends, or is it in deep trouble, as his three Democratic challengers contend?

title: HOLD THE BILLION BOXES OF DETERGENT!
description: IF EVERYBODY BOUGHT ONE SHOE American Capitalism in Communist China. By Graeme Browning. 239 pp. New York: Hill & Wang. $18.95.

title: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York
description: SENATE

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Vanderbilt; Students Bringing Health Screening To Appalachians
description: While her friends are building resumes or vacationing, Jesse Germond, a medical student, is a summer intern examining women for possible effects of inadequate medical care in rural communities all over the South.

title: Getting in Shape For Rough Treks
description: FOR years, rugged individualists have been shouldering backpacks and heading for the high country. But more and more, less-than-rugged vacationers are embarking on guided group treks through rough, remote regions such as the Himalayas and the Andes. Some 40,000 people trekked in Nepal in 1988. Mountain Travel, the biggest American adventure travel operator, says its trek bookings are up 35 percent this year.

title: Reports Contrast Housing in New York City
description: Two reports issued last week presented sharply different pictures of New York City's efforts to build and rehabilitate housing.

title: NONFICTION
description: THE STEVEN McDONALD STORY. By Steven McDonald and Patti Ann McDonald with E. J. Kahn 3d. (Donald I. Fine, $18.95.) On July 12, 1986, Steven McDonald, a young New York City police officer, was gunned down in Central Park while questioning three youths about bicycle thefts. In this autobiography, written with his wife, Patti Ann, who was pregnant at the time of the shooting, and the journalist E. J. Kahn 3d, Officer McDonald, a devout Roman Catholic, recalls his last words as he blacked out were ''God, don't let me die.'' The youth who shot him is currently serving a 3- to 10-year prison sentence. Officer McDonald got what amounts to a life term. Paralyzed from the neck down when a bullet severed his spine, he has no feeling below his chin, cannot breathe for more than a few minutes without a respirator, can barely speak and needs constant medical attention. As he recounts at length in his book, the extent of his injuries made him a celebrity initially, though he did not feel in any way heroic and, at times, cursed his fate. What is most surprising, and honorable, is how Officer McDonald's struggle to cope, and the financial and emotional support his family received from fellow police officers, the news media, the Mayor's office, New York City businessmen, civic organizations and the Catholic diocese led him to a truly heroic understanding. ''The Steven McDonald Story'' combines inspirational messages, family history, police and medical lore, told alternately by Officer McDonald and his wife, with an introduction by John Cardinal O'Connor and a few first-person accounts from individuals such as Mayor Edward I. Koch, who, in a peculiar aside, pats himself on the back for his extemporaneous eulogies at police funerals. Throughout the book, Officer McDonald dwells on the positive aspects of New York City, insisting that ''there is more love in this city than there are street corners.''

title: A Show Rider's Longest Fall
description: There is no way for a show rider to train for a fall. The horse goes one way, the body goes another way, and the former Olympian Michael Matz has an old surgical scar on his right shoulder to prove it.

title: A Horse and Carriage To Satisfy All Tastes
description: LEAD: HISTORY - or at least historical verisimilitude - is big business in Connecticut, and John and Janice Allegra rent it out on the hoof and by the carriage-load.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
There's No Job Too Big or Too Small
description: LEAD: IF the Marquis de Sade could come back today, he'd be a general contractor.

title: Discoveries on the Run
description: I AM a runner who has never had a ''high.'' Although I've run through 20 years of shoes, I've never experienced the spike of good feeling that I've heard and read about. But maybe I've felt something better.

title: Will Aikman Start?
description: He has a six-year, $11-million contract with the Dallas Cowboys. But does Troy Aikman have a starting job?

title: Homemade Tapes Can Be the Life (or Death) of the Party
description: Sooner or later, a rock critic has to put up or shut up. For me, that time is pre-party time, when the host, with a nod toward my ever-vaster record collection, asks me to make a dance tape or two. ''Sure, no problem,'' I say, with mounting dread. An awesome responsibility has been placed in my hands.

title: Dinkins Asserts City Has Failed Needy Children
description: The Manhattan Borough President, David N. Dinkins, yesterday denounced the Koch administration's policies on children's issues for what he termed a failure to cope with the plight of abused, sick, neglected, homeless and impoverished children.

title: Chicken Industry Called Unsafe and Uncontrolled
description: A coalition of farmers, workers and consumer groups has issued a broad attack on chicken producers, saying that excessive speed on processing lines increases bacteria contamination and aggravates health hazards for workers and consumers.

title: Power of the Marketplace
description: Two recent articles about the issues raised by the cancellation of the Robert Mapplethorpe photography exhibit at the Corcoran Gallery in Washington - Hilton Kramer's ''Is Art Above the Laws of Decency? (July 2) and Grace Glueck's ''Art on the Firing Line'' (July 9) - have prompted an unusually large number of letters from readers. Here is a sampling. To the Editor: Hilton Kramer's and Grace Glueck's articles well reflect upon the problem of censorship of art. But since both focus exclusively upon government censorship, another, more pervasive and perhaps more pernicious type of censorship may go unnoticed.

title: The Good Old Days in the Badlands
description: LEAD: A SOUVENIR edition of the newspaper in Medora, N.D., quotes Theodore Roosevelt's assessment of his time in this rough Western region: ''If it had not been for what I learned during the years spent in North Dakota, I never would have been President of the United States.'' While a visit to this town along the Little Missouri River will not assure your residing in the White White House, it is certain to provide you with plenty of what the asthmatic Roosevelt was looking for when he first came west in

title: Miss McAlister Has a Wedding
description: Caroline Louise McAlister, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Floyd McAlister of Sacramento, Calif., and Clinton DeBevoise Corcoran, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony C. Corcoran of Ridgefield, Conn., were married yesterday at the Little Chapel of the Glenn Memorial United Methodist Church at Emory University in Atlanta. The Rev. Francis K. Githieya, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: September Bridal For Leslie Cecil And J. C. Michael
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald Cecil of Harrison, N.Y., and Eze, France, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Leslie Cecil, to J. Creighton Michael, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Michael of Nashville. A September wedding is planned.

title: About Cars; Miata: Magic of Simplicity
description: I wheeled into the restaurant lot and parked where I could see the car from a window table. There were a couple of reasons for that. One, I liked to look at the car myself and, two, everybody else was nuts about it.

title: U.S. IS CRITICIZED ON SPY DETERRENCE
description: The chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee says the Government's efforts to deter espionage are being thwarted by bureaucratic bickering, inadequate budgets and a failure of Presidential leadership.

title: 'Siegfried' to Open First Wagnerfest
description: ''IT'S a very personal experience,'' said the soprano Lili Seggos as she discussed the Valhalla Wagnerfest, which bows this Saturday and next with full-scale performances of Wagner's ''Siegfried.''

title: PREMIER GETS POST
description: President Wojciech Jaruzelski resigned today as the leader of Poland's Communist Party and was replaced by his close associate, Prime Minister Mieczyslaw Rakowski, the Government press agency said.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Bishop; Deadline Looms In the Purchase Of a Campus
description: A prospective investor from Lubbock is trying to buy the campus of Bishop College, this city's sole traditionally black institution, which entered bankruptcy in 1987 and closed last August.

title: Strategic Retreat In Detroit
description: SOMETHING unusual happened this month when President Bush proposed a clean-air bill that could cost automakers $18 billion in the next decade: The industry greeted the sweeping proposals with qualified approval.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; For Yale, a Challenge in New Haven
description: WHILE many cities across Connecticut agonize over dilapidated housing in ravaged neighborhoods, a group of college students and volunteers is making a small but important contribution to the betterment of a rundown, drug-ridden neighborhood in New Haven called The Hill.

title: The Australian Solution
description: LEAD: Enough statistics, O.K.?

title: My Fair Ladybug
description: Ladybug, ladybug, you've found a home. Last week, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo signed legislation designating coccinella novemnotata - an orange-and-black species of ladybug - as the official New York State insect, putting it up there with the state flower (rose), state animal (beaver), state fossil (sea scorpion) and state muffin (apple). Like a lot of legislation, the effects of this measure may be more symbolic than real, simply to help educate the public about ''the important role of the insect,'' said a spokeswoman for the Governor. Said Louis Sorkin, an entomologist at the American Museum of Natural History, ''People often associate happy thoughts with ladybugs.''

title: WHAT'S NEW IN THE FURNITURE BUSINESS;
description: Kings and queens have always had furniture highly crafted and embellished with symbolism and art. ''But I don't know if there was ever a market for it,'' said Lois Lambert, owner of the Gallery of Functional Art in Santa Monica, Calif.

title: A Question Of Semantics
description: Two recent articles about the issues raised by the cancellation of the Robert Mapplethorpe photography exhibit at the Corcoran Gallery in Washington - Hilton Kramer's ''Is Art Above the Laws of Decency? (July 2) and Grace Glueck's ''Art on the Firing Line'' (July 9) - have prompted an unusually large number of letters from readers. Here is a sampling. To the Editor: One element in Mr. Kramer's article disturbs me: his free use of the term ''art'' without clear definition. May not much of the confusion in the art world today be due to semantics? Call Mapplethorpe's works just photos, and Serra's ''Tilted Arc'' a bronze fence, and we would probably see them with different eyes. Values in much that transpires in the art world are enhanced by inflated vocabulary, with the label ''art'' sufficient to sanctify many works and blur them from clear scrutiny.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We had a parquet wood floor installed in two rooms over a year ago and are having trouble with tiles buckling. In one room the tongue-and-groove, 12-inch square tiles were put down over a plywood base and these tiles are O.K. In the other room the tiles were put down directly on a concrete slab (without an underlayment) and these tiles started to buckle across the width of the the room during the first summer. This buckling subsided during the winter. Will the buckling subside in time, and would it help if we weighted the tiles down?

title: Concert Violinist Is Seized on Drug Charges
description: Eugene Fodor Jr., a prominent classical violinist, has been arrested on drug charges here on Martha's Vineyard and is being held in $50,000 bail.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: LION AT THE DOOR. By David Attoe. (Little, Brown, $17.95.) In this tightly written tripartite debut novel, David Attoe traces a spiral around a damaged life. Young Hazel Sapper is growing up rough in a mining town in Britain's Midlands. Cheeky in the face of punishment and full of love for the fields and meadows near her home, she is also deeply traumatized, having been raped by her father for as long as she can recall.

title: AT LAST, A BOY TO TOY WITH
description: LEAD: SECOND FIDDLE By Mary Wesley. 184 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

title: Balancing Video Ratings And Artwork
description: What sights should you and your children have to endure in a video store? For a young medium that many still associate with pornography and violence, often pictured on lurid cassette boxes, this is a contentious topic at a time when state and local governments are increasingly being urged to regulate store content.

title: Unrecorded Victory
description: The box score shows that the winning pitcher in the Athletics' 8-7 victory over the Seattle Mariners in Oakland on Friday night was Todd Burns. Box scores don't tell everything. Under the rules of baseball, Burns was entitled to the victory because as the fourth of the four pitchers used by Oakland during the see-saw battle, he was in the game when Oakland broke a tie in the bottom of the 11th inning.

title: The Emperor's Clothes
description: Two recent articles about the issues raised by the cancellation of the Robert Mapplethorpe photography exhibit at the Corcoran Gallery in Washington - Hilton Kramer's ''Is Art Above the Laws of Decency? (July 2) and Grace Glueck's ''Art on the Firing Line'' (July 9) - have prompted an unusually large number of letters from readers. Here is a sampling. To the Editor: God forbid that in the name of art we must now accept sadomasochism and pedophilia as valid expressions in art. Thanks to Hilton Kramer for putting some much needed clothes back on the emperor. DARRYL DAVIS Brooklyn

title:
ART;
Collage in a Diverse Context
description: LEAD: THERE are many reasons why an exhibition focusing on collage, assemblage and construction warrants attention, and most deal with the significance of these nontraditional approaches.

title: Saying Goodbye to a Fantasy
description: I WILL be 40 this year, and I am not quite sure how I should feel. This momentous year has coincidentally signaled the reappearance of some women of my past who helped shape my young thoughts on adulthood. My contemplation of 40 began when Harriet Nelson and June Cleaver tried to convince Kate Jackson that it was O.K. to be a working mother. It has continued with their motherly reassurance about everything from fast foods to stomach remedies.

title: Susan Woodring Plans a Wedding
description: Dr. and Mrs. Richard E. Woodring of Philadelphia have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan M. Woodring, to Craig N. Ahrens, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert W. Ahrens of Wellesley Hills, Mass. A September wedding is planned.

title: Ainsley McNeil Weds John Sadlo In Massachusetts
description: St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Weston, Mass., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Ainsley Robin McNeil, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Robin McNeil of Weston, to John William Sadlo, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley John Sadlo of North Tonawanda and Franklinville, N.Y. The Rev. David Van Dusen performed the ceremony.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Bermuda
description: Once or twice a year Bermuda seizes the opportunity to cast off its proper, well-manicured image to engage in islandwide fun and frolics.

title: Terence Frawley Wed to Tabitha Zane
description: At St. Elizabeth's Roman Catholic Church in New York, Tabitha Nelson Zane, the daughter of Suzanne Pederson-Zane of New York and John Zane of Santa Monica, Calif., was married yesterday to Terence Andrew Frawley, a son of Judge and Mrs. John D. Frawley of Elmira, N.Y. The Rev. Brian E. Frawley, the bridegroom's brother, performed the ceremony.

title: Choking the Poor on Medigap
description: Three medigap policies. One major medical policy. Plus Medicare. Fear and ignorance had driven the 75-year-old Philadelphia woman to cope with her husband's skyrocketing medical bills by desperately buying one medical insurance policy after another. Though she could barely afford necessities, she wound up spending thousands on policies she did not need.

title: Juliette Robbins Engaged to Marry Edward B. Bland
description: Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Robbins of Braintree, Vt., and Troy, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Juliette Laddon Robbins to Edward Bingham Bland, a son of Mrs. Richard H. Downes of Lawrenceville, N.J., and the late James Edward Bland. An August wedding is planned.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Miami; Teams Looking To Community For New Fans
description: The University of Miami Hurricanes have regularly been winning or coming close to national football championships during the 1980's, but they have been doing so with practically no vocal support from the university's Hispanic neighborhood. Now the school is calling signals that indicate it wants to win that game as well.

title:
VIEW OF SPORT;
Truth Didn't Understand the Consequences
description: LEAD: In the early 1980's, when I was old for a fighter and young for a referee, I met a man who made a profound change in the way I viewed boxing. Dr. Bennet Derby is a professor of Clinical Neurology and Pathology at New York University. I had the opportunity to study with him in his capacity as medical adviser to the New York State Athletic Commission when he was giving seminars on the subject of neurological assessments inside a boxing ring.

title: To Solve the Waste-Disposal Problem, Trash Makers Must Make Less Trash
description: Some world problems seem remote from Connecticut, but not the issue of trash. It is piling up in our backwayrds, begging to be burned, buried or recycled, and spawning a new industry of waste management.

title: Question Of the Week; Are Yanks Making The Right Moves?
description: The only move the Yankees should make, they can't. Get rid of George Steinbrenner. Until then, everything else is meaningless. JOHN CORCOS LEVY New York

title: CAMPUS LIFE: University of Texas; Infamous Weapons Are Put Up for Sale
description: The bullet marks from a 1966 sniping attack are no longer visible on buildings on the University of Texas campus. But the incident was recalled this month when the weapons the sniper used in the mass killing went on sale.

title: Scarsdale's Staging of 'Edwin Drood' Discovers Local Talent
description: WHEN Anthony Ross, the director of the Scarsdale Summer Music Theater, chose ''The Mystery of Edwin Drood'' for this summer's student production, he did not know that the playwright lived in Scarsdale. Rupert Holmes himself, his mind on the coming Broadway opening of his new play, ''Accomplice,'' was unaware of the summer theater's plans. It was the kind of serendipity befitting a writer who lets each Drood audience vote on how to end the play.

title: California Trend: Serious Magazines
description: In the trend-conscious world of Southern California magazines, where the staples are normally such fare as ''What Price Plastic Surgery?'' and ''Pools of the Stars,'' a new movement is emerging: seriousness.

title: Molly Whitaker to Wed in September
description: Mr. and Mrs. Hal Cummings Whitaker of Baltimore and Islesford, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Molleson Whitaker to Charles O'Donovan 4th, a son of Dr. and Mrs. O'Donovan of Ruxton, Md. A September wedding is planned.

title: Keeping The Deepest Secret of All
description: AS a child, I found it very hard to keep secrets, especially if they were happy secrets. A surprise party. Or a very special present. Or a special someone coming to visit. Serious secrets were another thing. I didn't like serious secrets. I didn't like knowing that something not too good was about to happen.

title: Bird Breaks a Bone
description: Larry Bird fractured a bone in his back five minutes into his first scrimmage at the Boston Celtics summer camp in Waltham, Mass., last night and is expected to be sidelined for four to six weeks.

title: Libby Ginway And a Doctor To Wed in '90
description: Mr. and Mrs. John R. Ginway of Lake Forest, Ill., and Mantoloking, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Elizabeth Ginway, to Dr. Cullen Ashley McAllen of San Antonio. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Ashley McAllen of Weslaco and Kerrville, Texas.

title: A Skirmish Over Seaborne Drugs
description: To the casual observer, a container of pumpkins transported by sea and resting on the docks here not long ago appeared harmless enough. But to the United States Customs inspectors poking bagfuls of the vegetable in search of cocaine, there was the very real possibility that the produce was just another hiding place for smuggled drugs.

title: Money-Back Guarantees Offered With Condos
description: PEOPLE who buy condominiums at Greystone on the Lake in Shelton or at Thermos on the Thames in Norwich will not have to worry about the value of their units dropping over the next few years. Or so the developers say.

title: American Tourist Shot Dead In Kenya Game-Park Ambush
description: Gunmen ambushed a group of American visitors touring a Kenyan game park, killing a Connecticut woman, wounding a man and robbing the group of money and jewelry, a victim said.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We had a parquet wood floor installed in two rooms over a year ago and are having trouble with tiles buckling. In one room the tongue-and-groove, 12-inch square tiles were put down over a plywood base and these tiles are O.K. In the other room the tiles were put down directly on a concrete slab (without an underlayment) and these tiles started to buckle across the width of the the room during the first summer. This buckling subsided during the winter. Will the buckling subside in time, and would it help if we weighted the tiles down?

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Tourists in Rome Warned on Attire And Behavior

title: How to Succeed in Business Without Even Going
description: AFTER working for five years as a producer of videotapes on employee training for Chase Manhattan Bank, Carol Rugh of Norwalk decided she had reached her plateau. The repetition of clients and the tedium of the same projects had become a major frustration. On the train into Grand Central Terminal one morning, Mrs. Rugh observed the blank expressions of her fellow commuters and decided she had had enough.

title: The Name's Serious. Yahoo Serious.
description: Tasmania, 1905. A young apple farmer with carrot-colored hair that forms a mushroom cloud around his head roams the orchards with his pet Tasmanian devil. But instead of worrying about harvest schedules or thunderstorms, he has on his mind nothing less than the state of the universe.

title: CONSUMER RATES
FASHION: Leading Questions; Are Pants Fit Attire for the Office?
description: Pants overshadowed skirts in most designers' fall collections, whether they were aimed at the high-fashion customer or the working woman. But many women worry about wearing trousers to the office. While the fashion and advertising industries accept pants, the banking and corporate worlds tend to be more conservative. Executive and professional women may no longer feel they must wear suits to work, but do they consider pants appropriate office attire? Gail M. Dudack, institutional analyst, S. G. Warburg & Company:

title: Soviet Congress Gets Dissident Bloc
description: Impatient Soviet legislators launched an independent parliamentary faction today to combat what their leaders called ''the Communist Party aristocracy'' and ''the Gorbachev status quo.''

title: Catering to a New Batch of Home Buyers
description: With baby boomers nesting, furniture sales - listless through the 1970's - are growing once again. Retail sales have climbed 24 percent since 1985, to $29.4 billion last year, according to the American Furniture Manufacturers Association, a trade group.

title: Music Is For Smiling, Too
description: A few years ago, Austrian television made a documentary about HK Gruber, the Viennese composer whose new Cello Concerto, written for Yo-Yo Ma, will have its first performance Thursday night as part of the annual Tanglewood Festival of Contemporary Music. In the television program, Mr. Gruber plays a sratchy old 78-r.p.m. disk of himself as a Vienna Choir Boy. He is also shown playing the double bass in the ORF Symphony, a job he has held since 1960. And, of course, he doesn't fail to mention that his great-great-grandfather happened to be Franz Xaver Gruber, the Austrian church organist who wrote the Christmas carol ''Silent Night.''

title: Eric Gaskins: Fashion Designer
description: ''I like clean, simple shapes and I'm trying to eliminate as much decoration as possible; color and line are all you need.''

title: Corrections
description: A brief report with an article on June 4 about whales off Montauk, L.I., misstated the schedule of service on the Long Island Rail Road between Montauk and Pennsylvania Station in New York. The departure and arrival times given applied to service on Saturday and Sunday, not Monday to Friday.

title: CONNECTICUT Q&A: William F. Werwaiss; 'It Costs $2 Million to Put a Switch In'
description: WILLIAM F. WERWAISS oversees regulatory matters at the Southern New England Telephone Company and has been increasingly busy as the company's rates and services are scrutinized and as deregulation of the intrastate telephone market is weighed.

title: TRAVEL WRITING: WHY I BOTHER
description: I used to have some sympathy with the bewildered browser in a bookstore who, seeing the stacks of travel books, asked, ''What are they for?'' Until recently I felt that was a fair question. The travel book had always seemed to me a somewhat insufficient form. Why write about that country? What's the occasion? What's the point? So often such journeys appeared little more than excuses for authors in search of material - rather suspicious outings, I always thought.

title: The Palm House Returns After a Disappearing Act
description: For architectural purists, few events this season have equaled in impact the brief opening in London of the newly renovated Palm House at the Royal Botanic Gardens at Kew. Beginning in late 1985, this crystalline 19th-century palace of a conservatory underwent a $12.8 million restoration during which all of its immense, hull-like curvilinear walls of glass and wrought iron disappeared and then reappeared in fresh materials. It returned, as if by magic, as the same sleek, multi-tiered structure with what is called its ''Victorian jelly mold'' profile that has made the Palm House, a sanctuary for tropical plants, one of the most distinctive and repeated forms in modern architecture. Illuminated from within at night, and reflected in a pond the full length of its facade, the Palm House emerged as the fragile ''balloon of light'' described in a recent poem by the English poet Herbert Lomas. The new Palm House has renewed its hold on the imagination.

title: Gnats, Ticks, Time and Happiness
description: IT is almost August. The locals say a wet spring has spawned the enormous clouds of gnats, and when you're not fanning them away from your face, you're checking your ankles for ticks. You are 80 miles from home, living temporarily in the Hamptons, in a cottage that smells of mold, Lysol and low tide. Your sunburn is blotchy and a peculiar spot has suddenly appeared on your left arm.

title: Ms. Evans to Wed James P. Haynie
description: Mr. and Mrs. John J. Evans 3d of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., and Center Harbor, N.H., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter Elizabeth Blakeley Evans and James Phillip Haynie, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth H. Haynie of Des Moines.

title: Simple Place in a Sophisticated Spot
description: EVERY year, residents from the Moriches to Montauk spend long summer evenings grumbling about the local restaurants: the crowds, the green summer service staffs, and the talented chefs who departed with last winter's first chilly blast.

title:
Long Island Interview Mary L. Cleave;
Astronaut Heads Back to Her Starry Future
description: LEAD: MARY L. CLEAVE, one of 13 women who are astronauts in the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's program, completed her second mission aboard the space shuttle Atlantis in April 1989.

title: Fostering America's Interests Abroad. . .
description: The 1980's has been a difficult decade for the World Bank. The early Reagan Administration shunned the official agency as an international welfare bureaucracy. Then the bank's reputation was hurt when a turbulent global economy shattered development efforts in Latin America and Sub-Saharan Africa. But the bank has since regained the support of the United States Government and adjusted many of its programs to cope better with the new global political economy.

title: Ms. Ledis to Wed David A. Cannon
description: Dr. and Mrs. Seymour Ledis of Levittown, Pa., have announced October wedding plans for their daughter, Nina Rae Ledis, and David Adam Cannon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan T. Cannon of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Longboat Key, Fla.

title: In Barnum Exhibit, Memories Go 'Round and 'Round
description: A PLUMP black pig, a handsome parade horse and a horse bedecked with red and amber jewels are among the beautifully carved and richly decorated carousel animals in the exhibition ''Catch a Brass Ring: Carousel Art From the Charlotte Dinger Collection'' at the Barnum Museum in Bridgeport.

title: Fishing the Waters Off San Francisco
description: AS I set off from Fisherman's Wharf on my first salmon fishing trip a decade ago, a soft pink dawn silhouetted San Francisco's skyline behind me and the full moon hung over the Golden Gate Bridge ahead. That was enough. I was hooked on salmon fishing before I ever put a line in the water.

title: Don't Minimize Government Terror in Salvador; Symbol of Violence
description: To the Editor:

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: LARRY ENGEL;
Storytelling With a TV Camera
description: LEAD: ''SERENDIPITY'' is how Larry Engel explains winning his first daytime Emmy award for cinematography. Filmed in Antarctica, his five half-hour episodes appeared on the Public Broadcasting Service science series ''3-2-1 Contact,'' produced by the Children's Television Workshop.

title: 'You Must Remember This'
description: To the Editor:

title: Skateboarders Outgrow Their 'Bad Boy' Image
description: For Jeron Hayes, there is only one true purpose to summer. It is the best time to work on wall rides, rail slides, inverts and tail slides. It is the best time to perfect maneuvers that will impress peers. It is the best time to ride a skateboard.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: ARLINGTON, VA.;
Marriott's First Coming Down
description: LEAD: THE Twin Bridges Marriott Motor Lodge in Arlington, Va., the first of nearly 500 hotels in the international Marriott Corporation chain, is to be razed before the end of the year to make way for an office development by the property owner, Equitable Real Estate Investment Management.

title: IN WOLFE'S CLOTHING
description: IN THE SHADOW OF THE GIANT: THOMAS WOLFE Correspondence of Edward C. Aswell and Elizabeth Nowell, 1949-1958. Edited by Mary Aswell Doll and Clara Stites. Illustrated. 256 pp. Athens: Ohio University Press. $27.95.

title: Musical to Reopen the Old Shakespeare
description: BEGINNING Wednesday, the American Conservatory Theater in San Francisco will be reactivating the former American Shakespeare Theater in Stratford with a mini-season of Sondheim and Shaw.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''When you reach the point where you're in danger of having more known spies than known surveillers, you've got problems.'' - Senator David L. Boren, Intelligence Committee chairman. [ 15:1. ]

title: Baines to Rangers For Fletcher
description: The Texas Rangers got the big bat they were seeking when they acquired the outfielder-designated hitter Harold Baines from the Chicago White Sox today for the shortstop Scott Fletcher and two top prospects.

title: Nancy Schulman Engaged to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Schulman of Kings Point, L.I., have announced plans for a September wedding for their daughter Nancy Schulman and Dr. Andrew I. Soiefer, the son of Estelle Wolinetz Soiefer of Great Neck, L.I., and the late Leon B. Soiefer.

title: Using Brokers to Sell Your Business
description: Last year, when Isadore Feinberg, chairman of the Delta Truck Body Company in Skippack, Pa., tried to sell a factory that he owned in Los Angeles, he found the task too time-consuming. He interviewed some business brokers to handle the job, but was put off by their requests for upfront fees. After many tries, he found a broker, Edmond F. Schnieders Jr. of Carlsbad, Calif., who was willing to wait for his commission. Mr. Feinberg subsequently sold the factory for $1 million more than his original asking price.

title: Thatcher's Britain Is the Model for 1992
description: The aim of Europe 1992 is to create a single large market in which increased competition will drive down prices and offer more choice to consumers. We call this the single market. I would like to explain why I think it will be good for Europe and for the United States.

title: Don't Minimize Government Terror in Salvador; Use Aid Leverage
description: To the Editor:

title: Finish Time Is Flawed Measure
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Making Use of Tomatoes on a Daily Basis
description: RIPE locally grown tomatoes are finally here. Because there is only a two- to three-month window of opportunity for enjoying them, they are worth savoring on a daily basis.

title: Golf
description: Casper Leads Seniors: Billy Casper marveled at his own performance after shooting a five-under-par 65 to lead the British Seniors Open with a nine-under-par 201 after the third round at Turnberry, Scotland, yesterday. Casper was being pursued by Bob Charles of New Zealand, who also shot a 65 for 203. So did 50-year-old Babe Hiskey of the United States, who had a 65 for 207 and third place.(AP) Stewart Ahead of Sutton: Payne Stewart shot an eight-under-par 64 yesterday for a one-stroke lead over Hal Sutton after three rounds of the $1 million Buick Open at Grand Blanc, Mich. Stewart was at 14-under-par 202 after three trips around the 7,014-yard course at Warwick Hills, about 50 miles north of Detroit. Sutton shot a 68.(AP) Tennis Mayotte to Play Gilbert: Top-seeded Tim Mayotte and second-seeded Brad Gilbert registered dissimilar victories yesterday to advance to the finals of the Sovran Bank Classic in Washington. Mayotte, ranked No. 11 in the world, yielded only 10 points on his serve in an easy 6-3, 6-2 victory over Todd Witsken, while Gilbert rallied from an 0-2 deficit in the third set to salvage a 6-4, 3-6, 6-3 victory over Richey Reneberg. Mayotte, who has not lost a set in four matches in the tournament, and Gilbert, ranked No. 12, will vie tonight for the $50,575 top prize.(AP) Prpic to Face Jaite: Martin Jaite of Argentina defeated Jens Woehrmann of West Germany, 5-7, 6-4, 6-3, yesterday to advance to the final of a grand prix tournament in Stuttgart, West Germany. Goran Prpic of Yugoslavia beat Sergio Bruguera of Spain, 3-6, 7-5, 6-1, in the other semifinal match and will meet Jaite today.(AP) Maleeva and Hack in Final: Top-seeded Katerina Maleeva of Bulgaria and an unseeded qualifier, Sabine Hack of West Germany, yesterday gained the final of the Volvo Ladies International tournament in Bastad, Sweden. Maleeva beat fourth-seeded Sandra Cecchini of Italy, 6-4, 2-6, 6-4. Hack defeated Maria Strandlund of Sweden, 6-2, 6-3. (AP) Sanchez and Novacek Win Matches: Emilio Sanchez of Spain and Karel Novacek of Czechoslovakia won semifinal matches in the Netherlands Nabisco Grand Prix tournament yesterday in Hilversum. Sanchez, seeded second, beat fifth-seeded Paolo Cane of Italy, 6-2, 6-2, and Novacek defeated Tomas Carbonell of Spain, 6-3, 7-6.(AP) Horse Show West German Wins Jumping Class: Dirk Schroeder of West Germany turned in a fast, faultless jumpoff aboard Lacross yesterday to win the main show jumping class in the $148,000 Stockholm international horse show. Schroeder clocked 41.29 seconds in an 11-way jumpoff to beat Hap Hansen on Last Laff. Hansen, of Coto di Casa, Calif., clocked 46.15. Rudolf Letter of Switzerland was third on the Olympic Stadium course, which had obstacles up to 5 feet 3 inches.(AP) Soccer Missouri and Virginia Clubs Win: The Busch Soccer Club of St. Louis scored three first-half goals yesterday to defeat the Chargers of Clearwater, Fla., 3-0, to capture the boys-under-16 title at the United States national youth soccer championships at Mitchel Park in Uniondale, L.I. Jason St. Gemme started the scoring with an 18-yard shot at 6:59. Derek Phillips added a second goal at 22:20, and Matthew McAvin closed out the scoring at 30:18 in the competition for the D.J. Niotis Cup.

title: Why A.T.& T. and Intel Linked Up
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has not been able to capitalize on its networking and telecommunications expertise in the business computer market. It has sold personal computers under the A.T.& T. label since 1984, but both the sales and the technology of the machines have been disappointing.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-17

title: Hitter's Big Switch
description: There is little glory in being the best hitter on the worst team, but Keith Moreland, who has been leading the Detroit Tigers with a .299 batting average, is about to get a different perspective of the American League East. Moreland, who can play first, third, the outfield or as a designated hitter, was traded by the last-place Tigers to the first-place Baltimore Orioles in exchange for a minor league pitcher, Brian Dubois. (AP)

title: Question Of the Week; Are Yanks Making The Right Moves?
description: Whoever thought that changing the Henderson-Washington-Winfield trio to a Polonia-Kelly-Barfield outfield would improve the team chemistry and actually make the Yanks a more interesting team to watch? A new bulldog pitcher, Walt Terrell, should add to Thrift's general manager plaudits. Hawkins-Terrell-Parker form a decent 1-2-3 rotation, and Chuck Cary has been extremely bright of late. Now, the Yanks are only one pitcher away from winning it all: Bob Feller. JEFFREY DIAMANT Staten Island

title: Helen Lindley Marries
description: Helen Stokes Lindley, the daughter of Daniel A. Lindley Jr. of New York and Evanston, Ill., and the late Amy Hoyt Lindley, and Paul Howard Hastings, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Hastings of Walla Walla, Wash., were married yesterday at Grace Episcopal Church in New York by the Rev. Christopher A. Brown. The bride, the stepdaughter of Lucia Woods Lindley, is a medical social worker at St. Vincent's Hospital Medical Center in New York. The bridegroom is a graphic artist.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: WITH all the venom directed at the Garden State Parkway lately, that luckless road probably can assume the unofficial title of New Jersey's most despised thoroughfare.

title: Review/Theater; A Harbach Musical From 1910
description: The Manhattan dance studio that is the setting for the first act of the Otto Harbach-Karl Hoschna musical ''Madame Sherry'' is a place where twittery socialities play at being budding Isadora Duncans. In ''Aesthetic Dancing/Every Little Movement,'' the opening number of the Goodspeed Opera House's glowing revival of the 1910 show, half a dozen students waft about the stage, their chiffon-draped arms spread like giant butterfly wings in an interpretive dance that looks at once silly and sensuous.

title: A Little Censorship
description: Two recent articles about the issues raised by the cancellation of the Robert Mapplethorpe photography exhibit at the Corcoran Gallery in Washington - Hilton Kramer's ''Is Art Above the Laws of Decency? (July 2) and Grace Glueck's ''Art on the Firing Line'' (July 9) - have prompted an unusually large number of letters from readers. Here is a sampling. To the Editor: What an astonishing column by Hilton Kramer. Mr. Kramer attacks, in an extraordinarily patronizing and condescending fashion, the judgment of the ''art-world establishment'' of which he has been one of the principal protagonists over the past years.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: THE REV. HUGH J. CORIGAN;
Management Training for the Parish Priest
description: LEAD: SMALL-BUSINESS people of all kinds have discovered how a computer, along with professional management techniques, can increase their organization and efficiency. So why not priests, who often supervise dozens of employees and oversee budgets that reach hundreds of thousands of dollars?

title: Those Silly, Bony, Hairy Knees of Summer
description: To the Editor:

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: MADISON, WIS.;
State Capital Moves Upscale
description: LEAD: RESIDENTIAL development directed toward affluent buyers or renters is making strides in this capital of 170,000 residents. Builders are not only finding interesting older buildings and recycling them to residential use, but also are building new housing.

title: Small Businesses Also Need Full Health Insurance Deductibility
description: To the Editor:

title: The Diversity of Victorian Majolica
description: Life-size earthenware storks, fish-patterned platters, leaf-embellished tureens - all in the brilliantly colored majolica glazes popularized in the Renaissance and revived in the Victorian period - have been pursued increasingly over the last decade by collectors, dealers and museum curators.

title: Decoys That Lure Collectors
description: IN a good season in Canada (and the fall of 1876 was a good season) the hunter and decoy carver George Warin could shoot 824 ducks during their annual migration. The Migratory Birds Convention Act of 1917 ended carnage on that scale, but thousands of duck decoys - the market hunters' essential tools - remain from those days. A thinner but unbroken stream of Canada geese, mallards, mergansers, bluebills, pintails, canvasbacks and wood ducks continued to emerge from cedar and pine blocks until they were displaced by plastic decoys in the 1950's.

title: The Gracious Airs of Newport
description: NEWPORT, R.I., most august of American resorts, is 350 years old this year. The oil spill in Narragansett Bay was a nasty birthday present, but it closed the beaches only briefly. Vacationers who prefer swimming, sunbathing and sailing can pursue the traditional seaside pleasures at Newport in this anniversary year, as always. But if that's all they do, they'll be missing a lot. Newport offers the most varied experience of vacation places, and it is very accessible.

title: Visions of Communal Life in Two Shows
description: At the Pelham Art Center are two exhibitions - ''City Life'' and ''Living Above the Store.'' The first is a group effort by the artists Walter Benke, Michael Singletary and Linda Schneiderman; the second, a solo by the photographer Tom Pich.

title: Lessons for Prisoners and Prisons
description: GETTING tough on crime is easy. The problem is what to do with the criminals afterward. Handed the charge of making room for an ever-spiraling number of inmates, jailers across the New York region are faced increasingly with a task that society has chosen to shirk - training, educating and rehabilitating a population that is overwhelmingly illiterate, unemployed or drug-addicted.

title: FASHION: Gone Fishing; If the Fin Fits, Someone Is Wearing It
description: August is the time of year when it would be nice to live the life of a fish. What could be better than being constantly underwater, borne by cool currents, feasting on colorful algae and, of course, smaller fish?

title: Chinese Army Major Defects To South Korea With His Wife
description: A Chinese army officer and his wife defected to South Korea today across the border dividing the two Koreas, the Defense Ministry said.

title: Penelope Christophorou, a Lawyer, Weds Gregory Pitaro, Medical Student
description: Penelope Christophorou, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Loucas Christophorou of Oak Ridge, Tenn., was married yesterday to Gregory Pitaro, a son of State Supreme Court Justice and Mrs. Nicholas L. Pitaro of Ozone Park, Queens, at St. Paul's Greek Orthodox Cathedral in Hempstead, L.I. The Rev. Stavros Papagathangelou, a grandfather of the bride, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Joakim Valasiadis and by two Roman Catholic priests, the Revs. Charles Beirne and Louis Garaventa.

title: Margaret Garrett Engaged to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Clarke Garrett of Carlisle, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Margaret Julie Garrett to Bruce Wolosoff, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Alvin B. Wolosoff of Kings Point, L.I. A September wedding is planned. Ms. Garrett, 24 years old, a modern dancer and actress who has performed with the Pennsylvania and Cleveland Ballets, is studying at the Royal Academy of Dramatic Arts in London. Her father is the Charles A. Dana Professor of History at Dickinson College, where her mother, Dr. Margaret Garrett, an associate dean of curriculum, also teaches English literature.

title: Los Angeles Herald Examiner Is Up for Sale
description: The Hearst Corporation has put the Los Angeles Herald Examiner up for sale, one of the newspaper's editors said.

title: Note to Posterity On Measuring Real Success
description: Two weeks ago today, Herbert von Karajan died. Probably the best-known conductor of the post-World War II era, he epitomized worldly success, with his adulatory audiences, hopelessly sold-out concerts, record sales in the millions and lavish life style.

title: The Satellite Dish Gains New Momentum - and Respect
description: For a while it seemed that America's latest rural status symbol had lost its status. For years, a backyard dish antenna betokened rustic chic and even made inroads into the suburbs. The dish, as it is commonly known, became part of the landscape.

title: A Puzzled Roberts Fights for His Job
description: William Roberts is angry because he seems to have lost his job as a starting offensive tackle for the Giants and, he says, no one has told him why. He says no one has told him anything.

title: Miss Orenstein Weds W. M. Sussman
description: At Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., Arlene Orenstein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Orenstein of New York and Roslyn, L.I., was married last evening to William Michael Sussman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Sussman of Manhasset, L.I., and Boca Raton, Fla. Rabbi Robert S. Widom and Cantor Henry Weintraub performed the ceremony.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption in some copies last Sunday, about Israel's allowing Palestinian students to return to school, misstated the day that classes resumed. It was Saturday, July 22.

title: Happy Hoteliers
description: To the Editor:

title: A Stellar Cast Films a Steamy Williams Play
description: Hidden away from the road in a secluded section of Pasadena, a Catholic girls school built in the 1920's, has been transformed into the rococo Royal Palms Hotel of St. Cloud, La. The California palms that line the long curving driveway have been draped with artificial Spanish moss to make them resemble the more lush, exotic foliage of the Deep South.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Tappan
description: THE quiet hamlet of Tappan, featured on maps dating back to 1614, is a living chronicle of the history of Rockland County. Despite its growth since George Washington used it as his Revolutionary War headquarters, in the late 18th century, he could still recognize Tappan's center, where 1960's split level homes are interspersed with historic landmarks on tree-lined, well-maintained streets.

title: The Outlook for Weather Forecasting
description: OVER the last three decades, the accuracy of short-term weather forecasts in the United States has about doubled, thanks to computers, satellites and radar. But early hopes that new techniques would provide precise forecasts a month or even a season in advance have long since faded, and scientists have lately faced something of a brick wall in trying to improve their predictive ability.

title: How to Play Musical Chairs In Harmony
description: I RECENTLY read Sylvia Holstein's article on the sadness of Musical Chairs [ Opinion, June 18 ] . I share her sadness, but it doesn't have to be so.

title: Miss Reddington, A Lawyer, Weds
description: The marriage of Kristine Marie Reddington, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry C. Reddington of Nutley, N.J., to Jeffrey Theodore Herlyn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Warner B. Herlyn of Mamaroneck, N.Y., took place yesterday at St. Clare's Roman Catholic Church in Clifton, N.J. Msgr. Brendan P. Madden performed the ceremony. The bride, an associate at the New York law firm of Jacobson & Triggs, graduated magna cum laude from Georgetown University, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, and from the New York University School of Law.

title: Palestinian Dies of Stabbing
description: A Palestinian accused of collaborating with Israel died today after being stabbed by unidentified attackers in the Shati refugee camp, in the occupied Gaza Strip, Arab hospital officials said. Palestinians said the man, Walid Barud, 23 years old, was known for collaborating with the Israeli authorities.

title: Vintage Coffee From East Africa
description: COFFEE, the daily eye-opener in a safari tent and the gracious finish to dinner around a campfire or in a lodge, is to East Africa what wine is to France. Indeed, in northern Tanzania near the town of Arusha and Mount Kilimanjaro, rows of neatly tended coffee plants line the route and cover sloping hillsides, like grapevines in Burgundy or Alsace.

title: Art as Religion
description: Two recent articles about the issues raised by the cancellation of the Robert Mapplethorpe photography exhibit at the Corcoran Gallery in Washington - Hilton Kramer's ''Is Art Above the Laws of Decency? (July 2) and Grace Glueck's ''Art on the Firing Line'' (July 9) - have prompted an unusually large number of letters from readers. Here is a sampling. To the Editor: Many people in the art world, having abandoned a religious faith or belief based on divinity and revelation, have made art their religion, elevating it to an absolute value, so that art has usurped the place normally or previously held by religious faith and commitment. For such people, attacks on art and the status of art arouse a reaction just like that induced in devout religious believers when their faith is attacked. These people cannot allow any value or consideration or standard to be placed above art. In other words, art has become an idolatry for many people in the art world, an idolatry that permits no challenge to its position and status.

title: On Language; Who's in Those Details?
description: THERE IS AN OLD German saying,'' a source in Bremen told The Washington Post's Hobart Rowen in 1978, ''that >the Devil is in the details.''

title: THE WORLD: An Update on the Destruction of Species; Where the Planet Is Losing Its Life Forms
description: A SYMPATHETIC world keeps careful watch on elephants, pandas, whales, whooping cranes, California condors, blackfooted ferrets and other highly visible endangered species. For scientists, the fates of these animals is of great concern, and environmental groups have been able to rally parts of the public to the cause of rescuing them from extinction.

title: Rhythm and Blues From the Era Of Possibilities
description: ''This is one time, baby (You Ain't Gonna Two-Time Me),'' recorded in 1949 by Johnny Moore and his Three Blazers, is a blues piece that drips with so much musical history it is almost a Rosetta stone of American music, albeit a minor one.

title: Marylanders Fighting Army Over Old School
description: What is the Army doing with a Japanese pagoda, an English castle, an Alpine chalet, a Greek theater and a Dutch windmill? Trying to get rid of them, actually, and in the process stirring up the neighbors for the second time in 17 years.

title: Q and A
description: New Hampshire

title: Jets' Defense Passes a Test
description: Joe Walton, the Jets' coach, said he was pleased by the work of his defensive line, which recorded six sacks, although the Jets were beaten, 20-17, today in a controlled scrimmage against the Washington Redskins.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Loudon, N.H.;
Homes Priced To Move
description: LEAD: MANUFACTURED homes in a planned development of 180 units are selling briskly here despite a sluggish housing market in the area around Concord, the state capital. A major reason is that the prices - $77,000 to $85,000 - are a third less than the average for the area.

title: Where Are We Heading?
description: Two recent articles about the issues raised by the cancellation of the Robert Mapplethorpe photography exhibit at the Corcoran Gallery in Washington - Hilton Kramer's ''Is Art Above the Laws of Decency? (July 2) and Grace Glueck's ''Art on the Firing Line'' (July 9) - have prompted an unusually large number of letters from readers. Here is a sampling. To the Editor: We all know the results of official state art. I know that in this country we are far from that, but when we talk about restricting government funds to support noncontroversial art, where are we heading? Is it not our glory to allow art its purview, and for the government to contribute to its support, when our democratic system of peer review validates artistic quality?

title: Donnie Moore and the Burdens of Baseball
description: Donnie Ray Moore, the former California Angel relief pitcher, who shot his wife and then killed himself 12 days ago, was being discussed recently by a few sportswriters at Shea Stadium. And the memory of perhaps the central moment in his life came back, the image of him on the mound in Anaheim Stadium, in that playoff game in 1986, the television camera zeroing in on his face, sweat-beaded, and his eyes in grim concentration.

title: Children Alone
description: To the Editor: The article on children traveling alone (Practical Traveler, June 11) left out directions on where a child can get help if things go wrong. In olden times at major railroad stations there were the conspicuously marked offices of the Travelers' Aid Society. Unfortunately today, even where such facilities exist, adequate signs are missing at most airports. If one wants to help a child who seeks aid there, I doubt that 1 in 200 people could direct a child to such an office.

title: King Glorious Holds On to Win Haskell
description: King Glorious was good enough to hold on for a three-length victory in the $500,000 Haskell Handicap today at Monmouth Park, but left the impression that stronger opposition and longer distances may give him serious trouble.

title: Showboat Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and the 6 months included a gain of $1,484,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Foley, as Speaker, Begins to Take Fighting Stance
description: Thomas S. Foley trades stories in the cloakroom, pops up in the members' dining room and has returned the fine art of schmoozing to the Speaker's office. He runs the House with a light hand, winning high marks from both sides of the aisle for restoring civility after the ethics wars that toppled Jim Wright.

title: ON YOUR OWN: Versatile Altimeter
description: The altimeter, an instrument that gauges altitude, can be a helpful navigation tool for back-country hiking, climbing, or skiing. Peet Brothers Company of Ocean, N.J. recently introduced an electronic altimeter, the Ultimeter Model 8, that gives you other reasons to take an altimeter along.

title: Galveston-Houston Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included tax benefits of $338,000 for the quarter and $523,000 for the 6 months. c-Included tax benefits of $286,000 and $500,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Year-ago results included pretax $375,000 representing the settlement of a future payment resulting from the sale of Triumph-Lor, the company's former joint venture.

title: Monarch Machine Tool reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
19 Connecticut Residents Return After Theft and Slaying in Kenya
description: Nineteen Connecticut residents arrived at Kennedy International Airport last night, three days after their safari in Kenya had been cut short by gunmen who stepped out of the bush in front of their vans on a rutted wilderness road, shot a woman to death and then robbed the others of up to $3,000.

title: Washington Talk; Risks to H.U.D. Rose After Its Shift Of Responsibility to Private Sector
