description: In a speech to the Heritage Foundation last year, Samuel R. Pierce Jr., then Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, extolled the virtues of turning over some functions of the Federal Government to the private sector and cited his own department as a model.

title: How the Mexican Debt Pact Was Achieved
description: About noon on Friday, July 21, the Finance Minister of Mexico, Pedro Aspe, placed a call to the Treasury Department.

title: America West Airlines Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included tax credits of $1,093,000 for the quarter and $4,722,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss Results for the year-ago quarter and 6-month included a gain of $3,444,000 from the retirement of debt.

title: Zycad Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Poland to End Rations And Food-Price Freeze
description: The Polish Government said today that it was going ahead with plans to lift a food-price freeze and abolish meat rationing on Tuesday, despite widespread public criticism that the step could cause an explosion in food prices and provoke disturbances.

title: United Industrial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Don't Expect to Find New Planets to Plunder
description: To the Editor:

title: A Rabbit's Tale: Bugs's 50 Years in Show Business
description: His regrets? None, save for the carrots of yesteryear. His health? Superb (''supoib'' was what he actually said). His attitude toward that harebrained upstart, Roger Rabbit? Paternal (''patoinal,'' as he put it). In fact, for a show-business legend preparing for his 50th-birthday celebration, that wascally wabbit Bugs Bunny is surprisingly sanguine about his life in the summer of 1989.

title: Fibreboard Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included gains from discontinued operations of $1,502,000 for the quarter and $2,514,000 for the 6 months. c-Included gains from discontinued operations of $547,000 and $17,097,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The company said the latest quarter included a reserve related to the restructuring of the Wood Products Group of $300,000. The company also said the year-ago quarter included gains from sale of real estate of $400,000.

title: Pinning Hopes on Films And on Mingling Well
description: Twelve film students from New York University came West, carrying with them ambition, hope and reels of their films on Tuesday and Wednesday for the annual screenings the university holds for Hollywood studio executives, agents, producers and others in the entertainment industry.

title: U.S. Steelmakers Face Pressures to Improve
description: The Bush Administration's plan to extend quotas on imported steel for two and a half years will create pressures on the American steel industry, forcing companies to make capital improvements in less time than they had planned, industry experts say.

title: Exxon Valdez Limps Into Port in San Diego
description: Amid tooting tugboats, the Exxon Valdez eased into port today for repairs, completing a journey from Alaska, where she caused the nation's worst oil spill last March 24.

title: 'The Mikado' Returns to City Opera
description: The lovely, understated production of ''The Mikado'' staged by Lotfi Mansouri for the New York City Opera was counted a success when it opened in 1984. But because of the vagaries of repertory rotation, Gilbert and Sullivan's Japanese fantasy vanished from the company's schedule after a second run the next year.

title: Soviet Villages Voice Fears on Chernobyl
description: New estimates of contamination from the Chernobyl nuclear disaster could mean that 100,000 more people will have to be evacuated from the area because of the risk of radiation, say local officials who are pressing the Kremlin for more aid.

title: Don't Expect to Find New Planets to Plunder; Next Step in Propulsion
description: To the Editor:

title: Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week
description: This week's Treasury calendar is limited to today's auctions of three- and six-month bills. On Friday three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.84 percent. Six-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.49 percent.

title: Commission Preserves Standards for Public Art
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Questionable Kind of Shrine
description: AT Cooperstown last week, a member of the Baseball Writers Association of America, one of the 800 who vote for candidates for the Hall of Fame, said he'd never vote for Pete Rose to enter the hallowed red-brick shrine if Rose were found to have gambled on baseball, let alone on his own team, the Cincinnati Reds.

title: National Pizza Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
No Headline
description: Hanson P.L.C., the aggressive British conglomerate, said the net proceeds of its initial public offering of 14.75 million shares in its Smith Corona Corporation subsidiary at $21 each totaled $291 million. The shares were sold to an underwriting group led by Shearson Lehman Hutton Holdings Inc. and Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The newly issued shares represent 48.8 percent of the company. Hanson will retain a 47.9 percent stake, and the rest is held by Smith Corona management.

title: An International Team At the Guggenheim Is Looking Outward
description: ''We're a kind of curatorial jam session,'' Germano Celant said smiling. Mr. Celant, recently named curator of contemporary art at the Guggenheim Museum, was referring to the new team of curators assembled by Thomas Krens, the Guggenheim's director since last July. ''We don't compete with each other because we're friends,'' Mr. Celant continued. ''We're each open to the other's ideas, and as a team we can begin to engage the global perspectives demanded by the museum of the future.''

title: Study on Bid by Austria
description: The European Community's executive commission received the go-ahead on Friday to study Austria's application for membership. Community officials said the 12 member governments had authorized the commission to undertake a study of the economic and legal implications of the application, the normal procedure for any membership bid. Austria lodged its application on July 17, but Belgium held up written approval for the study until it received assurances that the question of Austria's permanent neutrality would be examined.

title: Bridge
description: Players from New England and New York won major team titles Saturday at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals.

title: Management Science America Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago earnings reclassified to conform to present year presentation.

title: Another Setback for Bird
description: It was the moment for which the Boston Celtics had waited a long time. Larry Bird, who played in just six games last season, was scrimmaging again. He would show just how far he had progressed from surgery on both heels. He ran hard. Coach Jimmy Rodgers smiled. Then came the moment the Celtics dreaded. Bird fell with a thud under his basket just five minutes into the first workout Saturday night at the Celtics' summer camp for rookies, free agents and five veterans. He clutched his back, rolled over on his stomach and winced in pain.

title: M-I Schottenstein Homes Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. Seizes 9 Savings Units
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has been named managing agent for nine savings and loan institutions, bringing the total in the Government management program to 253 in 33 states.

title: H.U.D. Officials Study 2 Projects Backed by Pierce
description: In his final days as Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. personally approved two consulting contracts worth hundreds of thousands of dollars, in one case overruling department experts, housing department officials say.

title: Jets Lose Hasty at Cornerback
description: The young, inexperienced Jets secondary has lost its starting right cornerback, James Hasty, for at least the exhibition season. His replacement is Michael Mitchell, a 27-year-old who has been trying to land a job in the National Football League since 1983.

title: Officials Bask in Competition's Success
description: With the pop singer Ray Charles providing a rousing rendition of ''America, the Beautiful,'' the United States Olympic Sports Festival here ended today with organizers calling it one of the most successful in the event's 11-year history.

title: No New 'Roseanne' For Fall TV Season
description: Peter Tortorici, a vice president of programming for CBS, admits that his network not has found the breakthrough hit series it needs so desperately after three years as television's most conspicuous underachiever.

title: Soviet Press Suggests Rail Strike Is Possible
description: Soviet newspapers indicated today that rail strikes were possible and quoted officials as saying such stoppages could bring catastrophe and chaos.

title: Liggett Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A Gains-Tax Compromise Is Resisted
description: Efforts by the Bush Administration and Dan Rostenkowski, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, to strike a deal on reducing capital gains taxes are being complicated by opposition from rank-and-file legislators in both parties who question the value of any compromise.

title: Indexing Makes Tax On Capital Gains Fair
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics of The Times; Masks of Poverty
description: A New Yorker, returning to live in the city after years away, found himself unprepared for the visibility of poverty. He felt shock and self-blame as he stepped by a huddled man sleeping on a stairway or faced a timid young woman whispering, ''Please help me.''

title: Governor Welcomes Meeting
description: Gov. Mike Sullivan of Wyoming says he is delighted that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, plan to meet in his state, even though no one asked him about it in advance. Mr. Baker proposed last week that the Sept. 19-20 meeting with should take place in Wyoming, where he owns a ranch on the Wind River range. Mr. Sullivan, a Democrat interviewed here at the annual meeting of the National Governors' Association, said he learned of the meeting from news reports.

title: Court Finds Research Group Has News-Gathering Status
description: A Federal appeals court has ruled that the National Security Archive, a nonprofit research group that compiles documents on national security and foreign policies, qualifies as a news organization.

title: For Europe, U.S. May Spell TV
description: The explosion in the number of television stations in Europe has produced a billion-dollar boom in the sale of American programs on the Continent, but this bonanza has produced growing demands to limit how many American shows can be broadcast.

title: Key Production Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss Year-ago second quarter results reflected the company's pro rata share of Apache Petroleum Cos. LP's historical operations.

title: What Am I Anyway, A Zoo?
description: LEAD: Perusin' the news, as I have been for a while, I was surprised to find myself dissected, directed and interjected.

title: Harness Racing: The Big Test for Peace Corps
description: She has trotted to 17 victories in a row, but the biggest challenge for Peace Corps will come racing against colts in Saturday's Hambletonian, the most prestigious event in harness racing and the second leg of trotting's triple crown.

title: 'Dumping' of Limousines
description: American buyers of stretched limousines have been buying cheaper Canadian-made cars, a trend that has prompted American companies to accuse their Canadian counterparts of ''dumping.''

title: American League; Royals' Late Rally Edges Out Baltimore
description: Danny Tartabull hit a two-run single in the eighth inning this afternoon as the Royals rallied past the Baltimore Orioles, 7-6, marking the Orioles' 10th loss in 11 games.

title: Delay and Shoreham
description: Delay, long a tactic favored by the opponents of the Shoreham nuclear-power plant, is now being adopted by those fighting to keep the troubled reactor alive.

title: Jury Convicts 3 Mob Figures In Racket Case
description: Three men accused of being members of the Genovese crime family were convicted yesterday in Federal court on racketeering charges that included the 1986 murder of a New York City police detective in Queens.

title: 2 More Chinese Are Executed
description: The authorities in the central Chinese city of Wuhan said today that two criminals had been executed and 12 others sentenced to prison for their roles in turmoil during the crackdown on the democracy movement. The official New China News Agency identified the two as Yu Chunting and Guo Zhenghua, and said they were convicted of ''snatching firearms and ammunition, and deliberately killing a pregnant woman and a girl when robbing a house in Wuhan.''

title: Leaking Lard Causes a Scare
description: Several hundred people were evacuated from their homes for about five and a half hours Saturday when a freight train derailed here and a car began leaking what officials thought was battery acid. But the material turned out to be lard from a car of cow hides. The train was headed to Chicago from Detroit when the derailment occurred.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
description: Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising augmented its billings from Mexico on Friday by receiving the assignment to advertise Cancun, the popular Mexican resort.

title: Threat to Kill U.S. Hostage
description: A fundamentalist group in Lebanon vowed to kill an American hostage unless Israel frees one of its leaders, who was abducted Friday. Page A2.

title: REVIEW/MUSIC: Berkshire Choral Festival in Its Eighth Year
description: There is a category of musical event that exists as much for the benefit of those on stage as for their audience, if not more. Last night was an example: some 200 singers at the Berkshire Choral Festival sang for three times their number here. The music was the Te Deum from Verdi's Four Sacred Pieces and Bloch's Sacred Service. The Springfield Symphony Orchestra played and Margaret Hillis, the distinguished choral conductor from Chicago, presided.

title: Nancy E. Zaeh is Married
description: Nancy Elizabeth Zaeh, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert F. Zaeh of Murray Hill, N.J., was married yesterday to Dale Edward Eckart, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Carl Eckart of Indianapolis, at St. John's Evangelical Lutheran Church in Summit, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Franklin D. Fry and the Rev. Susan E. Nagle officiated. The bride, who will keep her name professionally, teaches French at the John M. Witherspoon Middle School in Princeton, N.J. The bridegroom is a senior engineer at the Exxon Chemical Company in Linden, N.J. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: Waverly Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting change of $596,000.

title: Sotomayor Has 8-Foot High Jump
description: First came the four-minute mile. Then the 17-foot pole vault. And now, the 8-foot high jump.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: UDC-Universal Development L.P. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS: BOXING;
From Stocks to Bouts
description: LEAD: When he traded in his boxing gloves for a briefcase and a monthly commutation ticket on the Long Island Railroad, Howard Davis Jr. the 1976 Olympic gold medalist, thought he would be a knockout on Wall Street. But after almost a year in training as a stockbrocker and not landing a major account, Davis is resuming his boxing career.

title: Insteel Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After income of $43,000 for the quarter and $1,775,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations; the 9 months also included income of $600,000 from an accounting change.

title: Betz Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Lopez Wins by One Stroke
description: Nancy Lopez rewarded her large gallery of fans with another steady round of golf and won the Atlantic City Classic by one shot this afternoon at the Sands Country Club.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Magazines; War Ends for Time Warner, But Some Concerns Linger
description: FOR many writers and editors at Time and its sibling magazines, the confirmation that the takeover war was over came on Wednesday morning, when operators began answering the telephone ''Time Warner'' instead of ''Time Incorporated.''

title: Carlson to Merge With Friday's
description: The TGI Friday's chain of casual restaurants will become a private company in a merger with Carlson Hospitality Group Inc., the parent of the Radisson hotel chain, the companies said Friday.

title: U.S. AGAIN SAYS NO TO CAMBODIA ROLE FOR KHMER ROUGE
description: In a strong reaffirmation of American policy, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that the United States opposes any role for the Khmer Rouge in a future Cambodian government.

title: Sports Illustrated and Writer Engage in a $200,000 Dispute
description: Frank Deford, who left Sports Illustrated in May, and his former employers at Time Inc. are accusing each other of disloyalty and betrayal in a dispute over more than $200,000.

title: Panel Starts Its Final Week Of Deliberations on Charter
description: The New York City Charter Revision Commission today begins its final week of deliberations on reshaping city government with most of its major recommendations for a referendum in November firmly set. But it must still resolve a range of questions about just how the new system will work if it is approved by the voters.

title: Don't Expect to Find New Planets to Plunder; Moon Poets
description: To the Editor:

title: Freeport-McMoran Energy Partners Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding represent units.

title: Participants in the Marathon Talks
description: Thirteen men worked far into the night last weekend in the Treasury's third-floor conference room to put together the Mexican debt accord:

title: Helping Gorby Succeed
description: What's the matter with you right-wingers, ask the liberal editorialists; don't you realize that our destiny is inextricably linked to the success of Mikhail Gorbachev?

title: PALESTINIANS GAIN RIGHT TO CONTEST HOUSE DEMOLITIONS
description: Israel's Supreme Court ruled today that Palestinians accused of wrongdoing must be given time to appeal through the military and civilian courts before the army demolishes their homes.

title: Liquidation Set For Financier
description: The estate of the Ohio financier Marvin Warner must be liquidated to settle $4.5 billion in claims against him, a Federal bankruptcy judge ruled on Friday.

title: Burmese Dissident Is Reportedly on a Fast
description: The Burmese opposition leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, has been on a hunger strike, taking only water, since she was put under house arrest on July 20, residents of the capital of Myanmar, formerly Burma, said today.

title: Living With Murderers in Cambodia
description: The core problem facing the international conference on Cambodia just under way in Paris is to define a realistic future role for the Khmer Rouge. When this group of fanatics held absolute power in the late 1970's, it was responsible for the deaths of a million people and the devastation of Cambodian society. It remains the single strongest indigenous military force in the country.

title: Slaying Brings a Neighborhood's Tensions to the Surface
description: West 114th Street, a block that slopes gently down toward Riverside Drive, was quiet yesterday, typical for a weekend, residents said. But inside a six-story red-brick building, the talk was fiery as residents wrestled fiercely with memories of a neighbor, a young computer engineer, and theories of why he was killed the day before.

title: REVIEW/BALLET: Mixed Bill of 3 Works by London Festival
description: London Festival Ballet has been directed since 1984 by Peter Schaufuss, the Danish dancer with whom New Yorkers became familiar when he was a principal with the New York City Ballet and the National Ballet of Canada in the 1970's.

title: Softsel Computer Products Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
One Dead, Two Injured In West Side Shooting
description: One man was killed and three other men were wounded last night in what the police said was apparently a drug-related dispute that involved a block-long chase on the Upper West Side. Two of the wounded were bystanders, a police spokesman said.

title: Kurt Lange, Physician And Journal Editor, 82
description: Dr. Kurt Lange, a professor emeritus of pediatrics and medicine at the New York Medical College and a consulting physician at Lenox Hill Hospital, died of heart disease Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 82 years old.

title: A Soviet Marshal Testifies
description: On NATO's military intentions and the threat of war:

title: Nancy Andrews, a Stage Actress, Singer and Comedian, Dies at 68
description: Nancy Andrews, a stage actress and singer hailed for starring performances in ''Little Me'' opposite Sid Caesar and in ''Tobacco Road'' with John Carradine, died on Saturday of a heart attack at St. John's Hospital in Queens. Miss Andrews, who was 68 years old, had lived in Manhattan for decades, but was confined to a nursing home in Queens for the last year.

title: Success at Last for Thompson
description: Leonard Thompson ended a 12-year interval without a victory today when Payne Stewart bogeyed the 18th hole, giving Thompson a one-stroke victory in the Buick Open.

title: Joslyn Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Latest quarter included a gain of $12 million from the settlement of a patent infringement lawsuit. The settlement gain was reduced by expenses incurred and to be incurred in connection with defending the patent and with income taxes. Latest second quarter also included a pre-tax charge of more than $5 million related to the company's defense business for estimated losses, product discontinuance and reorganization costs.

title: Seven Are Killed When Small Planes Collide
description: Two small planes collided in flight today and crashed near a shopping mall, killing seven people, the authorities said. One person on the ground was reported injured.

title: ON YOUR OWN; Outdoors: Fishing With Hemingway as a Guide
description: LEAD: ANYONE who spends much time outdoors in Michigan is likely to find himself crossing the trails of legends. Many of the most impressive trails tend to follow trout streams, and to have been made by one legend in particular: a young fellow from Oak Park, Ill., named Ernest Hemingway. Young Hemingway surveyed much of the best fishing in northern Michigan, and documented it so thoroughly and memorably that on certain waters it is difficult to find a stretch free of literary associations.

title: Medalist Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $214,000 for the quarter and $170,000 for the 6 months.

title: Union Texas Petroleum Holdngs reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Latest quarter and 6-month results included a $58.6 million gain from the settlement with insurers on Union Texas' business interruption policy regarding the July 6, 1988, explosion at the U.K. North Sea's piper field. The $58.6 million gain represented an accrual for payments to be received in the second half of 1989 and in 1990. The periods also included a $4.9 million gain from a gas contract settlement. Year-ago results included a $12.5 million gain in the second quarter and a $14.9 million gain in the first half from resolution of international tax issues and $5.5 million gain from a gas contract settlement.

title: French Trade Gap Cut
description: Record deliveries of Airbus airliners helped to trim France's trade deficit significantly in June, the Government said Friday. June's adjusted trade gap was 2.8 billion francs ($439 million), compared with 6.7 billion ($1.05 billion) in May. Most economists had expected about four billion francs ($627 million).

title: AIDS Panel to Organize After Delay of 7 Months
description: A new Federal AIDS commission created to lead the nation's fight against the epidemic will finally hold its first meeting on Thursday, seven months after the deadline set by law.

title: Worlds Collide in Tompkins Sq. Park
description: ''It's an interesting, intricate social situation,'' Nathaniel Hunter Jr. observed early yesterday morning from the bench in Tompkins Square Park, where he has lived for the last six years. ''The internal contradictions are constantly slamming into each other.''

title: U.S. Issues a Warning
description: The White House, responding to a threat by a pro-Iranian group to kill a United States Marine lieutenant colonel held hostage, warned today that the kidnappers of the colonel and any other Americans in Lebanon will be held responsible their safety.

title: Lucy C. Sloman, Planner, Weds
description: Lucy Carter Sloman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Sherk Sloman of Dallas, and Stephen Michael Antupit, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Nathaniel Antupit of Pound Ridge, N.Y., were married yesterday. Rabbi James Mirel performed the ceremony at Kiana Lodge in Agate Pass., Wash.

title: For Dinkins, Styles Range From Calm To Serious
description: About 200 worshippers were at Sunday morning services at a small church in East Harlem recently when the Rev. Edward J. Norman introduced David N. Dinkins, the Manhattan Borough President, as the man about to become the first black mayor of New York City.

title: Hitachi Drops Motorola Suit
description: Hitachi Ltd. has dropped a patent-infringement suit against Motorola Inc., the United States electronics company, a Hitachi spokesman said Friday.

title: NS Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
What's in a Paycheck?
description: Everybody knows that baseball salaries have been skyrocketing in recent years. But is there any rational consistency to the array of big league paychecks, a set of circumstances that explains why some players make more than others?

title: Computer-Magazine Giant Thrives on Global Approach
description: In the land of new magazines, a publisher with two successes in a row is practically a miracle worker. By that measure, Patrick J. McGovern is the prophet for his age.

title: Deborah L. Weiss Becomes a Bride
description: Deborah Lynn Weiss, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald L. Weiss of Massapequa, L.I., was married yesterday in New York at the Church Center for the United Nations to Robert Julian Geline, a son of Max E. Geline of Shorewood, Wis., and the late Rona Geline. The Rev. Duncan MacKenzie, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony, assisted by Rabbi Roy Rosenberg.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Marketing Drive Begun By C-M-E
description: CAMPBELL-MITHUN-ESTY celebrated its first anniversary last week by announcing its plan to position itself as a student of the North American mind.

title: Youthful Cast in 'Traviata,' in English
description: Visitors to the Glimmerglass Opera's current production will probably not find themselves recalling a Jonathan Miller ''Traviata'' in the way that one thinks of the Zeffirelli ''Boheme'' or the Sellars ''Don Giovanni.'' They are likelier to remember enjoying a sometimes touching youthful cast that acted with more coherence and specificity than is usual, some quizzical touches in the setting and an unusual immediacy of communication.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Delta Air Lines, Atlanta, named C. A. Thompson senior vice president and head of its stations division.

title: Top Rider Killed By Charging Bull
description: The 1987 world champion bull rider was killed today when he was thrown and gored in the back at the Cheyenne Frontier Days rodeo.

title: Mylan Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
On the Beach: Better Than 1988, but. . .
description: After the dismal summer of 1988, when fear of pollution and medical waste drove visitors from the beaches and threw beachfront economies into crisis, tourism officials and businesses in the shore communities of New Jersey and Long Island say the crowds are slowly returning.

title: Mets' Slide Reaches No. 6
description: The Mets tumbled to new depths today when they were beaten for the sixth straight time for their longest losing streak in four years, and they did it with doomsday flourishes.

title: INSIDE
description: Will Bloch Be Charged? Unusual factors, along with the difficulty of proving espionage, have for now hamstrung the case against the diplomat Felix S. Bloch. Page A12. 3 Guilty of Racketeering Three men were convicted in U.S. court on charges that included the slaying of a New York police detective. Page B1 Exporting TV Shows New stations in Europe have produced a billion-dollar boom in the sale of American programs. Page D1. 50 Governors, 50 Views Governors are divided not only on abortion but in their assessment of its political impact. Page A8.

title: Review/Pop; UPDATED GIRL-GROUP SOUND
description: The Shams, who played at the Ludlow Street Cafe on Wednesday night, update the girl-group sound of the 1960's by giving it a low-tech veneer. Where girl groups were the perfect corporate musical product, made by producers and slickly commercial, the Shams - Sue Garner on bass, Amanda Uprichard on percussion and Amy McMahon on guitar - have taken a minimalist route, emphasising the vocals, playing without much of a musical backdrop and keeping things raw.

title: Anderson Adjusts to (Ugh) Losing
description: Thirty years ago this summer, Sparky Anderson spent his only season as a major league baseball player as a second baseman with the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Adlai Stevenson: Wrong Opponents, Wrong Times
description: Adlai Stevenson His Life and Legacy By Porter McKeever Illustrated. 591 pages. William Morrow & Company. $25.

title: Comair Holdings Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Correction
description: A front-page picture caption in some copies on Saturday, about a meeting of Chinese students in the United States on the pro-democracy movement in China, misidentified the school at which the meeting took place. It was the University of Illinois at Chicago.

title: Young Dancers End a High-Stepping Summer
description: Like the children they are, the members of the National Dance Institute's summer program leaped, and laughed with their eyes. Like the dancers they wanted to be, they spun and high-stepped.

title: Polish Party and Solidarity: Still on Collision Course
description: The shuffling of Poland's Communist Party leadership on Saturday does not appear to have brought Poles significantly closer to the resolution of the country's severe economic problems.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-6

title: Nanometrics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the latest quarter and 6 months included a one-time $600,000 payment made by Jeol Ltd. of Japan to the company for a licenses under patents related to the company's field emission scanning electronic microscope technology.

July Wednesday New-Home Sales ... June Factory Orders ... June Thursday Leading Indicators ... June Productivity ... 2d qtr. New-Car Sales ... Late July Friday Employment ... July

title: Ocean Drilling & Exploration Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the latest second quarter and six months included a restructuring charge of $1,628,000. Latest six months also included a gain of $2 million from the reversal of a prior year provision for a natural gas pricing dispute.

title: Block Drug Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago earnings were restated for a 3 percent stock dividend declared in October 1988.

description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $1,109,000 from the repurchase of convertible debentures. c-Included extraordinary gains from the repurchase of convertible debentures of $797,000 and $1,094,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Komag Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and after tax credits of $114,000 for the quarter and $1,132,000 for the 6 months.

title: Results Plus
description: Auto Racing Senna Wins in West Germany: Ayrton Senna of Brazil won the German Grand Prix yesterday in Hockenheim, West Germany, by edging out his McLaren-Honda teammate, Alain Prost of France. The Brazilian pulled off the surprise victory by passing his French teammate with two laps to go in the 44-lap race on the 4.214-mile circuit. Senna finished the 185.41-mile race in 1 hour 21 minutes 43.302 seconds, 18.151 seconds ahead of Prost. The winner averaged 139.231 miles an hour. Nigel Mansell of Britain finished third in his Ferrari, a lap behind.(AP) Labonte Triumphs: Terry Labonte outdueled Darrell Waltrip and a host of challengers yesterday to become the 19th different winner in 21 years in the Diehard 500 at the Talladega Superspeedway. The 188-lap race at the Alabama raceway saw 10 drivers total 49 lead changes, the last coming on lap 176 when Labonte drove his Ford Thunderbird past Waltrip's Chevrolet Lumina into the lead. (AP) Tennis Agassi Beats Lendl: Andre Agassi beat Ivan Lendl, 7-6, 6-4, yesterday in the final of the four-man ANA Cup in Tokyo and earned $220,000, the richest winner's purse ever in a tournament in Japan. Lendl, the world's No. 1 player, squandered leads of 4 points to 2 and 6-5 in the first set tie breaker and ended up with the second prize of $140,000. Stefan Edberg defeated Mats Wilander, 6-4, 3-6, 7-6, before 14,356 spectators at Yokohama Arena to win the third prize of $80,000. Wilander received $60,000.(AP) Jaite Tops Prpic: Martin Jaite of Argentina easily won the $350,000 grand prix tournament in Stuttgart, West Germany, yesterday, defeating the teen-ager Goran Prpic of Yugoslavia, 6-3, 6-2, in the final. The 14th-seeded Jaite beat Prpic with a combination of masterful backhands, fierce volleys and powerful offensive attacks, dominating both sets.(AP) Gilbert-Mayotte Halted: Rain suspended last night's final of the Sovran Bank Classic in Washington with second-seeded Brad Gilbert holding a 6-3, 1-1 lead over top-seeded Tim Mayotte. The match will be resumed at 2 P.M. today.(AP) Soccer Trinidad and Tobago Wins: Leonson Lewis scored twice in the first 15 minutes of the second half, leading Trinidad and Tobago past El Salvador, 2-0, yesterday in a qualifying match for soccer's 1990 World Cup in Port-of-Spain, Trinidad.

title: Washington Talk; Congress
description: In 1796, James Madison, then a member of the House Ways and Means Committee, sounded a familiar warning: ''Our ordinary income is barely at a par with our ordinary expenditures and new taxes must be ready.'' Then as now, it was business as usual at Ways and Means.

title: Shift at Sporting News
description: Thomas G. Osenton has been named president and chief operating officer of the Sporting News Publishing Company, a unit of the Times Mirror Company. His appointment becomes effective Aug. 15. He succeeds Richard Waters, who has been named chairman. The company publishes The Sporting News, a St. Louis-based weekly with a circulation of 725,000, as well as magazines and books.

title: 7 East Coast States Agree to Cooperate In Anti-Drug Effort
description: The Governors of the mid-Atlantic states today signed a compact to share information on drug abuse programs and to cooperate on the enforcement of drug laws.

title: Tolleson's Hit Wins for Yanks
description: Six weeks had come and gone. June had turned to July, the Yankees had surged and then fallen, and Wayne Tolleson played and sat. But he did not hit.

title: Bic Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $2,800,000.

title: C. J. Kettler Wed To W. M. Hitzig
description: C. J. Kettler, a daughter of Ruth Kettler of New York and the late Morris Kettler, was married yesterday to William Maxwell Hitzig, a son of Candis Hall Gullino of Lido Beach, L.I., and the late Dr. William M. Hitzig, at the bridegroom's home in Bearsville, N.Y. Jules Viglielmo, a justice of the peace of Woodstock, N.Y., performed the ceremony.

title: Wynn's International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Latest 9-month results included a gain of $1,375,000, or 36 cents a share, from the sale of substantially all of the company's interest in Wynn-Kiki Inc., a joint venture. Year-ago 6-month results included a charge of $1,011,000, or 27 cents a share, for costs associated with management changes and termination of the company's supplemental retirement plan.

title: Sounds of Controversy
description: No one who has followed the vari-ous scandals that have hit collegiate athletics in recent years would doubt that good students are sometimes re-cruited to write papers for good ath-letes.

title: Question Box
description: Babe Ruth's Nemesis

title: Topics of The Times; Rolodex Rollover
description: In 1968, a frugal New Yorker inherited a Rolodex left behind by the previous occupant of her new office. The previous occupant probably inherited it from the office's previous occupant. When the New Yorker changed offices a decade ago, she brought the old Rolodex along.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International Report

title: Pilgrim's Pride Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: b-Net loss The 9-month 1988 results included a benefit of $9.6 million, or 42 cents a share, resulting from the cumulative effect of Pilgrim's early adoption of the provisions of Financial Accounting Standards Board Statement No. 96, Accounting for Income Taxes.

title: Pilots at Northwest Seek Arbitration in Contract Dispute
description: The pilots' union at Northwest Airlines requested binding arbitration on Friday after contract talks with the airline's management broke off. If the National Mediation Board grants the request, which is uncertain, a strike could be possible by late this summer.

title: Campaign Matters; The Debate Over Debates: Any Winners?
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo - he of the silver tongue - doesn't like candidate debates.

title: National League; Astros' Scott Wins His 17th
description: Mike Scott became the first 17-game winner in the major leagues as the Houston Astros moved within a game of the San Francisco Giants in the National League West with a 6-2 victory today.

title: Total Petroleum (North Amercan) Ltd(A) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Descendant Traces Path of Russian 'Apostle of Alaska'
description: Father Innocent Veniaminov sat in a New York office and wept. They were tears of joy, the Russian Orthodox monk from Leningrad insisted, because ''God protected me and gave me such a path in life.''

title: Rome Journal; A Mosque Is Built, Finally, in the City of St. Peter
description: When the idea first came up more than five decades ago - building a mosque in Rome for subjects from Italy's colonial holdings in Africa - Benito Mussolini is reported to have said absolutely no.

title: Kremlin Rebels Vote Leaders
description: Independent members of the new Soviet Parliament elected five chairmen today - including Boris N. Yeltsin, the Kremlin maverick, and Andrei D. Sakharov, the human rights campaigner - to lead their new group pressing for more rapid change. Mr. Yeltsin, who led the voting, will hold the rotating post of ''prime chairman'' for the first year. The others elected were the historian Yuri N. Afanaseyev, the economist Gavril K. Popov and Viktor Palm, an Estonian academic.

title: Howell Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Mexico Sees Gains in Debt Accord
description: With a debt-reduction agreement in his pocket after seven months of difficult negotiations, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari is seeking to convince Mexican and foreign investors that the accord is not just another debt rescheduling but the start of a permanent economic recovery.

title: Gilroy Journal; For the Garlic Eater: Follow Your Nose West
description: When the two huge dehydrators are operating at the Gilroy Food Company here, turning fresh garlic into powder and dried cloves, residents of this dusty valley town awake to the smell drifting through their windows.

title: Chernobyl Danger Persists
description: New estimates of contamination from the Chernobyl nuclear disaster could lead to the evacuation of 100,000 more people living nearby. Page A3.

title: Will Bloch Be Charged? F.B.I. Faces Many Pitfalls
description: A State Department official is reportedly videotaped handing a briefcase to a K.G.B. agent in Paris and is reportedly overheard being warned of discovery by the same Soviet agent. Later, by one account, he tells the Federal Bureau of Investigation that the Soviets have paid him a lot of money over many years.

title: Governors Are Divided Over Impact of Abortion Issue
description: Governors and other leaders in state capitals around the nation appear to be as divided about the potential political impact of the abortion issue as they are about abortion itself.

title: Lawsuits Don't Make A Cleaner Environment
description: To the Editor:

title: F.D.A. Inquiry on Generic Drugs Focuses on Changes in Ingredients
description: Amid widening allegations of improprieties in the Federal regulation of generic drugs, investigators at the Food and Drug Administration are completing special plant inspections of 11 drug manufacturers, Congressional and agency officials say.

title: Joyce Lieberman Weds H. H. Lopkin
description: Joyce Ann Lieberman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Levine of Douglaston, Queens, and Boca Raton, Fla., was married yesterday to Harvey Hugh Lopkin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Lopkin of Brooklyn and Tamarac, Fla. Rabbi Daniel Fogel officiated in the Mariners Chapel at the United States Merchant Marine Academy in Kings Point, L.I.

title: R. E. Cunningham Wed to Edith Locke
description: Edith Kyle Locke, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Locke of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Derby, Vt., and Richard Edward Cunningham, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Cunningham of Palm Coast, Fla., were married yesterday at the King Mansion in Tarrytown, N.Y. The Presbyterian ceremony was performed by the Rev. Frank A. Goodwin.

title: New Ball President Slated to Be Chief
description: The Ball Corporation has named Delmont A. Davis president and chief operating officer and indicated that he will be asked to lead the maker of packaging products in two years.

title: ON YOUR OWN: Making Safety a Fact, Not Just an Issue
description: ''WE want to run more, not less, in Central Park,'' said Fred Lebow. ''And we want to respond to the skeptics and the perception that Central Park isn't safe, while maintaining that people should use the park prudently. We eventually want to make the park safe enough so anyone, a man or a woman, can run anywhere in the park, day or night.''

title: Yields Expected to Drop Further
description: Credit market analysts expect Treasury bond yields to decline further in coming weeks. The yields fell below 8 percent for the first time in two years on Friday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The United States strongly believes that the Khmer Rouge should play no role in Cambodia's future.'' - Secretary of StateJames A. Baker 3d. [ A6:4. ]

Eliminating Risk of Rising Rates
description: Every spring, L. L. Bean Inc. begins preparing for the Christmas selling season knowing how much it will pay for sweaters, boots and parkas. But until recently, there had always been a question about another important cost - the interest on money it borrows to pay for the yearly buildup of inventory.

description: WITH stock prices at record levels, individual investors are growing less nervous.

title: Tax Watch; Tuition Refunds May Become Dear
description: IN the Congressional wrangling over proposals to cut the capital-gains tax, some lesser tax issues are escaping public scrutiny. One that is significant to a relatively small group of people, fewer than a million, but could well represent an investment in the country's future, is the tax treatment of tuition refunds from employers.

title: Donna M. Bertaccini Becomes a Bride
description: Donna Maria Bertaccini, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Bertaccini of Freeport, L.I., was married yesterday at her parents' home to Mark Dysart Molesworth, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon R. Molesworth of Tucson, Ariz. Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony.

title: The Hi-Fi Stack: Still Higher
description: The digital audio tape recorder is about to hit the American market, now that its producers have agreed on a chip to prevent unlimited copying of compact disks. Like compact disks, digital audio tape stores music as a stream of numbers, and gives sound of the same pure quality.

title: Lincoln Telecommunications reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Restarting Weapons Reactors To Cost 4 Times the Estimate
description: Westinghouse, the operator of the the country's largest nuclear weapons plant, has notified the Government that it will cost more than four times the previous estimate to repair and restart three reactors that are the only source of a gas vital to atomic warheads.

title: Soviet Leaders Debating Shape of a Future Army
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's proposal to cut 500,000 troops from the Soviet armed forces has started a debate between Soviet military leaders and civilian intellectuals who want radical changes in the military.

title: A Suspect in Inmate's Killing
description: Investigators have a suspect in the stabbing death Saturday of an inmate at the Clinton Correctional Facility, but no charges have been filed, authorities said today. The prisoner, whose name was withheld until relatives could be notified, told officials he had been stabbed in the neck at about 5:10 P.M. Saturday, said a state corrections spokesman, James Flateau. The inmate was pronounced dead about 6:15 P.M. in the prison infirmary.

title: Economic Watch; Western Credit for Moscow? Experts Are Split on Impact
description: Moscow has succeeded in coaxing striking miners back to the coal fields with a package of benefits reportedly worth $8 billion annually. But the miners' economic grievances were no greater than those of tens of millions of other Soviet workers. And few experts believe that the Soviet Union's sputtering economic machine can deliver soon on popular expectations of a bathtub for every family and sausage on every dinner plate.

title: Washington Talk; A Sampler of Programs, Audits and Losses
description: Here are some programs in which critical functions were transferred by the Department of Housing and Urban Development to the private sector. Audits by the department's Inspector General found that a lack of overseeing contributed to mismanagement; in some programs, overseeing improved after the reports were in.

title: Despite Low Pay, Publishing Holds its Lure
description: After graduating from Brown University in 1986, John Karp worked on newspapers in Providence, R.I., Washington and Miami. Five months ago he took a job as an editorial assistant at Random House Inc. for thousands of dollars less than he had been making as a reporter.

title: James B. Ramsey Jr., Consultant, 66
description: James B. Ramsey Jr., a financial consultant to the Small Business Administration in New York, died of a respiratory illness Saturday at the Carteret General Hospital in Morehead City, N.C., near his vacation home. He was 66 years and also lived in Wyckoff, N.J.

title: Savings and Loan Victory, in Sight
description: The House-Senate conference bill to clean up the savings and loan mess is a clear victory for the public interest over special-interest groups that fought it to the bitter end. The bill now is stronger than what President Bush proposed six months ago. It merits swift approval. The thrift industry is in crisis because of lax regulation, meddling Congressmen and senators and Reagan Administration indifference, plus rampant incompetence and outright fraud in the industry. Bailing out bankrupt thrifts will cost an estimated $166 billion, but the eventual price could be twice as high. Taxpayers will pay most of it.

title: Syntex's Head of Operations Named Leader of Company
description: The Syntex Corporation has announced that Paul E. Freiman will tomorrow become the third chief executive in its 45-year history. He has been president and chief operating officer of the pharmaceutical company, which is based in Palo Alto, Calif., since January 1987.

title: Chavez Stops Rival For 64th Straight
description: Julio Cesar Chavez of Mexico earned his 64th consecutive victory today with a seemingly nonchalant technical knockout of Kenneth Vice.

title: Turbo Resources reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a charge of $348,000 for the quarter and a $534,000 gan for the six months. c-Net income and included a tax credit of $2,087,000. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Nuclear Support Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and the 9 months is after a gain of $600,000 from an accounting change.

title: Tool Orders Rose 16% In June
description: Orders for American-made machine tools rebounded in June after a three-month decline, increasing 16 percent mostly because of a steep rise in foreign orders, a trade association said in its monthly report, to be released today.

title: Goody Products Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said results for the year-ago second quarter and 6-month included sales of $688,000 and $1,366,000, respectively, from Southeastern Box Co., a unit which was sold later in the year.

title: Fischer & Porter Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said in the latest and year-ago 6-month periods, preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income.

title: Sonat Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a gain of $13,130,000 from an accounting change. Latest quarter and 6-month results included income of $33.9 million, or 83 cents a share, related to the settlement of Southern Natural Gas Co.'s rate case and order 500 filing, $4.3 million of which represented Sonat's share of net income related to a refund received by Citrus Corp. from Southern Natural. Year-ago quarter and 6-month results included income of $14.9 million, or 37 cents a share, from the reversal of reserves related to a regulatory matter that was resolved in the period.

title: Beach Drivers Claim a Victory in Cape Cod Battle
description: The users of off-road vehicles are claiming victory here after the disclosure last week of the sudden transfer of the superintendent of the Cape Cod National Seashore.

title: Datron Systems reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ETHICS PANEL HEAD REBUTS A LOBBYIST
description: Representative Julian C. Dixon, chairman of the House ethics committee, says he was never lobbied by a company with which his wife now has a business arrangement, but the company's law firm says it got in touch with the Congressman on company business four times in 1986 and 1987.
